title: Your Money; Insuring Contents Of a Home
description: HOW can a homeowner know that the property in the home is adequately insured? Perhaps just as important, how can he or she know exactly what is in the home and what its real value is, so that the proper claim can be made and supported in case of fire or theft?

title: ON THE DAY AFTER, SOME EVES TO REMEMBER
description: The old has been rung out and the new has been rung in, and a lot of people are very happy. Not the least of their happiness is that New Year's Eve is over for another year.

title: Canada's Bishops Assail Ottawa Over Economy
description: Canada's Roman Catholic bishops have taken the unusual step of issuing a political statement criticizing the Government's economic policy.

title: Johnny Davis Sent to Hawks
description: The Indiana Pacers have traded the rights to Johnny Davis, a free-agent guard who has sat out the season, to the Atlanta Hawks for ''a substantial amount of cash'' and a second-round draft selection in 1983, Ray Compton, the Pacers' assistant general manager, said today.

title: CHILD-CARE NONPOLICY
description: Despite the dramatic increase in employment of working mothers over the past 30 years, the Government has failed to develop an adequate and equitable child-care policy. If the predominantly male political establishment in Washington were left to juggle family child-care chores for a few hectic months, perhaps then the lawmakers would begin to match the efforts of their European counterparts and finally create varied and broadly available childcare programs.

title:
PATENTS;
Tomography Scanner Is Improved by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has obtained a patent for an improvement to its tomography scanner, which revolves around a patient and takes X-ray images of selected planes of the body.

title: Louisiana Utility Sells 20% of Unit
description: The Central Louisiana Electric Company, based in Alexandria, La., said it had sold a 20 percent interest in its Rodemacher Unit 2 coal-fired generating plant to a group of Louisiana municipalities for $74.4 million.

title: TV: 'NATURE' EXAMINES ANIMAL COOPERATION
description: Among the incidental pleasures of tomorrow night's final program in Public Television's ''Nature'' series are scenes that remind us graphically that cliches such as ''pecking order'' and ''henpecked'' are actually derived from the barnyard. This refresher comes in the course of ''Living Together,'' an altogether fascinating exploration into why animals cooperate for the good of the group. It can be seen, as usual, at 8 P.M. on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: Fear of a Dallas Man Puts Marriage on Line
description: The police say an independent insurance salesman set out to rob a bank, thinking it might save his marriage, but ''chickened out'' twice at the last minute.

title: How Pratt Has Helped Thrift Units
description: A year ago, the direst warnings about the future of the nation's troubled thrift institutions came from Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates savings and loan associations. Now, thanks to lower interest rates and legislation that dramatically increases its powers, the thrift industry is in a far healthier condition - and probably no one is more gratified than Mr. Pratt, who says the industry has ''come through a lifethreatening crisis.''

title: SOVIET ROUTS MONTREAL
description: As the Soviet Union's top hockey goaltender for the last 14 years, Vladislav Tretiak long ago became one of that nation's sports heroes.

title: C.A.B. ENDING CONTROLS ON DOMESTIC AIR FARES
description: After 44 years, Government regulation of the domestic airline industry effectively ends with the coming of the new year as the Civil Aeronautics Board loses its regulatory control over airline fares.

title: Roll-call votes on tax bills, page 22.
description: After a marathon 20-hour session, Governor Kean and the New Jersey Legislature enacted a package of tax measures early today that eliminates the need for $150 million in budget cuts the Governor had scheduled to begin Saturday.

title: MAN HELD IN JERSEY ABDUCTION
description: A 22-year-old man was seized yesterday in Vermont in connection with the abduction of a 13-year-old New Jersey boy, according to the F.B.I.

title: Rabies Vaccinations for Cats Are Urged by Health Officials
description: Federal and state health officials have suggested that rabies vaccinations be required for cats as well as dogs.

title: Bruce Gamble Is Dead at 43; Former Goaltender in N.H.L.
description: Bruce Gamble, whose career as a goaltender in the National Hockey League was cut short by a heart attack in 1972, died Thursday of a heart attack suffered after an old-timers' game.

title: U.N.'S LEADER AFTER 1ST YEAR: MIXED RECORD
description: In his first year in office, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar says, his greatest achievement was his remarkably blunt account of the United Nations' impotence.

title: EL PASO CO. STARTS TALKS TO SELL KEY PROPERTIES
description: The El Paso Company said yesterday that it had begun discussions with a number of companies for the sale of its exploration properties and other assets, which are the main target of Burlington Northern Inc. in its attempt to take over the diversified energy company.

title: Miami Measles Alert Ends
description: Dade County health officials declared an end Thursday to the measles emergency that resulted in exclusion from county schools of students who had not been immunized against the disease.

title: Perkins in Goodbye, Cites Success Base
description: Ray Perkins, wearing an almosthoundstooth hat, delivered a valedictory today. He said he thought his major contribution in his four years as Giants' coach had been the installation of a winning attitude.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NO FOND RETURN OF LOVE. By Bar- bara Pym. 254 pages. E.P. Dutton. $12.95.

title: PROF. W. P. HALSTEAD
description: William P. Halstead, professor emeritus of speech communication and theater at the University of Michigan, died today in California.

title: TAX CHANGES FOR 1983 PACED BY 10% REDUCTION
description: Federal income taxes for a family of four earning $20,000 annually will drop $143 in 1983 under the third installment of a bill passed last year that cuts the tax rate.

title: CLOSE THE SUBWAY TRAINS' DANGEROUS GAPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Festival
description: St. John's will be seeking its third consecutive title in next winter's Holiday Festival basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: TAX INCREASE OPTIONS UNLIKELY, REAGAN AIDES SAY
description: President Reagan was described by his advisers today as increasingly unlikely to accept any recommendation to increase taxes to help close the Federal budget deficit for 1984.

title: FOUR BOMBS EXPLODE IN MANHATTAN AND BROOKLYN, INJURING 3 OFFICERS
description: At least four powerful bombs exploded in lower Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn within 90 minutes last night and injured three police officers, the police said.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: The West German Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, said today that he estimates the country's gross national product fell 1 percent in 1982. Government budget planning assumes a 1 percent G.N.P. decline in 1982 and zero growth in 1983.

title:
Patents;
57,000 Licenses In 1982
description: WASHINGTON MORE than 57,000 patents were granted in 1982, for inventions that included home computers, robots, genetic devices and ways to produce energy from atoms and sunbeams. About 40 percent of the inventors were foreigners, many of them Japanese.

title: IN A 3-MONTH SESSION, A BUSY DOCKET
description: The coming of the New Year finds that the Supreme Court has barely scratched the surface of its 1982-83 term. But while nine decisions down and perhaps 150 to go is not much of a scorecard, the first three months were not idle.

title: Fed's About-Face Under Volcker
description: As the recession deepened in 1982, the United States and the rest of the industrialized world focused on high interest rates as the cause - and on Paul A. Volcker as the culprit. The 6-foot-7, cigarsmoking chairman of the Federal Reserve Board came to be characterized as ''the second most powerful man in Washington.''

title: No Headline
description: COUNTY PULLS POLICE OUT OF POISONED MISSOURI TOWN

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday misspelled the name of the flutist in ''Passage'' in a dance program by Jean Erdman. He is Peter Ader.

title: Ermer Robinson, a Member Of First Harlem Globetrotters
description: Ermer Robinson, who joined the original Harlem Globetrotters comedy basketball team at the end of World War II, died Wednesday after a long struggle with cancer of the larynx, his friends and family said today.

title: TALKS CONTINUE
description: A strike threatened against the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven commuter rail lines was averted last night when the five unions still without new contracts agreed to work and continue negotiations.

title: MCDONNELL HUNT FOR JET ORDERS
description: Early in November, Charles Conrad, the former astronaut, returned triumphantly to this Middle Western aviation center from a monthlong worldwide trip to sell the DC-9 Super 80, McDonnell Douglas's latest airliner.

title: Mel Torme and Friends In Series in Jersey
description: Mel Torme and a variety of his musical friends will begin a monthlong series of weekend performances next Friday at 8:30 P.M. at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium, 200 Hackensack Avenue, in Hackensack, N.J. Appearing with Mr. Torme from Friday through Jan. 9 will be Carmen Cavallaro, Sylvia Syms, Marlene VerPlanck and Phil Woods.

title: Chase Lending Securities Again
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has resumed its business of lending securities, a practice that caused it an after-tax loss of $117 million last May.

title: DEBORAH LAWSON MARRIES IN ILLINOIS
description: Deborah Davis Lawson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence James Lawson Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill., was married yesterday to Paul Boyd Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Sherman Cleveland of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert W. Bowen performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Kenilworth Union Church.

title: SNOWLESS VERMONT IS HURTING
description: Residents of Stowe, Vt., which calls itself ''the Ski Capital of the East,'' remember all too well the holiday season in 1957, when it did not snow until New Year's Day. In those days, no snow meant hard times for the ski resort owners, their employees and the hundreds of people who worked in ancillary businesses throughout New England resort communities.

title: Team U.S.A., 3 Torpedo Gorky 2
description: Team U.S.A. defeated Torpedo Gorky of the Soviet Union, 3-2, to take the championship in the Battle Creek World Hockey Tournament.

title: Eastern Plans Pilot Layoffs
description: Eastern Airlines, anticipating a ''very, very tough year,'' will lay off 300 pilots in 1983, a spokesman has said. Eastern lost $87.1 million during the first three quarters of 1982, and analysts expect the company to report a loss for the year of at least $85 million.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The dual tasks of coaching Alabama next year and filling Bear Bryant's shoes will be too time-consuming for Ray Perkins to assume a third job. Perkins said yesterday that he did not want to be the school's athletic director, a post that Bryant is expected to relinquish before the football season opens next September.

title: MOSCOW INDICATES UNYIELDING STAND IN AFGHAN DISPUTE
description: The Soviet Union issued a statement through Tass, the official press agency, today declaring that its troops will remain in Afghanistan until longstanding Soviet conditions for their withdrawal are met.

title: Letter: On Ninth-Graders Shifting Teachers Disrupts Education
description: To the Editor:

title: OSWALD RYAN, 94, ONCE HEADED C.A.B.
description: Oswald Ryan, an original member of the Civil Aeronautics Board when it was created in 1938 and its chairman for one year in 1953, died Thursday at the home of his daughter in Houston. He was 94 years old.

title: JOHN MCMAHON JR. TO MARRY SUZANNE ELAINE GRAVES
description: The marriage of Suzanne Elaine Graves, president of Management Skills Inc., management consultants in Cambridge, Mass., to John Patrick McMahon Jr., Commissioner of Traffice and Parking for the City of Somerville, Mass., took place yesterday. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: MEXICANS BRACE FOR A CHEERLESS 1983
description: During the last weeks of the year, shops in the capital and hotels in tourist resorts were packed as Mexicans went on a wild shopping spree that seemed to contradict the daily headlines about the country's severe financial crisis.

title: THE 1983 COLLEGE BOWL GAMES
description: The 1983 College Bowl Games Rose Bowl At Pasadena, Calif., 69th game 5 P.M., NBC-TV U.C.L.A. (9-1-1) Rank: A.P. 5; U.P.I. 5, Times 9. Coach: Terry Donahue Michigan (8-3) Rank: Times 13; U.P.I. 17; A.P. 19 Coach: Bo Schembechler

title: ARTHUR HUGHES, 89, AN ACTOR
description: Arthur Hughes, for more than 50 years a character actor on the stage, died Tuesday of pneumonia in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bench Helps Tar Heels
description: It took a little while, but North Carolina apparently has developed the depth it needs to challenge for a second consecutive national basketball championship.

title: THE REST OF THE STORY
description: No one pays much attention to President Reagan's homespun folk tales anymore. That's because dyspeptic reporters criticize him every time for getting the dates or figures or facts wrong. So he's not very good at dates or figures or facts. But that's no reason to tune out when he's telling a good yarn.

title: Leagues Apart
description: The National Football League is not saying much about the new United States Football League and the competition for this season's college seniors. But somehow the two leagues have each wound up with an event at the same midtown hotel, the Grand Hyatt, on the same day, next Tuesday.

title: Poland Expels BBC Reporter
description: The Polish authorities told the British Broadcasting Corporation's Warsaw correspondent, Kevin Ruane, today that he must leave the country by Jan. 7, the BBC said. The BBC said it understood the ban was not directed Mr. Ruane personally and would apply to all its correspondents.

title: POP: STANDARDS BY JOE MASIELL
description: Joe Masiell has spent so much of his career over the last decade in one production or another of ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' that he has seemingly has become too closely associated with the show for his own comfort. At the Royal Roost, 154 West 13th Street, where he winds up a short run tomorrow, he concentrates on his own bravura Italianate vocal resources and a soft, intimate manner with pop standards before he gives in to the inevitability of a few Brel songs.

title: Industrial Recovery Is Predicted by U.S.
description: Manufacturing industries will make a broad comeback in 1983, according to a Government projection published today.

title: SUHARTO TO REQUIRE GREATER LOYALTY TO INDONESIA'S 5 KEY PRINCIPLES
description: The Government of President Suharto, apparently concerned after 15 years in power that Indonesia's official ideology could be challenged, has decided to require even firmer loyalty to five broad political principles listed in the preamble of the Constitution.

title: Singapore Airlines
description: Singapore Airlines has canceled the purchase of two A300 Airbus aircraft and dropped an option to buy two more A310-type planes from Airbus Industrie of France to enable it to buy newer generation aircraft, the airline spokesman said. ''We are interested in new technology, innovation and fuel efficiency,'' the spokesman said. ''There is usually a time lag of a few years between ordering and delivery of a plane,'' he said.

title: Britain's Line to Georgia
description: Back where Wayne Radloff lived long before he enrolled at the University of Georgia, some of the people might have a difficult time understanding what he is doing this week.

title: Taiwan Approves A.T.& T. Proposal
description: Taiwan's Cabinet has approved a $30 million to $40 million investment proposal by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to produce digital telephone exchange equipment and teleprinters, the Government reported today.

title: ITALY'S CUOMOS CLAIM MARIO AS FAVORITE SON
description: For generations there have been Cuomos in this poor mountain village, working the stubborn soil or eking out a living as tradesmen and artisans. They are still here. But now, there are Cuomos - and there are Cuomos.

title: Executives Promoted BY Times
description: The New York Times has named Russell T. Lewis vice president for circulation and Howard Bishow vice president for employee relations. The appointments were announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times and chairman of The New York Times Company.

title: LAST CONRAIL RUN LEAVES GAP FOR PHILADELPHIA COMMUTERS
description: Conrail's last train slowly pulled out of Philadelphia's Suburban Station at 6:35 P.M. today, 36 minutes behind schedule.

title: I.B.M. PRESIDENT IN THE 1960'S
description: Albert L. Williams, former president of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Thursday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla., after suffering a stroke. He was 71 years old and, before his retirement, had lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Lending Declines at City Banks; Savings Soar In Latest Week
description: Commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks dropped $366 million, to $59.3 billion, in the week ended Dec. 22, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Red Wings 4 Black Hawks 1
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Joe Paterson scored his second goal of the season and first in 18 games at 2:14 of the third period to break a 1-1 tie. Paterson broke down the left wing after taking a pass from Reggie Leach, and his shot from the faceoff circle went over the glove hand of Murray Bannerman, the Black Hawks' goalie.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 1, 1983; Markets
description: Stocks edged higher in slow trading, finishing a year that saw the strongest sustained rally since the bottom of the Depression in 1932. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.83, to 1,046.54, but advances outnumbered declines by 924 to 602 and most other indicators posted small gains. (Page 25.)

title: TOP HEALTH OFFICIAL URGES PER-ILLNESS MEDICARE FEES
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, says Congress could help restrain the rising cost of hospital care by setting uniform fees, but he maintains that the fee scale should apply only to Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: College's Offer of Free Tuition To Jobless Drawing Hundreds
description: Officials of the College of Mount St. Joseph say hundreds of area residents plan to take advantage of the school's offer of free tuition for the unemployed.

title: A STRICTER CODE ON PLANE NOISE IN EFFECT TODAY
description: New local regulations intended to reduce aircraft noise in the New York City area went into effect today, but several small airlines have asked for exemptions on the grounds of economic hardship, a lack of time to install new equipment and - in one case - a war.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: After what seemed like an endless period of extinction, triceratops is back in vogue again, and right here in New York City. In its heyday, the 30-foot-long bony-crested dinosaur was apparently found in places like Wyoming and Saskatchewan. But now a first-class facsimile of its remains in painted plastic is being turned out on Central Park West, in a dusty little shop inside the American Museum of Natural History, where Martin Cassidy and his volunteer staff manufacture dinosaur reproductions.

title: GEORGIA'S STRONG SECONDARY MAKES PASSING RISKY
description: Penn State's quarterback, Todd Blackledge, has overcome some good defenses this season in passing for more than a mile and a quarter and 22 touchdowns. But when Penn State and Georgia meet in the Sugar Bowl Saturday night to determine which one will be college football's final No. 1-ranked team for 1982, Blackledge will be facing the strongest defensive secondary he has thrown into this season.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY TROUPE IN PREMIERE OF 'FIRE'
description: ''Fire,'' is not so much a new ballet as a neo-ballet by Laura Dean for the Joffrey Ballet. The set and costumes are by the architect Michael Graves, and his meeting ground with the choreographer comes in the conscious attempt of both to refashion the recognizably traditional into something of their own.

title: Employee 'Sick Bank' Is Declared Too Costly
description: A ''sick bank'' from which Huntington city employees could draw additional time if they needed it has been disbanded by the acting city manager, Jean Dean.

title: Dec. 31 Holiday
description: Stock exchanges and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were open yesterday, but other commodities markets and United States Government offices were closed.

title: Kissinger Ties K.G.B.  To Shooting of Pope
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that accounts of the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II last year led ''almost to no other conclusion'' than that it was an operation by the Soviet secret police, the K.G.B.

title: Penguins Waive Price
description: ''Price has been killing us,'' said Coach Eddie Johnston of the Pittsburgh Penguins after Wednesday's 6-5 loss to the St. Louis Blues. But instead of an opponent, Johnston was describing the Penguins' Pat Price, the team's most valuable defenseman last season.

title: San Francisco Settles Integration Dispute
description: Twenty years of school desegregation fights among the city officials, state school officials and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have been settled with a city agreement to make major improvements in four largely black schools.

title: Glendale Federal
description: Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, a Glendale, Calif., thrift institution with $8 billion in assets and 170 branches in California and Florida, said it had acquired Tampa Federal Savings and Loan, based in Hillsborough County, Fla.

title: NEW YORK'S HEALTHY SUPPLY OF NICE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: TOKYO ARMS BUDGET: POLITICAL LIMITS
description: Despite a probable increase in Japanese military spending in the 1983 fiscal year of over 8 percnet, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone intends to keep the military budget within a politically acceptable ceiling of 1 percent of the gross national product next year, according to Foreign Ministry officials.

title: THINGS PASSED
description: At 3:37 in the afternoon of October 10 last, I read the final page of Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' I had started it 35 years earlier on a warm October night in 1947, and had read steadily for a year or two before realizing that I faced a monumental task.

title:
PATENTS;
A Genentech Process For Producing Proteins
description: Genentech Inc., a prominent genetic engineering company in San Francisco, received a patent this week for a method of producing certain proteins from microorganisms.

title: BALDWIN SELLS $250 MILLION IN BONDS
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation of Cincinnati has sold $250 million of tax-exempt municipal bonds from the portfolios of its insurance companies to eight securities concerns headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, a company official confirmed yesterday..

title: HEADED GEM COMPANY
description: Henry L. Lambert, one of New York's most respected jewelers for more than a half-century, died yesterday of heart failure at his Park Avenue home. He was 79 years old.

title: GAINES OF THE CHIEFS FACES JET FRIENDS
description: He is the only active player who has ever led the Jets in both rushing and receiving in one year. This season, in the year of their success, he is a forgotten man.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Fistful of Security

title: Anderson Is Reining In Continental's Lending
description: Over the past decade, Roger E. Anderson, the soft-spoken chairman of the Continental Illinois Corporation, has transformed the bank holding company into the largest and perhaps most competitive corporate lender in the United States. Until recently, the strategy seemed a great success.

title: DEFICITS AWAIT NEW GOVERNORS
description: All 16 newly elected governors who will take office in January face the prospect of having to recommend tax increases or reduction of services because of a shortage of revenue, according to a check of state capitals.

title: Ball Is Bringing Vigor To Prudential-Bache
description: People meeting George L. Ball, the 44-year-old president and chief executive officer of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., are struck by his youthful looks. But for a man with the face of a Cub Scout, Mr. Ball does not always act like one.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39. 1. Without Congressional approval, the Justice Department has announced a plan to enlarge the scope of the computers used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which are normally used to keep track of people accused of crimes. What is the new plan?

title: Futures Prices Higher For Meat and Livestock
description: Meat and livestock futures prices settled mostly higher in very light New Year's Eve trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the only major commodities exchange open today.

title: U.S. WINES: NEW RULES TAKE EFFECT
description: MORE stringent Federal regulations for labeling domestic wines go i nto effect today, providing more precise information about what is i nside the bottles.

title:
PATENTS;
Industrial Robot System Designed by Japanese
description: An industrial robot system patented this week for a Japanese company is designed to increase the signals from a machine tool to the robot that is supposed to operate it.

title: REAGAN SIGNS LAW ON PAJAMA MAKERS
description: President Reagan has signed legislation that will allow companies to seek Federal reimbursement for more than $50 million in losses suffered after the Government banned Tris, a flame retardant that many companies had used to meet Federal safety standards for children's pajamas.

title: C.N. STABLER 3D WEDS ELIZABETH SCOTT FINNIE
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Elizabeth Scott Finnie and Charles Norman Stabler 3d, graduates of Stanford University, were married by the Rev. Sarah Motley.

title: Surface Problems
description: The formal application made by the United States Soccer Federation to act as host for the World Cup is only the first of many steps that will have to be successfully taken if the 1986 tournament is to be brought to this country.

title: Mississippi College Aide Is Placed on Probation
description: An official at the University of Southern Mississippi has been placed on Federal probation for signing blank documents that were later sold to foreigners who wanted student visas.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mission of Merriment For the 'Flying Kitchen'

title: BRIEFING
description: All the Capital's a Stage

title: ISLANDERS LOSE TO SABRES
description: The Islanders, who already have fallen out of first place in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League, ended 1982 tonight by losing, 5-1, to the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Pros Size Up Carter's Chances
description: For the last three years, Anthony Carter of Michigan and Herschel Walker of Georgia have been first-team selections on The Sporting News's all-America football team. Selection to this team is particularly significant, because the choices are made by personnel directors and pro scouts in the National Football League.

title: WHEN CITY HALL NEEDS A PROBLEM-DUMPING SITE
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW EASES 0.83 TO END BANNER 1982
description: Stock prices rose slightly in slow trading yesterday, finishing a year that witnessed the strongest sustained rally since 1932. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.83, to 1,046.54.

title: DONATIONS FOR POOR QUICKLY DEPLETED IN BIG CITIES
description: The homeless and destitute people crowding shelters and lining up at soup kitchens over the holiday season were evidence of the increasingly grave predicament of the country's poor, according to church and welfare officials around the country.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Help! I'm Locked In a Blimpie's in TriBeCa

title: RAUCOUS HOLIDAY BEGINS WITH A PRAYER FOR PEACE
description: Twelve hours before Times Square would erupt with the clangor that traditionally welcomes the new year, the Church of St. Francis of Assisi filled with quiet voices offering special prayers for peace to mark the close of 1982 and the opening of a year that the Roman Catholic Church has dedicated to the cause of world peace.

title: 21 Is Drinking Age In Jersey Again
description: After a 10-year hiatus, New Jersey's legal drinking age is returning to 21 again. The law increasing the drinking age from 19 to 21, which was to go into effect automatically at 12:01 A.M. Saturday, allows individuals who were 19 before then to continue to drink and buy alcohol.

title: What Colleges Teach Athletes
description: The drama of today's bowl games will have died down by the time the National Collegiate Athletic Association convenes next month, but not the quieter, more intense drama over the proper role of sports in education. The N.C.A.A. will hear several proposals to toughen academic standards for college athletes. A committee of college presidents would require them to maintain better marks and particularly limit the participation of academically underprepared freshmen.

title: DE MONTEBELLO PURSUES A 'UNIVERSAL MUSEUM'
description: ''There isn't a curator in his right mind who wouldn't want to do a show like this,'' said Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''But there's a big difference between wanting such a show and actually doing it.''

title: More Jobless Seen For Connecticut
description: Temporary Christmas hiring contributed to a slight drop in Connecticut's jobless rate for November, but an increase in unemployment is likely over the next few months, a State Labor Department analyst said today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. To allow the Secret Service to use the computers to track people it believes may pose a threat to officials they guard. 2. The Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor was turned on, and it worked; nuclear fusion is what makes the sun shine. The reactor is expected to generate more fusion energy than the energy required to produce the machine.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We insist on our right to run the railroad and to tell employees where to work.'' - Richard Ravitch. (1:5.)

title: Past Plays Part in Rose Bowl
description: Bo Schembechler and Terry Donahue have done little to make the 69th Rose Bowl a casual affair. In fact, Saturday's game will mark the third time in the last 366 days that these two coaches have stood on opposite sidelines while their two teams battled.

title: Police in Miami Issue Warning to Whites
description: The police warned white motorists today to stay out of a black slum area in the aftermath of a riot as a festive crowd of as many as a half-million people attended the 49th annual King Orange Jamboree Parade.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Although I share Bernard Goldberg's chagrin at the rudeness of some New Yorkers, I must take issue with him on a couple of points: Mr. Goldberg seems to place most of the blame on service providers: cab drivers, toll collectors, et al. Having driven a cab here for the past several months (never failing to say ''take care'' or some friendly words apropos of a conversation I may have had with a passenger) I can assure him that recipients of services are just as capable of surliness.

title: Patriots' Feud Heats Up
description: The relationship between the all-pro guard John Hannah and Coach Ron Meyer of the New England Patriots has taken another turn for the worse. Hannah and the running back Andy Johnson, who has been on injured reserve for weeks despite being ready to play, met with Meyer in separate sessions that both players described as uncomplimentary.

title: THE BROKEN PROMISE OF RACIAL EQUITY IN TEACHER HIRING
description: To the Editor:

title: IN URUGUAY, A DEMOCRATIC STEP. MAYBE
description: Handed the opportunity, Uruguayans told off their military Government.

title: Radio Marti and the Voice of Congress
description: Among the casualties in the lame-duck session of Congress was Radio Marti, a gimmicky proposal to wage air war against Fidel Castro. Wisely, the Senate declined to join the House in approving start-up costs for the station.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POETRY PLUS

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Judge Finds Clothes Make the Man

title: THE MASTER BARGAINER
description: A t 7 o'clock one morning in early March 1966, the phone rang in Marvin Miller's home in New York. ''I can't sleep,'' said Robin Roberts, then a pitcher with Houston and a member of the players' committee to find an executive director for their union, calling from Florida. ''I was up all night thinking about this.''

title: German Retail Sales Off
description: West German retail turnover fell a real 4 to 5 percent in 1982 after a 2.5 percent decline in 1981, the president of the Association of Retail Traders, Friedrich Conzen, said today in an article in the daily Handelsblatt. He said sales totaled 427 billion marks in 1982 and turnover in the pre-Christmas period equaled the 1981 level of 18 billion marks. The mark is currently worth about 42 cents in United States currency.

title: STAGE: CAPRICORN GROUP IN 1617 MASQUE
description: The Renaissance masque was a most peculiar theatrical form. On the one hand, its blending of speech, music and dance made it a herald of what we today might call mixed media. Yet it was also a social event.

title: Judge Approves Railroad Plan
description: A Federal judge approved a reorganization plan for the Boston & Maine Railroad, moving the railroad a step closer to being acquired by Timothy Mellon, a Connecticut man who is rebuilding New England's railroads.

title: A New Governor
description: In welcoming Mario Cuomo to the governorship, we sense a break with tradition. There is something new about him and his ascent to power, though it is hard to define.

title: BRONX CONCERN ROBBED DEC. 12, REPORTS 2D THEFT
description: The Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx, which was robbed of about $11 million in cash Dec. 12, yesterday reported a theft of $225,000.

title: Rioting Continues In Southern India
description: Scattered rioting and arson by Moslem mobs were reported continuing today in the southern Indian city of Trivandrum. Troops were sent in after three people burned to death and rioters attacked the police on Thursday.

title: GENE-SPLICING PROJECT USING DIPHTHERIA APPROVED
description: A team of Harvard Medical School scientists has won Federal approval to conduct gene-splicing experiments with deadly diphtheria toxin in work they say may benefit cancer research.

title: No Headline
description: ARKANSAS TOPS FLORIDA, 28-24

title: 2,000 Fled Nicaragua For Honduras in Month
description: Some 2,000 refugees have crossed into Honduras from Nicaragua in the last month, bringing the total in camps near the border to about 21,000, the coordinator of the national refugee commission said today.

title: Bridge: New York's Player of Year Got to Know Second Place
description: Some three decades ago, Ben Hogan, on the first tee of an open championship that he proceeded to win, genially inquired: ''Who's going to be second?''

title: LOSING WEIGHT: MATCHING DIETS TO TEMPERAMENTS
description: It doesn't require any costly or involved research to discover that losing weight is among the top three New Year's resolutions made across the country. In my experience, success in that endeavor depends a great deal on choosing the right diet for one's temperament. Much attention rightfully is paid to diets that suit one's physical requirements, but I have found that it is equally important to follow a diet matched to my psychological makeup.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Nets vs.

title: Navigating Sea of Debt
description: In September, Jacques de Larosiere issued a blunt warning to bankers and finance ministers: Continue lending to developing nations, he said, or jeopardize ''the stability of the international financial system.''

title: ASPEN, WONDERING WHERE SKIERS ARE, GRAPPLES WITH QUESTIONS ON ITS FUTURE
description: For years this resort high in the Colorado Rockies has been America's premier ski town, a glittery wintertime refuge for the wealthy and the trendy.

title: General American, Mesa Hearing Set
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said the United States District Court for Delaware had scheduled a hearing for Jan. 7 to consider motions for injunctions by Mesa and the General American Oil Company of Texas.

title:
PATENTS;
Dental Drill Built With Anchor Pin
description: Dr. David G. Vlock, a New York dentist and an inventor, was granted patent No. 4,365,958 this week for a combined dental drill and anchor pin, to be used for a broken tooth. It will avoid the need of second drilling and pin insertion.

title: TENANTS WHO DOUBLE AS RENT GOUGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana National
description: The Indiana National Corporation, that state's second-largest bank holding company that also has major interests in financial services, said it would appeal yesterday's decision by Federal Judge William Steckler that dismissed its suit against the financiers Norman and Martin Rich of Davenport, Iowa. In its suit Indiana National charged that the Rich brothers had violated securities laws in their accumulation of its shares, now in excess of 9.6 percent, and sought to stop the Riches from acquiring more stock. Neither of the Rich brothers, who failed in a recent attempt to take over the Central National Bank of Chicago, could be reached for comment.

title: High-Scoring Orange Bowl Game Likely
description: The 49th Orange Bowl Classic, facing its first nonsellout in six years, gets under way Saturday with no special security precautions despite civil unrest in a neighborhood seven blocks away.

title: ISRAEL TRYING TO SOLVE DEADLOCK ON TALKS
description: Israeli delegates to the talks with Lebanon met today with several Cabinet ministers in an effort to find wording to break the deadlock on negotiating a normalization of relations between the two countries.

title: 2 Children Killed In House Fire
description: Two children were killed and their parents injured today in an early-morning house fire in this Delaware County village, Fire Chief Joseph Maddalone said.

title: HEMINGWAY SUBJECT OF OPERA
description: An opera based on the life and works of Ernest Hemingway will be given its premiere next year in Havana, according to Prensa Latina, Cuba's official news agency.

title: NEW DRINK FOR YOUNG ADULTS: CORDIALS
description: Although champagne may be the traditional New Year's drink, a sweeter one - the cordial - is fast becoming a standard way of drinking a toast to the future.

title: The Talk of Warsaw
description: Countless Poles spent the waning days of 1982 the way they have spent much of the year: standing in line. There were long, long lines for loaves of bread today, to last through another long holiday weekend. Lines for vodka for tonight's New Year celebrations. Lines for gasoline - some 50 cars at one station - to get all of the month's ration before the coupons expired. Lines at the Pewex stores, the ever-growing special chain set up by the Government where rare Western goodies like chocolate bars, Scotch and brandy are available so the authorities can obtain foreign currency. Lines everywhere.

title: Celebrating 70 Good Years
description: A mid the hectic hilarity and lonely apprehension that represent the city's New Year's Eve extremes, there were also quiet celebrations and affirmations. One such centered on the 70th wedding anniversary of Max and Annie Futernick of Little Neck, Queens, aged 95 and 94 respectively.

title: NOT SMOTHERS-IN-LAW
description: Like the mills of God, the houses of Congress grind slowly - so slowly, in fact, that by the time they pass protective legislation, an endangered species may be almost extinct.The Puerto Rican parrot, for example, was reduced to 13 birds before Congressionally aided efforts reversed the trend. The same may apply to mothers-in-law.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 1, 1983
description: International Soviet troops will stay in Afghanistan until the Soviet Union's conditions for their withdrawal are met, the Government said in a statement released through Tass, the official press agency. The statement appeared to be intended to reassure the Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan and to discourage speculation in the West that the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, might be preparing to accept a face-saving settlement to to extract more than 100,000 Soviet troops from a seemingly intractable war. (Page 1, Column 6. ) Poles turned out to beat the deadline for expiring ration coupons and lined up for bread, for vodka for New Year's Eve celebrations and for gasoline. The lines are the most visible sign of Poland's woes. One of the longest was formed outside a state-run apartment agency by people who stood in line round the clock for several days to register their children as prospective tenants. The average waiting time for an apartment is well over 16 years. (1:4-6.)

title: Fiesta Bowl Focus
description: American athletes have made significant contributions to the language with their ''thunder dunks,'' ''squib kicks'' and ''sky hooks.'' But the Oklahoma running back Marcus Dupree may be the first athlete to have inspired a technological breakthrough.

title: A Correction
description: An editorial Friday said the year 2000 won't be a Leap Year. It will be, as are all century years evenly divisible by 400.

title: GROUP PROMOTING MAN-BOY LOVE IS THE FOCUS OF POLICE INQUIRY
description: Four years ago this month, after two dozen men were indicted for sex crimes in the nearby town of Revere, a conference was held downtown at the Community Church of Boston. About 30 men stayed on to talk of the difficult issue discussed at the conference, and they decided to form an organization to promote understanding of their kind of love and to seek a change in the law.

title: Queens Girl, 13, Is Found Slain
description: The body of a 13-year-old girl who had been dragged into a van in Ridgewood, Queens, Wednesday evening was found in a lot half a mile away yesterday morning, the police said. The cause of death was not immediately determined.

title: No Headline
description: COMPANY NEWS; A.M.C. TO CHANGE JEEP AND CAR PRICES

title: CHINA SEEKS TO CUT REDUNDANT LABOR
description: China's capital has taken its own major step toward altering the nation's inflexible employment system by phasing out lifetime job tenure in its offices and enterprises.

title: 'Village' Park
description: The Parks Department's plan was to renovate Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, making it more as it was in the days of Henry James.

title: EUROPE: SLOGANS ARE NOT SOLUTIONS
description: LONDON IN Western Europe, if such a generalization can be attempted, the United States and the Reagan Administration are regarded at the moment as dangerous. Not so dangerous, of course, except to extreme leftists, as the Soviet Union, and certainly not malign in intent; but dangerous all the same. In Bonn, in Madrid, in Stockholm, in London, politicians and others feel as always that what Washington decides will have as much influence, or even more, on their economic and foreign policies as what they themselves decide. And they have had the feeling for almost two years that things are not under control in Washington. It is uncomfortable, one European foreign minister said, ''to sense that things are done with little regard for us and with great regard for a narrow ideology.''

title:
DINING OUT;
THREE VISITS ARE BETTER THAN ONE
description: ALTHOUGH some reviewers contend that one visit is all that is necessary to pass judgment on a restaurant, we have never found this to be the case. We have yet to discover a restaurant in any country that is consistent enough so that one visit mirrors the next (except for McDonald's). However, the first meal will usually decide whether a return visit is worthwhile.

title: HARMONIA MUNDI: A FINE LABEL EXPANDS; BY ALLAN KOZINN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: 'ROBIN HOOD' OF ZAMBIANS: END OF A MYTH
description: Mushala is dead. The name might not mean much to most people, but in Zambia over the years it has come to evoke a wide range of images, including those of public enemy No. 1, latter-day Robin Hood, gangster and, more lately, southern Africa's longest-running, one-man political insurgency.

title: BY GUY HENLE
description: GUY HENLE is a magazine editor who writes occasionally on food and travel.

title: IS THE DUTCH BALLET FALLING OUT OF STEP?
description: Three things about the Dutch National Ballet's recent appearance in New York stood out. The company's general level of dancing has seemingly declined, its choreographers don't always present women in an attractive light, and their works tend to fall into a rut of alienation studies that suffer from a time lag in the computer age.

title: 'Excellent Form' In Reining
description: With regard to the recent letter to the editor by Fred Samuel, I would like to clarify any lack of understanding that Mr. Samuel might have about the photo on the cover of the Long Island Weekly section (''Reining: A Bit of the Old West''). Perhaps explaining the mechanics of what is being done with the horse will induce a better understanding.

title: From Outer Space
description: It wasn't a bird or a plane, or even Superman - it was a meteorite, and it came from the sky, went through the roof, bounced in the living room and came to rest in the dining room of the home of Robert and Wanda Donahue in Wethersfield, Conn., last Nov. 8.

title: NEW GOVERNOR HAS BIG PLANS BUT THE DEFICIT LOOMS LARGER
description: ALBANY ONE evening last week, Mario M. Cuomo met with leaders of the court reform movement to enlist their support for changes in the process of nominating judges to fill vacancies on the Court of Appeals. After an amiable discussion and debate, and a pleasant dinner, the group found itself endorsing a package of measures that Mr. Cuomo will propose to the Legislature. ''If the next four years are as easy as this,'' he said as they adjourned, ''then count me in.''

title: BRITISH DRAMA
description: The American premiere of ''Another Country'' by Julian Mitchell will take place at 8 P.M. Thursday, at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. A drama about the British public school system in the 1930's, it won the Best Play award from the Society of West End Theaters in England last summer, and it is currently running at the Queen's Theater in London.

title:
GARDENING;
SAVING OUR ENDANGERED PLANTS
description: MOST everyone would agree that death and taxes are unavoidable. Plants do not have to pay taxes, unless their struggle to survive in the harsh environment of man-made pollution is considered as such. However, plants do die. In fact, the entire population of a species may die. The extinction of a plant species is final. When gone, it is no longer available to see, touch, smell, taste or study.

title: Police Search for Girl, 2, Abducted in Theft of Car
description: The police continued their search today for a 2-year-old girl who was asleep in the back seat of a car that was stolen in a New Year's Eve robbery.

title: FORECLOSURE SALVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowd, Handle Records Are Set at Meadowlands
description: The Meadowlands race track reported today that thoroughbred racing in 1982 set records in attendance and wagering.

title:
GARDENING;
SAVING OUR ENDANGERED PLANTS
description: MOST everyone would agree that death and taxes are unavoidable. Plants do not have to pay taxes, unless their struggle to survive in the harsh environment of man-made pollution is considered as such. However, plants do die. In fact, the entire population of a species may die. The extinction of a plant species is final. When gone, it is no longer available to see, touch, smell, taste or study.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Dying Room
description: Before a prisoner can be electrocuted in Illinois, his mind must be deemed fit for execution. But how, asked a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union, can a prisoner make a sensible decision about, say, an appeal if he's depressed by his surroundings? What if his cell on Death Row is like the cells at Illinois' facility in Menard - too small for sit-ups, let alone pacing?

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
VIDEO FESTIVAL
description: Since they have cameras and can travel anywhere their imaginations will take them, video artists these days are frequently at the forefront of creative media pursuits. On Tuesday, when it begins screening entries in the Eighth Annual Ithaca Video Festival, one of the leading anthologies of independent video, the Port Washington Public Library will offer samples of just how far this adventurous spirit goes. Works by eight artists will be shown at 7:30 P.M., including ''The Smothering Dreams,'' a tape by Daniel M. Reeves and Jon L. Hilton that is described as looking at this country's ''fascination with organized violence.''

title: FRENCH ARE PLANNING TO BOLSTER THEIR NUCLEAR FORCE
description: President Francois Mitterrand has announced that he has ordered a strengthening of France's nuclear strike forces. It was not clear if the President was speaking of a specific new program or a general effort. Mr. Mitterrand and French military officials have said for months that they consider the development of the country's nuclear forces to be one of their essential tasks in the more than five years remaining in the President's term.

title: No Headline
description: Any article written about the Welsh people that excludes their contribution to opera is unforgivable. Surely, Jan Morris will concede that the world has benefited by the presence of such operatic luminaries as Sir Geraint Evans, Margaret Price, and Gwyneth Jones, to name a few. GERALDINE SEGAL, Randallstown, Md.

title:
GARDENING;
SAVING OUR ENDANGERED PLANTS
description: MOST everyone would agree that death and taxes are unavoidable. Plants do not have to pay taxes, unless their struggle to survive in the harsh environment of man-made pollution is considered as such. However, plants do die. In fact, the entire population of a species may die. The extinction of a plant species is final. When gone, it is no longer available to see, touch, smell, taste or study.

title: A NEW LIFE AND A FUTURE TAKE SHAPE
description: HELLO, son or daughter. I write this before your birth, more to myself than to you. You are about the size of a bumblebee, they tell me, humming and growing, wrapped deep in the flesh of the woman I love, and I'm just barely 21 and trying to get used to the idea of fatherhood. Three years ago I was a child myself, looking to my parents the way you will look to me. Then my mother finished dying of cancer 14 months ago.

title: SOVIET: BEHIND ITS PROPAGANDA, SOME REAL FEARS
description: MOSCOW ONE day last week, the Soviet press accused the Reagan Administration of blocking ''progressive'' resolutions in the United Nations, abetting Israel's teritorial designs in Lebanon, aiding ''murderers, saboteurs and bandits'' in Afghanistan, bribing Pakistan with F-16 fighter-bombers, fomenting fresh trouble in Poland and stalemating the nuclear arms talks in Geneva. By Moscow standards, it was a restrained day. For most of the Administration's two years, the official line has been that Washington was in the hands of a lunatic fringe. Soviet leaders accused President Reagan of launching the ''madness'' of a fresh arms race, attempting to strong-arm Western Europe into submissiveness, stirring ''counterrevolution'' in Poland and backing repressive regimes in South Africa, South Korea and Chile. The line is that all this will fail, crushed beneath ''the wheel of history.'' But how strongly it is believed by the shrewd men who advise the tough-minded new leader, Yuri V. Andropov, is questionable. Soviet advisers probably anticipated that Washington would emerge from doubt and selfreproach after Vietnam and Watergate to reassert its power, particularly to check Soviet advances.

title: Sara S. Strong, Pianist, Wed to E. Reed Wilbur
description: Sara Sue Strong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Strong Jr. of Fairport, N.Y., was married yesterday to E. Reed Wilbur, son of Mrs. David B. VanDusen of Weston, Mass., and the late E. Reed Wilbur of Philadelphia. The Rev. VanDusen, the bridegroom's adoptive father and rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Fairport, assisted by the Rev. James F.M. Dollefeld.

title: 44 British Women Arrested After Invading U.S. Air Base
description: Forty-four women were arrested today after they scaled the fence of the Greenham Common United States Air Base and erected banners near a missile silo to protest the planned deployment of American-built cruise missiles.

title: CUOMO PLEDGES AID FOR THOSE IN NEED IN INAUGURAL TALK
description: Mario Matthew Cuomo, a Queens lawyer who first ran for public office only eight years ago, was inaugurated today at 1:30 P.M. as the 52d Governor of New York State, pledging that his administration would do more for people than simply balance budgets.

title: WINE IMPORTER PLEADS GUILTY ON FALSE LABELS
description: A wine-importing company based on Long Island has pleaded guilty to importing fraudulently from France more than 30,000 bottles of inexpensive wine that authorities said had been intentionally mislabeled by their bottler as high-quality Burgundies.

title: King Has 31 as Knicks Top Bullets, 98-77
description: The Knicks scored their easiest victory of the season last night, and it came against a team with a record better than .500. Dominating the backboards and getting 31 points from Bernard King, the Knicks overwhelmed the injury-plagued Washington Bullets, 98-77, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Fuel Shortage in Uganda
description: President Milton Obote has warned Uganda to expect a temporary fuel shortage because of a fire last month at the main oil terminal in neighboring Kenya. Mr. Obote's warning, in a New Year's Eve message, came as travelers returning from rural areas said some towns were already short of diesel fuel.

title: State Education Project For Hunters Defended
description: In reply to the Dec. 5 Opinion Page article on ''outdated'' hunting laws, I wish to point out that the state's Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife administers the Hunter Education Program, successful completion of which is mandatory to obtaining an initial hunting license.

title: Population of Belfast Drops 25% in Decade
description: The population of Belfast, capital of Northern Ireland and center of the British province's strife, has shrunk by about 25 percent since 1971, according to 1981 census figures published in The Irish Times.

title: Seaver Symbolic Of the Old Ideals
description: To the Sports Editor: Tom Seaver's return to New York is evidence that, in spite of the growing dehumanization of sports by big business, there is still a strong personal element in the whole enterprise. While Seaver certainly won a significant increase in security, the negotiations were nevertheless centered on the potential effect of the man himself in the Shea setting.

title: 13 HURT AS FRIGHTENED HORSE HITS RUNNERS IN PARK
description: Thirteen runners were injured and dozens of others knocked down when a a carriage horse frightened by New Year's Eve fireworks galloped headlong into the tightly packed vanguard of nearly 3,000 people at the start of the annual midnight Central Park road race.

title: LAWMAKERS TO MEET ON '83 ISSUES
description: HARTFORD IT will be a new start on some old problems when the General Assembly convenes Wednesday to swear in its new and re-elected members and to witness the inauguration of Governor O'Neill at a joint session in the Hall of the House.

title: DRIVER TAKES A LONG ROAD TO SUCCESS
description: Geoff Bodine, the winner of Nascar's Champion Spark Plug rookie-of-theyear award last season, was 10 years old in 1959 when he watched the first Daytona 500 from the grandstands with his father, who owned a little track himself in Chemung, N.Y. Last February, after 24 years of preparation, Bodine drove in the event that had become stock car racing's version of the Indianapolis 500.

title: THE SUN SETS ON THE SUNDANCE INN
description: There are probably many people who have stories to tell about the fun, and maybe even the romance, they found at Sundance Lodge, a privately owned recreation area on the banks of the Passaic River not far down Route 46 from the Willowbrook Mall in New Jersey.

title: No Headline
description: ARTIFICIAL HEART AMONG MANY '82 HEALTH GAINS

title: LIGHT AND QUICK, NEW POP SPREAD ITS SPIRIT DURING 1982
description: While the record industry could boast no runaway commercial phenomenon like ''E.T.,'' 1982 was still a turning point in which the bottom of a commercial trough was reached. The best-selling album to be released in 1982, the debut of the rock quartet Asia, sold 2.9 million copies. This compares with the 6 million sales of last year's number-one album, ''Hi Infidelity,'' by REO Speedwagon. But especially toward the end of the year, a broad new style of pop asserted itself. Embracing synthesized techno-pop, reggae, funk and Motown, this New Pop is rhythmically lighter and quicker than traditional rock. It favors video over radio, the synthesizer over the guitar, and computerized over manmade rhythms.

title: Fighting Reported In Afghan Capital
description: Soviet forces increased security in Kabul, the Afghan capital, this week after guerrilla attacks on two air bases and a gunfight in which Soviet troops mistakenly fired on Afghan soldiers, according to diplomatic reports from the city.

title: Set For Life
description: Glenn Hubbard of the Atlanta Braves could barely contain his enthusiasm after signing a five-year contract that made him one of the highest-paid second basemen in baseball.

title: MIssissippi Moves on Schools
description: New industries checking out Sun Belt locations have found it easy to write off Mississippi. A poorly educated work force is one reason. Only half the adults are high school graduates, and 10 percent of school-age children do not go to school.

title: MISCALCULATIONS ON SOLID WASTE
description: AS the Bridgeport solid-waste facility came on stream in the fall of 1980, malfunctions, miscalculations and outright failures developed on two fronts - technical and economic.

title: SHOULD AULD ACQUAINTANCES BE FORGOT? IT'S UP TO THEM
description: Pearl-pale and pink, the infant New Year trembles as it ponders the next 363 days. Surely the grieving child would be comforted if it knew the determined resolve of life's movers and shakers, the people who made 1982 so wonderful, so memorable. The rest of us might find comfort, too.

title: NEBRASKA RALLIES TO TOP L.S.U., 21-20
description: For most of three quarters tonight, Nebraska's offense, the most productive in college football this season, stuttered and stammered, turning the ball over five times on four fumbles and an interception.

title: Mary McGoldrick, Editor, Is to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. McGoldrick of Haverford, Pa., and Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth McGoldrick, to William Paul Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Jenkins of Arlington, Va. A July 23 wedding is planned in Philadelphia.

title: NEW OFFERINGS IN THE '83 PROGRAM
description: THE New Year is a time for fresh beginnings, and in Westchester we have, among other things, a new music director at Caramoor, a new dance program in Yonkers and a new music series for Port Chester.

title: Arizona State Triumphs, 32-21
description: Todd Hons, a junior quarterback, came back from a poor first half to lead Arizona State to 14 fourthquarter points for a 32-21 victory over Oklahoma today in the Fiesta Bowl.

title: Pulitzer's Price
description: The grungy divorce battle between Herbert Pulitzer Jr. and his wife, Roxanne, ended last week in a decided victory for the millionaire publishing heir. He got custody of their five-year-old twins; she got a judicial tongue-lashing and, compared to what she wanted, very little else.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ATECHNOLOGICAL innovation pioneered by a small Massachusetts company has made books and magazines substantially more accessible for Long Island's 4,500 blind residents, through the efforts of the Suffolk Cooperative Library System, the Xerox Corporation and New York State.

title: U.C.L.A. DEFEATS MICHIGAN BY 24-14
description: In the end, the two men who have been opponents on the playing field more in the last 366 days than any other two coaches in major college football did not look to find each other.

title:
HALFWAY MARK;
JAPAN: TWO BIG FRICTION POINTS
description: TOKYO PREMIER Yasuhiro Nakasone, who worries greatly about Japan's relations with the United States and favors a direct approach, is due in Washington this month for talks with President Reagan. At a time when Japan is under criticism in the United States for its defense and trade policies, Mr. Nakasone, in addition to establishing personal ties with the President, will be able to demonstrate some good will even it is short of the Administration's hopes.

title: Different Opinons
description: Half a team is almost never better than the whole, but for Oral Roberts University, it will have to do.

title: INAUGURATION IS MARKED BY GAIETY AND GLITCHES
description: It was billed as a people's inaugural, and beyond the formal oath was a daylong celebration of dancing and song, marchers in ermine and feathers, smiles and endless handshakes.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY COLLEGE

title: DISPUTED CITIZENSHIP LAW IN EFFECT IN BRITIAN
description: Britain's Nationality Act, which creates three separate categories of British subjects, went into effect today.

title: Lewis Takes The Third Exit
description: Drew Lewis is among the more capable, and toughest, of the Reaganauts. In two years as Secretary of Transportation, he enforced the decision not to rehire any of the 11,400 air traffic controllers fired by President Reagan and began de-emphasizing Government safety standards for autos; more recently, he helped talk Mr. Reagan into supporting the nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax increase to pay for road repairs and help mass transit.

title:
TELEVISION;
CABLE'S NICKELODEON WRESTLES WITH THE LURE OF COMMERICALS
FICTION
description: 1 1 14 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 8 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 3 4 19 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 4 3 18 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 5 5 8 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 6 6 12 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 7 7 18 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 8 9 22 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title: FIRST HURDLE TO A WEST UNITED ON EAST TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: 22 Food Outlets Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 22 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. The department also named eight restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for failing to do so.

title: Corruption Is a Two-Way Street
description: For months a scandal has simmered at the Connecticut Department of Transportation. Last week, as papers detailing charges of corruption in the awarding of millions of dollars in contracts were released in court, it threatened to boil over.

title: ATLANTIC CITY AIRPORT EXPERIENCES A BOOM IN PASSENGER TRAFFIC
description: When casinos struck gold in Atlantic City, the municipal airport was not far behind. In two years it has blossomed from a sleepy aircraft testing center to a bustling commercial passenger terminal serving 500,000 travelers a year.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Penguins Set Back Islanders
description: The Islanders lost their second consecutive road game tonight, this time by 2-1 to the Pittsburgh Penguins in the Civic Arena.

title: ACID WASTE DISPUTE IN BERGEN IS SETTLED
description: EAST RUTHERFORD THE Sewerage Authority here recently settled a $1.4 million lawsuit against a national oil products company, and officials say that enough money has been recouped to repair damage done to local sewer lines over the last 10 years.

title: THE QUIET MYSTIQUE OF THE SPECTATOR IN THE SEVENTH ROW
description: FROM Red Holzman's vantage point, the Knicks were playing a heady defense, trapping and helping out one another down low near the basket. But he was disappointed with their foul shooting.

title: On the Trail of Hot Pots
description: Before it hobbled away, the lame-duck Congress performed an important service for history. It approved a measure that can slow down the plunder of archeological sites.

title: ART
description: STONY BROOK THE world of dreams, where impression and invention often merge to produce vivid, sometimes disturbing, imagery, has attracted artists for centuries and continues to hold a strong appeal, particularly for those who subscribe to Carl Jung's theories of a ''collective unconscious.'' Since the advent of psychoanalysis and in the era of man's alienation from the natural environment, we have seen deliberate efforts by artists to get back in touch with what Jung considered to be the archetypal symbolism that speaks to all mankind on a primal level, bypassing knowledge, intellect and conscious reasoning.

title: THE ART OF MAKING BECKETT SCRUTABLE
description: DOBBS FERRY FOR The Acting Company, the process, not the play, is the thing. Most of its members spend a couple of seasons touring in one- and two-night stands across the country - with two-week engagements at the Kennedy Center in Washington in the winter and The American Place Theater in Manhattan in the spring. Then they are thrust into what they call the ''outside'' to make their own ways. According to Alan Schneider, co-artistic director with Michael Kahn, the company ''will always be youthful and always replace itself.''

title: Subway to the Rescue Of Congested Caracas
description: It took 35 years but on Sunday this city of four million people finally will have the first stage of a $2 billion subway system to ease the crush on its congested streets.

title: ON AUTHORITY
description: Authority is a subject on which most Americans consider themselves philosophers. No other people talk so insistently about the nature and the limits of authority as it applies to various social groups. The word ''right,'' in the sense of entitlement by authority, is constantly being expanded so that we even talk now of the right to sexual pleasure.

title: AN RX FOR AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: RAHWAY MERCK, one of the world's leading pharmaceutical and chemical manufacturers, is finding new ways to enhance and maintain its affirmative action plan. Phase III, a program established in 1981, is one indication of that.

title: BECOMING SAPIENS
description: THE CREATIVE EXPLOSION, An Inquiry into the Origins of Art and Religion. By John E. Pfeiffer. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $29.95.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: missioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, has abolished the agency's Division of Science and Research and dismissed Dr. Alden McLellan 4th of Lawrenceville, who headed the division.

title: TRIAL TO RESUME IN SINKING HOMES CASE
description: THE trial of the sinking homes of Norwalk will resume tomorrow morning in Stamford Superior Court as the judge, six jurors, eight lawyers and a renewed stream of witnesses consider whether anyone is responsible for what has been called an American dream turned into a nightmare.

title: BY GEORGE RAINE
description: GEORGE RAINE contributes to The New York Times from Salt Lake City.

title: BUS RIDERSHIP IS UP ON SUBUBAN LINES
description: MANY of Connecticut's suburban and small-city bus systems, born during the gas shortages of the 70's, are experiencing some of their best ridership levels yet, according to figures from the State Bureau of Public Transportation.

title: Barry Goldwater On
description: Defense General David C. Jones wrote a most interesting and, in my opinion, accurate paper on ''What's Wrong With Our Defense Establishment'' (Nov. 7). However, I want to add one more thought that I have been trying to develop for many years in the Senate, so far unsuccessfully.

title: HALFWAY MARK
description: THE Reagan Administration, reaching midterm last week, has moved swiftly to put its stamp on foreign policy, from missiles and pipeline diplomacy - East-West and West-West - to breaking new ground in the Middle East, Central America, Africa and Asia.

title: Jenkins, Edward J. Waite Marry in Darien
description: Leila Cassel Jenkins and Edward Judson Waite 3d were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Robert Nelson Back performed the ceremony.

title: FROM ETIQUETTE TO PROTOCOL
description: GILBERT A Comedy of Manners. By Judith Martin. 303 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: SUNDAY, JANUARY 2, 1983
description: International Moscow blamed the deadlocked talks on strategic arms reduction on American attempts to weaken the Soviet Union militarily. The Soviet views were expressed in a long editorial prepared for Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper. It was the fullest statement of Soviet policy on strategic arms issues since the Reagan Administration took office nearly two years ago. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: Judith Palmer Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Judith Ann Palmer to Timothy Chapin Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Benjamin Price of New Vernon, N.J., and Naples, Fla., has been announced by Miss Palmer's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Raymond Palmer of Homosassa, Fla. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is a zoologist at Busch Gardens in Tampa, Fla.

title: N.F.L. EVALUATING DECLINE IN FAN INTEREST AND TV RATINGS
description: SIX months ago, the owners of the National Football League's 28 t eams met in Phoenix to discuss, among other things, their complex r elationship with the N.F.L. Players Association and the possibility o f a strike.

title: DEDICATION KEEPS NEWARK GIRLS' SCHOOL ALIVE
description: NEWARK WHEN Denise Mitnaul entered St. Vincent Academy here in 1979, she said she was ''hanging by a thread.'' ''I could have gone either way,'' she recalled - and the same could have been said of the school itself. Now, more than three years later, Miss Mitnaul is no longer hanging by that solitary thread. Instead, she has found herself in the multicolored pattern that is the fabric of St. Vincent's.

title: Mr. Van Nest, Miss Kegg Set August Bridal
description: Virginia Kip Kegg of New York and Point O'Woods, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Kip Kegg, of Monkton, Md., to Dean Gillette Van Nest Jr., son of Mr. Van Nest of Bronxville, N.Y., and Point O'Woods and the late Maude Haulenbeek Van Nest.

title: CHINESE WITH A MANHATTAN TOUCH
description: HUNAN PAVILION opened in Great Neck a few months ago, one of several new Chinese restaurants on the Island announcing that some of the management and staff members were previously connected with the more elegant uptown Chinese restaurants in Manhattan. The food at Hunan Pavilion is astonishingly good on occasion, suggesting that the Manhattan connection has been effective. Unfortunately, there are disappointments as well.

title: AT CIGNA, EXPECTATIONS GONE AWRY
description: IT was billed early last year as a dream merger, a true marriage of e quals, the largest ever in the insurance industry. Take the C onnecticut General Corporation, with revenues in 1981 of $5.6 b illion and assets of $18 billion, and combine it with the INA C orporation, with revenues of $5.2 billion and assets of $11 billion.T he result was to be a perfect fit -two giants becoming a supergiant.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS. By Gail Godwin. (Avon, $3.95.) Gail Godwin orchestrates human entanglements with her customary skill in a novel about three women who are trying to refashion their lives. Our reviewer, Josephine Hendin, called ''A Mother and Two Daughters'' a generous, affirmative book that extends ''faith in the individual toward a vision of community, within the family, the town and, ultimately, the nation.'' Four earlier Gail Godwin novels - ''Glass People,'' ''The Odd Woman,'' ''The Perfectionists'' and ''Violet Clay'' - are being reissued by Warner Books this month.

title: THE TIME TO TRADE MORTGAGES
description: SINCE interest rates started dropping last autumn, the possibility o f mortgage refinancing has become a preoccupation with many h omeowners who bought at higher rates. For some, refinancing makes p erfect sense, but there are many variables that have to be weighed t o determine when is the most favorable time to do it.

title: CHICK COREA IS THINKING A LOT ABOUT MOZART NOW
description: There is a long tradition of classical music inspired by jazz. Milhaud, Ravel, Stravinsky, serious composers all, have found inspiration and revitalization in popular forms. But this crossfertilization can work both ways, and there are several examples of popular composers who made successful excursions into classical music. George Gershwin is one example. Duke Ellington is another. And a third is Chick Corea.

title: Student Appalled
description: To the Business Editor: I am writing this letter in regard to Barbara Bergmann's ''Social Security's Overblown Problems'' (Nov.14). As a high school student and future Social Security candidate, I heartily agree with her statement that it makes sense to pay Social Security benefits out of our general revenues.

title: FOR MEMBERS OF CITY'S BOMB SQUAD, A LONG, TEDIOUS AND DANGEROUS DAY
description: Lieut. Charles A. Luisi had a little trouble talking about it. Nothing that could be called tears, but the kind of little stutter that showed he was having a hard time swallowing.

title: WHAT SOLD IN 1982
description: Robert Ludlum's novel ''The Parsifal Mosaic'' was the biggest selling book in 1982, according to a New York Times survey, edging out the nonfiction best seller, ''Jane Fonda's Workout Book.'' Ranking first with independent bookstores and the major book chains, ''Parsifal'' sold almost twice as many copies as the fiction runnerup, ''North and South'' by John Jakes.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ADMITTEDLY, some authors of children's books are putting into print what they always wanted to tell their own children about life's challenges and choices.

title: FIGHT ON DRINKING ENLISTS 11-YEAR-OLDS
description: YEAR-OLD Cindy had had enough to drink. Now she wanted to go home before her parents discovered she had climbed out of her bedroom window to go to the party. Eileen, her sixth-grade classmate, who had driven her to the party, was acting wildly, gulping drinks and laughing raucously. In vain, Cindy implored Eileen to take her home.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Lewis will defend his long jump title in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Jan. 28.

title: CREATING A COMMUNITY IN CITY CO-OPS
description: In a city that breeds anonymity, and where many people don't even know their next-door neighbors, more and more residents of co-ops are working together to create a congenial small-town environment within their apartment buildings.

title: MAKING TALKING HEADS REALLY TALK
description: The ultimate in talking heads is upon us. Never have so many high government officials, experts on law and star journalists been assembled before the television cameras to discuss matters of such pith and moment. The results, which are revealing in an unsettling way, can be seen in "The Constitution--That Delicate Balance," a series that begins Wednesday evening at 10 on Channel 13. With luck, it may open the minds of television producers to the potentialities inherent in a much-maligned form.

title: POLISH TENNIS STAR HAS TASTE FOR ART
description: GREENWICH THE incongruity of it all amuses Wojtek Fibak. Here he is, a citizen of Poland, living in a Gothic-style manor set on 10 acres in the north country of this citadel of wealth, surrounded by French and Italian provincial furniture and valuable artworks, including the world's largest private collection of paintings by Polish masters.

title: Lynn Anne Norton Will Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel S. Norton Jr. of Ewingville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Anne Norton, to Philip Carter Poinier, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Poinier of Chester, N.J. The wedding is planned for April 16.

title: A NEW HOCKEY COACH SCORES POINTS
description: MOUNT VERNON WILL success spoil Brenda Marshall? That is the question friends of the new boys' ice-hockey coach at Mount Vernon High School jokingly asked after Miss Marshall's team had won a second game in four starts this season. Last year, the Knights won one game all season.

title: THE BRUTAL OCCUPIERS OF AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Ellen Stone, John B. Newman Become Engaged
