description: Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Stone of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Jane Ellen Stone, to John B. Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Newman of West Orange, N.J.

title: TURNING UP THE PRESSURE ON INDIA'S FREE PRESS
description: A serious browser picking up a book in an Indian book shop may be taken aback to discover that passages have been deleted. In Bombay, a volume of essays and pictures about that city bears ink smears blurring what someone considered an unflattering portrayal of an ethnic group. In New Delhi, whole paragraphs about the politically sensitive state of Kashmir in a popular travel guide have been blacked out.

title: WHEN TENANTS SPONSOR CO-OP CONVERSIONS
description: THE community of Jackson Heights in Queens is one of the city's greatest centers of cooperative h ousing. Edward A MacDougall built dozens of cooperatives there in t he 1920's.

title: MIDDLE EAST: HIGH ANXIETIES
description: JERUSALEM ONE of the few points of accord between Israelis and Arabs these days is their doubt that the United States has a coherent Middle East policy. The war in Lebanon, the Reagan plan, the continued high material support of Israel even in the midst of basic political disagreement - all have been blended into a cloudy picture of Washington's goals in the region.

title: Guam to Install Governor
description: People from all over this 212-squaremile Pacific island are invited to a daylong party Monday to celebrate the inauguration of Guam's new Governor. Ricardo J. Bordallo, leader of the island's Democrats, will be sworn in to succeed Gov. Paul Calvo, a Republican, who was narrowly defeated by Mr. Bordallo in the November election.

title: ECONOMIC BENEFITS AID JUNIOR RESERVE OFFICERS
description: DANBURY ''LEY-UFT! Ley-uft!'' barked Senior Master Sgt. Harry L. Lewis Jr., marking time for the 16 cadets wearing blue uniforms and black, mirror-polished shoes. ''Can't hear ya! Make it louder! That's better!'' he shouted in sing-song fashion as the stomping grew louder and caused the classroom floor to vibrate.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA: FEELING THE HEAT
description: MEXICO CITY THE Reagan Administration has succeeded in reasserting United States influence over Central America: Leftist guerrillas, radical priests, conservative businessmen and rightist army officers all find themselves reacting to the words and whims of Washington. But as viewed by many Central Americans, this huge political, military and economic power has been projected without being shaped to the region's realities and without the support of a philosophy that would provide consistency.

title: Stout S.M.U. Defense Holds Off Pitt, 7-3
description: There was no longer a need for speculation - a reason to dwell on the relative strength of the schedule or the individual merits of the players. Southern Methodist University had achieved its goal in the Cotton Bowl game against Pittsburgh today and now it was waiting to hear at least a polite round of applause. There was some, too, although it still wasn't enough to muffle the sounds of the critics.

title: Cairo Souk
description: To the Editor: William E. Farrell in his article entitled ''Finds in Cairo'' (Travel, June 27) wrote a glowing report about a shop called Senouhi, where the price was set without bargaining and the woman proprietor spoke English and carried a wealth of interesting merchandise. v. e spent three weeks in Egypt recently and made it a point to visit Mrs. Rashad's shop.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE TANGLED WING Biological Constraints on the Human Spirit. By Melvin Konner. 543 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $19.95.

title: THE YEARS MARCH ON, ETCHED IN MEMORY
description: THEY used to make us memorize dates in history class -1066, 1492, 1607 and 1776, to mention a few. Certainly they were important to human history, but their value to me as a child had more to do with A's and B's and report cards than with a burning need to remember such things.

title: Barbara Ingram Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barron Proctor Lambert of Stevenson, Md., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lambert's daughter, Barbara Purnell Ingram, to Thornley Anthony Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornley William Hart of New York and Cedarhurst, L.I. An April 16 wedding is planned in Baltimore.

title: Silence Is Preferred
description: DUCK blinds are conducive to philosophizing and the almost inevitable periods of inactivity a waterfowler faces make it essential that he choose his hunting companions wisely, for in these days of shorter seasons and fewer birds plump thoughts may be all he'll garner.

title: BOWLS TO STUDY SELECTION DATE
description: There may be bowl games matching the two top teams more often in the future if four of the five New Year's Day bowl games can agree on a later date for selecting teams each season. Officials of these four bowls - Cotton, Fiesta, Orange and Sugar - seem ready to come to an agreement to pick teams at least a week later than they have in the past.

title: NOW IF PICK 6 PAID OLD MONEY...
description: PHEW, but that was a close call! They actually picked one of my numbers during the big Pick-Six drawing on Dec. 2. That means I was only five numbers away from $11 million, and I can't begin to tell you what a relief it was to lose.

title: THE MUSIC SEASON HARDLY RESTS AT ALL
description: IT usually takes two or three weeks into January before the concert season gets back into full swing, but this year things are popping early. Today, for example, the Greenwich Choral Society holds auditions from noon to 2 P.M., and again from 7 to 9 at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, as the choir seeks to augment its size for the March 20 Bach's St. John Passion. Sopranos, tenors and basses will be especially welcomed, and applicants should come prepared to sing a hymn tune or any other simple piece.

title: Elizabeth Taylor in Accident
description: Elizabeth Taylor was slightly injured today when a limousine taking her to meet Defense Minister Ariel Sharon struck the back of a car in a heavy rainstorm. A spokesman for her during a 10-day visit to Israel said the actress was released from a hospital after aid for leg pains.

title: INVESTING THEIR TIME IN THE 14TH CENTURY
description: March by the Doubleday Crime Club, is the sort of author who makes you see double.

title: DEATH AND STRIFE RING IN THE YEAR IN LEBANON
description: Lebanon began the new year today in the old way - violently. The northern port city of Tripoli, which is under Syrian control, was the scene of fierce shelling exchanges between pro-and anti-Syrian Moslem factions who broke a week-old cease-fire and resumed killing one another.

title: Mailbox; Silence Is Best For Perkins Now
description: To the Sports Editor: I read with some disappointment the postgame comments of Ray Perkins after the Giants had lost to the Cardinals last weekend. He speculated that perhaps he had overestimated his own team's talent, that in the end the Giants weren't as good as he thought: ''In only two games this year did we deserve to be called a football team.'' These are strong words from a coach and, in light of his announced departure to Alabama, wholly inappropriate. Ray Perkins is going home and he is leaving his words in the air behind him for the rest of us (not to mention his team) to breathe.

title: ARBITRATION GROUP CELEBRATES 5TH YEAR
description: AFTER completing five years of work resolving more than 3,000 cases, the White Plains regional office of the American Arbitration Association will give itself an anniversary party on Thursday.

title: FOES OF SURINAMES'S LEADER SEEK TO ORGANIZE
description: Surinamese dissidents are trying to organize a movement in the Netherlands to overthrow the military Government of Col. Daysi Bouterse. But political rivalries among the dissident groups and the official hands-off policy of the Dutch Government appear to be hampering their efforts.

title: Part of the Family
description: From her birth, the only home 67-year-old Margaret Rice knew was one for the retarded in Spokane, Wash. Then she caught the eye of Diana Pollin, 38 and childless. Mrs. Pollin and her husband, Frank, had been unable to adopt children because of Mr. Pollin's age, 54.

title: THEY STUDY IT BY WRITING IT
description: IN its search for local history, one class at Deer Park High School has taken a bold approach. The class not only reads books on the Island's history, but also writes them.

title: The Nobel Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: Be a Knowbody
description: To the Editor:

title: Guerrillas Black Out Cities in Salvador
description: Saboteurs bombed power lines throughout the country, blacking out large sections of the capital and other cities as Salvadorans celebrated New Year's Eve.

title: 6 Whites and a Black Slain in Zimbabwe
description: Six whites and a black were killed Friday in two attacks by dissidents in southwestern Zimbabwe, the police and relatives said.

title: DISTURBING ONCE, COMPELLING NOW
description: THOMAS EAKINS, By Lloyd Goodrich. Ilustrated. Volume One, 336 pp. Volume Two, 357 pp. Cambridge, Mass., and Washington: Harvard University Press/The National Gallery of Art. $70 through March 31, $90 thereafter.

title: A COMPUTER VIEWS 1983
description: Since Time Magazine made a computer its Man of the Year and since the world is full of lies and lie-detectors, I plugged in my old truth-detector, Uniquack, and had a talk with him about where we are and where we're going.

title: 'RICHARD III' AS A BENEFIT
description: A group of traveling players from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Wellesley College will present their fully staged and costumed production of Shakespeare's ''Richard III'' at 8 P.M. on Saturday in Rye Neck High School.

title: A Call for Standards
description: Fearing that the student-athlete has gone the way of the single wing and high-top shoes, the presidents of the 20 universities in the Pacific-10 and Big Ten Conferences have appealed to their colleagues in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to support more stringent academic standards for student athletes. William Gerberding, the president of the University of Washington, said during a meeting in Seattle that the two conferences ''are determined to raise the level of scholarly achievement of students who compete in intercollegiate athletics, so that athletes are students first and actually making progress toward a degree.''

title: 'I KEEP PRAYING' FOR THE OPERATION
description: TRENTON ''IN YOUR lifetime,'' the doctor told the young people gathered around him in Mercer Medical Center here, ''you're going to be cured.''

title: Greece Ends Communist Exile
description: The civil war that devastated Greece from 1947 to 1949 led to the first major United States move to contain Communism in Europe. With the help of $300 million of American military and economic aid under the Truman Doctrine, the war ended in defeat for the Communist rebels.

title: Legal Aid Staff Ends Its Strike
description: Legal Aid lawyers in New York City seem better at plea bargaining than collective bargaining. Last week they ended a 10-week strike by accepting a two-year contract with annual raises of 6 percent and 5.2 percent - figures closer to the one-year, 5.3 percent deal the Legal Aid Society had offered than the 9 percent the lawyers had demanded.

title: Mr. Watt Rages at the Wilderness
description: It is hard to see the purpose of James Watt's latest assault on the wilderness, but perhaps none is intended. Like King Lear raging at the elements, the Secretary of the Interior hurls defiance as a matter of posturing, not policy.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN HAS SHELVED PLAN TO CUT $26 BILLION
description: President Reagan has decided not to seek most of the $26 billion in domestic spending cuts that he had asked Administration officials to come up with in November, according to White House aides.

title: A NOVEL OF PASTORAL VISION
description: ON THE BLACK HILL By Bruce Chatwin. 249 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75.

title: Borowiak Ousts Pfister
description: Jeff Borowiak beat Hank Pfister in an all-American match today, 6-4, 6-4, and reached the semifinals of the $75,000 Victorian Open tennis tournament.

title: South African Says Toll In Clashes Was Lower
description: A Government spokesman says an official estimate of casualties in a series of clashes between black students and the police in 1976-77 was slightly lower than one cited in a recent article in The New York Times. The Times's figure was based on compilations by journalists here.

title: CHINA: IF THIS IS FRIENDSHIP...
description: PEKING TO call the United States a superpower vying with the Soviet Union for world hegemony is hardly flattering, but it is illuminating. The old disparaging labels that have been resurrected here reflect the insecurity with which the regime regards the Reagan Administration.

title: BY ROBERT C. TUCKER
description: MEMOIRS By Petro G. Grigorenko. Translated by Thomas P. Whitney. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $19.95.

title: Amy Ruth Shorr Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Shorr of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ruth Shorr, to Martin Lawrence Kratish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kratish of Surfside, Fla. A May wedding is planned. Miss Shorr is a senior at the University of Florida. Her fiance is attending the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Bag Lady

title: CLEMENTE'S LEGACY FOR LATIN BALLPLAYERS
description: AN unforgettable incident hammered the consciousness of baseball fans on Dec. 31, 1972. Roberto Clemente and four others died when their plane crashed into the Caribbean shortly after takeoff from Puerto Rico. The baseball star's body was not recovered. He died bound for Nicaragua to help distribute relief supplies to earthquake victims.

title: Ayala, Boxer, Charged With Assaults, Burglary
description: Tony Ayala, the No.1 contender for the World Boxing Association junior middleweight title, was arrested this morning on charges of aggravated sexual assault, burglary and aggravated assault, the police said.

title: Day Has Most Winners
description: With two victories at Delta Downs in Vinton, La., Friday night, Pat Day beat out Angel Cordero Jr. for the most victories achieved in 1982. Cordero, whose mounts earned the most money this year, was tied with Day earlier Friday at 397, after Day rode two winners in the afternoon at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans.

title: EAST MEETS EAST IN A FINE BATTLE
description: International politics bedevil the world bridge scene from time to time, although the storms have been milder than they have been on occasion in the Olympic Games and other active sports. South Africa recently bowed to World Bridge Federation pressure and did not compete in the world championships in Biarritz; but that controversial country is still a member of the world organization and will compete in Mexico in 1984 unless the new Mexican government refuses them admission.

title: Alabama and Louisiana Get More Heavy Rains
description: By The Associated Press An additional round of heavy rains fell through much of the soggy South yesterday, flooding some streets in Mobile, Ala., and forcing more evacuations in Louisiana, where rivers still were rising.

title: 65 MILLION READERS ARE BEREFT OF 'DOONESBURY'
description: Michael J. Doonesbury and Garretson Beekman Trudeau have walked away from a stage composed of 723 newspapers in the United States with a combined readership of 65 million people.

title: New Contender In Lisbon Stakes
description: Portugal's Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao, who resigned two weeks ago, picked a successor last week. But his is not the final word; if it were, perhaps he wouldn't have felt obliged to quit as the head of the country's 14th government since democracy was restored in 1974.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SOME of the most recent lobbying in the County Office Building in White Plains has been done - where else? - in the lobby. It has had little to do with political arm twisting but a lot to do with buffed marble and burnished brass.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A New Start When folk music stepped aside for disco and punk rock, Tom Rush, one of the seminal folk singers of the 1960's and early 70's, moved to a farm in New Hampshire to raise a family and ''grow some dirt.'' Now, the acoustic guitarist and songwriter who influenced Joni Mitchell, Jackson Browne and James Taylor says he's making a new start.

title: KEAN TO SEEK CHANGES IN VEHICLE INSPECTIONS
description: Governor Kean has announced that he will send a 10-point program of changes in the state's motor vehicle inspection system to the State Legislature for its 1983 session, which begins Jan. 11.

title: Papayas and Slipped Disks
description: Folk medicine may take it for granted that many a remedy grows on trees, but it took the Food and Drug Administration nearly 10 years to decide that a papaya fruit derivative might safely replace surgery for some back pain.

title: LEGISLATORS WHO NEED ALL THE HELP THEY GOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Aronoff Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Aronoff of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ellen Aronoff, to Robert Edward Wagman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Wagman of West Orange, N.J. A June wedding is planned. The future bridegroom's father, a photographer, is owner of Eric Wagman Studio in South Orange, N.J.

title:
Antiques;
BERGENFIELD LEGACY: COOPER CHAIRS
description: to late 1800's, could be a difficult man. A story told about him by Harold Peter Bogert, one of his descendants still living in the area, reveals just how difficult.

title: BY PATRICIA WELLS; HONG KONG TEAS
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic for The International Herald Tribune.

title: DOWNTOWN: THE ORIGINAL PLACE TO LIVE
description: THREE hundred years ago, the Dutch thought it was a good n eighborhood to live in, and so did early Americans. Now the s outhern tip of Manhattan - originally known as New Amsterdam - is b eing rediscovered as a desirable, if not yet chic, place to settle.

title: HOMES FOR ONE
description: The single-family home may be heading for extinction in Manhattan, but another small effort to preserve the species is under way on East 71st Street between Second and Third Avenues. There, what was once a dormitory for Dominican nuns is being renovated by the Ambassador Construction Company into three private residences.

title: Eliza A. Shanley To Marry April 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Shanley of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eliza Ann Shanley, to Vincent James Carone Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carone of Hamden, Conn.

title: 5 TAX: BOON TO ROAD REPAIRS
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S five million motorists can expect some improvements in the state's highway system as the result of the increase of 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax.

title: HOW MAGIC WORKS
description: STOLEN LIGHTNING, The Social Theory of Magic. By Daniel Lawrence O'Keefe. 581 pp. New York: Continuum. $24.50.

title: WHAT LONG ISLAND SEEKS AS CONGRESS RETURNS
description: WASHINGTON THE haggling in Congress over job programs, the future of Social Security and the MX will continue in the 98th session as members return tomorrow from a vacation shortened by a divisive postelection session.

title: Ziyautdin Babakhanov Dies; A Leader of Soviet Moslems
description: Ziyautdin Babakhanov, for 25 years the nominal leader of the Moslems of Soviet Central Asia, died a week ago Thursday in Tashkent, according to an announcement in Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper. He was 73 years old.

title: SHADOWS IN A SEASON OF LIGHTS
description: EACH year at Christmastime, when I see the large pine tree and colorful lights framing a triangle of sparkle near the library of Colonial structure and the white church with its large steeple, I am reminded of a silent, soft family and town scene. A scene that would fit under a Christmas tree or on a lovely holiday card with a verse exclaiming ''Good will to you and your family.''

title: Gwen Mulhern Is Wed To Patrick S. Meade Jr.
description: Gwen N. Mulhern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Mulhern of Hillsdale, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick S. Meade Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meade of Dublin. The Rev. William Giblin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady Mother of the Church in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: A PROPOSAL TO CELEBRATE THE MILLENNIUM; BY ALVIN R. KRACHT
description: IT strikes me as curious that in this era of strategic planners, advance technologists and economic and social seers, no one has trumpeted the realization that we are on the threshold of a millennium, a scant 17 years ahead. Perhaps their concern with world overpopulation, depletion of resources, threats of famines and nuclear holocausts by the year 2000 has blurred any awareness of the enormous significance and potential in that momentous transition. It should not be so.

title: CINCINNATI CIVIC ATRIUM ASSAILED AS VAPID SPACE
description: A $93 million downtown development, once called an example of how private-public partnerships could save a decaying inner city, is under attack by critics who say it offers little to the public.

title: WARNER HIDES AN INSIDE STORY
description: At the end of Curt Warner's college career, his last game was not without pain. Four times in the second half of the Sugar Bowl game against Georgia, Warner was forced to leave the game with the same type of cramps that have been a problem throughout his career.

title: WHEN TO SELL IN TELECOMMUNICATIONS
description: NOW that the prices of the volatile telecommunications stocks have d oubled since the market began to surge in August, analysts are w ondering if it is time to sell or simply to hold their positions. Ifa n investor believes that history repeats itself, it might be a time t o get out. Twice in the last 18 months, sharp rises in t elecommunications stocks have wilted as anticipated pickups in d emand failed to take shape.

title: Sudanese Leaves for U.S.
description: President Gaafar el-Nimeiry, 53 years old, left today for a routine medical checkup in the United States, the Sudan News Agency reported.

title: Melisande Stone Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Law Stone 2d of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Melisande Grace Stone, to Maurice Clos-Versailles also of Greenwich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Clos-Versailles of Lembeye, France.

title: ISLANDS WITH A FRENCH ACCENT
description: FRANK J. PRIAL, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, was formerly a correspondent in the Paris bureau.

title: WASHINGTON'S NEW MOOD STIRS HOPES OF GROWTH
description: AS President Reagan approaches the halfway point of his term in o ffice this month, there has been a major change in the A dministration's attitude toward the economy. After a two-year s truggle to hold down prices - a battle that has driven unemployment a lmost to 11 percent - the White House now is in position to declare victory over inflation and move to the next challenge: restoring g rowth.

title: KEAN'S 'SOUNDING BOARD' PICKS UP BAD VIBES
description: The economic problems that dogged the New Jersey government last year quickly took the bloom off promises of bipartisan cooperation between the new Republican Governor and Democratic legislature. There was more acrimony than accord, and as a result, Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike have come to question Governor Kean's leadership during the first year of his administration.

title: Summer Wedding For Miss Maxwell
description: Mrs. James A. Maxwell of Worcester, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Mary Maxwell, to Gustaf Hakan Nicolaus Gunnarsson Lonaeus of Washington.

title: FOUR LONGTIME FAMILY FARMS HONERED BY NEW YORK GROUP
description: Four upstate farms that have remained in the same families for more than 100 years have been selected to receive Century Farm awards from the New York State Agricultural Society.

title: PHYLLIS WHITNEY'S CONTINUING SAGA
description: BROOKHAVEN ''HOW lucky I am that I can stay young writing,'' said Phyllis A. Whitney, the 79-year-old author of best sellers, with a smile as she relaxed in a wing chair, surrounded by hundreds of books arranged in bookcases and piled neatly on the floor of her living room in her modest home in this quiet South Shore neighborhood.

title: QUEENS NEIGHBORS TOUR THE CUOMOS' NEW HOME
description: Arlene D'Arienzo had a few moments to look about her as she sat in a car waiting to enter the gates of the house at 125 Eagle Street here.

title: WHEN A MOVIE DOESN'T HAVE TO PASS THE PLAUSIBILITY TEST
description: Plausibility is an unreliable weapon with which to attack a movie you don't like. Five minutes after ridiculing a film for its lack of plausibility, you may well find yourself defending a favorite work against the same sort of charge. The point is that all of us have different thresholds at which we suspend disbelief, and then gladly follow fictions to conclusions we find logical. When we admire a work for whatever reasons, logic can be put on hold. When we don't, we become ferociously, self-righteously logical, stern arbiters of reason.

title: THE AFTERMATH OF SURGERY: A FAMILY WAITS AND WATCHES
description: IHAD been warned about the color. ''Don't be upset by the color of h er skin afterward,'' someone had said. Yet the image remains, this w axy, gray-green look to the skin. The half-naked, sheet-covered f igure who is our mother shares this gray-green color with a select g roup of others. They lie quietly in the large room, visible through a forest of tubes, distinguishable from one another only by the b arest facial outlines.

title: Rowdyism Blamed for Deaths Of 2 Women in London Crowd
description: Witnesses blamed rowdyism for the trampling to death of two women early today during New Year's Eve celebrations in Trafalgar Square.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
TWO SELECTIONS, TWO VIEWS OF HISTORY
description: A question of truth in photography is raised by the radically different versions of American history given in two new books of 19th- and early 20th-century photographs. Benjamin Blom's ''New York Photographs, 1850-1950'' (Amaryllis/Dutton, $65 hardcover), gives an optimistic picture of life in New York. Blom sees this city as a microcosm of America, and he believes that America has, on the whole, kept its promises both to itself and to the rest of the world. (A shorter and reorganized version of Mr. Blom's book may be seen as an exhibition at the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue and 51st Street, through Jan. 8).

title: ONE THING IS SURE, UNCERTAINTY
description: ON Nov. 11 in Lublin, listening to news on the Voice of America and the BBC World Service, my Polish companion and I heard about strikes in some factories, demonstrations in the major cities and the arrest of 800 people; we also discovered that Leonid Brezhnev had died, Lech Walesa was being released and it was expected that martial law would be lifted by the end of the year. This streaming of events defines the literary as well as the political situation in Poland, a situation so unstable that the writers, whose main effort is to grasp what is happening to Poland, find themselves at a loss to keep up with it. And yet, as one well-known poet told me, ''Now there is only one subject - Poland, and what will happen to us all.''

title: Pillaging
description: To the Editor: In response to the letter from Elliot J. Moritz (Travel, Nov. 21) describing his enthusiasm at finding several small artifacts while visiting sites in Greece and Turkey, I say ''for shame.''

title: CANADA ADMITTED FEW REFUGEE JEWS
description: Canada's refusal to admit more than 5,000 Jewish refugees between 1933 when Hitler came to power and 1945 when Germany was defeated has been brought to light in a book that has become a best seller.

title: SKIING PEAK TO PEAK IN UTAH
description: Imagine a Rocky Mountain ski area with thousands of acres of open slopes and labyrinthine glades, with 126 trails and more than 35 lifts capable of hauling 43,600 skiers an hour to peaks as high as 11,000 feet above sea level. Such a complex does not quite exist but it has advanced beyond the realm of mere imagination: Five ski resorts in Utah's Wasatch Range have become partners in the Interconnect Adventure, a program that combines a daylong sampler of many of the state's most popular runs - at Park City, Solitude, Brighton, Alta and Snowbird - with guided ski touring through tranquil back country.

title: ACIDIC TIDE OF PIZZA SLUDGE THREATENS SOUTH OHIO TOWN
description: There was joy in Wellston, Ohio, last February when Jeno's Inc. opened a frozen pizza plant that would employ about 1,000 people and help relieve a local unemployment rate of around 20 percent.

title: LET'S NEGOTIATE WITH ANDROPOV
description: Within a month, the United States will resume negotiations with the Soviet Union on strategic and intermediate-range nuclear weapons. Lulled by the slow pace of these negotiations, preoccupied with our economy and the rebuilding before us at home, we - as a nation -are in danger of forgetting the sense of urgency that brought about these meetings in the first place.

title: DEBUNKING MYTHS ABOUT SERVICES
description: As more and more of America's gross national product is generated by service industries - such as medicine, law and finance - and less and less by traditional manufacturing, many questions are being raised about what the shift means for the economy. A common view holds that the service sector is characterized by relatively heavy labor inputs, small amounts of capital and, as a result, lower than average productivity gains.

title: Moscow Jousts With Pope
description: Between the Soviet Union and Pope John Paul II, the feeling is mutual. But last week, Christian charity was strained more than usual by a rare Soviet attack against the Polish Pontiff for ''subversive activity'' against Poland and other countries.

title: THE ENDURING ART OF SEVRES
description: OLIVIER BERNIER's ''Lafayette: Hero of Two Worlds,'' will be published by E.P.Dutton next fall.

title: STRAIGHTENING OUT YOUR RECORDS
description: IT is the time of year again in which many people, faced by piles ofb ills and receipts spilling over the edges of their desks, vow once a nd for all to organize their financial records.

title: Medical Examiner Off Critical List
description: Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan rendered his own second opinion last week in the case of Dr. Michael M. Baden, the beleaguered chief deputy medical examiner. This time, he changed his diagnosis.

title: PERIOD FURNITURE
description: Modernism, one of Manhattan's newest "antiques" shops, reflects the wider horizons collectors are now exploring in the 20th-century decorative arts. The highly sophisticated period furnishings it stocks, which are too young to be legally classified as "antiques," but are collected as if they were, represent a mix of the modern styles that have flourished in many countries since 1900.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Talking column last Sunday incorrectly described a law governing the size of reserve funds in cooperative conversions. The New York City Council has passed a law, effective Feb. 1, requiring a reserve fund of 3 percent of the total offering price in a conversion.

title: Marjorie McGraw Is to Be Married To M.E. Lewicki
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. McGraw of Essex Fells, N.J., and Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Lee McGraw, to Matthew E. Lewicki, son of Margaret H. Lewicki of Union, N.J., and the late Matthew E. Lewicki. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned.

title: The Beat Goes On
description: Dr. Denton Cooley has had a change of heart. For a while, the famous heart-transplant pioneer didn't see what all the fuss was about when doctors in Utah implanted the first permanent artificial heart. Dr. Cooley, the chief surgeon at the Texas Heart Institute, criticized them for implanting a device that he didn't think would work very long and ought to be used only ''on a real emergency basis.''

title: WINNING COMBINATION ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Dismisses Judges For 'Inhuman Behavior'
description: Two Iranian judges have been dismissed for overstepping their authority, the Teheran radio reported today. The revolutionary prosecutors of the northeastern town of Birjand and the southern town of Bushire have been dismissed for ''repeated violations and inhuman and un-Islamic behavior in their posts,'' the radio said.

title: HOW TO WIN A NOBEL
description: The dais was lined with some of the stars of the economics profession, including five winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. Hundreds more economists sat at tables below.

title: HAMBURG
description: To the Editor:

title: Kristen Zarfos to Wed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Dr. Kristen A. Zarfos of Guilford, Conn., to William A. Whalen 3d of Windham Center, Conn. The wedding is planned for May. The prospective bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Zarfos of Smithsburg, Md., is a staff emergency physician with the Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn., and the Shoreline Clinic in Essex, Conn. Mr. Whalen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Whalen Jr., is completing doctoral work in genetics at the University of Connecticut.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF GOV. CUOMO'S ADDRESS AT EMPIRE STATE PLAZA IN ALBANY
description: Following is a transcript of the inaugural address yesterday by Governor Cuomo as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES CAN'T AFFORD TO WAIT FOR 1984
description: Although it may seem that the Republic has hardly had time to recover from the 1980 Presidential campaign, the New Year brought an important benchmark of the 1984 campaign.

title: No Headline
description: Morton Hunt ends his article with a hope that we will somehow find a way of helping jurors reach their verdicts on the basis of rationality and responsibility rather than on personal prejudices arising from such variables as education, age, social status, personality traits, ethnic origins and religion.

title:
DANCE;
WINTER SERIES IN YONKERS FILLS GAP
description: ''I WANT to share my enthusiasm for dance with as many people as possible,'' Hal Passoth said. ''I don't think it's elitist or difficult. Nothing is as exciting for me as when I see an audience turn on, become discerning.''

title: U.S. TO COUNT PART OF MILITARY IN EMPLOYMENT TOTAL
description: The Labor Department will start counting military personnel based in the United States in its employment statistics this month, a move that will probably lower the unemployment rate reported by the Government, officials say.

title: Nets Win; Albert King Injured
description: The Nets defeated the Dallas Mavericks, 111-105, for their fifth consecutive victory tonight, but they may have lost Albert King for as long as four weeks.

title: U.S. Withholds Sea Law Funding
description: President Reagan has decided that those who don't play shouldn't pay. He announced last week that Washington would not honor assessmemts of up to $1 million a year for the new Law of the Sea Treaty preparatory commission.

title: Possible Solution To Fighting Over Court Nominees
description: The lawyer in Mario M. Cuomo might have liked nothing better than to haul the Judicial Nominating Commission before a judge for frustrating his bid to put a woman on New York State's highest court. But the governor in him decided last week that legislation was better than litigation.

title: BY LAWRENCE STONE
description: A HISTORY OF WOMEN'S BODIES By Edward Shorter. 398 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: Alison Eckstein and Seth Colton Engaged
description: Claire Butler Eckstein of New York and East Hampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alison Carter Eckstein, to Seth M. Colton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roger S. Colton of St. Paul. A June wedding is planned.

title: FROM SERENDIPITOUS MATERIALS TO JOSEPH CORNELL'S ART; WASHINGTON
description: When scholars do research at the National Museum of American Art's Joseph Cornell Study Center, they can dig into something more than the usual archives. Besides old books, engravings, photographs, scrapbooks, and the like - neatly packed in rows of cardboard cartons - there are games, antique toys, velvet remnants, turkey feathers, dime-store jewelry, sheet music, broken wineglasses, alphabet blocks, Victorian Christmas tree ornaments and thousands of other bits and pieces used by Joseph Cornell (1903-72) as ingredients of the box-constructions and collages for which he was celebrated. ''Cornell was not only a discriminating and insatiable collector, he was also a researcher, a curator and an archivist,'' says Lynda Roscoe Hartigan, assistant curator of 20th-century painting and sculpture at the museum, who is working on a catalogue raisonne of Cornell's works. ''The books formed a kind of 'reading and cutting' library, and he kept the rest of the material in cartons and folders as a kind of spare-parts department.''

title: Disaster Costs at $565 Million
description: The cost of Federal efforts to help the victims of storms, floods and other disasters that occurred in 1982 may reach nearly $600 million, officials said Friday.

title: CAMPUS COMPUTERS RESHAPE SOCIAL LIFE AND WORK HABITS
description: Guy Barudin and Julie Lewin, both students at Princeton University, began using the university's main computer last year to exchange electronic mail. ''Every few days I'd write her a little note, and when I'd log on there would usually be a note for me,'' Mr. Barudin recalled. ''It was just chit-chat.''

title: Susan G. Ross Is Affianced To Paul Cusack, a Designer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Ross of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Gillespie Ross, to Paul Edward Cusack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence X. Cusack of Manhasset, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: REMAINING ISSUES IN INDIAN POINT PLAN
description: THE emergency plans for the Indian Point Nuclear Power Station have been examined again by the Federal Government and once again found wanting, and for the fourth time in three years a deadline has been set for making the plans workable. This time, however, the planners appear to have come closer to satisfying the Federal agencies, as well as closer to wearing out the regulators' patience.

title: ST. PETER'S RELYING ON NATIVE TALENT
description: JERSEY CITY ''WE HAVE a number of reasons for feeling proud about our women's basketball team at St. Peter's College this season,'' said Coach Mike Granelli. ''But perhaps the thing about the squad that makes me proudest is that it is practically homegrown.''

title: REPORT RECOMMENDS CITY CHANGE METHOD OF CARING FOR ELDERLY
description: The number of the very elderly - people over 85 - will increase greatly by 1990, according to a study by the New York City Planning Commission, and the commission's chairman warns that the city needs new approaches for services.

title:
GARDENING;
SAVING OUR ENDANGERED PLANTS
description: MOST everyone would agree that death and taxes are unavoidable. Plants do not have to pay taxes, unless their struggle to survive in the harsh environment of man-made pollution is considered as such. However, plants do die. In fact, the entire population of a species may die. The extinction of a plant species is final. When gone, it is no longer available to see, touch, smell, taste or study.

title: Dr. Elsa L. Stone and Dr. Richard Granger Marry
description: The marriage of Dr. Elsa Louise Stone, an assistant clinical professor of pediatrics at the Yale University School of Medicine, to Dr. Richard Horace Granger, a professor of pediatrics at the Yale Child Study Center, took place yesterday at the bride's home in New Haven. Walter Lawton, leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony.

title: FOR DIABETICS, A NEW RAY OF HOPE
description: TRENTON AGROUP of New Jerseyans is helping to make medical history by participating in studies of the effects of biosynthetic human insulin, the first human health-care product produced through genetic engineering.

title: 30 Matisse Drawings
description: ''Matisse: 30 Drawings,'' an exhibition of works on paper by the modern French master, are on view at the Stephen Mazoh Gallery, 13 East 76th Street, through Jan. 14. The exhibition is supplemented by several of the artist's bronzes and a 1938 paper cutout version of his 1910 painting ''The Dance.'' Hours are Monday through Friday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays (but closed tomorrow), 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: 737-2203.

title: I enjoyed Elinor Robinson's article, ''Why Not Stay Married?'' I concur with her that two people can grow together in understanding and compassion. Where there is a lack of love, no concern for another's needs and no dialogue, a relationship suffers. There is no growth.
description: A factor that she did not include in her article is the economic aspect of marriage.

title: PARTNERS IN MARRIAGE, INDIVIDUALS IN ART
description: GARDEN CITY INSTANCES where both partners in a marriage are professional artists occur from time to time, but it is quite unusual for an exhibition to be devoted to artist couples. ''Related to the Arts - and Each Other,'' currently at the Adelphi University Alumni House Art Gallery, was conceived by the gallery director, Muriel Siris, who found the idea intriguing.

title: F.B.I. RADIO SEEKS TO LIMIT LISTENERS
description: Radio station KGB-770 transmits to a restricted audience in the nation's capital: agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, criminals and Soviet spies.

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor:

title: STARTING OFF CHURLISH
description: Here, in no particular order, are a few things I would happily do without in the New Year: Horror movies. People who tell me that the press should print more good news. Presidents who advocate a constitutional amendment to force future Presidents to balance the budget. Any further maudlin tributes to Bear Bryant. Politicians who decide they can defeat an opponent only if they ''raise his negative'' and do so with distortions, innuendo, misinformation, slander and downright lies.

title: PENN STATE STOPS TOP-RANKED GEORGIA, 27-23
description: Penn State put itself in position to be voted the final No.1-ranked team for the first time in its 96 years of football and 17 seasons under Coach Joe Paterno tonight as it scored a thrilling 27-23 victory over Georgia in the 49th Sugar Bowl game.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
PECULIAR POLITICS AND DANGEROUS DEFICITS
description: IN fiscal 1982, the Federal Government's deficit exceeded $100 b illion for the first time in our history, surpassing the previous 1 976 record by more than 50 percent. In fiscal 1983, the 1982 record i s likely to be broken by at least another 50 percent as the deficit s oars toward $200 billion.

title: Fuel-Tax Increase May Aid Boaters
description: Included in the five-cent-a-gallon fuel tax-increase bill passed by Congress before it adjourned for the holidays is a provision that is expected to result in a boon for recreational boating.

title: MILLER PROVED ALMOST IDEAL AS BASEBALL'S UNION CHIEF
description: WHEN the baseball players of 1966 elected Marvin Miller to be the executive director of their union, they made an almost perfect choice. At the time, however, they probably had no idea they had done so well.

title: PRAVDA SAYS STRATEGIC ARMS TALKS ARE DEADLOCKED AND BLAMES U.S.
description: The main Soviet Communist Party newspaper says a deadlock has developed in the talks with the United States on reducing nuclear strategic arms and attributes the impasse to American attempts to achieve military superiority.

title: A CHINESE DISCOVERY IN MADISON
description: MADISON IF a reader hadn't alerted us, we might never have discovered Chan's Roadside In tucked into the rear corner of a small, inconspicuous shopping complex in Madison. For all its early-American brick exterior, Chan's Roadside In is a proper Chinese restaurant. A small, square dining room has a slightly separated alcove containing a few tables. The dining room is decorated with beige bamboo-designed wallpaper with a few traditional Chinese paintings, red plasticseated chairs and red candles on each plain table. The menu is authentically Chinese, dominated by Sichuan and Hunan dishes.

title: OFFICE CURE
description: The former home of the Columbia Record Company in Bridgeport, Conn., is being developed into that city's first complex of medical office condominiums.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER CAPITALS, 7-2
description: Facing a team that had beaten and tied the Rangers in their previous meetings this season, Coach Herb Brooks forced his players to concentrate on their mistakes of the past. And after the Rangers beat the Washington Capitals, 7-2, at the Capital Centre tonight, Brooks said he thought the change of emphasis helped the Rangers maintain control in the surprisingly easy victory.

title: THE UNCONQUERABLE WELSH
description: Ancient nations like Wales are not anachronisms in the modern world, nor is loyalty to them a stubbornly irrational clinging to the past. Their persistence compels all of us to re-examine our ideas about political life.

title: Team U.S.A. Defeats Soviet Squad in Final
description: Team U.S.A. defeated Torpedo Gorky of the Soviet Union, 3-2, to take the championship in the Battle Creek World Hockey Tournament Friday night. Team U.S.A. rallied on third-period goals by Jeff Logan, Phil Verchota and Todd Johnson.

title: Wedding Planned By Carol J. Wilson
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wilson of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Jane Wilson, to Kenneth Rone Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Hunter Creech of Yorktown, Va. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Survival of the fittest may be a good working description of the process of evolution, but a government of humans should elevate itself to a higher order, one which tries to fill the cruel gaps left by chance and by a wisdom that we don't fully understand.'' - Governor Cuomo. (22:3.)

title: SLIGHT MAINTENANCE-CHARGE RISE FORESEEN
description: MOST cooperative buildings in New York face higher maintenance charges in 1983, but the increases w ill be smaller than those of the last few years. Budgets now being prepared for cooperatives show maintenance costs going up by about 5 percent. That compares with increases averaging 8 to 10 percent in 1982 and 11 percent in 1981, according to r ealestate analysts and managing agents.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SOMEONE said ''take your time'' the other day, and I heard the familiar expression as if for the first time. Maybe it was because of the press of the holidays, when time rushes past so quickly that I invoke the law of relativity, trying to make time stand still by rushing faster myself. Maybe it was the imminent new year that, like a birthday, is a time when I feel time fleeting. Whatever the reason, I heard a new meaning in ''take your time.''

title: CRIME FIGHTERS' SLATE CLEAN
description: WOODSTOCK THE unblemished record of the Woodstock Theft Detecting Society was kept clean for another year, after 186 years of combating crime in this rural northeastern town.

title: ENERGY AUDITS FOR COMPANIES
description: ARMED with the simple tools of his trade - thermometer, light meter, tape measure and sketch pad - Cornelius Crowley has been traveling to all corners of the state over the last three years, converting the message of energy conservation into dollars and cents for more than 3,000 small businesses.

title: HELPING UNEMPLOYED IS THE FIRST PRIORITY BUT IT'S EXPENSIVE
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the 98th Congress convenes tomorrow, members are likely to trip over one another in their eagerness to propose Federal action to reduce unemployment. But the hustle and bustle should not be mistaken for concrete action, which will cost money and be subject to approval by President Reagan.

title: Daniel Stern Is Fiance Of Susan E. Steinberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lippmann of Roanoke, Va., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lippmann's daughter, Susan E. Steinberg, to Daniel R. Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stern of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: DANCE The gala benefit that opens the Riverside Dance Festival winter season Wednesday is dedicated to the late critic, Walter Terry, and it promises to be an unusual one, dotted with dancers trying their hand at choreography.

title: David Riffe Keller Is Wed To Susan Moulton Keppel
description: Susan Moulton Keppel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Keppel of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to David Riffe Keller, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Keller of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Judith Baumer of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: 2 HOUSE FRESHMAN TAKE LEAD
description: NEW HAVEN IF BRUCE A. MORRISON gets his way, the Democratic Party will punish its alleged traitors and offer a clear alternative to President Reagan's policies. Nancy L. Johnson hopes to see the Republicans make headlines as a ''compassionate'' party.

title: Another Winter Of Discontent In Afghanistan
description: Soviet troops last week entered their fourth year in Afghanistan with little to show for it except a chorus of boos from around the world.

title: Hockey Notebook; Soviet Team Shows Manners and Skills
description: The Soviet all-star hockey team is accumulating lots of air mileage on its 10-day, six-game North American trip. After landing in Montreal from Moscow last Monday, the players flew west to Edmonton, Alberta, then east to Quebec and back to Montreal, then back west to Calgary for a game tonight against the Flames. Tomorrow they fly east again for a game in Minnesota Tuesday and the final game Thursday in Philadelphia.

title: MRS. NIXON CONTRIBUTES TO NEEDIEST
description: Patricia Nixon, the wife of former President Richard M. Nixon, has contributed $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of Freeman F. Gosden, who created and the played the role of Amos in the long-running radio and television comedy ''Amos and Andy.'' Mr. Gosden died on Dec. 10 in Los Angeles at the age of 83.

title: BUILDER FOR A 42D STREET SITE SOUGHT
description: THE search to replace developers who dropped out of the $1 billion p roject to revitalize 42d Street is a top priority of the newly e stablished Times Square Redevelopment Corporation, according to L awrence F. Graham, its president.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRAVDA EDITORIAL ON THE STRATEGIC ARMS TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from an editorial in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda as carried in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: ASTROLOGER CHARTS COUNTY'S PROSPECTS FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: THE New Year may well be an auspicious one for Westchester County: the county is entering the tricentennial of its founding with a new executive at its head, its moon in Aries, Pluto at its node and a mystic rectangle of five planets prominent. Consequently, according to one astrologer, Westchester is on the verge of becoming a trendsetter for the rest of the nation, but not before it weathers a period of problems.

title: ARTHUR RUBENSTEIN'S SALUTE TO A MISSING FLAG
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICE'S PIT: A DEEP SCAR IN ATLANTIC CITY'S BACKYARD
description: The mayors of the two municipalities in which Price's Pit is situated believe that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency will choose to do nothing about cleaning up the abandoned landfill, now that contaminated wells or those threatened with contamination have been shut down and alternate sources of water established.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Half-Price Sale At the Talbots

title: DID YOU HEAR THE ONE ABOUT...?
description: A businessman sitting at a table with three economists asked what they thought would happen to the economy. The first looked grim. The economy, he said, would recover, but slowly. The second also looked grim. The outlook, he said, was dismal. But the third, a mathematical economist from academia, shrugged his shoulders. The state of the economy, he said, was something that he simply did not pay much attention to.

title: EL AL IS EXPECTED TO RESUME
description: El Al was expected to resume service next week after a judge tonight reversed a liquidation order for the financially ailing state airline. Its planes have been grounded since Sept. 13, when striking flight attendants were locked out by management.

title: SEARCHING FOR A MANDATE IN THE RESULTS OF NOVEMBER
description: THE House of Representatives and the Senate aren't always on stage; it has just seemed that way of late. Tomorrow at noon, the 98th Congress is due to begin settling in for its two-year run. In addition to those ever-present economic issues, the new Congress will have on its agenda any number of matters - including immigration and Social Security changes -left unsettled by the old Congress, which barely made it out of Washington before Christmas.

title: Hamburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Kogler of Austria Takes Four-Hill Ski Jumping
description: PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, Jan. 1 (AP) - Armin Kogler of Austria edged Steinar Braaten of Norway by one-tenth of a point in winning the second ski-jumping competition of the Four-Hill tournament today.

title: CALCULATING THE ODDS ON ACCURATE RISK ASSESSMENT
description: Consider the problem of ethylene dibromide, a pesticide used in the battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly. Some specialists have questioned how much exposure to the pesticide will produce adverse health effects in humans and have prompted the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to examine the consequences of using the chemical. ''We have to hurry up without making a mistake,'' said David Bell, chief of economic impact assessments for the agency's office of regulatory analysis. ''You don't want harmful exposures to go on too long, but you don't want to make a snap decision either.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' occupies a special place in the operatic repertory. It is neither a tuneful potboiler nor a weighty Germanic exercise, and it lacks the built-in constituency that exists in this country for the standard Italian and German operas.

title: HE'S DOWN, BUT NOT OUT
description: TWO years ago, for 30 cents a share, the public was given a chance t o invest in a rather unusual company. It had no operating history a nd no assets beyond 150 minutes of film footage of Muhammad Ali. T he company, Meridian Productions, was going to produce movies and t elevision shows. One series, called ''For Love Not Money,'' was to f eature lawyers and judges awaken during the middle of the night to p lay ice hockey. Another would focus on Wall Street boxers who p racticed during their lunch hour and fought matches for charity.

title: A SUCCESSFUL MIX IN ROCKLAND
description: ONE should not expect an art exhibition entitled ''Eight Sensibilities'' to be a show with a unified theme. What is achieved at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery, near the Rockland County (N.Y.) community of Sparkill, is a good blending. It's like the mix at a successful dinner party whose guests not only are pretty well matched in intelligence and accomplishment, but who also come from different walks of life.

title: IT LOOKS LIKE GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE, BUT IT'S CIRCA 1980'S
description: SAG HARBOR ADECADE ago, Victorian meant old-fashioned, and gingerbread houses in the woods around Sag Harbor were languishing like eccentric furniture in Hamptons attics. Now the trend on the East End, an area known for futuristic architecture, is the construction of new old-fashioned houses and Victorian oddities.

title: Putting Juries on The Couch
description: Morton Hunt's article on the possibility of manipulating the minds of jurors fails to stress sufficiently two issues that underlie ''scientific'' jury selection (''Putting Juries on the Couch,'' Nov. 28). The lesser of these issues is that there is no way to know whether jury selection actually works. In those cases where social scientists have been employed to select juries, the outcomes that have ensued might as easily have resulted from the strength of the case as from the bias of the jury. Indeed, the literature is rife with examples of jurors who were selected by social scientists with high confidence that they would take a particular side, and who subsequently led the opposition. Jury selection, by itself, can never be said to augment materially the interests of a particular client since, once a jury is in place, there is no way to compare it with an unselected jury.

title: THE HANDY KNACK OF SINKING PILOT HOLES FOR WOOD SCREWS
description: EVERY woodworking manual and all how-to carpentry books tell the home carpenter that a pilot hole must be drilled for wood screws before driving them into lumber or plywood - yet a surprisingly large number of do-it-yourselfers don't know how to determine the size of hole needed for each screw.

title: AFFORDABLE LIVING SPACE FOR SINGLES
description: WHERE do you find affordable housing if you are single? Nassau C ounty has almost 60,000 people living in single-person households, b ut only 43,000 apartments. The overall vacancy rate for the county i s about 3 percent.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
CARRYING ON IN A CASALS TRADITION
description: STONY BROOK THE student leans into his instrument, coaxing dark and grainy sonorities from his cello with long strokes of the bow. He is interrupted by his teacher, who repeats the phrase a student has just played with the slightest difference of inflection, an almost imperceptible change of coloring.

title: At 62d New Year's Ball
description: New York's oldest debutante presentation and dinner dance took place last night at the Plaza Hotel, where 30 young women bowed to society at the 62d Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball. Stephanie Michele Tooman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ronald Tooman of Hilo, Hawaii, led the grand march of young women from this country and Europe and their escorts.

title: FEW CHEERFUL CHERUBS THIS YEAR FOR MITTERRAND
description: One of President Francois Mitterrand's advisers, who is paid to think wide and large, cast his eye joyously forward the other day and said he liked the looks of 1985. The intervening years? Seven hundred-odd days of discomfort for the short-view people to puzzle out, he explained.

title: BRITISH OPPOSE BAN ON DANISH FISHERMEN
description: Britain imposed a ban on commercial fishing by Denmark in coastal North Sea waters today but some Danish fishermen said they would ignore the regulation.

title: HELPING THE DEAF TO MANAGE MONEY
description: GROTON THREE years ago, Lyle Kennedy and his sister, Margaret, were getting to know each other again. Even though each had married and moved apart, they were now getting together at least once a month.

title: Article 129966 -- No Title
description: WHEN Herman Yellen bought his lottery ticket for 50 cents back in 1972, he had little idea he would become the state's first big lottery winner: The Westport resident won $75,000. The state did not have millionaire winners until 1975.

title: Carolyn Le Vine To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Saul Le Vine of Roslyn Heights, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn S. Le Vine, to David A. Topol, son of Dr. Phyllis Topol of Larchmont, and the late Arthur L. Topol.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: Andre Dunoyer de Segonzac (1884-1974) is a painter for whom not many a kind word has lately been said. He worked hard all his life, and his output as a painter in oils, as a watercolorist and as an etcher was very substantial.

title: NO ONE RULES IN CUOMO'S DIVIDED INNER CIRCLE
description: AS Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State, Mario M. Cuomo was not known for having a strong staff, partly because those offices were not much of a magnet to begin with. Also, he liked being a oneman show. This time, despite no shortage of applicants, the carefully choreographed series of appointments that followed his election as Governor again seems to signal Mr. Cuomo's determination to keep a tight rein on his administration.

title: PSYCHIATRIST MINISTERS TO ELDERLY POOR AT THEIR HOMES
description: Dr. Thomas Chiu makes psychiatric house calls on the elderly in Brooklyn. He interrupts their loneliness in apartments in city housing projects to listen to their complaints and fears. He talks to homeless and alienated women loaded down with shopping bags at the entrances to subway stations and offers them care on the spot.

title: AFRICA: NAMIBIA, AID AND IDEOLOGY
description: NAIROBI AFRICAN leaders, including moderate ones, criticize Washington's insistence that a settlement of the guerrilla war in Namibia (South-West Africa) include parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.

title: 'BATTLE FOR THE DOLLAR' LOOMS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY THE members of the Long Island delegation to the State Legislature will take their seats here on Wednesday with a long list of demands by Nassau and Suffolk officials. First among these demands are those seeking to have the state assume some of the costs of locally provided services.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I would like to know the names and addresses of tour companies that book tours for the disabled. - E.M., St. Louis Answer:Evergreen Travel Service's Wings on Wheels division, Lynnwood, Wash., and Flying Wheels Tours, Owatonna, Minn., are two companies with experience in providing such travel services.

title: POPE RENEWS BID FOR EFFORTS AT DISARMAMENT
description: Pope John Paul II called today on the world's opposing forces to carry out a joint program of disarmament. ''Peace cannot be built by some without the others,'' the Pope declared in a New Year's homily in St. Peter's Basilica, ''but all must undertake the task together.''

title: Make Bridgeport A Free Trade Zone
description: Here in Bridgeport, the state's largest city, the giant sleeps! Throughout Fairfield County and neighboring towns, there has been positive economic development, but here in the eye of the hurricane, no progress seems to be made.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: Holly Hammond Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Hammond Jr. of Westport, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly McKinnon Hammond, to John Whitney Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney M. Williams of Darien, Conn. An April 16 wedding is planned.

title: JETS START 2 DEFENSIVE BACKUPS
description: On the last day of their second regular season with the Jets, Ben Rudolph and Kenny Neil - backups for pro football's best known defensive line - will finally form a starting tandem.

title: ELECTRIC 'EXTREMITIES' AND A MUFFLED 'ALICE'
description: I am sure that the idealistic souls who mounted the expensive revival of Eva Le Gallienne's ''Alice in Wonderland'' at the Virginia opened it when they did as a holiday treat for the kiddies (who would of course bring their elders) and I am sure that all of us who trooped off to see it during Christmas week either were old enough to have seen the original (fondly remembered) or not old enough to have seen the original (and therefore warmly curious). We were treatminded, too. Alas. Though Miss Le Gallienne still flies in from the wings -on wires - looking like a chess piece that's been dropped in the powdered sugar, and though Kate Burton makes an appealingly sturdy, white-stockinged Alice, the entertainment is unexpectedly tepid. The treat of the week, in a genuinely savage irony, turned out to be a viciously conceived and recklessly played account of an attempted rape and the revenge it breeds. It's called ''Extremities,'' it's at the Westside Arts Center on 43d Street, and it's far from perfect. But William Mastrosimone's play bristles with so much energy that it makes you feel glad to be in a theater again, and I guess that's a reasonable facsimile of the holiday spirit (a little something to be surprised by, a little something to be grateful for).

title: 21 Are Honored for Heroism
description: The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission has honored 21 Americans and Canadians for risking their lives to save others from death. Four of those honored died in the rescue attempts.

title: WHEN THE BOYS ARE HOME AGAIN
description: THE morning after Christmas I wait for five hours, my hand poised on the eggbeater, ready for action. I tell callers I'm not available today: ''Eric and Andrew are home from college.''

title: Joe Paterno's Quest for No.1
description: NEW ORLEANS JOE PATERNO has always professed that ''being No.1'' is just opinion. He means primarily the opinion of those who vote in the two wire-service polls that rank the nation's college football teams - the coaches in the United Press International poll, the sportswriters and sportscasters in the Associated Press poll. He's had three unbeaten Penn State teams during the seasons of 1973, 1969 and 1968, but none ever was accorded the final No.1 ranking in the final and absolute opinion of the polls. Joe Paterno, of course, had a different opinion.

title: Miss Title to Wed Daniel Himelman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Title of New Orleans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hannah Title, to Daniel Jon Himelman, son of Municipal Court Judge William Himelman and Mrs. Himelman of Red Bank, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: DESPITE A RECOVERY, HIGH JOBLESS RATE IS EXPECTED DURING THE NEXT TWO YEARS
description: WASHINGTON UNLESS the American economy is sicker than even most pessimists think, recovery from the recession will come, sooner or later. Yet, unemployment - once again the public's paramount economic concern, now that inflation has abated - seems to have settled in for a long siege at the highest rates since World War II.

title:
DINING OUT;
A FEELING OF INFORMALITY IN BEDFORD
description: THE Village Inn of Bedford Village has the informal, slapdash atmosphere of a dated ski lodge. Seedy pine paneling, cheap-looking dinnerware, tables so closely spaced that waiting staff cannot serve properly all contribute to a low-grade ambience. The small, square and low-ceilinged back dining room lacks adequate ventilation and the air can become dense with cigarette smoke. Potentially more attractive with its cathedral ceiling and lovely fire, the first dining room serves as a thoroughfare for kitchen traffic and for diners passing to and from the back room. It is further used as a large service station where serving staff stand between tasks. All this casualness and rusticity necessitates a thick wallet. At these prices more elegant dishes can be had in more beautiful surroundings at any number of restaurants in the county.

title: TAMING THE OYSTER
description: Whenever considering oysters, my thoughts turn to one of the finest books that I have encountered about a single food - ''The Glorious Oyster,'' printed in England and edited by Hector Bolitho (Sidgwick and Jackson, 1960).

title: ECLIPSE VOTING IS WIDE OPEN
description: On Tuesday, the Eclipse Award winners will be announced, finally providing an answer to the vexing question of who was the horse of the year in 1982.

title: LEGISLATIVE RIFTS APT TO INTENSIFY IN ELECTION YEAR
description: TRENTON THE first year of the Kean administration, a period marked by economic problems and partisan bickering, has ended. Prospects for continued turmoil in the State House during the coming legislative election year also appear great, for every major bill will be debated with an eye toward its effect on the re-election chances of the 120 members of the Senate and Assembly.

title: EX-CUSTOMS OFFICIAL IS CHARGED WITH RACKETEERING
description: A former official of the United States Customs Service in New York has been indicted on Federal charges of conducting his office ''through a pattern of racketeering activity.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
TABLES FOR FUN OR FUNCTION
description: OF all the words in the collector's vocabulary, perhaps table conjures up mental pictures of more designs, forms, styles and activities than any other category of antiques.

title: I'VE BEEN RIDING ON THE RAILROAD- FOR 50 YEARS
description: IAM in my 50th year of commuting on the Long Island Rail Road. T hat's a milestone not matched by many of the railroad's employees, n ot even by its president, Robin H.H. Wilson, who had not yet been b orn when I began riding in 1933.

title: LANDMARKS CITED AS COUNTY TURNS 300
description: AS Karen M. Kennedy, a historic preservationist, said the other day, Rye Playland with its carousel and boardwalk may be considered frivolous by some people and the Yonkers Waterworks could be touted as mundane.

title: ABOARD THE AIR FARE MERRY-GO-ROUND
description: W ith little fanfare, American Express and Pan American World Airways have joined in a sales promotion that originally was intended for a relatively select group of travelers.

title: FOR NEW YORK'S NEW LEADER, A DAY OF FAMILY AND ROOTS
description: For Mario M. Cuomo it was a day to celebrate his family and his immigrant roots, to pay ''magnificent tribute'' to American democracy and to wonder at the ''improbability'' of it all.

title: MINORITY ENROLLMENT PROMOTED
description: A special state commission has recommended that a ''permanent body'' be established to guarantee that the enrollment of blacks, Hispanic people and members of other minority groups in New York State medical schools increases.

title: CAREER OF A SKATER NEAR TURNING POINT
description: JOHN PAUL LICARI has just added another gold medal to his collection of figure skating prizes, bringing him perhaps a step closer to becoming Connecticut's next world champion skater.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: A Matter of Sole

title: Arizona Tax Forms Offer Financing for Frog Study
description: By checking a box on their state tax return, Arizona taxpayers can donate money for the study of a rare frog they have probably never heard about.

title: BY ELIN SCHOEN
description: Elin Schoen is the author of ''Tales of an All-Night Town,'' an account of life in a poor Illinois community, and often writes on social issues. I never thought this could happen,'' Frank said softly. He had temporarily forgotten the embarrassment of being at the Center for Food Action in suburban Bergen County, New Jersey, waiting for free groceries. Frank, 46, had requested that his real name not be used, and, promised anonymity, he talked freely, his luminous black eyes enraged at times, at other times sad, bewildered or resigned. ''All the years I've saved, and what I've done in life - I did a little traveling and everything - and it just, it just went that way,'' said Frank. ''I just can't believe it, you know. I've never been like this in my life.''

title: Plea by Ex-Amoco Employee
description: A former Amoco Oil employee has pleaded not guilty to charges that he wrote letters threatening to damage the company's Texas City refinery. The former employee, Alton S. Edwards, faces up to 35 years in prison and $22,500 in fines if convicted. The trial was set for Feb. 15.

title: Military Analysis
description: Intelligence sources, citing some small shifts in Soviet military deployments in Eastern Europe, speculate that Moscow is readjusting its military strategy as a result of Middle Eastern developments and the expected arrival of new Atlantic alliance weapons.

title: CLOSE-TO-HOME ATTRACTS THE YOUNG
description: LONG ago, Nan Heathworth owned a spit of land on the North Shore but lost the papers that would have proved her title. The property was known as Mad Nan's Neck, as it appears on a map of Great Neck dated 1658.

title: INSEPARABLE FROM A SWAN
description: ANNA PAVLOVA Her Life and Art. By Keith Money. Illustrated. 425 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $55.

title: TEACHER, LAWYER, STATESMAN, BUT FIRST A POET
description: LETTERS OF ARCHIBALD MACLEISH 1907 to 1982. Edited by R. H. Winnick. 471 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $20.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: STARTING this month, 16 Connecticut hospitals will be linked to a telecommunications system designed to get two hours' worth of prenatal and perinatal care information to physicians in about 10 minutes.

title: U.S. Bows to Soviet, 5-3; Criticizes the Referee
description: The Soviet Union defeated the United States, 5-3, today and remained unbeaten after five games in the world junior hockey championship tournament.

title: The Baby Dam
description: The United States enters 1983 with 234 million inhabitants. That's four million more than in 1980; births are increasing; and some people think a new baby boom has begun. Baloney. The apt question about births, at this birth of a new year, is why there are so few.

title: Dream Team to Tackle the MX
description: Around Washington, high-level commissions usually have low levels of success; their recommendations are often filed and forgotten. The White House is banking everything on a new MX basing commission as an exception to the rule.

title: 3 Jockeys and an Agent Are Barred From Track
description: Three jockeys and a jockey's agent have been barred from racing at Waterford Park pending a hearing to investigate two races run Dec. 18.

title: Husband of Poisoned Woman Arraigned in California Case
description: A man who had attributed his wife's near-fatal poisoning to cyanide-tainted Anacin-3 capsules was arraigned Friday on charges of trying to kill her.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Corporate Apartments
description: Question: I moved in with my sister six years ago into a rentstabilized apartment. My name is not on the lease. If my sister were transferred to another state, could I be evicted? The landlord turns apartments that become vacant into corporate apartments with different people using them and huge rents, and I know he would like to get this apartment, too. Could you tell me what my legal situation is? ... D.R. South Ozone Park. Answer: Housing officials say that you probably could not be evicted because you took occupancy with the tenant and also because you are a close member of the tenant's family. When the current lease expires, ask the owner to put you on the lease. If he refuses, you may seek help from the Conciliation and Appeals Board. The issue is not simple, and the owner may bring an action in court against you, so you may need legal counsel.

title: AN OVERHAUL IS NEEDED IN FARM ECONOMICS
description: ON THE basis of the recent midterm election returns, one could safely say that Reaganomics is in need of a mid-course correction and that agronomics, although not an election issue, is also in need of adjustment.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BANGKOK
description: COLIN CAMPBELL is chief of The Times Bangkok bureau.

title: Getting a Bearing On Lehman Deal
description: New officials in Washington generally are advised to help keep the Administration clean by disposing properly of assets that might lead to conflicts of interest. Questions emerged last week whether Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. had done that.

title: REAGAN'S SEERS CUT ECONOMIC FORECAST
description: President Reagan's top economic advisors scaled back their forecast for growth in 1983 as they prepared the budget for the fiscal year 1984. The projected G.N.P. growth rate is expected to be less than 2 percent for the year instead of the 3.1 percent they had projected in September.

title: Boy Slain at L.I. Party; Police Accuse Girl, 14
description: A teen-age boy was stabbed to death at a New Year's Eve party here, and the Suffolk County police said today that a 14-year-old girl had been arrested and charged with murder.

title: The Rewards Of Marriage
description: Thanks for publishing ''Why Not Stay Married?'' (Opinion Page). In today's world, we do not have many opportunities to read such an article.

title:
STAMPS;
U.N. COMMEMORATIVES
description: The essential role that global telecommunications plays in maintaining peace and helping economic and social progress is the theme of the first commemorative issue of the United Nations, coming out Jan. 28.

title: BY MARGARET CROYDEN
description: MARGARET CROYDEN is a frequent contributor to the cultural pages of The Times.

title: SOME ALWAYS COMPLAIN
description: Team players may be divided into two types - the complainers and the winners. The typical complainer throws a fit if his captain puts him into the lineup two games in a row with Black.

title: Conductors and Living Composers
description: Donal Henahan's article about ''The Conductor as Endangered Species'' (Nov. 28) makes its points well. It is not the whole picture, however; the state of the crisis is partly defined by where one looks.

title: Giants Still Holding Slim Playoff Hope
description: Unless improbability and unlikelihood merge with surprise, the Giants will end their disappointing season Sunday. And with that will end Ray Perkins's four-year reign as the Giants' head coach.

title: Tylenol Extortion Charge
description: James W. Lewis has not been charged with planting the cyanide that killed seven people who took Tylenol in the Chicago area last fall, but he is accused of trying to make a bundle from their deaths. In a Federal court in Chicago last week, he pleaded not guilty to a charge that he tried to extort $1 million from the painkiller's manufacturer, Johnson & Johnson, with an offer to ''stop the killing'' in return for the cash.

title: Hilary H. Holmes, a Painter, to Marry Anita Heppenheimer, a Photographer
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Heppenheimer 3d of East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anita Ruxton Heppenheimer, to Hilary Halsted Holmes, son of Mrs. Hilary Holmes of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Dr. Holmes.

title: CHILE IMPROVES HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD BUT IS IT GOOD ENOUGH?
description: Recent crackdowns by the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, including the detention of some 200 protestors two weeks ago, have raised new questions about the Reagan Administration's desire to lift the United States embargo on arms to Chile.

title: SOME SMALL FRY SERVE LARGER PURPOSE
description: THOSE tiny fish that are making appearances in the market at this time of year are one of my favorite dishes when tossed in flour, deep-fried until golden and eaten with the fingers. This group includes whitebait - actually baby herrings or sprats - measuring about an inch and a half long and the larger smelts that measure about seven inches long. Also delicious cooked this way are fresh baby eels from Maine, about two inches long.
