They are as tiny as the ones in seaside restaurants in Morocco near Tangier, where they are served along with miniature octopus and whitebait, fried until crisp and served in sizzling heaps with lemon halves and bottles of cold rose wine.

title: A BLEAK REALITY TEMPERS CANADA'S UNION MILITANCY
description: During the Great Depression, Canada's army of unemployed roamed quixotically across this broad country in quest of work that did not exist. Finally, the federal Government herded them into work camps in British Columbia - where tens of thousands had ended up - and paid them the grand sum of $7.50 a month. Neither satisfied nor cowed, the angry men hopped freight trains to Vancouver to demonstrate for more money.

title: PHILHARMONIC: FIVE YOUNG PEOPLE DISPLAY THEIR TALENTS
description: It is the time of year for children to give, not just to receive, and Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta presented an enthusiastic audience with five generous young people. Three were violinists, one a pianist and the other played the French horn. Their ages ranged from 10 to 19, and all had performed previously at the Philharmonic's Young People's Concerts.

title: NEW VOTER DRIVE AIMS AT UNEMPLOYED AND WELFARE RECIPIENTS
description: Social workers and civil rights groups are organizing a nationwide voter registration drive designed to encourage greater political participation by the millions of people who are unemployed or who receive Government benefits such as food stamps and welfare.

title: BADEN CASE: GLIMPSE AT COUNTY WORKINGS
description: IN settling the controversy last week over Dr. Michael M. Baden and remarks on homicide attributed to him in a magazine article, the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, issued a statement praising Dr. Baden's ''professional capability'' and called off the county's efforts to have him dismissed as deputy chief medical examiner. Some observers interpreted Mr. Cohalan's sudden reversal as a white flag raised under pressure from Dr. Baden's lawyer, Robert Gottlieb.

title: O'ROURKE CHOOSES DELBELLO APPOINTEE TO BE HIS TOP AIDE
description: ANDREW P. O'ROURKE was taking a casual view last week of his swearing-in as County Executive. ''We're not overplaying the transition,'' he said of the ceremony, which is scheduled for tomorrow. ''It's a regular day. We'll adjourn at 11 o'clock for the event and then go back to work after lunch.''

title: A NEW WEALTH OF MATERIAL
description: Some see it as the rebirth of the belle epoque style; others detect links to 19th-century dandyism; still others regard it as divine decadence. Regardless, traditional decorating seems to be changing course, and nowhere is the shift more evident than in the fabrics that are currently turning decorators' heads.

title: Peking-Antigua Accord
description: China, which is trying to improve its ties with Latin America, established diplomatic relations today with the Caribbean island nation of Antigua and Barbuda, the official New China News Agency reported.

title:
CAMERA;
PLANNING IMPORTANT FOR HOME DARKROOM
AUDIO'S REVOLUTION CONTINUES
description: In an age more attuned to artifice than to nature, the terrestrial year with the quarter-time rhythm of its four seasons still beats the measure of our lives like a giant metronome. The year, after all, is not just a calendric convention; it is the way the sun spells our destiny. The matter lies altogether beyond our ken, and that's comforting in a way. With the new year, marked by the return of the sun to our part of the globe, we somehow feel protectively cradled within the clockwork of planetary motion, which after all is one of the few things one can count on.

title: Sports of the Times; A Century-Old Ringside Cry
description: THE first words of the year in this space are more than a century old. They were written by Jose Marti in 1882 after the bare-knuckle boxing match between John L. Sullivan and Paddy Ryan in Mississippi City, Miss.

title: THE 10 SUPER STOCKS OF 1982
description: WHO would have thought 12 months ago that Chrysler, the much m aligned auto maker, or Winnebago, the once hapless manufacturer of r ecreational vehicles, or Pulte Homes, a builder, would not only w eather one of the worst recessions ever but then soar past a stock m arket that was registering its biggest advance in history? Who couldh ave foreseen that Fay's Drug and Home Depot, chain store retailers p eddling rather mundane products, would capture Wall Street's fancy?

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
COMPUTERSPEAK RUSHES US TOWARD '1984'
description: IT seems as if we are about to fulfill one of George Orwell's prophesies a year early. In his book, ''1984,'' the author suggested that we would all be speaking a different language by now - Newspeak. He blamed the change on a manipulative government. If only he had fed his intuitions into an Apple or an IBM, he might have pointed to a different source - the home computer.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Westchester Weekly, the names of Ogden R. Reid and Anthony Veteran were reversed under their photographs in an article about Democrats interested in the position of County Executive.

title: Katherine Anne Porter
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER WINNING THE PRIZE IS WHEN TROUBLE REALLY STARTS
description: WHEN the latest group of Nobel Prize winners arrived in Stockholm last month to receive their medals, attention focused not only on the substance of their achievements but on the process of their selection. Dr.Kenneth G. Wilson, the laureate in physics, had said that he was especially surprised because he expected to share the Prize with two colleagues. And Dr. Sune K. Bergstroem, a Swede who shared the award for medicine, was chairman of the Nobel Foundation's board of directors. Though there was no question about the merit of their work, debate about the Prize's social patina came to the surface once again.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
FILL-IN-THE-BLANK WISHES TO MEET FILL-IN-THE-BLANK
description: ''W.W.F. wishes to meet man with sense of humor, kind, likes dancing, driving. Am looking for long-term relationship.'' ''European-born male, broadcast journalist, Ph.D., 43, 5-foot-11-inches, slim, not bed-looking, humorous, imaginative, quiet, home type, relaxed, likes nature, long walks, conversation, movies, TV, driving, caring, sharing, romance. Seeks sensitive, intelligent, whole-figured woman.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: RAPUNZEL Retold and illustrated by Jutta Ash. Unpaged. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95. RAPUNZEL Retold by Barbara Rogasky. Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. New York: Holiday House. $12.95.

title: Historic House Destroyed
description: An unoccupied 17th century farmhouse in this Cape Cod community has been destroyed by fire, the police say. The house was one of three buildings on a historic piece of property known as the Freeman Farm. The other two, a utility shed and a large barn, were not damaged in the fire that started about 5:30 A.M. Wednesday.

title: Miss Sproul, Banker, Wed
description: Margaret Pratt Sproul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Alexander Sproul of Staunton, Va., was married there yesterday to Henry Jackson Sargent Cheever, son of Dr. and Mrs. F.Sargent Cheever of Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. E.Guthrie Brown performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: BEATING THE ODDS TO BECOME A STAGE STAR
description: LONNY PRICE has learned that having a dream come true doesn't matter as much as having a dream. It appears that the 23-year-old actor keeps getting what he wants, but there's always a catch.

title: A FLOWER GARDEN FOR ALL OF $16.30
description: It's amazing what $16.30 will buy. It paid for all the seed packets needed to plant the 60x90-foot flower garden which bloomed last summer at Wave Hill, an environmental study center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The 28-acre property overlooks a high bluff on the Hudson River. It was the former Perkins-Freeman estate and was deeded to the City of New York in 1960 as a public garden and horticultural center.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CLUB CONCENTRATES ON BIBLICAL COINS
description: The Bible isn't usually thought of as a numismatic reference book, but for members of at least one coin club it's required reading. The club is the Biblical Numismatic Society, whose 500 members derive satisfaction - and inspiration - from studying and collecting the many coins with Biblical connections.

title: ROAD FUNDS FOR STATES INCREASING TO $11 BILLION WITH GAS TAX RISE
description: The states will receive an average 43 percent increase in highway construction money from the Government because of the 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax, with some states faring much better than others, according to estimates of the Transportation Department.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Huntington $185,000 *2*5 Harmony Road 5-bedroom, full-bath, 26-year-old *2*split level; central air-conditioning, formal *2*dining room; taxes $3,000. Northport $102,000 *2*36 Laurel Street 4-bedroom, 1.5-bath, 9-year-old *2*colonial; full basement, family room *2*with fireplace; taxes $2,800. Middle Island $59,900 *2*788 East Bartlett Avenue 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, *2*8-year-old colonial; formal dining room, *2*finished basement, den, one-acre lot; taxes $2,076. OTHER AREAS Dumont, N.J. $79,000 *2*16 Hillside Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year old *2*Cape Cod; new family room, detached 2-car *2*garage, 1 acre; taxes $2,518. Wilton, Conn. $237,600 *2*47 Mollbrook Drive 4-bedroom, 2.5 bath, *2*6-year-old colonial; wooded lot, 2.3 acres; *2*taxes $3,613. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $94,000 *2*41 Morningside Drive, 3-bedroom,2.5 bath, *2*10-year-old frame raised ranch; family *2*room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; *2*taxes $3,740 White Plains, N.Y. $94,000 *2*14 SurreyWay 3-bedroom, 1.5 bath, 46-year-old *2*frame colonial; sun room, formal dining *2*room, new roof; taxes $2,850.

title: Oostershuis Captures Coast Event by a Shot
description: Peter Oosterhuis shot a fourunder-par 68 in a round featuring six birdies to win the $150,000 Spalding Invitational golf tournament today.

title: FILM
description: A GREAT FRENCH ACTRESS SEIZES THE LIMELIGHT AT A MAJOR RETROSPECTIVE BY BERNARD DREW --------------------------------------------------------------------- Bernard Drew is an author and critic who writes regularly about film. PARIS ''Looking back over 50 years of making films, I don't think I can remember more than 10 of them,'' Edwige Feuillere sighs. ''I do recall that in the 1930's, when I was very busy making movies, French actresses were only permitted to play prostitutes, courtesans and striptease artists. I had to wait for the end of the war to become aristocratic and noble.

title: EFFECT OF PAY PACTS ON VOTE WEIGHED
description: ON the eve of this, his re-election campaign year, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan laid the groundwork for a possible endorsement by the politically active Civil Service Employees' Association with what a union official called an ''amazing'' contract settlement with the union.

title: THE SHULTZ METHOD
description: What is most striking about George P. Shultz is that he is so unhurried. Returning from the White House, he had hung up his pinstripe jacket and had put on a bright blue cardigan to receive this reporter in his cozy hide-away on the seventh floor of the State Department. He talked easily, taking time for an occasional anecdote. His large frame seemed confined as he leaned forward in his straightbacked chair in the room he uses for thinking and chatting, free for an hour or two a day from the pressures that bear down unceasingly on him as Secretary of State.

title: Rena A. Holt Plans to Wed Alan M. Franklin in April
description: Anne Holt of Riverdale, the Bronx, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Rena Alison Holt, to Alan M. Franklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Franklin of New York.

title: CENTER EXPLORES ETHICS OF ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: HASTINGS AS physicians at the University of Utah Medical Center closely watched the progress of Dr. Barney B. Clark, the first human to receive a mechanical heart, the philosophers and social scientists at the Hastings Center here have been studying the ethical and social problems that could be created by this new development.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SEA CLIFF
description: IN the weeks before Christmas, artists and craftsmen in the Long I sland village of Sea Cliff again opened their studios and workshops t o visitors and shoppers.

title: Inflation's Slowing
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Moderation of Inflation'' (Dec.5), Jonathan Fuerbringer characterizes ''the dramatic slowing of inflation'' as ''the outstanding achievement of President Reagan's economic policy.'' The fact is that the President's policies have virtually nothing to do with the current moderation of inflation. Disinflation is characteristic of depression regardless of the party in power.

title: CRIME
description: The skillful Ted Allbeury, who specializes in espionage novels, has written still another good one, SHADOW OF SHADOWS (Scribner's, $12.95). It is somewhat along the line of his own "The Other Side of Silence," published last year, and also has points in common with Richard Hoyt's recent--and admirable--"Trotsky's Run." In those two books the British spy Kim Philby makes an appearance. In "Shadow of Shadows" it is not Philby's career but rather that of a Philby-like double agent that is examined.

title: NEW OPERA MAY HAVE A FUTURE AFTER ALL
description: Where is opera going? Is it really a musty old museum, as some critics seem to believe and some opera companies seem intent on proving? Is privately supported opera, the kind that prevails on this continent, doomed to a cynical conservatism based on box-office receipts? Or are there signs that American opera companies actually do worry about the future of their art, after all?

title: First Steps Falter As Lebanon and Israel Open Talks
description: Lebanese and Israeli negotiators last week opened formal talks by exchanging conflicting visions of peaceful coexistence. Middle-level officials met with Morris Draper, the American envoy, in a rundown beach hotel at Khalde, Lebanon, under guard by Israeli tanks.

title: APEX Fares Go to Sea As APEC
description: Clearly inspired by the airline industry's APEX fares, the cruise ship industry -Home Lines Cruises, to be specific - has now come up with an APEC fare. APEC stands for Advanced Purchase Cruise, and like APEX, it constitutes a mechanism for stimulating early bookings in response to an offer of lower fares.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CURBS ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: President Reagan began 1983 with a plea that the nation get its drunken drivers ''off our roads and get them off now.''

title: The Mean Streak In Solar Power
description: Windmills may look benign next to fossil-fuel or nuclear power plants, but even Don Quixote knew that they are not free of risk. In a report issued last week by the National Audubon Society, the possible side effects of renewable energy sources were outlined so that ''bad choices can be avoided and decisions can be made early in the development of an energy technology to lessen the environmental harm.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Grandmaster Flash is a virtuoso disc jockey, who mixes music from multiple turntables into a danceable sonic collage; his ''Grandmaster Flash on the Wheels of Steel'' was one of 1981's most avant-garde hits. The Furious Five are rappers, who make staccato patterned speech serve as melody and percussion while Flash provides a beat.

title: HOW IMPORTANT IS THE MUSIC DEBUT?
description: For nearly a century, performing musicians have made their way to New York, intent on making an impression on the most demanding musical city in the world. Here, amid nearly two hundred concerts a week at the peak of season, featuring the most renowned artists schooled by the most prestigious conservatories, presented in nearly a dozen major halls and a score of minor ones and attended by highly sophisticated audiences - in this musical arena, performers arrive to make a ''New York debut.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ECONOMICS;
PEDDLING AN INCOMES POLICY, AGAIN
description: Just a few years ago, inflation was widely regarded as the public enemy No.1. But although inflation has been sliced in half, it remains a concern for many economists. And at the meetings last week, some kind of incomes policy - which would limit wage rises - surfaced several times as a possible solution.

title: ADDING INSULT TO ECONOMIC INJURY
description: THE jobless rate in New Jersey climbed to 9.9 percent in November, the highest in the state since 1977. This means that 365,000 people were out of work that month, people who will have to cope not only with searching for a job, but also with hostile unemployment officials.

title: HOT TIPS
description: Here's some more bad news for the members of the international oil cartel: A how-to-save-energy guidebook for owners of older homes - whose publication had been canceled by Federal budget cuts - is in print after all. Jeffrey Seisler, who headed the team that wrote the guide for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, decided not long ago that - Government financing or not - his product should be available.

title: F.A.L.N. PUERTO RICAN TERRORISTS SUSPECTED IN NEW YEAR BOMBINGS
description: Federal and city investigators said yesterday that a Puerto Rican terrorist group was apparently responsible for a series of bombings on New Year's Eve that rocked four government buildings in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn and seriously injured three police officers.

title: JERSEY PANEL ASKS CHANGES IN JURIES
description: A State Supreme Court panel has recommended wide changes in New Jersey's jury system, including the elimination of all exemptions from jury duty and the requirement that jurors be able to write in English.

title: FASHION
description: RETURNING TO THE BARE ESSENTIALS Designers may suggest, but women actually make fashion happen. After casting an eye over some of the gala parties that took place in New York recently, it is obvious that women have decided to show a bit of skin once again.

title: ARCHITECT'S FURNITURE AT THE WHITNEY
description: STAMFORD FOR the crowds thronging the Stamford Shopping Mall at Christmas there was clearly no time for a detour to the Whitney Museum, located in the Champion Building nearby (corner of Tresser Boulevard and Atlantic Street). And it's a pity, since the current show, ''Shape and Environment: Furniture by American Architects,'' would have addressed, if not soothed, tired sensibilities as well as aching feet. This is to assume, of course, that the reviewer is not alone in finding malls a mixed blessing - handy for having so much under one roof, but intimidating in their size and manipulative implications. Giving new meaning to the term, ''It's all done with mirrors,'' the Stamford specimen may be a midget by Californian standards but is still an illustration of the awesome power wielded by institutional architects.

title: DANCE AND TELL
description: FAR FROM DENMARK, By Peter Martins with Robert Cornfield.Illustrated. 242 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $24.95. LEAP YEAR A Year in the Life of a Dancer. By Christopher d'Amboise. Foreword by Lincoln Kirstein. Illustrated. 211 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: The Unconquerable Welsh
description: The remarkable achievement of the Welsh in Great Britain is that they have managed to maintain their separate identity (''The Unconquerable Welsh,'' by Jan Morris, Dec. 5). While they are less than three million strong in Wales, the Welsh heritage and spirit is alive and well in the Hughes, Thomas, Jenkins, Davis, Williams and Jones surnames in this country.
ON several occasions, I have been asked by American business people a bout Japan. They appear to be concerned about whether they will be a ble to understand the Japanese way of thinking.

title: DEMOCRATS EXPLOIT HELMS'S FILIBUSTER TACTICS
description: North Carolina Democrats have sought to capitalize on the furor over the filibuster in the special session of Congress last month by the state's two Republican Senators against legislation to raise the Federal gasoline tax. The Democrats here are quoting the Senators' colleagues, who indicated that the tactics of the filibusters threatened positive action on tobacco and peanut programs and issues involving small farms.

title: PANEL SUPPORTS CAREY VETOES OF CUSTODY BILLS
description: A state panel looking into the way courts award custody of children to divorcing parents in New York says Gov. Hugh L. Carey acted properly in vetoing joint-custody bills in 1981 and 1982.

title: MILLIONAIRE LOTTERY WINNERS TAKE THEIR GOOD FORTUNE IN STRIDE
description: PIERRETTE REYNOLDS, her husband Francis and their four children were living in public housing in Waterbury. They had just been told that their son Patrick, a handsome 10-year-old boy with cerebral palsy, was grinding his teeth so badly during his seizures that he needed $675 worth of dental work.

title: QUEEN OF ALL INSTRUMENTS
description: William F. Buckley Jr. is editor of National Review and author of the current best-seller "Atlantic High."At National Review, we give (of course) a Christmas party. For 10 years or so, up until a year ago, the guest performer was Fernando Valenti, once designated (in Time magazine) as ''the most exciting'' recitalist alive, performing on the harpsichord. Then the cancer hit (from which, happily, he is in remission) and, of course, he was making no commitments for the indefinite future. I thought of asking Judith Norell, not only a brilliant musician, but also a courageous one, as witness that for a couple of years she consented to be my teacher. But I thought that to present another harpsichordist would skirt insouciance - too much like the King is dead, long live the King. Better something completely different. Michael Sweeley, the president of the Caramoor music center near Katonah, N.Y., suggested Richard Vogt, Caramoor's choral director: who arrived, on a snowy Friday in December, at our place in Manhattan with an incredible 13 performers - singers, a cellist, a harpsichord accompanist and a clarinetist.

title: IN THE HEART OF NORWAY'S SKI COUNTRY
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: Luis Marin
description: Guilty, said the jury after six days of deliberations. Not guilty, said the judge four days later, reversing the verdict against Luis Marin in the fatal Stouffer's Inn fire. Mr. Marin, who had been a coffee waiter at the hotel, was accused of arson and murder in the Dec. 4, 1980, blaze in Harrison, N.Y., in which 26 business executives died.

title: Herpes Vaccine Ready for Tests
description: Herpes is forever, according to any number of current bad jokes, and it's true there is no hope of a cure at the moment. But two vaccines designed to provide immunity from the sexually transmitted disease are about to be tested on human subjects.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: HAITI BOMB BLAST KILLS 10 IN CAPITAL
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 1 (UPI) - A bomb exploded today in a car parked across the street from the presidential palace, killing at least 10 people and injuring dozens more, the police said. President Jean-Claude Duvalier was not in the capital at the time of blast. No group immediately claimed responsibility.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Basketball Houston Rockets vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee. (Television - ESPN Cable, 8 P.M.). Detroit Pistons vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif.

title: ACTRESS CREATES ROLE TO PRESERVE JEWISH LORE
description: SOPHIE shuffles in from the back of the auditorium, hunched over and telling people as she passes, ''Sorry I'm late. Happy Hanukkah. Sorry I'm late.'' The bus dropped her off 10 blocks too soon. And Sophie's legs can't walk 10 blocks as easily as they once did.

title: HERITAGE OF A TAX FORM
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: PRACTICES by medical examiners in Morris and Passaic Counties are being reviewed by Dr. Robert Goode, the State Medical Examiner, who has been pressing the respective Boards of Freeholders to correct lingering ''deficiencies.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: G.M.'s Clout in Steel Talks

title: Miami Police Dismantle Riot Area Encampment
description: The encampment of police officers around Miami's Overtown riot area was dismantled today. Local officials set out to salvage the city's reputation as a winter tourist site.

title: SAYS STATE IS IN 'DEPRESSION'
description: James J. Blanchard became Michigan's 45th Governor today, taking over the reins of a state slumped deep in recession and a government that is nearly insolvent.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: A New Crop of Golden Oldies

title: Watt Blazes More Trails to The Wilderness
description: While most Congressmen were in their home woods last week, the Department of Interior moved to cut millions of acres of real wilderness from Government holdings. Though the action did not automatically open the areas to ''multiple use'' - such as mining and lumbering - it removed special protections that prohibit such development.

title: ABSOLUTELY THE MOST
description: MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, By Judith Krantz. 531 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title: For Milliseconds, Fusion Reactor In Flashy Debut
description: Given the technical and economic uncertainty of continuing to produce electricity by splitting atoms, nuclear power advocates look toward a future when commercial energy will be generated by fusing them together. The allure is strong: Fusion theoretically releases more energy than is required to initiate it, radioactive waste disposal problems are of a lower magnitude, and utility companies could maintain centralized control over the source (which might not be the case if renewable sources of power such as wind or solar are widely adopted).

title: 2 British Airmen Facing Trial In the Shooting Down of a Jet
description: A Royal Air Force F-4 Phantom pilot and his navigator face court-martial this month after shooting down another R.A.F. jet during a training exercise, the British Broadcasting Corporation said today.

title: EVEN NOW, FRESH INSIGHTS INTO MATISSE
description: ZURICH One of the delusions of our day is that we know all about Matisse. This began in 1951, when Matisse was still alive and Alfred H. Barr Jr. published his not yet excelled book on the subject. It was enhanced in the late 1960's, when Frederick S. Wight organized the big retrospective for the University of California in Los Angeles that moved subsequently to Chicago and Boston. It reached its peak at the time of the Matisse centenary exhibition in Paris in 1970, which the critic Thomas B. Hess headlined without hyperbole as ''the most beautiful exhibition in the world.'' It was backed up by a museum show of Matisse's late works in paper (St. Louis and Detroit, 1977), by publications relating to the Matisse holdings in the Soviet Union, and by an exhibition called ''Matisse in the Museum of Modern Art'' in 1978.

title: JOSEPH M. O'FARRELL
description: -Joseph M. O'Farrell, who pioneered the breeding of Florida race horses at his Ocala Stud ranch, died of a heart attack Friday.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Anti-Klan Group Begins A Drive Against Racism
description: The National Anti-Klan Network has announced plans for a nationwide petition campaign aimed at pressuring the Federal Government to take a more active role in prosecuting people involved in racist and anti-Semitic acts.

title: Prelate Says Salvador's War Could Spread Across Region
description: El Salvador's Acting Archbishop said today that the nation's civil war could suffer a ''Vietnamization'' and spread across Central America and the Caribbean.

title: CAREY PANEL URGES INCREASES IN FEES
description: An advisory group formed last June by Gov. Hugh L. Carey has recommended higher marriage license fees, automobile registration charges and similar levies instead of increased taxes to help close any state budget deficit.

title: Union and Missouri Appoint Chairman
description: John C. Kenefick, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of both the Union Pacific and the Missouri Pacific in the first organizational steps to implement the recently approved merger of the Union Pacific, the Missouri Pacific and the Western Pacific.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Le Anne Schreiber LIFE AND DEATH ON THE CORPO- RATE BATTLEFIELD. How Compa- nies Win, Lose, Survive. By Paul Sol- man and Thomas Friedman. Simon & Schuster. 248 pages. $13.95.

title: ...AS PREDECESSOR RECALLS FRUSTRATION
description: Karen N. Gerard has left City Hall after nearly two years as a Deputy Mayor, professing delight that she took the job but confessing frustration that economic development - her responsibility - had in many ways been out of her control.

title: Zia Calls U.S. Tour Beneficial
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said today that he achieved more than expected during his recent visit to Washington, including a United States commitment to continue military and economic aid. Speaking on national television and radio, General Zia said that he was warmly received and that his trip had improved understanding of Pakistan's problems.

title: Deadly Miasma Over Missouri
description: In Fenton, Missouri, children play in contaminated areas where technicians wear respirators and protective clothing. In flood-struck Times Beach, the Red Cross has ordered its volunteers out of the danger zone while residents return unprotected to salvage their belongings. There's a painful gulf in Missouri between governors and governed, caused by the mystifyingly potent reach of a poison called dioxin.

title: ARCHITECTURAL SHAPES OF COATS
description: So far, the 1980's are shaping up as a decade of structured clothing, unlike the free-and-easy 60's and 70's. Shoulders are squared, lines are straight - what some are calling architectural.

title: Testimony Phase Over, Massacre Inquiry Says
description: The Israeli state commission investigating the Beirut massacre announced today that it had completed hearing testimony from witnesses. It set Jan. 16 as the date for the submission of written summations of testimony from the nine officials warned that they could be harmed by its findings, before drawing up its final conclusions.

title: A REQUEST FOR U.S. FUNDS TO CLEAN HUDSON DENIED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has rejected New York State's request for $20 million in Federal funds to help clean the Hudson River by dredging chemically contaminated sediment from the river bottom and burying it.

title: LEBANESE MOSLEMS ARE LEERY OF PEACE TALKS AND THE FUTURE
description: With the Christian-dominated Lebanese Government scheduled to resume negotiations with Israel on Monday, many Moslems here are worried about what will happen if an agreement is reached to withdraw Israeli and other foreign troops from the country.

title: ECONOMY TOP ISSUE FOR 98TH CONGRESS AS IT OPENS TODAY
description: The 98th Congress convenes here Monday for a session that leaders expect to be dominated by economic questions and to be shaped by a changing relationship between Capitol Hill and the White House.

title: Death Penalty Law Upheld
description: Pennsylvania's four-year-old death penalty was upheld Friday by the State Supreme Court in the statute's first judicial review. In a 4-to-3 decision, the court upheld the 1981 conviction and sentencing of Keith Zettlemoyer in the killing of a man who was to have been a witness against him in a robbery and kidnapping trial.

title: REAGAN'S FAITHFUL ALLIES
description: In this city, which makes history but prefers headlines, today's hottest story is President Reagan's problem with his allies on Capitol Hill. But those who believe that they see a divisive split between the President and Congressional Republicans ignore Ronald Reagan's many achievements, misunderstand the role of Congress, and exaggerate the tension between the Presidency and Congress that has naturally existed since the Founding Fathers found room for both in the Constitution.

title: Hearing on Prison Status Opens Today in Alabama
description: A Federal judge begins a weeklong hearing Monday to determine how much progress the state has made in improving conditions at its prisons in a decade of Federal court supervision.

title: 'MORE THAN JUST A PART OF ISRAEL'
description: Much has been written recently of the relation o f American Jews to Israel and of the character of the American J ewish community. I believe our community's self-image requires us tor ecognize that we are more than just a part of Israel. We must also a ffirm our own identity and integrity, even as we deepen our s olidarity with Israel.

title: No Headline
description: Lakers Triumph

title: BURGER DECLARES CONGRESS IGNORES BURDEN OF COURTS
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger criticized Congress today for what he said was its failure to ease the workload of the Federal courts. He also cautioned Congress against giving life tenure to Federal bankruptcy judges.

title: LEGISLATIVE SESSION EXPECTED TO FOCUS ON BUDGET DEFICIT
description: The New York State Legislature returns to Albany this week to confront a faltering state economy and a potential budget deficit of more than $1 billion that will largely shape - and limit - its actions in many areas.

title: INSIDE ANDROPOV'S MIND (3)
description: Only six weeks since I become General Secretary, a nd so much has happened.

title: TOP BONN SOCIALIST WILL MEET REAGAN
description: Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democratic Party's candidate for Chancellor in elections promised for March 6, will begin a three-day visit to Washington on Wednesday that will include talks on disarmament with President Reagan, a spokesman for Mr. Vogel's party said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will not wait for the President.'' - Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, the House majority leader. (A1:6.)

title: PENN STATE CHOSEN TOP 1982 TEAM IN NATION
description: Penn State was recognized unanimously today as the top college football team of 1982, the first time the Nittany Lions have been No.1 at the end of a season since they began playing intercollegiate football in 1887.

title: Ruby Kestenbaum Married
description: Ruby Hedy Kestenbaum, vice president and media director for Epstein, Raboy Advertising Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Joseph Gottlieb, director of convention services at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. Rabbis Leo Jung and Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kestenbaum of Forest Hills, Queens. Mr. Gottlieb is a son of Arthur Gottlieb of New York and the late Florence Gottlieb.

title: SALVADOR'S UNRECORDED TOLL: GRAVELY HURT SCHOOLS
description: Beyond the soldiers guarding the campus entrances, the abandoned buildings of the University of El Salvador are now barely visible. The weeds have grown tall since troops stormed and closed the institution more than two years ago.

title: OPEC IS ALIVE, IF NOT AS WELL AS IN 1980
description: To the Editor:

title: Mildred Dilling, 88, a Harpist, Performed for 5 Presidents
description: Mildred Dilling, a concert harpist who performed for five Presidents, taught Harpo Marx and owned the world's largest private collection of harps, died in her Manhattan home last Thursday. She was 88 years old.

title: Washington Watch; The Economy In a New Light
description: WASHINGTON JANUARY is economic numbers month here in the capital, with the White House set to produce the State of the Union address, the budget and the Economic Message.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Fare Surprise AWest Village resident visiting Princeton, N.J., this weekend was confounded by prices on the NJ T ransit train leaving Penn Station. Fishing for the usual $7.50 fare,s he was presented with a movie theater-type stub and charged $1.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KIPLING ADVENTURE

title: Indian Point 2 Back in Service
description: Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, in Westchester County, returned to operation at partial capacity yesterday after a three-month shutdown, officials of the utility announced.

title: U.S. TERMS MOSCOW'S CRITICISM A PLOY
description: The Reagan Administration today described a long Soviet criticism of the American position in the strategic arms talks as ''a negotiating ploy'' and repeated its optimism that an accord could be achieved.

title: A MAGNETIZED POSTAGE STAMP HOLDER
description: It's just the sort of product that might go unnoticed and unheralded, a neat, thin and altogether understated little item. One might even be puzzled by its function were it not for the neat white letters on one side that spell out ''STAMPS.''

title: Blair Ends a Service To Deliver Commercials
description: Blairsat, John Blair & Company's space-age delivery system for TV commercials scheduled for local use, transmitted its last spot Wednesday.

title: What Rights Do Grandparents Have?
description: Parents are encouraged to be serious: often they keep big albums in which they inscribe birth weights, tooth counts and immunization records. Grandparents are allowed to be giddy: often they carry little albums stamped with acronyms like S.O.G.W.P.I.P - Silly Old Grandmother With Pictures in Purse.

title: 4 French Silent Films Opening Museum Series
description: Screenings of four French silent films will open Part II of a ''Rediscovering French Film Retrospective'' next Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Anthony M. Livoti, 81; Ex-State Court Justice
description: Anthony M. Livoti, a retired State Supreme Court justice in Queens, died Saturday of a heart attack at North Ridge Hospital in Pompano Beach, Fla. Mr. Livoti, who had been living in Pompano Beach for several years, was 81 years old.

title: AUSTRALIAN MINING COMPANY REGROUPS
description: A year ago, Arvi H. Parbo, chairman of Western Mining Corporation Holdings, was reveling in Australia's resources boom. Earnings had hit a record $58 million (Australian) on revenues of $303.6 million for the year ended June 30, 1981.

title: ORANGE BOWL HAPPIER FOR GILL
description: To understand Turner Gill's joy in victory in the 1983 Orange Bowl early this morning is to understand his anguish in defeat after the 1982 game.

title: BEN H. HAZEN
description: Ben H. Hazen, the principal founder and former chairman of the board of the Benjamin Franklin Federal Savings & Loan Association, was found dead in his apartment here on Saturday.

title: City Police Officer Shoots L.I. Man
description: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and critically wounded a man who allegedly tried to rob him early today outside a tourism information office on the Southern State Parkway, the state police said.

title: FOR 'ANNIE' ON BROADWAY, NO MORE TOMORROWS
description: Leapin' Lizards! Not just one Annie but half a dozen or more on the stage of the Uris Theater. Also three or four Daddy Warbuckses and as many mean Miss Hannigans. All had performed, on Broadway or on tour, in a show that became an institution - the musical ''Annie.'' And they all took curtain calls after yesterday's matinee, which was the 2,377th and final performance of the production on Broadway.

title: THE LONG JOURNEY OF CALVIN PEETE
description: Not even the ugly duckling, it was suggested to Calvin Peete, started from as far back as he had. "But if my recollection is correct," said Calvin Peete, "didn't the ugly duckling grow into a beautiful swan?"

title: Pentagon Spent $2 Million Shuttling Congressmen in '82
description: The Pentagon provided more than $2 million in ''V.I.P.'' domestic travel service and related entertainment for members of Congress in 1982, it was reported today.

title: Teachers' Strike Entering 63d Day in Pennsylvania
description: The longest school strike in the history of Pennsylvania enters its 63d working day Monday with no negotiations scheduled.

title: CALIFORNIA PANEL SEES RISE IN RACIAL VIOLENCE
description: Racial, ethnic and religious violence in California is ''deeply rooted'' and getting worse, with a surge of anti-Semitism in the Los Angeles area, a state committee has found.

title: NEW YORK NEEDS AN ALL-STATE TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A QUICK PEEK AT G.N.P. OFTEN CLOSELY WATCHED
description: Four times a year, in the last month of every quarter, there appears a report on the health of the economy that has been dubbed ''the flash.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Dallas Cowboys vs. Vikings, at Minneapolis.(Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 9 P.M.). The roof on the Metrodome has been repaired in time for this final regular-season game.

title: STATE AGENCIES TAKE COMMAND OF CONRAIL LINES
description: Conrail's commuter rail lines in the New York region were taken over by state agencies this weekend. But, except for some new patches on conductors' uniforms, commuters will notice little difference in service.

title: Metrodome Roof Repaired for Game
description: The roof of the Metrodome, which deflated early Thursday when a snow-removal crane ripped a hole in its fabric cover, was reinflated today, clearing the way for the Vikings and the Dallas Cowboys to play the final regular-season game here Monday night.

title: Create Demand, Not Jobs
description: Like laborers paid at piecework rates, members of the 98th Congress convening at noon today will work overtime proposing new programs to create more jobs. With 12 million persons officially unemployed and more layoffs in prospect, the country certainly needs more jobs. But it does not follow that ''jobs programs'' are the answer.

title: MITTERRAND WON'T 'DREAM' OF CUTTING NUCLEAR FORCES
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that regardless of the outcome of United States-Soviet arms reduction talks under way in Geneva France would refuse to limit its nuclear forces.

title: Honors from the Queen
description: British business executives knighted by Queen Elizabeth II on her New Year's Honors List seemed to have made a joint resolution for 1983: Modesty.

title: POP MUSIC: BILLY JOEL IN A RESTRAINED MOOD
description: UNTIL the release of his newest album, ''The Nylon Curtain,'' Billy Joel seemed happy to be rock music's most versatile piano entertainer and the class cutup of his generation. But Mr. Joel is now 33 years old and no longer the precocious boy next door. For a decade, the multitalented singer, songwriter and pianist from Hicksville, L.I., has juggled the roles of frisky pop entertainer and acerbic suburban observer as easily as he has tried on different musical styles and mimicked other performers. It was clearly time for a change.

title: Sherill's Philosophy
description: For Jackie Sherrill, the differences between Pittsburgh and College Station, Tex., are much greater than time or distance. At the University of Pittsburgh he arrived as a relative unknown who assumed national prominence with the teams he built from 1977 to 1981. At Texas A&M he is, by his own admission, ''more of household word'' - the $287,000-a-year head football coach-athletic director who finshed with a disappointing 5-6 record his first year. During the Cotton Bowl game, Sherrill reflected on first year ups-and-downs at Texas A&M . ''There's a difference between building a program and a winning season - I could have got some junior college players and done that,'' he said. ''Building a solid foundation means discipline, education and great character. I know what it takes to build a program, I built one at Pittsburgh and I have the energy to build one more.''

title: TURKS REOPEN CASE WITH LINK TO POPE
description: The Turkish judicial authorities have begun new investigations into the 1979 slaying of a prominent Istanbul journalist that they think could throw light on the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II in May 1981.

title: FULL HOUSE AS CUOMOS TURN HOSTS
description: Thousands of New Yorkers lined up outside the Governor's mansion on Eagle Street today to meet their new first family.

title: Two Tied for Lead In Speed Skating
description: Leonard Nitz of Queens and Gerry Cassan of Ottawa tied for top honors in the senior men's event in the Dorp Travel speed-skating meet today.

title: Brooklyn Woman Is Strangled
description: An 84-year-old woman was found strangled in her ransacked Brooklyn apartment last night, the police said. The victim was identified as Gussie Cohen of 2106 Regent Place, in the Flatbush section.

title: UNDER A NEW FORMAT, SCRAMBLE RESUMES FOR MONEY
description: THE ''rabbit'' of professional golf is no more, gone into extinction with the mashie-niblick. The 1983 season of the PGA Tour will begin Thursday with a new concept of eligibility known as the All Exempt Tour, a landmark departure from long established policy. The All Exempt Tour is the centerpiece of a 1983 program that will offer nearly $22 million in purses, introduce a new series of events at a level slightly below the primary tour and expand an ambitious schedule of senior competition for stars whose names are still fondly remembered.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ATOM ACCIDENT RELIVED AT TRIAL
description: There are times when the courtroom for the Three Mile Island trial, which is trying to fix the blame for commercial nuclear energy's worst accident, seems more like an engineering laboratory.

title: PLIGHT OF POOR INSPIRES VERSE OF NEEDIEST CASES CONTRIBUTOR
description: New York residents feel a special responsibility and compassion for their impoverished, homeless neighbors. With gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, they try to ease the distress they see around them, especially during the year-end holiday season.

title: ORTHODOX JUDAISM'S VIEWS ON PROLONGING LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: S.M.U. CASTS DISSENTING VOTE
description: Southern Methodist University did not have to rely on its Pony Express backfield to carry this message to those who voted in the college football wire-service polls. Bobby Collins, the first-year coach who inherited a conference champion, made it clear that as the only unbeaten major-college team in the country, S.M.U.deserved to be ranked No.1.

title: SWISS BANKS INAUGURATE INSIDER-TRADING RULES
description: Swiss banks, under pressure from the United States, are warning their clients that if they want to buy or sell American stocks, they must accept the risk of having the Security and Exchange Commission told all about it.

title: Edward J. Donovan, 85, Dies; Ex-New York Correction Chief
description: Edward J. Donovan, former New York State Commissioner of Correction and the first Director of Personnel in Westchester County, died Saturday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: When Rivals First Met
description: When the football teams from Penn State and Georgia met in the Sugar Bowl Saturday night, it was not the first time that Herschel Walker of the Bulldogs and Curt Warner of the Nittany Lions met. When they both attended a dinner last February in New Haven to honor the Walter Camp All-America Team, there was a surprise.

title: Commodities; Precious Metal Forecasts
description: minded types, and from occasional hoarders to fast-moving speculators.

title: DEVILS DEFEAT CANUCKS BY 3-1
description: The Devils ended a three-game losing streak tonight by winning a game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the first time in a month with a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Learning From a Child

title: The Giftie Gie Us
description: Every once in a while Americans are lucky enough to have a social commentator with the gift Robert Burns wished for: the ability to make us see ourselves as others see us. Humor is what breaks down our resistance. Will Rogers mixed critical barbs at the inanities of the 1920's and 1930's with his cowboy jokes. We have ''Doonesbury.''

title: Long-Term Rates
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.56 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: THEATER: 'SKIRMISHES,' ENGLISH FAMILY DRAMA
description: CATHERINE HAYES, the author of a new play called ''Skirmishes'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, is the third female English playwright to receive a major New York production in the last month. Miss Hayes is not so boisterous as the Nell Dunn of ''Steaming,'' and she is not a daring theatrical iconoclast like the Caryl Churchill of ''Top Girls.'' But there's little question that Miss Hayes has written the most perfectly realized play of the group. ''Skirmishes'' is a small, quiet work that does everything it wants to do with precision and grace.

title: GRAND DEBUT OF AMERICAN BELL
description: High-technology companies often start with a few people working in a garage. American Bell Inc. will open for business today with 28,000 employees working in 700 buildings.

title: BALLET: A STYLISH JOFFREY 'PATINEURS'
description: A MUST in everybody's balletgoing should be Sir Frederick Ashton's 1937 charmer, ''Les Patineurs.'' Since the Joffrey Ballet revived it in 1977, the great English choreographer's ballet has been seen in the only American production that strives to reproduce the scenic and choreographic details of the original.

title: CITY SEEKS TO CUT TREATMENT LEVELS AT 6 SEWAGE SITES
description: New York City has applied to the Federal Government for permission to lower the required levels of sewage treatment at six city plants, two of them still under construction. The move is intended to save more than $550 million in building costs and more than $2 million a year in operating costs, city officials said yesterday.

title: Rams Eliminate 49ers, 21-20
description: The San Francisco 49ers, driving toward the same end zone where they earned a Super Bowl berth one year ago, came up losers today, 21-20, and missed their chance to make the playoffs.

title: Bridge: A Young New York Group Keeps Focus on Flexibility
description: Back in the 1950's the dominant players in the game were a group of New York experts who could play in a variety of partnerships because they used a common system.

title: NINTH-GRADE OPTION: POSTSCIPT TO A BAD IDEA
description: To the Editor:

title: A NONEXISTENT WEST BANK SOVEREIGNTY CLAIM
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Changes in Access

title: BROADWAY IS IN ITS WORST SLUMP IN A DECADE
description: The Broadway theater, bedeviled by a national recession and a season in which few shows have received critical and public acceptance, is in its worst slump in a decade.

title: PRUNING NESTLE'S OPERATIONS
description: This little Swiss town that is home to the corporate headquarters of Nestle S.A., the multinational food company that built its reputation on milk products, is situated amid vineyards of Pinot Blanc grapes that clamber up the shores of Lake Geneva.

title: THE FINALE WAS SWEET
description: PHILADELPHIA IN the locker room after the Giants had beaten the Eagles, 26-24, yesterday afternoon, someone asked Gary Jeter why he had helped carry Coach Ray Perkins off the field. ''To...'' said Jeter. Before the defensive end could continue, the guy sitting next to him, the tackle Gordon King, interjected, ''To get on TV.''

title: Finance Minister Keeps Japanese Budget Lean
description: The way Japan decides on a national budget, as it did last week, is akin to an elaborate and grueling Kabuki play. This time, the man at center stage was Noboru Takeshita, Japan's Minister of Finance.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 3, 1983
description: International A U.S. limit on Chinese textiles proposed by the Reagan Administration has aroused a protest in Peking. China strongly protested an announcement in the Federal Register that the United States would impose unilateral restraints Jan. 15 if the two sides could not reach an agreement in negotiations that are expected to resume in Peking this week. China is the world's largest textile producer. Its exports earn a quarter of its foreign exchange. (Page A1, Column 2.) Whether the murder of a journalist in Turkey could be connected to the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II is being investigated by Turkish authorities. Mehmet Ali Agca, who is serving a life sentence in Italy for shooting the Pope in 1981, confessed that he killed Abdi Ipekci, who was a prominent journalist in Istanbul. Mr. Agca was sentenced to death in the Ipekci case, but escaped from an Istanbul prison in 1979. (A1:1.)

title: OPTIMISTIC REPORT ON SLY WILLIAMS
description: Sly Williams underwent 45 minutes of arthroscopic surgery yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, and the prognosis was better than had been expected for the Knick forward.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Yugoslavs Win
description: Goren Prpic and Sabina Goles, Yugoslavia's best junior tennis players, today won the 18-year division singles titles in the Rolex international junior tournament.

title: OF FRUIT THEFT
description: McALLEN, Tex., Jan. 2 (AP) - Texas orange and grapefruit growers are mobilizing to combat millions of dollars in thefts from their orchards by culprits ranging from casual tourists to organized rings.

title: Flick Group Changes Leaders After Scandal
description: In 1947, when Friedrich Karl Flick was 20, an Allied tribunal sentenced his father, Friedrich Flick, chief of wartime Germany's biggest industrial empire, to seven years for using slave labor and committing other war crimes.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday gave an incorrect figure for the estimated Federal cost of reimbursing sleepwear manufacturers for losses incurred when the Government banned Tris, a flame retardant. The actual estimate, made in 1978 by the Congressional Budget Office, was $51 million.

title: SHAPRIO TAKES OATH OF OFFICE AS ESSEX COUNTY'S EXECUTIVE
description: Peter Shapiro, the 30-year-old Essex County Executive, took the oath of office here today for his second four-year term, calling upon government not to forget ''the vast numbers of people'' who he said were ''left out by our society.''

title: JETS FALL
description: Of all teams, the Chiefs, with seemingly little motivation, upset the Jets today and ended any chance for New York to have a home-field advantage in the playoff opener.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; British Complete Inquiry Into Falkland War

title: A New Bidder For Propane
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation has joined the suitors for the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation by announcing that it seeks to buy up to 3 million of Suburban's 5.3 million common shares at $48.50 each.

title: Flash Floods Leave 40 Dead in Brazil
description: A heavy rain swept through this mining capital today, causing flash floods that collapsed buildings and left 40 to 50 people dead, a civil defense spokesman said.

title: Capitals 7, Nordiques 4
description: QUEBEC (AP) - Dennis Maruk scored two goals and Mike Gartner had three assists for Washington.

title: U.S. EXPECTED TO END LONG FREEZE ON MILITARY AID FOR GUATEMALANS
description: Congressional and senior State Department officials said today that the United States was likely to end a long freeze on military aid to Guatemala soon. They said the policy change was expected because of signs that the Government of President Efrain Rios Montt had made progress in improving human rights conditions.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: What would the ruling be if a batter hits a hard, low ball that somehow impales itself on the pitcher's spikes? Is the ball still alive? If so, how does the pitcher get the batter out?

title: OPEC WITHOUT TEARS
description: Nothing in years has made me want to throw a rock t hrough a window as much as all the public fretting about the p rospect that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries mightc ollapse. It's astonishing that a regime as young as the n ine-yearold oil-price conspiracy, and one as obviously detrimental t o the health of the world, should have become so respectable.

title: WHEN A PARENT REMARRIES
description: "When I think of a stepparent I think of someone mean and someone who doesn't love you as much asy our own parent. But I know that isn't true. All I know is that I w ant my own mom and dad.''

title: Herbert Gambrell of S.M.U.; Teacher and Texas Historian
description: Herbert Pickens Gambrell, chairman emeritus of the Southern Methodist University history department, in which he served from 1947 to 1964, died Thursday at the age of 84.

title: SHIFT NEUTRALIZES WALKER RUN
description: The exchange took place in the second half. Herschel Walker, the Georgia tailback and the Heisman Trophy winner, could not recall which of the Penn State players stopped to say something. It might have been Walker Lee Ashley, but he was not sure. What Herschel Walker did recall were the message, his response and that Penn State had left an impression on him.

title: Crowds Interrupt French Auto Rally
description: Thousands of motor enthusiasts blocked roads and special test stretches today, hampering second-day progress of the Paris-Algiers-Dakar auto rally.

title: IRAQI CHIEF, IN APPARENT SHIFT, CITES ISRAELI NEED FOR SECURITY
description: Iraq made public a conversation today that it said had been held between President Saddam Hussein and a United States Congressman in which the Iraqi leader acknowledged, apparently for the first time, Israel's need for security.

title: DETECTIVES STUDY BLASTS THAT HURT 3 OFFICERS
description: Dozens of Federal and city investigators searched for witnesses and traced the materials of an unexploded bomb yesterday in a widening hunt for the terrorists believed to have planted four bombs that severely injured three policemen in Manhattan and Brooklyn on New Year's Eve.

title: A SHOWCASE FOR A PLAYOFF
description: NEW ORLEANS FROM his tan slacks up, Joe Paterno resembled a chemist after some hard hours in the lab. His nose glistened with perspiration. His blue Penn State tie sagged from the open collar of his button-down shirt. His thick tinted bifocal glasses were slightly askew. But below those tan slacks, he was wearing black ripple-soled football shoes over white sweat socks. Joe Paterno's lab had been the Superdome and his grand experiment had been completed. With a 27-23 victory over Georgia in the Sugar Bowl, his Nittany Lions appeared to have earned the final No.1 ranking in the wire-service polls for the first time in Penn State's history. But the 56-year-old coach was not gloating.

title: GREENSPAN WARNING ON LOANS
description: A major danger facing the international financial system is the possibility that a number of small- and mediumsized American banks may refuse or be unable to renew their shortterm loans to Mexico and other developing countries, the economist Alan Greenspan said today.

title: PENN STATE WON ON BALANCE
description: Penn State became the No.1 team in the nation in the final rankings because it had one of the most balanced offenses of any top college team in history. The Nittany Lions used all of their powerful assets Saturday night to beat Georgia, 27-23, in the Sugar Bowl.

title: MUSIC: NANCY LA MOTT SONGS
description: NANCY LA MOTT, who was singing at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, last weekend, is a teeny tiny woman who seems at first to have a teeny tiny voice. But that, it turns out, is just a come-on to an act in which she builds one vocal layer over another as her singing personality evolves.

title: Leafs 6, Wings 3
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Rick Vaive scored four goals and Dan Daoust had four assists, extending Toronto's unbeaten streak to four games.

title: RAIDERS RALLY TO DOWN CHARGERS, 41-34
description: Jim Plunkett, the quarterback of the Los Angeles Raiders, knew there was something amiss, even though his team was leading San Diego by 17 points in the middle of the third period. As he walked along the sidelines, he noticed that many teammates were starting to talk of victory. But he knew better.

title: RATES IN BIG YEAR-END SWING
description: The credit markets ended 1982 with interest rates swinging wildly as dealers and investors rushed to balance their books. In the midst of continued efforts by the Federal Reserve to accommodate the demand for cash and Treasury paper to dress up accounts, overnight interbank loan rates bounced between a high of 14 percent and a low of 3 percent before closing last week around 9 percent. But many dealers paid 14.5 percent to finance inventory.

title: Turkish Debt Repayments
description: Turkey made end-of-the-year debt repayments of $440 million, the central bank said. It said the repayments, made in the space of a week, illustrate Turkey's recovery from severe problems of the late 1970's, which forced it to reschedule some $3.2 billion of foreign debts in 1980.

title: Flyers 3, Black Hawks 1
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Lindsay Carson scored two goals in the third period to lift Philadelphia. Carson's tie-breaking goal dealt Chicago its first loss on home ice since Oct. 10 and stretched the Flyers' winning streak to six games. The Flyers were without their center, Ron Flockhart, who suffered a bruised left kneecap and tendon in the 4-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues Saturday and will be lost for 10 days to three weeks.

title: Guild and Wire Service Talks Break Down Over Night Pay
description: Negotiations between The Associated Press and the Wire Service Guild were broken off over the weekend in Manhattan. Being negotiated is a new two-year nationwide contract for 1,300 employees, mostly reporters and photographers, of the wire service.

title: Actor Achieves a Goal
description: In the summer of 1980, Jim Piddock, an English actor, went to see a play in London called ''The Boy's Own Story.'' The play, about a goalkeeper in soccer, wasn't a commercial success there and Mr. Piddock was able to obtain the option for the show. Now, after successful runs in San Francisco and Minneapolis, his one-man show has cracked the Big Apple.

title: CHINESE THREATEN TRADE REPRISALS IF U.S. CURBS IMPORTS OF TEXTILES
description: China said today that it would retaliate economically against the United States if the Reagan Administration carried out a threat to curb imports of Chinese textiles unilaterally later this month.

title: Zimbabwe Aide Accuses South Africa of Plot
description: Security Minister Emmerson Munangagwa said in an interview broadcast today that South Africa was recruiting and arming thousands of anti-Government dissidents to infiltrate Zimbabwe's southern province of Matabeleland.

title: Bills Join Move To Oust Garvey
description: Following the lead of the San Diego Chargers and several other teams, the Buffalo Bills have voted for the ouster of Ed Garvey as executive director of the National Football League Players Association.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Oil Inc. said it expected to invest $325 million for property acquisitions in the fiscal year ending next Sept. 30, down from $422.7 million in the previous fiscal year.

title: TV: SUZANNE SOMERS PLAYS FOR G.I.'S
description: PERHAPS aspiring to the mantle once worn by such entertainers as Bob Hope and Martha Raye, Suzanne Somers appears to be turning into a trouper in search of a war. Since leaving ABC's ''Three's Company,'' following a rather nasty and very public salary dispute, Miss Somers has been doing a nightclub act and an occasional variety special for CBS. Her last television appearance was taped aboard the aircraft carrier Ranger at the San Diego Naval Station. Tonight at 10, she can be seen entertaining Army and Air Force personnel at Ramstein Air Base in Kaiserslautern, West Germany. The hour is called, with an almost leering exclamation point, ''Suzanne Somers ... and 10,000 G.I.s!''

title: REDSKINS, RAIDERS TO BE HOSTS
description: The Los Angeles Raiders and Washington Redskins finished the National Football League's shortest season with victories yesterday to give them each an 8-1 record and the top-seeded position in their respective conferences for the 16-team Super Bowl tournament.

title: SOVIET TEAM LOSES TO THE FLAMES, 3-2
description: Lanny McDonald scored one goal and set up another for Calgary and led the Flames to a 3-2 victory over the Soviet Union all-star team tonight.

title: Heart Recipient Recovering
description: Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the world's first permanent artificial heart, marked his 32d day with the plastic pump today by sitting in a chair by his window and chatting with his wife, a spokesman for the University of Utah Medical Center said.

title: SURVEY FINDS 'BLEAK' OUTLOOK FOR CITIES LOSING FEDERAL AID
description: The nation's cities, their expenses growing faster than revenues despite layoffs and higher taxes, are giving up on trying to replace cuts in Federal aid with local funds, according to a survey.

title: Soviet Juniors Win
description: The Soviet Union clinched the World Junior Hockey championship today with one round left to play, defeating Finland by 7-2. In other games in the Leningrad tournament, Sweden downed Canada, 5-2; Czechoslovakia crushed West Germany, 9-0, and the United States routed Norway, 8-3.

title: Fireman Charged In 8 Fires on L.I.
description: A volunteer firefighter has been arrested and charged with setting eight fires on Long Island that caused more than $3 million in damage, the police said today.

title: CITY OF ADVERSITY GETS SOME NEWS THAT MAY HELP
description: People here in Johnstown take pride in adversity. And over the last century they have had a lot to be proud of.

title: PATRIOTS GET PLAYOFF SPOT
description: Steve Grogan's three touchdown passes, one following an interception by Mike Haynes, were the big plays for New England as the Patriots defeated the Buffalo Bills, 30-19, yesterday at Foxboro, Mass., and gained a place in the American Conference playoffs. It is their first playoff berth since 1978 and it was achieved by a team with a lot of new faces.

title: Banks Cool To Latest Account
description: Beginning Wednesday, many banks across the nation will start offering checking accounts free of interest-rate ceilings, but neither banks nor consumers are expected to show much enthusiasm for the new product.

title: Addendum
description: * Anita Hunter Associates, a new public relations company, at 477 Madison Avenue.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Different Slant on Limos

title: DEMOCRATS MAY STRIP GRAMM OF BUDGET SEAT
description: When the Democrats in the House of Representatives hold their organizational meetings this week, one item on the agenda will be whether to punish Representative Phil Gramm of Texas, a Democrat who was a leading supporter of President Reagan's budget initiatives over the past two years.

title: Bowls Fill the Skies
description: Bowl-game crowds tend to bring good economic tidings wherever they go, and the airlines are competing intensely for the right to fly them there.

title: Deukmejian Must Decide Fate of Empty Mansion
description: State officials have rejected bids to buy the vacant official Governor's mansion, so the Governorelect must deal with the 10-bedroom home built at the urging of Nancy Reagan.

title: CHINESE TRY A NEW APPROACH IN AFRICA
description: When Zhou Enlai toured Africa almost two decades ago, he remarked that the prospects for revolution in the continent were excellent. The inference drawn by Westerners was that Peking's intention was to export its own manner of forceful change and thus exploit to its advantage the fall of colonialism.

title: ENTER A NEW FISCAL DEPUTY MAYOR...
description: Kenneth Lipper has moved into City Hall, full of plans to make his twin responsibilities - finance and economic development - support each other.

title: ALCOHOL: AFTER NEW AGE LIMITS, THEN WHAT?
description: Gordon LeMatty, a high school baseball coach in Union, N.J., opened a local newspaper one day to see his photograph on the front page. It showed him in Shea Stadium receiving a plaque as ''Coach of the Year.'' In the back of the same paper, he read the story of his arrest for drunken driving.

title: NEW YEAR GIVES TIME FOR OLD FRIENDS
description: On holiday here, President Reagan does his paper work at Sunnylands, the lavish, art-filled compound of his hosts, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Annenberg. He plays golf on the Annenbergs' private course, and at sunset, from the estate's sprawling gardens, he can watch the San Jacinto Mountains turn violet.

title: BATTLE TAKES TOLL AT BURNUP & SIMS
description: Chaos and confusion. That is how Nick A. Caporella describes the condition of his company, Burnup & Sims Inc., a state he says is caused by an unfriendly takeover attempt by Victor Posner, the financier.

title: LIST OF 1982'S BIG EVENTS TOPPED BY ACQUISITIONS
description: THE events of 1982 that will have the greatest impact on marketing for the longest time are not necessarily the ones that caused the greatest splash at the time - the Tylenol poisoning tragedy or the National Football League players' strike - nor the ones that were the longest running - the still unfinished story of J. Walter Thompson's $30 million computer manipulation problems in its syndication unit.

title: Kurt Friedrichs, Taught Mathematics at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Kurt Otto Friedrichs, professor emeritus and retired chairman of the department of mathematics and former director of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University, died Saturday of cancer at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: No Big Offers Set This Week
description: No major new tax-exempt or corporate fixed-income securities have been scheduled for sale this week, according to leading investment bankers.

title: A Time to Remember
description: More than two million Americans will be experiencing great loneliness this holiday season.

title: DISPUTE INTENSIFIES OVER CHAVEZ'S LEADERSHIP OF FARM WORKERS
description: A small but insistent rebellion in the United Farm Workers against the leadership of Cesar Chavez has hardened into a bitter conflict.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 3, 1983; The Economy
description: High-interest checking accounts start Wednesday, but they are getting a cool reception. Bankers lament the burden of paying higher interest on top of rising costs to process checks; customers can expect higher checking fees. (Page D1.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Liberals on the Air

title: REAGAN PLEDGES AID TO LOUISIANA FLOOD AREA
description: President Reagan, making a quick stop at this flood-ravaged community on the way from California to the White House today, helped fill sandbags and assured flood victims that the Federal Government ''will provide every bit of assistance possible and without delay.''

title: Market Place; The Problems Facing Britoil
description: LONDON 'FIASCO'' seemed to be the most popular description of the Government's public offering of 51 percent of the shares in Britoil P.L.C. in November. Now, with more than a month of stock trading in the huge oil exploration company behind it, the City of London - Britain's Wall Street - hasn't the slightest reason to temper that assessment.

title: WHO WILL REVIEW EXECUTIVE PRIVILEGE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jacqueline Stern Wed To Dr. Avi Israel Einzig
description: Jacqueline Francine Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Stern of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Avi Israel Einzig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Einzig of @Bellerose, Queens. Rabbi Meyer Bilitzky performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Hearing for Ayala Scheduled Jan. 12
description: Tony Ayala remained in Passaic County Jail in Paterson today, his future as a top juniormiddleweight boxer in doubt.

title: TV: 'LISTEN TO YOUR HEART' ON CBS
description: FEW gimmicks are likely to produce more groans of recognition than the opening scene of a made-for-television movie that takes place in a singles bar. We all know by now, unto stupefaction, that the goodlooking guy who seems to be irresistible to every woman in the joint is really bored and is looking for a ''meaningful relationship.'' Warning: Tonight's TV movie, ''Listen to Your Heart,'' on CBS at 9 P.M. begins in a singles bar. Suggestion: Hang in there; the rest is all uphill.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Life of Eisenstein

title: PAN AM'S MARKETING ERROR
description: Pan American World Airways is seeking to recover from a costly marketing mistake it made involving travel agents last year, just as it enters the lean winter months when it must dip into cash reserves until the seasonal spring pickup begins.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LAST CALL

title: UNILEVER: BIG, PLODDING, SAFE
description: While the worldwide recession has buffeted European business in general, Unilever, the giant British-Dutch consumer products company, seems to be holding to a balanced, if plodding, course by virtue of its sheer size and stable management.

title: CURES FOR THE JETS MAY BE TOO LATE
description: W hen the Jets were at cruising altitude on their five-game winning streak not long ago, they were talking about the Super Bowl XVII tournament as if it was theirs to win. Now that the playoffs are here, those Jets appear to have dissolved into an entirely different team. The offense has no punch. The defense has no pass rush. But the Jets apparently lead the National Football League in overnight medical cures.

title: O'ROURKE BEGINS AS WESTCHESTER EXECUTIVE
description: In a crowded Republican celebration at which hundreds of invited guests were turned away, Andrew P. O'Rourke was sworn in today as Westchester's sixth County Executive. He succeeds Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello, the first Democrat to hold the post.

title: Edward Howard, 105, Senior U.S. Archbishop
description: Archbishop Edward D. Howard, who at 105 was the oldest Roman Catholic prelate in the nation, died Sunday night at a nursing home where he lived.

title: Cabby Suspended In Woman's Death
description: The driver of a taxicab that struck and killed a woman who pushed her granddaughter from its path before she was hit was suspended yesterday by the City Taxi and Limousine Commission. The police said the cab had no significant mechanical defects.

title: SOVIET BLOC CHIEFS TO MEET IN PRAGUE
description: Warsaw Pact foreign ministers were believed to be meeting privately in Prague today as party and government leaders of the seven-nation Communist alliance gathered for a meeting in the Czechoslovak capital.

title: Flooded Missouri Town In Dioxin Scare to Get Aid
description: President Reagan today designated the city of Times Beach, Mo., as eligible for Federal funds to clean up flood debris that may be contaminated by deadly dioxin.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Operations at steel mills in the United States improved slightly last week after falling to their lowest rate in 50 years, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50**Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OF APPLES, ORANGES AND NUCLEAR FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Steamer of the Major Indoor Soccer League have dismissed their head coach, Al Trost. ... Only 19 days before he was to defend his European featherweight championship, Pat Cowdell announced in London that he was retiring. Cowdell, who once went 15 rounds with the late Salvador Sanchez when Sanchez was the World Boxing Council's champion, had been scheduled to fight Francis Tripp of Lyons, France.

title: CARLUCCI: THOUGHTS ON GOVERNMENT AND LEAVING IT
description: Frank C. Carlucci ended a kaleidoscopic career as a Government manager last week with an uneasy feeling. The quality of people and programs in Government is headed for decline, he cautions, if top officials continue to find their incomes limited and their missions circumscribed by critics.

title: U.S. PROVIDES $175 MILLION TO AID 15 SAVINGS BANKS, MOSTLY IN CITY
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has pumped almost $175 million into 15 deeply troubled savings banks, most of them in New York City, the agency's chairman said yesterday.

title: Rangers Top Wings, 6-2
description: The Rangers trounced the Detroit Red Wings, 6-2, at Madison Square Garden last night for their third consecutive victory, but they may have lost Barry Beck again.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman & Co. has promoted Alfred B. Gates to vice president and general merchandise manager.

title: Bills' White Retires
description: In the first of what may prove to be many changes among the Buffalo Bills after their disappointing season, the standout defensive end Sherman White has announced his retirement. ''Physically I feel great,'' said White, an 11-year pro.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Phoenix Suns, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. Maurice Lucas faces his former teammates in his only appearance at the Garden this season.

title: JAZZ: MILES DAVIS GROUP
description: MILES DAVIS'S music since he came out of retirement in 1981 has been a game of cat-and-mouse. He has proved that he can still play trumpet with the ghostly tone and canny timing that established him in the jazz pantheon. Yet he has also, for the first time in his career, assembled a group that neither challenges nor stimulates him - a group that sounds best imitating earlier Davis bands. Mr. Davis now makes listeners wait for his own stretches of brilliance.

title: No Headline
description: ALABAMA IS UPSET BY FLORIDA, 89-85

title: Tokyo Trade Warning
description: The Japanese Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, warned recession-gripped Europe today not to expect more reductions in Japanese tariffs.

title: EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS: MISGIVINGS AND PRAISE
description: THE personal computer revolution is in full force throughout the school systems of our land. No educator wants to be last in this great instructional leap forward. Unfortunately, as happens in the case of so many leaps forward, this one is likely to prove to be a false step, in the wrong direction, with failure right around the corner. The fact of the matter is that while personal computers are a fine tool for learning about computers and the languages, like Basic, they speak, when it comes to teaching just about anything else of an elementary nature, they are an educational cop-out.

title: PUBLISHERS BATTLE THE GOOF AND THE GLITCH
description: The dust jacket on Bernard Malamud's recent ''God's Grace'' mistakenly identifies the novelist as the author of ''The Centaur,'' which was written by John Updike.

title: Action on Ayala
description: Prosecutors in San Antonio said yesterday that they planned to move immediately to revoke the 10-year probation being served by Tony Ayala, the highly ranked junior middleweight boxer who was jailed in Paterson, N.J., over the weekend on charges of burglary, assault and sexual abuse.
