District Attorney Sam Millsap said that he would file a motion today asking that the probated sentence given the boxer in 1980 for assaulting a woman be revoked in light of the New Jersey charges. Mr. Millsap said that he had reached agreement with the New Jersey authorities to have the 19-year-old Ayala, who continued to be held yesterday on $50,000 bond, returned to San Antonio for a probation-revocation hearing before he goes to trial on the new charges.

title: American Cyanamid
description: The American Cyanamid Company said today that it had acquired the manufacturing assets of the privately held Electro-Metalloid Corporation of Irvington, N.Y., for an undisclosed sum. It said the purchase includes the world rights to technology for coating graphite fibers used in aerospace and electronics industries.

title: SHERRY LANSING GOING TO PARAMOUNT
description: Sherry Lansing, who last month left 20th Century-Fox, where she had served as the first woman head of a major movie studio, has been given a five-year exclusive production contract with Paramount, Gulf and Western's motion picture company, effective Feb. 1. Miss Lansing will team up with Stanley R. Jaffe, the producer, in the new venture.

title: Baldwin-United Insurance Units
description: Two insurance units of the Baldwin-United Corporation were ''financially impaired'' for as long as six months last year, according to a newly released examiners' report by the Arkansas Insurance Department.

title: Forces in Zimbabwe Searching for Rebels
description: Thousands of troops and policemen using armored cars, helicopter gunships and planes are combing western Zimbabwe for armed rebels in the biggest military operation since the war for black rule ended three years ago.

title: Article 140656 -- No Title
description: The money market accounts that banks and savings institutions began offering Dec. 14 held an average of $52 billion through Dec. 22, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday.

title: S.I. AND QUEENS SCHOOLS LEAD IN READING SCORES
description: Schools on Staten Island and in the Douglaston-Little Neck section of northeastern Queens, perennial leaders in reading, ranked highest on the annual citywide reading achievement tests given last spring, according to a report released yesterday by the New York City Board of Education.

title: U.S. AIDES UNEASY ON SOVIET CODING
description: When strategic arms negotiations resume in Geneva next month, United States negotiators plan to protest that Soviet encoding of information transmitted from missiles on test flights has been excessive, Administration officials said today.

title: ZORAN AND KAMALI: SUCCESS WITH THE OFFBEAT
description: They work far from Seventh Avenue, the frenetic core of the garment industry. They avoid ''trends,'' though the clothes they design are always topical. Zoran Ladicorbic, whose headquarters are in Greenwich Village, and Norma Kamali, who works in the fashionable 50's, approach fashion from different directions, but each has come to stand for the avant-garde in style.

title: THE FOOTBALL FEAST VARIED IN QUALITY
description: A s Marcus Dupree was being led off the field to the locker room in the first half of Saturday afternoon's Fiesta Bowl, something was obviously wrong with Oklahoma's fine freshman running back. His jersey and shoulder pads were off, and he was surrounded by trainers and student aides.

title: VIKINGS BEAT COWBOYS, 31-27
description: Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota quarterback, hit Rickey Young with a 14-yard touchdown pass with 1 minute 52 seconds left in the game and gave the Vikings a 31-27 victory over the Dallas Cowboys last night. It was the National Football League's final regular-season game and it produced the longest run from scrimmage in league history, a 99-yard sprint by Tony Dorsett of the Cowboys.

title: CRITICS GROUP PICKS 'TOOTSIE'
description: ''Tootsie,'' the comedy about an out-of-work actor who masquerades as an actress to land a soap opera role, was voted best film of 1982 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 41-member group representing newspapers and magazines from New York, Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago and other cities. Dustin Hoffman was voted best actor for his performance in ''Tootsie,'' and Meryl Streep was named best actress for ''Sophie's Choice.''

title: No Headline
description: N. CAROLINA STATE TROUNCES FAIRLEIGH

title: ENTIRE FAMILIES JOIN IN MAKING DONATIONS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, giving has become a family affair, with even the youngest members joining their parents in an act of generosity.

title: RUMANIA TO POSTPONE PAYING WESTERN BANKS
description: Rumania has informed its major Western creditor banks that it will withhold repayment of $1.4 billion in debt principal due this year until a rescheduling agreement is worked out, bankers said today.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock and foreign exchange markets were closed yesterday in Canada, Britain, Japan and Australia in observance of holidays.

title: First U.S.F.L. Draft Set Today
description: The new United States Football League, whose 12 teams plan to play a spring-summer schedule beginning March 6, will conduct its first draft of college players today and tomorrow. Such a draft amounts to a strong challenge of the National Football League because the two leagues in many instances will be competing for the services of the same players.

title: Linda Hazard Frech And Arthur Taft Wed
description: Linda Hazard Frech, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans A. Frech of New York, was married yesterday to Arthur Thomas Taft, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Taft of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: BUNDY ON ARMS CONTROL
description: McGEORGE BUNDY, national security adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson before heading the Ford Foundation, has been teaching New York University students the history of political decisions relating to nuclear weapons, about which he is writing a book. And, as the old year slipped unceremoniously into the dustbin of history, the Boston Brahmin took a last look at the state of the nation's strategy on arms control strategy as well as on the MX, one of President Reagan's favorite missiles, found them wanting and, quite consciously, set up what he thinks the agenda for 1983 should be.

title: NOT JUST THE FITTEST
description: While others are telling us that the only good government is the one that gets off our backs, Mario Cuomo tells us that ''government can be a positive source for good.''

title: Scores on Reading Tests Given in Public Schools
description: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1982.

title: Peru's Leader Swears In 9 Cabinet Members
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry swore in nine Cabinet members today, including military men in all defense-related posts, in the most sweeping Government reorganization since he came to power in 1980.

title: Temple Names Coach
description: Bruce Arians, an assistant coach under Paul (Bear) Bryant at Alabama, was named head football coach at Temple yesterday.

title: DRAMATIC IMPROVEMENT OF TV IMAGE IN THE OFFING
description: WITH electronics getting smarter and friendlier every day, whether in the guise of personal computers or bionic organs, the friendly old television set has stayed essentially unchanged in this country since the advent of color broadcasting in the 1950's. But this long period of somnolence may end during the decade of the '80's. The change will not be so much a matter of program content - a social problem beyond technological considerations - as an evolutionary leap in equipment.

title: People
description: * Ronald W. Mitchell and Kenneth Rogers have been elected executive vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc.

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS BUILD NEW, PRAGMATIC IMAGE
description: A political gibe going the rounds in Madrid says that President Francois Mitterrand of France has done a great service to European Socialism by giving Spanish Socialists a good reason to pursue conservative economic policies.

title: TO END TURF WARS THAT FOIL DRUG CONTROL
description: Turf wars among Government agencies responsible for Federal control of narcotics, long a major obstacle to such control, would finally be eliminated by a bill that is awaiting President Reagan's signature. If he succumbs to bureaucratic arguments to veto it, he will invite a severe setback to his own commendable efforts to control drug trafficking and the crime it spawns in every corner of this country.

title: Official Retires At Texaco
description: Annon M. Card, president of Texaco Inc.'s Europe division and a vice president of the parent company, has taken early retirement at the age of 63, the company announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: French Player's Brilliance Deserved a Biarritz Award
description: When the World Bridge Championships were played recently in Biarritz, France, the French made considerable efforts to be gracious hosts. One could not blame them for the Atlantic gale that blew throughout the two weeks of play, but whether it was truly hospitable for the host country to carry off the main trophy - the Rosenblum Cup for Open Teams - is open to argument.

title: Chrysler-Jamaica Deal
description: The Chrysler Corporation agreed to sell pickup trucks to Jamaica in exchange for aluminum oxide, company officials said today.

title: THE JET FROM BUFFALO (MINN.)
description: T he roots of a suddenly significant part of the unit once known as the New York Sack Exchange cannot be traced to Wall Street, where a year ago the members of the Jets' defensive line were cheered by the shakers and movers of the financial world. For a variety of reasons, mostly a continuing series of injuries, a part of the Sack Exchange can be traced to Buffalo, Minn. (population approximately 4,000), where Barry Bennett, a 27-year-old defensive tackle, chooses to make his permanent home with his wife and three young children.

title: A LONG DROUGHT FOR DOLPHINS
description: For all their victories and accomplishments over recent years, the Miami Dolphins have not won a playoff game since they defeated the Minnesota Vikings in Super Bowl VIII. That was nine years ago. Since then, they have advanced to the playoffs four times and lost to Oakland, Houston, Pittsburgh and San Diego.

title: BRIEFING
description: Cooperation From Cuomo

title: Official Sentenced For Taking Payoffs
description: John Cassiliano, a New York City sanitation official who was dismissed after being convicted of taking payoffs from toxic-waste dumpers, was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison and fined $5,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm hopeful that we have reversed a continuing upward spiral of subway crime and have begun to see it come down.'' - James B. Meehan, chief of the Transit Authority Police. (A1:1.)

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT TO VISIT U.S. AMID TALK OF A POLITICAL RACE
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel starts a visit to the United States on Tuesday amid speculation by politicians and journalists that he might become a challenger to Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: Japan Retail Store Link
description: Nichii Company Ltd. and Uny Company Ltd., Japan's fourth- and sixth-largest department store groups, respectively, have agreed to merge their operations into the second-largest retail company in that country, both concerns announced yesterday in Tokyo.

title: Downhill at 70
description: When members of the 70 Plus Ski Club, who make up what could be called the not-over-the-downhill gang, get together to race, winning is not the bottom line. Although men's and women's races are held regularly, and will be capped this season by a March 2 meet at Hunter Mountain in New York, the purpose of the club is basically economic.

title: Boston's Mayor Upbeat In His Annual Message
description: Mayor Kevin H. White, in office longer than any other big city mayor, said today that the city was ''poised for flight'' and hinted he planned to stay as pilot.

title: Afghan Troops Reported To Mutiny and Kill 30
description: A group of Afghan soldiers mutinied at a Government outpost on Saturday, killed 30 officers and blew up an ammunition dump before joining guerrillas in the hills surrounding the garrison town of Khost, rebel sources said today.

title: DEFECTIVE ARGUMENTS FOR LEGAL HEROIN
description: To the Editor:

title: UNBEATEN ST. JOHN'S WINS 12TH IN ROW
description: Billy Goodwin, a senior who often plays in the shadow of other St. John's starters, scored a career-high 28 points, stole the ball three times and sparked the undefeated Redmen to a 79-62 victory over Seton Hall tonight.

title: Harriet Parsons, Film Maker; Daughter of Louella Parsons
description: Harriet Parsons, one of the first women film producers and the daughter of the Hollywood columnist Louella Parsons, died Sunday at St. John's Hospital after a two-year battle with cancer.

title: Lockheed Order
description: The Air Force gave the Lockheed Corporation a $609 million contract to build the first C-5B cargo plane and to buy material for 49 more planes. The C-5B's, to be built at Lockheed's Marietta, Ga., plant, are to help the Air Force to move very large cargo.

title: BRITAIN'S BLOOMING CHRISTMAS A 2-WEEK SEASON TO BE JOLLY
description: The 1981 holiday season was the first in London for Douglas A. Smith, the senior vice president sent to establish an office here for the Fleet National Bank of Rhode Island. He diligently trekked into the City of London, Britain's Wall Street, during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day.

title: PANEL ON U.S. JEWS AND HOLOCAUST IS DISSOLVED
description: A private commission of prominent American Jews, set up 15 months ago to examine the behavior of Jewish organizations in this country at the time of the Nazi campaign to annihilate European Jews, has split up in anger and dissension.

title: E.F. Hutton Is Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured the New York brokerage firm of E.F. Hutton & Company today for failing to supervise closely its employees in their dealings with credit and antifraud rules.

title: DR. JESSE B. ARONSON
description: Dr. Jesse B. Aronson, a public-health physician, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Productivity Offer For Ford Suppliers
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would sign long-term contracts with suppliers that promise to work on improving their labor productivity at an 8 percent annual rate.

title: REPORTED
description: After a long upward trend, the number of serious crimes reported on the New York City subway system remained roughly the same in 1982 as in 1981, according to preliminary data released yesterday by the Transit Authority police.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. said it had sold its Wells National Services unit, which markets patient-entertainment systems, to a company formed by the unit's management for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 4, 1983; The Economy
description: The F.D.I.C. has pumped almost $175 million into 15 troubled savings banks, most of them in New York City. The Federal agency acted under new powers granted last year by Congress, according to its chairman. Without such aid, officials said, the banks could not have continued operating much longer. The Bowery received $58.7 million in aid, by far the largest amount. (Page A1.)

title: No Headline
description: McCormack Shifted To New Seattle Post

title: No Headline
description: Britain's Oil Revenues

title: Western Airlines Given Aid
description: Western Airlines announced a series of agreements today indicating that its major lenders believe the airline has weathered the worst of its troubles.

title: KILAUEA, HAWAIIAN VOLCANO, ERUPTS AGAIN
description: Kilauea volcano, which erupted twice last year in short-lived blasts, threw spectacular fountains of lava 150 feet into the air along a three-mile front today.

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADER SAYS HIS PARTY WOULD CURB SOCIAL SECURITY COSTS
description: Representative James Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said today that Democrats were ready to call for a reduction in the growth of the cost of Social Security and other social programs.

title: New Neighbors, New Management; Nothing Personal
description: At the end of a year when Chinatown didn't want a jail, Glen Cove didn't want Soviet diplomats on the beach and nobody wanted the homeless, the Libyan Government has joined the club. It, or that portion of it planning to live in a 25-room mansion in Englewood, N.J., has been deemed undesirable by the neighbors.

title: Price a Nordique
description: With the loss of Mario Marois for at least three months, the Quebec Nordiques moved to shore up their defense by signing Pat Price, formerly of the Pittsburgh Penguins. Marois, a former Ranger, fractured a leg in two places during a game Thursday against the touring Soviet all-stars. Price was waived after a run-in last week with Coach Eddie Johnston.

title: MINNEAPOLIS
description: UNDER the microscope the man's cells looked bizarrely abnormal and highly malignant, very much like the deadly skin cancer, melanoma. The leg tumors from which they came were large and numerous, some more than two inches wide. Surely, the pathologist thought, by now the tumor would have spread and the patient should be very sick, if not dying.

title: U.S.F.L. Draft Assignments
description: Each of the 12 teams in the United States Football League may select and protect a total of 26 players from five colleges chosen by the team. Those players are exempted from today's draft.

title: Topics: New Neighbors, New Management; Railroad Switch
description: The name is unpromising: the Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company. That's a concoction, very like Conrail, whose passenger traffic the new company assumes.

title: 4 Police Unions Assail Policy on Fund Raising
description: Leaders of four New York City police unions charged the Police Department yesterday with threatening to penalize officers who attended a fund-raising party held last month to benefit six colleagues indicted on charges stemming from a bribery investigation.

title: SATURDAY REVIEW: THE PROFITABLE DECADES
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTLE-KNOWN MUSEUM FIT FOR A CZAR
description: The Hillwood Museum houses the most comprehensive collection of 19th-century Russian decorative art outside the Soviet Union, but is unknown to most Washingtonians and tourists. Its director, Roy D.R. Betteley, recalls that one Cabinet wife learned of the museum on a tour of the Hermitage in Leningrad. It was her Russian guide, he said, who told her of ''a marvelous collection in Washington.''

title: Norstar Purchase
description: Norstar Bancorp, a bank holding company based in Albany, said it had agreed to acquire 67.6 percent of the stock of the Bank of Commerce, based in New York, from a subsidiary of Financial General Corporation in a transaction valued at $50 million.

title: GLASEL PUTS DOWN TRUMPET, RAISES UNION BATON
description: The newly elected president of the nation's biggest musicians' union, John S. Glasel, says that he intends to encourage greater member participation in union affairs and that he will also demand strict enforcement of contract terms, including controversial rules governing standby musicians at Broadway theaters.

title: Danish Fishermen Sail Into Disputed Waters
description: Danish fisherman sailed six trawlers into disputed waters off Scotland today, but storm-tossed seas delayed a showdown with Britain over fishing rights.

title: OF APPLES, ORANGES AND NUCLEAR FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Mondale and Askew Register With Federal Election Panel
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale filed a report today with the Federal Election Commission, registering to be a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination and designating the Mondale for President Committee Inc. as his principal campaign committee.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Snoopy' vs. a Dirty Dog

title: Marietta Settles Titanium Cases
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Martin Marietta Corporation, in a consent agreement filed by the Justice Department, agreed to refrain from fixing titanium prices and from exchanging pricing information with other manufacturers. The agreement, filed with Federal District Court in Pittsburgh, will become final on approval by that court and will end a civil antitrust suit against Martin Marietta.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Afterlife of a Special Tree

title: Talking Business With 3 International Economists; World Upturn In '83 Expected
description: Much of the American Economics Association's annual meeting, held last week in New York, was given over to academic discussion of relatively esoteric issues. But three international economists - Lawrence J. Krause of the Brookings Institution, Bela A. Belassa, a professor of economics at Johns Hopkins University and a consultant to the World Bank, and Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics - took time out from the sessions to discuss the world economy and its prospects for growth.

title: Chess: Playing an Opening by Rote May Not Be the Best Route
description: Playing an opening by rote may be good enough if you can keep the rote right. The trouble is that there are many routine paths that diverge only slightly, but very significantly, from each other, and disaster awaits if you don't zag when the opponent zigs.

title: No Headline
description: Failure Spurs Belgian Sit-In

title: Doctor Says King Has Minor Injury
description: Albert King, the Net forward who injured his right knee in Saturday night's victory over Dallas, is expected to miss only tonight's game at Milwaukee.

title: PERPICH SPURNS MINNESOTA INAUGURATION TRADITION
description: Rudy Perpich reclaimed the Minnesota governorship today, spurning a traditional inauguration at the state Capitol in favor of a speech to students at Hibbing High School, his alma mater.

title: FRESHMEN IN CONGRESS TAKE OATH ON A BIG DAY
description: Amid ceremony and celebration, the new Democratic Senator from New Jersey, Frank R. Lautenberg, and seven new Representatives - five Democrats and two Republicans - from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut took the oath of office today.

title: SHERIFF HANDCUFFS A SALE OF HOMES OF UNEMPLOYED
description: Jobless homeowners here who thought they would lose their houses today because of overdue mortgage payments instead found themselves under the wing of the Allegheny County sheriff.

title: ANDROPOV'S TALL ORDER: ROUSING THE LOAFERS
description: After years of shirking on the job, the truck driver had a bad conscience. Then Yuri V. Andropov became the Soviet leader in November and put his foot down on an issue that has been helping to drag the economy toward stagnation: sloth, absenteeism and drunkenness.

title: Buyers Wary Within E.E.C.
description: The European Commission today reported a sharp deterioration in consumer confidence in the economies of the European Economic Community, dashing any immediate hopes of a consumer-led recovery from recession.

title: RATES TURN UP AFTER DECLINE
description: Interest rates rose modestly late yesterday, eliminating most declines that had occurred in earlier trading. The quick drop in prices and increase in rates was attributed to an announcement by the Federal Reserve of a smaller-than-expected $2.4 billion drop in the nation's basic money supply, and to a higher-than-expected 9 3/4 percent interest rate for overnight bank loans.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Modern Touch For the Art Commission

title: SATELLITES TO BE PUT ON TETHER
description: OUT at the frontier of space, where it is too high for aircraft and too low for spacecraft, scientific exploration has been relatively scant, the work of sounding rockets that have only a few minutes to collect data. Beginning in 1987, however, the space shuttles are expected to be equipped to ''troll'' that region with small satellites dangling at the end of a 60-mile-long line.

title: WARNINGS FROM SOUTH AFRICA TAKEN SERIOUSLY IN LESOTHO
description: There is no tendency, either in the Government of Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan or among Western diplomats, to discount the warnings of further military and economic reprisals that South Africa has been making ever since its raid here earlier this month on residences occupied by its own black exiles.

title: High on the Davis-Bacon Hog
description: The odious, wage-inflating Davis-Bacon Act has just won a battle; when will Congress mobilize against it to win the war?

title: Constance Barber Mellon, 41, Prominent Patron of the Arts
description: Constance Barber Mellon, a prominent patron of the arts in New York City and Washington, died on Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan of complications from meningitis and pneumonia. She was 41 years old and resided in Manhattan.

title: Oil Well Blast Kills Worker
description: An oil well exploded and caught fire today in rural west Texas, killing one worker and injuring at least three others, the authorities said. The explosion occurred at a Mobil Oil Company well about a mile northwest of here.

title: Gannett Sale
description: The Gannett Company agreed to sell its two UHF television stations, WLKY-TV in Louisville, Ky., and WPTA-TV in Fort Wayne, Ind., to the Pulitzer Publishing Company of St. Louis.

title: WILLIAM MCKNIGHT, FINANCER SAT ON MANY COMPANY BOARDS
description: William Gelon McKnight Jr., formerly a partner in Eastman Dillon, Union Securities, and a director of the Tidewater Oil Company and the Rhinelander Real Estate Company, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan after suffering a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: REAGAN APPOINTS A PANEL TO STUDY MX MISSILE SYSTEM
description: President Reagan today named a bipartisan commission to study the deadlocked MX missile issue, and its chairman quickly cautioned that the panel would not necessarily produce a workable solution.

title: AGENDA IS STILL IN CONTENTION
description: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators met today for the third time in a week but were still unable to agree on an agenda for talks. The Lebanese want the meetings to result in a withdrawal of foreign troops while the Israelis want them to end in a normalization of relations.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS ROSE SHARP 3.5% IN NOVEMBER
description: Spending on new construction rose 3.5 percent in November, the biggest one-month gain in nearly two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: LOOKING BACK AT IRAN
description: Nearly two years after the dramatic return of U.S. hostages, an Iranian official has given the real reasons for what happened.

title: Restore the Lid on Senate Income
description: Confusion in the closing days of the 97th Congress helped to obscure a bit of Senate hypocrisy on the question of its own members' pay.

title: JETS PLAN TO REACTIVATE KLECKO
description: Suddenly every injured regular for the Jets, including the standout defensive end Joe Klecko, today became a probable performer or Sunday's opening playoff game at Cincinnati against the Bengals.

title: DUTCHESS COUNTY HOPING TO SEVER M.T.A. TIES
description: In Dutchess County, there is talk of seceding from the region served by the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: PLAYSFrank Litsky
description: O ne reason the Giants beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 26-24, Sunday was their ability to convert third-down opportunities. Fifteen times they had third down, and nine times they made a first down.

title: Surgery for O'Reilly
description: Terry O'Reilly, the Boston Bruins' scrappy right wing, underwent surgery on his left knee yesterday and will be lost to the team for the rest of the season. The knee was injured last Friday when, in a game against Minnesota, O'Reilly caught his skate in a rut on the ice. ... Wayne Babych of the St. Louis Blues will be sidelined about two weeks because of cheekbone and nose fractures that he suffered in a fight with Behn Wilson of the Philadelphia Flyers on Saturday.

title: Video Recorder Fee
description: A new license fee for people using video recorders in France introduced Jan.1 is expected to raise about $34 million in extra revenue this year, Government officials said today. But officials expect only 500,000 of the estimated 800,000 video recorder users to pay the annual tax of $70, the same as for a color television set.

title: PAYING FOR GAS WITHOUT AN ATTENDANT
description: Service stations are experimenting with electronic advances that, if successful, could change the way customers fill their tanks and pay for gasoline. The innovations have sprung from pressures on oil companies to maintain their shares of a shrinking market.

title: Market Place; Stock-Split Candidates
description: WHEN a stock has been selling in, say, the 30's, and then gradually works its way up into the 50's or 60's, many investors start thinking that the time has come to split the stock.

title: DECEMBER SALES UP ONLY 4.8% IN CITY
description: December sales by New York's seven largest retailers rose an average of only 4.8 percent over the 1981 month, the smallest December gain in seven years, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: Muti Ill, to Miss Concert
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski will replace Riccardo Muti as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra concert next Tuesday at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Muti has a flu virus and is unable to travel. The program will retain Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 1, with Alexis Weissenberg as soloist, but Weber's ''Euryanthe'' Overture and Shostakovich's Symphony No. 1 will replace originally scheduled music by Schoenberg and Liszt.

title: KOCH TRIPLES REWARD OFFERED IN NEW YEAR BOMBINGS CASE
description: Mayor Koch yesterday denounced the terrorists who seriously wounded three police officers with dynamite bombs outside government buildings in the city last Friday night, and he posted an additional $30,000 reward for information leading to their capture and conviction.

title: Cash, 17, Captures Victorian Tennis
description: Pat Cash, a 17-year-old Australian who is the world's top junior tennis player, beat Rod Frawley today, 6-4, 7-6, and became the youngest winner ever of the Victorian Open.

title: 3M Assigns Titralac To Fallon McElligott
description: Fallon McElligott Rice, founded about a year and a half ago in Minneapolis, has just added one of the state's most important corporate citizens to its client list.

title: Cable Account Goes to Jordan
description: What's the best way for an ad agency to begin a new year? Announcing a new account, of course. And that's what Jordan, Case & McGrath did yesterday on the first working day of 1983.

title: Philadelphia Trains Few, But On Time, in Shift
description: The number of commuter trains was drastically curtailed, but officials reported few problems at rush hour today on the first work day since a local agency took over passenger rail service from Conrail.

title: Burnup & Sims President Stays
description: Nick A. Caporella agreed today to remain interim president and chief executive officer of Burnup & Sims Inc., which is fighting a takeover offer from financier Victor Posner.

title: IN THE COMPUTER AGE, INDIA STILL CONSULTS THE STARS
description: All around the convention hall, astrologers from across India pored over charts, scrolls and books of tables. Some wore robes, and some the mark of the Brahman on the forehead, but most looked like ordinary, everyday college professors or businessmen as they read horoscopes or scrutinized palms and foretold the futures of the well-off Delhi dwellers who had come for free consultations as part of last week's National Seminar on Astrology.

title: HIGH FUEL COSTS BENEFIT NATIONAL UTILITY SERVICE
description: Rising energy costs, a disaster for many companies, have benefited Theodore E. Maynard and his company, National Utility Service Inc. The closely held company, based in New York, monitors the energy bills of more than 22,000 clients and determines whether they are overpaying and how they can obtain the correct rates on their bills for gas, oil, electric, water and telecommunications. In return, NUS collects 50 percent of each refund it gets for its clients and 50 percent of any monthly savings during a five-year contract period. Revenues, which topped $30 million in 1981, have climbed as more companies have turned to NUS in an effort to reduce increasing energy costs.

title: AFTER 8 YEARS, U.S. COURT RELINQUISHES AUTHORITY FOR BOSTON SCHOOLS
description: There was no ceremony, no rite of passage, but the Federal District Court here took a historic step today toward ending the close supervision it has exercised over the Boston public schools since it ordered them desegregated in a series of rulings beginning in 1974.

title: Advertising; Ad Chiefs Discuss The Future
description: THE big stories in 1983 on the creative side of the advertising business are likely to be the reappearance of exciting advertising and the disappearance of the new wave variety. At least that is the opinion of a group of creative potentates who were asked yesterday to ponder the future.

title: Pabst Mergers
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had entered into definitive merger agreements with the G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Olympia Brewing Company.

title: STAGE: 'IOLANTHE' AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: CAN a half-fairy find happiness in the House of Lords? And if the peers of the realm were replaced by ''people of intelligence'' and then transformed into fairies, would the future of Great Britain be endangered?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Decisions, Decisions

title: Books Of The Times
description: LETTERS TO PHIL. Memories of a New York Boyhood, 1848-1856. By Gene Schermerhorn. 96 pages, 34 drawings by the author. New York Bound Book- shop/Leslie Dwinell. $10.95.

title: Stock Index Contracts Decline With Market
description: As usual, stock index futures prices yesterday followed the drop in the stock market. But the declines in the three indexes varied widely, much to the satisfaction of many traders who play the intermarket spreads in these futures.

title: THE DOUBTS THAT KEEP THE PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYAN OFFICIAL SEEKS TO DEFUSE CLASH IN JERSEY
description: The chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations offered yesterday to contribute money annually to a local charity to help diminish opposition to the Libyan Mission's purchase of a home in Englewood, N.J.

title: WASHINGTON ISN'T FRANCE'S CAPITAL
description: No French Government, Socialist or otherwise, will ever follow the United States into any global commercial strategy against the Soviet Union.

title: U.N. CHIEF CHIDES U.S. ON FUNDS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar rebuked the United States today for refusing to pay a $1 million assessment for a Law of the Sea commission.

title: Alabama Governor Tells Court of Prison Gains
description: Gov. Fob James of Alabama told a Federal judge today that the state had significantly improved conditions in its

title: DEUKMEJIAN GIVEN OATH IN CALIFORNIA
description: George Deukmejian took the oath of office as Governor of California today and minutes later issued an executive order to cut state spending by 2 percent and to freeze hiring, promotion, transfers, and out-of-state travel.

title: BURLINGTON MOVE IS REBUFFED
description: The chairman of Burlington Northern Inc., asked the El Paso Company yesterday to give his company an opportunity to outbid any offer made for El Paso's assets.

title: FACTORY ORDERS RISE 0.7%
description: Orders placed with United States factories for new manufactured goods rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November after having plunged 4.1 percent the previous month, the Government reported today.

title: DOW SLIDES BY 19.50 TO 1,027.04
description: New doubts that the expected economic recovery will actually materialize and concern that the interest rate slide might end sent stock prices plunging yesterday in the opening session of the New Year.

title: DANCE: 'NUTCRACKER'
description: THE New York City Ballet has its own New Year's Eve tradition, eagerly awaited each year by the cognoscenti who attend that evening's performance of ''The Nutcracker'' knowing that it is sometimes spiked with jokes or references to the ending of the year. Props and costumes have turned up in the wrong dances. Performers have exchanged roles and administrative personnel have taken to the stage. And choreography from other ballets has been substituted - often, as legend has it, at the last-minute urging of George Balanchine.

title: CUOMO APPOINTS A G.O.P. JUDGE TO APPEALS SEAT
description: Richard D. Simons, a Republican appellate judge from upstate New York, was named by Governor Cuomo today to fill a vacancy on the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: SCIENTISTS PONDER FORCING ASTEROIDS INTO SAFE ORBITS
description: ASTRONOMERS have recently discovered so many asteroids whose orbits cross that of the earth that some space scientists are proposing the development of ways to divert any of these potential giant meteoroids that may be found on a collision course with our planet. Fantastic as such an intervention with nature may seem, scientists who have studied the problem believe it can be done.

title: POLAND FORMS NEW UNIONS BUT CONCEDES ENTHUSIASM IS LOW
description: New officially sanctioned labor unions that are supposed to replace the banned independent Solidarity union came into existence today, but the Polish authorities conceded that they seemed to be attracting little enthusiasm from the workers.

title: Corning to Take $45 Million Charge
description: Corning Glass Works said it would take a $45 million charge against 1982 earnings to cover the cost of a restructuring, including the disposition of certain operations and the consolidation of others.

title: Q&A
description: Q. All other things being equal, will my car give me better gas mileage in the winter or the summer?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Bakeries Co. said it had completed a $20 million unsecured revolving credit agreement at prime with a group of banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.

title: D'AMATO A MODERATING INFLUENCE IN EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON SENATOR Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, sits on no education committees. His visibility and identification in the Senate during his first two years there have been highest on mass transit and housing issues.

title: N.F.L. Playoff Schedule
description: Below is the schedule for the first round of the National Football League playoffs. The figure in parentheses after the name of each team is that team's seeding.

title: Harvester Given Waiver
description: The International Harvester Company received a waiver of $200 million in pension payments to its present employees by one branch of the Government, but was sued by another branch of the Government that wants to increase the company's pension liability to some former employees, the company's 1982 annual report, published today, disclosed.

title: A Set of Racquets For Rock Record
description: Barry Gibb, the lead singer with the Bee Gees, the rock group, is such an avid tennis fan that he persuaded Ilie Nastase to collect a virtual all-star set of racquets - from Jimmy Connors, Bjorn Borg and Guillermo Vilas as well as from Nastase himself - at Nastase's recent tournament in Miami.

title: Carteret Savings
description: The Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Morristown, N.J., said it had made two acquisitions that added 11 branch offices and $153 million in deposits. Carteret said it had acquired four branches from the Freedom Savings and Loan Association of Tampa, Fla., and seven branches from a merger with Midtown Savings of Newark. Terms were not disclosed.

title: THE EVIL IN USING WRITING TO PUNISH
description: ''ONLY once have I written an angry letter to one of my children's teachers, and that was when our son was made to write an essay as a penalty for some transgression in class,'' a father recalled. In a note he attached to the essay, he said that as a writer himself he found it intolerable to have writing treated as punishment. The teacher, to his credit, replied that he had never thought of the matter in that light and would never again assign punitive essays.

title: F.W. EVERSLEY JR., CONTRACTOR, DEAD
description: Frederick W. Eversley Jr., a civil engineer and founder and former president of what was once one of the largest construction businesses with minority-group ownership in the New York area, died of a heart attack last Wednesday while swimming at his vacation home on Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Abscam Rights and Wrongs
description: After looking into the Abscam affair, a special Senate committee has absolved the F.B.I. of the charge of political persecution but rebuked it for mismanaging the case. The judgments are appropriate and welcome. Although all Abscam juries were impressed by the evidence against the favor-sellers in Congress, suspicion persisted of abuse of the investigative power along with fear of its partisan misuse. The committee rightly concludes that rules for similar undercover operations should now be written - by Congress.

title: Still Promoting
description: Don King, the loquacious promoter, is campaigning hard for the James J. Walker Award given by the Boxing Writers Association for ''long and meritorious service'' to the sport. He went so far as to keep comparatively quiet.

title: Reagan Is Said to Drop Arms Agency Nominee
description: President Reagan has decided not to go ahead with the nomination of Robert T. Grey as deputy director of the arms control agency, officials said today.

title: LONGTIME SECURITY AIDE LEADS MX PANEL
description: Brent Scowcroft, the former White House official and Air Force officer appointed today by President Reagan to study alternative ways to base the MX intercontinental missile, has long been thought of primarily as a loyal, self-effacing lieutenant of Henry A. Kissinger.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the closing of ''Annie'' after 2,377 performances gave the musical's ranking incorrectly in a list of longest-running shows and omitted two Broadway plays that had longer runs. ''Annie'' is No. 9. ''Life With Father'' and ''Tobacco Road'' also outranked it.

title: F.D.I.C. CRITICIZES FED ACTION
description: The feud between the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation over the purchase by the Dreyfus Corporation of a small New Jersey bank intensified today as the F.D.I.C. charged that the Federal Reserve had acted improperly in asserting its jurisdiction over the matter.

title: No Headline
description: The Giants' opponents for next season have been determined. They will play home games against Dallas, Washington, Philadelphia, St. Louis, Green Bay, the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego and Seattle.

title: Writer Helps Out
description: The official interpreter traveling with the Soviet all-star hockey team on its six-game series against National Hockey League clubs is also the official Soviet correspondent on the tour, and writes for Tass, the official Soviet press agency. He is Vsevolod V. Kukushkin, a small, plump, owlish-faced man, known by his nickname, Seva, the diminutive form of his first name.

title: LAWYERS SEEK BULGARIAN'S RELEASE
description: The two Italian lawyers representing the Bulgarian airline representative held here since November on suspicion of complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II moved in magistrates' court today for his release.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 4, 1983
description: International The Soviet economy has been hobbled by sloth, absenteeism and drunkenness. In his first major speech, Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet leader, declared war on ''shoddy work, inactivity and irresponsibility.'' Then, he had the Politburo issue a decree encouraging ordinary people to step up the flow of letters exposing idleness, poor management, the squandering of state resources and other ills. Pravda reported an avalanche of letters, including many contrite confessions. (Page A1, Columns 2-4.) Israeli and Lebanese negotiators met for the third time in a week, but were still unable to agree on an agenda for talks. The Lebanese want the talks to result in the withdrawal of all foreign troops from their soil and the Israelis want them to result in a normalization of Israeli-Lebanese links. (A3:1-2.)

title: Roblin Industries
description: Roblin Industries Inc., a specialty steel company in Buffalo, said it was unable to make payments on certain outstanding debentures, and that it may have to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. In an effort to avert a bankruptcy filing, the company said it would offer to exchange $50 principal amount of a new 14 percent convertible subordinated debenture due in 1986 for $50 principal amount of either its 6.5 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1984, or 12 percent subordinated debentures due in 1989.

title: E.P.A. Seeks Counsel For Gorsuch Defense
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said tonight that it would hire two lawyers from the firm of Ropes and Gray in Boston as consultants in the defense of Anne M. Gorsuch, the agency's administrator, who faces a charge of contempt of Congress for refusing to turn over documents.

title: Miami Mayor Forming Panel on Police Policies
description: Mayor Maurice Ferre announced today the formation of a committee, composed mostly of black citizens, to investigate the police policies that led to the fatal shooting of a young black.

title: Birth Risk of Nausea Drug
description: Numerous studies have explored the suggestion that the antinausea drug Bendectin, when taken during early pregnancy, increases the risk of birth defects. The results have been inconsistent, with some studies indicating a possible cause-and-effect relationship between Bendectin use and certain malformations and others showing such no such link.

title: EXIT PERKINS, ENTER PARCELLS FOR THE GIANTS
description: The players said goodbye, the old coach said goodbye, and the new coach said hello. And thus, the day after the Giants ended their season, there was a changing of the guard.

title: 98TH CONGRESS OPENS WITH CALLS FOR BIPARTISAN EFFORT ON ECONOMY
description: The 98th Congress opened for business today, and leaders from both parties called for greater bipartisan cooperation to deal with the country's economic problems.

title: Karl N. Bernstein, 89, Broadway Press Agent
description: Karl N. Bernstein, a theatrical press agent for more than 50 years, died last Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 89 years old.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: DON'T ask anyone in the fashion business about 1982 unless you want t o hear groans. However, while some pessimists are even saying that t hings may not pick up for six months, other people are forging a head with new ideas or new businesses.

title: Ancient Hormone in Yeast
description: A substance that initiates mating between yeast cells has been found so similar to a human reproductive hormone that it can perform a comparable role in mammals.

title: MONEY-MARKET FUNDS' NEW COMPETITORS
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN WILL TRIM BUDGET $30 BILLION FOR '84
description: President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1984 will contain $30 billion in cuts in domestic programs, but Mr. Reagan has yet to make decisions on additional steps to reduce the deficit, Administration officials said today.

title: Bradford National Says President Quit
description: The Bradford National Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, James L. Mann, had resigned. Roy B. Simpson, currently chairman of the executive committee, was named president and chief executive officer.

title: Walker Injured
description: The head trainer for Georgia's football team says he is unsure whether Herschel Walker will require surgery on his left shoulder. ''I just don't know,'' said the trainer, Warren Morris. Walker, the junior tailback and Heisman Trophy winner, missed two plays in the fourth quarter of Saturday night's 27-23 loss to Penn State in the Sugar Bowl after his shoulder ''popped out.''

title: CSX Earnings Fell 8% in '82
description: The CSX Corporation, the diversified transportation and natural resources company in Richmond, reported 1982 earnings fell 8 percent, to $338.4 million, from $367.7 million. Revenues dropped 9.2 percent, to $4.9 billion, from $5.4 billion.

title: News Analysis
description: The recent Government report on the World Airways jumbo jet that skidded into the shallow waters of Boston Harbor a year ago has turned out to be one of the more disquieting accident analyses of recent times.

title: Day of Mourning for Governor Observed in New Hampshire
description: Public and parochial schools and most state buildings were closed today for an official day of mourning as Gov. Hugh Gallen was buried. Hometown friends and family filled a simple wood-and-stone church overlooking the White Mountains here for the funeral mass for Mr. Gallen, 58 years old, who died Wednesday of kidney and liver failure.

title: ETAN PATZ CASE PUTS NEW FOCUS ON A SEXUAL DISORDER, PEDOPHILIA
description: WHEN disturbing new evidence recently revived the case of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who disappeared three years ago near his home in Manhattan, parental fears for the safety of small children were also reawakened.

title: Haselton Brothers' Role In Banking Innovations
description: Two of the most influential innovations in banking can be traced to the Haselton brothers of New England. When Ronald Haselton, 50, president and chief executive officer of the Consumer Savings Bank in Worcester, Mass., developed and put into effect the NOW account, the banking community predicted a disaster.

title: SCHOLARLY BUT REALISTIC
description: When Governor Cuomo called up Justice Richard D. Simons in Rome, N.Y., Sunday night to offer him a seat on the state's highest court, he added a proviso: that he get to Albany by 9:30 the following morning to attend a news conference and to be sworn in. Before Justice Simons had a chance to reply, however, his wife, Penny, assured Mr. Cuomo there would be no problem. ''He'll be there in 10 minutes,'' she exclaimed.

title: Protest of Farm Auction Starts Melee in Colorado
description: Sheriff's deputies used tear gas to disperse more than 200 chanting farmers trying to stop a public farm auction today after the protesters stormed the steps of the courthouse.

title: U.S. SAYS EX-AIDE STOLE ITS COMPUTER DATA
description: A former economist with the Federal Reserve Board who left to work for a brokerage firm was charged today with illegally tapping the Federal Reserve's computer to obtain secret data about the nation's money supply.

title: CIVIL DAMAGE CASE READY FOR JURORS
description: Final arguments were completed today in a $1 million civil damage suit brought by two former antipoverty workers against a rural Kentucky prosecutor, a former United States Senator and two of his aides.

title: Petrolane Inc. Sale
description: Petrolane Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Stater Brothers markets subsidiary to a group of unidentified private investors for about $110 million in cash, notes and securities.

title: Real Estate; Some Brokers Criticized
description: LEASES for commercial space in New York City are getting so complex that even the professionals who negotiate them may not understand them, according to Harry Huberth, president of Huberth & Huberth Inc., a major real estate firm.

title: MOBIL ENDS ACTIVITIES IN LIBYA
description: The Mobil Corporation, ending months of negotiations, announced yesterday that it had terminated its activities in Libya because of ''outstanding differences'' with the Libyan Government.

title: SPUR TO GENERAL AMERICAN BID
description: The General American Oil Company of Texas - seeking to generate interest in its two-week-old offer to pay $50 each for eight million of its own shares - said yesterday that it would proceed with its proposal even if the Mesa Petroleum Company terminated its competing takeover bid for General American at $40 a share.

title: STEELMAKER MIRRORS AUSTRALIA'S HEALTH
description: A cartoon in a business weekly recently showed an overweight steelworker with the initials of Australia's largest concern, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, on his sweatshirt, pleading with a caricature of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser.

title: BRANIFF NEAR ACCORD WITH ITS CREDITORS
description: Braniff International has reached a preliminary agreement with its creditors that would convert $467 million of secured debt into an unsecured claim of $250 million and permit Braniff to go ahead with a venture that would get part of its fleet flying again.

title: China's Premier Cancels $100 Million Zaire Debt
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China, who ended his visit to Zaire by canceling a $100 million debt to China, arrived in Congo today and wished its people ''new victories in their march toward development.''

title: MRS. CUOMO FINDS A HOME IN MANSION
description: Years ago, when her husband was working as a clerk on the State Court of Appeals, Matilda Cuomo used to stand outside the wrought-iron fence of the Governor's Mansion and stare. ''I was in awe,'' she recalled. ''I would stand by the fence and I'd say, 'My gosh, that's where the Governor lives.' ''

title: MILITARY PRIORITIES QUESTIONED
description: A group of 31 Republican members of Congress who voted against President Reagan on production of the MX missile has written to the President urging him to provide ''some clear direction on defense priorities.''

title: Barq Root Beer Chooses Avrett
description: New Orleans-based Barq's Inc., the producer of the root beer that for the last two years has been the country's fastest-growing soft drink, has assigned its national advertising account to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg. The budget is set for $3 million for this year and will probably be $10 million when the brand, now available to about 25 percent of the population, reaches national distribution.

title: Sears Using Needham For a New Campaign
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, preparing for its first consumer-oriented corporate ad campaign, went through all the agencies it currently employs and selected Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, which is in charge of its retail advertising.

title: D'AMATO APPOINTED TO SENATE COMMITTEE ON LABOR AND HEALTH
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, was appointed today to the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over education, labor and health programs.

title: Slalom to Mahre
description: Steve Mahre of the United States won the year's first World Cup slalom race today on an icy, difficult course that caused gate-fault disqualifications for his twin brother, Phil, and the Swedish star Ingemar Stenmark. Steve posted the fastest clean two runs of 49.05 and 49.91 seconds for a total time of 1 minute 38.96 seconds.

title: The Old Times Are Still the Best
description: The chairman of the boards returned to New York yesterday. And 13 years after he set the world indoor record in the 600-yard run, Martin McGrady is not surprised that his time of 1 minute 7.6 seconds has not been broken or even challenged.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Salmon Inspection

title: San Salvador's Army Reported to Kill 7 Rebels
description: Troops killed four guerrillas in repelling an attack on the eastern city of Usulutan and shot three insurgents dead at a leftist rally in a San Salvador shantytown, the authorities said today.

title: WHAT A FAIR TAX CAN DO FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Heublein Closing
description: Heublein Spirits announced tentative plans to close its four-year-old, $26 million production and bottling plant here, a move that would leave 230 people without jobs. Robert R. Weiss, company president, said the decision was based on an examination of the company's production capacities, the economy and the forecast of spirits sales through 1987. Heublein is a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries.

title: CBS GAINS IN RATINGS OF THE MORNING NEWS
description: ''The CBS Morning News,'' which since last March has had a new anchor team and format, is growing in popularity, while NBC's ''Today'' show has suffered a decline. But ABC's ''Good Morning America'' still continues to be the top-rated national morning news and information show.

title: ELDERLY ARE TERMED TARGETS OF FRAUD
description: Confidence artists are preying on the elderly as the prime targets for business and investment frauds that extract more than $5 billion a year, according to a report issued by Representative Claude Pepper, chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging.

title: V.M.S. Realty Inc.
description: V.M.S. Realty Inc., a national real estate investment corporation, said it had acquired the 21-story Western Publishing Building in New York from Olympia & York Developments Ltd. for $101 million. The building, built in 1963, encompasses the entire Third Avenue frontage between 51st and 52d Streets. Olympia & York, a closely held real estate company, bought the building in 1977 as part of a package deal that included eight properties.

title: The Soviet Riddle, and Ours
description: The Soviets, Churchill once said, present ''a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.'' That's not a bad way to describe the Reaganauts' approach to the Soviet Union. They see it as a military giant, but an economic invalid.

title: Italy's Cabinet Is Split Over Increase in Taxes
description: Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani's monthold Government appeared deeply split today after junior coalition partners bitterly attacked tax increases accepted last week at Cabinet level.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Taste of the Big Apple'

title: Advertising; Computer Animation Prospects
description: IF you are planning to make an animated commercial, you might go to one of the traditional animation houses. There are plenty around town. Most are not doing too well.

title: DEFENSE VS. ECONOMY
description: HIS IS the year of reckoning on defense spending for Congress, which faces a faltering economy and large budget deficits. The last Congress only made ''down payments'' on many weapons systems when it recently voted appropriations legislation for the current (1983) fiscal year; the full bills start coming due in appropriations measures that must be passed by the end of fiscal 1983 for fiscal 1984 (which starts Oct. 1).

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TROLLEYS

title: People
description: * James R. Weller and Louise McNamee have been named executive vice presidents at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: Atari Suit Settled
description: A suit filed by Atari against Imagic on Nov. 20 has been settled, the companies said. The suit charged that Imagic's version of the Demon Attack game that is compatible with Mattel Inc. equipment infringed the copyrights of Atari's version of Centuri's Phoenix arcade game, which is to be released soon. Imagic said it would continue to sell it version of the game, but the companies did not disclose settlement terms. Atari is a unit of Warner Communications Inc.

title: Harvester Accord
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it had reached an agreement with the City of Rock Island, Ill., in which the city will raise almost $7 million to help Harvester move its axle and transmission manufacturing operations and 500 jobs to Rock Island from Louisville, Ky. Under the accord, Rock Island will raise about $7 million through general obligation bonds and lend the funds to Harvester to help offset $13 million in relocation costs.

title: 1. A Traveling Office
description: The man or woman who travels on business and whose desk is in a hotel room often misses the small necessities that are taken for granted in the office. The makers of Boyt luggage have a handy idea in their ''Executive Companion,'' a zippered canvas case that is fitted with such things as paper clips, rubber bands, a tape dispenser, a hole puncher for paper, stapler, scissors, ruler, tape measure, business card holder, pen, knife, small flashlight, pencil sharpener and even a can opener and screwdriver. Everything fits neatly into its own comparment. The case is $40 in the fifth-floor luggage department at Macy's.

title: TV Networks to Cover News Session Tonight
description: President Reagan has scheduled his first news conference of the year Wednesday at 8 P.M. Eastern standard time in the East Room of the White House.

title: FOOD TRENDS: WHAT AMERICANS ARE BUYING
description: THE 1982 food year was one of fresh fads and fervid fitness, explored cuisines - Mexican and ''gourmet'' convenience foods'' among them - and expunged demons, namely salt and caffeine. Americans continued their helium-fueled search for lightness in everything from cereals and spaghetti sauce to wine -even that insouciant big guy on the block, Coca Cola, acknowledged that it was time to go on a diet. It was a year when old infatuations faded (nouvelle cuisine conceits) and new phoenixes rose from their crumbs (new American cuisine). It was also a year that spawned everything from the fanciful (spinach bubblegum, kosher tofu) to the fatuous (Paul Newman Salad Dressing).

title: National Medical Gains
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the fiscal second quarter, ended Nov. 30, rose 28 percent, to $21.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from income before nonrecurring credits of $16.8 million, or 36 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier.

title: D. G. Collins Weds Anne Weld Crawford
description: Anne Weld Crawford and Daniel Gerard Collins, professor of law at the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony.

title: Kidnap Suspect Brought to Jersey
description: A man accused of kidnapping a 13-year-old New Jersey boy and taking him to a cottage in Massachusetts used by a homosexual organization was extradited to New Jersey from Vermont today.

title: Union President Is Jailed As Teachers Stage Rally
description: The president of a teachers' union whose members defied a judge's back-to-work order went to jail tonight as about 500 people rallied in support.

title: Corning to Cut 1,000 Employees
description: Corning Glass Works said it was reducing its work force by more than 1,000 employees nationwide as part of a restructuring effort that will produce a $45 million after-tax earnings loss.

title: MITTERRAND INTERVIEW SNAGGED, 2 TV AIDES OUSTED
description: Two state television executives were dismissed today because a 140-foot mobile crane that was to have relayed an interview with President Francois Mitterrand had been sent to trim trees at the far end of France.

title: Charges Dismissed In Seymour Case
description: Disorderly conduct charges against Whitney North Seymour Jr. for political campaigning this summer on the grounds of the Albany County Fair were dismissed today in Guilderland Town Court.

title: Market Place; Stores' Hopes For Quarter
description: THE generally weak Christmas shopping season - which stores had counted on to produce as much as 25 percent of the year's sales and as much as 50 percent of profits - would appear to have dimmed prospects for the retailers' all-important fourth quarter, which ends on Jan. 30.

title: PASTERNAK PROSE RELEASED IN SOVIET
description: A Soviet publishing house has released the first official collection of prose writings by Boris Pasternak, author of the novel ''Dr. Zhivago,'' which is banned in the Soviet Union.

title: A NEW CHIEF IN CALIFORNIA: GEORGE DEUKMEJIAN JR.
description: ''You can't underestimate his ancestry,'' a former law partner of George Deukmejian recently told a reporter who was gathering background information on California's new Governor.

title: Eclipse for Conquistador Cielo
description: Conquistador Cielo, the 3-year-old colt whose domination of thoroughbred racing last year was as dazzling as it was brief, yesterday was named the 1982 horse of the year in the first split decision in the 12-year history of the Eclipse Awards.

title: M'DONALD GILLESPIE
description: McDonald Gillespie, a former executive director and president of the International Division of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc., died of cancer Sunday at his home in Canton Center, Conn.

title: PRESIDENT IS URGED TO BAR CRIME BILL
description: The Justice Department is recommending that President Reagan not sign a crime bill that was passed in the special session of Congress last month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Marilyn Monroe, In Vinyl and in Porcelain

title: NEW FROM I.R.S., 'IT'S TELE-TAX'
description: From the people who brought you form 1040 comes Tele-Tax, a new computerized telephone service intended to help answer questions raised by the 1040 and other tax forms. The Internal Revenue Service recently announced that the service would provide recorded information on 140 topics, including energy tax credits and claims for dependents.

title: Caesars Casino Fined $257,000
description: Caesars Boardwalk Regency Hotel-Casino was fined $257,000 today for breaking state gaming laws to help an industrialist who lost more than $1 million over a weekend in May 1981.

title: WIDE CHANGES AT BRITISH BANK
description: With the international banking system in crisis and with domestic competition intensifying, the National Westminster Bank, the world's ninth largest in terms of assets, is undergoing a changing of the guard.

title: All Leagues Look Alike
description: J ust when you thought it was safe to turn on the television set without being subjected at every hour to men in helmets careering against one another, a new football league made its first public appearance yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have cooked snails, which I love, out of the can with snail butter. I will probably never be faced with the problem of preparing live snails, but I am curious: how do you go about this?

title: THE POP LIFE
description: The big line moved one mile an hour So loud it really hurt. We filled conveyors We met production Back in '55. We were young and sure We Copyright were makin' Thunderbirds. c 1982 Gear Publishing/ASCAP.

title: Mortgage Rate Dips
description: The average interest rate charged for new mortgages slid to 14.26 percent in December, the same level as November 1980, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kickoff by Percy

title: UNLIKELY MOSCOW
description: Like most Americans, I suppose, I tend to think that all the dumbness is on our side. This is why it's so hard for me to believe it was the K.G.B. that engineered the shooting of the Pope.

title: Defense Case At Dirks Trial
description: Raymond L. Dirks, the securities analyst, presented a one-day defense case yesterday in his trial in Manhattan on civil charges of misleading investors in the Cayman Islands Reinsurance Corporation.

title: AFTERMATH OF HOLIDAYS: SIMPLICITY
description: FOR those who love their food rich and calorific, January, not April, is the cruelest month. This is the month of reckoning, the time when recipes calling for heavy cream, chocolate, sugar and perhaps even Champagne, truffles and caviar, are replaced by those calling for broccoli, turnips, pinto beans and oranges. It is the month for retrenching or following new resolutions, for saying ''Enough!'' to superrich dishes. People who forsook their diets at Thanskgiving and never quite returned know that now they have to pay the piper.

title: AUTHORITIES FORESEE LESS COMPLEX DISHES AND BRIGHTER FLAVORS
description: IN 1982 it became acceptable to serve American food on occasions other than Thanksgiving; slender, dark green leaves of mache were required in the well-dressed salad, and piles of tiny quail bones littered the best dinner plates.

title: GEORGE STEVENSON, PSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. George S. Stevenson, a psychiatrist and neurologist and an advocate for the mentally ill, died Sunday at a hospital in Burlington, Vt. He was 90 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly identified the organization for which Frank C. Carlucci, retiring Deputy Secretary of Defense, expects to direct a study of structural problems in the Federal budget. It is the Hudson Institute.

title: TOWARD A PROMPT CURE
description: To the Editor: It is regrettable that an otherwise comprehensive and accurate report on the accomplishments of the 97th Congress (news story Dec. 25) should, with regard to the fiscal problems of Social Security, reiterate the canard that ''both they (the Democrats) and the Republicans were apparently fearful of alienating voters by recommending either a reduction in benefits or an increase in taxes that most agreed were needed.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Syracuse at Providence. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.) Louisiana State at Kentucky. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Michigan State at Iowa.

title: THE FLAVOR OF THE BROWN-BAG WAY OF LIFE
description: DAVID LYON, a marketing specialist nurtured on radish sandwiches, began two years ago to chart what he calls the brown-bag lunch universe. He soon made his first discovery.

title: KODAK INCENTIVES TO CUT PAYROLL SET
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, striving to cut its labor costs, offered retirement and separation incentives today that most of its 93,200 employees would be eligible for at age 55.

title: ADVISE GOES WITH CONSENT
description: THE SENATE this month will begin a new round of confirmation hearings on the second wave of Reagan Administration appointees - those nominated to replace officials who left after the election. If history is any guide, the nominees will be highly controversial and the hearings predictably bland. The Senate seems to believe that if it cannot find evidence that would put a nominee behind bars, it might as well put him in office.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50 **Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A CLASSIC WASHINGTON SQUEEZE PLAY
description: Eugene V. Rostow came to Washington from Yale nearly two years ago determined to shape the Reagan Administration's arms control policies as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Today, he finds himself in the middle of a classic Washington squeeze play and his bureaucratic future is in doubt after the White House reneged on a pledge to seek Senate confirmation for one of his closest aides.

title: BRAKE TESTS ON 1980 G.M. X-CARS SUGGEST A WIDER RECALL IS NEEDED
description: Tens of thousands of 1980 General Motors Xcars now on the road have a hazardous tendency to lock their rear brakes, two Government tests indicate.

title: N.F.L. Schedules; American Conference
description: THE STANDINGS FINAL Monday Night's Game Minnesota 31, Dallas 27. American Conference Points W L T Pct. For Agt. *L.A. Raiders 8 1 0 .889 260 200 *Miami 7 2 0 .778 198 131 *Cincinnati 7 2 0 .778 232 177 *Pittsburgh 6 3 0 .667 204 146 *San Diego 6 3 0 .667 288 221 *Jets 6 3 0 .667 245 166 *New Englnd 5 4 0 .556 143 157 *Cleveland 4 5 0 .444 140 182 Seattle 4 5 0 .444 127 147 Kansas City 3 6 0 .333 175 184 Denver 2 7 0 .222 148 226 Houston 1 8 0 .111 136 245 Baltimore 0 8 1 .056 113 236 National Conference Points W L T Pct. For Agt. *Washington 8 1 0 .889 190 128 *Dallas 6 3 0 .667 226 145 *Green Bay 5 3 1 .611 226 169 *Minnesota 5 4 0 .556 187 198 *Atlanta 5 4 0 .556 183 199 *Tampa Bay 5 4 0 .556 158 178 *St. Louis 5 4 0 .556 135 170 *Detroit 4 5 0 .444 181 176 Giants 4 5 0 .444 164 160 New Orleans 4 5 0 .444 129 160 S. Francisco 3 6 0 .333 209 206 Philadelphia 3 6 0 .333 191 195 Chicago 3 6 0 .333 141 174 L.A. Rams 2 7 0 .222 200 250 * Clinched playoff spot.

title: Landmark At 40 Wall Is Sold;
description: One of the New York financial district's most prominent landmarks, the 70-story tower at 40 Wall Street, has changed hands in a $70 million deal.

title: Congress Tax Panel Names Chief of Staff
description: David H. Brockway, a lawyer, will move into one of Capitol Hill's most important positions in tax law when he becomes chief of staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation this month. He has been deputy chief since 1981.

title: THREE REASONS FOR INCREASED HOME SALES
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1983; The Economy
description: President Reagan was portrayed as standing firm on his budget despite fresh warnings from Senate Republicans that he must ease military spending. If not, according to Senator Paul Laxalt, Mr. Reagan's closest ally in Congress, the nation faces ''terrifying'' deficits. (Page A1.) The Congressional Budget Office and the Federal Reserve are forecasting a slow recovery this year. (D11.)

title: No Headline
description: Chrysler Rates

title: New Allegiance
description: There were no draftniks applauding or booing, because the event was closed to the public. But the format and setting were familiar, and so were the faces at the head table - Peter Hadhazy, Cal Lepore, Carl Marasco and Chet Simmons. Yesterday, however, the four were affiliated with the new United States Football League, not the National Football League, as director of operations, supervisor of officials, player personnel director and commissioner, respectively.

title: Burlington's Counterclaim
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said it had filed a counterclaim seeking an injunction against the sale by the El Paso Company of exploration properties and any other assets.

title: Home Video Is Sold
description: Joel Hartnett, chairman of Media Horizons, has sold Home Video magazine, his only consumer publication, to Viare Publishing, which will merge it into Video Review, which is said to be the most successful magazine in the field. The move will raise the circulation of Video Review with the March issue to 250,000 from 180,000.

title: The Right Salary
description: Yesterday's editorial about Congressional pay misstated the new salary of members of the House of Representatives. It is $69,800.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1983
description: International Violence flared in Tripoli, Lebanon, where thousands of civilians have fled to shelters and essential services have been severely disrupted. Reports from the port city said that competing Moslem militias were bombarding one another with artillery fire in many sections, including residential areas. (Page A1, Column 1.) Britain's ties with Saudi Arabia, a major trading partner, have been jeopardized by London's refusal to permit a meeting with an Arab delegation that included a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization. In retaliation, the Saudis have announced that a proposed trip to Riyadh by the Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, would ''not be convenient'' now. (A8:1-3.)

title: A DIFFERENT VOICE
description: There is a popular theory in the United States that more progress is made by the clash of contending people and forces than anything else, but Mario Cuomo, the new Governor of New York, has come forward with a different voice.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The Central Park Zoo is lonely now, lonely in the way that houses are when everyone has moved out, or the way that some seaside towns are this time of year. The zoo was never particularly crowded in the winter, but now it is in its dying days, a struck stage set of empty cages and musty hay, and the abandonment is palpable.

title: Careers; Business Role for Geography
description: MOST Americans learn the little geography they know in grade school, supplemented by maps at home. Perhaps as tourists they gain some additional knowledge.

title: Recipient of Artificial Heart Leaves His Room for 2d Time
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark has left his room in a wheelchair for a second time to visit briefly with the surgeon who gave him his artificial heart Dec. 2, hospital officials said today.

title: 49ers on Trading Block
description: Neither all-star berths nor Super Bowl rings are a guarantee of security in the National Football League, as four members of the San Francisco 49ers, three of them key figures in last year's championship triumph, may soon be reminded. Sources close to the team were quoted by United Press International yesterday as having said that the leading candidate to be traded was the free safety Dwight Hicks, who is scheduled to play in next month's Pro Bowl.

title: Bridge: A Lively Group Represents 150 Professionals in Game
description: By far the most energetic of the group of professional organizations that has sprung up in the past few years is the Association of Professional Bridge Players, headed by Ron Feldman of Berkeley, Calif. This is intended to be a bridge version of the Professional Golfers Association, and it represents more than 150 players who make their living on the tournament circuit.

title: WNET SETS COST-CUTTING CAMPAIGN
description: WNET/Channel 13 has embarked on a cost-cutting campaign to restore its financial viability without having to move entirely into the commercial television camp. That was the message delivered yesterday by the station's executives at a combination annual meeting and news conference to signal WNET's 20th birthday and to usher in a ''Year of Maturity,'' the year in which the station becomes 21 years old.

title: CHILE IS EXPECTED TO GET $900 MILLION I.M.F. LOAN
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve a $900 million loan to Chile at a meeting of its executive board next Monday, international monetary sources said today.

title: N.Y. Futures Exchange Fills Top Officer Post
description: Lewis J. Horowitz has been named president and chief executive officer of the New York Futures Exchange, becoming its third leader since it was created in March 1979.

title: TV: WIFE TIRES OF MARRIAGE
description: IN the opening scene of ''I Take These Men,'' the television movie on CBS tonight at 9:30, Susan Saint James tells James Murtaugh that she wants a divorce just as he is on the phone making reservations at Neptune's Grotto for their 15th anniversary dinner. He is insisting that they want a table facing the fish tank. It has been their traditional spot. The image also serves as a neat introduction to this curious romantic comedy because much of the action, directed by Larry Peerce, seems to be taking place under water, in a land where voices and gestures are oddly muted.

title: BAKED APPLE DISHES
description: THERE is nothing so humble yet wholesomely delicious as a baked apple. When the aim is a dessert that is sweet yet not too filling and easy to prepare, the center of a cored Golden Delicious -my favorite, although other varieties are equally suitable - is filled with a mixture of diced walnuts, butter and sugar.
