The skin is removed from the top quareter of the apple, which is baked in a 350-degree oven until thoroughly cooked but not too soft. Sometimes honey is substituted for sugar and cinnamon is added.

title: WHY CUOMO IS AGAINST THE ARTHUR KILL PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: AN 'INDIRECT SMEAR' ON SENATOR GLENN
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE RETURNS TO LEBANESE PORT
description: Tripoli, the northern Lebanese port city, was the scene of renewed clashes today between pro-Syrian and anti-Syrian Moslem militiamen. Thousands of civilians have been forced into shelters and essential services have been seriously disrupted.

title: Portugal Bid For Aid Seen
description: Portugal wants a major loan from the International Monetary Fund but cannot negotiate it until a new Government is formed, official sources said today.

title: REALITIES OF BUSINESS BRING AN END TO PUBLIC-INTEREST LAW FIRM
description: In 1978, Ramsey Clark, Melvin Wulf and Alan Levine set about to create a different kind of law firm. Clark, Wulf & Levine, its founders hoped, would represent only those committed to such interests as civil rights and civil liberties, peace, the poor, criminal justice, education and the environment.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: BOB ELLIOTT, the Bob of Bob and Ray, knows just when a bus ride is worth a news bulletin. This is not suprising, since Wally Ballou, the intrepid reporter, is Mr. Elliott's fictional alter ego. Not long ago Mr. Elliott was boarding a southbound M102 bus on Lexington Avenue at 10 in the morning. Scarcely had he placed his foot on the step, when something extraordinary occurred.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Attorney Denies Being Times's Source

title: Russians Set Back Stars, 6-3
description: Vladimir Krutov's second goal of the game capped a five-goal second-period outburst and sparked a Soviet Union all-star team to a 6-3 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Article 142586 -- No Title
description: Three weeks before a Bronx armored-car company was robbed of about $11 million, the police and the F.B.I., acting on information that there would be a theft, set up a stakeout outside the company's headquarters, law-enforcement officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Don King Pardoned
description: Don King, the fight promoter, was granted a pardon yesterday by Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio for a first-degree manslaughter conviction in 1966. Sentenced to one-to-20 years, he was released on parole five years later and obtained a final release from parole supervision in 1972.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TRAGEDY: JAIL PARTS LOVERS
description: She and Neil Aggett had been a couple for the better part of a decade. In that time, they both became doctors, then followed separate paths into welfare and trade union activities on behalf of black industrial workers.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A $75 million out-of-court settlement was announced today in 450 damage suits resulting from a fire that took 85 lives at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas.

title: Saxon Oil Debt
description: The Saxon Oil Company said it had agreed in principle with its creditors' committee and lending banks to pay in full creditors with claims of less than $10,000.

title: Floodwaters in Louisiana Recede in Some Regions
description: Floodwaters began receding in some bayous of Louisiana today, but a sandbag levee broke in Monroe, increasing the flooding in one subdivision.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 5, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

title: 62 VERTABRATES NOW UNDER CONSIDERATION AS IMPERILED SPECIES
description: The Interior Department has identified 62 birds, fish, mammals and other vertebrates that it will probably place on its list of endangered or threatened species, it was announced today.

title: MIXED RACE GROUP BACKS PRETORIA POLITICAL PLAN
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's plan to bring representatives of two nonwhite minorities into the central Government gained important support today as the largest political group among the mixed-race people called colored decided to take part in the new setup.

title: Marino and Elway Top U.S.F.L. Lists
description: John Elway of Stanford and Dan Marino of Pitt, two of the leading quarterbacks in college football last season, were among the players chosen yesterday as the most desired by the United States Football League for its first season, which is scheduled to begin March 6.

title: VILLANOVA AND IONA TRIUMPH
description: Both Iona and Villanova, led by their New York City recruits, continued their winning ways tonight. Villanova, with Stewart Granger, a guard from Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, and Ed Pinckney, a forward who played at Adlai Stevenson in the Bronx, turned back Boston College, 79-72, in the final game of a tripleheader before a crowd of 13,572 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Granger scored 24 points and Pinckney grabbed 13 rebounds

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY SUNS
description: The Knicks were booed as they left the court last night, not only because they were overwhelmed from the start by the Phoenix Suns and lost, 97-85, but also because the 7,766 fans at Madison Square Garden discovered first-hand how one-sided the trade of Maurice Lucas to Phoenix for Len (Truck) Robinson has become.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.O.Smith Corp. said it would recall up to 350 hourly workers in the next few weeks at its Milwaukee automotive division plant.

title: 4 SEVERELY HURT IN CHEMICAL FIRE IN CONNECTICUT
description: Four firefighters were badly burned by a plastic compound early today when a door on a chemical factory blew off in front of them as they battled a fire, officials said.

title: Nakasone Plans a Trip To Seoul for Aid Talks
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit South Korea next week for talks with President Chun Doo Hwan on a multibillion dollar aid agreement for Seoul, the Japanese Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Ladies Lunch
description: We meet at the end of every December in a small Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village. We are eight: women of varying ages, sizes, backgrounds, education and marital status. Several of us have children, most of us were born outside New York and each one of us says she really shouldn't have the pasta - and does.

title: LORD MELBOURNE'S LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBWAY PROJECTS BARRED ON ACCESS FOR THE DISABLED
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday barred renovation of 50 New York City subway stations because the plans do not include elevators for those confined to wheelchairs.

title: DOW UP BY 19.04 TO 1,046.08
description: Buoyed by energy and steel issues, the stock market yesterday very nearly reversed Monday's 19.50-point decline. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 19.04 points to close at 1,046.08, after being up only 7 points at 3 P.M. As a result of the strong final-hour gain, stocks that advanced in price led declines by 1,093 to 497 as volume swelled to 75.5 million shares, from 59.1 million Monday. The New York Stock Exchange Index advanced 1.50, to 81.29.

title: News Analysis
description: The Legal Aid Society's staff lawyers returned to work this week after a 10-week walkout, but the accord that made possible their return failed to settle most of the issues that had been raised when 550 lawyers began their strike on

title: NO DROP IN SAUDI OIL PRICE SEEN
description: The chairman of the Standard Oil Company of California said today that he saw no sign during a meeting here with Saudi Arabia's oil minister that the kingdom was planning to reduce its official oil price of $34 a barrel.

title: Rangers Reacquire Blues' Nedomansky
description: Vaclav Nedomansky, who left a positive impression in his one game as a Ranger at the start of the season, returned to the Rangers yesterday in a three-player trade with the St. Louis Blues. But it is Glen Hanlon, the other player the Rangers received, who could make an even bigger mark.

title: ALL-PRO
description: Following is The Associated Press's all-pro football team, selected by a group of 84 football writers across the country. FIRST TEAM Offense Wide Receivers - Wes Chandler, San Diego Chargers; Dwight Clark, San Francisco 49ers.

title: CONNECTICUT LEGISLATURE FACING GROWING DEFICIT
description: Connecticut's General Assembly will convene Wednesday to inaugurate Gov. William A. O'Neill and to confront a worsening state deficit.

title: Danish Fishing Vessel Intercepted by British
description: Britain today intercepted the first of about 100 Danish trawlers steaming toward its coastal waters in defiance of a new British ban on fishing off its shores.

title: WINE Q&A
description: Q. Is it true that the vineyards of Grands-Echezeaux yield only 3,700 gallons of Burgundy? If so, could you estimate the value of a full case of 1961? I have exhausted my search of rare wholesale listings, as none of this wine seems available on the open market.

title: PETER FALK CONTINUES A CUSTOM OF GIVING TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Peter Falk, the New York City-born screen and television actor, has continued his custom of contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, with a donation of $2,000 to the fund's 71st annual appeal.

title: Analysts Say Slump In Futures May Be Over
description: Although the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices fell a full point yesterday, to 234.8, commodity market analysts say the long price slide for basic farm crops and industrial raw materials may be at an end. Experience has shown that prices of futures contracts lead prices of the actual commodities by perhaps three months, they note.

title: ISLANDERS SNAP SABRES' STREAK
description: Coach Al Arbour, who rarely smiles, was almost beaming tonight after his New York Islanders beat the Buffalo Sabres by 5-2 and bounced back into second place in the Patrick Division.

title: ALAN KARCHER AIMS WIT AT KEAN ADMINISTRATION
description: While Governor Kean and most legislative leaders were closeted with their staffs during recent budget negotiations, Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher would saunter to the snack stand in the corridor of the State House, knowing full well that he would soon be surrounded by reporters.

title: COMMITTEE SELECTION: ART AND SCIENCE
description: With the right enemies, Representative Robert J. Mrazek has no trouble making friends. The freshman lawmaker from Huntington, L. I., was selected Monday for a seat on the prestigious Appropriations Committee, the sort of honor that seldom goes to a 36-year-old first-termer. But last November Mr. Mrazek defeated John LeBoutillier, a sharp-tongued Republican who made a specialty of assailing Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Few Democrats, least of all the Speaker, mourned Mr. LeBoutillier's departure.

title: Addendum
description: * Mal Ochs Associates, a new media research company, at 55 Whittington Road, White Plains.

title: 2 Volvo Dealer Groups Turn to New Agency
description: Rand G. Carnahan Jr., who once worked on the Volvo account at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, then was dealer advertising manager of Volvo of America, is running an ad agency that has just won two Volvo dealer advertising associations.

title: SAUDIS RETALIATE FOR BRITAIN'S STAND ON P.L.O.
description: Britain's political and economic relations with Saudi Arabia, one of its key trading partners, have been jeopardized by a dispute over the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: CUOMO ASKS STUDY OF M.T.A. IN A MOVE FOR MORE CONTROL
description: Governor Cuomo has ordered a special review of the structure of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority with an eye toward giving him more control over the agency, top aides to Mr. Cuomo said today.

title: WARSAW PACT'S LEADERS MEET
description: Leaders of Warsaw Pact nations opened a two-day meeting in Prague today with a discussion of what the Czechoslovak press agency described as ''the struggle for the preservation of peace.''

title: U.S. CONSIDERS CUTS IN NUTRITION PLANS
description: The Office of Management and Budget has tentatively decided to recommend reductions totaling $1.4 billion in domestic food assistance programs such as food stamps and school breakfasts for poor children for the fiscal year 1984.

title: The U.S.O. at Kennedy
description: The U.S.O. at Kennedy International Airport offers information and referral services, travel guidance, light refreshments and a complete nursery for the thousands of service personnel and their families who use the airport each year going to assignments around the country and overseas.

title: Dorsett Runs For 99 Yards And Record
description: Tony Dorsett, who was not supposed to carry the ball on the play, went 99 yards for a touchdown Monday night to set a National Football League record for the longest run from scrimmage, even though he had only nine Dallas Cowboy teammates on the field with him.

title: Massachusetts to End South Africa Investment
description: The Massachusetts Legislature, overriding a veto by Gov. Edward J. King, voted to withdraw all public pension funds invested in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: MY OWN HOBGOBLIN AND HOW IT GREW
description: Last of three articles on getting along when the whole world is against you. By JEAN KERR

title: UNESCO PACT DOESN'T CONCERN 'STOLEN ART'
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentines Report Using Soviet Arms in Falklands
description: Argentine forces used Soviet-built SAM-7 antiaircraft missiles during last year's war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, an official air force publication said today.

title: Falling Short of a Bonus
description: Carl Birdsong, the punter for the St. Louis Cardinals, lost a $5,000 bonus by 7.2 inches. He had an incentive clause in his contract that would have earned him the extra money had he averaged 44 yards during the regular season.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Anixter Brothers Inc.'s $42 million of 8 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003 were priced at par by underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins was named N.F.L. coach of the year in The Associated Press's poll of sportswriters. ... Don Shula, coach of the Miami Dolphins, has named his 23-year-old son, Dave, receiver coach on a permanent basis. Dave starred for Dartmouth and played one year with the Baltimore Colts. ... The Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League signed the running back Delvin Williams, who had two 1,200-yard seasons in the N.F.L.

title: DICK EMERY
description: Dick Emery, one of Britain's most highly paid comedians, died in a London hospital Sunday night, his agent said. He was 63.

title: FINNS' RESOLVE IS QUESTIONED
description: The Atlantic alliance commander, Gen. Bernard Rogers, said in an interview published here today that his command was worried that Finns might not defend their neutrality if the Soviet Union were to use their territory to attack NATO bases in Norway.

title: Saab Expects Sales Gain
description: Saab-Scania today predicted car sales of 90,000 for 1983 after a 17 percent rise last year to 86,500 from 1981's 74,000.

title: UPKEEP OF VALVE RECALLED AT TRIAL
description: The manager of maintenance at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant testified yesterday that no preventive maintenance had been done on a crucial valve that stuck open in the 1979 accident in one reactor there, allowing thousands of gallons of vital cooling water to escape.

title: PLAN $37 MILLION IN CUTS BOARD TELLS CITY SCHOOLS
description: Business managers of the city's 32 community school districts and principals of the 110 high schools were asked yesterday to submit detailed proposals by next Wednesday for cutting expenditures by a total of $37 million, starting in February.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT OPENS 11-DAY U.S. TRIP
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel began an 11-day visit here today as the Reagan Administration showed a degree of skittishness about the timing of his tour and its potential political impact in Israel.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ABF Energy Corp. has appointed to its board John Drisdale, former executive vice president of operations, Grace Petroleum Corp., a subsidiary of W.R. Grace, and Colin Evans, president of Kaiser Oil (U.S.) Ltd.

title: Kuwait Plans Legal Action
description: The Government has decided to begin legal proceedings against 12 Kuwaitis, including a member of Parliament, following a multibillion-dollar stock market crisis in the Persian Gulf state in July, official sources said today.

title: DOLE HOLDS MEETING TO SEEK A SOCIAL SECURITY CONSENSUS
description: In an attempt to seize the leadership on the Social Security issue and produce a bipartisan consensus, Senator Bob Dole met privately today with two Democrats to discuss how to restore the Social Security system to financial health.

title: CANADIANS DEBATE CATHOLIC CRITICISM
description: A group of Roman Catholic bishops has sharply criticized Canadian economic policies as aspects of a morally offensive capitalism that subordinates the needs of the unemployed and working poor to the quest for profits and investment capital.

title: RIVERSIDE MARKS 17 YEARS OF DANCE
description: DURING the dance explosion of the 1970's, groups of every description were supported by the Federal Government, helped to grow and travel to every corner of the country to perform for brand new audiences. But times are leaner and harder now. The old Dance Touring Program of the National Endowment for the Arts, which spread dance beyond the big cities, is no more. In its place is a system of financial support that does not require sponsors to present a quota of smaller, less-established companies.

title: BRITISH TIE TO ATLANTA COMPANY
description: The Plessey Company, a leading British electronics concern, plans to buy up to 30 percent of Scientific-Atlanta Inc. as part of an arrangement that will lead to broad cooperation between the two companies, they announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Corporate Earnings listing in Business Day yesterday incorrectly headlined the table that appeared between General Microwave and Microsemiconductor Corporation. The figures were for Oxford Industries, not the Health-Chem Corporation.

title: U.S.F.L.
description: The following players were rated as leading professional football prospects by Carl Marasco, personnel director of the United States Football League, and Jerry Jones, an independent evaluator of prospects. Before the U.S.F.L. draft began yesterday, each team selected a total of 26 players from the five colleges it had chosen within its territory. Those selections, were exempt from the drafting process are are designated below by (T). A draft choice is designated by the round of selection in parentheses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I knew this job was thankless, the incumbent would be beaten around the ears, if not flayed, and therefore, for a Yankee Puritan, like me, it was irresistible.'' - Eugene V. Rostow. (B8:6.)

title: WINE TALK
description: THE American wine boom has been fueled largely by the inexpensive so-called jug wines that are accessible to virtually all consumers. They tend to be uncomplicated, resistant to spoilage and pleasanttasting, although rarely great.

title: Quit the Bay of Piglets
description: When Congress asked why the C.I.A. is waging a secret war to overthrow the leftist regime in Nicaragua, the Administration said it isn't; America is only trying to harass the Sandinist junta, not overthrow it. This spongy distinction failed to impress the legislators. At the bipartisan urging of its intelligence committees, Congress has now informed President Reagan that he may not use American arms or manpower against Nicaragua.

title: Klecko to Test Knee Today
description: This is the day of Joe Klecko's big test. When the Jets resume practice at their Hofstra University training base in Hempstead, L.I., the right knee that was severely injured in the second game of the season will be tested in a contact drill for the first time since then. If the knee survives this and other contact work this week, Klecko will probably play Sunday at Cincinnati in the first round of the playoffs.

title: SOMETHING QUITE DIFFERENT AT LUNCHTIME
description: Allan Ripp is a New York writer who spends most of his lunch hours running six miles in Central Park.

title: Coleco Income Climbs Sharply
description: Coleco Industries, a leading maker of games and toys, said yesterday that its fourth quarter turned out better than anticipated and thus earnings for the year were ''well in excess of five times'' 1981's net income of $7.7 million, or $1.01 a share. The company also said that 1982 sales were about $500 million, compared with $178 million in 1981.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Daily Forward Changing to a Weekly

title: SCREEN: HARD VIEW OF AMERICA
description: JOAN HARVEY'S ''America: From Hitler to MX'' is an earnest but disorganized documentary that's quite literally all over the map, as Miss Harvey explores far more issues than she can manage. Her theory, largely unsupported here, postulates a connection between everything from the involvement of American corporations in making munitions for Germany during World War II to the ill effects on automobile workers of lead-based paint. These and various other points are illustrated with copious interviews and with newspaper clippings, which slow the film down considerably. It's not easy to read clippings during the course of any film, let alone one that's information-packed and sketchy, too.

title: Benchmark for New York
description: Governor Cuomo's first appointment to the New York Court of Appeals is a personal compliment to the court - the state's highest and one he has revered since he clerked there as a young lawyer. His choice, Richard Simons of Rome, is a jurist of proven ability and integrity.

title: Wrigley Gum Price Up
description: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company today raised the price of chewing gum. Six-pack units went up 7 cents, to 69 cents, and 10-pack units went up 13 cents, to 99 cents.

title: AGNEW GIVES $268,482 CHECK TO MARYLAND IN GRAFT LAWSUIT
description: A bribery suit against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew that began six years ago as a student law project ended today with payment of nearly $270,000 to the Maryland treasury.

title: CONSENSUS ON SLOW RECOVERY
description: The Congressional Budget Office and the Federal Reserve have joined top advisers in the Administration in forecasting a slow economic recovery this year, Government officials said today. The Budget Office is also predicting that the unemployment rate, currently about 10.8 percent, will be still be above 10 percent at the end of 1983 and as high as 9.5 percent on Election Day in 1984, they said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard CUSTOMS AND CHARACTERS. By Peter Quennell. Illustrated. 176 pages. Little, Brown. $16.50.

title: Night for Football
description: Last year, when the Clemson-Nebraska Orange Bowl game settled the No. 1 spot in college football, the Orange Bowl beat the Sugar Bowl (Pittsburgh-Georgia) by 18.0 to 11.8 in the Nielsen television ratings.

title: Playoff Schedule
description: The schedule for the first round of the N ational Football League playoffs. The f igure in parentheses after the name of e ach team is that team's seeding.

title: No Headline
description: SYRIA SAID TO BUILD NEW MISSILE BASES

title: BRZEZINSKI BELIEVES SOVIET WAS INVOLVED IN SHOOTING OF POPE
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, the White House national security adviser during the Carter Administration, said today that he believed the Soviet Union was involved in the shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: Executive Named At Apple Computer
description: E. Floyd Kvamme, who resigned last month as head of the National Semiconductor Corporation's computer subsidiary, has been named executive vice president of marketing and sales for Apple Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif.

title: Watson Is Signed
description: Bob Watson, the Atlanta Braves' part-time first baseman and top pinch-hitter, will play another season.

title: SUSAN STEIN SHIVA
description: Susan Stein Shiva, president of Ports of Call, travel consultants to Saks Fifth Avenue, died at her Manhattan home of cancer Monday evening. She was 46 years old.

title: BATTLING THE COMPUTER PIRATES
description: When the personal computer boom began two years ago, the leading software manufacturers, mindful of how piracy had drained profits from the record and videotape industries, declared war on entrepreneurs who illegally copied computer programs.

title: NEW CRISIS KNOCKS LISBON OFF COURSE
description: In the streets of Lisbon and towns and villages across the country, every available inch of wall space is plastered with peeling political posters and faded slogans.

title: The Standings; FINAL; MONDAY NIGHT'S GAME Minnesota 31, Dallas 27.; AMERICAN CONFERENCE
description: Points W HOLTPct.ForAgt. *L.A. Raiders 8 1 0 .889 HO260200 *Miami 7 2 0 HO .778198131 *Cincinnati 7 2 0 . 778232177 *Pittsburgh 6 3 0 . 667204146 *San Diego 6 3 0 .667 288221 *Jets 6 3 0 O .667245166 *New Englnd 5 4 0 .556 O143157 *Cleveland 4 5 0 *.444140182 Buffalo 4 5 0 .444150154 Seattle 4 5 0 .444127147 Kansas City 3 6 0 .333 175184 Denver 2 7 0 HO .222148226 Houston 1 8 0 .111136245 Baltimore 0 8 1 O .056113236 NATIONAL CONFERENCE Points W HOLTPct.ForAgt. *Washington 8 1 0 . 889190128 *Dallas 6 3 0 .667226145 *Green Bay 5 3 1 .611 HO226169 *Minnesota 5 4 0 *.556187198 *Atlanta 5 4 0 .556183199 *Tampa Bay 5 4 0 .556 HO158178 *St. Louis 5 4 0 .556 135170 *Detroit 4 5 0 .444181176 Giants 4 5 0 HO .444164160 New Orleans 4 5 0 .444 HO129160 S. title: Thrift Units Get 21 Billion
description: The new high-interest accounts designed to help banks and thrift institutions compete with money market mutual funds attracted an estimated $21.8 billion to savings and loan associations in the first week they were offered, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: No Headline
description: Malavasi Is Ousted By Rams

title: THE SOCIAL SECURITY CRISIS: LEGACY OF HOPEFUL GUESSES
description: In December 1977, President Carter gathered two dozen members of Congress in the Indian Treaty Room of the Executive Office Building for the signing of the Social Security Reform Act. There, before a battery of television cameras, Mr. Carter said that the additional revenue the act was providing would guarantee ''that from 1980 through 2030, the Social Security System will be sound.''

title: BENJAMIN ROSENTHAL, CONGRESSMAN FROM QUEENS FOR 2 DECADES, DIES
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Queens, a leading liberal Democrat who was elected to his 11th term in November, died today of cancer at Georgetown University Hospital.

title: BALLET: A JOFFREY REVIVAL
description: BALLETS can change in strange ways. Sometimes, of course, choreographers will change them deliberately. But even when no actual alterations are made, ballets can look different because the passage of time leads us to see them with fresh eyes. Two works on the Joffrey Ballet's Sunday afternoon program at the City Center could be cited as examples of such mysterious changes.

title: MET MUSEUM TO EXHIBIT LIECHTENSTEIN COLLECTION
description: The private collection of the Princes of Liechtenstein, an ancestral holding second to that of the kings and queens of England, is to be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the fall of 1985. This will be the first time in nearly 40 years that more than a small part of the collection has been on public view, and the exhibition will be on a scale comparable to that of the imminent Metropolitan show of treasures from the Vatican Museums.

title: TREASURY PRICES UNCHANGED
description: A late-afternoon decline in the Federal funds rate, the rate on overnight loans between banks, touched off a mild rally in the Government securities market yesterday. As a result, prices finished virtually unchanged for the day in moderate trading after showing earlier losses.

title: Soviet Wins Title
description: The Soviet Union defeated Sweden, 5-1, today and clinched the world junior hockey championship with a record of seven victories in seven games. Czechoslovakia defeated Finland, 5-3, to place second.

title: SHUTTLE CREW READY, BUT LIFTOFF DATE IS UNCERTAIN
description: The astronauts who are to fly the first mission of the new space shuttle Challenger said yesterday that they were ready to go, but space agency officials are not sure when their spaceship will be ready.

title:
Economic Scene;
Administration Report Card
description: THE Reagan Administration rolled into Washington two years ago pledged to a few simple propositions: cut tax rates, reduce government's role in the economy, keep money growth on a stable, noninflationary course and lift some of the burden of Federal regulation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most interesting winter dishes is that North African specialty couscous, which is occasionally found on menus in New York restaurants and is abundantly available in Paris.

title: Florida and Rhode Island Have Frugal Inaugurals
description: By United Press International Two Democratic Governors, Bob Graham of Florida and J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island, began new terms yesterday with ''no frills'' inaugurals that reflected the hard economic times their states face.

title: NETS WIN 6th STRAIGHT
description: The confidence is building for the Nets. No matter who they're playing, no matter how far behind they may fall, they still appear as if things are going their way.

title: Gerulaitis to Face Noah
description: Vitas Gerulaitis has drawn Yannick Noah, and Mats Wilander will play Jose-Luis Clerc in opening-round matches of the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament starting Jan. 18 at Madison Square Garden. The two other opening matches in the 12-player single-elimination event pit Johan Kriek against Steve Denton and Andres Gomez against Jose Higueras.

title: Soccer Travels
description: If the United States is ever to emerge as an international soccer power, the impetus must come from its young players, or so the word goes. Last night, 16 American teen-agers and their coaches, Angus McAlpine and Manfred Schellscheidt, left on a flight for Leningrad to play for the next 10 days in a six-team, under-18 international tournament.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WINTER'S cold winds, ice and snow are a challenge to those who want to stay in shape the year round. But it's a challenge that can be met, if you're willing to make adjustments in your routine for the sake of safety and comfort, and if you line up an indoor alternative for weather that is truly inclement.

title: Alcoa Sees Loss
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it expected a loss for the fourth quarter of 1982, despite a net gain of $13 million from a real estate sale.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 6, 1983; The Economy
description: The auto industry closed out its worst sales year in almost two decades, recording total car sales of 7.9 million. But in the final 10 days of the year, sales rose 28.5 percent for the Big Three. Most executives remained cautious in discussing the outlook for 1983. (Page D1.) Ford and Chrysler are asking banks to help finance their cut-rate financing programs for buyers of new cars. (D4.)

title: Funeral for Rosenthal Today
description: Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M. today for Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens. Mr. Rosenthal, 59 years old, who served 20 years in Congress, died of cancer Tuesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. The funeral will be at the Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills, 71-25 Main Street, Queens.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DUSK TO DAWN

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY SET FOR VOTE ON PLANT SAFETY GOALS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today gave preliminary approval to a safety goal policy for commercial reactors, and the commissioners said several existing plants did not meet the goals.

title: DOW OFF 1.19 AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday in accelerated trading, with some of the depressed domestic energy issues making the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session down 1.19 points, at 1,044.89, after climbing 19.04 points on Tuesday. In the overall market, however, stocks that advanced on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that declined by 1,049 to 554.

title: A Champion Is Accused
description: The way the Philadelphia police were telling it, the car ran a red light early yesterday morning and then led officers on a high-speed chase that covered 25 blocks before they pulled the driver over and found an unloaded .45-caliber pistol at his feet. That's not the way the driver was telling it.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 6, 1983
description: International A nuclear-powered Soviet satellite is apparently in trouble and will probably crash to earth this month, the Pentagon announced. It said the reconnaissance satellite was believed to contain about 100 pounds of enriched uranium and was similar to a Cosmos satellite that crashed in an uninhabited area of northern Canada in 1978, causing minor radiation contamination. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) A nonaggression pact would be signed by the Warsaw Pact members if the NATO countries pledged not to use force against the Soviet bloc nations, they announced at the end of a meeting in Prague. Western diplomats said they believed the proposal had no more chance of being accepted than a similar offer that NATO rejected in 1958 as meaningless. (A3:1-3.)

title: STEWART M. MONCHIK
description: Stewart M. Monchik, president of the Monchik-Weber Corporation, computer systems consultants, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Cos Cob, Conn. He had been suffering from multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow.

title: RESTORING THE LOOK OF GOLD
description: For sheer splendor, furniture and frames decorated with real gold are without equal. But restoring gold-leaf decoration is best left to craftsmen at museums and shops who specialize in it. The technique is time-consuming and materials and equipment are expensive. However, to repair decorative gold paint and imitation gold leaf, less costly substitutes can be used.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN electrical wall outlets are not exactly where needed, the only satisfactory permanent solution is to install additional ones that are more convenient. Adding outlets to an existing circuit does not increase that circuit's capacity, but it will provide added convenience and eliminate the need for multiple-outlet adapter plugs.

title: NEW YORK URGED TO REFORM ITS DISCIPLINING OF LAWYERS
description: A special committee of the American Bar Association has recommended broad changes in the way New York State disciplines its lawyers. It concluded that the present mechanism was ill-coordinated and poorly financed.

title: DEVILS ARE TIED BY LEAFS
description: In a game between the teams at the bottom of the National Hockey League, the New Jersey Devils relinquished a two-goal lead twice against the Toronto Maple Leafs and settled for a 4-4 tie tonight before a crowd of 9,330 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Both teams have 24 points, the fewest in the league.

title: CHINA STILL FIGHTING AN OLD ABUSE: WOMEN FOR SALE
description: The old practice of selling young women as brides or mistresses, often against their will, still persists in parts of rural China, despite determined efforts by the authorities to stop it.

title: Market Place; The Pluses At Warner
description: AFTER Warner Communications made its unexpected announcement last month that it expected a severe slump in its fourth-quarter earnings because of sluggish sales of video games made by its Atari subsidiary, analysts who championed Warner during its high-flying days hurriedly scratched it off their recommended lists. Warner shares were sent reeling.

title: Chrysler's Canada Aid in Doubt
description: The Chrysler Corporation is drafting a letter to the Canadian Government proposing what should be done with a $255 million financial aid package now that the auto maker no longer plans to build diesel engines in a Windsor, Ontario, plant, a company spokesman said. Walter McCall said he had ''no idea'' when the letter would be completed and would not elaborate on the contents.

title: Chance of a Lifetime
description: He may have made more money as an offensive lineman with the Miami Dolphins, but to Larry Little, the $25,000-a-year job as head coach of Bethune Cookman College in Daytona Beach, Fla., seemed like the chance of a lifetime. ''I spent 14 years in the N.F.L. preparing myself for this day,'' said Little, a Bethune Cookman alumnus, whose appointment as the school's coach was announced Tuesday. Little, a six-time all-pro player, has been athletic director at Edison High School in Miami since his retirement from the Dolphins in 1980.

title: GRAMM QUITS HOUSE FOR G.O.P. RACE
description: Two days after his fellow Democrats stripped him of his seat on the House Budget Committee, Representative Phil Gramm of Texas resigned from Congress today and announced that he would run for re-election as a Republican.

title: ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: ''My name is Susan Wu,'' began the letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I am a student in the fourth grade in P.S. 206, Brooklyn. My class and I were talking about how giving is much better than getting.''

title: New Chinese Truck
description: A Chinese plant is making a five-ton truck that uses 27 percent less fuel than old models, the official New China News Agency reported today. The agency said the Changchun No.1 motor vehicle plant in northeast China is making a truck with a 115-horsepower engine that can carry one ton for 62 miles on 1.4 gallons of oil.

title: HARD TIMES MOUNT FOR SPOKANE TRIBE
description: Unemployment has reached nearly 75 percent on the Spokane Indian Reservation near here, and tribal officials said they were worried that people could go hungry.

title: Wilson Aide Is Sentenced
description: A Federal District judge Tuesday sentenced Douglas Schlacter, an aide to Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, to six months in jail and three years probation and fined him $10,000 for helping Mr. Wilson smuggle weapons to Libya.

title: Superior Oil's Spending to Drop
description: The Superior Oil Company announced plans to spend $1.2 billion in 1983 for capital outlays and exploration, down from $1.3 billion in 1982.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS ASK DISMISSAL OF MIAMI POLICE CHIEF IN SHOOTING
description: Civil rights leaders called on Miami officials today to dismiss Police Chief Kenneth Harms, who said that ''hoodlums'' were responsible for two days of rioting that erupted last week after an officer shot and killed a black man.

title: Against Tipping
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Peter Kerr's report (''Holiday Tipping: Some Guidelines About Amounts,'' Dec. 16) may prove helpful for those caught up in the spoils and toils of this servant-master compulsive custom.

title: Ex-Timex Executive Gets Sealectro Position
description: Nicholas M. Mihalas, former president and chief operating officer of Timex Inc., has been named to similar posts at the Sealectro Corporation. Mr. Mihalas, 45, succeeds William Silberstein, who relinquishes the two posts but remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Missile Impossible
description: Looking back over ten years of planning for the MX missile, it would appear that the last thing needed is another study. A mere 34 possibilities for basing it have already been evaluated. Yet in truth what is needed is more study, not less. Congress was prudent to order a broad new Presidential report; Mr. Reagan has now assigned this mission to another study commission, but given it too little time.

title: World Bank Cuts Rate
description: The World Bank said today that it was reducing to 10.97 percent, from 11.43 percent, the interest rate it charges on new loans to developing countries. The new rate, which is adjusted every six months, will apply to loans made between now and next June 30.

title: NO CRIMINALITY SEEN IN CAMPAIGN TACTICS USED IN QUEENS RACE
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday that there was no basis for criminal prosecution in the tactics used in John F. Duane's successful campaign for the Assembly in Queens last fall.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, the Going Out Guide yesterday omitted the first name of a pipe player who appeared at Christ Church United Methodist yesterday and who will perform tonight at 8 at the American Irish Historical Society, Fifth Avenue and 81st Street. He is Bill Ochs.

title: William Stirling Dead; Top British Commando
description: Lieut. Col. William Stirling, who worked with his brother David in organizing Britain's Special Air Service Regiment in World War II, died Sunday, the King Edward VII Hospital for Officers reported. He was 71 years old.

title: Delay Disclosed by Pentagon In Its Cruise Missile Program
description: The Defense Department has acknowledged that adjustments in its troubled Tomahawk cruise missile program will cause delays in the operation of two models and increase the cost.

title: Phipps Steps Down
description: Ogden Mills (Dinny) Phipps announced his resignation yesterday as the chairman of the New York Racing Association, a post he has held for six and a half years.

title: WHY 52 UNION LEADERS ARE ON TRIAL IN TURKEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Upturn Seen By Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's economy is expected to achieve a growth rate of 6 percent in the next fiscal year, the British colony's financial secretary, John Bremridge, said today,

title: Economics Lab To Shed Operation
description: Economics Laboratory Inc. said it would discontinue its Apollo mining and utility operations, acquired in 1980, because they had not met objectives.

title: AGED COUPLE'S WANDERINGS END AFTER 9 DAYS
description: An elderly farm couple who apparently got lost in their car and wandered for nine days and possibly 4,000 miles along back roads were found today, unharmed but disoriented.

title: WARRANT ISSUED FOR SUSPECT IN NEW YEAR'S BOMBINGS
description: A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of a man in connection with last Friday's bombings in lower Manhattan and in Brooklyn that seriously injured three police officers.

title: Lawrence Williams, Author; Was Novelist and Playwright
description: Lawrence Williams, a novelist and playwright, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn.

title: 4 COUNTRIES TO DISCUSS CENTRAL AMERICA STRIFE
description: The Foreign Ministers of Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama are to meet this weekend in Panama to discuss possible new regional initiatives to promote peace in Central America, it was announced here today.

title: Yankees Name McHale
description: George Steinbrenner, principal owner of the Yankees, has named Eugene McHale the team's new president, succeeding Lou Saban, and David Weidler the club's administrative vice president, succeeding McHale. McHale, 44 years old, is the fourth president in the 10 years Steinbrenner has operated the Yankees. Weidler, 42, joined the Yankees in 1969 as manager of accounting.

title: Dance Film Series
description: Dance will be the subject of a Saturday afternoon film series to be presented at Theater of the Open Eye, sponsor of the program with Dance Films Association Inc. The series will open on Saturday with ''Films about Pioneers of Modern Dance,'' to be followed by an illustrated talk by Julia Levien on ''Isadora Duncan and the Transition to Modern Dance.''

title: TOKYO IS CLOSE TO A BIG AID PACT WITH SEOUL
description: Japan will conclude a multibillion dollar aid agreement with South Korea in time for a visit to Seoul next week by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, according to the Japanese Foreign Ministry.

title: ON THE CONTROL OF HUMAN GENETIC ENGINEERING
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Privilege Put to Good Use

title: Two Jazz Players, On Piano and Vibes
description: The jazz duo of Dave Samuels on vibes and Andy Laverne on piano, which is playing at Village West through Sunday, at times suggests a mini-Modern Jazz Quartet. The parallel of piano and vibes as the lead instruments is part of the connection, and some of Mr. Samuels's phrasing is occasionally reminiscent of the MJQ's Milt Jackson.

title: STUDENTS PICKET LAW COURSE IN RIGHTS PROTEST AT HARVARD
description: Students today picketed the opening session of a course at Harvard Law School taught by two prominent civil rights lawyers, one black and one white.

title: Richmond Unit In Default
description: The Richmond Tank Car Company, a Houston-based railroad car maker, said that its Richmond Leasing Company subsidiary had defaulted on payments owed under several agreements with banks and other institutional lenders, and that further defaults of other financial agreements were expected. Richmond declined to disclose the amount of the debt in question.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: TALE OF A HOUSE AND PRICES IT BROUGHT
description: At first glance, the house at 4902 Palisade Lane seems no different from the many pseudo-Federal brick homes that dot northwest Washington.

title: NUCLEAR-POWERED SOVIET SATELLITE IS EXPECTED TO CRASH THIS MONTH
description: The United States said today that a nuclearpowered Soviet reconnaissance satellite had apparently run into problems and would probably crash somewhere on the earth's surface before the end of the month.

title: POLL SHOWS A MARRIED SINGLE GAP IN LAST ELECTION
description: During and after last fall's election campaign, Republicans expressed strong fears that the increasingly Democratic leanings of women were creating a ''gender gap'' that threatened their party. But an extended analysis of the New York Times/CBS News Poll of actual voters on Election Day showed that the Republicans had another serious problem: the differences in voting preference between single and married voters.

title: 'Killer Frogs'
description: Texas Christian University's school nickname has always been the Horned Frogs. But around the Fort Worth campus these days, the nickname most identified with the school's basketball team is not Horned Frogs but ''Killer Frogs.''

title: WHAT CHILDREN 'SEE' WHEN WATCHING TV
description: HOW do children match up the world they live in with the one they see on television? Do they think that Superman is an actual person? Will they watch a cartoon character hit his animated friend on the head with a baseball bat and then try it on their playmates?

title: Danish Trawlers Make Contact With British
description: Danish ships trawling for fish in restricted North Sea zones reported their first contacts with British inspection ships today.

title: Newly Created Post At Lloyd's Is Filled
description: Ian Hay Davison, a 51-year-old senior partner in Arthur Andersen & Company, will become Lloyd's of London's first independent chief executive on Feb. 1. The appointment was made yesterday at the first meeting of the new 27-member governing council that has taken over responsibility for the three-century-old insurance market from a 16-member committee composed entirely of brokers and underwriters.

title: Soviet Dissident Says K.G.B.  Is Threatening to Arrest Him
description: Georgi Vladimov, the nonconformist writer and dissident, said today that he had been threatened with arrest unless he renounced his ''anti-Soviet activities'' and agreed to report on all his contacts with foreigners.

title: DISEASE STIRS FEAR ON BLOOD SUPPLY
description: Health officials trying to find ways to stop a deadly immune deficiency say they are afraid that whatever causes the mysterious illness might contaminate supplies of blood for transfusions.

title: Vatican Bank Inquiry Follows Jewish Protest
description: The Vatican has asked a Jewish research group for a copy of a 1946 United States Army report on a Nazi bank once headed by a man who was recently appointed to an advisory board to the Vatican Bank.

title: Jozef Glemp
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, 54 years old, was Pope John Paul's choice to lead the Roman Catholic Church in Poland at a time of civil unrest. Since being named to the post in July of 1981, Archbishop Glemp has sought to be a link between Catholics in Poland and the Polish-born Pope. His has been a moderate voice in the nation, steering a path between the military regime and the more radical segments of the labor union movement.

title: WOMAN IS FOUND SLAIN IN HER CAR IN MORRIS COUNTY
description: TROY HILLS, N.J., Jan. 5. - A 28-year-old woman was found shot to death in her car at a shopping center here this afternoon, the third woman found slain in the Morris County area in the last six weeks.

title: CITY BUILDINGS CHIEF RESIGNS TO ASSIST TIMES SQ. PROJECT
description: Irwin Fruchtman, New York City's Building Commissioner for the last four years, has resigned to become a vice president of the citystate agency seeking to redevelop the Times Square area, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Avon Sets Campaign To Recruit Saleswomen
description: Not many recruiters outside of the armed forces think of network television as an advertising medium. But the management of Avon Products not only has thought of it but will also break a four-week push on Monday that will be backed by a national print campaign bolstered by pop-up coupons and an 800 phone number.

title: KEY PROMOTION IS EXPECTED AT ABC
description: Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president of the American Broadcasting Companies, is to be appointed president of the corporation on Monday, senior executives said last night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Place for the Living, Too

title: Test Firing of MX Postponed
description: The first test firing of the MX intercontinental missile has been postponed until spring and the exact launching date has been classified, Air Force officials reported Tuesday. Maj. Ron Peck, a spokesman for the Western Space and Missile Center at this base on the central California coast, said the Congressional decision to deny funds for production of the MX forced a rescheduling of the Jan. 27 test date until March or April.

title: TRANSIT POST NOMINEE
description: Elizabeth Dole's nomination to be Secretary of Transportation is expected to alleviate what some White House officials have conceded privately to be an awkward situation.

title: Letter: On Consumer Debtors; The Politics of Bankruptcy Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Prisoners Are Housed In the Former U.S. Embassy
description: Iranian prisoners are being held in the former United States Embassy in Teheran because the country's jails are overcrowded, Amnesty International said in a report published today in London.

title: BRIEFING
description: Arab Client Dropped

title: FRANCE OUTLAWS A CORSICAN GROUP
description: The French Government responded today to a new series of terrorist attacks in Corsica by outlawing a separatist group that has said it was responsible for about 370 of the 800 armed raids and bombings on the Mediterranean island in 1982.

title: CRACKED PLANT VALVE FORCES CITY TO DUMP RAW WASTE IN RIVERS
description: A cracked valve at one of New York City's largest sewage treatment plants is forcing the city to pump 300 million gallons of raw sewage a day into the Harlem, Hudson and East Rivers until repairs can be made, city officials said yesterday.

title: Parents and Friends
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was deeply moved by Norma Rosen's evocation of friendship's role in maintaining parental sanity in the ''Hers'' column of Dec. 16. Sharing the exigencies of that awesome responsibility - the raising of another human being - with someone whose ego is not directly involved in the outcome mediates guilt and intensifies joy. For me friends have been a lifeline - extricating me from the isolation of single parenthood without extended family involvement.

title: U.S. Military Team Meets Nicaraguan Army Chiefs
description: A four-man United States military delegation met today with the leaders of the Nicaraguan Army, military sources here said.

title: Lure of New League
description: The new United States Football League drew three more former National Football League players out of retirement. Lydell Mitchell, a 33-year-old former Penn State back who spent most of his eight-year N.F.L. career with the Baltimore Colts, signed a contract with the Philadelphia Stars.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brass-Craft Manufacturing Co., Detroit, has named Larry J. LaBo, corporate controller, to the additional post of corporate treasurer.

title: PRESIDENT CHOOSES MRS. DOLE TO HEAD TRANSPORT AGENCY
description: President Reagan announced tonight that he was nominating Elizabeth H. Dole, a White House assistant for liaison with special interest groups, to serve as Secretary of Transportation. If confirmed by the Senate, Mrs. Dole would become the first woman to head a Cabinet agency in the Reagan Administration.

title: APARTMENT LOBBIES: CHRONICLE OF TASTE
description: THERE'S some difference in the meaning of the word ''luxury'' - as in ''luxury'' apartments - when used by those who build them and those who live in them. Some builders believe that any building with an elevator is a luxury apartment. Some tenants think luxury begins with a wood-burning fireplace.

title: SURVEY FINDS HISPANIC CATHOLICS FOLLOW OWN RULES
description: Hispanic people in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York strongly profess central Christian beliefs and at the same time engage in religious practices that often differ markedly from the habits and customs of previous waves of Catholic immigrants, according to a study released yesterday by the archdiocese.

title: 18 NEW CARDINALS NAMED BY PONTIFF
description: Pope John Paul II named 18 new cardinals today, among them Jozef Glemp, the Pontiff's successor as Primate of Poland, and Joseph I. Bernardin, the Archbishop of Chicago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Torah Information

title: Senators Request New Study To Assess Love Canal Safety
description: New York's United States Senators have requested a new Federal study to determine if the Love Canal area is now safe for residents.

title: CITY BALLET: ROBBINS'S 'MOTHER GOOSE'
description: HAVING concluded its run of ''The Nutcracker,'' the New York City Ballet returned to repertory on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. But even though the company no longer dwells in the land of the Sugar Plum Fairy, it has not left magic behind it. Tuesday's program had lots of magic. Its opening ballet even concerned fairy tales.

title: UNFINISHED FURNITURE GROWS IN POPULARITY
description: ONCE almost on a par with orange crates, unfinished furniture came only in plain pine or wood-veneered chip board, was slapped with paint and relegated to a life of storage duty. Cheap, yes, but nothing to brag about.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I live in a 20-year-old house that has redwood on the outside. Several years ago a woodpecker started making lacework out of the redwood siding along the garage side of the house. He disappeared for a while, but now he is back and is working on the front of the house. Can you tell me how to get rid of him and how to repair the damage?

title: Advertising; Bates Gets Ex-Y.& R.  Executive
description: MICHAEL L. BECKER has transferred his flag from Young & Rubicam, the largest American agency, where he was in the upper echelons of creative leadership, to Ted Bates Worldwide, No.4 in size, where he will be supreme creative commander in the New York office.

title: O'NEILL DESCRIBES AIDE: 'HE'S LIKE A SON TO ME
description: Outwardly, they are a study in contrasts, the portly, expansive, septuagenarian Speaker of the House and the young, bearded, scholarly aide. Inwardly, however, there are shared values that have led the Speaker to rely increasingly on the aide and make him one of the most influential, albeit unknown, men on Capitol Hill.

title: Giants' Lloyd Retires at 29
description: Dan Lloyd, a Giants linebacker who has been sidelined three seasons after overcoming cancer, announced his retirement today.

title: TV Summit
description: What does NBC really think of John Madden, the CBS football analyst? ''He's a lovable teddy bear,'' said Geoffrey Mason, the executive vice president of NBC Sports. ''I think he's brought a freshness to color commentary on football.

title: John Gray, 77, Senior Partner In Dewey, Ballantine Law Firm
description: John L. Gray, a senior partner in the law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died Dec. 29 of a cerebral hemorrhage at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and resided in Greenwich.

title: Yen Growing Stronger Again
description: The Japanese yen, after a dramatic and unexpected bout of weakness on the world's foreign exchange markets last year, is regaining strength.

title: Books Of The Times
description: FREUD AND MAN'S SOUL. By Bruno Bet- telheim. 111 pages. New York. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Richardson-Vicks
description: Richardson-Vicks Inc.'s Baker Instruments Corporation unit said a Federal court had enjoined the Laboratory Computer Services Corporation and its principals from using any proprietary information belonging to Baker. The injunction came in response to a suit filed Dec. 16 by Baker against Laboratory Computer and three of its officers, charging the officers with soliciting Baker engineers to engage in improper servicing of equipment and other activities.

title: Henry Moscow, Editor And Author, Dies at 77
description: Henry Moscow, former associate editor of Life International, which published the European edition of Life magazine, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Grand View-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Ampal-American Israel Corp. filed with the S.E.C. through Ampal Securities Corp., an Ampal-American subsidiary, for three series of debentures - $10 million of 10 percent redeemable debentures series MM, due in 1992; $6.25 million of 12 percent discount debentures series RR, zero coupon, due in 1992, and $20 million of 12 percent redeemable debentures series MN, due in 1992.

title: 3 Killed and 2 Wounded In Kentucky Shooting
description: A parole violator started shooting Tuesday when state troopers and sheriff's deputies went to his mountain home to arrest him, the authorities said. The gunman, one deputy and a bystander were killed in the shooting and two troopers were injured, one critically.

title: Lost Vacation For the Lakers
description: Pat Riley thought the idea made sense. The Los Angeles Lakers would play the Knicks here Saturday and the Nets Tuesday in New Jersey.

title: GOVERNMENT SECURITIES MIXED
description: Government security prices fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday. Treasury bill yields declined slightly, while returns on long-term bonds rose modestly in response to easing prices.

title: Reserves Fall In Britain
description: Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves fell sharply last month, reflecting the Bank of England's spending to defend the pound.

title: Convicted Murderer Wants Her Life Ended
description: A woman on death row, saying she is tired of an ''inhumane existence,'' is asking to die in Maryland's gas chamber.

title: CONCERT: PIANIST PLAYS STRAVINSKY
description: During the first half of Dorothy Lewis-Griffith's recital at Merkin Hall Tuesday night, the pianist, who is an associate professor of music at Valdosta State College in Georgia, was uncomfortable with the music and with the instrument. Stravinsky's ''Trois Mouvements de Petrouchka'' was played without conviction and was marred by lack of clarity and memory slips.

title: BOOM FADING, INDONESIA STARTS TO TIGHTEN ITS BELT
description: Not long ago, it appeared as if this nation and its long-booming economy would be spared the most serious consequences of the world recession.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. SUPPORTS MIXED-RACE PARTY ON JOINING PRETORIA POLITICAL PLAN

title: A DAY FOR ALBANY BABBLE AND BANTER
description: Above all, today was a day for speechmaking. But it was also a day for family, friends, political huddles, a small demonstration and a little bit of lobbying.

title: Bank Cleared To Buy Broker
description: The Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles said it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency for the purchase of Kahn & Company, a discount brokerage firm in the South.

title: One More Trial for Legal Aid
description: The warning that the strike against New York City's Legal Aid Society threatened its imminent destruction seems to have wonderfully concentrated the minds of negotiators on both sides. Mayor Koch properly cautions that even the new two-year settlement does not adequately protect the city against intolerable disruptions in its courts.

title: Jury Gets Civil Damage Case
description: A six-member jury began deliberation today in a $1 million civil damage suit filed by two former antipoverty workers more than 13 years ago. The jury had not reached a verdict after about three hours, and was told to return Thursday. The jurors will decide whether the late Senator John L. McClellan, two of his staff members and a former Kentucky prosecutor violated the consititutional rights of Alan and Margaret McSurely, who worked in an antipoverty program in Pike County, Ky.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Cuomo has used these first five days of his administration to lay out the difficult course he hopes to follow between his campaign promises to help people and the fact that in the next three months he must close what he described today as the biggest budget gap in the state's history.

title: AUTOS END A POOR 1982 ON THE RISE
description: The automobile industry closed the books today on its worst sales year in almost two decades, recording total car sales of 7,978,487, a 6.3 percent decline from 1981 and the weakest performance since 7.55 million were sold in 1963.

title: People
description: * Seena Harris Parker named vice president of National Lampoon Inc. and advertising director of National Lampoon and Heavy Metal magazines.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: El Dia de Los Reyes

title: Technology; More Reliable Computers
description: ONE frustrating thing about computers is their tendency to break down. As more people work with computers in increasingly important applications, the consequences of such breakdowns become more severe. Supermarket checkout lines stall. Airlines cannot make reservations. Bank teller machines cannot dispense cash.

title: Merrill Lynch Gets State Sale
description: New York State's spring borrowing, traditionally the nation's largest single tax-exempt financing, will be managed by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, investment bankers said yesterday. State officials said the note sale, scheduled for mid-April, will total nearly $4 billion.

title: Dr. Werner Brandt, 57, Led N.Y.U. Physics Lab
description: Dr. Werner Brandt, professor of physics at New York University, died of cancer Saturday at Shalgrenska Hospital in Goteborg, Sweden, where he was being treated. He was 57 years old and lived in Hoboken, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
BARGAIN HUNTING IN THE FLOWER DISTRICT
description: DURING the winter months, when cut flowers and plants are most appreciated - and most costly - shopping for bargains in the Manhattan flower district is probably a good idea. Following is a sampling of stores whose collective inventory should satisfy houseplant growers, flower arrangers and collectors of exotic plants alike. Prices, of course, vary widely depending on supply and demand. People's Flowers Corporation, 786 Avenue of the Americas (27th Street), 212-686-6291.

title: THE STRAIGHT STORY
description: Two spy stories - hidden for more than a generation - surfaced last week, each knifing to the heart of the questions ''What is treason? What is patriotism?''

title: NEED CITED FOR 'HIGH-COST ILLNESS' INSURANCE
description: Americans without Government health benefits pay half their medical bills for catastrophic illness, a Congressional study said in recommending that private employers be required to offer ''protection against the expenses of high-cost illness.''

title: 3 ARE INDICTED IN ATTEMPT TO SHIP TRUCK-MAKING MACHINES TO SOVIET
description: A Canadian and two United States businessmen, one of them a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, were indicted late Tuesday by a Federal grand jury on charges that they had tried to circumvent American export restrictions by shipping machines to the Soviet Union that could be used to make military trucks.

title: FUGITIVE EX-AGENT'S WIFE GIVES UP ON CHARGES INVOLVING ARMS SALES
description: Marilyn Terpil, the wife of Frank E. Terpil, a fugitive former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, has surrendered in New York in a case involving illegal arms sales to Uganda.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Awarded $45,000 Grant
description: Warner Communications Inc. has awarded a grant of $45,000 to the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: WAGNER TOPPLES DUKE, 84-77
description: Bob Mahalla, with 25 points, and Art Redmond, with 22, led Wagner to an 84-77 upset victory over Duke tonight.

title: PRO FOOTBALL'S $22 ROOTS
description: T he Super Bowl XVII tournament that begins Saturday involves millions of dollars in TV-network fees, ticket costs and player salaries. Once upon a time, pro football finance was simpler. At hand is the profit-and-loss statement for the 1905 Massillon (Ohio) Tigers, as prepared by Jacob J. Wise, their business manager.

title: QUESTIONABLE SHORTCUT TO FULL EMPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS REWARD LOYALTY IN GIVING ASSIGNMENTS
description: House Democrats finished filling most of their committee slots today, and their three days of effort sent warning to Southern conservatives who supported much of President Reagan's economic program in the last Congress.

title: 'LYRICS' SERIES FOCUSES ON TIN PAN ALLEY GLORY
description: After 12 seasons during which ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' has presented 60 programs built around the men and women who write the words to popular songs, the series will change its focus. This year, in performances over the next five months, it will go from the individuals who wrote the songs to ''The Glory Days of Tin Pan Alley,'' an overview of 50 years of song from 1880 to 1930.

title: Broadcast Group Acts On Ad Rule
description: The executive committee of the National Association of Broadcasters recommended today the dissolution of the association bureau that administers voluntary codes covering advertising practices of the nation's television and radio stations.

title: SAFETY AGENCY TO RULE SOON ON WIDER RECALL OF X-CARS
description: The National Highway Safety Traffic Administration said today that it was in the final stages of deciding whether some of General Motor's 1980 X-cars cars had a serious brake defect.

title: Richard Davis Quintet On Beat At Sweet Basil
description: One mark of a hot jazz rhythm section is that it shifts and slides and teases the beat. Another is that its rock-steady tempos always seem to be speeding up.

title: No Headline
description: Trade Talks With Japan

title: Modell Recovering
description: Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns who passed out briefly on a team charter flight to California, was reported in good condition yesterday and was given permission to leave the Ontario Community Hospital in California. A team spokesman said Modell, 57 years old, was unconscious for about 30 seconds before landing Tuesday night. ''Preliminary tests indicate Mr. Modell's condition was caused by something he ate or drank, and the combination of the cabin pressure,'' a team spokesman said.

title: JUDGE NAMES EXAMINER FOR DELOREAN MOTOR
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today appointed an independent examiner to search the books of the defunct DeLorean Motor Company for financial irregularities.

title: CUOMO ISSUES CALL FOR 'PARTNERSHIP' TO SPARK GROWTH
description: Governor Cuomo opened the 206th session of the New York State Legislature today, calling for a ''new partnership'' with business and labor and a program to provide billions of dollars for jobs, to house the homeless and to rebuild the state's crumbling roads and bridges.

title: Airlines Report Traffic Rise
description: Several major airlines reported yesterday that traffic increased in December and for the full year. The 1981 figures had been depressed by the air controllers' strike.

title: REAGAN IS SILENT ON POPE PLOT
description: President Reagan, asked Wednesday night about charges by Italian officials that Bulgaria instigated the shooting of Pope John Paul II in May 1981, said at his news conference tonight that it would ''not be proper'' to comment while the investigation was still under way.

title: SALVADOR ABDUCTION REPORTED
description: A United States church leader said today that unidentified gunmen had kidnapped two Salvadoran teenagers helping him organize a visit to El Salvador by members of Congress.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS SEARCH FOR TAINTED L.I. CLAMS
description: With more than 700 people on Long Island reported ill from having eaten contaminated clams, state and local inspectors crowded around local docks when today's catch was heaved ashore, outnumbering even the clammers themselves.

title: New American Library Revises Top Positions
description: Robert G. Diforio, chief executive officer of New American Library, has been promoted to chairman of the board of the publishing company. Mr. Diforio, who will continue as chief executive, named Marvin S. Brown president and chief administrative officer, effective Feb. 1.

title: Braniff-PSA Lease Venture Clears a Hurdle
description: The last labor barrier at Braniff International to its proposed venture with PSA Inc. was removed today by a Federal bankruptcy judge.

title: Holiday Inns
description: Holiday Inns Inc. said it had acquired the remaining 60 percent interest in River Boat Casino Inc. from Claudine Williams and other partners. It did not disclose the price of the purchase, which gives Holiday Inns all of the Holiday Casino and the Nob Hill Casino in Las Vegas, Nev. It had held a 40 percent interest in River Boat since 1979. Mrs. Williams, who founded the Holiday Casino in 1973, will continue as its chief executive officer, the company said.

title: BRITAIN CANCELS PYM'S PERSIAN GULF TOUR
description: A proposed Persian Gulf tour by Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, was canceled today amid signs of worsening relations between Britain and the Arab nations in the area.

title: Noted in Brief; Violinist and Teacher at Brooklyn College
description: Ora Shiran, an Israeli-born violinist now teaching at Brooklyn College, played music by Bach, Mozart, Schumann, Messiaen and George Calusdian at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night.

title: Capitol Cuts Back Nonstop Flights
description: Capitol International Airways said it was dropping its nonstop transcontinental flights and reducing the number of flights between the United States and Europe.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: DOLE ANNOUNCEMENT

title: Libbey-Owens
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company said it had been informed that Pilkington Brothers P.L.C. had completed the purchase of 3.33 million shares of Libbey common held by Gulf and Western Industries. Based on yesterday's closing price of $29 on the New York Stock Exchange, the transaction was worth about $96.5 million. Libbey said Pilkington had agreed to hold the shares in a separate account until the Federal Trade Commission had reviewed certain data.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF GOVERNOR CUOMO'S STATE OF THE STATE ADDRESS TO THE LEGISLATURE, CUOMO EMPHASIZES 'JOBS, JUSTICE, PARTNERSHIP AND A DRAWING ON RESOURCES'
description: Following is a transcript of Governor Cuomo's State of the State Message to the Legislature, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Four Blues-Inflected Jazz Guitarists Perform
description: Four guitarists - John Scofield, John Abercrombie, Vic Juris and Chuck Loeb - are appearing with a rhythm section at Fat Tuesday's through Saturday. Billed as ''Modern Guitar Masters Summit,'' their Tuesday set of solos, duets, trios and a quartet actually suggested that these players are fairly conservative.

title: FRANCHISER SEEKING AN IMPROVED IMAGE FOR USED CAR SALES
description: Would you buy a used car from this man? Jim Cummings, a 39-year-old former real estate broker, is well aware of the poor reputation of many automobile dealers throughout the country who sell used cars. To try to change that image and try to make money at the same time, he has established a company, Triexcellence Inc. It franchises used car departments of dealerships under the Triex brand name.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFTS AND QUILTING
description: Arts and Crafts Demonstration, Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue (53d Street), 212-755-4500, ext. 58.

title: Irving Acquisition
description: The Irving Trust Company's acquisition of a 35 percent stake in Banca della Svizzera Italiana of Lugano from Banca Commerciale Italiana of Milan has been concluded, Banca della Svizzera Italiana said in a statement. Under the $105 million transaction announced last June, Irving Trust acquires a 20 percent voting right in the Lugano bank, which retains a 7 percent voting right.

title: Bonnell Dispute Ends
description: Just two months after demanding to be traded by the Toronto Blue Jays in a dispute over insurance coverage, Barry Bonnell, an outfielder and licensed pilot, signed a new three-year contract with the club. He said that the dispute had been a ''misunderstanding,'' and that the club had apologized and agreed to the extra insurance payments to cover his flying. ... The Cincinnati Reds have granted the outfielder Mike Vail his wish to be traded.

title: Memorial Concert Scheduled For Valerie Weigl, Composer
description: A memorial concert for Valerie (Vally) Weigl, a composer, music therapist and peace activist, will be held on Jan. 30 at 2 P.M. at the Religious Society of Friends, 15 Rutherford Place, near East 15th Street.

title: LONG TEACHERS' STRIKE DIVIDES A BLUE-COLLAR TOWN IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The longest public teachers' strike in Pennsylvania history has turned union members against union members in this blue-collar community and is threatening to cost the district's 1,400 students a year's education.

title: HERS
description: WHEN we moved our small family to a suburb of Boston, we were lucky enough to meet another family lonelier than we were. Neither the man nor the woman had any kin closer than the West Coast; ours were in New York. They had three small children. Except for them and us, they knew no one.

title: Student, 15, Killed In Dispute in Bronx
description: A 15-year-old high school student was shot and killed yesterday morning following a dispute in front of a junior high school in the Bronx, the police said.

title: ISRAEL'S GLOBAL AMBITIONS
description: Recent Israeli diplomatic missions in Central America and Africa have drawn Americans' attention to Israel's global policies and ambitions. Many outsiders, who believe that Israel is bogged down in its own regional conflict, are surprised to hear that it has such ambitions. As a young, isolated nation, Israel sought friends where it could find them. But Israelis now see their country as an equal partner of the United States in a number of troubled third-world countries. Americans will find that Israel is a useful, resourceful ally, but they should also be aware that they are joining forces with an efficient military power that believes it is advancing American ideological interests -and, most importantly, expects Americans to recognize its help.

title: THE REAGAN RECORD (1)
description: Two years into the Reagan Presidency, Americans are beginning to suspect the awful truth: They have a government incompetent to govern, a President frozen in ideological fantasyland, an Administration spotted with fools and rogues.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IF you have an odd-shaped bathtub, the Barclay Company may have just the shower rod to fit it. The rod, in chrome or polished brass, comes in six configurations: a ''D'' or a ''U,'' a corner, a corner/ angle, a rectangle with a wall support and a rectangle with ceiling support (for free-standing tubs).

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Virdon is a baseball manager who moves around a lot, but when he looks out from a new dugout he apparently likes to see a familiar face, that of Mel Wright, for example. Fron 1973 until last year, Wright served as pitching coach under Virdon with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Yankees and the Houston Astros. Yesterday, it was announced that Wright would become the pitching coach under Virdon at the Montreal Expos. ... Darnell Valentine, the guard for the Portland Trail Blazers, will be out for six weeks after suffering a stress fracture of the left foot Tuesday night in a game against Indiana. ...Tim Rose, the defensive football coordinator at Miami of Ohio, was name head coach. He replaces Tom Reed, who is moving to North Carolina State.

title: My Mac Scores
description: My Mac held off a strong rally by Caveat today to win the $167,000 Tropical Park Derby for 3-year-olds by a halflength at Calder Race Course.

title: 76ers BEAT LAKERS IN OVERTIME, 122-120
description: Andrew Toney's driving bank shot with five seconds left in overtime tonight gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 122-120 victory over Los Angeles tonight and a two-game sweep of the Lakers in their regular-season series.

title: JOINING ARMY'S CHALLENGE
description: In a conference room in Michie Stadium, the football field where so much West Point athletic history has been recorded, Jim Young, the new head coach, today began to outline his plans for repairing Army's creaking football program.

title: E.E.C. Sugar Exports
description: Sugar exports subsidized by the European Economic Community have significantly damaged the American sugar industry and curtailed use of corn by the domestic sweetener industry, according to a study published today by Economic Perspectives Inc., a consulting firm. The study, done for the National Association of Corn Growers, said that the absence of such subsidized sugar exports would increase high-fructose corn syrup production in the United States by as much as 2.3 million metric tons.

title: Satin Brand Cigarettes Are Going National
description: Having achieved a 1.4 percent share of cigarette sales in test markets in Denver and Milwaukee with Satin, its new female-oriented cigarette brand, in only 12 weeks, Lorillard, a division of Loews Theaters, has decided to go for national introduction. And the company that previously brought you the Kent line True, Newport, Old Gold and Max, says that, as far as ad budgets go, this will be its most elaborate and expensive introduction.
