title: Orders Up In Germany
description: The Government said today that industrial orders had jumped sharply in November, prompting some optimism that an economic recovery may be on the way.

title: NEO-CLASSICAL TOUCHES TRANSFORM A TOWN HOUSE
description: HAVING good architectural manners - respecting the historical styles, building materials and ornamental details of a place - seems to concern an increasing number of architects today. It is no longer enough for designs merely to look original; being a ''good neighbor'' to whatever the surroundings happen to be is just as important.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. The Hawks have won seven of their last eight games against the Knicks, including the teams' only meeting this season.

title: LAME DUCKS, WITH PORK
description: Neither the self-praise that accompanied the opening of the new Congress this week nor the soothing comments of President Reagan when the old one adjourned can erase disgust over the lame-duck session that brought the 97th Congress to its sleazy close.

title: The Perfect Job
description: After a long and successful career as a world-class hurdler that included six national indoor titles, Patty Van Wolvelaere believes she has found the perfect job. Firefighting.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Down
description: The annual rate of inflation in the European Economic Community fell below 10 percent in November for the first time in more than three years, the community statistics office said today. It said a price increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent from the October level resulted in an annual inflation rate of 9.7 percent, the lowest since July 1979.

title: Colonial Plan
description: The Colonial Commercial Corporation, which filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws in November 1981, said yesterday that it had concluded its bankruptcy reorganization and that an order confirming its reorganization plan had been signed by the United States Bankruptcy Court. Under the plan, Colonial will distribute 12.5 million shares of convertible preferred stock warrants to acquire 3.2 million shares of common stock, and $3 million principal amount of debentures due beginning in 1991.

title: CALL TO ARM IN THE HOME IS DEBATED
description: Although homeowners in Howard Beach, Queens, still shake their heads in disbelief as they recall the predawn crime rampage five weeks ago in which a gang of shotgun-wielding youths terrorized their neighborhood, some are resisting calls to arm themselves for protection.

title: TRIPOLI REMAINS TENSE AFTER TRUCE IS DECLARED
description: For nearly a week, violence has been random and rampant in this seedy port set between the azure blue of the Mediterranean and high snow-capped hills in the distance.

title: MOST SHUN NEW BANK ACCOUNTS
description: Commercial banks and savings institutions yesterday began to offer a second money market account without an interest-rate ceiling, but customer response was light, a spot-check showed.

title: CUOMO TO FREEZE HOSPITAL BUILDING
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would order a one-year freeze on all new hospital construction in New York State in an effort to impose ''discipline'' on more than $5 billion in planned projects.

title: Wichita State Penalized 7th Time for Violations
description: Wichita State, the most heavily penalized school in National Collegiate Athletic Association history, was put on two-year probation today for violations in its football program.

title: Gas Pipeline to Ukraine
description: The Soviet Union has built a 2,090-mile pipeline to supply industrial regions in the Ukraine with gas from the Urengoi field in western Siberia, the official Tass press agency said today.

title: PLAYS/S. Johnson
description: I n the final moments of their game Tuesday night against the Bucks in Milwaukee, there was a feeling among the Nets that if they were beaten, it would be because of some clutch play by one of the Milwaukee stars -Marques Johnson, Sidney Moncrief or Junior Bridgeman - not because of any failing by the Nets.

title: No Headline
description: WARSAW PACT OFFERS NONAGGRESSION ACCORD

title: Jordan, Case Receives Nestle Unit Account
description: Accounts with a Continental flavor have come to Jordan, Case & McGrath; Broullard Communications, a division of J. Walter Thompson, and Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall.

title: Remy Martin Amerique Sets Agency Review
description: Because of a concern that a client conflict situation may develop under its new distribution system, Remy Martin Amerique, a subsidiary of the French cognac maker, has decided to review its relationship with Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner. The current ad budget is $4.5 million.

title: Precious Metal Prices Continue to Advance
description: Prices of precious metal futures continued to advance yesterday, spurred by an easing in short-term interest rates and a weaker dollar. Brokers, who had been expecting a post-holiday technical decline in gold and silver, said a sharp rise in platinum prices led the advance.

title: 23 CAR MAKERS URGE BANK FINANCE PLAN
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are asking banks and other lending institutions to participate in their recently announced cut-rate car financing programs.

title: DISEASES AWAITING THE ULTIMATE CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'ENTERPRISE' LOOKS AT BRANIFF
description: in view of the workings of our acquisitive instincts in real situations, and often succeed in capturing the drama behind, or above the bottom line.

title: HAS DIPLOMACY BECOME OUT OF DATE?
description: In this era of computers, satellite communication and secure telephone lines, is old-fashioned diplomacy out of date? Have striped-pants diplomacy and the diplomatic social whirl been supplanted by the new technology?

title: ARMS BUDGET RISE TO BE URGED IN '84
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger plans to submit a military spending proposal for 1984 to the White House this week that will be close to the $247 billion projected by the Reagan Administration a year ago, Defense Department officials said today. The officials suggested that the proposal will mean that Mr. Weinberger has resisted pressure to trim military spending to help reduce a Federal deficit projected at $200 billion for the next fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1.

title: UNCERTAIN THINK TANKS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER SALES STIR HOPE
description: In the long wait for an upturn in consumer spending, any hints of recovery are eagerly grabbed at. Recently many executives and economists have taken heart from the demand for appliances, electronic equipment and other consumer durable goods. Sales of these products in November and December were significantly higher than a year earlier.

title: A.T.& T. Planning Venture in Europe
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company and N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken of the Netherlands, a major electronics and telecommunications concern, said yesterday they that had agreed in principle to form a joint venture company.

title: JUDGE DENIES BAIL IN A CYANIDE CASE
description: Richard R. Bowen, who said his wife had been poisoned with cyanide-laced capsules of Maximum Strength Anacin-3, pleaded not guilty today of attempting to murder her.

title: The Circumnavigator With Sinking Feeling
description: An American trying to sail around the world said today that he had had one thought as his yacht began sinking in the Indian Ocean: ''I can't swim.''

title: The Governor and Mr. Cuomo
description: New York heard two State of the State speeches yesterday. The new Governor, like the old, spoke of hard times and the need to cap spending. Then the new man, Mario Cuomo, spoke of his determination to improve the lives of the needy. Neither voice explained how these goals can be reconciled.

title: O'NEILL, SWORN IN, SEES TOUGH TIMES FOR CONNECTICUT
description: Vowing ''dependable leadership'' for what he said would be difficult years ahead, William Atchison O'Neill, Connecticut's 84th Governor, was inaugurated today for a full, fouryear term in his own right.

title: Clack Indicted On Drug Charges
description: Jim Clack, a member of the 1974 and 1975 Pittsburgh Steelers Super Bowl champions, has been indicted on charges of conspiracy to deliver cocaine and delivery of cocaine by a Dare County grand jury.

title: Mrs. Helen Beal Woodward, An Author and Biographer
description: A memorial service will be held Wednesday for Helen Beal Woodward, 68 years old, a journalist, editor and author who died of cancer. Mrs. Woodward died Thursday at her home here.

title: KLECKO TESTS KNEE IN PRACTICE
description: Players suddenly looked around, halting the Jets' practice today, as the large figure of Joe Klecko reappeared for work on a football field for the first time in nearly four months.

title: CLASH OVER TINY JERSEY BANK
description: Just a few months ago, the Lincoln State Bank of East Orange was a tiny, one-location community lender virtually unknown outside this northern New Jersey town. Today, however, the only thing that has not changed at the bank is its modest size.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50 **Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIGHT OVER FUNDS DIVIDES SCIENTOLOGY GROUP
description: The Church of Scientology is embroiled in a bitter internal battle over the control of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: CABARET: MANNES SET TO MUSIC
description: ''ETIQUETTE'' is an amusing camp satire of high society: Emily Post by way of the Marx Brothers and Anna Russell. William M. Hoffman's and John Braden's self-styled ''musical revue with manners,'' which played briefly three years ago at La Mama, has been revised as a cabaret entertainment under the direction of a Playhouse of the Ridiculous co-founder, John Vaccaro.

title: 4 Are Killed in India In Election Violence
description: Four people were killed and more than 100 injured today in election violence in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.

title: Guatemalans Told They'll Get Assembly and a Constitution
description: President Efrain Rios Montt pledged today to install a popularly elected constituent assembly in Guatemala by March 23, 1984, exactly two years after he took power in a bloodless coup.

title: Rexon Appoints Officer
description: Gerald W. Fleming, 47, will become president and chief operating officer of the Rexon Business Machines Corporation effective Jan. 17, succeeding Ben C. Wang.

title: TOP 7 'TOP GIRLS' SPEAK OUT
description: Good-looking, smart and ruthless, Marlene is the top girl at Top Girls, the London employment agency she has bested every male rival to head. Efficient as a computer and about as warmhearted, she is the embodiment of corporate success - and she has no time for losers.

title: CITY AIDES FAIL TO GAIN SUPPORT ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, came here today to ask for $38 million in disputed special-education aid that he said was necessary to avert large cutbacks in programs. But state officials and legislators told him that there was no money to spare.

title: BRIEFS
description: * British Columbia Resources Investment Corp. said its B.C. Coal Ltd. unit would close its Balmer coal mine near Sparwood, British Columbia, for six weeks beginning Feb. 5 because of poor demand, and that it would reduce its permanent work force by about 400 hourly employees.

title: FTOREK SCORES TWO GOALS
description: The Rangers made a rousing third-period comeback last night at Madison Square Garden but had to settle for a 3-3 tie with the Buffalo Sabres. Robbie Ftorek's second goal of the game tied the score with 7 minutes 35 seconds remaining and extended the Rangers' unbeaten streak to four games.

title: Touche Buys Garr
description: Touche Ross & Company said yesterday that it had acquired Garr Industries, an Atlanta management consulting firm that concentrates on the retail industry. Touche Ross, an accounting and management consulting firm, said Garr would be operated as a separate entity with M. Andre Garr Jr. and Edwin Hinnefeld as its principal operating officers. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: ISRAELI PRESIDENT SEE PERIL IN ERODING TIE TO EGYPT
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel has told the Reagan Administration that, unless the deterioration in Israeli-Egyptian relations is halted, it will be difficult for Israelis to support President Reagan's peace initiative or other proposals intended to end the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Pittsburgh Judge Halts Mortgage Foreclosures
description: A judge halted mortgage foreclosures in Allegheny County today, citing the ''critical'' state of the local economy and the finances of many families.

title: Marietta Unit Sells Interest
description: Martin Marietta Aluminum, a unit of the Martin Marietta Corporation of Bethesda, Md., said yesterday that it had sold 30 percent of its 20 percent share in Halco Mining Inc.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY'S PAS DES DEESSES
description: BEFORE it became possible to photograph dancers at all, it was the vogue in the 19th century to capture their magic moments in lithographs and prints. Now, as the Joffrey Ballet demonstrated demurely and wittily in Tuesday night's revival of Robert Joffrey's ''Pas des Deesses,'' the attitude toward dance-imagery has come full circle.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ALTHOUGH Vladimir Kagan, right, designed the chair especially for a client who lived in Essex House, he found that other clients became interested in it. The slim two-tone lacquered wood design, which was inspired by the Art Deco architecture of the Essex House building, was then dubbed the Eva chair and incorporated in the furniture designer's new range, at a list price of $1,650.

title: Different View on Basketball
description: At this time last year, Kenny Dennard was sure he had learned to appreciate the way of life in the National Basketball Association. He did not need to play many games with the Great Falls Golden Nuggets, a Montana team in the Continental Basketball Association, after he had been cut by the Kansas City Kings of the N.B.A., to understand that an N.B.A. player's life was not as awful as some might think.

title: Quotation of theDay
description: ''As Governor, I will carry our case to the nation for the help that we need and deserve.

title: Angolan Rebels Seek Talks
description: Angola's main rebel movement, claiming to control all but three of the country's provinces, has called on the Government in Luanda to start immediate talks on forming a government of national unity. A communique issued here today by the movement, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, said it wanted to start talks with the Luanda regime so as to ''restore peace in Angola, secure national reconciliation and form a government of national unity, the sole expression of the will of the Angolan people.''

title: No Headline
description: KENTUCKY DEFEATS LOUISIANA ST., 52-50

title: IN CALIFORNIA, THE TURNOVER WITH TWISTS
description: A lot of formerly high-powered public figures here are back in the job market with the end of the administration of Edmund G. Brown Jr., but for only one person in California does the change of control in the Governor's office immediately threaten prison.

title: PIONEER IN UNDERWATER LIVING
description: Capt. George F. Bond, 67 years old, the Navy medical officer who pioneered the Sealab project that proved man could live on the ocean floor, died here Monday of heart disease. He had been hospitalized since Dec. 7.

title: Milton Bradley License
description: The North American Philips Corporation said yesterday that its subsidiary, the Magnavox Company, had granted the Milton Bradley Company a license to make and sell television games and game cartridges. The patents are owned by Sanders Associates and are exclusively licensed to Magnavox. Financial terms and other details were not disclosed.

title: Fed Ex-Aide Admits Guilt
description: Theode C. Langevin, the former Federal Reserve employee charged with illegally tapping the Fed's computers for secret money supply data, said today that he would plead guilty to the charges.

title: SARAH CALDWELL DEFENDS PHILIPPINE OPERA PROJECT
description: Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston, said today this would be a world without music if artists denied their music to every country supposed to have human rights problems.

title: Waiver Is Sought On Subway Access
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday sent a letter to Governor Cuomo asking him to exclude the subway system from public facilities that are required to provide access for people in wheelchairs.

title: Bridge: Early Battler for Brooklyn, Now 81, Kibitzes Regularly
description: Half a century ago there was a healthy bridge rivalry between Manhattan and Brooklyn. One of the chief battlers for Brooklyn was George Kennedy, who had all the pugnacity and competitive enthusiasm that one would expect from a man who had been a boxer in his youth.

title: HOW SERIOUSLY SHOULD 'TROCADEROS' BE TAKEN?
description: DURING the last decade there have been several dance companies with the word ''Trocadero'' (or, sometimes, ''Trockadero'') in their titles, the latest being Les Ballets Trocadero de la Karpova, which recently completed a run of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Books: A Writer's Homecoming
description: AN ORPHAN IN HISTORY, Retrieving a Jewish Legacy. By Paul Cowan. 246 pages. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: THE DOLLAR REWARDS IN OBVIATING TOXIC CLEANUPS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBWAY CARS HELD PERILOUS FOR THE BLIND
description: Spokesmen for New York's major organizations for the blind said yesterday that two models of the city's subway cars posed a serious danger to the blind, the visually impaired and the elderly.

title: Wichita State Disciplines 2 Coaches
description: Wichita State, whose football program was placed on two years' probation Wednesday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, responded today by freezing the salaries of Coach Willie Jeffries and his offensive coordinator, Fayne Henson, and by curtailing their off-campus recruiting.

title: CLASSES ARE ABUZZ OVER MOMENT OF SILENCE
description: At 9 A.M. today, Ann Pancila, secretary to the principal of James Caldwell High School here, switched on the public-address system, asked for the attention of the school's 754 students and, in a clear and authoritative voice, proclaimed, ''We are now going to observe one minute of silence.''

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL ON 5 GAS TAX RISE
description: President Reagan signed into law today the first increase in Federal gasoline taxes in 23 years, which will finance a program to rehabilitate and improve highways, bridges and mass transit systems.

title: 'BLACK HOLE' STAR IS BELIEVED FOUND
description: American and Canadian astronomers at an observatory in the Chilean Andes, scanning a small galaxy a short distance beyond the Milky Way, have identified what they believe to be the universe's second suspected stellar black hole.

title: MUST HELP SCHOOLS WITH ART
description: One of the world's best known art dealers was sentenced on a criminal conviction yesterday to set up a scholarship fund and artappreciation programs for New York City high school students.

title: The Pride and Joy Of Paul Brown
description: You will have to excuse Paul Brown for feeling somewhat proud this week. But of the 16 teams in the first round of the National Football League playoffs, six head coaches are proteges of the former Cleveland and Cincinnati coach.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Oregon Reports Testing Capsules of Fatal Bottle
description: A bottle of Anacin-3 taken from the home of a woman who died of cyanide poisoning contained cyanide gas but the remaining capsules were not tainted, medical experts said today.

title: Earthquakes Swarms Are Felt Over Wide Area of California
description: A swarm of hundreds of earthquakes shook a wide area of central California today. Groceries were knocked off store shelves, but there were no reports of injuries or major damage.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dan Fouts, the quarterback for the San Diego Chargers, who led the National Football League in total yardage for the fourth consecutive season, was named offensive player of the year by The Associated Press. Marcus Allen, the running back for the Los Angeles Raiders, who was the league's leading scorer, was named offensive rookie of the year. ... Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, who fainted during an plane flight Tuesday night, was released from a hospital in Ontario, Calif., after tests ruled out a heart attack. .. The Mets rounded out the lineup for their 1983 telecast team by signing Steve Zabriskie, an ABC Sports veteran.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''I DO not believe there's such a thing as a jazz singer,'' Mel Torme said the other day. ''Sarah Vaughan, Ella Fitzgerald, Joe Williams and I are basically pop singers with a deep imprimatur of jazz. Every pop singer is influenced a little by jazz, because it's our native folk art. But labeling someone a jazz, rather than a pop singer, is only a matter of degree of influence.''

title: LOW-GROWTH FORECAST IS ACCEPTED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan has accepted a scaled-down economic forecast of 1.4 percent economic growth this year over 1982, after adjustment for inflation, Administration officials said today.

title: EXPLOSION IS HEARD FOR MILES
description: Three fuel storage tanks in Newark exploded in a huge fireball early this morning, killing at least one person and injuring several others, authorities said.

title: Mime on Fourth St.
description: Zwi Kanar, a Polish-born mime, will appear weekends through Feb. 26 at the Dramatis Personae Theater, 25 East Fourth Street. Mr. Kanar has performed in the United States and abroad and is now based in New York. Performances this weekend are tonight and tomorrow at 10 and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $6 ($4 for students and the elderly). Reservations: 947-0159.

title: Training of Theater Producers Planned
description: The Theater Development Fund and the Foundation for the Extension and Development of the American Professional Theater announced yesterday the creation of the Commercial Theater Institute, for the purpose of training producers for commercial theater.

title: Dean Witter Sets Refunds to Clients
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said it would reimburse clients who suffered losses by purchasing stock in Millicom Inc., a company it had recommended. But the firm said it considered the case to be unique and that it would not protect customers from losses on every investment.

title: Salvador Holds Two On Subversion Charge
description: Two Salvadoran teen-agers who an American friend said were kidnapped are in police custody, accused of being messengers for leftist guerrillas, Antonio Moran, the Police Chief, said today.

title: Time of change in Chinese kitchen.
description: THAT change is not always progress is proved once again by the Chinese restaurant formerly known as Peng's, on 44th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, which was given a two-star rating in 1977. Renamed Peng Teng in May 1981, this spacious and attractive modern restaurant with its many comfortable private dining rooms still turns out some very good dishes. But based on five recent visits, the kitchen's performance has become markedly uneven.

title: CABERET: TERI KLAUSNER SINGS
description: TERRI KLAUSNER, who once sang the title role of ''Evita'' at matinees and more recently was one of the leads in ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' is breaking in a cabaret act at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, through tomorrow in which she is using her past as a launching pad for new material.

title: Parcells Rehires 3 Giant Assistants
description: Bill Parcells, the new head coach of the Giants, rehired Pat Hodgson, Romeo Crennel and Bill Belichick yesterday as assistant coaches and said that decisions on the five other assistants would be made soon.

title: Airline President Quits
description: Ned P. DeWitt, who was named president and chief operating officer of Western Airlines six months ago, has resigned, the Los Angelesbased airline said yesterday.

title: Joe Fields: Diligent Leader of Jets' Line
description: ''Richard, you gotta take a walk with me,'' Joe Fields told Richard Todd in the locker room before a Jet game at Shea Stadium recently.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1983; The Economy
description: The I.C.C. dropped a 48-year ban on railroads entering the commercial trucking business. The action will allow the railroads to move closer to becoming complete transportation companies. The trucking industry immediately challenged the decision and threatened court action. Analysts said that in time, many railroads would probably operate large trucking subsidiaries. (Page A1.)

title: NETS TRIUMPH FOR 7th IN ROW
description: Cries of ''Dee-fense, Dee-fense'' emanated from the crowd in the final moments tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, and the surging Nets responded, playing what Dennis Johnson of the Phoenix Suns called a ''swarming, harassing, confident'' defense.

title: 'PURIFYING' POLAND
description: Despite the regime's lifting of martial law, Poland is undergoing what could be called a process of ''purification'' - a purge of artists, intellectuals and opposition leaders that may be more dangerous and more far-reaching than anything witnessed in the Soviet bloc since the days of Stalin.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Shelter Art

title: Dantley's Season Ends
description: Adrian Dantley, the scoring leader in the National Basketball Association, will undergo surgery on his right wrist Tuesday to repair torn ligaments, Laura Herlovich, assistant public relations director for the Utah Jazz, said yesterday.

title: TV: 'CLOSEUP' ON LEBANON MASSACRE
description: ''OH, tell the world what happened to the Palestinian people!'' That refrain, wailed by a survivor of the September massacre in Lebanon, echoes through the ''ABC News Closeup'' being shown on Channel 7 tonight at 10. The hourlong report attributes the blame for the slaughter of some 800 people at the refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila ''to the wanton brutality of the Christian militiamen; to negligence by senior Israeli military officers; to the weakness of the Lebanese army and Government; to the indifference of Arab nations, and, finally, to the failure of an anxious American Government, which broke its word.''

title: Launching of Shuttle Delayed Until February
description: The launching of the space shuttle Challenger has been delayed until at least Feb. 1 and possibly ''much later in the month'' because of an unexplained hydrogen leak, officials at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration report.

title: Zumwalt at Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company has named Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt to its board, to succeed Ben H. Warren, a former vice chairman who is retiring, Harvester said.

title: Progress Seen On Braniff Plan
description: The chairman of Braniff International, Howard Putnam, said a judge's ruling that nullifed the grounded airline's last union contracts leaves the availability of landing slots as the only obstacle standing in the way of forming a joint venture with a California airline.

title: Blooms in I.B.M. Plaza
description: Orchids are in bloom, along with African violets, jade trees and a variety of bromeliads, at the new Shop-in-the-Garden in the garden plaza of the I.B.M. Building, Madison Avenue and 57th Street.

title: U.S. SAYS TREATY PROPOSAL DOESN'T SEEM TO BE NEW
description: The Reagan Administration said today after studying the Warsaw Pact's call for an East-West nonaggression treaty that, ''at first glance, it does not seem to represent anything new.''

title: DOW SOARS TO 1,070.92, A RECORD
description: Rising hopes of an economic recovery sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 26.03 points yesterday, to a record close of 1,070.92, in the heaviest trading in two months.

title: Morgan Shoots 65 at Tucson
description: Gil Morgan, without a victory on the PGA Tour since 1979, shot a five-under-par 65 today to take the first-round lead in the $300,000 Tucson Open, the first tournament on the 1983 tour.

title: BRITISH DETAINING A DANISH TRAWLER
description: British naval officers boarded a Danish trawler today and directed its captain to sail into an English port, an hour after he cast nets in restricted waters off the northeastern English coast, officials reported.

title: Pro Football Matchups; Defense Is Key to Playoff Fate of Bengals
description: On the second Sunday after the end of the football strike, the Cincinnati Bengals defeated the Los Angeles Raiders, 31-17, and limited Marcus Allen to a net gain of zero in his eight rushes. Twenty-two days later, the Bengals lost to the San Diego Chargers, 50-34, and gave up 661 yards of total offense.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Windfall

title: Police Test Devices To Remove Bombs
description: The City Police Department yesterday tested several remotecontrolled vehicles with mechanical arms that, according to the manufacturers, can remove unexploded bombs without endangering police officers.

title: Briton Admits He Left Secrets on the Subway
description: A British information officer admitted today that that he lost secret Government documents in a London subway train.

title: French actor remembers Hitchcock.
description: PHILIPPE NOIRET, the distinguished French actor, can be sardonic in two languages. Talking about his current movie, ''Coup de Torchon,'' now playing at the Paris Theater, he says, ''Last year in France, we have 12 nominations for Cesar, which is our Oscar. And we avoid every prize.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Greeter's Farewell

title: Sun Oil Price Cut
description: The Sun Company's Sun Refining and Marketing Company unit said it had cut its heating oil cargo price by 4 cents a gallon. The kerosene cargo price was lowered by 5.5 cents a gallon at the same time, it said.

title: Sindona Files Suit Over Legal Fees
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier serving a 25-year prison term for bank fraud, filed a lawsuit in Manhattan yesterday seeking the return of $150,000 in legal fees from one of his former lawyers.

title: 8 BURGLARIES ANGER 5th AVE. MERCHANT
description: In eight days during the Christmas holidays, a merchant on lower Fifth Avenue said, he reported eight burglaries at his furniture store, including three in one day and one in midafternoon.

title: GROUPS PROTEST TAX ON HEALTH BENEFITS
description: A wide range of business, labor and professional organizations joined two Senators today in urging President Reagan to reject proposals for a tax on health insurance benefits.

title: FEDERAL COURT CONGESTION: GRAVE BUT CURABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Funds Fall $4.2 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds declined by $4.2 billion, to a total of $207 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: A HAND REACHES FOR HOT POTATO OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Revising the Social Security system has become such a politically lethal issue that most politicians refer to it as the ''third rail,'' the electrified middle rail of a subway line - ''Touch it and you're dead.''

title: A FEAST FOR ADOLFO'S FANS
description: Many of the 400 women who turned out at noon yesterday to see Adolfo's showing of his spring and summer fashion collection at the St. Regis wore suits he had designed. The phenomenon was repeated at a second show in the afternoon. It is a sign of good manners as well as affection for the designer.

title: HEART PATIENT FACES SETBACKS
description: Doctors caring for Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, said today that he had suffered periods of mild kidney and lung insufficiency as well as mental confusion.

title: Saudis Firm on $34 Oil
description: Saudi Arabia will not cut its oil price from the present level of $34 a barrel and did not discuss such a move at a meeting with its United States partners in Geneva earlier this week, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman, quoted by the official Saudi Press Agency, said rumors that Saudi Arabia was considering an oil price cut were pure speculation, with no basis in fact.

title: MOURNERS AT FUNERAL FOR ROSENTHAL INCLUDE CUOMO, KOCH AND O'NEILL
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, who died of cancer Tuesday, was eulogized yesterday by scores of officials at funeral services at the Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills in Queens.

title: FOCUS ON RECOVERY
description: If President Reagan's roundabout answers at his last news conference are a guide to budgetary policy, they suggest that he will not seek new taxes or cut military spending significantly but will attack the budget deficit with further reductions in social spending. That puts him 33 and 1/3 percent on the right track.

title: Shearing at Michael's
description: The jazz pianist George Shearing, accompanied by the bassist Don Thompson, will appear through Feb. 26 at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.

title: BURLINGTON AND U.S. IN ACCORD
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday an agreement with Burlington Northern Inc. to solve antitrust problems that might arise if Burlington succeeded in taking over the El Paso Company.

title: A MOUNTAIN VILLAGE RUN AS A FAMILY BUSINESS FACES AN UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: The Dillards, who migrated here 200 years ago from Virginia in search of land and a fresh start, may have struck the best deal with the Indians this side of Manhattan.

title: ISRAEL AND THE DIASPORA INEXTRICABLY LINKED
description: To the Editor:

title: Postal Service Surplus
description: The Postal Service said today that it had a $710 million surplus in the last fiscal year, reversing the trend of losses the two previous years. The governing board of the service said there was a $1.082 billion surplus on operations.

title: MUSEUMS TURNING TO AIR RIGHTS FOR REVENUES
description: Many of New York City's museums, forced to find new ways to deal with economic pressures, have discovered that one of their most valuable assets is not hanging in their collections but above them - their air rights.

title: ELIZABETH COTTEN AT 90, BIGGER THAN THE TRADITION
description: ON Wednesday, Elizabeth Cotten turned 90 years old. The singer and guitarist's public celebration of the event will start with her performances tonight at Folk City, 130 West Third Street. It's an appropriate spot, since Mrs. Cotten's song ''Freight Train'' has been a staple of folk singers' repertories since the 1960's.

title: EXILED SOVIET GENERAL NOW IN QUEENS REFLECTS ON STRUGGLES WITH MOSCOW
description: Petro G. Grigorenko, the only army general to be exiled from the Soviet Union, lives with his wife, Zinaida, and his stepson, Oleg, in a modest Sunnyside, Queens, apartment that shows how little he was able to bring from his home in Moscow.

title: STRIKE EMPTIES GIRARD, A BOYS' HAVEN
description: Girard College is a special place to many in Philadelphia. It is a surrogate parent for fatherless boys like Michael Bleistein, 13 years old, and Odell Kyler, 14, for the motherless as well and for the underprivileged from broken homes.

title: THATCHER CABINET SHUFFLED, WITH EYE ON A POSSIBLE VOTE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher shuffled her Cabinet tonight in preparation for a general election that could take place within six months.

title: CHICAGO UPHELD ON SCHOOL PLAN WITHOUT BUSING
description: A Federal district judge today approved as constitutional a voluntary school desegregation plan that does not include busing of students.

title: FILM ON EDWARD CURTIS AND HIS STILLS OF INDIANS
description: Despite their shared origin and techniques, still photography and film are usually treated like oil and water. But the two will mix this month at the Queens Museum, where a program of seven films about important 19th- and 20th-century photographers is being presented in conjunction with an exhibition of vintage portrait photographs of North American Indians by Edward S. Curtis.

title: PEETERS FILLS BRUINS' NEED IN THE GOAL
description: Pete Peeters has taken the direct approach, if not doorto-door, then locker-to-locker, in this 1982-83 campaign. It's a short trek, once around the Boston Bruins' dressing room, with a smile on his face and his right hand extended toward his teammates like some stumping politician.

title: Kero-Sun Cutting Work Force 50%
description: Kero-Sun Inc., the company that pioneered the kerosene heater business in this country, said it would lay off 150 workers, or half its work force, on Friday.

title: HOSPITAL COUNCIL TAKES UP ORDER FOR FREEZE
description: The New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council convened yesterday with some misgiving about the wording of Governor Cuomo's order for a one-year statewide freeze on all major hospital construction.

title: THEATER: HITLER TRIAL IN 'PORTAGE TO SAN CRISTOBAL'
description: HARTFORD ALIVE at 90, Adolf Hitler is transported out of hiding in the Brazilian jungle. Such is the premise of George Steiner's novel, ''The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H.,'' as faithfully adapted for the stage by Christopher Hampton. The controversial work was presented in London last season and it is now playing at the Hartford Stage Company in a production starring John Cullum.

title:
Economic Scene;
Reagan's Shift In Emphasis
description: THE Administration's slogan during the election campaign last fall was ''stay the course.'' The challenge, as Martin Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser, has put it, was ''to look far enough into the future'' to encourage savings, investment and, hence, expansion. There is no hint that the President has abandoned his basic goal of sustainable economic growth through lower taxes, smaller government, stable money and less regulation.

title: DAVID J. ANDERSON
description: David J. Anderson, a builder and real estate developer in the Caribbean, died of a heart attack Monday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital on Long Island. He was 63 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I., and New York.

title: FRENCH FILM RETROSPECTIVE AT THE MODERN
description: THERE was a time, not so long ago, when people went to see films that showed nothing more than leaves rustling on a tree or a dog walking down the street or smoke billowing from a chimney. These simple films, many of them made by the Frenchmen Auguste and Louis Lumiere at the turn of the century, lasted about 90 seconds each and were often shown in rented basement rooms and meeting halls.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Pessimism in France
description: Some 92 percent of French chief executives questioned in an opinion poll for the Forum de l'Expansion Seminar in Paris said they were pessimistic about 1983 business prospects, it was disclosed today. Only 6 percent were optimistic. The poll, which questioned the chiefs of more than 500 companies in December, said that a majority saw little growth or a decline in France in 1983; price rises of 8 percent to 12 percent; unemployment at 2.5 million, and a devaluation of the franc.

title: ART OF BRIBERY IN JAKARTA: HOW IT WORKS, OR DOESN'T
description: A Western visitor here was late to lunch, he told his host, because he had tried, as an experiment, to retrieve his passport from the immigration department without paying a bribe.

title: FOR SKATERS, ABUNDANCE OF ICE
description: It has not been a good winter for those who like to wake up in the morning and find the hills covered with snow and the ponds smooth with ice. This winter's gentle weather has been a disappointment for skiers longing for a day on the slopes and for children hoping for a day off from school.

title: Market Place; Refinery Lures Two Shaheens
description: THE oil business isn't exactly booming these days - particularly in Canada - but John M. Shaheen, the 67-year-old oil executive and former owner of the ill-fated Come by Chance refinery in Newfoundland, said in an interview the other day that his youngest son, Bradford, who is 27, wants to buy the refinery and put it back into production.

title: Shotgun Was Used To Kill Woman
description: A woman found slain in her car at a shopping center in Parsippany died of two shotgun blasts fired at point-blank range, according to the preliminary results of an autopsy performed today.

title: Shearson Appoints 36-Year-Old Chief
description: Peter A. Cohen has been named president and chief executive of Shearson/American Express Inc., and at age 36 becomes the youngest head of a major Wall Street brokerage firm.

title: Jones & Laughlin Clean-Air Projects
description: The LTV Corporation said the Environmental Protection Agency had denied its application to extend the deadline for completing air pollution control projects at three plants belonging to its Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation unit.

title: Staying the Course in Connecticut
description: You might think a newly elected governor, at least on Inauguration Day, would be eager to set a new tone and direction, raising spirits even in grim times. Not in Connecticut. Still ducking crucial issues, Gov. William O'Neill began his term with an agenda of road repair, housing bonds and garbage disposal.

title: Deliveries and removals.
description: THE Chautauqua Institution in Chautauqua, N.Y., has not yet decided how to move a recently rediscovered 3,000-year-old, half-ton granite statue to Sotheby Parke Bernet, at York Avenue and 72d Street, for auction May 11. Chautauqua's problems, though slightly more complicated, are typical for first-time customers of art-auction houses who are trying to get their possessions delivered or removed from the galleries.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Princess of the City

title: BRIEFING
description: Switch for Hollings

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE WAR AGAINST THE AMAZONS. By Abby Wettan Kleinbaum. Illustrated. 240 pages. McGraw-Hill. $18.95.

title: Chase Lowers Some Rates
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third-largest Bank after the Bank of America and Citicorp, said yesterday that it had lowered many of the interest rates charged on auto, home improvement and personal unsecured loans by 1.25 percentage points.

title: 'Faust' and 'Wild Oats'
description: Goethe's ''Faust,'' Parts I and II, will be performed in repertory this weekend with John O'Keeffe's 18th-century comedy ''Wild Oats,'' at the C.S.C. Repertory, 136 East 13th Street.

title: News Analysis
description: The sustained economic recovery that President Reagan has pledged but has not produced is being threatened by record budget deficits that would not disappear even if the economy began to grow strongly.

title: Jobless Benefit Claims Decline
description: New applications for unemployment compensation declined by 27,000 in the week that ended on Christmas Day, the Labor Department reported today. It was the fourth decline in that figure in the last five weeks.

title: THE FATE OF REVOLUTION
description: Andrzej Wajda, the influential Polish film director, has taken a new look at revolution, in ''Danton.'' The film focuses on a short period of the French Revolution when Robespierre, carried away with the momentum of terror he has launched, sends his former comrade Danton and friends to the guillotine.

title: RARE SCROLL FOR MUSEUM
description: The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, known for its collection of Oriental art, has announced the acquisition of an early 12th-century Chinese handscroll for what was described as a ''high six-figure'' sum -considered one of the largest amounts ever paid for a Chinese painting.

title: Price of Gas May Rise 25%
description: The Energy Department said today that the price of natural gas used in home heating would rise 25 percent in the first quarter from the comparable 1982 period. This would put the average price at $6.17 per thousand cubic feet - 20 cents more than the projection made three months ago.

title: Bridge: Dissembling Is Permissible But Not by Using Gestures
description: One significant difference between poker and bridge is that the poker player may, if he chooses, put on an act, simulating happiness or gloom by gestures or facial expression. For the bridge player to do any such thing is improper. However, there is nothing to stop him from giving a false impression of his mood in a technical way, by the cards he plays.

title: King Awaits Word
description: Clyde King, who ended the season as manager of the Yankees but has not been told if he will remain in that job, said today that he would not fight for the job.

title: OPERA: UPTOWN FORAY IN 'LOVELY MUSIC' UNIT
description: MANHATTAN's new music is supposed to be divided between ''uptown'' and ''downtown,'' the former meaning old-fashioned cerebral modernism and the latter, post-Cageian experimentation. Periodically, a composer or group of composers associated with one camp will venture into the other. Sometimes that means Charles Wuorinen downtown, but more often it involves experimentalists marching up to Carnegie Hall or Town Hall, audiences and ambiences intact. In other words, the composers may move their performances uptown, but that hardly ensures an uptown audience.

title: STAGE: A BRITISH SCHOOL FOR FOREIGN STUDENTS
description: NEW HAVEN IF Humpty Dumpty were shaped like a cigar, he might look like Remak Ramsay in the Long Wharf Theater's production of Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms.'' Mr. Ramsay - tall, rail-thin, a bit baldish - has the innocent, eggy smile of a baby and seems just as fragile. He tends to perch himself precariously on a soiled, green easy chair, and we keep worrying that someone will shove him to the floor. We know that once that push comes Mr. Ramsay is certain to break.

title: Burleson Throwing
description: Nearly nine months after he suffered the kind of injury that can end a major league career, Rick Burleson, the shortstop for the California Angels, has begun throwing a baseball in an effort to restore his arm to playing condition. But after the first few throwing sessions, his prospects of returning to the lineup this year still seem doubtful.

title: 'DISHONORARIA'
description: The proliferation of political-action committees in Washington, and House members' recent $9,000 pay increase, have understandably attracted press and public attention. But the lifting of limits on what Senators can personally earn from outside honorariums may well be the worst legacy of the 97th Congress.

title: Montoya of Bengals Out
description: Max Montoya, Cincinnati's regular right guard, will miss Sunday's playoff game against the Jets, the Bengals said yesterday, because of a knee injury that he suffered in practice Wednesday. He is to be replaced by Glenn Bujnoch, a veteran who backed up at left guard this season.

title: PENTAGON IS TURNING 40
description: The Pentagon, conceived and born during World War II, a child when this country fought in Korea and becoming an adult as the Vietnam War began to escalate, is reaching middle age.

title: Leafs End Road Slump
description: Rick Vaive scored on a power play to snap a second-period tie tonight, and the Toronto Maple Leafs went on to defeat the Washington Capitals, 3-1, snapping a streak of 30 road games without a victory.

title: City Aide Favored For State Tax Job
description: Governor Cuomo is expected to select Martin Ives, New York City's first deputy comptroller, to be State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, Cuomo aides said yesterday.

title: A Tough Act To Follow
description: T he doctors told her later that her muscles helped save her life. All the hours spent on the exercise machine, all the pushups, all the swimming, had strengthened her chest and arms and stomach muscles so much that when the hansom cab ran over Donna Simms, she was not crushed to death.

title: U.S. Confirms General Met Sandinist Officials
description: The Pentagon confirmed today that Brig. Gen. William E. Odom, Army assistant chief of staff for intelligence, met with Sandinist officials Wednesday in Nicaragua. A spokesman said the general was on a ''routine operational tour'' that would include stops in Panama, Honduras and El Salvador.

title: Price Rises Ease in Italy
description: Consumer prices in Italy rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December from the previous month, the smallest monthly increase of the year, the Italian statistical agency Istat said today. December prices were up 16.3 percent from December 1981, slightly above the 16 percent ceiling set by the Government in its antiinflation campaign for 1982.

title: ART: 'FIGURES OF MYSTERY' SHOWS NEW WORK BY 10
description: THE current interest in figurative expressionism, whatever its other rewards, is a bonanza for the museum trade, since much of the new art - susceptible as it is to different interpretations -lends itself so well to the fabrication of theme shows. For a curator with a point to make, all it takes, very often, is a general casting call to galleries for work that will look good in the context of an exhibition. That's the feeling one gets from the current ''Figures of Mystery'' at the Queens Museum in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park through Jan. 23, which presents 10 artists whose work is characterized, according to the show's description, by ''raw emotions, an aura of mystery, enigma and vulnerability.''

title: 'BABY BELL' OFFERS ITS FIRST 2 PHONES
description: The fledging American Bell Inc. today introduced its first major consumer product - a telephone that can be programmed.

title: Bank-Theft Arrest In Waterbury Area
description: The police have made their first arrest in one of two night-depository thefts in the Waterbury area, charging a 29-year-old man with larceny and burglary, Inspector John Griffin said today.

title: Schub Recital in Queens
description: Andre-Michel Schub, gold-medal winner of the sixth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, will play a solo recital at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts tomorrow night at 8:30.

title: ISRAEL AND LEBANON FAIL ON AGENDA BUT CONSIDER U.S. PROPOSAL
description: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators, meeting today in the northern Israeli town of Qiryat Shemona, failed again to agree on an agenda to guide their talks on the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon.

title: DISTRESS SIGNS IN THE YUKON
description: In the 1898 Gold Rush, the Yukon seemed like the center of the world. A legend named Klondike Kate was the blue-eyed darling of the miners; booming Dawson fancied itself as the ''Paris of the North,'' and janitors were making small fortunes by panning barroom shavings for gold dust spilled the night before.

title: DANCE: SAMPLER OPENS RIVERSIDE FESTIVAL
description: RIVERSIDE Dance Festival celebrated itself and its new season Wednesday at Theater of the Riverside Church in a gala performance that had the right ingredients: good dance, interesting new faces and new works, a sense of community and some surprises.

title: INDIA SETS A VOTE IN STATE OF ASSAM
description: The Government announced today that elections would be held next month in the troubled northeastern state of Assam, and policemen there reportedly arrested about 20 student leaders of a movement that has vowed to block all voting.

title: MOSLEM MILITIAS CLASH IN 2 TRIPOLI SLUMS, KILLING 9
description: Rival Moslem militiamen clashed again in this northern Lebanese port city today, killing nine people.

title: U.S. DIFFERS AND SETS UP AN ALERT
description: Soviet officials denied yesterday that their nuclear-powered reconnaissance satellite was out of control and in danger of crashing to earth. But American officials said ''our information is different'' and placed a nuclear emergency search team on standby alert.

title: Friday; MUSICAL 'DIRT' ON 52D ST.
description: Bob Carroll will sing, talk, walk, crawl, and dance with willing members of the audience at 9 tonight and tomorrow night at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street, at 10th Avenue, in his new entertainment, ''Dirt '83.'' With four musical colleagues - Robbie McCauley, Ed Montgomery, David Sulzer and Miguel Rodriguez - he will also offer reworked parts of his ''Salmon Show'' and ''Dirt Show.'' Mr. Carroll is interested in all kinds of dirt: scandalous news, for instance, or moving continents, and members of the audience are encouraged to bring their own. Admission: $7. Reservations: 581-7032. SALSA IN A SOHO KITCHEN

title: The $1,000 Tower - and the Hungry
description: Though Ronald Reagan came to office preaching slogans about big, bad deficits, what he's preaching now is responsible fiscal policy. Forget the deficit, he says, until Government can steer the economy out of recession.

title: Walsh Weighs Future
description: The Los Angeles Rams hired an executive vice president yesterday, and the San Francisco 49ers were trying to keep their head coach. Ray Nagel, the athletic director at the University of Hawaii - and a personal friend of the Rams owner, Georgia Frontiere -was named the chief operating officer.

title: GIFTS IN MEMORIAL GIVEN TO NEEDIEST
description: Commemorations of anniversaries, marking both great historic occasions and memorable events in the life of a family, often inspire contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Coca-Cola Co. said it had sold its upstate New York bottling properties -including bottling facilities in Syracuse and Albany and distribution centers in nine communities - to companies affiliated with existing bottlers; the price was not disclosed.

title: OUTER BOROUGHS WILL GET RANGE OF CABLE SERVICE
description: The cable-television companies that will operate in the four boroughs outside Manhattan will be required to offer a wide range of services, including special channels for movies, entertainment and sports, city officials said yesterday.

title: NORMAN E. HORN
description: Norman E. Horn, a former general superintendent of the Wellington Sears Company, a textile manufacturing concern, died Wednesday at Waterbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 90 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: N.F.L. Ranking; Computer ranking based on games through Jan. 3 ;  OPPONENTS PERFORMANCES RANK TEAM Last Avg. Margin Avg. Margin Week Record of Victory Rating *Record of Victory
PHILLIPS MOVE TO BUY GENERAL AMERICAN SEEN
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has reached an agreement to acquire the General American Oil Company of Texas, apparently thwarting the Mesa Petroleum Company's unwelcome bid for a majority interest in General American, executives at one of the companies said today.

title: DUTIES ON SUBWAY CARS ARE OPPOSED BY RAVITCH
description: With lawyers and bankers at his side, Richard Ravitch, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, came here today to dissuade the Reagan Administration from penalizing the M.T.A. for ordering Canadian subway cars.

title: Night for Conigliaro
description: Ever since Tony Conigliaro suffered a near-fatal heart attack a year ago, the Boston Red Sox organization has been looking for a way to aid its former slugger, who was later stricken with a collapsed lung and pneumonia and is confined to a rehabilitation center. Yesterday, Haywood Sullivan, the club's general manager, announced that the team's home game with the Detroit Tigers on Monday, June 6, would be ''Tony Conigliaro Night.'' He will receive the full Red Sox share of the net gate receipts, which could amount to as much as $100,000.

title: OPTION TRADING CLEARED ON STOCK INDEX FUTURES
description: The Government yesterday approved the first options markets in stock index futures, one based on the Standard & Poor's 500 index and the other on the New York Stock Exchange's composite index.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEEK BUDGET SOLUTIONS AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: The Reagan Administration's basic decisions on a 1984 budget remained unsettled today, with White House officials reported still pondering a wide range of strategies. These included what aides described as a possible freeze of some spending levels to deal with the record Federal deficit.

title: Let Guatemala Prove Itself
description: A determined military regime, like Poland's, can usually impose a social peace of sorts. But few Americans would say this meets their human rights standard.

title: I.C.C. MOVES TO LET RAILROADS PROVIDE TRUCKING SERVICES
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today removed a 48-year-old barrier that had prevented railroads from moving into the commercial trucking business. The commission's action thus permits the rail lines to move closer to the goal of becoming complete transportation companies.

title: SHAVING: THE PERFECT BRUSH
description: Shaving is one of life's most boring - if regular -rituals for almost 50 percent of the population. Some men perform the ceremony automaton-style: it's their version of sleepwalking. Others, especially those with heavy beards, quite actively hate it. ''I've been shaving since I was 13,'' says one man, now in his mid-40's. ''Once a day every day and twice if I'm going out in the evening. I don't want to even try to work out how many months of my life that adds up to.'' ''To enjoy shaving,'' said another, ''you've got to be the kind of person who loves weeding.''

title: DUKAKIS, AT INAUGURATION, VOWS TO AID NEEDY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: In an inaugural ceremony colored by clerical prayers for an end to ''petty and partial politics,'' Gov. Edward J. King today walked down the Statehouse steps into the rain at the traditional hour of noon and Michael S. Dukakis was formally returned to the Governor's office he lost four years ago.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A state judge approved a $20 million settlement today for victims of the 1981 Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster.

title: FORD MADOX FORD'S 'THE GOOD SOLDIER'
description: IN a rare departure from its miniseries format, public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' is offering a two-hour dramatization of a famous novel in a single sitting Sunday night at 9 on WNET, Channel 13. The work is Ford Madox Ford's ''The Good Soldier,'' a book he began on his 40th birthday, in December 1913, to ''show what I could do.'' It has been adapted beautifully for television by Julian Mitchell. And with Peter Eckersley as producer and Kevin Billington as director, it has been transposed to the television screen splendidly.

title: Anniversary Plan
description: On Saturday, Dec. 29, 1934, the first college basketball doubleheader was played at Madison Square Garden. Frank McGuire, then a St. John's sophomore, recently recalled that night when Westminster beat St. John's and New York University beat Notre Dame.

title: U.S. Attorney Needn't Testify On News Report, Judge Rules
description: A Federal district judge ruled Tuesday that United States Attorney William Weld would not have to testify about an alleged unauthorized disclosure of information to Fox Butterfield, a reporter for The New York Times.

title: SOVIET BLOC GIVES DETAILS OF ITS PROPOSED NONAGGRESSISON ACT
description: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies made public today the details of a proposed nonaggression pact with the nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, saying that peace in the world depended heavily on lowering ''mistrust'' between the two alliances in Europe.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: NAKASONE URGES CLOSE TIES TO U.S. AND SEOUL
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that he favors close relations with the United States and South Korea to insure stability in East Asia at a time of ''recent strengthening of Soviet military pressure in the region.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It is not a dangerous situation, and we have no worries about the fate of this sputnik.''

title: Coming: A musical on the good years before Vietnam
description: TOM EYEN, who wrote the book and lyrics for ''Dreamgirls,'' and Alan Menken, the composer of ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' are collaborating on a new musical. Their show is about to take its first tentative step toward Broadway with a 12-week workshop production, which Mr. Eyen will direct.

title: Zenith and Taft Co.  In Teletext Venture
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation, a manufacturer of color televisions, desk top computers and cable television equipment, annouced today that it had signed a five-year agreement with the Taft Broadcasting Company to produce teletext receiving equipment.

title: WARSAW PACT COMMUNIQUE ON RELATIONS WITH NATO
description: Following are excerpts from a communique issued today by the Warsaw Pact, as distributed in translation from the Czech by Czechoslovakia's official press agency:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Bulls, at Chicago. The Nets, who took a six-game winning streak into last night's game against the Phoenix Suns, take to the road against the Bulls.

title: C.I.A.'S ASTOUNDING DATA ON THE U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: White Returns To Yanks
description: Three years after he failed to get the playing contract he wanted, Roy White returned to the Yankees yesterday with a coaching contract. ''I was never really bitter about leaving the Yankees,'' White, a Yankee player for 14 years, said at a Yankee Stadium news conference. ''I was disappointed, but that was a business decision.''

title: Boston Marathon To Keep Course
description: The Boston Marathon will be run over the same course it has used for the last 17 years despite a legal battle that might have changed its starting and finishing lines, officials said today.

title: BALLET: TWO JOFFREY HITS
description: THE Joffrey Ballet, which has only one week left of its City Center season after this weekend, came up with a most happy revival and a new popular success in a world premiere by Gerald Arpino Wednesday night.

title: Manhattan Wins
description: Free throws by Luke Johnson and Joe McGinnis gave Manhattan a 52-51 upset victory over Connecticut last night at Draddy Gymnasium.

title: Dioxin Debris to Remain In Times Beach, Mo.
description: Gov. Christopher S. Bond ordered a halt today to plans to move flood debris possibly contaminated with dioxin from Times Beach to a landfill in Warren County, about 40 miles away.

title: Oklahoma City Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today imposed a two-year probation on Oklahoma City University for a wide range of violations, including a cash Christmas present to the school's basketball team from its head coach.

title: VINCENT MCKIM WHITE
description: Vincent McKim White, a former vice president of Westinghouse Electric International, a division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: No Headline
description: Polish Newspaper Hails Appointment of Glemp

title: JUDGE BIDS U.S. ACT ON GAS CARCINOGEN
description: A Federal district judge here ordered the Occupational Safety and Health Administration today to act within 20 days to protect workers from a highly toxic, cancer-causing gas called ethylene oxide.

title: Myths That Textiles Weave
description: In childhood we thought that people on the other side of the world lived upside down. Presumably Chinese children think the same of us. And what must they think now that China's Communist Government is reading us lectures in free-market theory?

title: Frontier Air to Cut Nonunion Salaries
description: Frontier Holdings, the holding company for Frontier Airlines, said it would lower salaries for all management and nonunion employees - about 600 people - by 10 percent as the first step of ''substantial'' cost reductions.

title: CUSTODY DISPUTE IN BRINK'S CASE ARGUED IN COURT
description: State and Federal prosecutors clashed in court today in a dispute over custody of a witness in the Brink's robbery and murder case.

title: Short-Term Rates Down a Bit; Notes and Bonds Steady
description: Short-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday while yields for notes and bonds were about unchanged in quiet trading, securities dealers said.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 2 U.S. Diplomats Told To Get Out of Suriname

title: UPPER EAST SIDE ATTRACTS TWO MIXED-USE PROJECTS
description: A five-block stretch of Third Avenue just above 59th Street in Manhattan illuminates this truism of the development community: Despite the straitened conditions of the market generally, the East Side's allure for the affluent continues undiminished.

title: MOYERS AND KURALT PROGRAMS PLANNED BY CBS
description: CBS News announced yesterday that two of its best-known correspondents, Bill Moyers and Charles Kuralt, would each be featured in his own weekly public affairs series in prime time over 10 weeks next summer, possibly beginning as early as May. The separate half-hour programs will air back to back at an hour and day still to be determined.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: WHAT has become, by tradition, one of the most social weeks of the y ear, was followed by the equally traditional calm of the week after.P eople entertained small groups of friends or did not entertain at a ll. And those who did entertain, had their own reason, once again, t radition.

title: Nabisco Unit Sold
description: A group of Hygiene Industries management led by its president, Noel Levine, announced the acquisition of the operation from Nabisco Brands Inc. The group purchased all stock of Associated Products Inc., of which Hygiene, a manufacturer of shower curtains and bath accessories, is the major business, it said. Terms were not disclosed. Financing was arranged by First Boston.

title: City Opera Unit Opens 6-Week 'Carmen' Tour
description: The New York City Opera National Company, the touring arm of the New York City Opera, begins a six-week, 17-state tour of its new production of ''Carmen'' in Hershey, Pa., today.

title: AN AID TO HIKERS
description: I f you live in New York City, have a yen for woodland hiking but don't know how to begin, the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference can help.

title: HAWKS' FINAL SHOT TURNS BACK KNICKS
description: Eddie Johnson's 15-foot jumper from the right baseline with three seconds to play last night capped a frantic finish to a game in which the Atlanta Hawks edged the Knicks, 99-98, at Madison Square Garden. The victory ended a three-game losing streak for the Hawks.

title: ART: CLOCKS AT THE FRICK
description: CLOCKS don't count as art, some people say. Art is painting and drawing and sculpture. The rest is interior decoration. If clocks are allowed to be art, there'll be no end to it. Knives and forks will be art, and umbrellas and socks.

title: RUSSIANS BEAT FLYERS IN FINALE
description: The Soviet all-star team completed its sixgame trip through the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Philadelphia Flyers, 5-1, at the Spectrum. The victory gave the Russians a 4-2 record.

title: STATES' DELEGATES SET BY DEMOCRATS
description: The Democratic National Committee today announced the allocation of 3,923 delegate votes to the states for its 1984 Presidential nominating convention amid signs that several states were reluctant to pick their delegates under rules changes that were set last year.

title: NEW VOGUE: COMPANY CULTURE
description: In the 1960's, decentralization was the vogue in management. In the 1970's, corporate strategy became the buzzword. Now, corporate culture is the magic phrase that management consultants are breathing into the ears of American executives.

title: TAX CREDIT SALES
description: The LTV Corporation, Dallas, announced that it had sold tax benefits relating to approximately $116 million of equipment placed in service in the fourth quarter of 1982 for $38 million in cash. Separately, the Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, Houston, announced it had received $17.3 million for tax benefits from certain property.

title: French Aide to Visit U.S.
description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu said today that he would have talks with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger in Washington later this month. He told journalists that he would also probably meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz when he visits Washington Jan. 18.

title: Black Caucus Elects Chief
description: The Congressional Black Caucus has elected Representative Julian C. Dixon, Democrat of California, to serve as its chairman in the 98th Congress. Mr. Dixon succeeds Walter Fauntroy, a delegate to Congress from the District of Columbia, as leader of the 21-member caucus.

title: TWELFTH NIGHT REVELS CLOSE HOLIDAY SEASON WITH A FLOURISH
description: THIS is the weekend following Twelfth Night, whose feasts and festivals have for centuries marked the finale of the Christmas and New Year season. The tradition lives on, and in the next few days music and dance groups in surprising numbers will mark the occasion by putting on masks and putting on masques.

title: COURT SETS BACK A TAX DEDICATED TO MASS TRANSIT
description: A state appellate court ruled today that a key provision of a much-disputed 1980 tax to aid mass transit was unconstitutional.

title: Chairman Leaves Bank For Automation Venture
description: Alvin C. Rice has resigned as chairman of the Imperial Bank in Los Angeles. Mr. Rice and a group of investors are buying a subsidiary of the bank, Imperial Automation Inc., which will sell automated systems to financial institutions.

title: Suspect in Slaying Released on Bail
description: The woman accused of killing her boss last month at a Fifth Avenue law firm was released from jail yesterday on $15,000 bail, authorities said.

title: A.T.& T. Files Rate Proposal
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed rates for international telex and data transmission that undercut those offered by companies now specializing in such overseas service.

title: J. Stanford Smith, 68, Of International Paper
description: J. Stanford Smith, former chairman and chief executive officer of the International Paper Company, died of cancer yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Lion Talks
description: That unfamiliar voice two nights ago doing the color broadcast of a college basketball game on Columbia University's WKCR belonged to the school's mascot, the Lion, also known as Betsy Gallagher, a 20-year-old Barnard junior from Bronxville, N.Y. Miss Gallagher, it is believed, was the first woman to do the commentary or play by play on the oldest FM station in the country.

title: BREAD AND SUCCESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: A MATTER OF EVIDENCE
description: Current attempts to modify the exclusionary rule in law call to mind Woody Allen's sage observation that the lion and the lamb shall lie down together, but the lamb won't get much sleep. At issue is whether the United States Supreme Court should adhere to its nearly 70-year-old rule that evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures may not be used in a criminal trial.

title: STRAIGHT'S COMMENTS ON 'THE STRAIGHT STORY'
description: To the Editor:

title: AT 'PLENTY,' TRAFFIC MOVES BY MURMURS
description: Twenty-eight minutes into the play, there is the startling sound of pounding, running feet in the quiet blackness backstage. Kate Nelligan, the star of ''Plenty,'' which opened officially on Broadway last night, sprints into the tiny, flimsily curtained quick-change room in a corner just in back of the command post of Michael Chambers, the production stage manager.

title: S.E.C. Questions Offer for Propane
description: The Suburban Propane Gas Corporation said it had been advised by the Securities and Exchange Commission that a $48.50-a-share tender offer by the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation for 3 million Suburban shares raised certain questions under the Public Utility Holding Act of 1935.

title: AT INTERIOR, A VIEW ACROSS THE RIVER
description: When the often grumpy Harold L. Ickes moved into his suite as Secretary of the Interior in the new Interior Department building one fine spring morning in 1937, he was almost purring as he wrote in his then-secret diary:

title: MRS. GANDHI LOSES GRIP ON 2 STATES
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi suffered a major political defeat today when her Congress Party lost control of two southern states it had dominated since India became independent in 1947.

title: Reagan to Meet Farmers
description: President Reagan is to fly to Dallas next week to address the 64th annual meeting of the American Farm Bureau Federation, the White House announced today. Farm Bureau officials expect the President to make a major announcement in the speech.

title: Seafirst Names Credit Officer
description: Glenhall E. Taylor Jr., an executive vice president of Wells Fargo & Company, was named chief credit officer and executive vice president of the Seafirst Corporation and its Seattle First National Bank.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1983
description: International Soviet officials denied that a nuclear-powered reconnaissance satellite was out of control and in danger of crashing to earth, but United States officials said that the satellite was continuing to behave erratically and to lose altitude. The American officials warned they would be unable to give more than a few hours' warning of where or when the satellite was likely to crash. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Indira Gandhi suffered a major rebuff as her Congress Party lost control of two southern states that it had dominated since India became independent in 1947. Opposition parties swept to stunning victories in legislative elections in Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, the only states where the Prime Minister's party had not previously been defeated. (A1:1.)

title: A Greenpeace Trawler Seized in French Harbor
description: French officials, backed by policemen firing tear gas grenades, seized a trawler of the Greenpeace environmental movement today after it forced its way into this port in an attempt to prevent delivery of 24 tons of Japanese nuclear waste for reprocessing in France.

title: Advertising; Observing Methods At 3 Shops
description: BEHIND sterile-looking office building facades, the concept generators of advertising churn out their communications products for clients in every imaginable field.

title: Bonuses for Garvey
description: Two weeks after Steve Garvey left the Los Angeles Dodgers to sign with the San Diego Padres, the financial details of his five-year contract are beginning to emerge. According to The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, Garvey has been guaranteed $1.85 million for the 1983 season and could receive as much as $2.525 million -but only if the Padres draw at least 2.5 million fans and make it into the World Series. Last season, the team drew only 1.6 million fans and finished fourth in the National League's Western Division.

title: Cecil Wright, 74, Dies; Ex-President of Penney
description: Cecil L. Wright, former president and chief administrative officer of the J.C. Penney Company, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. Mr. Wright, who lived in Boynton Beach and Roaring Gap, N.C., was 74 years old.

title: 7 PERCENT RATE RISE FOR AUTO INSURANCE APPROVED BY JERSEY
description: A 7 percent increase in automobile insurance rates for 1.4 million New Jersey motorists was approved today by Insurance Commissioner Joseph F. Murphy.

title: Ex-Banker in Louisiana Kidnapped From Home
description: A helicopter and nearly 30 patrol cars scoured the backwater bayous of French-speaking Acadiana in southern Louisiana today for a retired bank official kidnapped from his home at knifepoint.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Margaret Denney and her co-workers are Information, which is a tall order anywhere, much less in New York. ''Is this Information?'' ask the voices on the other end of the line, and Miss Denney, directory assistance operator No. 5063, answers back, ''Yes it is,'' in the smoky voice that has led some people over the years to address her as ''Sir.''

title: Cadillac Fairview
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation, which is based in Toronto, said that its United States subsidiary, Cadillac Fairview U.S. Inc., had completed the sale of its investment in General Homes Consolidated Companies for $40 milion in cash and other considerations. General Consolidated is based in Houston. The sale is part of Cadillac Fairview's previously announced plan to sell all of its residential real estate holdings.

title: DIETING AS PAINLESSLY AS POSSIBLE
description: Few subjects inspire as much conversation and controversy as reducing diets. Last Saturday on this page I suggested that it is wise to find a diet that suits one psychologically, always assuming, of course, that it meets with a doctor's approval. It seems hard enough to battle temptation without also having to fight one's own basic temperament. Since then, I have received many helpful and interesting comments on other aspects of this subject.

title: Reaction to a Record
description: Wichita State has a record-breaking athletics program, and the university's president, Clark Ahlberg, isn't at all happy about it.

title: Books of the Times; Born Wet and Still Wet
description: DRINKING IN AMERICA. By Mark Ed- ward Lender and James Kirby Martin. Illustrated. 222 pages. The Free Press, a division of Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: POLLUTION
description: The Justice Department today announced it was seeking to impose penalties of roughly $115 million on the LTV Corporation because of what the department said was the failure of five of its Jones & Laughlin steel plants to meet Clean Air Act requirements.

title: Writing Exhibition Gets $150,000 Federal Grant
description: A $150,000 Federal grant will pay for a traveling exhibition tracing the history of writing from man's first scratchings on rocks 8,000 years ago through the evolution of the Roman alphabet in the 4th century, the National Endowment for the Humanities announced Thursday.

title: HERBERT M. ROSENTHAL
description: Herbert M. Rosenthal, a Manhattan businessman who was an advocate of community care for the mentally retarded, died Thursday of cancer at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. RELEASES GUIDELINES TOWARD 11 L.I.R.R. PACTS
description: The Presidential emergency board in the Long Island Rail Road contract disputes has recommended wage increases of 20 percent over three years as the basis for settlements with the 11 unions still without agreements.

title: CAREY'S 'MISCHIEF' NEEDS INVESTIGATING
description: To the Editor: On the eve of the New Year, New Yorkers were informed by their departing Governor that he had taken it upon himself to direct the utilization of state government services and funds for the benefit of candidates for office (news story Dec. 30).

title: Chinese Army Official Dies
