description: Yang Yong, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Chinese Army, died of an illness Thursday, China's official press agency reported today. He was 70 years old.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES DEFENSE CLAIMS IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Several defense challenges to the admissibility of critical evidence in the Brink's robbery and murder case were dismissed today by the presiding judge. The decisions cleared the way for use of the material in the trial of six suspects.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: St. Bart's (Cont'd.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not sure, even if we tried, if we could put it out.'' - John P. Caufield, director of the Newark Fire Department. (1:3.)

title: Stand Up Soon And Be Counted
description: New York State, like the World Boxing Council, Nevada and New Jersey, is changing some rules in the hope of making professional boxing safer. Jack Graham, recently promoted to a commissioner on the New York State Athletic Commission and put in charge of boxing by Jack Prenderville, the chairman, said the standing 8-count and a nonscoring referee would be adopted here ''very soon.''

title: ON WATCH FOR DISASTERS ACROSS THE U.S.
description: In the Watch Room of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, P.R. Ray's desk is surrounded by photographs of communities wrecked by hurricanes, blizzards and floods. Some pictures show people clinging to roofs as floods engulf their homes and others show bulldozers pushing mud out of commercial buildings.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision of a Federal district judge in Chicago approving a school desegregation plan with no mandatory busing represents a victory for Reagan Administration policies in one case, but it does not necessarily set a precedent for other cities or signal a wave of the future.

title: HONOR LOTTO LOSERS
description: The winners of vast sums in lotteries unfailingly have their pictures in the newspapers and on television. For a while, after the first news reports about their good luck, there are kind stories about these favored few. These people are lionized as heroes or heroines. Their fateful selection places them nearly at a level with those intrepid souls who rescue lads from ice floes or save helpless old ladies from raging conflagrations.

title: Happy Birthday
description: Copelan, Mitchell Griffin was happy to report, spent his birthday galloping. ''He's back in training and his eye is doing fine,'' said the trainer of Copelan, one of last year's top 2-year-old thoroughbreds.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alabama Power Company's first mortgage bonds have had their rating raised to BBB+ from BBB by Standard & Poor's, which cited a decision last November by the Alabama Public Service Commission to increase rates charged by the utility.

title: Topics; Opening Errors; Postal Portents
description: The search for portents of George Orwell's 1984 having begun, we modestly offer a recent brush with Big Brother in the waning days of '82:

title: U.S. TO LET BIG CONCERN GO INTO BROKERAGE BUSINESS
description: The Federal Reserve Board today allowed the BankAmerica Corporation, which owns the nation's largest bank, to buy a major discount stockbrokerage firm.

title: Gas-Buying Pattern
description: Natural gas prices are rising sharply because many pipeline companies are buying the most expensive gas and in some cases bypassing cheap gas, according to a study issued today by the General Accounting Office. The Congressional investigative agency said some pipelines had contracts requiring them to buy the high-priced gas, and some did so because they were affiliated with producers selling high-priced gas. The analysis did not specify which pipelines were buying the most expensive gas.

title: Foul Trouble At Its Worst
description: When Duchesne took the floor against Brownell-Talbot in a high school game in Omaha Thursday night, there were eight girls on the Duchesne squad. By the time the game was over, there was only Margy Lindsay.

title: U.S. TELLS SOVIET OF CONCERN OVER NEW MISSILES FOR SYRIA
description: The United States expressed official concern to the Soviet Union today over confirmed intelligence reports that Syria is building sites to handle a long-range Soviet-made antiaircraft missile that American officials fear could provoke a new round of violence in the Middle East.

title: Danish Captain Is Fined For Fishing Near Britain
description: An English court convicted the captain of a Danish trawler today for his ''flagrant and deliberate breach'' of new British laws banning Denmark from fishing inside a 12-mile zone and fined him $51,200.

title: BRUINS TIE DEVILS
description: Another collapse in the third period afflicted the New Jersey Devils tonight as they took no shots on goal and yielded two goals to the Boston Bruins, who gained a 2-2 tie.

title: MARKET EXTENDS ITS RALLY
description: The stock market extended its rally yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 5.15 points, to 1,076.07, exceeding the record set the day before. Trading continued heavy, reflecting activity by pension funds and other institutional investors.

title: JOFFREY: ASHTON'S 'ILLUMINATIONS' AND LAURA DEAN'S 'NIGHT'
description: Choreographers who base ballets upon literature may cause viewers to ponder both the actual steps in their ballets and the relationship between those steps and the literary source materials. One ballet that can prompt quite a bit of pondering is Frederick Ashton's ''Illuminations,'' to a melodious song cycle by Benjamin Britten based upon prose-poems by Arthur Rimbaud, the great 19th-century French poet.

title: Thousands Protest Italian Economic Policies
description: Thousands of workers demonstrated, occupied railroad stations and blocked highways in major cities across Italy today to protest the Government's tough new economic measures.

title: Sunbeam to Close Mississippi Plant
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, the Chicago-based consumer appliance subsidiary of Allegheny International, said that it planned to close its Forest, Miss., clock manufacturing plant and move the operations to its Hackensack, N.J. instruments manufacturing facility.

title:
PATENTS;
Patent Office Workers Receive an Award
description: The Department of Commerce presented an award for distinguished public service this week to employees of the Patent and Trademark Office, which is a division of the department.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STAR TREK

title: HOW TO CREATE NEW 'ANTIQUE' CLOTHING
description: Barbara Richer likes Victorian clothing. She used to buy it. Now she makes it. ''I had to alter things to fit,'' said Mrs. Richer, who is Henri Bendel's art director. ''So I started to sew. Then I discovered patterns for vintage clothing, and I loved the idea.''

title: NEW YORK-JERSEY JOBLESSNESS DECLINED SLIGHTLY LAST MONTH
description: The unemployment rates in New York State and New Jersey declined last month, but the job market in both states continued to show weakness, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. New York City's rate also went down slightly.

title: Japan Names U.N. Delegate
description: The Government today named Mizuo Kuroda as its chief delegate to the United Nations. The Foreign Ministry said Mr. Kuroda, 63 years old, would succeed Masahiro Nisibori, who is returning to Tokyo for a new assignment. Mr. Kuroda has served as Japan's Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Egypt and Australia.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN WEIGHS SLIGHT TRIM IN ARMS PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan was portrayed by White House officials today as increasingly likely to accept modest cuts in military spending in his 1984 budget along with a freeze on spending for selected Government programs.

title: FORECAST OF 25% RISE IN GAS PRICE DRAWS WARNING ON HOME HEATING
description: One day after the United States Department of Energy said natural gas prices would continue to rise sharply, New York officials cautioned consumers about converting their home heating systems from oil to natural gas.

title: IRAQ REPORTS FRANCE WILL BUY MORE OIL AND CONTINUE AID
description: Tareq Aziz, a Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, said today that France was increasing its purchases of Iraqi oil and continuing military aid on what he called a ''vast scale.''

title: Denial by Japanese
description: The Japan Chemical Fibers Association today denied assertions by American manufacturers that Japanese textile makers were selling certain products at unfairly low prices in the United States. It plans to ask the Government to challenge the dumping complaints.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: AFTER four and a half decades of testing, teasing and at times p oking holes in the products marketed by American private enterprise,C onsumer Reports last year faced a marketing problem of its own.

title: SALVADORAN COLONEL REFUSES AN ORDER
description: The military commander of a northern El Salvador province, angered over a transfer from his post, declared himself to be ''in rebellion'' against the Defense Minister late Thursday night and placed his troops on alert.

title: No Headline
description: McENROE DEFEATS LENDL FOR FIRST TIME IN YEAR

title: The U.S.O. Cares
description: Since 1941, one organization has existed solely to provide for the physical and spiritual well-being of American service men and women.

title: NETS WIN EIGHTH STRAIGHT
description: In the opening minutes tonight, the Nets did not look like a team that had just set a team record of seven straight victories. But they recovered their composure, and with the help of another strong performance from Mickey Johnson, they went on to extend their steak to eight games by defeating the struggling Chicago Bulls, 111-98, before 5,682 fans here at the Stadium.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Field Trip On Public-Service Law

title:
Patents;
Method To Cool Reactors
description: WASHINGTON AMETHOD of cooling a nuclear reactor with liquid metal was patented this week for the Department of Energy. A nuclear fuel made of uranium microspheres is covered for the agency by another of the week's patents.

title: GROUPS OF WORKERS DONATE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: Together with the office party, the exchange of holiday cards and gifts among employees is being abandoned in many business and professional establishments, and the savings are being donated to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: VILLANOVA DEFEATS IRISH, 61-55
description: Ed Pinckney scored 19 points, and John Pinone 16 tonight as Villanova rallied from an 8-point deficit in the second half to beat Notre Dame, 61-55.

title: NEAL M. M'MENAMIN
description: Neal M. McMenamin, former senior vice president of Edwin Bird Wilson, Inc., a New York City advertising agency, died last Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 54 years old.

title: Benjamin Kranz, a Manager Of Theater Units for 50 Years
description: Benjamin Kranz, a production stage manager for Broadway and national touring companies, died on Jan. 4 in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 72 years old.

title: Index; International
description: Israel's other wounds: The psy- chiatric casualties 2 Israeli M.P., at lunch with P.L.O. aide, urges Palestinian state 3 Salvadoran area's farmers sup- port rebellious colonel 4 Iraqi reports French military aid and increasing oil purchases 4 Around the World 5 West German election is called for March 6 5 Government/Politics Mayoral candidates of San Diego cite need to control for disasters across the U.S. 10 General Around the Nation 8 Two ex-antipoverty workers win $1.6 million in damages 9 Miami march in memory of slain black is canceled 10 Worker's part-time job is Electronics show gives consum- ers a peek at tomorrow 13 Joffrey revives ''Illuminations'' 13 NBC offers police and detective shows 47 Style Consumer Saturday 48 De Gustibus 48 How to create new competitive balance 19 Playoff struggle unites unhappy Patriots 19 Jets' defense must receive help from offense 20 24 Scouting: New York boxers to stand up and be counted 20 Players: Wennington and Ewing, elbow to elbow 20 It's fourth and one for Pittsburgh ticket-holders 20 Ira Berkow on Brooklyn Col- lege's aspirations 21 High-flying Lakers tonight are next headache for Knicks 21 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 11 Going Out Guide 14 Sports People 18 New York Day by Day 26 About New York 27 News Analysis William K. Stevens on the set- back to Mrs. Gandhi 3 Robert Pear on school desegrega- tion case in Chicago 11 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 8, 1983; Companies
description: The Federal Reserve agreed to let BankAmerica acquire Charles Schwab, a major discount brokerage firm. The decision sets the stage for commercial banks to get into the stockbrokerage business and own seats on stock exchanges. The Fed rejected securities industry arguments that such a move would violate a 1933 law separating commercial and investment banking. (Page 1.)

title: Swiss Expel 2 Soviet Envoys
description: The Swiss Government has expelled two Soviet diplomats after accusing them of political espionage. A Swiss Justice Ministry communique said today that the diplomats, who were not identified, ''caught the attention of the counterintelligence.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Hilmer Kenty, a lightweight boxer who had said that he might retire from boxing because of persistent health problems, plans to meet James Martinez of Houston in a bout tentatively set for Jan. 28 in Wyandotte, Mich. ... Danny White, the starting quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys, got good news yesterday when X-rays indicated he had no broken bones in his right thumb. He was listed as a''probable'' starter in tomorrow's game against Tampa Bay. ... Portland announced that it has agreed to terms with Don Buse, a veteran guard who was a free agent; the Trail Blazers will give the Indiana Pacers cash and other considerations to sign Buse.

title: DEMOCRATS GIVE UP ILLINOIS CAMPAIGN
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d conceded tonight to Gov. James R. Thompson, just hours after the Illinois Supreme Court rejected Mr. Stevenson's bid for a statewide recount of the Nov. 2 gubernatorial voting.

title: Cable TV to Offer Plays By Royal Shakespeare
description: Nederlander, which produces programs for cable television, has reached an agreement to present televised productions of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Details of the deal will be announced Wednesday at a press conference in London, according to John Springer, a spokesman for RKO-Nederlander.

title: PARLIAMENT IN BONN IS DISMISSED TO MAKE WAY FOR EARLY ELECTION
description: President Karl Carstens dissolved Parliament today and, bowing to the wishes of the nation's political parties, called an early general election for March 6.

title: Albert Sussman Wed To Carol F. Chandler
description: Carol F. Chandler, a registered nurse, and Albert Sussman of Hartsdale, N.Y., executive vice president of the International Council of Shopping Centers in New York, were married yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Cantor David Benedict of Temple Israel, Lawrence, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: GHOST FLEET
description: To the Editor: Last year, I reported a cab driver who pulled away from a Central Park West doorman after noticing that the would-be passenger was in a wheelchair. My experience with the Taxi and Limousine Commission was much like that described by Robert Curvin in his Editorial Notebook article.

title: SOVIET SAYS SATELLITE IS FALLING BUT IS UNDER CONTROL
description: The Soviet Union confirmed yesterday that Cosmos 1402, its nuclear-powered reconnaissance satellite, was falling out of space but said that measures had been taken to insure that radioactive components would burn up before reaching the earth.

title: Indiana Names Wyche
description: The dismissal of Lee Corso as head football coach at Indiana University three weeks ago raised two questions: What would Corso do next, and who would take his place? Yesterday, the answers started coming in. First, Corso disclosed that he was seriously considering taking a fund-raising post at the University of Louisville, the school he left before moving to Indiana 10 years ago. Then Indiana announced the name of Corso's replacement: Sam Wyche, a former Furman University quarterback who has been quarterback coach for the San Francisco 49ers for the last four years.

title: Teledyne Net Off 89.1%
description: Teledyne Inc. reported yesterday that a $49.1 million write-down on its investment in the International Harvester Company had sharply depressed earnings.

title: DEMOTION PLAN MAY BE DOOMED
description: A move within the National Collegiate Athletic Association to trim as many as 45 schools from Division I basketball has drawn opposition from the Big Eight Conference and the American Council on Education and as a result may be doomed.

title: A.M.C. to Offer 11.9% Financing
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would follow the lead of the Big Three auto makers and offer 11.9 percent financing for buyers of 1983 A.M.C., Jeep and Renault vehicles except the Jeep Wagoneer and all leftover 1982's.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. Although the Lakers went on to win the National Basketball Association's championship last season, they lost both regular-season games they played against the Knicks. This is their first meeting this season. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Manhattan vs. St. Peter's, followed by St. John's vs. Georgetown, at the Garden; first game, 1 P.M. (Television - USA Cable, St. John's-Georgetown only, 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WGBB, 1240, and WNYE-FM, 91.5; 3 P.M., St. John's-Georgetown only.)

title: EASY MOVIEGOING
description: To the Editor:

title: A CITIZENRY UNPROTECTED FROM NOSY COMPUTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OTHER ISRAELI CASUALTIES: THE MENTALLY SCARRED
description: A 35-year-old Israeli soldier collapsed on seeing other soldiers blown apart while under heavy artillery bombardment. Evacuated to a treatment center, he sat and stared at one spot on the floor, responding only when someone touched him and called his name. He refused to touch a rifle.

title: Take the A Train
description: Marty Glickman, the veteran radio announcer who for many years was the voice of the Knicks, should have known about the other ''city game.'' Glickman, who now broadcasts University of Connecticut games, was reminded when he tried to get from midtown Manhattan to the Bronx campus of Manhattan College, where UConn was playing Thursday night.

title: Abraham M. Rosenthal; Rebuilt Nedick's Chain
description: Abraham M. Rosenthal, president of the Nedick's chain for 14 years until 1948, died last Dec. 30 at the St. John's Rehabilitation Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., while on vacation. He was 99 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Whirlwind Tour
description: It meant spending New Year's Eve in a Cleveland motel en route to New Jersey, a 20-hour-straight drive on the way back and an 81-58 loss in between. But to the Division III basketball team of the University of Wisconsin at Platteville, the trip to Jersey City to play St. Peter's, a Division I team, and the side trip to New York City, was well worth it.

title: HEADED NATIONAL ARTS GROUP
description: Nancy Hanks, who headed the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Council on the Arts under the Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations, died last night of cancer at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 55 years old, and lived in Washington.

title: BRIEFING
description: Getting the Word to Reagan

title: 5 COMPANIES IN VENTURE TO RUN 2 PAY-TV UNITS
description: Three film studios and two companies with major positions in satellite entertainment announced yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to operate Showtime and The Movie Channel, the second- and third-largest pay-television networks.

title: FROM AREA'S FARMERS, SUPPORT FOR REBELLIOUS COLONEL
description: After Lieut. Col. Sigiferdo Ochoa Perez explained his refusal to accept orders to leave his battalion, he invited into his office a group of about 30 community leaders who had arrived to show support for him.

title: Moving the Handicapped, Vertically
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's efforts to rebuild 10 deteriorated stations have been brought to a dead stop by the state's Public Buildings Law. It seemed humane to the Legislature to accommodate the handicapped by installing elevators or ramps in any public building being renovated. Unfortunately, no one in Albany bothered to calculate how much it would cost to extend such a requirement to the 450-odd stations of the New York City subway system, almost all of which need substantial modernization.

title: Bridge: The Certainties of the Game Are Dull, if Not Unpleasant
description: Death and taxes were cited by Benjamin Franklin as the only sure things in this life. Those who favor security and certainty should consider that sure things are either positively unpleasant, like death and taxes, or merely dull. Uncertainty - or, if you prefer, variety - is the spice of life.

title: POSTAL SERVICE PLANS 9-DIGIT ZIP CODE FOR OCTOBER
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger said today that the Postal Service would start using the nine-digit ZIP code in October to process mail, despite criticisms of the longer code by some Congressmen and the General Accounting Office.

title: KARAJAN AND ORCHESTRA CLASH OVER CLARINETIST
description: Herbert von Karajan, conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, has canceled all television appearances and recordings with the orchestra in a major dispute with the musicians over a clarinetist.

title: Caesars Drops Bid For Dunes Hotel
description: Caesars World Inc. said it would not exercise an option to purchase the Dunes Hotel and Casinos Inc. in Las Vegas.

title: Rev. Mark A. Tennien, Missionary and Author
description: The Rev. Mark A. Tennien, a Maryknoll missionary and author who spent 20 years in China until he was expelled by the Communist government in 1951, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 82 years old and resided at Maryknoll, headquarters of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

title: 3 MILLION GALLONS OF GASOLINE BURN AFTER TANK EXPLOSION IN NEWARK
description: Millions of gallons of gasoline continued to burn in huge fireballs here this morning, after explosions early Friday ripped through a storage-tank farm, killing one worker, injuring 24 people and sending out shock waves felt for 100 miles.

title: INDEPENDENT TRUCKERS CALL STRIKE OVER TAX ON GASOLINE
description: Two major developments threatened the nation's trucking industry today as independent truckers called for a strike to protest the new increase in the gasoline tax and trucking companies demanded that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters meet to discuss possible contract concessions.

title: WHEN YOU'RE OUT OF SOOTHS
description: I'm a little late with my New Year's column, but frankly I've been having problems with it. People expect columnists to columnize, predict, make lists of last year's heroes and goats, look into the future for next year's sung and unsung. I thought for a while that this would be a piece of cake - because someone actually gave me a crystal ball over the holidays. It's very pretty, but I've rubbed it and spun it and stared long and deeply into it. And all I get is a wide-angle view of my office upside down.

title: Taylor Honored Again
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' second-year linebacker, was named by The Associated Press defensive player of the year in the National Football League. This is the second year Taylor has won the honor in the poll of 84 sportswriters and broadcasters.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS 9.7.% FOR YEAR, MOST SINCE '41
description: The nation's unemployment rate was 10.8 percent in December, almost unchanged from the revised 10.7 percent the month before, the Labor Department reported today.

title: HIS PART TIME JOB IS HELPING THE GOVERNMENT COUNT JOBLESS
description: On the morning of Dec. 13, Fred Urrutia, a tuba player by profession, gathered up an armful of Government forms, some pencils and a barrage of questions and drove across the George Washington Bridge to New Jersey.

title: HAD 'EXORCIST' ROLE
description: Toni Darnay, an actress, died of cancer Wednesday at her Manhattan home. She was 61 years old. Miss Darnay, who began her career as a nightclub dancer in her native Chicago, made her Broadway debut as a dancer in ''Sadie Thompson.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CREDIT CARD RATES STILL AT PEAK LEVEL
description: While rates on many consumer bank loans have started to slip, financing charges on most credit cards and revolving charge plans remain at their highest levels ever.

title: Everett Hughes, Sociologist Who Wrote Books, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Everett C. Hughes, a sociologist known for his work on medical education and the study of occupations, died Wednesday of Alzheimer's disease at the Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., where he lived.

title: Haley to Defend
description: Leroy Haley, the World Boxing Council super lightweight champion, will defend his title against the former champion Saoul Mamby at Cleveland Public Hall Feb. 13. Haley took the title from Mamby on a 15-round decision last August in suburban Highland Heights.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. The dust jacket copy incorrectly credits Bernard Malamud with writing ''The Centaur,'' actually the work of John Updike. 2. In her job as a special assistant for public liaison, Mrs. Dole had defended the Administration's economic policies while her husband, Senator Bob Dole, was publicly criticizing the same policies and offering alternatives.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 8, 1983
description: International The arms embargo on Guatemala was lifted by the Reagan Administration because of ''significant steps'' taken to end human rights abuses. The embargo's removal was regarded as an indication of the Administration's support for the Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt. (Page 1, Col. 1.) Confirmation of a falling satellite was received from the Russians, but they indicated that steps had been taken to prevent radioactive components from reaching the earth by splitting the satellite into fragments. But United States officials said they were not fully reassured by the Soviet explanation. Radar and tracking cameras indicated that the main body of the Soviet satellite, including a nuclear reactor and its enriched uranium fuel, appeared to remain intact. (1:1.)

title: South Korean Airliner Lands After Hijack Scare
description: A Korean Air Lines 747 jet on a flight from New York to Seoul with 236 people aboard made an emergency landing today at Tokyo's Narita airport after a passenger threatened to blow up the plane, the police said.

title: 7 Greenpeace Members Held After Protest in Copenhagen
description: Seven members of the Danish Greenpeace organization were arrested today after chaining themselves to the entrance of the French Embassy here, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: It was a political upset of astonishing and unexpected magnitude. ''We never expected this rout,'' Vansantrao Patil, the secretary of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party, said today in a rueful assessment of the party's defeat on Wednesday in legislative elections in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, where it had never lost.

title: Pan Am to Lease 2 Jets to Carrier
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. said it had signed a contract to lease two of its Boeing 727-135 jetliners to Air 1, a St. Louis carrier.

title: Trapper Sentenced as Killer
description: Claude L. Dallas Jr., 32 years old, a trapper convicted of killing two state game wardens, Bill Pogue, 50, and Conley Elms, 34, has been sentenced to 30 years in prison. He was convicted of voluntary manslaughter in the deaths of the Fish and Game Department wardens and was sentenced Tuesday. He had been charged with murder, but he testified that he shot Mr. Pogue and Mr. Elms in self-defense at his camp in January 1981.

title: HOCH TIES A MARK, LEADS TUCSON ON 63
description: Scott Hoch, starting his fourth year on the PGA Tour, tied the course record of seven-under-par 63 today and took the lead after the second round of the $300,000 Joe Garagiola Tucson Open.

title: CIVIL DAMAGES SUIT WON BY M'SURELYS
description: A Federal court jury tonight awarded more than $1.6 million in compensatory and punitive damages to Alan and Margaret McSurely, former antipoverty workers in Pike County, Kentucky, for state and Federal harassment that violated their constitutional rights.

title: G. Gilbert Wyland, a Designer Of Winners of America's Cup
description: G. Gilbert Wyland, senior vice president and former chief engineer of the naval architectural company that designed all but one of the America's Cup winners between 1958 and 1980, died of cancer Wednesday at Uncas-on-the-Thames Hospital in Norwich, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived in Mystic, Conn.

title: Judge Blocks Removal Of Missouri Flood Debris
description: A judge signed a temporary order tonight blocking the transfer of flood debris possibly contaminated with the deadly chemical dioxin from Times Beach to a landfill 40 miles away.

title: Jets' Defense Relies on Offense
description: There is nothing the Jets' offense can do about Ken Anderson of Cincinnati and his 70.55 percent passingcompletion record when they meet in the opening playoff game on Sunday. Or is there?

title:
PATENTS;
System to Transmit Coded Data by TV
description: A system for transmitting coded information by television has been invented for the video data systems division of Sterling Television Presentations, Hauppage, L.I. The method is designed to serve business communication requirements.

title: Sports of the Times; Brooklyn College And Aspirations
description: R uminating on the intercollegiate athletic program of Brooklyn College over the years - an uncommon rumination, at best - one might not have been surprised by a description from one of its quarterbacks of the early 1930's. ''I believe,'' he once recalled, ''that we were the only team in American history which before its opening game had never scrimmaged, lined up for a kickoff or thrown a pass. We lost, 38 to 0, to Trenton State Teachers.''

title: NEW MUSEUM GIVEN HOME IN SOHO
description: The New Museum, New York City's only museum concerned exclusively with contemporary art, has been given a permanent home in SoHo. In its new facilities on the first two and a half floors of the historic and landmark Astor Building at 583 Broadway, the museum will have four times its current exhibition space, as well as a library, an archive and an auditorium.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.00-11.50 **Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHANGING CHILDPROOF PACKAGES
description: Federal action is under way to revise childproof packaging for prescription drugs so that elderly people will be less inclined to reject it.

title: Lakers Next for Knicks
description: The Knicks opened this National Basketball Association season before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden. That was last Oct. 29, when the Philadelphia 76ers, with Moses Malone and Julius Erving, were the opposition and hopes for the Knicks were still high.

title: Steelers Caught Short
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers are beset by the worst administrative problem in their history: Hundreds of seasonticket holders have called to say that they have not received their tickets for Sunday's playoff game against San Diego.

title: Topics; Opening Errors; Busy Schedules
description: The letter proffering a questionnaire or asking for a credit reference for an acquaintance begins, ''Dear Sir or Madam: I want to thank you for taking time from your busy schedule to ...''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 12.

title: Money Supply Up $500 Million
description: Short-term interest rates rose very slightly late yesterday, as the credit markets shrugged off the Federal Reserve's report that the basic money supply had risen $500 million in the week ended Dec. 29.

title: Earthquakes Strike Area In California High Sierra
description: The remote Mammoth Lakes area of the High Sierra trembled with earthquakes today and geologists looked for signs of a long-threatened volcanic eruption.

title: Where to Find Patterns
description: Following are some sources for catalogues and patterns for antique clothing styles:

title: RANGERS TROUNCE NORDIQUES
description: An international anthem would have been more appropriate than the national anthems played before the New York Rangers' game against the Quebec Nordiques last night at Madison Square Garden. Players of four nationalities scored goals for the Rangers in their 5-1 victory.

title: KORF ASKS COURT FOR RECEIVER
description: In another major West German corporate failure, Korf Industrie und Handel G.m.b.H., the parent company of the Korf steel group, said today that it had asked for a court receiver to protect it from creditors.

title: ALVIN H. BERNDT
description: Alvin H. Berndt, a partner in the investment management concern of Lord Abbett & Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: THE NEW SOFTWARE SUPPLIERS
description: Mickey Mouse has come a long way since Walt Disney introduced him in 1928: Now, Mickey and his cartoon friends are featured in a line of home computer software being offered by a division of Walt Disney Productions.

title: ANACONDA IS ENDING OPERATIONS IN BUTTE
description: The Anaconda Minerals Company is shutting down operations on what was once called the ''richest hill on earth.'' Officials of the Atlantic Richfield Company subsidiary, blaming low copper prices, announced today that they are suspending the last mining and milling operations in Butte, once the nation's copper-mining capital.

title: Kostoff Exceeds Swim Best
description: Jeff Kostoff, a 17-year-old high school senior from Upland, Calif., recorded a world-best time of 7 minutes 44.53 seconds today in winning the 800-meter freestyle at the 1983 United States Swimming International championships.

title: 6 South African Soldiers Killed by Namibia Blast
description: Six South African soldiers were killed and two critically wounded by a landmine explosion in the northwestern area of South-West Africa, or Namibia, military headquarters said today.

title: School Strike Talks Slowed
description: A state mediator reported little progress today in renewed efforts to end the 67-day strike of teachers here. The talks today began with each side accusing the other of violating a news blackout imposed by the mediator, Thomas Quinn.

title: PROJECT FOR AGED IN FIGHT OVER WHO PICKS TENANTS
description: The construction of a 150-apartment building on the Lower East Side for the elderly poor is in jeopardy because of an argument between the project's nonprofit sponsor and a community group over who will pick the tenants.

title: Joseph Dixon, Bryn Mawr Link
description: The Joseph Dixon Crucible Company, a long-established manufacturer of writing and artists materials based in Jersey City, and the Bryn Mawr Corporation, a Vero Beach, Fla., operator of recreationalvehicle park sites and a charter bus service, reported jointly yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a transaction valued at about $27 million.

title: THE MISSING HALF OF SPORTS TEAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'PELLEAS ET M'ELISANDE' AT MET
description: Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' is a most unoperatic opera. Its leading characters find it terribly difficult to say what they mean, not so much because they want to be subtle or to talk in poetic circumlocutions as because they are inarticulate, frightened or confused. In other words, they speak and act pretty much the way you and I and people we meet every day speak, not the way heroes and villains of a child's fairy-tale world speak. They do not sing arias when they are happy, nor do they gather at the footlights in groups to vow vengeance when they are angry. In this sense, ''Pelleas'' is one of the most naturalistic operas ever written, though it wraps the fact in gauze.

title: 21 Israelis Wounded In Ambush Near Beirut
description: Gunmen ambushed an Israeli military bus south of Beirut today, wounding 21 Israeli soldiers. The Israeli command in Tel Aviv said the gunmen fired small arms and bazookas at the bus two miles east of the village of Kfar Sil.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESS RATE IS 12.8%
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 12.8 percent in December, the highest rate since the Depression, the Government reported today. Opposition spokesmen called for immediate action to revive the staggering economy and create jobs.

title: A Court Squabble
description: A lawyer representing Bobby Hull's former wife, Joanne Hull Robinson, charged yesterday that the retired hockey star misrepresented his assets during the couple's divorce proceedings two years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column in Busi- ness Day on Nov. 9 incorrectly identi- fied the first art director of Scientific American. He was K. Chester.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: All That Was Lacking Was the Bride and Groom

title: Your Money; A Tax Shelter For Employees
description: THE name may not have a comfortable or familiar ring, but 401(K) plans have become one of the most talked-about subjects in employeebenefit circles these days. As a result, these plans - a type of savings plan that allows workers to shelter income from taxes - have been adopted recently at many companies.

title: ELECTRONICS FAIR VIEWS CONSUMER'S TOMORROW
description: More than 70,000 people have poured into Las Vegas this week for the semiannual Consumer Electronics Show, filling hotels and planes to the bursting point. There was not a single plane seat available into Las Vegas from many major cities Thursday, as 40,000 retailers with aching feet toured exhibition halls - the aggregate length of 15 football fields - to look at the latest in home computers, video games, car stereos, pocket televisions, designer telephones and the other paraphernalia of the $15-billion-ayear consumer electronics industry.

title: GOALS IN PLAYOFFS UNITING PATRIOTS
description: Barely a week ago, a cartoon in The Boston Globe caught the mood of discontent enveloping the New England Patriots. There was Ron Meyer, the rookie coach, telling his players he wasn't upset about the cleat marks left on their uniforms in a 37-14 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, but warning them: ''I'm very upset about you spiking the ball. This week you're not allowed to leave your homes except to come to the stadium.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Holiday Farewell

title: U.S.F.L. Restricted Its Draft
description: The United States Football League made only 12 players available to its 12 teams on each of the first four rounds of its college draft last Tuesday.

title: THE RIGHT WAY TO QUALIFY A TEACHER
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANT OIL TANKS HAVE MANY TOOLS TO BATTLE BLAZES
description: Safety standards for petroleum storage tanks such as the Texaco tanks that exploded and burned here early today vary, but are usually determined by the kinds of material the tanks hold and their construction and location.

title: Article 150603 -- No Title
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had reached agreement to buy the General American Oil Company of Texas for nearly $1.2 billion in cash and securities.

title: U.S. LIFTS EMBARGO ON MILITARY SALES TO GUATEMALANS
description: The Reagan Administration today lifted the five-year-old embargo on arms sales to Guatemala because of what it said were ''significant steps'' taken by the Government to end human rights abuses.

title: Union Dues Position Corrected by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo's State of the State Message misstated his position on the rights of public-employee unions to collect dues from all government workers, aides to the Governor said yesterday.

title: On the Ice
description: At a time when Pelle Lindbergh, a goalie for the Philadelphia Flyers, couldn't be much hotter and his backup, Rick St. Croix, couldn't be much unhappier, Lindbergh got a jolt and St. Croix a possible promotion. Lindbergh, winner of seven straight games before Thursday night, injured his wrist in a game against the Soviet Union; he is expected to be out for three weeks. St. Croix, who asked recently to be traded for lack of playing time, is expected to take his place. ... Paul Boutilier, a 19-year-old defenseman, was recalled by the Islanders.

title: Hilary Fowler Weds Antony Northrop
description: Hilary Ludlow Fowler, daughter of Emma Fowler Black of New York and Lawrence, L.I., and the late Larned B. Fowler, was married in New York yesterday to Antony Patrick Clinton Northrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Northrop of Hadlow, England. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: SAN DIEGO TO CHANGE POLITICAL GUARD AFTER DECADE OF BATTLE OVER GROWTH
description: This fast-growing city at the southwestern corner of the nation is changing its political guard after more than a decade of stability. A new generation of leaders is vying for control of the city, and all are expressing the same battle cry: Don't ''Los Angelize'' San Diego.

title: MEMORIAL MARCH CANCELED IN MIAMI
description: A march planned for Saturday in memory of Nevell Johnson Jr., a 21-year-old black whose shooting by a police officer Dec. 28 incited two days of sporadic street disturbances, was called off today at the request of the dead man's family.

title: TV: ETHNICITY CROPS UP IN TWO CRIME SHOWS
description: Prime time on NBC tonight is taken up largely by two ''pilots,'' which, in these cases, is a euphemism for two aborted series. At 9 P.M. on WNBC-Channel 4, it's ''O'Malley,'' starring Mickey Rooney as a comical private detective, Irish obviously. At 10 P.M., it's ''Inspector Perez,'' starring Jose Perez as a humorous New York City policeman, Puerto Rican obviously, on loan to San Francisco. Despite their differing heritage, these two characters bear a family relationship to the many other ethnic policemen who have proved popular on television; O'Malley and Perez were evidently conceived in response to the season's taste for ethnicity. ''O'Malley'' was not available for review, but I did screen ''Inspector Perez,'' and I am moved to say a few words over the departed.

title: BULGARIAN HANDS FOR HIRE
description: The alleged Bulgarian secret police involvement in the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II in 1981 has not been proved and probably never will be. But few of the allegations circulating in Italy and the United States come as a surprise to Eastern Europeans.

title: British Official Leaves For Visit to Saudi Arabia
description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Geoffrey Howe, left today for a three-day visit to Saudi Arabia, which has sharply criticized Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's refusal to receive an Arab delegation that included a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: G.M. Planning Exclusive Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation says it plans to give each of its car divisions an exclusive model later in the decade, a move that would depart sharply from the auto maker's current strategy, but revert to tradition.

title: ISRAELI, AT LUNCH WITH P.L.O., SUPPORTS A PALESTINIAN STATE
description: A left-wing Israeli legislator attended a luncheon today with a representive of the Palestine Liberation Organization and urged the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank.

title: Bath Iron Funds
description: Maine's Supreme Judicial Court upheld the constitutionality of state financing for the expansion in Portland of the Bath Iron Works. State funds for the $46.7 million ship repair and overhaul facility had been challenged as unconstitutional by the Maine Common Cause. Voters approved $15 million in state bonds for the project in a statewide referendum in November 1981.

title: CITY ACTS TO CUT LEVEL OF STAFFING FOR FIRE TRUCKS
description: New York City is planning to reduce from five to four the number of firefighters riding on most of its pumper trucks, city aides said yesterday. The measure, proposed by budget officials, would save $16.1 million a year.

title: RUDEL REPLACING PATANE
description: Julius Rudel will replace Giuseppe Patane as conductor of tomorrow afternoon's concert by the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Patane is reported to have a severe lung infection.

title: Leonard Manning, 65, Fordham Law Professor
description: Leonard F. Manning, a professor of law at Fordham University, died Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 65 years old and lived in Point Lookout, N.Y.

title: Pains of Zimbabwe
description: To hear Ian Smith and his cronies, Zimbabwe has gone straight over the dam to Marxist tyranny. Its press is no longer free, it is drifting to a one-party system, and its brutal police are torturing innocent whites. All this could be dismissed as a gross caricature if the Government in Harare (as Salisbury is now called) did not make Mr. Smith look good by unwisely lifting his passport and searching his home.

title: TAXI COMMISSION'S HIGHEST PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TAXES, TAXIS AND THE POOR
description: One item in Mayor Koch's four-year fiscal plan is an increase in the transfer tax on the sale of taxicab medallions, from 5 percent to 8 percent. But any rise in the cost of these $62,000 medallions would make it that much harder for poor blacks and Puerto Ricans legally to enter a business that they now dominate illegally.

title: ALL-RUSSIAN HAT
description: To the Editor:

title: DEARTH OF INVENTION
description: One thing wrong with the economy is that there's nothing exciting to buy anymore. Business used to boom on sales of glamorous consumer products. Dazzling new chrome-heavy cars with tail fins and 360 horses under the hood aching to tear up the highway. Nineteen-inch television screens that brought Sid Caesar and Jack Webb - ''Just the facts, ma'am'' -right into the parlor.

title: SUBSTANCE RELEASES HUMAN GROWTH HORMONE
description: Scientists for the first time have reported successful use of a synthetic substance to set in motion the natural production of growth hormone in humans.

title: The Health of the Hospitals
description: With excellent reason, New York City's teaching hospitals say they are vitally important to the city's reputation as a world-renowned medical center. Yet years of stinting on maintenance to absorb rising operating costs have left them run down, and their buildings, designed in the early part of the century, can't accommodate hightech medicine. Nearly $2 billion in renovations, they say, is necessary to keep them competitive.

title: U.N. Chief to See Reagan
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced today that he would meet with President Reagan and other officials next Friday in Washington to discuss world problems.

title: ANOTHER CHANCE AT EWING
description: A s if it is not enough that Bill Wennington has to contend with Patrick Ewing this afternoon, he is coping with the after-effects of the flu. Wennington, the 7-foot St. John's sophomore, was sitting in his Jamaica Estates apartment on Thursday evening, drinking a cup of tea and waiting for a friend to bring dinner.

title: Baseball Clubs Warned
description: The presidents of the two leagues, Lee MacPhail of the American and Charles Feeney of the National, have notified baseball teams that they must adhere to the basic agreement that says no players except pitchers and catchers can be invited to spring training before March 1. Despite the rule, clubs generally have scheduled starting dates before March 1.

title: U.S. Official to Visit Haiti
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 7 (Reuters) - Thomas O. Enders, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, will begin a 48-hour visit to Haiti on Sunday, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Farmers Win Agreement On a Neighbor's Debt
description: About 50 farmers ended a protest today that lasted 10 hours at an office of the Production Credit Association when an official agreed to allow a farmer to renegotiate a $400,000 mortgage.

title: First Multifund Loses Decision
description: An official of the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled yesterday that First Multifund Advisory Corporation and its former chief executive, Milton Mound, had defrauded investors in the mutual funds it managed in the mid-1970's.

title: FEDERAL GRAND JURY INVESTIGATING CONGRESSMEN IN CAPITOL HILL DRUG USE CASE
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations that five or six members of the House of Representatives have been using marijuana or cocaine, according to senior lawenforcement officials familiar with the inquiry.

title: Esther Untermeyer, 88; A Zionist and Ex-Judge
description: Esther Antin Untermeyer, a former Municipal Court judge in Toledo, Ohio, who was active in the fight to create the State of Israel, died Tuesday of congestive heart failure at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BOC INVESTS ITS MONEY WHERE THE PROFITS ARE
description: For the BOC Group, the major producer of industrial gases that was formerly known as the British Oxygen Corporation, 1982 ended with a burst of activity: During the last quarter BOC, whose chief executive is a former New York lawyer, Richard V. Giordano, embarked on new ventures in the United States, South America and Japan, while raising $150.4 million in three stock offerings.

title: THE COURSE OF THE ROCKETS
description: JPL AND THE AMERICAN SPACE PROGRAM A History of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. By Clayton P. Koppes. Illustrated. 299 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: DEATH RATES DECLINE FOR ALL EXCEPT YOUNG PEOPLE
description: Death rates in the United States are declining for everybody except people from 15 to 24 years old, a Federal report says.

title: VIEWING CABLE TV: NEW TECHNOLOGY POSES LEGAL ISSUE
description: WHEN does watching television become a crime? According to spokesmen for the Long Island Cable Television Council, the crime begins when a viewer turns on a cable television program that has not been properly paid for.

title: RETURN OF THE MEGA-STORE
description: Contrary to what many merchants now believe, one retailing consultant says that stores of the near and not-so-near future may be larger rather than smaller.

title: Motion on Hearing
description: A hearing in Austin, Tex., to discuss the revocation of probation for Tony Ayala, the middleweight boxer, may be delayed for many months. A judge in Texas placed Ayala on 10 years' probation in 1980 for assaulting a woman when he was 15.

title: The 'Voluntary' Way
description: School buses were never supposed to provide anything more than a safe ride between classroom and home. But when passage between those two points meant crossing racial barriers, the buses turned into symbols of hope for many black students and Government meddling for many whites. Last week, a Federal judge in Chicago approved a voluntary plan for school desegregation that does not require busing but, it was widely agreed, will not produce desegregation, either.

title: John H. Ijams Engaged To Sarah H. Blatchford
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Blatchford of Orrington, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Howell Blatchford, to John Horton Ijams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seton Ijams of Lawrence, L.I.

title: WHEN FAMILIAR WORKS TAKE ON RENEWED VIGOR
description: Critics may be jaded, as members of the public sometimes complain. But they have their reasons: the very nature of their job puts them in constant confrontation with the egregious - which can be amusing, in a grim sort of way - or, more commonly, with the merely mediocre. Thus no one is more happy than the critic who stumbles upon a performance that breathes fresh life into even the most weary of warhorses.

title: TAXES RESOLVED, KEAN ADDRESSES OTHER PROBLEMS
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN showed perseverance in leading the Legislature to accept a compromise package of taxes on Dec. 31, just in time to avert $150 million in service and state-aid cuts over the next six months.

title: THE CHINESE: A WAY WITH MATHEMATICS
description: IN high schools and universities all over the United States, Asian students, especially Chinese, have been found to do exemplary work in mathematics and related subjects. Educators, often puzzled by their outstanding performance, have developed various theories to explain it. Some attribute it to the emphasis many Chinese families place on acquiring technological skills and to the value placed on education. Some believe that inherent in Chinese culture is a preference for the logical reasoning math provides. And several have said that the Chinese language, like mathematics, is symbolic, or that because math requires minimal verbal skills, it comes easier to students who grew up speaking Chinese.

title: JUSTICES WEIGH JURY PROPOSALS
description: TRENTON THE State Supreme Court is pondering the recommendations of a task force that would change the face, and faces, of the jury system in New Jersey.

title: ACCOSTED IN THE AISLES
description: WHOEVER said you can't tell a book by its cover knew what he was talking about. First impressions don't always tell the story. In my case, while first impressions are uncannily consistent, they're totally erroneous. And informing people that they are laboring under a misapprehension tends to elicit displays of strong emotions, including surprise, embarrassment, annoyance and anger, usually in that order and usually directed at me, especially the part about anger.

title: Laura A. Kiernan, A Reporter, Weds
description: Laura A. Kiernan, a reporter for The Washington Post, was married in Washington yesterday to Peter G. Beeson, director of the Criminal Enforcement Division of the Environmental Protection Agency. United States District Judge Harold H. Greene of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

title: CHILCREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BFG By Roald Dahl. Illustrated by Quentin Blake. 221 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 13)

title: No Headline
description: OPERA

title:
ART;
FURNITURE THAT BLENDS EXOTIC WOODS AND EXQUISITE DETAILS
description: the piecing of wood veneer to form complex pictures or decorative patterns -has never been a major interest of American furniture makers. We usually associate it with European craftsmanship, particularly the intricate English, French and Italian cabinet work of the 17th and 18th centuries. Even today, while we admire the skillful marquetry of the past, few of our craftsmen seem interested in developing such a specialty.

title: MRs. Dole Chosen For Cabinet Job
description: For those in the Washington fishbowl, it can be awkward to espouse causes one's spouse opposes. As a White House aide, Elizabeth H. Dole often found herself defending the Reagan Administration as vigorously as her husband, Senator Bob Dole, criticized it.

title: WHAT IS THE REAL SUBSTANCE OF 'SWAN LAKE'?
description: The problem of what constitutes a dance performance or a dance work - two distinct entities -rarely occurs to us. Yet these are exactly the issues with which the dance historian Selma Jeanne Cohen wrestles so provocatively in her new book, ''Next Week, Swan Lake: Reflections on Dance and Dances'' (Wesleyan University Press. $17.95).

title: The Failing Presidency
description: The stench of failure hangs over Ronald Reagan's White House. The people know it, judging by the opinion polls. Corporate titans know it and whisper disenchantment with a fellow conservative. Washington knows it when an Administration official calls the budgeting process ''an unmitigated outrage'' and when Mr. Reagan's closest friend in the Senate pronounces the President ''as very close to set in concrete.''

title: ON GREENPOINT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BLASTS SHOW F.A.L.N. RESILIENCE
description: Through eight years of bombings and other violent actions, a small Puerto Rican armed force known as the F.A.L.N. has established itself as one of the most elusive and resilient terrorist groups ever to operate in the United States, according to Federal and local law enforcement officials.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY LOSING MILLIONS AS MORE DEFECT
description: Local governments and nonprofit organizations are dropping out of the Social Security System at an accelerating rate, aggravating its financial problems.

title: PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor:

title: April London Wedding Set by Beverly E. Birks
description: Dr. Richard Savage Birks of Montreal has announced the engagement of his daughter, Beverly Earl Birks, to Robin William Gordon Raybould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon William Raybould of Seven Oaks, Kent, England. An April wedding is planned in London.

title: ISRAEL'S MORALITY SURVIVES BEIRUT
description: The verdict is in on the morality of the people of Israel.

title: WHITE PLAINS SHOWS OFFER 'MIXED BAG'
description: WHITE PLAINS IT'S a mixed bag on Martine Avenue this week, with a ''retrospective'' by Cab Calloway at the Public Library and, at the other end of the block in the Bridge Gallery, three area photographers working in black and white. Both shows remain open through Jan. 31.

title: IN BRUSSELS-HAUTE CUISINE A LA BELGIQUE
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: PRUDENT SPIDERS WEAVE KEEP-OFF-THE-WEB SIGN
description: Two species of spiders weave what amounts to signs saying ''Keep off the Web'' to prevent birds and large insects from damaging their property, two Cornell University researchers have found.

title: Drug Equipment Ban Upheld
description: A Montana law banning the selling of equipment to administer drugs is constitutional, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled.

JON COSIN and Tim Kaldis, both 17 years old, share a running joke: ''When I grow up to be physicist and he grows up to be a doctor,'' Mr. Kaldis says, pointing to his friend, ''we'll buy a radio station and operate it together.''

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Words, Glorious Words As common sense and experienced authors will tell you, editors are apt to buy manuscripts about their own hobbies, pastimes, interests and problems. When a publishing house issues book after book about sailing, it's a safe bet a reasonably senior editor there loves the sport and will respond with enthusiasm to submissions about it. Similar deductions help writers and agents place work about topics as diverse as coin collecting and child care or China and choral music.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: JOHN and Ann's, and before them, Smith's, at Denhoff and Bayview Walks, is now Mike the Greek's Diner. Where there were comic books on the shelves, there are now beer and wine bottles in cabinets behind sliding glass doors.

title: INMATES AT OSSINING SEIZE 16 OFFICERS AS HOSTAGES
description: Inmates at the Ossining Correctional Facility here seized 16 guards as hostages and took over their cell block containing 600 convicts last night, the state Department of Correctional Services said.

title: 2 HIGH AIDES TO BOSTON MAYOR BENEFITED FROM PROPERTY DEAL
description: Two of Mayor Kevin H. White's top assistants live in a $250,000 house that one of them bought in 1981 for less than $1, according to county records.

title: Seafarers
description: To the Editor:

title: THere They Go Again
description: Republican Presidential aspirants may have to put their ambitions in neutral until Ronald Reagan decides whether to seek re-election, but the Democrats officially began to gear up last week for 1984.

title: 12 in a Bus in Tel Aviv Wounded by Grenade
description: A bus driver and 11 passengers were wounded this evening when a grenade was thrown into a bus on the southern outskirts of the city, the police announced.

title: THE U.S.O. CARES
description: Since 1941, one organization has existed solely to provide for the physical and spiritual well-being of American service men and women.

title: COPING WITHOUT SANTA CLAUS
description: ''Coping with Santa Claus'' reminded my of the hot July day when my young son confronted his father and me with the question: Is there really a Santa Claus?

title: Laura Sipe Is Engaged In Virginia
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James R. Sipe of Harrisonburg, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Laura Ann Sipe, to William Constable Breed 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Breed 3d of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL KLECKO'S RETURN AFFECT JETS AS HIS ABSENCE DID?
description: CINCINNATI THIS week has been a combination of crisis and anticipation for the New York Jets -the sort of will-he, won't-he-play atmosphere missing from their camp since the days of Joe Namath.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS WIN 7TH STRAIGHT GAME

title: THE LEARNING-DISABLED CATCH ATTENTION
description: THEY call themselves ''remedial,'' ''tutorial,'' ''ungraded'' or ' 'catch-up'' schools, and they can cost up to $16,000 a year for t uition and board. But despite a recession that has hurt enrollment a t many traditional private secondary schools, most of the a pproximately two-dozen independent schools across the country that f ocus on learning-disabled youngsters say they are enrolling record n umbers of new students and compiling ''healthy'' waiting lists.

title: Cup Challengers Get Ready
description: Although the sailors preparing for the 25th challenge to the America's Cup next summer will not be arriving in Newport, R.I., until spring, intensive training is under way - from Italy's Gulf of Gaeta to Australia's Port Phillip Bay.

title: O'NEILL STIFFENS RULES FOR CONTRACTS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has announced two measures aimed at eliminating what he termed ''outside pressures'' in the awarding of contracts by Connecticut's Department of Transportation.

title: WOLF TRAP FARM PARK PLANS FUND-RAISING GALA
description: The Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts hopes to raise $400,000 toward replacing its burned-out center with a benefit next month that will have tickets selling for $10 to $1,000 each.

title: COPS AND ROBBERS
description: WHY ME, By Donald E. Westlake. 191 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.50. EASY MONEY By Sam Koperwas. 297 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.95.

title: WHEN A BEGIN OPPONENT TAKES HIS CASE TO THE AMERICAN PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: ...AND THE ONE WITH ALUMNI
description: THE candidate edged forward in his chair, knowing that the c assette-player rendition of his Mozart concerto was not enhanced by t he baritone accompaniment of his host's Labrador retriever.

title:
OLD MARKERS IMPERILED;
Stranger, stop and cast an eye; As you are now, so once was I, As I am now, so you shall be.  Prepare for death and follow me.
description: Jonathan Hutchinson died in 1717, but his tombstone is not at rest. In fact, it has traveled far and frequently since it was stolen by modernday grave robbers a dozen years ago from Hutchinson's final resting place in the Jonathan Trumbull Cemetery in Lebanon.

title: THE COMPUTER DEVELOPS SOME GLITCHES
description: FOR the first time since personal computers became widely available at the elementary-school level, educators and others are beginning to have doubts about the effectiveness of the devices in the teaching of basic skills. Most doubts are not directed at the microcomputers themselves, which have been widely hailed because they teach children that computers are a tool that can be mastered. ''Kids who are usually not motivated discover they have more control over their world from using a microcomputer,'' notes Gerald Bracey, citing studies he has conducted as head of research, testing and evaluation for the Virginia department of education.

title: 40-SEAT RESTAURANT TO OPEN IN LOEB BOATHOUSE
description: A 40-seat restaurant overlooking the lake in Central Park will open in the Loeb Memorial Boathouse in the spring, according to Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis. It will be part of a complete renovation of the popular meeting place for boaters, bikers, joggers, bird watchers and other park habitues.

title: Johnson Begins to Take Charge on Nets
description: Before the Nets were to play the Chicago Bulls Friday night, leotard-clad members of The Luvabulls cheerleading squad were putting the final touches on one of their more complicated routines. And in the stands, the early spectators were begining to find their places.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: As a frequent customer of many of the restaurants mentioned in Eileen Yin-Fei Lo's article on San Francisco Chinese restaurants, ''Where the Twain Meet - Deliciously'' (Travel, Dec. 5), I was particularly gratified to see Canton Teahouse listed in the dim sum section.

title: Susan Thorndike Engaged to S.A. Lacy
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Thorndike of Pittsford and Ithaca, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lee Thorndike, to Scott Ashby Lacy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lacy of Victor, N.Y.

title: RISE OF THE RESUME SLEUTH
description: ONE executive, applying for a middle-management job at a Middle W estern manufacturing plant, said he had supervised 15 employees at h is former job when he had actually supervised five. A laid-off a ccountant claimed to have a Master of Business Administration degreew hen all he had was a Bachelor of Arts. Both men had lied - and n either got the job.

title: WILL FRENCH CULTURE BE MORE FRENCH?
description: PARIS Normally, no one would worry very much about the future of culture in a country whose president brings Ambrose Bierce short stories with him on his recent plane trip to the United States, and totes Thomas Mann's thoughts on the predicament of Semhazai, God's unworthy messenger, for examination at 35,000 feet en route to Athens. Francois Mitterrand reads, and reads again, and will offer as a throwaway line the fact that his look at Semhazai and Jacob's Ladder somewhere over Greece was really his second time through Mann's ''The Young Joseph.''

title: AHOY! JUST OVER THE HORIZON, A FLEET OF PIRATE MOVIES
description: Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. LOS ANGELES The image might come from an old Errol Flynn swashbuckler: Two pirates crash through the plate-glass window of the ship's cabin, swinging on ropes that propel them across the deck. Only the incongruous burning embers in their 18th-century wigs suggest that the scene is not intended in dead earnest. ''Yellowbeard,'' the movie that features this spectacular stunt, is a pirate comedy concocted by several members of the Monty Python team and other comedians from both sides of the Atlantic, who have converged on the sleepy town of Zihuatanejo, Mexico, to revive a hardy old genre.

title: Prison Weddings
description: It is legal to get married in prison, but like everyone else, the convict must first obtain a license. This posed a problem at the Ossining (N.Y.) Correctional Facility in November 1981 when the Town Clerk refused to enter the prison to issue the licenses and the warden refused to let the prisoners go into town to get them.

title: AN '83 KICKOFF AT THE MEADOWLANDS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD THE Meadowlands Antiques Exposition, an annual wintertime event that will be held at the Sports Complex next Sunday, marks the start of what promises to be an active year for collectors and browsers alike.

title: ETHICS AND THE LAW: A CASE HISTORY
description: In a third-floor corridor of the Federal District Court on Manhattan's Foley Square, one afternoon last month, a tall, bespectacled man looking no more than his 36 years stood talking with friends, nervously drawing on a cigarette. Myron S. Goodman had, over the course of the 1970's, been the mastermind behind the meteoric growth of the multimillion-dollar O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc. He had become a leading figure in the computer-leasing field and an extravagant philanthropist. Now, together with his partner and brother-in-law, Mordecai Weissman, Goodman was to appear before Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. for sentencing in one of the most massive corporate frauds in American history. Goodman and Weissman had pleaded guilty to defrauding banks and other lenders of more than $210 million before their company went bankrupt in 1981. Along the way, they had hoodwinked some of the nation's largest and most prestigious companies, including Rockwell International, American Express, Chase Manhattan Bank and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: Miller and Kuhn: New Free Agents
description: To the Sports Editor: Sportscasters and sportswriters have made their annual report on the most significant sports events of 1982. Intent, as they seem to be, on reporting ''Who won?'' they failed to note two historic occasions in baseball.

title: Sports of the Times; Going Up Against Paul Brown
description: RESPECTED authority figures always stay up there on a pedestal - parents, a teacher, a neighborhood police officer, a drill sergeant, a member of the clergy. Even when youngsters grow taller than those on the pedestal, they continue to look up to that person who affected their lives. In a football sense, it's that way with Walt Michaels, the coach of the Jets, who will be playing the Cincinnati Bengals today in the Super Bowl XVII Tournament.

title: Jane Dinsmore to Wed William B. Hildebrand
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Ellsworth @Dinsmore of Convent Station, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth Dinsmore, to William Bennett Hildebrand, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Lee Hildebrand of Neenah, Wis.

title: Waiting on White
description: Although Danny White, the starting quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys, tested the sore thumb on his right hand by tossing a few passes yesterday, the Cowboys will wait until game time today before deciding if White will start against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in their National Football Conference playoff game at Irving, Tex. The Cowboys said that the odds that White would start were ''75 percent'' after he found his thumb ''still sore, but getting better.''

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Vermeil Is Going
description: Coach Dick Vermeil of the Philadelphia Eagles says he is not going to the Los Angeles Rams but he might be going somewhere - on a ''leave of absence'' from the team.

title: FEMALE PROFESSORS GAIN LITTLE GROUND
description: AS 1982 rolled to a close, little evidence of celebration could be heard from women academicians observing the 10th anniversary of mandatory sexual equality in education. Instead, the battle against sex discrimination in the hiring and tenure practices of the nation's colleges continued quietly, with persistence rather than precedent as the byword.

title: A JANUARY CLEARANCE OF SUGGESTIONS FOR THE FUTURE
description: It is the nature of the job that a film reviewer attend to the matters at hand, to the films and performances that, by hook and crook, have reached the screen. We are not cultural commissars who set future policy. We are reporters of specific events that have already happened. For most of the year this is as it should be. Over a period of time, however, there accumulate in the back of one's mind a lot of thoughts about films that have not been made, about performances that have not been given or even contracted for, about moviegoing in particular and the state of the art in general. Because these thoughts don't fit easily into individual reviews, they go unexpressed - that is, until today.

title: DOLPHINS AND PACKERS GAIN IN PLAYOFFS
description: The Miami Dolphins, who had not won a postseason game since their victory over the Minnesota Vikings in Super Bowl VIII in 1974, defeated the New England Patriots today, 28-13, and advanced to the second round of the National Football League playoffs.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE 'FIGHTINGEST FISH'
description: UNDERWATER canyons 70 miles and more off the South Shore are gaining worldwide recognition as one of the finest remaining big game fishing grounds on the planet, according to sport fishermen who know the canyon waters best.

title: Baughan to Coach Cornell
description: Maxie Baughan, an outstanding linebacker for 14 years in the National Football League, was named today coach at Cornell. He succeeded Bob Blackman, who resigned at the end of the 1982 season.

title: HARD SELL IN THE SHOWROOM
description: It is barely light these chilly Middle Western mornings, when the first customers line up in their troubled cars, trailing warm, white vapors outside the giant doors of the service department at Jennings Chevrolet in suburban Chicago. But soon the lights are on, the mechanics are filling the cavernous garage with the raucous rat-atats of their air wrenches, while in an adjacent room the hissing paint-spray guns of their body-shop colleagues erase the sudden scars of automotive indiscretions.

title: BOGOTA BEGINS SEEKING 'NEW PARTNERS' AMONG NONALIGNED
description: At a time when the Reagan Administration seeks to line up Latin America against Communist penetration, President Belisario Betancur Cuartas of Colombia has disturbed Washington by his interest in joining the nonaligned nations and by his refusal to isolate Cuba and Nicaragua from the Organization of American States. This week in Nicaragua, Colombia's neutralism will be on display for the first time at a meeting of foreign ministers of the nonaligned nations. And Colombia's desire to mediate in Central America led to a meeting with Mexico, Venezuela and Panama over the weekend in Panama to discuss peace initiatives. Recently, Mr. Betancur responded to written questions by Warren Hoge, a New York Times correspondent in Latin America.

title: PHILHARMONIC: WITOLD LUTOSLAWSKI'S BIRTHDAY
description: Witold Lutoslawski will be 70 years old on Jan. 25, and the New York Philharmonic was celebrating a little early Friday afternoon with a program at Avery Fisher Hall given over to this most distinguished of Polish composers. Zubin Mehta conducted the Concerto for Orchestra written in 1954, and Mr. Lutoslawski himself led two later pieces - the ''Novelette'' for orchestra and the Cello Concerto.

title:
STAMPS;
THE NEW CATALOGUES: BIGGER AND BIGGER
description: The 1983 stamp catalogues, which have been coming out a volume at a time, are now all in and all are bigger than ever. It is becoming apparent that the ways and byways of cataloguing are approaching a crossroads.

title: SCHERMERHORN ROW'S RESURRECTION IS CLOSE AT HAND
description: THE $9.6 million resurrection of Schermerhorn Row - 19 buildings in l ower Manhattan that make up one of the oldest commercial districts i n the United States - is nearing completion, and New York State h opes to have 29,000 square feet of commercial space ready to rent byM arch 1.

title: CONVERT TO COAL? PONDERING THE NEED--AND HEAVY COSTS
description: Massive overruns, lengthy delays and, lately, a dispute over evacuation plans have kept the Long Island Lighting Company's 809-megawatt nuclear power plant at Shoreham in the headlines. But with considerably less fanfare, Lilco has been studying another project that by one estimate could approach Shoreham's $3 billion price tag and, though it relies on an ancient energy source, be nearly as controversial.

title: Old Dove Flaps Its Wings Again
description: The North Atlantic allies last week got an offer they couldn't brusquely refuse - a Warsaw Pact proposal for a nonaggression treaty that appeared to be addressed at least as much to the West's people as their leaders.

title: Topics; UNSEASONABLE; Non-PACs
description: We were looking through the Washington, D.C., phone book the other day for the number of the Committee for Something-or-Other. We didn't find the one we were looking for, but found 41 others.

title: DANCE: MITCHELL ROSE WITH HUMOR
description: It was Mitchell Rose time on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. That may be the easiest way to describe Mr. Rose's solo performance. Was it dance? Theater? Mime? Performance art? It certainly was funny.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cresskill $85,000 *2*135 Monroe Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; wall-to-wall *2*carpeting, fireplacing in living room, den; *2*taxes $1,589 Montvale $97,500 *2*14 Magnolia Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*17-year-old split-level; covered deck, central *2*air-conditioning, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes, $1,885 Oradell $157,000 *2*442 Mildred Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, *2*9-year-old split level; fireplace in *2*family room, deck, finished basement; taxes $2,904 Tenafly $345,000 *2*133 Churchill Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath, *2*26-year-old ranch; fireplace in *2*family room, heated in-ground pool, redwood *2*deck, paneled recreation room in basement; taxes $5,923 OTHER AREAS Bedford, N.Y. $168,000 *2*Old Post Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old *2*masonry farmhouse; kitchen/ family room, *2*2 storage sheds, access to horse trails, *2*6 acres; taxes $3,688. Larchmont, N.Y. $94,000 *2*3 Winthrop Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 57 year-old *2*colonial; enclosed porch, den, stone patio, walk *2*to schools, 0.11 acre; taxes $1,952. Wilton, Conn. $207,500 *2*8 Serendipity Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old *2*contemporary; large pond on property, *2*2.1 acres; taxes $2,435. Riverhead, L.I. $73,500 *2*Louise Court, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old *2*ranch; full basement, den, deck, 2-car garage; *2*taxes $2,000.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALFRED STIEGLITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS & WRITINGS, by Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton. (Callaway Editions/National Gallery of Art. $75.) A selection of the great American photographer's work. FEIFFER, edited by Steven Heller. (Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $25; paper, $12.95.) Twenty-five years of Jules Feiffer's cartoons, with commentary by the artist. GRAMMAR AND GOOD TASTE, by Dennis E. Baron. (Yale University Press, $19.95.) A history of language reform in America. HOWARD HAWKS, STORYTELLER, by Gerald Mast. (Oxford University Press, $29.95.) An analysis of the film director's career. LEON BLUM, by Jean Lacouture. (Holmes & Meier. Cloth, $39.50; paper, $24.50.) A biography of the French Socialist statesman. THE LONGEST WAR, by Jacobo Timerman. (Alfred A. Knopf, $11.95.) A dovish report on the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: GETTING MORE FOR LESS
