description: In their zeal to cope with the economic vagaries, retailers are picking up ideas from manufacturers. A new technique to increase store and backroom productivity, known as ''Improshare,'' is being adopted by a number of retailers after successful use in manufacturing.

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE TO PRESS JAPAN ON DEFENSE
description: Mike Mansfield, the American Ambassador, says that while Japan has made ''very significant'' efforts to raise military spending, the United States will continue to press for further increases.

title: FROM SKIING TO SINGING
description: FARMINGVILLE THE Bald Hill Recreation Center, formerly a skiing facility, will be transformed into a cultural center by 1984 if Brookhaven Town receives $400,000 in state funds required to complete the project, according to Richard Araujo, coordinator of the Council on the Arts for the Town of Brookhaven.

title: DETROIT BANKS ON AN ERA OF GOOD FEELING
description: The automobile industry began 1983 with mildly encouraging sales reports and new labor contracts that were products of a tumultuous year of almost continuous bargaining. But a tense situation at the Chrysler Corporation and a strike by Chrysler's 10,000 Canadian workers have raised doubts that the new era in labor relations, proclaimed by many auto executives, has really arrived.

title:
GARDENING;
AVERTING PLANT DAMAGE BY SALT AND SNOW
description: UNLIKE other sections of the country, we have been fortunate in not having had to contend with severe blizzards and ice storms so far this winter. However, the inevitable is certain to happen sooner or later, and we, too, will be faced with digging out from beneath a mantle of white snow.

title: CURRICULUM COHERENCE? WHAT'S THAT?
description: WHILE pondering a possible strategy for this paper, I experienced s omething that had never happened to me before: my three g randchildren burst upon me and in a chorus asked, ''Fritzel, tell us- what was it like back in the good old days when there was coherencei n the undergraduate curriculum?'' I long ago learned how to answer aq uestion with a question, and promptly responded, ''And just what do y ou mean by coherence in the undergraduate curriculum?''

title: BRITAIN'S IMPERIAL MISCELLANY
description: JOHN RUSSELL is chief art critic for The New York Times.

title: IMPROVED RACEWAY A 'WINNER'
description: YONKERS LIKE the postman who performs his duties despite rain, sleet, snow and dark of night, Mike Petnuch, the track superintendent at Yonkers Raceway's Harness Horse Plant, is not deterred by weather. Newly created track surfaces, improved technology and costly machinery are the factors that enable Mr. Petnuch to cope with the elements.

title: THE MYTHS OF VICTORIAN WOMAN
description: WOMAN AND THE DEMON, The Life of a Victorian Myth. By Nina Auerbach. Illustrated. 255 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: No Headline
description: The marriage of Janice I. Kanter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Kanter of Clifton, N.J., to Dr. Jerry S. Apple, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Apple of Wallace, N.C., took place yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony. The bride is a speech pathologist. Her husband is a radiologist at the Duke Medical Center.

title: NEW LOOK OF THE COUNTY BOARD
description: THE county's Board of Legislators, facing a year of transition within its ranks and major changes in the county, has started with new leadership. Last week, it named Andrew A. Albanese, an Eastchester restaurateur, as its Chairman and Edward M. Gibbs, a Peekskill businessman, as vice chairman.

title: SALVADOR OFFICER REFUSES TO YIELD
description: The commander of the northern province of Cabanas said today that ''they will have to come in here and take me out dead'' to end his rebellion against the Defense Minister.

title: The Restoration Of East Rock Park
description: With regard to the recent developments between the Southern New England Telephone Company and New Haven's East Rock Park (Connecticut Journal, Dec. 12), it is important to realize that the proposal was withdrawn before meaningful programs for park improvement could be discussed.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: NISA: The Life and Words of a !Kung Woman. By Marjorie Shostak. (Vintage, $7.95.) ''Nisa'' is a duet of sorts between two women: an anthropologist and a chmber of one of the world's last traditional gatherer-hunter societies who reports on her life in an isolated corner of the Kalahari Desert in Botswana. Marjorie Shostak, who describes herself as ''a girl-woman, recently married, struggling with the issues of life, marriage, sexuality, work and identity,'' conducted 26 interviews with Nisa, a !Kung woman of about 50, to explore what being a woman means in different cultures and to see how much of human emotional life is universal.

title: Immunization
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW 'NICKLEBY' MADE THE JOURNEY TO TV
description: Benedict Nightingale writes frequently on cultural events in England. LONDON When the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' rolled its massive and majestic way into dramatic history on the stages of London and New York, even those critics who applauded rather than raved were agreed on one point: It was distinctively, unmistakably, quintessentially theatrical. You could see the same actors in up to a dozen different parts each, watch them miming their special effects, even chat to them on their occasional forays into the audience. How could all that informal excitement possibly be transferred to a small shiny screen in the living room?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They will have to come in here and take me out dead.'' - Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez of the Salvadoran Army. (3:1.)

title:
DINING OUT;
TASTE OF PUNJAB AT BOMBAY PALACE
description: THE name Bombay Palace is somewhat of a geographic misnomer. Far from reflecting the cuisine that is characteristic of coastal Bombay, dishes deliver with some accuracy the satisfying cuisine of India's land-locked far north - in particular, Punjab, the menu states. This kitchen has a style as distinct from the county's two other Indian restaurants as they have from each other.

title: Youth Slain Over Video Game
description: Danny Calhoun, a high school senior, was shot to death Friday in the parking lot of an arcade after a quarrel over 75 cents worth of video display games, the police said. uf30

title: COAST STARLIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SENDING BUSH TO EUROPE TO MEET THE ALLIES ON ARMS
description: President Reagan, citing ''encouraging words'' from the new Soviet leadership, announced today that he would send Vice President Bush to meet with America's European allies and to address the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LET'S DESTIGMATIZE MASS TRANSIT
description: LIKE many other states, New Jersey maintains a public transportation system that is subsidized by the taxpayers. I leave it to others to decide whether this is an example of welfare for the middle class or a far-sighted effort to reduce pollution and the consumption of gasoline.

title: IS THE BATTLE AGAINST CRIME MOSTLY A WAR OF WORDS?
description: Can a war on crime be won on the cheap? According to Senator Ernest F. Hollings and other critics of the Reagan criminal justice program, that is what the Administration has been trying to do for almost two years, and the answer is no. The $130 million special appropriation for a new program to combat narcotics trafficking by organized crime, requested by President Reagan in a preelection flourish in October, is just ''a drop in the bucket,'' the South Carolina Democrat declared during hearings on the measure last month.

title: Article 154308 -- No Title
description: FACED with a growing demand for medical services that has paralleled continued population growth in the northern part of the county, the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco has announced an ambitious expansion plan. The proposed $26 million construction program calls for the addition of 54 medical/surgical beds, and the construction of a three-story office building with a parking garage for up to 404 cars.

title: A GIDDY 'WHOOPEE' AT THE COACHLIGHT
description: WHAT is good for the Goodspeed Opera House is not necessarily good for Broadway. That has been proven over and over. Such old-time musicals as ''Going Up'' and ''The 5 O'Clock Girl'' had peppy lives in East Haddam's shining opera house and died almost instantly as Manhattan transplants.

title: BOXING SCORES SOME POINTS AS WHITE-COLLAR EXERCISE
description: Pow! Whomp! Thud! The sounds of 12-ounce boxing gloves hitting each other - and occasionally hitting a shoulder or a chin - filled Larry Williams's spacious midtown loft the other night. He and his friend Marc Solomon were ''going a few rounds,'' as they put it.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COZUMEL
description: MARLISE SIMONS reports for The New York Times from Mexico.

title: Meeting His Idol
description: Pat Lafontaine, a 17-year-old center from Detroit, who set a Quebec Major Junior Hockey League record by scoring points in 41 consecutive games for the Verdun Juniors, today will meet his idol, Guy Lafleur of the Canadiens, in ceremonies honoring him before a game in Montreal at the Verdun Auditorium. Lafontaine bettered the mark of 40 set 12 years ago by Lafleur when he played for the Quebec Ramparts.

title: A VAPOR BARRIER IS A FRIEND DURING THE HEATING SEASON
description: THE importance of having a vapor barrier installed in insulated walls, ceilings and floors has been widely written about in newspapers and magazines, so most homeowners are by now well aware of the value of such barriers. However, many letters received here indicate that numerous homeowners still do not know why, or even if, a vapor barrier is important. They are not certain why it is needed to help protect the house or how it can help in lowering heating costs.

title: Swim Mark for East German
description: Kristin Otto, a 16-year-old East German, bettered her world's best time in the women's 100-meter backstroke tonight in an international short-course meet at Indiana University.Her teammates, Birgit Meineke and Ute Geweniger, also scored victories.

title: WHY THE COWBOYS WIN: INSIDE LANDRY'S SYSTEM
description: THERE was a night in 1972 when every rookie trying to make the Dallas Cowboys Football Club slept with his phone off the hook. Early the next day, the Cowboys assembled for the first team meeting after the final cut that sets the roster for the year.

title: On the Alliance For Mental Health
description: I wish to thank you for publishing the article on ''Aiding Families of the Mentally Ill'' by Elizabeth Field (Dec. 12). This excellent article helps to increase public awareness of the serious problems faced by the mentally ill and their families.

title: MANY AIDING THE NEEDIEST GIVE THANKS
description: ''Because I have so much to be grateful for and because these are trying times for so many, I have increased my gift to $50 this year.''

title: Mary Ames Wadsworth Wed in Boston
description: Mary Ames Wadsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis L. Wadsworth Jr. of Plymouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Lawrence Allnutt Darby 3d, son of Mrs. Darby Jr. of Dawsonville, Md., and the late Mr. Darby. The Rev. Thomas Powers of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass., and the Rev. Charles C. Forman of King's Chapel Unitarian Church in Boston performed the ceremony in King's Chapel.

title: REAGAN REPORTED SEEKING A BIG RISE IN NUCLEAR FUNDS
description: President Reagan, who has brought spending for nuclear arms to a level nearly double that of four years ago, plans to ask for another big increase when he submits the new military budget to Congress later this month, according to senior Administration officials.

title: WEEKEND SCHOOLS TUNE UP THE GIFTED
description: TO the soft electronic rock music of Jean-Michel Jarre's ''Equinoix,'' six youthful pairs of eyes w atched the movement of abstract patterns made on a wall by a laser b eam. The patterns were created by vibrations from the tape r ecorder's speaker, which caused the laser beam to move.

title: Warriors Send Kenon To Cavaliers for Cash
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers announced today that they had acquired the forward Larry Kenon from the Golden State Warriors for cash. Kenon had been signed by the Warriors Dec. 5 after being placed on waivers earlier this season by the Chicago Bulls.

title: SHEDD NOW SEEKS 'A CHANGE OF PACE'
description: AFTER more than eight years as Connecticut's Commissioner of Education, Mark R. Shedd stepped down last week amid a flurry of generalities about his career, which has not been easy to define.

title: Britain Opposes Sale Of Arms to Guatemala
description: Britain will press the United States not to resume full arms sales to Guatemala after Washington's decision to sell $6.36 million worth of military parts to the Central American nation, British officials said today.

title: NICARAGUA ACCUSES EX-ENVOY ON FUNDS
description: Nicaraguan officals charged today that Managua's former Ambassador to the United States withdrew $668,000 from the embassy's account without authorization before he left office.

title:
FOR HER, BRITAIN IS THE STUFF OF DRAMA;
LONDON
description: ''Do you know, after 'Cloud 9' opened in New York, people there would come up to me in the street, hug me, and say I had changed their lives. You really can't ask for anything more than that! I must say that it gives me great pleasure to know the play has achieved a longer life than other plays of mine. Normally, writing a play is like carefully preparing a lovely meal only to see it gobbled up and gone in 15 minutes.''

title: The Not So Dumb Public
description: Russell Baker hit the nail on the head when he wrote, ''The Government ought to stop telling me I'm too dumb to have an opinion on it'' (''Nuclear Freeze Frame,'' Sunday Observer, Dec. 12).

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ALL-REQUEST CONCERT
description: Arthur Hollander is a pianist who likes to start at the end. That is, today when he appears at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater, instead of waiting for the encore portion of his program to play the pieces the audience usually wants to hear, he is dedicating the entire concert to an ''All-Request Program - Piano Favorites From Start to Finish.'' So along with some crowd-pleasers by Mozart, Rachmaninoff and Paderewski, when Mr. Hollander takes the stage at 3:15 P.M. he will play the ''Moonlight Sonata,'' ''The Minute Waltz,'' ''Fantasy Impromptu'' and ''Clair de Lune'' before anyone even asks. Guild Hall is on Main Streeet in East Hampton and tickets are $5, or $4 for members, students and the elderly. For reservations: 324-4050.GREAT PERFORMERS

title: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC: A NEW SOUND TO THE HALL
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia renamed itself the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the beginning of this season, and thus ostensibly began a new era. But its real new era arrived Friday night, with the inauguration of a new acoustical shell at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House. All such devices require time to get used to, time to experiment with different spatial arrangements of the musicians and different repertory.

title: STALLING ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Democratic National Committee has yielded again to the temptation to play politics with the Social Security issue, by circulating a fund-raising letter ostensibly aimed at saving the system from ''Republican special interests who really don't support it.''

title: Trial Lawyers Reply To Liability Article
description: The Association of Trial Lawyers of America-New Jersey Affiliate is constrained to reply to the comments of Mark C. Perlberg (Opinion Page, Dec. 12), which decried the holding of the Supreme Court of New Jersey in recent products liability decisions.

title: Bishops Stir Pot In Canada
description: The Roman Catholic Church, outspoken on worldly issues elsewhere in the hemisphere, has remained relatively quiet in Canada where about half the 24 million people are Catholic. But last week, with the country deep in recession and unemployment approaching 13 percent, a group of bishops raised a storm by denouncing Government priorities.

title: Connecticut Wakes Up Broke
description: The tide of red ink that has flooded Trenton and Albany is on the rise in Hartford. Officials who only months ago were projecting a $2 million budget surplus now say they expect a $46.5 million deficit in the current fiscal year and perhaps a $300 million gap next year, more than enough to put a damper on the festivities surrounding the inauguration last week of Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: Discounting
description: To the Business Editor: As noted in ''The Discount Brokers Storm Wall Street'' (Dec.26), discount securities dealers are here to stay. There is no evidence that the advice one buys from a full-service firm is worth its price, and in some cases it is worth less than nothing.

title: Peete Rallies to Lead by a Shot
description: Cal Peete, playing as he did last year, came from five shots back with a 66 and moved into a one-stroke lead today in the third round of the $300,000 Joe Garagiola Tucson Open golf tournament.

title: CHICAGO
description: ACHART on the front wall of Jim O'Connor's sixth-grade classroom at May School, where most students are at least a year behind, shows by a series of X's and slashes which students have passed tests - if not the first time, then the second. If at least 80 percent have not passed by the second time around on 80 percent of the tests, Mr. O'Connor has some answering to do to his principal.

title: Virginia R. Perry Plans April Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt O. Perry Jr. of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Riker Perry, to Peter Campbell Worcester, son of Dr. and Mrs. James N. Worcester Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: WINTER SWIMMING AND MORE AT HUDSON PARK BEACH
description: In the summer, the beach at New Rochelle's Hudson Park is understandably crowded. The sounds of competing radios and animated conversations mingle with those of children playing and lifeguards calling to wayward swimmers. At night, remnants of the daytime activity are left on the sand: forgotten towels, solitary sneakers and, of course, garbage. Empty soda cans, candy wrappers, and plastic cups litter the beach, lying side by side with the seaweed and seashells.

title: BENEFITS IN LEASING YOUR CONDOMINIUM
description: IF you have $10,000 to put down and another few hundred dollars a m onth to cover expenses, James Yacenda and William Govel believe thaty ou should start the year off by investing in a condominium that can b e rented.

title: Kerry J. Crowley Becomes Engaged To Peter Mellette
description: Mr. and Mrs. James G. Crowley of Lawrenceville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kerry Jamieson Crowley, to Peter Mason Mellette, son of Drs. Peter and Susan Mellette of Richmond.

title: Marisa del Rosario and Adam Begley Are Planning to Be Married In June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ruben F. del Rosario of San Juan, P.R., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marisa del Rosario, to Adam C. Begley, son of Sally Higginson Begley of Stockbridge, Mass., and Louis Begley of New York. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The sale of the Seattle Sounders of the North American Soccer League, who lost an estimated $3 million last season, may take place in a few days. John Best, the general manager, said he had met with Bruce Anderson, a former N.F.L. player who heads a group of interested investors. ... Pat Putnam of Sports Illustratedhas been named the 1982 winner of the Nat Fleischer Award for ''excellence in boxing journalism.'' The Boxing Writers Association will make the award to Putnam in March.

title: LEBANON'S MASSACRE INQUIRY MAKES LITTLE PROGRESS
description: Lebanon's inquiry into last September's massacre of Palestinian civilians by Christian Phalangist militiamen has made little headway and investigators say that most witnesses, frightened of reprisal, will not testify.

title: THE LONGEST TRADITON
description: GREEK POETRY From Homer To Seferis. By C.A. Trypanis. 896 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $50.

title: LANDFILLS: FURTHER INQUIRIES EXPECTED
description: TRENTON THE first accounting of its kind on hazardous-waste contamination in New Jersey, issued recently by the Federal Government, shows that the destruction of water supplies and other ecological damage from these wastes have been common and could be on the rise.

title: Edith Coates, 74, of British Opera
description: Edith Coates, a mezzo-soprano in British opera for half a century, died Friday. She was 74 years old. She died of pneumonia in the hospital, her family said. Mrs. Coates studied singing at London's Trinity College of Music.

title: Calendars Seized in Java
description: The police in East Java confiscated at least 100,000 calendars that carried the Communist symbol of the hammer and sickle, the official Antara News Agency reported today. The Communist Party and all printed materials related to Communism have been banned since a Communist coup attempt in 1965.

title: MADISON AVE. TOUCH SELLS COLLEGE DRIVES
description: CENTURY baronial dinners complete with suckling pig; a golf tournament led by one of the nation's leading professionals, and re-enactments of George Washington's inaugural dinner are among the new courtship rites lavished by colleges upon their patrons.

title: D. Edward Martin Wed To Leslie Gale Wasser
description: Leslie Gale Wasser, a certified public accountant, and D.Edward Martin, a partner in the New York office of Main Hurdman, a national public-accounting firm, were married yesterday at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. Rabbi Nathan Landman performed the ceremony.

title: Robert Alexander Marries Susan Freel on Long Island
description: Susan Christine Freel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Freel of Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert J. Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Alexander of Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Edward Muhes performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hempstead, L.I.

title: 2 LEADERS' OUSTER SOUGHT
description: About 130 Liberal Party state committee members, gathering despite court orders, yesterday demanded the resignation of two top officials of the party, bringing into the open a struggle for leadership control.

title: LATIN IS ALIVE AND WELL IN GRADE SCHOOL
description: WHEN 11-year-old Jean Brutus stood at the front of the fifth-grade classroom at Public S chool 152 in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and announced , ' 'Cantemus carmen 'Ardet Roma,' '' there wasn't a puzzled look to be s een among any of his classmates. After two months of Latin classes, t he children understood at once that what Jean had said was: ''Let's s ing the song 'Rome Is Burning.' '' And accordingly, to the tune of ' 'Frere Jacques,'' they did - in flawless Latin.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
'SURPLUS DUCKLINGS' AND THE SCHOOLS
description: LESS than three years ago, schools across the country were frantically switching programs, curriculums and priorities in an effort to incorporate the provisions of PL 94-142, which required handicapped students to receive ''equal and appropriate educational opportunities in the least restrictive environment.''

title: Reagan Ponders Lonely Decision, With Lots of Help
description: ''He makes himself believe eventually,'' is how a White House aide last week described how the President's mind works. By now, the Administration's truest believer has many options on which to build a new economic faith.

title: TEACHING TO THINK: A NEW EMPHASIS
description: LIKE most institutions of higher learning, Marymount Manhattan C ollege assumed in the past that entering freshmen had learned to t hink in high school. But the small liberal-arts institution tucked a mong the brownstones of New York's East Side found otherwise, and i ts new students must now register for a one-year course called ' 'Critical Thinking.'' The course, an intensive exploration of the a nalytical skills essential to learning, is similar to others being o ffered by more and more schools and colleges around the country. T his development reflects rising concern that many students go t hrough school without gaining the ability to analyze, synthesize andg eneralize.

title: N. CAROLINA HANDS SYRACUSE FIRST LOSS
description: Michael Jordan scored 18 points, and Brad Daugherty added 15 as North Carolina pulled away in the second half for an 87-64 victory over previously undefeated Syracuse tonight.

title: THE BIRTH, DEATH AND RESURECTION OF 'EXTREMITIES'
description: TRENTON ABOUT a week after ''Extremities'' opened Off-Broadway to mixed reviews and discouraging business, one of the producers, Frank Gero, assembled the actors, who had every reason to expect to hear a notice of closing.

title:
CAMERA;
GUIDE TO CHOOSING AND USING COLOR FILMS
Letters; A Builder Dissents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterno Honored Again As Top Eastern Coach
description: Joe Paterno, whose Penn State team was unanimously selected as the No. 1 college football team for 1982, was named yesterday as winner of the 15th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award as the Eastern major-college coach of the year. It is the record fifth time Paterno has been voted the Sheehan award by the New York Football Writers Association.

title: Princess Faika of Egypt Dies; Sister of King Farouk Was 55
description: Princess Faika, a sister of King Farouk, died here Friday after a long illness, officials said today.

title: CREEPING RENEWAL
description: Fifteen years after the site and environs of the former Washington Street Market were marked for urban renewal, construction is nearly set to begin on two of the key elements of the renewal plan. According to New York City officials, all but final Board of Estimate approval has been given for plans for Gateway Gardens, a commercial and residential complex, and a one-million-square-foot office building.

title: Sports of The Times; Vintage Days for St. John's
description: THESE are the good old days for St. John's University, just about as good as they've ever been. Everything is happening right for the college from the eastern end of Queens.

title: Christina Pittman To Marry in April
description: Betty Joan Pittman of Kent, Wash., and James William Pittman of Silver Spring, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Marie Pittman, to Timothy Warner Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and Ocean Reef, Fla. The wedding is planned for April 9.

title: SOME CHANGES HAVE BEEN MADE
description: LE RESTAURANT in Glen Cove opened late last winter and was reviewed here in June, receiving a one-star rating. There are reasons for a second review. Restaurateurs often insist that it takes at least six months for a new establishment to be running smoothly. In the case of Le Restaurant, the owner did not suggest that the initial review was premature, but after it appeared he indicated that some changes had been made and that perhaps there should be a re-evaluation in the future. The future is now.

title: LIVES THAT TOUCH WITHOUT INTIMACY
description: THE INFINITE PASSION OF EXPECTATION, Twenty-five Stories.By Gina Berriault. 252 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $12.50.

title: Film Forum Is Offering A Bunuel Retrospective
description: A Luis Bunuel retrospective will open the winter film series on Jan. 13 at Film Forum, 57 Watts Street.

title: HIS GOAL WAS A PORTRAIT OF GERMANY IN HIS TIME; WASHINGTON
description: August Sander (1876-1964), one of photography's great portraitists and surely Germany's greatest, wanted most of all to make a portrait of his times. About 1918 he conceived of a method, a vast documentary project he titled ''Menschen des 20 Jahrhunderts'' (literally, ''Men of the 20th Century''). He divided the social world as he knew it into 45 ''types'' ranging from the unemployed to aristocrats; for each ''type'' he planned to make 12 portraits, for a total of 520 photographs. It was a project that was to occupy him the rest of his life, and it was left unfinished at his death.

title: A FAMILY ALBUM AT FARLEIGH DICKINSON
description: MADISON ART IS supposed to speak for itself, but seldom does. Explanatory writing has become an essential part of its presentation; social forces also play a part, for new geniuses, like starlets, don't burst upon the scene unrecommended.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: DANCE ''Transfigured Night,'' an early work by Jiri Kylian, re-enters the Joffrey Ballet's repertory on Tuesday at City Center, where the company plays through next Sunday, Jan. 16. Set to Arnold Schoenberg's ''Verklaerte Nacht,'' the ballet is a Maelstrom of intense emotions suggested by Richard Dehmel's poem about a woman whose infidelity is forgiven by the man she loves. Anna Kisselgoff, reviewing the company premiere last year, described its blend of Expressionism and neo-Romanticism as ''impressively'' rendered by the Joffrey dancers. It will be performed Tuesday by Denise Jackson, James Canfield, DeAnn Duteil and Jerel Hilding. Who knows but that they'll have another hit on their hands?

title: Professor Suspended
description: A history professor who has been accused of inflating grades and providing advance test answers for varsity athletes in his classes, has been suspended without pay for three years by Florida State University. Edward Wynot, 39 years old, a tenured professor who has taught at the school for 12 years, was accused of raising grades for football and basketball players, causing a graduate assistant to provide advance answers to the athletes and lying about his actions.

title: No Headline
description: Ohio State Halts No.1 Indiana

title: TOM MCCALL, EX-OREGON GOVERNOR AND ENVIRONMENTALIST, DIES AT 69
description: Former Gov. Tom McCall of Oregon, who drew the nation's attention with pioneering curbs on uncontrolled land development and throwaway bottles, died yesterday morning of cancer at a hospital in Portland, Ore. He was 69 years old.

title: DIPLOMACY BY OTHER MEANS
description: WAR IN THE FALKLANDS, The Full Story. By The Sunday Times of London Insight Team. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: JAZZ PIANO: GEORGE SHEARING
description: George Shearing made his annual winter stand at Michael's Pub last year as part of a duo with the bassist Brian Torff. Mr. Torff has since formed a duo of his own and Mr. Shearing has returned to Michael's Pub for January and February with a new partner, Don Thompson.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK COURTS ARTS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THIS Middlesex County city, which houses the main campuses of Rutgers University as well as the headquarters of Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical concern, would become a major regional cultural center under plans disclosed last week by officials of the university, the city and the New Brunswick Development Corporation.

title: SEVERAL CITIES PLAN TO CUT FUEL COSTS BY PIPING HEAT FROM CENTRAL SOURCE
description: Cities around the nation are seeking to slash fuel costs and rebuild their downtowns with a method of heating and cooling that uses wasted energy and serves many buildings from one source.

title: Alyce Sher to Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Sher of New City, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Alyce Lynn Sher, to Michael Emanuel Kitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Kitt of Hartsdale, N.Y. Miss Sher, a graduate of Skidmore College, received a master's degree in dance therapy from Hunter College. Her fiance graduated from the West Virginia Institute of Technology. A June wedding is planned.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Pope John Paul II named 18 cardinals last week, who will receive their red hats at a consistory on Feb.2. This brings the number of members of the Sacred College of Cardinals to 138, of which 18 (who are more than 80 years old) do not share in the only right and duty that is particular to these princes of the church. That is to elect a pope. They do so in their role as titular parish priests of a church in Rome electing their bishop. To be the bishop of Rome makes the chosen prelate the head of the Roman Catholic Church. Cardinals also take part in consistories, whose function it is to give automatic approval to the pope's choices for the rank of cardinal. A consistory normally brings together the cardinals who are in or near Rome. Foreign cardinals need not make a special journey.

title: TALKING PICTURES MARK AN OBSCURE ANNIVERSARY
description: To put a new year into proper perspective, one would have to know the future. Failing that, one can still make a tolerable attempt at the construction of meaning by consulting the past. Perhaps that is why, at the beginning of a new year, we search for anniversaries - not merely as occasions for sentimental reminiscence, but as signposts and markers in the stream of events.

title: THE 'HOOK' A STUDENT NEEDS TO CATCH A TOP COLLEGE
description: MANY long-held assumptions about college admissions are no longer v alid - and some never have been. Among them is the assumption that ah igh school graduate with excellent grades and high standardized tests cores will be admitted wherever he applies.

title: ANOTHER ACT IN TERRORISM'S DEADLY DRAMA
description: To Oliver B. Revell, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's criminal division, ''Terrorism is a form of theater.'' If that's the case, then the New Year's Eve bombings in New York City were a kind of grisly theater of the absurd, one in which the victims of the violence are randomly selected.

title: DANCE: CRANKO'S 'PINEAPPLE POLL' BY THE JOFFREY
description: John Cranko's comic ''Pineapple Poll'' returned to the Joffrey Ballet Friday night at the City Center for the first time since 1978. Gilbert and Sullivan warmed over without words is not too easy a recipe to pull off and this revival came across as half-cooked porridge.

title: AMONG HISPANIC CATHOLICS, ANOTHER PATTERN OF PRACTICE
description: While many Roman Catholic officials have seen their dioceses become increasingly populated by Hispanic immigrants in recent decades, little formal study of the religious beliefs of these newcomers has been available to aid the church in reaching them with spiritual and social services.

title:
TV VIEW;
FIRST THE MUPPETS, NOW THE FRAGGLES
description: The Fraggles are about to slip into our lives. They are small, furry creatures, in all sorts of vibrant colors, with bright tufts of hair sprouting from their somewhat silly heads. They love to sing, and their basic philosophy is spelled out in a theme song: ''Dance your cares away/Worry's for another day/Let the music play/Down at Fraggle Rock.'' These immediately endearing creatures, who will make their debut tomorrow evening at 7:30 on the pay-cable channel of Home Box Office, are the latest batch of characters devised at Henson Associates, home of the Muppets and, more recently, the cast of the film ''The Dark Crystal.''

title: Paw Paw Sequel
description: When it comes to frugality in government, Paw Paw, W. Va., may be without a peer. But early last year the town, run by a $25-a-month mayor and operating on a yearly budget of $25,000, wondered if it could stay solvent.

title: RECOVERY IS IN THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER
description: LIVINGSTON KEN REYNOLDS looked at the nurses in the 3700 wing at St. Barnabas Medical Center here, where he had been a kidney-transplant patient three years earlier.

title: NEW APPROACHES TO NEW ENGLAND IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: "NEW ENGLAND PERAMBULATIONS" would do nicely enough as the title for the photography show now at the Lyme Historical Society, Old Lyme. But it's preceded by an admonitory colon and the word "Places"--a syntactical habit that seemingly has been plaguing the museum world forever. Apart from presuming a slow-witted audience, the mannerism epitomizes the didactic responsibility that art increasingly is expected to assume. No doubt this has something to do with the craze, not for knowledge, but for "information" and for the learning-teaching process in general.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A BAD PRECEDENT
description: ON Dec. 30, President Reagan put aside his free-market beliefs, as w ell as the budget-cutting advise from his Office of Management and B udget, and signed a $56 million sleepwear industry bailout bill. Thel egislation allows the Court of Claims to reimburse pajama makers, d istributors and retailers for losses incurred when the c ancercausing chemical Tris was banned in 1977.

title: A DRAMATIC CHANGE AT THE I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON IN an oak-paneled board room 12 stories above Pennsylvania Avenue, a wiry, grave-looking Frenchman named Jacques de Larosiere, with only the merest wisp of an accent in English, gently but firmly called the meeting to order.

title: BELLOWS'S WORLD: L.I. AND BEYOND
description: THE renowned American artist George Bellows (1882-1925) had strong ties to eastern Long Island - his father came from Good Ground (now known as Hampton Bays) and his mother was from Sag Harbor - and thus it is appropriate for the Guild Hall Museum to mount an exhibition in honor of his centennial. ''The World of George Bellows,'' organized by Helen A. Harrison, consultant curator, concentrates on the Bellows achievements in lithography, but also includes evidence of his skills in other media.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER James Earl Jones is giving one of his best stage performances of recent years in ''Master Harold...and the Boys,'' the powerful Athol Fugard play at the Lyceum. His task is not an easy one. The role of Sam, a tearoom waiter in 1950 South Africa, was originated by Zakes Mokae, who lent an almost Gandhi-like spiritual presence to the character. Mr. Jones can't duplicate that special kind of authority, but he nonetheless brings Sam warmth and twinkling humor - an effervescence we don't usually find in this actor's work. And in the play's searing climax, in which Sam is humiliated by the white boy he raised like a son, the actor grows into a compelling figure of moral rectitude.

title: NEW YORK STATE DRAFT SIGN-UP RATE IS TERMED FIFTH-LOWEST IN NATION
description: In the two years since mandatory draft registration was reinstituted, over 94 percent of the country's draft-age men have signed up. But in New York State, the rate of compliance is 87.2 percent, the fifth-lowest in the nation, according to the Selective Service. New Jersey and Connecticut are also below the national average.

title: Katherine R. Read and Steven D. Ezell Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry James Read of New Orleans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Roemer Read, to Steven Douglas Ezell of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Gerald Ezell of Nashville. The wedding is planned for Feb. 19.

title: Original Mandate
description: To the Business Editor: When William W. Winpisinger accused the current Department of Labor of ''Abandoning Its Original Mandate'' (Dec.5), he opened the way for Labor Department Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and Thorne G. Auchter, in charge of the department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration, to make sanctimonious claims that it is they who are serving all workers by their reliance on the cooperation of employers motivated equally by humanitarian and monetary considerations.

title: GARVEY, UNDER ATTACK, HINTS HE'LL STAY
description: In recent weeks, most players on six of the National Football League's 28 teams have called on Ed Garvey to resign as head of their union. Garvey will not say what he will do, although he indicates that he will stay on the job because he considers opposition part of the union process.

title: ACCORDING TO TRADITION
description: When Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H.M.S. Pinafore, or The Lass That Loved a Sailor'' was first produced at the Opera Comique in London 104 years ago, it ran for 571 performances.

title: MESSAGES IN STONE
description: Colonial tombstones are loaded with symbolism and often carved with admonitions for the living. According to Jonathan Fairbanks, curator of the American Decorative Arts and Sculpture Department of the Museum of Fine Arts of Boston, there are some very strong schools of carvers, ranging from primitive to sophisticated.

title: WALESA'S NEW JERSEY AMBASSADOR
description: JERSEY CITY WALTER S. BROLEWICZ is a modest man who doesn't particularly care about being the focus of public attention. However, he has promised his cousin, Lech Walesa, that he will keep the struggle of the Polish people before the American public.

title: TORONTO'S MALL IS A MAGNET
description: ANDREW H. MALCOLM, formerly Toronto bureau chief for The Times, recently became chief of the Chicago bureau.

title: 4 CITY HIGH SCHOOLS TO ADAPT PROGRAM TO MOTIVATE STUDENTS
description: With the help of a $400,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, New York City will attempt to improve the achievement of high school students by reproducing the characteristics of successful schools at institutions where student performance is lagging.

title: IMAGES OF A CITY
description: Anyone who takes delight in New York City and its architectural treasures probably enjoys poring over the vintage photographs of old mansions and neighborhoods that have been printed in abundance over the past century. All facets of New York's evolution have been documented and celebrated in numerous photo books and exhibitions, particularly during the last 15 years.

title: CONFUSION MARKS DEBUT OF AUTO TESTS
description: HOUR lines and confusion, which led some of the wrong people to show up at motor-vehicle stations last week, are expected to decrease with each passing day of the state's new auto inspection program, according to one of its officials.

title: New York Times Magazine January 9, 1983
description: William Safire 9 On Language Cap the Entitlement Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Writer on the Roof Andrew H. Malcolm 16 Hard Sell in the Showroom With sales prospects asking tough questions about the American car, it is the dealers who will be determining whether the automobile industry will retreat even further or advance at long last. Stuart Taylor Jr. 30 Ethics and the Law: A Case History When a law firm learned of rampant crime in a client company, it faced serious ethical issues.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 31 of The Times magazine today incompletely describes the role of two lawyers shown with Myron Goodman. They are not connected with the law firm named as a co-defendant in legal actions arising from the case of O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc.

title: SEVERINSEN TIMES TWO
description: Doc Severinsen, trumpeter and longtime leader of the orchestra on TV's ''Tonight'' show, will be featured in two pops concerts by the New Jersey Symphony - on Friday evening in New Brunswick and next Sunday afternoon in Newark.

title: Kathleen A.H. Evans Wed
description: The marriage of Kathleen Anthony Horne Evans to Austin Brandt Graff, a lawyer with the Navy Department in Washington, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: South Africa Raids Black Activist's Home
description: Policemen raided the home of Winnie Mandela, a banned black activist and the wife of Nelson Mandela, the jailed nationalist leader, on Friday and seized books, documents, a bedspread and other items, neighbors said.

title: ONE PERSPECTIVE ON A BIT OF DIVERSITY IN A COMMUNITY
description: IHEARD a woman say that she didn't want a group home on her street. She said the adult residents would be both an unpleasant sight and a danger to her children. Such people might, she said, even cause them physical harm.

title: FEDERAL STANDARDS FOR AWARDING OF LEGAL FEES ARE TIGHTENED
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that when a court awards legal fees in a civil-rights case, the lawyers can be paid only for the portion of the case that they win.

title: Mr. McHale Wed To Sally Simmons
description: The marriage of Sally Duncan Simmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Simmons of Greenwich, Conn., to John J. McHale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McHale of North Palm Beach, Fla., and Montreal, took place yesterday at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Bishop, assisted by the Rev. James Martin, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ISRAEL POINTS WAY FOR THE DISADVANTAGED
description: JERUSALEM IN the Israeli border town of Qiryat Shemona a group of visiting foreign educators gathered around a young paraprofessional aide in a community center as she explained to women from her neighborhood how to fill in a grid pattern. She referred to the lines she was telling them to draw as ''lying down'' and ''standing up,'' rather than horizontal and vertical.

title: AN ESSENCE OF SUMMER RECALLED
description: MY rosemary plant is in full bloom for the new year, wearing a halo of tiny, pale blue blossoms. This fall, we delayed bringing it inside until November and for our negligence our patient friend rewarded us with its best show in years. I can't remember how long we have had our rosemary: 15 years at least, maybe 20. When it was small we used to plant it in a corner of the vegetable garden in late spring. Then in October we would dig it up, pot it and bring it into the house.

title: FOR 1983 OPENERS, OFFERINGS ARE RICH
description: THE rush to get the new concert year under way has begun, and many of the county's top cultural organizations are readying their 1983 openers for this week or next. Today at 3 o'clock, for instance, the 17th season of Sunday concerts at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers continues with a performance of Schubert's magnificent song cycle ''Die Schone Mullerin.'' The tenor is Larry Bauer and Mary Sadovnikoff, a champion of authentic instrument usage, will be accompanying him on a fortepiano such as Schubert himself most likely knew.

title: EX-MANAGER IS FOUND GUILTY OF DEFRAUDING ELECTRIC UTILITY
description: A former employee of the South Norwalk Electric Works pleaded no contest this week to charges of defrauding the utility of more than $100,600 between May 1977 and December 1980.

title: ASSEMBLY COULD END EXISTENCE OF 7 BOARDS
description: Although Connecticut's unemployment rate has been inching upward, the state's Advisory Committee on High Unemployment Areas, formed in 1975 to assist "neglected" towns where the unemployment rate has been above the state average for at least a year, has not convened since 1978.

title: PHILADELPHIA
description: With a catchy title, a trendy theme and savvy curatorial ''sell,'' ''Image Scavengers,'' the current exhibition at the University of Pennsylvania's Institute of Contemporary Art (through Jan. 30), is a show whose organizers have worked hard to convince us there's more to it than meets the eye. Encompassing both painting and photography, it deals with the work of artists who, as children in the 1950's, were weaned on the ''sensory overload'' of the mass media - television, movies, magazines, newspapers, computers and such - and now ''recycle'' its imagery. This tendency toward mass media ''appropriation'' is one aspect of the new interest in figuration, says Janet Kardon, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art. With Paula Marincola, the Institute's assistant director, she has rounded up the work of 20 artists and photographers - some, such as Robert Longo, David Salle and Cindy Sherman, already flashes in the pantheon of the 1980's.

title: A PATCH OF GREEN
description: It took more than a special design effort to save almost all the oaks, elms, poplars and flowering Japanese plum trees on the site of the new David Chavis Houses for the elderly, now nearly finished, in the Beford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. It also took some determined community activists with a strong view of what their neighborhood needed.

title: RUMANIAN FAMILY STARTS A NEW LIFE
description: IT began about three years ago at a Soviet-Rumanian border crossing, when Sergiu Pop, an auto-body mechanic from Bucharest, approached Stanley Schear, a Scarsdale baker, to ask if he could use his limited knowledge of English to help the American, who was having difficulty with the Soviet customs officials.

title: JAZZ: JOE BUSHKIN QUARTET
description: Playing the piano is only a part of what Joe Bushkin is doing at the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, where he will be appearing through March 5. Mr. Bushkin, who is now 66 years old, is remembered as the pianist in Tommy Dorsey's band in 1940 and 1941, as the house pianist at the Embers in the early 50's and as Bing Crosby's piano accompanist in the mid-70's.

title: BOOK BACHELOR
description: ''I sold my books,'' my friend said. I looked at him in astonishment. He was a man who took immense pride in his books. For years he'd been manager of a major bookstore and during that time he'd collected thousands of volumes.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE UNICORN AND THE LAKE By Marianna Mayer. Illustrated by Michael Hague. Unpaged. New York: The Dial Press. $11.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: RECITAL: URSULA OPPENS
description: We can usually judge musicians by the people who come to hear them play. Ursula Oppens's audience at the 92d Street Y Thursday night, in any case, was large, admiring and raptly attentive throughout a difficult evening of piano music. Its devotion, indeed, seemed to mirror the musical concentration emanating from the stage. Not everyone may have liked everything Miss Oppens played or how she played it, but she never lost our attention for an instant.

title: SLOW RECOVERY OF HEART RECIPIENT MARKED BY MOMENTS OF PESSIMISM
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's steps from bed to wheelchair are short and shuffling, but mobility is now clearly an important part of his life, 38 days after he became the world's first recipient of a permanent artificial heart.

title: Blacks and Corporate Stress
description: Bebe Moore Campbell's ''Black Executives and Corporate Stress'' (Dec. 12) is an extraordinary and intelligent piece of writing. The situation in regard to black executives and the stress they experience is not inconsistent with the stress that I have experienced in education, particularly as education has attempted to adopt corporate methods.

title: WHEN YOU WANT OUT AS LENDER
description: IN the tough real-estate market of the last few years, many h omeowners found that the only way they could sell their houses a dvantageously was to give a mortgage loan to the buyer for part of t he purchase price.

title: SHULTZ IS BRIEFED BY EXPERTS FOR VISIT TO CHINA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met today with a group of China experts to prepare himself for his first visit to Peking early next month.

title: ...AND REASONING IN COLLEGE
description: IT is a crisp fall day, and the freshmen in John Chaffee's Critical Thought Skills course at La Guardia Community College are discussing cliches. Dr. Chaffee asks the 20 students, who range in age from 17 to 50, to define the word. No one raises his hand; the students all sit quietly as Dr. Chaffee writes ''Better late than never'' on the blackboard and explains that a cliche is a worn-out and overused expression that supposedly contains some truth.

title: Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES TALCOTT
description: James Talcott, retired chairman of James Talcott Inc., one of the oldest factoring and commercial finance companies in the country, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: THE DEMOCRATS GET EVEN
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the 98th Congress opened its doors last week, Representative Doug Barnard Jr., a four-term Democrat from Georgia, bid for a seat on the prestigious House Appropriations Committee. Mr. Barnard had a good case, since the slot had been held by a fellow Georgian. It went instead to Representative Bill Boner, a moderate from Tennessee.

title: SUNDAY, JANUARY, 9, 1983
description: International Vice President Bush will go to Europe Jan. 30 for talks with American allies and to address the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva, President Reagan announced in his weekly radio address. Mr. Reagan, citing ''encouraging words'' from the new Soviet leadership, said, ''Clearly the Soviets want to appear more responsive and reasonable.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) A visit to the Falkland Islands was made Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. She told the Falklanders that she had come ''to pay tribute to those who liberated the islands'' that Britain recaptured from Argentina in fighting last year. (1:5.)

title: SQUEEZING THE OLD STORE A BIT HARDER
description: Trying to avoid a continuation of the punishing slowdown they suffered last year, retailers of all sizes and inclinations are shaking off the Christmas blues and seeking new ways to grow.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I would like to spend three weeks seeing Gothic churches in Europe. Can you suggest an itinerary that includes less expensive lodging and transportation as well? - P.M.C., Maplewood, N.J. Answer:Great Gothic churches and cathedrals can be found in many places throughout Europe: England's Westminster Abbey, Salisbury and Ely as well as East Germany's Magdeburg, West Germany's Bamberg and Spain's Burgos are all among them. In the interest of seeing those of perhaps the greatest architectural and historical significance within three weeks, however, Charles Little of the Metropolitan Museum of Art staff suggested that you base yourself in Paris and start by visiting Saint-Denis on the city's northern outskirts; it is considered the first Gothic church, dating from around 1140. In Paris itself is the Cathedral of Notre Dame; its construction spanned the middle of the 12th century and continued into the 13th. Not far from Notre Dame are Sainte-Chapelle, dedicated in 1248, and Saint-Germain de Pres, with Gothic elements dating from the late 12th century in addition to earlier Romanesque.

title: THE LURE OF NEW YORK'S TAX-EXEMPTS
description: NEW YORK STATE and its authorities have a reputation in the t axexempt market of being among the most ingenious of borrowers, a s well as the most active.

title: PHILLIPS SEEKING GENERAL AMERICAN
description: Phillips Petroleum plans to buy the General American Oil Company of Texas for nearly $1.2 billion. As part of the surprise deal, the Mesa Petroleum Company agreed to withdraw its own offer, and General American agreed to pay Mesa $15 million for expenses incurred in its tender offer.

title: QUESTIONS LINGER ON PILGRIM STATE
description: BRENTWOOD STATE and county officials are wondering what to do next about the Pilgrim prison here. Governor Cuomo has promised to remove the prisoners, but there is no place to put them. And while county leaders want to turn the building into housing for the elderly, they do not know how much that would cost or where the money would come from.

title: RECITAL: JORGE BOLET, PIANO
description: Jorge Bolet's piano recital Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was cleverly assembled, both in terms of musical relationships and in its congeniality to his interpretive gifts. It began with more than just the perfunctory Haydn - both the dreamy Andante con Variazione in F minor and the Sonata in E flat (Hob.

title: Nottingham Upset, 2-0
description: Archie Gemmill scored on a free kick in the second half, helping Second Division Derby County to a surprising 2-0 victory over Nottingham Forest, a First Division team, today in a Football Association Cup third-round soccer game.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE 'CAP' LAW: THERE IS A NEED FOR ADJUSTMENT
description: LIKE everything else we do, running for political office should be a learning experience. Running for Freeholder in Morris County was no exception. Although the campaign was unsuccessful, I learned a great deal about the county, of which I am a native, and about some of the realities of county government.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Michelle Faurot And Mr. Carroll Are Wed in Rye
description: Michelle Anne Faurot, daughter of Mrs. Edmond Joseph Downing of Rye, N.Y., and Allen Reed Faurot of New York, was married yesterday to John Gregory Carroll, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Joseph Carroll of Baltimore and Fishers Island, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye by the Rev. Edward Johnston and the Rev. Francis Schemel, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CLEAN-AIR DEADLINE IS MET BY STATE
description: WASHINGTON D.C. LAST month, Connecticut appeared to be part of a select group: a handful of states that had met a deadline for cleaning up their air and would not face a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: Pet Insurance
description: Health insurance, with sickness and accident benefits, deductibles and major medical coverage, became available for family dogs and cats in April 1982. It was offered by companies in Monticello, N.Y., and Sacramento, Calif., and they had high hopes for expansion to other states.

title: Rosemary E. Monchun Plans to Marry May 28
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Monchun of Windsor, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Ellen Monchun, to Daniel V. DeClue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent DeClue of Rochester. Miss Monchun and her fiance, 1979 graduates of Amherst College, plan to be married May 28.

title: A NEW YORK SCHOOL FOR 'STREET KIDS'
description: Drum roll, please,'' said a student in the Living Language class at the Satellite Academy on Forsyth Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side. ''Start a beat, somebody,'' yelled another.

title: A FAMED PASTRY CHEF'S MOVEABLE FEAST
description: Whenever you find Gaston Lenotre among a group of people, he's always the one having the best time,'' says an acquaintance. At 62, France's most famous pastry chef has more energy and enthusiasm than those half his age. And so it comes as no surprise to find that this fun-loving man manages to combine his passion for play and his zeal for work in a most agreeable manner.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SOUTH ORANGE
description: THE village of South Orange, which spills down the steep side of S outh Mountain in a corner of Essex County, once advertised itself a s the ''Switzerland of America.'' Houses built into the mountainsideh ave such steeply raked front lawns that mowing is a strenuous battlew ith gravity.

title: BRINGING 'COUNTRY' TO THE COUNTRY House
description: ''Oh, it's Friday night at the Hastings House, Oh, Lord, are we having fun. Oh, it's Friday night at the Hastings House, And we love it and everyone.'' From ''Friday Night at the Has- tings House,'' words and music by Robert M. Robinson, Hastings resi- dent, air-conditioning contractor and self-avowed country and western music fan. By GARY KRISS

title: Pravda Assesses Blame On Food Output Woes
description: The Soviet Communist Party criticized the country's agriculture industry today, citing chronic problems of poor soil preparation, broken tractors and improper distribution of seeds and fertilizers.

title: ROstow's Deputy Walks the Plank; Rostow Hangs In
description: The standing of Jesse Helms and Company may have dipped for the moment on Capitol Hill, but at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, Senator Helms and his fellow conservatives appear to have clout to spare.

title: RAIDERS DEFEAT BROWNS
description: Alvin Garrett might have been the only member of the Washington Redskins who expressed some concern today after the National Conference's No.1 team overwhelmed the Detroit Lions, 31-7, in a first-round game of the National Football League playoffs.

title: No Headline
description: Bruins Hold Off Canadiens, 2-1

title: THE FRONT-DRIVE ADVANTAGE
description: LAST week's allegations of serious brake defects in some General Motors X-cars have prompted questions about Government action in regulating safety. But the G.M. case also points up some major differences in the handling characteristics of front- and rear-wheeldrive automobiles.

title: STATES REPORT RECESSION IS SQUEEZING BUDGETS
description: The financial condition of most states deteriorated last year, mainly as a result of the recession, the National Governors Association has reported.

title: A PARODY THAT FIZZLES, A DRAMA THAT BAFFLES
description: During the single intermission afforded by an enterprise known as ''Whodunnit,'' I spent part of my time leafing the evening's Playbill. The Playbill contained a piece about the absolutely dreadful manners of today's audiences, scolding them mercilessly and in some detail. Looking up from the Playbill and glancing round about me, I silently took leave to differ. It seemed to me that this audience had been behaving with an unbelievable - nay, an exquisite - decorum.

title:
A VOCATIONAL BIG BUSINESS;
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.
description: TWO weeks before graduation, 26-year-old Douglas R. Barnett of D enver considered five job offers before choosing to work for the M cDonnell Douglas Corporation. Three weeks before graduation, 2 2-year-old Michael Mallen of New Jersey turned down an offer from I nternational Business Machines Corporation before signing on with t he Burroughs Corporation.

title: FREE MARKET SHOULD PREVAIL IN EDUCATION
description: AN often overlooked feature of the American system of free enterprise is that not only are its economic consequences firmly dependent upon open competition in a free market, but also the Government permits, yea encourages, private enterprise to compete with government enterprise in many areas.

title:
OPINION;
WHAT THE BEACHCOMBER FOUND
description: THE beaches of Long Island are hardly those lush tropical locales that come to mind when one thinks of the term ''beachcomber.'' And while our Paumanok beaches yield no black pearls, no thousanddollars-a-pound lumps of ambergris, no tiger-striped seashell worth a mermaid's ransom, they do offer their own peculiar and stimulating gifts.

title: N.C.A.A. CONVENTION FACES LARGE ISSUES
description: SAN DIEGO AN attempt by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to demote 40 or more Division I basketball colleges to Division II appears doomed, according to James Frank, president of the N.C.A.A. and a member of the powerful 22-member council.

title: SALISBURY BLENDER IS PERFECTING HIS TEAS
description: At his bidding, the white china tea service arrives. John Harney holds up a finger. "Five minutes," he declares. "No more, no less."

title: Smokeless Work
description: Many workers who don't smoke believe they have a right to a smokefree job. Last October a Federal worker, Irene C. Parodi of Fremont, Calif., won a landmark court decision upholding that right.

title: Italy's Largest Unions Plan Regional Strikes
description: Italy's three main union federations, caught by surprise by a wave of spontaneous demonstrations against Government austerity measures, called today for a series of regional strikes next week to maintain the momentum of protest.

title: TAX REFUND TO STORES IS WEIGHED
description: WHITE PLAINS residents will have to return something to the B Altman & Company Department Store this year, and it won't be merchandise - it will be money, all or part of $488,000 won in a tax-reduction suit in October.

title: OFFICIALS CHIP AWAY AT PRISON PROBLEMS
description: NEWARK AREPORT prepared by a retired State Supreme Court justice last March concluded that inmates at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth were subjected to ''genuine privations and hardship which cannot be justified by the mere fact that a statewide prison-overcrowding problem exists.''

title: ENVOYS SAY TRIPOLI STRIFE MAY SNAG PULLOUT TALKS
description: The fighting in the northern port city of Tripoli is being watched by diplomats here who say they are concerned that the clashes could further complicate the bogged-down talks between Israel and Lebanon on the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon.

title: REAL ESTATE OPERATOR ADMITS TRYING TO BRIBE ADMINISTRATOR OF F.A.A.
description: A real-estate operator has pleaded guilty in Manhattan to a charge of attempting to bribe the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: F.I.T. FOR PEOPLE
description: The competition between pedestrians and vehicular traffic can be seen on every street in Manhattan, but the Fashion Institute of Technology has a plan to designate a final winner for West 27th Street, which bisects its Chelsea campus.

title: THE THEATER: 'ANGELUS'
description: Gene Ruffini's ''Angelus'' is a small, sincere play about an Italian-American family in the Bronx from the Depression to the 1970's. Tony Napoli has given the work a neat, kitchen-cabinet production at the American Theater of Actors, but the evening has only a marginal dramatic interest.

title: ORDERLY GAME PLAN FALTERS AS THE GAME DRAWS NEAR
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Reagan's proposed budget for 1984 was supposed to derive from a process as fine and precise as a Swiss watch. In November and December, he conducted orderly budget reviews, intending to complete most decisions by Christmas and then to make a few adjustments in the New Year. But last week, reports of major new budget initiatives popped up and disappeared like parts of a cuckoo clock gone awry.

title: ENTER DANCERS
description: The five-year-old Untermyer Performing Arts Summer Festival in Yonkers spins off into winter programming for the first time this year with a ''Winterdance '83'' series in Saunders Auditorium, the new Board of Education complex on Palmer Road.

title: MAKING THE 'AIRWAY ROBBERY' WORSE
description: THE deregulation of television, which is a popular concept in the Federal Communications Commission these days, will be particularly harmful to Long Islanders if it becomes law. Considering Long Island's vast population and extraordinary productivity, we make up one of the most underserved television communities in the nation.

title: Oregon Indians' Right to Hunt On Their Former Land Upheld
description: Klamath Indians have the right to hunt, fish and trap without state interference on 617,000 acres of former reservation land ceded to the Government in 1906, Federal District Judge Gus Solomon has ruled.

title: EL SALVADOR REBUFFS MISSING MAN'S KIN
description: BOGOTA THE family of a missing New Jersey freelance journalist was informed last week that the Salvadoran Government will not release a body that might be that of the missing man.

title: FLORIDA CONDOMINIUMS: A BUYER'S MARKET
description: ''SELL OR DIE,'' exhorts a wall sign in the sales office of Winston Towers, a seven-building condominium complex overlooking the greenstriped surf of upper Miami Beach. ''A reminder to the salesmen,'' said Len Worman, the sales manager, with a chuckle.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Spoofing Success RARELY does a trade paperback title outsell the No. 1 mass market book, although Kathleen Woodiwiss's ''Shanna'' and ''A Rose in Winter'' have both done so. Last week ''Items From Our Catalog'' by Alfred Gingold joined that select group when it outsold ''A Few Minutes With Andy Rooney'' on The New York Times list. Mr. Gingold's book, a parody of the popular L.L. Bean catalogue, sold particularly well among small independent stores.

title: IT'S A FARCE, ON THE SURFACE
description: EAST FARMINGDALE LAST summer the Arena Players Repertory Theater put on Don Flynn's ''Keep Krap Out of Kansas,'' a dreadful play with an obnoxious - and irrelevant - title. For his second Arena strikeout, Mr. Flynn has come up with an inoffensive title at most: ''The Pilgrims Landed Just Down the Road.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: ART When the New York Public Library puts on a show of illustrated books, it doesn't fool around. So rich are its own collections that when it displays first published editions of almost anything you might name, it can often accompany them with original sketches, drawings and manuscripts.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: DRINKING IN AMERICA By Mark Edward Lender and James Kirby Martin. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: The Free Press/Macmillan Publishing Co. $19.95.

title: PLOTS IN FAR PLACES
description: THE CHINA OPTION By Nancy Dall Milton. 311 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.THE SHATTERED EYE By Bill Granger. 245 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95.VANISHING POINT By Victor Canning. 201 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $10.95.By EVAN HUNTER

title:
GARDENING;
AVERTING PLANT DAMAGE BY SALT AND SNOW
description: UNLIKE other sections of the country, we have been fortunate in not having had to contend with severe blizzards and ice storms so far this winter. However, the inevitable is certain to happen sooner or later, and we, too, will be faced with digging out from beneath a mantle of white snow.

title: SYMBOLS AND ORDEALS
description: PRINCE OMBRA By Roderick MacLeish. 305 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $14.95.A NEW HISTORY OF TORMENTS By Zulfikar Ghose. 303 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.50.OXHERDING TALE By Charles Johnson. 176 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $10.95.

title:
OPINION;
A DIX HILLS REPLY TO THE 'STRANGER' FROM QUEENS
description: THE myth of Dix Hills continues (''A 'Stranger' From Queens,'' Opinion Page). Home of the ''nouveau riche,'' ''etherized'' nonplace, ''comatose'' land of no knapsacks.

title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Counts Against Air Controller Leader
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed charges against the president of a local chapter of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, calling the charges ''intentional discrimination.''

title: ATHENS PROCLAIMS 'FINAL' STAND ON U.S. BASES
description: The Government announced this week, without elaboration, that it had formulated its ''final'' position on the future of United States military bases in Greece.

title: EDINBURGH'S HISTORIC PRESTONFIELD
description: GARRY WILLS has written several works of history and politics, among them ''The Kennedy Imprisonment'' (Little, Brown).

title: SLIMMED EXPECTATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: ''How Poor''
description: To the Business Editor: In reply to Robert Pear's recommendation to tax Social Security benefits, ''How Poor Are the Elderly'' (Dec.19), I wish to point out that the Social Security worker has already paid a full tax on his 50 percent contribution to the fund. His employer has done likewise.

title: Arafat Visiting Jordan
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization leader, Yasir Arafat, arrived here today for talks with King Hussein on a possible P.L.O.-Jordanian confederation and on the King's recent visit to the United States.

title: METEORITE GOES ON PUBLIC DISPLAY
description: THE roof at 461 Church Street has been repaired and ''Wethersfield-1982,'' the six-pound meteorite that crashed into the home of Wanda and Robert Donahue two months ago, is in a Hartford bank vault, back from extensive testing at a Government laboratory in the State of Washington.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 15 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 9 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 3 3 20 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 4 6 13 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 5 4 19 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 5 9 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 7 7 19 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 8 8 23 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title: SINGLE, PREGNANT AND A CHILDREN'S ROLE MODEL
description: To the Editor:

title: BID FOR A SISTER CITY
description: LAST spring Thomas Holohan, a New Haven Alderman, closed his eyes and pointed his finger on a map of the Soviet Union. His finger landed on a port city, Novorossiisk, on the Black Sea.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Writer on the Roof

title: PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor: In regard to the article by Morton N. Cohen, ''Circling Puerto Rico by Car'' (Travel, Dec. 12), two summers ago my husband and I took the same trip, reversing the author's route by heading first due east to Fajardo. There we took a half-day boat trip to a tiny shell island for some snorkeling.

title: No Headline
description: Bebe Moore Campbell's article points out that there is a cycle of problems that still confront black people, even those ''who have made it.'' It would be a better social and economic world if we did recognize the capable and competent job that black business people perform.

title: Soviet Diet Standbys: Cereals and Potatoes
description: A study by the Central Intelligence Agency on the Soviet economy showed that the average Soviet diet contains far more grains and potatoes than the American diet and far less fish and meat.

title: Primary Residency
description: Question: My wife and I are both foreigners. Since my retirement we keep two homes, one abroad and the other in New York. We travel on nonimmigrant visas and usually stay here about five to six months a year. Recently, for the third time since we moved into our apartment in 1976, we received a letter from the managing agent asking if our apartment is a primary residence. Since I don't have any other place in this country, I answered accordingly, signed the lease and sent it back. I was soon asked to include a check for $82.45 to bring the security deposit current with the new rent, which I did. Later I received a letter from the agent advising me that it had come to his attention that the apartment was not my primary residence and asking me to submit proof to substantiate it or I would be refused the renewal. Is it legal for the owner to offer an extension of that lease, claim and receive money for the future security deposit and still withhold the lease? ... Z.G., Manhattan Answer: The courts have ruled that an owner is entitled to refuse a renewal lease to a nonprimary tenant and he may do so at any time up to the point where the owner signs a renewal lease. It is up to the Conciliation and Appeals Board (10 Columbus Circle, New York, N.Y. 10019) to decide whether your apartment is a primary residence and whether the landlord has executed the lease and thus has to wait until the lease has expired.

title: No Headline
description: Connors and Lendl Will Meet in Final

title: PROGRAM BRINGS OUT THE BEST IN GIFTED DEAF TEEN-AGERS
description: OMAHA KAREN MALISZEWSKI is a tall, slender strawberry-blonde 13-year-old who excels in mathematics, spelling and art. Except for math, Karen's grades do not reflect the fact that she has been identified as gifted, with an I.Q. of 140.

title: Coping Without Santa Claus
description: I read with interest Delia Ephron's article ''Coping with Santa Claus'' (Dec. 12). A few years ago, I, too, stood by the mantel, as my husband signed a ''Santa Claus'' response to the challenging letter left by our daughter.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE GOVERNMENT WAS TO BLAME, IN PART
description: LAST weekend, President Reagan signed into law a measure allowing t extile companies and children's sleepwear manufacturers, d istributors and retailers to file claims in the United States Court o f Claims for losses they incurred from the 1977 ban on Tris, the c hemical flame retardant.

title: RED TAPE BLOCKS BAYSIDE STREET REPAIR
description: There is a stretch of Bell Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, that is a country-like road, a narrow street lined with graceful trees, comfortable homes and broad expanses of lawn. It is the kind of street that seems more suitable to a suburb than to one of the five boroughs.

title: 3 Texas Justices Charged With Racist Actions
description: The Texas Civil Liberties Union called Friday for the removal from office of three justices of the peace who refused to perform interracial marriages.

title: French Film Series
description: A six-day retrospective of films by the French director Jean-Pierre Melville begins on Jan. 17 at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

title: VIOLIN: HAMAO FUJIWARA
description: Violin playing of untroubled smoothness was heard in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night when Hamao Fujiwara offered a recital consisting of the Tartini-Kreisler Variations on a Corelli Theme, Brahms's Sonata in A (Op. 100, No. 2), Bach's Partita in D minor for unaccompanied violin and Szymanowski's ''Mythes'' and Notturno et Tarantella. The assisting pianist was Katsurako Mikami.

title: CITY BALLET: CONTRASTS
description: The New York City Ballet presented two very different sides of itself on Friday at the New York State Theater, when Jerome Robbins's ''Four Chamber Works'' and George Balanchine's early masterwork ''Serenade'' re-entered the season's repertory.

title: Miss Setlow Weds Philippe Sommer
description: Carolyn E. Setlow, daughter of Herbert D. Setlow of Woodbridge, Conn., and the late Claire R. Setlow, was married yesterday to Philippe L. Sommer, son of Mrs. Georges M. Sommer of New York and the late Mr. Sommer. Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: DETERRENT TO A REFUELING OF INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: John Crawford Samuelson to Marry Gail Korman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sinclair Korman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Korman, to John Crawford Samuelson, son of Paul A. Samuelson of Belmont, Mass., and the late Marion Crawford Samuelson. A May wedding is planned in Scarsdale.

title: A HAPPY EXHANGE AT HOSPICE
description: IN a home for the dying in Branford, there is the unexpected laughter of children who walk through the halls and into the rooms of patients and ask the typical questions of the young, such as ''What's that?''

title: JAPAN'S HARD LOOK AT SOFTWARE
description: TOKYO THE image of the kind of person best-suited for creating software - the electronic instructions that tell computers what to do - is hardly in the Japanese mold: the hirsute nonconformist, working alone, fiddling obsessively with his algorithms.

title: NEW MONEY FOR THE NEW ROCKEFELLERS
description: AS legend has it, John D. Rockefeller, who turned an oil monopoly i nto one of the first great American family fortunes, used to give a way shiny new dimes in the depths of the Depression to those he p assed on the street. Some of his heirs may now be wishing that the p atriarch were still around to toss a little spare change their way.

title: MINOR WORK OF A MAJOR WRITER
