description: CREATURES IN AN ALPHABET, By Djuna Barnes. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: The Dial Press. $10.95. SMOKE And Other Early Stories. By Djuna Barnes. Edited, with an introduction, by Douglas Messerli. Illustrated. 180 pp. College Park, Md.: Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.

title: CARLA BLEY'S JAZZ STYLE TAPS MANY ROOTS
description: For someone who has felt that she was ''lost'' both personally and musically until she was 30 years old, Carla Bley, who is now 45, has managed to find a very positive and secure musical identity. This apparently has been paralleled by a happy resolution of her personal identity, since she has been married for 16 years to Michael Mantler, a trumpet player who is closely involved in all her musical works.

title: SAUERKRAUT ADDS ZEST TO WINTER CASSEROLES
description: THROUGHOUT history, brining was one method used to extend the shelf life of the vegetable harvest, providing vegetables for the table during the winter months in cold climates. Sauerkraut is nothing more than cabbage that has been cured with salt (pickled or brined are other terms). It is said to have been invented by the Gauls and its popularity throughout northern Europe continues to this day.

title: Anne Davidson to Marry David Hardy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Wetmore Davidson Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Treat Davidson, to David Robert Hardy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hardy of Lenox, Mass.

title: HOW NUTRITION BECAME A LIFE STYLE
description: SEVEN years ago, Si Kamen had a healthy crush on a seemingly lethargic Betty Banoff. On the sixth day of their courtship, he brought her a surprise: a bottle of multicolored, huge and odorous vitamin pills.

title: CELEBRATING ROBERT BURNS
description: Every Jan. 25, many Scots abandon any pretense of being hardworking sobersides and become the joyous, wild revelers their Pictish forebears were reputed to be. For almost two centuries, the birthday of Robert Burns, the beloved plowman poet of Scotland, has been celebrated with the legendary ''Burns Supper'' - an evening of song, speeches, poetry and dancing that is notable as well for the amount of whisky (which Burns himself so appreciated) consumed. The suppers have even given birth to a new verb: ''Burnsed.''

title: The Libyans Next Door
description: Englewood, N.J. could certainly use the nearly $14,000 a year that the chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations offered last week, but the city fathers would rather take it in taxes than accept it as a gift.

title: HOW GUILTY WERE THE FELLOW TRAVELERS?
description: A BETTER WORLD The Great Schism: Stalinism and the American Intellectuals. By William L. O'Neill. Illustrated. 447 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: A National New Yorker
description: It is hard to grasp the force of the late Ben Rosenthal from his laconic account of himself in the Congressional Directory. He listed his New York education, law practice and family and his 10 reelections to the House.

title: MONDALE TO ANNOUNCE CANDIDACY
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale will formally announce his candidacy for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination in the week of Feb. 21 at St. Paul, the capital of Minnesota, his native state.

title: HOW TO MAKE ACADEMIC REFORMS WORK
description: WITH the continuing criticism of college athletics, it is time the chief executive officers of our universities step in and take control of their athletic programs. They must formulate an academic admission policy and insure that athletes are on a degree program that is in keeping with the student-athlete concept of collegiate athletics.

title: DEEP THROAT WAS ...
description: LOST HONOR By John W. Dean 3d. 370 pp. Los Angeles: Stratford Press. Distributed by Harper & Row. $15.95. By NICHOLAS HORROCK

title: GERMAN CATHOLICS DEBATE ATOM ARMS
description: The Roman Catholic Church in West Germany is being pulled, with misgivings and reluctance, into a national debate on nuclear weapons, a debate in which until recently Protestant voices have been the most audible.

title: REAGAN AND ANDROPOV
description: The Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union have at least one thing in common: they are so suspicious of one another that whatever one side proposes, the other tends to reject. And this negative reaction applies even to the suggestion that the leaders of the two countries should get together and talk over their differences.

title: G.M. and Auto Union Seek Food for Needy
description: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation announced Thursday that they would jointly administer a nationwide food collection and distribution drive to help the needy.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A NATIVE SON LOST: A HAPPY?SAD TALE OF ORDINARY PEOPLE
description: THIS is a short account about one of New Jersey's native sons. He is not famous, but he is well worth knowing. Keith was born in Newark about 50 years ago. His family - his parents, a grandmother and Keith, the only child - lived in an apartment in a rundown two-family building in a rundown black section of the city.

title: BOOKS TO STIMULATE THE MIND AND THE EYE
description: Discovering antiques is no fun without books. They plot the course, widen the expectations, focus the eye and seed the mind with questions. Good books are, however, as rare as a Sung vase that provokes a sensitive person to pause or an exuberantly carved chair that tempts a connoisseur to caress it.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: A year ago, the Northwest Connecticut Association for the Arts, which was formed in 1980 specifically to address the possibility of restoring the Warner Theater, a lavish, Art Deco movie palace in Torrington, had high hopes, but only enough money to pay the telephone bill of the group's president, Kaye McIntyre.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Edwardian Passions He is the perfect Edwardian gentleman: cultivated, well-mannered, immaculately dressed. He is also one of the most lecherous and deceitful of men.

title: Cynthia R. Farber Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Farber of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Rachelle Farber, to Philip Jay Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Davis of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for early spring. Miss Farber is on the nursing staff of Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, where Mr. Davis is an investment broker with Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc.

title: THEATER: 'BRIDEGROOM'
description: Eudora Welty's ''The Robber Bridegroom'' is a dreamy, sometimes gruesome fairy tale about loyalty, love and duty in Rodney, Miss. Alfred Uhry's adaptation of the novella set to Robert Waldman's version of rural music, attempts to be a tall tale and a farce of mistaken identity. It had two runs on Broadway, in 1975 and 1976. But now that country music seems less exotic on the stage, it comes across as a ramshackle property, resisting all the spirit and attention lavished on it in the Equity Library Theater's revival.

title: IMPACT OF FIGHT TO HALT DRUG FLOW CALLED NEGLIGIBLE
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to stem the flow of illegal drugs into the country are having little impact so far, in part because of interagency rivalries and the failure to prosecute arrested drug traffickers, an investigative arm of Congress reports.

title: Janet Speckert Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Speckert of Bay Harbor, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lynn Speckert, to Harvey Richard Kent, son of Ruth Kent of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Louis Kent. The wedding is planned for March 5.

title: Coast Airport Wanderer Is Given a Home
description: A youth who cannot speak and who has lived for most of the last two years at Los Angeles International Airport has been placed in the temporary custody of a former airport custodian who befriended him.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR the fourth year running, Adelphi University in Garden City will host Career Day, a series of career workshops designed to give Nassau County high school juniors and seniors a greater insight into today's job market.

title: TEXT OF O'NEILL INAUGURAL MESSAGE
description: Following is the text of Governor O'Neill's inaugural address last Wednesday before a joint session of the General Assembly:

title: PITTSBURGH HOMEOWNERS GIVEN A REPRIEVE IN RISING FLOOD OF FORECLOSURES
description: The language was stiff with authority. The source, the sheriff's office, could have seemed ominous. But in a modest brick home on Pittsburgh's outskirts, the message was the first good news in a long time.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Jolisa A.M. Caso Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Caso of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jolisa Ann Margaret Caso, to Donald Sagstetter, son of Mrs. Franz Sagstetter and the late Mr. Sagstetter of Seaford, L.I. The wedding is planned for August. The bride's father is a lawyer in Merrick and was the Nassau County Executive from 1971 to 1978.

title: Martha Somes Glover Will Wed Dennis W. Perry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Ebner Glover of Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Somes Glover, to Dennis W. Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Perry of Needham, Mass. An April 16 wedding is planned.

title: A FOOLISH FIDELITY
description: Some years ago, when the French Defense was undergoing one of its down periods (as will happen to any opening from time to time), the East German grandmaster Wolfgang Uhlmann was asked why he continued to play - and fail - with it. His quaint and simple reply was, ''Well, it's my favorite defense.''

title: NATO Chief Attacked For Comments on Finns
description: Pravda today attacked the NATO commander, Gen. Bernard Rogers, for criticizing Finland's military policies and accused him of trying to sour relations between Helsinki and Moscow.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: EVERY evening for the last few weeks, about 50 men and five women have lined up outside a construction trailer on Mulberry Street in Newark and waited for the doors to open.

title: Headliners; Getting an Earful
description: The Philippines may not be a bastion of liberty, but Filipinos shouldn't be punished further by denying them grand opera, says Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston. Human rights activists had criticized Miss Caldwell's decision to help estabish an opera company in Manila under an agreement with the Philippines' First Lady, Imelda R. Marcos. Amnesty International has accused the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of widespread human rights abuses. At a news conference last week, Miss Caldwell said that if artists denied their talents to every country accused of such violations, ''you would not be having much music in this world.''

title: DAY CARE FINDS A HOME ON CAMPUS
description: EVERY weekday from 9 to 5, 4-year-old Ian Claxton attends the Children's Center at the State University College of New York at Purchase while his mother, Drew, goes to classes, studies in the library or participates in campus activities as a full-time student.

title: Topics; UNSEASONABLE; No Time Out
description: How many Real Men does it take to change a light bulb? None, it is said: Real Men aren't afraid of the dark. Perhaps not, at least not if the TV stays on - and if football stays on the screen.

title: Children and Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: A POLISH POPE COMPOUNDS KREMLIN'S FEARS
description: The smoke from the Vatican roof that heralded the election of a Polish Pope in October 1978 can have brought no joy to the Kremlin. Seating the Archbishop of Cracow on the throne of St. Peter would be sure to arouse the pride of 35 million Poles, and to signal nothing good for Soviet dominion over Karol Wojtyla's homeland. That Soviet leaders would have preferred almost any other choice seems sure.

title: MANILA TO UPGRADE ITS FORCES
description: The Government announced this week that the Philippines was acquiring new patrol boats, planes and guns to help it meet its increased responsibilities over surrounding waters as a signer of the new Law of the Sea Treaty.

title: NEWARK GASOLINE TANK BLAST TIED TO POSSIBLE SPILL
description: The Newark Fire Director said yesterday that accidental ''spillage or overfilling'' might have caused Friday's explosion of three gasoline storage tanks at a Texaco facility in Port Newark that killed one worker, injured 24 other people and was heard up to 130 miles away.

title: LAKERS DOWN KNICKS, 108-90
description: It was well into the second quarter last night before the Los Angeles Lakers and Earvin (Magic) Johnson became creative and got their running game going. Once they did, the Lakers, after trailing by 14 points in the first quarter, took command and scored a 108-90 victory over the Knicks before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: AN OVERDOSE OF POWER AND MONEY
description: FORMATION OF AMERICAN MEDICINE, By Paul Starr. 514 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: THE KINDERGARTEN IS GOING FULL TIME
description: WHEN the 5-year-old goes off to kindergarten in the 1980's, he may b e clutching a blanket for his nap and a lunchbox for his noon meal a s well as his mother's hand. For nearly a third of kindergarten p upils now attend full-day sessions, and such a schedule appears to b e an emerging factor in primary education.

title: Wendy Tara Gingold Plans To Wed J.A. Lichtenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gingold of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Tara Gingold, to Jeffrey Alan Lichtenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lichtenberg of Woodsburgh, L.I.

title: Dr. Marion Preston To Wed Physician
description: Mrs. Charles Drury Preston of Lake Forest, Ill., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Marion Mason Preston, to Dr. Russell Nicholas Ake Cecil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cumming Cecil of Rye, N.Y.
To the Editor:

title: MOre on MX
description: After 10 years of acrimony over where best to stash the MX, can yet another study group do any better in a month and a half? Maybe not, Brent Scowcroft, chairman of the latest commission said at a press conference. ''Obviously the problem is very difficult,'' he said.

title: AN INSTANCE OF THE IMPOSSIBLE VS. THE IMPROBABLE
description: The 1983 World Team Championships for the Bermuda Bowl in Stockholm in October will follow a new pattern. During the 30-year history of the event, all the zones have been given equal treatment. Now, however, for the first time since 1958, when the original U.S.A.-Europe encounter was expanded, the World Bridge Federation has recognized the fact that some zones are more equal than others.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: YONKERS officials have announced their latest plan for developing the city's waterfront, at a cost of $11.5 million. If realized, it would see the creation of a handsome seafood restaurant, an office building and a shopping center close to downtown, all from existing and unused facilities. A scaled-down version of an original $166 million plan that officials said was found to be ''too much to chew,'' it is being called ''the first phase'' or ''Phase 1A'' of the city's waterfront plans.

title: ST. JOHN'S SETS BACK GEORGETOWN, 76-67
description: The memories were still there. Three times last season, St. John's lost one-sided games to Georgetown and Patrick Ewing, its 7-foot center, and the memories of those games followed the Redmen all the way back to Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: THE NEED: TEACHERS WHO CAN MAKE THEM THINK
description: "If you define the idea of teaching thinking as respecting, strengthening and enriching natural child development - well, a lot of teachers are trained to do that,'' according to David Weikart, president of High/ Scope Educational Research Foundation. ''But if you're talking about teaching teachers specific thinking skills, I suspect the numbers are very small.''

title: 'A STUDIO IN MY POCKET'
description: AT the age of 60, the Iranian-born painter Manoucher Yektai can look back on a career in which his art has been exhibited in galleries and museums in such cities as New York, Paris, Washington, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Detroit.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOW TO GET AN AIR FARE REFUND
description: With many air fares subject to dramatic change, the prudent traveler might keep two points in mind. First, if a fare is reduced after you have paid for your ticket but before you fly, you are usually entitled to a refund of the difference. Second, once your reservations are confirmed and the ticket purchased, you are usually protected against any increase in price before you go.

title:
LIBRARIES ON THE WAY TO UNIVERSITYHOOD;
CHICAGO
description: MOST library users here still just drop in, pick out the books they w ant, check them out and go home to read. But for hundreds of o thers, the library has become their school, their college, in some c ases even their center for advanced study.

title: Tripoli Deaths; Diplomatic Shots
description: The presence of thousands of Syrian occupation troops in northern Lebanon provoked Moslems to kill Moslems in Tripoli last week. Dozens of civilians were killed as pro-and anti-Syrian militiamen clashed and forces headed by Rifaat al-Assad, brother of Syria's President, were said to be digging in.

title: T. S. Carter Weds Miss Stringfellow
description: Margaret Stuart Burwell Stringfellow of Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hargrave Stringfellow of Greensboro, N.C., was married yesterday to Thomas Scott Carter, son of the Rev. Thomas Eugene Carter also of Richmond, and the late Mrs. Carter. The ceremony was performed at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Greensboro by the Rev. George Kloster, assisted by the bridegroom's father, who is minister of the South Roanoke United Methodist Church..

title: Russian Roulette, Global Style
description: Cosmos 1402, a Soviet radar satellite powered by 100 pounds of uranium, is apparently out of control and about to re-enter the atmosphere. For the second time in four years, the world awaits the radioactive debris from a failed Soviet space spy. One failure is bad luck, two is bad management.

title: NEW GOVERNOR IN CALIFORNIA FACES A FIRE-BREATHING DEFICIT
description: Timothy Cardinal Manning, Archbishop of Los Angeles, asked in his invocation at Governor George Deukmejian's inaugural Monday, ''May the legend of Saint George be fulfilled in his administration and all the dragons be vanquished.''

title: Smith Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan J. Linowes To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. David F. Linowes of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Champaign, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Joyce Linowes, to Jeffrey Guy Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Allen of Salem, Ore.

title: PEEKSKILL SCHOOLS GOING CONDOMINIUM
description: The Peekskill home of Henry Ward Beecher, the abolitionist preacher, and Stowe Cottage, named for Harriet Beecher Stowe, his sister, are being turned into moderate-priced condominiums. For 40 years up to 1977, the properties had been St. Peter's Boys' School.

title: DANCE OF THE WHIRLING DERVISHES
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Athens bureau of The New York Times.

title: A NEW LIFE UNDER THE SOLAR COLLECTORS
description: ON a warm, June day two young boys slowly pedaled their bicycles past the house. ''You know what this is?'' the bigger boy asked his friend, pointing to the roof.

title:
NEW JERSEY DINING OUT;
NEW NAME CAN SPELL A DIFFERENCE
description: IN ITS second reincarnation in five years, Via Veneto - formerly La Forchetta d'Oro and, before that, Cassese's - has been operating under its present name and with a new Milanese chef, Franco Motti, for just over a month. Judging from the meals we sampled during several visits and a full house even during the holiday lull, Via Veneto should be here to stay.

title: SIX-PACKERS, SPARE THOSE BOTTLES
description: WHAT is that old expression? Champagne taste and a beer pocketbook? I am here to tell you it is not so. Beer drinkers are the most extravagant (and inconsiderate) people of all.

title: Fred Strasser Marries Mary C. Hickey at U.N.
description: Mary C. Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Hickey of Queens Village, was married yesterday to Fred Strasser, son of Mrs. Roger J. Strasser of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Strasser.

title: A Friend of Spinks Killed in Auto Crash
description: The woman being dated recently by Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, was killed Friday in a two-car collision that left another driver in guarded condition, the Pennsylvania State Police said.

title: No Headline
description: 55 NOMINATING JURORS FOR PULITZER JOURNALISM PRIZES SELECTED

title: AS THE TALKS STALL, ISRAELI DOUBTS DEEPEN ON THE WAR
description: When Israelis talk about the war in Lebanon these days, they are not quite sure what tense to use. Was it, or is it still? The battles are over but the casualties continue to mount, slowly, inexorably. Scarcely a day passes now without a grenade, a mine, a shooting attack on Israeli troops, apparently by Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Lynne Kelnberger to Wed
description: Andrew M. Wallace in May Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Kelnberger of Larchmont, N.Y. and Stratton, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynne Ann Kelnberger, to Andrew Michael Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Wallace of New Rochelle, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Terry Burrell is a singer who seems to grow with every performance. When she made her first Broadway appearance in ''Eubie'' in Sept. 1978, this Trinidad-born singer had only a single song, ''Weary.''

title: NOW THE HARVEST OF A SEARCH FOR NEW BALLET CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ''As America's national company, it is the responsibility of American Ballet Theater to pave the way for the next generation of de Milles, Robbinses and Lorings. New choreographers are the lifeblood of dance.''

title: HAITIANS FACING UNCERTAIN LEGAL STATUS
description: HEMPSTEAD HE arrived from Haiti by boat, destination Miami. He came ''to make big money in New York.'' Finanically responsible for his mother, two adult sisters and three young children (progeny of a common-law marriage), he desires a better life for his extended family in Portau-Prince.

title: Miss Stone Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Margaret Ann Stone to Mark Kevin Bowen has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David M. Stone of Glencoe, Ill., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert W. Bowen of Kenilworth, Ill.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A 'SECOND OPINION' FOR A HOSPITAL
description: AN AMBULANCE had to take my husband to the hospital when a sudden infection and high fever on top of a chronic hip injury left him limp and unable to move. My husband, an active, energetic, successful businessman, has a particular horror of helplessness and dependency.

title: HOW THE JUILLIARD QUARTET SHARES ITS ARTISTRY
description: Most Mondays and Tuesdays, between 8:30 in the morning and about half past noon, the members of the Juilliard String Quartet occupy four separate classrooms at the music school their ensemble is named for, each of them listening to, encouraging and advising a succession of student quartets. Together they coach 24 such ensembles each academic year, plus several more during their annual residencies at Michigan State University.

title: A PRIVATE PRIVATE EYE
description: SUN DOGS By Robert Olen Butler. 218 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $12.95.

title: On Overcoming Asthma in Sports
description: To the Sports Editor: The ''Players'' column on Jeannette Bolden by Malcolm Moran (The New York Times, Dec. 21) beautifully captured the courage of this spirited young woman and her will to win, despite the handicap of asthma.

title: On Greenpoint
description: To the Editor:

title: ROOM AT THE TOP
description: In the belief that there are people in Smithtown, L.I., interested in moving up but not out of that community, Andrew Rafuse, a builder, has acquired the 25-acre Lawrence estate in the Village of the Branch for a 32-home development. The estate is the last large undeveloped tract near the center of the North Shore town.

title: Mary F. Maher to Be Wed To Mark S. Sauvigne in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Maher of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Frances Maher, to Mark S. Sauvigne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Sauvigne of Searingtown, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: MUSICAL REVUE Calling itself ''a musical revue with manners,'' ''Etiquette'' made its debut at La Mama in l979 and is currently enjoying a welldeserved revival with Sunday night performances at s.n.a.f.u., 6th Avenue and 21st Street. Directed by Playhouse of the Ridiculous cofounder, John Vaccaro, with a book by William M. Hoffman and music and lyrics by John Braden, this spoof of a l940's Hollywood idea of high society is a superior musical frolic in the ridiculous theatrical mode.

title: OUTDOORS
description: WITH few exceptions, a fish properly prepared for the table is the culmination of the angling endeavor. It is also true that fish are abused in many kitchens, the most common sin being overcooking. One way to cope with both fresh andsaltwater species is to obtain A.J. McLane's ''North American Fish Cookery.'' Illustrated with stunning photographs by Arie deZanger, this is an excellent companion work to a much-acclaimed former effort by the same two, ''Encyclopedia of Fish Cookery.'' Both are published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston.

title: Mary M. Donegan to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Donegan of Alpine, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Michelle Donegan, to Cadet Douglas J. Quinlan of the United States Military Academy, son of Lieut. Col. Edward M. Quinlan, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Quinlan of Omaha. A May 29 wedding is planned. Miss Donegan, a registered nurse, works in the intensive-care unit of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CONTRACT AWARDED FOR OLYMPIC COIN PACKAGES
description: Few coin collectors have heard of Design Pak Incorporated, a Massachusetts company that designs and manufactures packages. However, many own items produced by that firm because Design Pak has provided packaging for many important numismatic programs in recent years.

title: NEW CHIEF OF BLINDNESS SOCIETY
description: Lisa Semple, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund since 1975, has been named executive director of the National Society to Prevent Blindness, the society announced.

title: U.S. Is Ruled Liable In Swine Flu Inoculation
description: Federal District Judge Barbara Rothstein has ruled that the Government's administration of the 1976 swine flu vaccination program was negligent and that an engineer and his wife can claim damages as a result of problems that he suffered from an inoculation.

title: STAHR, SCHOOL STAR, TAKES MILE IN 4:14:7
description: Mike Stahr of Carmel, N.Y., led from start to finish today in the one-mile schoolboy run at the Dartmouth Relays and won in 4 minutes 14.7 seconds, his fastest time so far in this indoor season.

title: Desaulniers Is Upset
description: Top-seeded Michael Desaulniers of New York was upset by Mario Sanchez, also of New York, in the quarterfinals at the World Professional squash racquets championship today, 18-17, 17-16, 15,12.

title: CONTRACTORS CITY WORKERS ARE WHITE'S BIGGEST FANS
description: Here as elsewhere, election campaigns involve politicians pursuing money and spending in pursuit of votes. But strange as it might seem in a city so consumed by politics, campaign contributions and the public somehow have diverged.

title: STRATEGY FOR THE CAMPUS INTERVIEW...
description: FOR the student choosing or seeking acceptance at a college, a visit to the campus and an interview with an admissions officer are important, though often terrifying. The student has to make a positive impression, and to do this he is tempted to become some imaginary ''perfect candidate'' in response to what he guesses the interviewer seeks. But he also must evaluate the institution he visits in order to compare it with his needs and expectations before he commits thousands of dollars.

title: Pasternak Makes 'Approved' List
description: ''In the Great Soviet,'' Boris Pasternak once said, ''the job of the poet is useless or vacant.'' Cracks like that and his novel, ''Dr. Zhivago'' -about an apolitical physician-poet preoccupied by love and religion -brought an avalanche of calumny down on one of Russia's greatest modern writers.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE FALSE DOCTRINES OF PRODUCTIVITY
description: AMERICA'S poor productivity record over the last decade has increasingly been attributed to an alleged failure of industrial corporations to invest for the long term. Searching for explanations of this supposedly myopic investment behavior, a number of influential pundits, most notably several members of the Harvard Business School faculty, have argued that the problem stems from industry's obsession with short-term results and its reliance on capital planning techniques biased against long-term investments.

title: Danes Cast About For Better Deal
description: Kent Kirk, a Danish fisherman and member of the European Parliament, loaded his trawler with aquavit, beer and 12 reporters last week. Then, while they sipped and noted, he cast his nets in Britain's 12-mile coastal waters in search of sprat, a tasty small herring-like fish.

title: C.I.A. SAYS SOVIET CAN ALMOST DO WITHOUT IMPORTS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, in a study of the Soviet economy, concludes that the Soviet Union's ability to live without imports is much greater than that of most, possibly all, other industrialized economies.

title: The Judge Eases Boston School Controls
description: For the past eight years, the hickory stick in Boston schools has been wielded by a Federal judge. After W. Arthur Garrity Jr. ordered the system desegregated in 1974, he came to control almost every aspect of school administration.

title: Polish Unions: Nothing Doing
description: Poland last week conceded that its new tame trade unions were off to a slow start. Big plants such as the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk and the Huta Warszawa steel plant in the capital have had trouble attracting even a few hundred prospective members.

title: DESERT OUTPOST RETAINS INDIA'S ARTISTIC GLORY
description: RAHUL SINGH is the editor of Reader's Digest in Bombay.

title: ISLANDERS ROUT NORDIQUES FOR 2D STRAIGHT
description: Ordinarily, a winning streak of two games would not be much cause for celebration, especially among players who have won their league's championship for three straight seasons.

title: ON THE SLIPPERY SLOPES OF SUMMITRY
description: Ronald Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov are caught up in a diplomatic minuet that seems inevitably to be leading to a Soviet-American summit sometime in the next two years. Every American President since Franklin D. Roosevelt has had one or more meetings with a Soviet leader and there is no reason to suppose that Mr. Reagan will be any different.

title: JILL LESLIE JELENKO TO MARRY FRANK CAPRIO, PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Frederick Jelenko Jr. of Golf Village, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Leslie Jelenko, to Frank B. Caprio of Beverly Hills, California, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank S. Caprio of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: BLACKS AND CORPORATE STRESS
description: My research on blacks in corporations generally, and at Xerox in particular, indicates that much stress is self-imposed. During the mid-1970's when significant effort, time and financial resources were expended to hire black (and other ''defined'' minorities) into the sales ranks, blacks, instead of attempting to ''fit'' into the fabric of corporate society, imposed self-segregation.

title: Winterlude In Canada
description: The affliction: Winter blahs. The prescription: Winterlude. About five years ago, some of the citizens of Ottawa put their heads together and came up with an assortment of festivities designed to take the sting out of February in the Canadian capital.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Cap the Entitlement

title: U.S. Juniors Win, 2-1
description: The United States defeated the Soviet Union, 2-1, today in the third international Granatkin junior soccer tournament at Leningrad, Tass, the official news agency, reported. Lane Kenworthy and George Gelnovatch scored for the Americans and Sergei Savchenko scored for the Soviet team. In another game, France defeated West Germany, 5-2.

title: WIDE IMPACT SEEN IN CHANGES PUT INTO EFFECT BY LEGISLATURE IN SUFFOLK
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature, in the span of a few days, has made changes in its leadership on both sides of the aisle and in its rules that are significant not only for the present but also for the future, Republican and Democratic legislators agreed last week.

title: CONCERT: CHICK COREA AND CHAMBER MUSIC GROUP
description: Popular musicians and those who, for lack of a more precise term, go under the name ''classical'' frequently eye one another across the fence that separates them and wonder how it got erected and why. During the most fertile periods in Western music's history, we know, the two traditions interbred constantly and comfortably. No doubt such a time will come again, probably so gradually that few people will recognize what is happening. The urge to merge is much too strong in this world to be kept in check indefinitely, even in the fine and lively arts. What we cannot know, however, is just how close music may be right now to such a seminal time.

title: ROCK: HELM-DANKO REUNION
description: The reunion of Levon Helm and Rick Danko in an acoustic set at the Ritz on Thursday poignantly reminded one of the greatness of The Band, the ensemble in which the two played. At its best, The Band evoked in a rock instrumental format an idealized vision of the American frontier by illustrating the deep interconnectedness of American roots styles.

title: COSTA RICA'S WARM WELCOME
description: JUNE BLUM is an American writer who lives in Costa Rica.

title: THE LOUVRE: PALACE OF MASTERWORKS
description: MICHAEL BRENSON is the art news reporter of The New York Times.

title: I MARRIED ADVENTURE (IN THE SCHOOLS)
description: IRECENTLY took a poll of the four kindergarten teachers in my husband's current school district and have confirmed a suspicion I have entertained for almost 34 years: not one of these lovely women has ever had a kindergarten pupil stand up in Show and Tell and announce, ''When I grow up I want to marry a public-school superintendent.'' (Or, for that matter, be one.)

title: 17 FOOD OUTLETS LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, the department also named four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and one that was closed for failing to do so.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:05 P.M. Kelly Tripucka, the Pistons' leading scorer, is traveling with the club but is hurt and not expected to play. The Nets were 4-2 against Detroit last season, but the Pistons won their only meeting this season, 102-97. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WVNJ 620, 7 P.M.) Bucks vs. Phoenix Suns, at Milwaukee (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.) Trail Blazers vs. Seattle SuperSonics, at Portland, Ore. (Television - ESPN 10:30 P.M.) College: Western Kentucky at North Carolina-Charlotte (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.); Wagner at Holy Cross, 3 P.M. Football Jets vs. Bengals, at Cincinnati, American Football Conference playoff game (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 3:30 P.M.) Dallas Cowboys vs. Tampa Bay Buccaneers, at Irving, Tex., National Football Conference playoff game (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 3:30 P.M.) Steelers vs. San Diego Chargers, at Pittsburgh, A.F.C. playoff game, 12:30 P.M. Minnesota Vikings vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Minneapolis, N.F.C. playoff game, 4 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Devils, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. This is the second of the Devils' four visits to the Garden this season. In the first, Ed Mio recorded the Rangers' only home shutout of the season, a 4-0 victory on Dec. 12. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M.; tape at 1 A.M. Radio - WNEW 1130 and WVNJ-FM 100.3, 7:30 P.M.) Flyers vs.

title: THIRD OF CITY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ATTEND CLASS TOO SELDOM TO LEARN
description: More than a third of the students in New York City high schools are chronically absent and miss so much class time that it is nearly impossible to teach them, according to the Board of Education.

title: CONCERT: CHILE'S TRIO ARTE
description: Once in a while, those of us accustomed to experiencing chamber music in concert halls are given the chance to follow the medium to its natural habitat. This was half the pleasure of hearing Chile's Trio Arte play Friday evening in the upstairs salon of the Center for Inter-American Relations on Park Avenue.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE FRAME
description: As Russell Baker began to develop his point that the Government has been telling the public they don't know enough about the freeze to have an opinion, and should leave the matter to ''experts,'' I started asking myself, ''Where have I heard this before?'' I remembered.

title: RESEARCH: PLAGIARY IS ONLY ONE PROBLEM
description: PLAGIARISM'S ghost is never lightly exorcised. The cases of Gabrielle Napolitano, whose degree from Princeton was w ithheld last spring because a Spanish paper she turned in was l argely plagiarized, and of Ronald Lewis, who was almost New Jersey'sE ducation Commissioner until his plagiarized dissertation came to l ight, are only the latest threads in an old and troubling fabric. T hey join the handful of public plagiarisms like that of Vijay Soman,t he Yale doctor who claimed in 1979 that another person's studies in i nsulin binding were his own, or that of Dr. John Long, a pathologista t Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston who in the same year s imply fabricated evidence to prove his points about cancer i mmunology, and unnumbered incidents in every school that raise deep q uestions about college papers generally.

title: FROM THE POETS IN THE KITCHEN
description: SOME years ago, when I was teaching a graduate seminar in fiction at Columbia University, a well-known male novelist visited my class to speak on his development as a writer. In discussing his formative years, he didn't realize it but he seriously endangered his life by remarking that women writers are luckier than those of his sex because they usually spend so much time as children around their mothers and their mothers' friends in the kitchen.

title: RECITAL: STEVEN MASI, PIANO
description: Steven Masi's New York debut at the Abraham Goodman House on Thursday night left little doubt that he is a pianist of gifts. But the overall impression was somewhat unsatisfying. Mr. Masi's pianism is marked by a solid technique, a sparing use of the sustain pedal, a polished tone - and rhythmic articulation so forthright and deliberate that musical fluidity is often lost.

title: Corporate Future
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the last two paragraphs of an Opinion Page article last Sunday were inadvertently omitted.

title: IF EXTRATERRESTRIALS DO EXIST: NOT TO WORRY
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Creeping Unemployment

title: No Headline
description: BRITAIN'S LEADER VISITS FALKLANDS

title: MIami May Find Obvious Answers
description: In Miami last week it was again time to brush aside the riot rubble and start parceling out the blame. The violence after Christmas in the Overtown area, near downtown Miami, Police Chief Kenneth Harms said, was the work of ''200 to 250 hoodlums.''

title: BUSES TO MANHATTAN: AN EXPRESS SUCCESS
description: POUND RIDGE HERBERT ZELTNER, a marketing and advertising consultant who commutes to 42d Street in Manhattan by bus from northern Westchester, says his only problem with the commuting service is its popularity.

title:
GARDENING;
AVERTING PLANT DAMAGE BY SALT AND SNOW
description: UNLIKE other sections of the country, we have been fortunate in not having had to contend with severe blizzards and ice storms so far this winter. However, the inevitable is certain to happen sooner or later, and we, too, will be faced with digging out from beneath a mantle of white snow.

title: CRIME
description: Michael Jahn, who won an Edgar in 1977 for the best paperback original (''The Quark Maneuver''), has not written many mystery novels since then, and reading NIGHT RITUALS (Norton, $12.95) allows us to see what we have been missing. This New York procedural, involving Lt. Bill Donovan of the West Side Major Crimes Unit, is about the random murder of women in Riverside Park - the hardest kind of crime to solve. There is no motivation, no thread. But since one of the women is the sister of the lieutenant's girlfriend, the solution becomes a very personal quest for him.

title: SLOW TIME FOR SUBSIDIZED HOUSING
description: FOR Clara Fox, who retired as executive director of the Settlement H ousing Fund Jan. 1, and Carol Lamberg, who is replacing her, it is n ot a happy time for subsidized housing.

title: GOODYEAR-STAYING ON TOP
description: year-old symbol, but its success. While the rest of the tire industry has been flattened by Detroit's slump and by stiff foreign competition, Goodyear has been riding as high as its famous symbol.

title: DANCE THE NIGHT AWAY
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. What's in a Name? Jan. 15 - More than 500 supporters of the Madison Square Boys' Club, many of them 25-to-35-year-olds, will attend the club's second annual Scholarship Ball scheduled for 9 P.M. at Astor Hall, the main lobby of the New York Public Library. The 1982 edition attracted 600, lasted until 3 A.M. and resulted in financial aid for students at such prominent preparatory schools and colleges as Choate Rosemary Hall and Smith. One of the older partygoers will be Bruce S. Gelb, chairman of the club and executive vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, which is helping to underwrite a blacktie event that will include light hors d'oeuvres, music for dancing and a cash bar. Despite its name the club has for 12 years included girls in the programs it offers at three clubhouses. Ball tickets: $35 each, $60 a couple.

title: State Elections Chip Away at Gandhi Base
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's hold on Indian politics appeared badly shaken last week after voters in three states elected opposition-party governments and strengthened the drive to local autonomy against her centralizing rule.

title: NEW YORK STATE'S ROAD TO RECOVERY IS UPHILL
description: STATE of the State messages give New York governors a chance to throw some ideas on the table before the Legislature throws them out, or so it seemed under Gov. Hugh L. Carey. Last week was Governor Cuomo's turn, and while he acknowledged that cash was limited, his ambitions clearly weren't. The Governor spoke of repairing roads, rails and ports, building new water supply systems and housing, and new aid programs for the homeless and the jobless. To help pay for all this, he called for $7 billion in new bonds and additional billions in public and private investment, though he also warned that sacrifices lay ahead. ''God - and Washington - will help those who help themselves,'' he said. With Albany facing its biggest budget deficits ever, Mr. Cuomo's financing proposals may have struck some as mortgaging the state's future. Others perhaps wondered why, while promising to reorganize a bloated bureaucracy to reduce waste, he proposed about a dozen new councils, committees, funds, offices, commissions, authorities and boards - not to mention an expanded Urban Development Corporation, a restructured Public Service Commission and, possibly, a dismembered Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But Mr. Cuomo was careful to credit lawmakers for many of the programs and they generally returned the praise. Last week The Week in Review asked seven New York Times reporters to assess the state of the state. Their reports follow. Economy: Facing Record Deficits By Josh Barbanel

title: PARIS WAS ALL THE WORLD TO MANET; WASHINGTON ''Manet and Modern Paris'' at the National Gallery of Art may or may not be a great exhibition, but it has a terrific title. Those four words made this particular visitor want to dance around the block like Gene Kelly in ''Singin' in the Rain,'' so vividly did they summon up the time when Manet was opening a whole slew of new options for painting and Paris was being torn apart and rebuilt in roughly the shape that we know today.
description: Manet would have liked that title, too. He was a true Parisian. He was born there, he was raised there, he went to a very good school there, he learned to think there and he never really wanted to be anywhere else. When he was in art school there was a famous male model who took a pride in the histrionic poses that showed off his musculature. Manet wouldn't have any of them. ''But, sir,'' said the model, ''my poses have helped more than one student to win first prize and get sent to Rome.'' ''But we are not in Rome,'' said Manet, ''and we don't want to be in Rome. We are in Paris. I for one intend to stay here.''

title: THE RIGHT PRICE FOR SHOPPERS
description: STAMFORD THE new Town Center shopping mall here currently offers shoppers few dining options, though more are to come this year. One restaurant that is open and flourishing is The Baker's Garden. This name seems appropriate because baking is done on the premises and croissants and other baked goods are sold from a window next to the entrance.

title: Third World Nations Expected to Assail U.S.
description: Members of the group of nations professing nonalignment are expected to approve a communique next week accusing the Reagan Administration of ''carrying out a hostile policy'' toward Nicaragua, Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman says.

title: Lorraine S. Shook Engaged to Dr. L.D. Berkowitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shook of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorraine Susan Shook, to Dr. Lloyd Douglas Berkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Berkowitz of Commack, L.I. The wedding is planned for March 5.

title: LATVIAN CARDINAL SURPRISE TO SOVIET
description: A spokesman for the Soviet organization that oversees church affairs says there was no prior contact with the Vatican about the elevation to cardinal of Archbishop Julijans Vaivods of Latvia.

title: Look Back In Anger
description: The distance of 40 years is apparently not enough to permit scrutiny of a painful subject: Could thousands of European Jews have been saved from the Holocaust if American Jewish organizations had campaigned for easing the restrictions on immigration for those fleeing Hitler? A private commission set up 15 months ago to find an answer has disintegrated with rancor on all sides.

title: BISHOPS, NUCLEAR ARMS AND THE HOLOCAUST
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILOSOPHY AT THE GRADE-SCHOOL LEVEL...
description: LYNBROOK, L.I. IN Sandra Candelaria's class the other day, the opening topic was the right to privacy. But by the time the bell rang 40 minutes later, her pupils had also delved into confidentiality, honesty, priests, doctors, the right to die and Russian dissidents.

title: Lisa Abby Raskin And Russell Janis Of Amherst Wed
description: Lisa Abby Raskin and Russell Andrew Janis, assistant professors at Amherst College, were married in Holyoke, Mass., last night. Rabbi Daniel Pernick, assisted by Cantor Sheri Blum, performed the ceremony at the Yankee Pedlar Inn.

title:
GARDENING;
AVERTING PLANT DAMAGE BY SALT AND SNOW
description: UNLIKE other sections of the country, we have been fortunate in not having had to contend with severe blizzards and ice storms so far this winter. However, the inevitable is certain to happen sooner or later, and we, too, will be faced with digging out from beneath a mantle of white snow.

title: TELEVISION THAT MAKES THEM THINK
description: YEAR-OLD Herbert Yancey is something of a blockbuster in Mariadele Musiala's fifth-grade classroom at the Charles P. Caldwell School in this city's South Side. He contends that what he likes to think about most is ''blockbusting,'' a term he defines as ''looking for the simplest solution to a complex problem.''

title: Cuomo Picks One of Theirs For the Bench
description: A Justice delayed, Governor Cuomo apparently concluded last week, also is justice denied. So in his first appointment since taking office, he named Richard D. Simons to New York's highest judicial body, the Court of Appeals.

title: Reds-Braves on April 4 Opens Baseball Season
description: The opening of the major league baseball season is only 85 days away. The Cincinnati Reds will have the honor of being the host team for the opening game of the 108th National League season, in a game against the West Division champion Atlanta Braves on April 4.

title: Understanding East and West
description: Having recently returned from a year in Japan, where I was a student at a Japanese university and my daughter a student at a Japanese elementary school, I was pleased to read Arthur Golden's article ''Group Think in Japan Inc.'' (Dec. 5). He makes a point that needs to be made.

title: ST. PETER'S DEFEATS MANHATTAN BY 45-39
description: St. Peter's made only three of 19 shots in the second half, but defeated Manhattan, 45-39, yesterday at Madison Square Garden. ''When the other team is three for 19, you should win,'' said Gordon Chiesa, Manhattan's coach, ''but it was a total breakdown of our offense.''

title: SOCIAL EXPERIMENT: NO VERDICT YET
description: CLARK WHEN a spokesman for the state's Department of Labor runs through a list of factory closings in New Jersey, he mentions the General Motors Corporation's former roller-bearing factory in this Union County community. And then he adds quickly that the plant opened again as soon as it was closed in October 1981 because employees bought it.

title: Fashion By Tonne Goodman
description: SWIMSUITS THAT ARE ALL 'WET'

title: HOTEL FAMILY GETS A COURT REPRIEVE
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE Malamut family, for many years leaders of the gambling-casino movement here, has received a last-minute court reprieve postponing a sheriff's sale of the Shelburne Hotel.

title: CUTTING PRICE NOT PROFIT
description: Despite the efforts of some retailers, trying to stop the discounting of clothing brands is proving to be as difficult as trying to stop a runaway locomotive by standing on the tracks. Discounting became a nationwide addiction and retailing's most striking characteristic in 1982, and many industry experts believe that it will accelerate in 1983.

title: FRUSTRATION IN THE RANKS HEIGHTENS SALVADOR'S MILITARY TROUBLES
description: As if it didn't have enough problems, the Salvadoran military last week faced a self-proclaimed ''rebellion'' by one of its most highly regarded commanders. The incident underscored the factionalism that has made it increasingly difficult for the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, to keep both the anti-guerrilla war and the political wrangling of his subordinates under control.

title: SECURITY GATES RATTLE HUNTINGTON
description: HUNTINGTON BURGLARY is a violation that you don't take seriously until it happens to you, and then you'd do anything to prevent it from happening again, said a Huntington Village restaurant owner, explaining why he had installed a metal security gate over the entryway.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY RISES? BRACE YOURSELF
description: NEW rules that will significantly lift 1983 Social Security contributions of millions of wage-earners went into e ffect last week, but the increases are mild compared with what may b e in store for workers - particularly those who are self-employed - o ver the next several years.

title: NEW DISKS STATE THE CASE FOR ZEMLINSKY
description: Many worthy 20th-century European composers are still grievously underrated on this side of the Atlantic. Names such as Franz Schmidt, Othmar Schoeck and Hans Pfitzner may be all but unknown to the average American concertgoer, although each of these men produced stirring music. It is doubtful that such neglect will soon be rectified, as posthumous revivals and re-evaluations are rare indeed - barring the case of Gustav Mahler and a Bach or two.

title: RANGERS, HANLON HOLD OFF DEVILS, 4-3
description: For his debut last night as the Rangers' newest goaltender, Glen Hanlon put on the predominantly blue socks with red and white trim that the Rangers wear for road games. ''One of the trainers looked at me and said, 'I don't know if you noticed, but we're playing at home tonight,' but I just pulled on my pads and hurried out on the ice,'' said Hanlon.

title: CITY BALLET: DANCERS IN NEW ROLES
description: TWO leading dancers of the New York City Ballet were featured in unfamiliar roles at the company's Saturday performances at the New York State Theater.

title: PERILS PRESENTED BY OUTSIDE INCOME
description: With seven children, three of whom are in college, and homes both here and in Utah, Senator Jake Garn says that he simply cannot live on his Senate salary of $60,662. Mr. Garn received an additional $48,000 in honorariums for speeches and writings in 1981, more than any other Senator, and he says that the extra income made it possible for him to remain in the Senate.

title: PRISON TRACES ITS HISTORY BACK TO 1825
description: In 1825, 150 convicts were shipped down the Hudson River by barge from Auburn Prison to the community of Sing Sing, a name borrowed from a local Indian tribe.

title: BRIGHTER OUTLOOK FOR PHILLIPS
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, the nation's 10th-largest energy concern, has seen its oil reserves shrink steadily. Unable to stem this decline through domestic drilling, the company invested heavily in the 1970's in oil exploration in the North Sea, off the coast of West Africa and in other regions abroad.

title: SITE UNSEEN
description: In the vocabulary of arms negotiations, the one phrase that both sides agree is taboo is ''on-site inspection.'' The reason the Soviets have expunged the phrase is that they have always opposed any suggestion to allow foreigners to come and inspect their weaponry. Such intrusions, they have unreasonably insisted for a generation, would merely be attempts to spy on the Soviet system.

title: 5 CANADIAN LOAN UNITS ARE SEIZED
description: Federal and provincial authorities have taken control of more than $2 billion (Canadian) of assets in three trust companies and two mortgage companies in a surprise move to protect depositors' interests.

title: Let the Crime Bill Die
description: An anti-crime package left for President Reagan by the last Congress will die unless he signs it before Friday. It contains some good provisions -heavily outweighed by bad ones. The bill deserves a peaceful death.

title: No Headline
description: FLYERS TROUNCE WHALERS FOR 9TH STRAIGHT

title: TRADITIONS OF HALF A CENTURY CONTINUED IN GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: Contributions that carry on a family tradition of giving are a major source of support for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, with some donors or their families loyally preserving a practice going back half a century or longer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Thrills in the Chill

title: IRAQI VISITS IRANIAN LEFTIST IN PARIS
description: The Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq and the exiled leader of an Iranian leftist group met for four hours today and said afterward that the war between their countries should be brought to an end.

title: China Seeking Asia Bank Seat
description: China has told the United States that it wants to displace Taiwan in the Asian Development Bank, a move that could add new strains to the Washington-Taipei relationship and create funding problems for the 45-nation institution in Congress.

title: Ailing Conductor Replaced
description: Henry Lewis has replaced Jesus Lopez-Cobos, the Spanish conductor, in tonight's concert performance of Rossini's opera ''Semiramide'' at Carnegie Hall, with Montserrat Caballe. Mr. Lopez-Cobos has a bronchial infection.

title: The Main Man
description: Although the Cleveland Cavaliers won only two of their first 10 games since they aquired World B. Free from the Golden State Warriors on Dec. 15, the free-spirited, offensive-minded guard was not discouraged last week.

title: Arsenic and Old Napoleon
description: History is the art of inferring what happened in the past. The historian's witnesses are all dead; what he must work with is the incomplete written record, in which the gaps may be more truthful than the documents left behind. But this subtle art is now threatened with confusion.

title: Tearful Islanders Mob Mrs. Thatcher on Visit
description: Hundreds of tearful islanders cheered and mobbed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today on the first full day of her surprise tour of this South Atlantic colony.

title: 7 Seized in Brawl; 3 L.I. Officers Hurt
description: Seven men, including three brothers, were arrested on riot charges today after a brawl between the Suffolk County police and two dozen guests at a bachelor party outside a Medford bar.

title: Market Place; Evaluating Steel Stocks
description: FOR investors with patience and a desire to minimize down-side risk, now may be the time to consider steel stocks. In the last few months, a number of events have led some analysts and institutional buyers to view more optimistically the outlook for steel producers, which have seen demand slump dramatically in the past few years. Indeed, part of the reason for the increased attention is the conclusion that conditions in the industry can't get much worse.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS WON'T PROSECUTE IN SCHUMER CASE
description: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, on Federal charges in connection with his 1980 campaign for the House, according to senior law-enforcement officials.

title: Advertising; Us Delays Plans to Go Weekly
description: LAST July Michael J. Boylan, executive vice president of Us magazine, promised a group of advertising types at a luncheon in the St. Regis that the magazine would double its publishing frequency to weekly in September and greatly increase its advertising income.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE NATION; Woman Dies as Propeller Rips Plane in Minnesota

title: MAURICE HUTCHESON, 85, LED CARPENTERS' UNION 2 DECADES
description: Maurice A. Hutcheson, the president of the 800,000-member carpenters' union for 20 years until his retirement in 1972, died yesterday in Lakeland, Fla. He was 85 years old and had retired to Florida after living for many years in Milan, Ind.

title: Mesa Leader Gains, Despite a Rebuff
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., founder and chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, was rebuffed last Friday -the second time in a year - in an attempt to acquire a major oil company, but nevertheless he has come out again with a handsome profit.

title: MUSIC: GREGG SMITHS
description: THE Gregg Smith Singers, through various incarnations under the direction of Gregg Smith, has been one of the most significant choral groups on the musical scene, associated both with performances of new works and scrupulous renditions of old.

title: OUTDOORS: FISHING HOLIDAY ON ICE
description: FOR those who can deal with the cold and overcome the perfectly reasonable notion that angling in the Northeast is over shortly before the first snow falls, ice fishing is a marvelous way to escape television's enervating embrace.

title: JUDGE EXTENDS RECEIVERSHIP OF TEAMSTERS' AGENCY
description: A Federal district judge has extended until Jan. 18 an order putting a receiver in control of the Chicago insurance agency that has processed teamsters' union health insurance claims for 32 years.

title: DR. HERSCHEL WEBB
description: Dr. Herschel Webb, professor of Japanese history and culture at Columbia University, died Saturday, apparently of a stroke, at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: COMPUTERS BENEFIT INSURANCE AGENTS
description: Tom Reardon, an independent insurance agent in Oyster Bay, L.I., communicates these days with the Travelers Corporation, one of the insurance companies he represents, by computer. ''With the computer,'' he said, ''we can issue auto policies the day after the person comes in, we can send messages to the company and we can give instantaneous quoting.''

title: Tremors in Yemen's North
description: Earth tremors shook Yemen's northern province of Sada last night but caused only minor damage, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today from Sana, the Yemeni capital. The Red Sea country has been jolted by earth tremors intermittently since Dec. 13, when an earthquake in Dhamar Province in the southeast killed some 3,000 people and left almost 400,000 homeless.

title: Laxalt Says Fiscal Cuts Must Include Military
description: Senator Paul Laxalt, one of President Reagan's closest informal advisers, said today that reductions in the new Federal budget must include military spending cuts or the national deficit would reach an ''intolerable'' level.

title: ALLIES PRIVATELY UNSURE OF BLOC'S OFFER
description: The Western European allies have reacted with public expressions of interest to the Warsaw Pact's call for an East-West nonaggression treaty, but in private the proposal is often described as another Soviet effort to hinder the possible deployment of new NATO nuclear missiles at the end of the year.

title: CITY TRAFFIC: MORE 'CURES FOR CAR CHOKING'
description: To the Editor:

title: BANKERS TO DISCUSS WORLD DEBT
description: In an effort to keep the international debt crisis from worsening, representatives of 35 major Western and Japanese banks will open two days of talks Monday in Washington to study the possibility of forming a new organization to better coordinate lending to developing countries.

title: CITY TRAFFIC: MORE 'CURES FOR CAR CHOKING'
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO ASSUMES A KEY ROLE IN THE OSSINING PRISON CRISIS
description: Minutes after the inmate takeover of a wing of the Ossining Correctional Facility, Governor Cuomo assumed a principal role in directing the state's effort to restore order at the prison, aides to Mr. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: REBUFFING THE CRITICS
description: George Vecsey

title: Foley and Seaman Named to Hall of Fame
description: Paul Foley and Alfred J. Seaman, a pair of seasoned pros who rose from the ranks of agency copywriters to become heads of two of the largest companies in the business, have both been voted into the American Advertising Federation's Advertising Hall of Fame.

title: JUGGLED DEFENSE DOES JOB
description: The Jets had practiced doing strange things all week: playing with two defensive linemen and using linebackers in various zones, or utilizing half a dozen defensive backs at the same time.

title: Letter: On Auto 'Accidents'; Get Tough With Drunk Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: APPEALS COURT REBUKES C.I.A. IN JONESTOWN INFORMATION CASE
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals has ruled that the Central Intelligence Agency acted improperly when it failed to respond promptly and fully to a journalist's request for information about the suicides and murders four years ago in Jonestown, Guyana.

title: MCNEIL RUNS FOR 211
description: The Jets, who had waited 14 years to win a postseason game, confused the Bengals defensively and overpowered them offensively today for a 44-17 victory in the first round of the Super Bowl XVII tournament.

title: MUSIC: FROM THE BAROQUE
description: IMAGINATIVE programs in our concert halls are rare enough, but imaginative program notes are still rarer; without notes, even the music can suffer. This was the case in Merkin Hall on Sunday afternoon, when the Clarion Music Society presented the first modern performances of a 1620 masque and of Alessandro Scarlatti's pastoral cantata ''Diana ed Endimione.''

title: ISLANDERS CHASING OLD STYLE
description: AT their best, the New York Islanders play an arrogant, authoritative brand of hockey, infused with so much positive energy that their National Hockey League opponents dread them.

title: TENSION IS SAID TO GROW IN STATE'S PACKED PRISONS
description: ''It's dangerous,'' Thomas A. Coughlin 3d said of the state's prison system, soon after becoming Correction Commissioner in 1979. ''We could have a minor incident blow up into a major incident just because things are tense.''

title: UConn Is Upset
description: Robin Dixon scored 35 points today and led New Hampshire to a 76-72 basketball upset over Connecticut. New Hampshire (5-5) hit 14 of 18 shots in the second half. UConn (7-4) was led by Earl Kelley's 15 points.

title: Memorial for Nancy Hanks
description: A memorial service for Nancy Hanks, who headed the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Council on the Arts in the Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations, will be held at 11 A.M. Jan. 18 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: BRADLEY, HIS SENATE SPURS WON, PUSHES TAX PLAN
description: Last year was something of a banner year for Senator Bill Bradley. After spending his first years in the Senate becoming acquainted with it, the New Jersey Democrat ended 1982 with several tangible achievements.

title: MXING UP PRIORITIES
description: Here we go again: another Presidential advisory commission to find a home for the MX.

title: Debra Wollens Wed to J.E. Newhouse
description: Debra Wollens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wollens of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan Edward Newhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Newhouse of New Orleans. Rabbi Simcha Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

title: Clevepak Restructures Its Top Management
description: The Clevepak Corporation, primarily a maker of paperboard and specialty packaging products, has announced four management changes designed to strengthen administration and control in its three principal product areas.

title: Cotton Dust Regulations For Mills May Be Eased
description: SALEM, N.C., Jan. 9 (AP) - Federal standards on cotton dust in textile mills may be eased next month to spare the industry from installing expensive equipment.

title: MAN AT WORK: MILDEST LAKER MAKES HIMSELF KNOWN
description: This is a forum of some of the National Basketball Association's best power forwards. The question is this: What was the first thought you had when playing the Los Angeles Lakers and seeing that you would be matched against this guy in the funny-looking glasses named Kurt Rambis?

title: Dr. Lawrence Grolnick Weds Maureen Cassidy
description: Maureen Cassidy, assistant principal of John Jay High School in Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Ely Grolnick, a psychiatrist in White Plains. Rabbi Leonard Troupp performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1983; The Economy
description: Administration talks on decontrolling natural gas prices continue, despite recent price increases that may add 20 percent or more to consumer heating bills this winter. (Page A1.)

title: POP: TORME AND FRIENDS
description: AT 57, an age when the vocal powers of most singers have severely diminished, Mel Torme is at the very peak of his. And at Friday's opening-night concert of the ''12 Days of Torme & Friends'' series at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J., the singer's impeccable pop-jazz technique and luminous musical intelligence combined to fashion definitive performances of songs by George and Ira Gershwin.

title: ADMINISTRATION STUDIES PROPOSALS FOR EASING PRICE CONTROLS ON GAS
description: The Reagan Administration is giving intensive scrutiny to proposals to ease price controls on natural gas, despite the prospect that, even with most gas prices still under controls, consumers' heating bills will again rise 20 percent or more this winter.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Must the hole on a golf green be on a straight line from any lie on the green? If the green is shaped as in the accompanying drawing is this a legal pin placement? If it is, may a player use a club other than the putter since the ball is on the green?

title: TV: 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' WEEK BEGINS
description: THE Royal Shakespeare Company's adaptation of Charles Dickens's ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' was a theatrical event both in London and New York. Now there is a television version, which, with the considerable support of Mobil Oil, can be seen on WNEW, Channel 5, beginning this evening at 8, over four consecutive nights.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. said the Amax Nickel Port Nickel Refinery in Braithwaite, La., would shut down for approximately two months next summer.

title: Austrian Captures Downhill
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Jan. 9 (UPI) - Erwin Resch of Austria won the World Cup downhill ski event today after a treacherous and spectacular ''S'' bend wiped out one-third of the top-ranked group of downhill stars.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Jazz Pianist's Holiday

title: Sherod at Ease Relaying Knicks' Plays
description: There are few plays the Knicks run that are not called from the bench by Hubie Brown, one of the few National Basketball Association coaches who dictates almost every play. His instructions are usually directed through Ed Sherod, the rookie playmaker on the court.

title: 'Mountain Man' Found Dead
description: Leslie Grover Wyman, a 44-yearold ''mountain man'' sought for nearly a week in the shootings of two police officers, was found dead today of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, sheriff's deputies said.

title: BRIEFING
description: Speaking Alphabetically

title: ROMANCE: A NET CAST WIDELY
description: DESPITE the fact that in some quarters it is considered as o ldfashioned as the water wheel, romance, its contemplation and the c ommunication of it between a man and a woman seem to be very much w ith us these days. Psychotherapists and psychoanalysts discuss it, a ttitudinal surveys deal with it, and ways in which it can be e nhanced become ever more popular.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Remembering, Evermore

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.48 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.38 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: Joseph Polser is Dead at 57; Press Secretary to Ohrenstein
description: Joseph Polser, press secretary to Manfred Ohrenstein, the New York State Senate minority leader, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 57 years old.

title: Security Police Patrol Tripoli In an Effort to Enforce Truce
description: Government security policemen patrolled slums in the northern city of Tripoli today in a new effort to enforce a cease-fire between warring pro-Syrian and anti-Syrian Moslem militia forces, the state radio reported.

title: IN DIOXIN-TAINTED TOWN, NO 'WELCOME' SIGNS
description: It has been a month since the rain-swollen Meramec River overflowed its banks and swept through this St. Louis suburb, leaving residents in fear that what little remained of their possessions might be contaminated with highly toxic dioxin.

title: TALKS AT OSSINING BEGIN AS PRISONERS STILL HOLD GUARDS
description: Convicts holding 17 guards hostage carried an uprising over crowded conditions into a second day today at the state correctional facility here. Negotiations with state officials had raised hopes for a settlement last night, but the talks were reported to have broken down over the question of amnesty.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A SCENE

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IRONWEED. By William Kennedy. 227 pages. Viking. $14.75.

title: BANKS GAIN BY ALTERING LATIN DEBT
description: International banks, while burdened by the inability of many developing nations to pay their debts on time, could earn more than $300 million in fees for rescheduling the loans of four Latin American countries.

title: Washington Watch; Pessimism And Regan
description: WASHINGTON THE mystery at the Treasury these days is what happened to the optimistic Secretary, Donald T. Regan, who has until now always been able to see a bright future through the gloom of deficits.

title: SWIM MARKS FALL
description: Birgit Meineke of East Germany got her third individual gold medal of the United States Swimming International meet and achieved her second world-best time today as she won the 100-meter freestyle in 53.99 seconds.

title: Pamela A. Levine Married To J.D. Turkel, a Lawyer
description: Pamela Ann Levine, daughter of Janis F. Levine of New Brunswick, N.J., and Robert P. Levine of Perth Amboy, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Jonathan Don Turkel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Turkel of Brooklyn. Rabbi Solomon J. Sharfman performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: 2 Injured Slightly In Copter Crash
description: A helicopter apparently developed engine trouble shortly before its pilot, an instructor teaching a student to fly, crash-landed the craft on a street.

title: DAY-CARE CENTERS ARE LINKED TO SOME DISEASES OF CHILDREN
description: Day-care centers have become ''networks'' for spreading diarrhea, dysentery and other intestinal diseases to children and their parents, causing outbreaks ''reminiscent of the presanitation days of the 17th century,'' a doctor reports.

title: NEW MARITAL STRESS: THE COMPUTER COMPLEX
description: From California's Silicon Valley comes word that a Universal Life minister is joining couples in electronic matrimony. Instead of ''I do,'' which means nothing to a computer, the bride and bridegroom type ''yes'' into the machine. Instead of wedding pictures, they get printouts of the ceremony. Will they live happily, electronically, ever after?

title: FORBIDDING LEGAL SERVICES' CLASS ACTIONS 'MAKES NO SENSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAYSPORTS
description: Basketball Army vs. Fordham, at Rose Hill Gymnasium, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:45 P.M.) Georgetown at Syracuse.

title: AUSTRALIAN VENTURE PREPARING TO MINE ARGYLE DIAMONDS
description: With a marketing agreement in hand, Australia's Argyle diamond mine is set to begin production in what could become the world's largest diamond mining operation by 1984.

title: Greece Devaluing Drachma 15%
description: The Greek Government, moving to narrow a gaping trade deficit and bolster the economy, announced tonight a 15 percent devaluation of the drachma and said it would take measures to control imports.

title: STUDY URGES CUTS IN FIRE DEPT. TO BOLSTER CITY POLICE BUDGET
description: New York City should maintain the size of its Police Department in coming years and make every effort to increase it, largely by diverting funds from the Fire Department, according to a study released yesterday by a private panel.

title: Surviving Justice
description: Two years ago, Judge William Hughes Mulligan left the Federal bench after 10 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He said the pay didn't bother him so much as the survivors' benefits. You can live on the pay, he said, ''but you can't die on it.''

title: COWBOYS OVERTAKE BUCCANEERS, 30-17
description: Monty Hunter, a rookie safety for the Dallas Cowboys but no stranger to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, intercepted a Doug Williams pass today and returned it 19 yards for a touchdown that moved the Cowboys into the lead and into the second round of the Super Bowl XVII tournament.

title: FOR STEPFAMILIES, SHARING AND EASING THE TENSIONS
description: For Marni Butterfield Julien, the 39-year-old owner of a Manhattan public relations agency, the decision to remarry early last year was one of understandable joy. What was less clear was how she would handle her new role as stepmother to the two daughters of her new husband, Morton Julien, 50, an insurance executive.

title: CLASHES IN 2 WEST BANK AREAS
description: Clashes between Jewish settlers and Arab residents were reported today in two main towns in the West Bank. In Nablus, in the north, soldiers fired tear gas to disperse 100 stone-throwing youths in the second day of disturbances.

title: N.F.L. Schedule Of Playoff Games
description: Opponents and starting times for the National Football League's conference semifinal games next weekend (all times E.S.T.): American Football Conference Saturday

title: Rock Found in the Antarctic May Have Come From Moon
description: Researchers say a rock the size of a golf ball found by an American expedition in the Antarctic may have come from the moon.

title: LAYOFFS AND FOREIGN GAINS SHAKING SECURITY OF LIFE IN ARIZONA COPPER TOWN
description: Don Arends's last weekly unemployment check came in the mail today, and with its arrival a cocoon of company-town life that has held him and his family for nearly 24 years began to unravel.

title: People
description: * Bernice F. Livingston appointed a senior vice president at Diener/Hauser/Bates, Los Angeles.

title: MGM/UA CUTTING DEBT
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has pared its long-term debt to a ''very manageable'' level, the company's chairman and chief executive said Saturday, using the proceeds from the sale of its music publishing unit and a portion of its pay television and home video subsidiary, plus two highly successful feature films.

title: A JEWISH PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: GAIN IS REPORTED ON 2-PARTY ACCORD ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: President Reagan's advisory commission on Social Security moved closer this weekend to a bipartisan agreement on measures to shore up the system, according to a Democrat on the panel.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY II OFFERS PREMIERS IN BALTIMORE
description: DUNDALK, Md. TWO world premieres, one recent ballet by a popular dancer and a modern classic were performed by the Joffrey II company on Saturday night in this Baltimore suburb. It was the sort of program that a New York dance fan would consider proper New York fare.

title: NETS TAKE 9TH IN ROW, 110-102
description: Otis Birdsong was bloodied in the nose, poked, bruised and often sent tumbling to the floor during tonight's game against the Detroit Pistons at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Yet when he dusted himself off for the final time, he applied the crucial blow for the Nets, scoring 10 consecutive points in a fourth-period surge and leading them to their ninth straight triumph, 110-102, before 10,256 fans.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Hanika Wins

title: Handling Your Agent
