description: Although the sports agent has been a familiar figure since players' salaries began escalating in the 1960's, many athletes have little knowledge of agents, their qualifications, services they should provide, how much money they should be paid and other information about the people who serve as their advisers and go-betweens in dealings with pro teams.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: LATE CHARGER PASS TOPS STEELERS, 31-28
description: Terry Bradshaw, reviving what some critics contend is an aging arm, tried to upstage Dan Fouts and his aerial circus today, but in the end an interception opened the way for the San Diego Chargers to defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 31-28.

title: PRAIRIE POSSE AIDS IN CAPTURE OF SUSPECT IN BANK ROBBERY
description: To anyone who did not know the First State Bank of Sharon had been robbed just last month, the white compact car parked behind it Tuesday afternoon might not have looked so suspicious.

title: Commodities; Note Trading Reset
description: TODAY was to have been the first day of trading in two-year Treasury notes on the Chicago Board of Trade. But so many brokerage houses asked for a delay so they could prepare their staffs and computers for the new financial instrument futures that officials of the nation's biggest exchange agreed late last week to put off the opening until Jan. 21, a Friday.

title: Reagan to Name G.M. Aide
description: President Reagan will nominate Barbara Jean Mahone, a manager with a division of the General Motors Corporation, to be chairman of the Federal Labor Relations Authority, the White House has announced. If confirmed by the Senate, Miss Mahone, 36 years old, would be among the highest-ranking black women named by Mr. Reagan.

title: Downhill Sizzler
description: The 175 members of a club whose rolls are restricted to chefs and owners of high-quality restaurants will assemble Sunday for an annual event that brings out the keenest competitive instincts of the participants. At Hunter (N.Y.) Mountain, attired in the traditional garb of the culinary arts - a chef's hat and a white coat -the contestants will take part not in an elite cookoff, but the eighth United States Chefs' Ski Club race.

title: TO BUOY EUROPE'S DEFENSE
description: In AN effort to rectify the military imbalance in Europe, a number of suggestions have been made to induce our European allies to increase substantially the level of their defense spending. Unfortunately, some of the most highly touted of these initiatives - both Senator Ted Stevens's proposal to withdraw 20,000 American troops from Europe and the proposed nuclear doctrine known as ''no first use'' - would be far more likely to weaken than strengthen the alliance.

title: IN RUGGED CORSICA, SEPARATISTS FEEL LASH OF PARIS
description: Scores of Sunday drivers took to the coast road south of here to enjoy a warm, brilliantly sunny day. On the Mediterranean beaches, abandoned by the tourists until next summer, parents, children and young lovers picnicked or sauntered along the water. It was all part of the good life that this island of sandy beaches, isolated coves and stony, ruggedly beautiful mountains can offer.

title: Lady Northcliffe First at Aqueduct
description: Lady Northcliffe, the fourth choice in the wagering, rallied to win the $57,300 Busanda Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: FEW BONDS SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
description: Few corporate bonds or tax-exempt debt issues are scheduled for sale this week, and no new Treasury notes or bonds are planned. Investment bankers noted that some corporate offerings might come to market, since dozens of companies have already registered debt issues with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: U.S. TRIAL IN HOTEL DISASTER SET TO BEGIN IN KANSAS CITY
description: Jury selection is to begin Monday in a suit to determine liability and punitive damages in the Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster, which left 114 people dead when two aerial walkways collapsed.

title: Sadat's Kinsman Offers To Make a Deal
description: Esmat Sadat offered today to hand over the assets he accrued during the regime of his older half brother, Anwar el-Sadat, valued by the state prosecutor's office at almost $150 million, in exchange for $2 million in cash.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Emigrant Savings Bank has promoted Francis A. Balzarini, Daniel C. Hickey, Charles R. Howe and Louis R. Oddo to vice president.

title: REPUBLICANS WHO LOST JOIN THE STRUGGLE FOR JOBS
description: It scarcely counts as a major element of the national problem, but unemployment among recently defeated Republican members of Congress, like that of the other 12 million Americans out of work, resists Reagan Administration efforts to cure it.

title: AMERICA'S ECONOMY NEEDS NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Samuel Insull Jr., 82; Son of Utility Magnate
description: Samuel Insull Jr., an insurance executive and son of the one-time billionaire utility magnate, is dead at the age of 82.

title: REPAIR OF PLANT ENDS DUMPING OF RAW SEWAGE
description: The Wards Island sewage treatment plant, disabled when a huge valve burst six days ago, was back in operation yesterday, ending the daily discharge of 300 million gallons of raw sewage into the Harlem, Hudson and East Rivers.

title: Coach's Threat Discounted
description: The commissioner of the Big East Conference said today that he thought John Thompson, Georgetown's basketball coach, had ''said it for effect'' when he threatened to tell Pat Ewing to turn professional at the end of the season if college officiating did not improve.

title: MORGAN WINNER IN PLAYOFF
description: Gil Morgan dropped a 22-foot birdie putt on the second extra hole to defeat Lanny Wadkins and Curtis Strange in a sudden-death playoff today to win the Joe Garagiola-Tucson Open, the opening event on the 1983 PGA Tour.

title: TV: VIRGINIA OPENS SERIES ON STATES
description: IT was with some foreboding that I approached the first program in Ted Turner's superambitious ''Portrait of America'' series, which begins on his superstation, WTBS cable, at 8:05 tonight. Had Mr. Turner not assured an interviewer in On Cable magazine that there would be no negatives along with the positives in this series of 60 hourlong documentaries. Did he not explain, ''This is like those books put out on states with beautiful photographs and descriptions of the state bird and flower. It's a Chamber of Commerce type of presentation''?

title: Vivian J. Green Is Wed To Dr. Steven Korner
description: Vivian J. Green and Dr. Steven Korner were married yesterday by Rabbi Robert Schumeister at the Pierre Hotel in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Sidney Gaines of New York and the late Dr. Wallace Green, an orthopedic surgeon.

title: CITY TRAFFIC: MORE 'CURES FOR CAR CHOKING'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Frey Approach
description: As batting coach of the Mets, Jim Frey naturally intends to offer assistance to all of the players under him, but he has a few special projects facing him in spring training. One is Hubie Brooks, the third baseman whose batting average dropped from .307 in his rookie season to .249 in 1982. Frey will also pay extra attention to George Foster and Mookie Wilson, outfielders who fell short of their batting potential last season.

title: Monsanto Worker Held In Industrial Espionage
description: An employee of the Monsanto Chemical Company was arrested here Saturday, accused of offering to sell $15 million in industrial secrets to a competing company, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: HOMOSEXUAL VIEWS ADOPTION APPROVAL AS VICTORY
description: Two years ago, when he was 27 years old, David Frater thought that it was time he enjoyed the satisfactions that he felt fatherhood would bring.

title: Weir Gets 77-6 3/4 In Weight Throw
description: Robert Weir of Southern Methodist University threw the 35-pound weight to a world indoor-best distance of 77 feet 6 3/4 inches today and won the event at the Dartmouth Relays.

title: Aileen R. Leventon Is Married to Marc J. Goldstein
description: Aileen R. Leventon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Leventon of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Marc J. Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goldstein of Amherst, N.Y. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Indiana Is Toppled In Columbus Again
description: When they took the court against Ohio State in Columbus, Ohio, Saturday night, the Indiana Hoosiers were undefeated and ranked No.1 in the nation. The Hoosiers made 50 percent of their shots from the floor and outrebounded Ohio State decisively, 35-18. They also connected on more field-goal attempts than the Buckeyes, 27 to 23.

title: Riddick Captures 55-Meter Dash
description: Steve Riddick, a 1976 Olympic gold medalist in the 400-meter relay, made his 1983 debut by winning the 55-meter dash today in the Manufacturers Hanover-Metropolitan Athletics Congress development meet at the United States Military Academy Fieldhouse.

title: THATCHER PRIDE IS SHOWING IN FALKLANDS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher toured military positions on the Falkland Islands today as opposition politicians at home accused her of trying to make political capital out of the British victory in the remote archipelago seven months ago.

title: THE REAGAN RECORD (2)
description: Last year one million children from low-income families dropped out of the Federal School Lunch Program. Many could not afford the higher prices schools were forced to charge when the Reagan Administration cut the Federal contribution. Others, so poor that they could have had their lunches free, found that their schools had given up the program because of new Federal restrictions.

title: FINDING NEW WAYS TO DESTROY TOXIC WASTES
description: Early in the morning and again after work, Frank Freestone drove last Thursday to a warehouse at the edge of the nearly abandoned Raritan Arsenal here. He watched white smoke rise from a stack and billow into the west wind. It was a scientist's little superstition, a sort of bed check on his invention.

title: Bombs Injure 9 At Soccer Game
description: At least nine people had to be treated in hospitals today for cuts they suffered when two homemade bombs exploded in the stands during a soccer game between Ajax of Amsterdam and FC Den Haag, the police said.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 1983
description: International Poles are still being arrested although the internment of political dissidents was formally ended with the suspension of the basic provisions of martial law. In their pursuit of underground Solidarity activists, authorities in their largest recent roundup just before New Year's seized 15 activists who were said to be operating an underground printing plant near Poznan. (Page A1, Column 1.) A rebellion in a Salvadoran province continued. El Salvador's Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, rejected a demand by one of his military commanders that he step down to end the rebellion in the northern province of Cabanas. But there were signs that regardless of the outcome of the rebellion, General Garcia's position was growing more difficult to maintain. (A1:1.)

title: TROUBLES STALK THE BEAUMONT
description: The Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center's perennial problem, has been closed since July 1981 and may not reopen for two more years. But there is plenty of rough and tumble going on behind the scenes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Banking on Atmosphere

title: A SHIFT IN TRADERS' APPROACH
description: The best investment strategies in the credit markets during 1983 may not be the same as in 1982. That seems to be the case now, with investors showing relatively little appetite for long-term Treasury bonds, even though such issues offered annualized returns of 30 percent and more last year, thanks to a combination of high yields and prices that rose as much as 25 percent.

title: 5 Inmate Centers Get a Reprieve
description: Governor Kean directed the Corrections Department today to keep the Skillman Correctional Facility for Boys open, along with four other inmate centers that were to have been closed shortly.

title: Guatemala Is Promised Civil Rule in '85
description: President Efrain Rios Montt will hand over power to an elected Government in 1985, Foreign Minister Eduardo Castillo Arriola said Saturday.

title: SEIZING OF POLISH ACTIVISTS GOES ON DESPITE SUSPENSION OF MARTIAL LAW
description: Although the internment of political dissidents was formally ended Dec. 30 with the suspension of the basic provisions of martial law, the authorities are still arresting underground Solidarity activists.

title: OIL-TO-COAL PLANT CONVERSION: A SUCCESS STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-CABINET MINISTER IN JAPAN
description: One of the more colorful leaders in Japanese politics, Ichiro Nakagawa, an outspoken right-winger, died of a heart attack today in his native Hokkaido.

title: Films by Melville
description: A six-day retrospective of films by the French director Jean-Pierre Melville begins next Monday at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

title: Karen Chrisbelle Dildilian Marries Ross H. Tartell
description: Karen Chrisbelle Dildilian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Armen A. Dildilian of Port Washington, L.I., and Miami Lakes, Fla., was married yesterday to Ross Howard Tartell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Tartell of West Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Charles Calcagni, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim officiated at the C.W. Post College Chapel in Greenvale, L.I.

title: Bridge: Garozzo Still a Fine Player, But His Old Team Is Gone
description: A man who a decade ago was widely thought to be the world's best player is not as much in the limelight as he used to be. Benito Garozzo of Rome is still a formidable performer, but with the disappearance of the great Italian Blue Team his chance of adding to his vast collection of world titles is quite small.

title: VIKINGS' RUNNING OVERCOMES FALCONS
description: Ted Brown, the running back who scored the winning touchdown on a 5-yard end run, and John Turner, the cornerback who intercepted two passes, were awarded game balls, the symbols of victory, after the Minnesota Vikings defeated the Atlanta Falcons, 30-24, today.

title: LENDL DEFEATS CONNORS
description: Ivan Lendl scored 24 aces today in a 4-6, 6-4, 7-5, 6-4 triumph over Jimmy Connors, the defender, in the final of the $250,000 Lite Challenge of Champions.

title: SALVADOR GENERAL SAYS HE WON'T QUIT
description: El Salvador's Defense Minister today rejected a demand by one of his military commanders that he step down to end the commander's rebellion in the northern province of Cabanas.

title: RECORD DAY FOR MCNEIL
description: CINCINNATI SOME of the Jets were sitting around after their team breakfast before yesterday's Super Bowl XVII playoff opener with the Cincinnati Bengals when Freeman McNeil, the Jets' all-pro running back, glanced across the table at Coach Walt Michaels.

title: Buying Agents' Survey Bleak
description: The industrial sector of the economy weakened further in December, as production, employment and prices continued to slide, according to a monthly survey of purchasing agents for American companies.

title: RETAILERS CAUTIOUS IN ORDERING APPAREL
description: Sakowitz Inc., the major fashion retailer in Houston, had a ''just passable'' Christmas. Because of this, and because of the tight economy, the retail chain will gear its spring apparel ordering strictly to last year's dollar level rather than increase it, as the company normally does each season.

title: Richmond Leasing Filing
description: The Richmond Leasing Company, an unconsolidated subsidiary of the Richmond Tank Car Company, Houston, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act while it reorganizes. On Wednesday the leasing company announced that it had defaulted on debt payments on several agreements with banks and other institutions. Neither the parent company or its consolidated subsidiaries filed for Chapter 11, and business in these operations will continue as usual.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The first priority is the lives of the 15 corrections officers. Secondly, however, we must be aware that the lives of potential hostages in prisons throughout New York would be endangered by any agreement that would unduly erode respect for the state's authority'' - Governor Cuomo. (B4:1.)

title: Brooklynite in Malaysia For Peace Corps Is Slain
description: A Peace Corps training officer from Brooklyn was stabbed to death Saturday night by a group of people as he left a bar here, Gary Brennaman, a local Peace Corps director, said today.

title: PIANO: C.-V. ALKAN BY RONALD SMITH
description: WE owe much to the British pianist Ronald Smith, who almost singlehandedly has retrieved the work of Charles-Valentin Alkan from its mid-19th-century burial place. Chopin admired this fierce, maniacally difficult music, but others - if they were ever aware of it - soon forgot it. Mr. Smith returned to the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night to remind us of Alkan's virtues.

title: Lippincott & Margulies Merges With Chajet
description: Lippincott & Margulies, the 36-year-old design firm, and the 10-year-old Chajet Design Group, which works principally in packaging, have merged, Walter P. Margulies and Clive Chajet said last week.

title: A Party Drops Out Of Bolivia's Coalition
description: The Movement of the Revolutionary Left, one of three leftist parties making up the coalition headed by President Hernan Siles Zuazo, pulled out of the Government today.

title: MUSIC: PRODIGIES AT WORK
description: ONLY in the worlds of mathematics and chess are child prodigies so stunning as in music. But though child mathematicians have done mature work, few musical prodigies give mature performances.

title: NEW FIRE ERUPTS
description: A four-alarm fire burned out of control through a Newark printing plant this morning, less than a mile from the still-smoldering Texaco gasoline storage tanks that exploded early Friday.

title: Linda App Is Wed To Eric Fleisher
description: Linda App, daughter of Barbara Green App of White Plains and Dr. Alva A. App of Nairobi, Kenya, was married yesterday to Eric David Fleisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Fleisher of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Bedford Historical Hall in Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: MARTIN HAS MEETING WITH STEINBRENNER
description: George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin met last night for the first time in the continuing negotiations to make Martin the Yankee manager a third time, a source familiar with the meeting said.

title: Kentucky 59 Mississippi State 53
description: Mississippi State's Kelvin Hildreth scored a rebounder that appeared to be the winning basket with six seconds left, but No.3 Kentucky tied it, 47-47, at the buzzer and won in overtime.

title: St. John's 3d In Poll
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, describes heightened expectations as a heavy burden.

title: Scott's No.3 Leaves; Job Will Go Unfilled
description: James D. Stocker, the No.3 man at the Scott Paper Company, resigned ''to pursue other opportunities,'' the Philadelphia-based company said yesterday.

title: NEW COLD-RESISTANT ORCHID
description: Laymond Hardy says he has created a coldresistant orchid that could revitalize the orchid industry in America. Mr. Hardy, 61, a Dade County genetic researcher, said he developed his new hybrid by crossing a tiny, rather lackluster Georgia orchid with a large and beautiful South American variety.

title: Maj. Gen. Cecil Moore Dies; Served on Eisenhower's Staff
description: Maj. Gen. Cecil R. Moore of the Army, who was chief engineer of the European theater of operations in World War II and served on Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's staff, died Saturday in his home here. Mr. Moore was 88 years old.

title: UTILITY RESTS CASE IN SUIT ON 3 MILE ISLAND MISHAP
description: Testimony for the utility that owns the Three Mile Island nuclear plant ended yesterday in the utility's suit against the builders of the plant over the 1979 accident there.

title: Tennessee 59, L.S.U. 58
description: Dale Ellis scored 23 points, including a 4-pointer in the final minutes, to rally Tennessee in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.

title: Chess: 3 Germans From the 1800's Gave the Bishops Their Due
description: It is difficult these days to imagine that, in the mid-19th century, knights were held superior to bishops. But it was only slowly that the value of bishops was understood.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from San Salvador Nov. 3 about Ambassador Deane R. Hin- ton's views on aid to El Salvador in- correctly identified an organization that took out newspaper advertise- ments attacking him. It was the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of El Salvador.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN MAY BACK TAX RISE FOR '85 AND LATER
description: President Reagan will probably agree to a special package of contingency tax increases to be put into effect in 1985 and thereafter if Federal budget deficits are not declining sharply enough, Administration officials said today.

title: HARD BY BUSY DELHI, TIMELESS INDIA SLUMBERS ON
description: Before the first, faint pink of dawn shows in the east, the milk sellers of Mandi are well on their way to town. With shiny cans hanging from the handlebars of their bicycles, they peddle along in groups of two or three through patches of fog, watching the road through the folds of the shawls they have wrapped around heads and shoulders against the January cold. Behind them, the lights of Mandi itself are strung out like jewels across rocky ridges that lie south of New Delhi.

title: 10,400 Renault Layoffs
description: Some 10,400 employees have been laid off indefinitely by Renault, the state-owned auto company, and production at its Flins factory near Paris is at a standstill because of a strike by paint workers, a Renault spokesman said today. ''Since this morning not one car has left the factory,'' the spokesman said. Renault is France's largest automobile manufacturer and Flins, with an output of some 1,600 vehicles a day, is normally its biggest factory in terms of volume.

title: Jockeys Suspended
description: The West Virginia State Racing Commission has suspended the licenses of four jockeys following an investigation into a race at Waterford Park last month that track officials said had an unusual trifecta betting pattern. Russell Applebee, 36, and John D. Rodriguez, 27, lost their licenses for five years; the terms of suspension for Raymond Hancock, 36, and James Thompson, 39, have not been determined. In addition, a spokesman for the commission said, one of the jockey's agents, Elmer Sensabaugh, had his racing license revoked permanently because officials said he was the ringleader.

title: DeBEERS DIAMOND SALES SHOW GAIN
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the South African mining and industrial company that controls 80 percent of the world diamond trade, said today that sales of raw and industrial diamonds were up 19.1 percent in the second half of last year, indicating that ''stability and calm'' had returned to the diamond market.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Macchiarola Mulls Over A Move

title: GEORGETOWN BEATS SYRACUSE
description: Georgetown may be down this season, but a crowd of 31,327, the largest for a college basketball game on campus, discovered tonight that the Hoyas were far from out. Led by 6-foot-1-inch Michael Jackson and 7-foot Pat Ewing, the short and the long of it on the Georgetown roster, the Hoyas scored a 97-92 victory over Syracuse.

title: Coach Rogers Stays Put
description: In his three years at Arizona State, Coach Darryl Rogers has compiled a 28-6 record, and his Sun Devils capped their 1982 season (10-2) by defeating Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl and being named the sixth-best football team in the nation in both news-agency polls. That was enough to make Rogers a hot prospect to move to the National Football League, and to those in the know the only question was which team would get him. Yesterday, Rogers supplied the answer: He will stay at Arizona State.

title: What's a Bank?
description: A big bank in California and a small bank in New Jersey have, coincidentally, demonstrated the radical changes in American finance - and Government's failure to define the direction of change.

title: MISTAKE NULLIFIES MCNEIL RECORD
description: On the television screen high above the Jets' locker room today, Bruce Harper scooted for 9 yards - the 9 that, as events proved earlier in the day, stood between Freeman McNeil and the greatest rushing performance ever in the National Football League playoffs.

title: News Analysis
description: When Vice President Bush arrives in Britain next month at the end of his seven-nation European tour, he will find America's closest European ally torn with uncertainty about nuclear weapons and strategy.

title: THE MUSCULAR DOLLAR: AN ECONOMIC LIABILITY
description: The greatest single problem facing the United States economy - and, too, the economies of much of the rest of the world - is the extraordinary global strength of the dollar. In the last 12 months alone, the dollar has appreciated 30 to 40 per cent against most world currencies. This has been wonderful for American tourists abroad but disastrous for farmers and automotive and steel workers at home.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: MOST attempts to reform the universities in the last 20 years have failed. They fell victim to the conservatism of faculties and weak presidential leadership. This is the judgment of Clark Kerr, a former president of the University of California who also was chairman of the Carnegie Council on Higher Education.

title: SURPRISES ARE THE ROUTINE IN PLAYOFFS
description: The four American conference teams whose victories this weekend moved them into the second round of the Super Bowl XVII tournament each advanced with the help of at least one player's timely and, perhaps, unexpected performance.

title: ISRAEL SHUTS SCHOOL IN WEST BANK
description: The Israeli military said today that it had closed a high school for a month in the occupied West Bank town of Nablus after one policeman was lightly wounded during the third day of clashes with Arab youths.

title: FAMILIES OF HOSTAGES WAITED AND HOPED
description: In a three-story green-and-white clapboard house a few hundred yards from a bluff overlooking the Ossining Correctional Facility, Delores Cross kept busy yesterday, trying not to dwell on the fact that her husband, Edward, was one of 17 correction officers held hostage at the prison.

title: HEADS FOR MIDEAST
description: Philip C. Habib, the special negotiator, conferred with President Reagan today and then left for the Middle East to try to end the stalemate over an agenda that has blocked progress in the negotiations on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: HOTEL DISASTER TRIAL AVERTED WITH A $10 MILLION ACCORD
description: A Federal district judge gave tentative approval today to a $10 million settlement in the collapse of two suspended walkways at the Kansas City Hyatt Regency Hotel in 1981.

title: A NEW TRACK FOR CHICAGO'S JMB REALTY
description: For more than a decade, Judd D. Malkin and Neil G. Bluhm have taken their share of risks in directing the JMB Realty Corporation, a Chicago real estate investment firm with nationwide interests.

title: ARMCO IS CLOSING SOME UNITS
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, announced yesterday that it was discontinuing some operations at three plants in Missouri, Ohio and Texas, resulting in a permanent loss of 2,200 jobs and contributing to a fourth-quarter loss of about $180 million.

title: Italian Workers Are Idle In a Second Tax Protest
description: Millions of workers walked off their jobs today for the second time in four days to protest a tax increase that economists said would cost the average Italian an additional $700 in taxes in 1983.

title: 'The Only Thing I Ever Watch ...'
description: There are TV snobs and TV snobs and last night was a prime time to weed out the Little Leaguers.

title: Chrysler Sees Slim '82 Profit
description: The Chrysler Corporation expects to show a slim profit for 1982, but a loss on its car-manufacturing operations, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, said.

title: SIMULCASTS CALLED KEY TO RACING ILLS
description: Concerned about dwindling attendance and betting at New York's horse racing tracks, a special legislative task force said in a report issued yesterday that simulcasting - the instant video transmission of races to offtrack locations - was the ''key'' to the problem.

title: Buying Fever Sweeps The Bullion Markets
description: Precious metals prices shot up again yesterday as buying fever swept bullion markets on both sides of the Atlantic. Market analysts attributed the advances of the last two sessions to a combination of strong demand and technical factors in both the London and New York bullion markets.

title: C.B.O.E. Disciplines 3
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today announced disciplinary actions against three members of the exchange.

title: NEW STUDY STANDARD ASKED FOR ATHLETES
description: The president of U.C.L.A., saying that the time has come, is leading a move to set new and higher academic standards for student-athletes.

title: WITH DUE CREDIT
description: To the Editor:

title: INQUIRY LINKS PUERTO RICO POLICE TO MURDER, ABDUCTION AND DRUGS
description: The United States Justice Department has been investigating members of the Puerto Rican police force in connection with murders, kidnappings, narcotics trafficking and the theft of $1.3 million in gold, according to Puerto Rican officials close to the inquiry.

title: JUGGLING THE CHANGING FIGURES IN THE CITY BUDGET BALANCING ACT
description: Ten days ago, New York City's economic forecasters, faced with a sluggish economy, reduced by $30 million their estimates of how much the city would receive this year from the financial-corporation tax.

title: Judge Bars Government From Collecting Milk Fee
description: A Federal district judge issued an injunction today barring the Government from collecting 50 cents on every 100 pounds of milk produced in the United States.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Chagra Murder Trial
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of a drug smuggler accused of paying a hit man $250,000 to kill a Texas Federal judge with a reputation for stiff sentences.

title: U.S. NARCOTICS CONTROL NEEDS NO CABINET POST
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERN FOR HOMELESS STIRS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: ''I am a resident alien who has spent seven happy years in New York, but from year to year I observe more and more sadness and misery in the streets surrounding me. Therefore I would like to contribute to your fund and hope that someone else, less fortunate, will be able to enjoy life in this city a little more.''

title: BONN SAYS G.N.P. FELL AGAIN IN '82
description: The West German economy, gripped by recession, declined in 1982 for the second consecutive year, according to provisional figures released today by the Government.

title: REAGAN CONSIDERING TAXING HEALTH PREMIUMS
description: A White House adviser said today that President Reagan would probably propose taxing employees for the health insurance premiums paid by their employers.

title: Greek Action Upsets E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community Commission today lamented Greece's decision to devalue the drachma without notifying its European trading partners. It said the move could affect other Common Market countries.

title: LEGAL BOARD FEES SAID TO BE VALID
description: An Office of Management and Budget investigation has cleared the Legal Services Corporation board of any wrongdoing in charging the Government expenses and fees of more than $240,000 for 11 months of work, a White House aide said today.

title: Emery's President Resigns His Posts
description: Gen. William G. Moore Jr. has resigned as president and chief operating officer of the Emery Air Freight Corporation, one of the nation's largest domestic air freight carriers.

title: GOULET BACK AFTER 8 YEARS
description: ROBERT GOULET'S cameo appearance in the movie ''Atlantic City'' showed a Las Vegas lounge lizard with enough sense of humor and self-confidence to do a wicked self-parody. And in his first New York performance in eight years, at the Grand Hyatt Hotel on Thursday, Mr. Goulet displayed the same cheery sense of the comic side of his profession.

title: Books Of The Times
description: NOW THAT THE BUFFALO'S GONE: A Study of Today's American Indians. By Alvin M. Josephy Jr. 301 pages. New York: Knopf. $15.95.

title: THE NEED EMERGES TO RESPOND TO THE RUSSIANS ON ARMS
description: The most recent maneuvering in the Kremlin and the White House over arms control is another reminder that foreign policy is often as much a matter of imagery, salesmanship and positioning as selling cars or winning domestic political campaigns.

title: U.S. Takeover Of Thrift Unit
description: Federal bank regulators today began operating the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan in a rare takeover in the wake of an order last August that the institution stop improper business practices.

title: POLISH STAFFS OF WESTERN OFFICES IN WARSAW CURBED
description: The authorities have refused to renew work permits for Polish employees of Western news organizations and have held up the permits of Poles working for Western embassies.

title: JUDGE TELLS YANKEES TO PLAY 1983 OPENER IN BRONX, NOT DENVER
description: The New York Yankees cannot play next season's first three scheduled home games in Denver instead of in Yankee Stadium, a judge ruled yesterday in a lawsuit that had been brought by New York City.

title: ISRAELI-LEBANESE AGENDA STILL ELUSIVE
description: A dispute over an agenda for discussions between Israel and Lebanon remained unresolved today, but negotiators said they would try to end the impasse at their sixth meeting on Thursday.

title: ZAMBIA IN A SQUEEZE
description: A major local story just now is about Chief Lukwesa, who was roundly beaten by his villagers, an event so unusual that nobody remembers anything like it in the country's history.

title: MacMillan Bloedel
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest products company, said that it had agreed to sell a half interest in Island Paper Mills Ltd., a producer of fine papers, to Fraser Inc. for $25 million. Noranda Mines Ltd., a major producer of copper and other metals, owns 64 percent of Fraser and 49 percent of MacMillan Bloedel. Island Paper operates a fine paper mill, wholly owned by MacMillan Bloedel, near Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Culprit to Victim, In One Quick Incident

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: How the Sultan's Secretary Got to City Hall

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For a Few Hours' Work

title: JUSTICES ACCEPT APPEAL BY FAMILY OF WOMAN TAINTED BY PLUTONIUM
description: The Supreme Court, disregarding advice it had sought from the Justice Department, agreed today to review a ruling that overturned a $10 million damage award in the death of a laboratory worker contaminated with plutonium.

title: Bridge: The Five-Card Restriction Can Bring Some Problems
description: The modern fashion for insisting on five cards for a major-suit opening tends to be carried too far: Players forget that the restriction does not apply when partner has already passed. In particular, a player in third position with minimum values should prefer a strong four-card major to a weak four-card minor since the fourth player is likely to be strong and the lead will be an important factor.

title: New Birth Control Rule Near
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today recommended a rule requiring family planning clinics supported by Federal money to notify parents of minors who receive birth control pills, diaphragms or intrauterine devices.

title: Socal-Sudan Deal
description: The chairman of the Standard Oil Company of California, George Keller, said his company would help finance a 900-mile oil pipeline in the Sudan and a terminal on the Red Sea. Chevron, a subsidiary of Socal, has discovered 200 million barrels of oil in the country, enough to allow pumping of 50,000 barrels a day for up to six years. The total cost of the project is estimated at $2.5 billion, $600 million of which has already been spent on exploration.

title: INJECTED CONTRACEPTIVE: HAZARD OR BOON?
description: A rare public board of inquiry opened a five-day hearing today to evaluate whether the drug Depo-Provera is an almost ideal contraceptive for women - or a potential cause of cancer, birth defects and other disease.

title: Union Is Opposing Cuts in Fire Dept.
description: The head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association yesterday criticized a Citizens Budget Commission recommendation that the size of the Police Department be increased, with the money largely coming from a reduction in the number of firefighters.

title: PLAYS
description: T he Jets had played through all of 1979, 1980, 1981 and the 1982 regular season without using it, but when they finally revived the play Sunday they did so with what proved to be spectacularly dramatic timing.

title: REAGAN, ANNOYED BY NEWS LEAKS, TELLS STAFF TO LIMIT PRESS RELATIONS
description: President Reagan complained today that news ''leaks'' were disrupting work on the budget and other matters and directed that White House staff members get clearance before discussing certain matters with reporters.

title: AT LAST, A CAPITAL CONVENTION CENTER
description: After years of bickering with Congress, the District of Columbia finally has a major convention center, a $98.7-million building that sprawls over three blocks of a rundown neighborhood that once was the heart of downtown Washington.

title: 'GEORGE MILLS' FICTION WINNER
description: ''George Mills'' (E.P. Dutton) by Stanley Elkin, a madcap novel that stretches across 10 centuries of history, yesterday was named the best fiction book of 1982 by the National Book Critics Circle.

title: 'DOUBLE STANDARD' IS SEEN FOR PIVOT MEN
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has been hacked, elbowed, poked in the eye and double- and triple-teamed in his 20 years of playing basketball. Yesterday, the Los Angeles Laker center defended Ralph Sampson and Pat Ewing, the nation's top college big men, for their involvement in physical confrontations during games last Saturday.

title: Hastings Trial Is Delayed
description: Alcee Hastings, Florida's first black Federal judge, today was given a two-day postponement of his trial on charges of conspiring to accept a $150,000 bribe and dropped his bid to move the proceedings from Miami. A second attempt to have the trial televised was denied by Federal District Judge Edward T. Gignoux of Maine. Jury selection was to begin Tuesday but Judge Gignoux agreed to delay the proceedings until Thursday.

title: FOR A SETTLEMENT, FUSE REAGAN AND ARAB IDEAS
description: Arab hopes are fast dwindling that the United States will be able to play the role that President Reagan staked out on Sept. 1 when he unveiled his Middle East proposals.

title: THE CITY;
description: A clerk who said she was forced to resign because of sexual harassment by an executive of the company that employed her has been awarded $15,188, the New York City Commission on Human Rights announced yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anglo American Corp. has elected Gavin Relly chairman, succeeding Harry F. Oppenheimer, who retired. J. Ogilvie Thompson and Nicholas F. Oppenheimer are deputy chairmen.

title: EMERGENCY MEDICINE ADAPTS TO THE SLOPES
description: Last Saturday, Debra Anne Rollins borrowed skis and boots, left her two young children at home and joined her husband, Kevin, to go skiing for the first time in years.

title: Bernard Griffin, 74, Executive Of the Longshoremen's Union
description: Bernard J. Griffin, a vice president of the Atlantic Coast District of the International Longshoremen's Association, died Sunday in Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 74 years old and lived in Rego Park and Breezy Point, Queens.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp.'s chairman, W. Paul Tippett, said the company expected to invest $500 million in new-car development in the next few years.

title: DEVILS' PENALTY-KILLING HALTS NORDIQUES
description: When the Devils win, which is not very often, Coach Billy MacMillan usually calls the victory ''a team effort.''

title: NEW YORK CITY BONDS RATED BA-1 BY MOODY'S
description: Moody's Investors Service affirmed yesterday its Ba-1 rating for New York City bonds, including a $100 million issue to be sold this week.

title: Turk Wounded in June Attack By Armenian Terrorists Dies
description: After eight months in a coma, a Turkish diplomat's wife died today of a head wound inflicted in the assassination of her husband in June, the radio said.

title: New Shuttle Delay
description: A rehearsal countdown for the launching of the space shuttle Challenger was postponed a day today because of failure of an electrical component, an inverter that converts direct current to alternating current for the spacecraft's fans and pumps.

title: THE SHAPES OF SUMMER FROM FIVE DESIGNERS
description: With much of winter yet to come and spring on the distant horizon, the watchword today in most Seventh Avenue showrooms is summer. This month the last segment of the warm-weather showings, which started in August with clothes for southern resorts, will be introduced to store buyers.

title: DOW RISES 16.28 AMID RATE HOPES
description: Expectations of lower interest rates and a stronger economy propelled the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 16.28 points yesterday, to a closing record of 1,092.35.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1983
description: International Upholding the Salvadoran regime, Administration officials said that President Reagan planned to certify to Congress within a few weeks that Salvador was making progress in human rights and political and economic changes despite the military crisis generated by the rebellion of a Salvadoran province commander. (Page A8, Columns 1-3.) Philip C. Habib met with President Reagan and then left for the Middle East to try to end a stalemate over an agenda that has snarled negotiations on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon. (A3:4-6.)

title: The Lesson of Cell Block B
description: Cell Block B is an ancient fortress of stone and iron that helped New York's Ossining Correctional Facility earn a forbidding reputation. The state is spending millions to make it habitable.

title: DEUKMEJIAN SEEKS BALANCED BUDGET
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today proposed to solve California's financial crisis by cutting spending, particularly for a number of programs favored by his predecessor, and carrying over half of this year's $1.5 billion deficit to next year.

title: KAFKA'S LIBRARY FOUND IN GERMAMY
description: Books have their fates. The personal library of Franz Kafka, which disappeared in the dark years of the Third Reich and which has been long sought by scholars as a possible key to elucidating obscure themes and unusual allusions in Kafka's writings, has been rediscovered in West Germany.

title: Bronzes Returned After Being Stolen
description: Two bronze statues stolen here last week have been returned. The statues, weighing 600 pounds and 400 pounds and valued at a total of $40,000, reappeared during the weekend, three days after having been stolen from the lawn of Inger Magliana, an art dealer.

title: Sony Agreement
description: The Sony Corporation announced in Tokyo that it and 12 other leading manufacturers of the floppy disk drive in Japan and the United States had agreed to support a mutually compatible format for 3.5-inch floppy disks they market or will market in the near future. Sony said that the companies involved in the format agreement in addition to its own, were Warner Communication's Atari division, Athana, the BASF Systems Corporation, the Memorex Corporation, Media Systems Technology Inc., Shugart Associates, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the Verbatim Corporation, Wabash Datatech Inc., Xidex, the Fuji Photo Film Company Ltd. and the TDK Electroinics Company of Japan.

title: U.S. JUDGE HALTS JERSEY SCHOOL'S SILENT MINUTE
description: A Federal judge today temporarily enjoined public schools in New Jersey from beginning each day with a one-minute period of silence. The restraining order is valid until next Tuesday, when a hearing will be held to determine if the practice violates the United States Constitution.

title: CBS Murder Trial Delayed a Month
description: The trial of Donald Nash, who is accused of slaying a Federal witness and three CBS technicians at a Hudson River pier garage, was postponed yesterday until Feb. 14 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: 4 Bowls Agree To Later Bids
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 10 (AP) The Sugar, Orange, Cotton and Fiesta Bowls agreed in principle today to extend the late November date for issuing invitations to their postseason games, perhaps to as late as the first weekend in December.

title: Reporting Date May Cut Games
description: The first 30 games of baseball's exhibition schedule could be in jeopardy if the players and owners cannot work out a compromise on a reporting date for players other than pitchers and catchers.

title: Michigan Governor Freezes Hiring and Cuts School Aid
description: Gov. James Blanchard froze state hiring today and ordered that $500 million in state aid to education be delayed indefinitely because of Michigan's budget crisis.

title: ANCIENT SUN CALENDARS
description: SOME modern astronomers have long sought to show that artifacts left by ancient peoples -such stone arrays as Stonehenge in England, for example, or the rock carvings of American natives -were made to monitor the seasonal movements of the sun. The monuments investigated have most often seemed to show correspondences to four key cyclical events: the winter and summer solstices, when the sun is lowest, then highest in the sky, and the spring and vernal equinoxes when the sun crosses the Equator and the lengths of day and night are almost equal.

title: Caterpillar Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, struck for 13-weeks by the United Automobile Workers, said that 1,000 employees would be laid off indefinitely, effective Feb. 7. The action brings to 2,300 the total number of salaried workers on indefinite layoff out of a total work force of more than 48,000.

title: Israel President, in New York, Meets With Cuomo and Koch
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel met yesterday with New York officials and other leaders here at the start of a four-day visit to New York City.

title: Suit on Georgia Race Rioting Brings Warning From Judge
description: Potential jurors for the trial of Johnson County officials accused of violating black demonstrators' civil rights in 1980 were urged by a judge Monday to decide whether they could render an impartial verdict.

title: DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: When Dr. John R. Merendino was practicing orthopedic surgery in Long Branch, N.J. a few years ago, skiing was far from his mind and that of his wife, Connie. Neither knew much more than how to snowplow.

title: Key Rates
description: *Split rate, 11.00-11.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Walker to Run
description: After he hurt his shoulder during Georgia's loss to Penn State in the Sugar Bowl, it appeared that Herschel Walker might have to pass up his usual appearance in the Millrose Games, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Jan. 28. The word from Georgia yesterday was that Walker's shoulder had healed and that the Heisman Trophy winner planned to run in the 60-yard dash. He finished sixth in the event in 1981 and came in fourth last year.

title: Accounts
description: * Whitney Communications to Van Brunt & Company for the consumer and trade magazine group. * Heublein to Laurence, Charles & Free for Lancers wines.

title: EL PASO AGREES ON SALE TO BURLINGTON
description: Burlington Northern Inc. and the El Paso Company said yesterday that they had reached an agreement under which Burlington would acquire a controlling interest in El Paso for $24 a share.

title: WORTHY'S GAMBLE REAPING DIVIDENDS
description: T he direction of James Worthy's professional basketball career was not determined solely by his decision last spring to give up a final year of college eligibility and apply for the National Basketball Association draft. When his mind was made up, all Worthy knew was that he would no longer play for the North Carolina Tar Heels. Because of the way the N.B.A. chooses to admit underclassmen, there was no way for Worthy to know at the time of his choice where his new home would be and, more important, what expectations would await him there.

title: ONE VICTIM OF URUGUAY'S MILITARY REGIME
description: To the Editor:

title: Reversing Heart Disease
description: For more than a decade now, Americans have been admonished to make changes in their diets to reduce their risk of dying prematurely of a heart attack. In reviewing the advice, however, many have wondered whether sacrificing their bacon-and-eggs breakfasts, steaks and rich desserts would result in real health gains. Would life really be longer, or would it only seem that way?

title: HOW DOES THE KAYPRO COMPARE WITH OSBORNE?
description: THE portable computer revolution in the form of the Osborne 1 has been with us for a couple of years now. As numerous other manufacturers enter the fray, it becomes obvious that most of the would-be competitors have so far missed the point of the revolution. Various computer companies are bringing out portables to challenge Adam Osborne's - when portability is not the factor that made the Osborne 1 the object of a cult spreading like a weed among computer cognoscenti.

title: CHIEF OF STATE'S PRISONS: THOMAS ALOYSIUS COUGHLIN 3d
description: ''There's no doubt about who's in charge - he's the captain,'' a correction union leader said yesterday of Thomas Aloysius Coughlin 3d, the New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services.

title: U.S. IS TARGET AT NICARAGUA TALKS
description: Third world nations began a weeklong ministerial meeting here today seemingly aimed at giving Nicaragua a strong vote of support in its dispute with the United States.

title: Market Place; Stock Surge Vs. U.S. Deficit
description: THE stock market continued to confound its doubters yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average sprinted 16.28 points, reaching a record high for the third consecutive trading session.

title: REAGAN PLANS TO CERTIFY RIGHTS PROGRESS IN SALVADOR
description: Administration officials said today that despite the military crisis in El Salvador caused by the rebellion of a province commander, President Reagan plans to certify to Congress in the next few weeks that the Central American nation is making progress in human rights and political and economic changes.

title: U.S. TO FINANCE STUDY IN NEWARK ON CRIME FEARS
description: A $1.8 million Federal program designed to study the fear of crime among residents here and develop ways of reducing that fear in inner-city neighborhoods across the country was announced today by city, state and Federal officials.

title: ALDEN J. CUSICK
description: Alden J. Cusick, former director of sales of the General Outdoor Advertising Company, operator of illuminated displays, died Saturday at a nursing home in Highland Park, Ill. He was 83 years old and was a resident of Wilmette, Ill.

title: VERMEIL QUITS, SAYING HE IS 'BURNED OUT'
description: Dick Vermeil, describing himself as ''emotionally burned out'' after seven years of self-imposed workdays of 18 and 20 hours, resigned today as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: HOWARD G. SAWYER
description: Howard G. Sawyer, an advertising executive, died at his home in Stamford, Conn., last Friday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

title: Miss Caballe Is Ill
description: Montserrat Caballe has canceled her recital appearance at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night because of a viral infection, which also caused her to cancel a performance in Carnegie Hall last night. Refunds to ticket holders for the Avery Fisher Hall recital are available at the box office or by mail.

title: THE BULLHORNS OF CELL BLOCK B: RELIABLE SOURCE OF INFORMATION
description: On a day when much about the takeover in the prison here was unclear, there was one continual, and, as it turned out, reliable source of information: the bullhorns of Cell Block B.

title: Greyhound Cuts Debt $30 Million
description: The Greyhound Corporation said it had completed two leasing transactions that would reduce consolidated debt by $30 million and contribute to future operating results.

title: Nevada National Bank Elects Chief Executive
description: Paul M. Homan, a high-ranking Federal banking official, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Nevada National Bank, the third-largest commercial bank in the state.

title: No Headline
description: MEMPHIS STATE, NEW NO. 1, UPSET, 69-56

title: ARTHUR C. BRYAN
description: Arthur C. Bryan, former vice chairman of Union Carbide Middle Africa and Southern Africa, which manages the operations of the Union Carbide Corporation in those regions, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT ORDERS COLONEL TO ACCEPT A TRANSFER
description: The provisional President of El Salvador tonight ordered the rebellious commander of a northern province to comply ''immediately and without conditions'' with an order transferring him to a diplomatic post.

title: OSSINING CONVICTS FREE ALL HOSTAGES AFTER 2-DAY SIEGE
description: All 17 guards held hostage by prison inmates here for two days were freed late last night and early today after a list of demands were read over television news broadcasts.

title: Martina Navratilova Wins Final
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova easily defeated West Germany's Sylvia Hanika, 6-1, 6-1, tonight in the final of a $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament at the Capital Centre.

title: LUMBER INDUSTRY IS STIRRING
description: Winter's smoke-gray skies and steady rains are rolling across the Pacific Northwest again, but the business outlook of many executives in the region's battered forest products industry is that brighter days are ahead.

title: OSSINING IS FIRST TEST IN HOSTAGE SITUATION FOR STATE CRISIS TEAM
description: The specially trained Crisis Intervention Team handling negotiations at the Ossining Correctional Facility underwent its first test in a hostage situation since it was formed five years ago, a state corrections official said yesterday.

title: BOWLING'S APPEAL CONTINUES TO GROW
description: W hen ''Pro Bowlers Tour'' begins its 22d consecutive season Saturday afternoon on ABC with the $135,000 Miller High Life Classic from Anaheim, Calif., a pro football playoff game and the East-West Shrine college football game will be vying for viewers on other networks.

title: THE PROVEN MERIT OF JOBS PROGRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Giardello
description: Joey Giardello was the world middleweight champion from Dec. 7, 1963 to Oct. 21, 1965.

title: TANK OVERFLOW LED TO NEWARK BLAST, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The explosion and fire at a Texaco gasoline storage terminal last Friday occurred after a storage tank was filled beyond its capacity, overflowed and caused a highly volatile cloud of vapor to form outside, Newark fire officials said today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. This was to have been Michael Ray Richardson's first return to New York since he was traded to the Warriors last October, but he has a sprained ankle and did not make the trip.

title: TV: WOMAN MINER AND RAPE VICTIM
description: THE week's CBS TV movies focus on two women standing up to social forces. Tonight, at 9 o'clock, on WCBS-Channel 2, Cheryl Ladd is ''Kentucky Woman,'' and tomorrow at 9, Valerie Harper plays a New York woman, who is a victim of rape. Both have difficulty in getting the people around them to take them seriously.

title: BEN BENN, PAINTER, DIES AT 98, EARLY ADVOCATE OF CUBISM
description: Ben Benn, a Russian-born American still-life and landscape painter who was part of the first generation of artists in America to try to digest the lessons of Cubism, died Friday in Connecticut. He was 98 years old.

title: THE SHY BEAVER: POWERFUL EFFECTS ON ECOLOGY SEEN IN NEW RESEARCH
description: AFEW years ago Robert Naiman was tramping through a virgin forest in eastern Quebec, in search of a pristine stream that had run the same course for decades, untainted by pollution and untouched by man.

title: JOFFREY: 'OFFENBACH'
description: Why a ballet revival comes to life one year and does not in another is a phenomenon common to many companies. Rather than wrestle with metaphysical explanations, one has simply to state that in this respect the Joffrey has had some hits and misses this season.

title: LIBEL SUIT IS FILED AGAINST 'MISSING'
description: Nathaniel Davis, the former United States Ambassador to Chile, and two other former American officials there filed a $60 million libel suit against the makers of the critically acclaimed film ''Missing'' today in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va.

title: SOTHEBY'S SALES FALL BELOW CHRISTIE'S
description: For the first time since the 1950's, the worldwide sales of Sotheby Parke Bernet have been exceeded for part of an auction season by Christie's sales.

title: INDEXING PERSONAL INCOME TAX
description: When the far-reaching income tax cut was enacted two years ago, the new law included a provision meant to eliminate what has come to be known as ''bracket creep.''

title: SAFETY GOALS SET BY NUCLEAR PANEL
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a new statement of safety goals for the nation's nuclear power plants, despite the objections of a senior advisory group that said the standards were not stringent enough.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What makes waves at the seashore?

title: AN OLD RIVALRY WITH 'OAKLAND'
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. S aturday the Jets will be playing in Los Angeles, but they'll be playing ''Oakland.'' Even though a Federal jury permitted Al Davis to move the Raider franchise to Los Angeles this season, most pro football followers still refer to the team as Oakland, as in ''Oakland's favored by 2 1/2 points this week.'' And yesterday Walt Michaels was talking about the Jets' preparations for the Raiders in the second round of the Super Bowl XVII tournament.

title: Ayala Is Indicted On Seven Counts
description: A Passaic County grand jury today indicted Tony Ayala Jr., the junior middleweight boxer, on charges of sexually assaulting a West Paterson woman on Jan 1.

title: 'THE DENVER YANKEES?'
description: ''The court easily finds a threat of irreparable injury to the city,'' Acting Justice Richard S. Lane said yesterday of the plan to have the Yankees play their first home games in Denver. Here are excerpts from his opinion:

title: New Role for Writer
description: He has followed baseball, he has written about baseball, and now Roger Kahn is going to get a chance to put his expertise into practice - as the operator of a new baseball franchise in Cooperstown, N. Y. Kahn, best known as the author of ''The Boys of Summer,'' was chosen by the New York-Pennsylvania League to run one of two expansion clubs that will bring the Class A league to 12 teams. The other club, in Gloversville, N.Y., will be run by Dave Brunk, who is also an owner of the Fort Myers team in the Florida State League.

title: ATTICA ON THEIR MINDS
description: All the players had Attica on their minds. Even the inmates - who hung a bedsheet banner outside one barred window that read, ''We Don't Want Another Attica.''

title: Berlitz Goes to Gillespie
description: The erudite staff of Gillespie Advertising in Princeton, N.J., will next be exercising their skills on behalf of Berlitz, the network of 67 language schools. The account should bill $1 million and help put the 10-year-old shop over the $10 million-in-billings mark for 1983. The last Berlitz agency was Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: SPENDING ON 1982 CONGRESS RACES WAS A RECORD $314 MILLION
description: Campaign spending on last year's Congressional races reached $314 million by late November and broke the 1979-80 record by $75 million, according to reports issued by the Federal Election Commission.

title: Kean and Reagan Meet on Fund Plan
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey met with President Reagan today to describe his plan for a state-created Infrastructure Bank that would finance, with Federal and state funds, the construction and repair of sewage plants, roads and bridges.

title: Houston 79 S.W. Louisiana 78
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Akeem Abdul Olajuwon blocked 11 shots, including one with five seconds that preserved a victory for Houston. George Almones, a Southwestern Louisiana freshman, who had 20 points, , attempted a 20-footer that was blocked by Olajuwon.

title: Business and the Law; Conglomerates: Test for Labor
description: WORKER solidarity is what unions are all about. But one of the most important legal questions in a new union campaign against Litton Industries is how much management solidarity there is at a multinational conglomerate.

title: President of Hicks Comments on Industry
description: D. Edward Ricchiuto, president of Hicks & Greist, has some thoughts on last Tuesday's column of comments by high-ranking creative leaders on the state of their advertising art.

title: 3 Climbers Die in Scotland
description: Three climbers missing since Saturday on Bachaille Etive mountain near Glencoe were found dead today, the police said. The two Englishmen and a Scotsman, all aged 23, apparently fell to their deaths.

title: Supreme Court to Rule On Depletion Allowance
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether producers of oil and natural gas may claim a depletion allowance on their Federal tax returns for years during which no production takes place.

title: LOOK WHO'S RUNNING FOR PRESIDENT
description: Nell K. Fiola has been testing the waters for a shot at the Presidency in 1984, but she says that all she finds is ice.

title: Sensormatic Plan
description: The Sensormatic Electronics Corporation has tentatively agreed to acquire the MSI Data Corporation in a $100 million deal, the companies announced.

title: Officer Shifts Made by ABC
description: The American Broadcasting Companies formally announced yesterday that Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president, has been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Advertising; Campbell's Spends Big On O-Pasta
description: O, House Speaker O'Neill or Peter O'Toole, has introduced a new advertising campaign that, at first glance, seems a little less O-positive.

title: Louisiana Abductor Silent
description: The authorities said today that they were baffled by nearly five days of silence from an abductor who dragged Aubrey LeHaye, an elderly financier, from his home and demanded $500,000 for his safe return.

title: To New York, With Love
description: THERE is no keeping up with the inimitable Brooke Astor, the philanthropist extraordinaire. She tore back from a Florida holiday especially for Mildred Hilson's elegant black-tie dinner the other night, and, having been presented with an occasion, she rose to it.

title: MANHATTAN COMMUNITY COLLEGE GETS A HOME AT LAST
description: After nearly 20 years of wandering in the midtown wilderness, the Borough of Manhattan Community College moved into new, campuslike quarters near the World Trade Center yesterday.

title: 'TOOTSIE' LEADS THE PACK OF CHRISTMAS FILM HITS
description: During the monthlong Christmas season that ended Sunday, moviegoers bought some $300 million worth of tickets and provided Hollywood with one runaway hit, one surprising success story and one unexpected disaster.

title: RETAILERS, AT MEETING, PREDICT 2-3% SALES GAIN
description: Retail sales, in real terms, will rise 2 to 3 percent this year over 1982, speakers predicted yesterday at the opening session of a national retailing meeting here. But they estimated that sales in the 1982 retailing year, which concludes at the end of January, would fall 1 percent from the previous year.

title: National Distillers To Buy Suburban
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation for an estimated $275 million in cash.

title: Mancini to Fight Briton
description: Ray Mancini, the lightweight champion of the World Boxing Association, has signed to fight Britain's George Feeney in a 10-round nontitle bout set for Feb. 6 in Saint Vincent, Italy.

title: EDUCATION
description: NEW YORK CITY has 55,000 public school teachers, more than the states of Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, Nevada, New Hampshire, North Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming combined. Last week, when the city school system threatened to lay off 1,800 teachers to cope with a budget deficit, some observers were unsure just how serious such a loss would be.

title: RATES MIXED IN SLOW TRADING
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday for issues due in eight years and less but were unchanged to slightly higher for long-term bonds.

title: JURY TRIAL BEGINS FOR YOUNG MAN ACCUSED OF 3 MAIN LINE SLAYINGS
description: A prosecutor, opening his court case today in the murders of the former chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, his wife and their housekeeper, outlined a chain of circumstantial evidence that, he said, would prove the slayings were committed by the crime-prone son of a well-to-do Pottstown family.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Congressman's Medal

title: True Masters
description: During the 1982 tennis season, 460 players took part in the Grand Prix men's singles tour, but the 12 who will take part in the Volvo Grand Prix Masters tournament next week at Madison Square Garden won 45 of the 80 tournaments last year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUPPETBILIA

title: REAGAN SET TO GO AHEAD WITH FARM SURPLUS PLAN
description: President Reagan is expected to announce Tuesday that his Administration will initiate a ''payment in kind'' program for farmers without waiting for Congress to pass certain enabling legislation he wanted last month.

title: BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Sent Mike O'Ber- r y, catcher who played last season with A AA team in Indianapolis, to Angels for J ohn Harris, first baseman. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Took Kelly Tri- p ucka off the injured list and allowed the 1 0-day contract of James Wilkes, forward, t o expire.

title: BAKER REPORTED PLANNING TO QUIT SENATE AFTER '84
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, has told his top aides that he will retire from the Senate when his term ends in December 1984, two of the aides said today.

title: Judge Orders Shift Of Brink's Suspect
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Rockland County authorities to relinquish custody of a Brink's defendant to Federal authorities next Monday.

title: Kodak Cutback
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which two weeks ago offered employees a voluntary incentive plan to trim its payroll, said that it was laying off 1,100 workers at its apparatus division. The division makes such equipment as camera bodies, microfilm processors and projectors. The cutbacks would not affect workers involved in the manufacture of Ekta print copiers or the new Disc camera.

title: Chile Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved an $882.5 million loan to Chile over the next two years to help that country repay heavy foreign debts.

title: No Headline
description: White Defends Record In Reaction to Article

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHAT does new mean? And who, everyone wanted to know, qualifies as n ew talent? That was the burning issue last week at a lunch meeting a s the jurors of the Council of Fashion Designers of America gatheredt o decide who in the fashion world should receive that organization'ss econd annual awards.

title: Trial Set for 3 On Exports
description: Two men, one of them a former C.I.A. agent, pleaded not guilty today to charges of violating the Export Administration Act. They and another man, all indicted last week, are accused of conspiring to ship a $5 million diesel-engine assembly line to the Soviet Union.

title: Letter: On the Appeals Court Judges Are Better Elected Than Selected
description: To the Editor:

title: Honor for Net
description: The recent efforts of Mickey Johnson, who has emerged as the Nets' emotional leader during the winning streak, earned him the selection yesterday as the N.B.A.'s Player of the Week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Yankee pin stripes belong to New York like Central Park, like the Statue of Liberty, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, like the Metropolitan Opera, like the Stock Exchange, like the lights of Broadway, etc.

title: Pension Panel Member Says Accord Isn't Near
description: The President's Commission on Social Security is still far from an agreement, despite recent behind-thescenes negotiations on such issues as imposing a tax on some retirees' benefits, panel members said today.

title: ON SHORT NOTICE
description: JULIUS RUDEL made the very best of a potentially bad situation Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The American Symphony Orchestra was to have been conducted by Giuseppe Patane, but Mr. Patane, suffering from pleurisy in Italy and unable to travel, had to cancel.

title: U.S. Declines a Stand On St. Louis Busing Plan
description: The Reagan Administration refused today to take a position on whether school districts in St. Louis's predominantly white suburbs should be forced to participate in a desegregation plan with the city.

title: Walter E. Cooke Is Dead at 72; Was Legislator From Brooklyn
description: Walter E. Cooke, a former member of the New York State Assembly and the New York State Senate, died on Dec. 31 at Community Hospital of Brooklyn of a respiratory infection. He was 72 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: AS TREMORS PERSIST, GEOLOGISTS MOVE IN
description: TEAMS of geologists and seismologists were surveying the snowcovered slopes and valleys around Mammoth Lakes, Calif., yesterday in an effort to assess the chances that the continuing earthquakes there might trigger a major volcanic eruption.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 11, 1983; The Economy
description: President Reagan will probably accept a special package of contingency tax increases if budget deficits are not declining sharply enough by 1985, according to Administration officials. (Page A1.) Despite widespread opposition, Mr. Reagan may also propose a tax on health insurance benefits, a White House adviser said. (B9.)

title: Klugman Takes Role Pitching Steak-Umms
description: It is not hard to believe that advertisers who hire actors long associated with physician roles - such as Robert Young - are hoping for a subliminal medical endorsement for their product to seep through.

title: ANDROPOV'S IGNORED OFFER ON CONVENTIONAL ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Record Lives
description: Keith Lincoln had not heard that he still held the record for the most yards gained rushing in a National Football League playoff game. But then, he did not realize it had ostensibly been broken Sunday by Freeman McNeil of the Jets.

title: Kim Says He'll Go Home After Medical Care
description: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition figure, said in Manhattan yesterday that he hoped to return to his country after undergoing medical treatment in the United States and that until his return he would dedicate himself to ''the democratic aspirations of the Korean people and the struggle for human rights.''

title: Connecticut Aide Pleads Not Guilty
description: Arthur B. Powers, a former State Transportation Commissioner, pleaded not guilty today to six corruption charges as his attorney raised the possibility of calling Gov. William A. O'Neill to testify.

title: Juilliard Plans Festival Of Contemporary Music
description: The Juilliard School will present a free Festival of Contemporary Music from Jan. 21 through Jan. 25. There will be five concerts at the Juilliard Theater and at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Anti-Semitic Incidents Found to Drop in Year
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday that the number of anti-Semitic incidents in the United States declined 14.9 percent in 1982 after increasing for three years.

title: LOUISIANA ELECTION SIGNALS END TO DELTA DYNASTY
description: For more than 60 years the ardently racist Judge Leander Perez and his sons ran the mineralrich Plaquemines Parish like a third world dictatorship and injected their influence into state and national politics.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Epiphany Celebrates 150 Epiphanies

title: Met Prospect Drowning Victim
description: The Mets were informed yesterday that Richard Webster, a 23-yearold pitcher in their minor league system, drowned with three companions over the weekend when their boat capsized on the Mississippi River near Memphis during a duck-hunting trip.

title: Suffolk Suspects Horse Druggings
description: Officials at Suffolk Downs are awaiting results of blood tests to determine whether horses were drugged in an attempt to rig Sunday's ninth-race feature, which was canceled after the behavior of several horses had caused suspicion.

title: Exxon Price Cut
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said that it had reduced by one-half cent in various parts of the nation the posted wholesale price for distillate fuel, including heating oil and diesel fuel. The Exxon unit said that prices had been lowered at its operations in the Northeast, Middle Atlantic region, Southeast and Gulf Coast. The company said that net posted prices in New York Harbor remained 84.50 cents a gallon for barge loads and 84.80 cents for cargoes.

title: 'Alice' Closes
description: ''Alice In Wonderland'' closed after the Sunday matinee at the Virginia Theater. The musical, directed by Eva Le Gallienne and starring Kate Burton, ran for 21 performances and 18 previews.

title: WHAT THE AMERASIAN ACT IS NOT MEANT TO DO
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. Says It Attacked Bus
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization took responsibility today for a grenade attack on a bus in Tel Aviv on Saturday in which 12 Israelis were wounded.

title: Zulu Chief Says the U.S.  Gave 'a Slap in the Face'
description: The leader of South Africa's largest political organization for blacks has criticized the United States State Department for endorsing a decision by a South African mixedrace party to accept a Government offer of token political representation in a revised parliamentary system.

title: RICHARD C. BRADLEY
description: Richard C. Bradley, a writer on boating, died of cancer Monday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford.

title: TANKS FOR THE ARMY: WHY THE NEW M-1 SHOULD PREVAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects for Hall
description: The results of one of the most wide-open elections in the 45-year history of baseball's Hall of Fame will be announced today, and Brooks Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles and Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants are expected to have outpolled 44 other candidates. Robinson, a star third baseman for 23 years, is one of 23 former players making the ballot for the first time.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK AND U.N. SKIRMISHING AGAIN
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and the United Nations are skirmishing again. Mrs. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, said in an interview that she saw some ''disturbing directions in U.N. practices which are deeply worrisome.'' She cited what she described as an ''erosion of restraint'' in spending money and a breach in ''the principle of universality,'' the prime example being an effort to oust Israel from the General Assembly.

title: Quote Annoys the President
description: President Reagan apparently is upset that he was quoted as saying that he ''had it up to my keister'' with unauthorized disclosures to reporters.

title: News Analysis
description: In an apparent effort to improve her standing among blacks here, Mayor Jane M. Byrne has appointed a black lawyer to the board of the Chicago Housing Authority and ordered the dismantling of iron gates that have helped keep adjacent black and white neighborhoods segregated.

title: Some Needed Humor
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Congratulations on bringing us Jean Kerr (''Trouble With Names? Not Me,'' Dec. 22)! I would like to thank you for such a delightful Christmas gift.

title: ARTHUR C. BRYAN
description: Arthur C. Bryan, former vice chairman of Union Carbide Middle Africa and Southern Africa, which manages the operations of the Union Carbide Corporation in those regions, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: REGAN PREPARING TAX REFORM PLANS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is preparing two sweeping tax reform proposals for possible inclusion in President Reagan's State of the Union address, although legislation to put them into effect might be delayed until 1984, Administration officials said today.

title: First Heal, Then Cut
description: Annual income 20, annual expenditure nineteen nineteen six, result happiness. Annual income 20, annual expenditure 20 ought and six, result misery. - Mr. Micawber, in ''David Copperfield.'' The prospect of a $200 billion Federal deficit spells political misery for a President who pledged to balance the 1984 budget. So desperate is the White House to trim the deficit that Caspar Weinberger now talks of cuts even in defense spending. But at the moment, the deficit is the wrong goal. The right one is economic health. What worked for Mr. Micawber has little relevance to the recession-racked American economy. Far from it: a deficit of $200 billion, or more, is needed to promote recovery.

title: Donations Defended
description: In trying to raise almost $80 million for its effort in next year's Games at Los Angeles, the United States Olympic Committee has been receiving donations from manufacturers of such products as candy and beer. This has produced some criticism from anti-alcohol and antijunk-food groups, but yesterday Bob Mathias, the two-time Olympic decathlon champion who heads the Olympic training center in Colorado Springs, defended the practice of signing up such corporate sponsors.

title: 'SLOW ATTACK,' A GERMAN IMPORT
