description: ''SLOW ATTACK'' (original title: ''Endstation Freiheit'') is a handsome, vivid, emotionally disorienting German film about a tough, youngish hoodlum named Nik Dellmann, who has the battered face of a boxer too long in the ring and who yearns to be a writer.

title: Pitchers Favored In Baseball Draft
description: Pitchers dominated baseball's 18th winter amateur draft yesterday, with 17 being chosen on the first round of the regular phase.

title: MOSCOW CLARIFIES MISSILE PROPOSAL
description: Visiting members of the United States Congress said today that they had been told by Soviet arms negotiators that Moscow would consider the destruction of some SS-20 missiles after withdrawing them from Europe as part of an accord.

title: Venture Is Redesigned
description: Joseph D. Giarraputo has been through a lot with his magazine, Venture, which he created for the entrepreneur.

title: Prices Worry Retailers
description: The public's faith in the credibility of prices of both branded and unbranded merchandise is wearing thin under the continuing wave of price-cutting under way in many stores, retailers agreed at a trade meeting in New York yesterday.

title: 3 SAID TO DIE IN LEBANON SHELLING
description: Artillery duels broke out today southeast of Beirut between Lebanese Christian and Druse militiamen near the presidential palace, reportedly killing three people and wounding nine.

title: INFORMATION ACT GETS NEW FEE RULE
description: The Reagan Administration, which has unsuccessfully urged Congress to narrow the Freedom of Information Act, is moving to cut the number of requests under the act that are granted free of charge.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Most turnips purchased in supermarkets and grocery stores are coated with wax, presumably to make them less perishable. Would you recommend scraping off this wax before cooking? I sometimes find it easier to peel certain vegetables after parboiling.

title: REBELIOUS SALVADOR COMMANDER AND FAVORITE OF THE RIGHT:SIGIFREDO OCHOA PEREZ
description: When Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez refused last week to accept the orders transferring him from his post as commander of the northern province of Cabanas to be military attache in Uruguay, it was not the first time that he had been at odds with the Government.

title: Colgate Weighing Role in Playoffs
description: Students, faculty and members of the athletic department at Colgate University are busy this week reviewing the question of whether to allow some of the school's sports teams to participate in postseason tournaments, particularly if they conflict with final examinations.

title: Market Place; The Nature Of Warrants
description: THE Chrysler Corporation's common stock was a huge winner on the New York Stock Exchange last year, starting out just above $3 a share and climbing above $18. But, percentagewise, Chrysler's warrants did even better, jumping from a low of 1 1/8 to a high of 10 1/2.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE LAST HERO. Wild Bill Donovan. By Anthony Cave Brown. 891 pages. Illus- trated. Times Books. $24.95.

title: DOCTORS HOPEFUL ON RELEASING HEART PATIENT
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's condition has improved to the point where he might leave the hospital as early as three weeks from now, but with ''significant lung and kidney impairment,'' his doctors said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CENTRAL PARK isn't exactly the Old West, despite the presence of horses and the persistent rumors that all those Western-cowboy cigarette ads were photographed near 90th Street next to the reservoir. Recently, however, the park - not unlike Tombstone or Dodge City - was the setting for what can only be described as a roundup of strays by a posse.

title: Swann Is Retiring
description: He took gymnastics and dance lessons as a child, and it was only a ''fluke,'' he says, that he ever became a football player in the first place. But once he got started, Lynn Swann proved pretty good at it, and last season, his ninth with the Pittsburgh Steelers, he became the top career pass receiver in the team's history. Yesterday Swann announced that he was retiring, to become a commentator for ABC's telecasts of United States Football League games.

title: PLAYERS CALL RETURN INEVITABLE
description: The return of Billy Martin was greeted by the Yankee players yesterday as a kind of historical imperative that transcended the manager's often turbulent relations with his team.

title: Portuguese Agree On a New Coalition
description: Portugal's ruling right-wing alliance reached basic agreement today on a new coalition Government to be led by a former Education Minister, Vitor Crespo.

title: NEW ENVIRONMENT CHIEF AN OLD HAND IN ALBANY
description: When official word of his appointment as Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation finally came, Henry G. Williams was without an office. To make room for staff members moving in with the new administration, he had relinquished his desk in the Lieutenant Governor's office and spent some time at home, studying the organizational manual of the department he would head.

title: TWO BOOKS ON THE BEST BOTTLINGS OF ITALY
description: THE wines of Italy have been receiving a lot of attention from consumers all over the world in recent years and now account for close to 60 percent of the Americn market for imported wine. Their popularity and diversity have inspired literary efforts, with several new or recent books on the subject.

title: ARAB WOUNDED IN JERUSALEM
description: An Arab was seriously wounded when a bomb exploded outside the Old City's walls this afternoon, a police spokesman said.

title: U.P.I. REPORTER IN POLAND IS BEING HELD BY THE POLICE
description: The United Press International bureau chief and a secretary for the news service were being held tonight in the central police station for questioning about what the police said were possible ''crimes against the state.''

title: MUSICIAN'S PORTRAIT
description: THERE are musicians whose work can't easily be encapsulated by the documentary film format, and there are others, like Gil Scott-Heron, who make a particularly keen impression this way. ''Black Wax,'' a 79-minute portrait of Mr. Scott-Heron made for British television, shows him off to excellent advantage.

title: Canada Surplus Shrinks
description: Canada's trade surplus in November narrowed to a seasonally adjusted $1.567 billion (Canadian) from $1.66 billion in October, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: Teamster Aide Indicted In New Kickback Case
description: Allen M. Dorfman, a Chicago insurance man and longtime associate of teamster union officials, and four others were charged today in a Federal grand jury indictment with engaging in a kickback scheme to defraud two culinary unions.

title: PRIME CUT HALF-POINT, TO 11%
description: The nation's leading banks, in an action that lagged considerably behind a sharp drop in the cost of their own funds, lowered their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 11 percent.

title: TV: LIFE IN A COSTA RICAN RAIN FOREST
description: NATURE photographers perform their wonders once again in ''Rain Forest,'' the National Geographic Society special that can be seen on WNET-Channel 13 at 8 tonight. In the sure hands of David and Carol Hughes, the cameras move deep within the dense growths of a Costa Rican rain forest to capture the cycles of life in its sunless depths. We find ourselves within touching distance of a brilliantly colored coral snake shedding its skin. We witness the happy culmination of frog courtships. Not only can we scrutinize every blotch on a beetle, but we can also watch the pseudo-scorpions prey on the mites that ride on the beetle's back.

title: Ossining Hostages And Day of Release
description: Following is a list of the Ossining hostages in order of their release: Released Saturday WAY, Lowell D., age and residence unavailable. Released 3:30 A.M. Sunday PERYEA, Patrick, Ossining, age unavaila ble.

title: Early I.M.F. Meeting
description: The International Monetary Fund's top policy-making body, the Interim Committee, is expected to meet in Washington on Feb.10-11, nearly three months earlier than originally planned.

title: THE MARTIN YEARS; ENTERING ERA III
description: A ll the logic says George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin can't work together. History says they will be at each other's throats by the All-Star Game. Intuition says Steinbrenner is going for the quick fix, to provide ''great copy for a lot of you folks - a great story for New York,'' as he put it yesterday.

title: SUSPECT, 18, KILLS HIMSELF
description: The music teacher at the high school here was shot and killed outside the schoolMonday night while adult-education classes and a volleyball game were under way inside.

title: PSA-Braniff Jobs
description: Former employees of the Braniff International Corporation, thrown out of work when the airline shut down May 12 and filed for bankruptcy protection, have begun receiving letters inviting them to apply for jobs with Pacific Southwest Airlines' proposed Texas division. PSA, under an agreement with Braniff, plans to lease some Braniff jets and use Braniff airport facilities and regulatory clearances in its Texas division. A PSA spokesman, William Hastings, said the company believed former Braniff employees would fill most of the 1,500 positions available in the new division.

title: Article 158698 -- No Title
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that Alitalia, Italy's national airline, had agreed to purchase 30 DC-9 Super 80 jets for a total price of more than $1 billion.

title: Nepal Arrests Proselytizer
description: Ganesh Lama, 22 years old, has been arrested for converting people to Christanity, a crime in this predominantly Hindu kingdom, Nepal's national news agency said today.

title: BOND PRICES RESIST CHANGE
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but market participants said there was still no sign of the investor demand needed to raise bond prices and reduce yields significantly.

title: DETAILS ON FED DATA THEFT
description: The first known theft of secret data on the nation's money supply from the Federal Reserve Board's computers was discovered because an alert employee questioned the apparent use of the computer by a fellow employee who was then on vacation.

title: Miss McKinney Slalom Winner
description: Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., overcame Erika Hess of Switzerland and won a slalom ski race today, the sixth victory of her World Cup career and the second by an American woman in two days. On Monday, Cindy Nelson won a supergiant slalom at Verbier.

title: Mellon Income Shows Increase
description: The Mellon National Corporation, the nation's 15th-largest bank holding company and the owner of the Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter net operating income rose 6.4 percent, to $40.6 million, or $2.06 a share, from $38.2 million, or $1.94 a share, in the 1981 period.

title: WEINBERGER URGES CUT OF $8 BILLION IN '84 ARMS RACE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger announced today that he had recommended to President Reagan an $8 billion reduction in military spending proposed for 1984 to help cut the projected Federal deficit of about $200 billion.

title: ZUNGAL OF ARROWS PLACED ON WAIVERS
description: Steve Zungul, the Major Indoor Soccer League's most prolific scorer ever, was placed on waivers yesterday by the New York Arrows. Team officials said that Zungul, a forward who has scored a league record of 372 career goals, would remain on M.I.S.L. waivers for 72 hours ''to see if there is any interest in this league.'' If Zungul clears waivers, Arrows officials said, he will be traded to a North American Soccer League team within the week.

title: VERSATILE STEAMERS
description: IN kitchens where storage space is a precious ingredient - and in New York that means the vast majority - it is important to consider multiple uses when buying cooking utensils.

title: Officer's Adopted Son In a 2d Suicide Threat
description: A teen-age runaway who was coaxed off a ledge in 1981 by a New York City police officer and was later adopted by the officer, yesterday taped a fake bomb to his chest and threatened to blow himself up on a busy Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN the past few years the cooks of this country have become far more creative and adventurous than ever before. They seem more willing to go far afield in the uses of herbs and spices and the matching of textures and flavors.

title: WARNER NAMES HEAD OF ELEKTRA RECORD UNIT
description: Warner Communications Inc. has announced that Bob Krasnow, vice president of Warner Bros. Records, has been named chairman of Elektra/Asylum Records. Both companies are units of Warner.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway runs from St. George to Tottenville, a funny hybrid of a train, part subway, part railroad. It is called simply the SIRT by some, and the Toonerville Trolley by others, in an expression of backhanded affection.

title: WHEN THE 'BLEAK' WAS CHIC SOMEWHERE
description: SALLY GREEN was tired of being seated in Siberia. She had so often been placed in the immediate vicinity of swinging kitchen doors that her shoulders were black and blue. She had gained many pounds from chewing on rolls during endless waiting for a waiter to bring food or a check. ''Why is he called a waiter,'' Sally asked bitterly, ''when I do all the waiting?''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: UNDERCOVER STORY

title: Careers; Penn State Team's Majors
description: IT takes a lot of meat and potatoes to feed the 26 members of the Penn State football team (11 offensive players and 11 defensive players plus four kicking and receiving specialists).

title: CREW OF 3 KILLED IN DETROIT CRASH ON UNITED AIRLINES CARGO JET
description: A DC-8 cargo plane carrying five pounds of low-level radioactive material and more than two tons of mail crashed in a swamp seconds after takeoff today, killing the jet's three crewmen.

title: Canal-Randolph
description: Asher Edelman said he and a shareholder, Eugene Eichenberg, had sued the Canal-Randolph Corporation, its chairman and others, charging violations of Federal securities laws and breaches of fiduciary duties. Mr. Edelman had previously said that he intended to wage a proxy contest for control of Canal-Randolph at its March 9 meeting. The suit charges the defendants with failing to disclose reportedly secret beneficial ownership of a large block of Canal-Randolph shares by the company's chairman, Sir Walter H. Salomon. Canal-Randolp is involved in real estate and stockyards.

title: Search Continues
description: Bill Walsh said yesterday that he would give up his job as coach of the San Francisco 49ers - but only if he could find the ''right man'' to take his place. And by his own account, that might not be an easy task. Walsh, who plans to retain his post as general manager, said that he had approached two prospects - Mike White of Illinois and John Robinson, the recently retired coach of Southern California -and that both men had turned him down.

title: 76ers 109, Hawks 99
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Moses Malone scored 31 points to lead Philadelphia to its eighth straight victory. Malone scored a pair of layups, one with 1:48 left in the game and the next with 1:16 remaining, to break open what had been a close game.

title: U.S. HINTS JORDAN IS READY TO TALK
description: Administration officials said today that they were counting on King Hussein of Jordan to declare his readiness to join in negotiations on Palestinian self-rule by the end of next month, provided he receives stronger backing than he has received up to now from Saudi Arabia.

title: Mildred Considine, 79, Dies; Writer on Society and Travel
description: Mildred A. Considine, a writer and the wife of Robert Considine, the late newspaper columnist, died yesterday of a heart attack. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEW LEADER IS SWORN IN BY NAVAJO INDIAN NATION
description: Before a crowd estimated at 8,000 people, the Navajo Indian nation inaugurated its 10th tribal chairman today, ending 12 years of rule by Peter MacDonald.

title: N.C.A.A. TIGHTENS ELIGIBILITY
description: Despite strong opposition from the 16 predominantly black colleges in Division I, the other major football and basketball schools overwhelmingly approved today the establishment of a minimum grade on college entrance examinations for a student to be eligible for intercollegiate sports in his freshman year.

title: Civil Servant Slain in Sicily
description: Gunmen shot a civil servant to death in the center of Palermo today in the first Mafia killing of 1983, the police said. Last year, 151 people were known to have died in bloodshed between rival clans in Sicily, and about the same number were reported missing.

title: FOR A TRADE POLICY FOUNDED ON REALISM
description: When the Senate Finance Committee holds trade hearings later this month, farmers in Kansas, auto makers in Michigan, scientists in Silicon Valley in California and Wall Street bankers will follow them carefully. Will they hear more than rhetoric about free trade from economic theorists and more than protectionist pleading from special-interest groups? Or will the Administration seize the day and begin to fashion an effective trade policy for the 1980's?

title: SHAKEOUT IN ROBOT INDUSTRY
description: The robotics industry, squeezed by competition and a recessionbattered market, is bracing for a shakeout. Some industry leaders think it has already begun.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Come Again?

title: CRACKS IN THE WALLS OF AMERICA'S 'BABY DAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT is a fallacy to believe that organized medicine chests, bureau drawers and closets are the ultimate proof of neatness. That they make life easier and are beautiful to behold cannot be denied but all this indicates only second-degree neatness. The ultimate test in the neat category is an address book.

title: Ford Plant Closing
description: The Ford Motor Company said its last operating assembly plant in California will close May 20, idling nearly 2,400 workers.

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1983; The Economy
description: Leading banks, in an action that lagged behind the drop in the cost of their funds, lowered their prime lending rates by half a point, to 11 percent. They cited doubts about the cost of new money market accounts and the possibility of large losses from loan defaults. The banks had been paying about 8 1/2 percent for their funds and charging corporate customers 11 1/2 percent and more. (Page D1.)

title: 'CAN'T TAKE IT WITH YOU' IS BOUNCING BACK TO LIFE
description: Alice Sycamore and Tony Kirby have decided to marry, and the terribly proper Kirbys are supposed to meet the Sycamores tomorrow night. Right now, Mrs. Sycamore is painting a toga-clad Mr. DePinna, who came to deliver ice eight years ago and never left. A Sycamore daughter is pirouetting around the living room to ''Scheherazade'' under the direction of her Russian emigre dancing teacher, who is largely naked. An actress that Mrs. Sycamore met on the bus and brought home has passed out, dead drunk, on the sofa. A day early, in walk the horrified Kirbys, in full evening dress.

title: MCI Net Soars 63.9%, to Peak
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that its net income in its fiscal third quarter ended Dec. 31 surged 63.9 percent, to a record $43.6 million, or 44 cents a share, from $26.6 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Ethics and Off-Duty Police
description: ''I am not in a position to direct individuals not to attend this proposed function,'' wrote a New York City Police Inspector, Aaron Rosenthal, on learning that officers under his supervision planned to attend a fund-raising party for several policemen indicted in a bribery investigation. ''I would assume,'' he added, ''any member who attends this assemblage must lack good judgment and proper decisionmaking ability.'' The letter was labeled ''Policy Statement'' and a threat of punishment was explicit. Eight officers ignored it.

title: Saudis May Give $6 Billion to I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to receive $6 billion in new credits from Saudi Arabia to bolster its financial resources, monetary officials said today.

title: SHARON DISMISSES IRAQI'S REMARK ON SECURITY
description: A recently disclosed statement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq on the need to create ''a state of security for the Israelis'' was dismissed today by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon as an effort ''to buy public opinion in order to receive American support against the Iranians in their war.''

title: EX-EDITOR OF BUSINESS WEEK
description: Elliott V. Bell, former editor and publisher of Business Week magazine, died yesterday at his home in Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y. He was 80 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.

title: RIGGS BANK CHAIRMAN LEAVES TO PRACTICE LAW
description: Vincent C. Burke, chairman of the Riggs National Bank in Washington since 1976, has resigned. He is the third senior executive to leave the bank since its controlling shareholder, Joseph L. Allbritton of Texas, became chief executive officer last September.

title: Thomson Press Adds Magazine
description: International Thomson Business Press is proving that just because it usually buys existing magazines that does not mean it cannot start one from scratch.

title: Population in the U.S.  Is Put at 232.6 Million
description: Census Bureau statisticians estimate that there were 232.6 million people in the United States on New Year's Day, an increase of more than 2.1 million from a year earlier.

title: THEATER: 'NIGHT, MOTHER' AT HARVARD
description: IT seems like just an ordinary night in an ordinary house in some ordinary Middle-American neighborhood. Jessie Cates (Kathy Bates) and Thelma (Anne Pitoniak), her widowed mother, are rattling around their living room, getting ready for another evening of dinner, crocheting and idle talk. But only a few minutes into Marsha Norman's new play, '' 'Night, Mother,'' Jessie makes a calm but shattering announcement. ''I'm going to kill myself, Mom,'' she says.

title: 9, INCLUDING 4 POLICEMEN, ACCUSED OF GAIN IN STOCK DATA MISUSE
description: Nine men, including four New York City police officers, were accused in a Federal lawsuit yesterday of fraudulently obtaining more than $1 million in profits by using ''insider'' information to buy and sell stocks.

title: ECONOMIC PURPLE HEARTS
description: THE CURRENT recession drags on, with a month of 10.8 per-cent unemployment just past. As the stop-go hard times reach their fourth calendar year, the victims of this necessary and indeed long-overdue economic slowdown seem to me to have accrued a special claim on the nation's sympathies and support. In the case of this extremely unusual recession, its victims - the unemployed, the homeless, the bankrupt businessmen and farmers - have a claim much like that of the victims and veterans of wars. That claim has been largely unanswered and therein lies a basic inequity.

title: Coast Women's Leader Arrested in Murder Case
description: The California president of the National Organization for Women and a prominent Democratic Party activist was arrested today on a 1965 Louisiana murder warrant.

title: SCHWEIKER RESIGNS POST IN CABINET TO JOIN AN INSURANCE ASSOCIATION
description: Secretary of Health and Human Services Richard S. Schweiker has resigned to take a job with the American Council on Life Insurance, an industry trade association, the White House announced tonight.

title: On Winter Vegetables
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The omission of collards from your list of winter vegetables (''The Art of Transforming Winter Vegetables,'' Dec. 22) can only encourage the suspicion in these parts that your writers are more rooted in asphalt than in the soil. YANCEY S. GILKERSON Greenville, S.C.

title: Bereavement Programs
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The Personal Health column (Nov. 24) discussing programs that provide humane treatment for the terminally ill highlighted an area too long overlooked by both the media and the general public.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've done this before and I'd rather take my chances with someone I've been down the road with before rather than someone new.'' - George Steinbrenner discussing Billy Martin. (A1:3.)

title: CONSERVATION EXPERT IS DISMISSED BY U.S. AFTER DENIAL OF STAY
description: The Reagan Administration today dismissed Maxine Savitz, the Government's top energy conservation expert, on one hour's notice. The dismissal came less than a day after the Merit Systems Protection Board refused a request to delay the dismissal

title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN WEAPON RAIDS IN NORTH JERSEY
description: Fifteen men, including a Hackensack police officer, were arrested yesterday in a series of raids in northern New Jersey that culminated a 10-month investigation into the sale of illegal firearms and explosives.

title: PENTAGON BUDGET PLANNING CRITICIZED BY 2 STUDIES
description: The large military budgets planned by the Reagan Administration will probably not increase the weapons and fighting abililty of United States armed forces because Pentagon planners have consistently and seriously underestimated the costs of weapons, two studies have concluded.

title: THE PASTA COURSE
description: I know how President Reagan feels about wanting to stay the course because I always stay the course myself when panicky heads are pleading with me to change the course.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. of Greenwich, Conn., said the merger of Penncorp into its Associated Madison Companies Inc. unit had been approved by the shareholders of both companies.

title: FALCONS JOIN EFFORT
description: The Atlanta Falcons have joined the attempt to sack Ed Garvey as head of the National Football League Players Association.

title: ITALIAN JUDGE INSPECTS APARTMENT OF SUSPECT IN BULGARIAN CASE
description: The judge heading an investigation into whether there was Bulgarian involvement in the 1981 attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II today inspected the apartment of a Bulgarian airline agent who is held on suspicion of complicity.

title: DELAYED FORMS MADE AVAILABLE FOR COLLEGE AID
description: The College Scholarship Service of the College Board announced yesterday that after a series of delays, applications for student aid are finally available. The board urged students and their parents to fill them out as quickly as possible.

title: INCOME-TAX WRONG IN NEED OF RIGHTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Stokely-Van Camp
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc., a producer of canned and frozen foods, said two suits had been filed against it in an effort to prevent a proposal by an investor group to take the company private. The suits, both filed in the Superior Court of Marion County, Ind., charged that the price proposed in the bid, $50 a share, was inadequate. Stokely-Van Camp shares closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $48.125, unchanged.

title: DESPITE INJUNCTION, 64 BLOCK SITE OF WATER PROJECT AND ARE ARRESTED
description: The police today arrested 64 demonstrators who blocked construction workers from the site of a proposed water pumping station here.

title: 6 Die at Brazilian Asylum
description: Six people were killed in a gunfight between riot policemen firing submachine guns and 25 armed inmates of an overcrowded mental institution, the police said. One of two guards taken hostage when the mutiny at Franco da Rocha began Sunday evening was killed by the rioters, the police said.

title: Walter E. Cooke Is Dead at 72; Ex-Assemblyman and Senator
description: Walter E. Cooke, a former member of the New York State Assembly and the New York State Senate, died on Dec. 31 at Community Hospital of Brooklyn of a respiratory infection. He was 72 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Lloyd's of London
description: Ian Posgate today won his high court battle against a decision of the committee of Lloyd's of London to suspend him indefinitely as an underwriter, the British news agency press association said. Mr. Posgate had been suspended from underwriting after Alexander & Alexander Services made allegations against him and four directors of the Alexander Howden Group, which A.& A. bought last year. But The association added that the court's decision did not automatically entitle Mr. Posgate to return to underwriting.

title: Decatur Pump Co.
description: The Decatur Pump Company, a maker of pumps used in residential wells and industrial processes, has been acquired by a company owned by the vice president for manufacturing of Decatur Pump and backers in New York.

title: JETS WILL AVOID HOLLYWOOD DISTRACTIONS
description: Coach Walt Michaels is as concerned by what he calls ''the distractions of Hollywood'' as he is by the Los Angeles Raiders, the team in black that is the Jets' next obstacle in the Super Bowl tournament.

title: PLEASURES OF THE JAPANESE TABLE
description: IN the kitchen or anywhere else, for that matter, Koei Hoshino is a colorful presence. Tall and sturdily built, clothed in a billowy purple and white robe, her head shorn as part of the ritual of her vocation, she is assistant abbess of the @Sanko-in Zen Buddhist temple in Koganei, on the outskirts of Tokyo.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE WARRIORS
description: The Knicks finally accumulated some points to go with the best defense in the National Basketball Association and overwhelmed the Golden State Warriors, 103-79, last night at Madison Square Garden. In ending a three-game losing streak, the Knicks scored more than 100 points for the first time in eight games and shot 56 percent from the field, a rarity this season.

title: MANAGER HAS WINNING TOUCH
description: When George Steinbrenner was asked yesterday why he had hired Billy Martin as the Yankees' manager for the third time, he said: ''You've got to go with a winner to have a winner. There are only two or three managers active in baseball who have winning records since they started and Alfred Martin is one of them. He has taken teams who have had no right to be winners and won with them.''

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1983
description: International Wide search warrants in Ontario have been suspended while appellate courts weigh their constitutional validity. The all-purpose search warrants, called writs of assistance, helped to inflame the American colonists to rebellion. (Page A7, Column 1.) King Hussein is being counted on by officials of the Reagan Administration to declare his readiness to join in negotiations on Palestinian self-rule by the end of next month. But they say that, to do so, the Jordanian leader must receive increased support from Saudi Arabia. (A11:1.)

title: A FRESHMAN ROCKS THE BIG 8
description: Wayman Tisdale is a reminder that the projections college recruiters make about heralded high school athletes are not always extravagant.

title: SCREEN: FASSBINDER'S 'STATIONMASTER'S WIFE'
description: ''The Stationmaster's Wife'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 25, 1982. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1.

title: NAKASONE AND CHUN MEET IN SEOUL TO DISCUSS BIG TOKYO AID PACKAGE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan and President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea met today in Seoul to discuss a multibillion dollar aid package.

title: AN OPERA OF ANOTHER TIME
description: The last of nearly 30 operas composed by Rossini in Italy, ''Semiramide'' is based on Voltaire's tragedy, ''Semiramis,'' a tale of court intrigue and regicide in ancient Babylonia.

title: NEWBERRY, CALDECOTT BOOK PRIZES AWARDED
description: Cynthia Voigt has been named the 1983 John Newbery Medal winner for ''Dicey's Song'' (Atheneum), and Marcia Brown is the 1983 Randolph Caldecott Medal winner for her illustrations of ''Shadow'' (Scribner's) by Blaise Cendrars. Both awards were announced yesterday in San Antonio during the midwinter meeting of the American Library Association.

title: A STATE'S STILLBORN CURB ON COMPANY TAKEOVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: RIC OCASEK, the tall, dark, lanky guitarist, vocalist and front man for the Cars, wrote all the songs on that group's four million-seller albums. He also produces albums, singles, even demo tapes for new bands he likes; Suicide, Romeo Void, Peter Dayton, and the Bad Brains have all benefited from his studio expertise. That would be plenty of work for most musicians, but it isn't enough for Mr. Ocasek, who is in his mid-30's and who has been playing and singing in rock bands for well over a decade.

title: CHILDREN INSPIRE AID FOR NEEDIEST
description: ''I derived so much joy from my daughter's first Christmas this year that I wanted to share a little bit of that pleasure.'' That note from Erica N. Picker of Astoria, Queens, was attached to a check for $50 as her contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WOODLAND CARIBOU IS PLACED ON LISTING OF IMPERILED SPECIES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today that the Selkirk herd of woodland caribou, the last indigenous caribou in the contiguous states, had been placed on the endangered species list.

title: Cedric Worth, Ex-Supervisor Of Films for Aerojet-General
description: Cedric R. Worth, former supervisor of documentary films for the Aerojet-General Corporation, an aerospace equipment manufacturer, died Jan 3 of arteriosclerosis in a nursing home in Claremont, Calif., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: REAGAN ACCEPTS CURB ON POWERS IN GRAIN DEALS
description: President Reagan, telling hard-pressed farmers that ''help is on the way,'' announced today that he would sign legislation that substantially restricts the power of the President to limit grain sales abroad as an instrument of foreign policy.

title: ST. JOHN'S STREAK HITS 14
description: Unbeaten St. John's equaled the best start in the school's history by winning its 14th game tonight, an 85-73 decision over Connecticut.

title: People
description: * Charles D. Einach has been named an executive vice president at Nadler & Larimer Inc.

title: MILD WEATHER ADDING TO BEACHES' WINTER ALURE
description: Ed Puglisi and Bill Caldarera would rather surf in January. ''No ugly people like in July,'' said Mr. Caldarera. ''In the summer, you get a lot of accidents and hostility,'' said Mr. Puglisi. ''A lot of hostility,'' said Mr. Caldarera. On this winter's day, there are only Mr. Puglisi, an emergency service worker at the Lincoln Tunnel, and Mr. Caldarera, a New York City sanitation worker, and cold, misty green waves, crashing. ''I love the feel of waves crashing on my head,'' Mr. Puglisi said.

title: 5 KILLED IN CRASH OF A SUN CO. JET
description: A private jet crashed in a cemetery today on approaching Toronto International Airport, killing five people, including two executives of the Sun Company and the president of its Canadian operation.

title: AUTOS SPUR INSTALLMENT OF DEBT JUMP
description: Americans increased their monthly installment debt in November by $2.52 billion, the biggest rise in more than a year, the Government reported today.

title: Trotter and Pen
description: As a writer, Red Smith always identified more with four-legged runners than those with two legs. On Sunday, during the Garden State Horse Sales at the Meadowlands, Morton Finder, the president of the Pine Hollow Stud Farm, will auction a stud fee to Green Speed, with the proceeds donated to the Red Smith Writing Scholarship at the late columnist's alma mater, Notre Dame.

title: Carrying Charge
description: Mike Malitz, the president of Top Rank Promotions, admits there is a ''danger'' of a boxer carrying his opponent to collect a bigger purse.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Disclosures, No News

title: Koppers Co.  To Report Loss
description: The Koppers Company said it would take a charge of more than $50 million against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect a write-down of its 23.5 percent interest in the Richmond Tank Car Company and other write-offs. As a result, it said, the company will report a loss for the 1982 fiscal year.

title: STEINBRENNER FINED $5,000 FOR REMARKS
description: The Yankees, who were fined $10,000 last summer for having failed to report to the American League office some details of their agreement with Dave Winfield, have been fined again - this time for $5,000 for George Steinbrenner's remarks about the owners of the Chicago White Sox.

title: PLEASURES OF THE JAPANESE TABLE
description: IT began with a culinary accident on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. It took me to a sushi master above the Gramercy Theater and then to a retired sumo wrestler in Greenwich Village. It led me to a chef who had cooked for the Emperor and Empress of Japan. And the journey is not over yet: I have only begun to discover the world of Japanese appetizers.

title: THE GREAT VINTAGES OF ALFRED KNOPF, 90
description: PURCHASE, N.Y. ALFRED A. KNOPF, oenophile, closely resembles Alfred A. Knopf, bibliophile. He is a collector of exquisite works, surrounding himself with the best, indulging a passion for the rare and exceptional, expressing intolerance for the mediocre and, at age 90, still keen about the differences.

title: Polish Priesthood Expanding Contrary to Worldwide Trend
description: The Vatican said today that the Roman Catholic priesthood was growing in Poland at a time when the number of priests worldwide has been dropping.

title: Clemson Rejects Dismissal Move
description: The Clemson Faculty Senate defeated a resolution today calling for the dismissal of Athletic Director Bill McLellan.

title: MARTIN TO MANAGE YANKEES FOR A THIRD TIME
description: Proclaiming the start of a ''new era for the third time,'' George Steinbrenner introduced Billy Martin yesterday as the new manager of the Yankees. Both men said things would be different this time because they had learned from their past experiences.

title: FINANCIAL SEEKS FIRST CHARTER
description: The fast-growing Financial Corporation of America announced today that it had agreed in principle to acquire the First Charter Financial Corporation, parent of California's third-largest savings and loan association, for an estimated $700 million.

title: Chrysler Canada
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it wants the Canadian Government to provide $200 million in loan guarantees for the auto maker's 1984 model small-van project at a Windsor, Ontario, plant.

title: A BLEAK LIFE GETS BLEAKER FOR SCOTTISH FISHERMEN
description: On the bad days, when the North Sea can suddenly boil up under a gale and throw a mountain of foaming water at a fishing boat, and a catch of whiting and haddock freezes to the pitching deck before it can be moved into a hold, the men of Pittenweem return early to port and brood about the future.

title: U.S. LAWYERS TASTE SALVADOR'S SYSTEM
description: Three New York lawyers, one of them the brother of a Maryknoll nun who was killed here two years ago, learned firsthand today that El Salvador's legal system is not like the one they are used to.

title: Namibia Political Leader Says He Will Quit
description: The chairman of the Council of Ministers of South-West Africa announced Monday night that he had decided to resign.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I loved Jean Kerr's article on ''Bell's Blues'' (Dec. 29) and share many of her frustrations. I too retain the letter system of dialing, often adding one like the D in ENDicott instead of 362, making it easier to recall the next four numbers. However, I outfoxed myself when I memorized my son's new unlisted telephone number. The first three letters spell GYM, but the phone booth I was in had only digits!
description: Perhaps Ma Bell could take one small step backward and retain letters in order to simplify the act of communication.CAROLYN GOODMAN EISNER Manhattan

title: Stifle the Squeal Rule
description: Regretting the sweep of the American sexual revolution is understandable, but denying its consequences is cruel. And if federally funded family planning clinics are required to notify parents of minors who receive contraceptive devices or prescriptions, as the outgoing Health and Human Services Secretary, Richard Schweiker, has asked, America's teen-agers will be cruelly served indeed.

title: GRAND JURY WITNESSES GIVEN NEW PROTECTION
description: The Supreme Court granted a new protection today for witnesses who have testified before a grand jury under a grant of immunity from prosecution.

title: WILLIAMS AND JOHNSON PACE NETS TO NO. 10
description: In a game matching a young team still looking to gain respect against a team that was the champion last season, the upstart Nets helped their budding reputation tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Lakers, 110-96. It was their 10th consecutive victory, which tied a franchise record.

title: ISLANDERS WIN THIRD STRAIGHT
description: The Islanders, with Roland Melanson in goal for the fourth consecutive game, continued their upsurge tonight by defeating the Winnipeg Jets, 4-1.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Israeli Visitors Get the Hook

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Big Red' Put Out to Pasture

title: Pargas Sales Plan
description: Pargas Inc., a distributor of liquefied petroleum gas based in Waldorf, Md., said it had retained Kidder Peabody & Company to investigate the possibility of a sale of the company.

title: Japan Car Exports
description: Japan will decide by March 31 whether to extend its voluntary limits on auto exports to the United States for another 12 months, an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today, declining to be identified. In May 1981, Japan agreed to limit car shipments to the United States to 1.68 million units in the fiscal year 1981, a level that was also set for the fiscal year 1982, which ended March 31.

title: El Al Trips Resuming
description: El Al Israel Airlines, whose planes have been grounded for the last four months, will resume passenger service on Wednesday.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Classes Held for Seniors Of Strike-Bound School
description: Classes were held for high school seniors in this strike-bound district today after the sheriff locked union leaders in his office and threatened to jail any teachers picketing in the state's longest school strike.

title: 2 Die, 3 Hurt in a Fire Laid to Two Arsonists
description: Two people died and three people were injured last night in an upper East side apartment building fire that was started by two men who ignited a flammable liquid in the main entrance of the six-story building, the police said.

title: 4 HOUSE FRESHMEN AND THE JOBS THEY CAME TO DO
description: One could not figure out his telephone. A second drove to Virginia twice trying to find the Capitol. A third worries about his daughter attending a strange new school.

title: Afghan Rebels Reported Holding Some Russians
description: Afghan rebels have kidnapped more than a dozen Soviet nationals, including several civilian advisers to the regime of President Babrak Karmal, from a crowded bazaar in the city of Mazar-i-Sharif on the Afghan-Soviet border, a Western diplomatic source said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Pasta and Calories

title: Harvester Accord
description: Officials of the International Harvester Company and the City of Rock Island have signed an agreement to sell $5.9 million of a $6.9 million bond issue intended to help the struggling farm-equipment manufacturer. The issue is intended to help finance the transfer of a Harvester production line from Louisville, Ky., to Rock Island.

title: Georgia Sheriff on Trial In Civil Rights Case
description: The longtime sheriff of Johnson County ran ''a reign of terror'' against blacks in the racially troubled spring of 1980, an attorney charged as a $21.3 million civil rights trial got under way today.

title: Detroit Center In Default
description: The owners of Detroit's Renaissance Center, the downtown riverfront hotel-shopping complex, are in technical default of their mortgage and will seek to restructure or reduce their payments, a spokesman said today.

title:
Economic Scene;
Housing Rise's Ripple Effect
description: HOUSING, the sick giant of the American economy, is finally starting to stir. Just about everyone, and the Reagan Administration in particular, is hoping that home building will be strong enough to help lift the whole economy out of its stagnant trough. Whether those hopes will be realized, however, is questionable. The answer depends on achieving lower interest rates despite a record Treasury deficit.

title: PICKING JURIES IS FOR LAWYERS, NOT JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it had completed its $53 million acquisition of the Charles Schwab Corporation, thus becoming the first domestic commercial banking company to own a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. BankAmerica is the parent company of the Bank of America, while Schwab is the parent of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm. The acquisition was approved last Friday by the Federal Reserve Board, despite vigorous opposition by the securities industry.

title: READER'S DIGEST FILLS NEW TV POST
description: The Reader's Digest said yesterday that it was branching into television programming and had hired Jeffrey S. Grant, formerly executive vice president and chief operating officer of the pay-TV Disney channel, as president of a new subsidiary to be known as Reader's Digest Entertainment Inc.

title: 'NICKLEBY' SCORES HIGH ON TV
description: A television adaptation of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the hit stage production of the Royal Shakespeare Company, attracted more viewers than one of the three major commercial networks, NBC, in New York and Chicago and shared top ratings in San Francisco on Monday night.

title: William Harms, 75, Pianist, Had Taught at Marymount
description: The pianist William Harms died Friday in Stamford, Conn. He was 75 years old. Born in Eureka, Kan., Mr. Harms was accepted by Joseph Hofmann as a scholarship student at the Curtis Institute of Music in 1929.

title: Accounts
description: * Associated Press Broadcast Services division to Needham, Harper & Steers, Washington.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FORT LEE'S NEW IDENTITY: SUBURBAN OFFICE CENTER
description: During the 1970's, this Bergen County city gained a reputation as a high-rise bedroom community for New York City because of its large number of apartment developments. In recent years, however, a surge of commercial development has carved out a matching identity for Fort Lee as a suburban office center.

title: BAKER'S TURNING POINT
description: Howard Baker of Tennessee, the Republican leader of the Senate, has let it be known that maybe he won't seek re-election in 1984 but may run for the Presidency then if President Reagan decides to go home.

title: HIGH TIME TO SUBSIDIZE INDUSTRIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: First Tournament of Year In New York Area to Begin
description: The first tournament of the year for enthusiasts of the New York metropolitan area - the Tristate Regional Championships - begins today. It is triply dichotomous. The players are already used to being divided into smoking and nonsmoking divisions, and to ''horizontal'' scheduling, which spreads some events over two days instead of one.

title: Dow Off 8.56 on Profit Taking
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday as investors cashed in profits taken from the 47-point run-up over the previous three sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average, which soared 16.28 points on Monday to a new high of 1,092.35, closed yesterday at 1,083.79, down 8.56.

title: CENTURY CLUB: MALE BASTION IS CHALLENGED
description: In 1857, the poet William Cullen Bryant and other ''gentlemen'' of artistic or intellectual achievement founded the Century Club. Its name was derived from the fact that its membership was originally limited to 100 men.

title: CANADIANS ATTACK OLD LEGAL DEVICE
description: Writs of assistance, a type of all-purpose search warrant that inflamed American colonists to rebellion more than 200 years ago, were suspended here last week as appellate courts considered their constitutional validity.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Required Reading Gramm as 'Enemy'

title: News Analysis
description: With the uprising at Cell Block B in Ossining peacefully resolved, Governor Cuomo must now deal with the larger problems that helped bring on the rebellion: the serious overcrowding and antiquated conditions at state prisons.

title: BOVINE REMEDY THAT HELPS HUMANS TOO
description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt. AMAN doesn't go into the business of making ointment for sore cow's udders expecting many surprises. That is why John L. Norris Jr., who took over the manufacture of Bag Balm from his father in 1934, is sometimes astonished at his mail.

title: How to Reward 'Progress' in Salvador
description: A cynical assumption underlies a provincial warlord's rebellion in El Salvador: that American aid will continue to flow no matter how insolent the military's behavior. Lamentably, the State Department seems eager to prove Colonel Ochoa right.

title: Officials Dispute Drug Evaluation
description: Laboratory tests on race horses so groggy that officials canceled their race showed no trace of chemicals today, but officials say they're sure someone drugged the horses.

title: HARSH NICARAGUAN ATTACK ON U.S. REPORTED REJECTED AT CONFERENCE
description: India, Yugoslavia and some other countries participating in the conference of nations professing to be nonaligned have rejected Nicaragua's criticism of the United States, sources close to the conference said today.

title: Aid to Drunk Driving Studies
description: The Department of Transportation today awarded $348,000 to New York and eight other states for studies to determine whether tougher laws on drunken driving have reduced the number of accidents linked to alcohol. The other states are Iowa, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Florida, Alabama, West Virginia, New York, Washington and Minnesota.

title: ARAB OIL PRICE TALKS SET
description: Oil ministers of Arab nations in the Persian Gulf region will meet Saturday in Bahrain to discuss oil prices, the Kuwait news agency reported today.

title: Nuclear Ship Gets New Port
description: The nuclear-powered guided missile cruiser Arkansas will change its home port from Norfolk, Va., to Alameda, Calif. in July, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. announced today. The move is part of a program to balance nuclear-powered surface ships between the Atlantic and Pacific fleets.

title: Glenn Branca to Present His Third Symphony
description: Glenn Branca, an avant-garde composer who makes use of rock instruments and attitudes, will present the first performance of his Symphony No. 3 (''Gloria'') at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Helen Owen Carey Playhouse starting tomorrow at 8 P.M.

title: 1. As if in Tahiti...
description: A woman who is fleeing winter for sun and sea needs a swimsuit coverup to take her from hotel to beach or swimming pool. One of the most packable and becoming cover ideas is the oversized scarf that weighs next to nothing and can be draped attractively like the garment that Tahitians call a pareu. Bergdorf's is importing the scarves, printed in Italy in lovely color combinations on thin cotton. They are large enough (62 by 46 inches) to be draped into dress length or at the waist for a long skirt. They will be priced at $38 in the store's main-floor scarf department at the end of this month.

title: Report of Bid to Kill Honecker Is Denied
description: East Germany today denied a West German magazine's assertion that Erich Honecker, the East German leader, was the target of a New Year's Eve assassination attempt, but its denial confirmed most details in the original account.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. The surging Nets face the Pacers for the first time this season. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) College Games: Manhattan at Fordham, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:45 P.M.); Pratt at C.W. Post, 8 P.M.; Adelphi at Southampton, 8 P.M.; Fairfield at Army, 7:15 P.M.; Jersey City State at Staten Island, 8 P.M. (Radio - WSIA-FM, 88.9; 7:50 P.M.); Providence at Seton Hall (Television - MSG Cable, 10:30 P.M., tape); Villanova at Pittsburgh (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Minnesota at Michigan (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.); Virginia at North Carolina State (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M., tape); Massachusetts at Connecticut, women's game, 7:30 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs.

title: HOT FLASHES ARE TOPIC FOR RESEARCH AND GROUP THERAPY
description: FIRST there is the premonition that something unsettling is about to occur. Then the heat is sensed in one area or another of the body and spreads and intensifies until, as a sufferer described it, ''you feel like an internal furnace.'' Sweat breaks out on the forehead, the hands, the scalp, between the breasts. Some women also feel tingling sensations, dizziness, nausea, heart palpitations and a rush of blood to the face. Then it passes; another hot flash, the most common and, for many, the most troublesome consequence of menopause, has ended - for the moment.

title: Advertising; R.C. Cola Account To Dancer
description: THE Chicago-based Royal Crown Cola Company, which has been losing market share to the soft drink giants despite some innovative marketing techniques, is moving its $20 million advertising account to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: GOVERNOR ORDERS INQUIRY BY STATE ON OSSINING SIEGE
description: Governor Cuomo today ordered a state investigation of the 53-hour siege at the Ossining Correctional Facility. And prison officials began to put into effect the agreement that led to the release early this morning of the guards who had been held hostage.

title: MISSOURI GOVERNOR PROPOSES STEPS TO FIGHT DIOXIN CRISIS
description: Gov. Christopher S. Bond today asked the Missouri Legislature for new measures to cope with the growing problem of dioxin contamination in the state.

title: IN OSSINING NEGOTIATIONS, A HITCH AT THE LAST MINUTE ADDED A LONG 24 HOURS
description: The state's Correction Commissioner, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, said yesterday that the guards held hostage by Ossining prison inmates were ''moments away'' from being freed Sunday night, when the televised remarks of a New York State Senator ''blew it.''

title: GOLD FEVER IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Even Wall Street's heady performance in the past six months looks skimpy compared with the surge in prices of gold and other mining stocks on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.

title: Kang Ryang Uk, 79, a Leader Of North Korean Communists
description: Kang Ryang Uk, one of North Korea's three vice presidents and chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, has died at the age of 79, the official Korean Central News Agency reported today.

title: KEAN URGES NONPARTISANSHIP TO RESOLVE STATE'S PROBLEMS
description: Governor Kean urged the New Jersey Legislature today to put aside the partisanship that he said undercut the effectiveness of the state government last year. He also asked the lawmakers to join him in trimming the size of the state bureaucracy and finding new ways to fight unemployment.

title: Mistake Put Miami Man In Jail for 2 Months
description: An innocent man spent two months behind bars because of an 11-year-old girl who told her family she had been raped so as to avoid being punished for wandering away, the police said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Scholarly Motivation

title: WORLDWIDE DEBT DATA FOR BANKS
description: Worried about shaky loans abroad and the threat they pose to the world banking system, 35 international banks today formed a clearinghouse to collect financial information on countries that have problems paying their foreign debts.

title: RIGHTS PANEL CRITICIZES PRESIDENT ON TWO AFFIRMATIVE ACTION STANDS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights criticized the Reagan Administration today for its opposition to broad-based affirmative action in two major civil rights cases.

title: OPERA: JUNE ANDERSON IN ROSSINI 'SEMIRAMIDE'
description: OPERA'S familiar rescue story, in which a young singer substitutes for a star and wins standing ovations, was re-enacted at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, this time with a twist. Because Montserrat Caballe, who was scheduled to sing the title role in a concert version of Rossini's ''Semiramide'' is notorious for canceling engagements, the young American soprano June Anderson was in place and well-prepared to take over for the Spanish diva. Miss Caballe, we were told, decided earlier in the day she was suffering from a viral infection.

title: Iranians to Lose Property If They Don't Go Home
description: Iran's Parliament passed a law today enabling the Government to confiscate the property of Iranian exiles if they fail to return home within two months, the Teheran radio said.

title: 9.6% OF KAISER STEEL ACQUIRED BY JACOBS
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis businessman and takeover specialist who had been bidding until late last year for the Pabst Brewing Company, said yesterday that he and three associates had acquired 9.6 percent of the Kaiser Steel Corporation.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IF you are at all susceptible to dry skin, the chances are that by now you have chapped lips, sandpaper hands and itchy alligator skin on your arms and legs. Winter is especially rough on human skin. The cold, dry air and wind outdoors and the even drier heated air indoors can parch the protective outer layer. The national penchant for frequent bathing compounds the problem by stripping the skin of protective oils that help to keep it moist.

title: VIOLA RECITAL: EMANUEL VARDI
description: EMANUEL VARDI was at one time an active advocate for the viola as a virtuoso instrument. He played with the NBC Symphony under Toscanini and transcribed and composed works for his instrument, which has all too often fallen in the cracks between its higher and lower pitched counterparts.

title: A COMPUTER SHOP AIMS AT INDIVIDUALS
description: Macy's Herald Square will open a soundproof computer shop this Sunday in its fifth-floor electronics department, targeted mainly at meeting the needs of small businesses and professionals who work at home.

title: BLACK COLLEGES THREATEN TO LEAVE N.C.A.A. OVER ACADEMIC POLICY
description: The heads of several predominantly black colleges threatened today to remove them from the National Collegiate Athletic Association because of a new rule requiring athletes to achieve a minimum score on college entrance examinations.

title: LEGRAND RICHARDS
description: LeGrand Richards, the Mormon Church's oldest general authority, died Tuesday at the age of 96. Mr. Richards died at at the home of his daughter, Nona Dyer, of ''causes incident to age,'' according to the church.

title: CHINA'S PART IN THE WAR ON U.S. TEXTILES
description: To the Editor:

title: OSTRICHES GIVE MORE THAN PLUMES FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: Diners at the Panorama Restaurant can choose between an omelet of ostrich egg - singular not plural, since one egg from this largest of birds is enough to feed 12 people - and ostrich steak chasseur.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am planning to remodel my bathroom. The walls are covered with tile up to about 48 inches from the floor, and I plan to leave it. I want to refinish above the tile with either cedar or redwood and then finish it with two coats of polyurethane. Friends tell me that the wood will warp from the steam, but the carpenter says this is not so. Who is right?

title: Advertising; Insurance Ads Aimed At Leaders
description: SUDDENLY, the ravages of the drunken driver have become a hot media topic. And, because there is a property and casualty insurance angle to the problem, the 22year-old Insurance Information Institute will use this long-overdue theme for the first ad in its first-ever corporate campaign.

title: Commonwealth Selling Unit to Apex
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its refinery and chemical plant in Penuelas, P.R., to the Apex Oil Company, a privately held refiner based in St. Louis.

title: Fire Truck Kills Boy, 3, in Brooklyn
description: A 3-year-old boy was killed yesterday when he darted out from between two parked cars and was crushed by a fire truck on its way to a blaze in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Rohm & Haas
description: The Rohm & Haas Company said it planned to reorganize its European operation to eliminate excess manufacturing capacity, resulting in a $5 million charge in the fourth quarter and about 500 layoffs. The reorganization, expected to be completed by the end of 1983, includes curtailment of some manufacturing operations in Italy and Britain, and consolidation of sales, technical and administrative staff throughout the region, it added.

title: MUSIC: COMPOSERS MARK 500th YEAR
description: ONE of the oldest of American new music organizations celebrated its 50th anniversary Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The National Association of Composers USA was formed in 1933 by the conductor and composer Henry Hadley, and his String Quartet (Op. 132) was part of the evening's program.

title: ARROWS ARE SEEKING TO AMERICANIZE SOCCER
description: With the announcement that Steve Zungul, the high scoring forward, had been put on waivers, the New York Arrows are close to ending an era in the Major Indoor Soccer League, which is in its fifth season.

title: Slicing the Pie
description: There hasn't been a welterweight boxing champion since the retirement of Sugar Ray Leonard last November, and the two top contenders, Milton McCrory of Detroit and Donald Curry of Fort Worth, ranked No. 1 and No. 2 by both the World Boxing Association and the World Boxing Council, have been reluctant to fight each other for the unified title. How much better, the thinking has gone - and how much bigger the purse - to let each man fight for one of the titles and then have the winners meet each other in a champion-versus-champion fight.

title: Shamrock to Pay Less for Some Oil
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation has cut the price it will pay for most of the crude it buys in the United States by $2 a barrel, to $30, a spokesman said.

title: POPE CASTS DOUBT ON TRIP TO POLAND
description: Pope John Paul II suggested doubt today that he would go through with his planned visit to Poland, which was postponed last year but rescheduled for next June by the Warsaw Government and the Vatican.

title: U.S. COURT ORDER BARS 9 FROM USE OF DATA ON STOCK
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had obtained a court order temporarily restraining nine men, including four New York City police officers, from using ''insider'' information to buy or sell stocks.

title: Customers Watch Jewelry Shop Theft
description: A Madison Avenue shop was robbed of an estimated $400,000 worth of jewelry yesterday afternoon by three thieves who shattered a frontwindow display case with a sledgehammer and seized the jewelry while startled customers and employees in the store stood by helplessly.

title: RETAILERS SEE LABEL SHAKEOUT
description: The sharp increase in the number of fashion designer labels and the proliferating number of products bearing these labels will force some of the labels out of the marketplace this year and next, speakers predicted yesterday at a retailing convention.

title: THE REGION
description: Budget cuts totaling $30 million will be mandated with an executive order to be issued by the end of this week, Governor Kean said today.

title: U.S. CABLE TV TO GET ROYAL SHAKESPEARE SHOWS
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company signed an agreement in London yesterday with an American television packager that could bring a wide variety of the company's old and new productions to the American television screen.

title: Athletic Flavor
description: If those athletes in the Budweiser Light commercials appear adept at stopping pucks and stuffing baskets, it's because they are, or were.

title: PLANS BY BRANIFF FACE CHALLENGES
description: Two court actions and objections raised by unsecured creditors could complicate Braniff's efforts to reorganize under the bankruptcy act and permit some of its planes to fly again.

title: Accounts
description: * Torrington Company, Torrington, Conn., to BBDM Inc., Chicago.

title: Sharks Off Florida Town Bring Ban on Swimming
description: About 500 migrating blacktip sharks moved close to tourist beaches for the second consecutive day today, forcing officials to ban swimming in the area.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY of the new hardware items, tools and other home products introduced in the last year are finding their way onto dealers' shelves. Here are some that space did not permit us to cover but that should still interest readers. Magnetic Storm Window Kit

title: SOURCES OF SUPPLY FOR ORNAMENTATION
description: For the person who cares about the architecural details and hardware that make a home individual and original - or perhaps authentic -several new books are of interest.Sourcebook of Architectural Orna- ment by Brent Brolin and Jean Richards (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $29.95).

title: NETS BREAK CLUB RECORD WITH 11TH VICTORY IN ROW
description: The Nets came close to having their winning streak broken against the struggling Indiana Pacers tonight, just when they believed they had the victory sealed. But in the end, they won by 120-114 for their 11th straight, the most in the franchise's history.

title: Eating Principle in Central Park
description: There's a new conflict in New York's Central Park between the principle of minimum traffic and minimum amenity - a snack in the colder months. Park Commissioner Davis would allow a small breach of principle to perpetuate year-round snacks at the Loeb Memorial Boathouse on the East Drive.

title: RECITAL: ISAAC STERN IN ANNIVERSARY RECITAL
description: ISAAC STERN made his New York debut at Town Hall in 1937, when he was 17, but the date he probably remembers at least as vividly was 1943. That was the year he first appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall, a place with whose history he was fated to become intimately linked. Last night, 40 years along, Mr. Stern gave an anniversary recital in the hall he was importantly instrumental in saving from the wrecking ball in 1960. It was a heavily attended event, as you might imagine, and why not? Even if Mr. Stern were not a continuing attraction as one of this century's foremost violinists, he is a man with friends. The hall could be almost be filled, for one thing, with musicians he has sponsored or otherwise helped along the way. Add to that the civic and artistic committees to which he belongs or has belonged and you have the nucleus of quite a cheering section.

title: ROBINSON, MARICHAL GAIN HALL
description: In one of the most wide-open elections in recent years, Brooks Robinson and Juan Marichal were voted into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday, but Harmon Killebrew, Luis Aparicio, Hoyt Wilhelm, Don Drysdale and Gil Hodges were not.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It has been a privilege to serve as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency for the past 20 months.

title: Cooperstown's Minorities
description: At the microphones, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was announcing that Brooks Robinson and Juan Marichal had been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, but behind him, upstaging him, a workman in olive-green clothes was perched on a ladder, silently hanging a red white and blue ''Baseball'' banner as a backdrop for the occasion. Somehow the workman belonged there yesterday as a reminder that two of Cooperstown's minorities were gaining - third basemen and Latin Americans.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. said it had sold its entire interest in Revere Copper and Brass Inc. - 1.9 million Revere common shares and $22.8 million principal amount of debentures - to Bear, Stearns & Co. for $17 million in cash.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE IMAGE PROBLEM IN BUDGET FIGHT
description: A year ago White House officials were convinced that President Reagan benefited from his image as a man clinging stubbornly to his ideals while many of his friends and allies were advocating changes in his economic strategy.

title: IRAN HOSTAGE CRISIS: NOTES TO A POSTSCRIPT
description: To the Editor:

title: ROSE FROM NEWSBOY TO MAJOR DISTRIBUTOR
description: Henry Garfinkle, who began selling newspapers on street corners and became a millionaire operator of newspaper and magazine distribution systems in New York, Boston and Toronto, died in his sleep Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: DO-IT-YOURSELF CHAIN SURGES IN SLUMP
description: On one of Bernard Marcus's frequent strolls through the aisles of a store of Home Depot Inc., the do-it-yourself home improvement chain based in Atlanta, the company's chairman and chief executive encountered a customer asking for help.

title: DOW TOUCHES 1,100, THEN SLIPS IN SELLOFF
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, the stock market's most widelyfollowed barometer, yesterday finished barely lower after piercing the 1,100 level for the first time in its history earlier in the session.

title: BRIEFING
description: Roll-Call Clock Call

title: FREED PRISON GUARDS THANK CAPTORS WHO SHIELDED THEM
description: The guards who had been held hostage at the state prison here for 53 hours thanked those among their captors who protected them today, saying the action ''will not soon be forgotten.''

title: Saudi Arabia Finds Coal
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, said today that it had discovered coal for the first time. It said exploration was being conducted around Mujamma in the north.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Russian Enigma: What's in the Gray Boxes?

title: BAR WEAPONS IN SPACE
description: The current scare over the possibility that a Soviet nuclear-powered satellite may crash to the Earth's surface highlights the need for a space arms-control agreement. But despite the dangers posed by the space-weapons race, there are few indications that the Administration seeks to resume antisatellite-weapons talks. As the tempo of weapons development quickens, time is running out for reaching a comprehensive space accord.

title: Addenda
description: * Doyle Dane Bernbach/West has formed a specialized Health Care group.

title: 7 Cuomo Aides to Get A Salary of $75,000
description: Seven key aides to Governor Cuomo will earn $75,000 or more a year, the State Comptroller's office announced today.

title: West German Hopeful Of Moscow Arms Pact
description: The leader of West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party, Hans-Jochen Vogel, a candidate for chancellor in elections in March, ended a visit here today that was marked by an intensification of Soviet efforts to keep new American medium-range missiles out of Europe.

title: OILER'S WAY OF KILLING TIME ON ICE
description: Pat Hughes, who was just trying to kill time, scored two goals within 25 seconds to break a National Hockey League record that is not even on the books.

title: ANTI-U.S. FARM RALLY IN JAPAN
description: Thousands of farmers chanting ''Down With America'' marched past the American Embassy today to protest growing pressure from Washington on Tokyo to import more United States farm products. It was one of the largest anti-American demonstrations in years.

title: Royal Bank of Canada Picks Senior Executive
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, Canada's largest chartered bank and the fourth-largest bank in North America, has named Allan R. Taylor president and chief operating officer.

title: Soviet Translator Is Expelled by Britain
description: Britain today ordered a Soviet translator to leave the country for activities ''incompatible with his status,'' apparently a reference to spying.

title: Beneficial Considering A Switch in Agencies
description: For the first time in its 25-year relationship with Al Paul Lefton Inc., the Beneficial Corporation is talking to other agencies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLUE HIGHWAYS: A JOURNEY INTO AMERICA. By William Least Heat Moon. Illustrated. 420 pages. An Atlan- tic Monthly Press Book: Little, Brown and Company. $17.50.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the pianist William Harms yesterday incorrectly named the college where he taught. It was Manhattanville, in Purchase, N.Y.

title: BELL WINS PLEA TO BLOCK AWARD OF $1.8 BILLION
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $1.8 billion antitrust award levied against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for trying to monopolize the long-distance telephone market.

title: THE CALENDAR OF EVENTS: URBAN PAST AND FUTURE
description: The Municipal Art Society's Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (at 51st Street), 212-935-3960.

title: WHY 'PLENTY' WINS OVER AMERICANS
description: DAVID HARE'S ''Plenty'' is an anomaly, all right. It's not only the one piece of brilliant theater to arrive on Broadway this season, but it's also that rare English play to receive a stronger critical and popular response on this side of the Atlantic than at home.

title: REAGAN CHOOSES EX-REP HECKLER TO BE THE NEW SECRETARY OF HEALTH
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Margaret M. Heckler, a former Representative from Massachusetts, to succeed Richard S. Schweiker as Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: Steel Industry Outlook
description: The annual production capability of the nation's steel industry will fall to an estimated 151.2 million short tons of raw steel in 1983 from 154 million in 1982, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. Based on a December survey, the industry trade association said production capability reached a record 160 million tons in 1977 and had declined gradually, to about 154 million tons in each of the past three years.

title: PAPERBACKS: GLOOMY SCENARIO
description: For executives in the mass-market paperback book industry, it's just one problem on top of another. Some say their total reading public has declined. Consumers are balking at higher prices. The surging popularity of romance novels, while good for revenues, has created retail bottlenecks.

title: U.S.F.L. Signs James of S.M.U.
description: The United States Football League took another premier player away from the National Football League yesterday when the Washington Federals signed Craig James, the Southern Methodist tailback.

title: TV: 'MYSTERY!' BACK ON A NEW DAY
description: WHAT accounts for the attraction that Victorian London holds for writers of mysteries? Can it be simply the sinister shadows thrown by the gas lamps or the celebrated eccentricities of the era? Does it have something to do with the ominous gap between the upper and lower classes? Or is it a literary inheritance - the enduring magic cast by Sherlock Holmes and the penny dreadfuls of the time?

title: Tory Leader Seeks to Calm Markets
description: In an effort to halt a run on the pound by nervous investors, a senior official of the Conservative Party said today that there would be no early general election.

title: BUSTLING AIRPORT IN VERMONT
description: For Tom Schmidt, director of operations at Burlington International Airport, the proof is in the parking lot - there is not enough space these days.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late Edition yesterday carried page C17 twice and omitted page C19, which included the Going Out Guide. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Y.& R. Lands a First With Proprietary Drugs
description: After 34 years as an American Home Products agency, Young & Rubicam has received its first proprietary drug assignments. The products, all from the Whitehall Laboratories division, are Maximum Strength Anacin, an analgesic; Anbesol, an antiseptic; Bronitin, an asthma relief product; Sleep-Eze; Neet, a hair remover, and Semicid, a contraceptive.

title: On the Road Again
description: Alan Jones, who retired a year after winning the Formula One championship in 1980, says he will return to automobile racing, but not in Formula One. Instead, Jones plans to drive a 1977 Chevrolet Monza in a 500-kilometer race scheduled for the streets of Miami next month.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Suns vs. Seattle SuperSonics, at Phoenix. (Television - USA Cable, 9 P.M.) College Game: Colorado at Kansas State (Television - ESPN, 11:30 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs.

title: IVES FAILS TO GET ALBANY TAX POST AMID CONFUSION
description: Martin Ives, deputy comptroller of New York City, wil not be appointed State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, both Mr. Ives and a spokesman for Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: REAGAN MAKES VOW OF NO BIG TAX RISE THIS YEAR OR NEXT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan pledged today that the Adminstration would not propose major tax increases this year or next.

title: FOR BLACK STUDIES, THE FIGHT GOES ON
description: After winning a decade's struggle for a respected role in American higher education, the field of black studies now finds itself challenged anew by the enrollment, tenure and other problems faced by the humanities and social sciences in general.

title: WRITER BIDS SOVIET LET HIM EMIGRATE
description: After a series of K.G.B searches, interrogations and threats, Georgi N. Vladimov, recognized as one of the Soviet Union's finest postwar writers, asked today to be allowed to emigrate.

title: Tose to Reduce Role
description: He just got a new coach - Marion Campbell for Dick Vermeil - his team is deeply in debt, and he's beginning to feel his age. So after 13 years as the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, 68-year-old Leonard Tose is thinking about selling part of his interest.

title: LIKE MOTHER, LIKE DAUGHTER (ALMOST)
description: MY mother was ahead of her time. The smell of home-ironed sheets and homemade madeleines elicits no deja vues in me, nor do I remember an anxious frown in response to straight A's, a scholarship or a job transfer away from marriage prospects. In the 1920's and 30's, at my mother's knee, I learned the lessons that are taught today: in career the expectation of equal status, money, responsibility and excitement; in parenthood equal work, responsibility and, within limits, function.

title: News Analysis
description: The crash of an Air Florida Boeing 737 taking off from snow-swept Washington National Airport just a year ago has generated or hastened several safety measures by the plane's manufacturer and governmental authorities.

title: 'SISTER MARY IGNATIUS' STIRS FIGHT IN ST. LOUIS
