description: Weeks of debate have preceded the opening here Friday of Christopher Durang's ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You,'' a satirical play about Roman Catholic education.

title: Sandoz Seeking Marietta Dye Unit
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation of Bethesda, Md., announced that Sandoz Ltd., a Swiss pharmaceutical and chemical maker, had agreed in principle to buy its Sodyeco division, which produces dyes. The company said it would not disclose the amount involved until a definitive agreement was reached, which is expected by the end of the month.

title: WIDER SHULTZ ROLE; Text of Reagan statement, page A9.
description: President Reagan dismissed Eugene V. Rostow today as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and said Secretary of State George P. Shultz would play the principal role in coordinating the Administration's arms control policies.

title: Dioxin Level Down In State Building
description: New tests taken at the Binghamton state office building show that levels of dioxin and another toxic chemical are near those ''deemed safe for human occupation,'' state officials reported today.

title: 'EVITA' SCANDAL IN VIENNA
description: A theatrical producer was sentenced to two years in jail Tuesday for hiring thugs to beat up the Viennese star of the musical ''Evita'' because he was in love with the star's understudy and wanted the understudy to take over the role.

title: A SCULPTURE NAMED 'CONNECTICUT'
description: In stocking feet the Indian would be 70 feet tall, but it's far from likely that he will ever stand up. Instead, Washington's newest monument will remain crouched atop a liquor store, 25 feet from elbow to elbow, arms poised to lift him over the parapet and onto the street below.

title: HERS
description: MY friend B has a tighter schedule than most but has always enjoyed it. She is up at 5 A.M., runs to a jogging track on the grounds of a neighborhood school, runs there from 5:30 to 6:00 A.M., then runs home and breakfasts with her school-age children, drives to her fulltime job at a school in Queens, is home in time to swim a half hour's worth of laps in a Y pool, then to supper and the evening chores of a parent and householder and the paperwork of a junior-high-school science teacher.

title: STATEMENT BY REAGAN ON CHANGES
description: Following is a statement by President Reagan on personnel changes in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency issued by the White House today:

title: Tikhon Y. Kiselev, 65, Leader of Byelorussia
description: Tikhon Y. Kiselev, the Communist Party leader of Byelorussia, died Tuesday after a ''prolonged illness,'' the press agency Tass said today. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. AND GREECE AT ODDS ON LANDINGS AT CRETE BASE
description: The United States has formally dismissed Greek accusations that it was trying to create ''a de facto situation'' with repeated unauthorized landings of American military aircraft at the Suda Air Base in Crete.

title: Discreet Viking
description: When Mike Lynn, the general manager, imported a professional cheerleader, Krazy George Henderson, to wake up Minnesota Viking fans during their last two games at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, the move seemed superfluous. The Vikings beat the Dallas Cowboys and Atlanta Falcons in thrilling victories, and the fans, who had tended to sit on their hands during the first five home games, led their own cheers.

title: ELECTION FUND DATA ON BOSTON'S MAYOR DISCLOSED
description: Three-fifths of the money Mayor Kevin H. White's campaign committee spent last year was used to pay his wife and to improve their home, according to a financial report the committee filed this week and businessmen who were paid by the committee.

title: Internorth Charge
description: Internorth Inc. of Omaha said it would take an after-tax charge of $64 million, or $1.44 a share, against 1982 earnings as a result of its decision to sell two little-used tankers and its coal properties.

title: 3 EXECUTIVES ACCUSED IN THEFT OF $100,000 AT SENTRY'S BUILDING
description: The three highest officials of a Bronx armored-car company that was robbed of $11 million in cash last month were charged yesterday with stealing $100,000 in a separate case.

title: Hisle Hangs Up Bat
description: Plagued by a recurring shoulder injury that kept him out for most of the last four seasons, Larry Hisle of the Milwaukee Brewers has decided to pass up another comeback attempt in favor of a job as an instructor with the Brewers' farm system. The power-hitting Hisle, 35 years old, went to the Brewers from the Minnesota Twins as a free agent in 1978, the year after he had led the American League with 119 runs batted in. In his first year at Milwaukee, he helped the Brewers to their first winning season, but he injured his shoulder early the next year and never played a full season afterward.

title: DEFAULT OF RENAISSANCE CENTER BRINGS MORE GLOOM TO DETROIT
description: The Renaissance Center has slid from a gleaming, five-tower symbol of hope for urban revival into default, further underscoring the uncertain future of downtown Detroit.

title: CULTIVATING CITRUS FOR ITS OWN SAKE
description: WHEN Theodore Kovaleff was 6 years old, he planted the pits from three grapefruit and an orange. Now, 30 years later, the plants grace his West Side apartment and he insists that he cannot understand how anyone grows an avacado after seeing a citrus plant.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 13, 1983
description: International Eugene V. Rostow was dismissed as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency by President Reagan, who said that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would play the principal role in coordinating arms control policies. Officials said that the dismissal of Mr. Rostow and other changes announced in the management of arms control matters were not based on ideological or policy reasons, but rather were intended to end the fragmentation and chaos that has existed for months in the bureaucracy. (Page A1, Column 1.) Poland expelled a U.S. reporter after holding her for 23 hours in Warsaw's police headquarters. The expulsion of Ruth E. Gruber, a correspondent for United Press International, centered on a packet on a train from Gdansk that officials said contained two illegally photographed rolls of pictures of military installations. (A12:4-6.)

title: TRIPUKA GETS 25 IN RETURN
description: Kelly Tripucka came off the injured reserve list and scored 25 points to lead Detroit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Datapoint Corp., San Antonio, has elected Joseph C. Ciasullo executive vice president, international operations.

title: Conoco Gas Sale
description: The Transco Energy Company and an American Natural Reourses Company unit announced their purchases of gas reserves and rights in the Mustang Island Block A-85 from the DuPont Company's Conoco Inc. subsidiary. Transco said it had paid $17 million to increase its interest in the block to 46 percent from 33 percent. American Natural Resources said it had increased its stake to 46.7 percent from 33 percent for $17.6 million.

title: WEST SIDE NEIGHBORS TRY TO SAVE S.R.O. HOTEL
description: A neighborhood group on Manhattan's Upper West Side is negotiating to buy a rundown single-room-occupancy hotel. The group says it wants to improve the building but continue to run it as a hotel, rather than allow it to be converted to luxury housing.

title: 2 in Fire Identified As Father and Son
description: The fatal victims of a fire Tuesday night in an apartment building on East 91st Street were identified yesterday as Albert Guierra and his 14-year-old son, Albert Jr.

title: THEATER: 'WILD OATS'
description: JOHN O'KEEFFE'S 18th-century comic romance ''Wild Oats'' is close to foolproof, but in its new production the Classic Stage Company is subjecting it to a stress test. The play's denouement is, as it should be, a euphoric unraveling of mistaken identity, paradise regained and virtue triumphant. There are coach stops along the way, however, when ''Wild Oats'' seems imperiled.

title: DANCE: GALA BY A JUNIOR DANCE TROUPE
description: ONE of the new trends in American dance, and perhaps only in American dance, is the growth of certain kinds of second companies attached to a senior troupe.

title: Surfing Master
description: Andres Gomez is back on the tennis court preparing for next week's Volvo Masters at Madison Square Garden. But during a recent vacation at his home in Guayaquil, Ecuador, the 6-foot-5-inch Gomez could not resist a trip to the beaches at Punta Blanca for some surfing.

title: Technology; Retailing, By Computer
description: FOR more than a decade, advanced electronic devices have been expanding their role in how stores are run and how goods are sold: While laser-equipped optical scanning devices have found their way to supermarket checkout counters, computer terminals have proliferated in the warehouses, management offices and other store departments.

title: East Germany Ousting West German Reporter
description: The East Berlin correspondent of the West German weekly magazine Stern, which on Tuesday reported an assassination attempt on the Communist Party leader Erich Honecker, was ordered today to leave East Germany within 48 hours.

title: FARMERS PLEASED BY REAGAN'S MOVE
description: LaMOURE, N.D. Jan. 12 - Farmers here in the heart of North Dakota's wheat-growing region reacted with guarded approval today to President Reagan's plan to return surplus grain to them for taking up to half their land out of production next season.

title: Who Runs Health and Welfare?
description: By reading between the lines, one can make a pretty good guess as to why Richard Schweiker has resigned as Secretary of Health and Human Services: frustration.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A WINNING HAND FOR CRABLE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. I t was early yesterday afternoon, but already the game faces were in place in the center of the Jet locker room. Hero sandwiches were passed out. A napkin was used to brush away the crumbs from the center of the table, and another napkin became a tally sheet. ''Deal the cards,'' Greg Buttle said.

title: PUPIL CHORUS TUNES UP FOR A VISIT TO VENEZUELA
description: Midway through the two-and-a-half-hour rehearsal, the singers were becoming restless. ''There will be no talking,'' said Josephine Morris, the chorus director at Intermediate School 44 in Manhattan, and there was no talking. ''Turn to your National Anthem of Venezuela.''

title: A DEFENSE BUDGET WORTH CUTTING
description: To the Editor:

title: 5.2% DROP SEEN IN '83 OUTLAYS
description: For the second consecutive year, American business executives are planning to reduce spending for expansion and modernization, a new Commerce Department survey indicated today.

title: Mr. Bush Into the Breach
description: This promises to be a fateful year for arms control, revealing whether the United States and Soviet Union can agree to limit their nuclear arsenals or will go on pursuing short-term advantages at great long-term cost. As President Reagan has observed, ''Clearly the Soviets (now) want to appear more responsive and reasonable.'' Just as clearly, so does the President. What is not so clear is whether Moscow and Washington prefer the appearance or the fact.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES STATE AUTHORITIES ON INVESTMENTS
description: As much as $100 million in investments by public authorities in New York State are endangered because of seriously inadequate investment guidelines and the absence of state oversight, according to a State Senate report issued yesterday.

title: PRETORIA'S FOES IN I.M.F. FOCUSED ON ECONOMICS
description: According to the confidential minutes of a closed-door meeting of the International Monetary Fund, opponents of a recent I.M.F. loan to South Africa sought to make their case against the loan strictly on economic grounds.

title: URSULA MEESE LOOKS TO THE YEAR 2000
description: Ursula Meese is looking to the future, not the time two years hence when she says her husband, Edwin, is determined to leave his post as counselor to President Reagan, but to the year 2000.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE DIET
description: Poor Michael Deaver.

title: Woolworth's Head To Join Melville
description: Richard L. Anderson, president and chief operating officer of the F.W. Woolworth Company, has resigned to join the Melville Corporation, where he will share the post of chief operating officer and be a member of the office of the chairman.

title: THE PEOPLE OF CUBA AWAIT RADIO MARTI
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Increases Issue
description: Strong demand from local investors enabled New York City to increase its bond issue to $150 million, from $100 million, and at the same time reduce slightly the interest rates it must pay.

title: 4 BANKS END LITIGATION OVER FLORIDA TAKEOVER
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., in a move that could speed its eventual merger with the Chemical Bank of New York, said last night that a settlement had been reached to end all litigation involving Florida National, Chemical, the Southeast Banking Corporation and C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera of Venezuela.

title: MAKERS VIE FOR MILLIONS IN HOME VIDEO GAMES
description: ''E.T.'' has been turned into a video game. So have the rock group Journey, Sylvester Stallone and Cookie Monster. John Dykstra, the Academy Award-winning special effects designer of ''Star Wars,'' will be designing games for Colecovision. Jonathan Winters will sell Gopher and Eggomania for U.S. Games. The former coach John Madden has been hired to help CBS Video Games create a sophisticated football cartridge.

title: THE 1982 AUCTION HIGHS, AND WHY
description: WHAT do a 14th-century English spoon, a weather vane shaped like the Statue of Liberty and a pair of French soup tureens once owned by a Russian nobleman have in common? All are superb specimens of their kind and all established auction records last year. And they did so despite the recession, which has caused a softening in prices for lesser offerings throughout the art market.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A 'Pretty Awesome' Round Of Democratic Parties

title: Mormon Named Member Of Nevada Gaming Board
description: A man who believes gambling is morally wrong has been named to the Nevada Gaming Control board, but he said his religious convictions would not detract from his job performance.

title: Boxer Refuses To Fade Away
description: The last man to fight Sugar Ray Leonard has been told to retire. But Bruce Finch, who was stopped by Leonard in a welterweight title shot in three rounds, will fight undefeated Pedro Vilella tomorrow night on a card that opens the 1983 boxing season at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: News Analysis
description: At a critical moment in the Reagan Administration, the President's leadership has taken some new setbacks from two unsolicited Cabinet resignations and the disclosure that the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., will probably not seek re-election in 1984 and could be positioning himself for a run for the Presidency if the President decides not to run again.

title: A LOOPHOLE TO CITIZENSHIP THAT MUST BE PLUGGED
description: To the Editor:

title: Missouri Flood Debris Hauled to Dump Site
description: The police escorted truckloads of debris out of this flood-damaged town today to a hazardous waste dump, but new government tests turned up no trace of toxic dioxin in the rubble.

title: On 'Family Affairs'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I am not yet a mother and the oldest of four children, but the power of Norma Rosen's words struck an invisible chord that denied categorization (Hers, Dec. 23).

title: WITH NEW LAW, DIVORCE FEES SOAR
description: Emily Jane Goodman practices law in New York City and writes frequently on legal matters.

title: 740 Suspected Marxists Go on Trial in Turkey
description: A mass trial of 740 suspected Marxists opened today, with the defendants facing murder, kidnapping and robbery charges stemming from an aborted leftist takeover of the Black Sea town of Fatsa, the state radio reported.

title: 2 Oilers Arrested On Drug Charges
description: Two members of the Houston Oilers were arrested tonight on on suspicion of drug possession. the police said. Sgt. James Ellis said Greg Stemrick, and J.C. Wilson, both cornerbacks, were arrested as they left the Sportsman's Lounge on the city's north side.

title: Surgery for Bert Jones
description: Even though Bert Jones is a right-handed passer, a back injury that caused numbness in his left arm kept the quarterback out of the Los Angeles Rams' lineup for the last four games of the season.

title: RAIDERS' CONCERN IS PENALTIES
description: After an 8-1 season that propelled the Los Angeles Raiders to the top of the American Conference, Coach Tom Flores said today that his concern as he prepares to face the Jets in the second round of the Super Bowl tournament was penalties.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Actors' Equity On the Taxi Front

title: GOOD DEEDS IN CITY BRING CONTRIBUTIONS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: The heroism of a 29-year-old father of eight who rescued a blind man from a subway track last month has inspired a former resident of the city to make his first contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A 3-Year U.P.I. Pact Grants Rise of $133
description: Tentative agreement on a three-year union contract covering 919 editorial employees of United Press International was reached by U.P.I.'s new management and the Wire Service Guild.

title: Reports of Insider Trading
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: REAGAN'S CHOICE FOR HEALTH CHIEF: MARGARET MARY HECKLER
description: Years ago when Margaret M. Heckler was an elected member of the Massachusetts Governor's Executive Council, her 4-year-old son announced one day, ''When I grow up, I am going to be

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS RALLY TO WIN 9TH IN ROW

title: High Finance
description: Nelson Skalbania, who made a fortune in real estate before losing it in professional sports ventures, has escaped bankruptcy, at least for the time being. Skalbania persuaded 120 creditors yesterday that he could pay off $39 million in debts within five years.

title: SIDNEY C. NORRIS
description: Sidney C. Norris, a lawyer and president of the Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation of New York, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Korf Debt Noted
description: Korf Industrie und Handel G.m.b.H., which asked for a court receiver last Friday to protect it from creditors, has debts of $153 million, the acting receiver, Jobst Wellensiek, said. Korf Industrie is the controlling company of the Korf steel group. Mr. Wellensiek said that he saw no possibility of keeping the Korf group in its present form.

title: BONN SAYS SOCIAL DEMOCRATS MIGHT HINDER ARMS DEBATE
description: The West German Government accused the opposition Social Democratic Party today of undermining efforts to persuade the Soviet Union to dismantle its medium-range missiles targeted on Western Europe.

title: Eugene V. Rostow
description: Since the early days of World War II, when he opposed the internment of United States citizens of Japanese descent, Eugene V. Rostow has been involved, off and on, in public disputes.

title: 13 Hurt as Car Rams Hospital
description: A man who apparently suffered a heart attack at the wheel of his automobile crashed the vehicle through a plate-glass window of a hospital waiting room here today, scattering patients and injuring 13 people.

title: N.Y.R.A. PICKS BANCROFT
description: Thomas M. Bancroft Jr., a business executive and owner of many stakes-winning horses, yesterday was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the New York Racing Association, which conducts thoroughbred racing at New York's major tracks.

title: JEWS' ROLE AS 'CHOSEN PEOPLE' DEBATED BY SCHOLARS
description: The idea that the Jews are ''the chosen people'' has been a vital part of Jewish identity for milleniums. But is this age-old belief, stated in Deuteronomy that ''the Lord thy God hath chosen thee to be a special people unto Himself,'' a beneficial affirmation of a singular role in the world for Jews or is it an outdated pretension full of harmful consequences?

title: ALUMNI RECRUITING CURTAILED
description: In a sweeping change aimed at curbing illegal offers by alumni, fans and other boosters, Divisions I and II of the three-division National Collegiate Athletic Association voted today to limit recruiting to ''institutional staff members'' only.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 13, 1983; Companies
description: A $1.8 billion antitrust award against A.T.& T. was rejected by a Federal appeals court. But the court upheld some of the antitrust findings in the case and ordered a new trial to set damages. The award, the largest in American law, had been made to MCI Communications in a suit charging that A.T.& T. had tried to monopolize the long-distance telephone market by denying intracity phone connections to MCI. (Page A1.)

title: ZIMBABWE UNDER SIEGE
description: A white business manager who helped keep Rhodesia going under sanctions during the Ian Smith years spoke about the present danger he sees facing Zimbabwe.

title: PHILADELPHIA
description: Frank L. Rizzo made it official today. At a crowded news conference, he issued his long-awaited announcement that he is a running again for Mayor, claimed credit for all the construction projects that have been under way in the city since he left office three years ago, promised a new program of economic development and confronted questions that are considered likely to dog his steps in the coming campaign.

title: Iran Increases Its Oil Output by 5%
description: Iran has announced that it has raised oil output by more than 5 percent this month despite attempts by other oil exporters to hold down overall production.

title: Tex Antoine, 59, Dies; TV Weather Forecaster
description: Tex Antoine, a weather forecaster for New York television stations for more than 25 years, died yesterday in his Park Avenue apartment. He was 59 years old.

title: Consolidated Foods Losing Its President
description: Robert Jaunich 2d resigned yesterday as president of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, a large Chicago-based food and consumer products conglomerate, to become president and chief executive of the Osborne Computer Corporation.

title: HOME BEAT
description: WHEN Cheryl Lewin, a graphic designer, began to redecorate her bedroom, she could not find any simple wallpaper she liked.

title: WAS SOVIET PRESIDENT FOR 12 YEARS
description: Former President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union, who assumed office in 1965 after the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev and was himself dismissed 12 years later, has died, a Government spokesman said today. He was 79 years old.

title: Dear Century Club
description: I have been reading with great interest the recent correspondence between those of you who think women should be admitted to your distinguished assemblage and those of you who do not.

title: LEBANON BIDS U.N. WIDEN PEACE ROLE
description: Lebanon has told the United Nations that it wants a greatly enlarged role for the 6,500-member United Nations peacekeeping force in the country, officials here said today.

title: Memphis Man Holds Police Officer Hostage
description: Lindberg Sanders, an unemployed construction worker who said he believed the world was about to end, held a policeman hostage for a second day today, refusing to talk to negotiators.

title: TWO ORGANIZATIONS ANNOUNCE PLAN TO PROTECT U.S. WETLANDS
description: A $50 million conservation program to preserve the country's diminishing wetlands has been initiated by the Nature Conservancy and the Richard King Mellon Foundation.

title: Sounders Sold; Coach Is Dropped
description: The Seattle Sounders, who made it to the Soccer Bowl last year before losing to the Cosmos, were sold today, and Coach Alan Hinton was discharged.

title: MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE CO. TO MOVE 600
description: The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York is planning to transfer about 600 employees from its midtown headquarters to a new office in Purchase, N.Y., company officials said yesterday. They said they expected the move to be completed by the middle of next year.

title: Bridge: A New Book for Beginners Is One of the Best in Years
description: One of the paradoxes of bridge literature is that books for good players outnumber those for beginners by perhaps 10 to 1, though the beginners outnumber the good players by a similar ratio. The reason, perhaps, is that some good players become addicted to books while beginners may be content to read just one, or even none at all.

title: Kenneth L. Adelman
description: The man President Reagan has selected to head the nation's arms control agency is a 36-year-old Republican who has served as deputy representative at the United Nations, a post that carries the rank of Ambassador.

title: CARROLL L. WILSON, SCIENCE AND ENERGY EXPERT
description: Carroll Louis Wilson, Mitsui professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who was an expert on the relationship between science and government, died of leukemia today at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 72 years old and lived in Seekonk, Mass., on the Rhode Island border.

title: Owner Weighing A Bid for Blues
description: The Ralston-Purina Company, which owns the St. Louis Blues, said today it was considering an offer from Batoni-Hunter Enterprises of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, to buy the team.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday, with most of the decline occurring late in the day after a flurry of activity that included a $100 million trade of long-term Treasury bonds.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 13, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 3 P.M.

title: Compton International Appoints an Executive
description: Donald B. Miller, 57-year-old former chairman and chief executive of Rumrill-Hoyt, has been named chairman of the executive committee of Compton International and director of business development of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide Network.

title: Cruelty to Children
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: William Faulkner's ''No one remembers Shakespeare's child'' response to his daughter's request for him to remain sober for her birthday seems to emanate more from his addiction to alcohol than his dedication to art (Hers, Dec. 30). There is never justification for a parent to be cruel to a child, yet we all are at different times to differing degrees.

title: THE 'Y' LYRICIST SERIES SHIFTS FOCUS TO HISTORICAL OVERVIEW
description: THE ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series opened its 13th season at the 92d Street Y last weekend with a new outlook. After 12 years of focusing each program on a writer of lyrics for popular songs who usually would be present to discuss his craft and, with the help of others, to illustrate it, the series has shifted focus from the lyricist to a historical overview of popular song.

title: 2 GROUPS URGE TAX INCREASES
description: A bipartisan group of 12 former top Government economic officials urged today that Congress and the Reagan Administration raise taxes to prevent ''huge budgetary deficits for the indefinite future.''

title: CODFISH CATCHES ARE PLENTIFUL
description: While most Northeast anglers are daydreaming of May's gentle embrace, some of their more hardy brethren go for codfish or whiting right through the winter. This is particularly true of Long Island's party boat patrons.

title: SHCHARANSKY'S WIFE ASKS MITTERRAND FOR HELP
description: Avital Shcharansky, wife of the imprisoned Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, urged President Francois Mitterrand of France today to ask Soviet leaders to free her husband.

title: Market Place; Technicians As Forecasters
description: ''I LIKE to read John Mendelson's material because he's been on target,'' a money manager said this week in assessing the predictive ability of technical market analysts.

title: KAISER'S LOSS WIDENS
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest aluminum producer after the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $123.4 million for 1982, compared with the 1981 quarter's much slimmer deficit of $16 million. The company attributed the loss to continuing weakness in the aluminum industry.

title: MEADOWLANDS GETS A PRESEASON BOWL
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today approved a preseason major-college football game to be played during the last week of August between two of the top teams in the nation at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. The game will be known as the Kickoff Classic and will count toward a team's season record.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Wonder in Winter: Narcissus Observed

title: S.I. COAL PROJECT, CALLED 'GAMBLE,' IS HALTED BY CITY
description: The plan to build a $500 million coal-export terminal on Staten Island was halted yesterday by the Koch administration. Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper, calling the proposal ''too much of a gamble, as opposed to a prudent investment,'' recommended that the city spend no more money on it, and the Mayor agreed.

title: U.P.I. CORRESPONDENT ORDERED EXPELLED BY POLAND
description: The Polish authorities today ordered the expulsion of a reporter for United Press International after holding her for 23 hours at police headquarters here.

title: RANGERS TIED BY JETS
description: There was nothing sharp about last night's game at Madison Square Garden, except perhaps Doug Soetaert's goaltending - and he allowed five Ranger goals.

title: PROFITS RISE AT 2 BANKS
description: J.P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that net operating income in the fourth quarter rose 4.9 percent, to $129.4 million, or $3.10 a share, from $123.3 million, or $2.98 a share, in the period a year earlier. The advance came despite a $30 million increase in the amount of money provided for loan losses.

title: World Bank Loan Plan
description: The World Bank's executive board will encourage, for the first time, more commercial bank lending to third world countries, despite the shakiness of many borrowers, monetary officials said today.

title: Ecuador Rescheduling
description: Ecuador has reached agreement with its creditor banks to refinance 26 percent of its public external debt of $4.68 billion over seven years with two years' grace, the Government said today. The agreement applies to the external debt due between November 1982 and December 1983.

title: ARMS CONTROL'S CRUCIAL 'LINKAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Preventing Poisoning
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The article by Elaine Louie, ''Baby-Proofing for a Safe Home'' (Dec. 16), is an excellent contribution to accident prevention in children but fails the reader in poison prevention.

title: Frederique Petrides, Leader In Women's Music Activities
description: Frederique Petrides, a pioneering woman conductor who led orchestras in New York and founded the West Side Community Concerts, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TAVERN IN TOWN

title: SANDINISTS ACCUSE U.S. OF TERRORISM
description: Nicaragua charged the Reagan Administration today with sponsoring ''a campaign of terror'' against Nicaragua, but renewed its offer to hold negotiations ''without conditions'' aimed at improving relations with the United States.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Borden Inc. filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for up to $200 million of debt securities, to be offered from time to time.

title: PRECIOUS-METALS FUTURES CLOSE WITH LARGE GAINS
description: The precious-metals futures markets resumed their strong advance yesterday, after pausing for a day in the belief that traders with huge recent paper profits in gold, platinum and silver would convert some of their gains into cash. This expectation was so strong in New York that brokers said pre-noon trading was uncommonly dull, with few signifcant price changes.

title: Del Monte Pact
description: The Del Monte Corporation and China have signed an agreement to develop joint food production and worldwide marketing ventures, it was announced. As part of the agreement, reached between Del Monte's international division and China's Shanghai Foodstuff Industry Association, Del Monte will aid China in developing an experimental farm in Shanghai, Robert A. Fox, Del Monte president, said. The first stage, planned for this month, will involve 10 acres on Zhong Ming Island in the Yangtze River delta, where Del Monte varieties of tomatoes, sweet corn, asparagus and sweet pea pods will be planted.

title: Kodak to Trim Capital Budget
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it will cut its budget for capital expenditures for 1983 to $1.36 billion from $1.53 billion in 1982, largely because several large capital projects are scheduled for completion in its chemical division in 1983.

title: DECEMBER RETAIL SALES DOWN 0.4%
description: In a lackluster Christmas selling season, American retailers' sales dropped four-tenths of 1 percent in December as car sales fell from the November level, Government figures showed today.

title: Mexico Plans Help on Debt
description: The Mexican Government announced a new plan today to help privately held companies pay foreign creditors, but it said the creditors must cooperate by extending repayment schedules.

title: Tokyo Politician's Death Is Now Called a Suicide
description: Ichiro Nakagawa, a former Cabinet minister whose death had been attributed to a heart attack, committed suicide by hanging, police officials said Tuesday.

title: THATCHER JOURNEY TO FALKLANDS ENDS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher left for Britain today after a five-day visit to the Falkland Islands.

title: FEDERAL WORKER PLAN STIRS SOCIAL SECURITY DISPUTE
description: A plan to include Federal workers in the Social Security System has resulted in one of the first skirmishes in this year's battle to reshape Social Security.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
VINTAGE LIGHT BULBS FOR A PERIOD LOOK
description: PROPER lighting is an important element in any room, and contemporary lights just won't do when you're trying to achieve an authentic old-fashioned look. Whether you are re-creating a period room or just want old-fashioned lighting, the actual bulb is almost as important as the fixture that holds it.

title: SALVADORAN COLONEL ENDS REBELLION AFTER 6 DAYS
description: The six-day-old rebellion of a military commander in a northern Salvadoran province ended without violence today as abruptly as it began. The full outlines of the settlement, however, remained unclear this evening.

title: Corsican Rebels Attack Home of 2 Teachers
description: Terrorists sprayed gunfire at the home of two teachers and bombed their car today in the 10th incident of separatist violence in two weeks on this French island.

title: WHITE HOUSE JOINS IN TALKS ON SOCIAL SECURITY WORRIES
description: Members of President Reagan's advisory panel on Social Security met with senior White House officials today in an effort to put together major elements of the Social Security financing bill that Congress is expected to pass in 1983.

title: Sampson Rallies Virginia
description: Ralph Sampson scored 33 points, 19 in the second half, to help Virginia overcome a 16-point deficit and defeat North Carolina State, 88-80, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: CHAMBER: LOFT RECITAL
description: IT seemed a bit incongruous at first for the cellist Fred Sherry and the pianist Rebecca Silver to join other players in an encore romp through Thelonious Monk's ''Lulu's Back in Town'' just after participating in a taut, rugged performance of Brahms's Piano Trio in C (Op. 87). But in a loft at 137 Greene Street in SoHo on Monday night, an unusual spirit could be felt throughout the recital.

title: REINTERPRETING LUXURY IN MODEL APARTMENTS
description: IN the past, when someone spoke of luxury apartments, a distinct image sprang to mind: stately, high-ceilinged, graciously proportioned rooms with paneled libraries, marble-floored ballrooms and a lot of architectural detailing. Spaces, in other words, that provided a sense of Old World stability and elegant living.

title: AGENCY CONSIDERS STOVE SAFETY LABELS
description: About 50 to 100 homes surveyed in recent years by a home inspector in suburban Virginia were ''ready to burn'' because of improperly installed wood-or coal-burning stoves, according to testimony before the Consumer Product Safety Commission today.

title: STUDENTS WHO SKIP SCHOOL TELL OF FAMILY PROBLEMS AND A SEARCH FOR IDENTITY
description: Diana Rosado, a bright and determined 16-year-old student, was called to her school's guidance office to explain her uncharacteristic absences. ''My mother left me,'' she said, and broke down sobbing as she told how her mother, troubled by illness and alcoholism, had walked out on her and her three sisters during the summer.

title: A PRIMER IN THE FINE ART OF LEAKING INFORMATION
description: A newspaper reporter newly assigned to cover the Pentagon was startled one Saturday afternoon in the autumn of 1979 to receive a call from a senior official in the Carter Administration who came right to the point:

title: SUSAN SARANDON'S ROUGHEST ROLE
description: At about 4 o'clock most weekday afternoons, Susan Sarandon starts feeling a little sick to her stomach. Curtain time is just four hours away for a drama in which she plays what she considers to be her most difficult role to date. She portrays a woman assaulted in her home by a would-be rapist in William Mastrosimone's ''Extremities'' at the Westside Arts Center on West 43d Street, a performance that has brought her critical praise.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT didn't matter at all to a group of her close friends that Eileen O 'Casey had already celebrated the New Year ''at a quiet evening withm y daughter, Shivaun, here in New York,'' she said. So the other e vening, nearly two weeks after New Year's Eve, they had themselves ac eidle in her honor.

title: Arms Control Agency
description: The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency was established on Sept. 26, 1961, as a semi-autonomous agency to develop and carry out Administration arms control policy.

title: Eaton May Close Plants
description: The Eaton Corporation said today that it might close two plants, idling 649 employees, because of slumping business.

title: 'Very Small' Peril Seen From Falling Satellite
description: The chances are ''very small'' that radioactive debris from a nuclear-powered Soviet satellite falling toward earth will imperil populated areas, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Loan Request By Argentina
description: Argentina is seeking a $500 million loan from the Bank of International Settlements, bank officials said today.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike Barred by Judge
description: A temporary restraining order forbidding a strike threatened for today by carmen on the Long Island Rail Road was signed yesterday by Judge I. Leo Glasser in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: STUY FINDS NEGLECT OF DATA HAMPERING FEDERAL HEALTH RULES
description: The failure of Federal agencies to examine and use relevant scientific data is leading to poor regulatory decisions in environmental protection and occupational and public health, according to a Brookings Institution study.

title: Nordiques Halted
description: Pete Peeters of the Bruins became the first goalie to shut out the Nordiques in 231 games as Boston beat Quebec, 2-0, tonight.

title: Farm Talks Adjourned
description: Officials of the United States and the European Common Market have agreed to adjourn talks aimed at averting an agricultural trade war.

title: Travelers Loan
description: The Travelers Corporation said it had written a $160 million mortgage, the largest ever on a single property, for Kalikow 101 Park Avenue Realty Corporation's new 50-story building at 101 Park Avenue in Manhattan. Travelers said the 1.2 million-square-foot building was 95 percent occupied.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it would distribute 2.4 million shares of $3 series convertible preferred stock, 1.1 million shares of $13.75 series preferred stock and $90.2 million of 13 1/4 percent notes due in 1993 to former Penncorp Financal Inc. shareholders as part of its acquisition of Penncorp.

title: Market Place; Valuating Bell's Shares
description: THE reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest corporation, is due to be completed by next Jan. 1. As a result, brokerage firms and other investors are trying to figure out the breakup value of the company's stock. Interested parties to the deliberations include Ma Bell's 3.2 million stockholders.

title: ABORTION: THE COURT WAS RIGHT
description: The 10th anniversary of the United States Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, on Jan. 22, arrives with the prospect of more years of turmoil. The drive to overthrow the decision has become a major social issue of our time. The struggle has hamstrung Congress, disrupting its legislative schedule and exhausting its energies.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly reported the number of shares outstanding of Home Depot Inc. of Atlanta.

title: THE WORLD'S IDLE CARGO FLEETS
description: From Piraeus to Hong Kong, from Baltimore to Liverpool, the world's major harbors are jammed with vessels built to transport American grain to the Soviet Union, Saudi oil to France, Japanese videotape recorders to Britain.

title: DANCE: ABT II SHOWCASE
description: FOR its first extended Manhattan season, which runs through Sunday evening at the Joyce Theater, American Ballet Theater II is presenting a series of ballets that for the most part are not seen in New York.

title: Managers: News and Baseball; The Dike
description: Washington is a place where people struggle to change laws. They sometimes succeed with legislative law, but never with natural law.

title: Andrew Fleischer, 101, Stethoscope Developer
description: Andrew W. Fleischer, who contributed in the early part of the century to the development of the modern stethoscope and the bloodpressure monitoring device, died Tuesday night at the Van Dyke Convalescent Home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 101 years old.

title: World Premiere
description: These are not exactly normal times for Carling Bassett. After all, how many 15-year-olds become a tennis professional one week and then make their motion-picture debut the following week?

title: PHYSICANS' JOURNAL CALLS FOR A BAN ON BOXING
description: Editorials in today's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association urged the banning of boxing in light of new evidence suggesting that chronic brain damage was prevalent among fighters.

title: HOLOCAUST PANEL'S FATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford to Omit Dividend Again
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it would not pay a first-quarter dividend to shareholders, marking the first time since it went public in 1956 that it will have gone for more than a year without paying a dividend.

title: S.E.C. Changes On Disclosure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it was planning to ease its disclosure rules so that companies could reduce the amount of information they release about management compensation.

title: Exxon Unit Prices
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. said it had lowered most United States wholesale heating oil prices by one-half cent to 1 cent a gallon and had raised some gasoline prices half a cent and 1 cent a gallon. A company spokesman said the unit had lowered distillate prices at most terminals east of the Rockies, adding that New York Harbor barge and cargo postings for heating oil were cut 1 cent.

title: AS HAZARDOUS WASTES KEEP SEEPING THROUGH E.P.A. RULES
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 3 editorial ''Deadly Miasma Over Missouri'' accurately points out the devastation that resulted from improper disposal of 48 pounds of dioxin, a toxic chemical.

title: CABARET: KEELY SMITH AND FRIEND AT MARTY'S
description: KEELY SMITH, who spent most of her career singing with a deadpan expression while the late Louis Prima pranced around her shouting out his parts of their songs, is at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street, this week and next with a new and totally different partner.

title: NEW-LATE NIGHT SCENE: GLITTER, YOUTH AND FOOD
description: You may not be able to hear Liza Minnelli's singing salute to ''the city that doesn't sleep'' on the jukebox at the Munson Diner and Tavern -where the disks are strictly Motown -but it's certainly there in spirit.

title: Financial Corp. Leader Interested in Motivation
description: Charles W. Knapp recalls that part of his motivation to succeed was instilled 30 years ago when he labored on scaffolding hitched to the exterior of Salt Lake City office buildings.

title: CHEMICAL SPILL ON I-81 FORCES EVACUATION UPSTATE
description: A tanker truck smashed into a disabled tractor-trailer truck on a highway here late Wednesday, spilling a toxic chemical and forcing hundreds of residents from their homes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Why should a claim for a damaged leg survive one's death where a claim for a damaged name does not? After death, the leg cannot be healed, but the reputation can.

title: FOLK SCULPTURE, A QUIRKILY AMERICAN ART, ON VIEW
description: THOSE who cling to the conviction that American folk art is lovable, unchallenging and easy to take ought to steer clear of ''The Shape of Things: Folk Sculpture From Two Centuries,'' the show that opened this week and runs through May at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: U.S. Asks High Court To Widen Evidence Rule
description: The Reagan Administration urged the Supreme Court today to allow illegally gathered evidence to be used in criminal trials if the police seized the items with a good-faith belief that they were acting legally.

title: Homeless Future For Indoor Track
description: The 102d Engineers Armory on 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue in Manhattan has been the home of high school and age-group indoor track meets for decades. This winter, between 25 and 30 indoor meets will be staged at the facility, with more than 1,400 athletes from countless Catholic and public high schools training there daily.

title: Guatemala to Reduce Its Demands Over Belize
description: President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala says that his Government intends to drop its demand in talks with Britain this month for sovereignty over all of the neighboring former British colony of Belize.

title: Officials Propose Shellfish Standards
description: Inspecting shellfish operations here, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, called today for uniform national standards for the shellfish industry, which has been hurt by the recent outbreak of illnesses caused by contaminated clams.

title: Canadian Pacific View
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. expects its operations to begin showing some improvement during the year as the Canadian and United States economies begin to recover, F.S. Burbidge, chairman and chief executive officer, said today.

title: Japanese fare for theater nights.
description: SIMPLE and pleasant Japanese food is always a welcome change from heavier cuisines, but especially so before the theater, when light but satisfying sustenance is wanted. An inviting, moderate-price option for Japanese food on the edge of the theater district is Sushiko on 55th Street, between Eighth Avenue and Broadway. Although the dining room, with its small sushi bar, is in need of sprucing up, it is a cheerful and informal setting in which to enjoy a number of well-prepared and engaging small dishes.

title: AS HAZARDOUS WASTES KEEP SEEPING THROUGH E.P.A. RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAFAT ENDS SOVIET TALKS ON JORDAN LINK
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, concluded meetings with Soviet leaders today saying that they had shown understanding for the prospect of a confederation between Jordan and a future Palestinian state.

title: Saving Face or the Falklands?
description: Prime Minister Thatcher's bold trip to the Falklands showed that in one sense she is capable of movement. But her Government's South Atlantic policy is another matter: it lies dead in the doldrums. By evading negotiations on the ultimate sovereignty of the islands, Mrs. Thatcher risks appearing just as stiff-necked and chauvinist as the Argentine junta she defeated.

title: Investors Study Kaiser Control
description: Four Minnesota investors, led by Irwin L. Jacobs, say they may seek control of the Kaiser Steel Corporation now that they own nearly 9.7 percent of the company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rx for Recovery

title: Watt Rejects 4 Requests For Mining in Florida
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced today that he was rejecting applications by four companies to mine phosphate in 52,000 acres of the Osceola National Forest in Florida.

title: Raider Backs Play It Close on Receivers
description: Jim Royer, the chief scout and pro personnel director for the Jets, scouted the Los Angeles Raiders' opening-round playoff victory over the Cleveland Browns last weekend and found a tactic that, Royer said, the Jets had not seen in years.

title: De Paul Star Suspended
description: Bernard Randolph, the leading scorer for De Paul's basketball team, has been suspended indefinitely by Coach Ray Meyer for ''disciplinary reasons.''

title: Air Florida Pilots' Accord
description: Air Florida and its unionized pilots have signed a no-strike contract under which an arbitrator would choose one offer or the other in a contract dispute.

title: VIOLA RECITAL: EMANUEL VARDI AT TULLY
description: EMANUEL VARDI was at one time an active advocate for the viola as a virtuoso instrument. He played with the NBC Symphony under Toscanini and transcribed and composed works for his instrument, which has all too often fallen in the cracks between its higher and lower pitched counterparts.

title: WHAT LEGAL SERVICES PAYS ITS PRESIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG 3'S AUTO SALES UP 10.5%
description: The nation's Big Three automobile makers, starting 1983 on an encouraging note, reported today that retail sales increased by 10.5 percent in the first 10 days of January, continuing an upward trend that began in October.

title: BRIEFING
description: Looking for a Leader

title: 4 CONCERTS HAIL FAMILIES OF GENIUS
description: IT'S a nice idea: musical dynasties. When the National Orchestra of New York gives the first of four concerts Sunday in Carnegie Recital Hall, it will be one - as will be the three others - that will make some listeners think of the old heredity-versus-environment debate that still agitates researchers in psychology and related sciences.

title: Bad TV Picture
description: To watch his team in action, Sam Schulman, the owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, has a satellite-dish television antenna outside his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., but he doesn't like what he has been seeing lately. The SuperSonics, who began the season by winning their first 12 games, have been in a slump.

title: WEEKEND OF TRIBUTES TO DR. KING
description: Irene Worth and Douglas Turner Ward will read, and the performers will include David Amram, kapelye (performers of klezmer music and Yiddish songs) and the Brooklyn Boys Chorus at the second Martin Luther King Jr. tribute tomorrow night from 7 to 9:30 at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Columbus Avenue at 60th Street.

title: THEATER: 'BLOOD MOON,' OF CRIME AND REVENGE
description: NICHOLAS KAZAN'S ''Blood Moon'' is a chilling Jacobean revenger's tale written from the perspective of a modern sensibility. Dealing with a young woman's savage act of reprisal against her rapist, it plays fair with its characters and their motivations, and is consistent with its own eye-for-an-eye code of morality. The play opens the season for the Production Company in its new home on West 28th Street.

title: TORRZ ACQUIRED BY METS
description: One month after they signed 38-year-old Tom Seaver, the Mets acquired 36-year-old Mike Torrez from the Boston Red Sox yesterday. And they conceded that they were buying time, perhaps two years, until the farm system could supply pitching talent.

title: Needham, Harper Loses S.C. Johnson & Son
description: In a terse announcement, Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, said it had resigned the S.C. Johnson & Son Inc. business, ''due to the recently enunciated competitive conflict policy.''

title: U.S.F.L. Strikes Again
description: The United States Football League made another big score yesterday when the Birmingham Stallions signed their top draft choice, Reggie Collier, the quarterback for Southern Mississippi. He is the third top college player in less than a week to pass up a likely draft by the National Football League and sign with the U.S.F.L.

title: TEDDY WILSON KEEPS DOING WHAT HE DOES BEST
description: TEDDY WILSON has arrived in town from Tokyo just in time to celebrate the 50th anniversary of his first recording, which he made on Jan. 26, 1933, when he was the pianist in Louis Armstrong's orchestra. Mr. Wilson opens tonight at the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street, and he will still be playing there on the anniversary, a week from next Wednesday.

title: A $1 Million Shot
description: Normally, the Continental Basketball Association's all-star game is a midseason yawner. But at this year's game on Feb. 19 at the 3,100-seat Washington Avenue Armory in Albany, one fan will have a chance to win $1 million.

title: Chief Kidder Economist To Start Advisory Firm
description: Sam I. Nakagama, chief economist and vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company, said yesterday that he planned to leave to set up his own economic advisory service.

title: Iona Shoots 77%; Wins, 99-80
description: Gary Springer made all 13 of his field-goal attempts as Iona shot a school-record 77 percent from the field tonight in a 99-80 victory over North Carolina-Charlotte.

title: N.F.L. Ranking; Computer ranking based on games through Jan. 9
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Friday; BUNUEL IN SOHO
description: A 15th-century saint dedicated to meditating atop a pillar in the desert is subjected to temptations by a female devil in ''Simon of the Desert,'' by the master of surrealist film, Luis Bunuel. The 1965 feature will be shown today at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street, at the start of a Bunuel retrospective that runs through Feb. 1. Another feature, ''Viridiana'' (1961), about corruption in the Roman Catholic Church, will also be shown today, along with a short, ''L'Age d'Or (1930), one of the director's experimental films with Salvador Dali. The site is two blocks north of Canal Street at the Avenue of the Americas. Admission: $4.50. Information: 431-1590. THE GOALIE OF 90TH ST.

title: STAINED GLASS CASTS ITS GLOW OVER THE CITY
description: THERE is something that the Metropolitan Museum of Art shares with the New York Yacht Club, the Dutch Reformed Church on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, St. David's School on East 89th Street, the Appellate Division Courthouse on Madison Avenue at 25th Street, the headquarters of the Columbia School of Journalism, the Players Club on Gramercy Park South, the United Nations Secretariat building, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Tavern on the Green and Maxwell's Plum.

title: MRS. ROSENTHAL IS IN CONTENTION FOR HOUSE SEAT
description: The wife of Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal and Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi have emerged as the leading candidates for the Democratic nomination to succeed Mr. Rosenthal, who died last week, Queens Democratic leaders said yesterday.

title: Turnover on Bourse Up
description: Turnover on the Paris Bourse last year rose by 44.8 percent, to 216.84 billion francs from 149.7 billion in 1981, the Stockbrokers' Association said today. The franc is currently worth about 15 cents in United States currency.

title: F.C.C. to Review Bell Divestiture
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it must approve details of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's planned divestiture of 22 operating companies before the divestiture, required under a Federal court order, can go ahead.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Dec. 14 about a freeze on hospital construction in New York State listed one hospital too many. Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center had already received approval for its construction plans and was not affected.

title: NOT ANTI-SEMITIC ATHENS TELLS JEWS
description: The Government has given new assurances to Greek Jews that, despite its strong criticism of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, it is not anti-Semitic.

title: Williams Resigns
description: Bill Williams, the head football coach at the University of San Diego, has resigned after school officials found evidence that he and an assistant coach had made illegal loans to athletes. Neither Williams nor other school officials would provide details of the investigation, but the school's athletic director, the Rev. Patrick Cahill, suggested that the loans had been for small amounts. ... Nebraska's football coach, Tom Osborne, said that if the academic entrance standards just adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association had been in effect over the last few years, a third of the athletes in the Big Eight Conference would have been disqualified from competition as freshmen.

title: A DECISION NEEDING UNDOING
description: A decade after the United States Supreme Court tried to settle the abortion issue, it is plainly evident that it did not. The Court failed politically. It failed socially. It failed legally. And it failed medically. Because of these failures, the American rightto-life movement remains alive and determined.

title: Mergers Down By 2% in 1982
description: Total merger and acquisition announcements were down 2 percent in 1982 from the previous year, while the total dollar value paid for all transactions dropped 35 percent from a record 1981 high, a report showed today.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 4th IN ROW
description: The Islanders, with the Bryan Trottier line producing three goals, defeated the Devils, 5-2, tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: A STATEMENT FROM SHULTZ AND QUERIES
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference held here today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, as recorded by The New York Times: Special to the New York Times

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Solar King Corp. of Waco, Tex., said it had declared a 2-for-1 stock split effective immediately for shareholders of record Jan. 13.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A police officer shot a man brandishing a five-inch knife on a midtown street at about 10:20 A.M. yesterday after he ignored orders to drop the weapon. The man, tentatively identified as 39-year-old Carl Hamilton, was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he was reported in serious condition with groin and stomach wounds. ... A 14-yearold boy who was not immediately identified was shot in a hip at about 10:30 A.M. after he resisted three thieves who were trying to steal his leather jacket in the hall of Eli Whitney High School in Brooklyn's Park Slope section. ... The gagged and bound body of Paul Prendergast, 87, who apparently choked to death, was found shortly after 8 A.M. in the ransacked bedroom of his home, at 121 Clarkson Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Physician's Farewell

title: ARGENTINE 'TIME FOR REVENGE'
description: ADOLFO Aristarain's ''Time for Revenge,'' which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, is a contemporary Argentine political melodrama that is so reticent about its politics that the meaning of its melodrama is ultimately sabotaged. Because it's also the kind of film that is impossible to discuss without going into its plot in detail, bear with me.

title: Home Heating Bills Rose 91% in Month
description: Colder weather caused the average home heating bill to rise by 91 percent from November to December, but a continuing decline in the cost of home heating oil helped offset the increase, according to officials of New York City's Consumer Affairs Department.

title: 550 Boats in 73d Show
description: With a record fleet of 550 power and sailboats, the 73d National Boat Show gets under way at 10 A.M. tomorrow at the Coliseum for a nine-day stand. A survey of the fleet during the first of two trade days yesterday indicated that the accent was on optimism and performance.

title: FOX CHOOSES NEW PRODUCTION CHIEF
description: Joe Wizan, an independent movie producer, was named president of 20th Century-Fox Productions last night, replacing Sherry Lansing who resigned last month to form an independent production unit at Paramount Pictures.

title: Winnebago's President Will Add More Duties
description: John K. Hanson, 69, the entrepreneur who founded Winnebago Industries 25 years ago, has stepped down as chief executive. Mr. Hanson, who owns 45 percent of Winnebago's stock, will continue as chairman.

title: Kenneth Crawford, 80; Newsweek Columnist
description: Kenneth G. Crawford, a journalist for 46 years and former columnist for Newsweek magazine, died today of lung cancer at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: OFFICER KILLED, MEMPHIS POLICE SLAY 7 CULTISTS
description: The police attacked a house with rifles and tear gas today, killing seven black members of a religious cult who had held an officer hostage for 30 hours while beating him to death.

title: REAGAN SAID TO WEIGH PROGRAM TO AID JOBLESS
description: President Reagan, urged by aides to seize the initiative on the unemployment issue, is expected to approve a package of incentives for businesses to hire the long-term unemployed, unemployed youths and those who have lost their jobs because of shutdowns.

title: 2 BUYERS DISCUSS A MERGER
description: The Associated Merchandising Corporation and Frederick Atkins Inc., the country's largest store-owned buying offices, have taken the first step toward a possible merger.

title: ONE FOR THE TANGO
description: Reagan Administration officials say the dismissal of Eugene Rostow means that Secretary of State Shultz will manage the Reagan Administration's arms control policy. That's good news - particularly if Mr. Shultz can remind the President of his own dictum that ''it takes two to tango.''

title: HEART STIMULANT LINKED TO ACIDITY
description: A drug product used for emergency injections into heart patients was found to be so extremely acid that it might have contributed to some of the deaths it was designed to prevent, according to a report in a medical journal.

title: RICHARD SCHWEIKER'S NEW EMPLOYER
description: It is a classic Washington pattern. A senior official leaves an Administration at midterm to take a lucrative position in private industry.

title: Some in Jersey to Get 1% Sales Tax Refund
description: Residents may be eligible under certain circumstances for a 1 percent refund on sales arranged before the state's sales tax went up from 5 to 6 percent on Jan. 3, Taxation Director Sidney Glaser said today.

title: Court Shift Urged To Aid City in Suits
description: Damage suits against New York City should be heard by Court of Claims judges, not before ''emotional'' juries in State Supreme Court or Civil Court, State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Art or Life?

title: ARKANSAS 66 TEXAS A&M 64
description: College Station, Tex. (UPI) - Unbeaten Arkansas, once leading by 15 points, needed two free throws by Willie Cutts, a freshman, with six seconds to play to give the Razorbacks the victory.

title: Greek Import Curbs
description: Greece, indicating it has a serious and persistent economic crisis, today announced import curbs in nine product categories ranging from children's toys to wines and spirits following a 15.5 percent devaluation of the drachma earlier this week.

title: Job Program Risks Discerned
description: Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told Congress Wednesday that there were ''risks and limitations'' to all the Federal job proposals being considered in an effort to reduce unemployment, now 10.8 percent.

title: Decision File Pet's Doorbell Gets a Patent
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has granted Lorin F. Sowards a patent (No. 4,323,883) for a pet's doorbell. ''That's right,'' said the inventor, an unemployed maintenance man from Brownville, Neb.

title: Advertising; Chanel Ad Surprises Researcher
description: GERALD LUKEMAN, stage actor, turned director, turned advertising research company president, looks at television commercials with a very knowing eye.

title:
Economic Scene;
Budget Debate: Two Questions
description: THERE are two strategic questions at the core of the great debate on the Federal budget that is racking Washington: First, how big should the Government be? Second, what is the optimal allocation of real resources among the military, transfer programs such as Social Security and public sector investment in roads, transit, schools and hospitals?

title: Freeze the Freeze Talk
description: When a TV cop pulls his pistol on a fleeing perpetrator and shouts ''Freeze!'' he means stop, right this second. That may work on ''CHiPs'' but it's no way to deal with the runaway budget deficit. All the talk of a budget freeze should stop, right this second. It's irresponsible.

title: 135,000 NAVAJOS' NEW LEADER
description: The man selected by the Navajo Nation to lead it for the next four years personifies the new mood among the 135,000 Indians who live on the reservation of 25,209 square miles.

title: INTEREST RATES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Interest rates were mixed but little changed in quiet trading yesterday. Rates were slightly lower for most issues due in less than five years but rose modestly for longer-term notes and bonds.

title: REBEL SALVADOR COLONEL MAY GET PLUM POST IN U.S.
description: The former commander of the northern province of Cabanas, who prompted a national crisis by refusing to obey transfer orders from the Minister of Defense, is likely to be sent to the Inter-American Defense Council in Washington for a year of study, according to a person familiar with the plans of the Salvadoran high command.

title: Ex-Charter President Joins CBS Publications
description: Thomas M. Kenney, former president of the Charter Publishing Company, has joined CBS Publications as vice president and general manager. And that job has been given additional responsibilities, as the company drops the group management system.

title: BRIEFS
description: *American Solar King Corp. of Waco, Tex., said it had declared a 2-for-1 stock split effective immediately for shareholders record Jan. 13.

title: THE LATEST BATTLE OF POITIERS
description: The first Battle of Poitiers, in which a Frank warlord known as Charles (The Hammer) Martel saved Christendom by crushing an advancing Moorish army in A.D. 732, is widely recognized as a turning point in world history.

title: NEW DELHI IMPOSES CENSORSHIP OF PRESS ON A TROUBLED STATE
description: Indian authorities have imposed press censorship in the northeastern state of Assam as part of a continuing crackdown on a student-led movement that demands the deportation of illegal immigrants from neighboring Bangladesh.

title: DESIGNER'S LIMITED EDITIONS: LINEN AND PIQUE FOR SPRING
description: Not all worthy New York fashion designers have fashion shows. Some, like Yeohlee Teng, quietly make their clothes in small quantities and show them to any buyer they can lure to their studios.

title: BLUE CHIPS ARE HIT
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in much slower trading as profit taking again weakened the list. The biggest losers were bluechip and energy-related issues.

title: STATE AUTHORITIES ADVISED TO ALTER INVESTING POLICIES
description: Tightened investment guidelines for the state's public-benefit corporations and authorities were urged at a state legislative hearing yesterday. But other witnesses cautioned that overly stringent regulations would curb investment flexibility.

title: MCNEIL MAKES BIG GAINS...AS ALLEN HITS HIS STRIDE
description: As the Los Angeles Raiders prepare to play the Jets tomorrow in an American Football Conference semifinal playoff game, the players and the officials in the front office of the Raiders are gushing about the multiple talents of Marcus Allen.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: *American Can Co. said it would distribute 2.4 million shares of $3 series convertible preferred stock, 1.1 million shares of $13.75 series preferred stock and $90.2 million of 13 1/4 percent notes due in 1993 to former Penncorp Financial Inc. shareholders as part of its acquisition of Penncorp.

title: MCNCINI LOOKING BEYOND KIM TRAGEDY
description: Ray Mancini kept insisting that there were ''no mental blocks,'' but yesterday, only hours before he left for Italy and his first fight since the fatal knockout of Duk Koo Kim two months ago, it did not take much to evoke tears or memories.

title: PROSPECTIVE BIDDERS ANGERED
description: A proposed bus-stop shelter contract was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate over complaints that it was ''punitive'' and ''highly unrealistic.''

title: SHOULD PAT EWING LEAVE GEORGETOWN?
description: A lot of people are exercised about John Thompson's proposal to take Patrick Ewing out of school. The Georgetown basketball coach is recommending that his 7-foot sophomore give up his education if the referees do not call the game to his liking.

title: COURT ALLOWS LIBEL SUIT DESPITE PLAINTIFF'S DEATH
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the family of a deceased target of the Abscam investigation can sue Time Inc. for libel to clear the man's name.

title: Water Line Vandal Gets 150-Day Term
description: The final defendant in the trials that arose from the 1981 vandalism to Newark's water supply system was sentenced today to 150 days in jail.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Hawks, at Atlanta. The Hawks have won both meetings between the teams this season, and eight of the last nine.

title: Coach Quits After Fight
description: After his Minnesota Stars won tonight, Coach Glen Sonmor announced that he was resigning as a result of a fight he had with a fan in Pittsburgh after a game there Wednesday night.

title: WALTER J. DANE
description: Walter J. Dane, vice president of sales and services in the Northeast for Eastern Airlines, died Wednesday of cancer at Mount Sinai Medical Center. Mr. Dane, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 59 years old.

title: MIAMI TRIAL OPENS FOR U.S. JUDGE CHARGED WITH BRIBERY CONSPIRACY
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings. He is believed by legal historians to be the first sitting Federal judge tried on criminal charges.

title: Sandinist Prisoners Tell of Foreign Advisers
description: The Nicaraguan Government presented today two so-called counterrevolutionary prisoners and a deserter from the Honduran Army who said that United States, Argentine and Honduran military instructors had been advising anti-Sandinist rebel groups based in Honduras.

title: Zellerbach Loss
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said it would report a 1982 loss of between $110 million and $115 million. It said 1982 results would include an after-tax charge of $125 million, or $4.65 a share, from the sale of its 84 percent interest in Crown Zellerbach Ltd. of Canada and the restructuring of operations. In 1981 Crown had net income of $75.3 million, or $2.47 a share, on sales of $3.15 billion.

title: GROLIER CLUB DISPLAYING RARITIES FROM HARVARD
description: It may not be the rarest of the remarkable treasures in Harvard's Houghton Library, but a telegram from John Reed on view in a loan exhibition that has just opened at the Grolier Club, is certainly a significant piece of 20th-century history and literature. It's a Western Union cablegram from Petrograd, sent Oct. 31, 1917, by the future author of ''10 Days That Shook the World'' to The New York Call, a Socialist newspaper. The cable sounds like Warren Beatty playing Reed in the movie ''Reds'' - except it's the real thing: KALEDINE AND COSSACKS HAVE PROCLAIMED MILITARY DICTATORSHIP GOOD TO BE ALIVE TROTSKY AND LENIN THROUGH CALL SEND TO AMERICAN REVOLUTIONARY INTERNATIONAL SOCIALISTS GREETING FROM FIRST PROLETARIAN REPUBLIC OF THE WORLD AND CALL TO ARMS FOR INTERNATIONAL SOCIAL REVOLUTION SEND ME MONEY.

title: A LUXERY APARTMENT HOUSE WILL RISE ON BROADWAY
description: As Norman Segal tells it, he pestered Stanley Zabar mercilessly. But Mr. Zabar, vice president of the Broadway food store, did not really care to sell the 20,000-square-foot site he owned on the east side of Broadway between 87th and 88th Streets.

title: SPANISH NETWORK TELLS OF GAINS IN BROADCASTING FROM MIAMI
description: At a time when many national and foreign news organizations are opening or expanding bureaus in Washington, the Spanish International Network has gone against the trend.

title: Sidney F. Brody, 67; Civic Leader in West; And Collector of Art
description: Sidney F. Brody, a Los Angeles real estate investor and civic leader, died of cancer Wednesday at his home there. He was 67 years old.

title: Kodak Price Rise
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will increase by about 4 percent the price it charges dealers for most types of conventional consumer and professional film, and will raise the price of black-and-white paper by about 6 percent, a spokesman, Timothy Elliott, said. The increase applies to orders received Jan. 26 and after.

title: CONCERT: GLENN BRANCA PREMIERE
description: LIKE some musical beast heaving itself up out of the primordial sonic sludge, Glenn Branca is back, this time with his Symphony No. 3 (''Gloria''), subtitled ''Music for the First 127 Intervals of the Harmonic Series.'' Mr. Branca's effort - and an effort it is, for all concerned - received its world premiere last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Helen Owen Carey Playhouse, as part of the academy's Next Wave series. The performance will be repeated tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 2.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 14, 1983; International
description: The U.S. and China failed to agree on limiting imports of Chinese textiles. Peking blamed the American side for the impasse. Washington said it will impose quotas on the Chinese textiles unilaterally, retroactive to Jan.1, when the previous accord expired. American officials said the U.S. still expects to reach an accord, but has no choice now but to impose the quotas temporarily. (Page A1.)

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 14, 1983
description: International Arms controls are strongly sought by President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. At a news conference, Mr. Shultz said that the President had a ''firm dedication'' to reaching such agreements with Moscow and that the dismissal of Eugene V. Rostow as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency would have no effect on the Administration's policies. (Page A1, Column 4.) An Israeli-Lebanese accord on an agenda for their talks was reached after three weeks of negotiation. An Israeli spokesman said the agenda included ''the termination of the state of war, a framework for mutual relations,'' security arrangements and the withdrawal of Israeli troops ''within the context of the evacuation of all foreign forces.'' (A1:5.)

title: Lawsuit Seeks Impact Study Of Close Spacing of the MX
description: A coalition of conservation and arms control groups has sued in Federal District Court to force a full environmental review of President Reagan's plan for closely spaced basing of the MX missile.

title: Joseph Rampal Dies in Paris; A Retired Professor of Flute
description: Joseph Rampal, father of the popular flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal and a retired professor of flute at the Marseilles Conservatory, died Tuesday in Paris.

title: CHEMICAL, MARINE MIDLAND UP
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, holding company for the Chemical Bank, which is the nation's sixth largest, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter operating profits before securities transactions rose 38.7 percent, to $80 million, or $2.73 a share, from $57.7 million, or $2.29 a share, a year earlier.

title: News Analysis
description: The opposition of the heads of several predominantly black colleges to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's new rule on athletic eligibility once again raises the issue of whether standardized college entrance examinations discriminate against minority students.

title: Indiana 69, Illinois 55
description: Randy Wittman scored 27 points, including 17 in the second half, and Ted Kitchel added 20 for Indiana in the Big Ten game.

title: NOVEMBER INVENTORIES SLID 1.1%
description: Improving sales, coupled with a continuing decline in production, allowed American businesses to reduce the value of their inventories of unsold goods by 1.1 percent in November, the biggest drop the Government has ever recorded, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: NEW POLICE CHIEF BATTLES CRIME BOOM IN HOUSTON
description: Lee P. Brown has served nine months as Police Chief in the city whose population, area and crime rate are all growing faster than anywhere else in the country.

title: 'Reopening the 1960's.'
description: WHEN P.S. 1 was Public School 1, it was the oldest and one of the largest public schools in Queens. In 1963, the school board decided that there were not enough students in the area to maintain the school, and the majestic, four-story, late-19th-century, red-brick building at 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City was abandoned. Since it was taken over in 1976 by the Institute of Art and Urban Resources - an organization founded in 1971 by Alanna Heiss, its executive director, to help artists find space in which to work - and was renamed Project Studios One, it has remained in some ways an educational institution, though of a very special and radical kind.

title: Founder of Petrie Replaces New Chief
description: Michael J. Boyle, a 38-year-old retailing executive who signed on with the Petrie Stores Corporation as heir to the founder, is leaving after less than two and a half months on the job.

title: Bridge: Once in a While, Both Bids And Play Are Unexpected
description: The great majority of bridge deals, unfortunately for the bridge writer, tend to follow well-trodden paths in both bidding and play; those that are interesting in the bidding tend to have dull play and vice versa. This leaves only a tiny percentage with taxing problems in both categories.

title: Rhodesia's Gift to Zimbabwe
description: At a time of desperation in most of Africa, Zimbabwe is one of the few countries doing relatively well.
