A major, and ironic, reason is that its economy coped with international sanctions for nearly 15 years after Rhodesia's unilateral declaration of independence, until the end of the civil war that led to the establishment of Zimbabwe.

title: Tylenol Extortion Trial Set
description: James W. Lewis, the man accused in the Tylenol extortion case, pleaded not guilty today before a Federal Magistrate to charges of mail fraud and making a false claim against the Government. The trial for Mr. Lewis, who is being held at the Federal penitentiary at Leavenworth, Kan., was placed on the Feb. 28 docket.

title: A CRIME BILL THAT DESERVES REAGAN'S SIGNATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUIT OVER FOOTBALL PLAYER'S DEATH IN COAST JAIL SETTLED FOR $1 MILLION
description: The parents of a college football player who died in 1981 in a jail cell will receive about $1 million in a legal settlement, a lawyer for a key defendant said today.

title: Car Bomb Kills 2 Near Beirut
description: A car bomb exploded today 12 miles south of here on the southern coastal highway controlled by Israeli forces. Two people were killed and several were wounded, state radio and witnesses said.

title: 'Rags,' a sequel about the people in the 'Fiddler' Story.
description: THE book musical, which was once thought to be an endangered species in the age of the so-called ''environmental'' or ''concept'' musical, is alive and well in the writing room of Joseph Stein, the librettist for ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' His latest musical is ''Rags,'' and his collaborators are two other theater veterans - Charles Strouse, who wrote the music for ''Annie'' and ''Applause,'' and Stephen Schwartz, the lyricist for ''Pippin'' and ''Godspell.'' The producer is Lee Guber. If all goes according to plan, ''Rags'' should open on Broadway next season.

title: Index; International
description: Hard times in northern Germany: quiet but deep A2 Government tells Greek Jews it's not anti-Semitic A2 Soviet cautious on a Palestinian- Jordanian link A3 Press censorship introduced in Assam A4 Around the World A5 Arms control: The U.S. team and the goals A6 Government/Politics Judge rules family of dead ex-official may sue for libel A10 New York proposes bus-stop shelter contract B3 Mrs. Rosenthal and Hevesi leading contenders for House post B3 Inquiry planned on TV commercials that Carey ordered B4 Tighter investment rules for state authorities urged B8 Washington Talk Briefing A16 The Bureaucracy: The art of leaking sensitive information A16 A look at Richard S. Schweiker's new employer A16 General Around the Nation A8 Prison inmates settle case against Alabama on conditions A9 Manufacturer of Three Mile Island plant opens trial defense A10 Spanish network tells of gains in broadcasting from Miami A14 Study finds neglect of data hampers U.S. health drules A15 Obituaries Dr. Edmund Jacobson, relaxation expert D15 Sidney F. Brody, Los Angeles civic leader D15 News Analysis Edward B. Fiske on S.A.T. scores required for student-athletes A11 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Memorials: Honoring Martin Luther King C17 Art: Stained glass in New York City C1

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES EXPRESS HAPPINESS IN SHARIN
description: ''We hope the gift enclosed will bring a small measure of warmth, food or comfort to some lonely person, child or adult,'' Victor Udoff of Teaneck, N.J., said in a note accompanying a donation of $250 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''Our own lives are full, and sharing is the least we can do.''

title: Glenn Files Presidential Paper
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio registered today as a Democratic Presidential candidate, and a top aide said he was already well on the way toward qualifying for Federal matching campaign funds.

title: STOCK INDEX OPTIONS SET BY KANSAS CITY BOARD
description: The Kansas City Board of Trade, after receiving permission yesterday to trade options on its Value Line stock index futures, said its new options market would open around Feb. 1 on the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's biggest commodity exchange.

title: ALABAMA SETTLES SUIT BY PRISONERS
description: A Federal district judge today approved an agreement in a decade-old case against Alabama's prison system, creating a four-member panel to monitor Gov-elect George C. Wallace's handling of prison affairs.

title: Unemployment Claims Rose at End of the Year
description: Some 550,000 Americans applied for unemployment benefits in the last week of 1982, an increase of 35,000 over the previous week and a reversal of the short decline that had heartened some economists.

title: JEWS OF EASTERN EUROPE
description: YOU don't have to be Jewish to love ''Image Before My Eyes,'' a sweet-tempered 90-minute evocation of Jewish life in Eastern Europe before World War II. Being shown tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. on Channel 13, it is the first of eight films that will be shown in a series that WNET calls ''Years of Darkness.'' As ''Image Before My Eyes'' makes luminously vivid, even those ominous years were not entirely dark.

title: Funds Down $1.6 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds declined by $1.6 billion, to $205.2 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the sixth weekly decline, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. This was substantially less than the previous week's decline of $4.2 billion.

title: Palmer Shoots a 66, Trails Zoeller by 2
description: Fuzzy Zoeller took the first-round lead in the Los Angeles Open with a 64 today, but Arnold Palmer took the spotlight on the Rancho Park municipal course.

title: WARSAW AIDE SAYS EXPULSION IS A WARNING TO ALL REPORTERS
description: The Polish Government said today that its decision to expel an American news agency correspondent was intended as a warning to all journalists here against maintaining contacts with what it denounced as the political opposition.

title: POP JAZZ
description: TWO outstanding jazz pianists, Muhal Richard Abrams and Marilyn Crispell, will be performing in New York this weekend. Miss Crispell will appear tonight at Soundscape, and Mr. Abrams will take a big band to Symphony Space on Sunday afternoon. Both of them might be considered avant-garde players, because they are comfortable with dissonance, free improvisation and other modern developments. But they have approached the jazz tradition in dissimilar, almost inverse ways.

title: Bank Manager Killed in Robbery
description: A 36-year-old bank manager was shot to death this morning by one of three men who held up the Investors Savings and Loan Association and escaped with an undetermined amount of money, the police said. The fatal shot was the only one fired.

title: RALPH ECCARD, 64, A JOCKEY AND TRAINER ON EAST COAST
description: Ralph Eccard, a longtime jockey and trainer at East Coast thoroughbred race tracks, died Wednesday at the age of 64.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A STATEMENT BY ROSTOW ON HIS DEPARTURE
description: I have invited you here this morning to say ''thank you'' and ''goodbye.'' We first met nearly two years ago. It was a dispiriting time for A.C.D.A. The agency had been neglected for several years. Much of its statutory jurisdiction had been taken over by others. As some of you may remember, I recalled on that occasion that I had dedicated a book to the Foreign Service and Civil Service of the United States.

title: Managers of Agencies In Jersey to Be Trained
description: Governor Kean signed an executive order today for Rutgers University to teach management techniques to supervisors of state agenices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Dutch in America

title: Brazilian Cleric Reports 7,291 Argentines Missing
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Sao Paulo released the names today of 7,291 people who he said had disappeared in Argentina in recent years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unwanted Visibility

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Andy Gibb Is Asked To Leave Hit Musical
description: Andy Gibb, the pop singer who has been playing the title role in the hit Broadway musical ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' at the Royale Theater, has been asked by the show's management to resign because of his ''inability to perform.'' His understudy, Doug Voet, replaced Mr. Gibb last night and is to remain in the role until a successor is chosen.

title: Anamax Slashing Copper Production
description: The Anamax Mining Company will suspend its Twin Buttes mine operations at the end of the month, laying off nearly half of its current work force, the company said today.

title: Sailor Gets Six Years Over Soviet Contacts
description: A Navy enlisted man has been sentenced to six years in prison for failing to report contacts with the Soviet Embassy in Washington and trying to sell embassy workers classified material, the Navy announced today.

title: STAGE: SCHOOL FOR SPIES IN 'ANOTHER COUNTRY'
description: Julian Mitchell, the author of the play ''Another Country,'' is not the first writer to observe that teen-age boys get a certain obscene pleasure out of caning one another in English public schools. And let's face it - audiences enjoy hearing about these rites, too. Plays, movies and novels about England's upper-crust educational institutions will always be popular because they show us the dirty, titillating underside of a social stratum that is supposed to exemplify decorum and propriety. We just never tire of watching the British ruling class with its pants down.

title: JOHN E. LAWLOR
description: John E. Lawlor, a senior associate in the law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft and a specialist in real-estate law, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan, apparently of a heart attack.

title: TAX FREE PROPERTIES IN CITY FACE FEES FOR TRASH PICKUP
description: Reversing a longstanding practice, the Koch administration is planning to charge tax-exempt properties a fee for garbage collection, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Tourism Up in China
description: China earned more than $800 million from foreign tourists last year, an increase of at least $20 million over 1981, the New China News Agency reported today. It said that the number of tourists in China increased last year despite the world economic recession, which reduced tourism in other countries. No figure was given for the total number of foreign visitors to China.

title: Treasures of Lindens.
description: MIRIAM HUBBARD MORRIS was an antiques collector to be reckoned with. Her 18th-century Washington home, called the Lindens, was toured by about 60,000 visitors over almost half a century. Her taste in Americana continued and reflected that of Etta Ross Hubbard, her mother, who was a pioneer turn-of-the-century collector.

title: OPERA: 'THE ABDUCTION' BY WASHINGTON TROUPE
description: Martin Feinstein, general director of the Washington Opera, has taken an enlightened route in his attempt to build his company into a major force in American opera. Instead of following the stereotyped path of the older sort of American company - several performances of standard repertory a year, with medium-tobig-name singers, plus an annual Luciano Pavarotti benefit gala - Mr. Feinstein has chosen to present a varied repertory in a small theater with mostly unknown singers, stressing ensemble quality and lively production.

title: ISRAELIS ACHEIVE AGENDA ACCORD WITH LEBANESE
description: After three weeks of negotiation, Israel and Lebanon reached agreement today on an agenda for their talks. An Israeli spokesman said the agenda included ''the termination of the state of war,'' ''a framework for mutual relations,'' security arrangements and the withdrawal of Israeli troops ''within the context of the evacuation of all foreign forces.''

title: CAREY'S USE OF TV ADS TO GET REVIEW
description: A State Senate committee today announced a review into the use of state-financed television commercials by former Gov. Hugh L. Carey in the closing weeks of the campaign for Governor last fall.

title: STURGES FILMS REMEMBERED IN SERIES AT REGENCY
description: PRESTON STURGES had one of the most meteoric directing careers in movie history, and his life was as freewheeling and urbane as his comedies. He was named Edmond P. Biden at his birth on Aug. 29, 1898, in Chicago, and was educated in private schools, mostly in France. At 16, he became manager of the Deauville branch of his mother's cosmetics company, and a few years later he invented a kissproof lipstick.

title: ART: FRANK STELLA'S PRINTS AT THE WHITNEY
description: WE'RE so accustomed to saluting Frank Stella's career as a painter - it's been nearly a quarter of a century since his debut in a Museum of Modern Art show at the age of 23 -that it comes as something of a shock to realize he's had another whole career, as a printmaker. The fact that Stella makes prints is by no means a secret, of course. What's surprising is the scope of this activity, now clearly laid out in ''Frank Stella: Prints 1967-82,'' the first full retrospective of Stella prints, on view at the Whitney Museum through March 13. A dazzling display, it comprises more than 150 works, beginning with the small, austere images of the late 1960's that diffidently mirrored his paintings, and ending with the big, exuberant pyrotechnics of today's output, works so boldly explorative of the medium itself that they give the word print a literal new dimension.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MINOR CHARACTERS. By Joyce John- son. 262 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95.

title: Rangers Get Help
description: The Rangers, who have been a bit thin on defense this season, picked up some experienced help by claiming Rick Chartraw, a 28-yearold who had been placed on waivers by the Los Angeles Kings. Chartraw had three goals and five assists in 31 games for the Kings this season.

title: Hiding Behind Information Fees
description: The Central Intelligence Agency may want to ''get rid of the Freedom of Information Act,'' in Director William Casey's blunt words, but at the Justice Department the approach is more subtle. There the strategy is to starve the act and encourage bureaucrats who make it harder for the public to get the information it seeks.

title: Namibia-Angola Linkage Rejected by Cuban
description: Vice President Juan Almeida Bosque of Cuba reiterated today that Cuban troops in Angola - estimated by Washington to number 30,000 - would leave only at the request of the Government and rejected a United States proposal linking their withdrawal with independence in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.

title: MILITARY LEADERS WOULD RATHER CUT WEAPONS THAN PAY
description: The Air Force's Chief of Staff, Gen. Charles A. Gabriel, said today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff would have urged a cut in arms programs rather than a pay freeze had they been consulted on the Reagan Administration's plan to slow military spending.

title: MISGUIDED ATTACKS ON AMERICAN WAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Leader Cool To Reagan Hiring Idea
description: The new chairman of United States Chamber of Commerce today brushed aside President Reagan's appeal for each business to hire one unemployed worker, saying, ''It is probably a good idea, but nothing more than a good idea.''

title: CONSERVATIVES OPPOSING OLD-AGE FUND TAX RISE
description: Conservative Republicans on President Reagan's advisory commission on Social Security took action today to block an emerging bipartisan compromise that they said would rely too much on new tax revenue and do too little to restrain the growth of old-age benefits.

title: GIVING JAZZ DANCE A LIFE OF ITS OWN
description: ''For a long time, we had to fight to enjoy ourselves dancing,'' Danny Buraczeski said the other day. ''And that's what 'On the Side of Light,' our New York premiere this weekend, is about.'' The dance will be performed by the Jazzdance-Danny Buraczeski Dance Company tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: CHRYSLER'S $1.1 BILLION SWAP PLAN
description: The Chrysler Corporation, whose stock has quadrupled in price in the past year, announced yesterday that it planned to issue new common stock and use it to retire $1.1 billion in obligations to banks and insurance companies.

title: Officials Arraigned In $100,000 Theft
description: Three executives of a Bronx armored car company were arraigned yesterday on charges of stealing $100,000 from a client. Their lawyers said they planned to plead not guilty.

title: Walker Indicted
description: Jimmy Walker, a former pro basketball player who starred at Providence, was indicted Wednesday by a Federal grand jury for failing to file federal tax returns in 1976 and 1977.

title: Manipulation Charged by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commision said it had settled a complaint filed in Federal court in New York, charging Texas General Resources Inc., a Houston-based energy concern, and Wilbur Edwin Bosarge, its chief executive, with fraud and market manipulation of shares of the Wainoco Oil Corporation.

title: TRUCKS MOVE DEBRIS FLOODS LEFT IN TOWN WITH DIOXIN TROUBLE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today made public more test results indicating that refuse spread through this dioxin-contaminated town by flooding last month did not contain amounts of dioxin above one part per billion, the level the tests were designed to detect. Meanwhile, a second convoy of trucks hauled loads of flood debris from the town.

title: Top Choice to Arrows
description: The New York Arrows of the Major Indoor Soccer League announced yesterday the signing of Joe Ulrich, their No.1 draft choice from Duke University.

title: LESLAW BDODENSKI
description: Leslaw Bdodenski, a prewar Polish diplomat, died of pneumonia on Dec. 28, at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 76 years old and lived in Ocean Grove, N.J. Mr. Bdodenski was in Poland's Foreign Service until the end of World War II. He then worked for Radio Free Europe until his retirement in 1971.

title: SPECIALIST IN TENSION CONTROL
description: Dr. Edmund Jacobson, a specialist in tension control, died last Friday at Northwestern University Hospital in Chicago. Dr. Jacobson, who for 50 years commuted between clinics in New York and Chicago, was 94 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Rostow-Shultz comments, page A6
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that President Reagan had a "firm dedication" to reaching arms control agreements with the Soviet Union and that the dismissal of Eugene V. Rostow as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency would have no effect on the Administration's policies.

title: Managers: News and Baseball; Winning Strategy
description: ''Few can say 'I'm a winning manager. I can win.' Billy can say that.'' Thus George Steinbrenner, owner of the New York Yankees, reintroduced the brilliant, volatile Billy Martin to preside for the third time over the pinstripes in the Bronx.

title: Celtics to Be Latest Nets' Test
description: ''Coming into any season, you always hope and think that you're going to do well,'' Otis Birdsong was saying amid the relief that prevailed in the locker room after the Nets had beaten the Indiana Pacers, 120-114, at Indianapolis Wednesday night for their 11th straight triumph.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SILENT FILM SCHEDULE
description: 'Pandora's Box,' the 1929 silent film by the German director G. W. Pabst, will be shown tomorrow night at 8 at the Collective for Living cinema at 52 White Street in TriBeCa. The film stars the American actress Louise Brooks as a woman convicted of murdering the man she loves; also in the film are Fritz Kortner and Franz Lederer. Admision is $3. Information: 925-2111

title: JAPAN STREAMLINING IMPORT RULES
description: Reacting to foreign criticism of its growing trade surpluses with the West, Japan announced today with much fanfare its third package of market-opening measures in less than a year. In adopting the new package, the Government is following up earlier tariff cuts and import quota increases with steps to dismantle Japan's numerous nontariff barriers to trade.

title: Sale by Manville
description: The Johns-Manville Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its asbestos-cement operations in Belgium to George Jacobs, managing director of its Belgian operations. No terms were disclosed by the company, a subsidiary of the Manville Corporation, the giant Denver-based manufacturer. In 1982, the Belgian operations contributed $23 million in sales and $2 million in net income.

title: MAKER OF 3 MILE ISLAND REACTOR OPENS DEFENSE CASE AT TRIAL
description: The manufacturer of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor opened its defense yesterday in the trial over the accident there by calling an engineer who indicated that the operators could have known by reading the control panel that the reactor was in danger.

title: Iowa 66 Northwestern 57
description: Greg Stokes scored 7 consecutive points early in the second half to put Iowa ahead to stay in the Big Ten Conference game. Stokes led Iowa with 17 points and Jim Stack led Northwestern with 25.

title: RECYCLING DAY IN ISLIP: NO GARBAGE PERMITTED
description: Peter Brown lifted the top of the trash can at 48 Candee Avenue in Sayville, and what he saw inside confirmed his worst fears - green olives.

title: DOLPHINS PRIMED TO GET BACK AT CHARGERS
description: It has been more than a year since that remarkable evening in the Orange Bowl, where the San Diego Chargers and the Miami Dolphins rode a physical and emotional roller coaster for 73 minutes 52 seconds. It was the fourth-longest playoff game in National Football League history, and by the time it ended - with a 41-38 Charger victory - it had qualified for consideration as one of the more exciting games ever played.

title: Intel's Net Climbs 73.9%
description: The Intel Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1982 climbed 73.9 percent, while revenues advanced 19.9 percent.

title: EX-GAMBLER CLAIMS PRO FOOTBALL FIXES
description: A former gambler awaiting sentencing on a Federal gun charge has said he fixed four professional football games a year during the 1968, 1969 and 1970 seasons at the behest of organized crime.

title: DUTCH RESISTANCE
description: THE Dutch film ''The Girl With the Red Hair'' would be drab even without its chief visual device, which makes it doubly so. The director, Ben Verbong, has faded the film's color so as to emphasize the heroine's flame-shaded coiffure, but he's done this so inexpertly that the hair looks brownish. Everything else in this feature-length film, Mr. Verbong's first, is a muddy green.

title: Argentine brings his hit to the U.S.
description: ''TIME FOR REVENGE,'' a psychological thriller from Argentina that opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse (it is reviewed on page C8), was inspired by a story that its writer-director, Adolfo Aristarain, heard in Spain. ''A guy fell off a horse,'' he says, ''and pretended to be struck dumb. He didn't speak for a year, not even to his brother. And a lawyer sued the horse's owner, and they collected money, and then the dumb man went to Lourdes and came out yelling: 'It's a miracle! I can talk!' ''

title: Still a Giant
description: Ron Erhardt, the offensive coordinator of the Giants last season, has been rehired by Bill Parcells, the new head coach. In 1979, when Erhardt was head coach of the New England Patriots, Parcells was his linebacker coach. With Erhardt as offensive coordinator this season, the Giants improved their offense by more than 33 yards a game, to 303.2 yards.

title: WATER WARNING BEING PREPARED BY CITY OFFICIALS
description: New York City will declare a drought warning unless a significant amount of rain or snow falls in the reservoir areas in the next few days, according to officials at the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdahl Corp. has decreased by 15 percent the purchase price for its 6000 series storage system.

title: Guatemala Says It Holds American as Guerrilla
description: The army said today that an American man and a Spanish woman have been arrested on charges of leading leftist guerrilla raids on sugar plantations and killing one plantation administrator.

title: WIFE MAY NOT KEEP ALL OF P.O.W.'S PAY
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here has ruled that a woman who lived with another man while her husband was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam was entitled to some of his pay but not the full $122,000 the Air Force is said to have given her.

title: DRIVING AGAINST THE SOCIAL CONTRACT
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39. 1. The person who owns this silver spoon must have been born with one in his or her mouth. Explain. 2. ''I've had it up to my keister with these leaks.'' Who made the remark and what was he talking about? 3. In New York City, the Citizen's Budget Commission issued a report that may be good news for one uniformed service but may make another uniformed service angry. Explain.

title: FORGOTTEN AMERICANS
description: A sign in a Veterans Administration Hospital reads, ''The Price of Freedom Is Visible Here,'' and the U.S.O. has not forgotten the men and women who have fought for the nation. The friendly smile of a volunteer and the red, white and blue U.S.O. banner make the Vietnam veterans in the 12 V.A. hospitals in the metropolitan area as well as the servicemen from World War I and World War II feel that their sacrifices are appreciated.

title: SAFETY AGENCY FINDS BRAKE DEFECT AFFECTS 320,000 OF G.M.'S X-CARS
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today announced a preliminary finding that the brakes on 320,000 General Motor's 1980 X-model cars were defective.

title: Group Asks to Sell Some KDT Stores
description: KDT Industries, a Newton, Mass. company that is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, said a group of unsecured creditors had filed an application with a Federal District Court in New York to force the company to sell or lease its 18 King's department stores in the Caribbean. KDT, which also operates 25 King's stores in the Northeastern United States, said it would oppose the motion, because it said prospects now ''appear good'' for the chain, which filed for Chapter 11 protection in August.

title: Mrs. Reagan Will Act In Antidrug TV Role
description: Nancy Reagan will appear in an antidrug cameo role on the NBC-TV comedy ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' her press secretary said Thursday.

title: She's a Natural
description: It began innocently enough for Shola Lynch two years ago. A friend of her father saw her running around a field in Central Park, thought she looked fast and told her mother that maybe she should consider a running career.

title: TOMATO OF FUTURE?
description: The State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University is trying to develop a tomato that can be picked red-ripe at the height of maturity and shipped to market without deteriorating.

title: Brooks Says Again He Is Not Leaving
description: Despite Glen Sonmor's resignation Thursday night as coach of the Minnesota North Stars and earlier speculation that Coach Herb Brooks of the Rangers was in line for that job, Brooks and the North Stars again denied the rumors yesterday.

title: Dear Roberto
description: For 10 years, Ray Arcel worked in the corner of Roberto Duran while the Panamanian boxer won the world lightweight and welterweight titles. Duran, no longer the fighter he once was, continues his latest comeback Jan. 29 when he meets Pipino Cuevas, the former welterweight champion, in what might as well be an old-timers' match in Los Angeles.

title: 10 to Share Prize In Jersey Lotto
description: The holders of 10 winning tickets, a record, are in line to share the top prize in this week's Pick-6 Lotto game, New Jersey State Lottery Director Hazel F. Gluck said today.

title: Ayala Out of Jail
description: Tony Ayala Jr. was released from jail in Paterson, N.J., on $75,000 bond yesterday. Ayala, the World Boxing Association's top-ranked junior-middleweight contender, had been imprisoned since New Year's Day, when he was charged with aggravated sexual assault.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. The late-medieval English spoon was sold in London last year for $24,410, the highest auction price ever paid for a spoon. 2. President Reagan made the remark in telling his staff to limit relations with the press. 3. The report recommended that the strength of the police force be maintained or increased largely by diverting funds from the Fire Department, whose force could be reduced because of a 27 percent decline in arson in the last five years.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Designated Bruce B ochy, reserve catcher, for assignment. If c lub does not make a deal for him within 10 d ays, he will be released. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Paul Moskau, p itcher, as free agent. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Announced that D an Quisenberry, relief pitcher, has a greed to a new four-year contract; an- n ounced that the club will continue to oper- a te Class AAA Omaha farm through com- i ng season. Parent team was unable to f ind a buyer for affiliate. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed David C ohen, shortstop, and assigned him to W isconsin farm team. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Al Cowens, o utfielder, to a three-year contract.

title: REAGAN DENIES ADMINISTRATION FALTERS
description: President Reagan today rejected criticism that his Administration was in disarray and contended that faulty news reports, not his leadership, had caused the problem.

title: BEST SITE FOR RESOURCE RECOVERY PLANT ONE
description: T o the Editor: The issues raised by New York City Comptroller Goldin in his Dec. 31 letter (''An Island Fit for a Resource Recovery Plant'') are legitimate environmental concerns, most of which are addressed in the Preliminary Draft Environmental Impact Statement prepared by the city's Department of Sanitation.

title: NO PARITY ON ARMS, AN EXPERT ASSERTS
description: The Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact have a nearly 6-to-1 superiority in missile launchers in Europe and an advantage of roughly 4 to 1 in missiles over the United States and NATO, instead of the parity described in Soviet publications, according to Donald R. Cotter, a civilian expert on nuclear strategy and weapons.

title: IF FEDERAL LEGISLATORS KNEW HUNGER
description: To the Editor:

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP MODESTLY
description: The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that M-2, now the most closely watched measure of the nation's money supply, rose a modest $14.1 billion in December.

title:
PATENTS;
Animal Vaccine
description: A vaccine against a skin disease in fur-bearing animals was patented this week by two Moscow inventors. Patent 4,368,191, for the vaccine and the method of its preparation, went to Arutjun K. Sarkinov and Lev I. Nikiforov, who work in veterinary medicine. The disease, which makes the fur and the flesh of the animals unmarketable, is caused by a pathogenic organism and can infect humans.

title: JUDGE VOIDS BERKELEY BAN ON ELECTROSHOCK THERAPY
description: A law banning electroshock therapy within the city limits of Berkeley has been voided by a judge here. Presiding Judge Donald P. McCullum of Alameda County Superior Court issued an injunction Thursday restraining the City of Berkeley from enforcing the prohibition pending a trial on the issues.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * AGS Computers had 1.1 million common shares priced for offering at $15.25 a share, through underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Inquiry Asked in Rosenbloom Death

title: Englewood Mayor Confers on Libyans
description: The Mayor of Englewood, N.J., and the Representative serving that city met for 90 minutes today with officials of the State Department to press their opposition to the purchase of an Englewood estate by Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Falcons Drop Coach
description: Losing coaches expect to be replaced. But Leeman Bennett's Atlanta Falcons had a 5-4 record this season, and Bennett thought he had an understanding with the Falcons' owner, Rankin Smith, that his job was secure.

title: No Headline
description: SHIPYARD PREVENTS WALESA FROM RETURNING TO HIS JOB

title: Tribute to Isak Dinesen
description: A multimedia tribute to the writer Isak Dinesen on Jan. 31 will open the 12th Writers in Performance series sponsored by the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: NETS STREAK ENDED AT 11 VICTORIES
description: The Boston Celtics ended the Nets' record winning streak with a jolt tonight. After the Nets had spent 22 euphoric days winning 11 consecutive games, they were trounced, 133-108, at Boston Garden before a sellout crowd of 15,320.

title: HEARINGS BEGIN ON BRANIFF DEAL
description: More than 150 spectators and lawyers packed the courtroom at the United States District Courthouse here today for the start of what could be the most critical hearing in the eightmonth-old bankruptcy proceeding of the Braniff International Corporation.

title: KING, SHEROD HURT
description: The fans at the Omni were friendlier to Hubie Brown tonight than were the Atlanta Hawks, the team he coached for five seasons before his dismissal in April 1981.

title: BIG 3'S UNITS RIVAL BANKS
description: In bold, black headlines over the past two weeks, the Big Three auto makers have been introducing their latest model: 11.9 percent financing.

title: fCo rt T pe's Spl c d
description: I am a performer of miracles. Minor miracles, to be sure, but miracles nonetheless.

title: PANEL SEEKS TO CUT THROUGH STATE'S TAX JUNGLE
description: Yankee and Mets fans pay them, but theatergoers do not. Orange juice is exempt, but orange drink is not. Eastman Kodak gets a big break, but advertising agencies do not.

title: Rainier National
description: The Rainier National Bank has shelved plans to move its credit card division to South Dakota and decided to raise its card user fees instead.

title: Australia Lifts Ban on Banks
description: Australia has decided to relax a ban that has been in place for 40 years and allow about 10 foreign banks to set up shop as a first step toward opening the market to overseas competition.

title: TOO FLAT TO FLY
description: As a formula for revolution, the so-called ''flat tax'' is hard to beat. This is why it's shocking to hear these rumors that a conservative like President Reagan may urge it on the Congress.

title: The Civil Rights of Police
description: To the Editor:

title: The Glamorous Artificial Heart
description: Barney Clark, the artificial-heart patient at the University of Utah, is in his seventh week of added life and his doctors are even talking of sending him home. That would be quite a feat, but it does not mean the Government's 20-year artificial-heart program is within reach of success. And if success were attainable, there may be better ways to invest our health funds.

title: Fire Safety, Fire Savings
description: How many firefighters does New York City need? Enough, obviously, to put out all its fires. The number of those fires has been decreasing for nearly five years - enough of a trend to suggest that cutbacks need not jeopardize public safety.

title: WARD-ALZADO: A PIVOTAL TEST
description: An early meeting between them left Chris Ward near tears. The most recent one sent Lyle Alzado home with nothing to show for his three hours of work except some shreds of Ward's jersey.

title: OPERA: 'CONTES D'HOFFMAN'
description: Opera companies must often wish they could cut and edit live performances the way the engineers do it in recording sessions, keeping the best segments and splicing them together into one ideal version. If that could be done, what a thoroughly dazzling ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' the Metropolitan Opera would have on its hands. The thought occurred to me on Thursday night as the Metropolitan's captivating production of Offenbach's masterpiece was having its first performance of the season.

title:
PATENTS;
A Cover for Umbrellas
description: Emanuel Dubinsky of Yonkers received a patent in 1970 for a rain and storage cover to protect garden umbrellas. There was no need to stand on a chair or table to put it on, and it has long been manufactured by Finkel Outdoor Products Inc. This week Mr. Dubinsky got patent 4,367,762 for a more compact version called the E.Z. Flip Umbrella Cover.

title: TRANSMUTING TRASH
description: The disagreement blocking a plan to build a steam-generating incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is much more than a squabble over whether Williamsburg residents will be forced to admit an unpleasant neighbor. The controvery points to a larger problem: If nothing is done, sometime soon New York City will face the monumental embarrassment of having no place to put its municipal solid waste (''M.S.W.,'' as experts tidily call it) - the 20,000 tons of garbage, waste paper, bottles and cans that, more or less encased in black plastic bags, grace sidewalks every day.

title: WILLIAM DOLE, 65, AN ARTIST WHO WAS KNOWN FOR COLLAGES
description: William Dole, an artist who was ranked internationally as one of the most distinguished practitioners of collage, died suddenly in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Thursday. He was 65 years old.

title:
PATENTS;
Universal Radiator For Automobiles
description: A universal radiator assembly patented this week by John J. MacIntosh of Hesperia, Calif., is intended to simplify the replacement of radiators in thousands of automobile models.

title: Rev. Norris Tibbetts; At Riverside 17 Years
description: The Rev. Norris L. Tibbetts, who was a minister at the Riverside Church in Manhattan for 17 years before he retired in 1959, died in his sleep on Thursday at the Navesink House, a retirement home in Red Bank, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: JOB BLACKMAIL
description: Can the creation of jobs be achieved only at the expense of environmental and health protections? Many in the Administration and the business community want the public to think so. But those who make such claims are resorting to job blackmail, playing upon fear of unemployment to win support for needless pollution.

title: Reagan to Travel to Chicago
description: President Reagan will make a one-day trip to Chicago Wednesday to revisit the Providence-St. Mel school, a predominantly black parochial school, and address a fund-raising event for Senator Charles H. Percy, a spokesman announced Thursday. Larry Speakes, deputy press secretary, said that Mr. Reagan would go to the school ''to see the progress'' that had been made since he visited there last May.

title: Interferon Is Used in Attempt To Save Life of Rabies Victim
description: A 30-year-old man battling a case of rabies that he apparently contracted when he was bitten by a dog in East Africa was reported to be in critical condition today as doctors used interferon in an attempt to save his life.

title: CHARLOTTE L. PURNICK
description: Charlotte Leah Purnick, a founder of Purnick & Dalstyle Inc., designers and manufacturers of furs in Manhattan, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Bayside, Queens. She was 67 years old.

title: DANCE: ABT II PRESENTS PREMIERE OF 'PASSAGE'
description: The indisputable hit of the new program given by American Ballet Theater II Thursday night was ''Passage,'' a dramatic and strangely haunting ballet by the young Canadian choreographer, James Kudelka.

title: ABORTION RULING: 10 YEARS OF BITTER CONFLICT
description: Ten years ago next Saturday the United States Supreme Court ruled that the decision to perform an abortion would be a private matter of concern only to the woman and her physician and that only in the later stages of pregnancy was the state entitled to any voice in the matter.

title: Olson, at 18-10 1/4, Tops Best Vault
description: Billy Olson of Abilene, Tex., bettered his world indoor-best height in the pole vault tonight at the Ottawa International Games, clearing the bar at 18 feet 10 1/4 inches. He set the previous best of 18-10 last year at the Millrose Games in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Technology column in Business Day Thursday incorrectly named the largest manufacturer of automatic bank teller machines. It is Diebold Inc.

title: News Analysis
description: The United States Government is expressing increasing anxiety as energy conservation and the recession bring a continuing decline in oil prices and talk of a precipitous drop this spring.

title: DECEMBER OUTPUT OFF BY ONLY 0.1%
description: Production of the nation's factories fell only one-tenth of 1 percent in December, the Federal Reserve reported today, giving a promising signal that the economy's longest decline since World War II may finally be touching bottom.

title: Federal Judge Orders CBS-TV To Delay '60 Minutes' Report
description: A Federal District judge today ordered CBS-TV not to broadcast a ''60 Minutes'' report this weekend about seven New Orleans police officers charged with violating the civil rights of blacks by beating, kicking and threatening to kill them in the course of investigating the 1980 slaying of a white officer.

title: U.S. KORF IS IN TROUBLE, TOO
description: Since Willy Korf became the first foreign owner of a producing American steel mill in 1969, competitors have admired the efficiency of his plants in South Carolina and Texas.

title: News Analysis
description: Civil libertarians and experts in communications law have mixed reactions to a judge's ruling that a libel suit brought by an individual before his death could be continued by his family.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST MAY BE INSPIRED BY A MISFORTUNE
description: Often because of personal experience with a particular misfortune, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask that their donations be used to ease suffering from afflictions that add to the burdens of the needy and neglected.

title: Earnings Off In Chemicals
description: The International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation reported yesterday that the slump in the overall economy caused net income in its second fiscal quarter to plunge 68.7 percent and sales to decline 11.6 percent.

title: El Paso Sheriff Test Is Found Difficult
description: Almost two-thirds of the people applying for openings in the El Paso Sheriff's Department failed an entrance examination that, among other things, asked them to spell ''felony,'' officials say.

title: Miss de Agostini Downhill Winner
description: Doris de Agostini of Switzerland turned in another of her strong performances today by winning her second World Cup downhill race of the season.

title: FILM: 'ANARCHISM IN AMERICA'
description: The Public Theater's latest free film program, to be shown Saturdays and Sundays at 2 P.M., is an exceptionally lucid and interesting documentary. It's a successful attempt to provide a capsule history and explanation of its subject. Beginning with footage of a new-wave band that mentions anarchy in its lyrics, and proceeding to interviews in which people on the street are asked what they think anarchism means (''I would say that it's a person trying to push his views down everybody's throat''), the film - ''Anarchism in America'' -proceeds to offer a cogent definition and to dispel as many misconceptions as it can.

title: PEREZ DE CUELLAR BACKS U.N. FORCE
description: A strong plea to continue the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was issued here today by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: Sweden Jobless Rate Up
description: Sweden's unemployment rate edged up to 3.2 percent in December from 3.1 percent in November and 2.9 percent in December 1981, the Government said today.

title: Italy Cuts Sentences Of Dozier's Kidnappers
description: An Italian appeals court reduced the sentences of 10 Red Brigades members convicted of kidnapping Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier and ordered a retrial for four still at large.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Some days, at the Sixth Precinct station house in Greenwich Village, Michael Fandal puts on a blue coat, a hat and a badge, and becomes Police Officer Fandal, assigned to patrol Washington Square Park. Some days, in tiny storage rooms smelling of dust and disinfectant, to one side of a school gymnasium, he puts on white and red greasepaint, striped socks and floppy old sneakers and becomes Ernest Desire, the clown.

title: Gulf Stressing Credit Cards
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation became the second major gasoline company this week to announce a new push to encourage the use of credit cards at its service stations.

title: CHILE, IN SURPRISE MOVE, IS TAKING OVER 8 BANKS
description: The Chilean Government took over eight banks yesterday. Bankers in New York said they were stunned by the move, and they predicted that it would plunge Chile into the same kind of liquidity crisis that has plagued other Latin American countries.

title: STATE JUSTICE IN BRINK'S TRIAL TELLS SHERIFF NOT TO OBEY FEDERAL ORDER
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the Rockland County sheriff today not to comply with a Federal Court order to give Federal authorities custody of a defendant in the Brink's robbery and murder case.

title: 'M*A*S*H' BIDS FAREWELL TO CAMERAS
description: After 11 years as one of the country's most popular television programs, the CBS antiwar comedy series ''M*A*S*H'' ended today, with hundreds of reporters and photographers watching the filming of the last scene.

title: TV: CHURCHILL'S WILDERNESS YEARS
description: Few masterpieces have appeared on ''Masterpiece Theater'' in the dozen years that Mobil Oil has been importing British fuel to light up American television, but the series has brought us literate scripts, stylish acting and classy settings, particularly of Britain in other eras. Tomorrow night at 9 o'clock on WNET-Channel 13, we are invited yet again by the smoke curling elegantly upward from a splendid Churchill-size cigar in a solid glass ashtray to that popular period known as between-the-wars.

title: Chapman Grant Dead at 95; Grandson of Ulysses S. Grant
description: Chapman Grant, historian, zoologist, publisher and grandson of Ulysses S. Grant, has died at the age of 95 in a nursing home.

title: FOR PEACEKEEPERS, AN UNCERTAIN TIME
description: It is thousands of miles from this obscure spot in southern Lebanon near the Israeli border to the United Nations headquarters in New York City. But events there are being closely watched by the inhabitants of Naqura, which is headquarters for about 6,300 soldiers from 11 nations.

title: AUSTRIAN IS LINKED TO ATTACK ON POPE
description: An Austrian arms dealer whose name has been mentioned in connection with the pistol used in the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II was arrested here Tuesday in an investigation into the smuggling of a consignment of weapons from Czechoslovakia.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1983; The Economy
description: Factory production fell only 0.1 percent in December, the Federal Reserve reported. The figure was seen by some economists as a signal that the recession may finally be touching bottom, but others were more cautious in their assessments. For all of 1982, the factory production index fell 8.2 percent, its sharpest decline since 1974, in the midst of another recession. (Page 1.) Producer prices rose 0.1 percent in December. The increase brought the rate for all of 1982 to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest rise in 11 years and half the 1981 rate. (31.)

title: U.S. ESTIMATES GAS PRICE RISE
description: Natural gas prices for most residential and industrial customers will rise by a total of $3 billion a year in both 1983 and 1984, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said today. In 1985, the increase is expected to decline to about $1.8 billion, it added.

title:
PATENTS;
Classroom Signals For Deaf Students
description: A method to improve the teaching of deaf students in a class with students with normal hearing was patented this week by Prof. Robert Sapora, who teaches English at Western Maryland College in Westminster.

title: Rick Middleton's New Priority
description: BOSTON I f the reputation he had established in New York was not enough, a conversation at the beginning of Rick Middleton's first training camp as a member of the Boston Bruins provided a clue that a change in priorities might be in order. He appeared a little heavier to Don Cherry, the Bruin coach in 1976, which made the coach wonder out loud if Middleton had done some weight-lifting during the offseason.

title: Joaquin Garrigues, 83, Spanish Legal Scholar
description: Joaquin Garrigues y Diaz-Canabate, a leading legal scholar in Spain who helped develop the country's body of corporate law, died Monday of heart failure in Madrid, where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: San Diego Arena Safety Questioned
description: City Councilman Bill Mitchell has urged ''the immediate closure'' of the San Diego Sports Arena, where the Clippers play their home games, because of a building specialist's recommendation that the roof be replaced to prevent a ''major accident.'' But San Diego Entertainment, which operates the 17-yearold arena, says closing it would be ''too dramatic a move.''

title: Quebec Smelter Deal
description: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today that he hopes a contract for a $1 billion aluminum smelter to be built in Quebec by Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A. will be signed in June.

title: TAO TO KOSHER TO ALBANIAN
description: Cookbook collectors in search of new and unusual esoterica should welcome the recent publication of three highly specialized and excellent works, widely divergent in appeal.

title: CONCERT: JULLIARD STRING QUARTET AT CARNEGIE
description: Of Beethoven's chamber works, none are more suited to the vastness of Carnegie Hall than the three ''Rasumovsky'' quartets. The Juilliard String Quartet played them all Friday night and to an audience that filled the hall and overflowed onto its stage. The Juilliard responded with some of Beethoven's grandest and most oratorical music.

title: Mets to Reassign Bochy, Catcher
description: Bruce Bochy, who was the Mets' No.2 catcher for the final five weeks of the season, was designated for reassignment yesterday, meaning that he will be released unless the team can make a deal for him in 10 days.

title: PUSHING ON WATER
description: Crime statistics are down somewhat in the city. But anarchy figures are up. According to my sources, anarchy increased by 17.2 percent last year. The Mayor, I am told, is contemplating the creation of an Anarchy-Control Commissioner. Things are serious.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Knicks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 8:05 P.M. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.) Fordham vs. St. Peter's, followed by Seton Hall vs. Syracuse, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7 P.M.. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - Fordham-St. Peter's, WFUV-FM, 90.7, 7 P.M.; Seton Hall-Syracuse, WNYE-FM, 91.5, 9:30 P.M.) North Carolina at Virginia (Television - Channel 4, 1:30 P.M.) Other College Games: St. John's at Boston College (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 7:30 P.M.); Providence at Villanova (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Clemson at Wake Forest (Television - ESPN, noon); Notre Dame at Marquette (Television - ESPN, 3 P.M.); Florida State at Virginia Tech (Television -USA Cable, 5:30 P.M.); Old Dominion at James Madison (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.); Wisconsin at Michigan (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); Oregon State at U.C.L.A. (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.); Oregon at Southern California (Television - USA Cable, 11 P.M.); Iona at Army, 2 P.M. (Radio - WFAS-FM, 103.9; 2 P.M.); Harvard at Columbia, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:30 P.M.).

title: HEART RECIPIENT OFFERED SPECIAL NO-RENT HOMES
description: A January thaw has erased the brown snow that covered the grounds of the city's better neighborhoods for weeks, and house hunters are beginning to inquire early about what properties will be available this year.

title: The Close and Its Choristers
description: Within the park-like close of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at Amsterdam Avenue and 111th Street, the Cathedral School has been turning out choirboys since 1901 -and, since 1976, choirgirls.

title: Reagan Vetoes Wilderness Bill
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have created seven wilderness areas in Florida, saying it would have required the Government to pay companies up to $200 million for minerals in the areas.

title: A BACKDOOR ASSAULT ON FAMILY PLANNING
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA IS ASSAILED IN SOVIET JOURNAL
description: A Soviet journal said today that Peking had undermined the fragile movement toward detente with Moscow by keeping longtime territorial claims and disputes alive and infusing its people with anti-Soviet sentiments.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LANDMARKS

title: Court Overturns Sears Judgment
description: A Federal appeals court overturned an $8 million patent infringement judgment against Sears, Roebuck & Company that had been awarded to the inventor of a quick-release socket wrench.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Living Link

title: KING BIRTHDAY SPARKS LESSON ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke years ago of a voice echoing through the long passageways of time that called for nonviolence in the fight for civil rights. In a school auditorium on the Lower East Side yesterday, young voices debated whether Dr. King's philosophy was the best way to realize his promise that ''we shall overcome.''

title: Tracy Austin In Semifinal
description: Third-seeded Tracy Austin defeated eighthseeded Anne Smith, 6-1, 6-2, tonight for the spot opposite Martina Navratilova in Saturday's semifinals in the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tennis tournament.

title: Cocaine Use Denied
description: A Texas drug dealer testified yesterday that he had used cocaine with Harvey Martin, the star defensive end for the Dallas Cowboys, who denied the accusation. ''It's all a lie,'' said Martin, who accused the drug dealer, Danny Stone, of committing perjury in his testimony against four persons charged with selling cocaine.

title: Knight's Removal Asked in Motion
description: Six senators introduced a motion in the Puerto Rican Senate today asking the United States Olympic Committee to remove Bobby Knight as coach of the American basketball team in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Rail Aid Measure Signed by Reagan
description: President Reagan today signed legislation that earmarks $30 million in Federal aid over the next three years for rail improvements between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, a growing casino-gambling resort.

title: Two Under Treatment
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers say that Steve Howe, their 24-year-old relief pitcher who was the National League's rookie of the year in 1980, underwent a five-week program for ''chemical dependency'' at The Meadows in Wickenburg, Ariz., late last year, and that the center fielder Ken Landreaux is currently being treated there. ... The Kansas City Royals have signed their star reliever, Dan Quisenberry, to a contract that is guaranteed through 1986 with an option for 1987. The Royals also got good news from George Brett, their all-star third baseman who had hinted he might not report to spring training if they did not extend his contract. Although the Royals refused, Brett said he would report to training camp on time. ... Chicago Cubs General Manager Dallas Green has been talking with his Los Angeles Dodgers counterpart, Al Campanis, and the result, he says, is a ''60-40'' chance the Cubs will acquire Ron Cey, the 34-year-old Dodger third baseman. ...

title: Jersey Prisoners Ordered From Jail
description: A judge has ordered the New Jersey Department of Corrections to remove all of its prisoners from the overcrowded Hudson County Jail by the end of February.

title: Lower Profits Seen by Socal
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, blaming reduced demand for petroleum products and the relatively high contract price it must pay for the oil it buys from Saudi Arabia, said yesterday that earnings in 1982 had falled almost 50 percent from a year earlier. It did not give details.

title: News Analysis
description: With less than 12 months left before American medium-range missiles are due to be deployed in Western Europe, the Soviet Union has begun to fine-tune a campaign designed to block their emplacement and leave at least some of its 340 SS-20 missiles in place.

title: CITY BALLET HOLDS BENEFIT FOR ITS SCHOOL ON JAN.19
description: The New York City Ballet's fifth annual gala for the school of American Ballet, its affiliated school, will take place on Jan.19 at the State Theater.

title: NONALIGNED BLOC BACKS NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua tonight won the backing of an important bloc of third world nations in its continuing dispute with the Reagan Administration over what it says is United States support for anti-Sandinist rebels based in neighboring Honduras.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: JAPANESE DECIDE TO PERMIT EXPORT OF MILITARY TECHNOLOGY TO THE U.S.
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who is preparing for talks with President Reagan in Washington next week, has decided to allow the export of Japanese military technology to the United States, a Cabinet announcement said today.

title: PALMER SHOOTS 69 FOR 135 BUT TRAILS BY 4
description: With all the things he has to think about - his business enterprises, golf-course construction, the design of golf clubs and endorsements - it is a wonder that Arnold Palmer has time to think about his game, let alone play it well.

title: Bridge:; Only Experience Can Teach Some Aspects of the Game
description: Some of the arts of bridge, such as constructive bidding and the techniques of dummy-play, can be learned out of a book. But when it comes to competitive bidding judgment, there is no substitute for experience.

title: No Headline
description: WIFE OF MEMPHIS CULT CHIEF ASKED THAT HE BE CONFINED

title: Paying for Liberty
description: Alan and Margaret McSurely struggled for 15 years to vindicate their right to urge social change, read unpopular literature, keep the Government from prying into their diaries and intimate letters. At long last a jury in Washington D.C. has delivered a ringing verdict: the late Senator John McClellan of Arkansas conspired with Senate aides and Kentucky law enforcement officials to rob the McSurelys of their liberties. The jury awarded them $1.6 million in damages.

title: 6TH GRADERS GIVE STUYVESANT AUTHORS MIXED REVIEWS
description: The books - one with a magic wand glued to the front, another bound with black velvet, another with gift-wrapping - were laid out on a table in the middle of the classroom.

title: INFANT MORTALITY IN CITY DECLINES TO A RECORD LOW
description: The rate of infant deaths in New York City dropped in 1982 to a record low, the Health Department said yesterday. It was the ninth consecutive year that the rate dropped.

title: A LEGISLATIVE BATTLE IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The legislative battle on abortion crosses national, state and local lines. What has happened to a piece of legislation in Pennsylvania basically typifies how the dispute over abortion is waged both by those who favor freedom of choice in the matter and by those who advocate what they term the right to life. The sequence of events was described by Morgan Plant, executive director of Planned Parenthood affiliates in Pennsylvania; the description was concurred in by Molly Kelly, executive director of the southeast chapter of Pennsylvanians for Human Life.

title: Texas Eastern Earnings Charge
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a Houston-based energy company, said it would take a charge of $25 million, or 97 cents a share, against fiscal year 1982 earnings to account for an exploratory well off the Red Sea coast of the Sudan that the company was forced to plug and abandon. Texas said the well indicated minor, but noncommercial, hydocarbon levels.

title: FROLICS IN FLORIDA AND OTHER ANTICS
description: What clearer signs could there be of a post-Christmas movie slump than the arrival of two mindless teen-age movies on the same day? ''Spring Fever'' and ''The Last American Virgin,'' both of which opened at neighborhood theaters yesterday, are aimed strictly at the drive-in crowd or its downtown equivalent. The second film is the more tolerable of the two, although it owes its locker-room humor to ''Porky's,'' a movie that was regrettably guaranteed to inspire imitation. Even the relatively clean-cut ''Spring Fever'' has enough raunchy touches to suggest (erroneously) that its characters aren't hopelessly square.

title: Belgian, Thought Dead On Everest, Turns Up
description: A Belgian climber thought to have died on Mount Everest two weeks ago turned up safe here today. Jean Bourgeois, 44 years old, an engineer from Dinant, Belgium, fell Dec. 30 while climbing with an 11-man French team.

title: Ending a Gallic Visit
description: Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris was headed for home last night after a week that brought four or five tete-a-tete sessions with the Mayor of New York, a call on President Reagan in Washington and a ''bon voyage et revenez'' from a gathering yesterday at New York University.

title: Meeting on Rules
description: The presidents of several predominantly black colleges plan to meet with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the civil rights activist, in Baton Rouge, La., next Tuesday to work out a common response to the new academic rules adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The presidents include Joseph B. Johnson of Grambling State and Jesse N. Stone Jr. of Southern University, who have denounced the new standards as racist. Despite those protests, William Gerberding, the president of the University of Washington, who is white, said yesterday that ''many black educators'' were in favor of the new rules.

title: FRICTION AT THE TOP THROWS OFF SPARKS AT ARMS CONTROL AGENCY
description: Considering that it is basically an advisory group and has no real power, the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency should be just another of those innocuous and anonymous Washington institutions, churning out technical studies and options papers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Welcome Change At 1 Police Plaza

title: Swiss Get Soviet Soldier
description: Another Soviet soldier captured by Afghan rebels and handed over to the International Commitee of the Red Cross arrived in Switzerland today for internment pending an end to hostilities. The soldier was the eighth kept in custody by the Swiss under an agreement between Switzerland, the Soviet Union, the Red Cross and Afghan resistance groups.

title: Poll Finds Democrats Favor Mondale for '84
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale holds a comfortable lead over other Democrats in the first Gallup Poll of Presidential preferences taken after Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said on Dec. 1 that he would not be a candidate.

title: MAIL-ORDER FAMILY HISTORIES
description: The book offer came in with the junk mail, b ut it was irresistible. Published by Sharon L. Taylor of Copley, O hio, the book was engagingly titled ''The Amazing Story of the L apinskis in America.'' At $26.35, it seemed an easy way to learn m ore about my wife's Polish ancestry.

title: Starting Over
description: Milt Williams has been biding his time since his semipro season ended with the New Jersey Rams of the Mid-East Football Conference last fall. There was a part-time job with the United Parcel Service and some work for his uncle.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Transcript of news session, page 10.
description: President Reagan said today that he was determined to make progress in arms control and that the United States was now ''in a position to get somewhere'' in negotiating agreements with the Soviet Union.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Carter-Ford Act

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wed at Last

title: 6 OIL NATIONS TO MEET
description: An Arab oil minister said today that a meeting Saturday of delegates from six Persian Gulf countries would not consider reducing their oil prices.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think inflation has come down and is not going to turn around on a dime and come back again.'' - Robert Ortner, the chief economist in the Commerce Department. (1:6.)

title: Friends at Last, Martin Says
description: Billy Martin has a golf date in southern California Monday. But it is not to be just another 18 holes. Martin will be playing with his new boss and apparently new friend, George Steinbrenner.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES CRIME BILL CALLING FOR A 'DRUG CZAR'
description: President Reagan today vetoed a crime bill passed in the last Congress, chiefly because it would have created a Cabinet-level director of Federal efforts to combat narcotics trafficking.

title: No Headline
description: MARCOS REFUSES RESIGNATION OF LONGTIME FOREIGN MINISTER

title: O.J. RATES MCNEIL AND ALLEN
description: LOS ANGELES I f it takes one to know two, O.J. Simpson is the man to measure the moves of Freeman McNeil and Marcus Allen. When the Jets go against the Raiders in the Super Bowl XVII tournament today, Freeman McNeil and Marcus Allen will be virtually on trial against each other. That's the matchup mentality - unfair, but unavoidable. In his Coliseum seat, meanwhile, O.J. Simpson will be watching the two all-pro running backs, who grew up watching him.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 1983
description: International The arms control talks with the Soviet Union are now ''in a position to get somewhere,'' President Reagan said. Meeting with reporters for the first time since he ordered the dismissal of Eugene V. Rostow as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Mr. Reagan said that as a result of his military modernization program, he had regained ''leverage'' over the Soviet Union and that Moscow now had ''an incentive'' to bargain seriously. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moves on detente with Moscow have been undermined by China's support of ancient territorial claims and disputes and its spreading of anti-Soviet sentiments in China, the Soviet weekly political journal, Novoye Vremya, said. A commentary listed in detail the Chinese encylopedias, textbooks and journals that continue to claim that the Soviet-Chinese border is the product of unequal czarist treaties, and that great stretches of Soviet territory in Siberia and the Far East historically belong to China. (1:1.)

title: A FED PUSH ON FOREIGN LOANS SEEN
description: Top officials of the Federal Reserve Board have been pushing the nation's banks to expand their loans to financially troubled developing nations, a former member of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers said today.

title: DOW CLIMBS BY 6.90, BUOYED BY A.T.& T.
description: The equity market registered a moderate advance yesterday, buoyed by favorable economic news and by the stellar performance of American Telephone, the nation's most widely held issue.

title: CONGRESSIONAL ARTS CAUCUS THRIVING
description: There are various caucuses in Congress, made up of members who want to promote such things as the rights of women, blacks and Hispanic-Americans, or the problems faced by people living in the suburbs or the countryside, or the special needs of the shipbuilding and steel industries. But not one has grown as fast as the two-year-old Congressional Arts Caucus, which had 166 members in the just-ended Congress and probably will have more in the current one.

title: TOAST TO THE STEAM AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: FINCH OUTPOINTED AT FELT FORUM
description: Pedro Vilella, a 23-year-old who won three New York Golden Gloves titles, scored a unanimous 10-round decision last night at the Felt Forum over Bruce Finch, the welterweight contender who was Sugar Ray Leonard's last opponent.

title: Boston Campaign Scrutinized
description: Mayor Kevin H. White's campaign committee has asked the state to determine if it was legal to spend $10,300 for renovating and furnishing the basement of Mr. White's Beacon Hill town house for use as a campaign office. Mr. White, a Democrat, has not announced if he will seek re-election this fall.

title: VERMEIL INTENSITY HURT, EX-EAGLE SAYS
description: Charlie Johnson was among the first persons to predict what would happen to Dick Vermeil. The 46-year-old Vermeil resigned last Monday after seven seasons as the coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, saying that he was burned out.

title: Pontiac Sports Car
description: The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac division will begin assembling two-seat sports cars at a plant in Pontiac, Mich., by late April or early May and will recall 1,900 workers by June for the work, William Hoglund, Pontiac general manager, said. The recalls will raise employment at the plant to 2,400. Mr. Hoglund said pilot production of the new Fiero model sports car will start on Jan. 24 and the car will go on sale in late September.

title: Federal Judge Upholds Alabama School Prayer
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a lawsuit challenging Alabama's school prayer laws, saying that the Constitution gives states the legal power to establish religion.

title: A Rich Rivalry Of Road Runners
description: Robert de Castella, the outstanding Australian marathoner, will make several racing appearances in the United States this winter, including a 5,000-meter duel against Alberto Salazar in the Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational meet Feb. 12 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Atkins Board To Study Merger
description: The board of directors of Frederick Atkins Inc. will meet next Thursday to consider a merger with the Associated Merchandising Corporation, Ferd Lawson, president of Atkins, said.

title: Your Money; Currency-Shift Speculations
description: THE recent weakness in the American dollar has opened some profitmaking opportunities for those attempting to take advantage of currency fluctuations. While playing the market in exchange rates has long been a tool for institutional investors and a relatively small group of individuals, an increasingly sophisticated investing public is now participating in this market, spurred by projections of further dollar weakness.

title: A GROWING U.S. BREED: RAILROAD HOBOS
description: George stood in the boxcar's gaping door as the Sonora Desert slid by under winter stars. Arcturus raced over the Picacho Mountains and the manlike saguaro cactus. Telephone lines dipped and rose, dipped and rose along the tracks, and over it all rang the clatter of an empty freight car, pitching and rocking and pounding through the Arizona night.

title: 76ers 115, Pistons 105
description: Julius Erving scored 24 points and Moses Malone 20 to power Philadelphia to its 10th straight victory. The game marked Erving's return to the Philadelphia lineup after a twogame absence.

title: WILLIAM E. PHILLIPS
description: William E. Phillips, former chief executive officer of the New York State Liquor Authority, died Wednesday of a heart seizure at a hospital in Jupiter, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in Tequesta, Fla.

title: How Chicago's Schools Will Be Desegregated
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP 0.1% IN DECEMBER
description: Producer prices rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in December, bringing the rate of increase for all of 1982 to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest in 11 years, the Government reported today.

title: Damson Consolidation
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had consolidated 22 oil and natural gas income and drilling funds and other assets into one unit, the Damson Consolidated Energy Income I, or DC I. Damson Consolidated will have an exchange value of about $305 million, the company said, and would own interests in about 1,681 wells and 190,500 acres.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday on a performance by the violist Emanuel Vardi incorrectly stated his age. He is 65 years old.

title: Columbia Wins On 55-Foot Shot
description: Darren Burnett, a senior guard, made a 55-foot shot at the buzzer last night to give Columbia a 48-46 victory in its Ivy League opener over Dartmouth. The triumph ended a five-game loss streak for Columbia (3-7).

title: Prelate Asks Children To Protest Abortion Law
description: Archbishop Joseph Bernardin made a televised appeal today to 133,000 Roman Catholic children in their classrooms, asking them to light candles to protest a decade of legal abortion.

title: CONGRESSMAN PROPOSES PLAN FOR 3 MILLION JOBS
description: Representative Paul Simon said today that he would introduce legislation to create three million public service jobs at the minimum wage for those who could not find work in the private sector.

title: Books of the Times; The Female Landscape
description: DIFFICULT WOMEN. By David Plante. 173 pages. Atheneum. $9.95.

title: LITTON IN ACCORD TO PAY $238 MILLION TO BUY ITEK
description: Litton Industries, the defense and industrial conglomerate, has agreed to acquire the Itek Corporation, a leading maker of electronic equipment for military aircraft, for $238 million in cash, the two companies announced today.

title: BERTHA ADKINS, REPUBLICAN AIDE AND GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL, IS DEAD
description: Bertha S. Adkins, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee and head of its women's division from 1953 to 1958 and Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare from 1958 to 1960, died yesterday of stomach cancer at Memorial Hospital in Easton, Md. She was 76 years old and lived in the Eastern Shore town of Oxford.

title: OFFICIALS AND NEWSMEN DISCUSS TV'S OSSINING ROLE
description: During the 53-hour uprising that started Saturday night at the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., television ''was constantly on our minds and in our discussions,'' said Timothy J. Russert, counselor to Governor Cuomo. ''It became part of the process.''

title: MRS. HECKLER DISPUTES 'TOKEN' WOMAN LABEL
description: Margaret M. Heckler, President Reagan's candidate for Secretary of Health and Human Services, today rejected a characterization of her as a ''token'' woman and said she was well qualified to head an agency with an annual budget of more than $275 billion.

title:
Patents;
Robot That 'Improves' Itself
description: WASHINGTON A LONG ISLAND electronics engineer was granted a patent this week for what he describes as a new generation of smart robots. Chou H. Li, the president of Lintel Technology Inc. in Roslyn, says the robots possess true ''intelligence'' and improve their performance dynamically and instantly and without human control or guidance.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MARY TYLER MOORE, the actress who portrayed a cold and disapproving mother in the film ''Ordinary People,'' has joined a Long Island child support group, contending that ''the child who lacks a stable family and community life needs a great deal of help.''

title: Future Events; Previews and Parties
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Well Endowed Jan. 19 - A preview of ''Celebration'' by Jacques d'Amboise will add a fillip to the fifth annual gala benefit for the endowment fund of the School of American Ballet at the State Theater at Lincoln Center. Twenty-four students will join 22 members of the New York City Ballet in the work, which the dancer-choreographer has dedicated to the faculty and staff of his alma mater. Two Balanchine ballets are also on the program, which will be preceded by cocktails on the theater's promenade and followed by a supper ball with rack of lamb as the piece de resistance. Alva O. Way, president of American Express, is corporate chairman in charge of drumming up the private support that seems essential to performing arts organizations in the 80's. Tickets for the performance and supper are $200 to $1,000. Tickets for cocktails and the performance are $45 to $100. Last year's gala, the single most important fund-raising event for the school, netted $265,810.

title: THE SCENE, DAY AND NIGHT
description: The Palm Beach town Council took at the resort's aging sewer system last July and made an excruciating decision: to tear up its palm-lined streets, including the three-block shopping district on Worth Avenue where everything that glitters probably is gold, to install $11 million worth of new drainpipes. The merchants, particularly the 240 owners of the tony shops on Worth, recoiled at the prospect of no parking places for the Rolls-Royce Corniches and Silver Shadows that double park there during the season and the unthinkable image of jackhammers mixing with haute couture.

title: PROGRAM IN THE BUS TERMINAL TO FOCUS ON STATE'S ARTISTS
description: PUCCINI arias and improvisational dance may seem incongruous in a bus terminal, but that perception may change once a series of free performances, art exhibitions and crafts demonstrations unfolds this week at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan.

title: A GENTLEMANLY PROFESSION ENTERS A TOUGH NEW ERA
description: At Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, a maid carries a tray of iced tea and cookies around to all the firm's lawyers every afternoon. It's a bit of elegance from the past that the 50-year-old Rockefeller Center firm still clings to.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH CAROLINA TOPS VIRGINIA

title: PALM BEACH: AN IMMUTABLE SOCIAL BASTION
description: MARYLIN BENDER, the author of ''The Beautiful People,'' published in 1967, is completing a book that reviews the same scene in the 1980's.

title: A PRACTITIONER OF NEW YORK EXPERTISE
description: It is easy to demonstrate that in the 1950's New York City was the bridge capital of America. During that period some 90 percent of the players who won the main national knockout titles, the Vanderbilt and the Spingold, were New Yorkers. It is less easy to measure the extent to which that dominance has slipped away.

title: CO-OP CONVERSATIONS DIVIDING TENANTS
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS ARE conversions of rental apartment buildings to cooperatives on the Island beginning to approach the dimensions of the phenomenon in New York City? If so, what are the implications for the availability of housing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties?

title: Racism Cited in Charge Against State Policeman
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that racism on the part of four state police officials prompted unsupported theft charges against a black lieutenant.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Holmdel $132,500 *2*7 Springvalley Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, *2*18-year-old colonial; studio loft, *2*window seats,; taxes $2,490. Long Branch $63,000 *2*35 Myrtle Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old *2*ranch; paneled recreation room with wet bar, patio, *2*central air-conditioning; taxes $587.
