Little Silver $85,900 *2*30 Almelia Court 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old *2*colonial; enclosed porch, fenced yard, *2*fireplace; taxes $2,379. Marlboro $165,000 *2*9 Vista Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 2 1/2-year-old *2*colonial; oak kitchen cabinets, gas barbecue, *2*treed lot; taxes $3,958. Oceanport $156,000 *2*Elinore Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, new *2*contemporary; sunken living room, central vacuum *2*system, cathedral ceilings; taxes not available. Rumson $190,000 *2*146 Avenue of Two Rivers 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath *2*Stanford Whtie-designed carriage house; *2*workshop, leaded stained glass; taxes $4,308. OTHER AREAS Massapequa, L.I. $103,000 *2*90 Rainbow Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, *2*20-year-old split level; formal dining *2*room, full basement; taxes $4,000. Peekskill, N.Y. $90,000 *2*20 First Street, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 18-year-old *2*frame ranch; family room, new deck, fruit *2*trees; taxes $3,186. Danbury, Conn. $81,900 *2*2 Wheeler Drive 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 bath, *2*8-year-old raised ranch, park-like *2*1/2-acre setting; taxes $1,124.

title: What to See at Show
description: Here is the general layout in the New York Coliseum: First floor: Fishing boats, ski boats, runabouts, high-performance craft, outboard and stern-drive engines.

title: CASEY AND HIS C.I.A. ON THE REBOUND
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, sat at the end of the mahogany conference table in his office. Outside, the late afternoon sun played across the trees that ring the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters in northern Virginia, filling the windows with a fresco of autumn colors. A short stack of documents, some stamped SECRET, rested at Mr. Casey's left elbow, and a yellow legal pad on which he had penciled several notes was positioned to his right.

title: Mary S. Blumenthal Married to Joel Lane
description: Mary Schaefer Blumenthal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot D. Blumenthal of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Joel Edmund Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Lane of New York. Rabbi Irving Block of the Brotherhood Synagogue performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: NONALIGNED GROUP EASES U.S. CRITICISM
description: Delegates to the ministerial conference of nations professing nonalignment, after hours of wrangling over a final communique, indirectly criticized the United States today for its role in Central America.

title: OLD-FASHIONED AND PLEASING FARE
description: SURFEITED with theme restaurants, boutique restaurants and other dining novelties, we found it refreshing to discover a simple, oldfashioned restaurant that is straightforward in its decor, uses fresh ingredients and prepares them (for the most part) with no-nonsense competence.

title: INTERIM ARMS PACT WEIGHED BY ALLIES
description: Interest is growing within the Italian and West German Governments in an ''interim solution'' on the deployment of new NATO medium-range nuclear missiles at the end of the year.

title: Old Buddies
description: To the Editor: Families of men buried in American military cemeteries in Europe can feel a peace knowing that the letter writer Murray A. Rosenberg, of Easton, Conn.

title: FASTER RIDE IN STORE ON NEW HAVEN LINE
description: COMMUTERS on New Haven line trains may have faster rides in the near future because of a change in the daily wheel inspections being conducted on the rail cars.

title: More on Rumors
description: To the Business Editor: In Marilyn Machlowitz's ''Killing Rumors Before They Kill a Company'' (Dec.19), there are two critical points that need further elaboration.

title: NO MATTER WHO WON, WASHINGTON LOST GROUND
description: The six-day rebellion of a regional military commander in northern El Salvador ended peacefully last week, but the ill-will and embarrassment it caused are likely to linger.

title: KOREAN COMIC IN 'THEY CALL ME BRUCE'
description: It's a long time between such film farces as ''They Call Me Bruce,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli II and at neighborhood houses, and one leaves it with mixed emotions. It is a hysterically insane - and inane -comedy send-up of kung fu epics, ethnic stereotypes, movie cliches and stand-up comic routines. But, surprise of surprises, despite your own better judgment, not to mention discerning taste and sophistication, you will find yourself giggling at this mixed bag of familiar silliness.

title: John W. Priddy 3d, 61, Pilot; Set Commercial Flight Mark
description: John Walter Priddy 3d, the first pilot in the commercial flight industry to log 40 years, died of cancer Friday at the age of 61.

title: L.I. ATOM PLANT NEARLY READY BUT THE DEBATE GOES ON AND ON
description: Long Island is preparing to enter the nuclear age, ending its near-total dependence on imported oil, with the completion of a reactor to provide a third of its electricity. But the plant is 10 years late and 10 times over budget, the most expensive reactor ever built, and its cost will probably make the area's bills the highest in the nation.

title: Mailbox; Many Impacts Of Ray Perkins
description: To the Sports Editor: After Joe Danelo kicked the winning field goal in the Giants' 26-24 final game victory, and only two seconds remained on the clock, Ray Perkins, often characterized as a stolid individual, shared his emotions freely with his team on the sidelines. Perkins was hoisted on the shoulders of several players as the game ended and his trip from the field seemed truly a joyous and triumphant one.

title:
GARDENING;
NUT TREES CAN YIELD FOOD AND SHADE
description: AS a youngster, my favorite cake was a simple, white cake with a light powdered-sugar icing. What made it special was that my mother always added hickory nuts to the ingredients.

title: RECOLLECTIONS ON THE WISDOM AND WIT OF AN ABSENT FRIEND
description: Red Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning sports columnist, died one year ago yesterday. In this article, W.C. Heinz recalls his longtime friend and colleague.

title: White House Issues a Paper To Hail Paperwork Reduction
description: In five pages of press releases and an 89-page booklet, the Reagan Administration has proclaimed that it will exceed its goal for reducing the paperwork burden on citizens.

title:
ART;
COLLECTION OF DOLL HOUSES: THE ABODES OF DREAMS
description: NEW CITY THE Historical Society of Rockland County is holding its seventh annual exhibition of doll houses. The show, which includes work from the 19th century through the present, is almost always interesting and sometimes it is very charming, indeed.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: No Headline
description: Cavaliers Upset Celtics, 90-86

title: Christine Doelger, Actress, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Ellin Doelger, to Christopher Thomas Jensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jensen of Wantagh, L.I.

title: YEAR'S FIRST STORM LASHES METROPOLITAN AREA
description: After weeks of dry autumnal weather, the first major storm of 1983 laid siege to the New York metropolitan area yesterday with pounding rains and blowing snow. It made driving hazardous but did not seriously disrupt normally light weekend travel schedules.

title: WINNING POSITIONS
description: The old saying, ''There's nothing harder to win than a won game,'' was, of course, never intended to be taken at face value, but rather as a caution.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYFather James Harold Flye, the Episcopalian priest best known to the public for his correspondence with the writer James Agee, spent most of his life as a teacher in a boys' school in Tennessee. He was not a professional photographer or even a serious amateur.

title: WHEN ONE ARTIST BRINGS HIS INSIGHT TO WORKS OF ANOTHER
description: If I were to say that ''Lucian Freud'' by Lawrence Gowing (Thames & Hudson, Inc., $35) is one of the best books ever written by one painter about another, it might sound like hyperbole. But it isn't. For one thing, the field is narrow and the competition small. Every artist thinks that he can come up with the last word on every other artist, but the last word in question is usually brief. One sentence, and all is said. Books by artists about other artists are few, therefore.

title: The Shards of Lebanon
description: No issue of substance required a month-long wrangle merely to set the agenda for negotiations about Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon. Off-stage voices, from Saudi Arabia or Syria, frightened the Lebanese about implying in any way that they were making a full peace. Israel, eager to pacify domestic dissent against its invasion, sought to create precisely that impression. And meanwhile, thousands of traders and tourists were crossing the border, expressing compatible urges that do not need to be labeled ''peace.''

title: CORPORATE LIFE IN THE COUNTRY
description: DURING the years that William K. Ketchum commuted an hour and a halff rom his home in Berkeley Heights, N. J., to American Telephone and T elegraph's Long Lines Division headquarters at 32 Avenue of the A mericas in Manhattan, he left his house at 7 in the morning and did n ot return until around 6 at night.

title: ALBANY DELEGATES OUTLINE ISSUES OF '83
description: ALBANY MORE money for education was the battle cry of state legislators as they returned to Albany at the start of the new legislative session. But many spoke gloomily about the state's budget deficit and warned of suffering ahead.

title: OPERA: 'MASKARADE,' BY CARL NIELSON
description: Carl Nielsen's ''Maskarade,'' presented by the Bronx Opera Company the last two weekends as part of the ''Scandinavia Today'' series in what was billed, improbably enough, as the first New York performances ever, counts as Denmark's national opera. Most national operas - Smetana's ''The Bartered Bride'' is the archetype - are tuneful, folkish affairs. ''Maskarade'' (1906) has its overt folk elements, to be sure. But this is really an altogether more sophisticated enterprise.

title: THE MAKING OF AN AMBASSADOR
description: No function of our Federal Government is so intimately related to the security, even the survival, of the American people as the conduct of our foreign policy. Wisdom in planning the policy, and skill in its implementation, have become critical national needs.

title: Drawing the Line At Chocolate
description: Japan last week arranged to sweeten the background music for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's visit with President Reagan on Tuesday. On some politically sensitive American export issues, however, dissonance persisted.

title: BOSTON'S NEW OLD HOTEL
description: LISA HAMMEL is a writer who divides her time between New York and Massachusetts.

title: THE SMALL HOTELS OF PARIS
description: PATRICIA WELLS is The International Herald Tribune's restaurant critic in Paris.

title: Meet Record For Hurdles
description: Benita Fitzgerald of the University of Tennessee broke her meet record for the second time tonight as she won the 60-yard hurdles at the Eastman Invitational track and field meet in East Tennessee State's Memorial Center.

title: ELIZABETH COLE TO WED MARTIN FINEGAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Cole of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Cole, to Martin Peter Finegan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Finegan of Munhall, Pa. A March wedding is planned.

title: MAN-BOY INQUIRIES FOCUS ON THE STATE
description: JERSEY CITY THE arrest, in recent weeks, of three men believed to be involved in a man-boy sex ring has brought nationwide attention to the abduction of boys by men who advocate sexual consent between adults and adolescents. However, investigations of missing boys and possible links to organized groups have been going on in New Jersey for nearly two years.

title: A PORTRAIT OF CHURCHILL BETWEEN THE WARS
description: John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: Article 167319 -- No Title
description: That thieves regularly pass through the Brooklyn Criminal Court Building is not unusual. It is unusual, however, when a thief strikes in the building itself - especially in one of its strongholds of security.

title: REDSKINS WIN, 21-7, REACH N.F.C. FINAL
description: With Joe Theismann and Alvin Garrett again combining on key pass plays and John Riggins again playing one-man ball control, the Washington Redskins marched methodically into the National Conference championship game today.

title: HIS OWN MUSIC IS MODERN, BUT HE DELIGHTS IN THE ROMANTICS
THE SHOW'S THE THING
description: If serenity, in fact, comes with age, then the Winter Antiques Show - which opens Friday and runs through Jan. 30 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street -should be a model of tranquility now that it is a ripe 29 years old. As a fund-raiser, the show has long since hit its stride, consistently net-ting a respectable $200,000-plus for the South Bronx's East Side House Settlement. Moreover, as a social happening, the opening night gala (Mrs. David K.E. Bruce is honorary chairman this year and the decor is by the English fashion designer Zandra Rhodes) seems to be firmly entrenched. The party is pretty, the ticket price attractive ($125 for the 5 P.M. cocktails and buffet, $75 for just cocktails at 6:30), and so the right crowd can be relied upon to turn up.

title: LIFE WAS FLAT, UNTIL THE HOUSE
description: THERE is more to getting used to this house than mowing the lawn and paying a 17 percent adjustable-rate mortgage. It's been about six months now that I've lived in this large, white, turn-of-thecentury, charming, center hall, in-need-of-repair Colonial. The one with chipped paint and seven gables. You can see it on the corner. It is the one my wife wanted, but we couldn't afford. It's the one we got anyway in a moment of passion, after many long-distance cries for help and that all-debatable thing called luck.

title: HARD ROCK: MOOREFIELD
description: Virgil Moorefield danced as he conducted his music Tuesday at the Mudd Club. He led a band of guitars, horns and percussion in five instrumental pieces, including the four on his new album, ''Transformations.''

title: RANDY NEWMAN'S NEW ALBUM IS TOP POP
description: Randy Newman's ''Trouble in Paradise'' (Warner Bros. 1-23755) continues the recorded odyssey of one of popular music's most individual talents. Some pop stars shift restlessly from style to style; others exploit fashion and then disappear when the fashion fades; nearly all - before the advent of new-wave rock, at least - aspire to massive commercial success.

title: NAKASONE OFF TOMORROW TO SEE REAGAN
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone leaves Monday to meet President Reagan in Washington for talks that officials here regard as among the most important in years because of rising tension between the two allies on trade and defense.

title: Wordpower Ends Impasse
description: Israel and Lebanon last week agreed on an agenda for peace negotiations after Israel decided that ''normalization'' by some other name could work as well. The major issues were still on the table, however.

title: 1860'S HOMES GET NEW TENANTS
description: PRESENT needs and past generosity were well served by an unusal construction project that was recently completed in Hartford. The Widows' Homes, twin buildings erected in the mid-1860's by a wealthy philanthropist, Lawson C. Ives, to shelter widows of Civil War soldiers, have been restored and transformed into housing for low-income families.

title: EDWARD RICE ENGAGED TO COURTNEY O'CONNELL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O'Connell of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Courtney O'Connell, to Edward Clayton Rice, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin C. Rice of San Francisco.The wedding is planned for April 30.

title: Anne Chase Robinson Weds Edward Murphy
description: Anne Chase Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Frederick L. Devereux Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., and the late John Trumbull Robinson of Tucson, Ariz., was married yesterday to Edward J. Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Murphy of Framingham, Mass. The Rev. Donald Boyer performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church, Woodstock, assisted by the Rev. William Casey, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE GIRL IN THE BOY GANG
description: MINOR CHARACTERS By Joyce Johnson. 262 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM As part of the ambitious six-week Janus Film Festival beginning Sunday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Ingmar Bergman will be honored with a series-within-the-series. Beginning Wednesday and continuing on various other dates during the program, nine outstanding Bergman films of the 1950's and 60's are scheduled.

title: Reading Problem
description: When Edward Donohue left Copiague High School in 1976, he had a diploma to prove he had graduated, but he couldn't read it. He could not read even a restaurant menu.

title: BERKELEY AFTERSHOCK
description: The zap was back in Berkeley, Calif. last week. Voters there had outlawed electroshock therapy in November, but Alameda County Superior Court Judge Donald P. McCullum said it was not constitutional to ban a legal treatment that was undertaken voluntarily.

title: NETS BOUNCE BACK, BEAT KNICKS, 100-96
description: The Nets were on the brink of beginning a streak of another sort here tonight, the losing sort. One night after their 11-game winning streak ended in an embarrassing 25-point loss to the Boston Celtics, one of pro basketball's best teams, the Nets barely avoided a loss to one of the worst teams, the Knicks.

title: Rewards Are Evident
description: Jacek Duda, 19, who left the Polish National basketball team in November to join his parents in Central Falls, R.I., has signed a letter of intent with Providence College and will start classes tomorrow.

title: MATERIALS GROW IN COMPLEXITY
description: What's it made of?. The standard query at the boat show accompanies or is implicit in a brisk thump of the hand to the hull concerned. Boat salesmen even have a name for the syndrome: ''Tire kicking.'' And, for the last 10 to 15 years their answer has invariably been the same, ''Fiberglass.''

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Alvin McCall is not always a perfectly polished and note-perfect cellist, but he is something infinitely more valuable - a true musician. Currently a student of Bernard Greenhouse at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, this young artist presented an enjoyable afternoon of music at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday.

title: Travelers' Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Basketball Bucks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Milwaukee (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) SuperSonics vs. Kansas City Kings, at Seattle (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) DePaul at Louisville (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Jacksonville at Alabama-Birmingham (Television -ESPN, 5 P.M.) Football Dolphins vs. San Diego Chargers, American Football Conference semifinal at the Orange Bowl, Miami (Television - Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880, 12:30 P.M.) Dallas Cowboys vs. Green Bay Packers, National Football Conference semifinal at Texas Stadium, Irving, Tex. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio -WCBS, 880, 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. Although the Flyers are on a 10-game winning streak, they have split previous two games with the Rangers. Each won on home ice. (Television - MSG 7:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130, 7:30 P.M.) Devils vs. Los Angeles Kings, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Kings are last in the Smythe Division, and the Devils are last in the Patrick Division. In their only other meeting this season, last Oct. 20, the Devils were beaten, 7-4, and started an 18-game streak without a victory. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WVNJ, 620, 7:30 P.M.) Other Events Boating: 73d annual National Boat Show, at New York Coliseum, 59th Street and Columbus Circle, second day, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing: Aqueduct Race Track, Ozone Park, Queens, 1:05 P.M. With a field of 16, the Affectionately Handicap for 3-year-old fillies and mares was split into $50,000-added divisions, which will be run as the seventh and eighth races.

title: JETS BEAT RAIDERS BY 17-14 TO GAIN A.F.C. FINAL
description: In a frenetic, gritty contest, the Jets toppled the Los Angeles Raiders by 17-14 today to propel themselves into the American Football Conference championship game.

title: INVITING THE ROBOT FOR COCKTAILS
description: ''He has to be led and cuddled and you have to be very patient with him. But he's very human-like.'' As the salesman spoke at the Consumer Electronics show, a crowd watched a three-foot-high plastic robot named B.O.B. spin on two slanted wheels and walk up to a bystander. The robot then twisted his head from side to side, and said a few words to the effect that he was acting completely on his own. He then walked to someone else and said he could ''turn on a dime'' and then did so.

title: FINANCIAL WIZARD OF ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Meyer Lansky, the reputed financial genius of the underworld, died today of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital here. He was 81 years old.

title: Information on Ski Races
description: Following are organizers and sponsors of citizen races that are held at Eastern skiing areas this season. Call them for location, date, time and other information.

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: Mention of the 17th-century Sephardic Portuguese synagogue of Amsterdam in the article ''Jewish Odyssey Is Recalled in Tel Aviv'' (Travel, Jan. 2) brought back a haunting memory of a Friday night service I attended there. The service started at sundown so all the candles in the chandeliers were lit, casting a soft light upon the congregation which numbered about 20.

title: ROBIN JILL ROSENTHAL IS ENGAGED TO DAVID S. MEHLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Rosenthal of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Jill Rosenthal, to David S. Mehler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Mehler of Baldwin Harbor, L.I.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE DEAN'S DECEMBER. By Saul Bellow. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) Saul Bellow's ninth novel switches rapidly back and forth between the anarchy of the American ''pleasure society'' in Chicago, where Dean Albert Corde works, and the mean-spirited bureaucracy of the police state in Bucharest, where he and his wife go when her mother becomes seriously ill. Reviewing the novel last year, Robert Towers declared, ''sentence by sentence, page by page, Saul Bellow is simply the best writer we have.'' Although ''The Dean's December'' is thematic and talky, Mr. Towers noted, ''the themes are fully grounded in the book's matrix of idea and event and language. And the talk is excellent.''

title: DAY L. PESSONI AND GEORGE B. KETCHMAN ARE ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Day Louise Pessoni to George Bonbright Ketcham, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., has been made known by the the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Pessoni of Middletown, Conn. A May 14 wedding is planned at St. James Episcopal Church in Glastonbury, Conn.

title: Regan on Deficit: Delay the Day Of Reckoning?
description: The White House imposed quiet, if not order, on the Administration's green eyeshade brigade last week. In the wake of a directive limiting low-level contacts with reporters, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan had a near monopoly on the spotlight when it came to talking about Topic A, the budget.

title: Dr. Jennifer Downey to Wed Dr. Hutson
description: Dorothy Downey of Santa Clara, Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Jennifer Ianthe Downey of Brooklyn, to Dr. John Milton Hutson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Hutson of Decatur, Ala. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Curry Chase Meredith to Marry July 23
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar S. Meredith of Dallas of the engagement of their daughter, Curry Chase Meredith, to Henry Darlington 3d, son of Mr. Darlington Jr. of New York and Mrs. Grant G. Simmons Jr. of Atlanta.

title: BLOWING UP
description: Many years ago, I read that if you reduced a typical human body to its chemical elements and sold them across the drugstore counter their value would be only 89 cents. Maybe it was 98 cents, or 78 cents. I'm vague on the precise figures, but anyhow it was a trifling sum.

title: U.S. ARMS IN EUROPE: 'FORMULA FOR ENDLESS CRISIS'
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE ROMAN TOUCH
description: The Los Angeles Olympic coin program will mark the return of Roman numerals to United States coinage -they will be used as part of the inscription to indicate the date with ''XXIII Olympiad.'' In a sense, this ''comeback'' is aptly timed because 1983 - the year of the first U.S. Olympic coin - is also the 100th anniversary of this nation's most familiar Roman numeral coin: the Liberty Head or ''V'' nickel.

title: Nuclear Power; Risks, During ...
description: It has been more than a quarter-century since a reactor at Shippingport, Pa., began to produce the nation's first commercial electricity from atomic energy. Last week, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved the first set of safety goals for such plants, but not without criticism from its own advisers.

title: AN ENTENTE IS IN EFFECT IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN'S first State of the State address last week and the reaction of the Democratic legislative leaders were noteworthy for what was not said. Mr. Kean made no bold new proposals, and the lawmakers refrained from criticizing the firstd-year performance of the Republican Governor.

title: UNCERTAINTY LINGERS OVER CLAMS ON L.I.
description: FREEPORT THERE are two men on the Island's South Shore who are known as Vinnie Fiore. Both of them have been in the shellfish business for 37 years - the kind of family-run partnership that is less common now than when they were younger men. One of the two Vinnies - the one whose birth certificate says his first name is really Fiorentino - can usually be found in their wholesale store in Freeport, selling clams bought from baymen by his brother, the other Vinnie Fiore, the one whose real name is Vincent.

title: Reactor Cleanup Plan Urged
description: A trade association for private electric utilities has approved a plan to ask its members to raise $150 million over six years, preferably from consumers, to help clean up the damaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island.

title: Conservationists Cross Fingers
description: A $50 million program aimed at saving the nation's wetlands, announced last week by the Richard King Mellon Foundation and the Nature Conservancy, has special appeal for Connecticut conservationists. With desirable land in the state going fast - 97 percent of coastal property, for example, is in private hands -they are making a strong pitch for funding from the program.

title: IN FARM BELT, FEAR OF FORECLOSURES RISES
description: All across the farm states, there is mounting alarm that the depressed state of the country's agricultural economy is going to reap a grim harvest of failures and foreclosures this year.

title: NEW ACADEMIC STANDARD: IS IT FAIR, WILL IT WORK?
description: THE search for academic eligibility standards for students who participate in intercollegiate athletics has created a new weakness in the relationship between major, predominantly white institutions and historically black institutions.

title: TV COURSES OFFER STUDENTS FLEXIBILITY
description: WITH seven children and a large house to take care of, Gail Moller of Wethersfield does not have the time to go back to college full time. So, on Sunday afternoons she turns her television to Channel 24 and watches ''The American Short Story.''

title: SLOGANS AREN'T THE WORLD
description: Dwight D. Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles proclaimed a fear of ''falling dominoes'' in Southeast Asia.

title: U.S. ARMS IN EUROPE: 'FORMULA FOR ENDLESS CRISIS'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Army's New Fighting Doctrine
description: Deborah Shapley's article ''The Army's New Fighting Doctrine'' (Nov. 28) was an important piece. Doctrine -how an army fights - is often more important in determining whether it wins or loses than hardware or overall expenditures.

title: 2 SITES NEEDED FOR GARBAGE COMPACTING
description: WHITE PLAINS FINDING an acceptable location for a garbage-transfer station, the county is discovering, can be a thornier problem than disposing of garbage itself.

title: Lisbon Alliance Wants Professor to Be Premier
description: Portugal's ruling right-wing alliance has formally asked President Antonio Ramalho Eanes to appoint a 50-year-old chemistry professor as Prime Minister of another coalition government.

title: THE COMMISSION'S INTERNAL DEBATE: FOR AN INCOME TAX
description: After a majority of tax commission members rejected the option of a proposed state income tax, 10 members signed a minority report urging tax reform for the state. The signers were Senator Audrey P. Beck, Democrat of Storrs; John Cunningham, president of the Stamford Labor Council; Representative Doreen Del Bianco, Democrat of Waterbury; former Senator Marcella C. Fahey, Democrat of East Hartford; Marilyn Ward Ford, professor of law, University of Bridgeport; Michael C. Lovell, professor of economics, Wesleyan University; E. Lea Marsh Jr., attorney, Deep River; Speaker of the House Irving J. Stolberg, Democrat of New Haven; Betty L. Tianti, secretarytreasurer, State A.F.L.-C.I.O., and former Representative Gardner E. Wright Jr., Democrat of Bristol. Following are excerpts from their dissenting views:

title: Leslie A. Jennings To Marry in June
description: Kathleen N. Jennings of Muttontown, L.I., and Daniel V. Jennings of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Anne Bohmann Jennings, to Hayward Hutchinson Gatch 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gatch Jr. of Santa Barbara, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: Western Press On Short Leash; In Poland
description: Will locking up the messenger prevent bad news? Poland's military rulers evidently think so. Last week they detained, then expelled a reporter for United Press International, Ruth Gruber, and bounced a correspondent for the British Broadcasting System, Kevin Ruane, after closing down the BBC bureau in Warsaw. Underlining the obvious, a Government spokesman told the foreign press corps that the expulsions should be taken as ''a warning signal'' not to deal with opposition groups or engage in ''intelligence'' gathering.

title: WILL A FINE 'SKIRMISH' LEAD TO THE MAIN BATTLE?
description: It isn't necessary to try to explain an exchange of glances that takes place midway through Catherine Hayes's 90-minute and intermissionless ''Skirmishes'' at the Manhattan Theater Club. The exchange is what it is, chilling to the bone whether you can parse it or not. Then, having begun as sheer malevolence, it turns rather quickly into an almost playful game of cat-and-mouse. Or mother-anddaughter, which here amounts to the same thing.

title: ELECTRONIC CAMPFIRE TALES
description: THE TWILIGHT ZONE COMPANION By Marc Scott Zicree. Illustrated. 447 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $9.95.

title: Meadowlands Racing Canceled by Snowstorm
description: Racing at the Meadowlands was canceled today after a snowstorm dumped more than six inches of snow over some parts of New Jersey.

title: DAY TO REMEMBER FOR THE LINEMEN
description: The Raiders had just gone ahead of the Jets, 14-10, when things got rougher on the line, where it had been hit, punch, scratch, push and pull all day.

title: Doorbell for Pets
description: As many pet owners know, cats and dogs can be murder on front doors. When the animals want out or in, many just scratch the door.

title: CENTRALIZE TRADE POLICY
description: for office are advised to listen - or appear to listen. Sometimes more is learned by watching. Surely this was my experience in 1982, when I attended the ritual murder of a foreign car.

title: WHO'S IN DISARRAY?
description: Since the beginning of the new year, President Reagan has been criticized more severely by both parties and the press than at any time since he entered the White House.

title: H.U.D., Privatized
description: The year is still young, but don't be surprised if Emanuel S. Savas is declared winner of the Brass Cup for Brazenness for 1983. Mr. Savas, a Federal official, has written a book titled ''How to Shrink Government: Privatizing the Public Sector.'' Mr. Savas's attack on lazy, empire-building bureaucrats carries the imprimatur of chief budget shaver David Stockman: ''Every taxpayer and elected official should read this book.''

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PAINTERS WHO EPLORED THE NEW ART OF PHOTOGRAPHY
description: The strength of photography vis a vis painting lies in its superior grasp of fact. Its weakness lies in its inability to transcend fact and realize an ideal. This is a fundamental truth that every glamour photographer vainly tries to overcome, and it is nicely illustrated by the current exhibition of painters' photographs at the Daniel Wolf Gallery, 30 West 57th Street, through Jan. 29.

title: DEEP RIVER CHOIR SPECIALIZES IN BELLS
description: LONG after the bells celebrating the New Year have stopped ringing, the handbells of a musical group in Deep River will keep on playing familiar tunes, the ringers wearing their matching blue jackets or their Western-style checked shirts.

title: Dorothy E. Weaver Is Engaged to Ethan J. Podell
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. Weaver of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Elise Weaver, to Ethan Jeremiah Podell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Odif Podell of Pleasantville, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June 4.

title: TAKING IN THE CHILDREN OF PRISONERS
description: THE first night our visitor spent with us, ''D'' and my daughter put on a ''show.'' She sang ''Ebony and Ivory,'' reciting the words she had so often heard on the radio, while not really being sure what they meant. My daughter sang along, also unaware of the significance of the lyrics -''Ebony and ivory, live together in perfect harmony, side by side on my piano keyboard, Oh Lord, why can't we?''

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: BROTHER OF THE MORE FAMOUS JACK By Barbara Trapido. 218 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: Britain Sets Trial for 3 Arabs In Shooting of Israeli Envoy
description: Three Arabs charged in connection with the June 3 shooting of Ambassador Shlomo Argov of Israel have been ordered to go on trial Wednesday at London's Central Criminal Court.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A PLEA TO REJECT ECONOMIC FASHION
description: ALTHOUGH it has become fashionable to argue that investors, p articularly institutional investors, have a ''get it now'' mentality, there is considerable evidence that the investment community is more than willing to take the long view. Both individual and institutional investors have recently poured vast sums into the stocks of fledgling companies engaged in microcomputers and genetic engineering. In addition, they continue to show a willingness to invest in stocks of some well-established growth companies that pay no current dividends.

title: BUYERS TURN TO THE LEAN, SPEEDY CRAFT
description: and undeniably sexy - high-performance boats are staking out a claim as the fastest growing segment of the recreational boating industry. Now, for the first time, many of them are being displayed at the National Boat Show in their own center on the fourth floor of the New York Colliseum.

title: FEAR OF CRIME HOBBLES CITIES AND CASTS SHADOW ON SUBURBS
description: NEWARK IN THIS city, as in many other communities across the state, residents scurry home with approaching nightfall, anxiously peering over their shoulders as they walk, crossing the street if a stranger approaches and barring the door once they are safely inside.

title: Swedes Invite Arafat
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has been invited to visit Sweden by the ruling Social Democratic Party, a party spokesman said today. No date has been set.

title: LARGER THAN LIFE ART
description: Visitors who view Karen Lewis's paintings, on exhibition today through Feb. 4 in the New Rochelle Public Library, may come face to face with their own likenesses. ''Most of the subjects are local,'' she said.

title: THE BULLS OF TEL AVIV
description: THERE'S a saying on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, where confidence is high and brokers tend to gloat.' 'In America, if they can't keep the Dow Jones over 1,000, why don't t hey just give it to us? We'll push it over 3,000.'' Truly, it would s eem that if anyone can do it, the Israelis can.

title: STRAUSS HAD SPECIAL AFFECTION FOR HIS 'GUNTRAM'
description: Parents often regard the first-born child with a worshipful awe that is denied to later arrivals. Anyone who is a second, or third, or 18th child knows that is the law of the litter, though one not always followed to the letter. It would seem only natural, then, for a composer to feel uncritical affection for a first-born work, particularly if it is coldly treated by a world that does not appreciate miracles. Unfortunately, biographers in the past have not been sensitive to such matters of the heart. There is no evidence, for instance, that Mozart went through life raging at the world for failing to recognize his modest little first opera, ''La Finta Semplice,'' as one of music's monuments.

title: THE NATION
description: By Carlyle C. Douglas, Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron Detroit's Jewel Looses Its Luster

title: Scratch Plate
description: It's the rare man who can make a really meaningful difference in a dog's life. But such a person is Lorin F. Sowards of Brownsville, Neb., who has just been granted a patent for a pet's doorbell that can signal a desire to get out as well as in.

title: NEW LOOKS IN SKI EQUIPMENT
description: Skiers in the market for equipment and clothing this season will find many new options, whether their preference be alpine skiing or cross-country. Technology is the byword, with strong but light spaceage materials replacing metal, and skis are showing up in fashion colors with bold graphics.

title:
ART;
LES LEVINE: HOLDING A REVERENCE FOR THE MUNDANE IN LIFE
description: AS a commentary on values, philosophers have pointed out that a child will just as readily play with a lump of coal as with a gold coin. This observation bears on the art of Les Levine. Although his subject matter is the banal, the overlooked, the barely defined but often the very necessary and life-supporting, Mr. Levine conveys this concept in a very deluxe way, using the classiest Madison Avenue and media techniques.

title: LIMITS ON CONSUMER LOAN RATES DEBATED IN ALBANY
description: Bankers, retailers and consumer advocates are disagreeing over a bill that would keep the cap off of interest rates on consumer loans in New York State.

title: ROME PLANS TO RESTORE THE GRANDEUR THAT WAS ROME
description: The city government announced a master plan this week to excavate and restore the ancient forums, demolish a main boulevard and make Rome's finest ruins an ''archeological park'' open only to pedestrians.

title: U.S. Finds River Flows Above Average for '82
description: After two relatively dry years, 1982 was wetter than the average year, the United States Geological Survey has reported.

title: THE ART OF THE POPES COMES TO AMERICA
description: one of the French Revolutionary Wars, to be exact - to coax a loan of artworks from among the vast treasures of the Vatican. After the Treaty of Tolentino in 1797, Napoleon Bonaparte's grenadiers pulled up in St. Peter's Square, filled their ox carts with precious paintings and sculpture and rumbled home to the Louvre. In Rome, where memories are measured in centuries, some observers regard that as the Vatican's first trav-eling art show.

title: FOR CRAFTSMEN, A GROWING LIBRARY
description: THE slower pace of craft shows at this time of year gives enthusiasts a chance to catch up on new publications in the field. Although the flow of new titles has decreased in recent years, those that do appear seem, in general, to offer more substantial content than the how-to books that preceded them.

title: It's All So Boring, Kean's Foes Complain
description: There wasn't much in Governor Kean's State of the State Message last week that the Democratically-controlled New Jersey Legislature disagreed with. In fact, the opposition complained, there wasn't much in the speech, period.

title: A BRAND-NEW YEAR FOR CONCERTS, TOO
description: IF the Connecticut Symphony last weekend had the honor of presenting the first major orchestral concert of the year, other ensembles in the state are following right behind, with their own 1983 openers scheduled for the next fortnight.

title: X-CAR DRIVERS SHOULD AVOID WET ROADS, CONSUMERIST SAYS
description: Clarence Ditlow, the director of a consumer group that lobbies for automobile safety, said today that owners of General Motors 1980 X-model cars should avoid driving them in the rain or snow.

title: Tweaking Uncle, But Not Too Hard
description: Bringing the foreign ministers of countries that profess nonalignment to Managua last week was an achievement in itself for the Nicaraguan junta, which used the occasion for speeches, news conferences and rallies attacking Washington. An effigy of Uncle Sam swung from a lamp post on the main boulevard as the foreign ministers argued over how far to go in endorsing the harsh language proposed by Nicaragua and Cuba, which is the current president of the 97-nation group.

title: Cash-Flow Problems
description: For a outfit in the business of protecting its clients' money, the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company of the Bronx has shown a remarkable propensity lately to separate them from it. Last week, 14 weeks after a guard was killed in a $35,000 armored car holdup, five weeks after an $11 million robbery at the firm's headquarters and three weeks after $225,000 in small bills disappeared from the same ''money room,'' authorities said another $100,000 was missing and arrested three top officials on charges of grand larceny and misappropriation of funds.

title: Sing Sing Boils Over
description: Hollywood may have given Sing Sing its notorious reputation but last week the prison lived up to it. For 53 hours, more than 500 inmates of Cell Block B, armed with clubs and homemade knives, held 17 guards hostage in a standoff that brought to mind another uprising 11 1/2 years earlier at Attica, where 43 died.

title: John S. Kiernan Weds Lisa Edmondson
description: Lisa Edmondson, a doctoral candidate in East Asian studies at Columbia University, was married in New York yesterday to John S. Kiernan, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: Fordham, Syracuse Triumph
description: Jerry Hobbie made critical free throws in the final minutes as Fordham defeated St. Peter's, 60-56, in the opener of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: STANDS VS. SHOPS
description: Maybe if these were better times, the plans of Pravin and Usha Joshi to build two newsstands on Continental Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, would still be moving ahead. But these are hard times, and as a result, the city's Transportation Department has agreed to review its approval of the two sites, which are on a block with three stores that also sell newspapers and magazines.

title: Spanish Cooking
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTERING TREND, NEW AIRLINE BEGINS
description: DESPITE the current economic weather, a new regional airline serving the Northeast area will begin operations tomorrow. Atlantic Express is entering a market already oversaturated by major carriers in a time when air travel is down and losses in the business are mounting.

title: GENERICS DISCOVER MADISON AVE.
description: A n unusual ad is starting to run today in newspapers around the country. It's for cigarettes, but don't look for cowboys or sweaty construction workers or carefree couples relaxing with nature and nicotine. Also, don't bother to look for a brand name. The ad simply touts a package labeled ''Cigarettes.''

title: Paulette Corbett Engaged To Mark Robert Damiano
description: Noel Corbett of the Bronx has announced the engagement of her daughter, Paulette Stephanie Corbett, to Mark Robert Damiano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Damiano of Yonkers.

title: A JULY WEDDING FOR HOLLY SCUDDER AND KEITH CHASE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Scudder Jr., of Neshanic, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Virginia Scudder, to Keith E. Chase of Richmond, Vt., son of Mrs. Virginia F. Chase of Glenburn, Me., and Raymond L. Chase of Bangor, Me.

title: Hempstead Plant And 'Thorn in a Side'
description: Re: The recent article on the Hempstead Resource Recovery Plant (''Recycling Dispute Is Reignited''): I am honestly annoyed and disgusted with Supervisor Gulotta's attitude about this thorn in the taxpayer's side. His closing remark ''Either the plant can operate without health hazards, in which case it should be placed in operation, or it cannot operate safely, in which case it should be abandoned,'' makes one wonder what alternatives Mr. Gulotta has up his sleeve for disposal of garbage ''should it be abandoned.''

title: CONCERT: COMPUTERS
description: Joel Chadabe brought himself and his musical computers to the Lovely Music Live series at Marymount Theater on Thursday night. There were three pieces - all with varying degrees of collaboration and tension betwen man and machine.

title: AT BATTERY PARK CITY, A RENT STRIKE
description: GATEWAY PLAZA, the $97 million apartment complex at Battery Park C ity that opened its doors to residents only last June, is in the m idst of a rent strike, according to spokesmen for the building's t enant organization.

title: ECONOMIC TROUBLE OF MIAMI'S BLACKS IS MAJOR ISSUE FACING PROSPERING CITY
description: As it strives to be a first-rank international city, Miami is being tested by race and class divisions, especially a smoldering resentment among blacks over their failure to benefit from the city's growing prosperity.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: IF YOU WANT THAT DISCOUNT, ASK
description: Is there any traveler who doesn't feel a twinge of elation at the thought of getting a bargain? Who would want to pay full price if he or she didn't have to? By the same token, one of the most disheartening aspects of travel is to discover, after paying for it, that you could have gotten your plane fare or Caribbean cruise or hotel room or restaurant meal for less.

title: TO EACH HIS OWN FANTASY LAND
description: FAY SMULEVITZ JOYCE is political editor of The St. Petersburg Times.

title: Joanne T. Bronski To Become Bride Of W.R. Henrick
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aloysius T. Bronski of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Theresa Bronski, to William Randolph Henrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Henrick of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THEATER: 'SPEAKEASY,' 5 DOROTHY PARKER STORIES
description: While a a number of the Algonquin wits, such as S.J. Perelman and Robert Benchley, have secure positions in America's pantheon of humorists, Dorothy Parker is an increasingly problematic figure. Many of her celebrated one-liners now seem like insult jokes and her light verse is outclassed by such writers as Judith Viorst. Furthermore, in the new show, ''Speakeasy,'' at the American Place Theater, her short fiction, as she might say, runs the gamut of emotions from A to B.

title: Couple Facing Charges In U.S. Welfare Fraud
description: Welfare fraud charges have been filed against a couple who drew the attention of President Reagan last year after they were portrayed as losing benefits under his economic policies.

title: Habib in Long Session With Lebanese Chiefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 (AP) Lebanese leaders held daylong talks today with the American special envoys Philip C. Habib and Morris Draper on ways to accelerate talks with Israel. Mr. Habib then returned to Israel.

title: Miss Maher Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Anne Maher to Michael S. Bruno Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Bruno of Tenafly, N.J., and Sherman, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Maher of Westfield, N.J., parents of the future bride. A summer wedding is planned.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Good News Amid the Gloom Approximately 14,000 publishers have books in print in the United States today and roughly 6,000 of them publish paperbacks. The figures come from the R.R. Bowker Company, a publisher of books about the book trade which has recently released this year's ''Books in Print'' directories.

title: WHEN THE GRAND MASTER IS A 'GHOST'
description: One shortcoming of most computerized chess games is that the computer can calculate its own moves but cannot make them itself. The human opponent must move the computer's pieces in response to lights or other signals from the machine.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Dance companies this week will explore new ways of combining movement with poetry and music. But another novelty consists entirely of old dances.

title: Trial-by-Inquiry For a Proposed Contraceptive
description: With all the hoopla that attended the advent of ''the pill,'' and all the opposition that didn't, a new contraceptive for women is bidding for Federal approval. Depo-Provera, a steroid injected every three months to prevent ovulation, was disapproved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1978. Last week the manufacturer, the Upjohn Company, tried a last resort - a public inquiry into the drug's merits by a panel of experts. The panel will submit a recommendation to the final arbiter, F.D.A. Commissioner Arthur Hull Hayes Jr.

title: 'NICKLEBY' DECLINED IN RATINGS
description: After a promising start, ratings for ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' in six major cities declined steadily over the four successive installments that appeared on prime-time television this week. The television adaptation of the Royal Shakespeare Company's eight-and-a-half-hour hit stage play was offered on an ad hoc network of 61 stations assembled by Mobil Oil.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 9.37 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 8.47 Maximum rate Money Market Funds 8.00 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Home Mortgage 14.26 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 17.25 Continental Illinois, Chicago 17.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 22.00

title: VIDEO COMES TO THE JUKEBOX
description: Video cassettes, videodisks and cable television have given rise to a new form of entertainment - video music. Instead of merely listening to one's favorite performers on the radio or phonograph, one can see them perform as well.

title: MEDICAL 'RIFT' INTENSIFIES
description: JUST three months after a liaison committee had pledged to improve strained relations between the state's Board of Medical Examiners and the Medical Society of New Jersey, things have taken a turn for the worse.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FAIRY TALES By Terry Jones. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 127 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 11)

title: Amy Grace Price to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Price of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Grace Price, to Jeffery Hugh Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh N. Jones of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: N.C.A.A.'S HIGH AIMS TURN INTO RIGHTS CONTROVERSY
description: Nearly 100 college and university presidents gathered at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention in San Diego last week convinced they were on a mission to repair some of the damage done by several scandals in recent years. They sought to enact a strong set of academic standards for athletes entering college, and hoped to be credited with creating a new public image of academic and athletic excellence in college sports.

title: TAX COULD RISE; Text of Reagan's statement, page 20.
description: Negotiators on President Reagan's advisory commission on Social Security reached bipartisan agreement tonight on the main elements of a financing package to be considered by Congress.

title: DEER ELUSIVE AS HUNT ENDS
description: LONG ISLAND'S deer hunting season came to a rather lackluster close last week as biologists and conservationists predicted a harvest of some 200 deer, about the same number that was cropped from the Island's growing herd last year.

title: RELOCATION'S IMPACT ON TAX BASE
description: THE arrival of the multinational corporations and their thousands ofw orkers has also changed the life of the rural communities in which t hey located.

title: Rare Books on Display
description: Thousands of books from the 1400's to the 20th century will be on sale today at the First Pelham Antiquarian Book Fair, at St. Clare's Hall on Second Avenue in Pelham, N.Y. Among the rare volumes on display are a 16th-century collection of Aesop's fables and a first edition, autographed copy of John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath.''

title: DAILY NEWS MAKING OPERATIONAL GAINS
description: The circulation of The Daily News has risen; its December advertising revenues were the best in its history, and its news pages have been expanded - a year after the newspaper was put up for sale amid talk that it would fold.

title: JANIE HORWITZ TO MARRY DANIEL R. POKRAS IN FALL
description: The engagement of Janie Kate Horwitz to Daniel R. Pokras, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pokras of Norwalk, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin M. Horwitz of Norwich, Conn.

title: LIVING IN THE TURNPIKE'S SHADOW
description: WHEN Roger Duffy heard a loud noise as he was watching television recently at his home on Peters Road in Greenwich, he went outside to investigate. A truck tire lay on the driveway and a large dent disfigured a door of his new car. Mr. Duffy deduced that the tire had rolled down his yard from a vehicle traveling on the Connecticut Turnpike, less than 20 yards away.

title: Dean Elliot Morrison Weds Diane Donofrio
description: Diane Donofrio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Donofrio of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dean Elliot Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Morrison of New York. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Leon Becker performed the ceremony at the Halloran House, a New York hotel.

title: 250-ACRE BUFFER ZONE INSURES SERENITY
description: If you yearn to live in serenity with no neighbors except birds, this may be your opportunity. To recoup some of the $400,000 that it spent to establish a preserve in Hunterdon County, the nonprofit New Jersey Conservation Foundation has decided to sell a 200-year-old farmhouse on an 11.6-acre tract surrounded by 250 acres that will remain forever undeveloped.

title: HOW MUCH PRIVACY FOR TOXIC SHOCK VICTIMS
description: The medical principle of confidentiality, a tenet of every physician's oath since Hippocrates, ''has become old, worn-out and useless - a decrepit concept,'' according to Dr. Mark Siegler, a Chicago physician.

title: Liverpool 1-0 Winner On a Last-Minute Goal
description: Ian Rush scored in the last minute, his 24th goal of the season, to give Liverpool a 1-0 victory over West Bromwich in soccer today.

title: DISCOUNT STORES MAKING INROADS
description: DISCOUNT clothing chains have opened Westchester branches in a flurry during the last six to nine months, despite the recession and an already competitive retailing market.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ON ACCORD
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's statement on the agreement reached tonight by his Commission on Social Security:

title: Getting There
description: Here are the hours, admission fees and a description of public transportation to the 73d National Boat Show which opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum on Columbus Circle between West 58th and West 60th Streets.

title: Town Eases Law on Drunks
description: The Town Council has passed a new public drunkenness ordinance which says an intoxicated person inside a car may be arrested.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SOMETHING OLD (AND NEW)
description: SHORT HILLS THE collection of furniture, accessories and antiques in Dante Cerza's store at 565 Millburn Avenue here is a reflection of Mr. Cerza's long experience as an interior designer with a taste for fine workmanship.

title: BOOKS
description: ''IF YOUR plans for a more-exciting 1983 include an extramarital affair,'' said Herbert S. Strean of Teaneck, a psychoanalyst and Distinguised Professor at the Graduate School of Social Work at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, ''be advised that such activity is neither healthy nor mature.''

title: A MAN LOOKING BACK, AROUND AND INSIDE
description: COURT OF MEMORY, By James McConkey. 338 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $14.95.

title: SUPERFUND FOR DIOXIN?
description: THE whirlpool of public fear, government policy and environmental science that surrounds dioxin is spinning with particular fury in Missouri, especially around the contaminated Meramec River town of Times Beach. Last week began with threats of civil disobedience and ended in relative calm, but what remained was a sense of confusion, and perhaps helplessness, over dioxin hazards and what to do about them.

title:
ANTIQUES;
STRATFORD OPENS SEASON
description: FOR 18 years, the first Connecticut show of the winter season to feature Early American furniture was the Wallingford Antiques Show, produced at the State Armory in that town. But the Wallingford building, in need of repairs, is one of the armories closed last autumn.

title: CITY IS READY TO TAKE ACTION ON GIANT 'EYESORE' BILLBOARD
description: New York City has been given the go-ahead by the state and the city's top legal officers to move against a giant cigarette billboard advertisement that residents of Washington Heights call an eyesore.

title: WOMEN SEEK ABORTION LOANS
description: AN increasing number of the women seeking loans for abortions through a new fund set up by the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut are not teen-agers, but adults, league officials say; many of them are no longer able to afford the average $200 cost because of unemployment.

title: MARGARET BENDER AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Bender of Short Hills, N.J, have announced the engagement Jean Bender, to Raymond R. Gillen of Schenectady, N.Y. An April wedding is planned. The prospective bridegroom is acting director of the procurament assistance program of the New York State Department of Commerce in Albany.

title: 5 RAILROAD BRIDGES TO BE REPAIRED
description: FIVE railroad bridges that open upward for river traffic are due for a $11 million mechanical tune-up starting this summer. The bridges, on the New Haven line, are in five communities from Milford to Greenwich.

title: PARLEY IN BERLIN COMPARES THE 80'S TO THE 30'S
description: An international conference to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Hitler's rise to power drew a parallel today between the current world financial crisis and arms race, and the Great Depression and rearmament that led to the rise of Nazism and World War II.

title: A Second Chance
description: In 1980, George (Buster) Rhymes set the University of Oklahoma football record for rushing by a freshman. Things have not gone well since.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
HARMING RAILROADS AND STATE'S RIGHTS
description: THE controversy over efforts by coal slurry proponents to obtain F ederal eminent domain privileges is so often crowded by side issues t hat the central question - the public interest - is seldom d iscussed. Let's place the matter in perspective.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LONDON
description: February is a nondescript sort of month, a time to rest up and pay up after the excesses of Christmas and the New Year and to await the magical renewal of spring. Maybe that's why the Romans made it our shortest month. But February does have its points: Mardi Gras in New Orleans and Carnival in Rio for revelers, Chinese New Year for gluttons, St. Valentine's Day for lovers young and old. It is also one of the best months of the year to visit London, especially if you like the visual arts, music and the theater - and you hate crowds. Feasting the Eyes

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books that, in the opinion of the Book Review staff, are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALFRED STIEGLITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS & WRITINGS, by Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton. (Callaway Editions/National Gallery of Art. $75.) A selection of the great American photographer's work.

title: WELCOME, KILLER TRUCKS
description: Just in time for Christmas, the lame-duck session of the 97th Congress handed a lavish gift to the truck and highway lobbies - killer trucks four times more lethal to human life than a passenger automobile and exponentially more destructive of the roads than any other vehicle.

title: Highgate
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: In the autumn of 1979, my mother killed the cats. We had seven; one morning, she grabbed four, took them to the vet and had them put to sleep. She said she didn't want to feed them anymore. It occurred to me that she might be going mad.

title: INTELLIGENCE AND SOMETIMES FOLLY
description: THE LAST HERO, Wild Bill Donovan. By Anthony Cave Brown. Illustrated. 891 pp. New York: Times Books. $24.95.

title: Suns 114, Clippers 101
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Walt Davis scored 20 of his season-high 38 points in the fourth period as Phoenix avoided a second-half collapse. Phoenix led by 82-60 with 2:26 left in the third period, but San Diego, behind the shooting of Al Wood, scored 15 of the final 17 points in closing the gap to 84-75 entering the final quarter.

title: FEAR OF CRIME HOBBLES CITIES AND CASTS SHADOWS ON SUBURBS
description: ALARMED by the recent murders of three young Morris County women and by a daytime attempt to abduct still another woman, many women are beginning to fear that suburban roads and parking lots are becoming as dangerous as city streets.

title: CENTENNIAL SALUTE
description: Although Igor Stravinsky is sometimes known as the father of 20thcentury music, little is known about him as the father of four children. In ''My Father, Stravinsky'' on Channel 13 on Wednesday at 9 P.M., one of his sons, Soulima, puts words to his father's music as he recalls his childhood adventures in an enchanted garden where music was magic.

title: TAKING THE MASK OFF NAIL PROBLEMS
description: As with many other beauty products, the emphasis in cosmetics for nails has turned to treatment. Rather than merely masking a problem, the latest products - many of which are available in kit form for athome use - are designed to strengthen the nails as they grow and protect them from peeling, splitting and breaking.

title: Charleston
description: To the Editor: Being a native Charlestonian, I am always elated to hear the many beauties of the port city extolled, as they were in the article by Ann Barry ''Looking Ahead to Charleston in Bloom'' (Travel, Dec. 19).

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE CAPITOL IS BUSTLING AGAIN
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly, in session for more than a week now, has yet to consider its first bill. But an effort has begun to cut down on the number of bills already cascading into the legislative hopper.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND PASSES RECORD ACHIEVED LAST YEAR
description: Contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record, exceeding the mark established last year.With about six weeks to go before the 71st annual campaign formally ends, donations to the fund brought the total yesterday to $1,553,134.77 and produced a million-dollar drive for the 13th year in a row. When the appeal ended last year on Feb. 27, more than 10,350 donors had contributed $1,535,501.34.

title: Cornwall
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: Fizzling Investment

title: Lock the Social Security Exits
description: Does it pay the citizen to stay in Social Security? For most of us, the answer doesn't matter because the tax and coverage are mandatory. But non-profit organizations and state and local governments have a choice. And growing numbers of them view Social Security as either a bad buy or a luxury they can no longer afford.

title: NOTEBOOK: HOSTAGE TALKS A FIRST FOR CRISIS TEAM
description: OSSINING ANTHONY K. UMINA'S job was over and his colleagues, members of the Crisis Intervention Team responsible for the agreement that ended the 53-hour siege at the state prison here, were urging him to get into a car heading back to Albany. But Mr. Umina paused; he had one more thing to say:

title:
GARDENING;
NUT TREES CAN YIELD FOOD AND SHADE
description: AS a youngster, my favorite cake was a simple, white cake with a light powdered-sugar icing. What made it special was that my mother always added hickory nuts to the ingredients.

title: Excerpts from ruling, page 31.
description: A Federal appeals panel yesterday overturned a lower court's order and ruled that CBS News may broadcast a ''60 Minutes'' segment tonight on police conduct in New Orleans.

title: WITH BUDGET AXES ALL ABOUT, SCHWEIKER PREFERRED A SCALPEL
description: A paradox ran through the tributes paid to Richard S. Schweiker after he offered his resignation as Secretary of Health and Human Services last week to become the chief lobbyist for the life insurance industry. For to the extent that he was well regarded by President Reagan, it was because he loyally carried out the President's policy of reducing Federal outlays, or the growth of Federal outlays, for health, welfare and social service programs. And to the extent that he was admired by special interest groups and constituents served by his department, it was because he defended these programs. Mrs. Heckler's Choices

title:
ART;
ANCIENT GLASS AT THE NEWARK MUSEUM
description: NEWARK PUBLIC attention to museums these days seems to be focused almost exclusively on temporary loan exhibitions. Yet the primary responsibility of any institution - especially one with a distinguished collection, such as the Newark Museum - must be caring for and presenting its own works.

title: BLACK JOBLESSNESS UP IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa returned to work this week after the midsummer holiday season that annually calls a halt to most construction and manufacturing, and there were strong indications that thousands of black migrant workers found they had no jobs to return to.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: An Anemic Send-Off

title: Correction
description: A review of ''The Deindustrialization of America'' by Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison (Dec. 12) incorrectly identified a corporation that has been ''diverting profits from its tire business'' into other fields. The book's reference was to the General Tire & Rubber Co.

title: Curtain Call
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
NUT TREES CAN YIELD FOOD AND SHADE
description: AS a youngster, my favorite cake was a simple, white cake with a light powdered-sugar icing. What made it special was that my mother always added hickory nuts to the ingredients.

title: W.B. Gardner to Wed Martha Shaughnessey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Batchelor of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Batchelor's daughter, Martha Anna Shaughnessey, to William Burnham Gardner, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Gardner of Woodbridge, N.J. The wedding is planned in April.

title: Katherine R. Rich, Editor, Weds Diego Olive, Writer
description: Katherine Russell Rich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Paddock Rich of Berwyn, Pa., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Diego Eduardo Olive of New York. The Rev. Gerald G. Alexander performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: Israelis Protest in West Bank
description: Several hundred Israeli leftists demonstrated in the half-completed Israeli settlement of Efrat in the West Bank today to protest the Government's settlement policy for the occupied area.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SOHO
description: PERHAPS there is no better measure of the protean nature of New YorkC ity than SoHo. In less than 15 years, a squalid, industrial area k nown mostly for noisy factories and choked streets has become a c entral symbol of the city's avant-garde culture.

title: STATUS CALLING? PICK UP THE PHONE
description: There have been designer clothes, designer fragrances and designer candy. Now comes the designer telephone. Pierre Cardin Electronique unveiled a new line of stylized telephones at the Consumer Electronics show. The company, a division of the Arrow Trading Corporation, a New York importer, entered the designer electronics business a year and a half ago, when it came out with its Pierre Cardin calculators, which were followed by Pierre Cardin clocks and radios.

title: FOR GOOD RESULTS WITH THE NEW AUTOMATIC
description: Many people who have acquired ''automatic'' cameras during this past holiday season may discover that the glowing promises of ''instant good pictures'' offered by television commercials and media ads may not always be completely fulfilled. It is not that these new cameras are incapable of performing as promised, but because many users do not take time to learn how to operate these sophisticated packages of electronics and fine lenses.

title: THE NEW YEAR'S NEW TAX PROVISIONS
description: THERE have been so many changes in the tax laws in the last few y ears that it is almost impossible for the average person to keep on t op of them. And on Jan. 1, a host of further changes -including a n ew system for withholding taxes on pension payments - went into e ffect and will have a widespread impact on millions of taxpayers. H ere's a rundown of some of those new provisions.

title: F-16's Reach Pakistan
description: The first 3 of 40 advanced F-16 fighter planes to be supplied by the United States to Pakistan arrived today, air force headquarters announced. A statement from the headquarters in Peshawar, capital of the northwest frontier province bordering Afghanistan, said 3 more would arrive in a few days.

title: SPECIAL ELECTION, SPECIAL ISSUE
description: A SPECIAL election in southwestern Suffolk County on Tuesday will produce a new county legislator and possibly the vote in the County Legislature that would make that the last special election.

title: WHAT'S THE SOCIALIST CURE FOR TWO LEFT FEET?
description: All of a sudden, governments lose their touch. They bump into things, botch them. They slip on roller skates and knock over flower pots. Whether the cause of the trouble is important becomes secondary; to the public, the government looks like a klutz.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5-2, FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: John Tonelli scored three goals tonight and led the Islanders to a 5-2 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Study Courses Abroad
description: Scholarly interests from the Silk Route of ancient China to the writing of screenplays are covered by seven study-abroad courses scheduled for this year by the University of California at Berkeley.

title: About the Retailing And Dining Scene
description: Regarding the letter by Irving Lerner (''Mamaroneck Avenue: A Vanishing Point?'' Dec. 26), I agree in general, but would like to add some important facts.

title: A Co-op's Responsibility
description: Question: The Q & A column (Dec. 19) said the city code had been interpreted to mean that when a building pipe bursts, the landlord must replaster and repaint the damage to the tenant's apartment. What happens if the landlord is a co-op? Must the co-op corporation repaint and repaper an apartment after it repairs a leaking steam riser? ... J.E.L., Manhattan. Answer: The Administrative Code of the City of New York says the owner of a multiple dwelling must keep it in good repair; this includes shareholder corporations that own cooperative apartment houses. Mary Ann Rothman, administrator of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said that some co-ops would repaint after repairing a wall that had been damaged by defects in the building system, but that most limit repairs to plastering and patching the damaged area. To recover more damages, a tenant must make a claim against the coop's insurance or his own homeowner's policy. Marc Luxemburg, chairman of the executive committee of the council, also notes that if a pipe bursts and the co-op board has to break through a tenant's wall to repair it, the board is not responsible for repairs to the wallpaper.

title: NEW YORK'S FENCERS CLUB REMAINS EN GARDE AT 100
description: For one hundred years they have met, drawn swords, done battle, then gone off for cocktails. And now members of New York's Fencers Club are preparing to celebrate the club's centennial.

title: NEW LIFE FOR ANCIENT MONUMENT IN JAVA
description: For the better part of a decade, lovers of ancient Eastern art, governments East and West and the Indonesian treasury have been paying archeologists, engineers and laborers to dismantle, repair and reassemble one of the great buildings of antiquity, the ninth century Buddhist monument of Borobudur in central Java.

title: FEMALE HUSKIES
description: ''It's going to be a tough year for us, but it's a great challenge for a young team and the future looks bright,'' was the assessment of the UConn women's basketball season by Jean Balthaser, the coach.

title: No Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: FATHER AND SON
description: FAR FROM THE SEA By Evan Hunter. 248 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: SECURING MORTGAGES IS DIFFICULT
description: VACATION property can be difficult to finance, and when you finally g et a mortgage, it may be more costly than than if the house were y our primary residence.

title: WESTBURY TEACHERS REACH PACT EARLY
description: WESTBURY AT their meeting on Wednesday, Westbury School Board trustees will formally approve a contract with the district's teachers that was reached with unusual speed. The new agreement was initialed by both sides in late December - more than six months before the expiration of the current contract on June 30.

title: TOXIC DUMPING UNIT IN NEW JERSEY IS REBUKED
description: A Federal and state task force created in New Jersey in 1978 to combat the illegal dumping of hazardous waste ''mishandled'' criminal investigations and ''misrepresented'' its actions in official reports, a House subcommittee charged yesterday.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF THE DUKE'S MIXTURE
description: Be a linguistic hawkshaw; follow a strange phrase to its roots. ''For years I have used an expression,'' writes Nancy Montgomery of Washington, ''to describe a strange combination of people, objects or events, calling it a duke's mixture. It never occurred to me that this was a phrase not in everyone's vocabulary until my new assistant asked me what it meant.''

title: BOATMEN DEPEND MORE ON LORAN C
description: AMONG boatmen, a dependency on the electronic Loran C navigation system is growing at an astonishing rate. Using a system of proven reliability, and with retail prices tumbling, Loran units in the Northeast are becoming both indispensable and affordable.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: White Plains: Last month, Mary Anne Venitucci was spending a quiet evening when she got a call from a friend. "She said she was stoned and drunk," recalled Miss Venitucci, a senior at White Plains High School. "So I told her to come over."

title: 17 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: THE MEDICAL CASE FOR ENDING BOXING
description: THE principal purpose of a boxing match is for one opponent to render the other injured, defenseless, incapacitated, unconscious. No caring person could have observed the events in professional prizefighting in the past few months and not have been revolted. No prudent physician could have watched the most recent debacle/mismatch on Nov. 26, 1982, between Larry Holmes and Randall (Tex) Cobb, and believe that the current boxing control system is functioning. The fact that this massacre came on the immediate heels of even more tragic fights serves to accentuate the uncontrolled situation.

title: SKILLMAN SCHOOL WINS A REPRIEVE
description: SKILLMAN FOUR young residents of the Training School for Boys here listened closely, their forkfuls of pot roast poised between plate and mouth as the superintendent, Alfred B. Vuocolo, tried to explain the events that led last Sunday to the announcement that their school would not be closed Jan. 31, as scheduled, because of state budget cuts.

title: Dance Celebrities To Honor Walter Terry
description: Celebrities from the world of dance will speak and perform at a celebration on Jan. 31 at City Center to honor the late Walter Terry, the dance critic. Highlights of the program will be the appearance of Heidi Ryom and Frank Andersen, two principal dancers with the Royal Danish Ballet, as well as performers from the Dance Theater of Harlem and the companies of Martha Graham and Alvin Ailey.

title: RIGHTS GROUP TO HONOR JAVITS
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits will be this year's recipient of the Charles Evans Hughes Gold Medal, given each year by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

title: TRIAL OF YONKERS PARTY LEADER ON EXTORTION CHARGE BEGINS
description: Federal prosecutors have presented several witnesses and taped conversations in the extortion trial of Angelo Grippo, the chairman of the Democratic Party in Yonkers.

title: 'BURNT-OUT' JUDGE LEAVES THE BENCH
description: Alan I. Friess gained more notoriety during his three and a half years as a Criminal Court judge in New York City than many of his colleagues do in a lifetime.

title: GOlden Road To Washington
description: Experts poring over the latest Federal Election Commission reports last week found some new numbers but few new patterns in money raising and spending on last year's Congressional races. With the tally almost all in - no more than a few million here and there is expected to be added in year-end reports due Jan. 31 - corporate political action committees, labor political action committees, incumbents and challengers were seen to have behaved pretty much as usual, only more so.

title: FILM FALLOUT
description: Career diplomats may have to take a little guff from time to time, but Nathaniel Davis draws the line at ''public disgrace, scorn and ridicule.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
