description: THE BORROWERS AVENGED By Mary Norton. Illustrated by Beth and Joe Krush. 298 pp. New York: $12.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: BONN'S CLIMATE IS PERFECT - FOR GROMYKO
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, was to arrive today in West Germany just as a momentous election campaign is gathering steam. Some weeks back, the Gromyko visit looked like a nice opportunity for the new Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, to demonstrate that his conservative Christian Democrats could deal with the Soviet Union, preserving continuity in policies staked out by Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Fifteen years after Martin Luther King's death, traces of bigotry and injustice still remain.'' - President Reagan. (14:1.) *

title: CAN A LIBERAL TRANSLATE THEORY INTO PRACTICE?
description: IT WAS easy to be a liberal when I was growing up in the early 1960's. At home and in my high school, we talked about the black plight in America. We believed that desegregation in the South must take place with ''all deliberate speed.''

title: Dr. Bailey W. Diffie Dead at 80; Taught History at City College
description: Dr. Bailey W. Diffie, a professor of history at City College for 35 years, died at his home in West Hollywood, Calif., on Wednesday.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
FOLK ARTS THRIVE IN A QUITO SHOP
description: TOM MILLER, the author of ''On the Border: Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier''(Harper & Row/Ace Books), is writing a nonfiction book based on his travels in Ecuador.

title: TV and Music
description: Under copyright laws, composers and publishers of music are entitled to royalties when their music is played. But a Federal judge ruled in August 1982 that the system under which 700 local television stations in the country were paying such royalties violated the antitrust laws.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Production in U.S. factories fell only one-tenth of one percent in December, the Federal Reserve said, giving a promising signal that the economic decline may be touching bottom. Auto production surged 13 percent, but business equipment output fell 19.5 percent. For the year, production fell 8.2 percent, the biggest annual decline since 1974.

title: FASTER RIDE IS IN STORE ON RAILROAD
description: COMMUTERS on New Haven line trains may have faster rides in the near future because of a change in the daily wheel inspections being conducted on the rail cars. But they still won't reach their destinations on schedule, according to officials of Metro North Commuter Service, which operates the rail line.

title: GRANDPARENTS HAVE VERY REAL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
HUMANITY'S HOPE LIES IN THE U.N.
description: DURING the Revolutionary War, the 13 former Colonies were drawn together by common danger, but afterward they sagged apart. The confederation under which they lived was not so much a government as a league of states. Congress was not a general legislature, but a diplomatic assembly in which the states had equal votes. There was no real executive or judiciary.

title: FUTURELESS MAN
description: INDEFENSIBLE WEAPONS The Political and Psychological Case Against Nuclearism. By Robert Jay Lifton and Richard Falk. 301 pp. New York: Basic Books. Cloth, $15.50. Paper, $6.95.NUKESPEAK Nuclear Language, Visions, and Mindset. By Stephen Hilgartner, Richard C. Bell and Rory O'Connor. Illustrated. 282 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $14.95.

title: THE SEXUAL MASQUERADE IS CONVEYING A NEW MESSAGE
description: Did anybody laugh when Marlene Dietrich put on white tie and tails? When Garbo swaggered through "Queen Christina" in doublet and tall boots? When Katharine Hepburn strode on screen in trousers, a shirt and a big boyish grin? No, because in assuming a man's clothes they were assuming a man's clothes they were assuming something of man's status. But a man in a dress is almost always a hoot. Unless, of course, he's the hero/heroine--whatever-of a movie called "Tootsie."

title: THE MAKING OF A WRITER
description: THERE were rented houses in Hamden, Conn. First a two-family house, painted blue on top and yellow on bottom; we lived in the blue, and moved when I was 1. Then a small gray house on Winette Street, the earliest remembered place: I pull a carrot for supper from the garden; I stand on the sidewalk holding a toy in the sun that never sets. Then a bigger house, at the corner of Whitney and Harmon, with a toolshed where I could perform 6-year-old carpentry. Then the big step - the down payment, the mortgage assumed on a house in Spring Glen that the bank had taken by foreclosure; this was the 1930's.

title: BEWARE THE AUDIO VERSION OF A 'FAST' SELL
description: Audio has been a prominent arena for the popular sport of knocking down straw men. As long as nobody looks closely, this kind of exercise makes you a hero at no risk. One such ploy is to tout measurements that have only a doubtful connection to audible performance -to play the numbers game with meaningless numbers. For example, some manufacturers have been rating their amplifiers for their ''speed,'' thereby leading audio fans to talk about ''fast'' amplifiers in much the same way as an earlier generation used to talk about fast girls. In either case, the term denotes responsiveness, and in amplifiers it means responsiveness of a special kind: the ability of the circuits to react quickly to sudden changes in the level and character of the sound to be reproduced. The implication is fostered that faster is better.

title: A CONCERT HONORS MARTIN LUTHER KING
TWO SCIENTISTS TO SHARE WOLF PRIZE FOR PHYSICS
description: The $100,000 Wolf Foundation prize for physics for 1982 will be shared by two scientists, born and trained in New York City, who were credited with discoveries of new particles that changed conceptions of the structure of matter.

title: CHANGES IN BOATS HELPFUL TO SAILORS
description: IN the years since World War II, cruising powerboats and sailboats have changed dramatically, and most of these changes have conferred real benefits upon the people who buy these boats. A walk through the National Boat Show at the Coliseum will confirm that the 1983 models offer choices in performance, accommodations and styling that would have startled the yachtsmen of the 1930's or even of the 1950's.

title: METAPHYSICS AND THE ART OF BIRD FEEDING
description: IHAD vowed after last winter that I was through trying to be nice to them. If they wouldn't come to me, to my charity and my suet, well, forget them.

title: Andrea Joseffer and James Edward McGrath Wed
description: Andrea Joseffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Joseffer of New York, was married yesterday in Grace Episcopal Church to James Edward McGrath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. McGrath of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr. of St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church performed the ceremony.

title: OPERETTA: DOUBLE BILL IN WASHINGTON
description: This month at the John F. Kennedy Center's Terrace Theater, the Washington Opera is presenting a revival with a wrinkle of its warmly received double bill from last season, Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Trial by Jury'' and Offenbach's ''Monsieur Choufleuri.''

title: Ireland Wins in Rugby
description: Ollie Campbell kicked 12 points in the first half to lead defending champion Ireland to a 15-13 victory over Scotland at Murrayfield today in their opening International Rugby Union championship match of the season. The victory was Ireland's first at Murrayfield since 1971.

title: Congressmen Visiting Athens For a Meeting of Legislators
description: A 21-member Congressional delegation from the United States is scheduled to arrive this weekend for the 21st meeting of American and European legislators, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Frying Pan to Fire Department
description: If New York City is to wage a war on crime, the Citizens Budget Commission said last week, it will have to draft the Fire Department. While the number of fires has declined 27 percent in the last five years, the civic group noted in its second study of city services, the number of firefighters has remained at about 11,500.

title: DERIVATION DETECTIVE
description: LISTENING TO AMERICA An Illustrated History of Words and Phrases From Our Lively and Splendid Past. By Stuart Berg Flexner. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: DREYFUS BETS ON THE LION AGAIN
description: NOT since the early 1970's has the Dreyfus lion leaped out of a s ubway station onto the nation's television sets. It was then that D reyfus, plagued by a slumping stock market and waning interest in i ts mutual funds, retired the symbol that helped catapult the i nvestment firm to the top ranks of the money management industry.

title: 'Freeze' Opponent Is Taken to Task
description: William E. Bishop's desperate search for an argument to rebut Theresa C. Smith's logically reasoned, factually based case for a nuclear freeze (Both articles appeared on the Opinion Page on Oct. 24; neither was intended as a rebuttal of the other) led him into the moral sewer thoroughly explored by the late, unlamented Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

title: No Aid for Steel
description: To the Business Editor: As the owner of a small printing company, I am dismayed by the views of Lloyd McBride, the president of the United Steelworkers union, in his article ''More Help Needed'' (Jan. 2). In the article he called for trade restraints and an infusion of public money to save the steelmaking industry in the United States.

title: A Season Greeting For the M.T.A.
description: The M.T.A.'s takeover of Conrail brought in the New Year with a bang, for Harlem Line commuters. After riding the train on the first day under the new management, I have come to a few conclusions as to their plans for the future.

title: LIGHT IS SHED ON THE SHARED TRAITS OF BAROQUE COMPOSERS
description: Variegated qualities of mind and heart may separate Corelli, Albinoni, Vivaldi and Couperin, but all share membership in a single fraternity. One sees in them features common to the Baroque, but each individual face is different - the directness of Corelli very far from Couperin's reticent introspection, Vivaldi's incendiary sense of excitement (and often paper-thin substance) more shrilly brilliant than the calm, deep voice of Albinoni.

title: STATE CHALLENGED ON COLLEGE CONTROL
description: TRENTON A1916 state law that requires all degree-granting colleges and universities in New Jersey to be licensed is being challenged in Federal District Court here as unconstitutional.

title: LEADER OF LIBERAL PARTY TRIES TO STRIP POWER FROM 2 RIVALS
description: Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, has moved to strip the powers from his two rivals for control of the party. The effort - against the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, the state chairman, and James F. Notaro, the party secretary and executive director - followed a call for their resignations at an ''informal'' state committee meeting Jan. 8. Both have rejected the demand.

title: INTERSTING ANCIENTS
description: WHO WAS WHO IN THE GREEK WORLD 776 BC-30 BC. Edited by Diana Bowder. Illustrated. 227 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: A Phaidon Book/Cornell University Press. $29.95. WHO WAS WHO IN THE ROMAN WORLD 753 BC-AD 476. Edited by Diana Bowder. Illustrated. 256 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: A Phaidon Book/Cornell University Press. $28.50.

title: Costa Rica Reports Capture Of 4 Anti-Sandinist Guerrillas
description: Rural guards have captured four guerrillas who planned using Costa Rica as a springboard for raiding neighboring Nicaragua, the police said.

title: Beth Harris Is Married
description: Elizabeth Selena Harris, daughter of Charles A. Harris and Dorothy Hoback Harris, both of New York, was married at the Mount Paran Church of God in Atlanta yesterday to Mark Laverne Robertson, son of the Rev. Arnold L. Robertson of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Mitzi Haymore Robertson.

title: COMPLICATED FRIENDSHIPS
description: DIFFICULT WOMEN, A Memoir of Three. By David Plante. 173 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95.

title: Miss Navrtilova Defeats Miss Austin
description: Martina Navratilova, the top-seeded player, gave Tracy Austin a lesson in power tennis tonight with a 6-2, 6-2 victory in the semifinals of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tennis tournament.

title: ON L.I., SHELLFISH RULES AREN'T THE ONLY PROBLEM
description: In Long Island communities where generations of baymen have reaped tidy profits from abundant offshore clam beds, the current generation says it is more profitable to stay home. With nearly a thousand people becoming ill from contaminated clams, demand has disappeared and prices have plunged, leading some experts to doubt whether clamming can remain a significant economic force.

title: CONCERT:LARRY NEWLAND
description: Larry Newland, the New York Philharmonic's assistant conductor, had the orchestra all to himself Friday, and his program was an original and frequently difficult one.

title: BRUINS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 2-0
description: Pete Peeters got the shutout, but Ed Mio made almost all the spectacular saves as the Boston Bruins beat the Rangers today, 2-0.

title: Maxine Groffsky, Literary Agent, Wed
description: Maxine Groffsky, a New York literary agent, was married yesterday to Winthrop Knowlton, chairman of Harper & Row. Civil Court Justice Leonard N. Cohen performed the ceremony at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Staley, friends of the couple.

title: ABOUT THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
CALIFORNIA CITIBANKER;
UNWELCOME AND UNRUFFLED
description: SAN FRANCISCO I n the 1970's, when its upstate New York division needed a facelift, Citicorp sent in Betty Sue Peabody, a tough-minded Texan. Within five years, she helped turn around the retail banking operation. Working with community bankers, she encouraged them to take on small business and personal loans that were profitable, and to bring in low-cost deposits. She set up a processing center in Rochester for government-guaranteed student loans and she won the respect of her colleagues.

title: 'Path to Power'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stunt Man Killed in Sky Dive
description: Joseph Svec of Houston, a veteran stunt man and parachutist, was killed Friday when he failed to pull his ripcords during the filming of a movie scene. Bob Phelps, manager of the California City Airport, said that the jump was going as planned and that a later examination showed nothing wrong with the 35-year-old stunt man's parachutes. The sequence being filmed for ''The Right Stuff,'' based on the book by Tom Wolfe, depicted a fighter pilot ejecting from an experimental plane.

title: WORK DUE TO BEGIN ON TRANSPORT CENTER AT STAMFORD
description: THE 7,000 or so people who get on and off more than 160 trains in the Stamford railroad station each workday will have to endure two years of construction turmoil starting in the next month or two, as the shabby, 87-year-old station is torn down and a new one built.

title: Susan Jane Hodesblatt Plans Wedding in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Hodesblatt of Monsey, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Hodesblatt, to Douglas Kramer McCormick, son of William T. McCormick of Millburn, N.J., and Ann McCormick of Atlanta.

title: Home Called the Place For Daily Prayer
description: Too many modern parents expect the school, the church and the police to make good citizens of their kids.

title: EXPRESSLY NOT FOR BEST-SELLER LISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrew J. Stein, Borough President, To Wed Lynn Forester Next Month
description: Andrew J. Stein, Borough President of Manhattan, and Lynn Forester, an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, plan to be married next month. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel will perform the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

title: NEW SHOW IN UNUSUAL SPACE
description: EAST, a former bank recently converted to artists' studios, made its debut as a gallery last fall with a ''salon des refuses'' from the Parrish Art Museum's now defunct juried exhibition. Since then, Nathan Kuhn, the facilities proprietor and himself a sculptor, has been busy organizing further shows and expanding the complex into nearby vacant commercial space.

title: Laurie Hadden Robertson Married to Amos K. Sweet
description: Laurie Hadden Robertson, daughter of Mrs. Donald L. Carter of East Greenwich, R.I., and the late Dr. Gordon Farquhar Robertson of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Ames Kendall Sweet, son of Judge Robert W. Sweet of New York and Lois Clapp Sweet of Patterson, N.Y. The Revs. Kenneth and Judith Gorsuch performed the ceremony at the West End Collegiate Church.

title: ON Both Sides Of the Law
description: Puerto Rico's police are among the most poorly paid under the American flag, but at least they once had a reputation for honesty. Now, however, Justice Department investigators say a two-year inquiry has turned up evidence that many of the Commonwealth's 8,000 peace officers are among the most corrupt anywhere.

title: EX-COMMANDANT OF MARINE CORPS
description: Gen. David M. Shoup, a retired Commandant of the Marine Corps, a World War II hero and an early, outspoken critic of United States involvement in the Vietnam War, died Thursday of a heart ailment at the Circle Terrace Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 78 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: Q & A
description: Question:My husband and I will be traveling with another couple to Ireland for two weeks during the month of April. We would like to plan our itinerary around any special events scheduled for that time of year, and we would like to go to the theater during our stay in Dublin; how do we arrange for tickets? - D.W.C., Wilmington, Del. Answer:Among events on the Irish Tourist Board's calendar during April are the International Opera Festival (Gaiety Theater, Dublin; April 4 to 23) and the Motor Racing Circuit of Ireland Rally (beginning in Belfast on Good Friday, April 1, continuing in Killarney with time trials in the Ring of Kerry region on Holy Saturday and Easter Sunday, and concluding in Belfast on Easter Monday, April 4). Other events include an Ireland vs. Wales rugby match (Dublin, April 9), the Cork National Boat Show (Cork, April 27 to 30) and the Galway Arts Festival (Galway, April 22 to May 1). The Galway festival will include performances of traditional Irish music and dance as well as mime, poetry readings and art exhibits.

title: PEKING'S NEW LINE CALLS FOR NEW HEROES
description: Anyone wondering where all the heroes have gone might contemplate Zhang Hua, who died last summer after he tried to save an old peasant from drowning in a pit of nightsoil.

title: Cornwall
description: To the Editor:

title: KAREN CARTER ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Karen Carter to George R. Caso 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ross J. Carter of Ellenburg, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Mr. Caso is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Caso Jr. of Merrick, L.I. A May 29 wedding is planned. Miss Carter and her fiance are lawyers. She is with the firm of Shaw, Goldman, Licitra, Levine & Weinberg P.C. in Garden City, L.I. Mr. Caso is with the New York firm of Goetz & Fitzpatrick P.C.

title: Gazpacho
description: To the Editor:

title: TINY BANK IN ILLINOIS WELCOMES ARMED CUSTOMERS
description: Banks rarely welcome customers carrying guns, but, in an attempt to compete commercially on a national level, the tiny Bank of Findlay has been giving away firearms to investors.

title: HAVE TAPE DECK WILL TRAVEL
description: Miron From wristwatch radios to Pac-Man phones, many new and unusual consumer electronics products are first shown to the industry at the semiannual International Consumer Electronics Show. Here's a sampling of some of the more unusual offerings from the most recent show, held earlier this month in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK METS (NL) - Named J ohn Tamargo as manager of Columbia, S .C., farm team in South Atlantic League. HOCKEY DETROIT (NHL) - Obtained Ivan Bol- d irev, center, from Vancouver for Mark K irton, center.

title: Amateur Ski Racing
description: Firefighters do it. Chefs do it. Bartenders and cowboys do it. Policemen and businessmen do it. And, increasingly, families and just plain people do it. They ski through gates for prizes, trophies, medals or just the glory of having stood all the way down the course.

title: Letters; The Lobby Swap
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Nakasone leaves tomorrow for talks in U.S. 3 Israeli President ends a cautious visit to the U.S. 3 Third world talks end as criti- cism of U.S. is toned down 4 Around the World 5 Black unemployment rate is ris- ing in South Africa 7 Greek Communists press Social- ists to toe a radical line 8 Parti Quebecois applies to join the Socialist International 9 Marine Corps concerned about safety of troops in Lebanon 9 Berlin parley sees parallel be- tween the 1980's and the 30's 12 Rome plans to restore ''grandeur that was Rome'' 12 Government/Politics Gallup Poll finds Reagan with low rating at midterm 15 South Carolina joins in bid to bar plutonium reactor 18 Regulation of loan interest rates is debated in Albany 22 Liberal Party leader moves to strip powers from two rivals 24 Subcommittee criticizes Jersey waste dumping task force 26 General Around the Nation 16 Armed customers are welcome at Illinois bank 16 Blacks' economic troubles con- front prospering Miami 16 Consumer activist warns on driv- ing G.M. title: THE GARBAGE CRISIS: GOING BEYOND 'GOOD GUYS' AND 'BAD GUYS'
description: IANSWERED a frantic telephone call recently from a desperatesounding man in California. The call was not unlike many I have received from all over the country in the last few years.

title: Rosenbloom Theory Doubted
description: The medical examiner who performed the autopsy on the body of Carroll Rosenbloom in 1979 rejects suggestions that Rosenbloom, the late Los Angeles Rams owner, may have been murdered while swimming off Golden Beach, a resort 10 miles north of Miami.

title: CITY BALLET: 'WHO CARES?' IN A NEW PRODUCTION
description: You will need very strong sunglasses to withstand the glare of the shiny new costumes in George Balanchine's always glittering Gershwin ballet, ''Who Cares?'' But no eyeshade could possibly triumph over the absolute dazzle with which the New York City Ballet now dances this fabulous ballet.

title: CITY COUNCIL RESHUFFLES PANELS AMID SOME RUFFLED FEATHERS
description: The reorganization of City Council committees is a periodic affair conducted more in the nooks and crannies of City Hall than in the Council's ornate second-floor chamber.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 16, 1983
description: International Eugene V. Rostow's dismissal by President Reagan as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency stemmed, in part, from his being admonished for exceeding his authority in arms talks with the Russians. Sources close to Mr. Rostow cited two instances: a meeting in Geneva last July and a private meeting Mr. Rostow held in Vienna with the head of a Soviet delegation. (Page 1, Column 6.) Italy and West Germany are becoming more interested in an ''interim solution'' on the deployment of new NATO medium-range nuclear missiles at the end of the year. This means that there is increased receptiveness in Rome and Bonn for the idea that NATO can reduce the number of American missiles it plans to station if there is Soviet willingness to reduce its total of SS-20 missilies targeted on Western Europe. (1:5.)

title: SOCIAL SECURITY REFORMERS AGREE ON A DEAL, FINALLY
description: Strip away the financial arcana that have ensnarled President Reagan's bipartisan advisory commission on Social Security for nearly a year and the central issue emerges clearly and simply. It is: who pays and who gets? Such questions are difficult for legislators to resolve because some voters inevitably feel they are losing something - and sometimes they are right.

title: HITS AND MISSES OF LAST SEASON
description: and that persists. Should our regional theaters be accorded a special set of beginning-of-the-year or end-of-theseason prizes - out-of-town Tonys, sort of?

title: ST. JOHN'S UPSET BY 68-64
description: The best start of any St. John's basketball team since the 1910-11 season had ended, and now it was time for the Redmen to go out into the snow and let Alex, their regular bus driver, attempt to take them back home.

title: Sevres
description: To the Editor: In reference to the article on ''The Enduring Art of Sevres'' (Travel, Jan 2), Roosevelt-Lincoln buffs know there is a Sevres porcelain head (almost two feet in height), at Sagamore Hill, Oyster Bay, L.I., made after a life mask of Lincoln patented by the Illinois sculptor Leonard Wells Volk.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
IDLE HOUR ARTISTS
description: Although they lived and worked at the Idle Hour Artists' Colony in Oakdale, there was nothing idle about the painters and sculptors who inhabited the renovated service buildings of the former Vanderbilt estate. During the colony's creative heyday, its residents turned out a steady flow of impressive work. Drawn from the 1930's, a particularly active period in the colony's history, some of this work - by such artists as Joseph Boston, George Elmer Browne, G. Glenn Newell, Carl Nordell and Roselle Osk - goes on exhibition at the Islip Art Gallery today.

title: Elderly Security
description: To the Business Editor: Robert Pear's article ''How Poor Are the Elderly'' (Dec.19), was a sad commentary on where America is going. It is easy to present statistics showing that we have come a long way, and that the elderly are no worse off than us younger folk.

title: WORDS AND PICTURES
description: THE AMERICAN HERITAGE DICTIONARY Second College Edition.Illustrated. 1,568 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95. Thumb-indexed, $14.95.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY RONNEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Warner, $3.95.) Reflections by the journalist and television commentator. 2 FEVER, by Robin Cook. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) Obsessions, personal and professional, prossess a cancer researcher: fiction 3 A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $3.95.) A death in the family creates a crisis for three female individualists: fiction. 4 SOPHIE'S CHOICE, by William Styron. (Bantam, $3.95.) the nature of evil seen through the lives of two doomed lovers: basis of the current film. 5 PACIFIC VORTEX! by Clive Cussler. (Bantam, $3.95.) Probing the mysteries of a perilous zone in the Pacific: fiction. 6 THE RESTAURANT AT THE END OF THE UNIVERSE, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $2.95.) Science-fiction satire. 7 THE HITCHHIKER'S GUIDE TO THE GALAXY, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $2.95.) Science-fiction satire. 8 PALOMINO, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.30.) After two sad love affairs, Samantha discovers other things that are important: fiction. 9 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) A nurses and her charges in a World War II Hospital: fiction. 10 LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Fawcett, $2.95.)

title: GRIM OUTLOOK FOR PRISONS, EXPERTS AGREE
description: There was so much talk about crime in the nation's gubernatorial races last fall that criminal justice experts from Brandeis University decided it would be an ideal time to study it. Predictably, they heard much about tougher sentences. Perhaps just as predictably, they heard little about the impact of tougher sentences on already overcrowded prisons, or how new prisons might be paid for, or what could be done until they were built or, for that matter, whether some of the prisoners now in them ought to be.

title: Times Beach Residents Take Plight to the Public
description: More than 100 residents of this dioxin-plagued community advertised their plight to the traveling public today, waving signs and banners at cars and trucks passing on nearby Interstate 44.

title: WAYS AND MEANS IN SOLIDARITY'S SUPPRESSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: REVENGE AND FRAUD
description: MEAN TIME By Christopher T. Leland. 211 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95. THE BRENDA MANEUVER By Stephen N. Rosenberg. 232 pp. New York: Newmarket Press. $13.95.

title: W.F. Miller Wed To Carol Caldwell
description: Carol Ann Caldwell, head of the paintings, drawings and watercolors department at Christie's East, a subsidiary in New York of Christie, Manson & Woods International, was married yesterday to Winthrop Farrell Miller, an account executive for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Services Corporation in New York.

title: HIS LATEST HIT
description: The traditional good-luck wish in theatrical circles is not ''break a nose.'' But then, Werner Ploner was not wishing fair fortune on Isabel Weicken, the star of the German-language version of ''Evita.'' Mr. Ploner, the producer of the show, was sentenced to two years in prison last week for paying a couple of goons $2,600 to beat up Miss Weicken so that her understudy, the light of his eye, could take over the starring role. Miss Weicken was assaulted after the show opened in Vienna in March, and missed 11 performances with a broken nose and other injuries.

title: Puppeteers at Columbia
description: A free afternoon of music, marionettes and film is planned today from 4 to 5:30 P.M., at the Center for Italian Studies (Casa Italiana) at Columbia University, 1161 Amsterdam Avenue, at 117th Street.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
BOOKS OR BOMBS? ITS MATTER OVER MIND
description: ARISTOTLE once quipped that educated people were superior to those who were uneducated ''as much as the living are to the dead.'' Education, he said, is an ornament in prosperity and a refuge in adversity.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: SOME of the worst fears that environmentalists had about 1982 proved unfounded. For example, Congress reauthorized the Endangered Species Act without substantially weakening it. Also, numerous proponents of the Clean Air Act in New Jersey recorded a victory of sorts when Congress refused to enact changes in that law that had the backing of the Reagan Administration.

title: VOLUNTEERS WHO SERVE HISTORY
description: WITH more than 17,000 landmark buildings and 42 historic districts t o protect, policing New York City's architectural resources can be ad aunting task. For the Landmarks Preservation Commission, a staff of 5 0 full-time members often proves insufficient.

title: Judith E. Kent to Be Wed To James Dimon in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Kent of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Ellen Kent, to James Dimon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Dimon of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Red Wings 4 Maple Leafs 3
description: DETROIT (AP) - Dwight Foster's goal at 9:06 of the third period gave Detroit the victory and moved the Red Wings to within 2 points of the third-place St. Louis Blues in the Norris Division. Detroit also increased its fourth-place lead over Toronto to 6 points.

title: The 'New' Bob Dole
description: As the former staff director of the Senate Nutrition Committee, who served under George McGovern while Robert Dole was a Republican member, I can personally attest to Senator Dole's ability to grow on the job (''The Clout of the 'New' Bob Dole,'' by Timothy B. Clark, Dec. 12).

title: PLEASURABLE COMPLEMENTS TO WINE
description: ALMOST a decade ago, the American Hotel in Sag Harbor, a former 19th-century merchants' lodging that had seen better days, was lovingly renovated and opened as a serious restaurant with a handful of guest rooms. It gradually evolved from a place notable mainly for its informally charming Victorian atmosphere to a restaurant that could boast one of the finest wine cellars in the country.

title: KIM SHEERAN FIANCEE OF MICHAEL E. O'BRIEN
description: James Jennings Sheeran of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., and Kathryn Leuver Sheeran of Upper Montclair, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter , Kathryn Lynn Sheeran, to Michael Edward O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lawrence O'Brien of Marshfield Hills, Mass.

title: HE IS MORE ENGLISH THAN ANY ENGLISHMAN
description: Edward Herrmann listens. He listens so intently, with his face and mind and body, that the audience is always aware of him. This is true for long moments when he does not have a single line to speak, even while Kate Nelligan, the female star playing opposite him in David Hare's ''Plenty,'' is sizzling and exploding all over the stage of the Plymouth in an almost nonstop display of verbal and emotional fireworks.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: EFFORTS to redevelop New Haven's downtown shopping area took a major step forward last week with the announcement that Yale University will assist in financing a $21 million complex for retail shops, housing and offices near the proposed Shubert Square entertainment district.

title: REagan Tries His Hand at Farm Politics
description: That more is less for the American farmer is not a matter of aesthetics but fact. As the United States Department of Agriculture announced last week that production of corn, wheat and some other major crops hit record highs in 1982, some farm prices stood at their lowest levels in a decade and net farm income was at its lowest in 50 years.

title: TELEVISION NEWS, PRO AND CON
description: MEDIA UNBOUND The Impact of Television Journalism on the Public. By Stephan Lesher. 285 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95. NEWSWATCH How TV Decides the News. By Av Westin. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: FINDING HELP FOR TIC DISORDERS
description: FIFTY years ago, soon after her mother died, Marilyn Light developed a set of mysterious symptoms. First, she blinked her eyes uncontrollably. Then gradually she began sticking out her tongue, making faces and producing barking sounds.

title: Walls Adjusts to Cowboys and Clings to Receivers
description: THE first time he ever played football wearing a Dallas Cowboys uniform, Everson Walls was covering a receiver from his cornerback position, and the receiver beat him on a pass play and ran for what would have been a touchdown, had it been a game instead of a practice session in mini-camp for rookies.

title: Military Analysis
description: There is a growing conviction in the navies of the United States and other Atlantic alliance countries that efforts to improve their antisubmarine warfare abilities may be the most significant of naval development programs.

title: U.S. FACING STRONGET CHALLENGE IN DEFENSE OF AMERICA'S CUP
description: Beginning next Sept. 13, a 12-meter yacht representing the United States will meet a foreign challenger for the 25th time in defense of spor's oldest and perhaps most hallowed trophy, the America's Cup.

title: After Ossining
description: ''We were lucky,'' concluded Thomas Coughlin, New York State's Commissioner of Correction, in assessing the uprising at the Ossining prison. By all accounts, he and Governor Cuomo exploited good luck with cool-headed negotiating that put down the revolt without bloodshed.

title: TWO CITIES AWAIT ACTION TO PERMIT SALES TAX OPTION
description: OFFICIALS in Mount Vernon and New Rochelle are awaiting the outcome of efforts in Albany that would enable the two cities to continue collecting their full 2 percent share of the local sales tax, instead of relinquishing 0.5 percent to the county, beginning in March.

title: NAVON ENDS CAUTIOUS VISIT TO U.S.
description: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel ended an 11-day visit to the United States today, a trip billed as nonpolitical but one that prominent American Jews said enhanced his reputation in this country.

title: SUITED FOR SPRING
description: The well-tailored and figure-fitting suit is again in the fashion spotlight. The jackets, of varying lengths, with or without belts, feature square shoulder lines, while the skirts are slim. As the right finishing touch for this dressed-up look, many designers are suggesting wide-brimmed hats and even gloves.

title: Canadian in Abu Dhabi
description: Foreign Trade Minister Gerald Regan of Canada met with Mahmoud Kruha, director of the state-owned Abu Dhabi National Oil Company today, the official press agency said. They discussed possible joint energy projects.

title: ANGLERS ROLL ROCKS AND DREAM OF SPRING
description: CROSS RIVER IT looked like a gathering of modern-day Druids in hip waders or the preparations for a Biblical stoning, but it was merely the Cross River ''rock rollers'' at work building a trout stream.

title: MARINES CONCERNED FOR SAFETY OF TROOPS ON DUTY IN LEBANON
description: A Marine Corps spokesman said today that there was ''professional concern'' among corps commanders for the safety of their troops in Lebanon.

title: MIRIAM GILL, JAMES STIRN ARE TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Goss of Chicago have announced the engagement of Mrs. Goss's daughter, Miriam Wellington Gill, to James Reid Stirn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles van Syckel Stirn of Dongan Hills, S.I., and Snug Harbor, Quebec. An April wedding is planned.

title: West Indian Athletes Touring South Africa
description: A breakaway team of West Indian cricketers began a tour of South Africa today to a standing ovation from a packed, multiracial crowd despite criticism over the tour from South African blacks and from abroad.

title: FIVE WHOM DAY CARE HELPED
description: MEDICAL day care is especially suited to two types of people, according to Natalie Zanetich, director of the medical day-care center at St. Ann's Home for the Aged in Jersey City.

title: QUARTET: MENDELSSOHN
description: The burgeoning of interest in chamber music over the last decade has encouraged the formation of many new string quartets of quality, and among the very best is the Mendelssohn Quartet, which gave a concert at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night.

title: Allison S. Troum to Marry Steven R. Davis in October
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan F. Troum of Oakhurst, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Susan Troum of Van Nuys, Calif., to Steven Russell Davis, also of Van Nuys, son of Ann Davis of West Los Angeles and the late Louis A. Davis. The wedding is planned for Oct. 30.

title: Gas-Switching Suit Settled
description: A company operating more than 100 gasoline stations in California has agreed to pay $167,500 in penalties and fees to end a suit accusing it of selling fuel with less than the posted octane.

title: DEBRA KLAUBER ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Klauber of Harrison, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Debra Ann Klauber, to Stacy J. Gill, son of Mrs. Janet Bent of Redwood City, Calif., and Marvin Gill of Tampa, Fla. An April wedding is planned. Miss Klauber is a teacher at the Technology Childrens Center in Cambridge, Mass. Mr. Gill is a systems analyst in Boston.

title: FICTION This Week 1 Last Week 1 Weeks On List 16 SPACE, by james A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction.
description: This Week 2 Last Week 2 Weeks On List 10 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' This Week 6 Last Week 3 Weeks On List 10 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's.

title: WHO CONTROLS THE SELECTION OF TENANTS?
description: THE practice of subletting apartments in the tight Manhattan rental m arket is growing fast, apartment owners and managers report, as c ourt decisions push the pendulum of power in landlord-tenant relations toward tenants.

title: DAY CARE FOR ADULTS IS GAINING MOMENTUM
description: The following article is based on reporting by Sandra Friedland and Gertrude Dubrovsky and was written by Mrs. Friedland. PLAINFIELD ''IFEEL like I've been born again,'' Edward Ginotti said after his first day at Muhlenberg Hospital's Adult Medical Day-Care Center here. ''I was getting so sick of looking at my four walls.''

title: BIRD AND ARTIST
description: THE STONOR EAGLES By William Horwood. 555 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $15.95.

title: BALLET: SCORE BY ROBERT SCHUMANN
description: The title is not the only strange thing about ''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze,' '' which the New York City Ballet presented for the first time this season on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WHY THOUSANDS WILL MARCH TO END ABORTION
description: COME next Saturday, thousands of New Jersey residents will get out of bed in the dark, board a bus before dawn and ride to Washington. There, they will probably stand around in the cold for an hour or two, listening to speakers.

title:
GARDENING;
NUT TREES CAN YIELD FOOD AND SHADE
description: AS a youngster, my favorite cake was a simple, white cake with a light powdered-sugar icing. What made it special was that my mother always added hickory nuts to the ingredients.

title: CAROLINA JOINS IN BID TO CURB PLUTONIUM PLANT
description: Hidden behind thousands of acres of slash pines, the Savannah River Plant has produced tritium and plutonium, the primary ingredients of nuclear bombs, for 30 years, without drawing much public attention.

title: JAZZ BAND: FRANK FOSTER
description: One of the circumstances that has led to the disappearance of the big band as a staple jazz form is pointed up by the ensemble that Frank Foster calls ''Living Color: 10 Shades of Black,'' which is at the Village Vanguard through today.

title: EVACUATION PLAN FOR SHOREHAM: LILCO'S OR COUNTY'S?
description: TOMORROW, the Suffolk County Legislature will begin eight days of hearings on a proposed emergency preparedness plan for the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear power plant at Shoreham. Testimony by county officials will be heard tomorrow, with Lilco personnel and independent experts to follow.

title: Polygraph Tests and Employment
description: The recent article on the use of polygraph tests in employment (''Use of Polygraph Growing on L.I.'') rightly points out that no licensing or even training is required to become a polygraph examiner in New York.

title: BALLET: 'PINEAPPLE,' AND NEW CAST
description: ''Pineapple Poll'' bounced into City Center on Wednesday with a new cast of Joffrey Ballet dancers, all of whom played up the ballet's giddy excesses with infectious enjoyment. Philip Jerry, as Captain Belaye, the handsome naval officer whom all the girls love, was all swaggering walk and stolid torso, head tilted toward the gods and mouth drawn into a handsome smirk.

title: ECHOES OF THE AEGEAN AT TARPON SPRINGS
description: MARK WEINTZ is a writer who lives in Winter Park, Fla.

title: 4 TIE FOR LEAD IN GOLF ON COAST
description: The third round of the Glen Campbell Los Angeles Open ended today with the leaderboard as crowded as the Santa Monica Freeway at rush hour. Four players were tied for first, including the venerable Gene Littler. And one stroke behind, four were tied for second, including the more venerable Arnold Palmer.

title: No Headline
description: Whalers Top Devils, 2-1

title: AMERICA'S MOST-PUNISHED UNIVERSITY
description: WICHITA, Kan. RUSSELL WENTWORTH is the Dean of University College and Continuing Education at Wichita State. He also is serving as the interim athetic director. Wentworth represented the university at last week's National Collegiate Athletic Association convention in San Diego. By his own admission, he has a limited knowledge of athletics. But Wentworth knows enough about the history of his school's athletic program to say he felt uncomfortable at the convention.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: While Ralph Manheim's new translation of Celine's ''Journey to the End of the Night'' (New Directions) is not an improvement on John H.P. Marks's fine 1934 version, it is good to see Celine being brought back to the public's attention. For all his paranoia and the questions raised by the anti-Semitic pamphlets he wrote at the time of World War II, Celine remains one of the great European novelists of the century, the only logical successor, one might say, to Dostoyevsky.

title: MT. HOLLY SPAWNS AN ARTS CENTER
description: MOUNT HOLLY LAST year, Thomas J. Ryan opened a theater to raise the arts consciousness of a community and to give himself a new lease on life. The 36-year-old Mr. Ryan, who moved from Mount Tabor, in Morris County, to Marlton three years ago, left his position as a territorial manager for an electronics concern, sold his shares in the business and, in October 1981, bought the 750-seat Mount Holly movie theater, which had been boarded up for years and was an eyesore in the middle of town.

title: MISS HOLLENBACH ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Kathryn Ann Hollenbach to Lieut. Charles B. Davis, Medical Corps, U.S.N.R., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Hollenbach of Chester, N.J. Lieutenant DAvis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles B. Davis of Belmont, Mass., is a pediatric intern at the Naval Regional Medical Center in San Diego. His financee is a graduate student in psychology at San Diego State University.

title: FROM THE DESK
description: By Marjorie Wolfe

title: EXECUTED BY THE STATE OF NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: China Talks Fail
description: The United States seeks stronger ties with China but business is business, as Peking discovered last week. A fourth round of talks on limiting Chinese textiles in the American market ended in disagreement and Washington imposed import curbs on its own.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHEN you look at a map of the United States, it seems as though the country has just landed a big fish off the East Coast. The fish, of course, is Long Island. It is not close enough to the continent to avoid traffic problems, and it is not far enough to become exotic. It is not Catalina and it is not Manhattan; it is something else that, for want of a better name, they decided to call Long Island.

title: Daun Paris Plans Feb. 27 Wedding
description: Carole Paris of Ridgewood, N.J., and Irin Paris of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daun Leslee Paris, to Peter Robert Hauspurg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hauspurg of Rye, N.Y.

title: SHEPPERD STRUDWICK, 75, ACTOR WHO PORTRAYED OVER 200 ROLES
description: Shepperd Strudwick, a character actor who appeared in more than 200 roles in movies and plays and on television, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: SCHOOL'S USE STIRS DISPUTE IN YONKERS
description: YONKERS CITY officials and members of the black community are embroiled in a bitter dispute over a proposal to convert a former elementary school into condominiums rather than low-income housing. The controversy comes at a time when the city is preparing to defend itself in a housing-discrimination suit filed two years ago by the United States Department of Justice.

title: Misguided Advice
description: To the Business Editor: The dedication to economic principles may yet destroy the global economy. Rudolph G. Penner's ''Peculiar Politics and Dangerous Deficits'' (Jan.2), and John Starrels's ''The Remedies Can Be Found at Home,'' in the same issue, are misguided critiques of the Federal deficits and weak investment in the steel industry.

title:
DINING OUT;
WINE LIST WITH A PATRIOTIC TOUCH
description: month-old restaurant whose forest-green and white bar, two-storied balconied dining room, zigzag mirrors and banquettes covered with flowered fabric lend a Floridian prettiness to the setting.

title: Chargers Are Confident Powerful Offense Can Go All the Way
description: SAN DIEGO CHARLIE JOINER, the wide receiver, foresees a game in which the San Diego Chargers score every time they have the ball. Kellen Winslow, the tight end, foresees a season in which the Chargers have three receivers each with 1,000 yards in catches, two running backs each with 1,000 yards rushing and the quarterback Dan Fouts with 5,000 yards of passing. Wes Chandler, the other wide receiver, says simply: ''This offense is capable of doing anything it wants to do.''

title: Dr. Schless Weds Dr. P.V. Marino
description: Dr. Anne-Ghislaine Schless, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hugh Schless of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Paul Vincent Marino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Marino of Arlington, Mass. The Rev. Guthrie Spears performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: East Edges West, 26-25, On Passing of Eason
description: Tony Eason combined with his Illinois teammate, Oliver Williams, on three pass completions late in the game to give the underdog East a 26-25 victory over the West today in the 58th Shrine All-Star Classic.

title: CRIME
description: Lieut. Leroy Powder of the Indianapolis Police Department (Missing Persons Bureau) makes a reappearance in Michael Z. Lewin's HARD LINE (Morrow, $11.95). As tough and crusty as ever, as honest and dedicated, as unlikable and compulsively one-sided, Powder still demonstrates an unexpected touch of humor and, underneath it all, a heart of gold. In short, he is a stereotype. But the skillful Mr. Lewin manages to imbue him with a certain reality.

title: STATE GIVES ROAD REPAIR TOP PRIORITY
description: TRENTON REPRIEVED by the passage of new Federal and state taxes, the New Jersey Department of Transportation has lifted its road-building moratorium and entered a period of unaccustomed fiscal soundness during which highway rehabilitation and the completion of missing road links share top priority.

title: CONCERT: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG
description: If power and technical brilliance were all that a first-rate pianist needed, then Alexis Weissenberg would be numbered among the greats. Mr. Weissenberg can play as rapidly and as loudly as anyone before the public today, but too often his pianism seems harsh and insensitive - technically flawless, but lacking a certain spiritual warmth.

title: Age-Group Record
description: Shola Lynch, an eighth-grade student at Hunter High School in Manhattan, who has been running for only two years, set a national age-group record for 13-year-olds yesterday when she turned in a time of 4 minutes 38.1 seconds in the 1,500-meter run. The recordbreaking performance came at the Pratt Institute Activity Center in Brooklyn during the second series of preliminary races of the Colgate Women's Games, which has drawn 20,000 local competitors. Miss Lynch, who runs for the Millrose Athletic Association, also won the 800-meter run in the mid-school division in 2:16.9.

title: Suzanne Carter to Wed Dr. Harvey M. Kramer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Carter of Roslyn, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Lisa Carter, to Dr. Harvey Merrill Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Kramer of Margate City, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Costa Rica Drops Charge
description: Costa Rica has dropped criminal charges against an American journalist accused of illegally practicing his profession here for lack of membership in the Costa Rican College of Journalists.

title: THE MAKING OF AN AMBASSADOR
description: On behalf of the American Chamber of Commerce of Mexico, which has worked closely with John Gavin since his arrival in Mexico, I would like to correct Malcolm Toon's unjust reference to Ambassador Gavin. In our experience, Ambassador Gavin has made the very strongest case for the politically appointed ambassador.

title: A 3,000 DOW-NOT JUST A PIPE DREAM
description: FOUR times in the past two weeks, the Dow Jones industrial average has hit record levels, but those a chievements pale next to the outer limits that a number of prominenti nvestment professionals forecast for the index of 30 of America's l argest corporations.

title: THE JUNIOR LEAGUE TAKES OFF WHITE GLOVES
description: Beverly Brooks is the deputy superintendent of a dingy women's prison on 11th Avenue that houses felons who have committed crimes from arson to murder. Many of them are 90 days away from release. When Mrs. Brooks heard the New York Junior League wanted to start a program at the Bayview Correctional Facility, she said she thought: ''What would they do here? And why would they come?''

title: NAVAJO NEW ORDER
description: At his inauguration as tribal chairman of the Navajo Indian nation last week, Peterson Zah called for treating the tribe's mineral wealth ''with all due respect for our Mother Earth.''

title: Sunday Morning Laughter
description: My family and I enjoyed Fred Ferretti's article ''New Breed of Stand-Up Comics'' (Dec. 5).

title: HOW DANCE AND OTHER ARTS INFLUENCE EACH OTHER
description: As a young dancer who had just left the Denishawn Company in the early 1920's to strike out on her own, Martha Graham was once returning to her home in California after a trip to the East. Stopping over in Chicago, she went to view a private art collection and saw, for the first time, a painting by Vassily Kandinsky. In its most abstract form - she recalled in telling the story at the American Dance Festival in 1981 - it struck her as a brilliant streak of red against a field of blue. Looking at this canvas, she said to herself, ''I will dance like that.''

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS TO GAIN SUPPORT FROM MINORITIES
description: At the urging of advisers who fear that his re-election may be in jeopardy, President Reagan has begun a series of program changes and initiatives to shore up his low political standing among blacks, the unemployed and especially women.

title: FEW CHANGES MADE IN STATE DELEGATION
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE indications that some members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation were restless at the end of the 97th Congress, there has been barely any change in their committee assignments in the new Congress that will begin work on Jan. 25.

title: COMMUNISTS PRESS GREECE TO TOE RADICAL LINE
description: Greece's Communist Party is pressing Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's ruling Socialist Party to live up to its program of radical change and, in particular, to adopt a more neutralist foreign policy.

title:
NUREYEV HAS KEPT THE BOSTON BALLET ON ITS TOES;
BOSTON
description: ''Randolph Neveroff'' is what he asked them to print on his black satin Boston Ballet road jacket. And to the Bostonians, who dance with Rudolf Nureyev in ''Don Quixote,'' which opens at the Uris Theater on Tuesday, ''Neveroff'' has a depth of meanings.

title: Rampage of The Rootless
description: Recession has hit hard in Europe's crowded cities, pinched for jobs and housing. Last week in Copenhagen, young people drawn from evenworse-off rural areas exploded in frustration when police used smoke bombs, water cannon, dog patrols and mass arrests to clear squatters from seven buildings slated for demolition.

title:
DINING OUT;
STURDY FARE IN A POLISHED SETTING
description: WE remember Manzi's Restaurant from its days on Riverdale Avenue in Yonkers. Tony Manzi cooked hearty dishes, Italian-Italian and not Italian-American (sometimes distinguished by the over-or exclusive use of canned tomato paste, making dishes here taste nothing like dishes there). He would ask diners what they would like him to make. The dishes decided upon, he would return to the kitchen to turn out some vibrant sauces and succulent meats and vegetables.

title: E.P.A. IS ORDERED TO PUBLISH ARSENIC POLLUTION STARDARDS
description: A Federal judge has ordered the United States Environmental Protection Agency to publish air-pollution standards for arsenic within 180 days.

title: 3 SECT MEBERS SLAIN IN SIEGE WERE SHOT IN HEAD
description: Gunshot wounds to the head killed at least three of the seven members of a religious sect who died Thursday in a police assault on a house where an officer had been held hostage and beaten to death, according to a medical examiner's report.

title: WHITHER ARTS-IN-EDUCATION PROGRAMS?
description: IN-EDUCATION programs designed to make an appreciation of the arts an integral part of the education of youngsters are still alive on Long Island, but just barely so in some areas.

title: Bolivian Aide Seeks Extradition of Ex-Nazi
description: Bolivia's public prosecutor has asked the Supreme Court to agree to extradite Klaus Barbie, a former SS commander in Lyons, France, to West Germany, legal officials said today.

title: Joyce Goldklang Weds in Teaneck
description: Joyce Ellen Goldklang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goldklang of Teaneck, N.J., and Becket, Mass., was married yesterday to Jay Harrison Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Diamond of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Israel Miller, senior vice president of Yeshiva University; Rabbi Bernard Walfish, the bride's uncle and executive director of the Rabbinical Council of America, and Rabbi David Feldman of the Jewish Center of Teaneck performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of Teaneck.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ One of the consequences of easy, instant electronic communication has been the loss of distinctive regional differences, particularly in speech and in music. This is notably true of jazz which has become so homogenized that, although one may perceive the personal or stylistic sources in a jazz musician's performance, regional influences are fading into the past.

title: CAMILLE BRANNON TO WED PHILIP C. LIVSEY IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Brannon Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Camille Brannon, to Philip Cameron Livsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Livsey of Greens Farms, Conn. The wedding is planned for August.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
A SUNNIER OUTLOOK FOR SELLING YOUR HOME
description: "The turnaround," said Peter Degnan, president of the West Orange real-estate company that bears his name, "has been amazing." His observation on the sharp increase in sales activity in the home resale market is being echoed by other brokers and mortgage lenders througout the state.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MIRROR: LUXURY TURNED NECESSITY
description: EVER since Narcissus, the beautiful Greek youth, fell spellbound beside a still pond, civilized men and women have considered the mirror a necessity as well as a luxury.

title: HOSPITABLE TO A FAULT
description: San Juan Bautista, a hamlet 95 miles south of San Francisco, may be the only community in America that tries to make a virtue out of a fault.

title: CAN 'THE SKIN OF OUR TEETH' SPEAK TO TODAY'S AUDIENCE
description: Stephen Farber is a Los Angeles-based writer who frequently reports on television. SAN DIEGO ''Television is usually so polite when it watches plays,'' Jack O'Brien was saying. ''That isn't true with sports, where you see linebackers roll over technicians with cameras, and you understand the excitment of the camera being there. Television is a participant in sports, as it is in news. But somehow when they go into the theater, they keep their white gloves on and stay back behind the balcony rail.''

title: 'NUTS' DRAWS CHEERS IN SECOND LIFE
description: LINDENHURST TO the ever growing list of meritorious plays that didn't ''make it'' in the mainstream theater but can have a healthy afterlife in the hinterlands, add Tom Topor's ''Nuts'' - a play for the people, if not the critics.

title: CANDACE A. SPIELBERGER MARRIES C.T. HAYDOCK
description: Candace Ann Spielberger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George L. Spielberger of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Charles Thorndike Haydock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Haydock of Chestnut Hill and Ipswich, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Allison Stokes, chaplain of Vassar College, performed the Episcopalian ceremony at the Vassar College Chapel.

title: WHAT DO THE TERMS MEAN?
description: LIKE other business offerings, prospectuses for cooperative conversions must be approved by the State Attorney General. But according to sections of recent laws, there are additional provisions applying solely to co-op conversions in New York City and suburban counties.

title: EIFFEL TOWER RESTAURANT IN CITY, IN 11,000 PARTS
description: The restaurant of the Eiffel Tower has arrived in New York City in more than 11,000 pieces. Once the restaurant, which seats about 120, was one of France's finer dining rooms and a favorite spot for royalty and tourists visiting Paris's famous landmark. Now the restaurant, like London Bridge, is a structure with a quintessentially European past that has made the voyage to the New World.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Mets announced that John Tamargo, a catcher who played in the major leagues for five years with three teams, has been named manager of their Columbia, S.C., farm club in the Class A South Atlantic League. ... Bernard Hinault, who has won the Tour de France bicycle race four times, will not compete in the Tour of America race in April because it coincides with a major race in France. ... The Detroit Red Wings have obtained the center Ivan Boldirev, who is 33 and in his 13th year, from the Vancouver Canucks in exchange for another center, Mark Kirton, 24. Boldirev had five goals and 20 assists in 39 games with Vancouver this season. In his National Hockey League career, he has 294 goals and 410 assists.

title: THE 'NEW' BOB DOLE
description: While the new Bob Dole is certainly better than the old Bob Dole, the fact remains that the Senator is chairman of the powerful Finance Committee. Senator Dole is not doing enough to rectify the policies being shaped by Reaganomics and the ultra-conservatives of the Republican Party. PAUL FEINER

title: Days of Doubt on Minute of Silence
description: In a preliminary test of its constitutionality last week, a law requiring a daily minute of silence in New Jersey schools didn't stand a prayer. Federal Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise said the statute was ''unconstitutional on its face'' and enjoined educators from enforcing it pending a hearing this week.

title: Sports of The Times; Bring On the Cowboys
description: ONLY the Redskins have a chance now. They will be sitting in front of their television sets today - the Hogs of the offensive line and the Fun Bunch Five of the receiving corps and all the other teamswithin-a-team - and they will be rooting for Dallas to beat Green Bay.

title: BALLET: 'DIARY' A SHOWCASE FOR 2 DANCERS
description: Lynne Taylor-Corbett's ''Diary'' has been performed in recent years by a number of small dance companies. With repetition, it comes to seem more sketchbook than diary - the not very bold work of a possibly fledgling choreographer, set to a song score by Judith Lander that sounds like a poor man's Jacques Brel.

title:
STAMPS;
NATIONWIDE TESTS TO ACCOUNT FOR OFFICIAL MAIL
description: The United States Postal Service has decided to move forward with its plan to change the whole process of Official Mail that is now in effect in the departments and agencies of the Federal Government.

title: WINTER'S WATERS YIELD SILVERY COD
description: LOOK for cod in winter. Although no longer as abundant in the waters of the Continental Shelf off New England and Canada as in centuries past, fresh cod remains a cold-weather staple in the Northeast. (Salted, the fish feeds populations on both sides of the Atlantic, as far south as Africa and Brazil.)

title: Debra Silverman And J.S. Marcus Become Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Silverman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Sue Silverman, to Jeffrey Samuel Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Marcus of Beachwood, Ohio.

title: Can Those Who Need Care Provide It?
description: A Dec. 19 Opinion Page article mentioned ''frail, forgetful'' men and women who ''sit and stare,'' and equated them with those who ''could handle light chores, read to children, help with their school work and provide oral histories not available elsewhere'' if there were foster homes available for them.

title:
ART;
SPOTLIGHT ON A PERMANENT COLLECTION
description: OVER the last decade large, temporary exhibitions have absorbed more of the attention of museums and their audiences, sometimes with the result that extraordinary works of art are practically ignored.

title: Celtics Obtain Wedman
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, at the bottom of the National Basketball Association's Central Division, are seeing little light from above, what with all of their first-round draft choices through 1986 having been traded. But late Friday, the Cavaliers put a glimmer into their future by trading Scott Wedman, one of their top players, to the Boston Celtics for Boston's No.1 selection in the 1983 draft, an undisclosed amount of cash and Darren Tillis, a seldom-used 6-11 rookie forward.

title: FAIR 'FAMILY' FINDS NEW HOMES
description: After the Danbury Fairgrounds was sold and the last fair held in the fall of last fair held in the fall of 1981, all of the fair's fantastic paraphernalia was put up for auction the following April.

title: A FRESH ASSAY OF THE COMIC GOLD OF PRESTON STURGIS
description: Prepare for a splendid treat: between 1940 and 1948 Preston Sturgis wrote and directed 11 films, 10 of which will be shown in the twoweek retrospective starting today at the Regency Theater. Three of these 10 films - ''Sullivan's Travels,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''The Palm Beach Story'' - are among the wittiest, most pungent, most sophisticated, most falling-down-funny comedies ever made in America. Six of the seven others are somewhat more modest in their achievements. They are merely very good to almost great, with moments of greatness in each.

title: BLACK BUILDERS TO BE RECRUITED FOR $10 MILLION AFRICAN PROJECT
description: The Harlem Urban Development Corporation has been asked by a communications company to recruit black contractors for a $10 million overseas construction project.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Rockabilly, Elvis Presley's music, sounded wild and dangerous to those who first heard it. But a quarter-century later, most rockabilly revivals seem quaint; its rebel spirit has moved on.

title: ROSTOW, NOT EXACTLY ON THE INSIDE TRACK, GETS DERAILED
description: President Reagan's dismissal last week of Eugene V. Rostow as Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency looked like high drama: Moscow continuing its ''peace offensive'' for the hearts and minds of Europeans, Mr. Rostow pressing to find common ground with Moscow and finally, the far right felling him and thus dashing hopes for negotiations.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: AFEDERAL hearing into safety at Indian Point's nuclear plants resumed last week with a verbal blast from the new County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke. ''That Con Edison, in good conscience, could reopen its plant - Indian Point 2 - on Jan. 2, and that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission could allow it is incredible in light of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's recent findings, which termed the evacuation portion of the utilities' emergency response plans 'deficient,' '' Mr. O'Rourke told the N.R.C. hearing.

title: SOVIET SAYS SATELLITE CORE WILL FALL NEXT MONTH, BUT DOUBTS DANGER
description: A senior Soviet scientist announced today that the nuclear fuel core of the Cosmos 1402 satellite would plunge into the earth's atmosphere in mid-February but said any fallout would be within safe limits.

title: SOVIET MAY PUSH ATOMIC ENERGY AT UNSAFE SPEEDS
description: In the West, it has been years since public officials or utility executives could laud the virtues of civil nuclear power without acknowledging concerns about safety and the environment. But the Soviet Union is perhaps the only major industrialized country that remains unhesitatingly committed to the expansion of its nuclear plants - as fast as money, technology and construction capacities allow.

title: THE POLICIES, AND THE PRODUCTS, OF LEE IACOCCA
description: ''IKNOW how these things get started,'' Lee Iacocca was saying. ''A couple of guys get together at the Detroit Press Club, and one of 'em says something and then the other one agrees, and pretty soon they're quoting each other in print.''

title: OFFICIALS IN CALIFORNIA SQUARE OFF IN DEBATE ON STATE'S BUDGET CRISIS
description: Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, and the Democrats who fill the rest of California's top offices are eyeball to eyeball over how to resolve the state's fiscal crisis.

title: GETTING FREEMAN MCNEIL INTO TOP SHAPE
description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON RICHIE BARATHY is not accustomed to being a spectator. He is a martial artist, a fitness expert, a television performer and a businessman. He likes doing, and does not care too much for watching. That is one of the reasons why he had a tough time sitting still during last week's New York Jets-Cincinnati Bengals football game and yesterday's Jets game in Los Angeles.

title: AN EYE FOR DISPLAY
description: There is a major difference in our experience of the antiques we find in museums and galleries and those we encounter in shops. In the former, we anticipate that through the organization of vintage objects someone else's greater insight will reveal special qualities of the antiques shown and the periods represented. In the latter, more often than not, a more casual arrangement of materials encourages us to browse, realizing in what may prove to be a haphazard pursuit, our own highly personal responses to objects that we see at close range and are encouraged to handle.

title: INDUSTRY EXPECTS RECORD SALES AT THE SHOW
description: ON the flybridge of the 46-foot sport fisherman, one takes the helm, gazes across the sea of faces and dreams of heading for the Hudson Canyon for marlin. Or, one climbs aboard a sloop and envisions casting off for Eaton's Neck, St. Thomas or Tahiti.

title: SOCIALIST ALLIANCE AT ISSUE IN CANADA
description: The ruling party of Quebec has applied for membership in the Socialist International, the worldwide organization of Socialists, Social Democrats and labor parties, and its bid was immediately challenged by a member from Canada.

title: SACHER TORTE, VIENNESE DELIGHT
description: The world may have paid more attention to the 250th anniversary of Haydn's birth than to the news that another Austrian gift to humankind, the sacher torte, was 150 years old in 1982. Yet many more visitors to Vienna polish off a wedge of the bittersweet chocolate cake, usually served with whipped cream, than will sit still in a concert hall to listen to 'The Creation' or 'The Seasons.'

title: Breaking Silence
description: George Hendrick, the St. Louis Cardinal outfielder, is well known for the silent attitude he has taken toward the press in recent years. Thus, reporters in St. Louis viewing a highlight film of the 1982 World Series were surprised to hear Hendrick's voice on the 30-minute film. In the third game, after he beat out an infield hit that precipitated an argument from the Milwaukee Brewers, Hendrick was heard to explain, ''It was my blazing speed.''

title: WEATHER A SETBACK TO HEATER FIRM
description: A WINTER ''that could be considered an anomaly by any standard,'' is the primary reason for the layoff by the Kero-Sun Corporation last week of 164 employees, more than half its work force, according to a spokesman for the Kent company that imports and markets kerosene heaters.

title: The Making of an Ambassador
description: Malcolm Toon's article ''In Defense of the Foreign Service'' (Dec. 12) suggests that a person whose only experience since college has been in Government bureaucracy is more capable of high-level statesmanship than someone of proved ability and significant achievement in the private sector.

title: Pro Publico
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: ALVIN LUCIER
description: The temptation was to find profound lessons in Alvin Lucier's sonic experiments on display at Marymount Manhattan College on Wednesday night, something about how art needs no shape, or how music is where you find it, or how one can learn how to ''be'' in the world without having to interpret it. For those who enjoy seeking out such lessons, the sound of a quarter hour of recorded static and squeals from the natural radio-frequency emissions in the ionosphere may have been engaging and provocative.

title: PUBLISH - ON 'SOCIAL COMMAND' - OR PERISH
description: The writer Georgi N. Vladimov last week finally raised the white flag, as he put it, and asked to leave the Soviet Union. He and his wife had been searched and questioned by the K.G.B., his typewriter, drafts and letters were confiscated, and he was ordered to repudiate his ''anti-Soviet'' activities in a letter by Jan. 20 or face unspecified consequences. Instead Mr. Vladimov wrote to Yuri V. Andropov. He would not recant; he was prepared for prison but not to have his wife arrested. ''I propose another solution,'' Mr. Vladimov told the new Communist Party leader, ''less damaging to our Government's prestige. I am ready to quit Russia. To be forced into this is painful and humiliating for us.''

title: RATING ON REAGAN LAGS AT MIDTERM
description: President Reagan's job-performance level at the midpoint of his term, as measured by the Gallup Poll, is substantially lower than those of his four elected predecessors at their halfway marks.

title: NEW YORK VS. PARIS: VIEWS OF AN ART REPORTER
description: Less than a year ago, I was speaking with an American painter about the subject among Americans in Paris: America and Europe. He lived in New York, was abroad for a year, and the magic of where he was had just begun to reveal itself. I was brought up in New York of European parents and had lived in Paris nine years. I said to him I didn't think I would ever go back. For one thing, in Paris I was only five hours by train from Vermeer's "View of Delft" in the Hague, or Grunewald's "Isenheim Altarpiece" "View of Delft" in the Hague or Grunewald's "Isenheim Altarpiece" in Colmar; with an overnight train I could step into the cold dawn light of Piero's "Resurrection" in sansepolcro, Italy, the next morning. Then, suddenly, I left. For seven months now, as art news reporter for this newspaper, I have been living with something dynamic, complex and very different. What follows is an attempt to present some thoughts and impressions either about or inspired by that multi-headed, many-sided thing known as the New York art world. Just before I left Paris, when I was wondering if something I was about to write was wrong, an American critic familiar with the subject told me: "Say it. You'll find out." This article can only be written with that very American advice in mind.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
COMPETITION WILL CUT SHIPPING COSTS
description: IN recent years, Congress has been working to remove the yoke of a c entury of regulation from the railroads. A major step was taken in 1 980 with the passage of the Staggers Rail Act, which gave the r ailroads new freedom in setting rates, streamlining operations and e ntering into long-term contracts.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Dual Role Vicki Lawrence is back. For 10 years she worked on ''The Carol Burnett Show,'' often playing Miss Burnett's sister but also playing the cantankerous, sarcastic mother in other sketches. Now, after a four-year hiatus, she has returned to television with her own show: ''Mama's Family,'' a situation comedy for NBC in which she re-creates her role as mother. The series, to be broadcast Saturday night from 9 to 9:30, was completed last September and taped in front of a live audience.

title: Prayer Event to Hear Reagan
description: President Reagan and Gen. John Vessey, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will be the featured speakers at the 31st annual National Prayer Breakfast Feb. 3, its sponsors announced Tuesday. About 3,500 people are expected to attend the event at the Washington Hilton Hotel.

title: Nancy Rogers and Richard Ohaus to Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Charles R. Rogers of Rumford, R.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Ellen Rogers of New Canaan, Conn., to Richard William Ohaus of Chatham, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Ohaus of New Vernon, N.J.

title: Nuclear Power: Another View
description: Even before I read the recent capsule profile of Nora Bredes in ''About Long Island,'' I was aware from hearing her at public meetings that she is highly dedicated to her antinuclear stance. After reading it, I was even more convinced that she hadn't done much homework before adopting it. She is quoted as saying that she had such a great affection for the North Shore and the Sound that she was ''outraged at the idea that they would put it all at risk with a nuclear power plant.''

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Blackfish Tautoga onitis Size: Averages one to six pounds. Color: Variable; greenish brown, bluish black, mottled, lighter on sides.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY AND SCHREKER
description: Franz Schreker's Chamber Symphony was the major item in a diverting program presented at Goodman House on Wednesday night by Music Today, and the work turned out to be a somewhat exotic essay, rather fascinating in its way.

title: JAZZ DUO: BYARD, KLOSS
description: The duo of Eric Kloss, a saxophonist, and Jaki Byard, a pianist, appearing at the Village West, Hudson Street at Bank Street through today, is a pairing of two jazz musicians who draw on an unusually broad range of sources.

title: FLICKERING FLUORESCENTS? REPAIRS USUALLY ARE NOT DIFFICULT
description: FLUORESCENT lighting has become increasingly popular in homes in recent years, not only because this type of lighting saves energy, but also because the tubes last a lot longer than incandescent bulbs do. In addition, fluorescent tubes are available in pleasant ''warmwhite'' tones that do not have the objectionable bluish-green cast that older-style fluorescents did, so many find them much more acceptable for home use.

title: THE ARMY'S NEW FIGHTING DOCTRINE
description: Although it was not discussed in Deborah Shapley's article, what is readily apparent to those who read current Army literature is the increasing reliance on tactical nuclear weapons to conduct portions of the deep attack. FM 100-5, the key doctrinal document in support of the new doctrine, emphasizes the ''integrated battlefield'' -the integrated use of conventional and nuclear fires.

title: A MUSEUM DISPLAYS THE CHARMS OF FOLK ART
description: NEWARK Before he became a museum figure, Captain Jinks of the Horse Marines, a snappy, soldierly presence of painted wood, resplendent in an ear-to-ear mustache and a uniform of red and yellow, stood for 50 years -from the late 19th to the early 20th centuries - in front of Feary's cigar store on the corner of Broad and Market Streets in Newark. He was rescued from guard duty and given to the Newark Museum in 1924, seven years after the museum began acquiring the quirky provincial objects, produced largely by anonymous 18th and 19thcentury craftsmen, that today come under the homely rubric of ''folk art.'' And now Captain Jinks, attributed to Thomas J. White (1825-1902), is part of a splendid and still-growing collection that the museum has every reason to celebrate.

title: Santo Domingo
description: To the Editor:

title: FINAL REPORT OF THE BIPARTISAN TAX COMMITTEE
description: The current session of the General Assembly, which convened Jan. 5, is expected to be dominated by debate over the state's fiscal problems and new or higher state taxes.
