title: THE STARCH OF LIFE
description: The origin of a food name is always intriguing, particularly when that food happens to be a favorite dish. And, where starches are concerned, there is nothing more palatable than rice. Over the years, we have wondered about the term Carolina rice that is so often found on labels, and only recently have we discovered its source. It seems that in the latter part of the 17th century, the year 1694 to be precise, a captain of an ailing sailing vessel put into what is now Charleston, S.C. He was en route from Madagascar to Europe, and he paid for his stay and repairs with several pounds of rice that was in the ship's hold. Thus, rice was introduced to America. The colonists planted the cereal, it flourished, and the strain was thenceforth known as Carolina.

title: 'Women's Bodies'
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST AND WEST MEET AMID MYSTERY IN PETER WEIR'S NEW FILM
description: Delicate but somehow menacing, intricate shadow figures dance before a screen in the half-dark of a hot Indonesian night: Prince Arjuna, the hero who can also be ''fickle and selfish''; Princess Srikandi, ''noble and proud, yet headstrong''; Semar, the grotesque dwarf who serves the prince. As the carved silhouettes tell their mystical story, the audience murmurs in the background, a Jakarta slum where noise itself is a constant murmur, fragmented and mysterious: bamboo creaks ominously, the night wind carries a snatch of laughter, the sound of weeping, a cry of alarm, the echo of a sigh.

title: WALT MICHAELS GETS A PHONE CALL
description: LOS ANGELES A t halftime, Walt Michaels was striding through the hallway to the Jets' locker room yesterday when a security guard had a message for him.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART What passes for realism in this country can be a dreary and pedestrian activity, unleavened by wit and weighted down by the look of a hard slog that has gone largely unrewarded.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; John Paul Speaks Out Against Death Penalty

title: LANDMARK STATUS FOR A SEWER VENT?
description: Anyone who believes that the shape of a building should suggest what is going on inside should visit Mamaroneck, N.Y., and take a look at the 125-foot Art Deco tower that dominates the harbor. Local sailors used to use its light, now not operating, for navigation, and a local artist, Grace Huntzey Pugh, has done hundreds of paintings that include it, among them a mural in St. Thomas Episcopal Church in the community.

title: APPEAL RULING CITES ALTERNATIVES TO CBS BAN
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, saying there were less drastic alternatives that would protect the right to a fair trial for seven New Orleans police officers facing civil rights charges, yesterday overturned a ban on a segment of ''60 Minutes.'' Here are excerpts from the decision:

title: U.S. AIDE REACHED ARMS AGREEMENT LATER RULED OUT
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials say the United States and Soviet negotiators worked out an informal agreement on limiting each side's medium-range missiles in Europe last July, but the accord was rejected by both Washington and Moscow.

title: HIGHGATE
description: To the Editor:

title: FARAWAY ATOMS
description: NUCLEAR POWER IN THE DEVELOPING WORLD By Daniel Poneman.254 pp. Winchester, Mass.: Allen & Unwin. $27.50.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ELEPHANT SCHOOL Written and photographed by John Stewart. 55 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.95. (Ages 7 to 10) THE PIANO MAKERS Written and photographed by David Anderson. 55 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: BUDGET WAVER
description: IT is the two-year mark of Ronald Reagan's Administration, time for the traditional Oz-like discovery by America at large that its latest President, beyond the staged thunder of incumbency, is a common man, more finite than voters were led to believe by his campaign rhetoric.

title: CREATING A TENANT
description: Clinton W. Blume, Jr., a vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, knew that the Chrysler Building needed a new club tenant for the three floors the Cloud Club had vacated in May 1979. And his wife, an officer of the Dubai Bank, had told him that the international banking community in New York City needed a social meeting place.

title: PIANO-DANCE COLLABORATION AT MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR IN THE world of contemporary American ballet, Peter Martins is recognized as an accomplished dancer and choreographer. His skill as a choreographer will be on view in Montclair Friday and Saturday, when the Hartford Ballet performs the world premiere of his newest work, ''Waltzes,'' set to 24 Schubert waltzes.

title: ... and After
description: Besides operating safety, the other great hang-up for nuclear power has been disposal of radioactive wastes. Utilities are storing about 8,000 metric tons of it at plants nationwide, and expect to generate another 24,000 tons by 1990.

title: AN EYE ON THE LAW AND MENTAL ILLNESS
description: ''I CAME in,'' said Hermine Plotnick of Great Neck, ''like the patients - as an involuntary commitment.'' Since April 1981, Mrs. Plotnick has been chief of forensic services at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens, where she has worked for the New York State Office of Mental Health for the last 20 of her 54 years. She is a principal figure in a recently published book, ''Is There No Place on Earth for Me?,'' a biography by Susan Sheehan of a Creedmoor patient.

title: WHEN INDOOR PLANTS HAVE THE BLAHS CURE THEM WITH SIMPLEST SOLUTIONS
description: Clare Sperapani is a professional horticulturist.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BANJO By Robert Newton Peck. Illustrated by Andrew Glass. 80 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 11)

title: HOCKEY STAR AIMS FOR THE SUMMAR GAME
description: Kir k McCaskill ended his college hockey career Tuesday night when his team, the University of vermont, lost, 7-2, on home ice to Harvard.

title: DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST CASES RISE TO MEET NEW HARDSHIPS
description: An awareness that more people may be suffering from economic hardship this year is reflected in many gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Some past contributors have decided to increase their donations to help meet what they consider the greater need.

title: TWO EAST RIVER BRIDGES IN LINE FOR FEDERAL FUNDS
description: Major structural repairs to the Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges and large-scale reconstruction of the West Side Highway and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive are among projects that officials say will be accelerated by an infusion of Federal funds approved by Congress last month.

title: LEGISLATURE WILL INVESTIGATE INMATE UPRISING AT OSSINING
description: Two committees of the New York State Legislature will conduct a joint investigation into the causes of the 53-hour inmate takeover at the state prison in Ossining, the chairmen of the panels said yesterday.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: SOLARZ WANTS SALVADOR'S ARMS AID TIED TO TALKS
description: A visiting United States Congressman has proposed tying future American military aid to El Salvador to the Government's willingness to open unconditional talks with the leftist guerrillas.

title: World Yacht Race Starts Third Leg
description: Philippe Jeantot of France, the overall race leader aboard Credit Agricole, headed the fleet out through Sydney Harbor today to begin the third leg, to Rio de Janeiro, of the single-handed round-the-world yacht race.

title: Fingerprints Plan For Pupils in Jersey
description: Nearly 44,000 elementary school students in Union County are to be fingerprinted during the next year to help locate them should they ever disappear.

title: Threat to Dolly Parton
description: The police searched today for an anonymous caller whose warning of a possible threat on the life of Dolly Parton forced her to cancel two shows at the Executive Inn Rivermont last night. Both shows were sold out at $52 a ticket.

title: News Analysis
description: A Federal judge's failure to block a television broadcast about an upcoming trial reinforces the concept that, except in very rare instances, only journalists have a right to decide what a news story says and when it should be run, legal experts said yesterday.

title: BERKELEY TOPS SCHOLARS' RANKINGS OF GRADUATE SCHOOLS' REPUTATIONS
description: The relative academic prestige of the country's top research universities has changed little over the last decade, according to a $500,000 study sponsored by four national academic organizations.

title: EX-IRANIAN HOSTAGES GATHER TO ASSESS THEIR EXPERIENCES
description: Marking the second anniversary of their release from Iran, four former hostages met yesterday in Brooklyn to share both a continuing fascination with the country that held them captive and what one called ''a new sense of humility'' about the role of diplomats and the power of great nations.

title: 'SKINS FIRST, SOCIAL SECURITY SECOND
description: At Blair House Saturday afternoon, negotiators were hammering out the package of proposed changes in the Social Security system. Across the street in the White House press room, Larry Speakes, the Presidential spokesman, said there would be no news before 4 P.M. When asked why, he deadpanned, ''No reason.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. The availability of Bernard King (sprained ankle), Ed Sherod (groin injury) and Sly Williams (sore knee) for the Knicks is uncertain.

title: THE MACCHIAROLA YEARS: EDUCATIONAL PROGRESS MARKED BY POLITICAL CONFLICTS
description: When a vacancy opened at one of the 110 New York City high schools under his jurisdiction, Frank J. Macchiarola made an unusual appointment: He took the job himself. What better way to understand the workings of a school, he explained, when he became acting principal of Jamaica High School in Queens.

title: Arby's Chooses Grey For $6 Million Account
description: Arby's, the Royal Crown Company subsidiary that is this nation's 10th-largest fast-food chain, selected Grey Advertising on Friday to replace Lois Pitts Gershon. The billings have been more than $6 million a year.

title: A Very Important Prime Minister
description: In the stream of foreign visitors to Washington, few rank in importance with tomorrow's - Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan. America's relations with Japan are central to world prosperity yet discussion of them is usually dominated by quarrels over Japanese cars and American beef. Much more than that is at stake.

title: Louisville Beats DePaul, 63-58
description: Rodney McCray, benched early in the first half, came back and scored 16 points, pacing Louisville to a 63-58 uphill basketball victory over DePaul today.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins Final, 6-3, 7-6
description: Martina Navratilova used her strong serve tonight to defeat Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-3, 7-6, in the final of a $150,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: 140 Challenges of Ads Resolved During 1982
description: When the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus closed its books in December, a month when it resolved 13 challenges to advertising assertions, the 1982 total stood at 140.

title: Salt Lake City Readers Given A Second Sunday Newspaper
description: For the first time in nearly 30 years, Salt Lake City residents this weekend had their choice of two Sunday morning newpapers.

title: NAKASONE TO FACE COMPLAINTS
description: When Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone arrives in Washington Monday after only 50 days in office, he will have to listen to a long string of complaints about the trading practices of his country.

title: Vladimir Bakaric, 70; Last of Tito's Comrades
description: Vice President Vladimir Bakaric died today at his home after a long illness, the official press agency Tanyug reported. He was 70 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Sir Alex McKay Dies; Australian Press Figure

title: CITY FACING SHARP NEW DROP IN TAX REVENUE, AIDES SAY
description: The Koch administration, forced to curtail its spending plans in each of the last two months because of growing budget deficits, is facing a sharp new decline in tax revenue, according to city officials.

title: A-ARMS OPPOSITION IN WEST GERMANY
description: West Germany's Green Party concluded a two-day convention today by confirming that its opposition to the deployment of American medium-range missiles will be the main plank in its platform for parliamentary elections in March.

title: CHIEF OF SCHOOLS QUITTING TO HEAD CITY CIVIC GROUP
description: Frank J. Macchiarola plans to resign today, after nearly five years as Chancellor of the city's public schools, to become the chief executive of the New York City Partnership, a business and civic group that directs projects in areas ranging from housing to summer jobs.

title: Jabbing at Danger
description: In just a few minutes, German Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut. Nervously huddled in his robe, he sat on the wooden bench against the concrete wall in the crowded and noisy Madison Square Garden dressing room he shared with two other fighters. That morning's newspaper had carried a front-page article saying the American Medical Association had discovered that boxing caused chronic brain damage and had called for its ban.

title: SHAPE UP, JAPAN
description: President Reagan and the Japanese Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, face a heavy agenda for their talks, which begin tomorrow, but if they gloss over the growing trade frictions between Japan and its trading partners they will make a potentially tragic mistake. While remedial actions will be required of both countries, Japan must make important changes in its world trade role. Measures to remove some nontariff barriers, announced Thursday, are a beginning but come very late and do not go far enough.

title: Talks on Debt Held by Cuba
description: Cuban officials have met in Panama with economics ministers from several Western nations in efforts to renegotiate payments on $2.6 billion in foreign debt, according to the Havana radio.

title: THE MIDTERM CRISIS
description: The breaking of the President is merrily under way. Mr. Reagans's split staff buttonholes reporters to portray him as unwilling to listen to reason, and what Mr. Eisenhower called ''sensation-seeking columnists'' berate him for not abandoning the principles on which he was elected.

title: Music From Alaska Celebrates 49th State
description: At Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night, the composer Judith Lang Zaimont made a brief speech preceding a performance of her haunting song cycle ''From the Great Land: Woman's Songs.'' In this setting of seven poems by Frank Buske, Miss Zaimont said that she had tried to ''convey the primitive raw beauty of Alaska, the discipline the climate imposes on habits of living and the overall vastness of the terrain.''

title: MUSIC: SCHUB PLAYS RECITAL
description: MICHEL SCHUB'SCarnegie Hall recital yesterday showed a pianist who seems sometimes too well trained for his own good. Mr. Schub's responsive ear and sound instincts are there, but they have trouble penetrating both his elegant virtuosity - which flitted over Beethoven's Opus 22 Sonata as if on automatic pilot - and his stagy hesitations - which often interrupted the natural course of two other pieces, Schumann's Symphonic Etudes and Mendelssohn's ''Variation Serieuses.'' Stretching Schumann's dignified Andante theme into a lugubrious lento was attention-getting, but it wasn't Schumann.

title: Arthur Space, TV Actor, Dies; Was Veterinarian on 'Lassie'
description: Arthur Space, an actor who appeared as a regular in two long-running television shows about animals, died of cancer Thursday in his Hollywood home.

title: Iraq Reports 66 Sorties; Algeria in Peace Effort
description: While an Algerian envoy sounded out proposals for a cease-fire between Iraq and Iran, Iraq reported today that its warplanes inflicted heavy damage on targets in the southern sector of the battlefront.

title: Commodities; A System For Stock Futures
description: FUTURES traders often joke that the biggest killings in any new market are usually made in its first year of trading, before the professional hedgers, speculators and arbitragers get a handle on the market. But it is nearly a year since the first of the three broadbased stock index futures markets opened, and the handle still seems to elude and frustrate the professionals.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS ATOP AGENDA
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, arrived in Bonn tonight for three days of talks with West German officials on possible nuclear-arms reductions in Europe.

title: TWO PRIVATE HOSPITALS IN CITY CUTTING BACK REBUILDING PLANS
description: Two of New York City's largest private teaching hospitals are pulling back on nearly $1 billion in planned rebuilding in response to Governor Cuomo's intention to freeze all hospital construction in the state for a year.

title: ROSTOW DEFENDS ARMS AGREEMENT DISOWNED BY U.S.
description: Eugene V. Rostow, the President's former arms control chief, said today that an informal agreement on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe worked out by United States and Soviet negotiators last July was ''a promising approach and well worth further study.''

title: MASSACRE PANEL FINISHES HEARINGS
description: The state commission investigating the Beirut massacre completed taking testimony today as lawyers for six senior officials gave oral summations of their clients' cases.

title: Klecko's Extra Sack
description: When the tendon on the right knee cap of Joe Klecko was torn last September, many doubted if the Jets' defensive end would even be jogging by January, much less playing in postseason competition. Remarkably, Klecko has played in the two playoff games.

title: SLIDING RATES SPUR ACTIVITY IN MORTGAGES
description: Mortgage rates have fallen by more than three percentage points in the last few months in the New York area, bringing eager home buyers who have been kept out of the market back to lenders for financing.

title: LEAVE THE NICARAGUANS ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Carole L. Weidman Wed to Bennett L. Nussbaum
description: The marriage of Carole L. Weidman to Bennett Lawrence Nussbaum took place yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: author of ''Love Has No Pride,'' one of the finest ballads of the rock era. But in her one and only solo album, now several years old, she emerged as an intriguing singer in the Maria Muldaur mold.

title: Lederle Aide Recruited To Lead Bio-Response
description: Robert F. Saydah, an executive who had been in charge of Lederle Laboratories' pharmaceutical business in the United States, has joined Bio-Response Inc., a small biotechnology company based in Wilton, Conn., as president and chief executive. Sarason D. Liebler, 46, who has been chief executive, will continue as vice chairman and become a vice president.

title: MUSIC: THE CELLO ART OF JANOS STARKER
description: SINCE beginning his solo concert career in earnest about a quarter of a century ago, the cellist Janos Starker has established himself as a major artist. He possesses all the theatrical and technical gifts of a virtuoso, but in addition, perhaps because of his experience as an orchestral cellist in the late 1940's and early 50's with the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, he possesses an unusually refined musical personality and a care for ensemble sound. He has never been an exploiter of his instrument; it has been a tool. And he spends much of his time as distinguished professor of music at Indiana University, where he has taught cellists since 1958.

title: News Analysis
description: The bipartisan accord achieved by the National Commission on Social Security Reform hands President Reagan a sorely needed political victory, White House officials said today, even though Mr.

title: LOS ANGELES POLICE SUBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: This city's police department is the subject of expanding inquiries into charges that it assigned undercover officers to spy on city officials, members of the city's Police Commission and citizens' groups.

title: CUT HOUSE SALARIES; INDEX 'EM TO RECOVERY
description: To publicize the difficulty of making ends meet on an annual salary of $60,662.50, Representative Ken Holland camped out on his office couch for several months in 1980. Although one constituent wrote to congratulate the ''only (Congressman) who ever gained any publicity from sleeping alone,'' Mr. Holland's salary did not go up, and last April the South Carolina Democrat announced his resignation from the House, citing pay as the chief reason.

title: FERTILIZATION CLINIC OPEN IN NEW YORK
description: The Presbyterian Hospital has established what is believed to be the first in vitro fertilization program in New York City and has selected 25 women as potential mothers of so-called test-tube babies.

title: U.S. Mother Hails Soviet's Aid for Son
description: An American teen-ager who has undergone therapy here for a rare degenerative eye disease has such improved vision from the first treatment that he is a superb video-game player, his mother said today.

title: Lansky Buried in Plain Coffin As 40 Attend Graveside Rite
description: Meyer Lansky, who gained the reputation of being a financial genius in the underworld, was buried today in a plain coffin.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A ball is hit to the right fielder in a softball game and, as he makes the catch, his momentum carries him over the fence. What is the ruling? What if he is in foul territory?

title: Fashion Program Extended
description: A retrospective of fashions by the designer Charles James has been extended through Feb. 13 at the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway at Washington Avenue.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: THE odd lineup of Ibex - synthesizer, saxophone and percussion - would make the trio sound unusual no matter what it played. But novelty was the least of the group's virtues Saturday at Public Access Synthesizer Studio.

title: No Headline
description: CONSERVATIVES MAKE AFFIRMATIVE ACTION A TARGET

title: TWO-FOOT SNOWFALL DELIGHTS RESORT OWNERS IN HUDSON VALLEY
description: After a month of complaints about a nearly snowless winter, a weekend storm dumped two feet or more on the resort areas of the Hudson Valley, the heaviest January snowfall ever recorded in the area.

title: Bridge: 2 Mixed Partnerships Win Titles in Tristate Regionals
description: Two mixed partnerships won major titles Friday and Saturday at the Tristate Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y. The Master Pairs, Flight A, went to Marty Bergen of White Plains and Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., both of whom are prominent on the national scene; and Harold Stengel and Joan Lepping of Boston headed the open division of the superflighted pairs.

title: NEW STUDY OF LOUISIANA JET CRASH SAYS TALL TREE WAS A FACTOR
description: A jet that crashed last July might have flown safely out of a severe downdraft if there had been no trees in the way, according to a special study prepared for Pan American World Airways.

title: Bernard Eric Stamler Marries Joan B. Kass
description: At Beth El Synagogue in Waterbury, Conn., Joan Barbara Kass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kass of Waterbury and Boynton Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Bernard Eric Stamler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Stamler of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Charles Freundlich, assisted by Cantor Irving Pinsky, performed the ceremony.

title: The Swede in the Gulag
description: Just 38 years ago today a remarkable Swede named Raoul Wallenberg disappeared in Budapest. He is by now a figure of myth and romance: the savior of 120,000 Hungarian Jews, later a prisoner in the Soviet Union, whose leaders, to this day, have failed to account persuasively for his fate.

title: REDEMPTION OF A KICKER
description: THE theme for the day was redemption, and Uwe von Schamann saw redemption floating toward him, waist high and as soft as a loaf of bread. He has recuperated from illness with encouragement from his friend, Rolf Benirschke, a fellow kicker who had recuperated from a worse illness. There is a strong bond between the two men, stronger than even the lonely trade they practice.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 17, 1983
description: International Eugene Rostow discussed the informal agreement on limiting mediumrange missiles in Europe worked out last July by United States and Soviet negotiators, led by Paul H. Nitze and Yuli A. Kvitsinky. He said it was ''a promising approach and well worth further study.'' The accord was rejected by both the United States and the Soviet Union. Mr. Rostow, recently dismissed as arms control chief by President Reagan, said that the United States, despite ojections raised in the Administration to what it said was Mr. Nitze's secret diplomacy, was more willing to keep the compromise idea alive than Moscow was. (Page A1, Column 2.) The world economic crisis will worsen unless other Western nations and Japan join the United States in getting their ecomomies moving again, an American policy maker said. Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel said at a news conference in Paris that it was now ''critically important'' for the health of the world economy that nations that have made progress in reducing inflation to take steps to insure that they enjoy a ''credible economic expansion.'' (A1:3.)

title: Lewis and Miss Valente Join 'Idomeneo' Cast
description: There were two cast changes in Saturday's performance of Mozart's grave and stately ''Idomeneo'' at the Metropolitan Opera House. Benita Valente assumed the grateful role of Ilia, the Trojan princess.

title: Miss Weber Wed To Robert Cahn
description: Nancy Weber and Robert Stern Cahn were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul Weber, in West Hartford, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Albert S. Cahn Jr. of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Cahn.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THREE NOVELS. The Mystic Masseur. The Suffrage of Elvira. Miguel Street. By V.S. Naipaul. 502 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: NORTH DAKOTA ROBBERS: RISK OF POSSES AND FEW HIDING PLACES
description: It had been nearly 50 years since anyone robbed a bank here in Nelson County, a snowswept swatch of flat farmland and blacktop road that sprawls across more than 1,000 square miles of northeastern North Dakota.

title: 6 Guilty in Newark In Marijuana Case
description: Six men were found guilty Saturday night of Federal drug possession and conspiracy charges in connection with the smuggling of 26 tons of marijuana, worth $13 million, into New Jersey from a Colombian freighter last July. Three other men accused in the scheme were acquitted.

title: EXPLOITERS: THEY TAKE, NEVER GIVE
description: AT the feast of life, there are always a few freeloaders. These are t he people with a talent for exploiting others, socially and e motionally.

title: RANGERS SHUT OUT 2D STRAIGHT TIME
description: ''It was a horrendous start,'' Coach Herb Brooks said of his Rangers' performance last night. He might also have mentioned that it was an awful finish and that there was not much to talk about in between.

title: JOSEPH H. LAUDER, EXECUTIVE, IS DEAD
description: Joseph H. Lauder, executive chairman and co-founder with his wife, Estee, of Estee Lauder Inc., the cosmetics concern, died Saturday night while visiting the East Side home of a son. He was in his 70's and lived in Manhattan and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Commemorating a Dreamer

title: Israeli Government Approves New West Bank Settlements
description: The Government today approved the establishment of four new settlements in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, a spokesman for the Ministerial Committee on Settlements said.

title: Medals and Ties
description: Tomorrow, at a closed session of the International Olympic Committee in Los Angeles, 70 years of frustration will end for the children of Jim Thorpe. The two gold medals that the famed Sac and Fox Indian won in the 1912 Olympic Games, only to be stripped of them after admitting that he had played professional baseball in 1910, will be returned to Mr. Thorpe's three daughters and four sons. Their father died in 1953.

title: Wisconsin House Fire Kills 3
description: A house fire today killed three members of a family and injured another, officials said. Smoke inhalation was responsible for the deaths of David Behrendt, 26 years old; his wife, Robin, 21, and their 11-month-old daughter, Crystal. Mr. Behrendt's mother, Virginia Behrendt, 58, was hospitalized and listed in critical condition.

title: CHILD PROBATION STUDIED BY CITY AFTER CRITICISM
description: Prompted by a critical report from a civic group, Mayor Koch has ordered a study on probation services for ''children in trouble.'' The Mayor directed John F. Keenan, the city's criminal justice coordinator, to look into the Family Court Division of the Department of Probation. Among other things, Mr. Keenan said, ''we want to see what improvements in procedures and training may be needed and are possible.''

title: Washington Watch; Lapse of Curbs Ends TV Saga
description: WASHINGTON FOREIGN policy controls barring American participation in the Moscow Olympics back in the summer of 1980 will quietly expire at the end of February. One result: the Russians will get a $14 million check from NBC.

title: Abducted Financier, 70, Found Dead in Bayou
description: The body of an elderly financier abducted from his home at knifepoint was discovered today in a Louisiana bayou, 10 days after the only contact from the man's abductor.

title: Market Place; The Search For Recovery
description: THE stock market spent last week searching for signs of an economic recovery. A close reading of the tea leaves proved inconclusive, but equity prices forged ahead anyway.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CANADA'S OIL IMPASSE
description: After years of haggling, it is a bit risky to predict an end to the impasse between the Canadian Government and Newfoundland over offshore drilling. The bitter dispute concerns which of them should manage the exploitation of the nearly two billion barrels of oil discovered off the province's rocky coast, as well as how to divide the taxes on that oil.

title: RIGHTS OF CHILEANS: WHAT IMPROVEMENT?
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Avis Chief At British Airways
description: Colin M. Marshall, a 49-year-old former chief executive of Avis Inc., has been named chief executive officer of state-owned British Airways, the troubled international carrier that the Government is trying to slim down and sell. He will take over the new post on Feb.1 from Roy Watts, who will retain his title of deputy chairman and concentrate on policy issues.

title: DEEPER MILITARY CUTS SOUGHT
description: Two Republican Senators said today that President Reagan must dig still deeper into military spending for 1984 to reduce projected budget deficits of $200 billion or more a year.

title: Truancy, the Festering Wound
description: Horace Mann's expectations for ''universal education'' have long since been disappointed, but it rightly remains the ideal of American society. Granting a right to schooling is one thing and making it good schooling yet another. Nothing can come of it, however, if so many young people simply won't go to school.

title: OUTDOORS: WATERFOWLING ON CAROLINA'S OUTER BANKS
description: WHEN camellias bloom in dooryards, waterfowl hunting is below par. The camellias graced the center of Vera Berg's dining-room table the night Joel Arrington of Raleigh, N.C., and I had supper with her and her husband, Vern, the owner of Outer Banks Waterfowl Inc., a hunting guide service that involves the coastal waters of Roanoke, Croatan, Albemarle, Currituck and Pamlico Sounds.

title: DECLINE IN HEALTH SERVICES FOR THE POOR CITED
description: In the last 18 months, every state has reduced health services for poor people, especially women and children, according to a report by the Children's Defense Fund.

title: TRUANT TEACHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: TODD EAGER TO PLAY DOLPHINS
description: Feet up on a table in his den, socks off, still aching happily from bumps and bruises incurred in Saturday's playoff victory at Los Angeles, Richard Todd was in a reflective mood today as he watched the Jets' next opponent, the Miami Dolphins, win on television.

title: THEATER: 'COMPANY' BY SAMUEL BECKETT
description: SAMUEL BECKETT'S book ''Company'' is the closest the author has come to an actual work of autobiography. In this brief work, 64 pages in the 1980 American edition, an unidentified listener spends sleepless nights ''devising figments to temper his nothingness.'' The figments are fictional representations of incidents, some of them traumatic, from Beckett's life - diving from a tree with his flight broken by branches; amusing his father by imitating his ''chuckle,'' feeling himself in adulthood shadowed by his father's ''shade.'' In its conversion of memory into myth, ''Company'' also becomes, by indirection, a commentary on the author's creative process.

title: 7 DEMOCRATS OPEN PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Seven leading Democrats launched the Presidential campaign for 1983 over the weekend with attacks on the Reagan Administration and promises to seek agreements on arms control, coupled with warnings against protectionism and the need for sacrifice.

title: MOVING TO REGAIN LABOR'S LOST POWER
description: There seems to be a fixed supply of glory in this town's professional political community. When reputations improve on one side, they decline on the other. Lately, such a transfer of prestige has been taking place across Lafayette Square, the statue-studded park between the White House and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters.

title: BISHOPS OF 2 FAITHS JOIN IN COMMUNION
description: Bishops of Episcopal and Lutheran churches held a joint communion service here today in an ecumenical innovation that the churches hope could be a model for other denominations.

title: CHINA TEXTILE WARNING
description: China's official party newspaper warned today that trade relations with the United States would suffer if the Reagan Administration retained curbs on imports of Chinese textiles.

title: People
description: * Paula Drillman, formerly of Marschalk, named executive vice president and research director of McCann-Erickson, U.S.A.

title: 8 NATIONS ASK OPEC TO MEET
description: Eight oil-producing nations, including several that have quarreled over pricing policies, called today for an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in what one minister described as a last attempt to head off a price war.

title: Florida Bank Link
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., based in Jacksonville, said it had agreed to acquire the Boulevard Bank in Key West for about $4.7 million in stock.

title: U.S. JUDGE RULES PARENT OR CHILD NEEDN'T TESTIFY AGAINST THE OTHER
description: In a decision that could have important implications for the judicial system, a Federal district judge in Las Vegas, Nev., has ruled that the privilege that prot0cts a husband or wife from being forced to testify against the other also applies to parents and children.

title: Auction Benefits Red Smith Fund
description: Bob Greenburg of Paramus and his wife, Jackie, owners of the Bunny Stable, were the winners today at the auction of a stud fee to Green Speed to benefit the Red Smith writing scholarship at Notre Dame.

title: MUGABE AND NKOMO
description: Three years after the end of a bloody war between white and black, this country is feeling the effects of rivalry between black ethnic and political groups. Its chance for internal peace could be greatly affected by a delicate political negotiation now going on.

title: Miss Cohen Wed To Steven Rosen
description: Judith Rita Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel S. Cohen of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Paul Rosen, son of Irving H. Rosen of Cincinnati and Gladys M. Rye of Dayton, Ohio. Rabbi Michael Schudrich performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POETRY

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank appointed David L. Balderach, Jeffrey L. Biever, Andrew W. Boraczek, Robert J. Brown, Nancy J. Carter, Henry J. Chaplin, Robert V. Chichetti, Thomas F. Conroy Jr. and Robert C. Carone vice presidents.

title: FIRST JERSEY IS ACCUSED BY S.E.C. ON GEOSEARCH
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed suit against First Jersey Securities Inc., its chairman and founder, Robert E. Brennan, and a senior executive, charging that they illegally manipulated the securities of a company that First Jersey actively traded in, taking in more than $3 million in profits.

title: GROWTH FOR INDUSTRIAL ECONOMIES URGED BY U.S. TO EASE DEBT CRISIS
description: Attempts to solve the international debt crisis will fail and the world recession will worsen unless other Western nations and Japan join the United States in getting their economies moving again, a senior American policymaker warned today.

title: COWBOYS WIN
description: Dennis Thurman, a quiet, introspective defensive back whose renown has been limited amid a cast of famous teammates, made three of the many big plays in the Dallas-Green Bay game today. The Cowboys needed Thurman's three interceptions of Lynn Dickey's passes to beat the Packers, which they did, 37-26, and the victory moved Dallas one step closer to the Super Bowl.

title: CUOMO VS. A MUCH-NEEDED POWER PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: ANALYSTS WARY ON DEFICITS
description: At the end of this month, President Reagan is to present a budget to Congress, an annual exercise that alarms many credit market analysts over the size of Government deficits and Treasury borrowings.

title: State and U.S. Prisoners Reach 405,371, a Record
description: The number of state and Federal prison inmates rose 11,055 in the third quarter of 1982, to a record of 405,371, the Justice Department said today.

title: BOGEYS DERAIL PALMER
description: It was too good to last. Arnold Palmer held the lead briefly today in the final round of the Glen Campbell Los Angeles Open, then shared it until, to the dismay of his fiercely vocal supporters, he was done in by three successive bogeys and then another one.

title: Marilyn Crispell, Pianist, Performs With Olatunji
description: The pianist Marilyn Crispell played two very different sets Friday at Soundscape. The first was a rhapsodic duet with the Nigerian conga drummer Babatunde Olatunji; the second deployed her quartet.

title: DANCE: CORBETT-BRODBECK SOLOS
description: SOME dancers celebrate the physical beauty of the body. Others, through skilled movement, seek to attain an almost transcendent spiritual state. But for Caitlin Corbett and Christine Brodbeck, who presented a program of solos Friday night at the Kitchen, the body was a stubborn clumsy beast that had to be tamed.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 17, 1983; International
description: The global debt crisis will persist unless industrial nations take steps to stimulate their economies, Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel warned. Otherwise, poorer nations will never be able to earn the money they need to repay their debts, he said. (Page A1.)

title: WALTS HITS 18 ACES
description: Victor Amaya made few mistakes but Butch Walts made almost none as he beat Amaya, 7-6, 7-6, in the final of the Louisiana-Pacific invitation tennis tournament today.

title: Inquiry Ruled Out On Harvey Martin
description: Local and Federal authorities said Friday that they will not investigate allegations that Harvey Martin, a defensive end for the Dallas Cowboys, purchased and used cocaine.

title: Tass Assails Reagan Over Martin Luther King
description: President Reagan's tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. ignored the way blacks are treated in the United States 15 years after the assassination of the civil rights leader, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: Dr. Michael M. Stewart, A Foundation Executive
description: Dr. Michael MacCracken Stewart, a vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation and associate professor at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital of complications following abdominal surgery. He was 46 years old and a resident of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: LAWMAKERS ASSERT PENSION PROPOSALS WILL BE APPROVED
description: Legislative leaders predicted today that Congress would approve the basic elements of a bipartisan commission's plan to shore up the Social Security system mainly by increasing taxes and delaying cost-of-living benefits.

title: BALLET: AT SEASON'S END, THE MANY JOFFREY FACETS
description: THE JOFFREY BALLET, which completed its New York season yesterday, presents a multifaceted personality to the world. The facets were in evidence in performances Saturday afternoon and evening at City Center.

title: CAN MIND GAMES WIN GAMES?
description: IT was cold, cold, cold. In Cincinnati on Jan. 10 of last year, the day of the American Football Conference championship game between the Bengals and the San Diego Chargers, the temperature was nine degrees below zero and the wind-chill factor made it feel like 59 degrees below zero. It was colder than the inside of a meat freezer. A fan could hear his teeth clicking like ice cubes in a glass.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We take a plunge into icy waters here. I am convinced that we shall find it refreshing and life-giving.''

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.37 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: 46 KILLED IN ANKARA AS A TURKISH JETLINER GOES DOWN IN STORM
description: A Turkish Airlines jetliner carrying 67 passengers and crew members crashed while landing in a storm at Ankara's airport today and 46 people were killed, the authorities reported.

title: HOW JETS GREW UP
description: LOS ANGELES NOBODY questions the Jets anymore. Suddenly many pro football people are nodding knowingly, as if they really knew it all along. Suddenly the Jets are being praised as the National Football League's ''most-talented'' team. Suddenly the Jets will be playing for the American Football Conference championship Sunday in Miami, with the winner qualifying for Super Bowl XVII against the Dallas Cowboys or the Washington Redskins.

title: 'SOPHIE'S FLATBUSH IS STILL HERE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Walesa at Gdansk Mass For Jailed Poles
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity Union, attended a special evening mass in Gdansk tonight for the 1,500 activists and dissidents in jail for martial law violations or awaiting trial.

title: RANKING OF UNIVERSITIES' REPUTATIONS AND NUMBER OF FACULTY PUBLICATIONS
description: Here are the rankings of graduate schools under two of the criteria in a study published by the Conference Board of Associated Research Councils.

title: DENTON SERVE A MASTER'S WEAPON
description: YOU will not find Steve Denton's serve in any of the textbooks on tennis technique, even though it is probably the most high-powered weapon on the men's tour and the equivalent of a Goose Gossage fastball.

title: U.S. Steel Plans 5% Cut in Pay
description: The United States Steel Corporation has informed general management and salaried employees of a 5 percent pay cut, effective Feb. 1. The cut would be the second 5 percent reduction in seven months.

title: SWITCH AT THE I.C.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Ex-prisoner of Iran tells story of brutality and killings A1 Southern Lebanon: rejected, ne- glected and occupied A2 Panel on Beirut massacre fin- ishes taking testimony A2 West Germany's Greens say new missiles will be main issue A3 39 die in Turkish air crash A4 Around the World A5 Congressman would link Salva- dor arms aid to talks A7 Government/Politics Conservatives assail pacts against discrimination A13 State Legislature committees to investigate Ossining uprising B1 Federal funds will aid Brooklyn and Williamsburg Bridges B2 Washington Talk A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political director assumes a central role A12 When the Redskins play, Social Security can wait A12 The Calendar A12 Briefing A12 General Around the Nation A8 Spate of bank robberies riled peo- ple in a North Dakota county A8 Los Angeles police undercover team subject of inquiry A9 Judge rules parent or child need- n't testify against other A10 Transit worker lives with bitter memories of Brooklyn beating B2 Former hostages of Iran gather to assess the event B4 DR. KING OBSERVANCE The New York City public schools will be closed today in honor of the birthday last Saturday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. All other serv- ices remain unaffected. SportsMonday Basketball: Nets hope to find steady emotional level C7

title: BENTON MURAL MAY BE SPLIT UP
description: An important mural by Thomas Hart Benton, the American painter, which was sold last May for a figure reported at $2 million on condition that the buyer would make ''every effort'' to keep the 10 panels together and in the United States, may now be broken up and sold abroad.

title: Alert Ends in Alabama After Nuclear Plant Leak
description: A site alert was declared today at The Browns Ferry nuclear power plant after operators found that radioactive water had leaked into the Tennessee River, but the alert was canceled after 10 1/2 hours.

title: SISTERS OF 'SKIRMISHES' WORK AT THEIR RELATIONSHIP
description: SUZANNE BERTISH and Fran Brill, who have won critical praise as the warring sisters in ''Skirmishes'' - Catherine Hayes's darkly comic slice of life at the Manhattan Theater Club - improvised an argument recently in a restaurant.

title: Let's Try a Police Corps
description: Families are strapped for college tuitions and cities are strapped for police. Why not offer scholarships to young people willing to serve a few years on the beat?

title: Decision Pending On U.S. Bike Race
description: Felix Levitan, director general of the Tour de France organization, says that a decision on which European riders can compete in the Tour of America bicycle race next spring has not yet been made. He denies reports that Bernard Hinault, the four-time winner of the Tour de France, will be barred.

title: Advertising; Compton Structure Adjusted
description: THERE is more to the promotion of Robert O. Jordan from vice chairman to chairman of Compton Advertising than immediately meets the eye.

title: WESTPORT TORN BY SOUP KITCHEN PROPOSAL
description: Here, in one of the wealthiest towns in Connecticut, the Rev. Theodore Hoskins wants to open a soup kitchen to feed the hungry. It would be best situated, he believes, downtown, near the park where perhaps a dozen homeless young men sleep - and amid such stores as Towne 'n' Tweed and the Chez Pierre.

title: Founder of Radiofone Heads Metromedia Unit
description: Robert Edwards, a 63-year-old entrepreneur who successfully started two companies in his career, has been named president of Metromedia's new telecommunications division.

title: AMERICAN TELLS OF LONG ORDEAL IN IRAN PRISONS
description: Four of the Americans who were held hostage in Iran remain fascinated with the country. Page B4. By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

title: SCARS LINGER FROM ASSAULT IN GRAVESEND
description: A circular mark the size of a nickel near Dennis Dixon's right ear is the only visible scar from the early-morning attack six months ago. But it is not the only scar.

title: Lisa Helmrich Is Wed To Nathaniel Akerman
description: Lisa J. Helmrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Helmrich of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nathaniel Howard Akerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Akerman of Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at Le Chateau, an inn in South Salem, N.Y.

title: NEW ISSUES WIDENING
description: This week's financings in the Treasury market are not expected to be much of a burden, but the increased size of every new issue is a harbinger of the Treasury's immense needs in the future.

title: SOUTH LEBANON: REJECTED, NEGLECTED AND OCCUPIED
description: Adib Basmas sat in a small cafe across from his supermarket and surveyed this battered southern Lebanese port. ''It's quiet,'' he said. ''Quite a lot of people have returned to repair their houses.''

title: Respect Eludes 'Skin Defense
description: Perhaps if the Washington Redskins win the National Conference championship Saturday, football aficionados will grudgingly concede that they are a good team.

title: COWBOYS WIN
description: A year ago in the Orange Bowl, the Miami Dolphins walked off the field heartbroken, losers in overtime, as the San Diego Chargers advanced to the American Conference championship game. Today, in a rematch, the Dolphins left exultant, winners by 34-13, in a game they dominated in nearly every way possible.

title: NETS HOPING TO USE VICTORY OVER KNICKS TO STEADY EMOTIONS
description: The Nets have done plenty of winning lately. Including Saturday's 110-96 triumph over the Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, they have won 12 of their last 13 games and 18 of their last 23.

title: BARTERING AIDS POOR NATIONS
description: When the International Commodities Export Company of White Plains recently received a $127 million fertilizer order from Indonesia, the company went through with the deal even though it knew it would not get any cash from the customer. Instead the company accepted payment in goods.

title: CLOSING IN ON R.J. REYNOLDS
description: For the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, it has been a nice quarter of a century: with its array of Winston, Salem, Camel and Vantage, among other brands, it has sold more cigarettes in the United States than anyone else for 25 consecutive years. For most of that time, Reynolds was so far ahead of its closest pursuer that there was no need to look back.

title: AUSTRIAN CAPTURES SLALOM
description: TSCHAGGUNS, Austria, Jan. 16 (AP) - Anni Kronbichler of Austria captured her first slalom event today in a race in which the World Cup point leaders, Erika Hess and Tamara McKinney, were disqualified.

title: JETS FACE ANOTHER OBSTACLE
description: The face of his next adversary appeared on the television screen in Walt Michaels's office today. ''How,'' asked Michaels, ''can you compete against Don Shula?'' As Shula, the coach of the Miami Dolphins, was shown walking off the field with a playoff victory, Michaels, the coach of the Jets, tossed his glasses on his desk.

title: THE NEWEST GAME IN TOWN
description: Will Trivial Pursuit beat Pac-Man? Can an old-fashioned board game compete with the marvels of electronic games? Selchow & Righter, who gave the world Scrabble, think so. And with a certain amount of cause.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about shipping in Business Day Friday incorrectly reported the tonnage of maritime vessels laid up last year.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Quarrel Over Peace

title: 2 JUSTICES REFUSE TO BAR BROADCAST
description: Three days of maneuvering over free press and fair trial issues ended yesterday when two justices of the United States Supreme Court declined to block a CBS News telecast about the conduct of seven New Orleans policemen.

title: Five Are Killed as 4 Cars Run Off a Collapsed Span
description: Five people were killed and four were injured tonight when four cars plunged ''one by one'' off a collapsed bridge into a dry creek bed, the Ohio Highway Patrol said.

title: BEHIND WAGNER'S 'RING'
description: THE kickoff program of ''Frontline,'' the much-heralded publictelevision series of 26 hourlong documentaries, which arrives at 8 tonight on Channel 13, is an exercise in guilt by association. The associations that concern the producers of ''An Unauthorized History of the N.F.L.'' are those between players and team owners on the one hand, and big-time gamblers said to be connected with organized crime on the other. A theme of the program is the disposition of National Football League officials to look the other way.

title: DEVILS SCORE 2 IN 47 SECONDS TO WIN, 5-3
description: The Devils scored two goals within 47 seconds midway through the third period and added an empty-net goal for a 5-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings tonight before a crowd of 10,367 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Officer in Miami Riot Is Relieved of Duty
description: Louis Cruz, a rookie police officer who saw his partner shoot a black man, sparking three days of violence in the Overtown section here, has been relieved of duty for wearing a hidden microphone and tape recorder, the officials said today.

title: ST. JOHN'S IS FOILED IN BID FOR NO. 1 SPOT
description: Blizzard conditions, the weather reports warned. But that made little difference at Boston College on Saturday night. There was an added incentive to return to campus before classes resume on Monday. St. John's, the third-ranked basketball team in the country, with its 14 straight victories, was thought to be the highest ranked team ever to play at the Heights campus.

title: BEARD IS INSTRUCTIVE ON KNICKS' TACTICS
description: T he success of the New Jersey Nets this season makes their games more entertaining and therefore more tempting to watch on television. But there is so much more to be learned by watching the Knicks telecasts.

title: HOME APPLIANCES ARE SLOWLY ADDING ELECTRONIC FEATURES
description: The home appliance industry, despite hesitation by some manufacturers, is slowly catching up with the electronics revolution. Today's appliance shoppers can buy a dishwasher that will start up hours after its owner is off to bed. A new refrigerator flashes a signal light when lint has accumulated beneath it. And microwave ovens have recently been equipped with something like an electronic sense of smell.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLORIDA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THOMAS H. M'DONOUGH
description: Thomas H. McDonough, executive vice president of the Civil Service Employees Association in Albany, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Colonie, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title: BY RIGHTS GROUPS
description: Civil rights advocates called upon the nation's highest military court today to strike down the death penalty provisions of the military justice code, which have not been updated to conform to Supreme Court rulings in recent years.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CO (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HONG KONG'S REALTY TUMBLE
description: Genius, it is said, is a rising market. And from 1977 to mid-1981, when property prices here quadrupled, Hong Kong was filled with brilliant financiers, developers and bankers.

title: MATHEMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1983
description: International Andrei A. Gromyko warned Bonn that it would be caught in a sharpened nuclear confrontation if new American medium-range missiles were deployed in Western Europe. On the second day of a visit to West Germany, the Soviet Foreign Minister also said that Moscow was ready to negotiate a reduction of its shorter-range SS-21, SS-22 and SS-23 nuclear weapons systems targeted on Western Europe on the basis of ''mutuality'' with NATO. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) The White House again repudiated as inadequate an informal agreement worked out by American and Soviet negotiators in Geneva last summer for limiting medium-range missiles in Europe. Officials underscored their opposition to any agreement that fell short of the American position, which calls for both sides to scrap all medium-range missiles. (A1:1.)

title: CONNORS RELISHING TOP SPOT
description: During a year-end vacation in which he did not pick up a tennis racquet for three and one-half weeks, Jimmy Connors said he had a little talk with himself about this question: Did he want to put himself this year through the same rigors that he experienced in 1982 to win Wimbledon, the United States Open and the year's No.1 ranking?

title: Charlotte Curtis; Irene Selznick: Her Story
description: THE view from Irene Mayer Selznick's dark green study is a peaceful one. She looks over Central Park, and on winter afternoons, when the sun is a faded pink, the dim light softens the buildings and bare trees, blurring their harsh lines.

title: SALARIES AT CITY U. CALLED TOO HIGH FOR CERTAIN JOBS
description: High-salaried employees who are hired without competitive tests are doing middle-level work at the City University, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: TB Is Found Still a Danger
description: Most of the sanitariums were shut down years ago. The mobile X-ray units no longer roll through dilapidated neighborhoods, and school children no longer fidget in anticipation of skin tests.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
Yale and Magazine In Suit Over Name
description: Yale University agreed today to let the Yale Literary Magazine continue publishing under that name until a suit between the two is settled, a lawyer for the magazine said.

title: ALLIED SECURITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: The compromise Social Security proposal worked out over the weekend by a Presidential commission would do what many workers feared most: It would increase the taxes workers contribute to the pension system. It would, however, repay them with a reasonable assurance that the old-age benefits that have become an integral part of Americans' retirement planning will be available well into the next century.

title: Salazar Nominated
description: The distance runners Alberto Salazar and Mary Decker Tabb are among 10 world-class performers who have been nominated for the Sullivan Award, which is given annually by the Amateur Athletic Union to the country's top amateur athlete. The other nominees for the award, which will be presented Feb. 21, are: The figure skater Scott Hamilton; the diver Greg Louganis; the skier Phil Mahre; the swimmer Mary T. Meagher; the synchronized swimmer Tracie Ruiz; the equestrian Melanie Smith; the boxer Tyrell Biggs, and the wrestler Gregory Gibson.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Please explain the differences between sleet, hail, freezing rain and snow.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DREW NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $87,000 for the latest first quarter and $525,000 for the year-ago first quarter

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 4
description: B-Including tax credits of $2,424,000 for the quarter and $3,729,000 for the 9 months; B-Net loss after a loss of $9,187,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the settlement of antitrust litigation

title: SHOOTING OF INNOCENT MAN JARS LONDON
description: The shooting of a London man by a special police squad over the weekend has shaken a society that is just getting accustomed to the idea of armed policemen.

title: Test Planned For Air Bags
description: The National Highway Safety Administration plans to install and test crash-cushioning air bags in some police cars in Arizona. Raymond A. Peck Jr., administrator of the Federal agency, said in a recent statement that he was ''committed to seeking automotive demonstration projects which assure continued research into reliable and cost effective auto safety technology for the American car-buying public.''

title: Top Court Refuses Hauptmann Bid
description: The 84-year-old widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, who was executed in 1936 for the kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh, lost a bid today before the United States Supreme Court to disqualify the judge hearing a $100 million wrongful death suit she filed in 1981.

title: The Chancellor Departs
description: In four and a half years as Chancellor of New York City's public schools, Frank Macchiarola was a dedicated, fair-minded leader and an aggressive innovator. He will be hard to replace.

title: NEW YORK SHARE IN DEFENSE WORK TERMED LAGGING
description: New York State fared relatively poorly compared with the rest of the Northeast-Middle West region in attracting Federal military spending, according to a study released today by a research group with bipartisan Congressional membership.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MISSOURI NOW FEARS 100 SITES COULD BE TAINTED BY DIOXIN
description: The number of sites suspected by Missouri officials of being contaminated with deadly dioxin has reached about 100, up from the 55 earlier suspected.

title: CONGRESSMAN IN SALVADOR FINDS THE 'REALITY' ELUSIVE
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a Democrat from Brooklyn, sat more than 2,400 miles away from home in a cellblock at the Mariona Prison here. In an I-can-take-anything tone he asked five of the political prisoners to describe the torture they had been subjected to after being arrested.

title: ARTHUR LEVEY
description: Arthur Levey, founder and president of the Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation, died last Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.

title: MORRIS L. ROSENBLUM
description: Morris L. Rosenblum, former vice president and creative director for advertising of Macy's New York, died Sunday at John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Lake Worth.

title: A RULE ON EVIDENCE VS. THE SEARCH FOR TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Anheuser-Busch
description: Dennis P. Long, president and chief operating officer of Anheuser-Busch Inc., said the brewery has earmarked $2 billion for capital expansion projects during the next five years. ''We have and will continue to finance such expansion in large measure through the reinvestment of earnings,'' he said. The company, which makes Budweiser and other beers, said it sold 59.1 million barrels of beer in 1982, up 8.5 percent from 1981 and an industry record.

title: VW Cuts in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. has started reorganizing and laying off some staff members in at least one department at its Troy, Mich., headquarters. A spokesman, Ted Kade, confirmed today that William H. Maypole, director of VW's styling design, had left the company and that his position had been eliminated as part of VW's cutback of 1,500 workers nationwide.

title: BANKERS TRUST OVERHAUL ON INVESTING EXPECTED
description: The Bankers Trust Company, one of the nation's largest institutional investors, is planning a major overhaul of its money management functions, according to well-placed sources in the financial community.

title: 2 in Texas Held in Threat To Poison Gallo Wine
description: A Federal magistrate has ordered two men jailed on charges they tried to extort $200,000 from Gallo Winery, one of the world's largest wine producers.

title: Colombia Man Kidnapped
description: The 23-year-old son of a rich cattle breeder in northern Colombia was kidnapped today, apparently by leftist guerrillas, military sources said. The man, Jose Ignacio Builes, was abducted early today in the town of San Roque, some 300 miles northwest of Bogota.

title: No Headline
description: A jumper by Clarence Tillman with 1:01 left lifted Rutgers. St. Joseph's (7-6 and 1-3 in the Atlantic 10) tied it, 77-77, with 1:39 to go. After Tillman sank his tiebreaker for Rutgers (11-2 and 3-0), Lonnie McFarlan of St. Joseph's missed a jumper. The rebound was knocked out of bounds at the buzzer.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $178,000 for the qr and $343,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $433,000 for the qr and $809,000 for the 6 mos

title: Article 171360 -- No Title
description: Senior monetary officials from 10 major industrial nations agreed tonight to make available a $20 billion emergency fund to help deeply indebted countries, according to participants at their meeting.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $4,400,000 for the qr and $12,739,000 for the yr...C-After an extraordinary loss of $1,794,000

title: PROCESSING WORDS
description: RECENTLY I heard of a college student who suddenly started coming home on weekends to use the family's new personal computer as well as to raid the refrigerator. The reason for the precipitous periodic homecoming was word processing. I find it hard to conceive of very many families that really need word processing. Nevertheless, in high schools and colleges, this particular new treatment of verbal expression seems to be falling rapidly into the scholastic category once traditionally reserved for the recipients of such comments as ''He always gets better grades because he types his reports.'' There is a large difference between the two, however. Unlike selecting a typewriter, when it comes to choosing a word processor, it's how the device is programmed to be used that counts. Excluding the lowercase percussive perambulations of Archie the Cockroach, typing can really be done in only one of two ways, by hunt and peck, or by touch. Processing words, on the other hand, offers a myriad of variants in operation, depending partly on the computer involved but even more on the software.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-including tax credits of $160,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for 6 months and income of $1,792,000 for 6 months from discontinued operations; C-Including income from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $194,000; D-Net loss including income of $308,000 from discontinued operations

title: Sharon Is Reported in Zaire For Talks on Security Links
description: Ariel Sharon, the Israeli Defense Minister, arrived in Zaire today for talks with President Sese Seko Mobutu on increased security ties between the two countries, informed sources said.

title: WALKER A DOLPHIN NEMISIS
description: Wesley Walker, who used to work hard at being a bachelor, went in a different direction from his Jets' teammates today.

title: New Stargell Role
description: He faced a few packed stadiums in his 20-year career, yet Willie Stargell, the former Pittsburgh Pirate who retired at age 41 after the 1982 season, A review appears on page C11. admitted that there was something unnerving about his performance at Carnegie Hall last night with the Eastman Philharmonia.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All figures have been restated to reflect 1981 and 1982 pooling of interest transactions

title: Abbie Hoffman Leads Protest on Water Project
description: Abbie Hoffman led about 200 protesters at the Bucks County Courthouse this morning to dramatize opposition to the Point Pleasant water diversion project, the county sheriff said.

title: Court to Weigh Pacts in Bankruptcy
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the legal obligations of bankrupt companies to honor existing labor contracts while undergoing reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.

title: McDonald to Promote Wise Lite-Line Snacks
description: McDonald & Little, Atlanta, since February 1981 the agency for the Borden Snack Food division, will be doing the introductory advertising for Borden's new Wise Lite-Line Snacks, which will be aiming for an older-than-usual group with a promise of low fat and low calories.

title: 6 SERVICEMEN AWAIT EXECUTION ON DEATH ROW
description: After 14 years without a death sentence among United States military personnel, six uniformed men are awaiting execution in the Disciplinary Barracks at Fort Leavenworth. All were condemned by military courts in the last three years.

title: Zungul Deal Seems Closer
description: The New York Arrows of the Major Indoor Soccer League are hoping to complete a deal for the high-scoring forward Steve Zungul today, if he clears waivers, as expected.

title: LOAN FLAWS IN ONTARIO
description: Investigations into three Canadian trust and loan companies whose $2 billion (Canadian) in assets were seized two weeks ago by the Ontario government have disclosed breaches in lending regulations and inaccurate records, a provincial official said today.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chrysler Cuts Certain Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had cut prices on its 1982- and 1983-model convertibles by as much as $2,505. The prices, effective today, resulted from ''efficiencies we have achieved'' as volume has increased, Tom Pappert, Chrysler vice president of United States automotive sales, said.

title: WALLACE TAKES 4TH OATH AS GOVERNOR OF ALABAMA
description: On the precise spot where he stood 20 years ago before the white columns of the state Capitol and promised the world ''segregation forever,'' George Corley Wallace today became the first man inaugurated for a fourth term as Governor of Alabama.

title: Afghans Are Reported Forming Guard Squads
description: Afghanistan's Marxist Government is ordering workers to form armed guard units to defend their factories and farms against attacks by anti-Government insurgents, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: FOR MEN, LONG IS WARMER
description: If this winter is remembered for anything, aside from the shortage of frigid weather, it may go down in fashion history as the time when New York men began to wear long overcoats again in earnest. Not since the days of maxicoats have men gone to such lengths to be fashionable.

title: NO SPIRAL, BUT PASS WORKED
description: It is common knowledge in the National Football League that Drew Pearson, the wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, was a quarterback in high school at South River, N.J., where he followed Joe Theismann at the position. It is also known that Pearson can throw a decent spiral pass.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acco Babcock Inc., Fairfield, Conn., has promoted Robert M. Miller to general counsel; Alvin R. Johnson to vice president, human resources; Jeffrey L. Currier to senior vice president, finance, and Peter W. Krehbiel to senior vice president, administration.

title: MEMPHIS ZEALOTS ALL SHOT IN HEAD
description: Seven religious zealots who were killed by the police when they rushed a house in which a fellow officer was being held captive were all shot in the head, according to medical reports released today.

title: DEMOCRATS AT PARLEY ON COAST PRESS TO REVIVE SOCIAL GOALS
description: With the state's top officials unable to agree on how to stop borrowing money to pay current bills, activists at the Democratic State Convention showed an overwhelming inclination over the weekend to return to their usual programs of imposing taxes to raise money to pay for a better life for the poor.

title: Soviet Is Said to Deploy New Missiles in Syria
description: The United States believes the Soviet Union has deployed SA-5 ground-to-air missiles in Syria, which would put most of Israel's airspace within Syrian range, United States intelligence officials said today.

title: Violence Kills 4 in India
description: Four people were killed in political violence over the past 24 hours in India's remote northeastern state of Tripura, the Press Trust of India news agency said today. A duskto-dawn curfew was imposed tonight on the town of Udaypur, about 35 miles from the state capital of Agartala, after two people were killed in clashes between rival political parties, it said.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income for the latest 9 mos reflects an increase of $654,000 or 8 cents a shr from a LIFO inventory adjustment

title: Airline Traffic Up 2.9% in 1982
description: The nation's troubled airlines reported today that their traffic in 1982 increased only slightly from the depressed previous year despite fare wars on many routes.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON SPRING TRAINING
description: The dispute over the starting dates for spring training was resolved yesterday when the baseball players and club owners reached a compromise that would delay several early camps by three or four days, including those of the Mets and Yankees.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anderson Strathclyde P.L.C. of Scotland said it had raised its offer for National Mine Service Co. to $13 a share from $12.50; National, also being sought by Longyear Co. for $12.50 a share, has approved Anderson's offer.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods include gain on sale of real estate purchase options of $14,291,000; the per share and shares outstanding figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE watchword of the week was flux. How could it be otherwise? The s cenery has lately been changing faster than you can say ''cocktail p arty,'' one of the best places to find out what the fashionable are d oing when they're not getting dressed.

title: WARM-WEATHER CLOTHES THAT WORK ALL YEAR
description: The trouble with summer is it can have too short a run, many fashion designers assert. If it gets too late a start, women are understandably reluctant to spend considerable amounts of money for clothes they are not likely to wear for more than a month or two. By the end of August, the eye wearies of bright colors, no matter how cheerful, and women turn to somber hues, designers believe.

title: Fiat in U.S. Sales Shift
description: Fiat Motors of North America will transfer car sales operations in the United States to Bricklin Inc., a spokesman for the parent company, Fiat S.p.A., said today. He said Fiat Motors of North America would continue to represent Fiat S.p.A. for service and consultation.

title: BASEBALL
description: LOS ANGELES (NL) - Named Mel Di- d ier, athletic director at the University of S outhwestern Louisiana, as special as- s ignments scout. OAKLAND (AL) - Traded Brian King- m an, pitcher, to Boston for a player to be n amed later.

title: Town Hall Blaze Kills Man in Jersey
description: A 21-year-old volunteer firefighter died yesterday afternoon while battling a general-alarm fire that caused extensive damage to the Municipal Building in New Milford, N.J., authorities reported.

title: DEFICIT IN THE $185 BILLION RANGE EXPECTED IN 1984 REAGAN BUDGET
description: With the reductions already approved and the bipartisan compromise just struck on Social Security revisions, President Reagan is preparing a 1984 budget likely to project a deficit in the range of $185 billion, Congressional and Administration sources said today.

title: THE ROLE OF THEORIES IN A TOWN DESPERATE TO KNOW
description: Only a year ago, Senate Republican leaders rejected President Reagan's proposed budget because it projected a deficit of $91.5 billion, paltry by today's standards. Such a deficit, they said, would send the wrong signal to the financial community, fueling inflation and driving up already high interest rates.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aqueduct Closed
description: Racing was canceled again at Aqueduct yesterday because of continued fears about the track condition. Racing had been canceled Sunday after the second race, when jockeys complained about slippery footing. Officials canceled yesterday's card when it appeared the track condition had not improved.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Raymond K. Price Jr., a longtime associate of former President Richard M. Nixon, has been hired as a personal consultant by William S. Paley, founder and chairman of CBS Inc.

title: CUOMO SAYS STATE MUST CUT SERVICES AND GAIN REVENUE
description: Governor Cuomo warned today that he would have to cut ''good programs'' and ''raise some revenues'' to close a budget deficit next year that he called the largest in the state's history.

title: STAGE: INTERART'S 'GROWING UP GOTHIC'
description: CLARE COSS'S ''Growing Up Gothic,'' a Women's Interart Center production at Theater for the New City, is an interminable study of family friction. The three-act play runs two and a half hours, but when it was over I felt as if I had aged at least 10 years. The program informs us that the time of the play is ''the present'' and the place is ''the past,'' but everything seems to be happening in a never-ending future.

title: Drew Is Due Back
description: He's been undergoing secret treatment for an undisclosed medical problem at an unidentified hospital since last Nov. 22, and now John Drew, the star basketball player for the Utah Jazz, is apparently well on his way to recovery. According to the Jazz coach, Frank Layden, Drew should be back by early next month and playing full time by mid-February.

title: Post in G.O.P. Is Lost Over Gift to Kennedy
description: A wealthy businessman who wanted to be Maryland's Republican national committeeman lost after it was learned that he had contributed $1,000 to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: Peking Chief Goes Home After Month in Africa
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China flew home today at the end of an 11-nation tour of Africa aimed at reasserting China's influence on the continent.

title: AVIS-HERTZ TUMULT GROWS
description: Avis and Hertz, never shy about fighting in public, are at it again. At issue this time are free gifts, disputed market share figures, corporate raiding accusations and possibly stolen documents.

title: FATHERS' SMOKING MAY HARM FETUSES
description: WHILE pregnant women have long been urged to give up smoking for the sake of their babies, similar advice might now also be given to prospective fathers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trigger for Insect Molting
description: Events that cause most insects to molt, pupate or metamorphose at a certain stage of their lives are usually seasonal or climatic changes, such as a rise in daily temperatures or an increase in the amount of daily sunlight. As a result, same-age members of a single insect species often molt synchronously when they receive such an external stimulus telling them it is time to shed their skins.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A U.S. PHYSICIST'S BOLDBID TO BE FIRST
description: DR. BURTON RICHTER is getting ready to battle a thousand of the best minds in the world of experimental science. Dr. Richter, a California physicist who often works in blue jeans and tennis shoes, won a Nobel Prize in 1976 for the discovery of one subatomic particle. Now he is in search of another.

title: FN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $13,656,000 for the qr and $20.4 million for the yr...C-Including a tax credit of $27,005,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,641,000

title: VIENNA GROUP, CHILD OF DETENTE, TIGHTENS BELT
