description: As the climate of East-West relations has chilled in recent months, an East-West research institute concerned with energy, food supply and other long-range international problems has been forced to curtail its activities.

title: Cretaceous Dark Deepens
description: The dinosaurs may have been starved into extinction because they could no longer find food in the total darkness caused by dust from a meteorite impact, according to an analysis published in the Jan. 21 issue of Science. The darkness, which may have persisted ''a few months,'' would also have halted photosynthesis on land and in the seas, bringing about mass extinctions of ocean creatures.

title: Cigna Is Separating Executives' Duties
description: The Cigna Corporation, a major diversified insurance company, has announced the end of an experiment in multiple-executive management that started when two insurance giants, the Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation, merged last year.

title: Quake Jolts Wide Greek Area; Italians and Yugoslavs Jarred
description: An earthquake shook a wide area of Greece today with tremors felt in Italy and Yugoslavia, a spokesman for the Athens observatory said.

title: SUITS BARRED IN GERM TEST DEATH
description: The family of a man who died shortly after the Army conducted secret germ warfare tests in 1950 does not have the right to sue the Federal Government for damages, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chase's Operating Income Off
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, citing problem loans overseas, including Latin America, said yesterday that its net operating income in the fourth quarter fell 29.9 percent, to $108 million, or $2.78 a share, from $154 million, or $4.40 a share, a year earlier.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes gains of $2,200,000 or 18 cents a shr for the latest qr and $3,700,000 or 30 cents a shr for the yr-ago qr from the sale of real estate...C-Includescharges of $2,000,000 or 17 cents a shr for the qr and $6,900,000 or 56 cents ashr for the yr due to the effect of the devaluation of the Mexican peso

title: INFORMAL AGREEMENT ON MISSILES IS CALLED INADEQUATE BY U.S.
description: The White House said today that an informal agreement worked out by the American and Soviet negotiators in Geneva last summer on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe was inadequate and could not have served as the basis for an accord.

title: DISPUTE RESOLVED ON BRINK'S DEFENDANT
description: The dispute between Federal and state prosecutors over a defendant in the Brink's robbery and murder case was resolved yesterday, with Federal authorities in Manhattan dropping their demands for permanent custody of the defendant.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLLEGE 'FACTORIES' AND THEIR OUTPUT
description: Ira Berkow Sports of The Times

title: THE REGION;
description: Governor Kean announced today that across-theboard budget cuts totaling $30 million would be made in the accounts of all state departments by June 30, the end of the fiscal year, to insure finishing the year with a balanced budget.

title: 400 Pounds of Cocaine Seized With 12 Arrests
description: Federal agents, watching movements around a pier, arrested 12 people early today after two men in wetsuits swam ashore with more than 400 pounds of cocaine, the authorities said. The seizure was said to be one of the biggest ever on the West Coast.

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $10.2 million and an extraordinary gain of $1.1 million

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bicycle Accountability

title: TV SNOBBERY'S SUPERLATIVE PRACTITIONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures adjusted to reflect 5% stock dividend paid Jan 3

title: Namibia's Council To Quit En Masse
description: West Africa, Jan. 17 (Reuters) - All the members of the South-West Africa Council of Ministers will resign Tuesday in support of their chairman, Dirk Mudge, the ruling Democratic Turnhalle Alliance said today.

title: FACTORY USE DOWN
description: The nation's manufacturers operated at only 67.3 percent of capacity in December, a record low, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. But economists said the 18-month slide was probably being reversed this month.

title: T.V.A. Says River Flow Diluted Radioactive Leak
description: The intermittent leaks that caused an alert Sunday at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant amounted to 312 gallons of radioactive water that contaminated 208,000 gallons of Tennessee River water, the Tennessee Valley Authority said today.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Helen Walker, 91, First Woman To Head U.S. Statistical Group
description: Helen M. Walker, a leader in educational statistics and the first woman to be president of the American Statistical Association, died Saturday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. She was 91 years old and lived in Teaneck.

title: Hofstra 81 Loyola, Maryland 69
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - David Taylor scored 25 points to lead Hofstra. Taylor, a 6-8 senior from Long Beach, L.I., scored 14 of his points in the second half as Hofstra (12-3) built a 21-point lead. Kevin House led the Loyola (0-11) with 25 points.

title: To Secure Social Security, for Now
description: The bipartisan rescue plan for Social Security finances isn't going to please anyone very much, which makes it politically potent, if not perfect. Conservatives will be unhappy about new taxes to raise some $88 billion over the decade. Liberals won't like the deferment of cost-of-living bonuses that will reduce benefits by $40 billion over the same period.

title: U.N. Arms Talks Resume
description: A United Nations working group resumed discussions today on the destruction and banning of chemical weapons. The group, a subsidiary of the 40-member Disarmament Conference, will report to the General Assembly late in the year.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE BREAKS. By Richard Price. 446 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: Starting Guard Quits at Texas
description: Jack Worthington, a sophomore starting guard, has left the University of Texas basketball team because of the ''pressure'' of the program, Coach Bob Weltlich said today.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: David Russell, St. John's senior forward, had X-rays taken of his left wrist yesterday, and although they were negative, the school says he is doubtful for tonight's game at home against Providence. ... Bucky Woy, the agent for Bob Horner, says the Atlanta Braves' power-hitting third baseman as agreed to a four-year contract worth more than $1 million a year. ... X-rays show that Pelle Lindbergh's wrist had been sprained, not broken, and that the Philadelphia Flyer goalie could be back on the ice next week. ... Neil Amdur, a sports reporter for The New York Times, received the Distinguished Media Service Award from the Association of Tennis Professionals at the association's annual dinner last night.

title: Harvester Plants
description: About 2,400 workers returned to their jobs for the first time in more than four months at two local International Harvester Company plants. Bill Greenhill, a Harvester spokesman in Chicago, said there were 3,200 working at the Rock Island tractor plant and the East Moline combine and parts plant. Some had remained on duty at the two plants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Terminal Decor

title: TV MOVIE: 'ILLUSIONS,' A CBS PUZZLER
description: FOR about the first hour of ''Illusions,'' tonight's made-fortelevision movie at 9 o'clock on CBS, interest builds at a fair pace in the tale of Linda, a perplexed young wife in San Francisco, who finds that her husband Larry was not the mere salesman of high-style clothing that she took him to be.

title: Conrail Protests Chessie's Tariffs
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation has filed a protest with the Interstate Commerce Commission charging that the Chessie System has made changes in its reciprocal switching tariffs that will have the effect of keeping rail prices artificially high for customers.

title: WALESA VOWS TO SUE FOR OLD JOB
description: Lech Walesa, who was head of the Solidarity union, which is now banned, said today that he would sue if necessary to win back his job at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk.

title: BANKERS TRUST OF SOUTH CAROLINA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: 3 Young New Yorkers Win Regional Swiss Team Title
description: The conclusion of the Tristate Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y., Sunday saw a victory for three young New York experts who have been consistently successful recently. The Swiss Team title went to Michael Rosmarin of Jamaica, Queens, Bob Jones of Auburndale, Queens, and Mel Colchamiro of Merrick, L.I., together with Ken Bercuson of Washington.

title: Cuomo to Reappoint Chief of Corrections
description: Governor Cuomo has decided to reappoint Thomas A. Coughlin, the state's Commissioner of Correction, and will announce the reappointment Tuesday, close aides of the Governor said tonight.

title: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Syracuse Downs Boston College, 102-85
description: Erich Santifer scored a career-high 30 points, and Tony Bruin had 29 as Syracuse built up an 11-point halftime lead and rolled to a 102-85 victory over Boston College tonight.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 18, 1983; International
description: Business and labor officials urged President Reagan to press for a wide array of trade concessions when he meets today with Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan, who is in Washington for a four-day visit. The aim of the trip is to try to repair serious strains in the two countries' relations. (Page A1.) Alaska proposed a $31.72 billion project to carry natural gas from its North Slope fields to a port where it would be liquefied and exported to Japan. The proposal was timed to coincide with Mr. Nakasone's visit. (D13.)

title: BAKER FENTRESS CO reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: ALLURE OF FLORIDA PALMS
description: It seemed about as nice a day as could be hoped for at this time of year. ''Could be better,'' said Don Pellegrini. ''It could be colder and rainy -maybe a little snow.'' Mr. Pellegrini sells Florida homes and lots here amid the Vision Center, Shoe Town and Pizza World on Old Country Road.

title: SHULA IS WARY OF JET RIVALRY
description: The last time one National Football League team defeated another three times in one season was 1965, when the Green Bay Packers beat the Baltimore Colts by scores of 20-17, 42-27 and 13-10. That third loss, in overtime of a conference playoff game, was most distressing for the Colts; it was decided by a field goal which, to this day, the Colts' coach suspects was not good.

title: GIVE NICARAGUA A CHANCE
description: Anastasio Somoza Debayle, when Nicaragua's dictator, once told Luis Echeverria, then President of Mexico: ''You should envy me. I have no problems. All I have to do is what Washington wants me to do.'' Today, Nicaragua's northern border is haunted by Somoza's ghosts: National Guardsmen of the ousted dictatorship, Honduran forces, Central Intelligence Agency hobgoblins. Their purpose is to make sure that once again Nicaragua does not give Washington headaches. But this situation, if unchecked, promises to give Washington its biggest headache since Vietnam.

title: A PESTICIDE, UNWELCOME ON LONG ISLAND, GOES SOUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBINSON EXCELS AS KNICKS TRIUMPH
description: Len (Truck) Robinson turned in his finest performance of the season last night as the Knicks defeated the Chicago Bulls, 119-109, at Madison Square Garden. Robinson, obtained in a trade for Maurice Lucas during the offseason, scored a season-high 26 points and got 13 rebounds.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRED M. HECHINGER
description: SOMETIMES, says Edward Miller, managing editor of Highwire magazine, he seems more like an English teacher than an editor. This is not surprising because he edits a magazine written mostly by students for students.

title: MONCHIK-WEBER ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A Rising Figure
description: Fred Sowerby could not believe his eyes last Sunday night, and when he told Howard Schmertz, the meet director for the Millrose Games, Schmertz could not believe his ears.

title: BLACKMUN ACCEPTS AFTERMATH OF WRITING ABORTION OPINION
description: ''Author of the abortion decision,'' Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun said softly and slowly, as if restudying the phrase. ''We all pick up tags. I'll carry this one to my grave.''

title: Code on Sprinklers Backed by Vergari
description: Saying that additional automatic sprinklers would have saved lives in the Stouffer's Inn fire in Harrison, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County today urged state officials to keep in a new statewide code a requirement for automatic sprinklers in public buildings.

title: CONCERT: WILLIE STARGELL AND EASTMAN ORCHESTRA
description: SINCE the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., many composers have used his speeches as inspiration or as text, or both. The assassinated civil-rights leader left a legacy of eloquence that naturally attracts musicians, who can appreciate the expressive power of his cadences and rhythms, not to mention the substance of his words. However, not many composers have successfully set anyone's inspirational prose, since the merger of prose and music is one of the trickiest of compositional problems.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAYOFFS AT MANSION PLANNED AS EXAMPLE FOR WEST VIRGINIA
description: This state's fiscal problems have extended to the Governor's mansion here, and Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th and his wife, Sharon, are giving up shrimp at receptions and making do with three fewer housekeepers for the next six months.

title: Mt. St. Helens Dam Holds Mud Off Cities, U.S. Says
description: Mudflows could bury cities up to 40 miles away if a dam built by debris in a lake at the base of the Mount St. Helens volcano should burst, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said today.

title: Pilots Resume El Al Flights
description: El Al resumed flying today after striking pilots returned to work under court-sanctioned threats of instant dismissal without severance pay if they refused to fly.

title: APPARENTLY A SUICIDE
description: Doodles Weaver, a rubber-faced comedian and musician who helped pioneer improvisational television comedy with his show in 1951, has died of what the police believed were self-inflicted gunshot wounds. He was 71 years old.

title: '84 OLYMPIC PLANS SAID TO BE ON SCHEDULE
description: Amateur athletic officials from round the world were told today that preparations for the 1984 Olympic Games were proceeding on schedule, and many said that they had no quarrel so far with the cost-cutting approach to the Games.

title: ADVANCED PATENT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
IMAGE
description: It is the small apartments of Paris, James Baldwin once said, that create the demand for cafes, bistros, tearooms and restaurants to complement private living space.

title: POSTAL SERVICE STUDY BY CONSUMER GROUP URGES NEW SUBSIDIES
description: The United States Postal Service, reorganized by Congress in 1970 to become self-supporting and independent of Federal aid, has turned its back on residential customers by cutting services and increasing postage rates, according to a report prepared by a Ralph Nader organization and made public here today.

title: PLASTIC WRAPPINGS DON'T ADD UP TO ART
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother, 34, Is Shot to Death Crossing Street With Children
description: A 34-year-old woman was shot dead as she crossed a busy intersection with her two young daughters in the Morrisania section of the Bronx shortly after 10 A.M. yesterday, the police said.

title: GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATOR INOUYE'S HAWAIIAN TOUCHES
description: Some of his aides were dismayed when Senator Daniel K. Inouye decided to move into the new Hart Senate Office Building.

title: DO GUNS CUT THE BUTTER?
description: Caspar W. Weinberger's proposal last w eek for limited cuts in the 1984 defense budget raises the question o f whether defense spending is good or bad for the economy - for u nemployment and fiscal problems. There are no easy answers to this q uestion, and both Congress and Secretary of Defense Weinberger have c onsiderable homework to do before making intelligent decisions abouth ow best to trim the defense budget.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Golden State Warriors vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Oakland, Calif. (Television - USA Cable, 10:30 P.M.) Colleges: Providence at St. John's, 8 P.M. The Redmen try to rebound from their first loss of the season against another tough Big East Conference rival.

title: No Headline
description: Jimmy Foster scored 17 of his 19 points in the first half as South Carolina (10-3) opened a 39-28 halftime lead.

title: The Fifth Man at a Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-MAYOR OF ENGLEWOOD ATTACKS CITY'S REJECTION OF LIBYAN MANSION
description: A former Mayor of Englewood, N.J., yesterday blamed ''self-styled Zionists'' for the city's opposition to the sale of a home to the chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations. The Rev. Walter S. Taylor, who was Mayor between 1972 and 1976, called on Englewood to ''let the Libyans in without vengeance, but with compassion.''

title: Talking Business with Gordon E. Moore of Intel
description: What I.B.M.'s Stake Means

title: THE MODERN MUSEUM'S NO-RISK PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is very hard to grasp what the reality of this place is.

title: A Parting Shot
description: Donnie Duncan, the Iowa State coach who is leaving football for a career in real estate, said yesterday that some of his rivals in the Big Eight had used dishonest recruiting methods and had ''bought'' key players. Duncan, who declined to name the offending coaches, said that his own recruiting had been honest during his four years at Iowa State.

title: OPERA: 'CATERINA CORNARO'
description: ''CATERINA CORNARO'' was the last of Donizetti's opera's to have a premiere during his lifetime. The composer did not want to write it; it was badly received and, according to the Bel Canto Opera, it did not receive a staged performance in North America until the company presented it Saturday night at Senator Robert F. Wagner Junior High School in Manhattan.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CANADA LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Hans Christensen, 58, Teacher Of Metalsmithing and Design
description: Hans Christensen, a silversmith who held the nation's only endowed chair in the crafts, was killed Sunday in an automobile accident in Henrietta, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester. He was 58 years old, and lived in Rochester.

title: People
description: * Richard L. Matthews named vice chairman/management committee of Kornhauser & Calene Inc.

title: Players Examine Basketball Books
description: The National Basketball Association, which has been crying poverty for a long time, has opened its books to the Players Association and now, after more than two months, the two sides are ready to resume bargaining today in Detroit on a new contract to replace the one that expired last June.

title: CITY PLAN TO CLOSE FISCAL GAP APPROVED DESPITE A WARNING
description: The State Municipal Assistance Corporation agreed yesterday to a refinancing plan that would allow New York City to postpone about $150 million in debt payments, but not without warning that the action could appear to be a budget gimmick.

title: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
General American
description: The General American Oil Company of Texas said 17.9 million of its shares had been tendered by last Friday's proration deadline in reponse to its $50-a-share offer, according to the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the company's depositor. General American said it would purchase 10.3 million, or 57.5 percent, of the shares tendered on a pro rata basis.

title: TV SNOBBERY'S SUPERLATIVE PRACTITIONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN AN EX-HOSTAGE THANKS HIS CAPTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.& T. Contract
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it had awarded its biggest fiber optic contract to its own manufacturing arm, the Western Electric Company.

title: PRECIOUS-METAL TRADERS CONVERT GAINS TO CASH
description: Prices of precious-metal futures yesterday ran into the inevitable profit taking that occurs after a long advance. Still, gold and silver futures managed to close with modest gains, while platinum finished with a small loss.

title: Setback In Africa
description: The Reagan Administration's attempt to reverse gears in southern Africa is moving us backward. Delegates from 30 African countries made that clear at the African-American Institute's conference here.

title: Tainted Food Is Investigated
description: Police investigating the mercury-contamination of an orange and a jar of mayonnaise purchased at stores less than a mile from each other said today that it may be impossible to link the two incidents. The police said the mercury was not toxic and that the stores had not received an extortion threat.

title: THE ADDICTIVE PERSONALITY: COMMON TRAITS ARE FOUND
description: Who is the addict? With addictive tragedies striking every community in the nation - with many millions of Americans addicted to alcohol and drugs alone - legions of scientists are asking: What aspects of psychological makeup contribute to addiction? Are there common threads that weave through all addictions, from hard drugs to cigarettes, from gambling to overeating?

title: APOLLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yugoslavia Discussing Debt Aid
description: Yugoslavia held talks today in Zurich with its creditor banks, starting a round of discussions expected to bring it relief from serious debt repayment problems, Swiss banking officials said.

title: Louisiana Bus Driver Is Slain
description: A woman with her 3-year-old daughter in tow cursed the driver of a public bus for not going her way, pulled a pistol from her purse and shot him to death, the authorities charged today.

title: H.U.D. SUSPENDS AIDE DURING INQUIRY
description: An Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Dr. E.S. Savas, was suspended from his post today after charges that he had used his staff during their working hours to edit and proofread a book he wrote.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: Strategy on Labor

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LAND, SEA, AIR

title: Judicial Mischief in New Orleans
description: The weekend furor over a televised segment on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' vividly illustrates how highly the nation values free expression and how firmly the Constitution condemns prior restraints against publishing and broadcasting. The case also shows that while constitutional priorities are clear to most judges, one who remains confused can cause untold mischief.

title: CITY REALTY TAX SET TO GO UP AS ASSESSMENTS INCREASE 5%
description: The taxable value of property in New York City has been tentatively assessed at $47.151 billion, an increase of $3.329 billion over the past year, the city's Finance Department announced yesterday.

title: Pacific Telephone
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said in a statement filed in Federal court here that although it was still not satisfied with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's divestiture plant, it now believed that the divestiture would leave Pacific Telephone as a viable entity. Pacific Telephone, which earlier had said that it would be threatened by the plan to split up the Bell System, said it had modified its opinion as a result of Congress's resolution of Pacific Telephone's back-tax case, which eliminated most of its $1.2 billion back-tax liability.

title: Virginia 66, Ga. Tech 52
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Ricky Stokes scored 5 points during a 13-0 spurt that erased a 6-point, second-half deficit for Virginia. Georgia Tech held a 40-34 lead with 15:12 remaining before the Cavaliers rallied. Othell Wilson sank two free throws and Craig Robinson scored from the baseline before Stokes converted a 3-point play on a driving layup with 11:51 remaining to give Virginia the lead for good at 41-40.

title: TWO CONTENDERS QUITTING RACE FOR ROSENTHAL SEAT
description: The two leading contenders for the Democratic nomination to succeed the late Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal surprised Democratic leaders in Queens yesterday by dropping out of the race.

title: CARTER AND FORD CRITICIZE ISRAELIS
description: Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford contend that the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza by the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is ''the major obstacle to any moderate Arab initiatives'' for peace in the Middle East.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS CHALLENGING STATES' POWERS IN COURT
description: The rapid rise of conservative Christian day schools in recent years has brought with it a series of legal challenges to the rarely contested right of the states to set minimum educational standards and otherwise regulate the primary and secondary education children within their borders shall receive. The courts are now being called upon to decide cases that are cast as struggles between religious freedom and state law - issues that have long lain dormant among mainstream parochial schools, where the biggest controversies have concerned state benefactions to religious schools - aid for textbooks, busing and school lunches, for example.

title: 3 Are Questionable
description: Three Cowboys were listed as questionable for Saturday's game. The defensive tackle John Dutton has a bruised thigh and did not suit up against Green Bay; the reserve running back James Jones has an ailing left knee, and the fullback Ron Springs a sprained right knee.

title: Kidnapped Basque Free; Giant Ransom Reported
description: Suspected guerrilla kidnappers freed the son of a prominent Basque factory owner on a lonely country road today. Basque sources said they believed that a $1.3 million ransom was paid in full.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT BOMBED IRAN OIL PORT
description: Iraq said tonight that its planes had bombed Iran's main oil-export terminal at Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf and a gas plant near the southern Iranian city of Ahwaz, making ''accurate and effective'' hits on both.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NASSAU TRUST CO (GLEN COVE, NY) reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lewis Eyes 29-Foot Long Jump
description: Carl Lewis, often compared to Jesse Owens by track experts, said yesterday that his training progress was where he wanted it to be for the sprints and the long jump in the 1984 Olympic Games.

title: Market Place; General Public Turnaround
description: THE stock market's recent advance has been led by ''the generals,'' big-name companies such as General Motors and General Electric. But, in more modest fashion, another general has been advancing lately.

title: DALLAS FEARS RIGGINS MOST
description: John Riggins and the condition of the field were cited in that order today by Tom Landry when the Dallas Cowboys' coach discussed the National Conference championship game in Washington Saturday against the Redskins.

title: HALVERSON NAMED TO ACT AS HEAD OF CITY SCHOOLS
description: Richard F. Halverson was named yesterday to be Acting Chancellor of the New York City schools after Frank J. Macchiarola, the Chancellor, confirmed that he was giving up the post to be president and chief executive officer of the New York City Partnership, a coalition of business groups.

title: THOUSANDS OF QUAKES: WHAT DO THEY MEAN?
description: SEVERAL areas of the United States are trembling with persistent seismic activity, and in some instances - particularly in the East - scientists are at a loss to know why. In the last two weeks more than 3,000 temblors have shaken the Mammoth Lakes area of California. Since last June there have been 500 earthquakes in Moodus, Conn. Last June there were more than 19,000 quakes in a small area of northcentral Arkansas.

title: NETS STAGE RALLY BUT LOSE TO HAWKS
description: The Nets overcame a 12-point deficit in the final quarter tonight, but the Atlanta Hawks scored the final 7 points to defeat New Jersey, 102-96, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ashland Oil Prices
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said it would reduce by $1 a barrel the price it pays for 40-degree-gravity crude oil in the areas where it purchases crude, effective tomorrow. It will pay $31 a barrel in Louisiana and Mississippi, $30 in Illinois and Indiana, $26 in North Dakota and $39 in Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia. Ashland attributed the price cut to the declining value of the principal products refined from the crude.

title: Mancini's Real Name
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, who is in St. Vincent, Italy, preparing for a nontitle fight Feb. 6 against George Feeney of England, revealed something of a secret yesterday.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess: Korchnoi and Timman Tie In 6-Game Training Match
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, the former challenger for the world championship, played and tied a six-game training match with the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman in Hilversum, the Netherlands. Each won one game and drew the rest.

title: Bleeding May Complicate Case Of Artificial Heart Patient
description: Persistent bleeding from the nose prompted doctors Monday to reduce the amount of anticoagulant medicine given to Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, and renewed their concern that the complication may be serious.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Muddled Origins

title: Home Federal
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had approved the closure and liquidation of the Valley First Federal Savings and Loan Association of El Centro, Calif., and the immediate transfer of its insured accounts to the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego.

title: Meadowlands Gets Title Bout
description: S.T. Gordon will defend his World Boxing Council cruiserweight title Feb.16 against Jesse Burnett in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, it was announced yesterday by Don King, the promoter.

title: BRAZIL'S NORTHEAST IS WILTING UNDER A SMILING SKY
description: The headline in the newspaper O Estado seemed at odds with the facts. ''The Weather Worsens,'' it proclaimed on a splendid morning abounding in sunlight and blue sky.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All year-ago figures restated to reflect acquisition of Citizens National Bank of Naples in August 1982

title: Internorth to Join A Pipeline Project
description: Internorth Inc., an energy conglomerate, said it would join the Energy Transportation Systems Inc. group in a coal slurry pipeline project. Under the project, a 1,400-mile pipeline costing an etimated $3.8 billion would be built to carry 30 million tons of crushed coal and water a year from Wyoming to plants in Southern states.

title: An Appraisal
description: It was not so very long ago that the Mayflower Hotel on Central Park West at 61st Street was typical of the city's fine apartment buildings of the 1920's. Designed by Emery Roth, one of the city's great apartment-house architects, it was one of those solid brick structures whose boxiness was lightened by an overlay of handsome and graceful stone and terra cotta ornament. Today, however, the Mayflower is not at all like the buildings that are its peers - it is now a harsh and ponderous box, looking more like a warehouse than a residence. Every piece of ornament, from the cornice at the top to the window pediments toward the bottom, has been stripped, and the result is a building that might better be named the De-flower. The hotel looks as if someone had applied a huge sanding machine to its facades, smoothing over everything and removing any object that dared project beyond the surface.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings are adjusted for the conversion of outstanding preferred shrs intoClass A common and Class B shrs in 1981

title: PLAYERS
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. T he bright lights were shining on Michael Adams on Saturday night after the biggest game of his life, and a crowd was listening to everything he said. Not far away in the Boston College basketball team's locker room, shortly after Adams had scored 27 points and had made eight steals in the victory over previously unbeaten St. John's, Kevin Mackey, the associate coach, stood and watched. ''I couldn't get over it,'' he said. ''All the cameras, all the writers. A year and a half ago, no one knew who he was, and no one wanted to know.''

title: 'ENTERTAINMENT TONIGHT,' TELEVISION'S 'NEWSZAK'
description: With a cheerful smile, the anchor makes her introduction. Coming up, she says: is a special report on ''the Broadway shows which have been blazing with glory ever since the current season began on June 1.''

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST AMERICAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 JERSEY OFFICIALS FREE OF CONFLICT, GOVERNOR FINDS
description: Governor Kean said today that he would not ask two state officials to divest themselves of stock or sever business connections with two companies that are bidding to operate proposed state video lottery games. The games are scheduled to be installed in hundreds of taverns and liquor stores this summer.

title: Advertising; A 'New Attitude' At Cuisine
description: THERE are so many things happening over at CBS Publications' Cuisine magazine with the February issue that it's enough to make your head swim. Or spin.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GROMYKO WARNS GERMANS OF RISK IF NEW U.S. MISSILES ARE DEPLOYED
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said tonight that West Germany would be caught in a sharpened nuclear confrontation if a new generation of American medium-range missiles was stationed in Western Europe.

title: DOW ADVANCES 3.96, TO 1,084.81
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, spurred by expectations of a cut in interest rates and by strong performances by American Telephone and International Business Machines, the market's current bellwethers.

title: PRESIDENT OF AMERICAN EXPRESS QUITS
description: The American Express Company lost its third senior executive in the past six weeks yesterday, when Alva O. Way, president of the company since 1981, resigned to become president of the Travelers Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest diversified financial services company.

title: DR. HILTON H. STOTHERS
description: Dr. Hilton H. Stothers, a surgeon, died Friday at Amsterdam House, a nursing home in Manhattan.

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIGHT OF NEW YORK'S HOMELESS PROMPTS GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the sight of the homeless and the wandering poor on the streets of New York is the most compelling reason for giving.

title: MERGER ACCORD SET BY DATA TERMINAL
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation agreed to acquire Data Terminal Systems Inc. in a twostep transaction valued at up to $50 million, the companies said today. They said National Semiconductor would offer $8 a share for up to 4.31 million, or about two-thirds, of Data Terminal's shares.

title: No Real Losers
description: The firemen defeated the policemen, 9-2, to even their 10-year-old ice hockey series at five games each, but goals were not the only way to keep score of the roughly played contest last Sunday night before a crowd of 10,000 at Madison Square Garden.

title: 2 G.I.'s in Sinai Force Wounded in Mine Blast
description: Two American members of the international peacekeeping force in the Sinai Peninsula were wounded, one seriously, by a mine explosion in the peninsula today, the force announced.

title: CARNIVOROUS SHRIMP ADDS TO CLAMS' WOES
description: WHILE some clams are causing problems for humans, shrimp, it turns out, are making life miserable for clams. The clams, which sometimes cause hepatitis and other maladies in humans, are being threatened on the nation's East Coast by a previously unsuspected predator - the snapping shrimp.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP INC (WATERBURY, CONN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings; C-net income

title: OPERA: SHIFTS IN 'TROVATORE'
description: THERE was a cast change within a cast change at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night. Adelaide Negri, the Argentinian soprano, was to have taken over the role of Leonora in Verdi's ''Il Trovatore'' but, being ill, gave way to Margarita Castro-Alberty.

title: Credit From Modell
description: Dr. Greg Collins, a consulting physician for the Cleveland Browns, has been credited by the Browns' owner, Art Modell, with successfully treating ''more than one'' Browns player for alcoholism and drug abuse. With the exception of Charles White, the Browns' running back who acknowledged his own problem and underwent four weeks of hospital treatment last summer, Modell would not identify the players in Dr. Collins's rehabilitation program.

title: TALKS IN LEBANON TURN TO SUBSTANCE
description: With a three-week-old argument over an agenda settled, Lebanese, Israeli and American negotiators held their first round of substantive negotiations today, focusing on how to end the state of war that has existed between Lebanon and Israel since the first Arab-Israeli war, in 1948.

title: END PRODUCTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ron Reagan Leaves Joffrey Ballet Company
description: The Joffrey Ballet announced yesterday that it has released Ron Reagan from his contract, effective immediately. Mr. Reagan, 24, a corps de ballet dancer with the company and a son of President Reagan, had asked for early release from the contract, which would have run through July 31, 1983.

description: B-Including tax credits of $149,000 for the latest first quarter and $299,000 for the year-ago first quarter

CUOMO'S REVENUE QUEST
description: The language of state budgets does not make for exciting reading. ''Forward commitment program,'' ''participation mortgage loans,'' ''tax-exempt borrowing'' and ''financial control capacity'' are not phrases that find their way into interviews on the happy-talk television news smile-a-thons.

title: BANK OF COMMERCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HORSE LOVERS TRY TO PRESERVE CITY'S UPSTATE FARM
description: An obscure piece of Orange County real estate owned by the people of New York City has become the focus of a bitter dispute between Koch administration officials, who would close it as an economy move, and horse lovers who want it to remain open.

title: WEYERHAEUSER UP; BOISE CASCADE OFF
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 rose 21.7 percent because of extraordinary gains, although sales declined 10 percent.

title: NATHAN AWARD IS WON BY JULIUS NOVICK
description: Julius Novick, a theater critic for The Village Voice, has been named winner of the George Jean Nathan Award for dramatic criticism. Mr. Novick will be presented with a check for $5,000 at a reception Feb. 7.

description: The Long, Cold Line

title: ALASKA SEEKS NEW NATURAL GAS PIPELINE
description: Alaska proposed a $31.72 billion project today to carry natural gas from its North Slope fields to a southern ice-free port where it would be liquefied and exported to Japan.

title: Eric Curwain, 83, Dies; British Wartime Agent
description: Eric Curwain, the British secret agent whose radio message from a Warsaw attic told Britain that the Nazi invasion of Poland had started, died Saturday. He was 83 years old.

title: JUSTICES TO DECIDE UNWED FATHER'S BID FOR CUSTODY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to define the right of an unmarried father to keep and raise his illegitimate child over the objections of the natural mother.

Why Holiday Inns And Y.& R. Split Up
description: While it is fairly well known that Campbell-Ewald and Kenyon & Eckhardt are finalists in a competition for the Holiday Inns account, the Memphis-based client only yesterday got around to officially severing its relationship with Young & Rubicam after seven years.

title: U.S. Won't Prosecute Schumer on '80 Race
description: The Department of Justice said today that it would not prosecute Representative Charles E. Schumer, whose 1980 campaign for the House of Representatives had been under scrutiny by the United States Attorney in Brooklyn.

title: SALVADORAN MILITARY POURS 4,000 TROOPS INTO COUNTERATTACK
description: The Salvadoran Government rushed 4,200 soldiers into Morazan Province today to try to counter gains by leftist guerrillas in the mountainous area of northeastern El Salvador.

description: Interest rates were mixed but little changed yesterday as credit market participants continue to wait for moves by the Federal Reserve to bring down short-term interest rates.

title: HOMELESS GET PLACE TO SLEEP ATOP NOB HILL
description: Fifty-four homeless people, waiting for their new shelter to open, lined up outside Grace Cathedral in the Nob Hill district, where imposing mansions were built from Gold Rush fortunes.

description: A sky-diving pig act at a music festival was postponed Sunday under pressure from an animal protection group that threatened to seek charges.

description: American business and labor representatives urged President Reagan today to press for a wide range of trade concessions in his White House meeting Tuesday with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan.

Los Angeles to Disband Police Undercover Unit
description: The City Police Commission voted unanimously today to disband the Los Angeles Police Department's Public Disorder Intelligence Division, an undercover unit that is under investigation for spying on city officials and lawful civic organizations.

title: STATE STUDY FINDS CORRUPTION IN CO-OP CITY REPAIR PROGRAM
description: A $150 million program to correct construction defects at Co-op City in the Bronx is ''beset by wide-ranging mismanagement, waste and corruption,'' the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

description: A dissenting member of the National Commission on Social Security Reform said today that the panel's plan to shore up the system would still leave its stability in doubt.

L.I.U. 80, St. Francis 70
description: Russell Davis connected on a jump shot four minutes into the second half to break a 43-43 tie, and Long Island University went on to win an Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro North game.

title: HARVESTER ASSESSES CHANCES OF SURVIVAL
description: The International Harvester Company disclosed in a 10-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it was ''rapidly exhausting the possibilities of further means to raise cash and reduce costs.'' It said it might be forced into bankruptcy if its latest restructuring plans failed and its markets did not recover.

title: Advertising; Klugman For Canon Copiers

He invited in his 14 area sales managers to vote for the personality. And having considered such characteristics as credibility, handsomeness and popularity they settled on Jack Klugman, half of the ''Odd Couple'' and now star of the TV ''Quincy'' series.

title: 'LIANNA,' FACULTY WIFE WITH MARITAL WOES
description: JOHN SAYLES has at least two and maybe three different personalities as an artist. He is a serious novelist (''Pride of the Bimbos''), the author or co-author of a number of quite wonderfully uninhibited screenplays for such B-movies as ''Battle Beyond the Stars'' and ''Alligator,'' as well as the writer-director of his own, far less hysterical films beginning with ''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'' and now including ''Lianna.''

description: Nancy Hanks, who twisted arms and charmed opponents in Congress and all over the country urging support for the arts, was remembered yesterday by Beverly Sills, Billy Taylor, Laurance S. Rockefeller and other friends and admirers at a memorial service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new equipment subsidiary, American Bell, yesterday introduced an office telephone system that pushed the company further into the office automation business.

description: Wang Laboratories Inc., an office automation company dominated by its founder, An Wang, yesterday announced the naming of a new president and a new vice chairman.

title: Business Asks Budget Cuts
description: Three leading business groups, fearing that the nation's economy is too weak to recover in the face of large Federal budget deficits, today urged Congress and the Reagan Administration to reduce spending sharply for defense, Social Security and other programs.

title: GETTING THE BEST AT THE HEIGHT OF CITRUS
description: THE citrus season, when produce stands are banked with the greatest variety of bright, shiny yellow and orange fruit, runs from November until April. Right now is the best time for eating your orange rather than just drinking its juice.

description: ''I'm just a country boy, living on the same farm I grew up on,'' said Enos Slaughter. ''There's this pond on it and I can just about open my window and go fishing from there.

description: THE need for improving productivity has changed some companies' whole approach to human resources, according to a survey recently made by A.T. Kearney Inc., a management consulting concern.

title: China Car Rentals
description: National Car Rental System Inc. of the United States now has a representative in China that will accept National's credit cards and advance reservations from its worldwide system, officials of Minneapolis-based National said. Starting Feb. 15 in Peking and other major cities, National customers will be able to reserve a car with driver. China does not have rental cars that can be driven by the customer.
