title: Market Place; Bank Stocks Downgraded
description: IN a delicately worded study, Merrill Lynch has reduced its investment opinion for the intermediate term on all big money-center banks for which it carried a ''buy'' or ''O.K. to buy'' rating.

title: Financial Net Shifts Carrier
description: The Financial News Network said today that it had raised $3.6 million through a new issue of 1.7 million common shares and that it intended to expand its programming day soon to twelve hours, from seven.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IN his indefatigable way, Lewis Burke Frumkes has been immersing himself in Gotham's continuing-education offerings. These everproliferating courses range from the useful, to the precious, to the bizarre, and Mr. Frumkes believes his expertise is now sufficient to justify starting his own school, ''The Education Exchange.'' Here are excerpts from his new catalogue: INTELLIGENCE 101 - WORKSHOP

title: GROMYKO REJECTS THE ZERO OPTION
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today rejected the Reagan Administration's ''zero option'' negotiating position at the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles. He blamed ''those who stand at the rudder'' in the United States for hindering progress in the talks.

title: SLUMP EVEN SLOWS NATION'S DRINKING
description: When things go wrong with the economy, the alcoholic beverage business usually holds its own. Drinking customs resist change, and almost anybody can afford a glass of beer. But in today's recession, many drinkers have reduced their intake or switched to less expensive drinks, and the $47 billion industry is suffering.

title: START WITH LEFTOVERS AND THE REST IS GRAVY
description: THIS is the tale of an incredible gravy whose five-day sojourn in the refrigerator was an inspiration to the cook, a gravy of such finesse that ... ''Oh, come, come,'' the skeptic objects. ''Leftover gravy, even if it is not five days old, is cold comfort indeed. What an unpromising beginning for a piece.''

title: Seagram to Close Louisville Plant
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons said it plans to phase out bottling and shipping operations at its Louisville plant by the end of April, close the plant by July and sell the 57-acre site.

title: FUNDS FOR AMERICAN ARTISTS PROPOSED
description: Paul H. Elicker, chairman of the SCM Corporation, called today for a greater role by the Federal Government in helping Ameicans take part in foreign art competitions.

title: Mexico Issues Request To Foreign Reporters
description: The Interior Ministry asked foreign magazine and newspaper correspondents today to voluntarily submit to the ministry copies of articles that they send abroad.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OFFICIALS GOVERN JERSEY BOROUGH FROM ELKS LODGE
description: The Borough of New Milford was conducting its business today from an auditorium at the Elks Lodge after a fire Monday caused extensive damage to the Municipal Building and destroyed the borough's tax records.

title: INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES READIER TO EXPAND
description: Finance ministers from 11 major industrial nations indicated today that they were much readier to stimulate their economies than they had been just a few weeks ago. The turnaround was attributed to the need to solve the persistent international debt crisis.

title: PROTEGEE OF KARAJAN IS HIRED
description: Herbert von Karajan, chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, says he fully supported the decision of Peter Girth, the orchestra manager, to give a one-year contract to Mr. Karajan's protegee, a virtuoso clarine@tist, over the protests of outraged orchestra members.

title: PRETORIA TAKES DIRECT CONTROL OVER NAMIBIA
description: South Africa dissolved the four-year-old National Assembly in South-West Africa today and announced that it was resuming direct rule.

title: 13% DROP IN HOUSING STARTS
description: Slowed by bad weather, housing starts fell 13 percent in December, to an annual rate of 1.22 million, the Government reported today. For all of 1982, work was started on just 1.061 million units, the lowest number since 1946.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rhone-Poulenc Plans
description: State-owned Rhone-Poulenc S.A. plans to step up investment to the equivalent of $450 million annually over the next three years from the equivalent of $300 million, a company spokesman said today.

title: Warner to Buy Pirates Interest
description: Warner Communications, which owns the Cosmos and has long sought an interest in a major league baseball team, will buy 48 percent of the Pittsburgh Pirates in a stock transaction announced today.

title: BLISS, A T, & CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Louisville 63, Tulane 55
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Milt Wagner led a 16-6 first-half scoring spurt to open a 10-point lead and pace the Cardinals (14-2) to a Metro Conference victory.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Broader Sulfite Review

title: FOR THE UPWARDLY MOBILE, WINE-TECH
description: JUST a glance at the current stack of catalogues shows a trend away from food-tech - machines that do unspeakable things to vegetables - to wine-tech - wine glasses, wine decanters, wine chillers, wine baskets, and, so help us, pneumatic corkscrews. Together, they threaten to do to drinking in the 80's what the Cuisinart did to eating in the 70's: raise it from a simple pleasure to an art form. It will no longer be enough to drink wine. In the 80's, you must revere it.

title: Florida Jury Selected At Trial of U.S. Judge
description: A jury of six men and six women was seated today in the trial of a Federal district judge who is charged with conspiracy to solicit a bribe and with obstruction of justice.

title: A Second Chance
description: Bernard Randolph, who was suspended from the DePaul basketball team after shouting criticism at his teammates during a loss to Loyola of Chicago last Wednesday, has been reinstated, but not as a starter. ''In coming back to the team, Bernard understood he would be the lowest man on the totem pole,'' said Coach Ray Meyer, adding that Randolph would have to ''work his way up from the bottom.''

title: FOR TEXAS, A DEMOCRAT IS BACK AT THE CONTROLS
description: Mark White took the oath to become the new Governor of Texas today and minutes later led a fervent crowd of about a thousand well-wishers through a chilly downpour to the gates of the Governor's mansion.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Keeping in Touch In the Tunnels

title: U.S. AND HONDURAS TO HOLD MANEUVERS CLOSE TO NICARAGUA
description: About 900 Army, Navy and Air Force personnel will take part next month in maneuvers in Honduras that will include a helicopter lift of Honduran soldiers into an area near the Nicaraguan border, the Pentagon said today.

title: Yankees Appoint Aide
description: Murray Cook, the director of scouting for the Pittsburgh Pirates, is moving to the Yankees as director of player development and scouting. He replaces Bill Livesey, who will manage the Yankees' farm team in Oneonta, N.Y. ... Bill Almon, the Chicago White Sox shortstop who became a free agent, signed a contract with the Oakland A's.

title: Energy Dept.'s No.2 to Leave
description: President Reagan has accepted the resignation of the Deputy Secretary of Energy, W. Kenneth Davis, the department announced. Mr. Davis, 64 years old, is expected to return to the private sector but it is not known whether he will rejoin the Bechtel Corporation, the large construction company based in San Francisco. Mr. Davis was a Bechtel vice president before taking the No.2 Energy Department spot under Secretary James B. Edwards.

title: Costly One-Course Meal
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Von Schamann Injured
description: The Dolphins learned today that Uwe von Schamann, their place-kicker, has a hairline fracture of a small bone in his back. The injury is not considered serious, and Coach Don Shula of Miami said he expected the kicker to handle extra-point attempts and field goals in Sunday's American Conference championship game here against the Jets. But the injury may limit von Schamann's range, as well as prevent him from kicking off.

title: Thorpe's Medals Returned
description: More than 70 years after he won them, Jim Thorpe's Olympic gold medals were returned to him posthumously today. Thorpe, who left an Indian reservation in rural Oklahoma to become perhaps the best all-round athlete that America has ever produced, surrendered the medals he won in the decathlon and pentathlon events in the 1912 Games at Stockholm after admitting that he had previously played two seasons as a $60-a-month semipro baseball player. In addition, his victories were expunged from the official Olympic record books.

title: Suntory-Anheuser
description: Suntory, the Japanese brewer, said it had agreed with the Anheuser-Busch Companies to produce Budweiser beer in Japan starting early next year.

title: EARLY 'ELECTIONEERING'
description: To the Editor:

title: POP MUSIC: MEL TORME'S HACKENSACK SERIES
description: MEL TORME'S salutes to jazz last weekend at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J., sustained a level of musical quality that one rarely encounters in any concert hall. The spark that gave these concerts a special excitement was provided by Rob McConnell and the Boss Brass, a highly reputed 21-piece jazz band from Toronto who were making their local debuts.

title: SOMERVILLE BELKIN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
THE NAKSONE TALKS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan had a pleasant and useful meeting here, but most of their economic and military differences were passed on to their subordinates for analysis until they meet again in Tokyo, probably in the autumn.

title: Diet COLA for the Poor
description: Washington's phrase of the day appears to be ''COLA delay,'' and superficially, it sounds defensible. But if it's applied to feeding the poor, it would mean only one thing: hunger.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HEMOPHILIAC GROUP WANTS BAR TO BLOOD LINKED TO SYNDROME
description: A ban on accepting blood donations that may reach hemophiliacs from those likely to be carriers of a disease that cripples the body's immune system has been recommended by the Medical and Scientific Advisory Council of the National Hemophilia Foundation.

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Dec 30, 1982

title: GEORGE KILLION, 81, A LEADER IN SHIP INDUSTRY AND POLITICS
description: George L. Killion, a former president of the American President Lines shipping company and a leading figure in Democratic Party politics, died Sunday of cardiorespiratory arrest at the Stanford University Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
76ers Capture 12th Straight
description: The Philadelphia 76ers tied a club record tonight by defeating the Cleveland Cavaliers, 98-90, for their 12th consecutive victory.

title: Japan's Steel Output Off
description: Japan's production of crude steel totaled 99.549 million metric tons in 1982, slipping below the level of 100 million tons for the first time in 10 years, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation announced today. A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds.

title: NATIONAL CENTRAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Watt Sees Reservations As Failure of Socialism
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt Tuesday called Indian reservations ''an example of the failure of socialism.''

title: SEOUL ACTING TO END POLITICAL BAN
description: President Chun Doo Hwan said today that he would move to lift the ban on 567 politicians barred from politics two years ago.

title: WAJDA'S FILM ON DANTON ANGERS THE FRENCH LEFT
description: When President Francois Mitterrand of France saw ''Danton,'' a new film about the French Revolution by the distinguished Polish director Andrzej Wajda, he left before the titles were finished to avoid answering questions about his reaction. It was a somewhat surprising disappearance since his Government had helped to finance the film.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $127,000 from discontinued operations...C-Incl uding income of$44,000 from discontinued operations

title: CUOMO PLEDGES OPENNESS WITH PRESS
description: After several weeks of internal discussion, Governor Cuomo announced today that his administration would follow a policy of ''openness and candor'' with the press.

title: FAMILY FOOD SHOPS, LOVINGLY PRESERVED
description: FOR New York families like the Allevas, the Anagnostous and the Fables, the Kurowyckys and the Weisses, a store, their store, is a living organism requiring, more often demanding, a constant nourishment that only they as families can provide with the labors of their hands and heads. Their lives are their stores, their stores their lives.

title: THE BIRTHDAY GIFT OF AMERICAN CITIZENSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: HEART RECIPIENT GETS SURGERY
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the first permanent artificial heart, was taken back into surgery late today, and two arteries in his left nasal passage that had been bleeding for 10 days were successfully sealed.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the New York Jets in Sports Pages yesterday gave an incorrect figure for Freeman McNeil's rushing total last Saturday. It was 105 yards.

title: A Legal Settlement
description: Quintin Dailey of the Chicago Bulls may be spared a civil trial growing out of his admitted assault on a nursing student in 1981 while he was attending the University of San Francisco. His lawyer, George C. Walker, said that he had reached a basic agreement on an out-of-court settlement of a $300,000 damage suit brought by Victoria Brick, the victim of the attack. Mr. Walker, who said that only a few minor details remained to be worked out, declined to discuss the provisions of the agreement.

title: KOCH OFFERS PLAN FOR 'DRAMATIC' CUT IN CITY'S SPENDING
description: Mayor Koch proposed a $16.5 billion preliminary budget yesterday for the next fiscal year. The Mayor said his proposal contained the most ''dramatic'' spending reductions and largest tax increases Text of Koch statement, page B4. that New Yorkers have faced since the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.

title: G.E. NET RISES 16% IN QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company, a diversified high-technology concern and the nation's leading electrical products company, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter increased 16 percent, while revenues slipped 1 percent.

title: NO VOTE ON MANDATORY STOVE LABELS
description: The Consumer Products Safety Commission postponed a vote today on whether to require detailed labels on woodand coal-burning stoves giving instructions on how to install and operate them. The vote was postponed because two of four commission members did not attend.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 figures were restated to reflect acquisition, McAllen State Bank, on apooling-of-interest basis

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdisco Corp. said its board would submit to shareholders a plan, calling for payment of $27.87 a share, for the company to go pivate in a merger with a concern owned by Bernard Goldberg, chairman.

title: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DISCOVERIES
description: THIS is the time for sniffles, sore throats and the aches and shivers of a cold or the flu. There's not much to do about it, except go to bed and let things run their course. One can, however, make the siege more comfortable with these small luxuries.

title: Golf Career in Danger
description: Stuart Hendley, the nation's top junior golfer, has been found to have a tumor on his leg that doctors say could end his career, but the high school senior has refused to accept that prognosis. ''They said I'd never play in another tournament, but they don't know me very well,'' said Hendley, who has some experience in overcoming handicaps.

title: DOLPHINS ADAPT TO ARNSPARGER METHOD
description: With his wire-framed glasses and his soft country drawl, Bill Arnsparger looks and sounds as if he would be more comfortable in a classroom than a locker room.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS BUYS FOREIGN UNITS OF BANK
description: Moving dramatically to increase its presence in international banking, the American Express Company announced yesterday that it was buying five European and Latin American operations of the Swiss-based Trade Development Bank Holding S.A. for $550 million in cash and securities.

title: Top Cowboy Draftee Starts to Contribute
description: Gil Brandt, who is in charge of new-talent acquisitions for the Dallas Cowboys, is sensitive about his firstround draft selections; the more obscure the athlete, the more acute the sensitivity.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mrs. Rosenthal Back in House Race
description: Lila Rosenthal, the wife of the late Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal said yesterday that she had ''reconsidered'' her decision of Monday and was ''actively going to seek the nomination'' for the House seat of the Queens Democrat.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: If the people building the New York Convention Center hadn't found Jerry Lowery in Houston, someone would have had to invent him. He is the perfect manager for this particular city and this particular project, a glass and metal grid behemoth of a gathering hall rising along the Hudson River.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $600,000 for the qr and $3 million for the yr...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $1.6 million

title: A CENTURY CLUB RULE IN NEED OF AN EXPLANATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Cincinnati Weighs Plan To Share Ballet Troupe
description: Cincinnati may soon share its resident ballet company with New Orleans in an arrangement that could set a precedent in the arts world.

title: JURY RETURNS GUILTY VERDICT IN MAIN LINE TRIPLE MURDER
description: A jury convicted Roger P. Buehl of first-degree murder today and recommended that he be sentenced to die in the electric chair for the slayings of a retired chairman of the Lockheed Corporation and two others.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS PROVIDENCE
description: David Russell, who started for St. John's against Providence last night despite a badly bruised left wrist, scored the first and last baskets of the game and had 20 points as St. John's won, 74-54, at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Fisheries Agency
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I would like to present a correction to Food Notes of Jan. 5.

title: Y.& R. Is Reunited With Pabst Brewing
description: Young & Rubicam, Chicago, which did advertising for Pabst Blue Ribbon and Andeker beers for two years starting in 1977, has been reunited with the Milwaukee-based Pabst Brewing and will be agency for Pabst Extra Light. That was the top of the account news yesterday.

title: Hijackers Release Hostages And Flee From a Thai Airport
description: Seven passengers were held hostage for six and a half hours today by three men who threatened to blow them up along with a Thai Airways plane if they were not given $13,000, three parachutes and another aircraft to fly them to northern Thailand.

title: PAC MONEY'S ROLE IN CONGRESS RAISES SUSPICIONS
description: Almost one-fourth of the House of Representatives, including the Speaker, the minority leader and other top leaders, raised more than half their 1982 campaign money from political action committees.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses of $489,000 for the qr and $10.9 million for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Including a gain of $2 million for the qr and a loss of $5.6 million for the yr from discontinued operations; shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid in Apr 1982 and payable in Mar 1983

title: A Title at the Waldorf
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In ''The Great Vintages of Alfred Knopf, 90'' (Jan. 12) you write that Claude Philippe was the chef at the Waldorf. His title was vice president in charge of sales and catering. JACK ROSEN Brooklyn

title: REPORTER'S CONVICTION UPHELD
description: New Brunswick's Court of Appeal has upheld the conviction of an American reporter, Beurmond Banville, for publishing restricted Canadian court proceedings in The Daily News in Bangor, Me. However, the court nullified the effect of the conviction on the reporter.

title: State Investigation Of Schumer Urged
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn has asked Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate charges that Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn illegally used State Assembly personnel and funds in his 1980 House race.

title: LCS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AIM Financial Services Inc., Boston, has named Frederick W. Newcomb president.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $237,000 for the quarter and $978,000 for the year; there were no share earnings for the latest quarter because preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded the net income

title: Rare Audible Is Right Call For Bruins
description: C alling an audible play is a familiar tactic in football - with the quarterback changing a pre-set play at the line of scrimmage. But it is rarely used in hockey, primarily because there is perhaps only one moment when there is enough time to call an audible - on the face-off. And even then a team is not assured of gaining the puck.

title: The Euromissile Misfire
description: The disclosure that American and Soviet negotiators informally explored a Euromissile compromise last July is a cause for hope - not the dismay implied by their Governments' disavowal of the deal. A good cause for dismay is the Reagan Administration's refusal, ever since, to permit the search for compromise to proceed.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AGAIN, FOR HIGHLAND SCOTS, THE SPECTER OF EVICTION
description: A century after hill farmers here on the Isle of Skye resisted eviction and helped end the infamous clearances, the people of this area and other parts of the rugged Scottish Highlands still cling to the land with fear and suspicion.

title: Topics; Updates; The Little Queen
description: To look at a photograph of Houston's Tent City is to remember ''My Man Godfrey,'' the 1930's film about a madcap heiress and the ''butler'' she found in a Hooverville. To hear a little girl ask her Mickey Mouse (no E.T. for her) if he's enjoying the bus ride, as we did recently, is to return to Saturday afternoon at the Bijou.

title: Thoughts on Borg From His Rivals
description: Can Bjorn Borg come back to the level of excellence he enjoyed as a five-time Wimbledon champion? Is the 26-year-old Swedish pro really hungry enough to chase the top spot in the men's game?

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include foreign currency translation gains of $8.4 million for the quarter and $30 million for the year; year-ago results include foreign currency translation gains of $9.7 million for the quarter and $22.2 million for the year

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have sold Jerry Garvin, a left-handed pitcher, to the St. Louis Cardinals. ... Michael Adams, a sophomore guard at Boston College, has been named the Big East Conference's player of the week. During the Eagles' upset victory over St. John's, Adams had 27 points, 8 steals and 5 assists.

title: Memphis Police Say Cult Members Fired; On Officers in Siege
description: The seven religious cult members who beat a patrolman to death after taking him hostage last week fired 12 shots at the assault team that stormed their house, the authorities said today.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITICORP PROFITS DROP 27%
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net operating income declined 27 percent from the period a year earlier, but some analysts contended that it was a fairly strong showing anyway.

title: THE ARABS' NEXT MOVE
description: At the heart of the recent dialogue between King Hussein and American officials is the credibility of American policy. The Arabs worry not only about the Administration's ability to carry out its expressed Middle East policies but also whether later administrations will feel committed to these policies.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $590,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 6 mos

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MERRILL BANKSHARES CO (BANGOR, ME) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 net income includes a gain of $1,748,000 from repurchase of debentures

title: Tennessee 73, Alabama 64
description: Tennessee's Michael Brooks scored 22 points and Tyrone Beaman hit four free throws in the final 1:19 as the Volunteers shook off persistent Alabama in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: WILLIAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $14,438,000, for the quarter and year, from an agreement to settle claims in class action lawsuits related to the sale of playwood; C-Net income

title: Spanish Abortionist Jailed
description: A nurse was sentenced today to 35 years in prison because he performed seven abortions, which are illegal in Spain. Six of the women who had the abortions received six-month sentences.

title: THEATER: 'TIBETAN BOOK OF THE DEAD'
description: AS a member of the Open Theater, Jean-Claude van Itallie wrote the text for ''The Serpent,'' a celebration of life as seen through the Book of Genesis. More than a dozen years later, the playwright contemplates death and dying in a new theater piece entitled ''The Tibetan Book of the Dead, or, How Not to Do It Again.'' As staged by Assurbanipal Babilla, an Iranian director, the work is now playing at La Mama Annex.

title: Long Teachers' Strike Ends in Pennsylvania
description: Pennsylvania's longest teachers' strike was settled today when both sides accepted a fact-finder's recommendations on salaries and layoffs to end the bitter 74-day walkout.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONE of the largest vintages in history has just gone into the cellars all over Europe, prompting many wine fanciers to reassess their holdings with an eye toward making room for the 1982's when they come on the market. It is also an appropriate time to re-evaluate some other recent harvests and update the vintage charts, for many wines not previously available are beginning to appear in stores and restaurants.

title: MANY ARCHITECTS ARE LOSING JOBS IN THE RECESSION
description: Scores of architects in New York City, the nation's leading architectural center, have been laid off in recent weeks as the recession has slowed or halted major commercial construction. Many firms have also stopped hiring and are undertaking strict costcutting measures.

title: TABLE-TOP HEATERS
description: YEARS ago, when fondue was the rage among Americans, every family seemed to have one of those little table-top heaters that were displayed when company came. Cheese would be melted in a pot over a Sterno flame and the guests would be given skewers with which to dip bread cubes into the molten mixture.

title: Flyers Halted
description: The Washington Capitals snapped Philadelphia's 12-game unbeaten streak by beating the Flyers, 4-1, tonight.

title: STEPHEN C. FLANDERS
description: Stephen C. Flanders, the chief political reporter for WCBS radio, died of a heart attack yesterday while on his way to a meeting at City Hall.

title: LeFlore to Stand Trial
description: A judge ruled in Chicago that Ron LeFlore, the White Sox outfielder, must stand trial on a drug-possession charge growing out of a search of his apartment last September. LeFlore had sought to have the charge dismissed on the ground that the 17 amphetamine pills the police say they found on his dresser could have belonged to any of several other people who were in the apartment at the time of the search. LeFlore declined to comment on the ruling.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 19, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.

title: BISHOPS IN VATICAN FOR NUCLEAR TALKS
description: Roman Catholic bishops from the United States who are drafting a pastoral letter opposing the use of nuclear weapons met today with European bishops and Vatican officials to obtain their views on the issue.

title: Union Oil Find Off California
description: The Union Oil Company of California said it had struck oil in the Santa Maria Basin, off the state's southern coast, where other companies last year made what was believed to be the biggest American oil discovery since Alaska's Prudhoe Bay field in 1968.

title: 20 GET CASH PRIZES IN 'GENIUS SEARCH'
description: A Chicago foundation interested in rewarding ''exceptionally talented individuals'' has selected 18 men and two women to receive prizes ranging from $24,000 to $60,000 annually for five years.

title: New Managing Partners Chosen at Lord, Abbett
description: Lord, Abbett & Company, manager of pension and mutual funds, named Ronald P. Lynch and John M. McCarthy as managing partners. The change follows the death on Jan.7 at age 69 of Alvin H. Berndt, who had been managing partner and chief executive. Mr. Lynch, 47, and Mr. McCarthy, 55, had worked closely with Mr. Berndt.

title: ISLANDERS WIN SIXTH STRAIGHT
description: By now, most of the Islanders have quelled the doubts that were raised about them in the first half of this season, when the club went through a 30-game slump. But there was one Islander who hadn't had his chance to snap out of the slump - until tonight.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Off 5.16 as Volume Drops
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday in slower trading as investors cashed in some of their recent gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced about 36 points since the beginning of the year, closed down 5.16 points, to 1,079.65. In the overall market, issues that declined on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 867 to 761.

title: Soviet's Spy Satellite Drops to Lower Orbit
description: The falling Soviet spy satellite Cosmos 1402 has dropped 2.5 miles closer to earth in the last 24 hours, to a low orbit of 126 miles, the Pentagon said today.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GISCARD AIDE FACES WAR-CRIMES CHARGE
description: A former high French Government official will be charged Wednesday with ''crimes against humanity'' in a case that has reopened one of the most sensitive questions in French life: the extent to which occupied France collaborated with the German Nazis in World War II.

title: ARTURO ILLIA, EX-PRESIDENT OF ARGENTINA, DIES AT 82
description: Former President Arturo Illia of Argentina died in a hospital today in Cordoba at the age of 82, hospital sources said. He had been admitted on Dec. 23 suffering from a lung ailment.

title: INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $21,000

title: BRIEFING
description: Reversal at Justice

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Ulster Guerrilla Warns of New Strife

title: Snowstorm in Eas
description: Gale-force winds and freak snow storms swept large parts of East Germany today, blocking railroads and felling trees and power lines.

title: A CENTURY CLUB RULE IN NEED OF AN EXPLANATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Tandy Computer
description: The Tandy Corporation said its Radio Shack division had introduced a new microcomputer, the TRS-80 model 12, and a 12-million-character hard disk drive system. Tandy said the new hardware would offer expandability, multi-language programming and increased data storage for applications requiring large information files or numerous transactions, such as inventory control, medical records, accounting or others.

title: PAINE WEBBER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the effectsof the 4-for-3 stock split declared Oct 26, 1982

title: VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $40,000 for the qr and $34,000 for the 6 mos and a net gain of $361,988 for the qr and 6 mos from the disposition of noncurrent assets of discontinued soft drink division

title: PAINE WEBBER UP SHARPLY
description: Paine Webber Inc., parent company of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, the brokerage house, reported yesterday that net earnings rose fourfold in the first quarter of its fiscal 1983 year to $28.08 million, or $1.95 a share, from $6.99 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes income of $879,000 from spunoff operations; year-ago results were restated to reflect the spinoff of Rollins Environmental Services Inc in Aug 1982

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ad Executive Indicted In Actor's Fatal Beating
description: A Manhattan advertising executive was charged with eight counts of perjury in connection with the fatal beating of his daughter's spurned suitor, according to an indictment unsealed yesterday.

title: Willie Stargell Has a New Team
description: I n his old clubhouse, there were always raucous jokes to keep down the tension. With his new team, the Eastman Philharmonia, Willie Stargell again found a way to make people relax.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net asset

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NCR UP
description: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter fell 14.7 percent, to $88 million, or $3.89 a share, from $103.2 million, or $4.49 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: 2 WRITERS GET 5-YEAR PRIZE
description: Cynthia Ozick and Raymond Carver, two critically acclaimed writers of fiction and nonfiction, have each been chosen to receive awards of $35,000 a year tax free for a minimum of five years. The grants are among the largest available to writers.

description: HAS the Reagan Administration changed its top economic priority from fighting inflation to pushing for economic recovery -not just for the United States but for the other leading countries of the industrial world?

title: Catching a Star
description: Stan White, the Detroit Lion linebacker who was one of the most militant leaders of last autumn's player strike, may now become the first leading National Football League player to jump to the new United States Football League. That prospect appeared to be in the offing yesterday when the Chicago Blitz called a news conference for today to announce the signing of ''a major National Football League player.'' Blitz officials would not say publicly who their catch was, but someone close to the negotiations identified him as White, an 11-year veteran scheduled to become a free agent when his contract with the Lions expires Feb. 1.

title: Martin Traced By Drug Agency
description: A Federal agent testified Monday that, through the use of electronic ''tracking and trace devices,'' the Drug Enforcement Administration had determined that the Dallas Cowboy defensive end Harvey Martin had contacted an admitted cocaine dealer.

title: Bridge:; Girl Is the Youngest to Be Life Master - for 12 Days
description: Track stars often have the experience of breaking a record only to have it surpassed within a few weeks, or even a few days. It is rare in a bridge context, but it happened recently to Adair Gellman of Bethesda, Md. On Oct. 24, at the age of 14 years, 6 months and 4 days, she became the youngest-ever life master among girls, breaking a record that had stood for six years.

title: PENALTY THREAT FAILS TO SLOW DAIRY PRODUCTION

title: Time With Children

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.6%
description: In a year of recession and layoffs, personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December and just 6.4 percent in all of 1982, the smallest gain in almost two decades but still enough to keep slightly ahead of inflation, Government figures showed today.

description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu left for Washington today after warning that the United States was in a position of inferiority in the arms race with the Soviet Union.

description: With New York City's fiscal prospects declining, Mayor Koch offers a new financial plan that, realistically, aims to balance his budget with a minimum of further outside help. He proposes to raise taxes, shrink payrolls by attrition and layoffs and reduce services.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nine Chicago Policemen Sentenced in Drug Case
description: Nine suspended police officers were sentenced to prison today for accepting bribes in a multimilliondollar drug operation. A 10th defendant is be sentenced later.

title: A CENTURY CLUB RULE IN NEED OF AN EXPLANATION
description: T o the Editor: I have read with interest the letters from members of the Century Club with regard to the admission of women (''Century Club: Male Bastion Is Challenged,'' news article Jan. 12). The names subscribed to the letters spoke volumes. The puzzle was to determine the foundations of the assertion that the presence of females would ''radically change the nature'' of the club.

title: FREE PUPIL RIDES MAY BE LIMITED BY SCHOOL BOARD
description: A plan that would increase the distance many pupils would have to live from schools to receive free transportation is among a package of items the New York City Board of Education will consider tonight to close a remaining budget deficit of $37 million. The original deficit was $73 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Dec. 29 about a Jewish chapel to be built at the United States Military Academy incorrectly described the relationship of the architect, Max Abramovitz, to the school. He was not a cadet.

title: Ex-Convict Guilty in Slayings
description: An ex-convict was found guilty last night of murder in the slayings of two Wall Street executives. The defendant, Nathan Dodell, 28 years old, of Manhattan, was convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in the June deaths of Michael Bonseiro, 32, of East Meadow, L.I., and Thomas Semple, 36, of Bloomfield, N.J. He was accused of killing the men during a robbery attempt in a men's room at 127 John Street. His job resume was found at the scene.

description: AT one time or another, perhaps just before a test, athletic contest, job interview or your wedding, you have no doubt developed a ''nervous stomach,'' suffering from cramps, gas and perhaps diarrhea.

title: MERGER OF TRADE AGENCIES IS HINTED
description: The Reagan Administration may ask Congress to combine the Government's foreign trade activities into a new trade agency that would be better able to handle conflicts with Japan and other countries, Administration officials said today.

Strange Accident
description: Steve Rosenbloom, former general manager of the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams, is in a New Orleans hospital recovering from what he has described as a freakish automobile accident last Sunday in which he suffered a fractured skull. His former wife, Renee Rosenbloom, who has been with him since the accident, said last night that Rosenbloom was driving a 1967 Glassic roadster, a fiberglassbodied replica of a 1931 Ford. Mrs. Rosenbloom said her husband told her he fell out of the car, which had no locks, and curtains instead of windows, when it ran off a curve on a cobble-stoned street and hit a loading dock.

title: Riggins Ends Silence
description: John Riggins broke an 18-month silence on interviews today, but declined to predict whether he would return to the Washington Redskins next season or become a free agent for the second time in his 11-year football career.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1983
description: International An unchanged U.S. stand on arms negotiations was indicated by Reagan Administration officials. They said that American representatives at the talks on limiting nuclear missiles would return to Geneva later this month with instructions to adhere firmly to the Administration's demand for reducing the missiles in Europe to zero. (Page A1, Column 1.) Andrei A. Gromyko rejected the Reagan Administration's ''zero option'' negotiating position at the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles. The Soviet Foreign Minister, speaking in Bonn, blamed ''those who stand at the rudder'' in Washington for hindering progress in the talks. (A11:1.)

title: RECITAL: INTROSPECTIVE MARILYN HORNE
description: THERE was a relaxed poise to Marilyn Horne's artful singing in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night, in the first of three scheduled recitals. After announcing that she was suffering from a cold and asking for the audience's indulgence, the mezzo-soprano went on to show that indulgence wasn't needed.

title: Upsala 90, City College 75
description: The Vikings (7-5) were led by Robert McCann's 28 points in the victory at Nat Holman Gym. Andre America scored 18 for City, which is 4-11.

title: LONG-TERM U.S. ISSUES OFF
description: Light but persistent selling eroded prices of long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday, while rates on bills and other short-term paper closed steady to slightly lower. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds finished with minor losses where changed at all.

title: 'DISARRAY' IN ATTENDANCE OFFICE LAID TO CUTS AND WEAK CONTROL
description: The New York City Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance, which is responsible for tracking down students who are long-term absentees, is badly managed and disorganized, according to board officials.

title: HIGH COURT WILL RULE ON LAW BARRING PICKETS AT ITS DOORS
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today in a case that struck close to home. At issue is a Federal law that bars picketing, distributing leaflets and demonstrating on the Supreme Court grounds, including the sidewalks that encircle the Court's square-block site on Capitol Hill.

title: Nakasone For Close U.S. Ties
description: Although Yasuhiro Nakasone took office as Japan's Prime Minister less than two months ago, he has spent his adult life in politics and has gained a reputation as a conservative who favors stronger national defense and close ties to the United States.

title: Ford-Carter Criticism Of Israel Pleases U.S.
description: The State Department expressed approval today of an article written by Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter in which the two former Presidents denounced Israeli policy on settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Topics; Updates; Playing Games
description: Stressful periods in history often produce emblematic games. It was Monopoly during the Great Depression, and you don't have to pass Go to learn why: It offered the delights of imaginary money, property and power.

description: WHEN preparing fish fillets in a professional kitchen I would almost invariably have added a ladle or so of court-bouillon, a wellseasoned liquid combined with vegetables, herbs and spices, and poached the fillets.

title: Newest Shrine
description: For six years, Bruce Pluckhahn has been scrounging flea markets and antique shops from Sixth Avenue to Paris in search of bowling memorabilia. What he has collected will, literally, fill a museum.

title: Bribery at Kodak
description: ROCHESTER Jan. 18 (AP) - The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating a bribery scheme at the Eastman Kodak Company in which some jobs were ''sold'' to prospective applicants, The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle reported. It said applicants paid up to $500 to at least two company employees for jobs at Kodak's Apparatus division. Kodak called the F.B.I. six months ago after hearing of ''payment for jobs,'' a company spokesman, Timothy Elliott, said.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: NEIL YOUNG'S fans have learned to expect the unexpected from him. In the course of his 15-year career, his records have ranged from the pure, lonesome sound of acoustic guitar, harmonica, and his reedy tenor voice to distorted heavy-metal rock, from songs with a topical bent to songs so personal nobody claimed to really understand them, from ragged, impromptu-sounding guitar and keyboard arrangements to pristine Nashville-style country-pop.

title: Zimbabwe Seizes Ex-Army Commander
description: The former Rhodesian Army commander, John Hickman, who led the war against black nationalists in the late 1970's, is being detained by authorities along with his business partner, Mr. Hickman's lawyers said today.

title: VIOLIN: RAFAIL SOBOLEVSKY
description: RAFAIL SOBOLEVSKY came to this country from the Soviet Union a few years ago and has been playing and teaching the violin from his base at Syracuse University ever since. Sunday night he gave his Carnegie Hall debut. Paul Ostrovsky was the pianist, and the music was by Brahms, Beethoven, Schubert, Shostakovich and Ravel.

title: Mexico Starts Jobs Program
description: The Government has announced a $2.7 billion emergency program aimed at generating up to 700,000 jobs in the face of some estimates that say 40 percent of the country's work force is unemployed or underemployed.

title: YEAR'S DECLINE 1.8%
description: The gross national product, the broadest measure of the nation's economy, declined at an annual rate of 2.5 percent in the final three months of last year, the Commerce Department reported today. For 1982 as a whole, it fell 1.8 percent, the sharpest year-to-year decline since 1946.

title: U.S. EXPERTS REPORT A FASTER RATE OF FALL FOR SOVIET'S SATELLITE
description: The falling Soviet reconnaissance satellite Cosmos 1402 is descending more rapidly now, at a rate of two to three miles a day, and a large fragment of it could plunge into the atmosphere as early as this weekend, according to United States intelligence experts.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH no home can be made completely burglar-proof, it can be made less inviting to burglars and prowlers. Burglars don't like to be delayed or to have attention called to them, so it helps to make their ''work'' either harder or noisier. An important defense, and the one requiring the smallest investment, is to have good locks on all doors and easily reached windows. The doors should have more than simple spring-latch locks (the kind that lock when the door is shut) because most of them can easily be forced with a credit card or similar piece of plastic. Doors should have at least one dead bolt, either as part of the main lock or separate from it. A dead bolt, which must be opened and closed with a key, has a rectangular bolt with a square end, which should project at least an inch into the door frame when locked.

title: Suriname Asks Envoy To Form Government
description: Suriname's military Government announced today that it had asked its Ambassador to the Netherlands, Hank Herrenberg, to form a new Government.

title: MEDVEDEV, A DISSIDENT HISTORIAN, IS GIVEN FORMAL WARNING IN SOVIET
description: Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident Marxist historian whose writings on Stalin, Khrushchev and other Soviet subjects have been published in the West, has been formally warned to halt his ''political lampooning'' or face criminal charges.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

description: The presidents of 39 private colleges in New York State announced their opposition today to the State University's plan to expand programs in engineering and technology.

title: Golden Bay Gets Zungul
description: Steve Zungul, the top scorer in the Major Indoor Soccer League, has cleared waivers and been traded to the Golden Bay Earthquakes, the Arrows said yesterday.

title: Syracuse Expels 2 Football Players
description: Jaime Covington, who led Syracuse's football team in rushing last season, and Jamie Kimmel, a defensive lineman, were expelled from school today for ''academic reasons.''

title: AMR Discloses Loss for 1982
description: The AMR Corporation, the holding company of American Airlines Inc., reported yesterday that, based on a preliminary, unaudited estimate, it would have a net loss of $19.6 million for 1982, in contrast to earnings of $47.4 million, or $1.21 a share, in 1981.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; An Argentine Dismisses 'Falkland Alert' Report

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RUBBINGS

title: SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
State Secret
description: Renaldo Snipes is rated ahead of Gerry Cooney and Hector Camacho ahead of Howard Davis Jr., according to the New York State Athletic Commission. The commission, planning a tournament this year to determine state champions in eight boxing divisions, does not expect to attract all its top-rated fighters.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Accu Test Systems Inc., an oilfield-supply testing company based in Houston, said it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, following the repossession of certain major pieces of equipment by its creditors.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Syria Says It Has Right To Deploy Missiles

title: KINGS DEFEAT KNICKS
description: Larry Drew scored 23 points and handed out nine assists for Kansas City as the Kings rallied for a 91-88 victory over the New York Knicks tonight.

title: Somalia Offers Ethiopia Talks on Border Feud
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia offered today to meet the Ethiopian leader Mengistu Haile Mariam to discuss an end to sporadic fighting on the border between their two countries.

title: The Governor's Court Case
description: It's not something Governor Cuomo will be sending to the State Assembly, but there is a piece of legislation he recommends: splitting professional basketball games into doubleheaders, with each half counting as a game.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $3,938,000 on sale of two department stores in California, $16,325,000 on sale of Royal Lahaina Hotel and $4,765,000 on other real property sales for quarter and year; C-Including income of $11,659,000 on real property sales; D-Including income of $2.3 million from discontinued operations, net gain of $5,572,000 on sale of airport concessions and net gain of $11,659,000 on real property sales

title: ATOM ENGINEER TESTIFIES HIS GUIDE WOULD HAVE PREVENTED ACCIDENT
description: An engineer in charge of analyzing safety measures for the manufacturer of the nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island testified yesterday that if his guidelines had been sent out to the operators of the plant the accident there never would have occurred.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A CASE IS MADE FOR OPTIMISM
description: Could the recovery turn out to be appreciably stronger than almost everyone expects? It has happened before. Although predictions for an anemic recovery still predominate, some economists foresee a somewhat snappier comeback.

title: HISTORIC HOUSE SOLD IN NATION'S CAPITAL
description: The Lindens, the historic 18th-century house that Mr. and Mrs. George Maurice Morris had dismantled in Danvers, Mass., some 50 years ago and reassembled here piece by piece, will shortly have another family joining the procession of people who have called the mansion home.

title: CAPITAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
N.C.A.A. Assailed by Jesse Jackson
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association imposed entrance-examination standards for Division I freshman athletes last week because ''white boys are inferior athletes to blacks,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson charged Tuesday.

title: 3 CANDIDATES FOR CHICAGO MAYOR CLASH IN DEBATE ON FINANCES
description: With one month left before the city's Democratic mayoral primary, campaigning between the three major contenders has heated up.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESIDENT IS REACHING OUT FOR ADVICE
description: Like other Presidents who have felt besieged by economic problems and press criticism, President Reagan has begun to reach outside his official family to call in prominent commentators, businessmen and politicians to chat with him about the nation's problems.

title: CARIBBEAN CRICKET IS A COUP FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: White South Africa, sports-mad but sportsstarved, appears to be trying to buy its way out of an international sports boycott over its policy of racial separation.

title: Serrano Stopped In Eighth Round
description: Roger Mayweather, in his 15th professional fight, won the World Boxing Association junior lightweight title tonight with an eighth-round knockout of Samuel Serrano.

title: Racal Earnings Rose in 1st Half
description: Racal Electronics P.L.C. said today that pretax earnings for the six months ending Oct. 15 rose 22.2 percent, to 47 million, or about $74 million at current exchange rates, from 38.4 million in the six-month period a year earlier. Turnover rose 18.3 percent, to about $567 million.

title: Mexico Clarifies Move On Foreign Reporters
description: The Mexican Government today denied issuing a request that foreign correspondents based here submit copies of their dispatches sent abroad.

title: James M. Geraghty, 78, Art Editor
description: James M. Geraghty, art editor of The New Yorker from 1939 until his retirement in 1973, died Sunday of a heart attack at his winter home in Venice, Fla. He was 78 years old and also lived in Weston, Conn.

title: TV: COLLEGE EDUCATION AT 'BASKETBALL MACHINE'
description: ''THE BASKETBALL MACHINE'' is a rewarding, yet exasperating piece of journalism, so effective in some ways, so evasive in others. The documentary, which is offered on ''CBS Reports'' at 10 o'clock tonight, on Channel 2, takes on a rich subject - the big business of intercollegiate basketball and its troubling effects on the players.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN PLANS $4 BILLION FOR WAR

title: PRIEST HELD POSTS IN BROOKLYN
description: The Rev. Robert P. Kennedy, the social action director of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn who took part in a wide variety of regional and national projects, died early yesterday at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: AN INVALID ARGUMENT AGAINST TAX INDEXING
description: To the Editor:

title: MODINE MANUFACTURINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: Strathclyde Bid Gains
description: The British Government's Trade Department said today that Anderson Strathclyde P.L.C.'s offer for shares in the National Mine Service Company of the United States would not be referred to the Monopolies Commission, meaning it may proceed. Anderson Strathclyde recently increased its tender offer for up to 2.45 million shares, or 50.5 percent, of National Mine to $13 a share from $12.50. The Longyear Company, part of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. group, is also bidding for National Mine shares.

title: Panhandle Fund
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said it had established an after-tax reserve of $26 million, or 63 cents a common share, for the company's cumulative investment in the proposed Alaskan natural gas pipeline because of uncertainty surrounding the project. The charge is to be reflected in fourth-quarter earnings, it said. The company noted that the sponsoring consortium had been unable last year to complete a feasible financing plan for the project, which it estimates will cost $30 billion for the pipeline and related facilities.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 25 percent stock divd issued in Jan 1983 and 577,500 additional shrs that were issued in Feb 1982

title: SOVIET SAYS JAPAN RISKS DEVASTATION
description: Moscow warned Japan tonight that it could face a retaliatory strike more devastating than the 1945 atomic bomb explosions if it agreed to the deployment of more weapons aimed at the Soviet Union.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including investment tax credits of $309,000 for the qr and $759,000 for the yr and an extraordinary tax credit of $1,225,000 for the yr...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $74,000 for the qr and $1,120,000 for the yr

title: SPAIN VS. BASQUE REBELS: WHAT PRICE TOUGHNESS?
description: The kidnapping of the son of a wealthy industrialist in the Basque region has called in doubt the Spanish Government's new policy of tough measures against terrorism.

title: North Sea Auction
description: The 15 oil blocks offered for auction this week in the eighth round of British North Sea licensing are likely to raise about $47 million for the Government, the Secretary of State for Energy, Nigel Lawson, said today.

title: McNeil Loses Yardage
description: Freeman McNeil of the Jets continues to lose yardage after the game is over. First, in the opening-round victory at Cincinnati, McNeil was credited with 211 rushing yards, which would have been a record for a National Football League playoff game, except that the total was 9 yards too many.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Golf Bob Hope Desert Classic, second round, at La Quinta, Calif. The only 90-hole tournament on the PGA Tour continues. Hockey Devils vs. St. Louis Blues, at Byrne Meaadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. New Jersey's Tapio Levo is the only defenseman in the National Hockey League who is leading his team in scoring.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $1,475,000 or 21 cents a shr on the sale of a cheese plant

title: KOCH SAYS 'NOT A SINGLE SYNAGOGUE' AIDS CITY'S PROGRAM FOR HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch chose a celebration at a West Side synagogue last night to complain that, among religious institutions providing beds for New York City's homeless population, ''there is not a single synagogue.''

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1982 TRADE SURPLUS OFF 21.2% IN JAPAN
description: Japan's trade surplus last year declined by 21.2 percent, to $6.88 billion, from $8.74 billion the year before, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: BEHIND ANGELO DONGHIA'S GRAY FLANNEL SUCCESS
description: WHEN Angelo Rafael Donghia arrived in New York in 1959, the decorating world still basked in the light of the pink silk lamp shade. Elsie de Wolfe and Syrie Maugham were decorating deities. Billy Baldwin was king. Arrayed beneath them, a small, select hierarchy led by Sister Parish, Dorothy Draper and Eleanor Brown ordered swags for the small, rich hierarchy of New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Palm Beach. The world had not yet been exposed to high tech or designer sheets.

title: PALOMAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: UNBEATEN ARKANSAS WINS 14th BY 69-55

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avis Rent A Car System has appointed John P. Kennedy vice president-operations.

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has supported President Reagan's foreign policy more completely than any other political leader in Western Europe, is starting to speak openly about the possibility of a short-term disarmament agreement with the Soviet Union that would fall short of Mr. Reagan's goals.

title: BANKAMERICA EARNINGS OFF 13.2% IN QUARTER
description: Two of the nation's largest banking organizations, the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco and the Continental Illinois Corporation of Chicago, yesterday reported sharp declines in fourth-quarter operating earnings.

title: Roundabout Ordeal for a Jet
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. T he first clue that something was wrong last Friday was when Kenny Neil looked around the terminal at La Guardia Airport and did not see a familiar face. There had just not been enough time for everything that Neil had to do that morning: the trip to the doctor, the mandatory team meeting at the Jet training facility, and the ride to the airport to catch the charter flight to Los Angeles for the playoff game last Saturday against the Raiders.

title: MITSUI MANUFACTURERS BANK (LOS ANGELES) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Club Mark for 76ers

title: STANDARD BROADCASTING LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
FRANK E. GAEBELEIN, AN EDUCATOR ON L.I., WRITER AND LECTURER
description: Frank E. Gaebelein, headmaster emeritus of the Stony Brook (L.I.) School, died yesterday of pneumonia at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 83 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1.9 million for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $223,671 for the qr and $396,217 for the 6 mos

title: William E. Martz, 37, Leading Chess Player
description: William Edward Martz, a leading American chess player for more than a decade, died of cancer on Monday in Milwaukee. He was 37 years old and lived in Wauwatosa, a Milwaukee suburb.

title: American General
description: The American General Corporation announced it would sell its Great Southern Life Insurance Company to the I.C.H. Corporation of Louisville, Ky., for $250 million.

title: Burglary Reported At Sentry Courier
description: A burglary occurred Tuesday night or early yesterday in the offices of the Bronx armored-car company that had been robbed last month of more than $11 million, the police said.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Greeks Protest a Freeze With Nationwide Strike
description: A nationwide work stoppage to protest a decision by the Government to freeze wages halted public transportation, closed schools and banks and stopped construction projects for today.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY IN MANHATTAN PLANNING TO RESIGN ON JUNE 1
description: John S. Martin Jr. announced yesterday that he would resign as the United States Attorney in Manhattan on June 1. Mr. Martin, who plans to return to private law practice, will complete three years of a term that normally runs for four years with the approval of the President. He was appointed when Jimmy Carter was President and was retained when President Reagan took office.

title: HAITIANS ARE HOLDING AMERICAN
description: A Haitian who has become a naturalized American citizen and lives on Long Island is being held by the Haitian Government for questioning about ''alleged involvement with Haitian dissident groups,'' according to John Caulfield, a State Department spokesman.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARCHITECTURAL CERAMICS SHOW
description: The art of using large-scale architectural ceramics to enhance public spaces is the subject of a new show at the Elements Gallery, where works by more than a dozen artists will be on display through Feb. 12.

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fixed-Income Prices Lower
description: Prices of fixed-income securities fell sharply yesterday as shortterm interest rates rose and investor concern mounted over the swelling calendar of Treasury borrowings. The concern was reflected by a general disinterest in the auction of two-year Treasury notes, which produced a much higher yield than had been expected on Tuesday.

title: World Fund Curbs Cited
description: A new agreement by industrial countries to make more funds available to nations in economic straits will not be used until the International Monetary Fund exhausts its own resources, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today.

title: OPENLY ARRIVED AT
description: When Woodrow Wilson included ''open covenants, openly arrived at'' among his Fourteen Points, diplomats the world over were dismayed at the American naivete. Wilson's right-hand man, Col. Edward House, hurried to assure them that ''openly arrived at'' meant only that secret agreements would not be binding, and was not intended to exclude confidential diplomatic negotiations.

title: U.S. Jobless Loan Sought by Jersey
description: The state will ask the Federal Government for a $130 million loan to cover unemployment benefits for March and April because its unemployment insurance trust fund has been ''drained,'' it was announced today.

title: The Chill Factor
description: The wind-chill factor at the Jets' training complex in Hempstead, L.I., was considerably below zero yesterday, when the team went through its practice session for the American Conference championship game Sunday at Miami.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: ROCKWELL POSTS A 13.6% GAIN
description: Aided by a significant increase in aerospace earnings, the Rockwell International Corporation reported yesterday that it had a 13.9 percent increase in net income for its first fiscal quarter.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wheeling Steel
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced price increases averaging 6 percent on some of its carbon and alloy sheet strip and plate products.

title: Market Place; A Goldbug's New Advice
description: LAST June 15, when the price of gold sank to $315 an ounce after having tumbled from its January 1980 record of $875, James Dines sent a telegram to subscribers of his investment advisory service.

title: MUSIC: THE PRESENT'S PAST
description: EVEN the present has a past. Given the self-contained isolation of most contemporary music, it is now possible for new-music groups to assemble historical programs. That is what the Bowery Ensemble did Tuesday night at Cooper Union, and an instructively pleasant evening it was.

title: BALCO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net loss; results have been adjusted to reflect an accounting change

title: SIMON, NORTON, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,435,000 or 16 cents a shr for the qr and6 mos from the purchase of debentures for sinking fund requirements, and incomefrom discontinued operations of $560,000 for the qr and $1,694,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago revs exclude $48,092,000 for the qr and $100,401,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: French Trade Deficit Wider
description: France today announced a 1982 trade deficit of $13.5 billion, which was lower than the Government had forecast but 50 percent higher than the 1981 figure.

title: CROMPTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Chase Lifts Payout
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation raised its dividend to 87 1/2 cents a common share from 85 cents, payable Feb. 15 to shareholders of record Feb.1. A spokesman for the company said, ''Excluding our Drysdale loss, we have shown an improvement on our return on assets and return on equity.''

title: 'GLOBAL AMBITIONS' UNBECOMING TO ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Theory of Relativity

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are not adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split payable Feb 10 to shareholders of record Jan 7

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
CENTRAL CAROLINA BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN CAUTIONS JAPAN OVER TRADE
description: President Reagan, cautioning that Japanese trade restrictions ''continue to weigh heavily'' on mutual relations, announced today that he and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan had agreed to press ahead with Japan's defensive rearmament and to study the issue of Japanese access to Alaskan oil.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS AND BANKER'S ROLE
description: Edmond J. Safra controls one of the biggest banking enterprises in the world, and he may soon become the largest single stockholder in the huge American Express Company.

title: OLD GLORIES OF CAPITOL BATHING TUBS
description: A century ago, a young Washington correspondent for a Cleveland newspaper wrote: ''The bathrooms of the Capitol are well patronized this season. Fifty members of the lower House take a bath every day, so the bath superintendent tells me, and nearly every Congressman has a bath now and then at the expense of Uncle Sam.''

title: NONRECOGNITION'S TRACK RECORD AS A U.S. WEAPON
description: To the Editor:

title: Pan Am Sets Refinancing
description: Pan American World Airways Inc., in a step that will ease its cash position, said that it had reached an agreement on the refinancing of about $82 million in payments that were due this year.

title: CUBS GET CEY FROM DODGERS
description: The Chicago Cubs acquired Ron Cey, the Los Angeles Dodgers' third baseman, in a trade for two minor-league players today.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Shot in Subways On Critical List
description: Two people were listed in critical condition yesterday after being shot in separate subway incidents in Brooklyn during Tuesday evening's rush hour, the police said yesterday.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NONPROFIT GROUPS FACE PENSION ISSUE
description: A bipartisan commission's proposal to require nonprofit institutions and their employees to pay Social Security taxes would bring more than a million additional people into the system and would supply the trust funds with more than $8 billion by the end of the decade.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy's Defense Sessions

title: SHAKEOUT IN RETAIL BUYING
description: When Henry Doneger started his buying office business in 1946, he benefited from retailers' need for help in filling their depleted merchandise pipelines. In those postwar years, some 65 buying office companies emerged to advise and assist thousands of retailers in placing orders.

title: Ham, First Chimp in Space, Dies in a Carolina Zoo at 26
description: Ham the chimpanzee, the first chimp to ride a rocket into space, is dead at the age of 26 after a brief career with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Israelis Will Reshape Zaire's Armed Forces
description: Israeli military advisers will restructure Zaire's 20,000-member armed forces under a fiveyear agreement between the two countries, President Mobutu Sese Seko said here today.

title: BRIBERY CASE AGAINST JUDGE CALLED 'JIGSAW PUZZLE'
description: Government prosecutors and defense lawyers here, trying the nation's first criminal case against a sitting Federal judge, agreed separately today that the largely circumstantial evidence in the case was subject to sharply differing interpretations.

title: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
22 IDENTIFIED BY ARMY 39 YEARS AFTER DEATH
description: The Army said today it had identified the remains of 22 soldiers killed in the World War II crash of a B-24 bomber in the jungles of New Guinea nearly 39 years ago.

title: Alaskan Gas Plan
description: Canadian natural gas industry executives indicated here today that they were undisturbed over the proposals by Alaska to change marketing strategies for its gas. According to Dianne Hall, senior vice president of Nova, an Alberta corporation and the Canadian sponsors of the Foothills Gas Transmission System, the proposal to sell Alaskan gas to Asian buyers instead of in the lower 48 states ''will not materially affect our plans.'' Foothills and its American associates continue to work on an overland pipeline route from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska to the United States.

title: The Wrinkle in College Sports Reform
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association deserves some credit for inching toward tighter academic standards for freshmen athletes. But its plan puts a strain on black colleges that fear the loss of their sports programs and threaten to quit the N.C.A.A. and the American Council on Education, which proposed the changes.

title: VILLANOVA TROUNCES SETON HALL
description: Villanova had no difficulty tonight as it trounced Seton Hall, 75-59, in a Big East Conference game that improved the Wildcats' somewhat deceiving league-leading record to 5-0.

title: AT-LARGE COUNCIL SETUP DEBATED AT CHARTER HEARING
description: The panel that will recommend changes in the New York City Charter - in effect, the municipal constitution - opened public hearings yesterday on the ways in which the city government can and must be changed.

title: UNITED BANKS OF COLORADO (DENVER) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $73,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of$185,000...C-After securities losses of $2,320,000 and a gain from discontinuedoperations of $2,082,000

title: News Analysis
description: Now that the initial excitement over the Reagan Administration's new agricultural payment program is subsiding, analysts are divided over whether it will have any real effect this year on the badly depressed farm economy.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOLLINGS BIDS REAGAN SHARPLY CUT GROWTH OF ARMS SPENDING
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, an influential member of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committees, said today that a ''national consensus'' in favor of strengthening military forces would evaporate unless President Reagan cooperated with Congress in drastically slowing the rate of increase in the military budget.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Charles Heidelberger, A Cancer Researcher
description: Dr. Charles Heidelberger, a cancer researcher who developed an anticancer drug and illuminated some of the chemical processes of malignancy, has died of cancer at the age of 62.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Flour Sale Angers E.E.C.
description: An American plan to sell a million metric tons of flour to Egypt below market rates provoked anger and dismay in the European Economic Community today.

title: Technology; Video Game Controllers
description: JOYSTICK controllers, the hand-held devices used to play home video games, are becoming important products in their own right. As video games become more complex, a new market is developing for controllers that are more comfortable or durable than the ones that come with the games or that can increase a player's score or make the game more fun.

title: Pregnant Teacher To Keep L.I. Job
description: A pregnant and unwed high-school teacher will be allowed to keep her job, according to officials of the East Hampton School Board.

title: THEATER: 'GILDED CAGE,' CAREER OF EVELYN NESBIT
description: THE ostensible moral to the story line of ''The Gilded Cage,'' a short musical at the Production Company, 15 West 28th Street, may well be ''There's a Broken Heart for Every Light on Broadway,'' the song that opens and closes this funny and fascinating summation of the career of Evelyn Nesbit. But the moral of this production is that one should never take anything for granted.

title: GROMYKO OFFERS NO SHIFT ON ARMS
description: Senior West German officials said today that Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, had not outlined any substantial changes in Moscow's nuclear arms negotiating positions during his four-day visit here.

title: Negotiations on U. S. Bases Are Renewed With the Greeks
description: Greek-American talks on the future of four United States bases in Greece resumed today as visiting members of Congress told Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou not to expect more rent.

title: BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,000 for the qr and $230,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: HARSHER GUN PENALTY UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state does not violate the constitutional protection against double jeopardy by treating the use of a gun to commit a crime as a separate and additional crime.

title: 'NICKEL AND DIME' CUTS EASE THE CITY'S BUDGET
description: Rikers Island inmates will repair chairs for city schools. Savings for the 1984 New York City budget: $29,000. The average time for delivery of a birth certificate will rise a bit from the current 3.7 days. Savings: $402,000. Fuel oil and diesel fuel will be shifted between two different storage barges at the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry. Savings: $100,000.

title: Westchester Plans Courtroom at Jail
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said today that the county planned to build a courtroom on the grounds of the Westchester County Jail to facilitate the arraignment of prisoners.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes special gain of $2,784,000...C-Net income after a charge of $796,000; yr-ago net income figures are restated

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the percentage decline in Citicorp's net operating income for the fourth quarter. It was 12.4 percent.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Doctor Accused of Fraud
description: The former chief of radiology at the Jersey City Medical Center was indicted by a Federal grand jury today in a reputed scheme to submit $43,000 in bogus bills for work he never performed. The doctor - Ricardo Baldonado, 39 years old, of Paramus - was named in a 35-count indictment accusing him filing false claims for Medicare and Medicaid payments in connection with his radiology work.

title: Desegregation, Chicago Style
description: What's the best way to desegregate a public school system when the racial mix of students is extremely unbalanced and the law does not countenance combining city and suburban schools? There is no good way.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 figures restated to reflect the acquisition in 1982 of Peoples National Bank in Lakewood, NJ and Washington Bank of a pooling-of-interest basis

title: Oak Industries
