description: Oak Industries, a cable-television equipment producer faced with slumping profits, said it was reshuffling its management and would lay off about 30 officers and staff employees. ''It's a fallout of the times,'' said Raymond W. Peirce, 58 years old, the company's president and chief operating officer. The company has said its problems resulted from cable-TV production difficulties, a flat cable-TV market and three devaluations of the Mexican peso, which have hurt Oak Industries' Mexican operations.

title: NEW CATHOLIC CODE EXPANDS WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: Women are to have some new rights and responsibilities in the Roman Catholic Church under a new code of canon law expected to be promulgated by Pope John Paul II next week.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''A high priority must be to get a hammerlock on this monster known as the Federal budget.'' - President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: REAGAN SEEKING BIPARTISAN MOVES IN BUDGET DISPUTE
description: Agreement on a compromise to save the Social Security system was reached after a year of intense negotiations. Washington Talk, page B16.

title: FIRST ARKANSAS BANKSTOCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $497,201 from the early retirement of capital notes

title: Victory for Mary Bacon
description: The spill that Mary Bacon took at the starting gate at the old Cahokia Downs race track in East St. Louis, Ill., in May 1979 was a nasty one, although she recovered in time to ride 68 horses in 1980 and 168 in 1981. Now Mrs. Bacon, whose pelvis and ribcage were crushed and who suffered a ruptured spleen in the accident, has achieved a victory in the damage suit she filed against the bankrupt race track.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STOVE RULE IS APPROVED
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today approved a rule requiring that wood- and coal-burning stoves be equipped with labels providing information about their installation, use and maintenance.

title: ROOS OF ST. LOUIS FED TO JOIN BEAR, STEARNS
description: Lawrence K. Roos may be leaving as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, but his monetarist voice will still be heard. Mr. Roos, who retires Feb. 1 at the Federal Reserve System's mandatory retirement age of 65, plans to associate himself with Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking firm, as a special limited partner and adviser on monetary policy.

title: Report Cites Plight of Blacks
description: The National Urban League, saying the plight of black Americans has grown worse in the last year, called on President Reagan today to declare a ''state of national economic emergency'' with guaranteed jobs for all.

title: E.E.C. Fertilizer Duties
description: The European Economic Community has imposed duties ranging from 12.01 percent to 19.05 percent on imports of certain fertlizers from the United States, a spokesman said today. He said countervailing duties would be charged on exports by the Allied Corporation, the Kaiser Aluminum Domestic and International Sales Corporation and the Transcontinental Fertilizer Company. Such duties are levied when manufacturers sell products abroad below domestic prices.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATEMENT ON BUDGET POLICY
description: Following is the text of a letter addressed to President Reagan and Congressional leaders from a group of 500 government, business and academic leaders. The group is led by six former Cabinet Secretaries, who entitled the letter, ''Bipartisan Appeal on the Budget Crisis.''

title: 5 DEFY COURT ORDER TO TESTIFY IN NEW YEAR'S EVE BOMBINGS
description: Five self-described advocates of Puerto Rican independence yesterday defied a Federal judge's order to testify before a grand jury looking into the New Year's Eve bombings in Manhattan and Brooklyn that severely injured three police officers. The five were permitted to remain free pending further legal proceedings.

title: Ruling Backs Nehemiah
description: If a movie is ever made of Renaldo Nehemiah's track career, ''Chariots of Confusion'' could be an appropriate title, at least after a decision announced yesterday by the United States Olympic Committee. It ruled that Nehemiah, the world-record hurdler who also plays wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers, was a professional only in football and thus could compete in amateur track events against American opponents - the first time a noncollege athlete has been granted such dual status.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per shr results reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid May 25, 1982 and a 50 percent stock divd paid Jan 14, 1983

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHINA, UPSET BY U.S. TRADE CURB, HALTING IMPORTS OF 3 COMMODITIES
description: China announced today that it was banning further purchases this year of cotton, soybeans and chemical fibers from the United States. The move was in retaliation for curbs imposed by the Reagan Administration on textile imports from China.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
Texas Monthly Leader Feels a Rebound Is Near
description: Among the formally garbed multitudes in the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday night when the Magazine Publishers Association honored Andrew Heiskell, retired chairman of Time Inc., was Michael R. Levy, the bearded young publisher of Texas Monthly.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 20, 1983
description: International Concern over NATO unity was reflected at the White House after many embassies reported diminishing support in Western Europe for the deployment of new American missiles in Europe and many other American policies. President Reagan instructed William A. Clark, his national security adviser, to head a Cabinet-level committee to promote diplomatic, military and arms control policies and he asked Peter H. Dailey, his 1980 campaign advertising manager and now Ambassador to Ireland, to lead an effort to win European backing for the missiles. (Page A1, Column 4.) Andrei A. Gromyko has not offered any substantial changes in Moscow's arms negotiating position, according to West German officials. The arms control issue, a major one in West Germany's election campaign, dominated their four days of talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister. (A11:1.)

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $5,072,000 from discontinued operations

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $14,000,000 or $1.96 a shr, from the sale of a subsidiary that owned the Stone & Webster Building in New York

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Coed Lunch at the Century

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Feb 1

title: Kodak Product
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced what it called ''the world's most advanced system yet'' for computerized storage of documents on microfilm. The Kodak KAR-4000 uses a computer, a cathode ray tube, a printer and a software package.

title: Trusthouse Net Up 5.9% in Year
description: Trusthouse Forte P.L.C., Britain's largest hotel and catering company, said today that it earned 46.8 million in the year ended Oct. 31, a 5.9 percent increase from 44.2 million the previous year. A pound is equivalent to about $1.57 at current exchange rates.

title: Coradian in Deal
description: The Coradian Corporation, a major installer of private telephone systems in New York and New Jersey, has signed a contract with American Telecom Inc. allowing American Telecom to purchase $2.5 million in Coradian securities. American Telecom, based in Anaheim, Calif., is an affiliate of Fujitsu Ltd. and expects to name Coradian as a distributor for some of its products. The deal comes after Coradian failed to reach an agreement with Burnup & Sims Inc.

title: VATICAN EXHIBIT'S TICKET SALES LAG
description: In an effort to boost lagging ticket sales to the ''Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art,'' the exhibition of masterworks from the Vatican museums at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Feb. 26 to June 12, the museum has decided to advertise the exhibition on the city's buses and subways.

title: STOCKS FALL ON NEWS OF ECONOMY
description: Increasing indications that the economy is still weak sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 11.59 points yesterday, to 1,068.06. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 80.9 million shares from 78.4 million shares on Tuesday.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ATTACKING CAFFEINE CONFUSION
description: CANADA DRY Ginger Ale will spend $2.1 million in five weeks in television, radio and newspapers to declare that it is not now, nor has it ever been, a caffeine-containing member of the soft-drink fraternity.

title: HARD DAYS CLOUD FIELDS OF SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY
description: The economic gloom that hangs over much of California's San Joaquin Valley is as thick as the foggy mists that have settled low over the region, as they do almost every January.

title: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Loan Disclosure Notice
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today released a staff accounting bulletin on disclosures by bank holding companies about loans to private and public borrowers ''in countries that are experiencing liquidity problems.'' The bulletin said the S.E.C. staff believes that negotiations between certain foreign countries and their lenders may be ''material developments'' that should be disclosed in reports submitted to the commission. The bulletin also states that it may also be necessary to disclose, for example, a program under which a foreign government in effect purchases obligations of private domestic borrowers to United States banks.

title: Media Prize Honors Marshall McLuhan
description: Canada today established a $42,000 International Media Communications Prize in honor of the late Marshall McLuhan, a professor at the University of Toronto who developed the phrase ''the medium is the message.''

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOSCOW DENOUNCES U.S. WEAPONS POLICY AS DANGER TO EUROPE
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda said today that right-wing politicians in the United States wanted to use nuclear weapons to dictate their will in Europe.

title: China Seeks Japan Aid
description: China has asked Japan for fresh economic aid for various development projects, Foreign Ministry officials said today. An official at the Foreign Ministry's Economic Cooperation Bureau said China did not mention any specific amount, nor the projects to be covered by Japanese aid.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WOODLEY SETTLES AS A STARTER
description: The watershed game was the last one of the regular season, Jan. 2 in Baltimore. The Miami Dolphins had played well before, winning six of their eight previous games in the strikeinterrupted season. But their offensive power was little more than the fullback Andra Franklin. That all changed in Baltimore, where the Dolphins won, 34-7.

title: A 2-DAY STRIKE OVER ELECTION PLAN BRINGS VIOLENCE TO AN INDIAN STATE
description: Sporadic violence was reported today from the northeastern state of Assam, where a two-day general strike protesting Government plans for elections closed businesses and schools.

title: Use of Railroad Passes Is Restricted by Kean
description: Governor Kean signed an order today restricting the use by state employees of free railroad passes, long considered a perquisite of state government, and called for a law eliminating them.

title: Bridge: Sometimes a 'Smart' Move May Turn Out Laughably
description: Back in the Culbertson era a famous series of bridge cartoons by H.T. Webster appeared regularly in The New York Herald Tribune. These focused on the rubber bridge game, then far more popular than it is today, and on the personal relationships of the players. A homeward-bound couple were often portrayed, with crackling commentary by the wife on her husband's performance.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: COMPROMISE AT LONG LAST
description: Moments after he was sworn in for a second term, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York walked across the blue-carpeted Senate floor and tapped Senator Bob Dole of Kansas on the shoulder. ''Are we going to let this commission die without giving it one more try?'' he asked.

title: Rock Island Plan
description: The Rock Island Railroad filed a reorganization plan in Federal court that would end all its rail operations, pay its debts and create a new company.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ANTIQUES AT ARMORY
description: Winter Antiques Show, Seventh Regi- ment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street, 212-570-2200.

title: Stadler Up by 3 On a 63
description: The 24th Bob Hope Desert Classic, a five-day marathon involving 136 professionals and 408 amateurs, got off to a windy and brisk start today, with Craig Stadler, the 1980 winner, leading a mass assault on par and gaining a three-stroke lead.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities gains of about $900,000 and cumulative effect of accounting change of about $31 million; the income before securities transactions for the latest fourth qr included a tax-free gain of $30.8 million or 21 cents per shr asa result of an exchange of debentures for preferred stock

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods do not reflect about $650,000 of tax credits available for carryforward to future periods

title: NO EXTRA SUGAR FOR A FEDERAL FOOD PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 15 Kidnappings in Colombia
description: Fifteen kidnappings have occurred in Colombia in the last three weeks, and 10 of them are believed to be the work of leftist guerrillas, the national police said today.

title: 'GLOBAL AMBITIONS' UNBECOMING TO ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAND JURY PROPOSES A VARIETY OF CHANGES AT UNION COUNTY JAIL
description: A special grand jury, ending a 16-month investigation of the Union County Jail, issued a report today calling for major changes to improve conditions for inmates at the overcrowded facility.

title: THE DANCE: KATHY DUNCAN
description: THE choreographer Kathy Duncan has long worked in a minimalist vein. Emerging from the intricately plotted patterns and simple moves and gestures of the dances performed by Kathy Duncan/Transition on Sunday at Washington Square Church were dramatic undercurrents that made for some of the most deeply touching dance of the season.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 20, 1983; The Economy
description: A group led by five former Treasury Secretaries urged the Reagan Administration and Congress to halve Federal budget deficits through severe cuts in Government spending and large tax increases. It voiced concern that the current fiscal course might ''lock the economy in stagnation'' for the rest of the century. The group -organized and led by Peter G. Peterson, who served as Secretary of Commerce during the Nixon Administration - includes 500 government, business and academic leaders. (Page A1.)

title: Hold the Road Against Trucks
description: Hard pressed by recession, the nation's truckers feel doubly abused by new highway taxes passed last month. And while their talk of a strike will probably fade with the arrival of this month's mortgage bills, there is little doubt that Congress will face great pressure to trim back the truck fees.

title: GOLDEN YEARS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
ORNATE FINIALS
description: SUCH details as handsome window hardware add a lot to the overall effect of a decorating plan. Well-designed curtain poles and finials are hard to find.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOLD JAPANESE FASHIONS FROM RUNAWAY TO STREET
description: AS any fashion observer can relate with some relish, there is a quantum difference between the way fashions look as presented on the designer's runway and the way the same outfits look on the women who eventually buy them. The new-wave Japanese fashions of Rei Kowakubo and Yohji Yamamato, two of the most talked-about Japanese talents of the moment, are a case in point.

title: SPRINKEL'S REMARKS STARTLE REGAN
description: The first that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan knew about the comments of his errant Under Secretary was early Monday, when Jacques de Larosiere, the managing director of the 146-nation International Monetary Fund, telephoned from Paris.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,672,000 from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to a merger of Budget Capital Corp into Financial Corp of America; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Dec

title: Westinghouse Off 2.2% in 4th Quarter
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 dipped 2.2 percent, while sales edged up 3.2 percent.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS (CORP) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books Of The Times
description: FLOATING DRAGON. By Peter Straub. 515 pages. Putnam. $15.95.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $2.1 million and a loss from discontinued operations of $5.9 million...C-Net income after securities gains of $3,000 a loss from discontinued operations of $1.2 million and extraordinary income of $6,720,000

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FRENCH SAY EVEN 50 SOVIET MISSILES ARE TOO MANY
description: A leading official of the French Socialist Party, apparently in a comment on American negotiating at the Geneva mediumrange missile talks, said today that allowing the Soviet Union to maintain 50 or more SS-20 missiles in Europe would not block its capacity to ''destroy every major strategic target.''

title: REAGAN INTENSIFIES DRIVE TO PROMOTE POLICIES IN EUROPE
description: The United States, alarmed by reports from its embassies of diminishing Western European support for many of its policies, is mounting an effort to improve its public relations in foreign affairs, Administration officials said today.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMTRAK TO REVIVE CAR TRAIN
description: Amtrak, the national passenger railroad, today approved a new automobile ferry service to begin late this year between Washington and Florida, the first of its kind since the Auto-Train Corporation went bankrupt and ceased operations in 1981.

title: Protection Added In Football Rules
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Associaton's football rules committee approved 44 rule changes today, with most designed to give added protection to quarterbacks, punters and kick returners.

title: Israel Firm on Putting Lookouts in Lebanon
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel would continue to insist on operating early-warning posts in Lebanon until a peace pact was signed.

title: TEAMSTER CO-DEFENDANTS ASSETS ARE UNFROZEN
description: A Federal district judge has decided to dissolve an order that had put into receivership the assets of the millionaire Allen Dorfman, who was convicted in the teamster bribery conspiracy trial.

title: Coast Builders' Union Accepts Pay Reduction
description: A major California construction union has agreed to accept pay reductions in a new contract in order to help create jobs for out-of-work members.

title: HUDSON'S PROSECUTOR ACCUSED AT U.S. TRIAL OF BLATANT EXTORTION
description: The United States Attorney charged in court today that Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. had ''blatantly, callously and systematically'' extorted $115,000 from a developer a year before he became the Hudson County Prosecutor.

title: Chrysler Discount
description: The Chrysler Corporation is selling its Dodge and Plymouth Colts for $205 less in California than in other parts of the country because of tough competition from imports in the California market, a company spokesman said.

title: White Jumps to Blitz
description: Stan White, the Detroit Lions linebacker has signed with the Chicago Blitz, becoming the first major player to jump from the National Football League to the United States Football League. White, a leader of the N.F.L. player strike last fall, said he expected no such trouble in the U.S.F.L. ... Mike Friede, a wide receiver formerly with the Giants, signed with the U.S.F.L.'s New Jersey Generals.

title: REAGAN CONSIDERING TAX-BREAK ACCOUNTS FOR COLLEGE SAVINGS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering proposing special savings accounts that would give parents a tax break on savings for their children's college education. Such ''independent education accounts'' might be similar to the individual retirement accounts that allow the deferral of taxes on money set aside specifically for retirement.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $225,000 on the exchange of debentures and a tax credit of $375,000...C-After a loss of $249,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1.6 million on the exchange of debentures

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Newest Times Sq. Tower

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF NEW JERSEY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lawrence Costello, 64, Principal of High School
description: Dr. Lawrence Costello, the principal of August Martin High School in Jamaica, Queens, died of a heart attack Monday while playing tennis at Alley Pond Park in Queens. He lived in Valley Stream, L.I., and was 64 years old.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
What's Under the N.F.L. Rugs?
description: T he National Football League has had to endure its most painful season - the transfer of a franchise without approval of the other clubs, a cocaine scandal among its players, a 57-day strike that shortened the schedule and now, with the approach of Super Bowl XVII, the rattling of gambling skeletons.

title: PAINTED FURNITURE: FROM THE SUBTLE TO THE WHIMSICAL
description: WHEN the country was young, the furniture of ordinary people was like them: sturdy, uncomplicated, hard-working and versatile. Early settlers took to dabbing paint on furniture as much to cover flaws and brighten dark rooms as to while away long winter evenings. But today furniture is no longer being painted as an afterthought. In fact, for the new crop of artists and artisans creating handmade, handpainted furniture, the design is as important as the painting.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WINTER BLOWS INTO NEW YORK AREA LATE BUT LIVELY
description: Temperatures plummeted to wintertime lows yesterday in the New York metropolitan area, and blustery winds made it seem even colder. In New York City, a low of 12 degrees was recorded at 5 A.M., the coldest day so far this year. The frigid air sent a record number of homeless people to city-operated shelters and prompted a flurry of calls for aid from motorists with malfunctioning cars.

title: GRAHAM WASHINGTON JACKSON, NAVY MUSICIAN
description: Graham Washington Jackson, a Navy musician who played for Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Jimmy Carter, died Saturday in Atlanta after a stroke. He was 79 years old.

title: WAR TO INTENSIFY, SALVADOR REBEL SAYS
description: A key political leader of El Salvador's insurgent forces said today that the guerrilla war had entered a ''new cycle'' and would soon engulf the central and southern parts of the country.

title: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Halting of Ship by Argentina Brings a Complaint by Brazil
description: Brazil has asked Argentina to explain why it intercepted a Brazilian Antarctic research vessel Tuesday in the disputed Beagle Channel, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Tax Studied By Feldstein
description: Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said tonight that he favored a proposal to reform the progressive income tax by changing to a system that would tax only what people spend.

title: Alfred M. Greenfield, Director Of N.Y.U. Glee Club 42 Years
description: Alfred M. Greenfield, an organist and composer who directed the New York University Glee Club for 42 years, died Friday in Princeton, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Drinking Age of 21 Proposed
description: The drinking age in Massachusetts, which was raised from 18 years to 20 in 1979, should be raised to 21 ''to help reduce the high incidence of drunken driving involving young people,'' the American Automobile Association said Tuesday.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUDICIAL MERIT SELECTION'S PROVEN MERIT
description: To the Editor:

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRISONS' CHALLENGE TO CUOMO
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo exercised admirable intelligence and patience in settling the 53-hour inmate takeover at the Ossining Correctional Facility. Now, a long-term and even more important challenge confronts him. He must resolve the underlying problem that made the siege at Ossining virtually inevitable - overcrowding.

title: RIGGINS BREAKS FREE TO LEAD THE REDSKINS
description: Now that John Riggins is speaking again, everybody is listening. And this is what the enigmatic running back of the Washington Redskins is saying about his new attitude, new role and new success:

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings for the latest qr are after provision for preferred divds

title: Motorcycle Imports Cited
description: The International Trade Commission ruled today that imports threatened the American motorcycle industry and said it was considering measures to protect domestic makers.

title: WITH RELATIONS SOUR, KREISKY IS BRAVING A U.S. TRIP
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky is scheduled to visit the United States starting Feb. 3 for talks with President Reagan at a time of clouded relations between the two countries.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN EXPRESS UP 16.6%
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that gains by several of its businesses lifted earnings 16.6 percent in the fourth quarter, while revenues advanced 12.5 percent.

title: U.S. Aides Say Curbs Won't Hurt
description: Agriculture and trade officials said today that China's decision to ban further imports of certain American commodities this year would cause a relatively small loss in overall United States commodity trade.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q&A
description: Q. Some bricks on the lower part of my house are showing severe signs of spalling or erosion. When a spatula is run over the surface a paste-like material comes off quite easily, leaving behind a hollowed-out cavity, in some cases an inch deep and running the length of the brick. All the bricks on that part of the house were painted about five years ago. Could this paint be the culprit, or is there such a thing as a bad brick?

title: Backlog Delaying Autopsy Reports
description: A backlog of about 1,000 cases at the State Medical Examiner's office here has caused delays of several months in the preparation of some final autopsy reports, the Examiner says.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DRAWING ROOM FABRICS
description: THE new all-cotton fabrics are of a heavier weight and have bolder and larger-scale patterns - and are designated as Drawing Room Fabrics, according to their English designer Laura Ashley.

title: No Headline
description: Penguins Tie Devils On a Late Goal, 1-1

title: Hussein to Visit Belgium
description: King Hussein of Jordan will visit here next week to brief Belgian officials on the Middle East. He will stop in Spain for talks with King Juan Carlos before coming to Belgium.

title: Yugoslavia Aid Planned
description: Representatives of 15 foreign governments have recommended a $1.3 billion medium-term credit for Yugoslavia for disbursement this year, a Swiss Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The recommendations were made on the basis that Yugoslavia meet several conditions.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VICTORIAN SOCIETY CELEBRATES 25th YEAR
description: It all started quietly enough over the gentle tinkle of teacups in the drawing room of the London home of Anne, Countess of Rosse. Among her guests were Sir John Betjeman, now the poet laureate; Sir Nikolaus Pevsner, the architectural historian; Mark Girouard, the author of books on the English country house; Oliver Messel, the interior and set designer; Sir John Pope-Hennessy, consultative chairman of European painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Sir Hugh Casson, president of the Royal Academy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trees of 'the People'

title: MUSIC: MODERNS IN TULLY HALL
description: THE infusion of energy from national folk cultures into the mainstream high-art tradition at the end of the 19th century and in the early decades of the 20th, was a remarkable phenomenon, occurring just as the modernist movement was attempting its own brand of revivification. Two examples of such works were presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall Monday night; their idiosyncrasies and earthy eccentricities made a Mozart performance seem almost precious.

title: New Building Dedicated At Wharton School
description: The University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School today held dedication ceremonies for a $16 million structure as part of a combined building that will become the business school's new headquarters.

title: Scudder Selling Tax-Exempts
description: Investment advisers at Scudder, Stevens & Clark yesterday offered to sell $170 million of tax-exempt bonds, as they try to lock in big profits earned in recent months when tax-exempt bond prices rose sharply while Treasury and corporate bond prices were stable.

title: NCR President Will Be Chief
description: The board of the NCR Corporation plans to name Charles E. Exley Jr., now president, to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: STUDY ON U.S. JEWS AND HOLOCAUST TO RESUME
description: Arthur J. Goldberg announced today that he planned to reconvene a commission of prominent American Jews to examine the behavior of Jewish organizations at the time of the Nazi campaign to annihilate European Jews.

title: BRITISH STAGE FEMINISTS AND U.S. POST-FEMINISTS
description: THREE plays by young Englishwomen recently opened in New York - Catherine Hayes's ''Skirmishes,'' Caryl Churchill's ''Top Girls'' and Nell Dunn's ''Steaming.'' Although they deal with different subjects in a variety of theatrical styles - from the anarchic absurdities of ''Top Girls'' to the naturalism of ''Steaming'' - each play makes a statement about the universality of sisterhood.

title: PSYCHIATRIC GROUP URGES STIFFER RULES FOR INSANITY PLEA
description: The American Psychiatric Association urged today that some form of insanity defense be retained in criminal trials, but it called for a ''tightening up'' of standards and procedures to protect the public against premature release of potentially dangerous individuals.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Offer Made In Nurses' Talks
description: Negotiators for 650 registered nurses at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn made a new proposal yesterday in a move to avert a strike set for 6 A.M. Monday. Details were not disclosed.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $9.6 million for the qr and $10 million for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $91,000 for the qr and $512,000 for the yr

title: ALAGASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report Jan. 12, accompanying an article about the Century Club, misidentified the artist who painted a gathering of members. He was Charles Yardley Turner.

title: Gastineau Accuses Dolphins
description: Mark Gastineau, the all-pro defensive end for the Jets, today accused the tight ends of the Dolphins of chopblocking, trying to halt him by hitting him laterally at the knee as he attempts to get past the tackle and rush the passer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Quintin Dailey, the Chicago Bulls' rookie, must make a public apology to Victoria Brick as part of an out-of-court settlement of a civil suit, Miss Brick's lawyer said yesterday. The suit grew out of Dailey's admitted assault of Miss Brick when Dailey attended the University of San Francisco.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Pensions by Sex
description: Are women who earn the same salaries as men entitled to the same amount of pension as men? At first, the answer seems an obvious ''yes.'' But as the courts are discovering, the underlying question is not simple, and neither is the answer.

title: HERITAGE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 results for the qr and yr include a $5,255,000 gain on the sale of a mortgage banking unit in Dec

title: NOAH IS WINNER OVER GERULAITIS
description: Yannick Noah moved into Ivan Lendl's path last night with a 4-6, 6-3, 6-2 victory over Vitas Gerulaitis in the Volvo Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6 DIE IN CRASH AT TOLL STATION IN CONNECTICUT
description: Six people were killed and four others were injured today when a tractor-trailer crashed into four cars at the Connecticut Turnpike tollbooth here, engulfing the truck and three of the cars in flames.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEEDIEST CASES RECEIVE GIFTS FROM FIRST-TIME CONTRIBUTORS
description: ''As I spend my first winter in New York, I am struck by how much more difficult it is just to live here than it was in California, from where I just moved. The needs of the street people cannot be so easily ignored as the temperature dips into the teens and the snow begins to fall.''

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sonmor in Hospital
description: Last Thursday Glen Sonmor, saying he was ''emotionally burned out,'' resigned as coach of the Minnesota North Stars following a fight with a heckler in a Pittsburgh restaurant.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS AIDE DEFENDS U.S. POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration's chief human rights spokesman characterized American foreign policy yesterday as being based on ''the simple fact that we believe the world to be an exceedingly dangerous place.''

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Results for the previous yr are not available since the company began operations in July 1981 as a result of the restructuring of Cenville Investors Inc

title: FOR JERSEY FARMERS, A BIT OF FUN IN SPITE OF A BLEAK OUTLOOK
description: The men who work the land gathered by the sea this week. In years past, this gathering would have been called a farmers' convention. Now it is a meeting of agronomists and ''agribusinessmen.''

title: South Central Bell
description: A service company that will perform computer, purchasing and other functions for South Central Bell and Southern Bell telephone companies will be situated in Birmingham, the companies said, bringing 700 jobs to the area. The two local telephone companies will be owned by a proposed holding company to be based in Atlanta after they are divested from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company next year.

title: CONNERY AND MOORE ARE BACK AS BOND IN '83Thou shall have a license to kill for a hundred lacking one. - King Henry VI, Part II
description: After 20 years of chasing archvillians and voluptuous women across the movie screen, Commander James Bond, a.k.a. Secret Agent 007, will be back again this year, this time in rival film versions.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
H.U.D. Aide Is Replaced
description: Dr. Benjamin Bobo, a deputy assistant secretary in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, was selected Tuesday to replace Dr. E.S. Savas, Assistant Secretary for policy development and research, who was suspended Monday pending the outcome of an investigation into various aspects of his official conduct.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
FORMER OFFICIALS START CAMPAIGN FOR DEFICIT CUTS
description: A bipartisan group led by five former Treasury Secretaries urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to cut Federal deficits by more than half through severe cuts in Government spending and large tax increases.

title: SCOTT PAPER'S CHIEF TO BE CHAIRMAN, TOO
description: Philip E. Lippincott, the 47-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Scott Paper Company, has been named to the additional post of chairman, effective Feb. 1.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Campaign Set Eye Safety
description: The Labor Department today announced a year-long special effort to improve eye protection in the workplace in cooperation with the National Society to Prevent Blindness. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said its inspectors would begin on April 4 to distribute special eye safety bulletins when they were on a job site.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $757,000 for the qr and $2,155,000 for the yr...C-After a loss of $3,160,000 from discontinued operations

title: ANDREA RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAZZ: MARSH GROUP APPEARS AT FORUM
description: THERE'S a winning subterfuge in Warne Marsh's tenor saxophone playing. His tone is feathery, and notes seem wafted rather than blown; his quartet sound is not too different from ''Background Music,'' as one tune the group played Sunday at the Jazz Forum was called.

title: ACTOR
description: The police are continuing to investigate possible links between a Manhattan public-relations executive and the murder of a young actor who had been spurned by the executive's daughter, the police and the District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: HERS
description: MY aunt tells the story of a woman of her generation who, in the Depression 30's, perpetrated an extraordinary hoax, even for those desperate times. She was clever and young and energetic, also poor and with few prospects. Her fiance having abandoned her in early pregnancy, she set out to locate, among the obituary listings, details about some freshly widowed childless gentleman who was rich. Her pregnancy was not yet at the dreaded stage of ''showing.'' Hastily she put her pennies together, bought a new dress and a bouquet of flowers and, wearing the one and carrying the other, presented herself at the door of a bereaved older gentleman whom she had never seen or heard of before.

title: 'RIGHTS' A CRITERION FOR SALVADOR AID?
description: With the approach of the deadline for the semi-annual Presidential certification of El Salvador, it is time not only to review once again the status of Salvadoran human rights but also to reassess whether human rights are a fitting and plausible criterion for granting aid to El Salvador.

title: SOWING SUMMER SEED INDOORS
description: PLANTING seed indoors is a good cure for a gardener's cabin fever, but the winter-bound must also be realistic. A garden will have only so much planting space this spring, and a house can spare little room for seedlings. Though small at the start, seedlings grow fast and often need transplanting to individual pots so they can grow even more.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $229,000 for the qr and $440,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $87,000...D-Net loss

title: Coal Miner Is Killed Near 1981 Accident Site
description: A coal miner was killed and four others were injured today in an underground cave-in about three miles from a mine where an explosion in 1981 killed 13 men.

title: LIVING WITH NEIGHBORS
description: Facing severe security and economic problems, this country's left-wing Government is trying to work out a more stable relationship with its powerful right-wing neighbor, South Africa. The aim is a mutual willingness to live and let live, and there are some signs of progress in that direction.

title: Economic Scene; Roundtable's View of U.S.
description: HOW do the leaders of big business regard the current state of the American economy -and what do they think needs to be done to improve it? One way to find out is to ask Ruben Mettler, chairman of the Business Roundtable, an association of the chief executive officers of 200 of the largest American corporations.

title: UNITED BANCORP-ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results restated to give effect to the merger of Bank of Northern Arizona accounted for under the pooling-of-interests method

title: Shaggy Bus Story
description: Tom Martin, an 18-year-old freshman left wing with the University of Denver, laughed yesterday at his new nicknames: Greyhound and Bus. ''It's really funny,'' said Martin. He was merely traded for a team bus. It was not, as first reported, a simple trade of an ice hockey player for a used bus. In fact, the Seattle Breakers of the Western Hockey League had to chip in $35,000 along with the rights to Martin in order to get the 14-year-old bus from the Victoria Cougars.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
One-Year Penalty
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's today placed the University of San Diego's football program on probation for one year.

title: Flyers 5, Flames 2
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Darryl Sittler scored an assist and a goal and become the 17th player in N.H.L. history to score 1,000 or more points, as he led the Philadelphia victory.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1,434,000 for the qr and yr from penalties on prepayments of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings...C-Net loss...D-Including again of $6,246,000 on the repurchase of mortgage-backed bonds

title: ELITE OF BEARDOM AT A TEA PARTY
description: PART I: In Which We Are Introduced to Winnie-the-Pooh and Some Bears, and the Story Begins. Here is Winnie-the-Pooh, coming into the Algonquin Hotel now, having arrived in a 1958 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith. This is, of course, a splendid thing, but not quite as wonderful as coming downstairs with Christopher Robin and going bump, bump, bump on the stairs. Since this isn't really the first paragraph of ''Winnie-the-Pooh,'' but rather a story about some bears, perhaps the Rolls-Royce will just have to do.

title: THE SOLE HOMELAND OF A JEWISH AMERICAN
description: To the Editor: I am troubled by the debate reflected in Bernice Tannenbaum's letter (Jan. 7) and Rabbi Schindler's Jan. 3 Op-Ed article, to which the letter responds.

title: Vanderbilt Corp., Atlantic in Rift
description: The Vanderbilt Energy Corporation said the Atlantic Oil Corporation had materially breached the merger agreement between the two companies and that it expected to recover substantial damages from Atlantic.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DECEPTION. By Nicolas Born. Translated from the German by Leila Vennewitz. 238 pages. Little, Brown. $15.50.

title: HAILS HIS RECORD
description: President Reagan, contending that his Administration never got from Congress the full economic plan needed to cure the recession, hailed his first two years in office today and insisted that he now had ''America on the mend.''

title: Spotlight on Elway
description: The New England Patriots, who had trouble this season choosing between Steve Grogan and Matt Cavanaugh, have apparently decided which quarterback is No. 1 - John Elway of Stanford. The problem, of course, is that Elway is the first choice of just about everybody, including the Baltimore Colts, who have first pick in the National Football League's college draft in April.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Local Mail

title: Arafat Meets 3 Israelis
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, held talks with three Israeli leftists this week, according to a joint statement today. The Israelis called the talks a ''victory for the moderates in the P.L.O.'' The Israelis were Uri Avnery, 59 years old, a publisher and former Member of Parliament for Sheli, Maj. Gen. Mattityahu Peled, retired, 59, and Yaacov Arnon, 69, a retired Treasury official. Neither side said when or where the meeting took place.

title: Snepsts Suspended
description: Harold Snepsts, a Vancouver Canucks defenseman, has been suspended for five game for his fight with a Calgary Flames' player outside the team dressing rooms at the Vancouver Coliseum, the National Hockey League announced. Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president, held separate meetings this week with Snepsts and Doug Risebrough of Calgary, who were involved in the Jan. 12 incident.

title: ISRAEL AND LEBANON TO STUDY 4 KEY ISSUES
description: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators, meeting today in the Israeli border town of Kiryat Shemona, announced the formation of four subcommittees to discuss the key issues growing out of Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: YANKS LOSE MAY
description: The Chicago White Sox surprised Rudy May and the Yankees yesterday when they selected him in the free-agent compensation draft. The White Sox had a selection in the draft because they had lost Steve Kemp, a Type A free agent who signed with the Yankees. Chicago could have taken a player from 19 other teams that took part in the draft last fall.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Judge Delays Hyatt Decision
description: A Federal district judge today delayed action on making final a $10 million settlement he tentatively approved Jan. 10 in the collapse of two suspended walkways at the Kansas City Hyatt Regency Hotel. The accident in July 1981 killed 114 people and injured more than 200.

title: Fulltime Clipper
description: Bill Walton officially became a full-time San Diego Clipper yesterday after getting the go-ahead from his orthopedist, Dr. Tony Daly.

title: Piazza Sentenced
description: John Piazza, who said in a television show broadcast last Monday that he had helped fix 12 National Football League games in a gambling scheme more than a decade ago, was sentenced today to nine years in prison on a Federal weapons charge.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a pretax charge of $1 million to cover severance payments and temporaryclosing expenses at two manufacturing plants in Michigan...C-Net income

title: Bridge: Unfortunately, Some Deals Retain a Haunting Quality
description: Some deals, particularly if they decide the destination of a major title, can haunt a player for years. In the diagram, cover the West and South hands, and study East's problem in defense against six clubs doubled.

title: U.S. CALLS 26 IN CITY POLICE GRAFT INQUIRY
description: Twenty-six present and former city police officers, including five sergeants, have been subpoenaed in a Federal undercover investigation of illegal activities at after-hours clubs and bars in Manhattan, Federal and city law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: DON'T ALTER THE BASICS OF SOCIAL SECURITY, PANEL ADVISES
description: The National Commission on Social Security reform, submitting its final report to President Reagan today, urged that Congress ''not alter the fundamental structure of the Social Security program or undermine its fundamental principles.''

title: MITTERRAND, ON BONN VISIT, WARNS AGAINST EFFORTS TO DIVIDE THE WEST
description: Marking the 20th anniversary of the friendship treaty between West Germany and France, President Francois Mitterrand urged unity in the Atlantic alliance today and warned against attempts to separate the United States and Western Europe.

title: DOLPHINS LINE IGNORES GASTINEAU'S DANCE
description: Mark Gastineau, the defensive end for the Jets who has an unusual way of celebrating a sack, has become a favorite subject around the training complex of the Dolphins.

title: Park Plan Is Attacked By Environmentalists
description: Conservationists are vigorously protesting a proposal now being studied by the National Park Service to return property within the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore in Lake Superior to its original owner.

title: BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MERCHANTS BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN SAID TO SEEK 135 BILLION TAX RISE FOR FUTURE IF NEEDED
description: President Reagan has decided to include in his Budget Message to Congress a package of about $135 billion in tax increases that could be levied later in the decade to help hold down the deficit, Administration officials said today.

title: THE SCREEN: 'INDEPENDENCE DAY'
description: THERE are times when you can tell everything you need to know about a film in the first few moments. Here is the way ''Independence Day'' begins with a lyric: Around us in everything we see Some are real and some are fantasy. Then we meet the heroine. Mary Ann Taylor (Kathleen Quinlan) is chasing through a small Southwestern town, taking pictures. She is wearing a red vest with lots of pockets, a beret with a feather in it and a bandana. Clearly, she's a nonconformist. A character. A real live wire.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures reflect a deduction in lieu of federal income tax; a companyspokesman said that as a result of tax loss carryforwards Penn Central pays no federal income tax

title: Top Board Official Yields Post at Time
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that Arthur Temple, a Texas lumber millionaire and major stockholder of the company, would retire as vice chairman effective immediately but would remain a director.

title: Ex-Agent Tells of Payoffs He Says Were for Judge
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation told a jury today that he posed as a convicted racketeer and paid $150,000 to a friend of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings for what the witness said was a reduction of two sentences imposed by the judge.

title: ALAN FLUSSER'S STYLES FOR FALL
description: The past was almost recaptured at the showing Wednesday of Alan Flusser's men's fall clothing. It all started convincingly enough at the Union League Club at 5 with champagne, crab claws and Lester Lanin's music echoing in the paneled library.

title: SOVIET PAPER RULES OUT AN INTERIM PACT ON MISSILES
description: A Soviet weekly calls ''absolutely unacceptable'' any compromise that would allow the West to deploy fewer American medium-range missiles in Europe in return for cuts in the existing Soviet force.

title: F.C.C. Studies Radio Phones
description: The Federal Communications Commission asked for public comment on petitions from two companies to set aside radio frequencies for services that would switch calls from home phones to car phones or permit people to make phone calls from an airplane.

title: Safer Sport Backed By Boxing Officials
description: Officials of eight athletic commissions, spurred by the recent criticisms of boxing after the death two months ago of Duk Koo Kim, met here yesterday and agreed to work together to make the sport safer.

title: Yugoslavia Says Albania Threatens to Use Force
description: The Yugoslav Government accused Albania today of ''openly threatening to use force'' against it and demanded an end to what it termed Albania's hostile policy.

title: Looking Ahead
description: Gregory Anrig, the president of the Educational Testing Service, which administers the Scholastic Aptitude Test, said that the move by the National Collegiate Athletic Association to require a score of 700 on that test ''will have effects that may not have been fully realized before this decision was made.'' Officials from a number of predominantly black colleges complained that the tests are culturally biased against blacks. Mr. Anrig said he agreed, but he also noted that although the percentage was lower, more whites than blacks fell under the 700 cutoff on last year's tests - 90,527 whites to 42,831 blacks. ''The issue, therefore, cuts across racial lines in addition to affecting minorities disproprotionately,'' he said.

title: DANCE: COURANTE IN BAROQUE PROGRAM
description: COURANTE, the baroque dance company that performed on Wednesday at Theater of the Riverside Church, takes its name from a social dance much enjoyed by Louis XIV. That blend of general history and its animating specifics made of Courante's program of baroque music and dance an evening of vivid theater, well performed and beautifully costumed.

title: CARESSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST UNITED BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. TRADE CHIEF SAYS NAKASONE TRIP HELPED EASE TENSIONS
description: During his four days in Washington, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone indicated clearly that he would take steps to increase American exports to Japan, American officials said today.

title: Air France Loss Doubles
description: Air France's losses more than doubled last year to 820 million francs, or $120.5 million, from 378 million francs, or $55.5 million, in 1981, the state-owned carrier reported today.

title: THEATER: 'CAINE MUTINY'
description: STAMFORD WHEN it stays within the boundaries of its genre, Herman Wouk's ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' remains a rousing courtroom drama. But when the author begins to moralize about patriotism, the play becomes facile. What it needs to carry an audience past the sermon is acting that is as polished as the gold buttons on the naval officers' uniforms. For the most part, that is what it receives in Arthur Sherman's revival at the Hartman Theater Company.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec 13, 1982

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 21, 1983; The Economy
description: President Reagan plans to include a $135 billion package of contingency tax increases in his budget message, according to Administration officials. The taxes would be imposed later in the decade if needed to help hold down the deficit. (Page A1.) Some economists argue that the huge deficits projected by the Administration would not necessarily harm the economy. (D1.) Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that if the Fed is to gain the flexibility to work for a recovery, projected deficits must be narrowed. (D3.)

title: SANDINIST GIVES U.S. DATA HE SAYS PROVES AN EX-ENVOY 'STOLE'
description: Nicaragua's Minister of Justice said today that he had presented ''conclusive evidence'' to United States officials that Managua's former Ambassador to the United States ''stole'' more than $618,000 from the embassy's bank account here.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YANG YONG, 70,LED CHINESE IN KOREA
description: Yang Yong, one of China's highest-ranking military officials, died Jan. 6 in Peking, according to Chinese press reports received in New York. He was 70 years old.

title: Food Price Rise Of 3%-6% Seen
description: Food prices in American grocery stores are likely to climb by 3 percent to 6 percent in 1983, while prices of food away from home are expected to be up 4 to 6 percent, an Agriculture Department economist, Denis Dunham, said today.

title: NASHVILLE CITY BANK & TRUST CO (TENN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for the Dec 31, 1982 pooling acquisition of Bancorp Bancshares Inc

title: HISTORY OF THE STRAUSS WORK
description: ''Guntram,'' the first of Richard Strauss's 15 operas, was written in 1892, when he was 28 years old and recuperating in Greece and Egypt from bouts with pneumonia and pleurisy. The three-act work had its premiere two years later in Weimar, with Pauline de Ahna, soon to become Strauss's wife, in the leading soprano role.

title: FEW DEFEND EX-PROSECUTOR WHO LOST RIGHTS SUIT
description: The family name of the Ratliffs, from Ada to Zack, fills almost a full page of the Pike County telephone directory, reflecting not only their number in this mountainous Appalachian coal country but also their power and wealth.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINAL REPORT OF THE COMMISSION ON SOCIAL SECURITY REFORM
description: Following are excerpts from the final report of the National Commission on Social Security Reform:

title: DEVILS GET TIE ON 3 GOALS IN 2d
description: For a change, the Devils kept the opposition scoreless in the third period tonight and that earned them a 3-3 tie against the St. Louis Blues before a crowd of 9,763 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: AMERICAN PAD & PAPER (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STRIP-MINING REGULATIONS PROPOSED FOR PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS
description: The Interior Department today announced new rules that it said it intended to impose on strip mining. The department said the rules would protect the environment while easing the regulatory burden on the coal industry.

title: CONDOMINIUM IS RISING AT MADISON AVE. AND 94th ST.
description: Until recently, the section of Madison Avenue from the mid-80's to the mid-90's was very much the poor relation, so to speak, of other streets in Carnegie Hill, the compact East Side enclave between Central Park and Lexington Avenue that includes several of the city's best-known museums and private schools.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $56 million for the qr and yr for the settlement of antitrust litigation, a gain of $130 million for the yr from an accounting change and a gain of $27 million for the yr from the exchange of debt for common shrs...C-Net income

title: EXCERPTS FROM DECISION ON HOUSING
description: Following are excerpts from the unanimous decision by New Jersey's Supreme Court on zoning ordinances and lowand moderate-income housing. The opinion was written by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Benefit

title: ART: JUDY PFAFF'S NEO-EXPRESSIONIST ENVIRONMENT
description: STEP into ''3-D,'' the big, ebullient environment created by Judy Pfaff at the Holly Solomon Gallery, 392 West Broadway, through Jan. 29, and you'll quickly realize that you've walked into nothing less than a giant painting of Abstract Expressionist persuasion. Walls, floor, ceiling and the space they enclose are all involved in a raucous extravaganza of hotly colored forms that somehow fall into - oh, a composition, if you will.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Centex Acceptance Corp., a Centex Corp. subsidiary, filed a shelf registration statement with the S.E.C. for up to $100 million of its G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds.

title: CONTRACEPTION: A RULE DIRECTED AT 'BAD KIDS' (MALES EXCEPTED)
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF 'MUDDY RIVER'
description: ''Muddy River'' was shown as part of the 1982 ''New Directors/New Films'' series. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times last April 19. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Warm-Up Woes Of a Young Cellist

title: NUCLEAR-POWERED SATELLITE MAY CRASH SUNDAY
description: With a disabled Soviet satellite falling toward earth ever faster, the Defense Department said yesterday that it was expected to plunge into the atmosphere and possibly scatter debris over the surface sometime between early Sunday morning and Monday afternoon.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Plausible Script

title: The searches of an Italian director.
description: AMONG the movies opening this weekend, there are, oddly, three that deal with that rite of passage through which young people travel to become grownups. One picture is Italian, another Australian and the third American, but in every case, the young people are oldfashioned, in the sense that they believe in work, love and honor (none of them sniff cocaine, or want to be rock stars); they meet the challenges offered them, and they give an audience a chance to cheer.

title: News Analysis
description: In putting together his 1984 budget, President Reagan faces deficits so vast that they alarm all former Treasury Secretaries still living and even his otherwise staunch allies among Republican businessmen. In the fiscal year 1980, the last full year of the Carter Administration, the deficit was $59.6 billion. Based on what is known of the upcoming budget that the President will present on Jan. 31, the deficit in the fiscal year 1984 will be around $185 billion, three times as large.

title: Advertising; Videotape Magazine Debut Set
description: SINCE 1976, a year after he graduated from Stanford with a degree in English, John A. Bunyan has been involved in the world of audiovisuals and videotape productions. And almost from the very beginning, he has seen the potential for a magazine-format videotape program.

title: 19 Aliens Are Indicted In Student Loan Fraud
description: Nineteen foreign students charged with obtaining thousands of dollars in Government-backed loans by claiming to be Americans or resident aliens were arraigned today as part of a nationwide crackdown on student loan fraud.

title: CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Getty Receives Drilling Approval
description: The Army Corps of Engineers approved the Getty Oil Company's controversial plan to drill for natural gas in an environmentally sensitive north Florida estuary.

title: DANCE: REVISED 'APOLLO'
description: IGOR STRAVINSKY composed the score for the ballet now known as ''Apollo'' on a Library of Congress commission from an American patron, Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge. The first choreography in Washington was by Adolph Bolm.

title: GEORGE ROY HINMAN SR. DIES: WAS ACTIVE IN YACHT RACING
description: George Roy Hinman Sr., a prominent New York yachtsman who was a familiar figure at America's Cup races from 1958 through 1980, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARNEY KESSEL'S IN TOWN, A HEADLINER THIS TIME
description: BARNEY KESSEL has been playing jazz guitar in celebrated company for four decades - in Artie Shaw's Gramercy Five in the mid-1940's, with the Oscar Peterson Trio in the early 50's, on the star-studded Jazz at the Philharmonic tours of the 50's, as one of the top Los Angeles studio musicians in the 60's and, in the 70's, as one-third of the Great Guitars, with Charlie Byrd and Herb Ellis.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRA FROM SCOTLAND
description: THE Scottish Chamber Orchestra, founded to play for the Scottish Opera in 1974, was conducted by Jaime Laredo at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, in the first of a series of concerts that will also include an appearance at Carnegie Hall.

title: RWANDA'S? UGANDA'S? 45,000 PEOPLE WITHOUT A COUNTRY
description: For thousands of refugees, caught here between hostilities, the tally of woes is long. Last October and November, 45,000 were obliged to leave places where they had long lived in the southern Ugandan district of Ankole and move southward into Rwanda. For many, Rwanda was supposed to be the land of their ancestors. But their welcome here, on the fringes of the Akagera game park, is restrained.

title: BIKING 'TIMERIDER'
description: ''TIMERIDER'' is about a motorcyle rider who, in the course of a desert race, gets mixed up with a time machine and finds himself in Mexico in 1875. It was directed by William Dear and written by him and Michael Nesmith, a former Monkee, who also wrote the film's music and is its executive producer.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $315,000 for the qr and $1,423,000 for the yr...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,646,000

title: PUBLISHING: WHEN BOOK IS RULED OUT BY LIBRARY
description: THE library systems of San Francisco, Chicago and Milwaukee have recently come under attack for a book alleged to be racially offensive. This time, however, the libraries are not under attack from self-styled censors but are themselves being accused of censorship for keeping the book off their shelves.

title: THE HEART OF 'THRESHOLD' AND BEYOND
description: The science in the film ''Threshold,'' in which an artificial heart is implanted in a woman patient, is an amalgam of fact and fancy - but it is not beyond the realm of possibility. The fictional artificial heart has its roots in much the same concept and history as the real one that was implanted more than a month ago in the chest of Dr. Barney B. Clark in Salt Lake City. In fact, the real and the imaginary devices were designed by the same man, Dr. Robert K. Jarvik of the University of Utah. But the models are far different from each other, both in their design concepts and details.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Market Place; De-Emphasis On Drug Issues
description: WALL STREET'S typical assessment of ethical drug stocks is that they can provide reasonably dependable earnings during a recession. The label on this group, as a result, identifies it as a ''defensive'' type of investment. In the last two years, a period marked by a sluggish economy, drug equities have turned in a creditable market performance.

title: MINORITIES FIGHT AT-LARGE SEATS ON CITY COUNCIL
description: Speaking for the black and Hispanic members of the City Council, Frederick E. Samuel told the Charter Revision Commission yesterday that they were ''steadfastly and vigorously'' opposed to any form of at-large representation on the Council.

title: U.S. STEEL, ARMCO INC. AND INLAND RAISE PRICES
description: Price increases for most basic steel products - the first in nearly two years - were announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, Armco Inc. and the Inland Steel Company. The three companies are ranked first, fifth and sixth in size in the United States.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Carl E. Casselman promoted to executive vice president, creative services at Lewis & Gilman Inc., Philadelphia.

title: 2 TOP IRISH POLICE OFFICIALS RESIGN
description: The two top officers of the Irish national police force announced their resignation tonight as a Government inquiry expanded into the police wiretapping of politicians and journalists during the administration of Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey.

title: A Marine Base McDonald's
description: McDonald's plans to open a restaurant Feb. 7 at sprawling Camp Pendleton, 60 miles north of San Diego. It will be the first time that a fast-food enterprise has been established on a United States military base, officials say.

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
A HOUSE DIVIDED
description: Virgil M. Everhart chopped and sawed away at the insides of his house today in the glare of television lights, cutting it in half because his wife had asked for an even property settlement in their divorce. He stopped after a judge criticized his ''cute trick'' and awarded his wife temporary child support and alimony.

title: Topics; Ever More; Amendment, Amended
description: Treasury Secretary Regan deserves credit for courage in pledging that the Administration will keep budget deficits under $200 billion in each of the next three years. That's a long way from the President's earlier pledge that he'd have the budget balanced by now, but at least it shows contact with reality.

title: MAN KILLED IN ATTEMPTED HIJACKING ON COAST
description: A man who said he had a bomb in a shoebox tried to hijack a jetliner to Afghanistan today, the authorities said, and was shot to death by one of two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who sneaked aboard when the plane landed at Portland. All 41 people aboard escaped unhurt and no bomb was found.

title: ENVIRNMENTAL PROTECTORS PREFER 'PRETENSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FAULTY COMPUTER AND WEATHER DELAY TEST FIRING OF PERSHING
description: A faulty computer and bad weather today forced a postponement of the third test firing of a Pershing 2 missile.

title: WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $30 million representing a provision for loss on disposition of certain coal mining assets...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $48.3 million from the exchange of debt for equity

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, opening sentences were omitted from an article about an Urban League survey of black America in the Late Edition yesterday. The article is reprinted today on page A11.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: NOT one but two celebrations went on Wednesday night at Lincoln C enter. One was a ballet by Jacques d'Amboise called ''Celebration.''T he other was the annual gala benefit for the School of American B allet, with a candle-lighted supper dance on the promenade of the N ew York State Theater after the performance.

title: British Spending Rises
description: Britain's consumer spending, seasonally adjusted at 1975 prices, rose 1.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 1982, to a record 18.5 billion. That followed a downward revised 1.1 percent rise in the third quarter, preliminary data from the Central Statistical Office shows. The pound is now worth about $1.56.

title: ALLEN DORFMAN BUILT WEALTH THROUGH TEAMSTER CONTACTS
description: Allen M. Dorfman, the Chicago insurance executive who was slain yesterday in a hotel parking lot near Chicago, built a huge financial empire through close associations with leaders of the teamsters' union that began more than 30 years ago.

title: U.S. WAS LESS EMPHATIC IN REJECTING MISSILES PROPOSAL, AIDES SAY
description: Although both the United States and the Soviet Union later disavowed a proposed understanding on intermediate-range missiles worked out in private at Geneva last summer, Washington did not close the door quite as firmly as Moscow, Reagan Administration officials disclosed today.

title: THE CONSUMER MOVEMENT: WHATEVER HAPPENED?
description: Consumer activists and the Reagan Administration alike say they represent consumers, but they seem to have different constituencies in mind.

title: Penthouse Executive Moves to New Job
description: The Magazine Publishers Association has announced that Marianne Howatson is to be the new senior vice president/marketing.

title: EGYPT ENTERS A ZONE IN ERROR
description: Two Egyptian tractors, reportedly guarded by armed Egyptian policemen, crossed into the neutral, disputed zone of Taba, on the Israeli-Egyptian border in Sinai, today in what Israel charged was a violation of an agreement between the two countries.

title: Key U.S. Trade Official, A Japan Specialist, Quits
description: David R. Macdonald, a specialist in Japanese trade issues, has resigned as deputy United States trade representative to return to private law practice, it was announced today.

title: TO FUND RETRAINING OF THE UNEMPLOYED
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvester Recall
description: The International Harvester Company announced a recall of all hourly production employees who had been on layoff status from its Indianapolis engine operations. The last group of 35 employees returned to work Jan. 10, bringing total employment at the facility to 1,242, it said. About 390 foundry workers remain on layoff, and 89 salaried and skilled trades employees have not been recalled, it said.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $247,000...C-Net income including a tax credit of $932,000

title: Hecht, Hollander Win Bollingen Poetry Prize
description: Anthony E. Hecht and John Hollander have won the 1983 Bollingen Prize in Poetry, which is given every two years to living American poets.

title: PNB MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $349,000 on the sale of real estate and a provision for losses on real estate loans and investments of $205,000

title: NEW BLOOD AT MIDSEASON: NBC UNVEILING 3 SERIES
description: THIS weekend brings the midseason unveiling on NBC of three new series that programmers hope will help revive the network's sagging prime-time fortunes. Having won higher compliments than ratings with such offbeat series as ''Taxi,'' ''Cheers'' and ''Fame,'' NBC moves to more familiar ground with ''Mama's Family,'' ''The Family Tree'' and ''The A Team.''

title: FOR LABOR, EMPLOYERS
description: Amid speculation about how to end the recession, one thing that has been relatively overlooked is the crucial importance of labormanagement relations in restoring the productivity necessary for economic recovery.

title: Flooding Said to Affect Half of All Ecuadoreans
description: About 4.5 million Ecuadoreans, about half the country's population, have been affected by recent flooding, Ecuadorean officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corp. has appointed Ronald D. Nichols president and division chief executive officer of Pomeroy's, Levittown, Pa., and Donald L. Triplett president and division chief executive officer of Troutman's, Greensburg, Pa.

title: AIRCRAFT ENGINES: STIFF RIVALRY
description: A decade ago, the engine makers for the aviation industry were doing business in a far simpler world. Pratt & Whitney dominated the market, each plane model was matched with a specific engine from a specific company, and the demands of the airframe makers and the airlines were easier to meet.

title: CUOMO PLANNING 7,000 NEW CELLS FOR STATE PRISONS
description: The Cuomo administration announced plans today to add 7,000 cells to new or existing prisons around the state to try to reduce severe overcrowding.

title: POP JAZZ
description: OUTSIDE of the backwoods, fans of bluegrass and old-timey music get their information through a grapevine of disk jockeys, small record labels, magazines and other fans. Kathy Kaplan has been active in that grapevine for more than a decade - as a writer, record producer, disk jockey (on WBAI-FM and WKCR) and, still, as a fan - although she was recently stricken with amyotropic lateral sclerosis, ''Lou Gehrig's Disease.''

title: Many Blood Banks Deny Request of Hemophiliacs; The Associated Press
description: Many of the nation's blood banks say they will not heed the advice of the National Hemophilia Foundation that male donors be asked whether they are homosexuals. The question is part of a effort to screen possible carriers of a disease that cripples the body's immune system.

title: The Jets' Coal Miner
description: L ance Mehl did not need his two game-saving interceptions and the hugs from his teammates last Saturday to convince him that football is a lovely occupation. He learned that lesson on his old summer job, when the roof of the coal mine collapsed.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bruins 4, Sabres 0
description: BOSTON (AP) - Pete Peeters earned his third shutout in four games and his seventh of the season to lift Boston to its sixth straight victory. Peeters, whose shutout string was broken Monday night in a 4-3 Bruin victory over Minnesota, had 20 saves in extending his unbeaten string to 24 games. He is 20-0-4 since a loss to Quebec last Nov. 11.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN HOME UP
description: Pfizer Inc., one of the nation's leading producers of ethical pharmaceuticals and chemicals, reported yesterday that the introduction of several new drugs had helped to increase earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 by 21.9 percent, while sales edged up 4.6 percent.

title: 'THRESHOLD,' A HOSPITAL DRAMA
description: ''THRESHOLD'' is such a rigorously unhackneyed, unhysterical medical drama that what one remembers about it first is not what one has seen on the screen but all of the cliches that the film makers have triumphantly resisted.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Nets, who have won 10 straight from Cleveland, will probably have Darryl Dawkins back at center. He missed Monday night's game because of a sprained right ankle. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Utah Jazz, at Salt Lake City. Bill Cartwright, the Knick center, needs only 1 point for a career total of 5,000. (Radio - WNEW, 1130; 9:30 P.M.) College Games: Dayton at DePaul (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M.); City College at Pace, 7 P.M.; Loyola of Baltimore at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; Sacred Heart at New Haven, 7:30 P.M.; George Washington at Monmouth, women's game, 6 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Jets, at Winnipeg, Manitoba. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M).

title: DISARRY TIME
description: After two years of coverage ranging from ecstatic to cautiously critical, the Washington press suddenly is in hot pursuit of ''an Administration in disarray,'' which is ''coming apart at the seams'' under the non-leadership of ''a detached President.''

title: Fire Extinguisher Is Banned by City
description: City officials yesterday announced a ban on the use of oldfashioned inverted ''soda acid'' fire extinguishers because the devices could explode and injure someone trying to use them.

title: CHINA TRADE STARS AT ANTIQUE SHOW
description: THE Winter Antiques Show has again transformed the interior of the Seventh Regiment Armory, that sprawling red brick fortress at Park Avenue and 66th Street, into a nine-day bazaar stocked with an exotic abundance of vintage wares that originally decorated everything from barns to palaces. The show, the country's most highly regarded antiques fair, establishes trends and sets prices for the entire antiques field.
