Most of the 73 dealers exhibiting this year have saved their rarest wares to present at this show.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
Fund Use Tightening Sought
description: The Reagan Administraton proposed rules today to insure that Federal funds are not used to underwrite political advocacy if the funds involve Government contracts and grants.

title: Politics as Usual For Coetzee Bout
description: The promoter Don King, who has long advised Larry Holmes not to meet the South African contender, Gerrie Coetzee, has agreed to let Michael Dokes, his other heavyweight champion, fight Coetzee.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $49,000

title: G.E. Plant Accused Of Water Pollution
description: Hazardous chemicals from the General Electric Company's Waterford plant have contaminated nearby ground water and the Hudson River, State Attorney General Robert Abrams charged today.

title: U.S. Rebuffs Soviet In Paramus Case
description: The United States has rejected Soviet charges that the police in Paramus, N.J., were guilty of ''rude, illegal and degrading actions'' when they arrested the wife of a Soviet diplomat last month who the police accused of shoplifting.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Frederick Atkins
description: The board of Frederick Atkins Inc. agreed to pursue a proposal for a possible merger with the Associated Merchandising Corporation.

title: HOUSE ARMS PANEL TORN BY A BATTLE 'OUT OF THE BLUE'
description: A spirited behind-the-scenes skirmish has developed between two senior members of the House Armed Services Committee, where squabbling over coveted subcommittee chairmanships has long been considered unseemly.

title: FLORIDA COAST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities gains of $419,534 and extraordinary gain of $1.4 million from debt for equity exchange

title: The Pentagon's High-Tech Rollers
description: The approaching struggle in Congress over reducing the Defense Department's budget will resemble a debate among surgeons about how best to contain an inoperable cancer. But cutting is not the only necessity; some cures lie deeper.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
WATT SAYS FOES WANT CENTRALIZATION OF POWER
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt was criticized today for saying that his environmental critics were pursuing the ''greater objective'' of the central control of society as the Nazis and Bolsheviks did.

title: Ever More; Unhappy Clams
description: The nation's demand for Long Island clams has plummeted since 800 Long Islanders became ill after eating them. The suspected clams are believed to have been smuggled in from out of state.

title: Du Pont Gives $50,000 Grant To Eagle Breeding Program
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today it would give $50,000 to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's program to increase the number of American bald eagles in the wild.

title: News Analysis
description: At the midpoint of his term of office, Ronald Reagan and his advisers are turning to new themes, public relations gestures and initiatives to revitalize a troubled

title: PRIVATE SCREENINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $13,180 for the qr and $6,784 for the 6 mos ...C-Yr-ago results are unavailable as Private Screenings became a public company in June1982

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $281,000 for the qr and $1.6 million for the yr and losses from discontinued operations of $757,000 for the qr and $2.1 million for the yr...C-After securities losses of $1.2 million a loss from discontinued operations of $561,000 and a loss on disposal of operations of $2.6 million

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARGOSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPERA: RICHARD STRAUSS'S 'GUNTRAM'
description: IN her years as an industrious restorer of musical antiques, Eve Queler has dusted off and polished up many a musty opera, including in recent times such collector's items as Boito's ''Nerone'' and Wagner's ''Rienzi.'' Long-neglected pieces often turn out to be so rickety as to be beyond repair, of course, but in almost every instance the concert performances by Miss Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York have filled out our understanding of the composer and his period. That certainly was true of her revival of ''Guntram'' at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, when Richard Strauss's first opera had its first American performance.

title: CONTRACEPTION: A RULE DIRECTED AT 'BAD KIDS' (MALES EXCEPTED)
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 8 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was down 5.9 percent, or 8 million shares, in the month ended Jan. 14, to 127.3 million shares. Last year the short interest totaled 85 million shares.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REDSKINS GUIDED BY A STEADY HAND
description: In a football playoff studded with well-known coaches like Don Shula, Tom Landry and Walt Michaels, what can you say about Joe Gibbs of Mocksville, N.C.?

title: BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Joe N olan, catcher, to three-year contract, a nd Benny Ayala, outfielder, for two y ears. CHICAGO (NL) - Acquired Ron Cey, t hird baseman, from Los Angeles for two m inor league players, Dan Cataline, out- f ielder, and Vance Lovelace, pitcher. R eached agreement in principle on a five- y ear contract with Cey. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Reached a greement with Bo Diaz, catcher, on a f our-year guaranteed contract, with op- t ion for a fifth year. SEATTLE (AL) - Selected Danny Tar- t abull, infielder, from free-agent compen- s ation pool. Mariners obtained him as pay- m ent for Floyd Bannister, pitcher and T ype A free agent, who signed with Chi- c ago White Sox. Tartabull, son of Jose T artabull, former major league outfield- e r, played in the Cincinnati Reds organiza- t ion.

title: CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,627,000...D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $20,289,000...E-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,916,000

title: Merola Plea Denied In Sentry Co. Case
description: A judge rejected a request yesterday by the Bronx District Attorney to revoke the bail of one of the three defendants in the Sentry Armored Car Courier Service case and to force another to surrender his passport.

title: No Headline
description: Morris Is Sentenced To 20 Years in Jail

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ALUMINUM PRODUCERS POST LOSSES
description: The three largest aluminum producers in North America yesterday reported substantial losses for the fourth quarter of 1982, making the quarter the worst in decades for the industry.

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
8th Grader Kills Youth, Then Himself at School
description: An eighth grader armed with two pistols opened fire in a junior high school study hall today, killing one student and wounding one, before shooting himself, the police said.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SINOPOLI CONDUCTS
description: GIUSEPPE SINOPOLI is a conductor and a composer, but in exactly what proportions we do not yet know. The Italian polymath (he is also a surgeon and a psychiatrist) might have enlightened us on that matter last night, but he withdrew from the program a suite from his opera, ''Lou Salome,'' reportedly in order to revise and shorten it. That was too bad, since it would have been nice to assess Mr. Sinopoli's conducting and composing skills in one gulp. However, the work he substituted on this New York Philharmonic program, Bruno Maderna's ''Biogramma'' for Large Orchestra, turned out to be one of real quality, though dated in style and probably of transient interest.

title: STOCKS UP IN HEAVIER TRADING
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday in heavier trading, with the depressed energy issues posting the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the day, gained 2.76 points, to 1,070.82. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 82.8 million shares from 80.9 million Wednesday.

title: Rise in New Products Called a Sign of Upturn
description: Beverly Hills Kitty Litter, with each package made of $10,000 in shredded currency, and hard-to-order Hopfenperle beer from the Swiss brewer Feldschlosschen were among the 143 new products entering the marketplace in December, as noted by Martin J. Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News.

title: Gulf Canada Pact
description: Canada has approved an exploration agreement in the Beaufort Sea with Gulf Canada Resources Inc., involving capital and operating expenditures of more than $1 billion (Canadian), John Monroe, Minister of Indian and Northern Affairs, said. The five-year agreement can be extended to seven years if Gulf, operator on the lands, increases its drilling commitment beyond five wells. Gulf Canada Resources Inc. is a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Company.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
ISRAELI COURT TOLD OF DRIVE ON ARABS
description: A lawyer for an Israeli major who is being tried with six soldiers on charges of beating West Bank Arabs has submitted secret documents to back his contention that the army Chief of Staff had ordered tough measures to be used to quell disturbances.

title: Papp's plan to aid theater has key ingredient: money.
description: ''THE Broadway theater and the noncommercial theater seem to be at a standstill,'' Joseph Papp began. ''Our theater is not alive. Our theater is not vital. So, the question is, what can we do to aggressively go out and get things moving?''

title: YVES TANGUY, A SURREALIST FOR THE FUN OF IT
description: IT is a happy chance that has brought to the Guggenheim Museum, as of today and through Feb. 27, a retrospective exhibition of paintings by Yves Tanguy. With one or two pictures added and one or two taken away, this is fundamentally the show that was seen last year at the Pompidou Center in Paris, though it lacks the voluminous documentation that made that exhibition as much of a joy to read as to look at. The Guggenheim show comes with a brochure that includes a vivid and enlightening personal memoir of Tanguy by Sir Roland Penrose, the English painter, poet, collector and critic.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 21, 1983
description: International France strongly defended the basing of new American medium-range missiles in Europe in the absence of a Soviet-American arms agreement. President Francois Mitterrand, on a visit to Bonn, criticized the Soviet military buildup, urged unity in NATO and warned against efforts to separate the United States and Western Europe. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) Optimism on arms control talks with the Soviet Union was expressed by President Reagan because, he said, ''a perpetual arms race'' is not in Moscow's interest. (A1:4.)

title: Evaluation Of Currencies
description: The Swiss franc and Japanese yen are likely to be the strongest currencies in 1983, the Union Bank of Switzerland said today in a review of foreign exchange prospects for 1983.

title: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Super Bowl Ring Stolen
description: Larry Grantham, a linebacker for the Jet team that won the 1969 Super Bowl, was sleeping in his hotel room early Wednesday morning when a burglar escaped with $1,000 in cash and valuables, including Grantham's Super Bowl ring.

title: A POLICE OFFICER'S RIGHT TO AID A COLLEAGUE
description: To the Editor:

title: New Computers Displayed by NCR
description: The NCR Corporation displayed a new line of microcomputers and a network for resource sharing and announced new software licensing agreements with Digital Research Inc.

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52

title: First-Time Claims for Benefits By Unemployed Are Up Again
description: About 568,000 Americans filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits in the week ended Jan. 8, the second consecutive week of rising applications, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results are in U.S. dollars

title: OPEC TALKS EXPECTED TO FOCUS ON PRODUCTION
description: The 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, at their meeting this weekend in Geneva, will focus much more intensively on how much oil each produces, rather than on past conflicts over pricing.

title: 2 discoveries of furniture.
description: THE top two lots of 18th-century furniture being offered in Americana sales next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, are such stuff as dreams are made on in the auction world - unexpected discoveries. The auctions, which also include furnishings, folk art, 19th-century paintings, drawings and prints, take place next Thursday through Jan. 29, each day at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: AT THE ROOT OF ACADEMIC INERTIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Ever More; Poetic Tribute
description: Once upon a midnight dreary - two nights ago, as a matter of fact - 70 people gathered in a Baltimore cemetery to celebrate Edgar Allan Poe's birthday with a glass of Amontillado and a reading of his poems. When the crowd dispersed, five of them hid among the catacombs, waiting to see if they could discover who, every Jan. 19 for the last 33 years, has placed a half-empty bottle of cognac and three roses on the poet's grave.

title: Let Facts, Not Faith, Guide the Police
description: The Supreme Court surprised everyone last fall by inviting special argument about relaxing the so-called exclusionary rule, which bars the use at trial of illegally acquired evidence. The Justice Department's eager response, however, was neither surprising nor persuasive.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Britain's Palace Intruder Is Freed From a Hospital
description: Michael Fagan, an unemployed laborer who entered Queen Elizabeth's private bedroom in Buckingham Palace last July, was freed Wednesday night from a maximum security hospital in Liverpool on the ruling of an official mental health tribunal.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Jury Says Officers Acted Properly in Capital Death
description: A Federal grand jury concluded that there had been no wrongdoing by the police when officers killed an antinuclear protester who threatened to blow up the Washington Monument Dec. 8, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'MAN FROM SNOWY RIVER'
description: THERE are not so many big westerns around that one can easily dismiss the Australian ''The Man From Snowy River,'' which opens today at the Baronet and 34th Street East Theaters. To appreciate it fully, however, one must have a completely uncritical fondness for Kirk Douglas as he acts his heart out in two roles; for picturesque landscapes; for silly plots, and for dialogue that leans heavily on aphorisms too homespun to be repeated in a big-city newspaper.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Saturday about Korf Industries misstated the amount of a loan that Korf wants restructured. It is $147 million.

title: PRESIDENT VOICES OPTIMISM ON PACT TO CURB MISSILES
description: President Reagan said today that he was optimistic that progress would be made in arms control talks because ''a perpetual arms race'' is not in the Soviet Union's interest.

title: SCA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Whoever would bet on the decoupling of the European continent and the American continent would put into question the maintenance of equilibrium and thus the maintenance of peace.'' - President Francois Mitterrand of France. (A1:2.)

title: Chessie Replies In Conrail Dispute
description: A rate dispute involving Conrail and the Chessie System is the result of anticompetitive steps by Conrail, according to a spokesman for Chessie who was responding to similar accusations from Conrail.

title: URBAN LEAGUE SEEKS GUARANTEED JOBS FOR ALL
description: The National Urban League, saying the plight of black Americans has grown worse in the last year, called on President Reagan Wednesday to declare a ''state of national economic emergency'' with guaranteed jobs for all.

title: 3 SYNAGOGUES TO AID CITY'S HOMELESS
description: The New York Board of Rabbis announced yesterday that three of its affiliated synagogues would provide a total of 15 to 20 beds for the homeless in New York City and that other synagogues outside the group were already doing so.

title: BACKDATED MEMO ON RIGHTS IS CONCEDED
description: The Justice Department has acknowledged backdating a document that figures prominently in a voting rights case in New Orleans.

title: MUMMENSCHANZ BOUNCES BACK AT 92D STREET Y
description: A CURVACEOUS female, clad in a black body stocking from the top of her head to her ankles, has rolls of pink toilet paper sticking out from her hidden face to form eyes, ears, nose and mouth. She runs trippingly across the stage, streaming two long trails of pink double-ply behind her. A male, also in black, swivels to watch her; his features, made of yellow toilet paper rolls, begin to tremble. The two flirt, pulling out, tearing off and swirling reams of paper to denote words, weeping, embraces. He sends her a message: she scans it hastily like a strip of ticker tape, then rejects it. He bunches up paper to make her a bouquet: she plucks shreds from it as if she were playing ''He loves me, he loves me not'' with daisy petals.

title: STADLER LEADS DESERT CLASSIC BY 6 SHOTS
description: Craig Stadler continued to dominate the Bob Hope Desert Classic today as he took a six-stroke lead at the end of the second round. Stadler, the PGA Tour's leading money winner last season with $446,462, added a 66 to his 63 on Wednesday for a total of 129, which is 15 under par for the two rounds.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed; One-Year Bill Brings 8.007%
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday. Short-term rates rose less than a tenth of a percentage point, while yields on long-term bonds fell by even less.

title: FACED LONG TERM BRIBERY CASE
description: Allen M. Dorfman, a consultant to the teamsters' union who was recently convicted of conspiring to bribe a United States Senator, was slain this afternoon in the icy parking lot of a suburban hotel restaurant.

title: Litton Industries Chief Seeks Balanced Growth
description: The recent offer by Litton Industries to acquire the Itek Corporation for $238 million in cash has evoked memories of the takeover binge that made Litton one of the glamour conglomerates in the 1960's - and a major Wall Street disappointment in the early 1970's.

title: Inquiry Into Crash On Turnpike Starts
description: State and Federal investigators began today to try to reconstruct a fiery crash that resulted in the deaths of seven people and injuries to three others at the Stratford tollbooth on the Connecticut Turnpike on Wednesday.

title: MCENROE AND VILAS IN SEMIFINALS
description: Showtime returned to the Volvo Masters last night at Madison Square Garden. And, in the middle of everything, as usual, was John McEnroe. McEnroe won, as usual, 6-3, 6-4, from Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina for a spot in tomorrow afternoon's semifinals against Guillermo Vilas, who ousted Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 7-5, 6-4, earlier in the day.

title: Scholarship Fund
description: The $30-a-person luncheon in New Jersey the other day was in honor of Ray Perkins, the Alabama-bound former coach of the Giants.

title: G.M. May Rehire
description: Up to 5,400 auto workers who were laid off last year when two Pontiac plants were closed could be back at work at the General Motors Corporation's new Orion Township assembly facility by fall, a G.M. spokesman said.

title: DON COSTA, MUSICIAN-CONDUCTOR
description: Don Costa, the musician who discovered the singer Paul Anka and conducted and arranged hit albums for Frank Sinatra and dozens of other top stars, died here Wednesday night. He was 57 years old.

title: SURREAL SOUTH AFRICA
description: There is an otherworldly quality about South African life. It gives a strange sense of detachment from everywhere else.

title: Williams Seeks Second Opinion
description: Sly Williams, the Knick forward who has been troubled by a sore left knee, will seek a second opinion, possibly today, from Dr. Vincent Turco, the orthopedic surgeon for the Hartford Whalers hockey team.

title: SCREEN: 'YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY'
description: PETER WEIR'S ''The Year of Living Dangerously'' is a good, romantic melodrama that suffers more than most good, romantic melodramas in not being much better than it is. This film should be some kind of epic. It's set in and around Jakarta in 1965, in the last months of the flamboyant, one-man rule of President Sukarno, the Indonesian nationalist hero who aspired to be a Third World leader abroad, to reconcile left and right at home and to be the playboy of the Eastern world.

title: AMERICAN BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 results were restated to reflect the merger with National Bank & TrustCo of Kennett Square, Pa., in Mar 1982 on a pooling-of-interests basis

title: Native American and Japanese-style.
description: ONE of the saddest of phenomena to witness is a near-miss. A case in point is the year-and-a-half-old American Harvest, a high, wide and handsome clublike restaurant in the trim, polished Vista International Hotel next to the World Trade Center. This should have been a bright addition to the local restaurant scene. There are few options for good food downtown and few restaurants anywhere that are as spacious and relatively quiet. The menu is original and interesting, and it changes monthly to incorporate seasonal products - cranberries in December, potatoes in January - in stylized, native preparations. But though there are enough decent dishes for a pleasant lunch or dinner when you're in this part of town, neither food nor service merits a special trip.

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $146,600 for the qr and $293,700for the 6 mos

title: Goodyear Plant Set for South
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced it would locate a $50 million steel wire cord manufacturing plant for radial tires in Asheboro, N.C., employing 350 people.

title: CONTRACEPTION: A RULE DIRECTED AT 'BAD KIDS' (MALES EXCEPTED)
description: To the Editor: The ''squeal rule'' is blatantly sexist. If teen-age girls must be reported to their parents for getting a contraceptive pill or device, then shouldn't the local druggist be required to notify parents when Junior comes in and buys a box of condoms? If ever there was a contraceptive device, that's it. v. hy should a girl be penalized and the boy let go scot-free? ALVIN TRESSELT West Redding, Conn., Jan. 14, 1983

title: AMSTAR CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
CONIFER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'YEAR OF LIVING DANGEROUSLY'
description: PETER WEIR'S ''The Year of Living Dangerously'' is a good, romantic melodrama that suffers more than most good, romantic melodramas in not being much better than it is. This film should be some kind of epic. It's set in and around Jakarta in 1965, in the last months of the flamboyant, one-man rule of President Sukarno, the Indonesian nationalist hero who aspired to be a Third World leader abroad, to reconcile left and right at home and to be the playboy of the Eastern world.

title: STREAK IS NOW 6-0-1
description: In a cautious game spiced by sporadic acts of daring, Mark Napier's game-tying goal tonight was the appropriate final touch. There was nothing cautious about it.

title: Pregame Shows
description: What is the atmosphere in the locker room of the Jets before a big game? A bit strange. Before the last regular-season game of 1981, which the Jets needed to win to reach the playoffs, Marty Lyons, the defensive tackle, broke both his helmet and a table at Shea Stadium after throwing the helmet and then kicking the table.

title: Friday; 'WALTZES' IN MONTCLAIR
description: The pianist Ruth Laredo will play Schubert waltzes as members of the Hartford Ballet dance around her tonight at 8 in the world premiere of ''Waltzes,'' a Peter Martins ballet. The event, at Montclair (N.J.) State College, is the second collaboration between Miss Laredo and the company, and is intended to evoke the intimate ambience of a 19th-century drawing room. Repeated tomorrow night at 8, same site -Valley Road and Normal Avenue in Upper Montclair - and Sunday at 8 P.M. at Suffern (N.Y.) High School on Viola Road. Tickets at Montclair: $10 ($8 for students with Montclair identification and for the elderly). Reservations: (201) 893-5112. Suffern tickets: $7 ($6 for the elderly, $5 for students). Information: (914) 356-4650, extension 218. ART UNDER THE CLOCKTOWER

title: Toyota and G.M.  Set U.S. Venture
description: Toyota and the General Motors Corporation have reached a broad agreement on a joint venture to make between 200,000 and 300,000 front-wheel-drive cars a year, Toyota sources said.

title: C-COR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Free Chamber Concert
description: The Prima Chamber Ensemble, a quartet that specializes in works by women composers, will give a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: Mitchell Energy
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation said it had agreed in principle with an unidentified investor to form a partnership for acquiring up to $100 million of oil and gas properties.

title: Yugoslav Refining Deal
description: Iran and Yugoslavia have agreed to an arrangement under which Iranian crude oil will be refined in Yugoslavia for the world market, the press agency for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: Jean Harris Asks High Court Review
description: The Supreme Court was asked today by Jean Harris, who was convicted in in the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, to review her case because of massive publicity and prejudicial evidence.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MIDLAND GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
JAPANESE TO STUDY GUARDING SEA LANE
description: On his return Friday from talks in Washington with President Reagan, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will set in motion a United States-Japanese study on how Japan can take charge of the security of sea lanes in the western Pacific.

title: TEAM AMERICA JOINS N.A.S.L.
description: The United States Soccer Federation said yesterday that Team America, the recently conceived squad that is intended to make the country a force at the world-class level, would join the North American Soccer League for a full 30-game schedule this year.

title: Eurodollar Bonds Gain
description: The Eurodollar bond market, which has been flooded with about $5.5 billion in new issues this year, rose today in late trading but not enough to offset Wednesday's sharp drop.

title: Attack on Legal Services Cited
description: A former director of the Legal Services Corporation whose nomination to the agency was later withdrawn by President Reagan today denounced the Administration's efforts to abolish the agency.

title: JETS' SALAAM ALTERS HIS FOCUS
description: When dissension rippled through the Jets' defensive line earlier this season, Abdul Salaam was the buffer.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects a negative impact of $20,000 for the qr and $40,000,000 for the yr related to foreign currency fluctuations...C-After a charge of $52,400,000 representing one-time losses associated with discontinued operations

title: CITY LOBBYIST QUITS JOB IN WASHINGTON
description: The Washington lobbyist for New York City's interests here, Julian Spirer, said today he was leaving to join a Washington law firm after five years in the $55,000-a-year post.

title: GRANDMA LEE'S GOOD NEWS ENDS
description: The idea behind Grandma Lee's, a Canadian fastfood chain, seemed ready-made for success: ''To serve food the way Grandma made it - if you remember Grandma at the turn of the century,'' according to Josef Meyer, the company's former vice president,

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest qr and yr earnings include operations of the six banks in Western Colorado acquired June 1, 1981 for the full yr; the yr-ago amounts include operations of these banks for only seven months; the latest periods also include the operations of Littleton National Bank since acquisition Aug 31, 1982 and of Alameda National Bank since acquisition Nov 8, 1982; the yr-ago earnings include gain on sale of Piedmont Mortgage's mortgage servicing portfolio of $595,000 or 9 cents per shr

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE COLD FACTS OF ALBANY
description: Now is the discontent of Albany's winter. The snow fell deeper here this week than it has in quite some time, and it still lies in drifts and piles and heaps that shift with the blustery wind.

title: Bolivia Cabinet Collapses After 3 Months in Office
description: The civilian coalition Cabinet that took office three months ago after nearly two decades of military rule collapsed today over what some politicians described as a dispute over presidential powers.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains of $8,600,000 on Ticorassett sales and $2,700,000 on income tax benefits...C-After a loss from discontinued operations and a gain of $12,000,000 on the sale of tax benefits and $6,200,000 on the exchange of stock for debt

title: NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shrs outstdng have increased as a result of the public auction held in Apr 1982 of $825,000 shrs of common stock

title: 3 in Plane Arrested On Drug Charges
description: Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday when they landed a single-engine plane loaded with 1,400 pounds of marijuana at a Rockland County airport after a nonstop flight from Jamaica, a spokesman for the United States Customs Service said.

title: Less Oil Used By U.S. in '82
description: The United States consumed almost 6 percent less oil in 1982 and cut oil imports by 20 percent compared with the previous year, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: Penn Central Up 23.2%
description: The Penn Central Corporation said yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1982 rose 23.2 percent, to $39.3 million, or 96 cents a share, from $31.9 million, or 73 cents a share, in the similar 1981 period.

title: Head of Aircraft Project Struggles to Raise Cash
description: In Youngstown, Ohio, one of the most economically depressed areas in the nation, an attempt is being made by the Commuter Aircraft Corporation to manufacture a new 50-passenger propjet. The company has yet to create any assembly line jobs, but it has hired a new chairman and chief executive, Frank F. Davis.

title: Borg May Quit, Rome Paper Says
description: A Rome newspaper, La Repubblica, reported yesterday that Bjorn Borg was tired of playing tennis and wanted to quit. According to The Associated Press, the newspaper also reported that Borg had told Julian Jakobi and Peter Warr, who are affiliated with the Internatiuonal Management Group that represents Borg, that he wanted to get out of about 50 contracts he had signed with various companies and sponsors.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Index; International
description: Rwanda's? Uganda's? 45,000 peo- ple without a country A2 Israel charges Egypt with viola- tion in disputed zone A3 Two top police officials in Ireland resign A3 U.S. and Japan to study sea-lane role for Tokyo A4 Around the World A5 Computer and weather force postponement of Pershing test A6 Soviet weekly rejects accord on medium-range missiles A6 U.S. was less emphatic in reject- ing arms proposal, aides say A7 Government/Politics Justice Dept. concedes backdat ing memo A15 Reporter's notebook: Cold times in Albany B3 Minority-group members of City Council oppose at-large seats B3 Excerpts from New Jersey Su- preme Court ruling on zoning B8 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Consumer activists versus the Reagan Administration A16 House Armed Services panel is focus of internal skirmish A16 Energy Interior Dept. announces new rules for strip mining A10 General Around the Nation A10 Few defend ex-prosecutor who lost rights suit A10 Hijacker of Northwest jetliner on coast reported killed A10 Despite leaks in economy, city still afloat, Koch says B3 News Analysis Steven R. Weisman on Reagan Administration at midterm A1 Jonathan Fuerbringer discusses budget deficits D1 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 China trade stars at antiques show C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: PRETORIA'S WARS
description: An undeclared war in southern Africa threatens to draw both superpowers into a protracted, region-wide conflict. While the Administration has been chasing a Namibian settlement, South Africa has changed the rules of the game in southern Africa. In the latter part of the 1970's, its harassment focused on the Cubanbacked Government in Angola, raiding its territory and aiding Unita insurgents there. In the past several years, however, South Africa has greatly extended its direct and indirect military offensive, which now includes Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Lesotho as well.

title: THEATER: 'ENTERTAINER,' WITH NICOL WILLIAMSON
description: ALTHOUGH John Osborne's ''The Entertainer'' is much beloved by theater people -it presents the theater itself as a paradigm of Life - it is almost never revived. The huge stumbling block, of course, is Laurence Olivier. Those fortunate enough to have seen him originate the title role of Archie Rice, whether in London in 1957 or on Broadway in 1958, invariably consider the performance an indelible experience. The rest of us, who know Mr. Olivier's Archie from the 1960 film version, also find the star and the role inseparable. Only an actor of rare courage would even dream of following a legend into the flickering center spotlight of Mr. Osborne's bitter elegy for a dying England.

title: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary items

title: Article 179373 -- No Title
description: A $1.5 billion credit was arranged yesterday by the nation's leading banks to strengthen the Seafirst Corporation of Seattle, which last night reported an operating loss of $61.4 million for the fourth quarter of 1982 and a loss of $90.2 million for the year.

title: Nehemiah in Millrose
description: A day after the United States Olympic Committee ruled that he was an amateur in everything but football, Renaldo Nehemiah, the highhurdling wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers, was officially entered in the Millrose Games, to be held at Madison Square Garden next Friday.

title: PAST ACTS OF COMPASSION SPUR CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The memory of beloved family members who showed compassion for the poor, the neglected and the unfortunate is honored by many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: DESPITE ECONOMIC TROUBLES, CITY'S STILL AFLOAT, KOCH SAYS
description: With manufacturing jobs in New York City at a record low and service jobs not growing as quickly as in the recent past, with hotel occupancy down and tourism off, some might see troubled days ahead.

title: Storm Uproots Rig in Gulf
description: The rig Ocean Driller broke from its mooring early today in a storm in the Gulf of Mexico 10 miles from the mouth of the Mississippi, forcing the evacuating of 42 workers. A crew of 10 remained on the rig in the afternoon as it drifted slowly to the southwest, guided by the workboat Morning Light, according to Al Spindler, a spokesman for the Ocean Drilling and Exploration Company.

title: JERSEY RULING AIDS HOUSING FOR POOR
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, angered that 10 years of court rulings had failed to achieve housing in the suburbs for the poor, today ordered all municipalities to take steps to insure housing opportunities for low- and moderate-income families.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wollman Rink Returns To the Action

title: SALARIES BEING CUT AT BETHLEHEM STEEL
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, said today that it is reducing the salaries of 14,000 of its salaried employees effective Feb. 1.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds declined by $3.4 billion, to $201.8 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the seventh consecutive weekly drop, bringing the assets to their lowest level since last June.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Big-City Law, Country Style

title: DEFICITS CRITICIZED BY VOLCKER
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said tonight that the large Government deficits projected by the Reagan Administration for the mid-1980's must be narrowed if the Fed is to have the flexibility to work for a lasting economic recovery.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.C.L.A. Wins
description: Kenny Fields scored 19 points, and Ralph Jackson had 17 tonight to lead top-ranked U.C.L.A., which extended its 22-year winning streak over California with a 68-63 victory. The Bruins beat California for the 47th straight time and improved their record this season to 12-1, 5-0 in the Pacific-10 conference. California (7-5 and 2-2) last beat U.C.L.A. on Feb. 24, 1961.

title: Dr. Louis O. Mink Jr., 61, Dies; Taught Philosophy at Wesleyan
description: Dr. Louis O. Mink Jr. a member of the Wesleyan University faculty for 30 years, died at Hartford Hospital on Wednesday, two weeks after suffering a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived in Middletown, Conn.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MIDTERM REPORT FOM WHITE HOUSE ON REAGAN PRESIDENCY
description: Following are excerpts from a midterm report on the Reagan Presidency issued today by the White House: President Reagan came to office convinced that the way to solve America's problems was to build on her basic underlying strengths - including her economic and military strength. Perhaps the two greatest accomplishments of his first two years have come in laying twin foundations for the revitalization of both. Foundation for Economic Recovery in Place

title: PERSHING 2 MAKES TEST FLIGHT
description: The Pershing 2 missile, which President Reagan plans to deploy in Europe, made its first full 800-mile test flight today, something it had failed to do in two previous tests.

title:
THE HIGH STAKES OF OPEC ACTIONS;
News Analysis
description: The 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are meeting this weekend in Geneva in an atmosphere of high international drama. Behind the meeting room's closed doors, the prospects for world economic recovery, the solvency of nations and the stability of major multinational banks could all be on the table.

title: THEY MADE IT HAPPEN
description: On those occasions when government does its job well, it is often because special individuals determined to do the right thing were able to overcome the cumbersome apparatus that envelops government employees and sometimes suffocates them.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column in some editions yesterday incorrectly described the views of Gregory Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service, on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, which the service administers. He says the test treats blacks and whites equally. His criticism of the National Collegiate Athletic Association is that it fixed a rigid cutoff score, 700, for freshman athletes.

title: The Many Moods Of John McEnroe
description: J ohn McEnroe, sweet John McEnroe, gentle John McEnroe, winsome John McEnroe came through a portal and stepped onto the brightly lighted tennis court of Madison Square Garden as if he had gotten up on the wrong side of the bedstead.

title: Von Schamann Still Uncertain
description: Coach Don Shula of the Dolphins said today that the decision on whether to use his place-kicker, Uwe von Schamann, in the American Conference championship game against the Jets will not be made until just before game time Sunday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 21.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST ALSO OFFER WAYS TO AID THEM
description: Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund sometimes suggest less obvious ways of helping the poor and neglected. Most contributors ask that their donations provide food, clothing or shelter for the city's needy, but Larry Ash of Philadelphia had a different idea.

title: AREA COSTS OFF 0.6% LAST MONTH
description: Inflationary pressures in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area eased in most categories of consumer spending last year, capped by a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices in December.

title: Indoor Marks Set
description: Mary Decker Tabb and Evelyn Ashford achieved world indoor bests tonight in the Los Angeles Invitational track and field meet.

title: South Africa and Angola Said to Negotiate Pact
description: South Africa and Angola are secretly negotiating a nonaggression and economic cooperation pact, The Johannesburg Star reported today.

title: REAGAN CERTIFIES SALVADOR FOR AID: HAILS PROGRESS DESPITE 'OBSTACLES'
description: President Reagan certified to Congress today that despite ''great obstacles'' El Salvador was not only making progress on human rights but was also laying the foundation for democratic government.

title: BONN OPPOSITION PRESSES U.S. ON ARMS
description: Hans-Jochen Vogel, the opposition Social Democratic candidate for Chancellor, said today that the United States should make a constructive counteroffer to the latest Soviet proposal to reduce medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 22, 1983
description: International The U.S. will show flexibility in the talks on medium-range missiles in Europe if the Soviet Union demonstrates some new ''give,'' , the chief American negotiator hinted after a meeting with President Reagan. Mr. Reagan and the negotiator, Paul H. Nitze, have defended the so-called zero option proposed by the United States in November 1981 as the best way to deal with the European missile issue. But Mr. Nitze seemed to suggest that Washington might drop the zero option in response to some undefined concessions by Moscow. (Page 1, Column 3.) A helpful American counterproposal to the latest Soviet proposal to reduce medium-range missiles in Europe would not only be welcomed, but demanded, by the opposition Social Democratic candidate for Chancellor of West Germany. Han-Jochen Vogel's address to a party meeting tended to portray the United States as delaying progress in the Geneva arms reduction talks, which are scheduled to resume Thursday. (4:4.)

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 22, 1983; The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index fell 0.3 percent in December, pulled downward by declining home mortgage rates. The Labor Department said the decline brought the inflation rate for all of 1982 to 3.9 percent, a full point below most forecasts. It was the lowest rate since 1972 when, with price controls in place, the figure was 3.4 percent. The sharp decline was seen as the strongest sign to date that the runaway price increases of recent years have been arrested, at least for a while. But officials concede that one of the main reasons is the 17-month recession, during which the unemployment rate has risen to 10.8 percent, the highest since 1940. (Page 1.) In the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area, prices fell 0.6 percent last month. (38.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battle of the Gridiron: Apples vs. Oranges

title: Borg Skips Three Events
description: Bjorn Borg has withdrawn from Volvo Grand Prix tournaments in Brussels, Rotterdam and Milan during the month of March, sources close to the Men's International Professional Tennis Council said last night.

title: 3 STATE-OWNED BUILDINGS OPEN AS SHELTERS IN CITY
description: Three state-owned buildings - the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street in Manhattan, the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx and a former Y.M.C.A. building at 55 Hanson Place in downtown Brooklyn -began serving as shelters last night for homeless men in New York City.

title: TIGHTEN CASINOS' CREDITS IN JERSEY
description: In the past three weeks, the state's Division of Gaming Enforcement has charged Atlantic City casinos with violating credit regulations. One was fined. This apparent abuse suggests a crying need for stricter casino credit laws in New Jersey.

title: CONSUMER PRICES OFF 0.3% IN MONTH ON MORTGAGE DROP
description: The Consumer Price Index, pulled down by lower interest rates on home mortgages, dropped by three-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Title Defense
description: Juan LaPorte plans to make his first defense of the World Boxing Council's featherweight title in San Juan on Feb. 20. The opponent will be Ruben Castillo of Bakersfield, Calif. In keeping with a new W.B.C. safety rule involving title bouts, the fight will be only 12 rounds, instead of the previous limit of 15. ... Because of a virus, the World Boxing Association's bantamweight champion, Jeff Chandler, has postponed his title defense against Jose Canizales, which had been scheduled for next Saturday.

title: Hudson's Bay Freezes Wages
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's biggest trading concern, froze the wages of its 44,000 employees for an undetermined period.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Abortion Ruling, 10 Years After

title: Jones & Laughlin To Shut Plant
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation will close a suburban Youngstown coke oven during the first week of February, and ultimately shut down the facility permanently, officials said.

title: Sentry Courier Reports Armored Car Missing
description: The Sentry Armored Car Courier Company, which lost $11 million six weeks ago and has gone out of business after more burglaries, thefts and legal seizures, has reported yet another loss - a $9,000 armored car.

title: SATELLITE'S PLUNGE IS LIKELY SUNDAY
description: The falling nuclear-powered Soviet satellite brushed closer to the outer fringes of the earth's atmosphere yesterday and this led to new, more refined predictions that it would most likely take its final plunge sometime tomorrow evening.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A New York Knight

title: Washington Talk; EDUCATION OF A CONSERVATIVE IDEALIST
description: When Howard H. Dana Jr. was tapped by President Reagan to come to Washington and help tame the program that provides legal aid to poor people, he felt he had something more than just a patronage plum.

title: F813 Jeter and Giants Now in Accord
description: Forget the reports about the Giants trading Gary Jeter, their sixyear defensive end. Jeter and Bill Parcells, the new head coach, have patched up their differences.

title: 'RESTLESS SEEKER FOR JUSTICE': ROBERT NATHAN WILENTZ
description: For Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court, his 270-page opinion Thursday that required municipalities to provide housing opportunities for the poor was another chance to express his concern for social issues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States Government is saying bluntly that taxpayer funds will not be used to provide a college education for students who do not comply with the Selective Service registration requirements.'' - T.H. Bell, Secretary of Education. (1:4.)

title: I.B.M. NET UP 27%, BUT STOCK DROPS SHARPLY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its profit rose by 27.9 percent for the fourth quarter, but the company's shares fell sharply in heavy trading because analysts had expected a much bigger increase. Much of the improvement was attributed to a change in accounting methods.

title: NEHEMIAH RETURN IN JEOPARDY
description: The head of track and field's world governing body issued a ruling yesterday that officials said would make it impossible for them to allow Renaldo Nehemiah, the wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers and former high-hurdles champion, to compete in the Millrose Games next Friday.

title: Canada Inflation Down
description: The inflation rate in Canada declined in December for the seventh consecutive month and finished the year at 10.8 percent, the Government said today. The drop in December, of one-half a percentage point, to an annual rate of 9.3 percent, was due largely to a fall in food and transportation costs, it said. Last summer mandatory wage and price controls were introduced for the public sector, pegging wages to a 6 percent ceiling for the first year and 5 percent for the second.

title: Foreman in U.S.F.L.
description: While Gilliam was getting ready to join the Gold training camp early next month, another U.S.F.L. club, the Los Angeles Express, was signing Chuck Foreman, now 32, who set a club career record of 5,879 yards rushing in his seven seasons with the Minnesota Vikings. He has not played since 1980, when he was dropped by the New England Patriots.

title:
Patents;
Solar Rays Mapped for Satellites
description: WASHINGTON ADESKTOP indicator for planning the orbital missions of solarpowered satellites was patented this week for the Rockwell International Corporation, Downey, Calif.

title: Services for Helen Scully
description: Memorial services for Helen M. Scully, who died Jan. 14 in Coos Bay, Ore., will be held next Wednesday at 11 A.M. at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., and next Thursday at 10 A.M. at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church, also in Scarsdale. Mrs. Scully, under the name Helen Shea, was on the New York stage in the 1920's and 30's and for many years was in charge of the recording section of Recording for the Blind in New York.

title: Celtics 117, Bulls 106
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Robert Parish scored 26 points and Kevin McHale 22 as Boston held off a fourth-quarter surge.

title: Your Money; Alternative Minimum Tax
description: BEGINNING this year, the alternative minimum tax - a term that a relatively small number of Americans have been aware of, and a tax that relatively few have paid thus far -will have an effect on many more Federal income taxpayers. That is because the rules for computing this tax were changed by the 1982 tax law, and a number of new strategies are being devised to reduce tax liabilities that might otherwise be due.

title: INQUIRY INTO H.U.D. OFFICIAL IS SENT TO JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
description: An internal investigation of a suspended Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Dr. E.S. Savas, has been referred to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution, sources at the Justice Department said today.

title: Valenzuela Balks
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers who held out last year until spring training was nearly over, filed for salary arbitration yesterday. Valenzuela's request could produce the largest salary figures - both demanded and offered -ever submitted in arbitration, whose purpose is to resolve pay differences involving a player who is not under contract but is not eligible for free agency.

title: Morris Refuses To Inform
description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris said today that he had rejected a plea bargain in his case because it would have required him to identify other players involved with illegal drugs.

title: Majorette Weight Rule Found Discriminatory
description: School officials discriminated on the basis of sex when they ordered a 16-year-old majorette to lose weight or sit out football games, investigators for the State Human Relations Commission said today.

title: 2 More Resign In Irish Wiretapping
description: Two former Government officials resigned from their opposition posts today in Ireland's growing wiretapping scandal, which has already prompted the resignation of two police chiefs.

title: Italian Police Seize 3 Wanted In $15 Million Theft in Spain
description: Italian police today arrested two men and a woman, all Italians, wanted in a $15 million bank robbery in Spain's Costa del Sol.

title: WATER TOO GOOD NOT TO METER
description: To the Editor:

title: RCA Off 6.6% in Quarter
description: The RCA Corporation, the diverse electronics and communications company that is parent of the NBC network, announced yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter of 1982 fell 6.6 percent while profits for the full year rose sharply from 1981's depressed results.

title: 2 Killed in Blaze Kin of Firefighter
description: A fire in Corona, Queens, killed the 91-year-old grandmother and an aunt of one of the firefighters responding to the blaze about 2 A.M. yesterday, fire officials said.

title: ELMA LOINES
description: Elma Loines, founder of the Master School of Music in Brooklyn, which trained classical singers until it closed in 1927, died last Monday at her home in Winter Park, Fla.

title: Osma Gallinger Tod, 87, Dies; Writer and Expert on Weaving
description: Osma Gallinger Tod, an author, editor and authority on weaving, basketry and related crafts, died Jan. 10 at Centerville, Mass. Mrs. Tod, who lived in Coral Gables, Fla., and had a summer residence in Provincetown, Mass., was 87 years old.

title: BASEBALL
description: CLEVELAND (AL) - Acquired Jim E ssian, catcher, from Seattle for a player t o be named. Assigned John Bonhet, pitch- e r, to Charleston of the International L eague. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Announced a greement to contract terms with U.L. W ashington, shortstop; Willie Aikens, f irst baseman, and Greg Pryor, utility in- f ielder. METS (NL) - Released Bruce Bochy, c atcher, for the purpose of giving him his u nconditional release. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Pete Red- f ern, pitcher, and John Castino, infielder, t o one-year contracts. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed Al H olland, pitcher, to a three-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Don R obinson, pitcher, to a multiyear con- t ract. Appointed Milt Graff director of s couting. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Jim Gott, p itcher; Rance Mulliniks and Tim Thomp- s on, infielders, and Jay Schroeder, catch- e r. YANKEES (AL) - Signed Steve C omer, free-agent pitcher, formerly of the T exas Rangers, to a one-year contract.

title: AFTER 7 YEARS, TOWN REMAINS UNDER FIRE FOR ITS ZONING CODE
description: Seven years ago, this sprawling community of housing clusters and cornfields in the South Jersey flatlands became a catchword for open housing for the poor in the suburbs and countryside.

title: FROM THE GRATEFUL GERMANS, CARE PACKAGES FOR DETROIT
description: The sad stories of hunger and homelessness coming from this recession-stricken city have rekindled memories of American help to postwar Europe among some Germans, who today begun sending money and CARE packages to the poor of Detroit.

title: F.B.I. SEARCHES FOR WITNESSES TO SLAYING OF TEAMSTER PENSION FIGURE
description: A swarm of Federal investigators sought more witnesses today to the killing Thursday of Allen M. Dorfman, a Chicagoan with close ties to the hierarchy of the Mafia and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: CONNORS, LENDL GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: When Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl last played each other, officially, Connors stroked, stoked, wiggled and waved his way to the United States Open singles title last September.

title: SHIP THAT HIT ANDREA DORIA IS HIT
description: The ship that collided with the Andrea Doria in 1956 was involved in a collision with a West German submarine before dawn today. There were no injuries, and both vessels continued under their own power.

title: No Headline
description: COMPANY NEWS; OCCIDENTAL WRITES OFF VENTURE

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan on Lenin

title: East Bloc Again Warns West on New Missiles
description: Soviet bloc nations today issued a new warning of countermeasures if the North Atlantic Treaty Organization goes ahead with deployment of new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: BOSTON BALLET: EVA EVDOKIMOVA IN 'QUIXOTE'
description: At its best, Rudolf Nureyev's production of ''Don Quixote'' for the Boston Ballet has an unforced charm. But at Thursday night's performance in the Uris Theater, some of the dancers confused being easygoing with being lackadaisical, and Mr. Nureyev's reinterpretation of a celebrated 19th-century comic ballet just poked along at times.

title: All Royals Signed
description: There will be no contract problems for the Kansas City Royals this season. Although no terms were announced, the Royals reached agreements with the last three unsigned players - U.L. Washington, the shortstop (three years); Greg Pryor, a utility infielder (two years), and Willie Aikens, first baseman (one year). ... The Yankees, whose pitching leans to the left, added a right-hander, Steve Comer, 29 years old.

title: SOVIET PEACE DRIVES: '53 and '83
description: Is history repeating itself? Within 10 days after Josef Stalin died in 1953, his successors, like Leonid I. Brezhnev's, launched a peace offensive. Like the Reagan Administration, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles doubted that the change in leadership signaled any basic alteration in the Soviet system and its foreign policy.

title: U.S. SUIT CHARGES CICERO, ILL., HAS POLICY TO EXCLUDE BLACKS
description: The Justice Department charged today that the Chicago suburb of Cicero excluded blacks from living there or working in town government jobs.

title: Free Trade Can't Be a Free-for-all
description: Last Saturday the United States clamped a ceiling on imports of Chinese textiles. On Tuesday Washington defied the European Common Market by subsidizing a sale of American wheat flour to Egypt. By Wednesday the Chinese had retaliated against our textile curbs and - while Japan's Prime Minister was still in Washington - the United States had begun a new action against Japanese motorcyles. Thursday the Japanese steel producers fired back a legal volley to stop American steel makers from blocking more of their exports.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY JAZZ, 108-93
description: Darrell Griffith scored 13 of his 38 points in the fourth quarter as the Utah Jazz broke open a tight game and defeated the Knicks, 108-93, tonight.

title: Heart Patient Celebrates His 62d Birthday
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, celebrated his 62nd birthday today with his family and doctors and a birthday cake from his wife and the hospital staff.

title: A Big Attraction
description: What Coach Jim Boeheim calls ''the phenomenon of the Carrier Dome'' has transformed Syracuse University's basketball program into the greatest attendance magnet in National Collegiate Athletic Association history.

title: 2d Chinese Executed For Economic Crimes
description: An accountant has been executed in China for embezzling more than $300,000 from the bank where he worked in Guangdong Province, on the border with Hong Kong, the New China News Agency said today.

title: 76ers 130, Sonics 117
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Moses Malone and Julius Erving combined for 61 points as Philadelphia extended the longest winning streak of the season to 14 games.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The education of Lucille Jongebloed began in September, when she became a chauffeur in the Fugazy limousine company's Express fleet. Mrs. Jongebloed was born in Queens and has lived there all her life, but Manhattan was more or less a mystery to her, and Greenwich Village was nothing but a tangle of tiny streets somewhere slightly north of the World Trade Center.

title: Bridge: A Team Can Always Rally; Even When All Seems Lost
description: In a head-to-head knockout match, a team that has a massive lead going into the final set of deals is understandably confident, and those on the opposing team may be resigned to their fate. But there have been cases of remarkable reversals of fortune on major occasions.

title: TWO GALAS OPEN THE WINTER ANTIQUES SHOW
description: Before the opening parties last night for the 29th Winter Antiques Show, the cavernous and frigid Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street was a busy place.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: To the Rescue

title: BAKER RULES OUT RE-ELECTION BID BUT MIGHT SEEK PRESIDENCY IN '88
description: Declaring ''there is life after the Senate,'' Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, formerly announced today that he would not seek re-election to a fourth term in 1984 but nevertheless would remain involved in public affairs.

title: A QUIET STYLE OF WINNING
description: When Arnold Palmer completed the final round of the Los Angeles Open last Sunday, most of the gallery of 20,000 or so streamed to the exits without waiting to see who would win the tournament. The winner, finishing in the threesome behind Palmer's, was Gil Morgan, who earned his second victory in the two weeks of the 1983 PGA Tour; the first was at Tucson.

title: LOU MICHAELS RECALLS 1969
description: T omorrow afternoon, at his home at Swoyersville, Pa., Lou Michaels, the athletic director at the Luzerne County Prison, will sit in front of a television set and watch the American Football Conference championship game between the Jets and the Dolphins from the Orange Bowl in Miami. He will watch with more than a casual interest.

title: Miss Ruiz de Castilla Wed
description: Patricia Ruiz de Castilla, daughter of Countess Yolanda Ruiz de Castilla of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Count Arturo Ruiz de Castilla y Jauregui, was married in Venice Dec. 28 to Nicholas Jellicoe, son of Earl Jellicoe and Patricia Lady Jellicoe of London. Don Rosolino Scarpa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Chiesa San Nicolo dei Mendicoli. The bride is an advertising sales representative at GEO magazine. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Jellicoe, an account executive with Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, is a grandson of the first Earl Jellicoe, commander in chief of the British Grand Fleet in World War I.

title: DR. SOL SPIEGELMAN, MICROBIOLOGIST AT COLUMBIA AND GENETICIST, DIES
description: Dr. Sol Spiegelman, a Columbia University microbiologist who was internationally known for his research in genetics, virology and the molecular basis of cancer, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHANGE PLEDGED IN PRECINCT CITED IN INVESTIGATION
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that he was planning a major shuffle of ''administration and personnel'' of the 10th Precinct in Manhattan, which has figured prominently in a Federal investigation into charges of police corruption and other misconduct.

title: Chance for Gilliam
description: He had one of the most promising starts of any quarterback in professional football, but an admitted drug addiction and other problems cut short the career of Joe Gilliam with the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: F.B.I. Tells of Troubles Of Coast Jet's Hijacker
description: The takeover of a jetliner that ended in death for the mentally retarded hijacker would probably have been handled differently had the Federal Bureau of Investigation known the troubled history of the slain man, an agent said today.

title: CABLE TV IS SAID TO TOP NETWORKS IN MOVIE VIOLENCE
description: Cable television may have set its first significant record. According to a new study, there is three times more violence on the pay-cable movie channels than on prime-time network television.

title: Jaime G. Gubbins Wed To Claire Stockmeyer
description: Claire Cleveland Stockmeyer, daughter of Carolyn Stockmeyer Leubsdorf of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Edwin W. Stockmeyer, was married yesterday to Jaime Granger Gubbins, son of Caroline Granger Gubbins of Lima, Peru, and Los Angeles, and the late Reginald J. Gubbins. The ceremony was performed at the Montgomery County Court in Rockville, Md., by Howard Smith, a deputy clerk.

title: Grace Withdrawal
description: W.R. Grace & Company said it was ending work on its project to produce 12,500 barrels of gasoline a day from coal at Baskett, Ky., because it was unable to reach agreement with the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, a Federal agency. Grace wanted the Government to own a majority of the $3 billion project, so that Grace would not have to take unacceptable risks. The fuels agency did not find that approach acceptable, Grace said.

title: Players' Union Protests Selection of May
description: Maybe Rudy May won't be leaving the Yankees after all. May, the Yankee pitcher selected by the Chicago White Sox in the free-agent compensation draft on Thursday, became the center of a dispute yesterday when the Major League Baseball Players Association contended that he was improperly placed in the pool.

title: News Analysis
description: In December 1979, the Koch administration was charged in a lawsuit with failing to provide decent shelter for the homeless. The case focused not only on the untold thousands of people who wandered the city's streets night and day, but also on the several hundred who were sleeping each night on plastic chairs in the Men's Shelter, in lower Manhattan, where the city placed most of those who sought shelter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Honoring One of Our Own

title: Report Card
description: Remarkably, Ronald Reagan, the paladin of the right, has started to sound like a centrist. ''I have to say you're doing something right when you're getting rocks thrown at you from both sides,'' he said Thursday after evaluating his first two years in office. Considering the other Washington-Dallas contest that will take place today, it's small wonder that Mr. Reagan is turning defensive.

title: SHARON DEFENDS PACT WITH ZAIRE
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon defended Israel's new arms and military aid agreement with Zaire today as a step toward increasing Israeli influence in Africa.

title: Bell Unit Seeks $6.6 Billion
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday asked the Federal Communications Commission to approve $6.6 billion in additional capitalization of its American Bell Inc. subsidiary.

title: Joan M. Fagan and David R. Cross, Lawyers, Wed
description: Joan M. Fagan and David R. Cross, lawyers in Milwaukee, were married there yesterday by Judge Michael J. Skwierawski, who performed the ceremony in his Circuit Court chambers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MILESTONE

title: Queens Election Is Set for March 1
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday set March 1 for a special election to fill the post of the late Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Queens.

title: NITZE SUGGESTS U.S. MIGHT BE FLEXIBLE IN TALKS ON ARMS
description: Paul H. Nitze, the chief American negotiator at the talks on medium-range missiles in Europe, hinted strongly today after a meeting with President Reagan that the United States would show flexibility if the Soviet Union demonstrated some new ''give'' in its proposals.

title: 17.84 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,052.98
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 17.84 points yesterday, to 1,052.98, amid growing investor apprehension over rising interest rates.

title: HOW THE ZONING RULING WILL OPERATE
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court issued a sweeping ruling Thursday ordering municipalities to take steps to insure housing opportunities for low- and moderate-income families.

title: 4 NAMED TO BOARD OF LEGAL AID UNIT
description: President Reagan appointed four men today to interim terms on the board of the troubled Legal Services Corporation, using a method that bypasses the normal process of Senate confirmation.

title: Trial Is Set for 5 In F.A.L.N. Inquiry
description: Five advocates of Puerto Rican independence were ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to stand trial Feb. 7 on criminal contempt charges stemming from their refusal to testify before a grand jury looking into bombings on New Year's Eve in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: MET MUSEUM ADDS CENTER TO AID VISITS
description: A new educational and orientation center aimed at making the Metropolitan Museum of Art more accessible to its visitors opens to the public today.

title: Letter: On the Dioxin Threat The Red Cross Stands By in Missouri
description: Your Jan. 3 editorial entitled ''Deadly Miasma Over Missouri'' stated that the American Red Cross had ordered its volunteer disaster relief workers out of Times Beach, Mo., a community said by Federal Government officials to be heavily contaminated by dioxin, a potent chemical believed to be the cause of cancer and birth defects.

title: BP Alaska to Sell Oil Rights to Gulf
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. said that its subsidiary BP Alaska Exploration Inc. had agreed to sell certain Beaufort Sea assets to the Gulf Oil Corporation and Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine for $56 million.

title: Dead Identified In Turnpike Crash
description: The seven people who were fatally injured Wednesday in a fiery crash of a tractor-trailer and four cars at the Stratford tollbooth on the Connecticut Turnpike were all women and children, the state police said today.

title: Snowstorm Hits South, Causing Traffic Mishaps Accidents As Storm Moves North
description: A storm with freezing rain and snow fanned north from the South yesterday, making travel hazardous from New Mexico to West Virginia.

title: SOUP LINES RETURN FOR DOWN AND OUT OF PARIS
description: The Salvation Army soup truck was about 10 minutes late the other night and the little crowd, a quorum of misery, waited, silent as the river below: hardly a word, barely a complaint, down and out on the Quai d'Austerlitz, between the railway station and the Seine, waiting for a little delivery truck and a plastic bowl of vegetable soup.

title: QUEBEC'S ECONOMIC DISTRESS
description: Annual snowfall in the province of Quebec often surpasses 10 feet, an affliction that led Voltaire to dismiss New France as ''a few acres of snow.'' In what has been a freakishly mild winter, snow now seems the least of Quebec's concerns. It is the economy that is the problem.

title: OPPOSITION IN OPEC TO QUOTA PLAN SAID TO RISE
description: New resistance developed today within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to a proposal that the 13 OPEC nations agree on lower production quotas to help firm up world oil prices.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday, discussing the new Commissioner of Juvenile Justice, misstated the reason for the resignation of his predecessor, Paul A. Strasburg. Mr. Strasburg opposed building a juvenile center atop a planned jail in Chinatown.

title: SUBWAYS ARE FOR THE HANDICAPPED, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Squash Gets Cup
description: Squash racquets now has its answer to the Davis Cup in tennis and the Ryder Cup in golf. Five-man teams from the United States and Canada will meet today and tomorrow at the Lincoln Squash Club, 1 Harkness Plaza, for the newly established Loews Cup.

title: Walter Ullmann Is Dead at 72; Was Scholar on Middle Ages
description: Walter Ullmann, a noted Cambridge University history professor who specialized in medieval canon law, the papacy and government in the Middle Ages, has died at his Cambridge home, his family said today. He was 72 years old.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as securities dealers speculated that the Federal Reserve might not continue to bring down short-term interest rates.

title: INLAND STEEL LOSS WIDENS
description: The Inland Steel Company yesterday reported a loss of $31.5 million for the fourth quarter, considerably widening the $1.6 million deficit the company posted in the fourth quarter of 1981.

title: Apple Wins Ban
description: The Apple Computer Company won an interim injunction in the Singapore High Court banning the sale of some microcomputers bearing the names of various tropical fruits. The California-based company contended that some brands of computer sold on the local market infringed its original patent.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES DENYING FUNDS TO STUDENTS NOT SIGNED FOR DRAFT
description: The Reagan Administration issued proposed regulations today for denying Federal education loans to male students who refuse to register for the military draft.

title: Tests Discover Dioxin In a Missouri Cow
description: Preliminary tests show dioxin in the tissue of a cow raised on a southwest Missouri farm where the toxic chemical has been found in the soil, the Government said today.

title: WEISSENBERG RECITAL OFF
description: An all-Chopin recital by the pianist Alexis Weissenberg scheduled for tonight in Carnegie Hall has been canceled because of illness.

title: DOMINICAN LOAN IS SET BY I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund, after helping to manage a $6 billion rescue package for Yugoslavia earlier this week, today approved a $450 million loan to the Dominican Republic and on Monday will consider a $2 billion loan to Argentina.

title: JETS GET 3 IN 2D PERIOD AND BEAT RANGERS
description: Three quick goals in the second period and outstanding goaltending by the rookie Brian Hayward, playing his second game as a Jet, enabled Winnipeg to defeat the Rangers, 4-1, tonight.

title: CONSERVATIVES BID REAGAN CUT MORE
description: The Heritage Foundation, a conservative public policy research organization with strong White House ties, has taken a detailed look at President Reagan's first two years in office and concluded that he has squandered much of his political capital. It says he can recover only if he returns to the hard-line principles that it says won him election.

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Abuse of Boy
description: A New York man pleaded guilty to abusing a 13-year-old Highlands, N.J., boy, the Monmouth County Prosecutor said today.

title: Westport's Needy To Get Bag Lunches
description: Hungry people in Westport, Conn., will begin receiving bag lunches at a fire station early next week, city officials and members of a Homeless People's Committee said yesterday.

title: The Ayatollah Discovers Injustice
description: Ayatollah Khomeini, of all people, is declaiming against the excesses of Iranian justice. In a recent message on the Teheran radio, the octogenarian cleric found it ''unacceptable and intolerable that in the name of revolution and under the pretext of being revolutionary, heaven forbid, somebody be oppressed or measures contrary to divine laws and the great Islamic ethics be carried out by individuals ignorant of matters spiritual.''

title: TV: HOSPITAL-DISASTER MOVIE
description: If television series about hospitals are popular and if disaster movies are popular, why not a television movie about a disaster in a hospital? Such, I suppose, was the torch of inspiration that set off ''Uncommon Valor,'' the made-for-television film on CBS-TV tonight.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC WITH SINOPOLI
description: Giuseppe Sinopoli is a conductor and a composer, but in exactly what proportions we do not yet know. The Italian polymath (he is also a surgeon and a psychiatrist) might have enlightened us on that matter Thursday night, but he withdrew from the program a suite from his opera, ''Lou Salome,'' reportedly in order to revise and shorten it. That was too bad, since it would have been nice to assess Mr. Sinopoli's conducting and composing skills in one gulp. However, the work he substituted on this New York Philharmonic program, Bruno Maderna's ''Biogramma'' for Large Orchestra, turned out to be one of real quality, though dated in style and probably of transient interest.

title: Robert Carson, Screen Writer, Won Award for 'Star Is Born'
description: Robert Carson, who won an Academy Award in 1937 for his screenplay of ''A Star Is Born,'' died Wednesday at U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: LET THE PRIVATE SECTOR RESCUE PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Canso Chief Resigns Post
description: Donald L. Hiebert has become the third senior officer of United Canso Oil and Gas Ltd. of Calgary to leave the group within the last 12 months.

title: FACTORY ORDERS ROSE RECORD 12% IN DECEMBER
description: In an encouraging new sign of economic recovery, the Commerce Department said today that orders to United States factories for durable goods rose a record 12 percent in December.

title: CITY BALLET: 'CELEBRATION' BY JACQUES D'AMBOISE
description: ''Celebration,'' which had its official premiere with the New York City Ballet Thursday night at the State Theater, marks a striking breakthrough for Jacques d'Amboise as a choreographer.

title: CANADA-U.S. PACT ON MISSILE TESTS IS DELAYED
description: Political pressure from an increasingly assertive disarmament movement has delayed the signing of an agreement with the United States to permit testing of unarmed cruise missiles in northern Alberta.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Nuggets, at Denver. (Radio - WNEW, 1130; 9:30 P.M.) Local College Games: Fordham at Iona, 2 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7, and WFAS-FM, 103.9, 2 P.M.); Manhattan at Fairfield, 2 P.M.; West Virginia at Rutgers, 5 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 5 P.M. Radio - WRSU-FM, 88.7; 5 P.M.); .

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AGAINST PUERTO RICAN STATEHOOD
description: The resurgence of F.A.L.N. violence in New York City gives rise once again to the question of what Washington's policy should be toward Puerto Rico.

title: NETS TOP CAVALIERS BY 105-99
description: A week ago, the Nets, then the hottest team in the league, were routed by the Celtics in Boston so thoroughly that their captain, Foots Walker, said afterward, ''The way we played tonight, even Cleveland would've beaten us.''

title: FIVE LOCAL OFFICES MAY CLOSE
description: WITH more austerity just around the corner for New York City g overnment, it came as no surprise to people at the Department of C onsumer Affairs that they, just like teachers and policemen, faced ab leaker fiscal 1984.
