But some present and former department o fficials reacted with particular remorse when they heard about one p ossible cutback: the closing of five neighborhood offices.

title: Fought Shoots 62 and Takes 2-Shot Lead
description: On golf courses as well conditioned as the ones here, and with the most talented players in the business as competition, shooting par is like standing still. Craig Stadler, leader of the first two rounds of the Bob Hope Desert Classic, demonstrated that premise today in the third round. As Stadler scored a par 72, John Fought flew by him with a 62 for 199 and took a twostroke lead.

title: Abraham Wolk Dies; Was Pittsburgh Leader
description: Abraham L. Wolk, a former Pittsburgh City Councilman and Allegheny County judge, died Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived since 1973. He was 91 years old.

title: Obituary; Jack Whittemore, Was Agent For Jazz Players and Singers
description: Jack Whittemore, an agent who represented jazz musicians and singers for nearly 50 years, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: OFFICIALS STUMP FOR NEW PROGRAM TO IDLE FARMLAND
description: Much of the land that normally provides food for a good share of the world will lie fallow this year, according to farmers across the Middle West.

title: GOOD HOT SOUP: 16 PLACES TO GO
description: Now that the promise of a frigid winter is being fulfilled, steaming sustenance by way of fragrant hot soups is needed. Fortunately for anyone who walks around the city, there are warming havens in all parts of town where one can rest, recover from the effects of the wind-chill factor and have a bracing bowl of soup.

title: NO DRIFT TOWARD NEUTRALISM, KOHL TELLS THE FRENCH
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought to reassure West Germany's allies today that his country was not drifting into neutralism and pacifism.

title: Reynolds Move To Cut Staff
description: SALEM, N.C., Jan. 21 (AP) - R.J. Reynolds Industries said it was asking more than 10 percent of its cigarette workers to quit or retire early, and that it had already cut back next week's production schedule at the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company to four days, as a result of an expected sales decline attributable to the increase in the Federal tax on cigarettes .

title: EX-DEFENSE CHIEF, CITING CONFLICT, QUITS MX PANEL
description: Former Defense Secretary Harold Brown resigned today as a member of the advisory commission that President Reagan appointed to suggest solutions to the deadlocked MX missile issue.

title: 3 KILLED, 22 INJURED IN CRASH OF A BUS AND TRUCK UPSTATE
description: A Greyhound bus traveling at high speed rammed into the rear of a tractor-trailer on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway today, killing three passengers and injuring 22 others, many seriously, the state police said.

title: POLITICS AND COSTS HINDER LAND PROGRAM
description: The land redistribution program is mired in debt and is caught between two political forces, one of which would like to see it succeed and another that has tried to undermine its success, according to Government and labor officials here.

title: 2 Uganda Officials and Priest Accused of Aiding Guerrillas
description: Vice President Paulo Muwanga has accused two opposition Members of Parliament and a Roman Catholic priest of collaborating with anti-Government guerrillas, the Ugandan radio said today.

title: SLAYING IS ONLY LATEST CRIME TO TOUCH TEAMSTERS' UNION
description: The teamsters' union, characterized for decades by corruption and criminal activity, has been touched by violence again with the murder Thursday of Allen M. Dorfman, a long-time consultant to its Central States Pension Fund.

title: Riggins Seen as Key in Snow
description: Moments after his arrival at National Airport here this afternoon, Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys was told about the weather prediction for Saturday. Snow, beginning early and turning to sleet or rain in the afternoon.

title: NEW YORK'S 'BEST HOUSING HOPE' IS DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: DAN RIVER, ICAHN IN TRUCE FOR NOW
description: The battle between Dan River Inc. and a group led by the New York investor Carl C. Icahn involving the group's efforts to take control of the Virginia-based textile company was halted today - at least until mid-September.

title: CASTLE OF ASTORS SOLD IN ENGLAND
description: Hever Castle in Kent, England, the setting of the courtship of Anne Boleyn and Henry VIII and the home since 1903 of William Waldorf Astor and his heirs, was sold yesterday.

title: Books of the Times; Ideal American Couple
description: SARA AND GERALD. By Honoria Murphy Donnelly with Richard N. Billings. Foreword by William M. Donnelly. Il- lustrated. 254 pages. Times Books. $17.95.

title:
PATENTS;
Test Hole Device Used In Oil and Gas Searches
description: A method and apparatus for determining the presence of oil and gas in the earth surrounding a bore hole has been patented for the Schlumberger Technology Corporation of New York. A computer programmer analyzes the characteristics shown on explorations under the surface.

title: HOW TO LURE AN ARMY OF CAR STRIPPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Depleted Team
description: Three members of the St. Louis University basketball team - Kevin Strozier, Guy Moore and Greg Polite -were declared academically ineligible yesterday, leaving the Metro Conference school with only seven players. Coach Rich Grawer said he planned to fill out the squad with several walk-ons who worked out with the team earlier in the season. ... John Flowers, a 6-9 sophomore who played in 29 games last season, has quit the Indiana University team.

title: Powell Faces Key Test; Powell-Betters a Key Matchup
description: Marvin Powell insists that the memories of several recent poor performances, so out of keeping with his outstanding career as the Jets' right offensive tackle, have not left him troubled about his Sunday assignment - the Miami Dolphins' 6-foot-7-inch, 260-pound left end, Doug Betters.

title: CHANGE OF BACKBONE
description: With the United States moving inexorably from an industrial economy to a service economy, sentimentalists may shed a tear for the passing of the blue-collar worker, for he will soon be as extinct as the farmer.

title: TO CREATE JOBS AND BOOST PENSION FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The Take a Teddy to Tea Society, which meets every Jamuary at the Algonquin Hotel to celebrate the birthday of A.A. Milne, honored a stuffed Pooh that Milne sent his publisher in 1947.

title: 9 Bombs Defused After Fire In Bakery in Anaheim, Calif.
description: Nine bombs filled with ''highly volatile'' powder were defused today, several hours after they were found by firefighters who had been dispatched to a fire in a bakery late Thursday night, police said.

title:
PATENTS;
Feb. 12-13 Display Set For New Inventions
description: More than 70 new inventions, described as reflecting the latest technology, will be displayed to visitors at the Patent and Trademark Office in Arlington, Va., on Feb. 12 and 13.

title: EX-AGENT IS ACCUSED OF A SCHEME TO KILL 2 OF HIS PROSECUTORS
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent convicted last year of smuggling weapons to Libya, recently tried to have two Federal prosecutors and five Government witnesses killed, according to Federal law enforcement officials.

title: THE PROBLEMS OF MENTAL ILLNESS ARE COMPOUNDED BEHIND BARS
description: Physicians for the United States Navy certified Larry Lyons as an acute schizophrenic. So did doctors at several mental hospitals. But when he was examined at the Mid-Hudson Psychiatric Center near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., following a 1978 arrest on attempted robbery charges, doctors concluded he was only ''malingering.''

title:
GARDENING;
THE TIME TO CORRECT GARDEN DEFICIENCIES
description: PLANTS are the key to the survival of life on earth. Green plants capture the energy of the sun through the process of photosynthesis. That captured energy not only provides sustenance for the plants, but is the source of energy, food and much of the shelter for animal life, including man.

title: Ivory Powers
description: The pecking order of American universities got a 13-year, $500,000 updating last week from the Conference Board of Associated Research Councils, an ad hoc group of academic organizations. It showed that standards of education still flow mostly from the traditional towers: Ivy League schools, Big Ten universities, and public and private research universities in California.

title: AGENCIES DEAL FOR DOLLARS IN A NEW ROUND OF FISCAL POLITICS
description: TO judge by its size and weight, the $16.5 billion preliminary budget for the 1984 fiscal year that Mayor Koch released last week was nothing if not prodigious. Unfortunately, the inch-thick document was short on good news - it called for 1,800 fewer cops on the streets and 550 fewer sanitation workers to keep those streets clean. And New Yorkers will have to pay more for less if the Mayor wins approval for tax increases on stock sales and real estate transactions, cigarettes, wine and gasoline, and movie, theater and concert tickets, among other items.

title: VIDEO GAMES POSE THORNY LEGAL ISSUE
description: A RESOLUTION enacted by the Suffolk County Legislature in November asserting that certain video games promote criminal activity, and are thus ''an imminent danger to the health and safety'' of Suffolk residents, has involved the county in a manufacturer's lawsuit asking $11 million in damages.

title: THE FIRST WORD ON WHAT KILLED NAPOLEON
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: THIRD-WORLD AID CALLED DRAIN ON SOVIET RESOURCES

title: ALICE M. CONLON BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Conlon of Queens Village, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Alice Marie Conlon, to Roman Choma, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stefan Choma of New York. Miss Conlan is assistant head nurse in psychiatry at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Choma is an administrator at the Hunts Point Produce Markets in the Bronx.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are all parents. Many of our children are in their teens.

title: PIQUE IN WASHINGTON OVER THOSE 'MODERATE' SAUDIS
description: When President Reagan presented his Middle East peace initiative in September, it was taken for granted in Washington that Saudi Arabia could be counted on to use its financial leverage to encourage both Jordan's King Hussein and the Palestinians to come to the bargaining table. And when Israel and Lebanon entered into peace and withdrawal talks, American officials assumed the Saudis would help Lebanon sell an American-mediated agreement with Israel to Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, to secure withdrawal of their forces as well. But after three months of largely fruitless negotiations on both fronts, it has become apparent that Saudi assistance has not been and probably won't be forthcoming, leading piqued Reagan Administration officials to wonder, ''Just how moderate are the 'moderate' Saudis?''

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Phantom Returns''The Phantom of the Opera,'' Gaston Leroux's 1911 novel about a disfigured musician who seeks revenge for the death of his operasinger wife, has had three movie treatments. The novel was first made into a silent film in 1925 with Lon Chaney, Norman Kerry and Mary Philbin and was directed by Rupert Julian. Mordaunt Hall, The New York Times film critic, called it ''an ultra fantastic melodrama,'' adding that it was ''a well-dressed thriller, with capable acting by the villain, a stiff and silted hero and an insipid heroine.''

title: Benjamin B. Naumoff, Ex-Head Of Region for U.S. Labor Dept.
description: Benjamin B. Naumoff, the East Coast regional administrator of the United States Department of Labor from 1961 until he retired in 1978, died last Tuesday of a heart attack at the North Broward Medical Center in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: SHARI MARA HANANIA ENGAGED TO MARK D. DIRECTOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. N. David Hanania of White Plains have made known the engagement of their daughter Shari Mara Hanania, to Mark Dean Director, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Director of White Plains and Longboat Key, Florida.

title:
OPINION;
ART BEHIND BARS: CAPTURING A MOMENT OF WINNING
description: THE classroom is bare, the walls and ceiling bone white, the floor old blocks of red tile. Thirty new desks, plastic tops and seats, steel legs and book racks, are lined up in neat rows. The floor used to be swept clean; but whoever swept it discovered that this is a messy class. Now the floor is littered with cigarette butts and the ignored coffee cans that were intended to be used as ash trays. The room is cleaned after class.

title: FUNNY IF IT WEREN'T SO BAD
description: CASES, By Howard T. Senzel. 259 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Calming Waters On the Falklands
description: The Falkland Islands war was nobody's fault but Argentina's, a British commission of inquiry decided last week. The panel, including opposition party members, exonerated Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and British intelligence for failing to foresee or avert the two-month $2.6 billion war that took the lives of 255 Britons and nearly 712 Argentines.

title: John Fulop Jr. Marries Sidney Ann Mackenzie
description: Sidney Ann Mackenzie, daughter of John Mackenzie of New York and Sintra, Portugal, and Mrs. Ann J. Payne of Easton, Md., was married yesterday to John Fulop Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Fulop of New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. John Johnson performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York.

title: 2 NEW HOTELS
description: Attracted by the concentration of Fortune 500 company headquarters in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, Holiday Inns has begun construction of hotels in White Plains and Stamford that will cater to corporate clients.

title: PRINCETON: DIVERSE ART ON DISPLAY
description: PRINCETON THE 34 paintings, prints and sculptures now at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art, 8 Chambers Street, are belied by their title, ''Elements of Abstraction.'' For this is a catholic selection that contains opposites as extreme as a 1975 optical canvas by Richard Anuskiewicz and B.J.O. Nordfeldt's brown-toned ''Still Life With Lobster and Sea Urchins,'' dated 1932.

title: PROTON THEORY IS CHALLENGED
description: The most ambitious effort to test the hypothesis that protons are all destined to decay has so far failed to confirm the process. Evidence reported by physicists last fall suggested that the particles, the basic building blocks of matter, had long, but finite, lifetimes. But a recent report by researchers who participated in an Ohio study says that proton lifetimes may be even longer than the billions of years previously estimated. They also say this could mean theories predicting such decay are invalid.

title: LETTERS
description: A Question of Values In the County

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE REFORMS LEAVE MANY PROBLEMS
description: The following article was written by Michael J. Boskin and John B. Shoven, economics professors at Stanford Unversity, and by Laurence J. Kotlikoff, economics professor at Yale.THE Social Security Commission's bipartisan proposal represents a r emarkable compromise on perhaps the most controversial and p olitically charged issue of this decade. The package, which shores u p Social Security's short-run finances, represents a very painful a nd hard-struck bargain. Unfortunately, this package falls far short o f comprehensively resolving either Social Security's long-term f inancial crisis or the system's equally serious and longstanding s tructural problems.

title: HARDSHIP LINKED TO ECONOMY SPURS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the nation's economic situation - with high unemployment, inflation and cutbacks in social services - appears to be the primary cause of the human suffering they see around them.

title: 18TH-CENTURY FURNISHINGS SELL FOR RECORD $2.3 MILLION
description: A collection of 18th-century furnishings of the late Miriam Hubbard Morris sold at Christie's yesterday for $2.3 million, establishing a new high for a one-day sale of Americana.

title: Budget or No, Reagan Keeps The Show Going
description: As White House budget hands scurried about backstage last week trying to find the right numbers, their principal was front and center, looking to set the right tone.

title: Witness Excused
description: In a decision that could make prosecution witnesses harder to find, a Federal judge in Nevada ruled last week that children cannot be forced to testify against their parents. A Justice Department spokesman said that if the ruling stands it will significantly extend the right of prospective witnesses to refuse to testify.

title: 'LONGEST WAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ARKANSAS IS UPSET BY HOUSTON

title: They Gave At the Office
description: Dr. E.S. Savas not only wrote the book on ''Privatizing the Public Sector,'' but apparently practiced it. Dr. Savas, an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was suspended last week pending an investigation of charges that he had Government employees spend tax payers' time working on the personal book project, for which he got a $6,000 advance. The Inspector General is also looking into the circumstances under which the high bidder was awarded a H.U.D. consulting contract on Dr. Savas's recommendation. The company, Ecodata Inc. of New York, is run by a former colleague of Dr. Savas.

title: A SONG IS NO LONGER STRICTLY A SONG, NOW IT'S 'VIDEO'
description: John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: COUNTY OFFICIALS TESTIFY AT STATE FIRE-CODE HEARING
description: HARRISON THE scene was a familiar one at the Stouffer's Inn here - a gathering of sales executives, a meeting behind closed doors and, in the hallway outside those doors, a coffee waitress gathering up the leftover cups from a midmorning break.

title: Glenn Visits Venezuela
description: Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, discussed Central America and Latin American debt problems during a two-day visit to Venezuela, American Embassy officials said today. The 1984 Presidential candidate arrived Friday.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: HEMPSTEAD THE training camp of the New York Jets will be deserted today. The gate will be locked. The team's private security guard, known as Harry the Cop, can relax; he doesn't have to chase away curious pedestrians who peek in through the shrubbery on Hempstead Turnpike. Overhead helicopters will not be viewed suspiciously as a possible spy plane commissioned by the Raiders. The Jets, after all, have a championship game in Miami to play.

title:
ART;
DUAL APPROACHES IN SCULPTURE
description: HUNTINGTON WHEN Hiram Powers's life-size marble nude, ''The Greek Slave,'' was exposed to the scrutiny of Victorian society, her unclad figure was heavily shrouded in a cloak of moral sentiment so thick that none but the most depraved could view her as anything other than a spiritual body ''clothed with chastity,'' as one poet put it.

title: BUCKLE-UP LAW FOR YOUNGSTERS NEEDS SUPPORT
description: IN my earlier years I clung to the belief that our society put special emphasis on the welfare of its children. However, over the years, I realized that we are more schizophrenic than devoted and I came to view overt gestures with a jaundiced eye.

title: Millrose Adds 2 Stars
description: The field for Friday's Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden grew by two indoor record-holders yesterday: Mark Enyeart, who set a mark of 1 minute 16.91 seconds for 600 meters last weekend at Sherbrooke, Quebec, will run in the 800, and Randy Wilson, who has done 1:47:97 for the 880-yard run, will compete in the 1,000 meters. ... The field for the Vitalis/ U.S. Olympic Invitational at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Feb. 12 also grew by two indoor record-holders. One is Marita Koch, who has lowered the women's mark for 400 meters six times since 1978.

title: SUNDAY, JANUARY 23, 1983
description: International A totally revised code of canon law for the Roman Catholic Church is expected to be issued Tuesday by Pope John Paul II. The revision took nearly 20 years and reflects the sweeping changes set forth by the Second Vatican Council. The revised code places more emphasis on meeting the needs of people rather than on legal strictures, according to churchmen who took part in the revision. One of the changes reduces offenses punishable by excommunication from 37 to six. (Page 1, Column 4.)

title: A 24-HOUR HOTLINE FOR TENSE WORKERS
description: JOHN was a scientist employed by a large corporation. He performed well enough, but he was not working up to his potential. Later, in therapy, it emerged that his father had discouraged him even in childhood from being aggressive and intellectually assertive.

title: TALKS OPEN ON LINK TO ATLANTIC CITY
description: TRENTON OFFICIALS representing the state's Department of Transportation and Amtrak met in Washington last week to begin work on a plan for passenger rail service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City by Sept. 30, 1985.

title: Goldberg Revives Holocaust Study
description: Arthur J. Goldberg has decided that a study of what American Jewish organizations did or did not do about the Holocaust will continue, even if he has to pay for it himself. The former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court said last week he would personally assure funding of the project, which had been abandoned by its original sponsor.

title: CAMERA RECORDS STATE IN TRANSITION
description: HOW the state responded to the invention of photography is the theme of an exhibition entitled ''The Connecticut Yankee and the Camera'' on view at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: LISBON LURCHES THROUGH 15TH GOVERNMENTAL CRISIS
description: Several weeks ago a cartoon in a right-wing weekly depicted an unemployment office advertising the job of Prime Minister. There was only one applicant - ''E.T.''

title: IN BOCES PROGRAM, 'YOU'RE NOT AFRAID'
description: FROM the outside, the low institutional-style buildings that make up the Boces Bellport campus hardly look as if they would house a refuge for troubled teen-age girls. But the single large room where a group of pregnant adolescents spend six and a half hours every weekday is a haven where they are nurtured, educated, protected and emotionally supported.

title: MALL OF THE 50'S BRIGHTENING ITS IMAGE
description: Take a 1950's vintage shopping center, add some shrubbery, skylights, fountains, a big new anchor store and a group of fast-food restaurants serving ''international'' foods, and what have you got? The shopping mall of the 80's, according to Lorna Rudnick, vice president of marketing for Kravco Inc., which is supervising a $30 million renovation of the Green Acres Shopping Center in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Policeman Is Dismissed
description: A police officer was dismissed after being charged with leading other officers on a highway chase after they tried to stop him for passing a red light, officials said. The officer, George Pitts, was indicted.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: NEWLY compiled data from the 1980 census has confirmed what anyone who tried to buy a house in Connecticut in the last decade already knew - the value of single-family houses in the state increased sharply between 1970 and 1980.

title: F.A. GRANT-SUTTIE IS WED IN CAPITAL TO MISS GINSBURGH
description: Carolyn Forrest Ginsburgh, daughter of Major Gen. (U.S.A.F.-ret.) and Mrs. Robert Neville Ginsburgh of Chevy Chase, Md., and Rehoboth Beach, Del., was married yesterday to Francis Aeneas Grant-Suttie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ian Grant-Suttie of Bethesda, Md., and Woodstock, Vt. The ceremony was performed at the National Episcopal Cathedral in Washington by the Rev. John Rivers of St. Dunstan's Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md., and the Rev. Barney Jones of Duke University in Durham, N.C.

title: THE PROFESSOR'S CLASS ACT
description: The Professor's Class Act Without notes and relying on a translator, Peynaud, the master oenologist from France, enchants 200 Americans during a memorable tasting of 17 outstanding wines. Emile Peynaud has turned wine making into a true science.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A steel structure in Melville that was abandoned midway through construction nearly 10 years ago and has since become something of an area landmark will finally be completed by its new owner, Melville Industrial Associates.

title: JAZZ BASSIST: HARVIE SWARTZ
description: Harvie Swartz, one of the more ubiquitous jazz bassists in town, has been developing a string trio over the last year that has already become an unusually original and provocative jazz group.

title: JANE E. BOSSARD TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs J. Gray Bossard of Mount Lebanon, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth Bossard, to Nicholas L. Marton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miklos B. Marton of New York. Miss Bossard and her fiance, graduates of Cornell University, attend the University of Tulsa, where she is a law student and he a candidate for a master's degree in environmental science.

title: RECENT SALES
description: East Brunswick $95,000 *2*8 Dobson 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old *2*2-story house; fireplace, barbecue, *2*cental air-conditioning; taxes $2,600. Edison $99,000 *2*48 Dale Drive, 3-bedroom, 2 bath, *2*14-year-oldranch; patio, shed, central *2*air-conditioning; taxes $1,810 Ocean Township $79,500 *2*1901 Waverly Street, 4-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, *2*8-year-old bilevel; central air-conditioning, pool, *2*rear patio; taxes $1,436. Howell $73,000 *2*11 Meadowbrook Drive, 4-bedroom 2-1/2 bath, *2*15-year-old colonial; central air-conditioning, *2*gas utilities; taxes $1,625. West Long Branch $86,500 *2*74 Golf Street, 4-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*20-year-old split level; central *2*air-conditioning; taxes $1,527. West Milford $142,000 *2*93 Point Breeze Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*7-year-old 2-story house; lakefront property, *2*oak floors, deck and patio; taxes $2,338. OTHER AREAS Westport, Conn. $365,000 *2*2 Nassau Road, 4-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, *2*3-year-old custom contemporary; *2*on water with mooring rights; taxes $5,288. New Rochelle, N. Y. $105,000 *2*28 Troy Lane, 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 28-year-old *2*brick/ frame split level; aluminum *2*siding, 79-by 101-foot lot; taxes $2,532. South Hempstead, L.I. $68,000 *2*1154 Webber Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2-bath *2*20-year-old Cape Cod; full *2*basement, formal dining room; taxes $2,000.

title:
OPINION;
LOOKING BEYOND THE NEW YEAR: RECOMMITMENTS
description: I'M done with empty resolutions that peter out soon after New Year's Day. For too long, I've made them with half-hearted conviction that dissipates with the passage of time. It's time, now, for a whole new perspective on not only the new year but on the longer road that lies ahead. Instead of ''resolution,'' it's going to be ''recommitment.''

title: Black Youths in Florida Pelt Police With Rocks
description: A crowd of black youths pelted police officers with rocks for two hours tonight in a poor neighborhood known as ''Little Vietnam'' in apparent retaliation for the arrest of a suspected drug dealer and five other people, the police said. The area returned to quiet when two city council members, both of them black, urged the crowd to go home.

title: ALBANY PONDERS ITS OWN LATEST BUDGET CRISIS
description: ALBANY AS Mayor Koch unleashed his ''tough program'' last week, Governor Cuomo was mulling some tough budget choices of his own. By Feb. 1, Mr. Cuomo is required to close a deficit he has estimated at $1.8 billion, give or take $200 million.

title: PLAYING FOR N.F.L. TITLE: ANXIETY AMID THE GLORY
description: ILOOK across the distance of years at the current National Football L eague championship games with a large degree of empathy and relief. T he empathy is for players who spend days in preparation with an a nxiety that can neither be ignored nor eased, and I am relieved thata fter playing in championship games in 1968, I did not have that e xperience again.

title: On Mrs. Thatcher
description: To the Business Editor: Denis Healey's ''The Experiment Has Not Worked'' (Dec. 26), is his verdict on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic program. I disagree.

title: RABBI USING MODERN MEDIUM IN CALL FOR TRADITIONAL VALUES
description: For three years now, Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson has been mixing modern technology with ancient tradition in his efforts to urge all Jews to be more observant of their religious laws.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: In the Stratosphere

title: Military Analysis
description: Western intelligence analysts say that the Soviet forces in Afghanistan, now in their fourth winter there, appear to be absorbing the basic lessons of guerrilla warfare.

title: WHERE TO PUT YOUR I.R.A. MONEY
description: THERE is still time to make a contribution to your 1982 Individual R etirement Account and take advantage of one of the most generous p rovisions of the tax code.

title:
GARDENING;
THE TIME TO CORRECT GARDEN DEFICIENCIES
description: PLANTS are the key to the survival of life on earth. Green plants capture the energy of the sun through the process of photosynthesis. That captured energy not only provides sustenance for the plants, but is the source of energy, food and much of the shelter for animal life, including man.

title: Social Security Panel Comes Up With Something
description: ''Nobody is enamored with this solution,'' James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, remarked last week. But, he noted, ''a long and bitter fight in Congress would not have produced anything better.''

title: OBSCURITY AND COMEDY BLEND TO BUOY 'COUP DE TORCHON'
description: A movie doesn't have to be altogether clear to be immensely satisfying. Take, for example, Bertrand Tavernier's new French film, ''Coup de Torchon'' (translated by its distributors as ''Clean Slate''), which starts out as a conventional if exotic comedy, set in a small, parched town in French West Africa in 1938, and turns into a most provocative, wittily misanthropic melodrama set in the landscape of the soul.

title: No Headline
description: To determine the ''particular amalgam of forces which drives couples apart after 40 years'' is not as difficult as Barbara Cain assumes. There is a moment in the life of a successful man when, after years of working hard, he looks up and finds his life lacking.

title: U.S. MAY END ITS ARMS EMBARGO OF ARGENTINA
description: The Reagan Administration is seriously considering lifting the ban on arms sales to Argentina but maintaining the arms embargo of Chile, members of a visiting United States Congressional group said here today.

title: A SLAIN JANE DOE IS GIVEN THE FUNERAL OF A PRINCESS
description: On a July morning, she was found in the Cedar Ridge Cemetery here, murdered. Today she was brought back, to be buried. Officially, she remains nameless and unclaimed, the mystery of her murder unsolved.

title: Abortion at 10
description: Ten years after the Supreme Court's judgment to legalize abortion, the right of a woman to terminate her pregnancy is recognized by most Americans and still bitterly disputed by a minority. It now appears that, in 1973, the high court led rather than followed the election returns. The right-to-life movement failed last year to undo the decision in Congress and in attempts to punish supporting legislators at the polls.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS SYRACUSE BY 68-57
description: St. John's broke a tie with six minutes to go, scored the next 10 points and went on to beat Syracuse, 68-57, tonight in a Big East Conference game before a crowd of 32,382 at the Carrier Dome.

title: MOVIE INVESTMENTS, NOT ALWAYS STARS
description: ''T OOTSIE,'' the Columbia Pictures movie about a man who - to win a role in a television series - turns into a woman, has turned thousands of investors into wealthier people. On the other hand, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's ''Pennies From Heaven,'' a musical comedy set in the Depression, won't bring its backers any great windfall.

title: Hockey Program in Peril at Notre Dame
description: The University of Notre Dame is on the verge of terminating hockey as a varsity sport. Citing an annual deficit of ''around $250,000'' in the sport, the university's athletic director, Eugene Corrigan, said in a recent interview that the program was ''under review'' and may not survive on the varsity level.

title: Doria Treasure
description: So when will that safe recovered from the sunken liner Andrea Doria be opened? In March 1982 it was at rest in a special cold-water tank in the New York Aquarium, and Peter Gimbel, who led the expedition that recovered the reputed treasure, said he hoped to open it live on television that fall at the end of a film about the expedition.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Jan. 16 Week in Review misidentified a monument in Java. The photograph was of Prambanan

title: KATHERINE C. SMITH AND PETER V. WALL ARE MARRIED
description: At the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Katharine Crosby Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Kingman Crosby of Sarasota, Fla., and Centerville, Mass., was married to Peter Viner Wall, son of Dr. and Mrs. Halmer C. Wall of New Canaan. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony.

title: CARMELITA HINTON, EDUCATOR WHO FOUNDED PUTNEY SCHOOL
description: Carmelita Chase Hinton, an educator who founded the Putney School, a progressive secondary school in Putney, Vt., died Jan. 16 after a stroke at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. She was 92 years old and lived in Concord.

title: AMELIA KAREN DUROSKA IS WED TO RICHARD J. LEIDL
description: Amelia Karen Duroska, a legislative assistant in the Washington office of Representative Joseph G. Minisn, Democrat of New Jersey, was married yesterday to Richard John Leidl, a lawyer in Washington. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, N.J., by the Rev. Walter Sobol.

title: No Headline
description: Research on chimpanzee language is no longer being extensively funded by Government research agencies not because of a few skeptics wielding undue influence, but because it has become widely recognized in the scientific community that claims concerning talking apes were exaggerated at best. Other primate research that was more competently performed and showed more concrete results - concerning, for example, chimpanzees' nonverbal thinking skills - has gained wide acceptance and continued funding. There is no conspiracy to repress ape language studies, only the recognition that more than 10 years of this research has demonstrated very little about linguistic capacities in nonhuman species or about the nature of language. MARK SEIDENBERG, Assistant Professor, Department of Psychology, McGill University, Montreal

title: DEMOCRATS FROM L.I. IN KEY ROLES IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON THE Democrats will have more control over the House of Representatives when it reconvenes on Tuesday, and nowhere is this more evident than in the committees. Since gaining 26 more House seats in the last election, the Democrats have a two-to-one edge over the Republicans.

title: LANDMARK DISPUTE
description: It's been a long time since Flushing was a town, but the Town Hall that reminds the community of its roots still stands on Northern Boulevard. These days, however, the 1862 Romanesque Revival structure, which was declared a landmark in 1968, sports a sign advertising that medical office space can be rented inside.

title: LINDA BUCHANNAN WILL BE MARRIED TO BOYD ALLEN 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell Clise Buchanan of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Ann Buchanan, to Boyd Allen 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Boyd Allen Jr., of Warren, N.J.

title: Man's Intrusion on the Deer
description: THE decline, precipitous in some instances, in the number of deer taken by hunters during the past season in New England and the Province of Quebec dramatizes the problems faced by fish and game departments in their management of the species.

title: PAPER THAT STIMULATES ARTISTIC CREATIVITY
description: ARTISTS frequently find that working on paper encourages a flow of new thoughts about creativity, and frequently about experimentation as well. This spirit comes across with considerable strength in three exhibitions currently on view in Port Washington.

title: ROLE OF STRING GROUP IN COUNTY IS PRAISED
description: ''IT is one of the most thrilling things in the world to play in an orchestra,'' said Westchester's County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, who credits his own salad days as a clarinetist with having sparked a lifelong interest in music. ''You can't be exposed to it without the experience lighting a love in you, without gaining a whole new dimension as a person.''

title:
CAMERA;
A FEW POINTERS FOR THOSE SPECIAL EFFECTS
MARRIAGE PLANNED BY MISS CREVISTON
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Creviston of Urbana, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Lynn Creviston, to Reginald Coombe Shiverick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Asa Shiverick Jr., of Chagrin Falls, Ohio.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: MANY top executives in Westchester give the county high marks as a business location - more than have ever done so before - in a new survey of corporate attitudes.

title: Want to Make A Deal?
description: Francisco Fiallos Navarro, who resigned recently as Nicaraguan Ambassador to the United States to protest his country's ''leftist dictatorship,'' claims he didn't steal $600,000 from the sale of Nicaragua's ambassadorial residence. Diplomat that he is, however, Mr. Fiallos offered to return the money to the Sandinist Government if it would stop trying to prosecute him, Justice Minister Carlos Arguello said last week. Mr. Arguello didn't seem inclined to go for the deal. He said he had given the Justice Department ''incontrovertible evidence'' of Mr. Fiallos's guilt.

title: 'LOOPHOLE TO BE WON' FOR THE PAYERS OF RENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY BEGINS INTO MEMPHIS SHOOTINGS
description: Federal agents have begun investigating the police shooting of seven black religious cultists who held a white police officer hostage for 30 hours last week. The officer was killed by the group before the police stormed the house.

title: PATRICIA A. HUMBERT WEDS EDWARD F. MCLAUGHLIN JR.
description: Patricia Ann Humbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Humbert of East Patchogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Francis McLaughlin Jr., son of Edith McLaughlin of Walnut Creek, Calif., and the late Mr. McLaughlin. The Rev. Robert L. Zerbe, an Episcopal priest, performed an ecunemical ceremony in the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Subplot on the Sidelines
description: THEORETICALLY, the head coaches are always center stage. When the Jets go against the Dolphins today for the opportunity to represent the American Conference in Super Bowl XVII, the primary plot will focus on the strategic decisions and the facial expressions of Walt Michaels and Don Shula along the sidelines. But alongside the head coaches, a subplot involving two tacticians with telephone headsets, Joe Walton and Bill Arnsparger, will be equally compelling. And perhaps more important.

title: LISA ANN BRANCH ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elmer A. Branch of Normandy Beach, N.J., formerly of Chatham Township, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Branch, to Robert Michael Quinn of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Quinn of Wayland, Mass.The wedding is planned in August.

title: TAKING STOCK IN TEXAS
description: PAULA SPAN is a writer who recently returned to the New York area from Texas.

title: GREECE EMBRACES A FUGITIVE TURKISH DIRECTOR
description: A Turkish film director who is wanted for murder in Turkey was acclaimed here this week at the Greek premiere of his prize-winning film ''Yol.''

title: U.S. AGENCY URGES $2 BILLION CUT IN HOSPITAL BUILDING PLANS IN CITY
description: Manhattan's large private teaching hospitals should eliminate 1,000 unneeded beds, consolidate expensive services and use space in other hospitals, a federally financed agency has recommended.

title: 2 National Marks Set At Yale Schoolboy Meet
description: Two national high school indoor records were set today in the Yale Invitational track meet.

title: BETH ANN WILSON TO BECOME BRIDE
description: Sylvia Wilson of Dayton, Ohio and Ithaca, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Beth Ann Wilson, to James Richard Thomsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Thomsen of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Dayton and Cincinnati, Ohio. The future also is a daughter of the late Sigmund Wilson.

title: Jewish Odyssey
description: To the Editor: The article ''Jewish Odyssey'' (Travel, Jan. 2) states that the synagogue in Newport, R.I., was ''built with a trapdoor leading to an underground passageway because the Jews, poised for disaster, were not sure they were welcome in America.'' Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED VS. THE DOUBTERS
description: CINCINNATI ON the surface, things look rosy at Baldwin-United. The Cincinnati-based corporation, once known only as a producer of high-quality pianos, has transformed itself since 1968 into a near-supermarket of financial services. Its earnings rose nearly 50 percent last year; assets have tripled in two years, and its recent acquisition of the MGIC Investment Corporation, the nation's leading residential mortgage insurer, could pay off handsomely once the economy shakes off the recession.

title: MARCOS, IN 'HARD REALITIES,' CUTS BUDGET 18%
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced deep cuts in Government spending this week and appealed for public understanding of the ''hard realities'' confronting the Philippine economy.

title: POLICE CITE TRUCK'S DAMAGED TIRES IN UPSTATE CRASH
description: The state police investigating the crash of a Greyhound bus and a tractor-trailer that killed three bus passengers and injured 22 others said yesterday that damaged tires on the truck might have been a contributing factor in the accident.

title: SATISFYING OBSESSIONS FROM CLAUDEL TO 'KALKI'
description: John McAleer teaches English at Boston College. He is also the author of nine books, president of the Thoreau Society and is hard at work on a biography of Ralph Waldo Emerson. But for two years Professor McAleer has burned the midnight oil as editor and publisher of ''The Thorndyke File,'' a biannual magazine devoted to the life and literature of R.Austin Freeman, a British doctor-turned-prolificnovelist whose first book appeared around the turn of the century.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BUILDING FOR TOMORROW Putting Waste to Work. By Martin Pawley. Illustrated. 192 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $17.95.

title: 3,000 Line Up Seeking Jobs
description: Nearly 3,000 job-seekers braved freezing temperatures today to apply for 100 apprenticeships at the Sun Oil Company refinery near here, company officials said. The first people in line arrived at 8 A.M. Friday, and by dawn the line stretched more than 500 yards. James Dulaney, Sun's manager for industrial relations, said he had spoken to people who traveled from as far away as Houston looking for work this morning.

title: No Headline
description: Rockets Scoreless in Overtime

title: Watch What You Say
description: William Safire's article ''Watch What You Say'' (On Language, Dec. 26) was timely in this era of high technology and computer panic. As an educator for the last 15 years, I have witnessed a considerable decline in children's knowledge and understanding of fractions, a trend which may be directly attributed to their diminished exposure to the circular, segmented faces of their ''old-fashioned'' watches.

title: CTW IN GEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: 'VOICE OVER,' TALE OF RADIO STAR
description: Chris Monger's ''Voice Over'' has perversity and originality in about equal measure. It tells of a grubby radio star named Fats Bannerman who, at the beginning of the film, holds his audience rapt with a version of ''Pride and Prejudice,'' which he passes off as a serial of his own creation.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS IN MIDDLE OF DISPUTE
description: NEARLY a decade after an 18-month tour of duty in Vietnam, Randy Good instinctively makes the gesture of reaching for a holster when a car backfires or a low-flying helicopter startles him.

title: A Brief Rebellion by Inmates Is Quelled at a Marseilles Jail
description: Riot policemen fired tear gas and charged onto the roof of a building at Baumettes Prison in Marseilles today to put down a brief rebellion by prisoners demanding better conditions, officials said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S FAILED SCHEME IS BIGGER LOSS FOR NAMIBIA
description: South Africa's effort to shape a political alternative to the insurgent movement it has been fighting in the territory known as Namibia collapsed last week, further frustrating Washington's hopes for a negotiated settlement of Africa's most protracted diplomatic problem.

title: CANADIAN WOMEN ASSAIL A PLAN FOR EROTIC TV
description: Dozens of women's groups held outdoor rallies in Canada's major cities this week to demand that the Government revoke the license of a new pay television channel because it plans to show erotic programs produced by the Playboy company of the United States.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Your Jan. 9 news article about defections from Social Security neglects to review the advantages this program has over alternative plans.

title: COETZEE AND THOMAS IN DRAW
description: Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa and Pinklon Thomas of Philadelphia fought to a 10-round draw today that kept both contenders in line for heavyweight title bouts.

title: JITNEY AT CROSSROADS IN VOTE ON UNION
description: IT'S called a jitney, not a bus; it was named the ''carrier of style'' by Vogue magazine, and its riders sip mineral water as they travel from Manhattan's East Side to the Island's East End. But its owner, Hampton Jitney Inc., suffers headaches not unlike any other public transportation system, and the latest challenge is the prospect of unionization.

title: PIANO VIRTUOSOS DISPLAY VARIED ART ON NEW RELEASES
description: Of the making of pianists there is no end, and this truism inevitably extends to piano recordings. To get recognition in the unending flow of disks that flood the market, the recording must be made by an exceptional artist or be devoted to unusual repertory. A recent issue that satisfies both criteria comes from Earl Wild and is a recording of a recital he played in Carnegie Hall on Nov. 1, 1981 called ''The Art of the Transcription'' (Audiofon 2008-2, two disks).

title: 'MUDDY RIVER'-A JAPANESE MOVIE THAT DEFIED THE ODDS
NEW HAVEN HIRINGS EXAMINED
description: NEW HAVEN THE Board of Aldermen here has begun investigating allegedly widespread illegal hirings by Mayor Biagio DiLieto's administration. At the same time, the Mayor has been conducting his own inquiry. And a third investigation has been called for by his chief political rival.

title: Speed Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTWAR MUSIC: JUILLIARD FESTIVAL
description: Yearly events such as the Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music serve several purposes. They are teaching tools, for one - dragging career-minded young Juilliard virtuosos momentarily away from their Tchaikovsky and Mendelssohn concertos and sitting them down to face the music of their own time.

title: MCENROE AND LENDL GAIN MASTERS FINAL
description: The force of Ivan Lendl's serve and ground strokes overwhelmed Jimmy Connors, 6-3, 6-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament.

title: SCOTT E. SHERMAN, LETA WONG TO WED
description: The engagement of Leta Nanette Wong to Scott Elliot Sherman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Kellogg H. Wong of Rye, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Sherman, also of Rye.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST VIEWS CHILD'S SOCIAL LIFE
description: WHEN Ruth Formanek speaks of her life and her work, a philosophy emerges. Sometimes the words vary, but the thought is always the same: ''Knowledge should be at the service of society.''

title: Fought Leads by 1 on a 70-269
description: There is a saying among professional golfers that advises: If you don't like it on the tour, you could try working for a living.

title: From Three R's To Six Figures For Macchiarola
description: Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola dropped out of the New York City school system last week. He traded his $85,000-a-year job running the nation's largest district for the $150,000 presidency of the New York City Partnership, a coalition of civic-minded business groups.

title: MADRID'S GRAND HOTELS
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Bonn bureau of The New York Times.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Directors' Cinema

title: IN FRANCE, THE CIDER SPARKLES
description: LUCINDA FRANKS, who frequently writes for The Times, is working on a novel.

title: THE DISSIDENTS' DISSIDENT
description: ON SAKHAROV Edited by Alexander Babyonyshev. Translated by Guy Daniels. 283 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $15.95. Vintage, paper, $6.95.

title: PRESSED-WOOD PRODUCTS: NEW TARGET FOR SAFETY COMMISSION
description: Last April, when the Government banned urea formaldehyde foam insulation in houses for causing respiratory problems and possibly cancer, its formaldehyde worries seemed settled. They weren't.

title: SHAPING SHIPS OF DREAMS
description: One of the most romantic-sounding businesses is housed in a huge, leaky old factory building in South Norwalk a block from the Norwalk River drawbridge. That's where John and Tom Wisner, brothers in their mid-20's, build custom boats - ships of dreams.

title: A WINTER CARNIVAL
description: Most of the delights of a typical winter day in New England will be available at the Thames Science Center Winter Carnival, scheduled from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday in the center's arboretum on Gallows Lane, New London.

title: INSIDE THE 'BEST-RUN COMPANIES'
description: In Search of Excellence: Lessons From America's Best-Run Companies, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr. Harper & Row, New York. 360 pages, $19.95. WHILE many companies have succumbed to obsolescence and managerial a rteriosclerosis, many others have thrived under battle conditions. ' 'In Search of Excellence'' is a celebration of 43 of them, includingD elta Air Lines, I.B.M., Texas Instruments, McDonald's, the Frito-Layd ivision of Pepsico, Kodak, Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Procter & Gamble,D igital Equipment and 3M.

title: Analysis: The Knicks and the Nets Halfway Through the Season; KNICKS: A NEW LOOK, BUT FEW WATCH
description: THE Knicks' attendance is running at a 17-year low. The team is buried in last place in the Atlantic Division with a 14-26 record, the sixth worst in the 23-team National Basketball Association.

title: JUNE WEDDING PLANNED FOR KATHERINE RUSSELL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Russell Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine S. Russell to Stephen B. McCurdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. McCurdy of Mountain Lakes, N. J.

title: DEMONSTRATIONS MARK 10 YEARS OF LEGAL ABORTION
description: About 26,000 people marked the 10th anniversary today of the Supreme Court's decision legalizing abortion by marching on the Capitol to demand legislation overturning the ruling.
Size: Male, to five inches. Female, a bit smaller. Color: Blue-black, with a scattering of round yellow spots on smooth carapace.

title: HUMOR'S PECKING ORDER
description: WHEN former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger noted that ''Power is the ultimate aphrodisiac,'' he might well have tacked on, ''and the ultimate wit-maker.''

title: EDISON PACT SIGNED
description: WEST ORANGE THOMAS ALVA EDISON spent 44 of his most productive years working in his laboratory here. It will take scholars almost half as long (the estimate is 20 years) to examine the 3.5 million pages of his documents and assemble from them a historically complete collection.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: WILLIAM BARANYAY will leave his position as executive director of the 4,000-member New Jersey Audubon Society on April 1 to become a regional director of Ducks Unlimited, a national waterfowl and wetlands conservation and hunting group.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN QUEBEC CITY
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN is chief of the Ottawa bureau of The Times.

title: Salvador Passes A Progress Test
description: Salvadoran civilians are still being killed by the thousands annually, the Reagan Administration conceded last week, but the trend in official violence is down and the Government is ''making serious efforts to improve the situation.'' The State Department therefore duly certified El Salvador as entitled to receive $25 million in military aid that Congress has approved for fiscal 1983. Without the aid, Ambassador Deane R. Hinton argued, Government forces would probably be defeated by the leftist guerrillas.

title: FOR THE WHITE HOUSE, SOME OPTIONS ON THE ECONOMY
description: Question: In the next 10 days, President Reagan will present his State of the Union Message, his budget for 1984 and his annual Economic Report. Experience tells us that such policy statements are optimistic about where a President can take the country. Is there any genuine basis for optimism now about the economy?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 19 of the Arts and Leisure section today about women in symphony orchestras misidentifies Doriot Anthony Dwyer. She is the Boston Symphony's principal flutist.

title: TASS SEES U.S. CREATING COSMOS 'HULLABALOO'
description: In only the third Soviet comment on Cosmos 1402 in the two and a half weeks since the Pentagon first raised an alarm about the demobilized nuclear-powered reconnaissance satellite, Tass accused Washington Friday night of mounting a ''provocative hullabaloo'' about the satellite in order to deflect attention from America's arms buildup.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Whither Inflation?

title: DIAMONDS CAN CRACK, BUT WILL DE BEERS?
description: Diamonds may be nature's hardest substance but they shatter if struck the wrong way. The lesson has worried many a diamond miner, merchant and jeweler during the five decades that South Africa's De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. has brought profits and stability to the diamond industry by maintaining what, in theory, is very fragile - an international monopoly.

title: WORDS ARE WEAPONS AS TALKS RESUME
description: WASHINGTON SOVIET and American negotiators are returning to the Geneva arms talks on Thursday after a remarkable week of polemics and posturing that tended to obscure the possibility that Washington and Moscow may yet reach agreements on nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: JESSICA WINSLOW WEDS STEPHEN SMAHA
description: Jessica Winslow, daughter of Theresa Winslow of Vineland, N.J., and the late John R. Winslow, was married yesterday to Stephen E. Smaha, son of Donald Smaha of Falmouth, Me., and Jeanne Smaha of Portland, Me.

title: Ex-Head of American Express To Lead Presbyterian Hospital
description: Howard L. Clark, a former chief executive officer and chairman of the American Express Company, has been elected chairman of the board of Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Rushlaw Sled Leads
description: Brent Rushlaw and Jim Tyler recorded the best times in both heats today to take the lead in the national two-man bobsled championships.

title: FOR WASHINGTON, A TASTE OF CANADA
description: ''Have you been warned that this is a foody evening?'' the wife of the Canadian Ambassador asked the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and his wife as they stepped into the drawing room.

title: VIOLENCE RULES CENTRAL AMERICA DESPITE PACTS AND PLANS FOR PEACE
description: Five years after the first rebellions against Nicaragua's Somoza regime began to spread instability through the region, Central America is still at war with itself.

title: RESTORING THE BALANCE
description: Just before he departs for renewed negotiations on nuclear missiles in Europe, Paul Nitze has left the strong impression that the U.S. would be willing to reconsider its position if the Soviet Union makes a ''serious'' proposal.

title: 'TREASURE OF FOUR CROWNS'
description: The Lupo-Anthony-Quintano production ''Treasure of the Four Crowns'' is inspired, as they say, in equal measure by ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and the trio's earlier opus, ''Comin' at Ya.'' That makes it a 3-D adventure film. It comes as close to being unwatchable as a movie can be, as a result of the combined effects of amateur acting, idiotic plot, murky camera work and the cheapest-looking props you can imagine. Even the music is misguided. The score offers the most benign of happy-ending music just as one character's face is turning maggoty and melting.

title: 'CAINE MUTINY': MIXED VERDICT
description: Martial,'' derived from his 1950 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Caine Mutiny,'' still works.

title: PLAINFIELD GALLERY: BIG STRIDES IN A SHORT CAREER
description: PLAINFIELD IT LOOKS as though Tweed will not get its railroad station after all, thanks to the recent change in the city's administration. It was about 18 months ago that this snappily named group of artists was promised the handsome, old Jersey Central depot as a permanent home, and ever since it has been planning for the move (with some financial help from the Gannett Foundation).

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
DECLARATIONS OF INDEPENDENCE, BUT FOR WHOM?
description: OF course, the children think I'm nuts but I line them up anyhow and deliver my speech: ''Don't call, never mind the dinner invitations, I don't feel like going fishing, I know you want to be nice, but your mother and I have too much to do, you can do us a favor and let us give you a call, we're too busy right now.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
HOW A STRONG DOLLAR THREW THE FED
description: THE monetary origins of the current world depression should not be b lamed on the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, but on the n arrowness of mainline Keynesian and Monetarist teachings about c ontrol of the money supply.

title: EX-GOV. MILLIKEN FINDS BASIC CHANGES ARE NEEDED IN MIDWEST
description: The files are still unpacked. The floors remain bare. The fumes of fresh varnish linger around the new bookshelves. And the desk rests uncluttered by the broad window overlooking the stormy green bay.

title: THE CHEFS' TRAINING IS EVIDENT
description: THOSE who have already discovered Nook and Cranny in Wantagh have been on the inside track for what is probably the best French food on the South Shore of Nassau County. This small restaurant close by the Wantagh station could be a neighborhood pub in any of a dozen towns and villages. The bar area is separated from the modest-sized dining room, which has both booth and table seating. The room is pleasant enough, with wood paneling, hanging plants and tablecloths. The menu is hardly typical, however.

title: HANS SYBERG'S ADAPTATION OF 'PARSIFAL'
description: Hans Jurgen Syberberg's film version of Richard Wagner's music drama, ''Parsifal,'' should enthrall both film lovers and Wagner fans. Mr. Syberberg's work represents not only the summation of his career thus far, but is as gripping, strange and, in the end, devotionally faithful a staging as any Wagner opera has received in our time.

title: CLAUDIA MARY HAUFE IS ENGAGED TO RICHARD J. BELL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Robert Haufe of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Mary Haufe, to Richard James Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Drummond Crilley Bell of Fairfield, Conn.

title: ENGLEWOOD CONCERT
description: The soprano Marilyn Horne will perform Thursday evening at the John Harms Englewood Plaza in a program including works by Nin, Strauss, Rossini, Bizet, Poulenc and Falla.

title: A NATIVE SON LEADS THE BASEL BALLET

MAILBAG;
FILMING HOLMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Debtor Nations To Get a Boost
description: Two ways to help the debt-burdened nations, and themselves, got general approval last week among 11 of the wealthiest members and associates of the International Monetary Fund.

title: New Approach Used To Patients' Concerns
description: The hospital experience described in the Jan. 9 Opinion Page article is, unfortunately, not an uncommon one. When patients and their families face problems and concerns over serious or just ''bewildering'' matters, they don't know whom to speak to.

title: JAZZ TO BALLET
description: The Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, near the Mosholu Parkway exit of the Saw Mill River Parkway, has an array of performances scheduled this week through March that could help reduce the midwinter doldrums to a minimum.

title: Musings on Muse
description: Britain has its poet laureate; the United States has its Consultant in Poetry in English to the Library of Congress. When Anthony Hecht, the Pulitzer Prize poet and professor of poetry at the University of Rochester, took over last October as the 20th Consultant, it became almost obligatory for him to write a poem about the city of Washington.

title: Feds Yield on Brink's Witness
description: Even if Samuel Brown, a defendant in the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders, is singing to the Feds, he will still have to face the music in court. So it seemed last week after United States Attorney John S. Martin Jr. dropped his demand for permanent custody of Mr. Brown and promised not to interfere with his prosecution by the state.

title: Marino's Passing Leads North Squad to Victory
description: Dan Marino threw a pair of 11-yard touchdown passes in the second half as the North team beat the South, 14-6, in the 34th Senior Bowl college all-star football game today.

title: FALKLANDERS' FREEDOM NEEDS NO DISPOSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Masley Leads in Event For U.S. Luge Title
description: Frank Masley of Newark, Del., held the lead after two heats of the national luge championships today.

title: U.S. SURPLUS-LAND SALES: SNAGS AND GAINS
description: THE Reagan Administration's program of selling unneeded Federal p roperty to the highest bidder to help reduce the national debt has m et with some success and some confusion in the New York metropolitana rea this winter.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE AGE OF WONDERS. By Aharon Appelfeld. (Pocket/Washington Square, $3.95.) In the second of his novels to be published in this country, the Israeli writer Aharon Appelfeld tells the story of Bruno, the son of an intellectual Austrian Jew. Propelled into the path of Hitler's juggernaut in part one of the book, Bruno returns to his homeland 20 years after the war in part two. Our critic, Joel Agee, found this a beautifully written novel despite some dramatic weakness in its second section and noted that ''many desolate epiphanies, fathomless little pools of sorrow ... open up here and there in the steady flow of the narrative with cumulative tragic force.''

title: WINTER ON EAST END: QUIETER THIS YEAR?
description: IN the absence of hard facts, up-to-date surveys or dependable indicators, gauging the health of the East End economy from season to season is an activity more intuitive than rational. Those who engage in it tend to rely rather heavily on things like the Friday night car count at certain key traffic lights, the length of the line at the movies or the number of newspapers left on the shelf Sunday at noon.

title: THE NEW CHIEF OF SHEARSON/AMERICAN EXPRESS IS AN OLD PRO AT 36
description: WHEN Peter A. Cohen got the word that he would be elected president a nd chief executive of Shearson/American Express at a board meeting e arlier this month, the 36-year-old executive arrived for the o fficial proceedings with a big paper bag.

title: REDRAWING A PANEL ON DRAWING LINES
description: IT was a seemingly straightforward initiative that Andrew A. Albanese, the new Chairman of the Board of Legislators, was announcing at last Monday's session: he was appointing a three-member committee to handle the issue of reapportionment, or the remaking of legislative districts to conform to the 1980 census.

title: LEBANON ACCEPTS PROPOSAL BY HABIB
description: The Lebanese Government has told the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, that it is willing to accept United Nations or other multinational troops, including Americans, to man early-warning stations being demanded by Israel in southern Lebanon, a senior Lebanese negotiator said today.

title: MICHAELS IS STILL SURPRISING PEOPLE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. WHEN the football strike had ended last November and the Jets celebrated by trouncing the Baltimore Colts, Coach Walt Michaels received one of the most unusual game balls of his career: A game ball for compassion. The game ball is awarded by the team captains only after a victory to someone who has played a key role. Michaels had received them for his strategy as assistant coach in charge of the defense in the 1960's, and he also had been given game balls since becoming head coach in 1977.

title: MEAT ROLLS BY MANY OTHER NAMES
description: There is a great deal of romance involved in food nomenclature. A century and more ago, for example, it was fashionable to name foods for royalty and friends. Thus we gained such dishes as tournedos Henri IV, creme du Barry, which is cream of cauliflower, and Lady Curzon soup, which is a curried cream of green turtle soup. (Lady Curzon, by the way, was an American who was married to the English viceroy of India.) Similarly, the dishes named for operas and opera stars are quite famous, and include Melba toast, chicken Tetrazzini and tournedos Belle Helene.

title: Stamford Arts Center Gains Some Praise
description: I'm sorry that one of your readers didn't like the December offering of the Stamford Center for the Arts (Letters to the Connecticut Editor, Dec. 26). If he expected Broadway or Lincoln Center productions, then his disappointment is understandable.

title: SAUDIS SEEKING TO SETTLE OPEC DISPUTE
description: Saudi Arabia will present a plan at an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to settle a bitter dispute over the allocation of oil-production ceilings that threatens the group's unity, senior OPEC officials said today.

title: JAY TEAGLE PLANS TO WED ALASTAIR KEITH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Page Wright Smith of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter, Jayne Will Teagle, to Alastair James Keith, son of Lord Keith of Castleacre, Norfolk, England, and Lady Ariel Keith of London.

title: WHO SHOULD PAY FOR NUCLEAR SAFETY?
description: WHITE PLAINS AS the debate over nuclear safety swirls around Indian Point, politicians are placing increasing pressure on nuclear-plant operators to defray more of the costs of radiological emergency planning.

title: PRINCETON VOTES A 12.6% RISE FOR TUITION, ROOM AND BOARD
description: Undergraduates at Princeton University will pay nearly $13,000 for tuition and room and board next year, a 12.6 percent increase, under a plan approved today by the university's board of trustees.

title: HUNTING FOR STORE SITES IN HASTINGS
description: AFIRE on Dec. 13 near the heart of Hastings-on-Hudson's commercial district has produced side effects that may be harder to control than the blaze, which seriously damaged the village's oldest commercial building and forced several businesses into the streets just before Christmas.

title: FAIRFIELD PORTER: BEHIND THE COZINESS, A FIERCE FREEDOM; BOSTON
description: The retrospective exhibition of paintings and watercolors by Fairfield Porter (1907-75) at the Boston Museum of Fine Art makes an effect of quite exceptional jubilation. Skies are wide and high. The air is clear, with salt breezes blowing in from the ocean. The light is generosity made visible.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Marcia Recktenwald Weds Kenneth Eberl
description: Marcia Katherine Recktenwald, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald E. Recktenwald of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to Kenneth Anthony Eberl, son of Mrs. Anthony M. Eberl of Buffalo and the late Mr. Eberl. The Rev. Peter Stuhlmiller performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family.

title: MONTCLAIR SCIENTIST SMOOTHES WAY FOR SPACE PROBES
description: MONTCLAIR THE three stations of the Deep Space Network are expected to be operated more efficiently and economically as a result of research by a professor of psychology and human engineering at Montclair State College.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: My Reception, Your Shivaree

title: A RIGHTFUL PLACE FOR SEMANTIC SYMBOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatry Panel Takes a Stand on Taking the Stand
description: When a jury last year found John W. Hinckley Jr. not guilty of shooting the President by reason of insanity, psychiatry became selfconscious. The trial had revealed disarray not only in the defendant's mind but among mental health experts, who could not agree on whether Mr. Hinckley was legally insane.

title: FARM PRICE PROPS EXPECTED TO RISE ABOVE '82 RECORD
description: Federal costs for farm price supports soared to the highest level in the 50-year history of these programs in the last fiscal year and are expected to be even higher this year.

title: 2,621 Dogs Entered
description: The entry for the 107th annual Westminster Kennel Club show has closed with 2,621 dogs representing 137 breeds or varieties. The event take place Feb. 14-15 in Madison Square Garden.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: POPE SET TO ISSUE NEW CHURCH LAWS EASING STRICTURES
description: A totally revised code of Roman Catholic canon law breaks new ground by stressing rights of the laity, allowing bishops to make more decisions locally and reducing the number of religious obligations expected of Catholics, according to church specialists familiar with the draft submitted to Pope John Paul II.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN ASIAN TOUCH TO FISH DISHES
description: TUCKED in the corner of a Fort Lee shopping center is the two-yearold offshoot of Janice's Fish Place in Greenwich Village. This informal outpost, with its large bar, rustic paneling and butcherblock tables, follows the same format originated by Hisae Vilca and Janice Rubin - that of fresh, lightly cooked seafood and vegetarian dishes combining elements of both Oriental and Continental cuisines.

title: Offense
description: 82 DURIEL HARRIS: Wide receiver, 5 feet 11 inches, 176 pounds, 28 years old, 7th season. 22 catches for 331 yards and 1 touchdown. Caught more passes than any other Dolphin wide receiver. 79 JON GIESLER: Left tackle, 6-5, 260, 26, 4th. No. 1 draft choice in 1979, a starter in 1980. 67 BOB KUECHENBERG: Left gaurd, 6-2, 255, 35, 13th. Oldest Dolphin. Was a starter on the Super Bowl teams of the early 1970's. 57 DWIGHT STEPHENSON: Center. 6-2, 255, 25, 3d. Won the starting job over Mark Dennard before the first game of the season. 60 JEFF TOEWS: Right guard, 6-3, 255, 25, 4th. Became a starter when Ed Newman injured his knee late in the season. 68 ERIC LAAKSO: Right tackle, 6-4, 265, 26, 5th. Prevented the Jets' Mark Gastineau from sacking the quarterback in the season opener. 81 JIMMY CEFALO: Wide receiver, 5-11, 188, 26, 5th. 17 catches for 356 yards. Former player at Penn State. Has the best hands of all the Dolphins receivers. 84 BRUCE HARDY: Tight end, 6-4, 230, 26, 5th. 12 catches for 66 yards. One of three tight ends used by the Dolphins. Is a better receiver than blocker. 16 DAVID WOODLEY: Quarterback, 6-2, 204, 24, 3d. Completed 54.7 percent of his passes for 1,080 yards and 5 touchdowns. In two playoff games, he has completed 33 of 41 passes for 441 yards.

title: PLEASANT FARE ON THE WATERFRONT
description: MEMORABLE waterfront dining in Connecticut is rarer than we would wish. So when you find a restaurant on the water that is both attractive and serves competent food, you feel a sense of triumph.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: ALL ABOUT TOLL-FREE 800 NUMBERS
description: O ne slogan that has gained wide usage among telephone subscribers is ''Let Your Fingers Do the Walking,'' referring to the Yellow Pages of the phone book and meaning that one can do his or her shopping and arrange home repairs and the like by telephone rather than by going out on foot.

title: BALTIMORE GROUP AMONG RECITALISTS
description: ''Greensleeves and Other Delights'' was an appropriate title for the Renaissance Ensemble of Baltimore's afternoon concert last Sunday at the Corpus Christi Church, for much of the program was delightful indeed.

title: AN ODD RARITY
description: This is a shaggy paw story. First came a whole bunch of hairy chairs, all carved in Philadelphia two centuries ago. So rare were these five chairs with furry feet that everyone thought they'd be the last examples of hairy-paw furniture to appear.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
EMPATHY: THE MISSING INGREDIENT
description: ARIEL SHARON, Israel's Defense Minister, is reported to have defended his decision to permit Christian militiamen to enter the Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut by saying that never in his wildest imagination did he envision the possibility of a massacre.

title: More Homeless And More Help
description: Bitter cold forced almost 5,000 of New York City's homeless into shelters last week, the highest figure since the Depression. With the city compelled by law to find a place for all of them, Mayor Koch stepped up his campaign to get others - this time, Jewish congregations - to help bear the burden.

title: CINEMATIC ART VS. REALITY IN INDONESIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bernard Kalb, who covered Indonesia for The New York Times, is now the State Department correspondent for NBC News.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DOCTOR WITH A GOOD DOGHOUSE-SIDE MANNER
description: OSSINING DR. Steven A. Gottschalk was making his first house call of the day. The weather was freakish for January, soft and sunny, and he rolled back the sun roof of his tiny Renault Le Car. He was wearing corduroy jeans, a down vest and, because they are comfortable for standing, wooden clogs.

title: STAGE: 'BOY'S OWN STORY'
description: Peter Flannery's ''The Boy's Own Story'' is a one-man-team play about the field trials and the personal ordeals of an over-the-hill British football goalkeeper. At the York Theater Company, the evening's actor is Jim Piddock, an Englishman last seen on Broadway in ''Present Laughter.'' Physically this may be the most demanding stage assignment since Gunther Gebel-Williams last placed his head inside the mouth of a lion.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Among the other distinctions of Wild Bill Davison, the firey, hardpunching, sassy-toned coronetist who plays his horn as though he were trying to live up to the fact that he comes from a town in Ohio called Defiance, is that he's the only musician who has ever been booked as a headliner for a week or more at Eddie Condon's, the jazz club at 144 West 54th Street, since it opened in March, 1975.

title: A Monetarist Flaw
description: To the Business Editor: H. Erich Heinemann's ''The Fed's Uncertain New Strategy'' (Dec.19) attempted to provide a balanced report between the monetarists and nonmonetarists concerning the Fed's current policy efforts. Nevertheless, he gives somewhat greater weight, and even greater credence, to the monetarist fears. This is that by moving to a stimulative posture to combat the recession, the Fed runs the risk of reigniting inflationary expectations.

title: Letters; Tower Protested
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE CHANCE OF A LIFETIME IS LOST FOREVER
description: Is there anything more disheartening to discover, after an encounter with one of the world's greatest players, that in one moment you had the opportunity to win with the most spectacular move of your career? This was the unfortunate mishap of the Swedish international master Lars-Ake Schneider in the 13th round of the Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Up to 50% Off on Shoes In Two Shops

title: PROBATION CHIEF ADMITS DROP IN YOUTH SERVICES
description: New York City's Probation Commissioner, responding to continuing criticism of his agency's handling of troubled young people, has acknowledged the existence of ''very real problems'' the department he has headed since 1978.

title: JACKSON HEIGHTS
description: IN 1909, the Queensboro Corporation began transforming 100 blocks off armland in northern Queens into a neighborhood that could lure r esidents from Manhattan, seven miles away. Moving people to what w ere still the cornfields of Queens meant, the company decided, that c harm had to be built into its new Jackson Heights community.

title: NOW Official Indicted
description: Unlike her former husband John Sidote, Ginny Foat took the high road after they parted company.

title: HABIB AND MUBARAK IN TALKS
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, met with President Hosni Mubarak today to brief him on the negotiations for the withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: ELIZABETH NELSON PLANS A WEDDING
description: Mrs. Richard A. Nelson of Woodstock, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carol Ann Nelson, to Laurance A. Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Read of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Portal Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: City Track May Lose Armory
description: The Cardinal Hayes Games have been held for 34 years in the 102d Engineers Armory in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. But yesterday's edition, with an entry of 165 high schools and more than 3,000 athletes, could be the final one at the armory.

title: LIEUT. BETH GAMBACCINI MARRIES LEUT. SCOTT GURD
description: Lieut. Beth Horan Gambaccini and Lieut. Scott Haakon Gurd, who are stationed in Fort Jackson, S.C. with the Army, were married yesterday in the Main Chapel at Governors Island.

title: Yes, Welcome the Deficit
description: People ask, why the turnabout? Last year we wanted taxes raised to reduce the Federal deficit; now we're almost eager to hold the deficit high. Just so.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC The Violent Femmes, a mostly acoustic folk-punk trio from Minneapolis, have stirred up more excitement and garnered more admiring reviews, than any other new, unrecorded band in recent memory. The ''Femmes'' are actually three young men; ''femmes'' was a locker-room insult when they were attending high school.

title: No Salvation Seen In Bus Stewardesses
description: While I agree with the author of ''Let's Destigmatize Mass Transit'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 9) that making mass transportation more appealing to the commuter could have positive results, I take exception to one of his suggestions.

title: DESIGN
