description: Familiarity Breeds Harmony A team of designers creates a miniature villa for a professor of art history that manages to be both at peace with its stunning natural setting and an intriguing piece of architecture. t is just the sort of building site that imposes special pressures on thoughtful people concerned with preserving the environment - two and one-quarter acres overlooking Cayuga Lake near Ithaca, N.Y. So when the owner, Robert C. Hobbs, a professor of art history and a curator at Cornell University's Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art, approached the architectural designers Simon Ungers and Laszlo Kiss, he did so with books on solar earth shelters dutifully tucked under his arm. Kiss and Ungers were mildly appalled, they later confessed: appalled because their training as architects had left them with the conviction that a building ought to be something more than ''a hole in the ground,'' but only mildly so because they were confident that Hobbs, a specialist in contemporary art, could be brought around to their point of view.

title: Doesn't Grow on Trees
description: Nature's isn't the only greenery that some environmentalists get worked up about, it seems.

title: DR. ELLEN ADAMS TO WED LAWYER
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Elizabeth McCann Adams of Honolulu of the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Ellen Elizabeth Adams, to James Putnam Bassett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Putnam Bassett of Fairfield, Conn., and North Pomfret, Vt.

title: CONFOUNDING FATHER
description: AARON BURR The Conspiracy and Years of Exile 1805-1836. By Milton Lomask. Illustrated. 476 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: SHULA'S STYLE: A MELLOW INTENSITY
description: MIAMI EVERY so often during those moments in which success and circumstances have pushed Don Shula to the forefront, someone asks him how he has changed in the 20 years he has coached in the National Football League. Shula has heard the question so many times, it makes him laugh. He heard it again last week, as his Dolphins prepared to play the Jets today in the semifinals of the Super Bowl XVII tournament. He laughed again and said, ''I keep hearing I've mellowed.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART The spacious, sheltered mall between 42d and 43d Streets that belongs to the City University Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street, provides a challenging site for sculpture, with its architectural setting of raw concrete, bathed in cavernous gloom. But it presents no problems for Kit-yin Snyder, whose high, light-trapping arches, built from bricklike modules of wire mesh, form an elegant maze that gives viewers a sense of airy transparency as they pass through it.

title: WINNING, LOSING-AND WHY
description: Life and Death on the Corporate Battlefield: How Companies Win, Lose, Survive, by Paul Solman and Thomas Friedman. Simon & Schuster, New York. 248 pages, $13.95. IN 1917, the United States Steel Corporation was the world's largestc ompany, five times larger than its nearest competitor. Last year t he faltering giant, America's first billion-dollar corporation, r anked 17th in assets among industrials, and now is scrambling to d iversify out of the moribund domestic steel industry and fighting f or its financial life.

title: LEGALIZED LOFTS: A NEW ERA IS BEGINNING
description: NOT long ago, New York City's residential loft market was c onsidered a wild frontier, complete with pioneers and its own brand o f justice. But law and order has finally come to the frontier: S weeping zoning changes and new legislation are putting into place a p lan designed to end the confusion and legal ambiguities of loft l iving.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column of Jan. 9 inaccurately described the reason that travel agents will not provide refunds for air tickets that they did not originally issue. Under rules of the Air Traffic Conference, a trade organization that governs such matters, agencies are prohibited from doing so.

title: HERE COMES THE DIGITAL ERA
description: As a gambling town, Las Vegas never quite matched the cachet of Baden-Baden or Monte Carlo, and I am sure that the architecture of these places has as much to do with this as the different gaming traditions in Europe and the Far West. In Germany and Monaco, the setting is rococo - playful, but with a sense of balance and restraint. In such an ambiance, even the most passionate gambling seems like a graceful game, though one might emerge from it as severely clipped as the hedges in those exquisite casino gardens. By contrast, the whole city of Las Vegas looks like a huge, blinking slot machine. This sets quite a different mood and makes wagering in the West seem a grim challenge to fortune rather than an elegant diversion.

title: SOME RUNNERS WHO CAN END U.S. 1500-METER FRUSTRATION
description: The football Giants haven't been champions since 1956. The Rangers haven't won the Stanley Cup in nearly 43 years. These are but momentary frustrations, and purely of a local nature, compared with the agony track fans across the country suffer as because of the American inability to win the 1,500-meter run at the Olympic Games.

title:
STAMPS;
HISTORIC CASTLES AND CHURCHES OF IRELAND
description: Ireland has begun a new definitive series, an event of philatelic note. This is only the third time in the more than 60 years since the country gained independence that it has published a series.

title: RITUAL RECALLS 'REFUSENIK' PLIGHT
description: WHEN Matthew Karp stands up on Saturday and chants the prayer that begins his bar mitzvah service at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, he will be doing more than celebrating his formal entry into the adult Jewish community. He will be sharing the service with Vitalli Kanovsky, a 13-year-old boy in Russia he has never met and who may not even know about his American counterpart. Although Matthew has written to him, the letters may never have been delivered.

title: PREGNANT AND GOING TO SCHOOL
description: ''IUSED to walk in the hallways of my other school real terrified. It's more comfortable here. We're one big family. And I don't have to worry about crowded hallways or kids looking at me funny,'' said a 16-year-old girl, her hands resting on her slightly rounded stomach, just beginning to stretch the boundaries of a maroon sweatsuit.

title: PANEL SEEKS TO SHARPEN ETHICS CODE
description: HARTFORD DESPITE a distinct lack of interest by Connecticut's citizenry, a special committee recommended last week that the General Assembly tighten the code of ethics governing the conduct of state officials and lobbyists.

title: A VIOLINIST WHO DECIDED TO EXPAND HIS HORIZONS
description: ''This I promise,'' Jaime Laredo says with a laugh, as he sets out pretzels and beer in the living room of his spacious apartment high above Riverside Drive, ''I'm not going to be one of those instrumentalists who stop playing when they pick up the baton. I am not going to suddenly become a full-time conductor, nor do I dream of working with a massive orchestra. I have no secret urge to conduct the Mahler Second.''

title: NEW YORK STUDIES FOOD BANK OPERATED FOR NEEDY IN JERSEY
description: They came to the warehouse driving pick-up trucks and vans and, occasionally, a station wagon. A few minutes later, they pulled away loaded up with the donated foodstuffs that Kathleen Di Chiara and her volunteer helpers had persuaded companies to contribute for the hungry.

title: FAVORITES AND HOPEFULS AS THEY GO TO THE POST
description: Advance men with walkie-talkies, maneuverings over how to conduct a straw poll, and even serious speeches on national problems were the ways the Democrats chose to demonstrate that their 1984 Presidential contest is on, even before a single would-be President has formally declared his candidacy.

title: Future Events; Formal Occasions
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Corporate Clout Jan. 27 - A black-tie dinner in the Imperial Ballroom at the Sheraton Centre will raise money to establish a faculty development fund at Manhattan College in Riverdale, the Bronx, and honor Richard R. Shinn. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company chairman will receive the de la Salle Medal in recognition of his contributions to the advancement of business, the arts and education in America. Brother J. Stephen Sullivan, president of the coeducational college run by the Brothers of the Christian Schools, will present the award named for the founder of the order. Dinner was planned by a committee of 90 business leaders. Tickets, $285.

title: NEW CANAAN TAKES RIBBING WITH LAUGHTER
description: WHEN Paul Killiam was 10 years old and a soprano, he portrayed Josephine in a school production of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H.M.S. Pinafore.'' His voice later would change, but not his aspiration.

title:
GARDENING;
THE TIME TO CORRECT GARDEN DEFICIENCIES
description: PLANTS are the key to the survival of life on earth. Green plants capture the energy of the sun through the process of photosynthesis. That captured energy not only provides sustenance for the plants, but is the source of energy, food and much of the shelter for animal life, including man.

title: MISS RODIN WEDS A FELLOW LAWYER
description: Michele Rodin, daughter of Mrs. Gloria Rodin of Floral Park, L.I., and Mr. Bernard M. Rodin of Manhasset, L.I., and Miami Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Paul Jawin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jawin of Douglaston, Queens. The ceremony was performed by New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams and New York State Supreme Court Justice Israel Rubin at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title:
ART;
VIEWS BOTH ROMANTIC AND CEREBRAL
description: CARLUS DYER affords a crash course in post-modernism, perhaps the most overworked term in contemporary art. However, it acquires real meaning in the selection of his paintings done since 1970 at the Silvermine Guild Center for the Arts in New Canaan.

title: TAKING TEA IN LONDON TOWN
description: PAMELA HARLECH is a writer who lives in London.

title: China Closes Some Gates
description: China last week provided a taste of what all-out protectionism could be like, slapping a ban on further purchases this year of American cotton, soybeans and synthetic fibers. The ban, mainly affecting $60 million in soybean imports, was only a pinprick in Chinese-American trade that totaled $5.3 billion last year and is expected to go higher with Chinese oil and Boeing 737 aircraft deliveries in 1983.

title: Turkish Office in Paris Attacked by Armenians
description: Armenian guerrillas threw grenades at the Paris office of Turkish Airlines today and a bomb was later discovered near the airline's counter at Orly airport.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: In an article on reviewing books that recently appeared in The New Criterion, Joseph Epstein said that ''most current-day reviewers err on the side of generosity.'' Yet if you were to talk to publishers and authors, you might hear that reviewers are ravening beasts who open their mouths only to breath flames.

title: A LITTLE GOOD NEWS
description: There is some good news in the capital of the United States, after all. Recently, when it appeared that the American economy was getting out of hand, and even that its Social Security system was going bankrupt, some longing for unity began to intrude on the clamor of the front pages.

title: REDSKINS DEFEAT COWBOYS 31-17, AND ADVANCE TO THE SUPER BOWL
description: The Washington Redskins battered, bruised and broke the Dallas Cowboys today in their game for the National Conference championship.

title: Lawmakers' Smoking Curbed
description: The Arkansas House of Representatives has approved a resolution urging members not to smoke in the chamber.

title: No Headline
description: Eugene Linden's article questions the future of chimpanzees used in relatively short-term biomedical research studies. It recognizes the ''pressures on the animals in the wild,'' yet it proposes either to release the animals into the wild (where they might fall prey to local hunters) or ''to build a preserve in the United States.''

title: NEW YORK ROCK: AN UNDERGROUND LODE
description: New York's underground rock scene - a loose and often competitive confederation of bands, clubs, and independent record labels - has triggered a number of worldwide pop music trends since its beginnings in the mid-1970's. Punk, funk, the psychedelic revival and various crossovers blending rock with African and Latin pop influences started in Manhattan's rock clubs and made their way to England, Europe and other rock centers, often without causing much of a stir at home.

title: SKI WEAR SHAPES UP
description: Ski Wear Shapes Up New synthetic insulations are creating a slimmer look. Though they share many of down's heat-providing qualities, they are lighter, less bulky and less expensive. merica's preoccupation with getting into shape has not been lost on ski-wear manufacturers this winter, and many have styled their clothing with a noticeable nod to the body-conscious. The puffy garments of seasons past, which made even the fittest man look as though he needed to miss a meal or two, have given way to ski wear that is at once flattering and functional.

title: MISS EMMET, SETH G. HEALD ARE TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Emmet of Westford, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Caroline MacLaren Emmet, to Seth Galbraith Heald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrell Heald of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: NEIL WHITMAN TO WED SUSAN LEIGH HOLLANDER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Zander Hollander of New York and Millerton, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Leigh Hollander, to Neil Philip Whitman, son of Mrs. Richard Tartakoff of Avon, Conn., and the late George Whitman of Sharon, Mass.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: IF DOROTHY GILLESPIE'S art pertained only to the strategies of color, the sensuousness of texture and the dynamic effects of movement, it would be enough to satisfy any sensitive eye.

title: Speed Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: A BRIDGE BETWEEN TWO CULTURES
description: DEMAREST ''TRADITIONAL Korean Pottery; Contemporary Korean Painting,'' an exhibition in the new gallery at the Old Church Cultural Center, brings together two sets of Asian-born artists, each reflecting their heritage in a different way.

title: PUERTO RICO'S SMALL, SELECT MUSEUMS
description: MORTON N. COHEN, the editor of ''The Letters of Lewis Carroll'' (two volumes), lives part of the year in Puerto Rico.

title: MISS WENDER WILL MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wender of Memphis have made known the engagement of their daughter Jill Robin Wender, to Elliot Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Goldstein of Monsey, N.Y.

title: 15 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: JOYCE E. BOLAND IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John P. Boland of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Joyce Elizabeth Boland, to Vincent George DeVito, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo A. DeVito of Hicksville, L.I. Miss Boland, a law student at Fordham University, graduated summa cum laude from St. John's University, as did her fiance. He is a researcher with CBS.

title: 'DESPERATE HOURS' SHORT ON THRILLS
description: ''THE DESPERATE HOURS'' is a psychological thriller that's superficial upon analysis and short on thrills. In the Theater Three production in Port Jefferson, which runs through Feb. 5, the director, George Carabin, appears to have emphasized yet another facet of Joseph Hayes's 1955 melodrama: the philosophizing, preachy part.

title: A COSTLY MERGER FOR OCCIDENTAL
description: LOS ANGELES SIXTEEN stories above this city, in a penthouse office decorated with everything from a Rubens canvas to autographed pictures of virtually every world leader, Dr. Armand Hammer grinned with delight over Occidental Petroleum's $4 billion purchase of Cities Service. ''It's a great acquisition,'' said Occidental's 84-year-old chairman. ''I'm happy with it.'' And, taking aim at the seven major oil companies, he gleefully added: ''It may be that there will be eight sisters instead of seven.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: UNCLE TERRIBLE More Adventures of Anatole. By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by David McPhail. 120 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Flaming Object Is Said to Fall From the Sky Onto Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lankan scientists said today that they were trying to determine if a blazing object the size of a tennis ball that dropped from the sky was a fragment of the falling Soviet Cosmos satellite.

title: KAREN SCOTT AFFIANCED TO A
description: TEACHER OF MUSIC

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IT'S MIDWINTER 'CABIN FEVER' TIME AGAIN
description: HERE it is, the middle of winter, and I've just finished reading (again) a book entitled ''Under Barnegat's Beam,'' an engrossing history of Long Beach Island by Bayrd Randolph Kraft. Yes, I guess I've got ''cabin fever.''

title: Nakasone and Reagan Pitch Some Metaphors
description: Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone acknowledged the ''showers'' of protests and ''storms'' of complaints that greeted his first visit to Washington last week but made it plain he could do little to change the weather.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Tax-change proposals are expected to be part of President Reagan's State of the Union message Tuesday. The President said last week that he was considering modified flat-rate plans to simplify the income tax. Martin S. Feldstein, his economic adviser, discussed another option - a tax on consumption but not on savings.

title: MISS EHRENKRANZ TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. N. Joel Ehrenkranz of Coral Gables, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Faith Ehrenkranz, to Robert Lawrence Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Goodman of Livingston, N.J.

title: WHEN SEIZING POWER IS EASIER THAN EXERCISING IT
description: After a tumultuous period of economic crises and violence in Latin America, an encouraging development has emerged - military retreats in the face of popular pressure for the restoration of representative government.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A TRIUMPH OF BIPARTISAN NEGOTIATING
description: THE compromise agreement on Social Security reached by the National Commission on Social Security Reform, if ultimately a pproved by Congress and the President, will go down in history as a l andmark in political statesmanship.

title: FROM RIGHT TO LEFT
description: A LIFE WITH THE PRINTED WORD By John Chamberlain. Introduction by William F. Buckley Jr. 191 pp. Chicago: Regnery Gateway. $12.95.

title: I.M. PEI REDISCOVERS CHINA
description: Paul Goldberger is the architecture critic of The New York Times. The architect I.M. Pei, creator of the East Building of the National Gallery in Washington, the New York City Convention and Exhibition Center and some of the most conspicuous skyscrapers of the last decade, does not normally design relatively modest 325-room, low-rise hotels. But few of the small hotels he would be likely to disdain as unworthy of his time are intended for a hillside 25 miles outside of Peking, and so when the Government of China invited him to design such a building in 1978, he did not say no. He returned to China - where he had been born in 1917 - and began to produce what in short order became the most eagerly awaited piece of architecture in recent Chinese history. The building is called Xiangshan (meaning ''Fragrant Hill'') Hotel, and it will not be entirely completed until this spring, when it will serve as a luxury hotel mostly for foreign visitors. Its first wing opened last October, before a gathering of Chinese dignitaries and Americans, including Pei's friend Jacqueline Onassis, at whose behest he had designed the John F. Kennedy Library near Boston. Fragrant Hill resembles neither that building nor the National Gallery, nor any of Pei's other well-known works; it is no exaggeration to say that it is a mix of Chinese and Western architectures the likes of which have never been seen in China or anywhere else. t is too soon for a formal critical evaluation of Fragrant Hill, which is impossible in any event without a visit to the building, which this critic has yet to make.

title: TV: 'MALIBU,' FOUR HOURS, TWO PARTS
description: Start with Kim Novak, George Hamilton, James Coburn, Eva Marie Saint, Valerie Perrine, Anthony Newley, Troy Donahue and some lesser personalities. Add chunks of love affairs, financial finagling and television careerism. Garnish generously with beauteous bodies on beach and in boudoir. And there you have ''Malibu,'' the four-hour television movie showing in two two-hour parts on Channel 7 at 9 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: CONVERSION IS NO SIGN OF A TRUCE
description: A building may have survived conversion and officially become a c ooperative, but that does not mean the battles are over. The old o wner, or sponsor, and residents may continue to find themselves i mmersed in conflict.

title: ALBANY, AWAITING THE BUDGET, BARELY BUDGES
description: A nervous quiet has descended on the State Capitol as the Legislature awaits the release of the new budget Feb. 1.

title: ''Second Nature V'' by Paul Eluard
description: In honour of the dumb the blind the deaf Shouldering the great black stone The things of time passing simply away

title: POlicing The Police
description: Several big cities have in recent years reined in their police department's intelligence-gathering squads. But the Los Angeles Police Department's Public Disorder Intelligence Division has been something of a throwback.

title: FAILED MUTINY IS REPORTED IN TANZANIA
description: A small-scale army mutiny in northern Tanzania this month underlined that nation's economic malaise but apparently failed to dent President Julius K. Nyerere's grasp on the country.

title: TRIESTE: BETWEEN THE TWO EUROPES
description: WILLIAM WEAVER is the author of several books on Italian opera, including ''The Golden Century of Italian Opera'' (Thames and Hudson). He lives in Tuscany.

title: HOLDING ON TO WHAT YOU'VE GOT
description: CROSS SECTIONS From a Decade of Change. By Elizabeth Janeway. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.95.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am going to Italy during Easter vacation this spring with my high school Italian class, and I would like to know if there are any open-air food or flea markets in Rome and Venice at that time of year. - S.M., Woodbury, N.Y. Answer:Rome's big flea market is situated at Porta Portese, on the Trastevere side of the Aventino bridge over the Tiber River. The market is open every day of the week and all kinds of goods are available, from automobile parts to the small objects, frequently called collectibles, that are found in flea markets in the United States. Sunday is the biggest day of the week at Porta Portese, with many people coming in from the countryside to sell goods.

title: BENEFACTOR SEEKING A 'LIVE MONUMENT'
description: Joseph S. Gruss arrived here in 1939 from Poland, a 37-year-old banker who had been wise enough to establish a travel bureau in New York. At a time when few Jews in Poland were allowed to leave the country, the bureau gave Mr. Gruss a valid business reason to travel.

title: 'Longest War'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITHER THE AMERICAN SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM?
description: To the Editor:

title: RE-IMAGINED IN ENGLISH
description: THE RANDOM HOUSE BOOK OF TWENTIETH-CENTURY FRENCH POETRY, Edited by Paul Auster. 635 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Prosecution Rests Case Against Federal Judge
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the bribery conspiracy trial of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings, the first sitting Federal judge to be accused of committing a crime.

title: Army Job Bias
description: As an employer, the Army concedes that it discriminates. Because of the nature of its work, it says, it cannot hire homosexuals.

title: BEYOND SCHOOLWORK
description: LEBERT LESTER, 15 years old, lives in the impoverished North End of Hartford. Every Tuesday night, he is part of a noisy crowd of some 200 children and teen-agers who congregate in a parking lot on Main Street. Lebert and his companions huddle in front of the locked doors of a dilapidated brick building.

title: A DANCE TROUPE REBOUNDS
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem is back in town, opening at City Center on Tuesday for a five-week season. It is likely that no congratulatory telegram this season will have quite the ring of pointed truth of one the company received last year from Tennessee Williams. The occasion was its first New York performance of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' a ballet inspired by Mr. Williams's play. The telegram said ''Success and all of that, but remember the road to success is paved with mad ideas.''

title: EX-FREEDOM RIDER SUES U.S. '61 INJURIES
description: A former Freedom Rider is seeking $100,000 in damages for injuries he suffered in a major civil-rights conflict more than 20 years ago. The case concerns James Peck of Manhattan, who sued the Federal Government, contending that the Federal Bureau of Investigation could have prevented the Ku Klux Klan from attacking him and other Freedom Riders in May 1961 at a bus terminal in Birmingham, Ala.

title: FLEXIBILITY HELD KEY TO STRENGTH OF THE ECONOMY
description: WEST ORANGE A business analyst whose specialty is teaching people to use change to their advantage told New Jersey businessmen and executives here last week that they could outwit the genie who was causing the economy to behave so perversely if they learned to play its game.

title: PLIGHT OF THE GRAY DIVORCEE
description: Women who have been homemakers for a lifetime, who have had no business experience, may also be very inexperienced bargainers when it comes time to divorce (''Plight of the Gray Divorcee,'' by Barbara S. Cain, Dec. 19).

title: Job Problem Called Worse Than Reported
description: The unemployment problem is far greater than publicized by the government because of people like me. While I sympathize with Lorraine Morgan (''Adding Insult to Economic Injury,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 2), I can go her one better toward showing the inequity of the ''system.''

title: MIDWIVES' USE NOW COVERED BY INSURANCE
description: Several years ago a midwife delivered the baby of a constituent of a New York City member of the State Assembly. ''She was very excited about the experience,'' the Assemblyman, Richard N. Gottfried, recalled, ''but very annoyed that her insurance policy didn't cover the birth.''

title: Funny Business On the Force
description: When the Knapp Commission set out to cull bad apples from the New York Police Department 10 years ago, it found them by the bushel. Federal investigators who revealed a new corruption inquiry last week said they didn't expect their haul to match Knapp's hundreds, but it appeared they might come up with a baker's dozen or two.

title: LETTERS
description: Development And the Pine Barrens

title: VIETNAM'S 10 YEARS OF 'PEACE'
description: Ten years ago today, Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho met in a French Communist Party villa in Gif-sur-Yvette, a Parisian suburb, to initial the ''Agreement on Ending the War and Restoring Peace in Vietnam.'' Four days later, the Secretary of State and the Foreign Ministers of North Vietnam and South Vietnam signed the document at a ceremony in Paris, and on March 27, 1973, the last uniformed American soldier left Vietnamese territory, ending more than a decade of direct American military involvement there.

title: PROTESTANT WINS FORDHAM BIAS SUIT
description: An associate professor who charged that Fordham University had denied him tenure because he is a Protestant has won a settlement from the school.

title: V.A. Loan Availability
description: Question: My spouse and I have a combined gross annual income of $70,000 and are entitled to a Veterans Administration home loan. How do we find a lending institution that makes such loans, and what is the maximum amount we can borrow? ... C.E.R., Manhattan. Answer: The ''V.A. loan'' is not a loan, but a mortgage guaranty to a lender. The V.A. will guarantee 60 percent of the mortgage up to $27,500. Lending institutions use different formulas for determining the size of a loan, taking into consideration such factors as your gross monthly income, your credit rating and other debts. Try your bank or ask it to recommend a lender; you also can check the Yellow Pages under mortgages. The V.A. cannot recommend banks, but has counselors to answer questions; go to the regional office, 252 Seventh Avenue, or call 620-6442.

title: DOUBLE BARRELED JUSTICE UPHELD
description: While many states mete out harsher punishment for crimes committed with firearms than for similar violations without arms, criminals in Missouri have been getting one sentence for doing wrong and a separate sentence for doing it at gunpoint. Some, including the Missouri Supreme Court, thought this was one jeopardy too many.

title: 2 'BAD PASSES' HALT HOGEBOOM
description: Gary Hogeboom might be an answer to a trivia quiz, as in, ''Who is Gary Hogeboom?'' Professional football people have known who he is, though until today few have known how good he is. But here, though the Redskins beat his Dallas Cowboys, 31-17, in the National Conference championship game, Hogeboom proved he can play quarterback in the National Football League.

title: Cyanide Threat Disrupts Louisiana Water Systems
description: This small city and the nearby community of Delcambre shut down their water systems today and began flushing them because of anonymous telephone threats that cyanide had been dumped into the water.

title: Dear Mrs. SORT
description: We have no wish to be mean-spirited, Mrs. SORT. We applaud the Postal Service for running a surplus last year and, furthermore, you may share our impression that the mail seems to be moving faster.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Seattle SuperSonics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:40 P.M. The last time the Nets played the Sonics (Nov. 21) they broke Seattle's 12-game winning streak, 111-91. (Television -Sports@Channel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620 7:30 P.M. Indiana Pacers vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN 10:30 P.M.).

title: A MOMENT OF TRIUMPH; NORTH S 6 5 4 H J 9 8 5 2 D K 6 C 4 3 2
description: WEST EAST S A 3 2 S 7 H 7 4 3 H K Q 10 6 D 7 2 D J 10 9 8 5 4 3 C K J 9 8 7 C 5 SOUTH(D) S K Q J 10 9 8 H A D A Q C A Q 10 6 North and South were vulnerable. The bidding: South West North East 2C Dbl. Pass 2D 4S Pass Pass Pass

title: Offense
description: 85 WESLEY WALKER: Wide receiver, 6 feet, 179 pounds, 27 years old, 6th season. Had 39 receptions for 620 yards in regular season, 15 for 314 in playoffs. Is playing at peak and has outstanding record against Miami. 72 CHRIS WARD: Left tackle, 6-3, 270, 27, 5th. Burly run-blocker whose emotions in past often led to penalties. Has learned to passprotect. 70 STAN WALDEMORE: Left guard, 6-4, 267, 27, 5th. Very strong, avoids penalties. 65 JOE FIELDS: Center, 6-2, 253, 29, 8th. Pro Bowl player; spirit of offensive line. 60 DAN ALEXANDER: Right guard, 6-4, 260, 27, 6th. Durable; highly regarded by opposing coaches. 79 MARVIN POWELL: Right tackle, 6-5, 268, 27, 6th. Perennial all-pro who halts pass-rushers and blocks effectively for runners. 83 JEROME BARKUM: Tight end, 6-4, 227, 32, 11th. 19 catches for 182 yards in regular season, 2 for 20 in playoffs. Senior Jet, good hands. Used in clutch situations. 80 JOHNNY (LAM) JONES: Wide receiver, 5-11, 183, 24, 3d. 18 catches for 294 yards in regular season, 4 for 74 in playoffs. A threat because of speed. Has learned to hold on to ball. 14 RICHARD TODD: Quarterback, 6-2, 207, 29, 7th.

title: Boston College Settles Score
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing with regard to a statement about Boston College's freshman admissions that appeared recently (''New Academic Standard: Is It Fair, Will It Work?'' The New York Times, Jan. 16).

title:
GARDENING;
THE TIME TO CORRECT GARDEN DEFICIENCIES
description: PLANTS are the key to the survival of life on earth. Green plants capture the energy of the sun through the process of photosynthesis. That captured energy not only provides sustenance for the plants, but is the source of energy, food and much of the shelter for animal life, including man.

title:
THEATER;
THE STORY OF A WARTIME HEROINE COMES TO THE STAGE
description: Hannah Senesh has been called the Joan of Arc of Israel. As a young girl in Budapest on the eve of World War II, she obeyed an inner voice which told her to leave her comfortable home and go to build Israel. She was safe there when Jews were dying by the millions in the death camps, but her inner voice told her she must return to Budapest to help rescue her people. Like Joan, she went into battle wearing men's clothing. Hannah wore a paratrooper's outfit when she floated out of the skies above Yugoslavia in the spring of 1944 on a daredevil mission. She was captured and tortured, but would not betray her secrets. She was 23 when she was executed by a firing squad in the courtyard of a Budapest prison on Nov. 7, 1944.

title: LOCAL DISPUTES WITH FOREIGN MISSIONS CALL FOR DIPLOMACY
description: A North Korean diplomat named Nam Chol O sits in his country's Mission to the United Nations on East 80th Street in Manhattan, spared by diplomatic immunity from facing an indictment in a September attack on a Westchester woman. Glen Cove, L.I., ruffled by reports Russian diplomats are spying from their tax-free mansion, takes away their beach cards. And now this city of 25,000 is trying to keep a Libyan diplomat from moving in by denying a tax exemption on a newly purchased $1 million home and preparing to go to Federal court to block the sale.

title: Contreras Is Winner
description: Toby Contreras, who in three previous events had never finished higher than 98th, captured a $135,000 Professional Bowlers Association event today with a 221-212 triumph over Charlie Tapp in the final. Contreras, 25 years old, of Kansas City, Mo., earned $23,000. Tapp, who won $12,000, has appeared in a final round 10 times and hasnever won.

title: EXECUTIVE RACE STARTS IN EARNEST
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo, immersed in Albany budget talks, could not make it to the county last week when he endorsed Anthony Veteran, the Greenburgh Supervisor, for County Executive, but that did not seem to matter much. Mr. Veteran tends to fill a room himself, and he did so easily as the 1983 race for the county's top post got under way.

title: Soviet Asserts Britain Risked Nuclear Mishap in Falklands
description: The Soviet Union accused Britain today of risking a nuclear disaster during its war with Argentina to recapture the Falkland Islands.

title: LIFE ON THE LAM
description: IRONWEED, By William Kennedy. 227 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75.

title: FREE RIDES ON THE WAY OUT
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN moved last week to end a privilege enjoyed by a growing number of state officials and employees at the expense of taxpayers: free railroad passes.

title: SALLY M. SANDBERG PLANNING TO WED CLEMENT WOOD 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Robert Kopp of Winnetka, Ill, and North Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Sally M. Sandberg, to Clement B. Wood, 3d, son of Mr. Wood of Spetsai, Greece, and Water Mill, L.I., and Mrs. C. Daggett Harvey of Chicago.

title: Clam Boat Is Lost Off Jersey; Search for 3 on Board Halted
description: A clamming boat disappeared off the South Jersey Coast Friday and the Coast Guard today abandoned its search for the three men aboard.

title: DEath With A Vengeance
description: In 1967, two masked men fired sawed-off shotguns at Allen M. Dorfman and missed. Last week, in a hotel parking lot in one of Chicago's northern suburbs, Mr. Dorfman's luck ran out.

title: THE MACDOWELL COLONY, WITH GHOSTS
description: THIS year marks the 75th anniversary of the MacDowell Colony, and I long to know what Edwin Arlington Robinson has to say about it. I've worked in Veltin, the MacDowell studio in which Robinson spent 24 summers; every morning before I entered the studio in which Edwin Arlington Robinson wrote his poetry I paused to read a bronze plaque sunk into the stone facade: ''I shall have more to say when I am dead. - E.A.R.'' Every morning I implored Mr. Robinson to keep it on ice till I was well out of the New Hampshire woods.

title: FEAR OF INTERFACING
description: Just like you, I too was once afraid of computers. What a silly fear it was. With a few hours of study, I have grasped the essential simplicity underlying the operation of these delightful machines and look forward to spending many happy years with my home computer as soon as I can afford one. To help others enjoy this pleasure, let me show how easily the computer can be mastered.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY DEBORAH HART
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Edward Hart Jr. of New York and Aiken, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Hart, to Nigel John Ballard of New York, son of Wing Comdr. Dennis Alexander Ballard, Royal Air Force, retired, and Mrs. Ballard of Melbourne, Australia.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE VISIGOTHS' LEGACY: SALAD BARS
description: LONG ago, before there were dishes such as sauteed mushrooms, prime ribs and chilled carafes of house wine, hordes of ravenous barbarians, known as Visigoths, lunged through Europe in search of a good, filling meal.

title: Hayes Sets Record
description: No player has spent more time running up and down National Basketball Association courts than Elvin Hayes. The 6-foot-9 1/2-inch center, now with the Houston Rockets, is 37 years old and in his 15th pro season.

title: AN UPSTART BROKER BATTLES THE S.E.C.
description: TO many prime-time television viewers, Robert E. Brennan is a f amiliar figure. In commercial after commercial, he poses alongside a thoroughbred race horse, or a sleek limousine, touting the virtues o f old-fashioned risk-taking and the brokerage firm he owns, First J ersey Securities Inc. The message is clear: The rewards are s ubstantial for those willing to take a chance with little-known s tocks researched and recommended by First Jersey.

title: REFORM JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: When word leaked out last Thanksgiving weekend that the Administration was thinking of raising taxes on unemployment benefits to increase Federal revenues, the President's liberal critics reacted with the satisfied glee that comes with catching a mortal enemy in flagrante delicto. The Great Communicator, they cried, wasn't just oblivious to the jobless in South Succotash - he wanted to punish them.

title: WEST VIRGINIA TOPS RUTGERS BY 71-63
description: West Virginia, whose 34-game home winning streak was ended by St. Bonaventure last Thursday night, stopped the home winning streak of Rutgers at 14 games with a 71-63 victory in an Atlantic 10 Conference game today.

title: DONALD MADDEN, ACTOR, DEAD AT 49
description: Donald Madden, an actor acclaimed for his classical roles on Broadway and in regional theaters, died yesterday of cancer in Central Islip, L.I. He was 49 years old and was living at the home of his cousin, Christine Brennan, in Central Islip.

title: France Rakes Up A Bitter Past
description: Maurice Papon, once one of France's most prominent civil servants and politicians, discovered last week that the pain of history may subside for a while but never really goes away. After 40 years in high posts, he was indicted in Bordeaux for ''crimes against humanity'' for the part he allegedly played in sending Jewish children to Auschwitz during the Nazi occupation in 1942.

title: DOFF THE HAIR SHIRT; EAT LOW-FAT MEALS
description: NOW that the holidays are well and truly over, it is time once again to think about eating sensibly. This does not mean wearing a hair shirt at the dinner table. But it does mean dispensing with rich, buttery foods and looking to ways of enjoying meals without detriment of health.

title: OFFICIALS THINK THAT PRISON WALLS KEPT DORFMAN'S ACCOMPLICE ALIVE
description: A cadre of lawyers for Allen M. Dorfman, the Chicago insurance executive slain Thursday, struggled mightily to free him on $5 million bail after his conviction last month of conspiracy to bribe a United States Senator.

title: Records Fall at Aqueduct
description: Two stakes records and one track record for the inner track fell in a little more than an hour at Aqueduct yesterday. The stakes standard for a mile and a sixteenth was first broken by Nelson Bunker Hunt's Adept in the first division of the Affectionately Handicap.

title: F.A.A. HEARING SET ON CASINO PROPOSAL
description: ATLANTIC CITY REPRESENTATIVES of the Golden Nugget Hotel-Casino will appear at a Federal Aviation Agency hearing Wednesday in the first of two attempts to have regulations changed so they can build a second casino on an approach to this city.

title: Topics; Rude Greetings; Let History Judge
description: Few Soviet voices are braver, or blunter, than Roy A. Medvedev's. He once wryly remarked, ''If by some miracle, Marx, Engels and Lenin were to appear among us, most of the works they might write ... would not be passed for publication.''

title: DIOXIN'S PERIL TO HUMANS: PROOF IS ELUSIVE
description: The deadly chemical dioxin, an unwanted byproduct of herbicides, pesticides and other industrial products, is raising increasing concern among government agencies, scientific researchers and people who may come in contact with it.

title:
DINING OUT;
OUT OF THE FISH SHOP, INTO THE PAN
description: EXCEPT for some expansion here and there, Westchester Trawler has not changed much over the years. The large dining room beyond the fish shop remains lined with weathered planks and suspended fish netting and scattered with sea shells, life preservers and other artifacts from the rusty-anchor school of fish-restaurant decorating. But under the ownership of four brothers from the Amendola family, certain features have recently been reshaped and refurbished: the facade neatly refinished and a glittery, pin-lighted bar installed and separated from the dining room by white stucco Mediterranean arches.

title: LETTERS
description: Cohalan's Position On Farmland Program

title: SEEKING CLEAN WATER
description: PROPOSED responses to wide and well-documented water contamination on the North Fork are under discussion among local officials. One recommendation, offered by an environmental consulting concern, is that public water systems in the Town of Riverhead and the incorporated Village of Greenport be extended to serve residents whose private wells are threatened or already tainted by agricultural chemicals or salt-water intrusion.

title: LETTERS
description: End to Hollow Promises On Police Is Needed

title: Advertising Hopes
description: To the Business Editor: Andrew Feinberg's article ''A Tough Sell for Madison Avenue'' (Dec. 12), presented evidence that many of the ''giant'' advertising agencies have become prophets of gloom, at least for the immediate future.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN THE last two years, Federal budget cuts have shifted responsibility for many social programs to state governments, which are themselves financially hard-pressed, and to the private sector.

title: Warsaw Newspaper Says Price Rises Are Planned
description: The Polish authorities are planning 15 percent price increases on gas, electricity, coal, cigarettes, coffee and some kinds of fish, the newspaper Zycie Warszawy said today.

title: WITH INFLATION DOWN SHARPLY, INDUSTRIAL NATIONS ARE CASTING ABOUT FOR ; WAYS TO GROW
description: PARIS WHEN Beryl Sprinkel, the Under Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, urged industrial nations toward ''credible economic expansion'' at a meeting of finance ministers in Paris last week, European financial leaders thought the economist was signaling a change in the Reagan Administration's fiscal policies, from a preoccupation with inflation to a drive for growth.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE COUNTRY LOOK
description: SIXTY exhibitors from Connecticut and nearby states will gather next weekend to exhibit an eclectic variety of furniture and decorations at the third annual Country Antiques Show.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER'S DEFORMED BABY REJECTED
description: The surrogate mother of a deformed baby says she plans to put the boy up for adoption because the man she contends is the father has also rejected him. The baby was born Jan. 10 and remains in the hospital without a name.

title: Italians Bar Release Of Bulgarian Suspect
description: An Italian investigating magistrate today rejected a request for the release of Sergei Ivanov Antonov, a Bulgarian detained for suspected complicity in the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II in 1981, officials of the Italian Justice Ministry said.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT NUGGETS
description: Ed Sherod scored the final 4 points, including two free throws with nine seconds to play, to give the Knicks a 102-98 victory over the Denver Nuggets tonight.

title: A GUARD LEADER CRITICIZES PRISONS
description: IN the wake of the uprising at the Ossining Correctional Facility earlier this month that focused attention on prison conditions for inmates, the president of the Minority Corrections Officers Association last week criticized conditions for guards at state correctional facilities.

title: LETTERS
description: Local History And the Young

title: NEARING COMPLETE RENOVATION OF INTERIOR DEPARTMENT RULES
description: While Interior Secretary James G. Watt continues to make waves - and enjoy it - with his provocative public statements, his major activity this year and next is likely to be a quiet, behind-the-scenes drive to institutionalize his effort to reverse the direction of Federal land and resource policies.

title: GEORGE WALLACE PICKS UP ON A DIFFERENT NOTE
description: GEORGE C. WALLACE last week became the first man to be sworn in for a fourth term as Governor of Alabama, but stranger things have happened. One of them was that Mr. Wallace won with surprisingly strong support from black voters.

title: Scott Wins 3:56.29 Mile From Flynn in Stretch
description: Steve Scott of the United States ran a 3:56.29 mile today and beat Ray Flynn of Ireland in the feature event at the final meet of the 1983 New Zealand international track series.

title: STATE TO FIGHT U.S. REJECTION OF CLEANUP OF HUDSON PCB'S
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation is seeking to overturn a Federal rejection of its $27.6 million plan to clean the upper Hudson River by dredging PCB-contaminated sediment and burying it.

title: JETS STIRRING HIGH EXCITEMENT IN MIAMI
description: In a game that appears to rival some Super Bowls for attention, the New York Jets and the Miami Dolphins meet Sunday for the American Football Conference championship.

title: 'SWEET PEA,' ITALIAN COMEDY
description: Peter Del Monte's ''Sweet Pea'' (''Piso Pisello'') is a sweet, mostly inoffensive Italian comedy based on a single joke that it pursues with the doggedness of a stand-up comic who stays on too long.

title: WILLIAM L. HANAWAY
description: William Lippincott Hanaway, a partner in the New York law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan for 33 years until his retirement in 1970, died Jan. 13 at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center of complications after a stroke. He was 84 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: NONFICTION
description: 1 2 53 JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical well-being. 2 3 11 MEGATRENDS, by John Naisbitt. (Warner, $15.50.) Predictions about America in the next decade based on an analysis of conditions today. 3 1 14 AND MORE BY ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum, $12.95.) A new collection of essays by the journalist and television commentator. 4 6 50 WHEN BAD THINGS HAPPEN TO GOOD PEOPLE, by Harold S. Kushner. (Schocken, $10.95.) Comforting thoughts from a rabbi. 5 10 17 THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Morrow, $15.) How to increase the productivity of those with whom you work as well as your own. 6 4 40 LIVING, LOVING & LEARNING, by Leo Buscaglia. (Holt/Slack, $13.50.) Inspirational talks by a University of Southern California professor. 7 8 2 IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert Waterman. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) Lessons to be learned from well-run American corporations.

title: IT'S OLD HOME WEEK FOR STATE MUSICIANS
description: WHEN the Port Chester Council for the Arts begins its ambitious new Sunday afternoon series at 4 this afternoon, in the Summerfield Methodist Church on King Street in the Westchester County community, it will be like old home week for Connecticut musicians. Concert master of the 13-member professional orchestra is Asya Meshberg of Norwalk. The solo flutist, Jean Whiton, and the music director, Joseph Leniado-Chira, both live in Greenwich.

title: HOW AN AMERICAN SCULPTOR FOUND HER TRUE METIER
description: When she died of a brain tumor in 1970 at the age of 34, Eva Hesse had already proved herself a sculptor of considerable power, and her use of new ''soft'' materials, along with the humor, eroticism and body metaphor expressed in her work, has affected a whole generation of artists, with a particularly liberating impact on women.

title: 271.2 Million in Soviet
description: The population of the Soviet Union was 271.2 million on Jan. 1, the Government's Central Statistical Board announced today. The figure shows that the Soviet population increased by 2.4 million in 1982, one of the lowest growth rates since World War II.

title: DISKS PAY HOMAGE TO GRIFFES'S MUSIC
description: The laudable effort by American musical historians to rediscover our own art-music tradition has led to some remarkable exhumations, above all Charles Ives. But any nationalistically motivated search through the past can lead to the undue exaltation of dross, too. So it is a pleasure to report that the musical community and the record companies have turned their attentions to a genuinely worthy American composer, Charles Tomlinson Griffes.

title: RAISING KIDS-THE DAIRY KIND
description: The first thing you have to get used to when talking to Mason and Peter Cable is that when they talk fondly about their kids, they are not speaking colloqually. The kids -wide-eyed and friendly - are the youngest occupants of a small building that serves as the Cables' goat dairy.

title: WOMEN ARE BREAKING THE SYMPHONIC BARRIERS
description: Gynephobia, a dread disease that once was rampant in the world's symphony orchestras, is no longer common among the educated classes in this country. Vaccines, available in most urban centers, have been found to counteract it. However, fear of women still is endemic in many of the great European orchestras, including those in such relatively enlightened places as Vienna and London. That is why it came as such a surprise last year when the Berlin Philharmonic admitted a woman to membership for the first time in its 100-year history. The pioneer was Madeleine Carruzzo, a 26-year-old violinist who auditioned d won out over 12 males. But then just the other day, as if shocked by their own audacity, the Berliners threatened to strike in protest against the decision by their music director, Herbert von Karajan, to bring a second female into the orchestra, this time a clarinetist.

title: U.S. CHECKING NUCLEAR PLANTS ON FAULTY PARTS
description: The Government has begun investigating whether nuclear plants throughout the country are using substandard steel components that were sold to them fraudulently marked, according to Government documents and officials.

title: DEBORAH S. ROSS TO WED IN MARCH
description: Deborah Starr Ross, an accountant with the Commercial Credit Corporation in Baltimore, and Richard Jackson Chambliss Jr., an electrical engineer for the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company, plan to be married March 12.

title: Historian on Notice
description: History, as Roy A. Medvedev sees it, isn't their story, as Soviet leaders see it.

title: Helping Hands In Stamford
description: Our thanks to you, and to reporter Andree Brooks, for giving credit in the article ''Companies Offer Help on Housing'' (Dec. 26) to the role Stamford corporations and banks are playing in providing financial support for the moderate-cost housing programs of this community's New Neighborhoods Inc.

title: Bum Phillips's View
description: In Mobile, Ala., while preparing the South squad for yesterday's annual Senior Bowl football game, Coach Bum Phillips of the New Orleans Saints disclosed his attitude toward the United States Football League, which begins its first season in March. The new league has signed some college seniors who might have been selected in April's National Football League draft.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
ADULTS: KIDS' NO. 1 PROBLEM
description: ''WHAT'S wrong with kids today?'' You hear that question wherever you go, from P.T.A. conferences to cocktail parties. As a teacher, I have a somewhat unusual answer: Nothing.If you substituted tomato paste for baking powder and vegetable soup for eggs in baking a cake, you would have little reason to be outraged, or even surprised, when you produced a vile-tasting, red pancake. You certainly wouldn't berate the cake manque for not living up to the picture in the cookbook.

title: AT SKI AREAS, SNOW NEWS IS GOOD NEWS
description: NEW JERSEY homeowners may have been pleased with the relatively mild winter - and low fuel bills - that lingered until mid-January, but the state's ski-resort operators saw the unseasonable weather in terms of layoffs and low returns.

title: Ocean Yacht Racing Changes
description: One of the largest Grand Prix fleets in recent years, at least 90 boats, is gathering in St. Petersburg, Fla., for the six-race Southern Ocean Racing Conference, considered the national championship of Grand prix yacht racing. Preliminary races will be held next weekend with the conference starting Feb. 6 in St. Petersburg and winding up Feb. 25 in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: PEGGY B. JACKSON BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Jackson of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Peggy B. Jackson, to Todd D. Hallinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Hallinger of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 'IF HE WERE ALIVE TODAY, WAGNER WOULD USE TV'
TOBI A. GRUSZECKI TO MARRY R.S. WEITZNER, EXECUTIVE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gruszecki of Roslyn Heights, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Tobi Ann Gruszecki, to Robert S. Weitzner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Weitzner of Old Brookville, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: A STUDY OF STUDIOS
description: IMAGINATION'S CHAMBER Artists and Their Studios. By Michael Peppiatt and Alice Bellony-Rewald. Illustrated. 232 pp. Boston: New York Graphic Society/Little, Brown & Co. $45.

title: Ushering In The Year 4681
description: Anyone already in the mood for another New Year's celebration need not wait 11 months. There's a new year beginning next month, when the Chinese year 4681 is ushered in under a system of chronology dating back to 27 B.C.

title: 'LONGEST WAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: ALASKANS URGING FOREIGN OIL SALES
description: A study by an Alaska state commission, strongly critical of the Federal Government, will be formally delivered to the Governor tomorrowin Juneau and to the Legislature Tuesday.

title: CITY RENEWING ITS PLEA FOR TOUGHER CRIMINAL LAWS
description: The Koch administration will again seek tougher state criminal laws - including a mandatory five-year addition to all prison sentences for felonies committed with a gun - from the Legislature.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: THE PLIGHT OF THE GRAY DIVORCEE
description: As a New York attorney, whose practice is devoted exclusively to family law, I would like to offer some comments on Barbara Cain's article. New York State recently enacted-equitable distribution legislation (July 19, 1980). One of the purposes of this legislation was to command recognition that marriage is a partnership of coequals and, upon marital dissolution, there should be equitable distribution of all family assets accumulated during the marriage, with maintenance payments premised upon the economic basis of reasonable need and the ability to pay. While maintenance payments can be limited in amount and duration, they can, where appropriate, be ordered on a permanent basis. This can be done when a spouse has been out of the labor market and lacks sufficient resources or when a spouse has sacrificed her business or professional career to serve as a parent or homemaker. Equitable distribution, as enacted in New York, directs a judge to take into account the contributions of a homemaker spouse.

title: SECRETARY'S WINS AND LOSSES
description: IN his first two years in office, James G. Watt probably proposed as many significant changes in the Federal government's land and resource policies as any Interior Secretary in history. Here are some of his proposals and their fate:

title: A TOWN GETS RID OF 2-4-5T
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP A hazardous-waste disposal company picked up two corroded drums here last week, thus ending a long official search and a lot of unofficial uneasiness.

title: THINGS TO COME: SPRING '83
description: IT'S not only love that makes it ''June in January.'' In the cockeyed world of books, the new spring catalogues have just arrived. Covering titles coming out between snowfall and sunburn, they promise possibly lasting and - when compared to other entertainments - relatively inexpensive pleasures. These include prose and poetry from old pros and neophytes; coffeetable books; more than the usual number on how to cope (especially with the recession and nuclear peril); memoirs of statesmen and fallen movie idols; investigatory wonders; and of course more from the richest feline in history, Garfield, plus (while Rome burns and acid rain falls) a book called ''What to Name the Cat.'' *

title: Flooding in Leningrad
description: Large areas of Leningrad were flooded overnight as a storm in the Gulf of Finland swept water up the Neva River, raising it six feet above its normal level.

title: BUS TERMINAL: REBUILDING IN LAST PHASE
description: ''WE THINK that our patrons deserve more than basic plastic and men's-room tile,'' Peter C. Goldmark Jr. said of the big building with the red, cross-hatched steel beams on the outside.

title: WHEN BAD ACTING IS BAD-AND GOOD
description: MONTCLAIR THE paradox of Anton Chekov's plays can be perceived on paper. On stage, it rarely comes alive. Despairing, bored, wasted, doomed characters sit around and mope, erupting into fits of emotional excess and then returning to languor.

title: WOMAN SHOT BY ROBBERS ON L.I.
description: A 19-year-old Long Island woman was shot in the head and critically wounded when she was held up at the wheel of her car early yesterday in Suffolk County by a man she and three friends had met to buy marijuana, the police reported.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dick Vermeil, who resigned as coach of the Philadelphia Eagles at the end of the regular season, saying that he was ''burned out,'' has signed to become an analyst for National Football League broadcasts with CBS-TV, beginning next season. ... Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers all-star guard, missed practice yesterday while undergoing treatment on a strained right arch suffered in Friday's victory over San Antonio. But X-rays showed no broken bones, and the team said a decision would be made before the game on whether Johnson could play against the Indiana Pacers at the Forum tonight. ... Bill Walsh, the head coach and general manager of the San Francisco 49ers, is scheduled to meet Monday with the team's owner, Edward DeBartolo Jr., to discuss again Walsh's future as the team's coach.

title:
OPINION;
ARE WE ON THE RIGHT TRACK?
description: ONE toothless comb ... the rinds of an orange ... a plastic hanger ... 23 beer and soda cans ... two windblown umbrellas ... a shirt ... a glove ... an empty bottle of gin. All lie carelessly strewn on the westbound tracks of the Long Island Rail Road station at Great Neck. The glitter of broken glass draws my eye toward the debris below. But a train soon arrives to cover the evidence. What, I wonder, will future archelogists make of us, judging from such dismal discards of our civilization?

title: 'NINE' COMPOSER FOLLOWS TRADITION
description: MAURY YESTON, a professor of music at Yale University and the composer of the music and lyrics for the Broadway musical ''Nine,'' says that most musicals develop from ''an awful idea.''

title: PHILOSOPHICAL PAINT
description: THIS IS NOT A PIPE, By Michel Foucault. With illustrations and letters by Rene Magritte. Translated, with an introduction, by James Harkness. 66 pp. Berkeley: Quantum Books. University of California Press. $14.95.

title: BOSTON'S NONSTOP TEA PARTY
description: LINDA CHARLTON is a writer who lives in Canaan, N.Y.

title: Analysis: The Knicks and The Nets Halfway Through the Season; NETS: MOVING TOWARD THE TOP OF THE LEAGUE
description: string center, will soon be 31 years old. Just one teammate, Foots Walker, is older. None of the Nets has been a pro basketball player longer than Elmore, who is in his ninth season.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: Mount Laurel Revisited
description: In the years since the New Jersey Supreme Court struck down exclusionary zoning in Mount Laurel Township, and by extension communities like it throughout the state, it has become apparent that landmark rulings do not always change the lay of the land. So last week the state's highest court handed down Mount Laurel II.

title: DR. ALLEN TO WED SUSAN A HEUCK
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Heuck of Cincinnatio have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Arnold Heuck, to Dr. Peter Sutton Allen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeremiah M. Allen Jr. of Amherst, Mass. The wedding is planned for April.

title:
OPINION;
UNDERNEATH IT ALL
description: ONE cold morning, I put on a thermal undershirt for the first time. When I finished dressing, I noticed that the shirt sleeves were longer than my blouse sleeves and that the shirt showed in my neckline. It reminded me of another time.

title: OLSON LOOKS TO 19-FOOT VAULT
description: After breaking his week-old world-best in the pole vault, Billy Olson says he can go higher. ''When I get on a fast runway and get the pole I want, 19 feet will come,'' he said after having soared 18 feet 11 inches at the Sunkist Invitational Friday night.

title: No Headline
description: Canadian Captures Downhill

title: WHITHER THE AMERICAN SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM?
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT LUDEMANN TO WED ALICIA E. LEVITSKY, A NURSE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Levitsky of Oakland Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alicia E. Levitsky, to Robert A. Ludemann, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Ludemann of of Patterson, N.Y.

title: SAN FRANSISCO BALLET IS THRIVING AT 50
description: ''In the confused and consistently shifting ballet picture in America today, the San Francisco Ballet is a telling example of what admirable results can be achieved in a modest frame with personal and artistic integrity and singleness of purpose and direction.'' With the exception of ''modest frame,'' this appreciation fits the San Francisco Ballet as tightly today as when it was first published. This was in 1949, in ''Ballet, the Emergence of an American Art,'' an enduring survey of American ballet by George Amberg, then Theater Arts Consultant at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Hoggish on the Redskins
description: JOHN RIGGINS was elected a member of the fraternity of Hogs early this season when he showed he was not afraid to grovel in the earth with his offensive linemen.

title: JUNE WEDDING PLANNED BY REBECCA J. BEAUDRY
description: The engagement of Rebecca Joan Beaudry to Clinton Spurr Marshall has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Beaudry of Biddeford Pool, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Marshall Jr. of Irvington, N.Y., and Biddeford Pool.

title: PROSPECTS FOR MORE SCHOOL AID UNCERTAIN
description: ALBANY THE annual skirmish over state education aid is taking place on a battlefield of budget deficits and fiscal austerity that could produce little new money for Long Island school districts. The budget problem, which Governor Cuomo has called the worst in the state's history, will also influence debate over the ''Robin Hood'' question - should the state take aid away from wealthy districts and give it to relatively poor school districts?

title: BARRIERS IN ROAD DEBATED
description: AN array of black and yellow ''dead end'' signs confronts southbound motorists on Grand Avenue in South Farmingdale. The drivers then notice the squat metal barrier driven into the asphalt to block their way out of the Allen Boulevard Industrial Park.

title: THE GROUPS THAT STIFLE GROWTH
description: The Rise and Decline of Nations: Economic Growth, Stagflation, and Social Rigidities, by Mancur Olson. Yale University Press, New Haven, Conn. 273 pages, $14.95.

title: 3 MAJOR TV NETWORKS ASKING SYNDICATION RIGHTS ON SHOWS
description: The three major television networks will formally ask the Federal Communications Commission this week to permit them to sell television programs to individual stations after the programs are run on their networks.

title: DEFENSE: THE COUNTRY'S 'QUIET' BUSINESS
description: DEFENSE contracts generated more than $150 million in sales last year for an estimated 160 businesses in the county, and officials concerned with promoting Westchester's economic growth say that amount could have important implications for marketing the county as an excellent site for businesses.

title: 'LEFT OF BALLET, RIGHT OF MODERN'
description: IT'S been about five years since Lynne Taylor-Corbett hung up her dancing shoes and began concentrating full time on choreography. And much to her surprise, the young choreographer - whose works have entered into the repertory of the American Ballet Theater (''Diary'' will be performed Saturday, when American Ballet Theater II appears in Freeport) - doesn't miss performing at all.

title: DISCOVERING THE BEETHOVEN INSIDE THE MONUMENT
description: If Ludwig van Beethoven was, as Wagner said, a ''titan wrestling with the gods,'' he obviously won the bout. He has become a figure of Olympian stature. Nearly every composer of the 19th-century wrote in his shadow and none doubted his supremacy. Today, his stern glance, defiant chin and unkempt hair grace bookshelves, record covers and piano cabinetry. His music practically defines the purpose of the symphony orchestra. Beethoven is not just an ordinary composer of great achievement. He is an icon -heroic, revolutionary, inspired.

title: A COUNSELOR FOR THOSE MOVING OVERSEAS
description: ALTHOUGH Barbara Harris has never been overseas, after 10 years of e xperience in the real-estate business she saw a growing need for i nternational corporate-relocation services. Nearly a year ago, she s tarted Metropolitan Relocation Consultants in Somerville to fill theg ap.

title: 3 Assert Justice System In Salvador Is Negligent
description: More than two years after four American churchwomen were murdered in El Salvador, little has been done to bring the perpetrators to justice, according to three New York lawyers who recently returned from a nine-day inspection tour of the Latin American country.

title: ORCHIDS THRIVE ON A WINDOWSILL WITH LITTLE CARE
A JUST WAGE SCALE FOR FAMILY CHORES
description: ITHOUGHT I was prepared for parenthood. I took all the courses: C hild Development, Psychology of Adolescence, Methods in Spoiling, G uilt for Majors. Unfortunately, none of them addressed the most d ifficult question of all - whether, when and how much to pay the c hildren.

title: THE DELICATE LINK BETWEEN TENANT AND SUBTENANT
description: THREE years ago, a midtown lawyer decided that he was being i llegally overcharged for an apartment he had subleased on Park A venue from a tenant named Syd Krantz. Mr. Krantz was charging $1,500 a month for a one-bedroom apartment on which he himself was paying t he owner $540. So the subtenant, Lenard H. Mandel, started to withhold rent payments. Mr. Krantz brought suit, and the court sent the case to the Conciliation and Appeals Board for a ruling on what the rent should be.

title: SMOOTH MILITARY DRAMA
description: AS a bristling courtroom drama, Herman Wouk's ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,'' derived from his 1950 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Caine Mutiny,'' still works.

title:
OPINION;
FIRE ESCAPES AND STUFF! GEE!
description: IHAVE good news for urban planners: The gentrification of New York City will be completed by the next generation. All our little suburban kids are going back.

title: ARE THESE FEMINISTS TOO HARD ON WOMEN?
description: Naturally, most feminist plays up to now have been written by women. Pretty soon, though, I'm afraid that male playwrights may have to take over. Somebody's got to be more sympathetic to the women on the job. Certainly Caryl Churchill isn't very nice to them in her ''Top Girls,'' which will be available with its original London cast for one more week at the Public (after which an American company will go into rehearsal and, three weeks later, reopen the hard-hearted piece). Miss Churchill is the author of the antically successful ''Cloud 9,'' and, since the opening sequence of this new one scrambles history and a few other things even more cavalierly than ''Cloud 9'' did, you can't tell right off just how kindly or how cold-blooded she means to be tonight.

title: FLYERS' ROOKIE HALTS ISLANDERS
description: Until tonight, Bob Froese had no firsthand experience with the Patrick Division rivalry that has simmered between the Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers for nine seasons.

title: THE UNIVERSE AND DR. HAWKING
description: Michael Harwood is a freelance writer who reports frequently on science and the environment.The theoretical physicist, although he deals in such arcane, modern concepts as curved time and space, is part of a philosophical and spiritual tradition older than recorded history. He seeks to know not just life as he experiences it but how the hidden parts of the universe work and fit together. Ultimately he hopes to learn if and how and why the universe began and if and how and why it will end.

title: WHEN CURATOR'S IMAGINATION COLORS HISTORY
description: Photography's most beguiling characteristic - its ability to make anything and everything look interesting - is also its most problematic insofar as its claims to esthetic significance are concerned. If photographs are inherently fascinating, the argument goes, what does it matter what the photographer's intentions were? Indeed, what does it matter who the photographer was? Either all of photography's issue is art, or none, take your pick. Efforts to resolve this theoretical impasse center around the notion of selectivity: the photographer and his intentions matter because he decides what, from the world's vast cornucopia of appearances, to show us.

title: Charity at Odds
description: When Robert Brinkley Smithers of Mill Neck, L.I., a recovered alcoholic, said in 1971 that he intended to give $10 million to Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan to set up an alcoholic treatment center, he was about to set a record. It was destined to be the largest single grant to fight alcoholism ever made by anyone, including the Federal Government.

title: Mailbox; Faster Boats, More Trouble
description: To the Sports Editor: A recent article in the Boat Show Section about high-speed boats causes me to write. The article (''Buyers Turn to the Lean, Speedy Craft,'' The New York Times, Jan. 16) points out that the new, highpowered and extra-fast speedboats are attracting many buyers.

title: APRIL
description: Announcement has been made by Marguerite M. Ziemer of Buzzards Bay, Mass., of the engagement of her daughter, Carol Ann Ziemer, to Stephen Price Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Colton P. Wagner of East Norwich, L.I.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SILVER AGLITTER IN MONTCLAIR SHOW
description: MONTCLAIR A COLLECTION of 100 pieces of silver made for domestic use from 1641 to the early 19th century will be on view at the Montclair Museum through June 20.

title: AMY DICKINSON TO WED D.S. BECKWITH
description: Mrs. Lanford Barrows of Cincinnati has announced the engagement of her daughter, Amy Bostwick Dickinson, to David Stanly , son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Ruffin Beckwith Jr., of Princeton, N.J.

title: ROLE IN CONGRESS IS STRONGER
description: WASHINGTON CONNECTICUT'S Congressional delegates have gained significant committee assignments in the new Congress, greatly bolstering the stature of a small and relatively junior delegation. ''I think the new delegation looks great,'' said Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Fairfield and the senior member of the group.

title: CHERYL SOLOMON AFFIANCED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Solomon of Hicksville, L. I. of the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Robin Solomon, to Todd Glenn Pollack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pollack of Monroe, N. Y.

title: CO-OP AGREES TO PLAN INCREASING MINORITY RESIDENTS
description: A large state-aided, middle-income housing cooperative in Brooklyn whose residents are nearly all white has agreed to a plan for increasing the number of black and Hispanic families in the development as vacancies occur.

title: Endangered Chimps in the Lab
description: In reference to Eugene Linden's article ''Endangered Chimps in the Lab'' (Dec. 19), it seems that our Federally subsidized institutions are at it again.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Travel Books the Teamwork Way Publishers and booksellers push diet and tax books at this time of year, because in theory everyone's eager to be sensible about food and money after the excesses of the holiday season. But since most of us have a constant desire for special treats, they're also promoting new and updated travel titles that list enticing places to go and exciting things to do.
To the Editor:

title: KAREN MOLOZNIK PLANS A SEPTEMBER WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Moloznik of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen L. Moloznik, to Kevin P. Norton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Norton of Englewood, N.J.

title: ISRAEL PUTTING SEVERE CURBS ON CIGARETTE ADS
description: Israel, a nation of four million people in which smoking-related illnesses kill about 3,000 people a year, has decided to impose tight restrictions on cigarette advertising.

title: Tunisia Is Holding 45 As Islamic Extremists
description: The Tunisian authorities have arrested 45 people suspected of membership in extremist Islamic groups, the newspaper Le Temps said today.

title: RUSSIAN CRAFT HITS UPPER ATMOSPHERE
description: The four-ton hulk of the Soviet satellite Cosmos 1402 nosed into the rarefied upper atmosphere last night and was still expected to plunge toward earth tonight, according to Soviet and American predictions.

title: Hollings Registers With Panel As Candidate for Presidency
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina has registered with the Federal Election Commission as a candidate for the Presidency, becoming the sixth major Democrat to file the formal declaration for 1984.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDAL ENTRIES SOUGHT FOR INTERNATIONAL SHOW
description: The American Medallic Sculpture Association, not yet one year old, has undertaken a task destined to hasten its maturity. The New Yorkbased organization will coordinate United States participation in this year's exhibition and symposium of the prestigious Federation Internationale de la Medaille (FIDEM).

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Ballet is popping up all over the city this week, what with four major companies in town. But the week also offers plenty of modern dance of all varieties.

title: CHANNEL 21, IN FISCAL BIND, SHIFTS FORMAT
description: CONTINUING the cost-cutting strategy that forced the cancellation of its nightly news program last year, Long Island's financially troubled public television station is revamping its schedule so that its remaining local news and public affairs shows will be broadcast on Thursday evenings rather than on different nights throughout the week.

title:
MAILBAG;
ON FILM PLAUSIBILITY
description: Vincent Canby's column on plausibility in the movies When a Movie Doesn't Have to Pass the Plausibility Test." Jan.2 is on to something. "Tootsie " is a wonderful movie, but is it at all likely that after his unmasking on national television, the Dustin Hoffman character would be back in Central Park shoving mimes? Hardly.

title: No Headline
description: My 33-year marriage broke up when I was 55. ''Plight of the Gray Divorcee'' certainly tells it like it is, and I wish that six years ago, when I began my unilateral journey, I had been able to find a group like Ann Arbor's Divorce After 60.

title: A DIARY OF THE NEW SPAIN
description: Barbara Probst Solomon is the author of three books on Spain, including ''Short Flights,'' to be published by Viking Penguin in June. We are still traumatized by the Spanish Civil War. It was the first military proving ground of Fascism and Stalinism, with democracy squeezed and smashed in between, and for most of us Spain continues to mean ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' Ernest Hemingway, George Orwell, Andre Malraux. I've been back from Spain for more than two months now, and my friends' questions about the Socialist landslide in the Oct. 28 general elections have shown me how abiding are the gut fears we Americans have about that country's destiny.

title: WHAT'S AHEAD FOR STATE HOUSING?
description: WHEN Yvonne Scruggs-Leftwich was a young woman in Buffalo in the 1 950's, she saw the results of one of the country's earliest u rbanrenewal projects: Years after the east side of downtown Buffalo w as cleared for potential development, the land still stood empty anda community had been uprooted.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO FITTING JOINTS, HERE'S HOW THE PROS DO IT
description: ONE major sign of whether a woodworking job was done by a skilled carpenter or an inexperienced amateur is the neatness of the joints where two pieces of molding or trim come together. This is most often evident in corner joints.
