However, poorly done fittings are even more noticeable when they occur in butt joints - that is, where two pieces are joined end to end because one piece is not long enough to go all the way across (or all the way up and down) the surface being worked on.

title: District Telegraph Hires Gilbert, Whitney
description: Gilbert, Whitney & Johns of Whippany, N.J., has become the ad agency for American District Telegraph, which is said to be the country's largest and oldest company in electronic security systems. These days it's what you call a growth company.

title: Reynolds Metals Shifts Management
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum concern after the Aluminum Company of America, has promoted William O. Bourke, a former auto executive, to president and chief operating officer. Mr. Bourke, 55 years old, succeeds John E. Blomquist, 68, who was named a vice chairman.

title: FREE RIDING MAY CEASE FOR 60,000 PUPILS IN CITY
description: More than 60,000 students who ride to school free will lose that privilege on Feb. 1 if the Board of Education adopts a budget-cutting proposal tomorrow.

title: TV: 'RING' CYCLE OPENING WITH 'DAS RHEINGOLD'
description: FOLLOWING last Monday's hourlong anticipatory documentary, the Public Broadcasting Service presentation of the complete Wagner ''Ring of the Nibelungs'' gets under way in earnest tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 with the telecast of the first of the ''Ring'' music dramas, ''Das Rheingold.'' This performance, and those to come, will frustrate and enrage Wagner purists. But the directorial innovations are never less than fascinating, and for the neophyte and for those concerned with the human drama in Wagner the experience will be positively riveting.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Steve Buttle's goal gave the Pittsburgh Spirit a 3-2 victory over the New York Arrows today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game.

title: MUSIC: LES BROWN AND BAND COME EAST FOR TORME SERIES
description: SINCE Les Brown settled in California 35 years ago, his Band of Reknown has rarely ventured farther east than Las Vegas. Its appearance last weekend for three nights with Mel Torme at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack was an unusual opportunity for Easterners to hear one of the few surviving Swing Era bands that has retained the style and sound of the period and yet has a freshness that makes it seem quite up to date.

title: FERGUS, IN PLAYOFF, DEFEATS CALDWELL
description: ''You come to the last hole needing birdie and you make birdie - or it's over.'' It was as simple as that today for Keith Fergus, a lean, 6-foot Texan; Fergus won the Bob Hope Desert Classic by holing a 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th green and then going on to beat Rex Caldwell on the first hole of a playoff. It was the third victory of Fergus's career on the PGA Tour, which began in 1977.

title: Basketball Cutoff Angers Viewers
description: The game between the nation's two top-rated women's basketball teams, Southern California and Louisiana Tech, was down to the final three minutes, but instead of seeing the exciting conclusion, viewers in Northern Louisiana saw the comedymusic show ''Hee-Haw.'' Telephone calls were received from viewers protesting the cutoff.

title: Wyoming Youth Faces Trial As Adult in Father's Slaying
description: A 16-year-old boy charged with killing his father will stand trial as an adult Feb. 14, a state judge ruled Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: 76ER STREAK ENDS

title: Nancy Schaffir Is Wed To Anatole Gershman
description: Nancy Schaffir, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Schaffir of New York, was married yesterday to Anatole Gershman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vitaly Gershman, also of New York, formerly of Moscow. Rabbi Abe Weissman performed the ceremony at the home of a friend of the couple in Manhattan.

title: RECORD SYRACUSE CROWD FAILED TO RATTLE ST. JOHN'S
description: St. John's had no difficulty with fan reaction or noise in the second half at Syracuse's Carrier Dome Saturday night, when the Redmen stormed by the Orange to win, 68-57, before a crowd of 32,382, the largest ever to watch a college basketball game at an on-campus arena.

title: TO RETAIN POWER OVER THE LIFE-BEARERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Aitkin And Lewis To Merge
description: UNDER the benevolent gaze of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, two major Philadelphia ad agencies are going to merge. They are Lewis & Gilman, the largest agency in town, and the Aitkin-Kynett Company, the oldest.

title: Soviet Emigres at La Mama
description: The St. Petersburg Players, an acting troupe of Soviet emigres, is offering ''Fantasies of Pushkin,'' a work based on the writings of the Russian poet, at La Mama, E.T.C, 74A East Fourth Street.

title: MUSIC: WESTERN WIND TEAMS WITH SICILIAN MARIONETTES
description: IN a strange and confusing clash of cultures, the Western Wind vocal ensemble and the Manteo Sicilian Marionette Theater brought music and spoken drama to Symphony Space on Saturday afternoon. The Western Wind, with its turn-of-the-17th century costumes, sang and dramatized madrigals by Monteverdi, Gesualdo and one by Marenzio with text by Ariosto.

title: Drug Arrests Cause Violence in Cocoa, Fla.
description: Community officials met with black residents today after the arrest of four men touched off three hours of stone and bottle throwing in a predominantly black neighborhood Saturday night.

title: FORMER NEW YORKERS REMAIN LOYAL TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Loyalty to New York City is common among many former residents who, often from a distance, express their concern for its poor with contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PORTUGUESE LEADER TO CALL ELECTIONS SOON IN CRISIS
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes said today that he would dissolve Parliament and call early general elections after the departing coalition Government worked out a 1983 national budget.

title: Avant-Garde Show Set For Performance Space
description: More than 30 avant-garde performers will participate in a four-show benefit Friday and Saturday for Performance Space 122, an experimental theater house.

title: Canada Beats U.S.
description: Team Canada beat the United States, 3-2, in the first Loews Cup professional team squash racquets tournament at the Lincoln Squash Club yesterday.

title: Longyear Co.  Ends Its Bid
description: The Longyear Company of Minneapolis, which had been involved in a takeover fight for control of the National Mine Service Company, a mine equipment supplier, has announced the termination of its $13-ashare offer.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Albany's general obligation debt rating was lowered by Standard & Poor's to BBB, its lowest investment grade, because of poor financial operations and lack of proper fiscal controls.

title: Islander Spirit High
description: The Islanders did not show anger after their 1-0 loss to Philadelphia at Nassau Coliseum Saturday night. They seemed disappointed but not dismayed.

title: U.N. Envoy Pursues Afghan Talks in Pakistan
description: A special United Nations envoy arrived here today on the second stage of a diplomatic mission seeking a political solution to the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and said he had made a good start with talks in Teheran.

title: Alfa Group's Debt Plan
description: Grupo Industrial Alfa, Mexico's biggest private company, has proposed a 90-day extension of its corporate and debt restructuring plan to some 130 of its creditors. Alfa, which owes $2.3 billion to foreign creditors, said the modified plan called for varying percentages of cash interest payments on certain subsidiaries' debts and the continued suspension of amortization and other debt repayments. Alfa added that it needed more time to carry out its restructuring plan, which would reduce the company to its core steel and petrochemical units.

title: STORES REASSESS VIDEO GAMES
description: About this time last year, the coin-operated video games that Genovese Drug Stores had installed in some of its outlets seemed a welcome way to perk up cash flow. As shoppers dropped their quarters into the machines to do battle with electronic attackers, store managers saw the units as a novel source of revenue that required the outlay of only a small amount of space in return.

title: MICROSCOPE DEVISED FOR RECORDING ATOMIC STRUCTURES OF MOST SOLIDS
description: A University of Chicago scientist has designed an electron microscope to detect objects one-third the size of those now observable, which would make it possible to see the atomic structure of most solids for the first time.

title: People
description: * Alan H. Zwiebel elected a senior vice president of Young & Rubicam USA.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Life For a Graceful Remnant

title: Memphis State 57; North Carolina State 53
description: Phillip Haynes scored on a driving layup with 50 seconds left to give Memphis State the victory.

title: 3 More Louisiana Towns Affected by Poison Scare
description: Two cities shut off their water services today after anonymous callers said their water systems had been poisoned with cyanide, and another caller told a third city that cyanide would be put in its water supply.

title: CUOMO REQUESTS A REVIEW OF TWO INSURANCE RULINGS
description: Governor Cuomo has asked his counsel to review two recent rulings by the State Insurance Superintendent, Albert B. Lewis, a holdover from the administration of Hugh L. Carey.

title: Bishops Tell Marcos His Policies Aid Rebels
description: Philippine bishops warned President Ferdinand E. Marcos today that his policies were providing ''fodder to revolutionary groups'' and spurring peasant support for Communist guerrillas.

title: EFFECTS OF PROPOSITION 13 TO STRIKE CALIFORNIA CITIES
description: The bill for Proposition 13, the 1978 property tax revolt, is coming due this year for California municipalities, according to state and local officials.

title: Divers Set Back In Search For Boat
description: Fog and high winds forced state police scuba divers to return to shore today after an unsuccessful search for a clamming boat believed to have sunk north of Atlantic City with three crewmen aboard.

title: STATE FINDS EVASION OF SALES TAXES ON GAS
description: New York State's new system of collecting gasoline sales taxes has resulted in widespread evasion and the loss of revenue for the state, New York City and the suburban counties, according to officials of the state and the fuel industry.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN SUSPECT TERRAIN. By John McPhee. 209 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: OSCAR FILM IS CRITICAL OF ISRAEL
description: The Israel Film Board, a 10-member advisory board appointed by the Government, has selected ''Hamsin,'' a film critical of Israel as its nominee for the best foreign-language picture in Hollywood's Acaademy Awards competition. The choice comes at a time when Israelis are increasingly sensitive to the way they are seen overseas.

title: CONTINGENCY RESPONSE PLANS BY U.S. FOR SATELLITE ARE KEPT LARGELY SECRET
description: As a large fragment of a Soviet satellite was plunging toward earth today, passing over the Eastern United States on its final orbit, the Federal Government, like many others around the world, had special agencies keeping track and ready to take emergency actions.

title: Knicks' Robinson Is Finding His Role
description: Len (Truck) Robinson was happy to come to the New York Knicks and glad to leave the Phoenix Suns and Coach John MacLeod after last season. The power forward had born the brunt of the criticism for the Suns' early elimination from last season's playoffs.

title: Peruvians Report 7 Guerrillas Died in Battle With Peasants
description: Seven suspected leftist guerrillas have been killed in a battle with peasants in the Andean province of Ayacucho, the police said today.

title: BORG DECIDES NOT TO COME BACK
description: Bjorn Borg has decided not to play a Grand Prix schedule or in any Grand Slam events this year, and has perhaps ended his tennis career. In a series of rapidly changing developments during the last 48 hours, Borg told a Swedish newspaper, Kvallposten of Malmo, that he did not have the proper motivation to regain the world's No.1 ranking.

title: The Missing Master
description: WHERE is Bjorn Borg, now that we really need him? Out in Thailand, playing exhibitions and telling a Swedish journalist friend that he cannot find the energy to fight his way back to the top.

title: DOLPHINS' COVERAGE GOT IN TODD'S WAY
description: Nothing they tried had worked. When the Jets tried to pass, it seemed that Richard Todd was always throwing toward at least two white Miami Dolphin jerseys.

title: Hickey and Bisso Victors in Bobsled
description: Bob Hickey of Keene, N.Y., and Rich Bisso of Plattsburgh, N.Y., rallied to win the national two-man bobsled championships in a steady rain today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Venerable Shop in Limbo

title: CITY GIFT SHOP FOR GARDENERS
description: New York museums have started a trend by opening branches of their gift shops in midtown. First there was the Brooklyn Museum's shop in the Citicorp building, followed by the Metropolitan Museum of Art's shops in the New York Public Library's Mid-Manhattan branch and Macy's. Now the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has joined in, opening a shop in the glass-enclosed lobby of the new I.B.M. building at 57th Street and Madison Avenue.

title: No Headline
description: Devils Beaten, 3-1; Lever Misses Game

title: CONTRACTS SHOW BASEBALL IS TRULY A NUMBERS GAME
description: MODERN baseball economics at times has produced new methods of measuring a player's value. For example, even a child with a calculator could figure out that in 1981 Rennie Stennett's $600,000 salary meant he earned $6,896.55 for each time at bat, because he batted only 87 times that year. That, of course, is a figurative mathematical measurement.

title: OPEC'S MINISTERS AGREE TO REDUCE PROJECTED OUTPUT
description: OPEC oil ministers agreed today to reduce the total projected amount of oil that the group's 13 members would produce this year. One minister said that Saudi Arabia would bear the brunt of the reduction.

title: Hope Trio Last
description: The winning threesome of amateurs turned in a score of 63 under par, with allowances for their handicaps and integrating the scores of their professional playing partners in the best-ball scores. The amateurs were Jim Saul of La Quinta Country Club, Thomas Marquez of Dallas and Louis Souza of Bermuda Dunes Country Club.

title: RIGHTS AND CENTRAL AMERICA: FOR MANY, SITUATION IS GRIM
description: Here in El Salvador, the Government is holding more than 700 people in prison under suspicion of subversive activity. There are, for the most part, no formal charges, no trials, no definite sentences.

title: LEADER'S INDICTMENT IN SLAYING STIRS TURMOIL IN COAST UNIT OF NOW
description: California members of the National Organization for Women spent several days angrily speculating what enemy of feminism had been responsible for their president's arrest on murder charges.

title: HEALTH CARE COSTS UP 11%, NEARLY TRIPLE INFLATION RATE
description: The cost of medical care increased 11 percent last year, or nearly three times as much as the Consumer Price Index for all items. Overall, the index rose just 3.9 percent in 1982, the smallest increase in a decade.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AUTEUR, AUTEUR!

title: GARBAGE BURNING PLAN IS ASSAILED
description: Three new studies show that the garbage-burning incinerator proposed for the Brooklyn Navy Yard is the ''wrong plant at the wrong place,'' according to City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Five Playwrights Win Dramatists-CBS Prizes
description: Five playwrights will receive $5,000 each as the first winners of a playwrighting award jointly sponsored by the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild and CBS Inc. Included in the FDG/CBS New Plays Program award is the staging of each playwright's work at regional theaters .

title: GEORGE R. BROWN, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: George R. Brown, a construction executive who played an important role in President Johnson's rise in politics, died Saturday at the age of 84.

title: ISRAEL, DESPITE BEGIN
description: The United States might not like Menachem Begin. But Israel is crucial to us - to our national-security planning - and that means personality differences have to be set aside so that America might capitalize on its own natural strengths, and Israel's.

title: THE PROPER STRATEGIC MIX IN LIEU OF DENSE-PACKED MX'S
description: To the Editor:

title: Pride of a Nation
description: When Juan Marichal was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Jan. 12, his triumph was joyously shared by most residents of the Dominican Republic, who had long waited for a native of their island to gain the sport's ultimate tribute. Although baseball is the most popular sport among the island's 5.5 million inhabitants, no native Dominican had ever before risen so high in ''the king of sports.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: *American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Michael I. Roth senior vice president, corporate finance and tax. *American International Airways Inc., Trevose, Pa., has named Bruce B. Edmondson vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Meminger Is Out as Coach
description: Dean Meminger was dismissed today as coach of the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association. James Coyne, the club president, said that Phil Jackson, former player and assistant coach with the Nets, would be signed as the new coach on Wednesday.

title: EUROBOND MARKET STALLS AFTER SURGE
description: The Eurobond market staggered last week after beginning 1983 with a record-shattering wave of new issues that had left observers and participants agreeing that some of the banks and other institutions that manage such issues might have let their competitive instincts get out of hand.

title: Index; International
description: Notes on China: Mao's widow works in a doll factory A2 Portuguese President to call elec- tions soon A3 China denies it has claims to territory held by Soviet A3 Israeli officials says U.S. plan on Lebanon is unacceptable A4 Internal Polish report blames past leaders for labor troubles A6 Around the World A7 Government/Politics Hard times force end to Louisi- ana's profligacy A15 Three studies criticize city plans for a garbage-burning plant B2 Washington Talk Q.&A.: Vice President Bush on his upcoming European trip A10 Government office provides a guide to Government offices A10 The Calendar A10 Briefing A10 General Around the Nation A8 Sideline puts businessman in spotlight in dioxin case A8 Farmers from seven states draw plan to ease plight A8 Catholic bishops ready to finish statement on atom arms A13 Vermont's Governor presses for state job-creating plan A13 Feminist leader's arrest stirs turmoil on Coast A16 East Coast cheerleaders met in competition in New Jersey B1 Cuomo asks counsel to study 2 in- surance rulings B2 Four people died in the crash of a plane near Atlantic City B3 Man stabs four people in mosque in Brooklyn B3 SportsMonday Basketball: Nets beat Sonics by 105-102 C11

title: ISSUES TIED TO DEMAND
description: The volume of new corporate issues continues to be less than some traders had forecast, but it could increase sharply if investor demand improves. Corporations will continue to sell more issues than are formally scheduled, as large companies are relying increasingly on shelf registrations that allow them to sell quickly when conditions are favorable.

title: MUSIC: COPENHAGEN TRIO
description: GOETHE once called the playing of chamber music a discourse between reasonable people. One was reminded of those words at Hunter Playhouse on Saturday night while listening to the Copenhagen String Trio.

title: JETS GET GREETING AT HOME
description: Between 75 and 100 vocal fans, some waiting more than two hours in heavy rain and dense fog, last night greeted the Jets at the Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport. The fans carried Jet pennants and some passed the time by drinking beer and telling stories about their favorite pro football players.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Rabbit Town' Honors a Friend

title: ARMS TALKS: A 'DIFFICULT ENVIRONMENT'
description: Vice President Bush is going off to Western Europe next week to talk to the NATO allies about the control of nuclear weapons. This is part of President Reagan's new ''public diplomacy'' experiment, designed to counter the tactics of the new Andropov regime in Moscow.

title: A Monkey Wrench for Family Planning
description: Since 1978, the Alan Guttmacher Institute, under a grant from the Federal Agency for International Development, has been publishing and distributing International Family Planning Perspectives, a quarterly that goes to about 25,000 family planning workers around the world. All are on an A.I.D.-approved list and most work in countries that are actual or potential recipients of American development assistance.

title: LOUISIANA FORCED TO CHANGE SPENDTHRIFT TUNE
description: Louisiana, one of the richest states in the nation only two years ago, has begun to grapple with a state budget that is millions of dollars short of meeting this year's expenses.

title: BALLET: 1947 BALANCHINE A TRIUMPH IN CAPITAL
description: An exceptional ballet -both scintillating and tender - that George Balanchine created in 1947, has been brought back from a 30-year period of oblivion with care and success by American Ballet Theater.

title: Poles to Permit Showing Of 'Danton,' Wajda Film
description: ''Danton,'' the new film about the French Revolution by the Polish film director Andrzej Wajda, will have its premiere in Warsaw on Jan. 31, the state television said tonight.

title: IN SCARSDALE, REPUBLICANS ARE A MINORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief for Texaco Europe
description: Paul B. Hicks Jr., a vice president at Texaco Inc., has been named president of Texaco Europe. Mr. Hicks, 57 years old, succeeds Annon M. Card, 63, whose early retirement had been announced.

title: IRAN'S LASTING WAR ON 300,000 IRANIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Service With a Smile

title: David Henry Richter Marries Golde Hyman
description: Golde Judith Hyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hyman of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to David Henry Richter, son of William Richter of Chicago and the late Mrs. Richter. Rabbi Alan D. Fuchs performed the ceremony at the Plum Street Temple.

title: BALLET: 'WALTZES' BY PETER MARTINS
description: THE Hartford Ballet has come up with a bright idea. Last year, Michael Uthoff, its director, invited Ruth Laredo, the concert pianist, to play at a gala performance of ballets to piano music. The event was so successful that Miss Laredo and the company decided to continue their association, and they were together again for a performance Friday night at Montclair State College in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: PUT TAIWAN ON HOLD
description: United States relations with China are in trouble. American euphoria over China has paled, and China's suspicions about the influence of Western ideas on its society have grown. New irritants have emerged on levels of American textile imports from China and Chinese purchases of American agricultural products, and American refusal to grant licenses to export some technology to China. The Chinese are not as alarmed by the Soviet Union as they once were. But the key long-term political problem for which neither Washington nor Peking has a solution acceptable to the other remains Taiwan.

title: THE SHRINKING STEEL INDUSTRY
description: Blasting open hearth furnaces and brawny men, helmets under their arms, filing through gates of chain link fences have long been the symbols of United States industrial might.

title: CONNECTICUT'S INTERSTATE BANKING DEBATE
description: Opening Connecticut's borders to out-of-state banks is shaping up as one of the more contentious issues on the agenda of the General Assembly, just getting organized for its legislative session.

title: Midtown Cafe Robbed; Police Seize 4 Suspects
description: Three gunmen burst into a Manhattan restaurant Saturday night and robbed diners of money and jewelry and also emptied a cash register. The robbers fled, but within minutes four suspects were arrested.

title: TWO COURT SYSTEMS IN DIRE NEED OF RELIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CITES SLOW '82 OUTPUT
description: Economic indicators for 1982, published today in major Soviet newspapers, confirmed a continuing slowdown in most key industrial and agricultural sectors of the Soviet Union.

title: Concern On Future Of C.F.T.C.
description: A week after Philip McBride Johnson announced his intent to resign as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission by May 1, the industry was still in a state of shock, just as it was when he assumed the post on June 8, 1981. But this time, the reasons for the industry's concerns are vastly different.

title: CITY BRACES FOR CRISIS IN SHELTERING DISPLACED FAMILIES AT LOW RENTS
description: Burned out, frozen out or evicted from their homes, more than 1,500 families - 20 percent more than a year ago - are being housed by the city in hotels or apartment buildings.

title: FARMERS FROM 7 STATES DRAW PLANS TO EASE PLIGHT
description: A rare form of agrarian organization, the child of distress in rural regions, completed a conference this weekend on strategies aimed at a peaceful revolution by American farmers.

title: DOMESTIC CHANGES, THEN AID FOR I.M.F.
description: Congress will convene tomorrow to hear the State of the Union Message, and in a few days will receive the budget message. A world suffering from the Great Recession will be watching anxiously to see whether the Government of the United States is capable of governing.

title: LEFTIST LEADERS IN EUROPE WARN OF FISCAL CRISIS
description: The leaders of six Socialist governments in Europe said today that an international economic crisis threatened both industrialized and less developed nations.

title: Letter: On Male Clubs Admit Women? No Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 PEOPLE KILLED IN JERSEY CRASH OF SMALL PLANE
description: The four people aboard a twin-engine airplane from Illinois were killed last night when the aircraft crashed while making an instrument approach to an airport near Atlantic City in drizzle and fog, authorities said.

title: COGHLAN AIMS TO RESUME HIS MASTERY OF THE INDOOR MILE
description: RYE, N.Y. TO the neighbors in this Westchester community, Eamonn Coghlan is just another jogger, emerging from his front door every morning dressed in a cheerful shade of synthetic warmups and matching ski cap. They see him mostly through bleary eyes and icy windshields as he charges into a winter head wind and they wonder why joggers wouldn't rather spend this time snug beneath a layer or two of blankets.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Post for Inman

title: The Boys of Winter
description: Dr. Leonard Arnold, 61 years old, saw his first Chicago Cubs game in the 1929 World Series. Fifty-four years later he painfully recalls Chicago's Hack Wilson misjudging a fly ball in that game and Philadelphia overcoming a 8-0 Chicago lead to win, 10-8.

title: Fireman Dies in Peoria Blaze
description: One fireman was killed and another seriously injured early today when a wall and roof collapsed on them as they fought a fire at a downtown business and apartment building. Capt. Vernon Gudrat, 38 years old, died of head injuries, and Michael Morrow, 31, was listed in fair condition in a hospital with head and shoulder injuries.

title: READING HOWARD'S MIND
description: Here I am, just like Ted Kennedy - declared out for '84, declared in for '88. Of course, my little bombshell of an announcement only means I'm out of the Senate race, not the Presidential race, in 1984. Here's how I figure it: there's a 50-50 chance of the President running again. Even if he chooses to run, there's a good chance of our losing the Senate. We have nearly twice as many seats up for grabs as the Democrats do in '84, and I cannot think of anything more boring than to carry the Reagan flag as minority leader.

title: Bank Deluged by People Seeking Gift Pistols
description: The manager of a bank offering a set of pistols to long-term depositors says the response to the promotion ''has surpassed all my wildest dreams.''

title: 466 Surrender in Thailand
description: The military radio said 466 Communist insurgents and their dependents in northeast Thailand surrendered to security forces today, the latest to take advantage of a Government amnesty proclaimed Dec. 1. Several mass surrenders took place soon after the amnesty announcement, part of the Government's effort to quell an insurgency movement in northern Thailand.

title: Dr. Bernard M. Pohoryles, 70, Professor at Pace University
description: Dr. Bernard M. Pohoryles, professor emeritus of foreign languages at Pace University in Manhattan, died Friday at Beekman Downtown Hospital after suffering a stroke Thursday.

title: WIDOW MAKES DOLLS WITH A VENGEANCE, THEY SAY
description: On Tuesday it will have been exactly two years since the radicals known as the Gang of Four were found guilty of almost all the evils that racked China during the bitter decade of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Bridge: The 'Thinking Aloud' Style Seems to Help the Reader
description: Two decades ago Terence Reese, the English authority, wrote a book in which he tackled practical problems while thinking aloud, so to speak, for the benefit of the reader. This excellent approach has been little imitated, but Mike Lawrence of Berkeley, Calif., like Reese a former world champion, has now followed in the same track with equally good results.

title: Boris A. Krukoff, 84, A Botanist and Curator
description: Boris A. Krukoff, a botanist and an honorary curator at the New York Botanical Garden, died last Wednesday of congestive heart failure at Smithtown (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Smithtown.

title: TV: 'FRONTLINE' EXAMINES FIVE DEATHS IN GREENSBORO
description: THE gunning down in Greensboro, N.C., in November 1979 of five members of the Communist Workers Party by Ku Klux Klansmen while the Greensboro police were on their lunch break is the subject of tonight's ''Frontline,'' the new public television documentary series, on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock. It is a more provocative piece of journalism than last week's somewhat fuzzy opening program on football gambling, owing largely to interviews with a Klansman-police informer named Ed Dawson, who appears to have played only too active a part in the bloody events.

title: ANALYSTS UNSURE ABOUT RATES
description: The credit markets are now plagued with doubts about the direction of interest rates, as signs emerge that the economy is strengthening and as the Federal Reserve delays a reduction in short-term interest rates, which have not come as quickly as some had expected.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it had agreed to sell its Simplicity Manufacturing division to privately held Wesray Equipment Inc.

title: Emanuel Redfield, 78, Civil Liberties Counsel
description: Emanuel Redfield, a lawyer and longtime counsel for the New York Civil Liberties Union, died Thursday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Redfield was 78 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 3 MILE ISLAND TRIAL BECOMES LEARNING PROCESS FOR THE JUDGE
description: Because a nuclear plant is such a complex piece of machinery, experts explaining parts of it at the negligence trial over the Three Mile Island accident try to couch their descriptions in familiar images.

title: Gasoline Price Declines
description: The average retail price of gasoline in the United States dropped nearly 2 cents a gallon during the past two weeks and the long decline is accelerating, an oil industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today. His survey showed the average price, including taxes, was at $1.1858, down 1.9 cents from the Jan. 7 survey.

title: ACTS BY TERRORISTS TURN REPORTERS INTO PARTICIPANTS
description: A spate of recent incidents in which reporters were involved in helping to defuse terrorist situations has renewed some perennial questions of journalistic practice. How can you be impartial about an event you are part of? Whom are you serving - the police, the terrorists, the public or your own news organization?

title: Washington Watch; Regan, the Fed And Sprinkel
description: WASHINGTON ALL during the Reagan Administration, relations between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board have been rocky. And with the unemployment rate at a post-World War II record of 10.8 percent, the President and his top economic advisers regularly blame the Fed's conduct of monetary policy and, they contend, the resulting high interest rates.

title: LENDL WINS 3-SET FINAL
description: The toss was high, slightly to the right and in front, as Ivan Lendl cocked the cannon at 1-2, 30-40 in the third set. Then the ball exploded off his graphite racquet with a boom, another of the highpowered first serves that helped to dominate and demoralize John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the final of the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament.

title: Jazz Bassist to Appear In Concert With Tashi
description: The jazz bassist Eddie Gomez will appear in a concert by the group Tashi on Feb. 27 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street. The concert, the first in a series of three by the quintet, will include two premieres - Sonata for Violin and Piano by Ruth Crawford Seeger and Fortune by Charles Wuorinen. Mr. Wuorinen will take part in the concert.

title: News Analysis
description: President Francois Mitterrand's address to the West German Parliament, warning about the dangers of splitting the United States from the defense of Europe, has opened up a new area of the missile debate that American speechmakers have carefully avoided.

title: G.O.P. GOVERNOR URGES VERMONT JOBS PROGRAM
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling, a Republican, has surprised almost everyone in Vermont politics with a proposal for public works jobs that some call reminiscent of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.

title: Court Erred in Barring Parole for Young Killer
description: A minor convicted of first-degree murder may not be sentenced to a life term without the possibilty of parole, even under California's tougher sentencing law, the California Supreme Court has ruled.

title: U.S. OFFER ASSAILED BY AN ISRAELI AIDE
description: An Israeli Government official said today that an American compromise plan to speed the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon was still unacceptable despite official Lebanese acceptance of the proposal over the weekend.

title: RIDER 'COMFORTS': TRACKING THE ODDS ON CITY TRANSIT
description: When a passenger gets ready to board a subway train, there is a 1-in-20 chance that a door will not open. If the passenger manages to enter through a working door, there is a 1-in-3 chance that there will be no subway map and nearly a guarantee that there will be graffiti.

title: BUSINESS SIDELINE PUTS OIL DEALER IN THE SPOTLIGHT IN MISSOURI'S DIOXIN CASE
description: Russell Bliss has a 200-acre farm, a stable of prize-winning show horses and a fleet of custom-made cars whose celebrated former owners have included Elvis Presley, Howard Hughes and John F. and Jacqueline Kennedy.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1983
description: International The Soviet satellite plunged through Earth's atmosphere. If any debris from the nuclear-powered Cosmos 1402 survived, it apparently fell harmlessly into a remote section of the Indian Ocean. The North American Aerospace Defense Command estimated that the crippled satellite entered the dense atmosphere at 5:21 P.M. Eastern standard time in an area far south of the Indian subcontinent and far west of Australia. (Page A1, Column 6.) A reduction in the OPEC oil output projected for this year was agreed on by the organization's 13 oil ministers at a meeting in Geneva. One minister said that Saudi Arabia would bear the brunt of the reduction. A serious dispute over how to adjust oil price to reflect differences in quality remained unresolved. (A1:3.)

title: NO EXCUSE FOR MISSING TARPAULIN
description: MIAMI TO their credit, the Jets did not use the absence of a tarpaulin as an alibi. The overnight rain had turned much of the Orange Bowl football field into a rice paddy and the rest into a skating rink. But after the Miami Dolphins qualified yesterday for Super Bowl XVII as the American Conference champion with a 14-0 victory, the Jets did not complain too loudly.

title: SCOTT ENTERPRISES HEAD SEEKS EXPANSION CAPITAL
description: Frank N. Scott Jr. has been named chairman of the Gallery of Homes Inc. That's understandable: he recently bought the real estate franchising chain.

title: Strike in Britain Raises Fears of Health Risks
description: About 29,000 water and sewerage workers went on strike in Britain at midnight as contract talks broke down, raising fears for the health of millions of Britons.

title: DOLPHINS BEAT JETS, 14-0, AND GO TO SUPER BOWL
description: The New York Jets' 14-year wait for an American Conference championship game ended dismally today. The Dolphins intercepted Richard Todd five times, with one interception leading to a touchdown and another going for a touchdown in a 14-0 Miami victory.

title: Finland's Nykanen Wins Ski Jumping; SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Matti Nykanen of Finland soared 125.5 meters on his second jump to win the 90-meter event at the Molson World Cup ski-jumping championships today.

title: A GOVERNMENT OFFICE SEEKS TO UNTANGLE A FEDERAL MAZE
description: From the outside looking in, and often from the inside out as well, the Federal Government seems a jumble of bureaus and bureaucrats, offices and officials, navigable only by the brave or the foolish.

title: THE WOES OF INJURED ATHLETES
description: THE medical verdict was in, and it was not good. At the summit of h er strength, the flowering of her form, Deborah E. Smith, a Vogue f ashion editor and 7:30 A.M. devotee of the health-club pool, was f orbidden to swim - at least indoors. ''It sounds silly,'' she said, ' 'but I became allergic to chlorine.'' One week out of the water, s he also became angry and depressed. ''I thought my world had c ollapsed,'' Mrs. Smith said.

title: TO RETAIN POWER OVER THE LIFE-BEARERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BAKER BACKING REAGAN FOR '84
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., conceded today that he once said "pretty harsh things" about President Reagan, but now he hopes the "result-oriented President" will run for re-election.

title: RUSSIAN SATELLITE FALLS HARMLESSLY OVER INDIAN OCEAN
description: The nuclear-powered Soviet satellite Cosmos 1402 plunged through the atmosphere today and, if any of it survived, the debris apparently fell harmlessly into a section of the Indian Ocean.

title: Jobless Rise Hits Every Region
description: Soaring unemployment hit the South and other parts of the Sun Belt as well as the industrial Middle West and Northeast from November 1981 to last November, according to the Government's new state-by-state unemployment figures.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: College Basketball Villanova at St. John's, 8 P.M. First place in the Big East Conference is at stake. The Redmen (6-1 in league play) are fresh from a victory at Syracuse and the Wildcats (5-0) have won their last 10 games, their longest winning streak since 1971.

title: CAMPS SELL ADVENTURES FOR SUMMER
description: There were photographs, videotape machines, color slides projected onto screens, and they all showed images of summer paradise - such things as rafts coursing through white water, tents pitched in sylvan glades, sleek horses with happy children atop them.

title: Jeff Companion's Wins at Aqueduct
description: Jeff's Companion, owned by the Aisco Stable and ridden by Antonio Graell, took command at the half-mile pole and went on to register a 3 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $55,400 Count Fleet Handicap at a fog-bound Aqueduct Race Track.

title: OFFENSES HAMPERED BY SOGGY FIELD
description: The grass field for today's Jets-Dolphins championship game was spongy from rain, so spongy that Mike Augustyniak of the Jets was to describe it as ''mushy.''

title: Avalanches Kill 4 in Iceland
description: Two avalanches killed four people and swept away dozens of cars and houses in northwest Iceland Saturday night, the police said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They played better than us, and they deserve to go to the Super Bowl.'' - Richard Todd, Jets quarterback. (C10:4.)

title: MISSOURI IS BEATEN BY 60-59
description: A free throw by Terry Reason with 77 seconds left and a steal by Kerry Trotter in the closing seconds lifted Marquette to a 60-59 victory against Missouri in overtime today.

title: Decertify Hypocrisy on Salvador
description: Whenever Congress ties a string to American aid, it can put a knot in American diplomacy. The mischief of legislative meddling is all too apparent in the confusion and hypocrisy promoted by the law that compels the President to say again, as he does semiannually, what hardly any American believes: that El Salvador is ''making progress'' in its respect for human rights and political reforms.

title: NETS DEFEAT SONICS ON LATE FOUL SHOTS
description: In the final moments of their 105-102 triumph over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight, it was not difficult for the Nets to figure how to stop their foes. They thought back to late last season, when James Donaldson, who at 7 feet 2 inches and 275 pounds was the largest man on the floor, led the Sonics to victory against them with a hook shot in the final seconds.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Andrea Schone of East Germany set a women's world record of 7 minutes 40.97 seconds in the 5,000 meters today and won the European speed skating championship at the end of a two-day meet.

title: NEW CHIEF EXPECTED AT BONWIT
description: The Allied Stores Corporation today will appoint a new president of its flagging Bonwit Teller division, the fashion-oriented store chain that it purchased in 1979.

title: PARKING FIGHT MAY USE PHOTOS FROM SWEEPERS
description: New York City's Sanitation Department is considering a new weapon to battle the illegally parked cars that impede its street-cleaning efforts: photographs.

title: Syria and Libya Back Efforts to Topple Iraqi
description: Syria and Libya, pledging to stand beside Iran against ''hostile forces,'' expressed support today for efforts to overthrow the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein.

title: TRUCKING INDUSTRY'S BID FOR NEW CONCESSIONS DEEPENS TEAMSTERS' TROUBLES
description: In their 1965 book ''Hoffa and the Teamsters,'' Ralph C. James and Estelle D. James wrote of how contract negotiations were conducted under James R. Hoffa when he was president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Florida Prison Erupts After an Inmate Is Shot
description: Inmates set fires and vandalized parts of a state prison here today in a disturbance that was set off about 7 A.M. when an inmate was shot by a guard, apparently in an escape attempt.

title: Walton Reports Head-Coach Bids
description: With the Jets' season over, Joe Walton, their offensive coordinator, acknowledged today that he had been approached by other teams to discuss their head-coaching vacancies.

title: KEY ROLE FOR DUHE IN DOLPHIN SHUTOUT
description: A week ago, when the Miami Dolphins defeated the San Diego Chargers in the second round of the National Football League playoffs, A.J. Duhe and the Dolphins' other defensive starters were slightly piqued at the end of the game: They had wanted a shutout, they said, and didn't get it, winning by 34-13.

title: ROCK: MISSION OF BURMA
description: MISSION OF BURMA started its first set Friday at CBGB like a typical punk-rock band, with a screech of guitar, a pummeling riff for bass and drums, and shouted vocals. But that set, drawn mostly from Mission of Burma's new album, ''Vs.,'' proved it is by no means a monolithic punk band.

title: FLYERS AND FROESE DEFEAT RANGERS, 3-1
description: If the Flyers keep winning the way they have in recent games, they will make shambles of the Patrick Division, supposedly the most competitive in the National Hockey League.

title: MUSIC: BASSIST TALVELA IN FULL SCHUBERT CYCLE
description: WhEN imagining an introspective, melancholy German Romantic lover, Martti Talvela is not the figure that comes to mind. The bearded Finnish bass, sturdily standing more than six-and-a-half feet above the stage is not a mere baritone likely to be tossed about by the harshest of winds, or lured into rocky crags by a will-'o-the-wisp. Nor would the snarling dogs, phantom suns and hoar-frost of Wilhelm Muller's poetry seem to hold much power over this figure, who -when he was toppled, as the title figure in the Metropolitan Opera performances of ''Boris Godunov'' this season,was undone by a Gargantuan guilt and madness.

title: Redskins Molded By a Master Scout
description: The Washington Redskins became a Super Bowl team because of the collective effort of the players and their coaches that peaked in the decisive defeat of the Dallas Cowboys Saturday in the National Conference championship game.

title: A NEW LOOK AT ANXIETY'S MANY FACES
description: As Sandra Turner described it to her psychiatrist, the severe anxiety attacks she'd been having for the last six months were close to unbearable. ''My chest tightens,'' she said, ''my palms sweat, I have a sense of dread, and it feels like I'm losing control.'' The attacks seemed to arise spontaneously in a variety of situations where ease of exit was difficult - places like supermarket lines, buses, crowded stores, restaurants and elevators.

title: INTERNAL POLISH REPORT BLAMES LEADERS FOR LABOR UPHEAVALS
description: An internal Communist Party report recently shown to Western correspondents here blames the ''incompetence'' of previous leaders for Polish labor upheavals from 1956 to 1980.

title: GLOSSARY OF COMMON DISORDERS
description: The investigators at the Anxiety Disorders Clinic draw a line between anxiety disorders involving panic attacks and those that do not.

title: Jazz Benefit for Henry St.
description: Count Basie, Tony Bennett amd Carmen McRae will perform in concert tonight in Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall to raise funds to help reopen the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center of the Henry Street Settlement, at 466 Grand Street.

title: DISCOVERY BY UNION OIL SPURS INTEREST ON COAST
description: A new oil discovery seven miles north of the rich Point Arguello field off the coast of southern California has bolstered some projections of large reserves for the area, known as the Santa Maria basin.

title: TB Cases Decline In Connecticut
description: The number of new tuberculosis cases in Connecticut fell in 1982 after increasing the two previous years, according to state health officials.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Nashua Chief Retiring; Successor Is Sought
description: ''I wanted to do it,'' James E. Conway said. ''It just seemed to me like I wanted to be retired. With that in mind, I talked to the directors and decided to proceed with it.''

title: Webster Decides To Forgo Appeal
description: The attorney for Ben Webster, one of the nation's leading harness drivers, said today that Webster would not appeal his 90-day suspension and $5,000 fine for conduct ''detrimental to racing.''

title: STAGE: 'DICK DETERRED,' A WATERGATE MUSICAL
description: YOU get the idea of ''Dick Deterred,'' a musical at the No Smoking Playhouse commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Watergate affair, right from its punning name, a play on Shakespeare's ''Richard III,'' which provides the format from which this takeoff takes off.

title: Market Place; New Questions For Traders
description: MANAGERS of pension funds, mutual funds and other large sources of institutional money have fed the bull market with baskets of cash since last August. Now and then, individual investors tossed a few tidbits into the ring.

title: PEKING SAYS IT DOESN'T COVET ANY TERRITORY HELD BY SOVIET
description: China said today that it had no territorial claims on the Soviet Union and accused the Soviet press of intentionally distorting its stand on their longstanding border dispute.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 1983; International
description: OPEC reached agreement on lowering total projected oil output this year. But the meeting in Geneva failed to solve a serious dispute over pricing. The talks resume today. (Page A1.)

title: JOSEPHINE RIZZUTO
description: Josephine Rizzuto, the founder with her late husband of the Conair Corporation, a manufacturer of hand-held hair dryers, died Friday of cancer at her home in Brooklyn. She was 80 years old.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS SET TO FINISH LETTER ON ATOM ARMS
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, after consulting with Reagan Administration officials and spokesmen for European prelates, is set to resume preparing the final draft of a broad statement condemning nuclear arms. No major changes are expected in the earlier draft.

title: Dear Centurion
description: I confess to being somewhat startled by your assumption (in the letter below) that my letter about your club's refusal to admit women as members was occasioned by a desire to boost a presumed brotherin-law's career. I am willing to entertain the possibility that I am, as you say, ''dreary'' and ''literal-minded,''(though not ''perhaps fictitious''). May I add, however, that I expect a lawyer of your credentials to mount more than an ad feminam defense of his convictions?

title: El Paso to Cut Gas Cost
description: The El Paso Company has announced that, begining March 1, its interstate pipeline subsidiary, the El Paso Natural Gas Company, will lower the price it pays for natural gas produced from below 15,000 feet and tight sands formations to $5 per thousand cubic feet. It said this would affect about 75 percent of the 250 million cubic feet of deregulated deep and tight-sands gas purchased daily by its pipeline unit. This will cut the unit's gas costs by up to $250 million annually.

title: REAGAN DOUBTS RESTRUCTURING SOON
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he opposes the idea of contingency tax increases starting in the 1986 fiscal year.

title: Lorraine Brown Is Bride of John Davis
description: Lorraine Eddy Brown, daughter of Mrs. L. Eddy Brown of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Bruce Ford Brown of Annapolis, Md., was married yesterday to John Richard Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lee Davis of Godalming, Surrey, England. The Rev. Clarke Kimberly Oler performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, Calif.

title: MUSIC: QUEENS SYMPHONY MARKS 30TH ANNIVERSARY
description: THE Queens Symphony Orchestra celebrated its 30th anniversary at the Colden Center on Saturday night with a new piece commissioned for the occasion and a performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. David Katz conducted both works, along with Copland's ''Fanfare for the Common Man,'' which opened the concert.

title: Former Irish Premier Confronts His Critics
description: Former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey confronted critics in his Fianna Fail Party today over his role in a wiretapping scandal.

title: Light Up in Comfort
description: When 2,000 drivers of buses, taxis, limousines and vans drop their passengers at the Rose Bowl for the viewing of Super Bowl XVII next Sunday, passing the next three hours will not be the time-killing chore it usually is for drivers while waiting for the game to end and their passengers to reappear.

title: Vision And Reality
description: Mozambicans say that theirs is not a multiracial but a ''nonracial'' society. By that they mean that people think of themselves first as Mozambicans, not as members of this or that group: black or brown or white or Indian.

title: 1,800 CHEERLEADERS GIVE A RAH RAH RAH FOR SIS BOOM BAH
description: Outside, people here were grumbling on a gloomy winter's day about the Jets losing and the possibility that radioactive satellite debris might soon be falling on their heads along with the torrential, freezing rain.

title: ROCK: ALUMNI OF ZAPPA
description: based rock quintet, three of whose principal players used to work with Frank Zappa, has emerged as one of the most promising American bands to play in a synthesized, techno-pop idiom. And at the Beacon Theater on Saturday, the group performed a concert whose most impressive feature was the rhythmic coordination between its exceptional drummer, Terry Bozzio, and two synthesizer players.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mrs. Rockefeller Named to a Board

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A receiver in a professional football game catches a pass near the goal line. One foot lands inbounds, but not in the end zone. As he crosses the goal line, his other foot comes down out of bounds. Is it a touchdown? What happens if a back running with the ball does the same thing?

title: FALKLAND POLITICAL BATTLE FAR FROM OVER IN BRITAIN
description: The political battle over the Falkland Islands resumes on Tuesday with a two-day debate in the House of Commons that will reopen the question of long-term British administration of the archipelago.

title: MANSION ANTIQUES ARE REJECTED BY MRS. KEAN
description: There were heavy sideboards with cornucopia carvings and large claw feet. There was a mahogany dining table on a pedestal base carved as a basket of fruit. There was a Grecian-style couch with paw feet and gold rosettes in the blue-silk upholstery. There were pier tables with hairy knees, side chairs with cloven hooves and chandeliers dripping prisms.

title: Man Stabs Four People In Mosque in Brooklyn
description: A man described as a former member of a Muslim religious group invaded a mosque in Brooklyn's Bushwick section yesterday afternoon and stabbed four people, one critically, before being overpowered, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: SKI VICTORY TO MISS MCKINNEY

title: ESTELLE WINWOOD TURNING 100 FEISTILY
description: On the brink of her 100th birthday Monday, Estelle Winwood tipples Gallo cream sherry, plays bridge three times a week and smokes three packs of cigarettes a day.

title: UNITED STATES LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,800,000 for the qr and $6,600,000 for the yr...C-After a loss of $2,000,000 from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect investment in a savings and loan association as a discontinued operations

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 results are for 14 weeks for the qr and 53 weeks for the yr, while the1981 results are for 13 weeks for the qr and 52 weeks for the yr

title: COUNTY JUDGE TO CONDUCT TRIAL OF 6 IN BRINK'S CASE
description: The state judge who has presided over pretrial hearings in the Brink's robbery and murder case will be replaced when the trial of six defendants starts on March 1 in Goshen, N.Y., court officials said yesterday.

title: Bankruptcy Stand Shifted
description: The Reagan Administration, changing its position, today supported a Judicial Conference proposal to name administrators to handle routine bankruptcy cases while letting Federal District Court judges handle other matters.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 25, 1983
description: International OPEC members failed to agree on ways to apportion their share of a shrinking world oil market, causing a serious split among the oil ministers at their consultative meeting in Geneva. Agreement was blocked by unexpectedly insistent demands by Saudi Arabia and several of its Persian Gulf allies that settlement of a dispute over price discounting would have to precede agreement on production plans. The Saudi protest also threatened a partial agreement reached Sunday on lowering the group's maximum oil production this year to 17.5 million barrels a day. (Page A1, Column 6.) The slow pace of the talks in Lebanon on the withdrawal of foreign troops is worrying Administration officials. They are saying both publicly and privately that the sluggishness could lead to new difficulties in Israel-American relations. (A1:1.)

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPEC NATIONS FAIL TO AGREE ON LEVEL OF OIL PRODUCTION
description: An emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended today in disagreement over production quotas, raising the possibility that oil prices will decline further.

title: Solidarity Radio Activists Go on Trial in Poland
description: Eight activists of the banned Solidarity union who started an illegal radio station last April went on trial in military court today, charged with disseminating news that could touch off ''unrest and riots.''

title: Armco Reports Quarterly Loss
description: Armco Inc., the nation's seventhlargest steel company, reported today that it had a $183 million loss in the fourth quarter, of which $53 million was in operating losses and the rest in special charges.

title: Andropov Letter Says Shcharansky Ends Fast
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, has ended his hunger strike and is in good health, the French Communist Party leader, Georges Marchais, said today, citing a letter he had received from Yuri V. Andropov.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN OUTLINES POLICY ON TRIBES

title: Article 187510 -- No Title
description: The operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant agreed out of court yesterday to accept $37 million in settling its suit against the manufacturer of the disabled reactor.

title: Soccer Questions
description: Beginning next week, the best American professional soccer players will confront a difficult career decision: whether or not to accept an invitation to play for Team America. And some of those players say that their decision is being made more difficult by the unanswered questions surrounding the team.

title: JUAN CARLOS ZABALA
description: Juan Carlos Zabala, who won the marathon at the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, died today of a heart attack, hospital officials reported. He was 71 years old. Mr. Zabala, the first Latin American to win the gold medal in an Olympic marathon, was hospitalized early this month because of injuries suffered in a fall.

title: TV: 'MISS LONELYHEARTS'
description: ''MISS LONELYHEARTS,'' Nathanael West's story about a young male reporter turned advice-to-the-miserable columnist, is hard to categorize. It is sketchy for a novel, yet there is nothing incomplete about it. The characters are barely developed, yet their stories carry tremendous force. His ''world of misery and suffering peopled by creatures who are strangers to everything but disease and policemen,'' stays with the reader, the stuff of broodings in the night. West was a diagnostician of mankind's wounds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Japan's postwar prosperity has flourished under our present Constitution, but the stormy seas which plague the world also strike relentlessly at Japan, as seen in the increasingly harsh trade friction.'' - Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. (A4:3.)

title: Begin Wins Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today defeated, by 60 to 51, a motion of no confidence on the ground that the number of poor had risen in Israel. Speaking for Labor, Rafi Edri quoted data from a study showing that the number of poor families had increased from 14,000 in 1977 to 33,900 in 1981. The Deputy Minister of Welfare, Benzion Rubin, said the figures did not take into account increased assistance to the needy.

title: ANY DECLINE SOON IN OIL PRICES MAY BE SMALL, ANALYSTS SAY
description: The breakdown of the OPEC meeting in Geneva yesterday has set the stage for a slight decline in oil prices and a further cutback in production by Saudi Arabia and its allies on the Arabian Peninsula, energy economists said yesterday.

title: Decision on May Expected Today
description: Ray Grebey, director of the owners' Player Relations Committee, discussed the Rudy May case with the league presidents, Lee MacPhail and Chub Feeney, yesterday, and said afterward that a decision was expected today.

title: RUSSIANS SEEK ROLE AT GATT
description: The Soviet Union is taking soundings to apply for observer status with the organization that sets global trade policy, posing a problem for the United States and other Western powers, Reagan Administration officials reported today.

title: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN HEROES OF SCIENCE GO ASTRAY?
description: century dabbling with alchemy, compulsively heading down a blind alley. A misguided quest also took hold of Alfred Russel Wallace, co-discoverer of the theory of evolution by natural selection, who spent long years mired in futile attempts to communicate with spirits of the dead.

title: SIFCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW RESTRICTION ON WHOLESALING BEER DENOUNCED
description: Brewers are adopting ''anticompetitive'' distribution practices that will drive up the cost of beer to consumers by hundreds of millions of dollars, the State Attorney General said today.

title: A CASE OF COVERAGE SURPASSING THE PLAY
description: T he game may not have lived up to expectations, at least for Jet fans, but Dick Enberg, Merlin Olsen and the NBC production crew did. During Sunday's telecast of the Miami Dolphins' 14-0 victory for the American Football Conference championship, Mr. Enberg and Mr. Olsen did their usual expert job as announcers. And their commentary was supported by the excellent behind-the-scenes work of NBC's football production crew, under the leadership of Ted Nathanson, the network's coordinating producer for all football telecasts, who directed Sunday's game.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to dec 31
description: B-Net income after income from disc oper of $2,100,000 for the qr and $2,600,000 for the yr...C-After a loss of $17,800,000 from the sale of Singer's air conditioning and heating equipment division, a gain of $18,900,000 from bond repurchases, and income of $7,500,000 from the reduction of estimated liability related to business machines operations discontinued in 1975; results for the latest qr reflect a $10,000,000 pretax reduction in the reserve established in 1979 for restructuring of manuf facil in No Amer & Europe which was essentially compl '82

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 results are restated

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; net loss for the latest 4th qr reflects a pretax loss of $44.9 million from the sale of subsidiaries, a pretax gain of $9.1 million on the sale of an investment in an affiliate, a pretax provision of $80.8 million for resturctured operations and a pretax charge of $28.1 million from an early retirement program; results for the latest qr and yr reflect the adoption of a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Mary Martin: She's Still A Cockeyed Optimist
description: THE legendary Mary Martin, long the queen of the American musical theater, was in town on one of those brief, overscheduled trips involving personal appearances, parties and reams of carefully orchestrated publicity, the sort of celebratory madhouse accorded the especially beloved famous whose endorsement does wonders for whatever it touches.

title: ADMINISTRATION ISSUES TOUGHER PAROLE GUIDELINES
description: The Reagan Administration, having failed to get Congress to eliminate paroles for Federal prisoners, issued tough new parole guidelines today designed to keep violent criminals and drug offenders in prison longer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DANCE

title: DOLPHINS FAVORED BY 2 1/2 POINTS
description: The Miami Dolphins are a 2 1/2-point favorite to beat the Washington Redskins in the Super Bowl next Sunday, Harrah's Reno Race and Sports Book said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: ROBERT GRAVES. By Martin Seymour- Smith. 624 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Win- ston. $22.50.

title: CLUES TO SLAYING OF TEAMSTER ADVISER SOUGHT IN WIRETAP FROM TRIAL
description: Federal authorities investigating the slaying of Allen M. Dorfman outside Chicago Thursday are studying one of the wiretapped telephone conversations used as evidence against Mr. Dorfman and four others at their recent bribery conspiracy trial.

title: U.N. CHIEF SAID TO PLAN TRIP TO SOVIET ON AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will visit the Soviet Union in March and intends while there to make a fresh effort to win a withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan, Western diplomats said today.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $20,000 and includes an after-tax gain of $352,000from the sale of property...C-After securities gains of $1,000 and includes an after-tax gain of $1,586,000 from the sale of property; the earnings per shr for1981 have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd

title: Shepperd Strudwick Rites
description: A memorial service for Shepperd Strudwick will be held Friday at 11 A.M. at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. The actor died on Jan. 15 at the age of 75. The service is open to the public.

title: Reliance Has 5.71% Of Paine Webber
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, a subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., said yesterday that it had acquired 5.71 percent of Paine Webber Inc., the holding company that owns the Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. brokerage firm, as an investment.

title: Family Battery
description: The young man warming up Tom Seaver under the stands in Shea Stadium yesterday was one of the recent draft selections of the Montreal Expos: 21-year-old Jeff Wilpon of Palm Beach Junior College in Florida.

title: CITY FINDS LANDLORDS VIOLATE REQUIREMENT ON SMOKE DETECTORS
description: One year after a local law took effect requiring smoke detectors to be placed in individual apartments, about a third of the apartment buildings in the city are violating it, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Judge's Mother Testifies He Wanted to Cooperate
description: Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings began his defense today against bribery conspiracy charges with testimony from his mother that he wanted to cooperate with the Federal Bureau of Investigation when the man said to be his co-conspirator was arrested.

title: 1982 A BONANZA YEAR AT MOVIE BOX OFFICES
description: The results for 1982 are now in: The year was a box-office bonanza for movie makers. More than $3.4 billion worth of tickets were sold across the country, a box-office record. Records have been set in recent years because of increases in ticket prices. But the 1982 mark was 16 percent higher than the record set in 1981, while inflation of ticket prices was only 6.5 percent.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AMERICAN high schools are in disarray because the necessary policy decisions are being left unmade by so many - by local authorities, by state governments, the universities and the Federal Government. This charge is brought by Michael W. Kirst, professor of education at Stanford University and former president of the California State Board of Education, in a policy paper for the Institute for Research on Educational Finance and Governance at Stanford. The paper was prepared for the 1983 yearbook of the National Society for the Study of Education, to be published later in the spring.

title: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and yr do not reflect $4,900,000 in repair costs resulting from the shutdown of a nuclear power plant

title: Westinghouse
description: The United States Justice Department's antitrust section has objected to the planned takeover by the North American Philips Corporation of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's lamp business, a spokesman for NV Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken said. The spokesman said the department has instructed Westinghouse to seek another buyer for its 11 lamp-manufacturing plants by Feb. 18 because it believes such a takeover would distort competition. However, the department is likely to drop its objections if no other buyer can be found, the spokesman said.

title: Maltese Premier Wins A Libel Suit in Britain
description: Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta won a libel case in London's High Court today against a British newspaper that had said he intended to bulldoze the graves of British war dead.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Rector From Sotheby's

title: THE HART BUILDING: FOR $137.7 MILLION, NOT ENOUGH
description: Why is it that the Federal Government always seems to be 20 years behind the times when it comes to architecture? The Everett McKinley Dirksen Senate Office Building, finished in 1958, has, inside, the air of a commercial building of the late 1930's. Now comes the new Philip A. Hart Senate Office Building, into which the first handful of an eventual 50 senators and their staffs are moving, some with no great enthusiasm.

title: Poor Subsidy, Poor Schools
description: Lost Tax Dollars, and Fairness, From College Accounts

title: Whaler Coach Quits
description: The Hartford Whalers lost 15 of their last 18 games, set a team record by losing 10 road games in a row and put a lock on last place in the Adams Division of the National Hockey League. So it was not surprising yesterday when Larry Kish, the coach since last June, resigned. He will be replaced for the rest of the season by Larry Pleau, a former Whaler coach who is now the club's director of hockey operations. ... Don Lever, captain of the New Jersey Devils, who was struck in the temple with a puck Sunday night, was only stunned, the team said yesterday, and he is scheduled to play at left wing against the Flyers tonight. ... The Edmonton Oilers have sent Grant Fuhr, their all-star goaltender, to the Moncton Alpines of the American Hockey League.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Burnup & Sims
description: Burnup & Sims INc., a Fort Lauderdale-based telecommunications companuy, said it has been advised that San Diego County had canceled a contract valued at $25 million for the purchase, installation and maintenance of a new microwave telephone system. Gene Strul, a spokesman for Burnup & Sims, called the contract cancellation a "major occurrence," but said the company did not see it as a loss becuase it was "bound for litigation." He said that the company would not consider its impact until the courts ruled.

title: R.J. KUTAK, LEADER IN BAR ETHICS WORK, DIES
description: Robert J. Kutak, an Omaha lawyer who took a leading role in efforts to redefine the ethical obligations of the bar, died in Minneapolis Sunday after a heart attack. He was 50 years old.

title: STANDARD OIL CO (IND) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After nonrecurring refinery closing charges of $54,000,000...C-After refineryclosing charges of $23,000,000 a gain of $80,000,000 on the disposition of Cyprus Anvil Mining Corp and LIFO benefit of $71,000,000; results for 1982 include a$110,000,000 benefit from the drawdown of petroleum and chemical product inventories valued under the LIFO method

title: CENTRAL HUDSON GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5,292,000

title: Holiday Inns Account Is Subject of Rumors
description: In the arena of hotel promotion yesterday there was a possible decision and a certain decision. The former involved Holiday Inns and the latter the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bert Jones, the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback, underwent surgery yesterday to remove a ruptured cervical disk and fuse two vertebrae. Jones did not play after he was injured Nov. 21 in the fourth game of the season.

title: Arafat Says a P.L.O. Member Will Talk With Mrs. Thatcher
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that a representative of his group would go to London and meet Queen Elizabeth and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the group's press agency reported.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ONE A CELEBRITY AND ONE A RECLUSE
description: LOS ANGELES O ne quarterback in Super Bowl XVII is a Washington celebrity, the other a Miami recluse. Joe Theismann is often on display at his two restaurants in the nation's capital. He is also a radio disk jockey, has written a book, has appeared in a movie (''The Man With Bogart's Face''), and on a TV show (''B.J. and the Bear''), and he is always available to speak at functions.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Including a gain of $466,906 from the resturcturing of debt

title: Marietta Has Deficit
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced yesterday that it lost $2.4 million in the fourth quarter contrasted with net earnings of $38.6 million, or $1.08 a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales advanced to $940.3 million, from $860.5 million.

title: NORTHWEST BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN'S POLICIES LOSE FAVOR IN POLL
description: President Reagan will deliver his nationally televised State of the Union Message tonight at 9 o'clock By HOWELL RAINES

title: Loss at Falconbridge
description: Falconbridge Ltd. said yesterday that it had lost $85.3 million (Canadian) in 1982, much wider than the loss of $3.9 million in 1981, as a result of ''substantially lower'' nickel sales, as well as lower metal prices and higher costs. It cited expenses because of shutdowns at its Sudbury, Ontario, operation, a refinery in Norway, Falconbridge Dominicana, Falconbridge Copper's Lake Dufault division and United Keno Hill Mines Ltd. The Sudbury operation, the refinery and Falconbridge Dominicana have resumed production.

title: RECITAL: FAITH ESHAM, SOPRANO, SINGS AT TULLY HALL
description: AS a song recitalist, Faith Esham begins with a serious handicap. The art-song literature has a heavy proportion of pieces that call for the singer to bemoan his or her lost love or other impending tragedy. Miss Esham's program last night at Alice Tully Hall, where she gave a recital as one of four artists who shared the 1980 Naumburg Vocal Award, included the usual number of such sad songs. Now, it is entirely possible for a young, talented soprano with movie-star looks and an irrepresibly charming manner to persuade me that she is probing the lower layers of despair and melancholy, but that soprano has her work cut out for her. Nature has stacked the cards against her.

title: Trial as Adults Set In Conrail Derailing
description: Three 16-year-old youths accused of derailing a Conrail commuter train in Fair Lawn last July 7 that killed the engineer were ordered today to stand trial as adults in Superior Court.

title: GENERAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 figures restated for acquisitions of the Belleville National Bank

title: METHOD USED IN TAKING POLL
description: The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 16 through Jan. 19 with 1,597 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: AJINOMOTO, BUILT BY M.S.G., MOVES INTO BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: In addition to the four basic tastes, sweet, bitter, salty and sour, there is another that the Japanese call umami. ''It is delicious,'' said Katsuhiro Utada, president of the Ajinomoto Company. It has no English translation, but it is widely known by its chemical name: monosodium glutamate, or M.S.G.

title: Pact Reached on Defects in 4 Million G.M. Cars

The move will be effective Feb.1. Mr. Ruben, who is chairman and chief executive officer of the Jordan Marsh department stores, Miami, which is also an Allied division, succeeds Helen Galland, who has resigned as Bonwit's president.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pay What You Think
description: The President, as you know, has been exhorting all Americans to help get the Federal Government out of hock by reaching deeper into their pockets and doing more ''voluntarism.'' As usual, New Yorkers are leading the pack. The big banks here have decided that the way to get voluntarism off the ground is to make their tax contributions voluntary -that is, they will pay City Hall and Albany whatever they think they ought to pay, not what the tax laws say they should pay.

title: POUND HITS RECORD LOW AMID BLEAK OIL OUTLOOK
description: Weakened by both domestic and international pressures, the British pound fell almost 3 cents today to a record low against the dollar on the news that OPEC ministers, meeting in Geneva, had failed to reach agreement on oil production quotas and pricing.

title: KOCH ORDERS PANEL TO REVIEW TAX INCENTIVES FOR BUSINESSES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had ordered a study of city tax incentive programs for businesses, with the expectation that there would be a reduction in the available benefits.

title: Walsh to Stay
description: When his San Francisco 49ers, last year's Super Bowl champions, ended their season with a disappointing 3-6 record, Bill Walsh wondered if, perhaps, it was time to let someone else take over as head coach while he continued as general manager. On the other hand, he thought, maybe that wasn't such a good idea. Walsh debated with himself for several weeks. Yesterday, Walsh announced his decision: He will remain as the 49ers' coach.

If the fashion world is any indicator, t he answer seems to be any time, all the time - whenever, in fact, t hose who design clothes are in need of a little inspiration. For if a nything seems certain these days, it is that fashion cannot move f orward without first looking back.

title: IN PARIS, LONG, LEAN AND LIVELY

Most of the elite group of 23 designers who show made-to-order collections have moved their presentations out of their salons into hotels and exhibition halls, where the runways are longer, the music livelier and the mannequins are encouraged to prance and cavort instead of just looking sultry.

Mr. MacFarlane, who also had a home in Grosse Pointe, Mich., suffered a stroke two days before Christmas. He was 75 years old.

In addition, some local affiliates of PBS will be carrying the message, either live or as a taped delayed broadcast later in the evening.

The 1983 Porsche 911SC Cabriolet will cost $34,450. The last Porsche convertible sold in the United States was the 1965 Porsche 356SC Cabriolet.
