title: Hope for Streater
description: For Steve Streater, once a star defensive back for North Carolina, a promising professional football career came to a tragic end before it ever started. On his way back to school in April 1981, after signing a contract with the Washington Redskins, he was in an automobile wreck that left him paralyzed from the waist down. Doctors have told Streater it is unlikely he will ever walk again, but Streater, doubtful about the prognosis, applied for an experimental computerized therapy program operated by Dr. Gerald Petrofsky at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, and has been accepted.

description: In general, it is true that if a partnership planning to play a game contract can locate an eight-card fit in a major suit, it should not consider game in a minor. But like all useful bridge generalities, there are exceptions.

title: PART AIRSHIP, PART COPTER, ALL DEBATABLE
description: A 1,000-foot-long corrugated cocoon dominates the windswept flats of the Naval Air Engineering Center here. Inside, a colossal creature grows, one that is to emerge this summer, signaling what some people hope will be an important step in the rebirth of lighter-than-air transportation.

title: ADDICT'S BRAIN: CHEMISTRY HOLDS HOPE FOR ANSWERS
description: THERE is a minute blue spot in the human brain, a cluster of only several thousand cells, that has profound effects on the billions of other brain cells around and above it. This cluster of cells, called the locus coeruleus because of its blue tint, seems to be a key place where anxiety and fear take shape and where the painful sensations of withdrawal from narcotic drugs may have at least part of their origins. The locus has become a target of much scientific study because its activity offers clues to parts of the immense puzzle of the chemistry of the brain and the derangements of that chemistry caused by drugs. In recent years scientists have made giant strides in identifying a whole host of chemicals through which the brain acts in health and disease, in normality and in such aberrations as drug addiction. The focus of scientific attention is now on efforts to understand just how that multitude of different chemicals and nerve circuits actually do the brain's work - that most complex of biochemical performances in the panoply of life on earth.

title: BEYOND ECONOMIC ILLUSION
description: A serious strategy to end the recession will involve big outlays of Federal dollars and a comprehensive plan of action. The deficit will come down significantly when employment improves - at the rate of roughly $30 billion for each point, or a total of about $160 billion at 5.5 percent unemployment.

description: Fernando Valenzuela and the Los Angeles Dodgers established salary arbitration milestones yesterday, with Valenzuela submitting a salary figure of $1 million a year, and the Dodgers offering $750,000.

title: FRANK J. DOHERTY
description: Frank J. Doherty, who was an assistant press secretary to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1961-62, died last Friday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 50 years old and lived in Oakton, Va.

title: AN INN'S LESSON: IT'S NOT RUN BY POPOVERS ALONE
description: This is a story of New England country inns, of those who yearn to live, for a time, the country life, and of one family that made the transition from the suburban forefront of the American present to the back roads of the American past. There, they keep an inn, and offer others who have that dream a chance to try it on, to see if the reality is warm, or numbing in its routine.

title: GRATEFUL EMIGRES CONTRIBUTE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: ''Growing up in war-torn countries, we have been the recipients of American generosity. It is now our good fortune and our pleasure to return at least some of those favors.''

title: HIGH COURT BARS APPEAL ON BUSING BY NASHVILLE AND THE JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal from a school desegregation order in Nashville that entails the widespread busing of students from kindergarten through high school.

title: PAX AFRIKAANSA
description: Leaders of neighboring black states and resistance movements have a clear idea of what they believe to be South Africa's current strategy. In their analysis, it is to weaken their countries and make them submit to a kind of Pax Afrikaansa - enforcing permanent economic dependence and military vulnerability that will leave South Africa's regime unchallenged at home and easily dominant in the region. It would be like the Soviet Union's satellite-nation system.

title: First Chicago Earnings Rise
description: The First Chicago Corporation announced yesterday record fourthquarter operating earnings. Earnings before security transactions increased 15 percent, to $41.8 million, or 96 cents a share, compared with $36.4 million for the fourth quarter of 1981.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Including pretax gains of $96 million for the qr and $98 million for the yr on the sale of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp common stock, a pretax provision of $90 million for the qr and yr for restructuring costs and net equity in earnings of associated companies of $3.5 million for the qr and $25.7 million for the yr;C-After a pretax provision of $11.3 million for the qr and yr for restructuing costs and net equity in earnings of associated companies of $12 million for the qr and $50.37 million for the yr

title: RANGERS ARE FOILED BY PEETERS AGAIN
description: The Boston Bruins demonstrated again last night why they have the best record in the National Hockey League. They dominated the Rangers in a 3-1 triumph at Madison Square Garden.

title: Marino-Express Talks
description: Saying ''There's no way I can get the same kind of money in the N.F.L.,'' Dan Marino, the University of Pittsburgh quarterback, opened negotiations with the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League. ''I think the U.S.F.L. is credible, with the type of coaches they have from the N.F.L. and from Canada,'' he said.

title: In the Soup
description: Folk wisdom insists that if it's fun, it must be illegal, immoral or fattening. In the case of Michael Deaver, the White House aide, folk wisdom is two-thirds correct.

title: JETS GIVE CREDIT TO DOLPHINS' DEFENSE
description: Sunday night, after the Dolphins defeated the Jets in the American Conference championship game, 14-0, Richard and Lulu Todd went out to dinner with Bob Baumhower. Todd is the Jets' quarterback. Baumhower is the Dolphins' nose tackle. They have been friends since the early 1970's, when they played for the University of Alabama. Now they are partners in a restaurant in Fort Lauderdale.

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains of $1,702,000 from a cumulative effect of an accounting changeand $17,497,000 from an extraordinary item

title: RALLY BY ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS VILLANOVA
description: Down by 8 points with 12 minutes to go, St. John's kept its poise and came back steadily to defeat Villanova, 80-71, last night before a record crowd of 6,461 at Alumni Hall.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued air freight forwarding operations of $3.7 million for the qr and $14.9 million for the yr...C-Including a gain of $3.6 million from discontinued operations and a gain of $102.2 million on the sale of Burlington Northern Air Freignt Inc; yr-ago results have been restated for comparability

title: Valentine, Angels Agree
description: Ellis Valentine, the Met outfielder who became a free agent after the 1982 season, has concluded an agreement with the California Angels. He is expected to take over the right-field position held last year by Reggie Jackson, who is becoming the team's designated hitter in place of Don Baylor, recently acquired by the Yankees.

title: Advertising; Marsteller Sports Car Campaign
description: SURE, the gambling is fun, but what this country's 125 Alfa Romeo dealers will really be doing on Paradise Island Thursday is learning about the new advertising campaign that is scheduled to break next Monday.

title: DIGITAL ALSO OFF
description: The Hughes Tool Company reported yesterday that the sharp drop in domestic oil drilling caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 to plunge 83.7 percent and sales to decline by 29.4 percent.

title: FOR CALDWELL, PUTTER STILL HIS NEMESIS
description: P utting is not the strongest part of Rex Caldwell's golf game, and he considers that the reason he has not won a tournament in his nine years on tour. In 1978, after he three-putted his way out of a chance to win the Hawaiian Open, he went home to practice putting for a week, dawn to dusk. Later he was often in contention, particularly in the 1979 P.G.A. championship.

title: SECURITY TIGHT AS JURY SELECTION BEGINS AT TRIAL OF EX-C.I.A. AGENT
description: Tight security arrangments were imposed today as jury selection began in the trial of Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency employee charged with smuggling 20 tons of restricted plastic explosives to Libya in 1977.

title: THE DANCE: WORKS BY BALANCHINE
description: IN some unusually well-danced performances over the weekend at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet offered works by George Balanchine that ranged from exquisite miniatures to jolly festivities. It was a fitting program, since Saturday was Mr. Balanchine's 79th birthday.

title: HUGHES TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Express International Bank Corp. will issue 100 million Swiss francs of bonds due in 1993 on the Swiss market through Soditic S.A. Coupon and issue price are to be set Jan. 28.

title: SOO LINE RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gastineau Suffers The Pain of Defeat
description: MIAMI T he last time Mark Gastineau raised his arms while wearing his green Jet jersey this season, he was not standing over a fallen quarterback and milking a personal moment of triumph. He was standing in the middle of a quiet dressing room on Sunday afternoon, after the Jets had lost the American Conference championship game to the Miami Dolphins, and slowly raising each arm so that the tape could be cut from the end of his sleeves.

title: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC: JULLIARD CONCERTS
description: THE most noticeable thing about two concerts in the Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music Saturday night and Sunday afternoon is how far from a ''festival'' they seemed. Though tickets were given away for unclaimed seats, the Juilliard Theater seemed at least half empty. ''Contemporary music'' still exists in a professional world that most listeners hardly notice, relegated to a sparsely attended ''festival'' rather than to everyday experience.

title: APPRAISING THE APPLE IIe
description: LAST week Apple Computer Inc. stopped making the tremendously popular Apple II Plus and immediately started the assembly lines running again to crank out the Apple IIe. The company had added a letter to the name, removed a lot of pieces from the computer, and came up with two questions: Will it sell? And should you as a consumer consider buying one? The answer to both is a definitive ''maybe.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airborne Freight Corp., Seattle, has named Hal D. McClellan vice president of personnel and labor relations. * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected Joseph E. Maroun a vice president.

title: ENERGY FUTURES PLUNGE AFTER OPEC TALKS FAIL
description: Energy futures prices plunged yesterday along with the cash market for heating oil and gasoline. The sharp break came after the latest meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended in disarray, thus raising the prospect that exporters would continue to ignore price and production guidelines.

title: GIBRALTAR SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $14.6 million from the sale of branch offices...C-Net loss

title: CHARTERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MX ISN'T ISSUE NO. 1
description: A debate is raging in this country over how to cope with the Russians. We need to sort out what the argument is really about before we get lost in the swamp of debating whether or not to build the MX and how to base it.

title: RURAL 'COLONELS' OF BRAZIL: THEIR POWER NEVER DIES
description: Smoothing the wrinkles in his white cotton suit and righting the droop in the brim of his straw hat, Jose Abilio de Albuquerque Avila would provide a set answer for those who speculated that the hinterland power brokers like him, known in Brazil as ''colonels,'' were losing their influence.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHELL MISSES SITE OF LEBANON TALKS
description: A Katyusha rocket exploded today next to the seaside hotel where American, Lebanese and Israeli negotiators had gathered for the latest round of their talks.

title: GAS SERVICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Chess: Sometimes Even the Finest Play as if They're Dreaming
description: There are days when nothing goes right. It's not a matter of making an outright careless blunder so much as being unable to get into the game.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Search for Gladys Miller

title: Bendix-Fiat Deal
description: The Bendix Corporation's president, Frederick Searby, said Bendix would pay more than $30 million in cash for its previously announced acquisition of a 30 percent equity interest in Fiat S.p.A.'s Comau S.p.A. unit. Bendix and Comau also agreed to establish a joint venture in the United States that will be managed and 90 percent owned by Bendix. He said the company, which will assemble and distribute flexible-manufacturing machine systems, is expected to have annual sales of $75 million in the first year. Mr. Searby also said Bendix had ''other deals in the works but not as large as this one.''

title: GETTY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHIEF
description: Both sides presented their summations yesterday in the extortion trial of the Yonkers Democratic Party chairman, Angelo Grippo, who is charged with obtaining cash payoffs from a toy-store company.

title: No Headline
description: Ford Plans Recall Of 900 Workers

title: G.O.P. Chief Quits In Connecticut
description: Ralph E. Capecelatro, Connecticut's Republican state chairman the last three years, announced today that he would resign effective Feb. 22.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARCO DECLINES 7.6%
description: Two major oil companies, the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Atlantic Richfield Company, reported depressed fourth-quarter earnings yesterday. Both blamed the weak market for oil and gas resulting from the recession and conservation.

title: 2 Kenyans to Be Tried On Charges of Treason
description: The assistant editor of The Sunday Standard, a Nairobi newspaper, and the son of former Vice President Oginga Odinga were ordered to stand trial today on charges of treason and plotting to overthrow the Government.

title: JUSTICES GRANT A STAY OF EXECUTION FOR TEXAS CONVICT NEARING DOOM
description: The Supreme Court granted a last-minute stay of execution today to a condemned Texas murderer and agreed to a full review of both the procedure for Federal courts to handle death penalty appeals and of some aspects of the man's death sentence.

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income which includes an extraordinary credit of $10,800,000 for the qr and yr; for the yr 1982 Phelps Dodge obtained $36,300,000 from the sale of tax benefits

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Saturday on fourth-quarter earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation reported two figures incorrectly. Revenue rose 23.1 percent in the quarter. The company said that an accounting change for foreign-currency translations increased earnings 11.3 percent.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: FEW people die of nosebleeds. But it can happen. When Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, had 11 blood transfusions last week, then returned to the operating room to stop a nosebleed, many people learned just how serious this common condition can be.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3.6 million on an insurance settlement, a gain of $1.3 million from the sale of oil and gas interests and a charge of $4.1 million for the discontinuation of the solvents business and transfer of certain research developments and plastics division management personnel

title: SMITHSONIAN REGENTS AFFIRM THEIR CLOSED-MEETING POLICY
description: The regents of the Smithsonian Institution today reaffirmed their custom of barring the public and the press from their meetings.

title: BERKLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Semiconductor Accord
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation and the Standard Microsystems Corporation said today that they had signed an agreement covering the cross-licensing of each other's patents.

title: Article 187658 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: MORO'S KILLERS AMONG 32 JAILED FOR LIFE IN ITALY
description: An Italian jury sentenced 32 members of the Red Brigades to life prison terms today for the kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro and other crimes.

title: The Namibian Albatross
description: To justify its illegal occupation of Namibia, South Africa has long maintained that it was staying on to protect the cause of pluralism against leftist usurpers - and particularly to advance a genuine grass-roots party called the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance. That argument collapsed last week, however, when South Africa dissolved the alliance's grip on power in Namibia, treating Dirk Mudge, the alliance leader, as a disposable puppet.

title: GUARDED BY AK-47's, SANDINISTS TAKE TO THE FIELDS
description: In the state-owned plantation El Limon, a mile from Nicaragua's border with Honduras, Sandinist soldiers carrying AK-47 assault rifles patrolled the shaded hillside where young volunteers were busily picking coffee beans.

title: ELLIS BANKING CORP (BRADENTON, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNICKS WIN BY 33 BEFORE 6,514 AT GARDEN
description: The Knicks opened the second half of their disappointing season with their easiest victory of the season. They overwhelmed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 111-78, last night before a crowd of 6,514, the smallest since the current Madison Square Garden opened in February 1968.

title: Auxiliary Bishop Named for Newark
description: The Vatican today appointed a 61-year-old priest to be an auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

title: Big East Promotion
description: If Billy Packer and Al McGuire have their way, it will be the Big East against the rest of the United States in a new all-star basketball game for college seniors. The game, of which Packer and McGuire would be promoters, would be held each spring at Syracuse's Carrier Dome.

title: More U.S. Farm-Export Aid Pledged
description: The United States will press its campaign to end European Economic Community subsidies of farm exports, which take markets away from economically depressed American farmers, two Administration officials told Congress today.

title: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income, the sales for the latest fourth qr and yr include results from U.S. Steel's recently acquired Marathon Oil Co unit

title: HYDROGEN LEAK FORCES SECOND SPACE SHUTTLE DELAY
description: Another hydrogen leak detected in a second test firing of the space shuttle Challenger's main engines will delay its launching at least several weeks, a top space agency official said today.

title: Bridge: The Judge Was Surprised, But His Wife Knew Better
description: The career of a bridge player follows a progression rather like that of a lawyer. He begins by being hungry, tricky and aggressive and winds up with great experience and mature judgment. This reflection is prompted by a man who follows both paths: Judge Burrell Ives Humphreys of New Jersey Superior Court in Paterson.

title: Home Resales Low Last Year
description: Despite increases over the last four months, resales of single-family houses dropped last year to the lowest level in more than a decade, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Frances Cole, Music Teacher, Dies at 45
description: Frances Cole, a harpsichordist and teacher, died in her New York apartment Monday afternoon after a long illness. She was 45 years old.

title: 3 Youths Arraigned In Jersey Derailing
description: Three 16-year-old youths facing trial as adults on charges of derailing a commuter train and killing the engineer were arraigned today in State Superior Court.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'ZERO' MAY MEAN NOTHING
description: In explaining the dismissal of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency director, Eugene V. Rostow, and the reported reprimand of the negotiator on intermediate-range nuclear forces, Paul H. Nitze, apparently for taking his job too seriously, the Reagan Administration has made one fact clear. Those responsible for strategic nuclear policy still believe that more American nuclear weapons, rather than fewer Soviet missiles, mean greater security.

title: HUBBELL, HARVEY, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harmless Cyanide Level Found in Town's Water
description: Harmless traces of cyanide were found today in the water supply here, while a continuing rash of anonymous threats prompted the officials to turn off the taps in four more Louisiana towns.

title: British Water Workers Reject Pay Offer
description: Talks on ending Britain's first national water workers strike broke down today and 6 million Britons were told they would probably have to keep boiling their water at least until the end of the week.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MIDTOWN SOUTH: A LOWER-RENT REFUGE FOR BUSINESSES
description: For the last three years, a commercial revitalization has been under way in what is called Midtown South. Its boundaries, which have been expanding with the spread of redevelopment, are roughly from the 30's to the teens and from Fifth Avenue to Lexington Avenue, according to brokers active in the area.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOLEDO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $10,807,000 for the qr and yr on the exchange of debt for equity

title: FRANKLIN FITS IN CZONKA MOLD
description: Coach Don Shula still has fond memories of Larry Csonka, the big fullback of the Miami Dolphins' Super Bowl teams in the early 1970's.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ARMS PROPOSALS OFFER HOPE, U.N. CHIEF SAYS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who warned in September that the world was on the brink of anarchy, said today that ''the atmosphere is improving'' because of Soviet-American efforts at curbing nuclear weapons.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: EVER since childhood I have had a particular fondness for pork. It doesn't really matter in what manner it is prepared as long as it is prepared well. I also love winter vegetables, things like cabbage and turnips and rutabaga, carrots and beets.

title: COMMERCIAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOCAL OFF 25.6%
description: Weakened by sagging demand and lower oil prices, the Exxon Corporation's net income rose 6.9 percent in the fourth quarter, while that of the Standard Oil Company of California skidded 25.6 percent, the companies reported yesterday.

title: FOREMOST-MCKESSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from disocntinued operations of $550,000 for the qr and $5 million for the 9 mos...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the qr and $6.1 million for the 9 mos

title: GREAT LAKES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
M.T.A. NEGOTIATORS TRY TO AVOID A U.S. PENALTY
description: Negotiations were under way here today to try to keep the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from having to pay millions of dollars in penalty duties on the subway cars it has ordered from a Canadian company.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted; results for the latest qr and 9 mos have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52; all results reflectthe acquisition of Capex Corp on a pooling of interests basis

title: Carlotta Reiner, Actress, 84; Was the Conductor's Widow
description: Carlotta Reiner, widow of the conductor Fritz Reiner, died at her home in Weston, Conn., on Monday.

title: Puzzling Booms Jolt Jersey Again
description: Windows and dishes rattled in homes along the Jersey Shore for the second straight day today, and puzzled officials said the tremors might have been caused by sonic booms.

title: Oil Shock in Reverse
description: The OPEC countries, for the fourth time in recent months, have failed to agree on the price of oil and suddenly everyone seems alarmed that it may drop. Why, in heaven's name? Lower oil prices would not be an undiluted blessing. But if this third, reverse oil shock occurs it should be welcomed, not feared.

title: ABORTION OPPOSITION STRESSED IN KIDNAPPING TRIAL IN ILLINOIS
description: The attorney for a man on trial in the abduction of a doctor who performed abortions in nearby Granite City has made his client's opposition to abortion a central part of the defense.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARSH & MCLENNAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SELLING THE U.S. POPCORN HABIT IN BRITAIN
description: Popcorn, which was enjoyed by the Pilgrims at the Thanksgiving feast at Plymouth, should no longer be regarded merely as Yankee junk food, the United States Government maintains.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL SECURITIES & RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a pretax gain of $2,300,000 from the sale of a minority owned subsidiary

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: Glenn Gets a Boost

title: Waiting for Henry
description: The Reagan Administration has good reason, as it says, to be ''extremely concerned'' about the slow pace at which Israel negotiates the terms of its withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: LAGERFELD GUIDES CHANEL INTO 80'S
description: The day belonged to Karl Lagerfeld, though there was plenty of other excitement on the couture fashion scene as the spring and summer openings here continued. The German-born designer, who has been living in Paris since he was in his teens, had dared to tackle the House of Chanel - a national monument with which one does not trifle. Mr. Lagerfeld didn't trifle.

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EVANGELIST'S 'CATHEDRAL' LOSES TAX EXEMPTION
description: When Orange County's Crystal Cathedral opened in 1980, a local music critic wrote, ''People in glass houses should not give concerts.'' He was complaining about poor acoustics in the huge glass-walled church here designed by the architect Philip Johnson. But, unwittingly, he was anticipating a complaint filed against the church recently by California tax officials.

title: THE DANCE: BASEL BALLET MAKES AMERICAN DEBUT
description: THE up-and-coming young ballet company in Europe, it has been rumored, is the Basel Ballet from Switzerland and last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music it made a fresh-as-a-daisy American debut.

title: Massachusetts Tannery Charged in Waste Case
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a Massachusetts leather company and four of its officials today on criminal charges of illegally storing and disposing of hazardous wastes.

title: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
South Africa Prepares For New Angola Talks
description: South Africa said tonight that preparatory negotiations would be held this week to pave the way for further talks with Angola on an independence settlement in South-West Africa.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHIEF OF DEMOCRATS FOR YONKERS FOUND GUILTY OF EXTORTION
description: Angelo Grippo, the Democratic Party chairman in Yonkers, was convicted last night of participating in the extortion of $12,000 from a chain of toy stores.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently reread the novel ''Our Mutual Friend'' by Charles Dickens and paused over the sentence, ''No supper did Miss Potterson take that night, and only half her usual tumbler of hot Port Negus.'' I trust that negus is a drink but have never heard of it otherwise. Are you familiar with it?

title: Cuomo Denies Bid In Schumer Case
description: Governor Cuomo has rejected a request to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate charges that Representative Charles E. Schumer illegally used State Assembly personnel and money in his 1980 House race, a Cuomo spokesman said yesterday.

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After the favorable effects of LIFO adjustments resulting from an inventory reduction program begun mid-yr and accelerated during the qr; results for the latest qr benefitted from an advance sale of uranium which provided a net gain to Union Carbide of $22,500,000

title: Peter Sellars Drops Out Of 'My One and Only'
description: Peter Sellars, who was to direct ''My One and Only,'' the new musical starring Tommy Tune and Twiggy, left the production yesterday in Boston, where it is to open a pre-Broadway tryout Feb. 3. No replacement has been named, but one of the producers said it was ''possible'' that Mr. Tune, who directed the Broadway hit ''Nine,'' might take over.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Movie Director Gets Them To the Court on Time

title: CHARGES FILED AFTER STUDENT IS FORCE-FED
description: A public-school teacher and a teacher's aide face a hearing Feb. 8 in Harris County Criminal Court on charges of injuring a child by using force to feed a 9-year-old boy who refused to finish his school lunch. School officials insist those involved were following proper policy.

title: I.B.M. to Offer Robot System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was introducing a computer-controlled robotic system that can perform a variety of industrial operations.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST REFLECT CONCERNS ABOUT CHILDREN
description: When tragedy strikes children, a special compassion is felt by many who are not directly affected, and contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often reflect that feeling.

title: NEW YORK COMMISSONER PROPOSES STARTING CHILDREN IN SCHOOL AT AGE 4
description: New York State's Education Commissioner said today that his department was beginning to study a plan to start children in school at age 4 and have them graduate after completing the 11th grade.

title: CHINA REPORTS BIRTH OF PANDA
description: China disclosed today the birth of another panda in captivity and said the orphaned cub has received round-theclock attention in a children's hospital and in a first-class army ward for the first five months of its life.

title: DOCTORS STILL HOPEFUL DESPITE NOSEBLEEDS IN HEART PATIENT
description: A medical spokesman said yesterday that Dr. Barney B. Clark's continuous nosebleeds had brought him a serious setback but that doctors were encouraged by other aspects of the artificial heart case.

title: FESTIVAL: NEW MUSIC AT JUILLIARD
description: THE Juilliard School's Festival of Contemporary Music went out with a bang last night, although the last concert in this annual series was mostly given over to whimpers. Eleazar de Carvalho conducted the Juilliard Symphony in an ultimately riotous performance of Almeida Prado's ''Aurora'' (1975) that succeeded in raising a great deal of dust, if not much more than passing musical interest.

title: A Freeway Named Desire
description: LOS ANGELES B ack in drama class, our professor used to say the best theater came when somebody was trying to do something and somebody else was trying to stop it. It sounds pretty simple, but that's exactly what this Super Bowl needs - a little drama.

title: EDWARD ELLSBERG, NAVAL SALVAGE EXPERT, DIES
description: Edward Ellsberg, a naval salvage expert whose daring exploits in raising vessels from the bottom of the sea captured the public imagination between the two world wars, died Monday of cancer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 91 years old and had lived for the last three decades in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has named Joe L. Miller, president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman.

title: Frank Stiffel Is Winner Of Editors' Book Award
description: ''The Tale of the Ring: A Kaddish'' by Frank Stiffel, a memoir of the concentration camps in Treblinka and Auschwitz, has won the second annual Editors' Book Award, established by Pushcart Press to recognize unpublished books of special literary quality and significance. The winner was selected from 82 manuscripts nominated by editors in 42 publishing houses.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Vacant President's Post Filled at Midland Glass
description: The Midland Glass Company, a leading maker of glass bottles for the beer and soft-drink industry, has named Franklin E. Whitmore president and chief operating officer.

title: BLACKS IN CHICAGO PRESS VOTING DRIVE
description: Thomas Johnson walked into the community center at East Park Shore, a predominantly black neighborhood about five miles south of the Loop, and asked voting registrars if he was properly registered to vote in the Democratic mayoral primary on Feb. 22. Told that he was, Mr. Johnson said, ''I thought so, but since this is the last day to register I just wanted to make sure.''

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a gain of $660,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of assets and an extraordinary gain of $260,000 for the qr and 6 mos on debt restructuring...C-After a gain of $303,000 on the sale of securities

title: Benefits for the Child
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: With respect to ''Mothers Who Shift Back From Jobs to Homemaking'' (Jan. 19), one must think of the psychic rewards for the child and not just for the mother when that child is mothered by one who is enjoying that role. For mothers as well as for anyone else, some time and interests of one's own are crucial for a satisfying life style.

description: The Buffalo Savings Bank, which plans to change its name next week to the Goldome Bank, has reached into the Marine Midland organization for a new president and chief operating officer.

description: The Cuomo administration will propose the use of up to $200 million dollars in bonds from a state economic development agency to build new prison cells around the state, key administration aides said today.

title: HAYES IS FINED BY CLUB
description: The Nets' three-game swing through Texas got off to an inauspicious beginning tonight as they were beaten, 114-111, by the Houston Rockets, the team at the bottom of the league.

SEAVER AND TORREZ: 'NEW' ERA FOR METS
description: Mike Torrez and Tom Seaver made their first appearance together at Shea Stadium yesterday as the two newest and oldest pitchers on the Mets, and accepted their roles as senior models for a young staff. But Torrez conceded that he still carried the mental scar of the home run that Bucky Dent hit against him in Fenway Park for the Yankees in the 1978 playoff game.

MCCRAY BROTHERS EXCEL FOR LOUISVILLE
description: Rodney McCray was the quintessential younger brother. He moved when Scooter said move, played ball when Scooter said play, and, he says, ''since he never led me anywhere I wasn't supposed to be, I followed when he led.''

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 26, 1983
description: International Revised Roman Catholic canon laws were signed by Pope John Paul II. They incorporate many of the changes brought about by the Second Vatican Council, the historic ecumenical meeting that was held in the 1960's under the auspices of Pope John XXIII. The code will not officially take effect until Nov. 27, but most of the changes have been put into practice by Roman Catholics around the world. (Page A1, Column 3.) A Turk wanted in Italy for complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II says he has never met the man who shot the Pope in 1981. But the suspect, Bekir Celenk, said in Sofia, Bulgaria, that he had been in Bulgaria at the same time that Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting the Pope, was reportedly there. Unconfirmed Italian newspaper reports have said that Mr. Celenk offered Mr. Agca $1.25 million in German marks on behalf of the Bulgarian secret service to shoot the Pope. (A1:1.)

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After reductions of $32,100,000 for the qr and $82,900,000 for the yr from the unfavorable impact of foreign exchange

title: A Matter of Grades
description: Ozell Jones had a 2.38 high school average when physical education courses were included, and a 1.59 when they were not. Since the National Collegiate Athletic Association requires freshman athletes to have had at least a 2.0 average in high school, his old school obligingly used the higher average when Jones entered Wichita State on a basketball scholarship in 1979.

title: Bolivia Is Reported to Seize Barbie, a Nazi War Criminal
description: A convicted Nazi war criminal, Klaus Barbie, was arrested by the police today and taken to a prison here, sources close to Mr. Barbie said.

title: Criticism of Knight
description: Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo of Puerto Rico has written a second letter to the United States Olympic Committee protesting the selection of Bobby Knight as the coach of the United States' 1984 basketball team. Knight has not been popular in Puerto Rico since an altercation during the 1979 Pan American Games that led to his conviction, in absentia, of assaulting a Puerto Rican policeman.

title: Breakers Seek Patriot
description: Andy Johnson, the New England Patriot running back, may become the second National Football League player to jump to the United States Football League. Officials of the Boston Breakers said yesterday that they were ''close'' to signing Johnson, who was one of the dissidents in a seasonlong dispute with Ron Meyer, the Patriots' rookie head coach. Stan White, the Detroit Lion linebacker, became the first active N.F.L. player to jump to the new league, by signing with the Chicago Blitz. ... Chuck Studley, the San Francisco 49ers' defensive coordinator, has resigned to take a similar job at Houston.

title: TV: 'RUNNING OUT' ON 'G.E. THEATER'
description: ''RUNNING OUT'' should have been called ''Dragging On.'' This ''G.E. Theater'' offering tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS stretches a slight tale to an excruciating two hours, like a kid tormenting a piece of chewing gum long after it has lost all flavor.

title: THREE M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $7 million from an exchange of stock for bonds

title: William H. Daniels, Ex-Judge; Was U.S. Spy in World War II
description: Former Judge William Hawk Daniels, who served as a spy behind German lines in World War II, has died. He was 68 years old.

title: China to Free 15 Vietnamese
description: China will release 11 captured Vietnamese soldiers and 4 convicted Vietnamese spies on Feb. 5 so they can return to their families for Tet, the Lunar New Year, the official New China News Agency reported today. Vietnam announced earlier that it would release 35 Chinese captives for the holiday, which falls on Feb. 13 this year.

title: News Analysis
description: The revised code of Roman Catholic canon law, which brings the church's law into line with the teaching of the Second Vatican Council, represents an attempt by the hierarchy to modify the role of legal statutes in a church sometimes seen in the past as too concerned with rules.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S STATE OF THE UNION MESSAGE TO THE NATION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's State of the Union Message delivered to Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Jets Find Success Has Drawbacks
description: The New York Jets' fine showing this season has given them an unenviable position in the college draft -they will choose 24th in the 28-team league - and it also has placed the Dallas Cowboys ahead of them in the draft for the first time since 1969.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: D'Amato Plans Ahead

title: Economic Scene; Deficit-Cutters Vs. Tolerators
description: THIS is the time of year when - with the State of the Union Message, the Budget Message and the Economic Report of the President all coming toether in a rush - the Great Communicator must become the Great Bookkeeper. At this point, the public might welcome a guide on the economic consequences of major actions to cut the big budget deficit versus accepting the deficit in a time of high unemployment as a necessary or even a desirable thing.

title: DONOVAN ACCUSER SETTLES CASE AGAINST HIS UNION FOR $65,000
description: A laborer who charged that his union had prevented him from getting work because of his criticism of its hiring practices received $65,000 yesterday in a settlement negotiated by the city's Human Rights Commission.

title: EASTERN AIR HAS PROFIT
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. today reported a fourthquarter profit of $12.2 million, in contrast to a loss of $26.7 million for the last period of 1981, mainly as a result of a $20.2 million increase in the sale of tax benefits. Revenues in the latest quarter increased 5 percent, to $937.4 million, from $892.6 million.

title: Con Ed Rises 19% in Quarter
description: The Consoldidated Edison Company of New York yesterday announced a sharp increase in both net income and revenue for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Say They Downed a Copter
description: Leftist guerrillas said today that they had shot down an air force helicopter, captured a village in northern Chalatenango Province and kept Government forces pinned down in eastern Morazan Province.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: MARK L. LEVINE looked at his wristwatch one day, and suddenly two thoughts flashed through his mind. The first was that the watch was an unnecessary weight on his arm, another of life's minor irritants. The second was that being aware of the time didn't get him anywhere more quickly. The logic of these conclusions was so irrefutable that he stopped wearing a watch.

title: 2 YEARS OF LOSSES AT HARLEY-DAVIDSON
description: When Vaughn Beals led a buy-out of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company from AMF Inc. in 1981, the numbers seemed promising. Harley-Davidson, beneficiary of the leather jacket/big bike mystique and the only American company to manufacture motorcycles since 1948, had recorded pretax earnings the year before of $12.3 million on record sales of $289 million.

title: KOCH TARGETS: FROM BRITAIN TO BANKS
description: What do Britain, Saudi Arabia, President Reagan's policies, the stock market, Albany, doctors, lawyers, bankers, contractors, unions and landlords have in common?

description: O f the 512 games played in the National Hockey League through Monday night, only 15 had been shutouts, and seven had been registered by Pete Peeters, the Boston Bruins goalie.

title: Marcolino Candau, 71, Former W.H.O. Chief
description: Dr. Marcolino G. Candau, retired Director General of the United Nations World Health Organization, died here Monday of cancer at the age of 71.

title: RECESSION'S WORST-HIT AREAS
description: As the recession winds down, the statistical indicators are telling a tale of an economy that, broadly speaking, suffered less in the period since July 1981 than during the 1974-75 recession, the worst since World War II. But by some narrower measures, the toll that the latest downturn has taken on an already battered economy has been much worse.

title: High Court Ruling Sought on Asbestos
description: The Keene Corporation, the GAF Corporation and Pacor Inc., which together face thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits, have asked the United States Supreme Court to strike down Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland's order allowing the cases to go forward even though the Manville Corporation - their co-defendant and the world's largest asbestos manufacturer - is in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Kaiser to Curtail Aluminum Output
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced that it would close two aluminum production lines at its Chalmette, La., plant, and gradually curtail production of reduction grade alumina at its Baton Rouge, La., facility.

title: BAN ON PRIOR RESTRAINT IS NOT WITHOUT COST
description: To the Editor:

title: BABY, YOU'RE THE GREATEST
description: IT was a bitter January morning in Gotham, just the kind of Siberian day when Alice Kramden and Trixie Norton used to linger over their coffee cups on the set of ''The Honeymooners'' as Ralph and Ed headed out into the cold, cruel city, muttering about how sweet it wasn't.

title: Exclusionary-Rule Fight Moves to Supreme Court
description: Must criminals invariably be set free when the evidence of their guilt has been obtained through unconstitutional searches and seizures?

title: Hutton's Profit Rises 72.9%
description: The E.F. Hutton Group Inc., the investment banking and brokerage concern, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 72.9 percent, to a record $40.8 million, or $2.13 a share, from $23.6 million, or $1.27 a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Outside Director Picked As Republic Chairman
description: The Republic Corporation, the big Los Angeles company with interests in several industries, has named Irving Mitchell Felt as its chairman.

description: ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT BANKS. By John A. Cook and Robert Wool. 229 pages. Bantam hardcover. $13.95.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOK OF JAZZ

title: BIG MEN OF MEMPHIS GO TO THE BIG CITY
description: They sat hunched over their trays, their long legs tucked under the small tables and their identity unknown to the lunchtime crowd that filled the fast-food restaurant on Seventh Avenue.

title: Ruling Keeps May a Yankee
description: Rudy May, who never really left, returned to the Yankees yesterday. The Player Relations Committee, which represents the owners; and the league presidents, Lee MacPhail of the American and Charles Feeney of the National, voided the selection of May by the Chicago White Sox in the free-agent compensation draft held last Thursday. They agreed with the Major League Baseball Players Association and Richard Moss, May's lawyer, that the pitcher should have been on the Yankees' protected list, and thus not eligible for selection, because he had a no-trade provision in his contract.

title: Student Is a Suicide
description: A 23-year-old part-time student at the Fashion Institute of Technology yesterday committed suicide by hanging herself from the roof of the school's administration building, the police said.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN RY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEMORABLE RE-CREATIONS OF RESTAURANT FAVORITES
description: THERE are times when Pierre Franey and I, having sampled a dish in a restaurant, will attempt to reproduce it at home. These endeavors tend to have an especially gratifying quality; I think it comes both from the sense of accomplishment that results when using your own judgment in the kitchen and having the dish come out properly and from being able to duplicate a well remembered experience. If the meal in the restaurant was uncommonly good, I find that I become almost nostalgic when I successfully re-create it in my kitchen.

title: Team America Has Field of 39
description: Nine members of the Cosmos were among the 39 players invited yesterday to attend the first training camp of Team America, the Washington-based franchise that will compete in the North American Soccer League this season. The team will be made up of 20 players who are United States citizens and have never played for another country.

title: ALL THE COMFORTS OF A MILITARY HOSPITAL
description: A few years ago, Senator John C. Stennis was shot twice and critically wounded by young assailants. As an ambulance team prepared to rush him to a university hospital in downtown Washington, he groggily mumbled: ''Please take me to Walter Reed.''

title: Advertising; A.A.F. Sets National Awards
description: WITH the promise of reasonable entry fees and good judging, the American Advertising Federation yesterday jumped into the national advertising awards arena, a place of frequent controversy.

title: 3 Found Guilty Of Slaying Officer
description: Three Queens men were convicted yesterday of killing an off-duty police officer as he came to the aid of his father-in-law in a robbery attempt.

title: ART: MET RAISES CURTAIN ON TREASURES OF VATICAN
description: ''THE Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art'' at the Metropolitan Museum does not open to the general public until Feb. 26. But as of today, it will be open six days a week to those Members of the Museum who have taken up the offer of tickets. It will also be open in the evening to the guests of one or more of the many organizations that have made special arrangements with the Met. In one way and another, more than 100,000 people will see the exhibition in the next few weeks. It is for this reason that it is being reviewed here today. There will be further coverage at the time of the general opening.

title: MACCHIAROLA OFFERS PLAN TO AVERT LAYOFFS
description: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday afternoon proposed a plan to prevent the threatened layoff of 1,800 New York City schoolteachers and cuts in busing for pupils in kindergarten through the fourth grade. The plan, which was approved last night by the Board of Education, would raise the price of a school lunch by 5 cents and end the use of bus passes for many fifth and sixth graders.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: FASHIONS come and go with dizzying rapidity in the competitive, pressurized world of rock-and-roll, and at the moment few styles are more unfashionable than Southern rock. Practically everything about it runs against the grain of the latest rock trends - the music's firm grounding in blues, gospel and jazz, the bands' fondness for long guitar solos and jazz-inspired instrumental jamming, even the beards and jeans and long hair that are still the preferred mode of grooming and dress for many Southern rockers.

title: Treasury Statement

title: Cuomo Selects Head Of Mortgage Agency
description: Governor Cuomo today recommended that Wallace Ford 2d become the new executive director of the State Mortgage Agency, which was created in 1970 to provide banks with new sources of home mortgage money. The agency's five-member board of directors must approve the nomination.

Dance Award Winners

The awards will be presented by Leonard Bernstein, Erik Bruhn, Francis Ford Coppola and Jerome Robbins on March 21.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Two Barks and No Bite From Mr. Watt
description: It's been a busy few days for James Watt, the Savonarola who serves as Secretary of the Interior. Last Wednesday he held up Indian reservations as examples of the failure of socialism, prompting Indian leaders across the country to call for his resignation. On Thursday appeared an interview in which he accused his environmental critics of planning, like the Nazis or Bolsheviks, to centralize control of society. On Friday he stepped down from his pulpit to issue some regulations on strip mining.

title: Bryant in Hospital
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant was admitted to a hospital here tonight after experiencing chest pains.

SEEKS STANDBY TAX FOR 1985
description: President Reagan, pressing his theme that ''America is on the mend,'' urged the new Congress in the State of the Union Message tonight to support a broad freeze in the growth of domestic spending programs. He also asked it to allow military spending to continue to rise sharply.

title: DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. STEEL'S 1982 LOSS A RECORD
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's larget steelmaker, reported yesterday that it lost $363 million in the fourth quarter and $361 million for all of 1982, the largest one-year loss in its history.

title: Treasury Re-funding Awaited; Traders Stay On Sidelines
description: Investors and traders in fixed-income securities moved to the sidelines yesterday as they paused to await the Treasury's midquarter re-funding terms, due to be issued after the stock markets close today, as well as President Reagan's State of the Union Message, which was delivered last night.

title: DEMOCRATS LIST OWN IDEAS IN RESPONSE
description: The Democrats argued on national television tonight that government could work for the American people and actively promote economic growth, a tougher trade policy, a strong defense and a freeze on nuclear weapons.

description: Frederic P. Wiedersum, who designed more than 500 schools, most of them on Long Island, and scores of other buildings and public works during a 60-year career, died Sunday at the Nassau County Medical Center.

REVUE: 'SLAP HAPPY'
description: ''SLAP HAPPY,'' at the Other End, is a slapdash comedy revue in which a four-man troupe from Boston tries too hard to too little comic effect. Whether joking or juggling - or doing both at the same time - the company is short on spontaneity.

description: Don Reese, the former defensive lineman whose article in Sports Illustrated last summer disclosed widespread cocaine use among National Football League players, began serving a minimum of six months in prison today.

title: A Little Late
description: Once, when they were the welterweight champions of the split boxing world, a fight between Roberto Duran and Pipino Cuevas would have been one of the big attractions of the sports year. On Saturday in Los Angeles, the faded former champions will finally meet, about two and a half years too late to stir up much business at the Felt Forum, where the 10-round bout will be shown live on closed-circuit television.

title: MOOD AND HOT FLASHES
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I am appalled at the story which deals with the problem of hot flashes. What particularly makes me bristle is that this research is federally funded, another case of the wasteful extravagance of our politicians.

title: Borg Will Play April Exhibition
description: Bjorn Borg, who announced his retirement from tournament tennis last Sunday, will face John McEnroe in an exhibition match here April 9-10, sponsors said today.

description: Democratic leaders in the Senate and House said today that any delays in Social Security benefits should be linked to changes in the tax cut scheduled for July, which they said favored the wealthy.

title: MCI Corp. Moving To Westchester
description: MCI International, a subsidiary of MCI Communications Corporation, has announced plans to move its headquarters from New York City to the village of Rye Brook in Westchester County in April. About 350 of the company's 900 employees will be involved in the shift, a spokesman said yesterday.

description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the nation's leading manufacturer of machine tools, said it expects to report a loss of about $2.5 million for the fourth quarter of 1982, compared with a profit of $16.2 million, or 72 cents a share, in the same period of 1981.
