title: U.S. Steel Duty
description: The European Economic Community has instituted an antidumping measure against the United States Steel Corporation for its exports of isopropylidenediphenol, a stabilizer used for hydraulic fluids and polyvinyl chloride. It said the product would be subject to an import duty of 37.6 percent, which will apply for four months or until the Common Market adopts definitive measures.

title: L.I. Fire Kills 3
description: A man and two children were killed here this morning when fire swept through their house, the police said.

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED ON A MISSILE SHIFT
description: Senior State Department officials, who only last week argued for delaying any changes in President Reagan's zero-option proposal on medium-range missiles until after the West German elections on March 6, are now pressing the White House to move sooner, according to Administration officials.

title: NL NET OFF
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation reported yesterday that a continuing deterioration of the agricultural equipment and lift truck markets resulted in a fourth-quarter loss of $130.3 million, compared with a deficit of $46.1 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPAIRING CHINA TIES
description: .8,2ANN ARBOR, Mich. - The United States is losing the advantage it once derived from the Sino-American-Soviet triangle. Not even the most subtle diplomacy is likely to restore that advantage, but we can still limit the damage wrought in recent years. In the long run, American-Chinese relations are strongly linked to our relations with the world's other leading capitals - particularly Moscow -but during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit to Peking next week the two sides can take a number of small steps to stop the erosion of ties.

title: REAGAN'S WHITE FLAG
description: What a disappointment. The themeless pudding called this year's State of the Union address was a series of banalities intended to ingratiate the President with his political opposition; instead, this worst of Reagan speeches invited the grinning contempt it received.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHILE good locks and alarm systems are two of the best defenses against burglars, giving a house a lived-in look can also be an effective deterrent, whether the family is on vacation or just out for the evening.

title: Baxter's Net Up by 24.5%
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories said that gains in manufacturing productivity helped cause net income in the fourth quarter of last year to increase by 24.5 percent, to $53.9 million, or 76 cents a share, from $43.3 million, or 62 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

description: Results for the second qr reflect a stock split to be paid Feb 18

title: '82 TRADE GAP IS RECORD, BUT DECEMBER IMPROVED
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit narrowed a bit in December, the Government reported today. But this still brought the total 1982 trade gap to a record $42.7 billion, despite a big drop in payments for imported oil. And the new record will probably be broken by $20 billion or more this year, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said.

title: Technology; Improvements In Coal Boilers
description: FOR nearly a decade, manufacturers of industrial boiler systems have been been trying to design and market improved coal-fired heating and power-generating systems.

title: Time Out For The Bear
description: LOS ANGELES P aul (Bear) Bryant stopped the clock in football yesterday. Even the shilling for Super Bowl XVII had to pause for a prayer after the death of the legendary Alabama coach whose teams had won more games, 323, than those of any other coach in college football. His stature is perhaps best remembered by a quiet moment at the 1978 Sugar Bowl after a 35-6 victory over Ohio State, then coached by Woody Hayes, in what was college football's Appomattox in reverse.

title: Swissair Capacity
description: Swissair is raising scheduled capacity by 4.5 percent to meet an expected traffic increase of 4 percent in 1983, Alex Kaufmann, marketing director, said. In the company magazine, he said a 1 percent rise in traffic recorded in 1982 was not nearly enough to cover costs, let alone write-offs on new planes. Swissair expects freight and mail business to increasse by 7 percent each and passenger traffic to increase by 2 percent this year, he said.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO A 'RACIST' N.C.A.A. RULE CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANT CONFERENCE
description: A conference entitled ''Making Brooklyn Bloom,'' Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., is designed to demonstrate through landscaping and horticulture how one can improve homes and neighborhoods.

description: THE PAINTED LADY. By Fran,coise Sagan. Translated by Lee Fahnestock. 468 pages. E.P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: Moore, Harris Unhappy Dolphins
description: Nat Moore and Duriel Harris are the most successful wide receivers that the Miami Dolphins have ever had. Moore's 339 catches for 5,284 yards are team records; Harris is second in both categories with 251 catches and 4,250 yards.

title: BORROWING NEEDS TREASURY JUMP
description: The Treasury late yesterday disclosed borrowing plans for the first half of 1983 that are substantially higher than the credit markets had been anticipating, raising the prospect that the seven-month drop in interest rates might be over.

WARREN E. IRVIN
description: Warren E. Irvin, a former reporter for The New York Times, NBC and the BBC, died Saturday at his home in Cockeysville, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: CBS Stores Sale
description: CBS Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell its 83 Pacific Stereo Outlets to Burke Mathes, the former president of Curtis Mathes.

description: Shr earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan 3, 1983

description: * American Savings and Loan Association of Florida said it would terminate its tender offer for all shares of Home Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: He was a close second in last year's Wanamaker Mile and was looking forward to the race tomorrow night, but illness has forced Tom Byers to withdraw from the Millrose Games and may cause him to miss the entire indoor season. According to the meet's director, Howard Schmertz, Byers has developed pulmonary complications from a viral infection and will be in an Atlanta hospital undergoing tests when the milers line up at Madison Square Garden.

description: The Cost of Free Food

title: WITNESS SAYS DRIVER LIED ABOUT SPRAYING DIOXIN
description: A part-owner of a stable where 62 horses died after dioxin-tainted oil was sprayed testified today before the Missouri Hazardous Waste Management Commssion that the man who sprayed the oil had told her it contained a special fly-killing ingredient.

description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: CHRYSLER ENDS SOUTH AFRICA ROLE
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to sell its stake in a South African auto manufacturer in what is believed to be one of the biggest withdrawals by an American company from this country in recent years.

title: BONN'S FOREIGN MINISTER SEES REAGAN ON MISSILES
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said today after meeting with President Reagan that both governments still believed the American proposal to eliminate all Soviet and American medium-range missiles ''would provide the best solution for Europe, for West Germany and for the West as a whole.''

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
AGRICULTURE SECRETARY IS HOPEFUL STILL
description: If you are looking for the Reagan Administration's leading victim of circumstances, you can start with Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, although he would not agree.

title: SAN JOSE WATER WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EATON TO SELL OR END SEVERAL OPTIONS
description: The Eaton Corporation announced plans today to sell or discontinue several operations and said it would result in an after-tax charge for the year of about $205 million. The company also said the charge would cause it to have a loss for the year, but did not disclose the size, and said it was cutting its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share, from 43 cents.

title: TANAKA PROSECUTORS DEMAND 5 YEARS IN PRISON AND A FINE
description: After six years of court proceedings, the prosecution in the Lockheed bribery trial demanded today that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka be sentenced to five years in prison and fined the equivalent of $2.14 million.

title: The Fast Track
description: Dick Buerkle once set a world record for the indoor mile on it. In fact, 22 world records were set on what used to be Madison Square Garden's indoor track.

description: Eight decades ago a young lawyer who had emerged as the leader of the poor and generally scorned Indian community in South Africa had a vision of whites and Indians living a life of harmony and simplicity in an unspoiled rural setting.

title: CHB FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Shakeout
description: The British oil marketing and petrochemical businesses face the prospect of substantial losses this year after each lost about 500 million, or the equivalent of $769.5 miilion at current exchange rates, in 1982, according to John Jennings, Shell's exploration and production manager in Britain. He said at a meeting here that in 1982 ''both had roughly twice the manufacturing capacity they needed and a major shakeout was in progress.''

title: 'THE GIRL FROM LORRAINE'
description: THE heroine of Claude Goretta's ''Girl From Lorraine'' is greatly beloved in the small town she has decided to leave. ''Farewell, Christine,'' the local chorus sings sweetly. ''Do not go.'' And then, jokingly: ''Here where the dirt never ends/You know we are all your friends.'' But Christine is about to move to Paris, where she hopes to work at architectural drafting and pursue the adventurous life of a young career woman. Her friends at home show more than a few traces of good-natured envy as they wistfully bid her goodbye.

title: Bus Line in Jersey Closing Tomorrow
description: The Manhattan Bus Company today told its 100 workers that it would shut down Friday. Service for 5,000 daily riders from Passaic and Bergen Counties and the northern part of Hudson County to New York City is to cease, the company said.

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Cool to Reagan Speech
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's State of the Union Message Tuesday offered no prospect of improved Soviet-American relations.

title: Marble, Not Plaster
description: TO THE HOME EDITOR: Your article on ''Apartment Lobbies: A Chronicle of Taste'' (Jan. 6) was both interesting and informative.

10,000 Teachers Go on Strike Against 41 Quebec Colleges
description: More than 10,000 teachers went on strike at 4l of 46 provincial community colleges today in the first stage of what is planned as an expanding illegal general strike by a coalition of unions representing 250,000 public employees.

STAGE: 'MODERN LADIES OF GUANABACOA,' CUBA IN '28
description: IN ''The Modern Ladies of Guanabacoa,'' which opened last night at the Ensemble Studio Theater, the playwright Eduardo Machado wants to show us just how Cuba was dragged kicking and screaming into the 20th century.

title: FROM FILMS TO CEMENT
description: Burt Sugarman, a Hollywood producer of films and television programs, is also an investor. He has moved into cement in a big way. Mr. Sugarman owns 10 percent of the common stock of the Giant Portland and Masonry Cement Company of Columbia, S.C., which has been suffering losses in recent years.

title: 3,000 Evacuated After Leak
description: A toxic cloud of sulfuric acid vapor hovered over the city today after a pipe ruptured at a chemical plant. Ten people were injured and 3,000 others were forced to leave their homes for seven hours when a pipe at the Ulrich Chemical Company plant broke about noon, spilling 5,000 gallons of acid into a safety dike. Residents were allowed to return home around 7:30 P.M. Two people remained hospitalized tonight.

title: GENERAL FOODS UP 25.6% P.&G., 9.9.%
description: Some of the nation's major consumer products manufacturers yesterday reported modest increases in earnings for the latest quarter, along with declining sales that indicated a slowdown in consumer spending for food, tobacco and some household items.

title: BRYANT'S HELPFULNESS RECALLED
description: The world of football reacted with shock and sadness to the announcement of the sudden death of Bear Bryant yesterday. The players who had performed under the coach who won more college football games than anyone else in history felt the grief sharply. But many remembered him for the influence he had on their lives off the football field.

title: GARDENING
description: ABASIC fact of city life is that there's just not a lot of growing space. So when spring seed catalogues arrive with enticing images of enormous melons, the city gardener may toss them aside and proceed with more realistic endeavors.

title: PROFITS OFF AT TEXACO, MOBIL, SHELL
description: Three of the nation's largest oil companies reported lower fourthquarter earnings yesterday, blaming them on the weak demand for oil and slim profit margins in Europe. The Mobil Corporation said its earnings fell 52 percent, Texaco Inc. reported a 39.6 decline and the Shell Oil Company said its net income dropped 4.4 percent.

title: USE OF RACKETEERING LAW IS BARRED IN CASE AGAINST CROATIAN TERRORISTS
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a major racketeering law could not be used to prosecute terrorists and other groups that commit criminal acts for political reasons rather than for profit.

title: Legal Services Outside the Law
description: None of the four men President Reagan has appointed to the board of the Legal Services Corporation actively opposes providing effective lawyers to the poor. That is faint praise, but a great leap forward.

title: OFFICERS STRIPPED OB THEIR BADGES IN POLICE INQUIRY
description: Fourteen police officers who were summoned before a Federal grand jury looking into suspected police corruption and misconduct were stripped of their shields and weapons yesterday and placed on modified assignments.

title: Barry Galbraith, Guitarist; Recorded in 50's and 60's
description: Barry Galbraith, a guitarist who recorded extensively in the 1950's and 60's, died of cancer on Jan. 13 in Bennington, Vt. He was 63 years old.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1982 are after a charge of $440,000 for the costs associated with changing distribution to independent dealers, and include a provision of $1,000,000 for expected costs associated with further consolidated of manufacturing operations

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West German Surplus Cited
description: West Germany had a current account surplus of $2.2 billion and a trade surplus of $2.6 billion last month, the Government said today.

title: Michaels Explains Monday Absence
description: Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets explained yesterday that he did not attend the team's final meeting Monday because of a cold.

title: Advertising; Revlon May Raise Ad Budget
description: REVLON, a leader in the cosmetics and fragrance industry, which is known for having fairly tight strings on its ad budget, is describing its planned 1983 advertising budget for its fragrances as ''huge.''

title: OMARK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCHOOL PICKS PRESIDENT
description: Thomas F. Schutte, president of the Philadelphia College of Art, will become president of Rhode Island School of Design in August, the 106-year-old art school said today.

title: Suffolk Suspends Owner-Trainer
description: George Leone, a horse owner and trainer, was suspended today until Aug. 29, 10 days beyond the end of the current meeting at Suffolk Downs.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET WILL SEEK TO TAX HEALTH PREMIUMS
description: President Reagan will propose a new tax on health insurance provided by employers and a requirement that elderly people pay a larger share of routine hospital expenses, Administration officials said today. The tax is expected to raise $2.7 billion a year.

title: Lawyer Backs Judge In Return of Money
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings returned $845,000 seized from two convicted racketeers because of legal precedent, not because of a bribe, one of the convicts' lawyers testified today.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HENRY L. SCHWARTZ
description: Henry L. Schwartz, a founder of the Paragon Oil Company and president of the Brookdale Foundation, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: The Police Blotter
description: The proprietor of a jewelry store in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn shot one of two armed men who attempted to rob her and drove off the other. Virginia Rodriguez Valasquez, 47 years old, the proprietor of Rodriguez Jewelry, 615 Sutter Avenue, fired five shots at the men, who entered her store just after noon.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
League Expands
description: LaSalle and Holy Cross will join the Metro Atlantic Conference next season. Jimmy McDermott, the commissioner of the league, will make the official announcement today. This will increase the Metro Atlantic Conference from six to eight teams: Army, Iona, Manhattan, Fairfield, St. Peter's, Fordham, LaSalle and Holy Cross.

title: CLAUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
South African Gold
description: South Africa's gold output rose to 664.2 metric tons in 1982 from 656.9 tons the previous year, the Chamber of Mines said today.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $718,600 on the sale of real estate...C-After a loss of $159,900 on the sale of investment securities and a gain of $300,000 on the sale of real estate

title: DEMOCRATS MODIFY TAX-PENSION LINK
description: Democratic Congressional leaders backed away today from suggestions Tuesday that they might try to link the proposed six-month delay in Social Security benefits to reductions in tax benefits that mostly benefit the wealthy.

title: REAGAN MAY RAISE EX-IM BANK FUNDS
description: In his budget for the 1984 fiscal year, President Reagan will propose bolstering the Export-Import Bank, the Government agency that aids American exporters by making loans to foreign purchasers of American goods.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV RULE CHANGES URGED
description: The United States Departments of Justice and Commerce yesterday urged the Federal Communications Commission to repeal its financial interest and syndication rules.

title: Hey, Big Spender
description: The State of the Union, to judge by the President's words, is togetherness. He talked about bipartisanship and working together a dozen times in his report to Congress Tuesday. A retreat toward moderation, conservatives fear. Let Reagan be Reagan, they say. But which one? Two Ronald Reagans emerge from this address. One, realistic at last about the big economic picture, has become probably the biggest spender ever. The other is the same old warrior against the poor.

title: Finland's Foreign Debt
description: Finland had an $840 million balance of payments deficit and owed about $7.5 billion abroad at the end of 1982, the central bank said today. The foreign debt rose by $1.87 billion last year, according to a preliminary estimate.

title: JAZZ: WILD BILL DAVISON'S 77TH BIRTHDAY
description: WILD BILL DAVISON has come back to New York to celebrate his 77th birthday at Eddie Condon's, 144 West 54th Street, where he will be playing his cornet until tomorrow night. Mr. Davison is sitting in with the regular Condon band, led by the bassist Red Balaban, and he took pains the other night to point out that he was not choosing the tunes the band was playing, which included ''Who's Sorry Now?,'' ''Sugar,'' ''Avalon'' and ''Louisiana.''

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Miss Schlamme Singing
description: Martha Schlamme will perform songs by Kurt Weill, Jacques Brel and others for the next four weekends at Jason's, 23 West 73d Street.

title: PRETORIA PURSUING WIDE ANGOLA PACT
description: South Africa is seeking to negotiate a ceasefire with Angola as a preliminary step toward settling the tangled issues of independence for South-West Africa and a Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today.

title: CONCERT: PERCUSSION WORKS
description: Apercussion ensemble concert that begins with a work by Lou Harrison and ends with one by Edgard Varese puts those composers whose works fall between at something of a disadvantage. A reminder of this was provided by the New Music Consort program performed under the direction of Claire Heldrich at Symphony Space on Tuesday night.

title: Dravo of Pittsburgh Fills a Top Position
description: Thomas F. Faught Jr., president and chief operating officer of the Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh, has been named to the additional post of chief executive, succeeding Robert Dickey 3d. Mr. Dickey, who reaches normal retirement age this month, will continue as chairman through the company's annual meeting in April.

title: Warning on Fever Issued
description: Doctors today warned vacationers to Caribbean and Latin American resorts to take precautions against bringing home dengue fever, a mosquito-transmitted disease rarely seen in the United States. Most cased imported into the United States are introduced by infected travelers returning from tourist areas such as Mexico, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, St. Thomas, Guadeloupe, St. Martin and Curacao.

title: 93 WORKS FROM MELLON COLLECTION GIVEN TO NATIONAL GALLERY
description: Paul Mellon, whose father provided the funds to build the National Gallery of Art more than 40 years ago, today gave the museum 93 works of art from his private collection.

title: Man in Wheelchair Robbed in 'Village'
description: A thief robbed a handicapped man on a street in Greenwich Village yesterday, taking from him his jewelry and his wheelchair, the police said.

title: CRS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRYANT'S DOCTOR TELLS OF LENGTHY ILLNESS
description: Bear Bryant's personal physician, Dr. William Hill, said today that the most successful coach in college football history had struggled with ''serious health problems'' for three years before his death Wednesday.

title: PULLOUT BY ISRAEL URGED BY MUBARAK
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today, after meeting with President Reagan, that ''top priority'' had to be given to bringing about the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon before time ran out on the latest Middle East peace efforts.

title: Dow Jones Net Up 4.7%
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 4.7 percent, to $24.4 million, from $23.3 million, in the fourth quarter. The publisher and news service said that revenue was up 13.4 percent, to $197.6 million, up from $173.4 million.

title: AFGHANS, IN NEW YORK, TELL OF A MASSACRE BY RUSSIANS
description: Soviet soldiers surrounded an Afghan village with tanks in September and, in a brief occupation, massacred 105 of its inhabitants, including 12 children, who were hiding in a covered irrigation canal, three former residents of the village said Wednesday.

title: 'ENIGMA,' WITH MARTIN SHEEN
description: THERE are plenty of mysteries about ''Enigma'' but they aren't necessarily the ones the film makers intended. As directed by Jeannot Szwarc, best known for ''Jaws II'' and ''Somewhere in Time,'' this is the spy film at its most absurdly hard-boiled and at its most icily perfunctory. It is punctuated by crisp titles (indicating the date of each scene), played very close to the vest and riddled with false alarms -as when one character gets a good scare when his cat leaps out from beside the refrigerator, and another when he sees a shadowy shape behind his shower curtain. The silhouette, he discovers, belongs to his own not especially treacherous gray suit.

title: WHEN BIRTH CONTROL IS NOT ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Analysts Differ Over Exxon
description: HOW is an investor to assess an enormous company whose stock is selling below book value and yielding 10 percent and whose earnings are expected to increase in 1983?

title: Treasury Bill Rates Decline; Bond Prices Show Gains
description: Treasury bill rates fell and bond prices rose moderately yesterday in response to the Government's February re-funding terms, which were announced late Wednesday. But dealers said that trading was apathetic and that many investors and traders had seized upon even modest upturns to lighten their portfolios.

title: Itel Tax Deficiency
description: The Itel Corporation said it had received notice of a proposed Federal tax deficiency of about $20 million, covering the years 1976 to 1978, that it believes it may be able to resolve for an amount that would not be material. Itel said, however, that the matter could take some time to resolve and its reorganization plan could be delayed if the company was unable to complete the matter promptly.

title: Article 200550 -- No Title
description: Federal agents have recovered $750,000 worth of paintings that thieves were clever enough to steal from Andrew Wyeth's house but apparently didn't know how to sell in the intricate world of art.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a special tax provision of $615,000

title: SEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fowler Rejoins Yanks
description: Art Fowler, who goes wherever Billy Martin goes, has rejoined the Yankees as pitching coach.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
IN SURINAME 'THEY MAKE YOU FULL OF HOLES, MAN'
description: After the executions of 15 civic leaders here who were promoting a return to democracy, the military rulers of Suriname and a small group of leftist supporters appear well on the way to implanting a police state leaning toward Cuba.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paterno Criticized
description: Lenny Moore, the former Penn State football star, says that Coach Joe Paterno is not handling black athletes properly and that the national champion Nittany Lions have racial problems. But Paterno says Moore, who played at Penn State from 1953 to 1955 before starring with the Baltimore Colts, doesn't know what he's talking about.

description: B-After a special charge of $9,500,000 for the qr and yr for the settlement of litigation claims...C-Net income

title: Worn Gasket Is Blamed For Nuclear Plant Leak
description: A worn-out gasket caused a leak at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant that resulted in the dumping of 208,000 gallons of radioactive water into the Tennessee River on Jan. 16, officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority said Wednesday.

title: No Headline
description: Pan Am Trims Florida Fares

title: Pirates Invite Jones
description: In his two seasons pitching with the Mets, Randy Jones had a 1-8 record in 1981 and a 7-10 mark last year, which brought the lefthander's career record to 100-123.

title: Bridge:; Squandering of a Trump Can Lead to Hard Times
description: Most of those who live in a highly productive industrial society feel no need to observe the traditional attitudes expressed in such sayings as ''waste not, want not'' or ''penny-wise, pound-foolish.'' But this frugality, parsimony or plain meanness is often needed, and sometimes neglected, at the bridge table.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 28, 1983
description: International Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, said after meeting with President Reagan in Washington that ''top priority'' had to be given to bringing about the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon before time ran out on the latest Middle East peace efforts. A senior State Department official said later that Mr. Reagan told the Egyptian leader that he shared his concerns about the slow pace of the Israeli-Lebanese negotiations. (Page A1, Column 3.) Sofia, Bulgaria, which is known as a restrictive Communist capital that has also gained the reputation of being a focal point of highliving international crime syndicates, has come under intense scrutiny with investigations into reports that it may have been involved in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II. (A1:5.)

title: CHET LAABS
description: Chet Laabs, a former major league outfielder who is perhaps best remembered for a strikeout, died of a heart ailment Wednesday. He was 70 years old.

title: Garden Shifts Titles
description: A series of personnel changes was announced yesterday by Charles G. Bluhdorn, the chairman of Gulf and Western Industries, Madison Square Garden's corporate parent. Taking it from the top, Irving Mitchell Felt, the Garden's chairman of the board, becomes honorary chairman of the board; David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the Garden's president and chief executive officer, becomes chairman and chief executive officer, and John H. Krumpe Jr., the executive vice president, becomes president and chief operating officer.

title: Varsity Hockey Dropped by Irish
description: Citing substantial financial losses and disappointing student support, the University of Notre Dame announced today that it was dropping ice hockey as a Division I sport and would play at a club level next season.

title: THE ORDEAL OF LEBANON GOES ON AS THREE FOREIGN ARMIES DIG IN
description: Despite months of negotiations on the withdrawal of all foreign armies from Lebanon, it has become clear in recent weeks that the Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces now crowded into this tiny country are all planning on a long stay.

title: 2 GROUPS ARGUE IN COURT OVER N.A.A.C.P. NAME
description: With the great desegregation victories for which they fought side by side echoing like distant memories, two nationally prominent civil rights organizations clashed in court today in dubious battle over five initials.

description: The Transit Authority police seized 525 people suspected of jumping subway turnstiles to evade the fare, smoking, littering and other offenses in a 10-hour sweep through Brooklyn's 171 subway stations that ended early yesterday.

title: TROUBLE-SHOOTING JURIST FOR U.S. JUDGE'S TRIAL
description: Edward T. Gignoux has seen his share of tough court cases as the lone Federal district judge in Maine for most of his 26 years on the bench. Now, 1,600 miles away from home and only a few months short of retirement, Judge Gignoux is presiding over what might be the toughest assignment for any judge, the trial of a peer. The 66-year-old judge is conducting the trial here of Alcee L. Hastings of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judge Hastings, whose trial is expected to end this week, is the first sitting Federal judge to be prosecuted on criminal charges.

title: Inmate Writer Fails To Block Transfer
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Connecticut Department of Corrections can transfer out of a state prison an inmate who writes a column for a local newspaper in which he has often criticized the prison administration.

title: New Equal Rights Bill Is Introduced in Senate
description: The Federal equal rights amendment was re-introduced Wednesday in the Senate with a bipartisan group of Senators predicting passage and opponents calling it a ''phony symbol'' backed by ''wimps.''

title: KIN OF LOST AMERICANS MARK INDOCHINA ACCORD
description: Mary Rose of Birmingham, Ala., still wakes up in the middle of the night and imagines that her son, Capt. Scott Ketchie, is alive in a prison camp in Vietnam.

title: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
5 DIE IN B-52 FIRE AT AIR BASE
description: A B-52G bomber parked on a maintenance ramp exploded in a huge fireball today, killing five people and injuring eight others at Grand Forks Air Force Base, the authorities said.

title: Chemical Sues 11 Utilities
description: The Chemical Bank of New York is suing 11 Oregon public utilities to force them to pay their shares of the multibillion-dollar debt on two terminated nuclear power plants.

PRIDE AND PRESSURE MARK NEW BRIGHTON
description: New Brighton, despite being just minutes from the Staten Island ferry terminal, has a tranquil ambiance. Since it is at the island's northeastern tip, many of its single-family homes and apartment buildings have vistas of lower Manhattan across Upper New York Bay.

Rudolf P. Berle, Lawyer And County Supervisor
description: Rudolf P. Berle, senior partner of the law firm of Berle & Berle of New York City and a former member of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Friday; FROM AUTHOR OF 'PLENTY'
description: The New York premiere of a play by David Hare, whose acclaimed ''Plenty'' is now on Broadway, opens tonight at 8 at the SoHo Rep, 19 Mercer Street. Called ''Fanshen,'' it tells the true story of a village caught in the upheavals of the Chinese Revolution. However, it is being done with a multiracial cast to emphasize the play's broader concerns. Mr. Hare has said that ''Fanshen'' is not only about land reform but also about the relationship in any society between leaders and the led. It deals with the difficulties of effecting change, too. The play won high praise when it opened in London in 1975. ''Fanshen,'' which means ''to enter a new world'' and is based on a book by William Hinton, will play Thursdays through Sundays until Feb. 20. Tickets: $8. Reservations: 925-2588.

title: Advertising; Parade's $1 Million Campaign
description: PARADE magazine, the Sunday newspaper supplement that calls itself the world's largest-circulation magazine, is starting a new $1 million ad campaign Monday that will not overlook its size.

title: WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREAT LAKES GOVERNORS FACE NEED FOR TAX RISE
description: With the inaugural cheer behind them and the grim task of budget-writing at hand, the Great Lakes areas' four new Democratic Governors are edging toward similar plans of attack on their states' mounting budget deficits: quote Franklin D. Roosevelt and raise taxes.

title: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,630,000,000 from discontinued operations, which included aloss of $775,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: A case study in instant success.
description: ANYONE interested in learning how a restaurant can become an instant success, would find the new Jockey Club a perfect case study. In just eight weeks, this generally comfortable English drawing-room-style restaurant on Central Park South, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has developed such a huge following that it has been difficult and, at times, impossible to get reservations. Tables at dinner are filled by a conservatively and expensively dressed old-guard clientele, the women wearing black dresses and pearls, the men in dark three-piece suits. Almost the only exceptions are dinner guests in black tie. At the entrance, limousines wait, often three deep.

title: Fraunces Tavern Offers 18th-Century Puppetry
description: Hand-carved marionettes, reminiscent of those made in the 18th century, will be used in a puppet show Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street. The show, presented by Dan Butterworth and his Marionettes, will be done in the style of Colonial tavern entertainment as part of a museum exhibition called ''Taverns: For the Entertainment of Friends and Strangers,'' which runs through June 10.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEEDIEST HELPED BY INGENIOUS SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: The ingenuity of schoolchildren in raising money for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has again been impressive in this year's 71st annual appeal.

title: TO NELMS, KICK RETURNING IS ART FORM
description: Mike Nelms is a Pro Bowl kick returner for the third time in his three National Football League seasons. A desire for excitement, he says, has helped.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLACK SHEEP. By Christopher Simon Sykes. 285 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $17.75.

title: Auto Exports Fall in Japan
description: Japan's exports of motor vehicles fell 7.6 percent last year, to 5.59 million units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. It was the first year-toyear drop since Japan began full-scale auto exports more than 20 years ago.

title: YANKEE OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Financial Services Get New Scrutiny
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company and other retailers may be forced to give up their new financial services businesses, William Isaac, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, warned today. He told reporters that new rules are under study to roll back the way businesses not previously affiliated with finance have been selling financial services.

title: South African Officer Arrested in Spying Case
description: A South African commodore has been arrested in connection with spying for the Soviet Union.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Profiting From Deadlines

title: NEW MELLON DONATION SHOWS UNUSUAL RANGE AND DIVERSITY
description: THE new Mellon donation of 93 works of art to the National Gallery of Art in Washington - much of which has for some years been on loan to the museum - is exceptional in its range and diversity.

title: Agency Cautions Consumers On Use of Kerosene Heaters
description: Kerosene heaters used in a confined area for a long time can cause air pollution above established health standards, the Consumer Product Safety Commission was told today.

title: Thrift Units' Deposits Up
description: For the first time in almost a year, savings and loan associations reported that savers deposited more money in their accounts in December than they withdrew, the Government said today. The surge was credited to the new so-called money market deposit account.

description: BASEBALL

title: CANADIANS DEFEAT SLUMPING RANGERS, 4-1
description: Most of the fans began leaving Madison Square Garden with five minutes left in the game between the Rangers and the Canadiens last night, but they would have missed little even if they had left after the first period.

title: Stadium Lawsuit Is Filed by Bears
description: The Chicago Bears filed suit today, charging that the Chicago Park District broke a contract by allowing the Chicago Blitz to earn $2 million a season from luxurious skyboxes the Bears built at Soldier Field for more than $5 million.

title: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gulf Profit Off 24.9% In Quarter; Sun and Sohio Also Decline
description: Three large oil companies, the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Sun Company and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), reported lower fourthquarter earnings yesterday, which they said were caused by continuing declines in demand and falling prices.

title: A VARIED WEEKEND FOR MUSICAL ADVENTURING
description: JAZZ tends to hibernate in small, crowded cellar clubs and lofts during the winter, with occasional concerts as a change of pace. With the coming of summer and the Kool Jazz Festival, the music bursts into the concert halls and the streets, shakes the cold out of its bones and begins to strut. At least, that's been the routine in recent years. It's a routine Lehman College's first Midwinter Jazz Festival aims to shake up a bit.

description: Louise Berenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Kaufman of Mohegan Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Raymond Fink of New York.

description: Assets of the money market funds declined during the week ended Wednesday, the eighth drop in a row, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: FUTURES OPTIONS TO START ON 2 EXCHANGES
description: Today, less than a year after first offering stock index futures, Chicago's Mercantile Exchange and New York's Futures Exchange will introduce options on those futures, in the hope that they can attract some of the money that is flowing into the stock and options markets.

title: BIAS AGAINST GIRLS FOUND IN CITY TECHNICAL SCHOOLS
description: Discrimination against girls in New York City's vocational high schools is denying them equal opportunity, and there are few signs of improvement, according to a study released yesterday by a private education group.

title: Realized Potential
description: Bill Halterman, a 34-year-old amputee who says skiing on one leg ''has been the greatest thing for me,'' wants to share his exhilaration with other handicapped persons. Mr. Halterman, a New York investment banker who lost his right leg in a 1974 car accident, said ''skiing is just a tremendous way of building confidence.''

title: LILLIAN BENDEL
description: Lillian Hirschler Bendel, who was active in philanthropies and was the wife of Henri Bendel, the fashion retailer, died of emphysema on Wednesday at New York Hospital.

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS DUNN'S 'WATERFALL,' WITH POETS
description: DOUGLAS DUNN'S ''The Secret of the Waterfall,'' a new work performed on Tuesday at his SoHo studio, is that rare mix of dance and words that works. One might have expected it to, considering that Mr. Dunn's collaborators were the poets Anne Waldman and Reed Bye, and the scene designers Mimi Gross and Charles Atlas. But the piece also works because its three elements are so inextricably combined.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Mavericks, at Dallas. The Nets, beaten by the Houston Rockets on Tuesday night, continue their trip through Texas.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the qr and $146,000 for the yr

title: Del Rice, a Former Manager And Baseball Player, Is Dead
description: Del Rice, a longtime major league catcher who became the manager of the California Angels, died Wednesday evening while attending a benefit dinner in his honor at Los Coyotes Country Club. He was 60 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Incentives Enriching Baseball Contracts
description: When he signed a new three-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals last week, Ozzie Smith received a free membership to the stadium club at Busch Memorial Stadium. The membership carries a onetime initiation fee of $300 and year-round dues of $20 a month. That would make the value of Smith's new contract $3,601,020. The other $3.6 million is for playing baseball.

title: 2 MORE AGENCIES ADDED TO INQUIRY INTO CORRUPTION
description: A Federal investigation into suspected police corruption and misconduct is also looking into allegations involving payoffs to employees of the Fire and Sanitation Departments, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * The Amalgamated Sugar Co. said it was considering a plan to acquire Keystone Consolidated Industries, a steel, wire and hardware products manufacturer, for an undisclosed amount of stock.

title: ENSERCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,283,000 on the termination of charter agreement and the sale of assets

title: Jane Sabersky, 71, Curator at Columbia
description: Jane Sabersky, an art curator and exhibition organizer, died of a heart attack last Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old, and from 1971 until her retirement in 1981 had served as curator of art properties for Columbia University.

title: FIRST BANCGROUP-ALABAMA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISSOURI PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Missouri Pacific Corp is a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Corp

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLICE CADETS, YES
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW JUMPS BY 25.66 TO 1,063.65
description: The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25.66 points yesterday, to 1,063.65, as the latest economic news bolstered investor confidence that the economy is recovering from recession.

title: N.F.L. Loses on Vending
description: A Federal judge denied today an attempt by the National Football League to prevent street vendors from selling Super Bowl souvenirs not licensed by the league.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,200,000 for the qr from the exchange of stock for debentures and $2,900,000 for the 9 mos from the retirement of notes...C-Net loss

title: NATIONAL UTILITIES & INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW HEAD OF PRODUCTION IS NAMED BY PARAMOUNT
description: Frank Mancuso, the 48-year-old president of distribution at Paramount Pictures, has been made president of the studio's motion-picture division. His new title makes him the overseer of production, as well as distribution, at Paramount.

title: CONCERT: OBERLIN COLLEGE
description: THE Oberlin College Choir and Orchestra celebrated the Ohio school's 150th anniversary in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night with a performance of Benjamin Britten's ''Cantata Academica,'' written for the 500th anniversary celebration of Switzerland's Basel University in 1960.

title: NJ Transit to Fill Idled Bus Routes
description: NJ Transit, the state transportation agency, will assume all the routes currently served by the bankrupt Manhattan Bus Company, contingent in some cases on approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission, an NJ Transit spokesman said yesterday.

title: ISLANDERS HOLD OFF KINGS
description: After going five games without a goal, Mike Bossy scored three times at the Los Angeles Forum tonight to lead the Islanders to a 6-4 victory over the Kings.

title: LAYOFFS PLANNED FOR 1,000 TEACHERS IN CITY ON MONDAY
description: The New York City Board of Education is planning to lay off 1,000 teachers on Monday, officials said yesterday. The decision came after Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the State Senate, refused to endorse a legislative plan to provide $9 million in state funds for the city's public schools.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the Western Pacific Railroad Co is a subsidiary of Union Pacific Corp

title: MIRRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses of $3,491,000 for the qr and $4,223,000 for the yr fromdiscontinued operations

title: OLSON PREPARED TO TRY 19-FOOT VAULT TONIGHT
description: Billy Olson is no longer intimidated by the prospect of trying to clear 19 feet in the pole vault. ''I've had plenty of chances now,'' the 24-year-old vaulter from Abilene, Tex., said earlier this week. ''If I can make 18-11, there's no question I can make 19 feet.''

title: 'CROTCHETY' DEMOCRAT ENLIVENS TRADE PANEL
description: A large red sign from a defunct novelty shop hangs over the doorway of the vaulting Federal Trade Commission office: ''Magic Tricks Jokes Fireworks.''

title: People
description: * William T. Hazard and Clayton Wilhite have been promoted to executive vice president at Ammirati & Puris Inc.

title: DONNELLEY, R R, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CUOMO SAYS HE WILL AVOID RAISING STATE'S MAJOR TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that his budget proposal would not include increases in the state's corporate tax, income tax or sales tax, the three taxes that provide most of the state's revenues.

title: 4 LEAD PHOENIX ON 65's
description: The Phoenix Open, the fourth event on this season's PGA Tour, got off to a brisk and rather windy start today with four players tying for the lead at 65, six under par for the Phoenix Country Club.

title: Flagship Banks
description: Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami said that the United States District Court for the District of Columbia had denied without ruling on the merits its motion for a 10-day restraining order against an action by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Xerox Net Falls 52.4%
description: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that its net income plunged 52.4 percent in the fourth quarter from the period a year earlier. It cited the weak economy, restructuring costs and currency fluctuations.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A fierce storm battered the length of the California coast today, with waves up to 20 feet destroying beach houses, forcing families to flee and collapsing part of the famed Santa Monica pier.

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
VOLCKER STRESSES GOAL OF ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Fed was continuing to push for an economic recovery, but he warned that the threat of future budget deficits could make that job much more difficult.

title: Mother of Coast Mayor Dies
description: Betty Goldman, the mother of Mayor Dianne Feinstein, died Tuesday at a nursing home after a long illness.

title: RANGEL SEEKING U.S. AID FOR SHELTERING HOMELESS
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan told the United States Conference of Mayors here today that he would introduce legislation to provide Federal assistance to help cities build and operate shelters for the homeless.

title: PER SPOOK, HANAE MORI AND GRES COMPLETE PARIS FASHION SHOWS
description: Hanae Mori introduced some Oriental notes in her couture showing today and Per Spook presented casual clothes topped by 10-gallon hats. They have a cowboy look and are completely different from anything else shown here. Then Alix Gres presented her collection this afternoon and the spring and summer couture showings ended.

title: Decision File Greetings From the I.R.S.
description: Two million taxpayers owe the Internal Revenue Service a total of $7.8 billion and the agency is tired of hearing that the check is in the mail.

title: Bridge and Road Repair Approved
description: A $2.4 billion, five-year plan to repair New York City's roads and bridges with Federal funds was approved yesterday, state officials said.

title: DESEGREGATION OF SCHOOLS SPLITS ONCE-QUIET TOWN
description: For decades, parents in search of a better education for their children have moved from the cities to this suburb. Now the future of the very thing that attracted them, the public school system, is dividing them in a battle over desegregation.

title: IAN SMITH AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. George L. Tunick, 72, Dies; Ex-Greenwich Health Official
description: Dr. George L. Tunick, a former Medical Examiner of Greenwich, Conn., and chairman of the Greenwich Board of Health for nearly a decade, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at his Greenwich home. He was 72 years old.

title: Sports of the Times; The Bear Was Just 'Worn Out'
description: It is eerie to read the tributes to Bear Bryant that were delivered only last month when he announced his retirement. His friends and his admirers - no detractors surfaced then or now - spoke familiarly of him, as if they expected to have his company at conferences, at big games and on the golf course for many years to come.

title: McDonnell Douglas Up
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said earnings in its fourth quarter rose 72.5 percent, to $60.9 million, or $1.54 a share, from $35.3 million, or 90 cents a share, in the 1981 period.

title: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $50,000 for the qr and $170,000 for the 6mos

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Union Pacific Falls by 36.5%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter fell 36.5 percent, to $80 million, or 82 cents a share, from $126 million, or $1.31 a share, a year earlier.

title: CHEAPER OIL'S BENEFITS
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is unlikely to prevent a further decline in oil prices. Maintaining a $30 to $34 price per barrel would require large coordinated cutbacks in production. As OPEC's Geneva meetings demonstrated, this is more than the cartel can manage.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Sports Pages article about the Team America soccer squad gave an incorrect listing of Cosmos players in some editions Wednesday. The last player listed, Njego Pesa, is a member of the Tulsa Roughnecks. The Cosmos player that should have been listed is Steve Moyers.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes a tax credit of $89,000...C-Net loss

WESTERN MARINE ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for 14 weeks to Jan 1
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Jan 1983

title: ABORTION FOE IS CONVICTED IN COUPLE'S ABDUCTION
description: The leader of a small anti-abortion group called the Army of God was found guilty today of trying to close an abortion clinic by abducting its owner and his wife.

title: GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the losses in the latest periods include pretax reserves of $14.5million for the yr and $8 million for the qr for the estimated cost of an assetredeployment plan

title: Smithsonian Festival Will Focus on Jersey
description: Governor Kean announced today that New Jersey had accepted an invitation to be the featured state in the Smithsonian Institution's Festival of American Folklife next summer.

title: A VARIED WEEKEND FOR MUSICAL ADVENTURING
description: HOW do you take your Wagner? Sparingly, at widely spaced intervals? Or straight? If you prefer it neat, the Wagner Society of New York may have something for you: an all-day-and-most-of-the-night presentation of the complete ''Ring'' cycle. Thirteen hours and 9 minutes of opera, plus eight intermissions (adding up to 4 hours and 14 minutes), for a grand total of 17 hours and 23 minutes, ''a musical 'Forsyte Saga,' '' in the words of one British critic.

title: SOVIET UNION SHOWS BACKING FOR A ZONE FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
description: The Soviet Union expressed support today for a proposal to create a zone in central Europe that would be clear of all battlefield nuclear weapons.

title: ONE SWITCH BY STENNIS TRIPS A ROW OF DOMINOES
description: Senator John C. Stennis, a courtly, 81-yearold Mississippian, has long been considered the Senate's leading authority on military affairs. He has spent more than 30 years on the Armed Services Committee, serving with Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard B. Russell, among other Senate luminaries. For 12 years he headed the committee, and when the Republicans gained control of the Senate he became the ranking Democrat.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Senior Scholars Make Their Point
description: The Ionas of the world, united in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference, have perhaps answered a charge made by Dr. Joab Thomas, the president of the University of Alabama and of the College Football Association. Dr. Thomas last fall blamed ''the Ionas and schools like that who have voted down our attempts to upgrade our academic standards.''

title: SUN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes after-tax gains from divestments of $299,000,000 for the qr and $434,000,000 for the yr

title: Angela Lansbury and 'Mame' just can't stay apart.
description: THERE is a recurring theme in Angela Lansbury's life. ''People are always asking me, 'When are you going to do ''Mame'' again?' '' she said the other day. At last, Miss Lansbury has an answer for her fans: she will do ''Mame'' again on Broadway this fall. Miss Lansbury, who was a sensation as the original zesty, eccentric, extravagantly wealthy Mame in 1966, will go into rehearsal in May, play in San Diego, Los Angeles and San Francisco over the summer and open on Broadway in October.

title: A VARIED WEEKEND FOR MUSICAL ADVENTURING
description: AS a boy growing up in Hollywood, it mattered not a fig to Leonard Slatkin that Igor Stravinsky and Arnold Schoenberg were constantly wandering into his home to hear his parents make music and to sample the cook's pecan pie. ''But meeting Doris Day or Betty Grable in a restaurant or at a studio - boy, that was something!'' Mr. Slatkin said the other day.

title: A Sane View of Insanity
description: The insanity acquittal of the President's assailant, John Hinckley, stirred angry Americans to question the validity of the insanity defense. The Administration said it should be abolished. Others complained that medical experts so swayed the jury that they were in effect deciding moral questions about criminal guilt. Psychiatrists share that concern, as a sensible report by the American Psychiatric Association demonstrates.

title: PHILHARMONIC GOING MODERN
description: The New York Philharmonic will present at Lincoln Center in June six concerts of orchestral music composed since 1968. A festival, entitled ''Horizon '83 - A New Romanticism?'' will take place at Avery Fisher Hall from June 2 to June 15 and will include world premieres by Marc Antonio Consoli, George Crumb, Fred Lerdahl and Bernard Rands.

INTERPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Topics; Public Service; Goad of Ethics
description: Robert Kutak was a fresh breeze in legal circles, a cyclone actually. In his short career - he died at the age of 50 the other day - he sparked at least two revolutions.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Cuomo has made much of his determination to fulfill campaign promises, but the exact nature of some of those promises has proved to be elusive.

title: O'NEILL SAYS HOUSE MAY ASK $5 BILLION FOR JOB PROGRAMS
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that House Democrats would propose substantial programs to create jobs at a cost of at least $5 billion in the current fiscal year.

title: Bill Barron's Quartet
description: The tenor saxophonist Bill Barron, who generally occupies himself with teaching, will make one of his occasional New York appearances leading a quartet Sunday at Jazz Forum, 648 Broadway, at Bleecker Street (477-2655). There are three sets beginning at 10 P.M.; admission is $6.

description: Shr earnings reflect a 50 percent stock divd paid Dec 29

title: A.T.& T'S PROFITS ROSE 6.7% IN 1982
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its profits for last year rose 6.7 percent, less than half the growth achieved in 1981.

title: Giardello Wins in Debut
description: Joey Giardello Jr., son and namesake of the former world middleweight champion, made a successful professional debut tonight by scoring a third-round technical knockout over William Tull of Philadelphia in a junior-lightweight bout.

title: INDIANA GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Want Ads Up Again
description: The help-wanted advertising index rose five points in December, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Conference Board reported yesterday. But the index remained far below levels of a year ago, the business-supported research group said.

title: Stanley C. Rayfield, Author Of Photojournalism Books
description: Stanley C. Rayfield, the author and editor of two books on photojournalism at Life magazine in the 1950's, died Sunday at the Crouse Irving Hospital in Syracuse. He was 81 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: N. Carolina Wins, 80-78

title: Dorfman Associate Indicted
description: Anthony Spilotro, a friend of the slain Teamsters' associate Allen M. Dorfman, was indicted today in the 1962 ''contract killings'' of James Miraglia and William McCarthy in Chicago. Mr. Spilotro was arrested today in Nevada by Federal Bureau of Investigationagents on a fugitive warrant. Assistant State's Attorney Paul Nealis called him ''the liaison between Chicago organized crime and organized crime in Las Vegas.''

title: MACNEIL PROGRAM EXPANDING
description: ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,'' a nightly half hour of news and analysis on public television, will be expanded to an hour this year, possibly as early as July 1.

title: Dressing Up Drumthwacket
description: Will we ever know what really happened at Drumthwacket? Will the mystery of who ordered the dispersal of the American Empire furniture ever be solved? (And now that we're accustomed to ''Drumthwacket'' - Scottish for hill and thicket -will we ever be able to thtop thaying it?)

title: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AGM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Gets N.C.A.A. Rebuke
description: The University of Washington has been publicly reprimanded for three rules violations in its 1980 unsuccessful recruiting of a basketball player, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.

title: A big sale of ceramics.
description: THE second part of one of this season's most successful auctions at Sotheby Parke Bernet takes place on Saturday, Feb. 5, at 2 P.M. Being offered is the ceramics collection of Wilfrid Swall, and the exhibition of the lavishly decorated 19th-century monumental vases, plates and decorations at the gallery on York Avenue at 72d Street begins tomorrow and continues through next Friday.

title: GEORGES BIDAULT, RESISTANCE HERO WHO LATER LED A REVOLT, IS DEAD
description: Georges Bidault, a Resistance leader who became Foreign Minister and Prime Minister of France and then a wanted man for his opposition to freedom for Algeria, died today in a hospital in Cambo-les-Bains, near Bayonne, in southwest France. He was 83 years old and had suffered a stroke in December. ---- From Hero to Exile By Henry Giniger

title: SILAS B. FISHKIND
description: Silas B. Fishkind, who retired as assistant to the sports editor of The New York Times in 1962, died Wednesday at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old and lived in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: CONCERT: MENUHIN AND THE PHILHARMONIC
description: WE hear a lot about personality in the great virtuoso violinists of yore and what a difference it made in their playing. Elders among us can still testify to the reality of the Kreisler charm, the Elman tone, the Szgeti intellect and so on, while in certain instances such individual qualities even can be heard trying to break through in their old recordings.

title: Miss Jaeger Gains
description: Andrea Jaeger, seeded first, easily defeated JoAnne Russell, 6-3, 6-1, today in a third-round match of the $100,000 Avon Cup tournament. Miss Jaeger advanced to a quarterfinal meeting against Dianne Fromholtz of Australia.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,790,000 for the qr and yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,821,000 for the qr and $9,675,000 for the yr

title: EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quebec Is Preparing To Fine Strikers
description: As a spreading general strike by provincial employees shut down all public schools in this province, Premier Rene Levesque's government prepared today to fine those already striking. It also warned that if the illegal walkouts hit hospitals and psychiatric clinics as strike organizers vowed harsh new penalties would be legislated against the unions.

title: Bolivia Accuses Barbie Of Organizing Ex-Nazis
description: A former Nazi SS officer, Klaus Barbie, who was arrested Tuesday in Bolivia, has been charged with organizing other former Nazis and sympathizers as mercenaries paid through cocaine sales and using them to silence foes of past military regimes, Bolivian officials said.

GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Welcome Mat Out

title: Martin Marietta's Chief Adds Role of Chairman
description: Thomas G. Pownall, president and chief executive of the Martin Marietta Corporation and a key player in one of the most bizarre corporate takeover fights ever, has been named to the additional post of chairman.

title: FALKLANDS PROTECTORATE NO ONE WOULD PROTECT
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: HARRIET DE ROSIERE, who was born in Columbus, Ohio, married a FrenchV iscount and lives in Houston, celebrated her birthday this week in N ew York. Naturally, the Viscountess, who was wearing a Nina Ricci d ress and Marina B. jewels, did not announce which birthday it was, b ut one of the guests said she looked 10 years younger than she did 1 0 years ago, which provoked a lot of conversation.

title: Topics; Public Service; Like Summer Camp
description: ''The problem of a park,'' wrote Frederick Olmsted, the man who designed Central Park, ''is the reconciliation of adequate beauty of nature in scenery, and holding it available to the use of those needing it.'' Few have fulfilled that mission better than Gordon Davis, who has just resigned as New York's Parks Commissioner.

title: GULF OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest qr earnings include LIFO profits of $180 million against $15 millionin yr-earlier period; the 1982 qr also includes a charge of $50 million for certain department of energy matters; the 1982 earnings included $439 million before tax of LIFO inventory liquidation profits compared to $15 million in 1981

title: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
AMERICAN, GERMAN COMMON INTERESTS
description: West Germany's debate about deploying medium-range American nuclear missiles highlights the inescapable paradox in any West German government's approach to East-West relations. Whether Christian Democrats or Social Democrats govern in Bonn after the federal elections on March 6, national interest will require from the government both loyalty to the Atlantic alliance and engagement with the Soviet Union - both a strong defense for the West and active negotiations with the East. Pursuing both courses simultaneously and deflecting American and Russian pressures to choose definitely between them is the essence of Bonn's security policy.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RICHARDSON-VICKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for the adoption of the LIFO inventory valuation method

title: Transition Effected At Transamerica
description: James R. Harvey has been elected chairman of the Transamerica Corporation, a San Francisco conglomerate with revenues last year of $4.3 billion.

title: ART: 9-PAINTING SHOW THAT'S BEST OF SEASON
description: THE most distinguished show of the season so far can be seen at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, through Feb. 23. It has a very plain title - ''A Painting Exhibition'' -and there are only nine paintings in it. But their mutual interaction has been brought about by a superior intelligence, and they have been installed with a subtlety of perception that we do not always find in major museums. The artists involved are (in alphabetical order) Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Brice Marden, Robert Mangold, Elizabeth Murray, Robert Ryman, Frank Stella, Susan Rothenberg and Terry Winters. Almost without exception, they have sent major new works.

title: ANOTHER LONG SHOT
description: In this city of constant political calculations, one of the most interesting now tests the acumen of Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas - to be or not to be a candidate for the Presidency.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 28, 1983; Companies
description: Western Electric will close its Kearny, N.J., plant as part of a plan to reduce idle capacity. The decision will eliminate 4,000 jobs at Kearny, while cutbacks at two other sites, including the Hawthorne Works in Cicero, Ill., Western's oldest plant, will cost 2,700 jobs. The streamlining by Western reflects the impact of the recession as well as a desire to become more competitive now that it is no longer assured of business from Bell's subsidiaries. (Page A1.)

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Japan Tunnel Ranks As Largest in World
description: Japanese engineers today completed a 33.7-mile tunnel, the longest in the world, under the Tsugaru Strait. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone pressed a button in his office in Tokyo, setting off a dynamite blast that tore apart a rock wall, linking the ends of the tunnel.

title: WHAT THE E.P.A. IS DOING ABOUT DIOXIN
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. TO REHIRE 21,400 AS AUTO OUTPUT RISES
description: An influx of orders for new cars prompted major auto companies today to call back thousands of laid-off workers, announce an increase in production schedules and, in one case, reopen a closed plant.

title: GAINS AGAINST ORGANIZED CRIME ARE REPORTED BY REAGAN OFFICIALS
description: The Reagan Administration's two top law-enforcement officials expressed guarded optimism before a Senate committee today that the Government might be starting to prevail against some elements of organized crime.

title: Missile Trees and the Geneva Woods
description: The Geneva woods may still be too chilly for more private Soviet-American strolls and bargaining over Euromissiles. But as the formal negotiations resume, including a visit from Vice President Bush, a compromise like the one attempted last July is in the European air. Both sides would be better off talking compromise instead of begging the West German electorate to decide.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP JAZZ
description: THE music that will be played at Sweet Basil this weekend by Abdullah Ibrahim, the pianist and composer from Cape Town, who was known as Dollar Brand until his conversion to Islam in 1968, reflects some of the influences on his development as a musician. They will include compositions by Duke Ellington, with whom Mr. Ibrahim had a very close relationship, and compositions of his own that draw on both indigenous African musical traditions and jazz and blues sources. Two of the pianist's works are dedicated to Thelonious Monk, the pianist, and to John Coltrane, the saxophonist.

title: ABELARD, MEDVEDEV: SAME BOAT AND PADDLE
description: I thought of Peter Abelard when I read about the crackdown in Moscow against the noted dissident historian Roy A. Medvedev.

title: Bach at Museum
description: The Bach Aria Group will play arias and duets from Bach cantatas at the Metropolitan Museum tonight at 8.

title: G.E. TO SELL A UNIT FOR $2.4 BILLION
description: The General Electric Company, in a major move to free up money to invest in high technology, announced last night that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell Utah International Inc., a major subsidiary, for $2.4 billion in cash to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd., Australia's giant steel and natural resource company.

title: STANDARD OIL CO (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSEUM PLUMBS MYSTERIES OF DEEP
description: Great white sharks charge at a cage in which a researcher waits to fire a small, instrument-laden harpoon into one of them. One shark's head bursts part-way through the bars and becomes stuck, leading to frantic thrashing.

title: AMERICAN HOSPITAL SUPPLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $400,000 for the qr and $34 million for the yr from discontinued operations and gains of $17.6 million for the qr and $25.5 million for the yr on the retirement of debt...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $4.1 million for the qr and $13.1 million for the yr

description: B-Including income of $1,084,000 from an accounting change

title: INVESTIGATORS OF SENTRY THEFT ARE OPTIMISTIC OVER LEADS
description: The quarries are $11 million and the gunmen who stole it last month from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx. For the 37 hunters - a special unit of investigators - the sevenweek search has produced a tangle of clues and possible evidence that they believe will soon uncover the suspects.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: B-Includes income of $130,000 from discontinued operations; results for the yr-ago 9 mos have been restated to reflect an accounting change for foreign currency translation under F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 which increased the net income by $119,000 or 5 cents a shr

title: A FIRKUSNY TRIBUTE TO HIS CZECH COUNTRYMEN
description: The pianist Rudolf Firkusny has long been known for his selfeffacing approach to performing and for his loyalty to the music of his native Czechoslovakia. Both qualities should be in evidence tonight and Sunday, when Mr. Firkusny will join the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Dvorak's Trio in F minor and in the Capriccio for Piano Left-Hand, Flute and Brass by Mr. Firkusny's first teacher, the composer Leos Janacek.

title: CANADA ALLOWS NEW GAS EXPORTS TO JAPAN, NOT NORTHEASTERN U.S.
description: Canada's National Energy Board today authorized substantial new shipments of natural gas to Japan instead of meeting requests from importers in the Northeastern United States.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
The hurdles a film maker must get over.
description: IN Australia, the movie business, which has flown high for a few years, may be about to crash. A week or so ago, the actors' union decided to shut out non-Australian performers, but nobody else seems to think that will solve the industry's problems. Mel Gibson, who plays the lead in ''The Year of Living Dangerously,'' says Australian film makers have been greedy. ''Sometimes they act like a bunch of kids over there. You could get a tax writeoff if you invested in a motion picture, so, rather than doing good films, people would do stuff half-cocked. Now the tax laws have changed, and that's thrown a spanner into the works.''

title: ART: HIRSCHL AND ADLER OPEN MODERN GALLERY
description: OPENING a gallery, like having a baby, calls for optimism as well as planning in even the best of economic times. With Hirschl and Adler, faith is born of experience, for that gallery has been in existence some 30 years, dealing in 19th- and early-20th-century American art, generally of a conservative kind. That it has elected to move deeper into the modern era and to expand its premises is therefore an event of some importance.

title: HARLEM DANCERS AND DIAGHILEV DAYS
description: No new production of the Dance Theater of Harlem this season has caused such intense curiosity as the revival of Bronislava Nijinska's ''Les Biches,'' which will be performed tonight, tomorrow afternoon and Sunday night at City Center, where the company will play through Feb. 27. But then, the ballet, restaged for Dance Theater by Irina Nijinska, the choreographer's daughter, has stirred more than its share of talk from its first performance by Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes on Jan. 6, 1924, in Monte Carlo.

title: OPEC RIFT UNSETTLES MEXICO
description: Before Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog set off on a tour of Western financial capitals last week, Mexico's hard-pressed Government appeared to have worked out almost to the penny how it would cover import needs and interest payments this year.

title: DINOSAUR EXTINCTION THEORY IS CHALLENGED BY NEW STUDY
description: Two scientists have reported geological evidence that challenges the recent and widely discussed theory that the dinosaurs and numerous other species became extinct when the earth was struck by an asteroid about 65 million years ago.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Raid Army's Biggest Barracks
description: Guerrillas attacked the San Carlos army barracks, El Salvador's biggest, and other military posts early today in what officials here said were the most daring raids in months. The San Carlos barracks are about a mile from the United States Embassy.

title: DOW JONES & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan 31

title: Fed Chairman Noncommittal
description: In the first public comment on his prospects for reappointment, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that he had ''no expectations one way or the other'' of being reappointed by the President.

title: E.T., Call Home
description: The National Football League Alumni Association has a message board at Super Bowl headquarters in Los Angeles and, naturally, the same people who used to clutter blackboards in high school with so-called jokes are having a field day.

title: Delta Air Lines Reports a Loss
description: Delta Air Lines yesterday reported a loss of $5.6 million for its fiscal second quarter, ended Dec. 31, in contrast to a profit of $8.5 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Leo Santini, a Vice President Of 7 Santini Brothers Movers
description: Brig. Gen. Leo A. Santini, retired, executive vice president of the Seven Santini Brothers International Moving Company, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Harvester Extends Its Debt Swap
description: The International Harvester Company, which has been pressing its public debtholders for concessions, said that it would extend for the third time the deadline on its offer to exchange old bonds for new debentures with detachable warrants.

title: Super Bowl XVII Dolphins' Cornerbacks an Efficient Pair
description: Jan. 27 - In the three playoff victories that brought the Miami Dolphins to their Super Bowl XVII match against the Washington Redskins on Sunday in the Rose Bowl, opposing wide receivers have caught 10 passes for 132 yards.

title: THE COUTURE'S OWN GALA
description: The social life of the city is carefully entwined with the fashion world during the week of haute couture openings. After their first show the designers entertain their favorite clients at small lunches and dinners. But there have been some larger gatherings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''But you get certain privileges in the Senate, and sometimes you get the short end of the stick; I had my short-end years.'' - Senator John C. Stennis. (A18:6.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City Knocking On Wetland's Door

title: BUSH, ON EVE OF NEW TRIP, ASKS RUSSIANS FOR NEW IDEAS
description: Vice President Bush, disclosing that he would meet with Soviet arms negotiators in Geneva on his trip to Europe, urged Moscow today to come forward with a balanced, equal proposal for sharp limits on Soviet and American nuclear forces in Europe.

title: Falling Sculpture Kills Woman
description: A 25-year-old Manhattan woman who worked in the lower Manhattan studio and gallery of the sculptor Beverly Pepper was killed Wednesday when one of the artist's 10-foot-tall, 500-pound iron sculptures apparently fell on her.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
