title: TEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reluctant Guests
description: Officials of the North American Soccer League were keeping officially mum on the response of players invited to try out for the league's newest franchise, Team America. If the reactions of the four Seattle Sounders on the invitation list are typical, silence is probably the best policy.

title: ALEX BLACKMAN
description: Alex Blackman, chairman of the Shore Lobster and Shrimp Corporation, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Malverne, L.I. He was 69 years old.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: The British trade surplus rose to the equivalent of $910 million in December, from $725 million in November, the Trade Department said today.

title: Bobsled Winners
description: Bob Hickey and Rich Bisso, both of New York State, won the North American two-man bobsled championship today at Mount Van Hoevenberg. Hickey, of Keene, and Bisso, from Plattsburgh, came from behind in the final two heats to defeat Brent Rushlaw and Jim Tyler of Saranac Lake, N.Y., the second-place finishers.

title: Big Payday Lost
description: On New Year's Day at their training camp in Great Gorge, N.J., Davey Moore, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, and his manager, Leon Washington, were listening to the radio. This was going to be a good year, they figured, capped by a $1.5 million payday to defend against Tony Ayala Jr. in the spring.

title: SCANNING FOUR CENTURIES OF THEATER DESIGN
description: THE permanence of the art of theater is not limited to printed plays, recordings and personal memories. It is also evident in stage and costume design, and in the architecture of theaters themselves. Drawings, etchings and models of past productions and theater buildings make it possible to reconstruct the theatrical past.

title: Flyers 5, Jets 2
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Mark Taylor and Ray Allison scored a pair of goals 35 seconds apart in the third period to seal the Philadelphia victory.

title: PRETORIA'S ISRAEL MASK
description: Comparison with Israel has become an insistent theme in South Africa when people there discuss their country's actions. It keeps popping up, so heatedly that it inevitably involves America - as though the United States does and must have the same attitude toward both countries.

STAGE: 'MISANTHROPE' AT CIRCLE IN THE SQUARE
description: THANKS to Brian Bedford, the Circle in the Square's new and excessively becalmed revival of ''The Misanthrope'' does provide a rough idea of why Moliere's bleak comedy endures. Mr. Bedford, an actor of sure-footed intelligence and reticent passions, provides a protagonist who, like the play that contains him, skirts both the ridiculous and the tragic. More important, his Alceste is a man with a mystery at his core. In concert with Moliere, the actor asks us to contemplate the troubling and often hidden ambiguities of the heart.

title: Soup Kitchen Sets Westport Opening
description: A soup kitchen will open in Westport, Conn., on Monday, a group called the Homeless People's Committee announced yesterday. Two men who have been fasting since Jan. 16 said they would eat again after the first bowl of soup was served.

title: Manville Outlines a Plan on Claims
description: The Manville Corporation outlined a proposal today that could reduce its liability in thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits by removing those suits from court jurisdiction and submitting them to arbitration.

title: BOMBING ROCKS LESOTHO AS 9 BLACK NATIONS MEET
description: Explosives, apparently planted by an exiled Lesotho opposition group that operates with tacit South African support, went off at a water storage installation here early today shortly before the opening of a conference of nine black African nations seeking reduced economic dependence on Pretoria.

title: THAT FINE PRINT IN BANK ADS
description: A blizzard of bank ads promoting the new money-market-rate accounts has hit in the last month. They feature big numbers, in big bold type. But some Government agencies and consumer advocates taking a close look at the promotions are concerned about what lies in the fine print.

SENATE PANEL COOL TO ARMS NOMINEE
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's choice to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, had a cool reception from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as the panel began confirmation hearings on his nomination.

'A Tough Appearance'
description: T he new Republican national chairman, Frank Fahrenkopf of Nevada, is planning to inaugurate his leadership with a bold and unusual political move.for a Republican chairman. After his election today, he will announce plans to attend the annual A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in Bal Harbour, Fla., next month to try to make friends for the party or at least reduce animosity toward it.

title: CORRECTION
description: A proposal to amend the New York State gross receipts tax on oil was incorrectly described in some editions yesterday by aides to Governor Cuomo. The amendment would permit oil companies to pass along the cost of the tax to consumers in New York State.

title: Paris Cartier Store Robbed
description: Three gunmen held up a Cartier jewelry store in central Paris today and got away with items worth about $1.4 million, the police said.

title: PLOT ON POPE ASIDE, BULGARIA'S NOTORIETY RESTS ON SMUGGLING
description: Sofia, known as one of the most restrictive Communist capitals, has in recent years gained the paradoxical reputation of also being one of the focal points of high-living international crime syndicates.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY BACKS INJECTIONS FOR EXECUTIONS
description: The New Jersey Assembly passed a bill today to require lethal injection as the state's method of capital punishment.The Assembly voted for the bill, 46 to 12, despite some objections that the method amounted to ''mollycoddling'' killers. Forty-one votes were needed for passage.

title: TV: A NEW 'PHANTOM OF THE OPERA'
description: WHY another version of ''Phantom of the Opera?'' Well, why not? Where else nowadays can you find a cracked conductor, an imperiled soprano, a lascivious baron, so many spooky corridors and so much Gothic huggermugger under one chandeliered roof? For those who didn't catch any of the previous versions, which starred Lon Chaney (1925), Claude Rains (1943) and Herbert Lom (1962), this is the tale of a conductor, played tomorrow night at 9 on Channel 2 by Maximilian Schell, whose wife (Jane Seymour) commits suicide after an unsuccessful debut in ''Faust.''

title: BRACKET-CREEP REMEDY WITHOUT SIDE EFFECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Told to Keep Pros Out of Track
description: The head of the world governing body of track and field has threatened action that would interfere with plans for the 1984 Summer Games if the United States Olympic Committee doesn't bow to international rules banning professionals from all amateur competition.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Deficits And Realism
description: IS President Reagan's new realism for real? That depends on how one defines realism. As the term is used by modern writers and artists, realism means looking at life as it is, without being visionary or idealistic. Thus, an ashcan is an ashcan, a jobless worker is a jobless worker, not a heroic, if drafted, soldier in the fight against inflation. The President now, realistically, sees a string of deficits in the $200 billion to $300 billion class stretching far into the future unless painful surgery on the budget is performed; once, he envisioned a balanced budget, first in the current, 1983 fiscal year, then in the 1984 fiscal year.

title: ART: A REVIVAL OF RECOGNITION FOR SIX
description: IN the big, heady bustle of our pluralistic art scene, some good work inevitably gets lost. For one, it may not lend itself to trendy categorizations or theme shows; then again, an artist may be between dealers, so to speak, and too shy or busy to push him- or herself; thirdly, the world may simply be looking the other way. And so the idea of bringing together ''established professionals who deserve wider recognition'' is certainly not to be quibbled with. This highminded, nontheme theme is the premise of ''Exceptions,'' a show at the Pratt Manhattan Center Gallery, 160 Lexington Avenue, at 30th Street (through Feb. 19), which exposes the work of six artists who have been on the scene for a while but have not exhibited in New York for the last few years.

title: PANEL URGES NEW LAWS TO AID CRIME VICTIMS
description: Concluding that the rights of victims have been made secondary to the rights of criminals, the President's Task Force on Victims of Crime today issued a report urging changes in the law and the Constitution.

title: STUDY VOTED FOR REFUSE-BURNING PLANT
description: Contracts for consulting work needed for a final decision on whether to build a garbage-burning incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard were approved yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Your Money; Studying Costs To Save More
description: AS the Federal Government wrestles with its budget, individuals might consider doing the same. Few individuals keep detailed records of what they spend in the same way that a Government agency does. But for most individuals, the question usually becomes one of whether they are saving enough.

title: ROZELLE REVIEWS '82 SEASON
description: After a player strike, disclosures of drug abuse, lawsuits involving the Raiders' move from Oakland to Los Angeles, and accusations of illegal gambling and thrown games, Commissioner Pete Rozelle conceded today that it had been ''a very distasteful year for the players, coaches and owners of the National Football League.''

title: MUBARAK ASKS ISRAELI MODERATION
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in a speech last night to the Foreign Policy Association, a New York-based organization, called on Israel to show moderation toward the Palestinians.

title: Dublin Prime Minister Visits Northern Ireland
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald has broken new ground by traveling to British-ruled Northern Ireland and speaking out on the troubles there, which he called ''the greatest single political crisis in Western Europe.''

title: Charges Ruled Out In Fatal Bus Crash
description: District Attorney Michael Kavanagh of Ulster County said today that there was not enough evidence to bring criminal charges against the drivers of a bus and a truck that crashed on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway earlier this month, killing three people.

description: V.S. Naipaul has been named winner of the Jerusalem Prize, awarded every two years to a writer whose work expresses the idea of "the freedom of the individual in society."

description: Fourteen months after a Harvard University student from New Jersey vanished in Boston, authorities say they are investigating information that the woman might have been slain by a Boston man facing murder charges in another case.

description: The National Congress of American Indians today formally applauded President Reagan's new statement on Indian policy, particularly the President's promise that his Administration would more often deal directly with the tribes on a government-togovernment basis.

description: The $9 million in state money needed to avert a threatened layoff of 1,000 New York City teachers will be provided, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

description: Greg Stemrick, a starting cornerback for the Houston Oilers, was indicted by a Harris County grand jury today on charges of cocaine possession.

GIRL, 6, KILLED IN NEWARK FIRE
description: A 6-year-old girl was killed and eight people were injured when a suspicious fire swept through a three-story frame building here early this morning. Some of the building's tenants were hurt when they jumped from second- and third-story windows to escape the flames.

title: ELDERLY LOVERS CONFRONT A SINGULAR KIND OF GRIEF
description: Frank Martin is not a very big man and he looked even smaller bundled up in a bulky ski sweater, wisps of white hair peeking out from under a thick woolen cap. His upper Yorkville apartment was not very warm, although he was.

title: DEVELOPER IN ABSCAM CASE GETS THREE YEARS IN PRISON
description: A New Jersey real-estate developer convicted of conspiring to bribe Congressmen was sentenced to three years in prison yesterday by a judge who said that ''corruption that destroys the faith of the citizen in his representatives simply cannot be tolerated in a democratic republic.''

title: B.P., Shell Raise Prices
description: British companies are raising the price of gasoline despite widespread predictions that world oil prices may fall because of competition among major exporters. British Petroleum and the Shell Oil Company announced today that they were adding 1 1/2 cents a gallon to their retail prices.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
The Talk of Lisbon
description: The depth of political passions in Portugal can be measured by the height of the political posters on the walls. An ever-rising tidewater mark of democracy, in some places they are up to the third story now. For some reason a lot of poster plasterers don't want to cover up those already there. Artists at heart, they don't want to besmirch the oeuvre. For the political archeologist, this makes for a field day. It's possible to meander along a cobbled back street and unearth history with a simple glance up at the peeling pink facade of an 18th-century villa - layer upon layer of slogans and artwork from bygone elections and controversies that have given this country 14 Governments in the last nine years.

title:

description: WASHINGTON FIVE persons who obtained the original patents for important developments will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame on Feb. 13. They will join 44 other members, including Thomas A. Edison and Henry Ford.

description: The police caught Britain's most-wanted man tonight after a chase through a subway tunnel just hours after offering a reward for his capture.

description: Virginia Mauret, founder and director of the Young Artists Opera, died in New York City Jan. 16.

title: BOEING'S TOUCHY JAPANESE TIE
description: When the Japanese decided to build a train, they built one of the fastest anywhere. When they decided to produce cars, they produced some of the most efficient. And when they turned their sights on computers, their rapid rise stunned the competition. Now, the Japanese are looking for new industries to master, and they have chosen aerospace, commercial aircraft production in particular.

title: Paper Says Article on Mixup At Boston Pub Is Inaccurate
description: Secret Service officials denied a newspaper report today that President Reagan's unexpected visit to a Boston bar Wednesday foiled a stakeout by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the paper later said the news article was inaccurate.

title: Kidnappers Free Italian, 72
description: A 72-year-old toy manufacturer, Aldredo Capacchietti, was freed unharmed near a highway outside Pescara today after his family paid $410,000 ransom, the police said.

title: ACCUSED U.S. JUDGE ON WITNESS STAND
description: A Federal district judge facing charges of conspiracy to solicit a bribe and obstruction of justice took the witness stand here today in his own defense, offering an explanation of his contacts with the man alleged to be his co-conspirator that differs sharply from the one offered by the Government.

title: FRANK B. BANE, 89, FIRST SOCIAL SECURITY CHIEF
description: Frank B. Bane, the first administrator of the Social Security System and an author of the legislation that created it, died Sunday of cancer at the Washington House retirement home in Alexandria, Va. He was 89 years old.

title: MOVING A-WASTE
description: Does transportation of nuclear waste pose unprecedented dangers? This question is central to a case that is to begin Feb. 14 in the United States Court of Appeals in New York City. The appeal arose from a decision by the Federal District Court in Manhattan to uphold the city's ban on the movement of radioactive waste within municipal limits.

title: RESCIND TAX CUT, U.S. MAYORS URGE
description: Leaders of the United States Conference of Mayors today called for repeal of the third installment of President Reagan's income tax cut, with the proceeds going to an emergency urban aid program and cutting then deficit.

title: Revere Copper
description: Revere Copper & Brass Inc., which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, said its 1982 fourth-quarter results would contain a provision for reserves of about $99.8 million, some $88.3 million of which would be applicable to its Scottsboro, Ala. aluminum reduction plant, which was closed indefinitely in June, 1982. Revere said the total provision also includes reserves applicable to closed copper and brass operations, and that despite recent improvement in aluminum demand, the selling price for primary aluminum remains substantially below the estimated production cost at the Scottsboro facility. The company said it is uncertain when it may become feasible to reopen the plant.

title: Gunman Wounds Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty transit police officer was shot twice early yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with one of two men who tried to rob him, the police said. The two men escaped, but one may have been wounded.

title: 2 Stocks Up Slightly On Economic News
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday, buoyed by additional indications that the economy may be improving. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up 10.49 points at 1 P.M., its high for the session, closed ahead 1.10 points, to 1,064.75, as profit-taking erased some of the earlier gains. For the week, the average rose 11.75 points.

title: MOVIE ABOUT TERRORISTS' USE OF NEWS
description: The troubling issue of the manipulation of television news by terrorists has arisen with increasing frequency in recent years. It was most evident during the Iranian hostage crisis, and more recently the uprising at the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., provoked questions about how television news should react when it is reporting on something involving human lives at stake.

title: First-Time Claims by Jobless Are Fewest Since Fall of '81
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits by Americans totaled 491,000 in the week ended Jan. 15, the lowest filing level since September 1981, the Labor Department said Thursday.

title: DISPUTING LANDLORDS ON RENT
description: FOR months you have scoured the newspaper ads for apartments. You'vek nocked on doors, talked to superintendents, followed up rumors, p ossibly hired an agent who charges a hefty finder's fee. And now, a lmost unbelievably, you have found a vacant rent-stabilized a partment in New York City. Dare you try to find out if the landlord i s charging an illegally high rent?

title: 'PENZANCE' TO MAKE DEBUTE ON PAY TV
description: Three weeks from tonight, Hollywood takes a daring step into what one studio chairman has called ''the electronic fireplace.''

title: IKE AND REAGAN
description: Ronald Reagan, The Great Communicator, has a lot to learn about being persuasive from Dwight D. Eisenhower, who is remembered for bumbling public utterances.

title: TWO-CITY COMPANIES, A NEW TREND IN DANCE
description: The Joffrey Ballet is well along with its plans to become a bicoastal ballet company, based both in New York City, its home for 28 years, and in Los Angeles. The Cincinnati Ballet is negotiating to become the New Orleans City Ballet part of each year, and the Hartford and Fort Worth Ballets are working on a plan to co-produce the classics.

title: BIAS SUIT MADE GRIMMER BY A SUICIDE
description: The recent suicide of the most prominent black executive at the Volkswagen of America factory here has brought national attention to a racial discrimination suit against the automobile maker.

title: Youth Division Head Nominated by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo today nominated a North Carolina official as Director of the state's Division for Youth. In a statement, Mr. Cuomo said that the official, Leonard Dunston, 42 years old, would take the post previously held by Frank A. Hall.

title: GATX Profit Falls 59%
description: The GATX Corporation, a leading manufacturer and lessor of capital equipment, including railroad cars and ocean vessels, today reported a 59 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings, to $6.3 million, or 51 cents a share, from $15.4 million, or $1.19 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Vandals Damage Weekly Newspaper
description: The office of Our Town, a weekly newspaper that is distributed free to apartment buildings on Manhattan's East Side, was vandalized Thursday, according to the paper's publisher, Edward Kayatt.

title: Paul M. O'Brien Dead; Aide to City Comptroller
description: Paul M. O'Brien, New York City's third deputy comptroller, died yesterday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I., after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

ECONOMIC INDICATOR MAKES BEST GAIN IN 2 YEARS
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, intended to forecast economic trends, rose 1.5 percent in December, the largest increase in the past two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Polish Primate Meets Pope; Glemp Is 'Sure' of Papal Visit
description: Pope John Paul II conferred for half an hour today with Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, who arrived Thursday to be made a Cardinal.

title: Airline Smoke Rules Restored
description: A Federal appeals court today restored protections for nonsmokers on airliners, 16 months after the Civil Aeronautics Board dropped them in favor of self-regulation by the airlines.

title: GOING TO THE ROOT OF THE SUPER BOWL
description: LOS ANGELES M ore than 100,000 fans will be packed into the Rose Bowl in Pasadena tomorrow to watch Super Bowl XVII, more than 100 million people will view it on television, and an estimated $600 million will be bet on whether the Miami team or Washington can push a football across a stripe of white paint with greater frequency.

title: PANHANDLE BACKED ON ALGERIA GAS PACT
description: A Federal administrative law judge recommended today that import contracts for Algerian natural gas be upheld.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Fight Decision
description: Russ Anderson of the Hartford Whalers admitted that he deliberately struck Dave Taylor of the Los Angeles Kings with his stick in a game Jan. 20, but when the matter came up at a hearing on Thursday before Brian O'Neill, executive vice president of the National Hockey League, Anderson argued that he had been provoked.

title: News Analysis

title: Pershing 2 Test Called Success
description: The Army has pronounced successful the test flight last week of a Pershing 2 missile, the type scheduled for deployment in West Germany beginning in December.

description: President Reagan is proposing an $848.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1984 that keeps pace with expected inflation and projects a deficit of $189 billion, provided Congress enacts a series of freezes and reductions in domestic programs.

title: Paperwork's 2 Sides: Reality/noisu11I
description: A recent change of jobs that moved me out of a laboratory and into an administrative office has provided me an opportunity to study people who take paperwork very seriously. Some take the filing and filling out of various forms so seriously that I conclude theirs is a form of social behavior that can be described as cultural schizophrenia.

title: Petrofina Selling Stake
description: Petrofina S.A. said it planned to sell its remaining stake in Petrofina Canada, now known as Petro-Canada Enterprises Inc. Petrofina said in a statement other Petrofina Canada shareholders have until Feb. 28 to respond to the offer. In 1981 petrofina began selling its approximately 8 million shares of Petrofina Canada, about 70 percent of the company.

title: NIGERIA'S ILLEGAL ALIENS LEAVING AMID CHAOS
description: Thousands of Ghanaians were moving onto the Lagos dockside today, joining tens of thousands already there, in the hope of getting a ship home after the Nigerian Government ordered them out of the country as illegal aliens.

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MORE ODDITIES THAN RECORDS
description: Among the unscheduled stops at the Millrose Games last night: On the final lap of the women's mile, Mary Decker Tabb stumbled while lapping Angelita Lind of Puerto Rico. Miss Lind's failure to move aside, Mrs. Tabb said, cost her two seconds, although she won easily. She found her time of 4:25.27 slightly embarrassing, saying, ''It was one of my slowest miles.''

title: SALVADOR RIGHTIST SUFFERS A SETBACK
description: The coalition of five-right wing parties that dominates the Constituent Assembly here showed some signs of weakening Thursday evening when Roberto d'Aubuisson, its leader and the president of the Assembly, failed in his attempt to block a Cabinet appointment.

description: In an interview in the current Carnegie Hall program booklet, Leonard Slatkin says that he has chosen warhorse symphonies to conclude the St. Louis Symphony's two winter New York programs because he feels his ensemble is now ready to be measured against the ''yardstick'' of the other major orchestras that play regularly in the hall.

description: Governor Cuomo will ask the Legislature to approve a 36 percent increase in unemployment insurance, raising the maximum benefit from $125 to $170 a week, senior administration aides said yesterday.

Gen. Maurice Preston Dead; Led Early Raid Over Germany
description: Gen. Maurice A. Preston, retired, of the Air Force, who led the 1943 ''Black Thursday'' bombing raid on ballbearing factories at Schweinfurt, Germany, died Tuesday of cancer. He was 70 years old.

description: Several Western nations pledged $206.5 million in additional grants and loans today to help nine southern African countries end their economic dependence on whiteruled South Africa.

title: Bridge: Trying to Overpower Foe May Not Be Wisest Course
description: A boxer who knows that he is winning on points should not be overaggressive and risk being knocked out. Similarly a bridge player who knows he is winning on match points should not venture too much. This applies not merely to overall strategy in terms of a session of play but also in the framework of a single deal.

title: Return to the Falkland Riddle
description: The Falkland war is over, but Britain's dilemma remains. It is clearly defined by Sir Nicholas Henderson, London's Ambassador to Washington during the crisis: Without a deal with Argentina, the islands' development will lag and Britain will be saddled with a huge military burden. But, he wisely adds, there'll be no deal until Argentina gets some satisfaction concerning ''sovereignty.''

title: KEARNY PLANT IS DYING, ALONG WITH AN OLD ERA
description: At its robust best just after World War II, Western Electric's Kearny Works employed 24,000 people and boasted that it was the busiest manufacturing plant in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's empire.

title: FAMILY CELEBRATIONS MARKED WITH GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: The observance of memorable occasions - of birthdays and wedding anniversaries, of days remembered and treasured - often inspires a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help those less fortunate.

title: Billy Fury, 42, British Singer; Is Called Heart Attack Victim
description: The British pop singer Billy Fury died today at his home here - reportedly of a heart attack.

title: Judge Grants New Trial In 10-Year-Old Murder
description: Judge Edward Blake of Common Pleas Court today ordered a new trial for a man convicted of rape and murder almost 10 years ago in what became known as the ''Art Museum Murder'' case.

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 29, 1983
description: International A Government shake-up in India brought about the resignation of the 60 members of the Cabinet and Council of Ministers. Only Prime Minister Indira Gandhi remained in office. It was believed likely that Mrs. Gandhi would accept most of the resignations, which followed the recent unexpected and decisive defeat of her Congress Party in two strongholds in southern India where the party had never lost. (Page 1, Column 1.) 14 people were killed in Lebanon when a car packed with explosives blew up outside an office building belonging to Yassir Arafat's Al Fatah Palestinian guerrilla group. Beirut television said the attack took place near Shtaura in eastern Lebanon. A group calling itself the ''Front to Liberate Lebanon From Foreigners'' said it was responsible for the attack. (1:2.) American officials were impressed by the strong concern of Egypt's President that Syria, as well as Israel, withdraw its forces from Lebanon to prevent the country from being permanently partitioned. Officials who have spoken with President Mubarak and senior Egyptian aides during a two-day visit to Washington said Mr. Mubarak had told them of his distrust of the motives of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. (4:1.)

title: BALLET: NIJINSKA 'BIRCHES,' BY THE HARLEM DANCERS
description: Bronislava Nijinska's ballet ''Les Biches,'' created to a commissioned score by Francis Poulenc in 1924 for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, is considered one of the milestones of ballet history.

description: B-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $9,960,000

title: Britain Gets Tough
description: Neil MacFarlane, Britain's Minister of Sports, has a plan to stop riots and other violence by soccer fans.

title: CALIFORNIA COAST HIT BY 4TH STORM AMID A CLEAN UP
description: Coastal areas of California that sustained millions of dollars in tidal and flood damage Thursday were struck today by yet another Pacific storm, this one feared to be carrying even more rains to the storm-battered state.

PATENTS;
Packaging Design
description: Sanford Redmond of New York, who has successfully invented packages for edibles, got a patent this week for another that holds butter, margarine, peanut butter and the like in a sealed container that, when opened, leaves the contents available on a flat card. Mr. Redmond, who received patent 4,369,885, says the Sealed Reddies, designed to avoid greasy fingers, are being produced and distributed by a number of plants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: ''C heck these breads by tapping and listening for the hollow sound,'' Charles Hill remembers having told his most recent baking class at the New York Restaurant School on West 34th Street. Now, he says with chagrin, ''I totally forgot I was teaching a deaf class.''

title: A HERO'S FAREWELL IS GIVEN TO BRYANT
description: Thousands lined the highways from Tuscaloosa today and surrounded the gravesite here to bid a hero's farewell to Bear Bryant, the most successful coach in college football history.

title: Carrier Ready to Rejoin Fleet
description: The renovated aircraft carrier Saratoga is scheduled to leave the Philadelphia Naval Yard Wednesday to rejoin the fleet, the Navy announced today. The ship has been in Philadelphia for 27 months to undergo a $526 million overhaul designed to extend her life by an additional 15 years.

title: LEBANON CAR-BLAST KILLS 14 AT CENTER FOR ARAFAT P.L.O. WING
description: A car packed with explosives blew up today in eastern Lebanon outside a building belonging to Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah Palestinian guerrilla group, killing 14 people, the state-run Beirut television said.

title: TOP LAWMAKERS PRAISE 'REALISM' OF REAGAN PLAN
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders today fastened on a single word, ''realistic,'' to describe the economic underpinning of President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1984.

title: Report Says Ex-Head of V.A.  Flew Home at U.S. Expense
description: Robert P. Nimmo, who resigned as head of the Veterans Administration in November, made four trips to his California home at Government expense in his first 11 months in office, according to Government auditors.

title: FROM FAR TO FOOTBALL AGAIN
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. U nwittingly, Vern den Herder, the veteran defensive end of the Miami Dolphins, may have discovered the perfect training regimen for the professional football player. He did not work out last summer. He did not lift weights. He did not run. While other players were working at training camps, den Herder's physical preparation was done on farmland in the heartland of America. There was a good reason for this new schedule. ''In my mind,'' den Herder said, ''I was retired.''

title: The Crime of Sentencing
description: Joe is in prison for robbing a gas station in Brooklyn. Sam is in for robbing one in a village upstate. They compare notes: Joe's maximum sentence is six years; he could be out in two. Sam's maximum is 25 years; with luck, he'll be out in 10. Neither understands the disparity, nor knows for sure when he will actually get out. Neither do their victims, who also ask why Joe and Sam shouldn't serve full terms.

title: Team America Coach
description: Alkis Panagoulias, a 48-year-old native of Greece and a naturalized American citizen, was named yesterday coach of Team America, the Washington-based squad that will operate as the national team of the United States and play this season in the North American Soccer League. description: Question: What is round, inflated and stacked in 667 cartons in the rotunda of Madison Square Garden? Answer: 8,000 basketballs. They were shipped from New London, Ohio, and unloaded from a truck yesterday afternoon, and now they are crammed (a dozen to the box) into the storage space where circus elephants and prize show dogs are sometimes housed.

STUDY FINDS FEWER FRESHMEN IN COLLEGE LOOK TO TEACHING
description: College freshmen today are less interested in becoming teachers than at any time in the last 17 years, according to a national survey sponsored by the American Council on Education and the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: REAGAN ASKS WIDE CUTS IN PRGRAMS TO AID POOR
description: President Reagan's new budget proposes further cutbacks in Federal programs for poor people, including welfare, food stamps and nutrition assistance for children, in an effort to save $14 billion over the next five years.

title: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ILL-CHOSEN LOCATION FOR AN S.R.O. HOTEL
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRBUS SALES LOSS TIED TO BETTER U.S. TERMS
description: The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, America's principal manufacturers of commercial aircraft, are beginning to win back part of the passenger jet market that they lost to the European Airbus by offering prospective clients more generous financing, the head of France's biggest aircraft manufacturer said today.

title: NEW CROP PROGRAM IS WORRYING FARM SUPPLIERS
description: Strong crosscurrents appear to lie ahead for this country's rural towns and villages, with waves of bankruptcies and new spurts of unemployment, as a result of a Federal program designed to help farmers.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $4,688,000

title: Communications Gap
description: The way the communications major was telling it yesterday, the contract negotiations with the cable television operator have reached ''an impasse.'' The way the cable television operator was telling it, the talks will be back on the track as soon as the details of the complicated job offer are properly explained.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. San Diego Clippers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Spurs, at San Antonio. (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 8:30 P.M.) Major College Games: St. John's at Manhattan, 3 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; WGBB, 1240; 3 P.M.); Syracuse at Villanova (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 1 P.M.); DePaul at Alabama-Birmingham (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.); Georgia Tech at North Carolina (Television -ESPN, 1 P.M.); Louisville at Virginia (Television -Channel 4, 3 P.M.); Old Dominion at South Florida (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.); Providence at Pittsburgh (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Purdue at Michigan State (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.).

title: WHEN FINESSE IS NOT ONE OF THE HOUSE SPECIALTIES
description: Many restaurant owners who take pride in their professionalism often fail to recognize that certain small, subtle details of service are essential. Performed incorrectly, they become the mark of the amateur. For all of those points of service there are traditional procedures that, when followed, lead to successful performance.

title: TRAIL BY TELEVISION
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Flourite said it had agreed to sell its operated subsidiaries to privately held NRG Exploration Inc. in a transaction valued at $28.5 million (Canadian.)

title: THE REGION
description: A disabled shipyard worker from Camden County and his wife, a housekeeper, were declared the winners of $3,536,652 today in the New Jersey Lottery's Pick-6 Lotto game.

title: White House Desire: Upbeat on the News
description: A Presidential spokesman, Larry Speakes, proposed today that the printed and electronic press, especially the television networks, begin covering ''good news'' as a regular feature.

title: THE REGION
description: Eleven students and three teachers were overcome today by gas at a junior high school in this Camden County community, the police said. The building was evacuated, and authorities said they believed that someone had released a can of tear gas or Chemical Mace.

title: COMMONWEALTH TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 18 about a proposed natural gas pipeline in Alaska gave an incorrect figure for total construction costs. The correct figure is $25.2 billion.

title: U.S. Gain Cited On Canada Gas
description: Canada's plans to export natural gas to Japan in 1986 for the first time are no threat to American supplies, United States officials said today.

title: POLICE SEIZE 4 AS MEMBERS OF GROUP THAT HAS ROBBED 40 BANKS IN CITY
description: The police said yesterday that they had arrested three men and a woman who were part of a group that had robbed 40 banks in Brooklyn and Manhattan of more than $78,000 since October.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: R obert Kennedy Jr., who failed the New York bar exam last year, is working hard to pass it.

title: FRANK J. FINAN
description: Frank J. Finan, a retired senior vice president of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, died Jan. 21 of heart disease in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 66 years old and had lived for many years in Franklin Square, L.I.

title: WALTON CHOOSES HIS COURSE
description: One thing hasn't changed from five years ago. At the end of a basketball game, Bill Walton is spent. Totally. ''There's one slight difference,'' Walton said. ''I'm getting to that point a lot quicker these days.'' There was a grin on his face. ''It's coming, slowly,'' Walton said of his game. ''I'm feeling better with each game.'' The Bill Walton comeback is no longer fantasy. It is in full swing. On Jan. 20, Walton was given permission by his orthopedist to train and play full time.

title: Doctor Convicted In Boxing Death
description: A court found a doctor guilty today of second-degree manslaughter in having failed to take proper action after a boxing match that led to the death of one of the fighters, Angelo Jacopucci.

title: How Not to Lose More State Money
description: New York State lost $21 million in 1982 because its Dormitory Authority invested a much larger sum with a bond dealer who went bankrupt. Legislative inquiries now seek to determine what happened and make sure it doesn't happen again.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Braniff Leasing Decision Near
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers heard closing arguments on whether grounded Braniff International can help bail itself out by leasing planes and facilities to Pacific Southwest Airlines.

title: MEDICAL 'FAILURE' CITED BY PENTAGON
description: A Pentagon report, citing ''sufficient reasons'' for concern about the high death rate of heart patients who underwent surgery at an Air Force hospital in Texas, says the military's medical system should be evaluated.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
SUCH NICE PEOPLE
description: This is New York: Fellow parks his car at the curb. Sometimes he parks around the corner, sometimes across the street, sometimes right under your window.

title: ALBANY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Australian to See Reagan
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia has accepted President Reagan's invitation to meet with him March 5 in San Francisco, the White House announced today. Mr. Reagan will be in San Francisco as host to Queen Elizabeth II.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $13.1 million for the qr and$14.4 million for the 6 mos

title: DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRITISH SAID TO WAIT ON OIL PRICES
description: Oil industry sources said today that there was little likelihood of any official change in North Sea oil prices until some action on pricing or production is taken by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries or by a major non-OPEC producer such as Mexico.

title: THE PITFALLS OF RANKING U.S. UNIVERSITY GRADUATE SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Oldest Black Newspaper Celebrates Its 100th Year
description: The nation's oldest black newspaper, founded by 13 former slaves, celebrated its 100th anniversary this week with a special full-color edition.

title: Gulf Sale to Shell
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced the sale of its marketing and refining interests in Switzerland to Shell Oil Company. Under terms of the transaction, to take place Jan. 31, Shell will acquire the shares of Gulf Oil (Switzerland), which has about 100 employees and some 8 percent of the Swiss oil products market. Shell Petroleum N.V. will acquire Gulf's 25 percent interest in a 65,000 barrel per day refinery, of which 75 percent is already owned by Shell, the companies said in a joint statement issued from Gulf's Pittsburgh headquarters.

title: Zaire Debt Accord
description: Zaire has reached a ''gentlemen's agreement'' with its foreign banks for payment of 1982 arrears on its debt rescheduling program, which was set up in 1980, Grindlays Bank P.L.C. said today.

title: BRADLEY, MILTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1984 BUDGET IN BRIEF
description: Following are highlights of the President's 1984 budget, an outline of which was sent to Congress today: Spending - Outlays in the fiscal year 1984, which begins this Oct. 1, will total $848 billion, up from $805 billion in 1983. Spending is projected to rise to $1,127 billion by 1988.

title: DAYTON POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $2,060,000 for the qr and a special gain of $10,283,000 for the yr; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchange

title: PRICES END MOSTLY UNCHANGED
description: Next week's huge auction of Treasury debt issues overshadowed any response in the credit market yesterday to the modest drop in the nation's basic money supply. Prices of Treasury securities closed mostly unchanged after drifting lower most of the day on thin trading volume.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After capacity curtailment adjustments and divestitures...C-Ne t income...D-After gain of $51 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; the company also restated its results for the first three qr to reflect the effect of the accounting changes

title: U.C.L.A. UPSET BY ALABAMA, 70-67
description: Mike Davis of Alabama hit two free throws with 10 seconds left tonight to halt a U.C.L.A. rally as the Crimson Tide scored a 70-67 upset of the top-ranked Bruins.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of approximately $28.7 million from reversal of provisions made in prior periods in connection with potential pipeline tariff refunds; shr earnings figures assume the conversion of the $3.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock and exercise of stock options

title: Removal of Judge Is Urged by Panel
description: The state's Commission on Judicial Conduct today recommended that a town justice from Clinton County be removed from office for having ''routinely'' failed to advise defendants of their rights to counsel, pretrial hearings and trial by jury.

title: First for Austrian Skier
description: The World Cup race yesterday was the first in Yugoslavia, and the first official trial of the new ''Olympia'' course on Mount Bjelasnica that will be the site of the downhill skiing competition at the 1984 Winter Olympics. Gerhard Pfaffenbichler, a 22-year-old reserve on the Austrian national team, completed the 3,070-meter course in 1 minute 48.81 seconds in winning his first World Cup event.

title:
PATENTS;
An X-Ray Telescope For Space Exploration
description: An X-ray telescope with extended range, to be used aboard rockets and satellites for exploration of stars, galaxies and the sun, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Richard B. Hoover, an aerospace scientist at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama.

title: GHR ENERGY IN CHAPTER 11 PETITION
description: For the second time in less than a decade, a company owned and operated by John R. Stanley, an oil industry entrepreneur, has filed for bankruptcy.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Japanese Surplus Down
description: Japan, which is under pressure to cut its exports to the West, announced today an $18.19 billion trade surplus with the world last year, down from $19.97 billion in 1981. The Finance Ministry said exports amounted to $137.65 billion and imports to $119.46 billion.

title: KOCH'S MISGUIDED 'SERMON' ABOUT THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

description: For a year now, Thomas H. Kean has been Governor of New Jersey. In an interview with Joseph F. Sullivan of The New York Times, Mr. Kean discussed his governorship - from aspects of the job that surprised him to his relations with the Legislature. Here are some of the things he had to say: Special to the New York Times

title: Goodrich Deficit
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company's chairman, John D. Ong, said that the company would report next month a loss of about $14 million from operations for the fourth quarter and an after-tax provision of about $20 million from the restructuring of several businesses. A year earlier it earned $32.4 million.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRANCE DEPLOYS 9 NEW NUCLEAR MISSILES
description: France announced today that nine new ballistic missiles were officially operational, completing the modernization of its ground-launched strategic force, and said nuclear deterrence was the only way to maintain national independence

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
20,000 JOIN QUEBEC STRIKE
description: aid workers joined an illegal strike by Quebec civil servants today.

title: BIRTH-CONTROL RULE: CLINICS PONDER EFFECTS
description: ''If my parents were to get a letter saying that I had received birth control, they would yell and scream - and maybe kick me out of the house,'' a 17-year-old high-school senior from Queens said the other day at the Margaret Sanger Center of Planned Parenthood of New York City.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The days of smokestacks, the days of factories are over. You'll never see them built again.'' - Frank Carine, a worker at the Western Electric plant in Kearny, N.J. (25:1.)

title: Eight Die in Apartment; Unvented Heater Blamed
description: Eight people, seven of them children or teenagers, were found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning today in a small apartment, the authorities said. A ninth person was hospitalized.

title: Expensive Cases
description: Fernando Valenzuela may have set the tone. The Dodger left-hander filed his salary arbitration case this week, asking $1 million for next season; the Dodgers offered $750,000.

title: MERCEDES WILL OFFER AIR BAGS AS OPTIONS ON SOME '84 MODELS
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America announced yesterday that it would make an air-bag safety system available as an option in the United States and Canada beginning with some 1984 models. A unresolved dispute over air bags and other passive restraints has been going on in this country since the mid-1960's.

title: MUSIC: JUPITER ORCHESTRA
description: The Jupiter Symphony's program of Haydn, Schumann, Ives and Mozart Thursday night drifted up from the stage of Alice Tully Hall like a fresh breeze. Jens Nygaard's small orchestra may not have the finely sharpened ensemble tone of a year-round orchestra, but its players obviously cared about their music and obviously enjoyed playing every note of it.

title: TOTAL PETROLEUM (NORTH AMERICA) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a pretax gain of $27,400,000 on the sale of stock...C-Net loss

title: REPUBLICANS' ORGANIZER
description: Fresh out of law school in 1967, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr. was taken by a friend to meet the entire Nevada Young Republicans Club - all three members. One week later they elected Mr. Fahrenkopf their chairman, and in the next two years those first three members were joined by some 500 others.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Senator Bob Dole made the comment as he praised his wife, Elizabeth, Transportation Secretary-designate, at Senate confirmation hearings.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 30.

title: Dodgers Abandon Their Private Jet
description: One more institution is leaving the Los Angeles Dodgers in a winter that saw the departure of Steve Garvey and Ron Cey: the team's private airliner. And, as in the case of the star infielders, the reasons are age and money.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest qr and yr rev included a $1.6 million and $6.8 million, respectively, from electric rate increases which are subject to refund; this increased net income by $800,000 in the qr and $3.3 million in the yr

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $4.8 million for the qr and $15.9 million fora the yr and a gain of $27.4 million for the qr and yr on the sale of aircraft; yr-ago results include the acquisition of Kirsch Co

title: AMERADA HESS DOWN 9.5%
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday that special charges had caused earnings to fall 17.1 percent in the fourth quarter. Revenues dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Yankees Sign May
description: Rudy May could not reach agreement with the Yankees on a one-year contract before he temporarily and erroneously became a member of the Chicago White Sox. Now that he is a full-fledged Yankee again, he has signed a two-year extension to the contract he signed as a free agent three years ago. Financial terms were not announced, but a source familiar with the deal said it was believed to be worth about $1.4 million.

title: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESIGNATION OF INDIAN CABINET CONFIRMED BY DELHI AIDE
description: All 60 members of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Cabinet and Council of Ministers, except Mrs. Gandhi herself, have resigned, one of the resigning ministers confirmed today.

title: MUBARAK STRESSES A SYRIAN PULLOUT
description: Although President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has given priority to urging Israel to withdraw from Lebanon, he has impressed American officials with his equally strong concern that Syria pull its forces out of Lebanon to prevent a permanent partition of that country.

title: Secret Data Recovered In Burned-Out Bomber
description: The authorities recovered topsecret information and the bodies of five Air Force men today from the wreckage of a B-52G bomber that exploded and burned Thursday while it was undergoing a routine check.

title: CONVICTIONS UPHELD IN POINT-SHAVE CASE
description: The convictions of all five defendants in the Boston College point-shaving case were upheld on appeal yesterday. The decision, which came in Manhattan from a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, rejected key defense arguments over an article in Sports Illustrated magazine. The judges thus supported, as a First Amendment right, reporters' protection of material that they obtain in criminal as well as civil cases.

title: UNION CARBIDE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEWIS JUMPS 28- 1 4 AND COGHLAN WINS MILE AT MILLROSE
description: Carl Lewis again leaped past 28 feet in the long jump, and Eamonn Coghlan won a fifth Wanamaker Mile during the 76th annual Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings for 1982 include a gain of $44 cents a shr from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for unbilled rev

title: GUARANTY TRUST CO OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NETS WIN, 115-110, END DALLAS STREAK
description: When Buck Williams steps to the free-throw line, he barely makes half his shots. But with nine seconds left tonight, Williams ignored a vociferous banner-waving group behind the backboard and hit two free throws to help the Nets score a 115-110 victory over the Mavericks.

title: Kim's Mother Is a Suicide
description: The mother of Duk-Koo Kim, the South Korean boxer who died of brain injuries suffered in a match with Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini last November, committed suicide, the police said today.

title: WHEN PLANNING TO INVEST IN TREASURIES
description: THIS week the Treasury is selling notes and bonds totaling $14.5 b illion, a record package that is needed to finance a record Federal b udget deficit.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE INS AND OUTS OF AIRPORT DEPARTURE TAXES
description: The scenario is familiar. You are touring abroad, in South America, perhaps, and are about to leave Venezuela for Brazil. You have paid your hotel bill and spent all your remaining bolivares except just enough to cover your taxi fare to the airport and a tip for the porter there. But when you check in at the departure counter of Viasa, the Venezuelan airline, you get a shock. You are told to pay an airport tax of 45 bolivares or $11 at a slightly inflated exchange rate if you prefer to use dollars (based on information supplied by the airline in New York).

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AFTER two years, $1.7 million in expenditures and the formulation of 16 recommend ations, a study of the sewer needs of Port Washington, Manhasset and Great Neck has been completed. One of the most controversial proposals calls for the construction of a $13 million ''outfall pipe'' in Manhasset Bay.

title: SOMETHING TERRIBLE HAPPENED
description: THE ANARCHISTS OF CASAS VIEJAS By Jerome R. Mintz. Illustrated. 336 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $20.

title: Hunt On Nationwide For Wretched Writers
description: A search is on for the nation's most wretched writers. English professors at San Jose State University have announced that the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, which is in its second year, has been opened to the public for the first time.

title: Ryan Rejects Pay Cut
description: Nolan Ryan says he has rejected a proposal by the Houston Astros that he take a pay cut for next season in return for an extension of the four-year, $4.5 million contract he signed in 1980. The pitcher, 36 years old, is under contract for the 1983 season, but he says that negotiations to extend the agreement through 1985 have recessed.

title: No Headline
description: SYRACUSE BEATEN BY VILLANOVA

title: DANCE: RIVERSIDE FESTIVAL
description: The Riverside Dance Festival came up with some promising new talent with its Choreo Showcase I program Thursday at the theater of the Riverside Church.

title: RETURN OF BODY EXPECTED
description: BOGOTA ABODY that may be that of a missing New Jersey freelance journalist is expected to be shipped to the United States this week at the request of Representative Robert Torricelli, a freshman Democrat from New Milford.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: ECONOMISTS FOR BEGINNERS. By Bernard Caravan. (Pantheon, $3.95.) Using drawings like the one above, along with short expository blocks of text and quotations from Adam Smith, David Ricardo, Thomas Malthus, John Stuart Mill, Karl Marx, Alfred Marshall and John Maynard Keynes, Bernard Caravan sets forth economic theories of value, production and distribution. This volume, an original that is also available in hard-cover, is one of a dozen ''documentary comicbooks'' published by Pantheon.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE BUSINESS OF LAW;
description: Mr. Flom may have the most lucrative firm but Martin Lipton, his only serious rival in the takeover field, is said to have a higher billing rate: $350 an hour. (The top hourly rate at Skadden Arps, the guide says, is $285 an hour.)

title: New York Hiker Freezes In Pennsylvania Woods
description: A hiker lost in a state game park with a companion died after he fell into a creek and was forced to spend the night in 25 degree temperatures, the state police said today.

title: ECONOMY: 'WHY NOT TELL IT AS IT IS?'
description: To the Editor:

title: ACROSS 42 BRIDGES THROUGH FLORIDA'S KEYS
description: You can fly from Miami to Key West in 45 minutes if you are in a hurry, but if you want one of the more memorable automobile odysseys, drive the Overseas Highway across a 113-mile chain of coral and limestone islands connected by 42 bridges, one of them seven miles long. You pass a few honky-tonk towns and trailer parks on U.S. 1, but their ugliness is far outweighed by the waters ranging from aquamarine to deep blue and emerald green, and the dazzling sunsets and sunrises. If you leave U.S. 1 on some of the Keys you will find underwater worlds of silent beauty, tropical birds and deer the size of goats.

title: Torre's Diet Campaign
description: Joe Torre, who batted .363 and became the National League's most valuable player in 1971 after losing 25 pounds before the season, is a firm believer in slimness on the diamond. The Atlanta Braves manager helped arrange that the contract for Bob Horner, the slugging third baseman, contain a clause calling for a $100,000 annual bonus if Horner can keep his weight at 215 throughout the season.

title: St. John's Defeats Manhattan, 65-58
description: St. John's, after making a change in its starting lineup for the first time in 22 months because of an injury, continued its superb free-throw shooting to defeat Manhattan, 65-58, yesterday before 2,500 at Draddy Gym in the Bronx.

title: SHULTZ LEAVES U.S. FOR 12-DAY MISSION TO 3 ASIAN NATIONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz left today on a 12-day mission to the Far East in which he hopes to ease the strains and disagreements that have arisen in Chinese-American relations.

title: The Fine Line Of 'Psych Outs'
description: To the Sports Editor: Your recent article concerning various examples of athletes or teams being ''psyched out'' by their opponents (''Can Mind Games Win Games?'' The New York Times, Jan. 17) recalled to me a similar experience I had many years ago as a member of the West Point tennis team.

title: CITY EXPANDING ITS HOME-LOAN PROGRAM
description: AFTER just a year in operation, a city-sponsored program s ubsidizing low-interest loans to moderate-income homeowners will be e xpanded because of what its director describes as an expression of c onfidence by the banking community.

title: Susan Beth Pelino Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C.Richard Pelino of Fairport, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Beth Pelino, to Leo A. Fitzgerald, son of Eileen Fitzgerald of Bay Head, N.J., and the late Thomas Fitzgerald. A May wedding is planned. at the New York University School of Law. His mother is a vice

title: LIGHT HAS LOST ITS BEAUTY
description: AT this moment, long rays of a winter afternoon sun are hitting a plant growing in a fat, old cookie jar. The pot is a glazed fireengine red. The plant - a profusely growing spider - is a yin-yang of greens: darkest forest and lightest lime.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ When Jim Hall first appeared on the jazz scene 27 years ago as the guitarist in the Chico Hamilton Quintet, he was a startling contrast to the steady string of guitarists influenced by Charlie Christian, who had dominated the field for the previous 15 years. Despite the fact that Mr. Christian had been Mr. Hall's primary guitar influence when he was starting to play, Mr. Hall was more interested in the work of such saxophonists as Sonny Rollins, Ben Webster, Coleman Hawkins and Don Byas.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MICAH WILLIAMS: SELF-TAUGHT ARTIST EXCELLED IN PASTELS
description: FREEHOLD THE upper stairwell in the Monmouth County Historical Association building at 70 Court Street is filled with a permanent collection of 19 pastel portraits attributed to Micah Williams, the self-taught New Jersey artist.

title:
GARDENING;
YEARS OF ASPARAGUS FROM LITTLE LABOR
description: WHEN the seed and nursery catalogues arrive by mail, can spring be far behind? Each day brings another catalogue extolling the virtues of new roses, generations-old vegetable varieties, dwarf conifers, new marigolds, extra-sweet sweetcorn, an undreamed number of beans and even a new hybrid asparagus.

title: JOHN SAYLES MASTERS THE TELLING DETAIL
description: Every now and then, a movie will serve as a point of reference for the post-Woodstock generation, describing the maturation process in simple but wry terms, and affecting a deceptively nondramatic style. Alain Tanner's ''Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000'' was one. Another was John Sayles's ''Return of the Secaucus Seven.'' And Mr. Sayles's new ''Lianna'' is another, even if it appears to tackle a subject too limited to have this widespread relevance. Although ''Lianna'' explicitly tells the story of a 33-year-old wife who leaves her husband for a woman, it's about much more.

title: TRUCK SEIZURE EYED IN TOXIC DUMPING
description: THE seizure of vehicles used in narcotics, gambling, pornography and unlicensed cigarette trafficking is an established lawenforcement tactic. Now the Suffolk County Legislature is considering a proposed vehicle-seizure law aimed at midnight dumpers and others who illegally transport and dispose of hazardous waste.

title: CONCERT: BACH
description: If J. S. Bach's 200-odd cantatas still make up one of the undiscovered treasures of musical literature, it's not the fault of the Bach Aria Group. This venerable ensemble, now in its 37th year, continues to present conservative and somewhat cautious performances of the Bach arias that inspired its name.

title: SONG OF THE OPEN ROAD TURNING SAD
description: ''There's no better job in the world than trucking, when it's 65 out and the sun is shining and you're driving down the highway,'' said Chris A. Wesling, an independent truck driver.

title: U.S. TRIES NEW TACK IN DRUG FIGHT AS GLOBAL SUPPLY AND USE MOUNT
description: Almost 10 years after the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration was created to unify efforts against narcotics, the Government is still struggling to find the best way to fight the growing problem of drug use and distribution.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday accompanying an article on hospital construction in New York City misidentified Anthony L. Watson. He is executive director of the New York City Health Systems Agency, a Federal agency created by Congress.

title: THE INS AND OUTS OF I.R.A. ACCOUNTS
description: Deciding where to stash your contribution to an Individual Retirement Account is only one of many factors to take into consideration when setting up a retirement savings program. Below are answers to some commonly asked questions by first-time I.R.A. investors. Q.I don't have the cash to set up an I.R.A. Can I borrow to do it? A.Yes. Not only is your I.R.A. contribution tax-deductible, but so are your borrowing costs. As long as the return on your I.R.A. investment -which compounds tax-free until you begin making withdrawals at retirement age - exceeds the after-tax cost of your loan, you come out ahead. (To determine the after-tax cost of a loan, multiply your tax rate by the interest rate on the loan.) But be sure you have adequate savings on hand for emergencies and other expenses, such as your children's college education, because you pay a 10 percent penalty for any money prematurely withdrawn from your I.R.A. Q.My company has a payroll deduction plan for making contributions to an I.R.A. Should I take advantage of it? A.It all depends. If you find it difficult to save regularly, and this is the only way you can be assured of making the maximum contribution, by all means go ahead.

title: OVER- OR UNDERRIPE, MYRIAD USES FOR THE BANANA
description: AMERICANS consume more bananas than any other type of fruit. And no wonder. Bananas are aseasonal, prepacked in individual servings with easily removable biodegradable coverings (tear off end, pull skin down) and conveniently capable of being shipped green to ripen in your kitchen. Had the banana been designed by a wholesaler he could hardly have done better.

title: No Headline
description: Nordiques Overtake Devils, 6-4

title: ECONOMIC INDEX RISES IMPRESSIVELY
description: Key economic indicators soared in December. The index of leading economic indicators - intended to forecast economic trends - gained 1.5 percent, the biggest monthly increase in more than two years. The Commerce Department cautioned that the size of the increase could be revised downward later.

title: NETS BEATEN BY SPURS, 120-109
description: Gene Banks, the muscular forward who is in his second season, scored a career-high 32 points for San Antonio and led a charge against the Nets that gave the Spurs a 120-109 victory tonight before 11,945 at the HemisFair Arena.

title: DETROIT'S COSTLY EFFORT TO CHALLENGE THE IMPORTS
description: DETROIT IMPORTED cars, once rare birds found at the curb of the avant-garde in university towns and in the multiple garages of the rich, have, in effect, today become the American car. They are not only the choice of some 30 percent of the car-buying public - it was less than half that 10 years ago - but they have also become the design and manufacturing ideal, the role model, of the domestic auto makers.

title: INVEST IN EGYPT, MUBARAK APPEALS
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt ended his visit to the United States yesterday with an appeal for increased American investment in his country.

title: BEHIND THE LINES OF CABLE TV ON L.I.
description: AT the age of 43, Michael Zenobio of Sands Point is the president of Abcon Associates of New York City, a concern that traces its ancestry to a house-painting business founded by his late father in the Bronx in 1913. Today Abcon goes far beyond house painting; in fact, it has played a key role in the establishment of major cable television facilities on the Island, in Smithtown.

title: A LOSER IN PRINCETON AND A WINNER IN MILLBURN
description: PRINCETON IT IS Dec. 9, 1980, the morning after John Lennon was shot. Nine characters are standing around on Central Park West, across the street from the site of the crime. They are supposed to be reflecting upon what it all represents.

title: Boyce Wins Iona Mile in 4:29.6
description: Joe Boyce, a Holy Trinity High School senior, won the mile run in 4 minutes 29.6 seconds at the 20th Iona Spike Shoe Club Games yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: MT. LAUREL: NEW PATH TO OLD GOAL
description: MOUNT LAUREL TOWNSHIP ''FINALLY,'' Ethel Lawrence said, ''here is the highest court in the state defending the constitutional right of poor people.'' There was a tone of weary pride in her voice, the kind that comes with the end of a long, painful conflict.

title: PRESERVATION HALL PIANO STAR
description: Emma (Sweet Emma) Barrett, a jazz pianist, died here Friday morning after she suffered a stroke Thursday. She was 85 years old.

title: THE FUTURE AND DANGERS OF SOCIAL SECURITY 'FUTUROLOGY'
description: To the Editor:

title: MGM, ITS IMAGE BRUISED, IS STRAINING TO FIND HITS
description: EVERY afternoon at around five o'clock Frank Rothman looks at the numbers. That's almost second nature for the chairman and chief executive of MGM, who occupies the same chair from which Louis B. Mayer and, later, Irving Thalberg, once examined the rising box office receipts that established Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as one of Hollywood's most powerful studios during the 1930's.

title: NEAR-RECORD PERFORMANCES MARK MILLROSE GAMES
description: In a sport in which inches and fractions can determine world records, the 76th Wanamaker Millrose Games Friday night had a series of near-misses.

title: STAYING POWER
description: At least according to the statistics, Brown, Wood, Ivey, Mitchell & Petty would seem to be the most pleasant major law firm in New York. Although firms in some smaller cities have almost no turnover, Brown Wood - whose clients include E.F. Hutton, Kidder Peabody and Merrill Lynch - has the lowest turnover of the New York firms profiled, with only 3 percent of its young lawyers leaving in 1981-82.

title: POPULAR FOR SUNDAY BRUCH
description: BACK during the Revolutionary War, an inn run by Jacob and Mary Bull was supposedly a gathering place for the Continental Army marching from their supply depot in Lebanon to Washington's headquarters in New York.

title: TOWN BUYS A BEACH
description: THE residents of Old Saybrook, a shoreline town about halfway between New Haven and New London, have just bought themselves a beach. State environmental officials say they have not heard of such a thing in decades - although they say that as the shoreline's population swells, there is an increasing need for public beaches.

title: BUSES TO GET TRACKING DEVICES
description: REBECCA BAILEY, a domestic worker who lives in Eastchester, is a regular bus rider, and the other day she discovered that she could ride free of charge midday within White Plains. She scolded the driver.

title: BAR-LE-DUC CURRANT PRESERVES
description: T he land that gave gastronomy the quiche - the Lorraine region of France - boasts another delicacy, this one so exquisite it once drew royal personages to the tiny village where it is produced.

title: CITY TO TRY AGAIN TO CONVERT ARMY TERMINAL INTO INDUSTRIAL PARK
description: The Koch administration has prepared a new proposal for turning the old Brooklyn Army Terminal in Bay Ridge into a manufacturing center for light industry.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Schaefer
description: Jeanne Rolston Schaefer of Springfield, Pa., and Harry Julius Schaefer 3d of Media, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lynne Schaefer, of Newark, Del., to Craig Hollis Grosby, son of Robert Nachman Grosby of Norwalk, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. and the late Eleanor Hurwitz Grosby. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: GERMANS MARK THE PAST, AND AT MOURNFUL LENGTH
description: BONN ON Monday, Jan. 30, 1933, after an anxious and sleepless night, Adolf Hitler was summoned from the Kaiserhof hotel in Berlin to the chambers of Germany's failing, 86-year-old President, Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg, who asked him to become the troubled nation's Chancellor. Beginning that day, Germany was transformed into the savage dictatorship that dragged Europe into the horrors of total war and mass extermination.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: DEALS may be clinched on the tennis court or during golf, but don't talk business while you are curling. That is the admonition issued by aficionados of this sport, which entails sliding 42-pound stones down a sheet of ice toward a bull's-eye-like target on the surface. It is a game played with surprising fervor and regularity by about 300 Westchester residents.

title: Time Is Held Ripe For Hospital Reform
description: E.E. Tennenbaum's log of her husband's week in a hospital (Opinion Page, Jan. 8) so closely tracked my own observations in daily visits to a hospitalized friend that I rush to agree that her experience was ''usual and shocking'' and that ''the time seems ripe for reform.'' RITA M. SIERKS

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BY ANY NAME, IT'S STILL AN IMPERIAL BALLET
description: Ten years ago, on Jan. 12, 1973, George Balanchine's ''Ballet Imperial'' was renamed ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2.'' It thereby turned into yet another work in the New York City Ballet's repertory known only by the title of its musical score. Nevertheless, it can be argued that it still remains ''imperial'' and it has certainly looked imperial in performances this season at the State Theater.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BECAUSE boardwalk and theme-park amusement games did poorly last summer, the state's Amusement Control Commission is considering raising limits on admission prices and the value of prizes.

title: FOREIGN SMALL CARS IMPROVE IN U.S. CRASH TESTS
description: WASHINGTON FOREIGN small cars, which did worse than their domestic counterparts in the first Federal tests of crash-worthiness in 1980, have made substantial improvements, according to test results announced recently by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: BARBARA MARTIN TO WED FREDERICK H. TAYLOR JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chester N. Martin of Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Carol Martin, to Frederick Harvey Taylor Jr., son of Dr. Taylor, and Rita Gerish Taylor of Charlotte, N.C.

title: LONDON'S STATELY CHINA EMPORIUM
description: DONALD GODDARD is a London-based writer.

title: MOST LUCRATIVE
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom is ''thought to be the most lucrative major law firm in the country,'' the guide says, in part because of the unique retainer arrangement set up by takeover specialist Joseph Flom.

title: NOTHING COMES CHEAP, NOT EVEN LOW OIL PRICES
description: PARIS THE Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may be a victim of its own success, a condition unlikely to evoke sympathy from some in the West. But does the industrialized world really have an interest in watching the cartel die? This is the dilemma posed for oil consumers and other producers as OPEC flounders in a world awash with energy, unable to control the plummeting price of oil.

title: O'ROURKE BIDS UTILITY AGENCY HELP KEEP G.M. IN COUNTY
description: WESTCHESTER'S new Public Utility Agency, which was established to bring low-cost electricity to the county, met a new administration last week and received a very specific assignment: help keep the General Motors plant in the county.

title: Government Gets Silent Treatment On School Busing
description: As part of its broad attack on busing as a means for achieving desegregation, the Reagan Administration joined the Nashville school board in November in an attempt to win Supreme Court approval of its arguments. Last week the Justices, without dissent or comment, simply refused to hear the case, thus leaving the Tennessee city's widespread busing system intact.

title: CELEBRATING BLACK HISTORY, AND THE FUTURE
description: WHITE PLAINS AS blacks in the county and nationwide prepare to observe February as Black History Month, their attention will be focused not only on the past but also on the future.

title: Excerpts from message, page 24.
description: Governor Kean will ask the New Jersey Legislature on Monday to approve a $6.8 billion budget with no new taxes but with further increases in tuition at state colleges and in fares for mass transit.

title: LOWER TIRE SALES FORCE COMPANIES TO DIVERSIFY
description: AKRON AFTER a year of industrywide plant closings and heavy job cuts caused by reduced demand for tires for passenger cars, the country's largest rubber companies are working to develop new markets and products.

title: MIDWINTER CONCERTS
description: IF any doubts remain that we have an abundance and diversity of cultural happenings in Westchester, a look at the schedule over the next couple of weeks should dispel them. This afternoon, for example, not even the Super Bowl game has slowed down the musical action - there are at least six major events on the scoreboard for 3 P.M. alone.

title: Three Mile Island Litigants Find a No-Fault Solution
description: The maker and the master of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant decided last week that enough was enough. Eager to end the three-month trial before it further damaged the whole industry's reputation, they agreed to settle out of court and not seek to pin responsibility for the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power.

title: THE BIGGEST-BAKER & McKENZIE
description: With more than 600 lawyers in 29 different offices scattered from Sao Paulo to Sydney to Singapore, Baker & McKenzie is the largest law firm in the world, the only truly global one and the first to have to face the kinds of management problems that plague the Big Eight accounting firms, to which it is often compared.

title: HISTORIC SPACE
description: The Brooklyn Bridge has been celebrated in many and varied ways, but in honor of its centennial birthday May 24, New Yorkers and tourists will be treated to a new perspective on this architectural and engineering marvel.

title: LONG AFTER THE EL, WHAT'S ON THIRD?  A WALL OF TOWERS
description: FOR three quarters of a century, Third Avenue was dominated by the rumble of the El. It was a dingy,c obblestoned corridor lined with neighborhood saloons, cheap r estaurants and run-down tenements. But when the El was dismantled in1 955, developers rushed to rebuild Third Avenue, and the first of a n ew generation of office structures went up in 1956.

title: A 'RING' THAT REVEALS WAGNER'S HUMAN DRAMA
description: Were one to wait for the Public Broadcasting Service to get around to completing its presentation of the Bayreuth centennial ''Ring of the Nibelung'' before commenting on the production as a whole, one would have to postpone any overview until mid-June. Wagner meant his cycle to be experienced on four consecutive nights. The worst single thing about this ''Ring'' is PBS's philistine decision to string out the music dramas over six months and to divide the three longer operas by a week. Thus, ''Das Rheingold'' was telecast last Monday night, but we will have to wait until Feb. 21 and 28 for ''Die Walkure,'' April 11 and 18 for ''Siegfried'' and June 6 and 13 for ''Gotterdammerung.''
