What is good enough for ''Masterpiece Theater'' and ''Nicholas Nickleby'' is apparently not good enough for Richard Wagner.

title: THEY'RE 'FLYING' ON THE ICE
description: A GUST of wind sent Thomas Halsey's DN-Class iceboat flying across the ice on Mecox Bay. Little heralded, Mr. Halsey has been on the bay in the last few days getting ready to compete for the world championship in iceboating, a sport that Long Islanders have been enjoying for more than a century.

title: LEGISLATURE FIGHTS KEAN OVER VIDEO GAMBLING
description: TRENTON THE Democratically controlled Legislature and the Kean administration have found something new to disagree about as they begin their second year together - video games that pay off in cash prizes. The New Jersey Lottery Commission, with Governor Kean's blessing, wants to conduct an experiment by placing about 100 of the games in taverns and package stores around the state this summer. If all goes well, it hopes to install about 5,000 thereafter and expects to raise more than $200 million, about half of which would go to the state.

title: Static in the Cosmic Club
description: Terrestrial Intelligence, was recently endorsed by a slew of Nobel scientists and others who affirmed that the quest ''assumes nothing about other civilizations that has not transpired in ours.'' That argument is ingeniously disputed by Frank Tipler, a physicist at Tulane University.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEN WARY OF CONTINGENT TAX INCREASE
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee said today that the growing feeling of the Democratic majority was to reject President Reagan's call for contingency taxes.

title: FRIVOLITY FOR THE SUPER BOWL
description: WHILE many football fans focus on the Super Bowl today, John Kasper of Southbury will be eating tortillas right on the 50-yard line - at his home.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
ACCLAIMED QUARTET
description: The Guarneri String Quartet -which, according to Raymond Ericson, a New York Times critic, is ''almost too good to be true'' - will play next Sunday afternoon in Montclair.

title: MANY DONORS TO NEEDIEST CITE SHARING
description: Although many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund seek to aid special groups, such as the homeless or the elderly, many others want only to share their own well-being with those who have much less.

title: Claudia Pelliccioni to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aurelius J. Pelliccioni of Ebensburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Anne Pelliccioni, to Maj. John Robert Hickey of the Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick V. Hickey of Hempstead, L.I. Major Hickey, whose marriage ended in divorce, is stationed at the MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla. president with I.T.& T. in San Francisco. His father was a partner in

title: Old Buddies
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the Philippine budget incorrectly described the revised 1983 figure announced by President Ferdinand E. Marcos. He said the budget would be reduced 18 percent, to $5.72 billion.

title: SUNDAY, JANUARY 30, 1983
description: International Better Chinese-American relations is one of the objectives of a 12-day visit to the Far East by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, his first visit to the region since taking office last July. In addition to China, where he will spend four days, Mr. Shultz will visit Japan and South Korea. (Page 1, Column 1.) Lebanon's massacre inquiry has proceeded slowly in determining responsibility for the killing of Palestinian civilians in Beirut refugee camps. While an Israeli commission is preparing its findings, the Lebanese Government's investigator says he does not know who committed the murders, or when he will be able to find out. (1:2-3.)

title: No Headline
description: Let me assure William Buckley that harpsichord building and playing continues all over America.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Most people think of the Netherlands in the 17th century as the stronghold of European still-life painting. Whether in flower painting, or in the portrayal of household objects, or in more elaborate assemblages that served a symbolic purpose, the Dutch masters could be counted upon to excel.

title: Furnace Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Confession Time In Poland
description: Polish workers have been making trouble for their Communist leaders for more than 25 years. Last week, some people in the regime, in a moment of candor, showed an internal party report to Western correspondents blaming the trouble on the leaders, not the workers.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Inflationary Advance

title: A PAVILION
description: Given the likelihood of a moratorium being imposed soon on building new hospital space in Manhattan, the nine-story, 200,000-square-foot addition to The New York Hospital now under construction may be one of the last such major additions to go up in this borough for a while. The addition, to be known as the C.V. Starr Pavilion, is expected to be completed in the fall of 1985.

title: AN AMERICAN MASTER COMES INTO HIS OWN; WASHINGTON
description: Twenty-five years ago it would have seemed out of the question that John Frederick Peto (1854-l907) would one day be given a one-man show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. Peto in his lifetime had very little success, and until lately he was ranked even by enthusiasts for 19th-century American painting as an amiable near-virtuoso in the simulation of everyday objects, a successor and imitator of the still-life painter William Harnett (1848-92) and an artist more attractive to collectors of undemanding Americana than to students of high art. At the National Gallery in the late 1950's he would have been sent round to the service entrance.

title: REAGAN LESS COMBATIVE AS BUDGET WARS GET STARTED
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S second State of the Union Message, delivered to Congress last week, and his Budget and annual Economic Report, to be presented this week, represent an effort by the Administration to change its tone and correct some of the mistakes it made during its first two years in office.

title: A Correction
description: An article on Soviet nuclear power in The Week in Review of Jan.16 incorrectly noted the capacity of new reactors. They are billion-watt plants.

title: Trying to Put Double-Decker Back on the Track
description: With regard to the recent article by John P. Brion, ''I've Been Riding on the Railroad - for 50 Years'' (Opinion Page), I would like to point out that one double-deck car remains on Long Island.

title: HOW ARTISTRY SHAPED THE SETTING FOR THE MET'S VATICAN SHOW
description: ''A n exhibition is not the illustration of a text, it is not a book. It is a medium with its own language and rules. You have to provide a total experience where the work of art, the colors, the lighting, the whole environment go hand-in-hand. The experience must be true. There must be a sequence of perceptions that has a parallel in the flow of history.''

title: 2 CONCERTS OFFER HOMEGROWN MUSIC
description: COMPOSITIONS by several New Jersey composers will be the focal point of concerts by two of the state's chamber orchestras. The Little Orchestra of Princeton, under Portia Sonnenfeld, will present the world premier of Harold Oliver's Concerto for Violin and Strings at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the auditorium of Princeton High School.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: AARON BURR, by Milton Lomask. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.50.) The second volume of a two-volume biography, this one covering the years 1805-36. ALFRED STIEGLITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS & WRITINGS, by Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton. (Callaway Editions/National Gallery of Art, $75.) A selection of the great American photographer's work. COURT OF MEMORY, by James McConkey. (E.P. Dutton, $14.95.) Twenty-one autobiographical meditations by the fiction writer and college teacher. FEIFFER, edited by Steven Heller. (Alfred A. Knopf, cloth, $25; paper, $12.95.) Twenty-five years of Jules Feiffer's cartoons, with commentary by the artist. HOWARD HAWKS, STORYTELLER, by Gerald Mast. (Oxford University Press, $29.95.) An analysis of the film director's career. IRONWEED, by William Kennedy. (The Viking Press, $14.75.) A novel of Albany low life in the 30's. THE LAST HERO, by Anthony Cave Brown. (Times Books, $24.95.) The story of Wild Bill Donovan and the O.S.S., the World War II intelligence organization he ran.

title: TEAMSTER FUND TO PURCHASE DORFMAN INSURANCE AGENCY
description: The teamsters' Central States Health and Welfare Fund has reached an agreement in Federal District Court to buy for $12.75 million the insurance agency of Allen M. Dorfman, who was killed in a Chicago suburb Jan. 20.

title: Unemployment Rate Steady in Connecticut
description: Employment in Connecticut's manufacturing industries continued to plummet in December, but pre-holiday hiring by stores helped hold the statewide jobless rate nearly steady.

title: RURAL COMMUNITY SEARCHES ITS 200-YEAR HISTORY
description: WHEN Claire St. John Pedersen studies her family roots, she traces them back to the mid-1700's when two St. John brothers, Timothy and Daniel, traveled across Connecticut from their home in Norwalk and settled in the northwestern hills of Ellsworth, an area of rich farmland atop Sharon Mountain.

title: JOANNE MARIE TIERNEY TO WED THOMAS MARR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Tierney of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Marie Tierney, to Thomas Marr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Marr of Rockville, Md.

title: Lauren Viegas Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Viegas of Saddle River, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Ann Viegas, to Craig Thorpe Adams, son of Dr. and Mrs. William John Adams of Fox Chapel, Pa. A June wedding is planned. Miss Viegas is a graduate student at Georgetown University, where her fiance is a first-year student at the School of Medicine.

title: THE QUIET SUPER BOWL, WHERE DEFENSE SHOULD REIGN
description: LOS ANGELES PERHAPS today's game will be only a Slightly Super Bowl; after all, the teams played a short National Football League season, went through the turmoil of a strike and the pressures of three playoff games, and now are contestants in a game that most observers believe will have little action.

title: OVER-OR UNDERRIPE, MYRIAD USES FOR BANANA
description: AMERICANS consume more bananas than any other type of fruit. And no wonder. Bananas are aseasonal, prepacked in individual servings with easily removable biodegradable coverings (tear off end, pull skin down) and conveniently capable of being shipped green to ripen in your kitchen. Had the banana been designed by a wholesaler he could hardly have done better.

title: WORLD'S FOOD FOR THE WORLD'S HUNGRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Boss Too Helpful
description: Yonkers Democratic boss Angelo Grippo was known as the man to see for help with a problem at City Hall. Also as the man to pay, a Federal court jury concluded last week.

title: Belief Is No Defense
description: The road to a possible 40 years in prison and a $20,000 fine was paved with good intentions, according to lawyers representing the leader of a small anti-abortion group called the Army of God. Don Benny Anderson was convicted last week of attempting to obstruct interstate commerce and conspiring to do so. Mr. Anderson had abducted the owners of an abortion clinic and held them captive for eight days in a concrete bunker. Defense lawyer Wayne T. Schoeneberg did not dispute the evidence of his client's action, but tried impressing jurors in closing arguments that Mr. Anderson had acted in the ''sincere belief that abortion is wrong.''

title: MOORE STOPS CHALLENGER IN 4TH
description: Davey Moore knocked Gary Guiden out of the ring today. Moore's personal photographer helped roll Guiden back. But Guiden, a 28-year-old unemployed factory worker from Muncie, Ind., could not beat the count of Referee Vincent Rainone. And so Moore, with the knockout at 2 minutes 18 seconds of the fourth round, made the third successful defense of his World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship.

title: The Price Perplex
description: February is the official release date for paperback editions of ''North and South'' by John Jakes at $4.95 ($1 more than the usual top price for mass-market fiction); ''The Bastard,'' also by Mr. Jakes, at $1.95 (temporarily reduced from $3.95); ''The Parsifal Mosaic'' by Robert Ludlum at $4.50 (55 cents more than it was originally designed to cost); ''Tender Is the Night'' by F. Scott Fitzgerald at $3.95 ($2 less than the same book from the same publisher in a larger paperback format); and ''The Winds of War'' by Herman Wouk at $4.95 (which first appeared in paperback in 1973 at $2.25).

title: HIGH-TECH DRIVE SPURS RIVALRY AMONG COLLEGES
description: THE wooing of high-technology industries by the Island's business community has created a rivalry between public and private colleges on the Island. At stake are state funds and, perhaps more significantly in an era of declining enrollments, students seeking training in high-tech fields such as electronics and aeronautics.

title: Mailbox; A Sporting Side In Boxing, Too
description: To the Sports Editor: Your reprint on Jan. 16 of the editorial by George D. Lundberg, M.D., editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, shows a misguided attack on boxing as a sport (''The Medical Case for Ending Boxing''). I have never been a professional boxer, I am not a physician, but I have boxed as an amateur at the University of Michigan, and believe I understand the sporting side of boxing.

title: Molly McKitterick to Wed Allan Eustis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel McKitterick of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Molly McKitterick, to Allan Chotard Eustis 3d, son of Ann Hyde Eustis of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Eustis Jr. The wedding is to be March 26.

title: MORE THAN MEDALS SPUR ELMAR OLIVEIRA
JUDGE DEFENDS ACTIONS OF COLLEAGUE CHARGED BY STATE WITH MISCONDUCT
description: William M. Erlbaum, a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan, has strongly defended the actions that led to misconduct charges being filed against a former judicial colleague, Alan I. Friess.

title:
OPINION;
A PLEA TO EASE EYE-CARE RULES
description: ''COME ON over, Pete, and we'll take a look at it.'' That was my response to Pete, who has been my eye-care patient for eight years, when he called on a Friday afternoon to report that his left eye had been acting up all day.

title: AN AUSTRIAN INN FOR ALL SEASONS
description: By Kay Eldredge

title: AIDES' TENACITY LED TO REAGAN TAX SHIFT
description: For months, President Reagan told his aides the same thing: he was not going to raise taxes to reduce the Federal deficit. Yet his aides persisted, virtually unanimously, in thinking that new taxes would eventually be necessary.

title: A GRAB BAG OF THE LATEST IN AUDIO EQUIPMENT
description: The impending digital bouleversement of the audio scene should not be allowed to upstage less sensational but in many ways more immediate developments seen and heard at the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Braving the throngs of visitors and breathing hard in the sticky atmosphere of promotional lard and piffle that pervades such occasions, a hardened explorer could discover a fair number of very good and occasionally innovative designs.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Dance The Dancemobile Winter Series sponsored by the Harlem Cultural Council at the Symphony Space gets underway on Wednesday with a premiere that honors Eubie Blake, on the composer-pianist's 100th birthday. Dianne McIntyre, the first of the black choreographers whose work will be on view with 15 dance companies through Feb. 13, will present a new piece set to previously unperformed music by Mr. Blake.

title: LEARNING FROM DISNEY AND DICKENS
description: The following essay, which he titled ''Cartoons,'' was one of the last works of the novelist, short story writer and essayist, John Gardner, who died in a motorcycle accident last September at the age of 49. It forms part of a forthcoming book of essays by diverse writers, ''In Praise of What Persists,'' edited by Stephen Berg.

title: THE VICTORIANS
description: Victorian - a pejorative term in some quarters - is an era that is beginning to lose its stuffy image as it takes on the luster of distance.

title: EX-PREMIER FAILS TEST IN CANADIAN PARTY VOTE
description: The head of Canada's parliamentary opposition, former Prime Minister Joe Clark, agreed to contest his leadership with all rivals after a Progressive Conservative Party convention denied him a vote of confidence in Winnipeg Friday night.

title: No Headline
description: The examples of nursing care cited in the article as resulting from the implementation of primary-care nursing are not dependent on the model of nursing care within an institution. Nurses are responsible for such decision making no matter where or how they practice.

title: COMMUTERS VENT THEIR FRUSTRATION
description: WESTPORT TWO Fairfield County legislators are planning to organize bus trips to Hartford within the next few weeks so that angry rail commuters can tell Governor O'Neill and other state leaders of their frustrations over problems on the New Haven line.

title: Miss Thompson To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Thompson of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristin Kjaer Thompson, to William Leeth Patterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Patterson of Vero Beach, Fla., and Erie, Pa. A July 9 wedding is planned.

title: Elephantiasis in Indonesia
description: A local newspaper reported today that 24,600 people in northern Indonesia were suffering from elephantiasis, a chronic disease that swells the legs and hardens the skin. It is caused by a certain kind of mosquito bite. The newspaper, Sinar Harapan, said the epidemic was in Sumatra, where a mosquito eradication project is under way.

title: NEW LENSES AND FILMS FOR 35MM PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: Among the many new camera products introduced during the past year have been many new lenses for 35mm cameras. Zoom lenses, which can replace several wide-angle, normal, and telephoto lenses with only a single lens, have become particularly popular.

title: RIGGINS KEEPS STEPPING OUT, BUT ALWAYS AS A TEAM PLAYER
description: COSTA MESA, Calif. JOHN RIGGINS is different. In his early days in pro football, when he played fullback for the Jets, he wore his hair one year in an Afro and another year in a Mohawk cut. Then he shaved his head.

title: DIOXIN EXPERTS GET UNFRIENDLY GREETING AT MISSOURI MEETING
description: Federal and state officials came to Jefferson County today in an effort to reassure residents by explaining their efforts to handle the dioxin contamination of many of the county's communities.

title: A $750 Tantrum
description: After viewing films of Don Nelson in his temper tantrum during his team's 1-point loss to the Philadelphia 76ers Jan. 12, the National Basketball Association has fined the Milwaukee coach $750 for misconduct.

title: New York Times Magazine January 30, 1983
description: William Safire 8 On Language Ay, There's the Rub Russell Baker 18 Sunday Observer Phone Shopping Walter Reich 20 The World of Soviet Psychiatry An American doctor on a visit to Moscow finds that Soviet abuse of psychiatry in dissident cases may stem not only from K.G.B. orders but from the distortions of Soviet life. Bernard Holland 28 Domingo: The Well-Tempered Tenor Placido Domingo, with his glowing sound, has challenged Luciano Pavarotti - and, many say, surpassed him - for the title of the world's leading tenor.

title: DEER HUNT HALTED IN HARRIMAN PARK
description: After allowing deer hunting in Harriman State Park for two successive years, the Palisades Interstate Park Commission this week voted to suspend its controversial ''deer reduction program'' for this year.

title:
CRAFTS;
A SHANGRI-LA FOR WEAVERS
description: IN the middle of the pressures of exams, term papers and endless academic deadlines, there is on the campus of Marymount College in Tarrytown a tranquil look where time stands still and pressures evaporate. It is the delightfully cozy Craft Skellar, situated in a corner of North Hall. On paper, the Craft Skellar is described as a ''nonprofit community center, established to encourage the artistic use of fibers in general and weaving in particular.'' In spirit, however, it is much more than that.

title: TELVISION WEEK
description: Detailed, Careful Work Though Gregory Peck's first acting experience took place on the stage, he has made his mark in films for nearly 40 years. Until recently, he has shied away from television. His first appearance in a TV movie was as Abraham Lincoln in last fall's mini-series, ''The Blue and the Gray.'' His second will be ''The Scarlet and the Black,'' to be broadcast Wednesday on CBS at 8 P.M. In this new TV movie, Mr. Peck portrays Monsignor Hugh O'Flaherty, the World War II Vatican official who helped hide Allied prisoner-of-war escapees. John Gielgud and Christopher Plummer co-star.

title: EMANUEL HAYT
description: Emanuel Hayt, an expert in health-care law, died Friday of a heart attack at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 83 years old and resided in Great Neck, L.I.

title: THE RIGHT FASTENER IS ESSENTIAL WHEN HANGING WALL OBJECTS
description: SOONER or later every homeowner is faced with the task of mounting, hanging or fastening something to a wall inside the house. If that wall happens to be covered with wood paneling, the problem is simple - you simply drive in a few screws or nails to do the job.

title: DETROIT FINDS A BRIGHT NOTE IN THE 'MINITRUCK'
description: DETROIT DOMESTICALLY produced small pickup trucks are providing a note of encouragement to United States automobile makers. In their full first year on the market, they are luring an increasing number of buyers in a market once dominated by the Japanese.

title: POP VOCALIST: MEREDITH D' AMBROSIO
description: uf813Meredith D'Ambrosio, a singer and pianist from Boston who is making her New York debut at Village West, Hudson Street at Bank Street, through tonight, draws on a repertory of literate, specialized songs that are usually associated with such singers as Blossom Dearie and the late Teddi King.

title: The Fast Track Through School
description: In confronting the problems of the coming decade, the New York State Education Commissioner said last week, it might be advisable to start early. Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach wasn't referring to those who make education policy.

title: INFIGHTING SLOWS SALVADOR'S PLANS
description: A political setback suffered last week by the leader of El Salvador's rightist coalition has strengthened the view of many officials here that the struggle over long-promised social and economic programs is far from over.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''Poppie Nongena,'' at St. Clement's Church, is a lively showcase for an exceptionally gifted troupe of South African actors, many of whom are now living in exile in the United States. Originally produced in Afrikaans at Johannesberg's Market Theater, the play is a journey through 40 years in the life of one black woman.

title: Mellon's Gift
description: Andrew Mellon built the National Gallery of Art 40 years ago with a $15 million contribution.

title: Crystal Concerts
description: Religious groups should render unto heaven what is heaven's and unto the state nothing, since they're tax exempt.

title: THE WAR OF WORDS
description: Vice President Bush has gone off to Europe to tell allied officials that President Reagan is really serious about controlling the nuclear arms race with the Soviet Union, but he has at least two problems.

title: No Headline
description: In a picture illustrating Elin Schoen's article, I spotted a single can of soda (the most expensive way to buy it - 55 cents at most delicatessens) and a pack of cigarettes ($1.10 at the last vending machine I saw).

title: Political Power Is Held To Affect Waste Sites
description: Economically depressed regions could end up with some of the nation's radioactive waste sites because they have less political power to resist Federal policy, a Governmentfinanced study asserts.

title: Wilson's Other Other Life
description: At the start of his first arms smuggling trial, lawyers for Edwin P. Wilson said they would convince a jury that he was acting with the full knowledge of his former employer, the Central Intelligence Agency. They didn't, and he was convicted.

title: VATICAN AIDE HINTS POPE WROTE LETTER TO BREZHNEV
description: A senior Vatican official today repeated a denial that Pope John Paul II had written Leonid I. Brezhnev threatening to return to Poland to lead a resistance movement in the event of a Soviet invasion.

title: January 30, 1983
description: NONFICTION THE ANARCHISTS OF CASAS VIEJAS. By Jerome R. Mintz. 12 ANGER: The Misunderstood Emotion. By Carol Tavris. 7 THE APOCALYPTIC PREMISE: Nuclear Arms Debated.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. IS 'ON THE MEND'
description: President Reagan sounded his theme last week that 'America is on the mend' as he delivered his second State of the Union address.

title: THE WELL-TEMPERED TENOR
description: One hundred and fifty years ago, opera created a new and noble line of singer - the modern tenor. Now, and for the next two months, Placido Domingo, the Spanish-born, 42-year-old reigning tenor of our time, holds court at Lincoln Center. After taping a public-television concert tonight with the baritone Sherrill Milnes from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera - to be seen by 10 million people when televised in May - Domingo takes up residence at the Met for February and March, singing 14 performances of four operas.

title: BUSINESS TALKS BACK TO REAGAN
description: A NEWSPAPER advertisement calls the Reagan fiscal policies ''senseless.'' On national television, the President is said to have ''missed the chance.'' And in an interview, a top official blames Mr. Reagan for ''exponentially expanding deficits of gargantuan proportions.''

title: French Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD ON SHARING U.S. FUNDS
description: HARTFORD WHAT does a state do when Washington gives it more control over spending Federal money for social programs but less money to spend? Connecticut came up with its answer last week, and state officials said it was an innovative way to cope with the ''new federalism'' of the Reagan Administration.

title: FORD'S CHIEF SEES PERFORMANCE AND PRICE AS KEYS
description: DETROIT AFTER three years of slumping sales, will the American automobile industry pull out of the doldrums in 1983? Will new types of vehicles come to the fore over the next few years? Does the proliferation of high-performance cars mean a new horsepower race? Philip Caldwell, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, America's No. 2 auto maker, recently talked about these and other automotive issues.

title: No Headline
description: The most important aspect of primary-care nursing is what Natalie Spingarn describes as the ability to cut across the established medical-care lines, or what nurses often call ''the gray area of nursingmedical care.'' The central issue is apparent in Dr. Myles Sheehan's observation that sharing patient responsibilities with P.C.N.'s may be threatening to some doctors. Getting doctors to think twice when a nurse, who has more experience with a patient, suggests an alternative is something many nurses, including P.C.N.'s, have been striving for for a long time. PAMELA S. CLARK, R.N.C., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: HOW TO SAVOR AN ENCHANTED ISLAND
description: PAMELA G. HOLLIE, a financial reporter for The Times, was formerly a correspondent in Southeast Asia.

title: No Headline
description: At Massachusetts General Hospital, we have another, relatively new, nursing role which may be of interest to your readers - that of the psychiatric clinical nurse specialist in a general hospital setting.

title: No Headline
description: GHANA ADMITS ITS PEOPLE FROM NIGERIA

title: Jan L. Crawford Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Webb Crawford of Mount Holly, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jan Louise Crawford, to David James Hennessy, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Francis Hennessy of Saddle River, N.J. A May wedding is planned. The future bride and her fiance graduated from the University of Vermont. Mr. Hennessy is doing graduate work in international relations at Syracuse University.

title: Oil Rig Fells Cable Cars, Killing 7 in Singapore
description: A giant floating oil rig struck cable-car wires over Singapore Harbor today, dropping seven tourists to their deaths and trapping 18 others in cable cars swinging 100 feet above the water, the police said.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Henning
description: Mrs. James B. Cavanagh of New York and Greenville, Del., and Robert E. Henning of Woodstock, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alyson Balfour Henning, to Alexander D. Walker 3d, son of Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and A. David Walker of Greenwich. A summer wedding is planned.

title: NAZI'S RISE TO POWER MADE LITTLE IMPRESSION
description: IN 1938, The New Yorker published a cartoon by James Thurber of a woman looking up from her newspaper and asking her husband, ''Who is this Hitler and what does he want?'' This was funny because it was almost impossible to imagine anyone at that date who was not only aware of Hitler but spent a good deal of time worrying about what he might do next. But five years earlier this was far from being the case. On Jan. 30, 1933, when Adolf Hitler was appointed Chancellor of Germany by the ailing Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg and thousands of uniformed storm troopers and youth groups marched down the Wilhelmstrasse to greet the new ruler, there was a sense in Germany of a new awakening and a break with the past.

title: Miss Kissin Plans Wedding April 23
description: Irving Kissin of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Amanda Kissin, to Peter Low, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Low of Belmont, Mass. The wedding is to be April 23.

title: TO DETER AND DEFUSE
description: THINKING ABOUT THE NEXT WAR By Thomas Powers. 153 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95.

title: MRS. GANDHI NAMES 12 NEW MINISTERS
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formally accepted the resignations of seven central Government ministers and appointed 12 new ones today, some to newly created posts.

title: JAZZ PIANO: ABDULLAH IBRAHAIM
description: The Abdullah Ibrahim Quartet opened a five-night stand Tuesday at Sweet Basil with a determinedly understated set. Mr. Ibrahim, the South African pianist who first recorded under the name Dollar Brand, has long been known for his slow-rolling gospel vamps, ringing tremolos and celebratory full-band shouts. But in Tuesday's early set he downplayed those trademarks, as if to show just how much else he can do.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY THREAT HINTS OF TROUBLE AHEAD
description: The first and formal Democratic response to President Reagan's State of the Union Message last week was a prerecorded 28-minute television special peopled by two dozen office holders and a dozen citizens. A deliberate effort to portray a loyal opposition with a program of its own, it was long on caring for the country and light on criticism of the Reagan economic and social policies.

title: Pat Bradley Leads by 2 on 206
description: Pat Bradley scored her second straight 69 to take a two-stroke lead over Beth Daniel today after the third round of the $150,000 Mazda Classic of Deer Creek.

title: Elena Maria Echarte and Edward C. Lord 3d Wed
description: Elena Maria Echarte, daughter of Elena Aguilera Echarte of Palm Beach, Fla., and Pedro Pablo Echarte of Miami, was married yesterday to Edward Crary Lord 3d, son of Mr. Lord 2d of Syosset, L.I., and the late Mrs. Lord. The Rev. Ross Garnsey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: ROME'S FINEST HIDING PLACES
description: LOUIS INTURRISI, who was a Fulbright scholar in Sicily, teaches English at the University of Rome.

title: Sports of The Times; Returning to the Scene
description: FOR nine years Bob Kuechenberg carried his memories of three Super Bowls, wondering if he would ever get to do it again. For 10 years George Starke lived with the memory of sitting in the stands and watching his teammates play in a Super Bowl.

title: Anne N. Hoskins Engaged to Wed W.T. Emmet 2d
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Hobart Hoskins of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Nivin Hoskins, to William Temple Emmet 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet Jr. of Westford and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: THE LAMENTATIONS OF RABBI X
description: The author of the following article says it was based on a prenuptial conversation that he and his wife-to-be had with the rabbi who married them 10 years ago.

title: Weds Eduardo Estades, Lawyer
description: Constance Louise Romero, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Romero of Hamden, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Eduardo Rene Estades, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis G. Estades of Rio Piedras, P.R. The Rev. Harold Elliot Barrett performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: Richard Olstein, Annette Healey Exchange Vows
description: Annette M. Healey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Healey of Crowborough, Sussex, England, and Philadelphia, and Richard Olstein of New York were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: STRINGS: PANOCHA QUARTET
description: It is always a pleasure to encounter a chamber group so versatile and convincing as the Panocha String Quartet. The Prague-based quartet consists of the violinists Jiri Panocha and Pavel Zejfart, the violist Miroslav Sehnoutka, and the cellist Jaroslav Kulhan; their performance at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night was a model of taste and expressivity.

title: The Trees Are All Ear
description: We were more than a little cheered a year or so ago to learn that one of our favorite foods, aside from being tasty, was also healthy. The ingredient in question is that highly edible fungus known in English as tree ears and in Chinese as mo-er.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE MARKS THE FOUNDING OF GEORGIA
description: The 250th anniversary of the founding of Georgia by a group of 125 colonists is being observed with a 13-cent commemorative postal card that will be issued in Savannah on Feb. 12. This is the exact date in 1623 when the colonists, lead by James Edward Oglethorpe, landed on a bluff 18 miles up the Savannah River after a two-month rough passage from England.

title: WITNESS TO WAR'S WASTE
description: CHRONICLE OF YOUTH The War Diary 1913-1917. By Vera Brittain. Edited by Alan Bishop with Terry Smart. 382 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.50.

title: Susan A. Voorhis To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Voorhis of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Anne Voorhis, to Hugh McCauley Balloch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Balloch, also of Wilton. A May wedding is planned.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH THE GANDHI WHO STANDS BEHIND 'GANDHI'
ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN my used-car days, I had the idea that buying a new car would be a thrill, an occasion for pride and excitement, and that owning one would be heaven.

title: PORTUGUESE CRISIS STALLS TALKS ON U.S. BASES
description: Portugal's Government crisis has stalled negotiations with the United States on the status of a strategic air base in the Azores and on an American request for its first military installations on the Portuguese mainland.

title: THE THIRD WEEK
description: Political reforms almost always seem to have unintended consequences. Efforts by the Democrats to shorten their interminable primary season, for a current example, have put new emphasis on the ability of Presidential candidates to raise ''early money.'' That may deliver a big advantage to Walter Mondale.

title: TRANSFORMING THE WORLD INTO FEELING
description: THE SELECTED POETRY OF RAINER MARIA RILKE Edited and translated by Stephen Mitchell. Introduction by Robert Hass. 356 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Dr. Deborah B. Shapse To Wed a Psychiatrist
description: The engagement of Dr. Deborah Beth Shapse to Dr. Paul Steven Sachs, son of Gloria Sachs of Englewood, N.J., and the late Charles Sachs, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Shapse of Chester, N.J., parents of the future bride. A May wedding is planned.

title: Moro's Killers Get Life in Jail
description: Italy feared revolution or repression might be at hand five years ago when Red Brigades seized and killed Aldo Moro, the former Prime Minister. But general mayhem did not ensue, democracy survived and last week a jury at a mass trial in Rome levied the maximum punishment for Mr. Moro's assassins.

title: EX-COAST OFFICIAL TO GET G.O.P. POST
description: Ed Reinecke, forced to resign as Lieutenant Governor nine years ago when he was convicted of perjury, will be elected by acclamation Sunday as chairman of the California Republican Party.

title: A CITY CONSIDERS PRIVATE FIRE SERVICE
description: FOR three decades, cities and towns in the South and Southwest have been turning to private contractors to provide municipal fire protection. Now, following the initial approval of the City Council of Willimantic of a proposal by the Florida-based Wackenhut Corporation, the effort to reduce firefighting budgets by moving from publicly operated departments to private services has reached New England.

title: Layoffs, Taxes To Close Albany Budget Deficit
description: Many politicians break campaign promises and then deny they made them, but Governor Cuomo may be the only one to keep a pledge he insists he never uttered. Whether or not he actually vowed to hold the line on the state's business, income and sales taxes while running for office last year - the Governor and the record seem to disagree - the budget Mr. Cuomo will send to the Legislature Tuesday will do just that.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cliffside Park $68,000 *2*438 Anderson Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; new tile bath, *2*semifinished basement; taxes $1,000. Denville $115,000 *2*534 Openaki Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*23-year-old ranch; 2.7-acre lot near brook, *2*enclosed porch, stone fireplace in living room; taxes $2,041. Short Hills $225,000 *2*79 Old Short Hills Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*4-year-old colonial; finished basement, family *2*room with fireplace; taxes $4,380. Upper Montclair $119,000 *2*43 College Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*55-year-old colonial; two-car garage, deck off *2*master bedroom; taxes $3,442. Westfield $197,000 *2*842 Bradford Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*55-year-old colonial; leaded-glass windows *2*and French doors, new kitchen and *2*bath; taxes $4,028. West Orange $112,500 *2*24 Lowell Place 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old Tudor; cathedral ceiling, stone *2*fireplace, modern kitchen; taxes $2,840. OTHER AREAS Ossining, N.Y. $86,000 *2*52 Iroquois Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old *2*Cape Cod; finished playroom, 62- by *2*121-foot lot; taxes $2,671. Madison, Conn. $97,000 *2*26 Fairfield Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*16-year-old Dutch colonial; electric *2*heat; taxes $1,519. Setauket, L.I. $72,000 *2*32 Black Locust Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*11-year-old ranch; full basement, formal *2*dining room; taxes $2,400.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAVANNAH
description: They are preparing a February birthday party in Savannah, Georgia, to celebrate the arrival of some three dozen families from England 250 years ago to found the 13th British colony in America.

title:
ART;
IN SCULPTURE AND DRAWINGS, THE HUMANISTIC CURRENT RUNS DEEP
description: TO mark its first anniversary, the North Shore Sculpture Center in Great Neck has departed from its usual program of group exhibitions to present a one-person show of the work of Alfred Van Loen, a sculptor whose influence on the Island, both as a teacher and through public commissions, has been considerable.

title: INDIAN TRIBES SKEPTICAL ON POLICY SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON FOR American Indians, last week's events had a painfully familier look and sound as the Reagan Administration, like so many of its predecessors, announced a new Indian affairs policy. Once again, the Indians were presented with a statement notable for its language but lacking specific proposals for dealing with the unemployment, poverty and disease characteristic of reservation life.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
SHE TOOK THE PLUNGE INTO OPERA
description: MYRNA BISMARCK sang before she talked. But brought up in a family that considered ''music too frivolous,'' the soprano, who will star in the Nassau Lyric Opera Company's production of ''The Marriage of Figaro'' Saturday at 8 P.M. at the C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater, had to enter the business through what she calls ''the back door.''

title: CONCERT: OZAWA'S 'FAUST'
description: Berlioz's ''The Damnation of Faust'' is not heard too often today, perhaps because it is so easily misunderstood. If it is thought of as an opera without sets and costumes; if it is thought of as crudely pictorial with its invocations of hunting horns, heartbeats and a Hungarian march; if it is regarded as lacking in spirituality because of its rejection of Germanic conceptions of the Faustian soul - that is, if it is not taken on its own terms, it is bound to seem an anomaly.

title: OF SNOWS AND THE CARS OF YESTERYEAR
description: Here in New England and throughout the Northeast, snow is closely followed by the spreading of rock salt on the roads. But rock salt not only melts snow; it also causes rust.

title: ROCK 'N' ROLL: TINA TURNER, GOSPEL STYLE
description: Tina Turner is the rare rock singer over 40 years of age who possesses seemingly inexhaustible stamina. Thursday, with her fivepiece band and two backup singer-dancers, she delighted a packed house at the Ritz with an evening of steamy old-time rock-and-roll.

title: Malcolm Dixon to Be Wed To Elizabeth A. Mortimer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Mortimer of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Mortimer, to Malcolm John Dixon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Dixon of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Harvard Replies
description: To the Business Editor: Dean Richard R. West and Prof. Dennis E. Logue of Dartmouth questioned our ideas about managers' role in our nation's faltering industrial competitiveness (''The False Doctrines of Productivity,'' Jan.9, and ''A Plea to Reject Economic Fashion,'' Jan.16). While we welcome debate on these issues, we believe that their comments are misleading in a number of important respects.

title:
GARDENING;
YEARS OF ASPARAGUS FROM LITTLE LABOR
description: WHEN the seed and nursery catalogues arrive by mail, can spring be far behind? Each day brings another catalogue extolling the virtues of new roses, generations-old vegetable varieties, dwarf conifers, new marigolds, extra-sweet sweetcorn, an undreamed number of beans and even a new hybrid asparagus.

title: A GIFT OF RARE YIDDISH BOOKS
description: THE recent dramatic revival in Yiddish language and culture will be emphasized in ceremonies today at 2 P.M. when more than 300 rare and out-of-print books are given to the Great Neck Public Library.

title: Winning Design
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN STANDS BY 'ZERO OPTION'
description: A day before the arrival of Vice President Bush, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that the United States ''zero-option'' proposal would be the ''most desirable'' result of the Geneva arms negotiations.

title: ON THEIR HOME TURF, JAPANESE CAR COMPANIES THINK BIG
description: TOKYO THE Japanese automobile on its native soil is a sight to behold. In this nation of car doters, the vehicular specimens on the road invariably look like they have just been driven off the showroom floor. No scratches, dents or dirt mar their glistening exteriors.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE APOCALYPTIC PREMISE Nuclear Arms Debated. Thirty-one Essays by Statesmen, Scholars, Religious Leaders and Journalists. Edited by Ernest W. Lefever and E. Stephen Hunt. 417 pp. Washington: Ethics and Public Policy Center. Cloth, $14. Paper, $9.

title: Owing the U.S.
description: People who had been overpaid by the Social Security Administration owed it $2 billion in June 1982, but the agency said it was running 28 percent ahead of the previous year in recovering the debts.

title: Oral Roberts's Word on Cancer
description: The war against cancer may soon be joined by Christian soldiers called to battle by evangelist Oral Roberts. In solicitations launched this month, Mr. Roberts said Jesus appeared to him and declared a breakthrough will occur at the still-rising City of Faith medical center in Tulsa, Okla.

title: GREECE GIVES WIVES EQUAL VOICE IN THE HOME
description: Legislation intended to give married women an equal voice with their husbands in all matters of family life was unanimously adopted this week by the Greek Parliament.

title: Of Wives and Mothers, Careers and Choices
description: Re: ''The Case of the Missing Career,'' Opinion Page, by Irene McCoy: The plaint of the author has become all too common and it is becoming somewhat boring. She repeats the frequently stated excuse that ''they haven't gotten pregnant. They hadn't packed up and taken off in the wake of their spouses.'' ''They'' being all the other people who had established themselves in their careers.

title: Memory Refreshed
description: A former administrator of the Boston Redevelopment Authority, George N. Collatos has changed his tune about his political activities. Mr. Collatos is already serving a three-year sentence for extortion.

title:
THE TALK OF MERRICK ROAD;
WHERE DEVOTION TO THE CAR IS A WAY OF LIFE
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I. AT the western end of the strip is Coro Auto Center, which will fix your transmission. Then comes a used car lot called D@&@S Auto Sales, and then Kenny's Auto Body, and West Amity Auto Parts. After that is Volvoville U.S.A., whose sign proclaims it to be ''America's Largest Volvo Dealer.''

title: SCHOLARS WITHOUT SCHOOLS
description: IN A basement workshop in his Lawrenceville home, Tom Adams, an English teacher, peers through a microscope, manipulating slides of nematodes, algae or protozoa and firing off an electronic flash to photograph them.

title: TENNIS PARTIES: SOCIAL WEEKENDS
description: On Friday nights, while many single New Yorkers are bending their elbows and socializing in their neighborhood bars, hundreds of their counterparts are choosing real exercise at a social ritual known as the tennis party.

title: UNLOCK THE STOREHOUSES
description: Editor: The lead article on your Jan. 23 front page reports on the staggering cost of farm price supports. The additional cost to the taxpayer of storing the surplus produce is a further burden.

title: LEBANON'S MASSACRE INQUIRY: FEW ANSWERS AFTER 4 MONTHS
description: While the Israeli commission investigating the killing of Palestinian civilians in Beirut refugee camps is preparing its findings, the Lebanese Government's investigator says he does not know who committed the murders, or when he will be able to find out.

title: Susan Carr Haley Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Haley of Hingham, Mass., formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carr Haley, to Donald Taylor Kingman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Kingman of Norwell, Mass. Miss Haley is with the department of services at the University of Southern Maine in Portland, where Mr. Kingman is a resident director counselor. A June marriage is planned.

title: SOMETHING DIFFERENT FOR CHICAGO VOTERS
description: This city doesn't formally elect its mayor until April 12, but, barring the unexpected, it will be the results of the Democratic primary coming up on George Washington's Birthday that really count. It has been, after all, 56 years since a Republican had anything more than a prayer's chance of winning. Accordingly, Chicago's new mayor will almost certainly emerge from the following Democratic cast:

title: CONSUMERS PROTESTING RISE IN GAS HEAT'S COST
description: The Church of St. John Kanty in Buffalo is locked five days a week because the rising cost of natural gas has made it too expensive to heat the spired, neo-Gothic building.

title: POP SINGER: JOEY HEATHERTON
description: Joey Heatherton, who is appearing at Marty's, combines the roles of brassy Las Vegas showgirl and whispery pop chanteuse in ways that aren't always appropriate for the stage of an intimate supper club. Miss Heatherton has a little voice and a hesitant style of phrasing that recall Marilyn Monroe.

title: A 2-POET HOUSEHOLD
description: THE poets Margaret Gibson and David McKain built their home on a secluded rural lot in Preston, where the uneven roads twist through woods so thick that the only sounds come from the life within. It is the kind of territory that stokes introspection.

title: NASSAU WEIGHS SUIT ON INSURANCE SPLIT
description: WHILE Joseph M. Margiotta is appealing to the United States Supreme Court his conviction in the Nassau County insurance premium-splitting scandal, the county is laying the groundwork for a possible civil suit against the Republican politicians who, at Mr. Margiotta's direction, received county and town insurance commissions for little or no work.

title: Pain
description: Anthony Villane is a New Jersey assemblyman and a dentist. We don't know what kind of dentist, but when it comes to crime, he's obviously no Painless Parker.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF RECEPTION FOR MCI
description: RYE BROOK OFFICIALS in Rye and Harrison have put out the welcome mat for MCI International, the newest company to opt to put its corporate headquarters in Westchester.

title: A Correction
description: Frank E. Morris was incorrectly identified in The Week in Review of Jan. 16. Mr. Morris, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, was an official in the Treasury Department in the Kennedy Administration.

title: FRENCH GITES
description: To the Editor: I have read the article entitled ''Country Comfort in France'' but find it hard to believe that a car is indispensable in renting a gite.

title: DANCE: PHOEBE NEVILLE
description: The Phoebe Neville Dance Company demonstrated that small can be beautiful at its Thursday night performance at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery. Miss Neville is a miniaturist whose dances are nevertheless so mysterious that they can give viewers the shudders.

title:
DINING OUT;
SERENE ITALIAN WITH A LIGHT TOUCH
description: CLASS has reached Port Chester's main shopping street, in Angsavanee, a plush, glowing, serene restaurant that serves excellent, light renditions of Italian cuisine. The Thai chef and owner, Charlie Touthong, has named the restaurant after his wife. The name means ''Shoulders of a Goddess.''

title: Obligation to Deaf
description: The question before the United States Supreme Court was: What did the Federal Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975 mean when it said handicapped children were entitled to a ''free appropriate public education''?

title: AMERICAN DESK SELLS FOR $687,500 AT SOTHEBY'S
description: An 18th-century Chippendale desk-dressing table, boldly carved in Newport, R.I., with a blockfront and four shell carvings, sold yesterday for $687,500 at Sotheby Parke Bernet to Harold Sack of Israel Sack, the 57th Street dealers.

title: RETHINKING THE WINTER ANTIQUES SHOW
description: Discussions have raged throughout this year's Winter Antiques Show, about how, if at all, the fair should change. The event, the nation's most prestigious bazaar for second-hand wares, attracting 73 dealers as participants and about 25,000 viewers, ends its nine-day run and 29th appearance tonight at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Patrick Leads North Dakota
description: The University of North Dakota has been doing a good job of defending its national collegiate hockey championship despite heavy graduation losses and a roster overloaded with underclassmen.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Phone Shopping

title: BATTERED BUT NOT BEATEN, THE 'WRECK' FACES ONE MORE ROUND ON THE ROAD
description: SOME people need a shrink or a weekly trip to the hairdresser. The Wreck, a '76 wagon long of tooth and battered of body, needs Hector the Transplant King. This costs more than a bread box, and only somewhat less than psychotherapy. In return, the car operates 80 percent of the time, unless it's cold or hot, when bets are off, or unless someone has patted the grille, setting the fan in motion and drinking up the zest in the battery.

title: 'INDEPENDENTS' IN ART
description: When it comes to the contemporary art scene, few women have had as much impact as Louise Nevelson and Georgia O'Keeffe. Contrasting their contributions, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art today opens ''Nevelson and O'Keeffe: Independents of the 20th Century.''

title: WEINBERGER BIDS CONGRESS TRIM PORK BARREL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who has been under continuing Congressional pressure to reduce military spending, plans to challenge Congress to cut funds that Congress itself has added to the 1983 military budget, Pentagon officials said today.

title: BABY BENZ IS A BIG STEP FOR THE 'QUIET GIANT'
description: THE late Karlfried Nordmann used to like to say that Mercedes-Benz was ''just a little car company,'' but the former president of the company's North American division would chortle as he said it. The fact is that, despite its carefully cultivated low profile, Mercedes is something of a quiet giant.

title: FIGURING TAXES ON PAYMENTS
description: PEOPLE who used some sort of creative financing to sell their homes w ill find that the new mechanisms require special treatment at tax t ime.

title: No Headline
description: Rita Webb Smith has hit upon the most practical immediate solution to the problem with her survival clinic. We at the Center for Farm and Food Research also advocate this approach.

title: IN SPITE OF ITS CAST, 'WHATTASHOW' IS NO SHOW
description: THE cabaret mini-revue has made a major comeback. How, then, can a producer resist being trendy? Spurred by a couple of Manhattan successes - ''Upstairs at O'Neals' '' and ''Forbidden Broadway'' - W. Matthew Senie, who put on plays at Fairfield's Scenario Restaurant for five years, is trying out ''Whattashow,'' downstairs at Axelrod's Emporium Restaurant in Westport. For Mr. Senie, this is a Fairfield County experiment with Off Broadway aspirations.

title: Judith Berkowitz To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Berkowitz of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Michele Berkowitz, to Jeffrey Jay Tretin, son of Laura F. Tretin of New York and the late Louis Tretin. A June wedding is planned.

title: Work Toward A Mutual Problem
description: The article ''Miscalculations on Solid Waste,'' by Weston's First Selectman, Susan J. Hutchinson, in the Jan. 2 issue of Connecticut Opinion contains some errors of fact as well as some misunderstanding of the work that had gone into this entire project.

title: THE JAPANESE DESIGNER WHO PAVED THE WAY
description: At age 44, Issey Miyake ranks as Japan's leading designer. Since 1971, when his ultramodern designs first appeared at Bloomingdale's in New York, his clothes have been stocked and sold in stores across this country, and his companies now generate $50 million in annual sales, worldwide.

title: PETER DUFAULT TO MARRY JANET GLENN IN SUMMER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jules Glenn of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Ellen Glenn, to Peter John Dufault , son of Dr. and Mrs. John Dufault of Holden, Mass.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Bonanza for Depositors

title: THE SHOREHAM HEARINGS: TESTIMONY ON EVACUATION PLANS
description: FOR the last two weeks, the Suffolk County Legislature conducted hearings on a proposed emergency preparedness plan for the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear power plant at Shoreham. The issue is vital to the future of the plant because an emergency plan must be approved by the state's Disaster Preparedness Commission and forwarded to the Federal Emergency Management Agency before Lilco can begin operating the Shoreham plant.

title: PETE ROZELLE'S WORLD: SHAKEN BUT NOT FALLEN
description: UNLIKE Louis XIV, who declared, ''L'etat, c'est moi,'' Pete Rozelle h as never been heard in a similar spirit to proclaim in French, E nglish, Kurdish or any other language, ''I am the N.F.L.''

title: WHY IS THERE SO MUCH FLIMFLAMMERY IN OPERA NOWADAYS?
description: I suppose every child goes through a period when life offers no greater joy than the opportunity to play a trick on someone, preferably an adult. For a time in my own boyhood, I was enthralled by practical jokes and magic (the palm buzzer and the disappearing handkerchief were specialties). I particularly treasured an innocentlooking kaleidoscope that left the person who looked through it with a circle of black shoe polish around the eye. While rotating the eyepiece and marveling at the patterns that resulted from chance rearrangement of colored bits of glass, the victim was unknowingly conspiring in his or her own embarrassment. I never tired of this joke, although others soon did. In fact, the pool of potential du-s ran out when all available family members and schoolyard colleagues had cooperated once or, if they were especially amiable, twice.

title: GIVEBACKS COST A PAN AM CAPTAIN LITTLE, BUT COULD MEAN A LOT TO THE AIRLINE
description: WHEN Richard Wiese started flying for Pan Am in 1955, he was doing aj ob he had longed for since he was a boy, when he would watch Pan A m's clippers fly across Long Island Sound heading to destinations a ll around the world.

title: AMERICA'S NEGLECTED ELDERLY
description: Didi Moore is a New York based freelance writer with a special interest in family issues. he crisis with my mother began when she was just 80,'' said a 49-year-old public-relations woman from the East Coast. ''She'd had a couple of falls before, but this time it happened in the middle of the night. She tried to get to the phone, but she fell again. Fortunately, my uncle just happened to come by the next morning.

title: FRENCH TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GREAT ZAMBEZI RIVER EXPEDITION
description: FRANZ LIDZ writes for Sports Illustrated.

title: Bronx Jeers?
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM NOVEL TO TV-A FOUR-YEAR SAGA
description: ''I've always loved to re-create the past,'' muses producerdirector Dan Curtis. ''It's an escape to a better time. I know you can't call Hitler a better time, but the period of the Second World War was a time full of hope, the last phase of innocence. I love the romanticism of that era. In a way, I feel like Miniver Cheevy - born too late.''

title: MEDICAL-CARE SPENDING FOUND A MAJOR CONCERN WITHIN CITY
description: Spending on health care became the predominant concern of New York City's poor, aged and disabled last year, according to a survey by Louis Harris and Associates.

title: Zoning People In, Not Out
description: ''If sound planning of an area allows the rich and middle class, it must also allow the poor. And if the area will accommodate factories, it must also find space for workers.'' So rules the New Jersey Supreme Court, reaffirming its position that exclusionary suburban zoning violates the state constitution. The unanimous decision, written by Chief Justice Robert Wilentz, blends passion, precision and firmness. It's stirred controversy. It also merits applause.

title: COMMUTING ON AN 'UNDISCOVERED SECRET'
description: MANY commuter rail lines linking New York to the New Jersey suburbs have been torn up or abandoned, but t here still exist some 450 miles of track in the northern and centrals ections of the state that can carry commuters into the city in v arying degrees of comfort, speed and regularity.

title: Clear and Present Slogans
description: The President declares the Federal deficit to be ''a clear and present danger to the basic health of our Republic.'' There's a clearer, more present danger: That he will, using political subterfuge, continue to steer economic policy in the wrong direction. Public Enemy No. 1 is not the deficit; it is the recession.

title: GROWING FAST AT FINLEY KUMBLE
description: The fastest-growing law firm in the country is Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg & Casey, a New York-based firm that was organized in 1968 and now has about 270 lawyers. Since 1979, Finley Kumble has expanded 296 percent - almost eight times the national average for the period. Most of that growth has come through mergers with other firms and by hiring away big-name partners.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Lets Her People Go
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi last week tried to right her ship by clearing the decks. Dozens of Cabinet Ministers and other top Government and Congress Party officials were obliged to sign letters of resignation, and yesterday she dismissed a few to combat the ruling party's growing reputation for mismanagement and corruption.

title: Can They Get To West Bank From Here?
description: The ''north bank problem,'' shorthand in the Middle East for Israel's insistence on retaining a military presence in Lebanon, is testing Washington's patience. President Reagan used a White House visit by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak last week to make clear his unhappiness with the lack of progress on Israeli withdrawal. Until that changed, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's postponed visit to Washington was being kept on hold.

title: ADVENTURES OF A 10-LIRA PIECE
description: A COIN IN NINE HANDS By Marguerite Yourcenar. Translated by Dori Katz in collaboration with the author. 174 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: AFTER 314,131 MILES, WHY IS THIS MAN SMILING?
description: WASHINGTON IN the service of the Reagan Administration, Vice President George Bush has traveled 314,131 miles to such destinations as Zimbabwe, Peking, Scranton and Albuquerque, and today he is off to Western Europe on his most ambitious excercise in public relations diplomacy -trying to persuade a nervous and skeptical Europe that Ronald Reagan is both reasonable and serious about arms control.

title: FASHION;Loose Translator
description: We must break away from conventional forms of dress for the new woman of today. We need a new strong image, not a revisit to the past. I have been trying for three years. This time, I think I have been most successful.''

title: SKIES BRIGHTEN FOR OWNERS OF FLOOD-PRONE HOMES
description: OWNERS of homes in low-lying parts of New York City may soon be able to buy up to $245,000 in low-cost i nsurance against water damage resulting from flooding under the N ational Flood Insurance Program.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: SHOULD state lawmakers propose laws that they do not believe in and that they know have no chance for serious discussion, let alone approval by their colleagues in the General Assembly?

title: FUNK: SHRIEKBACK, A QUINTET
description: Two members of Shriekback played in highly original British bands of the late 1970's. The quintet's keyboardist is Barry Andrews, formerly of XTC and the League of Gentlemen, and its bassist is Dave Allen, who was in the Gang of Four.

title: British Water Workers Vote to Continue Strike
description: Britain's water and sewerage workers voted today to continue their six-day strike, ignoring Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's call for a return to work.

title: 27 Aces in Lendl Victory
description: Ivan Lendl, hitting 27 aces, defeated Kevin Curren today in a semifinal of the World Championship Tennis $250,000 winter finals.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: EVEN though the Federal Environmental Protection Agency recently identified 65 of the worst hazardous waste sites in New Jersey, it never investigated 900 businesses that regularly discharge pollutants directly into the ground or into lagoons or other water impoundments.

title: IN THE OLDE WAYS
description: Cooking lunch on the woodstove in Washington Irving's kitchen, concocting herbal medicines that were used in the 18th century, picking and carding wool and then spinning and weaving it on antique looms, blacksmithing, learning how to light a room with fat or whale oil - these are a few of the things to be learned at the Sleepy Hollow Restorations workshops.

title: THE DANCE: LAMPERT TROUPE
description: Rachel Lampert is probably best known as a teller of dark tales. Her potent new ''Strategy,'' a modern dance work performed by Rachel Lampert and Dancers on Friday at the New York University Tisch School of the Arts, belongs nominally to that genre. It is, after all, a chill look at a driven businessman. But there are no props and no refugees from short stories here. Miss Lampert does her telling in sheer physical terms, with just a touch of costume to stamp the message.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT PENGUINS, 2-1
description: Coach Herb Brooks got a double dose of pleasure tonight when the Rangers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 2-1. Not only did the team break out of its four-game losing slump, but the decisive goal was scored by one of Brooks's proteges from the University of Minnesota and his 1980 Olympic champion hockey team.

title: Ashley Alexandra Carlin to Marry Brian Formento
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carlin of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ashley Alexandra Carlin, to Brian Walter Formento, son of Mr. and Mrs. John David Formento of Elkhart, Ind., and Chicago.

title: ARTHUR'S SISTER'S STORY
description: THE MISTS OF AVALON By Marion Zimmer Bradley. 876 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: 2 PREMIERES MARK EGLEVSKY'S NEXT STOP
description: AT a City Center rehearsal studio, the choreographer Daniel Levans tapped his foot and counted aloud to the syncopated beats of Paul Hindemith's ''Kammermusik Number Five.'' He gestured bits of movement as dancers looked on. Stopping the tape recorder once again, he turned. ''You're doing a promenade. It doesn't hit arabesque until the count of three.''

title: ZEN AND THE STANFORD BUSINESS STUDENT
description: PALO ALTO, Calif. IN a darkened classroom, 25 students gather in a semicircle and listen to the soothing tunes of a Hindu musician. Eyes closed, the students sit on the floor, backs straight, hands on thighs, legs crossed. They chant in unison.

title: ANOTHER WAY TO PREDICT THE WEATHER
description: year-old meteorologist at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury, calculated a differential advection index three times higher than that of a normally severe storm, indicating that a tornado was on the way.

title: Miss Rudkin to Wed Jeffrey F. Allsopp
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Rudkin of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathrine Rudkin, to Jeffrey Forester Allsopp, son of Mrs. Peter Bonfield Allsopp of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Mr. Allsopp. A May 28 wedding is planned.

title: Boise State's Coach Moves to Iowa State
description: Jim Criner, who produced two Big Sky Conference championships and one Division I-AA title in seven years as Boise State's football coach, has resigned to become coach at Iowa State. He replaces Donnie Duncan, who quit two weeks ago to enter private business.

title: CLIPPERS DEFEAT KNICKS, 106-97
description: The big news last night was to have been Bill Walton's return to Madison Square Garden after an absence of more than five years. Instead, it was Randy Smith, a former Knick, and Lowes Moore, a Nets' castoff, who hurt the Knicks most in their 106-97 loss to the San Diego Clippers.

title: ALLAN A. BROWN
description: Allan A. Brown, a certified public accountant, died of cancer Friday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, where he was being treated.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BUYING THE NIGHT FLIGHT The Autobiography of a Woman Foreign Correspondent. By Georgie Anne Geyer. 337 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: A Kicker Comes Back
description: Tim Mazzetti, the second-leading scorer in Atlanta Falcons' history with 233 points from 1978 to 1981, has signed as a place-kicker with the Boston Breakers of the United States Football League. Mazzetti, 26 years old, who has worked for the last two years as a sportscaster in Atlanta, twice kicked 54-yard field goals during his senior year at the University of Pennsylvania before joining the National Football League. ... The N.F.L. Alumni Association, which is made up of 3,000 former players and 1,500 active ones, has designated a team of 11 players of the year.

title: ON BOOKS ON WAR
description: Plutarch tells of a Greek general who overheard a philosopher discussing warfare. The general said the philosopher talked well but was not to be believed, since he had never heard the blast of the battle trumpet. That story says a great deal about how people have discussed war.

title: LOANS OFFERED BY BIG 3 ARE COMPETITIVE
description: WITH the average 1983 car costing around $10,000 and upward when the cost of financing is added on, prospective buyers who want to pay less for a new car would be wise to arrange financing through an automobile dealer.

title: HOME MECHANICS: A DYING BREED?
description: KENWOOD MARKESSON remembers a time not too long ago when, armed with a screwdriver, a wrench and a dose of common sense, he could adjust the carburetor or tune up the engine of just about any car.

title: Montana Town's Police Vote to End Strike
description: Striking police officers returned to work today after voting to accept a new contract, ending a walkout that had left this town of 10,500 people with the police chief as the only law-enforcement officer since Wednesday.

title: CLUES GET WARM IN THE SEARCH FOR PLANET X
description: SOMETHING out there beyond the farthest reaches of the known solar system seems to be tugging at Uranus and Neptune. Some gravitational force keeps perturbing the two giant planets, causing irregularities in their orbits. The force suggests a presence far away and unseen, a large object that may be the long-sought Planet X.

title: The Beautiful Peril
description: Not bad enough the environment is threatened by PCB's, dioxin and acid rain. In June 1982 Robert A. Malecki, a wildlife biologist at Cornell University's College of Agriculture and Life

title: 32 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 32 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and three that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: No Headline
description: N. CAROLINA WINS AS JORDAN SCORES 39

title: OLD DOGS STILL BITE
description: Beware of old men playing conservative openings -they may just mean business. This advice comes too late for the English international master Jonathan Mestel, who learned the hard way in his game with a former world champion, Vasily Smsylov of the Soviet Union, at the Las Palmas Interzonal Tournament.

title: RIBERA'S VISION STILL DAZZLES THE EYE
'LEMON LAW' GAINS ATTENTION
description: THE state ''lemon law,'' the first in the nation, is attracting attention from the rest of the country, as complaints from new-car owners are starting to trickle into Better Business Bureaus and lawyer's offices. The law, designed to provide remedies to owners of new cars which do not work, entitles consumers to a new car or their money back under certain circumstances.

title: WHAT THE CHINESE WANT NOW
description: PEKING WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrives in Peking this week, he will find Chinese-American relations in the doldrums, with friendship between the two countries snagged on the shoals of hard reality. The malaise goes beyond basic incompatibility of ideological systems to the differences that separate the developing world, of which China is the largest country, and the industrialized nations. This was evident in the dispute that erupted this month over American curbs on Chinese textile imports.

title: The Human Condition: A Study in Diversity
description: An article on the front page of the business section of The Times entitled ''Brokers Aglow at Meeting'' described the good cheer and conviviality marking the convention of our country's investment bankers. They were celebrating the richest quarter in their history.

title:
ANTIQUES;
EXPERTS TO LECTURE IN FARMINGTON
description: THE Stanley-Whitman House in Farmington will hold its annual winter evening lecture series Feb. 9, 16 and 23. The focus of the series will be on Early American art and culture as explored by three widely known authorities on the history of the period.

title: Primary-Care
description: Nursing As a student at the Boston University School of Nursing, I have been wondering whether, after a challenging and difficult educational experience, I, too, will eventually enter the roll of nursing dropouts, once I see my skills undervalued at work (''Primary Nurses Bring Back One-on-One Care,'' by Natalie Davis Spingarn, Dec. 26). If more hospitals follow Beth-Israel's lead, then I am sure I will stay in my profession -as long as I know that I have a place where I can truly benefit the patient.

title: Turkey Executes 5, Including an Armenian
description: Five convicted murderers, including an Armenian gunman who stormed the Ankara airport last August, were executed in Turkey early today, officials said. Nine people were killed and more than 70 wounded in the attack on the airport.

title: Q&A
description: Question:We are planning a driving trip out West in April, and would like to know if there are any bus companies that provide tour service from either Flagstaff or Phoenix that would take us to the Grand Canyon and other tourist attractions in the region. -R.E.H., Whiting, N.J. Answer:For a basic packet of information on tourist attractions in Arizona, write to the Arizona Office of Tourism (3507 North Central Avenue, Suite 506, Phoenix, Ariz. 85012; 602-255-3618). If you have an interest such as camping, or a specific need such as wheelchair accessibility, include it in your request.

title: A COMMUTER'S GUIDE TO ETIQUETTE
description: IT is 8:45 on a Tuesday morning. I have just arrived in the city, as I do every weekday morning. I am still smarting from the rapturedisrupting ring of my alarm clock some two hours ago. But I am getting over it, inching my way back into the survivalist mentality I have developed after years of weathering the commute to work.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: MOSLEMS now have a place of worship in Purchase. Although some residents had expressed reservations about the idea, the Town Board of Harrison has approved giving Moslems, followers of Mohammed, the permit needed to establish a center for worship and study. It overturned the Harrison Planning Board, which had recommended rejecting the application.

title: Hunger In America
description: It is ironic that we once again have hunger in America, at a time when the Federal Government is spending hundreds of millions of dollars to store surplus agricultural products (''Once Again, Hunger Troubles America,'' by Elin Schoen, Jan. 2). Surely, if we can figure out how to send a man to the moon and how to make an artificial heart, we can figure out how to get surplus cheese and powdered milk to the poor. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: SHOPLIFTING BY ELDERLY ON INCREASE
description: ''AT the Farmer's Market last week, I saw an elderly, frail man stuff a grapefruit into his jacket pocket and shuffle across the road,'' Dorothy Perron, a Ridgewood gerontologist, told a group of elderly people in Paterson. ''I felt conflicting emotions about it.''

title: DONATIONS TO ENABLE COLUMBIA TO EXPAND PROGRAM IN BUSINESS
description: Columbia University has received $2.5 million from the Uris Brothers Foundation and $500,000 from the Mobil Foundation for an expansion of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.

title: CHEAP OIL AND LESSER DEFICITS WON'T KILL US
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTY LINES FADE AS CONGRESS'S BUDGET PANELS PREPARE TO CUT MILITARY
description: SPENDING By EDWARD COWAN WASHINGTON Afew hours before President Reagan gave his report on the State of the Union last week, White House chief of staff James A. Baker 3d phoned Representative James R. Jones, the Oklahoma Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. According to a Jones aide, Mr. Baker offered assurances that Mr. Reagan was sincere in what he was going to say about bipartisan cooperation.

title: 'WHATTASHOW': A SMALL REVUE
description: THE cabaret minirevue has made a major comeback. How, then, can a producer resist being trendy? Spurred by a couple of Manhattan successes - ''Upstairs at O'Neals' '' and ''Forbidden Broadway'' - W. Matthew Senie, who put on plays at Fairfield, Conn.'s Scenario Restaurant for five years, is trying out ''Whattashow,'' downstairs at Axelrod's Emporium Restaurant in Westport, Conn. For Mr. Senie, this is an experiment with Off Broadway aspirations.

title: DANCE: JOHANNA BOYCE
description: The dancers came and went, to and fro, and back and forth, in Johanna Boyce's ''With Longings to Realize,'' the new work that Johanna Boyce and Performance Group presented Wednesday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. And the dancers kept on going to and fro and back and forth over and over again for almost an hour in this piece in which the choreography was created by the performers in collaboration with Miss Boyce.

title: AN INTELLIGENCE UNIT IS REPORTEDLY READY TO END OPERATIONS
description: The International Reporting Information Systems, a private company formed in late 1981 to gather intelligence, plans to file for bankruptcy, according to several employees.

title:
ART;
AT PACE, IT'S LEONARDO, BUT IS IT ART?
description: THE link with art in the current exhibition at the Briarcliff campus of Pace University is so tenuous that one can wonder what it is doing in an art gallery at all. But a magnetic name is attached to it: Leonardo da Vinci, the jack-of-all-trades who was also master of all.

title: CALDWELL POSTS 67 AND LEADS BY A STROKE
description: In rainy conditions that he described as ''absolutely miserable,'' Rex Caldwell birdied the 18th hole today to take the lead in the third round of the Phoenix Open.

title: IVAN ILLICH: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE!
description: GENDER By Ivan Illich. 192 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95.

title: May Wedding Set For Miss Brown
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wellington Brown Jr. of Berwyn, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Clarke Brown, to Douglas Edward Seiler, son of Arthur John Paul Seiler of Haverford, Pa., and Helena, Mont., and the late Jean Watson Seiler of Bryn Mawr, Pa.
