A May wedding is planned.

title: China's Trade Surplus Reaches a Record High
description: China registered a record $4.6 billion trade surplus last year, according to preliminary official figures released today.

title: CUOMO AIDES MOVE TO MENDS SPLIT IN LIBERAL PARTY
description: Liberal Party leaders said late yesterday evening that they had worked out a tentative compromise with the help of aides to Governor Cuomo that would end one of the most serious divisions in the party's 40-year history.

title: Rodney Ballek Married To Deborah E. Baxter
description: Deborah E. Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Baxter of Madison, Conn., was married yesterday to Rodney F. Ballek of Scarsdale, N.Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Ballek of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Donald Thiel performed the ceremony at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale.

title: DANCE MARATHON WITH AN UPBEAT GOAL
description: UNLESS they have seen the movie ''They Shoot Horses, Don't They,'' most people in my generation don't know what a dance marathon is really like. Recently, I took part in a 12-hour dance-a-thon organized by students from the Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua to raise money for the Blythedale Children's Hospital at Valhalla. Each participant enlisted sponsors to pay them so much for each hour they lasted in the marathon. The rules were simple: either you danced for 50 minutes, took a 10-minute break, then went back onto the dance floor, or you were asked politely by the chaperones to leave.

title: TIME IS FELICITOUS FOR PRESSING BUDGET REFORM
description: THIS year, Westchester has a new County Executive and a new Chairman of the Board of Legislators. It also has one of two new county Legislators and should soon have the other - and all of the officials will have been appointed. It is the first time in nine years that the Republicans will control the county's executive and legislative branches of government.

title: The Greater New York Automobile Show
description: The show runs through Feb. 6 at the New York Coliseum, 59th Street and Broadway, from 11 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow through Saturday, and 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. today and next Sunday.

title: Mary Childs Weidlein Plans to Marry John Stuart Mackintosh in September
description: The engagement of Mary Childs Weidlein to John Stuart Mackintosh has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ray Weidlein Jr. of New York and Ligonier, Pa., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of David Delamater Mackintosh of Dover, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I., and the late Sarah Rice Mackintosh.

title:
GARDENING;
YEARS OF ASPARAGUS FROM LIITLE LABOR
description: WHEN the seed and nursery catalogues arrive by mail, can spring be far behind? Each day brings another catalogue extolling the virtues of new roses, generations-old vegetable varieties, dwarf conifers, new marigolds, extra-sweet sweetcorn, an undreamed number of beans and even a new hybrid asparagus.

title: EXCERPTS FROM KEAN'S MESSAGE OUTLINING NEW AUSTERITY BUDGET FOR JERSEY
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's message on New Jersey's 1983-84 state budget: We all know that these are difficult times, and the budget I present you with today reflects these times. It is a budget that anticipates the austerity we will face in the coming year. It is a budget that demands that we meet the challenge of diminishing resources with imagination and tough decisions.

title: DOLPHINS SCOUTING
description: This scouting report on the Miami Dolphins was compiled by Jim Royer of the Jets. Royer, the Jets' pro personnel director and chief scout, was assisted by William N. Wallace of The New York Times.

title: Princeton Theological Elects Pastor and Professor as Head
description: The Rev. Dr. Thomas W. Gillespie, a California pastor and professor, has been named president of Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary by a vote of the board of trustees.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT CANUCKS BY 5-3
description: Dave Williams lost his temper, the Vancouver Canucks lost the game, and there was a connection between the two.

title: KICK FINISH OVERDUE
description: LOS ANGELES ONLY two field-goal kickers have endured in Super Bowl history - Jim O'Brien for winning a game, Garo Yepremian for nearly losing a game. Jim O'Brien kicked a 32-yarder in V that lifted the Baltimore Colts over the Dallas Cowboys, 16-13, with only five seconds remaining. Garo Yepremian, after his field-goal attempt was blocked in VII, scooped up the ball and searched in panic for a receiver. As he threw, the ball slipped out of his hand as if it were a wet bar of soap. Mike Bass of the Washington Redskins snatched what was recorded as a fumble and dashed 49 yards for a touchdown, but the Miami Dolphins completed a 14-7 victory for a perfect 17-0 season.

title: A NOVEL KIND OF PUBLIC HOUSING
description: With their balconies and somewhat Art Deco look, the two apartment buildings whose refurbishing has been designed by Shelly Kroop and James McCullar, architects, could be intended for middle- or even upper-class tenants. But these two buildings are in the South Bronx, and until their reconstruction began recently they were abandoned and decaying.

title: The Weak Force Be With You
description: The universe is governed by four forces of interaction, most physicists believe. Some theorists go even further. They think the four forces derived from one big bang in the first moments of the cosmos' creation. If true, this would mean that a grand unification theory could explain it all - every interaction among every particle of matter, from star formation to cell metabolism.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Stockman hadn't been in the room five minutes when Reagan looked up and said, 'I can't go to the country with these deficits.' '' - Michael K. Deaver, White House deputy chief of staff. (1:4.)

title: SOME L.I. HOSPITALS BALK AT PENTAGON REQUEST FOR SPACE
description: LONG considered a scarce commodity by medical staffs and administrators, civilian hospital beds on Long Island are being sought by military planners, forcing many administrators to decide whether they can forfeit 50 beds each to the Department of Defense.

title: Tennis Casualties
description: The $375,000 United States Pro indoor tennis championships begin tomorrow in Philadelphia with three players on the sidelines because of injuries. Vitas Gerulaitis, who had been seeded third, withdrew last week, as did Jay Lapidus and Vince Van Patten.

title: THANKS FOR THE SUPER BOWL MEMORIES
description: ANYBODY who has ever played in the Super Bowl has special memories. Today, the Miami Dolphins and the Washington Redskins will create their own moments - joyous for some, sad for others. I was fortunate to have been part of four Super Bowl championship teams with the Pittsburgh Steelers, so almost all my memories are pleasant.

title: WILL GLADFLY BE A PHOENIX?
description: CLIFTON THE office remains open, and telephone callers are still greeted by a secretary saying, ''Independent Prospector,'' but for the first time in 23 years the opinions and actions of one of Passaic County's best-known figures remain a mystery.

title: NEW LURES FOR A NEW TYPE OF BUYER
description: IN what may seem like a throwback to the 1960's, Detroit is trying to sell glamour and innovation to lure potential automobile buyers who have not been attracted to the plain vanilla family sedans and compact economy cars the auto makers have been offering lately.

title: 19 IN NEW YORK HIGH SCHOOLS ARE SCIENCE CONTEST WINNERS
description: Nineteen high school students from New York were among the 40 national winners of the 42d annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: WANTED: ONE POLITICALLY UTILITARIAN GROUNDHOG
description: IN what appears to be a major policy decision, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke will attempt to bring down Westchester's utility costs by bringing up groundhogs this Wednesday, in conjunction with the national observance of Groundhog Day. At first denying any awareness of the holiday, Mr. O'Rourke later confirmed that he would use the occasion to stage ''a media event'' at Muscoot Farm Park in Somers, a county-owned recreational facility.

title: CUOMO TO PROPOSE SWEEPING CHANGES IN AID FOR SCHOOLS
description: Governor Cuomo will ask the State Legislature Tuesday to make sweeping changes in the way the state finances education, giving more money to poor school districts and less to wealthy ones, the Governor's budget aides said today.

title: NEW BILL MAY HELP N.J. FARMS
description: NEW JERSEY is finding it harder and harder to live up to its nickname. In the last two decades, the Garden State has lost a third of its farmland, or half a million acres. Still, as Governor Kean noted during the State Agricultural Convention in Cherry Hill last week - the second major farm meeting held this month - one out of every four jobs in New Jersey is connected with agriculture and food processing, which has a $2 billion to $3 billion impact on the state's economy. Mr. Kean did more than tell those in the audience how important he thought they were. He signed two significant pieces of legislation, a right-to-farm law protecting farmers from nuisance suits or local regulations regarding such things as fertilization, irrigation and noise, and a farmland preservation program setting aside state funds to purchase development rights and pay for soil and water conservation efforts. It will be up to Arthur R. Brown Jr., who became State Agriculture Secretary in July, to implement these measures. Mr. Brown, who was an agricultural agent for 11 years and helped pioneer new techniques in agronomy, recently discussed some of the troubles facing New Jersey farmers with Michael Norman, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times. Excerpts from their conversation follow.

title: Duran Defeats Cuevas On Knockout in Fourth
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI) - Roberto Duran scored a fourth-round knockout of Pipino Cuevas tonight in a scheduled 12-round elimination fight between the former world champions. Duran, the former world lightweight and welterweight champion, caught Cuevas with a hard right hand to the chin.

title: OWNERS RETAIN OLD CARS LONGER, DRIVING PRICES UP
description: The boom in the used car market, which is twice as large as the new car market, slackened somewhat at the end of 1982, but prices for used automobiles are still at a premium, good used cars are in short supply, and owners find themselves holding onto their cars longer and longer.

title: RUSTPROOFERS PREDICT A SURGE IN BUSINESS
description: A NEW car, generally speaking, starts to rust within 25 days, but the rustproofing industry has been in the doldrums lately for lack of new-car sales, as well as competition from car dealers who have begun to do their own rustproofing and auto makers who have made cars more resistant to corrosion.

title: CAROL A. NELSON TO WED LAURANCE READ
description: Mrs. Richard A. Nelson of Woodstock, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carol Ann Nelson, to Laurance A. Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Read of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Men Posing as Patrons Rob Bar and Shoot Two
description: Six men posing as patrons of a bar suddenly pulled out guns, ordered customers to the floor, stole their cash and jewelry and shot two people early today, the police said.

title:
OPINION;
NURSING HOMES, DESPITE THE PRESS, AREN'T ALL BAD
description: LONG before a person reaches the traditional age of three score and 10, she usually learns that life brings some very tough choices that nevertheless have to be made.

title: DOLPHIN'S DEFENSIVE UNIT: A FORCE BY ANY NAME
description: IT has become rather fashionable in the National Football League to find a nickname for the various units that have excelled throughout the year, a custom begun quite a few years ago when certain Minnesota Vikings were Purple People Eaters, a quartet of Los Angeles Rams were the Fearsome Foursome and a bunch of anonymous Miami Dolphins were the No-Name Defense. Later came Steel Curtains, Doomsday Defenses, Sack Packs, Orange Crushes, Grits Blitzes and Sack Exchanges.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
IT'S THE FAIREST WAY TO TAX THE PUBLIC
description: LIKE a blind date, the idea of a consumption tax conjures up very d ifferent images in the minds of different people. Some fear it will m istreat the poor and oppress the elderly. Others fear it will i ntroduce a radical new tax. But it won't. The outstanding feature ofa consumption tax is that it is fair to the entire taxpaying public.

title: Clock Stopped On Death Row
description: For the second time in two months, an inmate on Texas's death row appealed to the Supreme Court for an 11th-hour stay of execution. The difference last week was that the Court not only granted a reprieve, but decided to use the case of Thomas A. Barefoot to determine ''the appropriate standard for granting or denying'' any prisoner a stay of execution while his appeal is in progress.

title: Adirondack Snow Beckons
description: IF, in the company of a few individuals of the same persuasion, you wish to enjoy the white silence of the winter woods, Dick Beamish's Adirondack Ski Tours will serve you well.

title:
ART;
DRAWINGS THAT IMPRESS, NOT ONLY FOR SIZE
description: THE first thing to be said about the monumental drawings currently on view at C.W. Post's Hillwood Art Gallery in Brookville is that they are quite unlike anything we usually associate with the tradition of drawing. They are breathtaking spatial statements rather than intimate views of an artist's thoughts, and they are huge creations that assault our sense of gravity instead of whispering softly as intellectual products related to planning, designing and visual writing.

title: THE VASTNESS OF COURCHEVEL
description: ROBERT WOOL is a New York book packager and author of ''All You Need to Know About Banks'' (Bantam).

title: Counting Zeros May Still Add Up To Something
description: Washington and Moscow began a new round of their 14-month-old talks on medium-range missiles last week with signs that tough bargaining may get under way soon, amidst the Soviet peace offensive.

title: U.S. to Monitor Strike Talks
description: The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will monitor contract talks between the striking United Automobile Workers and the Caterpillar Tractor Company when they resume Feb. 8. About 21,000 union members at 18 Caterpillar facilities in Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Tennessee have been on strike nearly four months.

title: Black Executives in Corporate America
description: As a successful black executive who has lived with the problems of being black in corporate America and has enjoyed the challenge, I would like to respond to Bebe Moore Campbell's article ''Black Executives and Corporate Stress'' (Dec. 12). My personal stress is not in being black, but is related rather to the task of achieving my annual divisional-departmental goals.

title: BALI: JOURNEY TO A LEGEND
description: CHARLES P. CORN, a New York writer, spent three months in the Far East last year while doing research for a novel.

title: Judge in Ruvoldt Trial Assesses Bribery Count
description: The Federal judge in the bribery, extortion and conspiracy trial of Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr., the suspended Hudson County Prosecutor, said today that he might drop a bribery charge.

title: 'CATS' BENEFITS FOR ACTORS
description: There will be a benefit performance of "Cats" for the Actors Fund on Feb. 6 at 7 P.M. Tickets, which range from $27.50 to $45, are available at the Wintergarden Theater, 1634 Broadway. Information: 221-7300.

title: IN YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN FLATBUSH
description: kept gabled houses with o ak wainscoting, wide porch swings and deep window seats stand just a round corners from boarded-up storefronts.

title: FEDERAL OFFICE BUILDING ON STATEN ISLAND DAMAGED BY A BOMB
description: A bomb went off Friday night in a Federal building on Staten Island that houses offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a post office and recruiting stations for the Navy and Air Force, authorities said yesterday.

title:
DINING OUT;
DOWN-HOME MEXICO IN PRINCETON
description: IT'S difficult to imagine Mexican food more carefully prepared than at Mexican Village II, a seven-month-old restaurant on a back street in Princeton. There is no liquor license, neither are there any fancy decorations; just two simple dining rooms with white walls hung with a few woven Mexican wall hangings. And although the yellow cloth napkins are obviously chosen to complement the brown tablecloths, the last named are covered with sheets of clear plastic.

title: Boston Buses to Get Radios
description: To combat crime on public buses, drivers will be equipped with two-way radios so they can communicate with a central operations center, according to the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The move came Monday after three bus drivers were beaten in separate incidents on Jan. 22.

title: DESIGN
description: The true test of a vacation house is not so much how it shines in the best of times, but how it weathers the worst. Unfortunately, it may be asking too much of landowners who are in the throes of a dream about to come true to contemplate the possibility that a view might one day turn into a neighboring house or that the friendly dynamics of a houseful of rainbound guests might suddenly disintegrate. Consequently, it generally falls to the architect to add the critical pinches of pessimism, all the while making sure that the final confection suggests no possible condition other than a state of perpetual earthly bliss.

title: IMPOSSIBLE RATES UNFAIR ADVANTAGES
description: THE consumption tax is a bad idea. It does not meet the test of t axation according to the ability to pay; it would tax the wrong p eople at the wrong time; it would be as prone to erosion through l oopholes as the income tax, and it would lead to an excessive c oncentration of wealth.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: SUNDAY, JANUARY 30 Basketball Celtics vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Boston. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Notre Dame at U.C.L.A. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Football Super Bowl XVII, at Pasadena, Calif. Miami Dolphins, American Conference champions, vs. Washington Redskins, National Conference champions. Ten years ago, the Dolphins beat the Redskins, 14-7, and completed a 17-0 season. (Television - Channel 4, 6 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 6 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Oilers at Edmonton, 8:05 P.M. The Islanders won both earlier meetings this season, by 6-4 in Edmonton and by 4-2 at Nassau Coliseum. (Television - SportsChannel and WHT cables, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, WGBB 1240 and WALK-FM 97.5, 8 P.M.) Rangers vs. Black Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, 7:35 P.M. This will be the Rangers' last home game until Feb. 16. Their five-game road trip has stops in Los Angeles, St. Louis, Chicago, Minnesota and Montreal. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130, 7:30 P.M.) Indoor Soccer Arrows vs. Phoenix Inferno, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. The Arrows are 0-2 against the Inferno this season. Phoenix has two former Arrows on its team, Damir Sutevski and Gene Strenicer. (Radio -WGBB, 1240, 2 P.M.) Other Events Golf: Phoenix Open, final round of PGA tournament (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Mazda Classic of Deer Creek, final round, at Deerfield Beach, Fla. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M.) Harness Racing: Weekly highlights from the Meadowlands, East Rutherford, N.J. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight) Sled-Dog Racing: Alpo International Championships, at the Hotel Saranac, Saranac Lake, N.Y., 9:30 A.M. Tennis: Women's Avon Cup, at Marco Island, Fla.

title: LEWISBORO DEBATES ITS 'FLOATING ZONE'
description: HOMEOWNERS in the village of Lewisboro were surprised when they received notice that the town was looking at a plan for a $33 million office building to go up in the middle of their residential neighborhood. Surely, they thought, the town's zoning policies protect them from having to put up with more traffic, more noise and more competition for the underground water. But they were wrong.

title: NEW WAVE OF 4-WHEEL-DRIVE CARS MAKES A MARK
description: TEN years ago motorists who wanted four-wheel drive were limited to the Chevrolet Blazer, Ford Bronco, American Motors Jeep or International Scout, box-shaped vehicles that shared the utilitarian nature, bulkiness and hard ride of trucks. They were noisy, gulped a gallon of gasoline every 8 to 10 miles and had luxury-car price tags.

title: Portugal Going Back to the Polls
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes decided last week that the best medicine for Portugal's political ills was a new election. But he delayed filling the prescription.

title: Vietnamese Criticize Reagan On American Foreign Policy
description: President Reagan is ''incapable'' and has not learned from his mistakes, the Vietnamese Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan said today.

title: DOUBTS ARE RAISED OVER SHCHARANSKY
description: The mother of the imprisoned dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky has said that after an unsuccessful effort to visit her son in prison she still has no evidence that he has abandoned his four-month hunger strike.

title: 22 Killed and 20 Hurt In Mexican Road Crash
description: A bus headed for the United States border collided with a truck north of here today, killing 22 people and injuring 20, a highway police spokesman reported.

title: FOR MANHATTAN PARKERS, SPACE TOPS THE WORRY LIST
description: ''PARKING in Manhattan?'' echoed Victor Ross, a spokesman with the city's Department of Traffic. ''What's that?'' What it is, for those who drive on this tiny island, is expensive, risky and scarce. Drivers who parked in Manhattan received three million parking tickets in 1982. They lost 15,313 cars to theft. They retrieved 72,406 towed cars, including 600 diplomats' cars, DPL plates and all. They spent untold hours prowling city blocks for parking spaces and untold dollars on garage fees.

title: Norway
description: To the Editor: Surely Ruth Robinson is in error when she writes in the article ''In the Heart of Norway's Ski Country'' (Travel, Jan. 2) that a trail in the Rondane National Park went ''past clusters of quaint little seters, or cabins, perched on the hillside.'' v. . A. Kirkeby's ''Norsk-Engelsk Ordbok'' (Oslo: Kunnskapsforlaget, 1979) defines the word ''seter'' as ''1. mountain (summer) pasture; alpine pasture; 2. mountain farm; temporary farm on the upland pastures.''

title: Space Museum to Get Pioneer Chimpanzee
description: Ham, the pioneering space chimpanzee that died Jan 17 at the age of 26, will be stuffed and lent to the International Space Hall of Fame in Alamogordo, N.M., by the Smithsonian Institution, according to an Air Force spokesman.

title: SMOKEY ROBINSON BUILDS A POP PARADISE
description: Smokey Robinson's ''Touch the Sky'' (Tamla 6030PL) continues the career renaissance of a singer and songwriter whose early 1960's hits with his group, The Miracles, were the financial cornerstone of the fledgling Motown Records. Mr. Robinson, who will be 43 years old next month, is the only major act besides Stevie Wonder from the label's golden era who has remained consistently in the Motown fold. That may be one reason why his many solo albums, including ''Touch the Sky,'' share an appealingly old-fashioned simplicity.

title: THREAT TO HIGHWAY MONEY ENLIVENS SPEED LAW FIGHT
description: THE federally mandated maximum speed limit of 55 miles per hour is one of the most unpopular laws in the country since Prohibition, according to many Western state legislators and troopers who are charged with enforcing it.

title: Rumble
description: Is it the will of Congress that double-trailer trucks up to 75 feet long must be allowed on New York City's streets and expressways? The trucking industry says that's just what it won last month: absolute rights along interstate roadways and reasonable access to those routes from city streets.

title: IMPOLITIC POLITICIAN
description: TONY CROSLAND By Susan Crosland. Illustrated. 422 pp. Salem, N.H.: Jonathan Cape. $19.95.

title: Katherine Schleyer to Marry
description: The engagement of Katherine Parsons Schleyer to Ulrich Richard Geister, son of Luise Geister of Wobbel, West Germany, and the late Konrad Geister, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Walter L. Schleyer of Swarthmore, Pa., parents of the future bride.

title: AMELIORATING THE TENSIONS BETWEEN LAW AND THEOLOGY
description: FOR many Roman Catholics, the mention of canon law stirs nervous thoughts of discipline and judgment. The canons prescribe everything from the baptizing of babies to the handling of church funds, and thus have the practical effect of bringing church teachings down to life's realities.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: Rent-Controlled Increases
description: Question: I have lived for 30 years in a rent-controlled apartment. My rent was raised in January 1982 and the landlord sold the building last August. Last Sept. 1, the new landlord raised the rent and supported it with a form from the Rent Control Division. Last Oct. 1, he raised it again with another form from the division. Can I appeal to a court of law? ... B.S., the Bronx. Answer: You should first direct your questions about these increases to the District Rent Office at 260 East 161st Street, The Bronx, N.Y. 10451; telephone 585-2600. If you are unhappy with the response, file a protest with the Rent Control Commissioner, 17 John Street, New York, N.Y. 10038. Harry Michelson, general counsel for the Rent Control Division, says these steps must be taken before you may challenge the increases in court.

title: EASED EYE-CARE RULES SOUGHT
description: TO end what they consider outmoded restrictions, many of New Jersey's 750 optometrists are promoting legislation now before the Assembly that would let them treat patients with uncomplicated common eye ailments, patients they now must refer to physicians.

title: THE SECRET OF PLANNING A CAREFREE BORDER
description: This is the traditional time for deciding how best to brighten up the grounds when warm weather comes again. If your staff of trained horticulturists is already starting hybrid lilies in the greehouse or if you run to the garden center for a couple flats of pink petunias in spring, what follows may be of limited interest.

title: No Headline
description: TRENTON HORTENSE GREEN, who was the first crafts coordinator of the State Council on the Arts, is once more in that post - now called ''Crafts Consultant'' - on a part-time basis.

title: N.Y.U. GETTING A REALTY DATA CENTER
description: A $250,000 gift to the New York University School of Continuing Education by the family of Sylvan Lawrence will be used to set up a Data and Research Center at the N.Y.U. Real Estate Institute, according to Larry Silverstein, the institute's chairman.

title: Ellen Coker Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Westfield Coker Jr. of Hartsville, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Sasser Coker, to Tyler Baldwin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baldwin of Fairfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: REDSKINS SCOUTING
description: This scouting report on the Washington Redskins was compiled by Bill Parcells of the Giants. Parcells, the Giants' former defensive coordinator and now the head coach, was assisted by William N. Wallace of The New York Times.

title: No Headline
description: Cavs Beat Sonics

title: JERSEY CHURCH COLLEGE TESTING STATE LICENSING
description: New Jersey has become a testing ground for the right of states to set and enforce standards to maintain the integrity of the bachelor's degree.

title: FILM: 'THE NIGHT OF THE SHOOTING STARS
description: ''The Night of the Shooting Stars'' was shown as part of the 1982 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 29, 1982. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets.

title: Karen Ann Sweeney Married to Mark Van Mactas
description: Karen Ann Sweeney, daughter of Mrs. William Watts Sweeney of Montvale, N.J., and the late Dr. Sweeney, was married yesterday to Mark Van Mactas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mactas of Washington Township, N.J. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in Brooklyn, performed the ceremony at the Hilton Inn in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Queen of All Instruments
description: Thank you for William F. Buckley's excellent article on harpsichords (''Queen of All Instruments,'' Jan. 2).

title: HOW TO FIND A RICH (OR RANKLED) LAWYER
description: Two years ago, when The American Lawyer Guide to Law Firms appeared, it was hailed as a major breakthrough, the first systematic look beyond the secrecy that shrouds the nation's major law firms. In March, a much-expanded second edition - now known as The American Lawyer Guide to Leading Law Firms - is coming out, and it contains some advances of its own.

title: L'ECOLE SCHOOL IN LARCHMONT
description: ''WE live in such an international world,'' said Katrine Watkins, the co-founder and co-director of the French-American School of New York, situated in Larchmont. ''It's a shame that this huge country which is so powerful is not bilingual, and considers itself monolingual,'' The three-year-old school is the only bilingual French-American school on the East Coast, although similar schools do operate in California and Oregon.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
HOW TO COORDINATE CENTRAL BANK POLICIES
description: THE events in the arcane world of international exchange rates over t he last two years plainly illustrate why the major industrial c ountries must coordinate their monetary polices if we are to mount a sustained world recovery and avoid the cyclical ups and downs in t he future.

title: French Gites
description: To the Editor:

title: A BRITON MAKES A CASE FOR EARLY MUSIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Article 197609 -- No Title
description: A former Kitsap County sheriff's deputy, paralyzed since he was shot by an off-duty Poulsbo police officer in 1977, has been awarded $3.6 million. The verdict issued Friday by a King County Superior Court jury absolved the city of Poulsbo, Kitsap County and a holster manufacturer from liability in the suit filed by former Deputy John Strachan, leaving former Officer Marc Christensen as the only remaining defendant.

title: Frances A. Peeples, Nurse Wed to William Whitman
description: Frances Ann Peeples, daughter of Mrs. Otis B. Peeples of Estill, S.C., and the late Mr. Peeples, was married yesterday to William W. Whitman, son of Mrs. Ernest S. Arsenault of Catamet, Mass., and the late Frederick G. Whitman of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dana Hornig, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at Mr. and Mrs. Arsenault's home.

title: Reader Wants More Day Care Centers
description: Sandra Friedland's Jan. 16 article on day care for adults no doubt brought joy to the hearts of many residents of Union County. What deflates the joy is that Muhlenberg Hospital's center in Plainfield is the only one of its kind in Union County.

title: MARCEL MARCEAU SCHEDULED
description: Marcel Marceau, who last appeared in the metropolitan area in the mid-1970's, will begin a six-week run on March 8 at the Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street. Mr. Marceau recently made his debut in China, beocming the first European mime to perform there. Tickets, which range from $15 to $32.50, go on sale Feb. 14.

title: WHAT TIME IS IT?  ASK THE SUN
description: ZVI GEZARI, a retired mechanical engineer and an astronomy enthusiast, gazes out the large north window of his weekend home in Rocky Point at a timeless view. It encompasses much of the four and a half acres of grass and woodlands surrounding his house, a glimpse of Long Island Sound and a striking collection of scientifically accurate sundials that he has constructed himself.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 18 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 3 12 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 3 2 12 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 4 4 22 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 5 6 22 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 5 16 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 7 7 13 LIFE, THE UNIVERSE AND EVERYTHING, by Douglas Adams. (Harmony, $9.95.) On a journey through space, two men find answers to all their questions about existence: science fiction-fantasy. 8 9 19 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel.

title: Correction
description: In an article on Hungarian cuisine (Travel, May 9) Transylvania was incorrectly described as being part of Hungary. While Transylvanian cooking continues to be a mainstay of the Hungarian kitchen, the province itself has since 1920 been part of Rumania.

title: NEW LIFE FOR AN ARTHUR MILLER PLAY
description: Just off a plane at Kennedy Airport a while back, Arthur Miller left his name with the limousine service for a ride home to Roxbury, Conn., and wandered off, waiting to be called. The terminal was in noisy chaos; the college-age clerk on the car service desk was immersed in a book and may have paged Mr. Miller in a mumble. The car had gone when Mr. Miller again stood at the counter, his anger receding with the discovery that the boy was caught up in ''The Crucible.''

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Thanks to her long association with the Philip Glass Ensemble, Iris Hiskey is already a well-known soprano. However, her afternoon recital last Sunday at the Abraham Goodman House marked Miss Hiskey's New York debut as a solo artist.

title: NEW SEA WARS ON THE HORIZON
description: When Kent Kirk, the dashing Danish fisherman, challenged Britain's claim to monopolize fishing for offshore sprat and the Royal Navy took his trawler into port, it was the latest episode in a long history of clashes over who shall harvest the riches of the sea.

title: GLEN COVE MANSION FACES VOTE ON FATE
description: ALONG the meandering two-lane blacktop in Glen Cove called Lattingtown Road is another Gold Coast estate whose days as a private residence may soon end - and some local residents are opposed to that.

title: New Attempts to Defeat a Crippler
description: The history of multiple sclerosis, a crippling disease of the nervous system that afflicts about 250,000 Americans, is riddled with bogus therapeutic claims. Last week, the New England Journal of Medicine reported two experimental treatments that point to real progress.

title: THAT'S GOOD
description: The New York City Department of Parks and Recreation has 25,000 acres of parks, 900 playgrounds, 104 swimming pools, seven ice rinks, six beaches and one lame duck commissioner who in five years on the job has changed the department more than anyone since Robert Moses.

title: THE WORLD OF SOVIET PSYCHIATRY
description: Dr. Walter Reich, a psychiatrist, is a fellow at the Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian Studies of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington. he building in one of Moscow's older neighborhoods seemed ordinary enough to me, familiar in the drab way so many psychiatric hospitals are familiar, its grounds tended by patients and its gates manned by guards. Yet there was something special about this particular building, something that had drawn me to it from half a world away. It was the source of theories of mental illness that, since the late 1960's, had been applied to Soviet dissidents with results that shocked the West. And it was the headquarters of the author of those theories, whose life and work I had been studying for a decade. Waiting for me inside that building was the man in charge of the Soviet Union's psychiatric profession, Dr. Andrei V. Snezhnevsky.

title: EX-PROSECUTOR UP FOR JUDGESHIP
description: Peter C. Dorsey, a former Unite States Attorney for Connecticut, has been recommended by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for nomination as a judge in Federal District Court, an aide to the Senator said today.

title: NEW FIGHT DEVELOPING IN U.S. ON SALVADOR AID
description: A new fight is developing over aid to El Salvador, with the House, Senate and State Department all disputing the amount that each of the others contends Congress authorized for that country.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT TO RIVAL THE DEPRESSION
description: COLUMBIA, S.C. WHAT is a depression? Comparisons of current conditions with the Great Depression of the 1930's are tenuous, and social and economic conditions are difficult to measure. Yet the nation is told that this is the worst economy, with the highest unemployment rate, since the Great Depression.

title: THE VICTORY THAT BROUGHT UNITY TO WASHINGTON
description: IT was as though Gabriel had blown the last trumpet and all had been saved. There could scarcely be any greater natural public joy than that which ran through the hearts and minds of the residents of Washington following the Redskins' victory over the Dallas Cowboys in last Saturday's National Football League title game - unless ''what might have been'' the joy in Mudville had mighty Casey not struck out.

title: SHARP DROP IN BANK ROBBERIES CITED BY NEW YORK CITY POLICE
description: The number of bank robberies in New York City dropped sharply last year, police officials say. They attribute the drop to combined city and Federal investigative efforts and increased security measures taken by the banks.

title: RX FOR THE AGING AUTO: STRIPES, STEREOS AND SUN ROOFS
description: HYMIE'S Auto Radio on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn used to sell almost all its car stereos and tape decks to local teen-agers who were looking to jazz up their shabby jalopies. Or the youths would head over to Neptune Avenue to buy shiny vinyl roofs at Cropsey Auto Tops.

title: R.B. Bookout to Wed Colleen Therese Miller
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Miller of Mountain Lakes, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Colleen Therese Miller, to Randall Barry Bookout, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Barry Bookout of Brea, Calif.

title: Harold R. Boulware, Lawyer; Was a Pioneer in Civil Rights
description: Harold R. Boulware, a lawyer and civil rights pioneer who played a key role in the Supreme Court's 1954 landmark decision banning school segregation, died Thursday of cancer. He was 69 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
YEARS OF ASPARAGUS FROM LITTLE LABOR
description: WHEN the seed and nursery catalogues arrive by mail, can spring be far behind? Each day brings another catalogue extolling the virtues of new roses, generations-old vegetable varieties, dwarf conifers, new marigolds, extra-sweet sweetcorn, an undreamed number of beans and even a new hybrid asparagus.

title: Opponents of Marcos Call for Free Elections
description: Opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos called on him tonight to permit free elections. They spoke to about 5,000 people at a political rally at a downtown plaza.

title: SCARSDALE GIRL A NO. 1 IN TENNIS
description: SCARSDALE ''WOW! I'm No. 1, but I can't believe it.'' Melissa Brown, a tall 14 year old from Scarsdale with dark hair and long, slender legs, need not have been surprised at being named the best tennis player in the country in her 14-and-under age group.

title: Crazed, Perhaps, But Not Corrupt
description: When they threw the book at the four Croatians who plotted to bomb a Yugoslav independence day celebration in New York City in 1980, prosecutors hurled one chapter too many. So ruled a Federal appeals court last week in overturning the terrorists' conviction on a racketeering charge.

title: 2 MISSIONS, COMMON STRATEGY
description: It is a sad fact that the missions to Western Europe and China by Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, respectively, are salvage operations - not the two prongs of a successful global strategy designed to stabilize the East-West conflict. That the East-West relationship is the underlying focus of these missions is confirmed by a glance at the map. Both regions are the vital extremities of the Eurasian continent, which Moscow has been attempting to dominate. A solid American-European and an American-Chinese connection are thus central to the containment of the Soviet Union and to the eventual shaping of a healthier East-West relationship.

title: A SHOSTAKOVICH BALLET RETURNS FROM LIMBO
description: Tickets for the new Bolshoi Ballet production, ''The Golden Age,'' are at the moment the hottest cultural item in Moscow. Even the foreign tourist hotels, which usually hoard a supply of Bolshoi tickets to sell for western currency, have none to offer, and needless to say they have been unavailable at the Bolshoi box office or the hundreds of theater kiosks scattered throughout the city. Members of the company have been unable to get them for family and friends. In the weeks since the work's premiere on Nov. 4, just before the biggest Soviet holiday, the anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, tickets have been distributed behind closed doors, through connections and conniving. Most likely they will not be easily available to the general public for another six months or so, after the influential few have seen the production and some of the excitement has died down.

title:
OPINION;
HIGH TECHNOLOGY IS NOT A PANACEA
description: TWENTY years ago, when I matriculated as a freshman in college, ''management'' and ''high technology'' were not yet the slogans of administrators in higher education.

title: JONES'S NOVELS: FROM HERE TO POSTERITY?
description: ''THIS is the song of the men who have no place, played by a man who has never had a place,'' James Jones wrote in ''From Here to Eternity'' of a taps played by Robert E. Lee Prewitt, reverberating through the quad and briefly uniting each calloused listener with his fellow soldiers.

title: DR. DORIS DANIELSON TO WED DR. DREW LOMBARDI IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Danielson of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Doris J. Danielson, to Dr. Drew R. Lombardi, son of Dr. and Mrs. Angelo R. Lombardi of Leonia, N.J.

title: WITH POETS AT THE MICROPHONE, THE WORDS ARE OFTEN MUSIC
Lizabeth Beauregard, Banker, Marries
description: Lizabeth A. Beauregard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Beauregard of Holyoke, Mass., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to William B. Weaver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard G. Weaver of Raleigh, N.C. The ceremony was performed at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli, the pastor.

title: LOVING AND FLYING
description: OPEN SEASON By James Magnuson. 354 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95. SLIPSTREAM By Roger McDonald. 318 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Co. $15.50.

title: GIVING IT AWAY
description: Does your company own an apartment house, warehouse, parcel of vacant land or other property that is losing money or sitting idle? The answer to the problem might be to give the property away to the Trust for Public Land and take a tax credit for the contribution.

title: Offense Receivers
description: 87 Charlie Brown, wide receiver, 5 feet 10 inches, 179 pounds, 1st. All-Pro in his first year. Caught nine touchdown passes in 12 games this season. 89 Alvin Garrett, wide receiver, 5-7, 178, 3d. Improbable playoff hero who caught four scores in first two playoff games after just one catch during season. 85 Don Warren, tight end, 6-4, 242, 4th. Caught 27 passes during regular season. Others: 80 Virgil Seay; 88 Rick Walker; 82 Rich Caster; 86 Clint Didier.

title: No Headline
description: Toll in Lebanese Blast Is Estimated at 15 to 30

title:
NUMISMATICS;
IMPROVEMENT MADE IN FINAL OLYMPIC DESIGNS
description: Production is about to start on the first of the three United States Olympic coins, following what appears to have been significant improvements in its design. The final design differs substantially from versions that were seen in preliminary sketches and photographs, and in general the change is for the better.

title: U.S. TRIES NEW TACK IN DRUG FIGHT AS GLOBAL SUPPLY AND USE MOUNT
description: The production and use of illegal drugs is growing throughout most of the world, breeding violent crime and threatening political stability, a United Nations agency reported today.

title: MORE STATES EXTEND BENEFITS
description: Seven more states have begun paying jobless workers up to 13 weeks of extended unemployment benefits, bringing the total of to 20 states, the Labor Department announced. Unemployment insurance benefits, are provided through regular state benefits of about 26 weeks, extended benefits of up to 13 weeks more and new Federal supplemental compensation benefits of up to 16 weeks.

title: 'SPY' PHOTOGRAPHERS TRY TO TAKE THE SURPRISE OUT OF THE FUTURE
description: DETROIT JIM DUNNE is a hunter. He spends a good deal of time hiding behind trees and bushes and stalking the streets, shooting things. His weapon, however, is a camera and his prey new models of automobiles.

title: Bomb Threat by Man Delays Outgoing Orlando Air Traffic
description: The police halted outgoing flights and held 3,500 people outside the main terminal at Orlando International Airport for four and a half hours today after a man said he had a bomb in his flight bag.

title: Birth-Control Rule Challenged
description: Whether its Secretary-designate was ready or not, the Health and Human Services Department's disputed rule on contraceptives for teen-agers got into the Federal Register -and into Federal court - last week.

title: COMPUTERIZED EXTRAS ABOUND IN LUXURY CARS
description: DETROIT LESS than a decade after they argued that computers would force sticker prices up, automobile makers are now equipping their luxury models with a wide range of computerized dashboard devices to lure technology-conscious, affluent buyers into the showrooms.

title: THE WRITING IN THE ROCKS
description: IN SUSPECT TERRAIN By John McPhee. 210 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: Miss Finamore, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy P. Finamore of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Anne Finamore, to Stephen Markley Young, son of Col. Mason James Young Jr., U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Young of Newport News, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC: MODERNS II
description: Machines, in a sense, are extensions of our limbs and organs. And just as gears and levers add power to the human arm, so can electronic gadgetry stretch the power and flexibility of human vocal chords to new and unnatural dimensions.

title: Paula E. Leuchs Wed in Bermuda
description: Paula Elisabeth Leuchs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Leuchs of Monterey, Mass., was married in Warwick, Bermuda, yesterday to Kevin Rudyard Moats, son of Marjorie Lehmann Moats of Boston and Benjamin F. Moats of St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Dr. F.J. Marshal performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Christ Church.

title: NAMING A NEW CAR REMAINS MORE AN ART THAN A SCIENCE
description: DETROIT IT is one of the last pieces to be added to a new car, but one that is thought about, talked about and thoroughly researched, sometimes before the car is on the drawing boards. It can help an average car sell well or a good one sell great.

title: HEAD OF CONSUMER AFFAIRS ASSESSES FIRST YEAR ON JOB
description: Last Feb. 1, Simon P. Gourdine became Commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, an agency charged with educating consumers and protecting them from abuses in the marketplace.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGY AND POLITICS OF ANGER
description: ANGER The Misunderstood Emotion. By Carol Tavris. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: MISSING IT BY A HAIRLINE
description: THE first symptoms are insidious. A slight, self-imposed stiffness in the neck during windy days, a reluctance to open car windows, a total avoidance of sun-roofs and convertibles.

title: Satellite Ends Up Hot but Harmless
description: The end of Cosmos 1402, at 5:21 P.M. Eastern standard time last Sunday, was everything everyone hoped for - harmless. It came over the Indian Ocean 1,100 miles southeast of the nearest habitation, the British-owned island of Diego Garcia.

title: ARTISTS CHAMPION OTHER ARTISTS
description: RENDER unto Connecticut the art that is Connecticut's and the resulting show, given a knowledgeable curator, will be pretty much a chip off the old New York block. Eight of the 21 participants in ''Connecticut Painters 7 Plus 7 Plus 7,'' at Hartford's Wadsworth Atheneum, are well known on the Manhattan circuit and of these a handful have reputations that transcend political boundaries.

title: Mary A. Shea Is the Fiancee Of Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shea of Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ann Shea, to Alexander Thomson Farley, son of Jane T. Farley of Mill Neck, L.I., and Edward I. Farley of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Offense Receivers
description: 82 Duriel Harris, wide receiver, 5 feet 11 inches, 176 pounds, 7th season. Has lost some speed but still can make spectacular catch. 81 Jimmy Cefalo, wide receiver, 5-11, 188, 5th. Not very quick but manages to get the job done. Excellent hands, good on sideline routes. 84 Bruce Hardy, tight end, 6-4, 230, 5th. The best all-round athlete among the three tight ends. Others: 89 Nat Moore; 85 Mark Duper; 88 Vince Heflin; 86 Ronnie Lee; 80 Joe Rose.

title: Clarifying Points On Solid Waste
description: At all times, but especially at this time, with the state legislature beginning its session, it is vital that misinformation not be allowed to stand as fact. Thus, this letter is an effort to clarify certain points and correct certain other points in the article by Susan J. Hutchinson (''Miscalculations on Solid Waste,'' Jan. 2).

title: Ruppert Wrangle
description: In the glory years of the New York Yankees, when Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig reigned and the team won baseball pennants with monotony, the name Ruppert won applause. Jacob Ruppert was, of course, the team's owner and the operator of a brewery bearing his name in Manhattan.

title: RESTRICTED CHOICE
description: There is an area of playing technique which is familiar ground to modern experts but is not well understood by the average player. It was not understood at all, even by the experts, in the Culbertson era. An article by me in an English magazine some 30 years ago drew attention to the concept, and its ramifications were developed by other theorists.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: CUSTOMS AND CHARACTERS Contemporary Portraits. By Peter Quennell. Illustrated. 176 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $16.50.

title: THE SORROWS OF A 'SUPERPORT- TOO MUCH, TOO LATE
description: NEW ORLEANS ALITTLE over a decade ago, when oil was selling for only $2 a barrel, America was burning so much of it that oil companies began relying on supertankers, some almost as long as the Empire State Building is tall, to carry supplies from the Persian Gulf.

title: A BOOK, A WARM FIRE AND A GUINEA PIG
description: IVOWED we would never have a pet. But occasionally, on a cold night in his wing chair in front of the wood stove, my husband would reach out for another manuscript or book and he would have that look: a dog would feel great on his lap at this time of the evening. His parents had had one, half dachshund and half something else.

title: THIS 'ENTERTAINER' NEEDS A TRANSFUSION OF VITALITY
description: One's first temptation in discussing the Roundabout's revival of John Osborne's ''The Entertainer'' is to remark, or remember, that when the piece was first done in 1957, Laurence Olivier was not only the entertainer, he was the entertainment. Not that the evening was ever meant to be a jolly one, kept alive by a rude wink and coarse high spirits. It was transparently meant to record the disillusion that had overtaken the British Lion and all its cubs at about the time of the Suez crisis, and the beat of its battered heart was always down, down, down. The festering dank green walls that currently back up the players on West 23d Street are quite moldy enough for the evening's purposes: they look as though you could scrape a substitute for penicillin right off them and make a fortune on the black market.

title: BLUE ANGELS IN DRIVE FOR NO. 1 U.S. SPOT
description: FROM his sideline vantage point, Louis Kern observes the play of his Blue Angels with a serenity that is a bit uncommon among basketball coaches. He doesn't pace the floor; he often sits. His instructions aren't shouted, they are enunciated. But then again, he has not had much to complain about. His team has been winning - consistently.

title: Customs Raises Duty-Free Allowance
description: Travelers who approach shopping with zest are now able to approach customs with a bit more pleasure. On Jan. 27, customs regulations were liberalized to permit United States citizens to bring home more acquisitions under their duty-free allowance. Instead of being allowed to bring in $300 worth of goods, travelers will be permitted to bring in $400 worth; and for those returning from such United States possessias Guam, American Samoa and the United States Virgin Islands, the exemption has risen to $800 from the previous total - $ 600.

title: Hanging Up On Kearny
description: Though the years, the fortunes of Kearny, N.J., have been linked to those of the Western Electric Company, the town's biggest employer and taxpayer. Lately, the giant phone manufacturer has been struggling, and last week the town suffered.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Ay, There's the Rub

title: THREE DISTINCT APPROACHES TO SKYSCRAPER DESIGN
description: The Museum of Modern Art could have titled its new architecture exhibition ''Buildings by Trustees,'' but it did not. Instead, the exhibition was called ''Three Skyscrapers,'' an apt enough title in one sense, though it makes no reference to the fact that two of the three skyscrapers on view were designed by members of the museum's board of trustees.

title: PENSIONS BY SEX: THE OTHER WRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REALITY BEHIND '84 CHARING CROSS ROAD'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Hulbert is theater critic for The Dallas Times Herald.

title: ITALIAN FARE SERVED WITH FINESSE
description: ATTILIO'S is a comfortable storefront Italian restaurant in West Hempstead. The chef, who was born and raised in Italy, worked in several Italian restaurants on the Island before opening this place about three years ago. His cooking is straightforward, well-seasoned and presented with a good deal of finesse.

title: Capitol Elephantiasis
description: Why do you get the best view of Warsaw from the towering Palace of Culture and Science built by Stalin? Because, the answer goes, it's the one place from which you can't see the Palace of Culture and Science. For that same reason, Capitol Hill is fast becoming the best vantage point in Washington.

title: French Music on Radio
description: French musical works written from the Middle Ages to the present will be broadcast on radio station WNCN-FM, 104.3 on the dial, in a 13-week series, ''Musique de la Belle France.'' Beginning this week, programs will be aired at 8 P.M. every Saturday except March 19, when the time will be 7 P.M. First to be heard will be D'Indy's Symphony on a French Mountain Air and Bizet's ''L'Arlessienne'' Suite No. 2.'' The series is subsidized by the French Government and sponsored by Avon Products.

title: Italian Skier Wins
description: Maria-Rosa Quario of Italy captured a rain-marred slalom race today, her first World Cup victory since 1979.

title: SUBURBAN CORPORATE LUNCH: CULTURE PLUS EXCERCISE CLASSES
description: First there were the fitness centers, the aerobic dance classes and racquet ball. Then came the training courses in accounting and financial management, followed by classes in ''country kinds of activities, like hiking.''

title: Scoring Dynamics
description: During the winter months, Jeff Brezovar has a busy schedule. He is a major in mechanical engineering at the Milwaukee School of Engineering and studies hard enough to maintain a 3.67 grade average while enrolled in courses such as thermodynamics, strength of materials, heat transfer and mechanical design.

title: Rear Adm. Harmon B. Sherry, A Prisoner of Japanese in War
description: Rear Adm. Harmon Bradford Sherry, retired, who served on a submarine in World War II and was captured by the Japanese, died Tuesday of cancer at Keller Army Hospital at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: DIOXIN'S EFFECT IN ITALY LESS SEVERE THAN HAD BEEN FEARED
description: On a clear July day seven summers ago, a quiet Saturday in the Lombardy region of northern Italy just an hour's drive from the Alps, a soft explosion at a small chemical plant at Seveso sent a column of smoke and particles of debris mushrooming into the afternoon sky.

title: REDSKINS BEAT DOLPHINS, 27-17, IN SUPER BOWL
description: The Washington Redskins employed an awesome combination - muscle and finesse - to win Super Bowl XVII today from the most sophisticated defensive team in football.

title: 3 Aides See Inflation Peril
description: Three middle-level economists in the Administration have been trying in vain since December to present to the Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs the inflationary dangers they believe are posed by the current 15 percent growth in the money supply. The council's 10 members include the Vice President, Secretary of State and Secretary of the Treasury.

title: U.S. ROLE ON MASSACRE DENIED
description: Reagan Administration and Congressional officials today denied a report published in The Sunday Times of London that the United States knew a massacre was under way in two Palestinian refugee camps last September a day before the killings ended.

title: All in the Family
description: Not only does Don Shula produce fine football teams, five of whom have played in the Super Bowl, he also raises outstanding players. The 53-year-old coach of the Miami Dolphins, who was voted the coach of the decade of the 1970's by the Pro Football Hall of Fame's selection committee, has passed on his drive for excellence to his sons, David and Michael.

title: A BIG DAY FOR A BIG, FESTIVE PICNIC
description: It looked like the biggest picnic ever thrown in America. The hours before Super Bowl XVII were festive, noisy and colorful, under a bright blue sky and with the San Gabriel Mountains as a backdrop.

title: CONGRESS LEADERS EXPECT TO ALTER REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: Lawmakers in both major political parties said today that they expected Congress to make major changes in President Reagan's budget to reduce the large deficits that loom for the rest of this decade.

title: ADVEST GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAGNER DEVOTEES GO ON FULL CYCLE WITH 13-HOUR-AND-9-MINUTE 'RING' ON TV
description: Yolanda Velasco attended wearing a Wagner T-shirt and a Brunnhildetype helmet, complete with horns. Dr. Lawrence L. Geeslin came all the way from Florida.

title: SIGNALS UNCLEAR ON FED POLICY
description: Dealers in Government securities expect to bid for a record amount of Treasury notes and bonds this week without any assistance from the Federal Reserve on interest rates. Its policies in the last six months have helped reduce short-term rates and stimulate sales of Treasury issues.

title: Two Set Records
description: Sal Vega and Doreen Ennis-Schwartz each established course records in winning the New York Road Runners Club 25-kilometer run yesterday morning at Central Park.

title: CONVINCING EUROPE AND CHINA
description: Vice President Bush and George P. Shultz have their work cut out for them.

title: Advertising; Food Insert To Benefit Easter Seal
description: THE March issue of Best Food Day Color Inserts from Newspaper Coop Couponing will be special in a number of ways: most important will be the approximately $1.5 million it will raise for the nation's handicapped through the National Easter Seal Society.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Neon Wars

title: Dolphins Lament 2 Vital Misses
description: Their moments had come and gone, thus ending Miami's hope for another Super Bowl championship today. Kim Bokamper, a defensive end, had the ball in his hands with the goal line at his feet. Don McNeal, a defensive back, had John Riggins.

title: L.P.G.A. OPENING ITS RICHEST SEASON
description: WHEN Pat Bradley won first prize of $22,500 in the L.P.G.A. Mazda Classic at Florida's Deer Creek course yesterday, she became the first golfer to cash in a winner's check from the record total of $7,050,000 that will be paid out during 36 tournaments this year.

title: Aides Leave at Merrill And Morgan Stanley
description: Richard Hoffman, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and a well-known market analyst, is leaving.

title: Arrows Defeated In Overtime, 3-2
description: Ruben Astigarraga scored at 7 minutes 12 seconds of overtime to give the Phoenix Inferno a 3-2 victory over the New York Arrows today in a Major Indoor Soccer League game. Phoenix evened its record at 13-13. The Arrows fell to 13-10.

title: ON SUPER SUNDAY, SUPER PARTY XVII
description: This is a country where each is free to observe Super Bowl Sunday in his or her own way. About 100 million people were expected to watch Super Bowl XVII, according to pregame estimates - and most of them were at Walter Peek's house, or so it seemed at kickoff time as guests jostled for drinks, dip and viewing positions.

title: SOLOMON Z. FERZIGER
description: Solomon Z. Ferziger, senior partner in the New York law firm of Ferziger Wohl Finkelstein & Rothman, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: $24 Award to a Rockefeller

title: UTILITY REGULATORS NEED PEOPLE'S INPUT
description: Editor: Now that Governor Cuomo has called for a restructuring of the New York State Public Service Commission (the commission that approves all utility rate hikes), it is appropriate to suggest some reforms that have not been put forth previously.

title: John R. Bingham Dead at 82; Pioneer in Film Distribution
description: John R. Bingham, who until his retirement in the late 1960's was president of one of the country's first film distributing companies Association Films, died of complications, apparently resulting from a malfunctioning liver, in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Leonia, N. J.

title: AN AMERICAN OPPURTUNITY IN VIETNAM
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Club Wins
description: The Bronx International Athletic Club scored 28 points to win the Metropolitan Athletics Congress men's junior track championships yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory. Iona College and the Central Park Track Club tied for second in team scoring with 21 points.

title: Mexico Acts to Protect Guatemalan Refugees
description: Mexico has stepped up security measures on its southern border to protect Guatemalan refugees after four of them were killed last week by a band of 100 armed men, according to the Interior Ministry.

title: A Banker by Day Tends His Sculpture at Night
description: John Safer, a Washington real estate developer, lawyer, financier and chairman of the obard of the District of Columbia National Bank is listed in Who's Who in America as a Sculptor.

title: AFTER 17 HOURS OF TUMULT, HARDING IS LIBERALS' BOSS
description: A tumultuous 17-hour Liberal Party meeting ended near dawn yesterday with Raymond B. Harding, the longtime vice chairman and party leader, in control of the party and very likely its patronage recommendations.

title: Postal Workers Await Lost Mail: Their Pay
description: About 500 United States Postal Service workers will get their paychecks three days late because their original checks were lost in the mail.

title: Texas Suit on Vote Dismissed
description: A panel of three Federal judges Saturday dismissed a lawsuit seeking to delay the special election set for Feb. 12 in which Representative Phil Gramm, a Democrat, is seeking to reclaim his House seat as a Republican.

title: Core of Soviet Satellite May Crash This Week
description: The Soviet Union told the United Nations Friday that the nuclear fuel core of its Cosmos 1402 satellite would enter the earth's atmosphere sometime between Thursday and Feb. 8 and burn up completely.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Continental Finance Corp. filed $100 million of G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.

title: FOR THE SPEAKER, AN ELEGANT DOMAIN
description: Although a generous House of Representatives gave away many of the old treasures once housed there, the Speakers' Rooms just off the House floor are still among the most beautiful office suites in the Capitol.

title: SALAZAR TELLS OF A $60,000 OFFER TO RACE
description: Alberto Salazar charged yesterday that prominent officials of The Athletics Congress had offered to pay him $60,000 for running in an impending marathon in Los Angeles.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEIGHBORS: THE CHAINS WON'T BREAK
description: At a conference of African nations here the other day, speaker after speaker inveighed against a South African commando attack on this modest capital Dec. 9 in which 42 people were killed.

title: Britain May Use Troops In Water Walkout
description: The Government warned striking water and sewerage workers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland tonight that it would bring in troops if conditions became very serious.

title: Market Place; OPEC Sets Off 2 Reactions
description: JANUS, the ancient Roman god with two faces looking in opposite directions, could have symbolized part of the action in last week's stock market: airline stocks rose and oil issues fell in response to the same event.

title: News Analysis
description: The out-of-court settlement that brought an abrupt end to the trial over responsibility for the Three Mile Island nuclear accident left many questions unanswered, especially the question of guilt.

title: FORCING CHILDREN INTO SPORTS
description: year-old son, Alan. Alan had beenp laying competitive sports in a host of Los Angeles peewee leagues s ince the age of 7, but he had never shown great promise or even somep romise. In fact, there were times when he felt humiliated by his c lumsiness. He didn't get much sympathy from his father: Henry, as t he coach of Alan's Little League baseball team, wanted his son to bea real spark plug.

title: Navon Is Said to Decide To Bar Re-election Bid
description: President Yitzhak Navon has decided not to run for re-election, Israeli state radio quoted unidentified sources as saying today.

title: Celtics End Streak By Lakers, 110-95
description: Larry Bird scored 15 of his 21 points in the third quarter as the Celtics broke a seven-game winning streak by Los Angeles with a 110-95 victory today over the Lakers.

title: ISRAELIS ATTACKED
description: Artillery duels between Christian and Druse militiamen spread to Beirut today. In another incident, an Israeli soldier was killed while patrolling the outskirts of the capital. According to an Israeli military spokesman in East Beirut, four or five gunmen opened fire with rocket-propelled grenades on a patrol that consisted of two armored personnel carriers and then escaped into West Beirut behind an Italian contingent of the international peacekeeping force. In addition to the Israeli soldier who was killed, three others were wounded, the Israeli spokesman said.

title: Yacht Christened For America's Cup
description: Liberty, the newest 12-Meter yacht for the defense of the America's Cup next summer was christened today in ceremonies at the San Diego Yacht Club.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express International Banking Corp. has elected Robert F. Smith president and chief operating officer and James R. Greene vice chairman. * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected John E. Chester a vice president.

title: U.S.F.L. GENERALS SET TO OPEN CAMP
description: The United States Football League, the new 12-team organization that begins a spring-summer schedule on March 6, will open its training camps this week at sites in Florida, Arizona and California.

title: PROFITS VS. ASSETS IN MEASURING BANKS
description: Many bankers have grown fond of playing down size as a measure of a banking company's prowess. Earnings rather than assets, they say, should be the true measure of a bank's stature.

title: Like a Pendulum Do
description: One day last summer, Jim Flood was working on his putting on a practice green at the La Jolla (Calif.) Country Club. Flood, who invented the graphite shaft golf club in 1972, flipped the blade of his club around so that it was pointing toward his feet and then stroked a few balls. With an idea in his mind, he promptly headed for his workshop.

title: Iran Says 6 Commanders Were Killed by Iraqis
description: Iran said today that six commanders of its Islamic Revolutionary Guards were killed and a seventh was wounded while touring the Iran-Iraq battlefront.

title: MISS BRADLEY GAINS A 7-STROKE VICTORY
description: Pat Bradley birdied two of the first four holes today and went on to shoot a six-under-par 66 and run away with the $150,000 Mazda Classic, the first women's tour event of the year.

title: BRITISH GLOOMY ON JOB OUTLOOK
description: One year ago, when it was announced that British unemployment had surpassed three million, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had to struggle to make herself heard over shouts of ''Shame'' and ''Resign'' in the House of Commons.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Flushing Troupe Gets a Hint of Broadway

title: Celebration Breaks Out In Capital
description: Honking car horns could be heard from the White House to Virginia tonight after the Washington Redskins earned their first Super Bowl victory by beating the Miami Dolphins, 27-17.

title: 56 for Tripucka
description: Kelly Tripucka scored a team-record 56 points, as he and Isiah Thomas led a rally in the final 6 minutes 30 seconds that gave the Detroit Pistons a 128-126 victory over the Chicago Bulls Saturday night.

title: EVEN STEAM BATH IS NO REFUGE FOR SOVIET SHIRKERS
description: Muscovites poking through shops these days have something more to fear than empty shelves. Since Yuri V. Andropov declared war on the Russians' waning taste for work, the police have taken to making surprise raids on shops, markets, beer halls, railroad stations and even that last refuge of the absentee bureaucrat, the Turkish bath.

title: East German Driver Defects
description: A 38-year-old truck driver escaped across the heavily fortified East German border into the West German state of Lower Saxony Saturday night, border guards said today.

title: Super Bowl Records
description: The records set or tied at Super Bowl XVII, with old records in parentheses: RECORDS SET

title: FRITZ MACHLUP, 80, AN ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Fritz Machlup, an internationally known economist and teacher, died yesterday at the Medical Center at Princeton in New Jersey, after suffering a heart attack. He was 80 years old, and lived in Princeton.

title: UNLIKELY PRETENDER TO HAGLER'S THRONE
description: year-old former hod carrier with no great love for boxing but an admiration for fighters with ''character,'' has been preparing to take the world middleweight title from Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

title: GOOD FORTUNE OFTEN SHARED WITH NEEDIEST
description: A stroke of luck or an unexpected bonus often reminds the recipient that The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund can turn such good fortune into help for the city's poor.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A receiver in a professional football game is attempting to catch a pass in the end zone, and the officials call defensive pass interference and unnecessary roughness by the defender. Where is the ball marked?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOUSING

title: Swiss Electric Tower Blasted
description: An electricity tower carrying power from a Swiss nuclear plant to France and West Germany was blown up near here early today. No injuries were reported, the police said.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Kansas City Kings, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. Knick fans will get their first look, and their only one this season, at Ray Williams in a Kings' uniform. The former guard for the Knicks and the Nets scored 35 points on Saturday, but Kansas City lost its fifth straight game. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: Georgetown vs. Villanova, at the Palestra, Philadelphia (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M; Channel 11, 11:30 P.M., tape.) St. Joseph's at DePaul (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M., tape.) Virginia Tech at Memphis St. (Television - USA Cable, midnight, tape.)

title: THE LESSON OF GANDHI IS RECALLED
description: Early on, he was dismissed as a utopian crank, a hopelessly impractical visionary whose asceticism and fasts and theories of nonviolence would be crushed by the reality of power.

title: Kedir Wins Race
description: Mohamed Kedir of Ethiopia, the world champion, won the 28th San Sebastian international crosscountry race today. Kedir covered the 6.1-mile course in 29 minutes 58 seconds at the Lasarte Hippodrome, followed by a countryman, Estetu Tura, in 30:16.

title: Reeves President Leaves
description: Seth H. Baker, president of the Reeves Communications Corporation of New York since October 1981, has resigned. He said he plans to start a new company with a group of investors. Mr. Baker, 53 years old, said he would become chairman and chief executive of Baker Communications, a television and film company to be set up in Los Angeles. At Reeves, an entertainment and communications company, Marvin H. Green Jr., 47, chairman and chief executive, will assume the duties of president.

title: PONTIAC RELENTS
description: PASADENA, Calif. THE day of the game dawned bright and clear. That was the biggest upset of all on Super Sunday, even more momentous than the Redskins' beating the odds against the Dolphins.

title: SECURITIES DEALERS IN REFORMS
description: The government securities market, shaken by the collapse last year of three dealer firms, has changed some of the practices that brought on the failures and is considering other reforms to help prevent future ones.

title: Kim's Mother Commits Suicide
description: The mother of Duk-Koo Kim, the South Korean boxer who died of brain injuries suffered in a match with Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini last November, committed suicide, the police said today.

title: Margarita G. Smith, 60, Dies; Magazine Editor and Writer
description: Margarita G. Smith, a magazine editor and writer, died of heart failure last Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nightfall in Suriname
description: Friends of Desi Bouterse, the ruler of Suriname, probably contend that he has the best intentions for his sad, sick country. And that he's kind to children. They will say he really didn't like having to order the butchery of 15 opposition leaders on Dec. 8. And, as his new friends in Cuba, particularly, like to say, it's all the fault of American imperialism and multinationals anyway.

title: JOHN M. GRAHAM 2D
description: John Meredith Graham 2d, a museum curator who served at the Brooklyn Museum and at Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia, died last Thursday in Mentone, Ala., where he lived.

title: INMATE SURVEY FINDS HEAVY ALCOHOL ABUSE BY MANY CRIMINALS
description: A survey of inmates in state prisons found that nearly a third said they were drinking very heavily just before committing their crimes, and 20 percent said they drank very heavily every day in the year before they went to prison.

title: ALLEN, PERENNIAL AUTHORITY, EXERTS HIS STYLE
description: LOS ANGELES IF it's not the towels, it's the tickets. If it's not the stapler, it's the soap. George Allen is 60 years old, and there are dozens of details that still obsess him - not to mention putting together a football team named the Chicago Blitz in his return to coaching after five seasons.

title: Allied to Acquire Instrumentation
description: The Allied Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy Instrumentation Laboratory Inc., a maker of medical, scientific and industrial instruments, for more than $100 million.

title: A New Beat For Riggins
description: 17 victory in Super Bowl XVII yesterday, the Redskins' fullback rumbled for a record 166 yards. But he ran away from the Miami Dolphins for the 43-yard touchdown that settled the game.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 4-2
description: Playing their third game of a five-game trip, the Islanders posted their third straight victory by defeating the Edmonton Oilers, 4-2, tonight.

title: HOW DAVID HARE FAILED TO SELL A SCRIPT TO U.S. TV
description: Is television drama a tough field to crack in America? Not just tough, says David Hare, the successful British playwright, it's virtually impossible.

title: SOME TRUCKS HALT TO PROTEST GAS TAX
description: Some of the nation's more than 100,000 independent truckers pulled their rigs off the road at 12:01 A.M. today to protest increased fuel and road use taxes, but other drivers vowed to keep on trucking.

title: Teachers' Group to Back Affirmative Action Plans
description: The National Education Association says that despite opposition from many of its 1.6 million members it will file a brief supporting affirmative action in a reverse discrimination suit before the Supreme Court.

title: NEW SAMOA BOOK CHALLENGES MARGARET MEAD'S CONCLUSIONS
description: Two months before its official publication date, a book maintaining that the late anthropologist Margaret Mead seriously misrepresented the culture and character of Samoa has ignited heated discussion within the behaviorial sciences.

title: GENERALS FINALLY FIND SOMETHING NOT IN COMMON-AN INDICTMENT
description: For 20 years, three generals with the same last name got one another's mail and telephone calls. Now one of them has been indicted on embezzlement charges, and one of the others says the resulting confusion was ''a little scary.'' Last week a grand jury indicted Maj. Gen. Richard B. Collins of the Air Force, retired, on charges of embezzling $445,000 from the military when he was stationed overseas. General Collins, 53 years old, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., promised to appear in court this week and was not jailed.
