title: BRIEFING
description: Carter to Visit Mideast

title: Last of Family At Pabst Quits
description: August U. Pabst, the last member of the founding family of the Pabst Brewing Company still holding a top position with the company, has announced his resignation as executive vice president and a director.

title: 8 NEWSMEN IN PERU, MISTAKEN FOR REBELS, ARE SLAIN IN AMBUSH
description: Eight Peruvian journalists were ambushed and killed by a band of Andean peasants who mistook them for leftist guerrillas, the military command announced today.

title: 3 JAPANESE-AMERICANS ASK COURT TO OVERTURN WARTIME CONVICTIONS
description: Forty years after they were convicted of violating wartime curfew and evacuation orders, three Americans of Japanese ancestry have gone to a Federal court seeking to have their convictions overturned.

title: L.I. SCHOOL BOARD ENDS ITS FIGHT TO BAN BOOKS
description: After seven years of battling, marked by petitions, name-calling and a ruling by the United States Supreme Court, the Island Trees book-banning case is just about closed.

title: CABARET: 'ENCHANTED EVENING'
description: ''SOME ENCHANTED EVENING,'' the third Rodgers and Hammerstein salute in the long-running ''King Cole Loves Broadway'' series at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, is the liveliest show yet in the four-year existence of the series. Given an enlarged stage, a new choreographer, Barbara Siman Strouse, has physically loosened up the production.

title: Washington Watch; Battle Brewing On Trade Law
description: WASHINGTON ''LOOK for blood on the floor before this is over,'' said one key Administration figure as the hawks and doves of East-West trade circled over the Export Administration Act of 1979. The legislation, under which President Carter and President Reagan have imposed foreign policy trade sanctions against the Soviet Union, will expire Sept. 30 unless it is renewed.

title: BLACK HAWKS RALLY TO TIE RANGERS, 5-4
description: Rallying for three goals in the third period, the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Rangers, 5-4, last night at Madison Square Garden. Just when the Rangers seemed destined to win their second straight game, the Hawks opened an all-out assault midway through the final period and stole the victory.

title: THE REAGAN REVOLUTION: THE PLANS, THE PROGRESS
description: In February 1981, President Reagan unveiled 84 proposals for reducing or eliminating Federal programs. This was the opening salvo of what came to be known as the Reagan revolution.

title: Scientific American Plans March Campaign
description: Another magazine with a new ad campaign in the works is Scientific American, but it is not due until March. By then, according to C. John Kirby, vice president-advertising director, things are going to be looking better after a dismal January and February, during which combined ad pages will be 40 percent less than the same period in 1982. And 1982 was no bargain, either. Ad pages for the year were down 11.8 percent, to 1,000, and last summer it was announced that the circulation rate base was going to be cut to 550,000, from 615,000, because sales could not meet those guarantees.

title: New Delays Expected On Connecticut Trains
description: Repairs of bridges on the New Haven rail line could add to commuting delays this year, rail officials said today.

title: REDSKINS TRIUMPH OVER DOLPHINS
description: A Super Bowl game that might have been dull and ordinary because of the defensive strength of both teams was nothing of the kind. John Riggins ran for 166 yards and the winning touchdown today to lead the Washington Redskins to a 27-17 victory over the Miami Dolphins in Super Bowl XVII.

title: AIM IS TO REASSURE ALLIES ON ARMS
description: Vice President Bush arrived here tonight on the first leg of a seven-nation West European visit that is aimed at affirming to America's allies the Reagan Administration's commitment to arms reduction.

title: STAGE: MAGIC OF 'MERLIN' IS IN HENNING'S ILLUSIONS
description: IF ''Merlin,'' the musical at the Mark Hellinger, devoted its entire length to the magic tricks of Doug Henning, it would be something to see. Mr. Henning is beyond compare as an illusionist, and the half-dozen or so major stunts he pulls off in this show are indeed spectacular. They involve levitation, leaping flames, dancing water, a floating bubble with a man inside and, in the incredible piece de resistance that opens Act II, a live white horse and rider that vanish into thin air. Mr. Henning believes in magic, and he makes us true believers, too.

title: THE PUBLIC RELATIONS BACKFIRE AND WHAT FOLLOWED
description: When the White House announced this month that it was attempting to shut off all unauthorized ''leaks'' of information to reporters, an attendant risk was implied: The Administration's public relations burden now would, by design and necessity, fall more heavily shoulders of President Reagan himself.

title: NEW AID FOR THE JOBLESS TRIED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Government officials, industry and private groups in western Pennsylvania are taking action to help unemployed people keep their homes and medical benefits.

title: Article 195701 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: HER HOME INVADED, WIDOW IS TERRORIZED FOR 2 MONTHS
description: For two months a reclusive 74-year-old widow in Hopewell, Va., was the virtual captive of a group of juveniles and adults who subjected her to physical and mental abuse and drained her checking account of more than $7,000.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. HAS NO KEY TO LEBANON IMPASSE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that after a weeklong review of the Middle East situation, the Reagan Administration had no formula to propose to speed a breakthrough in the talks on withdrawing foreign troops in Lebanon.

title: ANALYZING COMMODITY PRICES
description: When steel scrap prices popped upward in January, Alan Greenspan's first reaction was that there was a mistake in the figures. The New York economist, who served as chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, had the numbers checked twice before he would believe that prices had really risen.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Sympathetic Ear For Owners of Sick Pets

title: GILDER TRIUMPHS IN 8 EXTRA HOLES
description: Bob Gilder won the Phoenix Open golf tournament today, beating Rex Caldwell on the eighth hole of a playoff. The exhausting finish was a sort of reprise for Gilder, because it was here in 1976 that the former Arizona State star won his first professional tournament.

title: The Economy
description: Congress may greatly alter the President's budget proposals to reduce the swelling deficits. Huge cuts in defense spending, including the elimination of the MX missile system, are high on the list of savings being discussed by the lawmakers. (Page A1.)

title: 11 Hurt in Train Derailment
description: Eleven people were injured today when a Chicago-bound Amtrak train with 81 people aboard slammed into an empty freight car and derailed, an Amtrak spokesman said. The conductor, engineer, five Amtrak workers, three passengers and a firefighter were injured, the spokesman said. The officials said damage to the Amtrak Zephyr, which was eastbound from San Francisco, was extensive.

title: Briton Sets Bigger Goal For Oppenheimer Unit
description: Sir John Buckley, the new chairman of Oppenheimer International Ltd., the London subsidiary of the New York stockbroker and fund manager, has set himself a formidable goal.

title: KEYNSIANISM 'WILL DO'
description: 913To the Editor:

title: Death and the Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court, which is supposed to look after the fair administration of the death penalty, now leads the nation in mismanaging that sentence. Justice Potter Stewart's vivid complaint a decade ago that the penalty was ''so freakishly and so wantonly imposed'' can now be properly directed to the highest court in the land.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Outdoors column of Sunday's sports section, the date of the next lecture to be presented by Manhattan's Theodore Gordon Flyfishers Inc., and the phone number for one of the organizers, were listed incorrectly. The next lecture will be Feb. 2, and the phone number for David Berman is (212)-361-3052.

title: FINANCIAL FUTURES AS BAROMETER
description: NO traders are as fickle as those in the commodity futures market: they thrive on the volatility of prices, unlike stock investors who think in terms of company earnings, dividends and other longer-term factors. Financial futures provide good illustrations of the changing preferences of traders in these markets in recent months.

title: MONEY SUPPLY GROWTH STIRS INVESTOR CAUTION
description: The financial community - institutional investors, bankers and security dealers - is beginning to question what it sees as an effort by the Federal Reserve to push interest rates down by adding to the money supply, according to a spot check of opinion across the country at the end of last week.

title: BONN'S FREE DEMOCRATS SEE A SHAFT OF SUNLIGHT
description: The small Free Democratic Party, the junior partner in the governing coalition, ended a two-day convention today buoyed by public-opinion polls that for the first time show it winning almost enough votes to remain in Parliament after the March 6 elections.

title: PIPES AT ATOM PLANTS INVESTIGATED
description: The operators of two nuclear reactors in New York and one in New Jersey say that their plants use piping made by a company that has pleaded guilty to fraudulently mislabeling the strength of its steel components. The use of the piping in atomic power plants is under investigation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: CHILDREN'S WEAR FROM THE 40'S AND 50'S
description: The mothers and fathers grew up in the post-World War II years of pedal pushers, saddle shoes and dresses like Dorothy's in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Now parental nostalgia is spilling over onto the offspring. Boys and girls who will be creating their own fads as teen-agers in the 1990's are being introduced to clothes that make them look the way their parents do in black-and-white family snapshots.

title: FOR PRIVATE GAIN
description: The charge made in this space two weeks ago - that assistant to the President Michael Deaver had acted unethically in signing a contract to produce a diet book while in the White House - was met with snickering all around.

title: CONCERT: DOMINGO AND MILNES AT THE OPERA
description: WHETHER by chance or by some unperceived design, the performing arts - at least at a star level -seem to have drifted into the world of men. At the movies, Paul Newman stands tall, but where are the Hedy Lamarrs and Rita Hayworths of 40 years ago? Margot Fonteyn dominated the ballet after World War II, but today it is Nureyev and Baryshnikov who grasp our attention.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FINGERPRINT. An Uncommon Autobiog- raphy. By John Sack. 230 pages. Ran- dom House. $13.95.

title: RESOURCE RECOVERY IN FLORIDA: LARGE-SCALE, SAFE AND PROFITABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: EVIDENCE IS EVIDENCE, 'TAINTED' OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Birdsong Troubled By Talk of Trade
description: It has taken more than a year for Otis Birdsong to feel at home as a Net. After a knee injury, long delays on his new home, and the unsuccessful experiment of playing alongside Ray Williams, he has just begun to be at ease.

title: No Headline
description: A Hitler Anniversary Recalled at Reichstag

title: AREA OFFICIALS ASSESS IMPACT OF THE FEDERAL BUDGET IN 1983
description: As officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut awaited delivery of President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1984, they noted that Congress had sharply limited the cuts he proposed last year.

title: THEISMANN STOPPED ONLY BY HIS EMOTIONS
description: Joe Theismann, the quarterback for the Washington Redskins, is a man of many words. Today, in the locker room after the 27-17 Super Bowl victory over the Miami Dolphins, Theismann delivered a few thousand words. Then, swept up by the emotion of the moment, he stopped.

title: CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN CONVENTION URGES REAGAN TO SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: The California Republican Party, which gave its heart to Ronald Reagan in 1966, adopted a resolution at its convention here today that asks the President to run for reelection next year.

title: TOOL ORDERS PLUMMETED 49.1% IN '82
description: In one of the worst years in its history, the machine tool industry closed out 1982 by posting a 49.1 percent decline in orders from 1981.

title: CONFIDENT SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Afrikaner Nationalists who run this country's politics have always tended to be distant and bristling in dealing with the foreign press. This year, at the opening of the parliamentary session, the leaders from Prime Minister P.W. Botha down have joked with correspondents at receptions and responded amiably to questions on substance.

title: Bridge: Cheaters Are Rare Indeed When Cash Is Not at Stake
description: Statistics on the frequency of deliberate cheating are about as hard to come by as those on the frequency of undetected murders. One can say, however, that the incidence is very small indeed in both areas, and that Americans behave better than Europeans in the bridge department but worse in the crime department.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 31, 1983
description: International Artillery duels in Lebanon between Christian and Druse militias spread to Beirut. In another incident, an Israeli soldier was killed while patrolling the outskirts of the capital by gunmen armed with rocket-propelled grenades. Three other Israeli soldiers were wounded. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Administration has no formula to propose to speed a breakthrough in the talks on withdrawing foreign troops in Lebanon, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. He also ruled out applying pressure on Israel to make concessions. Some White House officials have suggested a cut or a suspension in aid to Israel if more flexibility is not shown. (A6:3.)

title: Britons and U.S. Ad Agency Discuss a Campaign on Arms
description: Britain's Defense Ministry is discussing with an American advertising agency a campaign to be paid for by British taxpayers aimed at counteracting growing support for nuclear disarmament.

title: ECONOMY CARVES NEW TRAIL OF TEARS FOR TRIBE
description: Since morning, Jerry Phillips and his wife and mother have been squatting at the edge of a broken cliff near here, scrabbling among the sharp rocks for shards of a green gemstone called peridot.

title: FEVERS ARE ADDED TO QUARANTINE LIST
description: The nation's foreign quarantine regulations are being revised for the first time in 27 years to list a deadly array of fevers said to be capable of creating a public health threat in this country.

title: BALLET: BASEL'S VISIT TO BROOKLYN ENDS
description: THE New York premiere of Heinz Spoerli's Brahms ballet ''Four Songs for Women's Chorus'' on Saturday night, along with several debuts, marked the closing weekend of the Basel Ballet's season in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet International'' series.

title: Duran Is Winner Over Cuevas in 4th
description: Roberto Duran, the former lightweight and welterweight champion, put himself into position for another title shot with a fourth-round knockout of Pipino Cuevas Saturday night in a scheduled 12-round elimination fight between former world champions.

title: OUTDOORS: The Lay of the Land
description: GOOD maps are to the woods wanderer - whether hiker, fisherman, hunter or canoeist - as a good library is to a scholar. I never enter a wilderness area without first consulting a topographic map of the region, and a compass and the map are with me when I set forth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Jan. 3 on Broadway theater economics was incorrect, according to a new statistical analysis. A corrective article appears on page C26.

title: SLUMP ON BROADWAY IS REASSESSED
description: A new statistical analysis conducted by The New York Times shows that an article appearing in The Times on Jan. 3 was incorrect in stating that the Broadway theater is experiencing the worst slump in a decade. But the slump does mark the first time in a decade that such statistical measures of Broadway's health as attendance have been in decline.

title: Tenative Pact Reached In California, Pa., Schools
description: Negotiators for striking teachers and officials in the California Area School District accepted a contract settlement tonight, ending an 82-day strike, the state's longest teachers' walkout.

title: MISS BELLAMY URGES CITY TAX RISE LIMITED TO INCOME ABOVE $30,000
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy proposed yesterday that New York City raise its income tax on the wealthiest 10 percent of the city's taxpayers: those earning more than $30,000.

title: CUOMO TO SEEK CUT IN FUNDS FOR ARTS
description: Governor Cuomo will propose a cut of more than 10 percent in the state's contributions to the arts, including grants to major cultural institutions, state budget officials said today.

title: Berkeley and Its Restaurants Are Feuding Over Mushrooms
description: A crackdown on wild mushrooms is turning into a feud between Berkeley restaurateurs who want to keep the wild fungi on their menus and health officials who want them off.

title: Index; International
description: Exodus of aliens from Nigeria speeds up A2 Surprise raids netting shirking Muscovites A3 Around the World A5 Tokyo is undecided on U.S. re- quest for aid to Lebanon A6 West Germany's Free Demo- crats scenting survival A7 Dioxin's effects less than feared in Italy A13 Government/Politics Regional officials note that Con- gress limited '83 budget cuts A19 Cuomo confidant to take two top posts at development agency B1 Carol Bellamy proposes extra tax on incomes over $30,000 B8 Washington Talk White House: The peril of the new public relations policy A16 A banker who hopes to be remem- bered as a sculptor A16 Office Suites: Speaker O'Neill's mixes clutter and elegance A16 The Calendar A16 Briefing A16 General Around the Nation A8 U.S. revises quarantine rules to add deadly fevers to list A9 Widow terrorized in her home for two months A10 California convention urges Rea- gan to run again A19 Difference between 2 retired generals: One is indicted A20 Suburban companies filling cul- tural needs of city workers B1 Law professor sues a law dean over credit for writings B3 Super Bowl Sunday was a circus in a New Rochelle backyard B4 L.I. school board ends book-ban- ning case by lifting all curbs B7 SportsMonday Super Bowl XVII: America's big- gest picnic at Rose Bowl C9

title: STRIKERS CONDEMN LEVESQUE, THEIR OLD ALLY, AS A TRAITOR
description: For the more than 200,000 illegally striking provincial workers and for the government of Premier Rene Levesque, which is threatening to dismiss them and impose heavy fines, this weekend was spent in charting the territory between bravado and courage.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 31, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Non-Use of Force - 3 P.M.

title: Jailed Baptist Minister Scheduled for Release
description: A Baptist minister who spent four months in jail for refusing to close his nonaccredited school will embark on a series of speaking engagements after his release Monday, according to his wife, Tressie.

title: CASHING IN ON COOKIE CRAZE
description: With a favorite recipe, an image of home-baked goodness and help from her husband - a professional financial adviser - a 26-year-old woman has built a $30 million cookie chain on the West Coast that is now heading East.

title: Smith and Walton Too Much for Knicks
description: The story is old: Let a player go and he comes back to beat you. That was the script that Randy Smith wrote for himself Saturday night in his return to Madison Square Garden.

title: Defense Fudge, and Vanilla
description: Congressmen of both parties are demanding that defense spending be cut, but Mr. Reagan has no serious offer to make. In his State of the Union Address he merely extended a savings program proposed earlier by Caspar Weinberger. Their approach ducks the problem.

title: Israeli Unit to Needham
description: Needham, Harper & Steers's Issues and Images unit has just won the Israel Government Tourist Office, which has a budget of around $1.5 million and for the last 25 years has been an account of Doyle Dane Bernbach -most recently of its Group Two unit.

title: TV: FALLEN FALSTAFF OF 'MERRY WIVES'
description: THE Sir John Falstaff reincarnated by Shakespeare in ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' after his offstage death in ''Henry V'' is a chastened man. He is down at the heels and destined to have his friends and his plots turn against him. Where once he was a jester, now he is a worn-out buffoon, a foil for lesser men - and women.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Any cut is a blow.'' - Anthony A. Bliss, general manager of the Metrolitan Opera, on proposed state budget. (B8:3.)

title: TOKYO SAYS REQUEST THAT IT AID LEBANON IS BEING CONSIDERED
description: Foreign Ministry officials said today that the Japanese Government was considering a request by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to contribute to the financing of the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title: Hathaway Moving
description: The Silverman Mower agency of Syracuse and New York has just been picked by C.F. Hathaway, the shirtmaker, to be its ad agency. This follows by almost two years the agency's appointment as the Warnaco subsidiary's sales promotion agency. The account was last at Ogilvy & Mather, which long ago created the man with the eyepatch who made the Hathaway Man famous, although it didn't increase the advertising budget all that much.

title: PROFESSOR OF LAW SUES DEAN OVER CREDIT FOR HIS WRITINGS
description: A professor at Brooklyn Law School has charged that the dean of the St. John's University School of Law wrongly took credit from him for writings published in legal volumes.

title: EXODUS OF ALIENS PICKS UP IN NIGERIA
description: The exodus of West Africans expelled from Nigeria speeded up dramatically today after Ghana opened a border crossing point to allow its citizens to return home overland.

title: Energy Expert Gets A Top Post at Tosco
description: When world oil prices surged during the so-called price shocks of 1973 and 1979, Maurice F. Strong, the peripatetic Canadian businessman and statesman, recognized that developing countries could least afford the increases and would suffer the most.

title: SALVADOR REBELS PUSHING DRIVE IN 3 PROVINCES
description: A guerrilla offensive that began in the northern province of Morazan early this month has spread to two more provinces.

title: Lendl Wins 62d in Row
description: Ivan Lendl defeated Guillermo Vilas, 7-5, 6-2, 2-6, 6-4, and won the $250,000 World Championship Tennis winter final at Cobo Arena today.

title: People
description: * John Miller named senior vice president, director of client services at Soskin/Thompson Associates, a division of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A.

title: Christopher Johnson Weds Maureen Piga
description: Maureen Elizabeth Piga, an employment assistance coordinator at the National Center for Paralegal Training in New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Johnson of Brooklyn. The Rev. Stephen Brunnguell performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

title: AT TWO SCHOOLS, SHARP CONTRASTS IN STUDENT ABSENTEEISM
description: Every week at Hillcrest High School in Queens the attendance records for each of the 3,300 students are fed into a computer. It digests the information and then automatically prints postcards to be mailed to the parents of students who were marked present in the morning but cut classes later in the day.

title: COSMOS' FALLOUT: GAULING
description: The French commonly assert that their gallant ancestors, the G auls, feared only one thing - that the sky might fall on their h eads. A few days ago, the entire world shared that fear.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. DEFEATS IRISH

title: CENTURIONS' PRIVILEGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa Makes a Big Impression
description: Bob Hansen and Mark Gannon, freshman reserves at the time, are the only current Iowa players who were members of the Hawkeye team that reached the Final Four of the 1980 National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: POLISH CHURCH REPORTS POPE WILL VISIT JUNE 18
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Poland announced today that Pope John Paul II would begin the second visit of his papacy to his native country on June 18.

title: Hildgartner Takes Men's Luge Title
description: Paul Hildgartner of Italy had the fastest time in today's final to capture the men's title in the World Cup men's luge championships at Mount Van Hoevenburg near here.

title: ADVICE FOR WOMEN WHO DRIVE ALONE
description: Lucille Burrascano was driving to her summer house in Montauk, L.I., around 2 A.M. one summer night when a man in a car pulled up alongside her. He sounded his horn and motioned for her to pull over.

title: 4 DAYS OF TREASURY SALES THIS WEEK
description: In the Treasury market this week, an auction is scheduled every day except Friday. Treasury financings will be frequent and large in coming weeks, as Government experts estimated last week that they would need to raise $59.5 billion this quarter and $33 billion to $38 billion next quarter.

title: CUOMO CHOOSES CAMPAIGN AIDE FOR 2D STATE POST
description: The Cuomo administration has begun a major overhaul of the state's Urban Development Corporation, but the investment banker who the Governor said would be president of the corporation has declined the job.
